{"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "A counterargument to the idea that young women ought to just extricate themselves from sexual situations in which they aren\u2019t having any fun soon circulated, maintaining that the culture conditions them to acquiesce, to prioritize the needs of others before their own. \u201cIt feels paralyzing to assert ourselves,\u2019\u2019 Jill Filipovic wrote in The Guardian in reaction to all of this. And yet when I look around at millennial women, problems with inhibition or the ability to hang on to a healthy sense of entitlement are not the ones I am quickest to identify.\n\nA few days before the Ansari controversy erupted, some number of young women had taken to eviscerate the writer Katie Roiphe on Twitter, for a piece she was writing for Harper\u2019s Magazine, related to the movement against harassment, but still weeks away from publication.\n\nThis week, when the HLN television host Ashleigh Banfield called out Babe for the Ansari story, claiming that it threatened to dilute the crucial work of #MeToo and that Grace had merely endured a \u201cbad date,\u201d the writer of the piece, Katie Way, 22, lashed out in an email that Ms. Banfield read on air. It called her \u201ca second-wave feminist has-been,\u201d who \u201cI\u2019m certain no one under 45 has ever heard of,\u201d and went on to ridicule her hair and lipstick. And yet, Ms. Banfield suddenly had a currency she hadn\u2019t had in years.\n\nThe quiet treatment of Mathilde Krim, when stacked up against the ubiquity of Grace, ultimately reveals a strain of internet sexism that we are all complicit in perpetuating and barely address \u2014 the bestowing of outsize rewards, measured in publicity, for certain female narratives over others, for stories that invite judgments and counterjudgments, nearly always about sex and domestic complexity. Just a few days ago, a young writer, Moira Donegan, found herself anointed in the wake of a well-crafted and thoroughly absorbing essay she wrote for The Cut, in which she announced that she was the woman who had created the fabled list meant to steer women away from potentially dangerous men in the media. And yet this kind of success isn\u2019t scalable. It is nearly impossible to imagine a similar reception for a 25-year old woman who composed a powerful piece about how she came to believe in the moral necessity of, say, congestion pricing.\n\nIn the course of her career, the academic Anne-Marie Slaughter had written two books and countless scholarly articles about foreign policy, but it wasn\u2019t until she wrote a cover story in 2012 for The Atlantic \u2014 \u201cWhy Women Still Can\u2019t Have It All,\u201d about her decision to leave the State Department and spend more time at home \u2014 that she became widely known.", "title": "#MeToo and the Marketing of Female Narrative", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "HOW MUCH $1.55 million\n\nSIZE 4,200 square feet\n\nPRICE PER SQUARE FOOT $369\n\nSETTING The house is in the West Lakeview/Roscoe Village neighborhood northwest of downtown, an area with shops, restaurants and easy access to Interstate 90. It is zoned for the highly regarded public Jahn School of Fine Arts.\n\nINDOORS Built as a model home for Noah Properties, a luxury construction company, and later occupied by an interior designer, the house is a showplace of elegant finishes and features. It has solid wood doors, wide-plank floors, high-end light fixtures and a lavish use of tile.\n\nOn the main level, the living room has a wall of floor-to-ceiling windows and a wood-burning fireplace. The adjacent dining area is defined a by gridded wood ceiling decoration that is repeated in the family room. The kitchen has 3.5-inch-thick beveled Carrara marble countertops, a center island that seats six, two ovens, two dishwashers, a Sub-Zero refrigerator and freezer and a large glass wine cooler. The kitchen flows into a family room that has a fireplace and French doors leading to a rear deck. The powder room is tiled up to the ceiling (typical of many of the home\u2019s bathroom walls) and has crystal pendant lights.\n\nUpstairs is a master suite with carved pocket doors that open into a bathroom with a walk-in shower and soaking tub in the center and vanities on opposite walls. Two additional bedrooms on this floor share a bathroom with dual vessel sinks and a shower.\n\nDownstairs is a light-filled recreation area with a kitchenette, a bedroom, a bathroom with a tub and shower, a media room (the projector and screen come with the house) and a laundry room with a marble countertop and marble tile.\n\nOUTDOOR SPACE A flight of stairs from the second level leads to an indoor wet bar and a partially covered roof deck that is wired for surround sound and cable, and includes a gas fireplace and views of downtown Chicago. She pronounced it perfect.\n\nA complimentary truffle is nothing to sniff at. The chocolates at Teuscher, which arrive every Monday from Zurich, Switzerland, are not cheap: they sell for $112 per pound or around $3.36 per piece. Fancy fantasy boxes, which include 3D elephants blowing flowers out of their trunks and wide-winged ladybugs, are extra.\n\nThe Champagne truffles, which are sold singly or set, like precious gems, in lime green boxes tied with gold ribbon, were introduced in 1947. They were the creation of Dolf Teuscher, the founder.\n\n\u201cMy father got the idea during a heat wave, which is a confectioner\u2019s nightmare,\u201d said Dolf Teuscher Jr., who was visiting the store from his home in Zurich. \u201cHe saw two Champagne buckets sitting on the top of a glass cabinet. That night, he dreamed of the buckets and saw himself making Champagne truffles and selling them like crazy. We\u2019ve never changed the recipe.\u201d\n\nMr. Teuscher recently added rose and lavender truffles to the collection that includes salted caramel, pistachio, orange and Grand Marnier flavors.\n\n\u201cThe oil inside is natural,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s very expensive \u2014 $15,000 a quart, but you only need a few drops.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSara Yoffe, a nurse at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, had tasted Teuscher chocolates only a couple of times. She stopped in to buy a 16-piece box of Champagne truffles for her grandmother\u2019s 85th birthday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cShe and my grandfather, who has passed, went to Switzerland every year for 40 years,\u201d Ms. Yoffe said. \u201cShe loves them \u2014 she\u2019ll eat one after dinner each night with her espresso.\u201d\n\nValentine\u2019s Day, not surprisingly, is Teuscher\u2019s biggest sales day of the year, and even the phone lines are busy. A massive development, it has its own power plant, schools, recreation center and ZIP code. The sale has garnered some notoriety not just because of its size but also because President Trump has a small stake in the complex.\n\nCarol G. Deane, the managing partner of Starrett City Associates, who was behind the sale, had argued in court that she balanced the need to satisfy shareholders with a deal that could win government approval and preserve Starrett City as a home for low- and moderate-income New Yorkers.\n\nMore than 70 percent of the limited partners and beneficial owners approved the deal in September.\n\n\u201cWe are pleased with the decision denying plaintiffs\u2019 efforts to derail the sale of Spring Creek Towers,\u201d Ms. Deane said in a statement Tuesday, \u201cbut not surprised because of the care we put into the process and choosing a buyer who is committed to maintaining the development as affordable and a quality place to live for the 15,000 residents who call it home.\u201d\n\nJoshua D.N. Hess, a lawyer for the dissidents, said Tuesday that they were reviewing the judge\u2019s order and their options, which could include suing for damages.\n\nMr. Deane died in 2010. Her name and cause of death had not yet been released.\n\nThe woman had been taken to Regional Medical Center Bayonet Point in critical condition on Sunday and died at 10:42 p.m., the hospital spokesman, Kurt Conover, said on Monday. The epicenter was in the Pacific Ocean around 25 miles from the town of Acari.\n\nGov. Yamila Osorio of the surrounding Arequipa region said on Twitter that a 55-year-old man had died in the town of Yauca after being crushed by rock. Jorge Ch\u00e1vez, the chief of Peru\u2019s Civil Defense Institute, told the local radio station RPP that 65 people had been injured, but withdrew his earlier statement that a second person had died in the town of Bella Union.", "title": "1 Dead as Earthquake Strikes Peru", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Sandy and Dennis have an older daughter, Jane, 37, an apprentice carpenter, who is not addicted. She has tried to distance herself from the family drama and has moved out of the area. Although she visits often, moving away has left her with what she describes as survivor\u2019s guilt.\n\n\u201cI had to make a conscious effort to put space between myself and them, for my own self-preservation,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019d already come to terms with the fact that my brother was going to die \u2014 I\u2019ve already mourned him.\u201d\n\nJane has thought long and hard about why some people from the same background become addicted and others don\u2019t. She thinks she was spared because she never tried opioids in the first place.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know anyone who just \u2018tried\u2019 it and then stopped,\u201d she said. \u201cWatching Pat do this was heartbreaking, but watching Betsy \u2014 who was outgoing, did well in high school and was planning on college \u2014 was super frustrating. I wanted to shake her, and say, \u2018You know how this goes. Knock it off.\u2019\u201d\n\nSandy said that Betsy, who completed a highly structured treatment program and underwent cognitive behavioral therapy, seemed more motivated than Patrick to quit.\n\nAnd Betsy, who started using drugs at 19, said she suspected that Patrick had a harder time quitting because he had started when he was 14. A Surgeon General\u2019s report in 2016 said that the younger people are when they start taking drugs, the more likely they are to become addicted long-term. \u201cHis brain is still that young,\u201d Betsy said. \u201cAs intelligent as he is, this is his only coping mechanism.\u201d\n\nIt was especially difficult getting clean while her brother was still using, Betsy said, as she cuddled a frisky mutt outside the animal shelter. Now, Patrick stays with his father and Betsy lives with her mother; everyone is wary that if the siblings lived together, they could drag one another down.\n\nPhoto\n\nPatrick said Betsy had succeeded where he had not because she had found passion in her work. She saw glimpses of herself in the shelter dogs and their painful pasts; when she was 8, her parents divorced and her father was drinking. She said she sometimes had to take care of him.\n\n\u201cShe loves those dogs,\u201d Patrick said.\n\nHe said that during periods when he has been clean, he tends to take on too much, as he did last year when he signed up for multiple coding courses at community college. He said the heavy caseload left him frustrated, with failing grades. That preceded the relapse in May when he overdosed four times in a single afternoon.\n\nLike many parents in families torn apart by drugs, Sandy has blamed herself. For a time, she wondered if she was too permissive, even as she reported her children to the police and kicked them out of the house.\n\nAt Al-Anon sessions for families of alcoholics, Sandy learned what are known as the four C\u2019s \u2014 \u201cYou didn\u2019t cause it, you can\u2019t control it and you can\u2019t cure it, but you can contribute to it.\u201d She said she came to understand that she had been an enabler. \u201cEven though you think you\u2019re helping them, you\u2019re not,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow, Sandy sounds almost fatalistic about addiction.\n\n\u201cYou could be the best parent in the world, but if it\u2019s going to happen, it\u2019s going to happen,\u201d she said. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t matter what walk of life you come from.\u201d\n\nPatrick lives with his father, but he often feels crowded by him and visits his mother a lot, usually for supper.\n\nAs a late fall day turned to dusk, Patrick lounged on an overstuffed chair in her living room. He said he had not used drugs since he went to jail in July and had applied for a job at a local packaging plant. But he also said he had no self-confidence and no idea how to break free from his cravings.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m afraid I\u2019m going to screw it up all over again,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s what happens every time.\u201d\n\nHe said he knew he was not a sympathetic figure, that people may look at his life and wonder why he cannot pull himself out of this hole, especially with so much family backing.\n\n\u201cI feel like I\u2019ve got nothing to offer,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m depressed all the time, and I\u2019m isolating myself. I don\u2019t really know what sober people do.\u201d\n\nHis eyes welled with tears and he scraped them, hard, with his open palms.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want people to pity me,\u201d he added. \u201cBut I don\u2019t want to lie to people about my past, either. I have a hard time asking for help. I always say, \u2018I got this.\u2019 But I never got this.\u201d\n\nSeeking Solid Ground\n\nOn an unseasonably warm night in late October, Sandy attended a support group for parents of addicted children.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn this evening, 17 people showed up at the group, called Families Sharing Without Shame. All had adult children either in the throes of addiction or in recovery. As they sat in a circle, they shared their horror at discovering the drug use going on under their roofs. They drew nods of recognition when they said they finally understood why their teaspoons were vanishing from their kitchens (powdered opioids are heated in a spoon with water to convert them to a liquid that can be injected).\n\nUnlike some of the other parents, Sandy seemed battle hardened, like one who had been immersed in a war for a long time.", "title": "1 Son, 4 Overdoses, 6 Hours", "authors": ["Katharine Q. Seelye"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "COPENHAGEN \u2014 About 1,000 adults and adolescents may face prosecution for sharing online video of two 15-year-olds having sex, and more people may be charged for spreading the images, the Danish National Police said Monday.\n\nConsensual sex between 15-year-olds is legal in Denmark, but anyone who forwarded the video violated the law against distributing child pornography, the police explained. The two video clips \u2014 one 50 seconds long, the other 9 seconds \u2014 were shared through Facebook\u2019s Messenger app.\n\nThe case prompted outrage when it was first reported last year, because the video appeared to show the girl being abused, penetrated with foreign objects. The girl has said that she consented to sex, but not to the abuse or to the recording.\n\nThe police notified 1,004 people on Monday that they faced preliminary charges, which the police can issue on their own; prosecutors will decide whether to proceed with charges and take the cases to trial. Investigators are looking into whether the video was distributed on platforms other than Facebook.", "title": "1,000 Danes Accused of Child Pornography for Sharing Video of Teens", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nThe Sundance Film Festival started Thursday in Park City, Utah, where through Jan. 28 many of the year\u2019s most anticipated indie films will be making their debuts. The festival is also prohibitively expensive to attend, difficult to navigate, and is usually blisteringly cold and slushy. Opting for the couch instead? Host your own film festival, featuring these popular and influential movies from Sundance festivals past.\n\nFrances McDormand in \u201cBlood Simple.\u201d USA Films Movie Blood Simple Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 1985 Sundance was still known by its original moniker, the U.S. Film Festival (though its operation had just been assumed by the Sundance Institute), when the Coen Brothers\u2019 debut film won the Grand Jury Prize for a drama in 1985. A delightfully inventive and deliciously scuzzy riff on the classics of film noir, it takes the genre\u2019s stock characters \u2014 the honorable private eye; the femme fatale; the innocent man, wrongly accused \u2014 and turns them upside down, all while showing off the kind of razzle-dazzle visual style that has helped define their work ever since (and the work of director Barry Sonnenfeld, who was their cinematographer). And it was the film debut of Frances McDormand, who is both earnest and ruthless as the female lead.\n\nPeter Gallagher and Laura San Giacomo in \u201cSex, Lies, and Videotape.\u201d Miramax Films Movie Sex, Lies, and Videotape Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 1989 Steven Soderbergh\u2019s feature debut \u2014 which won the Audience Award and went on to win the Palme d\u2019Or at Cannes \u2014 was, in many ways, the quintessential Sundance movie: small in scale and intimate in scope, consisting mostly of four people talking in rooms. But the subject of that talk (sex, and the lack thereof) and the intensity and candor of that talk were what made the movie so singularly compelling, along with the deftly observed performances of its four lead actors (Andie MacDowell, James Spader, Peter Gallagher and Laura San Giacomo). Its subsequent acquisition and commercial success helped make studios aware of how much money could be made by these small-budget movies they were showing up in the mountains.\n\n0\n\nFrom left, Michael Madsen, Harvey Keitel and Steve Buscemi in \u201cReservoir Dogs.\u201d Miramax Films Movie Reservoir Dogs Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 1992 In 1991, Quentin Tarantino made use of the Sundance Institute Lab Program \u2014 which pairs novice directors with experienced mentors \u2014 to workshop his screenplay about a jewel heist gone awry. (Among Tarantino\u2019s most important mentors there was the director Terry Gilliam.) The next year, he returned to Park City with the finished feature, which notoriously failed to win at Sundance but went on to blow through the indie world like a tornado. Assembling an enviable ensemble cast of hard-boiled character actor types, Tarantino shook up the clich\u00e9s of the heist movie: He skipped over the robbery itself entirely, focusing instead on the assembly of the crew and their frayed nerves at a meet-up afterward, keeping viewers off-balance with a scrambled chronology that revealed new complexities of plot and character with each scene.\n\nJason Mewes, left, and Kevin Smith in \u201cClerks.\u201d View Askew Productions Movie Clerks Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 1994 Two years later, another scrappy, movie-crazy kid brought this chatty, low-budget debut to Sundance and took the town by storm, winning a filmmakers\u2019 trophy for dramatic features. But unlike his predecessors on this list, that filmmaker, Kevin Smith, wasn\u2019t trying to impress anyone with the slickness of his debut feature; he embraced the low budget, shooting his grubby, grainy movie during late nights at the convenience store and video shop where he worked (and which inspired the events of the film). Ultimately, its surveillance-camera aesthetic worked to the picture\u2019s benefit; it captured a particular kind of pop-culture-obsessed slacker, and became a defining ode to Generation X.\n\nMichael Williams in \u201cThe Blair Witch Project.\u201d Artisan Entertainment Movie The Blair Witch Project Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 1999 The audience at the midnight premiere of this 1999 entry by Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez was particularly lucky, as it was the only audience to see it entirely unspoiled \u2014 and thus, left to stumble out into the snow at 2 a.m., unsure whether they\u2019d just witnessed a kind of snuff film or a very clever mockumentary. That thin line between stylistic fact and narrative fiction continued to compel and confuse audiences well past that first late-night screening, turning \u201cBlair Witch\u201d into the first Sundance film to gross over $100 million when it hit theaters that summer \u2014 and reminding moviegoers that the tension of peering into the darkness could prove far scarier than scenes of blood and gore.\n\nMichelle Rodriguez in '\u2018Girlfight.\u201d Andrea Morini/Screen Gems Movie Girlfight Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 2000 By the end of the 1990s, Sundance had become the target festival for American independent filmmakers \u2014 and industry types had begun to descend on Park City every January to pluck out the Next Big Thing. They found two of them in this 2000 drama (which won a directing award and tied for the Grand Jury Prize): director Karyn Kusama, who crafts this story of a take-no-prisoners female boxer with a verisimilitude and frankness that transcends sports movie clich\u00e9s, and Michelle Rodriguez, whose leading performance is equal parts tough and tender. Both later found success in much bigger pictures, but they\u2019ve rarely found such perfect expressions of their singular voices.\n\nAdepero Oduye in \u201cPariah.\u201d Focus Features Movie Pariah Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 2011 In the years since \u201cGirlfight,\u201d Sundance\u2019s programmers have clearly attempted to widen the scope of the stories its filmmakers tell, complementing their always noteworthy world-cinema programming by increasing the number of works by women and people of color in the domestic selections. One of the best of the recent crop is this intimate character study from the writer-director Dee Rees (who went on to direct and help write \u201cMudbound\u201d), which concerns a young Brooklyn lesbian\u2019s voyage of self-discovery. The story may not be earth-shattering, but the approach is: Rees renders her story with an insider\u2019s eye, filling her frames with characters we rarely see in mainstream cinema and approaching them with the kind of empathy and honesty that\u2019s just as rare.\n\nEmayatzy Corinealdi in \u201cMiddle of Nowhere.\u201d Participant Media Movie Middle of Nowhere Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 2012 Director Ava DuVernay and her \u201cSelma\u201d star David Oyelowo first collaborated for this keenly observed and deeply moving drama about a kindhearted young woman (Emayatzy Corinealdi) who begins to question her dedication to her incarcerated husband when she meets a warm and winning bus driver (Oyelowo). DuVernay dramatizes these lives of quiet desperation with subtlety and grace, and the performances are remarkable; Corinealdi is particularly skilled at putting across the emotional urgency of her character\u2019s situation and the questions it prompts about who she is and who she wants to be. DuVernay won the directing award for a domestic drama for \u201cMiddle of Nowhere,\u201d making her the first African-American woman to take that prize.\n\n0\n\nTessa Thompson and Brandon Bell in \u201cDear White People.\u201d Lionsgate Movie Dear White People Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like Class of 2014 Justin Simien won a special jury award for breakthrough talent for this fiercely funny and wickedly provocative take on race and gender relations on college campuses, which hit Park City like a lightning bolt in 2014. Wittily orchestrating the attempts by several characters to fit in or call out their contemporaries, Simien\u2019s scathing screenplay is both socially conscious and blissfully entertaining \u2014 a kind of hybrid between intellectual debate and sketch comedy. And he provides a showcase for a star-making performance by Tessa Thompson, who burns with the rage of a campus activist and slowly reveals the complex allegiances that motivate her.", "title": "10 Breakout Films of Sundances Past, and Where to Stream Them", "authors": ["Jason Bailey"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "FRANKFURT \u2014 In 2014, as evidence mounted about the harmful effects of diesel exhaust on human health, scientists in an Albuquerque laboratory conducted an unusual experiment: Ten monkeys squatted in airtight chambers, watching cartoons for entertainment as they inhaled fumes from a diesel Volkswagen Beetle.\n\nGerman automakers had financed the experiment in an attempt to prove that diesel vehicles with the latest technology were cleaner than the smoky models of old. But the American scientists conducting the test were unaware of one critical fact: The Beetle provided by Volkswagen had been rigged to produce pollution levels that were far less harmful in the lab than they were on the road.\n\nThe results were being deliberately manipulated.\n\nThe Albuquerque monkey research, which has not been previously reported, is a new dimension in a global emissions scandal that has already forced Volkswagen to plead guilty to federal fraud and conspiracy charges in the United States and to pay more than $26 billion in fines.\n\nThe company admitted to installing software in vehicles that enabled them to cheat on emissions tests. But legal proceedings and government records show that Volkswagen and other European automakers were also engaged in a prolonged, well-financed effort to produce academic research that they hoped would influence political debate and preserve tax privileges for diesel fuel.", "title": "10 Monkeys and a Beetle: Inside VW\u2019s Campaign for \u2018Clean Diesel\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAmong our recommended works of fiction this week is Ali Smith\u2019s \u201cWinter,\u201d an \u201cinsubordinate folk tale\u201d that continues her projected quartet tied to the seasons. Two classic novels, Nella Larsen\u2019s \u201cPassing\u201d (1929) and George S. Schuyler\u2019s \u201cBlack No More\u201d (1931), have been reissued in time for Black History Month. Ruby Namdar\u2019s \u201cThe Ruined House\u201d is an intense novel about Jewish life that won Israel\u2019s most lucrative literary award. And Laszlo Krasznahorkai\u2019s \u201cThe World Goes On\u201d is full of the sprawling sentences for which the Hungarian writer has become known. In nonfiction, a wide array of subjects: threats to democracy, ancient crafts, strategy during the Vietnam War, Ezra Pound in confinement and the Nobel Prize winner J. M. Coetzee\u2019s literary criticism.\n\nJohn Williams\n\nDaily Books Editor and Staff Writer\n\nWINTER, by Ali Smith. (Pantheon, $25.95.) The second novel in Smith\u2019s projected seasonal cycle is an insubordinate folk tale, with echoes of the fiction of Iris Murdoch and Angela Carter. In it, four characters gather in a big rambling house and have at each other. Our critic Dwight Garner says that the book\u2019s elastic structure, like that of the previous novel, \u201cAutumn,\u201d \u201callows Smith the freedom to write as if improvising a bedtime story. The combination of dreaminess and acuity is what gives these books their tang.\u201d\n\nPASSING, by Nella Larsen. (Penguin Classics, $14.) BLACK NO MORE, by George S. Schuyler. (Penguin Classics, $16.) Racial passing is the central concern of both of these influential, if woefully under-read, American classics, which have been reissued in handsome new editions in time for Black History Month. \u201cFor their wildly differing approaches, the novels are both curious about what it means to feel, as well as be, truly free, and how freedom and safety might be at odds,\u201d our critic Parul Sehgal writes. \u201cThey are derisive about fantasies of racial purity, black or white. They are unsparing on the madness of racial classification but frank, and very beautiful, on the lure of racial belonging.\u201d\n\nHOW DEMOCRACIES DIE, by Steven Levitsky and Daniel Ziblatt. (Crown, $26.) In this \u201clucid and essential\u201d guide, two political scientists write about the norms that have sustained American democracy, and argue that President Trump has tried to eviscerate more than one of those norms. Our critic Jennifer Szalai, summarizing the book\u2019s circumspect conclusion, writes: \u201cThere is no democratic paradise, no easy way out. Democracy, when it functions properly, is hard, grinding work. This message may not be as loud and as lurid as what passes for politics these days, but it might be the one we need to hear.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCRAEFT: An Inquiry Into the Origins and True Meaning of Traditional Crafts, by Alexander Langlands. (Norton, $26.95.) Langlands is a sort of method archaeologist, unearthing the various ways that humans used their hands for thousands of years and taking it upon himself to do things like cutting hay, building a drystone wall and making a skep for beekeeping. Our reviewer Michael Bierut writes: \u201cLanglands, surprisingly unsentimental for someone who made his fame doing historical re-enactments, resists the pull of nostalgia. Yet he makes a persuasive case that the surrender of our lives to machines represents a regression.\u201d", "title": "10 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nFor many of us, it\u2019s bitterly cold outside, and we all just made it through another year of yelling at one another about popular culture and politics. Doesn\u2019t it seem as if the world were conspiring to push us all into our living rooms to watch more TV? Luckily, January has arguably become a more important month in the TV calendar than September, with some of the most popular and ambitious shows now arriving in what used to be called midseason.\n\nThis January has TV adaptations of best-selling crime novels, cult comic books and the short stories of Philip K. Dick. We\u2019ll also see the return of one of the most beloved shows of the \u201990s, and one of the most acclaimed of 2017 \u2014 and the debut of Dylan McDermott\u2019s cheesy new pilot\u2019s mustache. There\u2019s a lot to talk about this month; here\u2019s a taste of what\u2019s ahead:\n\nFOX\n\n\u2018LA to Vegas\u2019\n\nStarts: Jan. 2, on Fox.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nA mustachioed Dylan McDermott plays a weathered airline pilot who leads his eccentric crew on weekend jaunts back and forth from Los Angeles to Las Vegas, in this snappy sitcom that\u2019s part workplace comedy, part \u201cLove Boat\u201d-like compendium of travel anecdotes. Creator Lon Zimmet previously wrote for shows like \u201cHappy Endings,\u201d \u201cUnbreakable Kimmy Schmidt\u201d and \u201cSuperstore.\u201d \u201cLA to Vegas\u201d promises to be every bit as fast-paced and loony, with an unending string of passengers to keep the story ideas coming.\n\n\u2014\n\nFreeform\n\n\u2018grown-ish\u2019\n\nStarts: Jan. 3, on Freeform.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe likable young actress Yara Shahidi transfers her \u201cblack-ish\u201d character, Zoey Johnson, to a new sitcom, set at a typical modern college where the students are actively engaged both inside and outside the classroom. If the backdoor pilot that aired on its parent show last season is any indication, expect \u201cgrown-ish\u201d to deal with the changing politics of academia and Zoey\u2019s efforts to establish her own social and racial identity.\n\n\u2014\n\n0\n\nONE Media\n\n\u2018The X-Files\u2019 Season 11\n\nStarts: Jan. 3, on Fox.\n\nJan. 3, on Fox. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nLast year\u2019s abbreviated six-episode season of \u201cThe X-Files\u201d couldn\u2019t measure up to the classic episodes of the late \u201990s, but a few strong episodes were sprinkled into the mix. And for fans, just seeing David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson investigating the supernatural again as the F.B.I. agents Fox Mulder and Dana Scully was reason enough to tune in. A sizable viewing audience for Season 10 all but assured a Season 11. This time, the band\u2019s back together for 10 episodes, some of which will follow the continuing mystery of Mulder and Scully\u2019s missing son, others of which will be stand-alone adventures, penned by the longtime \u201cX-Files\u201d writers Darin Morgan, Glen Morgan and James Wong.\n\n\u2014\n\nThe Chi\n\n\u2018The Chi\u2019\n\nStarts: Jan. 7, on Showtime.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAt a time when Chicago\u2019s gang violence has become a political talking-point on the right and left, Lena Waithe, the Emmy-winning writer-actress from \u201cMaster of None,\u201d looks to offer a more complex view of her home city with \u201cThe Chi,\u201d an ensemble drama about a family and its friends, who are pushing to get ahead while living on the South Side. Jason Mitchell (so good in \u201cStraight Outta Compton\u201d and \u201cMudbound\u201d) stars as an aspiring restaurateur, whose skills and opportunities are often outweighed by his obligations to the people he grew up with.\n\n\u2014\n\nPrime Video\n\n\u2018Philip K. Dick\u2019s Electric Dreams\u2019\n\nStarts: Jan. 12, on Amazon.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe short stories and novels of visionary science-fiction writer Philip K. Dick have been adapted into such movies as \u201cBlade Runner,\u201d \u201cTotal Recall\u201d and \u201cMinority Report,\u201d as well as the TV series \u201cThe Man in the High Castle.\u201d For this anthology series, Ronald D. Moore (a writer and producer for \u201cBattlestar Galactica\u201d and \u201cOutlander\u201d) enlisted Steve Buscemi, Anna Paquin, Terrence Howard, Bryan Cranston, Geraldine Chaplin and others to play out some of Dick\u2019s more provocative stories. As with most of Dick\u2019s work, expect deep and troubling explorations of the ways in which future technology might affect the human spirit.\n\n\u2014\n\nThe CW Television Network\n\n\u2018Black Lightning\u2019\n\nStarts: Jan. 16 on the CW.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe network and producers behind some of today\u2019s best live-action superhero shows dig back into the DC Comics archives to revive Black Lightning, an African-American vigilante with electrical powers. Greg Berlanti and the veteran husband-and-wife writing team Mara Brock Akil and Salim Akil have cast Cress Williams as an older version of the hero, who\u2019s drawn back into crime-fighting years after hanging up his costume. At the moment, the new series isn\u2019t intended to be part of the fictional universe shared by several of the CW\u2019s superhero shows \u2014 known to fans as the Arrowverse \u2014 though if it does well, we could someday see crossovers with the likes of \u201cThe Flash\u201d and \u201cSupergirl.\u201d\n\n\u2014\n\nFX Networks\n\n\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace: American Crime Story\u2019 Starts: Jan. 17 on FX.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nIt\u2019s going to be tough for the second season of FX\u2019s anthology series \u201cAmerican Crime Story\u201d to top its award-winning first run, \u201cThe People v. O.J. Simpson\u201d \u2014 especially since its original creators, Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski, are no longer on board. Still, the producer and director Ryan Murphy has assembled a good cast to tell the story of the fashion designer Gianni Versace\u2019s death at the hands of the serial killer Andrew Cunanan. Edgar Ram\u00edrez plays Versace, while Ricky Martin plays his boyfriend, Pen\u00e9lope Cruz plays his sister Donatella and Darren Criss is the killer who preyed on wealthy gay men.\n\n\u2014\n\nTNT\n\n\u2018The Alienist\u2019\n\nStarts: Jan. 22, on TNT.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nCaleb Carr\u2019s best-selling historical crime novel \u201cThe Alienist\u201d followed a winding path to the small screen. A movie adaptation stalled in the \u201990s, then a parade of A-list writers and directors (including John Sayles and Cary Fukunaga) took a shot at whittling the grim book into something more audience-friendly for TV. Now, TNT is finally set to air the result of that collaboration, which stars Daniel Br\u00fchl as an 1890s psychologist and police consultant in New York, who uses controversial methods to track a serial killer \u2014 at the behest of the new police commissioner, Teddy Roosevelt. Dakota Fanning and Luke Evans also star in this dark mystery that doubles as a look at turn-of-the-century America.\n\n\u2014\n\nHBO\n\n\u2018Mosaic\u2019\n\nStarts: Jan. 22, on HBO.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe relentlessly experimental director Steven Soderbergh and screenwriter Ed Solomon introduced their murder mystery, \u201cMosaic,\u201d back in November as an interactive iOS and Android app, turning the story into an elaborate \u201cchoose your own adventure\u201d game. The HBO version of \u201cMosaic\u201d eliminates the branching element, delivering a more straightforward narrative about a children\u2019s book author (played by Sharon Stone), the man accused of killing her, and the amateur sleuths looking into what really happened.\n\n\u2014\n\nNetflix\n\n\u2018One Day at a Time\u2019 Season 2\n\nStarts: Jan. 26 on Netflix.\n\nJan. 26 on Netflix. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThe TV year got off to a great start in 2017 with this reimagining of Norman Lear\u2019s long-running \u201970s-and-\u201980s sitcom \u201cOne Day at a Time.\u201d Now, just a few weeks into 2018, the writer-producers Gloria Calder\u00f3n Kellett and Mike Royce revisit working-class Los Angeles and the Cuban-American Alvarez family, as they lovingly argue about everything from global politics to contemporary gender roles. Like Season 1, the second season will use an old-fashioned three-camera, live-audience format as a way to lend the episodes some of the immediacy of theater.\n\nAlso of interest (new and returning): \u201cEllen\u2019s Game of Games\u201d (NBC, Jan. 2), \u201c9-1-1\u201d (Fox, Jan. 3), \u201cThe Four: Battle for Stardom\u201d (Fox, Jan. 4),\u201cChild Support\u201d (ABC, Jan. 5), \u201cComedians in Cars Getting Coffee\u201d (Netflix, Jan. 5), \u201cDevilman Crybaby\u201d (Netflix, Jan. 5), \u201c75th Annual Golden Globe Awards\u201d (NBC, Jan. 7), \u201cDavid Bowie: The Last Five Years\u201d (HBO, Jan. 8), \u201cAlone Together\u201d (Freeform, Jan. 10), \u201cThe Magicians\u201d (Syfy, Jan. 10), \u201cDisjointed\u201d (Netflix, Jan. 12), \u201cCrashing\u201d (HBO, Jan. 14), \u201cDivorce\u201d (HBO, Jan. 14), \u201cHot Streets\u201d (Adult Swim, Jan. 14), \u201cDetectorists\u201d (Acorn TV, Jan. 15), \u201cCorporate\u201d (Comedy Central, Jan. 17), \u201cThe Path\u201d (Hulu, Jan. 17), \u201cBeyond\u201d (Freeform, Jan. 18), \u201cPortlandia\u201d (IFC, Jan. 18), \u201cGrace and Frankie\u201d (Netflix, Jan. 19), \u201cHigh Maintenance\u201d (HBO, Jan. 19), \u201cCounterpart\u201d (Starz, Jan. 21), \u201cThe Resident\u201d (Fox, Jan. 21), \u201cBaskets\u201d (FX, Jan. 23), \u201cBellevue\u201d (WGN, Jan. 23), \u201cDrunk History\u201d (Comedy Central, Jan. 23), \u201cWaco\u201d (Paramount, Jan. 24), \u201cDirty Money\u201d (Netflix, Jan. 26), \u201cStep Up: High Water\u201d (YouTube Red, Jan. 31)", "title": "10 Shows We\u2019ll Be Talking About in January", "authors": ["Noel Murray"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nThe evidence that President Trump obstructed justice has come in dribs and drabs. But when that evidence is compiled in one place, I think it becomes overwhelming.\n\nMy column this morning is organized around a list of 10 instances when Trump has tried to interfere with the federal investigation into his campaign\u2019s relationship with Russia. You can read the column here.\n\nI decided to use a list for historical reasons. When Congress drafted articles of impeachment against both Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton, it used a list to make the case that each had obstructed justice. Nixon\u2019s list \u2014 in the first article of impeachment passed by the House Judiciary Committee \u2014 had nine items. Clinton\u2019s list had seven. My list for Trump has 10 items (and of course is based only on the publicly known facts so far).", "title": "Opinion | 10 Ways Trump Has Obstructed Justice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Our list this week starts off with two very different debut novels. Hermione Hoby\u2019s \u201cNeon in Daylight\u201d borrows its title from the poet Frank O\u2019Hara, and recalls prior novels about ambivalent women by writers like Joan Didion and Zadie Smith. A. J. Finn\u2019s \u201cThe Woman in the Window,\u201d already a best seller, is packed with Hitchcock references and plot twists. Other suggestions include a sweeping history of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, an account of how Istanbul has evolved through the centuries and James Lee Burke\u2019s latest Dave Robicheaux mystery.\n\nJohn Williams\n\nDaily Books Editor and Staff Writer\n\nNEON IN DAYLIGHT, by Hermione Hoby. (Catapult, $16.95.) In Hoby\u2019s radiant first novel, Kate, a British Ph.D. student, is visiting New York in 2012, in the waning days of summer. Hurricane Sandy is about to unleash itself on the city. Our critic Parul Sehgal says the book\u2019s characters are \u201cpropelled less by desire than by a desire for desire; for any kind of strong feeling, really,\u201d and that \u201cprecision \u2014 of observation, of language \u2014 is Hoby\u2019s gift. Her sentences are sleek and tailored. Language molds snugly to thought.\u201d\n\nTHE WOMAN IN THE WINDOW, by A. J. Finn. (William Morrow, $26.99.) Finn is actually Dan Mallory, a longtime editor of mystery fiction who is well versed in the tricks of the trade. His first novel starts out with a setup reminiscent of Alfred Hitchcock\u2019s \u201cRear Window.\u201d An agoraphobic woman thinks she has witnessed a crime in a neighboring building. But has she? Our reviewer Janet Maslin writes: \u201cDear other books with unreliable narrators: This one will see you and raise you.\u201d\n\nENEMIES AND NEIGHBORS: Arabs and Jews in Palestine and Israel, 1917-2017, by Ian Black. (Atlantic Monthly, $30.) Black, a veteran correspondent for The Guardian, argues in this sweeping history that Zionism and Palestinian nationalism were irreconcilable from the start, and that peace is as remote as ever.", "title": "11 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Becoming a mother is one of the most transformative life experiences. Some women find complete satisfaction in the role, while others are forced to make difficult choices or wish they had remained childless. We set out to capture the breadth of this human phenomenon. We posted a call-out on our social media channels asking you to share your stories \u2014 and more than 1,300 of you responded. This six-part video series is the result. Video\n\n_____", "title": "11 of Our Best Weekend Reads", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "And just like that, we\u2019re in 2018. It\u2019s Golden Globes weekend, so get to know some of the nominees (Greta Gerwig, Tom Hanks and Meryl Streep). You might be reckoning with frigid temperatures \u2014 and maybe your New Year\u2019s resolutions (we\u2019re not judgy if you haven\u2019t kept them). So wrap up in a warm blanket and read a few of these great stories. If video is more your thing, we have that, too!\n\nPhoto\n\nIt built the city. Now, no matter the cost \u2014 at least $100 billion \u2014 the New York City must rebuild it to survive. And ICYMI, Brian M. Rosenthal wrote last week about the astronomical cost of building a mile of subway track: $3.5 billion. She said Netflix offered her a six-figure deal compared with multimillion-dollar payouts for Dave Chappelle and Amy Schumer.", "title": "15-Minute Stand-Up Specials? Netflix Is Trying a New Format", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019m aware I should be grateful the days are rushing by for me. I have ill friends in almost constant discomfort who describe their days as \u201cunending\u201d and \u201chard to fill.\u201d One recently told me, \u201cTime goes about as fast as I can push this walker.\u201d\n\nKnowing I\u2019m a stumble away from a walker of my own has me examining how I spend the days left to me. That is more difficult than it seems as my mind often resembles a theater, transforming the most casual stroll into a play noisy with dialogue.\n\nDoes the girl texting as she hurries forward realize she\u2019s going to plow into me? Are there enough hedge-fund managers to fill all the apartment buildings shooting skyward around me? Which is more likely to hit me as I cross this street, a taxi or a bike?\n\nHardest for me is reflecting quietly on the path I\u2019ve taken to where I have yet to go. I know I have to make some profound changes in my behavior if I am to recapture the adventure and passion I experienced during the first 18 years of my life. That means being willing at 88 to acknowledge I have to break habits that are comfortable but confining.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe place to begin was the theater of my mind. I read of a brain training center that treats children with behavioral problems and adults entering dementia. I called and asked if their neurofeedback program could help a healthy brain achieve a better balance between the noisy frequencies that fill my mind with chatter and the quieter, more calming ones. They said it might, and I decided to participate in a few sessions.\n\nI followed a therapist to a soundproofed room, where electrodes were attached to various parts of my head and connected to a computer that measured the electrical patterns of my brain. The therapist\u2019s objective was to invigorate neurons that were less active \u2014 the rarely quiet part of my brain \u2014 while dimming those firing more vigorously. After six sessions, I had no idea if my mind attained a healthy equilibrium between chatter and calm.\n\nI do know I emerged determined to find in my daily life the tranquillity I experienced in that room. While I\u2019ve meditated for years, the peace I feel during 30 minutes of mindfulness is quickly eclipsed by noise in the street and in my head. I had to begin replacing the dramas playing in my mind with the quiet needed to reflect on how I was going to spend the time remaining to me.\n\nI\u2019m trying to break other habits in far more conventional ways. As in many long marriages, my wife and I enjoy spending time with the same friends, watch the same television programs, favor the same restaurants, schedule vacations to many of the same places, avoid activities that venture too far from the familiar.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe decided to become more adventurous, shedding some of those habits. European friends of ours always seem to find the time for an afternoon coffee or glass of wine, something we never did. Now, spontaneously, one of us will suggest going to a coffee shop or cafe just to talk, and we do. It\u2019s hardly a lifestyle revolution, but it does encourage us to examine everything we do automatically, and brings some freshness to a marriage that started when Dwight Eisenhower was elected president.\n\nMy fitness regimen had also become habitual: treadmill, swimming, core exercises and resistance training. Watching others work out in different ways tempted me to vary that routine. When I read about a rehabilitation program designed for a New York Giant defensive lineman who had mangled his hand, it made me wonder if I could ask new things of my body.\n\nThe gym he went to was near my home, and I arranged a meeting with his trainer and asked if he could design a far less rigorous program for me. He added exercises I had never attempted, pedaling and running in brief bursts of intensity, lifting weights while balancing on one foot, focusing more on reaching and lifting movements that mimic the functions of everyday life, countering the stiffness accompanying aging by stretching, bending and leaping. The workout I now follow is mentally and physically taxing but within the capabilities of someone my age, and I regard it as part of my intention to ask more of my mind and body in these remaining years.\n\nNone of these efforts to break old habits will add one day to my life. But I feel I\u2019ve stepped off the conveyor and am experiencing some of the passion and adventure I felt in the first 18 years of my life.", "title": "18 Years Into the New Millennium, Finding My Younger Self", "authors": ["Robert W. Goldfarb"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "A century ago this year, artillery fell silent across Europe. Communists dismantled an empire. The most devastating pandemic in six centuries swept the globe.\n\nThe events of 1918 still resonate today.\n\nOn the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month of the year, the gunfire of World War I ceased over borders wholly transformed. The bodies of the fallen littered Europe from the English Channel to the Adriatic Sea. Politically and socially, the ripple effects reached far beyond the trenches and chemical laboratories from which the war had been fought.\n\nRussia, reeling from the previous year\u2019s revolution, endured a vicious civil war, punctuated by the execution of Czar Nicholas II and his family in the dead of night. Finland fought its own civil war after breaking from the Russian Empire. Polish troops, fresh off their nation\u2019s declaration of statehood, massacred Jews in three days of pogroms.", "title": "1918 Brought an Armistice, but Also a World of Death", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 There is a loud outcry throughout England against the generous rations that are given to the German war prisoners in internment camps in Great Britain. This criticism is being accentuated as the food queues in London lengthen and as the Germans continue their bombardments of London.\n\nLetters innumerable are written to the newspapers complaining against the allowances of food to the Germans, and the Government is almost ordered by public sentiment to reduce their fare.\n\nA correspondent, writing to the \u201cDaily Express,\u201d says: \u2014\n\n\u201cFor breakfast the fortunate people in the camp have a big plateful of porridge, tea, bread, margarine, and part of their weekly ration of 7oz. of jam if they care to draw on it. For dinner they have 6oz. of beef or mutton, 10oz. of vegetables (potatoes and cabbage, cauliflower or other greenstuff in season), bread, and rice, tapioca, or semolina, when cheese is not available. They had cheese up to last week, although very few people outside the camp could get it. For tea they have bread, margarine, jam and tea. They have two meatless days a week, and on these occasions they are provided with 12oz. of salted herring a day.\n\n\u201cThe meat supply, we are told, is only sufficient to allow each British citizen a pound a week; but in practice even this amount cannot be had. The allowance of the German is nearly double, and he gets his supply daily without effort and without worry.\u201d\n\n\u2014 The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 31, 1918", "title": "1918: German Prisoners Are Overfed, Britons Say", "authors": ["The International Herald Tribune", "International Herald Tribune"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "In telephone interviews, David and Alexis Lerner, resident directors of a dormitory at the college who knew Hannah, said she had successfully petitioned the school to install bins and freezers for residents to collect materials for composting.\n\nImage A picture from Irene Steinberg\u2019s Facebook page of her family, who lived in Scarsdale, N.Y. The plea was sealed until this week when it was made public as part of an unrelated pending corruption case on Long Island.\n\nThe guilty plea was won by federal prosecutors in the Eastern District, which covers Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island.\n\nMr. de Blasio\u2019s ties to Mr. Singh and several other campaign donors for whom he did favors were investigated by federal prosecutors in the Southern District, which includes Manhattan. They decided not to bring charges against Mr. de Blasio or his aides \u2014 but in doing so, last year, they issued a cutting statement raising questions about the mayor\u2019s ethics and making it clear he had done favors for donors.\n\nA similar case arose with the other donor, Jona S. Rechnitz, who made campaign contributions and gave money to a nonprofit group the mayor created to support his City Hall agenda.\n\nIn return, Mr. Rechnitz got access to Mr. de Blasio, calling and emailing him. The result was personal attention when Mr. Rechnitz, a real estate investor, had problems with the city. A friend\u2019s water bill overcharges got quickly resolved. Mr. Rechnitz got a meeting with the head of a city agency that had fined one of his properties for an illegal hotel.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Rechnitz pleaded guilty in 2016 to honest services wire fraud. But although Mr. de Blasio solicited and received the donations and made it possible for Mr. Rechnitz to get special access, he was not charged.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeveral factors were in play.\n\nThe United States Supreme Court set a much higher bar for public corruption cases with its 2016 ruling that reversed the bribery conviction of the former Virginia governor, Bob McDonnell. In the ruling, the court determined that making introductions or setting up meetings, even in exchange for gifts or financial benefits, did not constitute a crime.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs a consequence, several prominent corruption convictions were set aside, and prosecutors have become more cautious in taking on such cases.\n\nFurthermore, bribery cases against elected officials based on campaign contributions are rare, the legal experts said. That is in part because the Supreme Court has drawn a clear distinction between a legal contribution to a political campaign and other kinds of payments like cash, gifts or other benefits that in effect go into the pocket of a public servant.\n\nIt may also have been that it was simply easier for prosecutors to bring charges against the person buying access, because the men admitted guilt, in the face of abundant evidence, as part of plea deals in which they agreed to cooperate with the government against other defendants. Mr. Singh is a witness in corruption trials on Long Island; Mr. Rechnitz testified against a labor official who was accused of steering millions of dollars of officers\u2019 retirement funds into a hedge fund in exchange for promised kickbacks.\n\nNonetheless, the outcomes seem incongruous: Mr. Singh pleaded guilty to bribing the mayor, charges brought by the Eastern District prosecutors, while those in the Southern District examined the same conduct and chose not to charge the mayor. But current and former federal prosecutors and defense lawyers said there could be several explanations.\n\n\u201cWhen there\u2019s an allegation that money has changed hands,\u201d said Paul J. Fishman, who served as the United States attorney in New Jersey for more than seven years, \u201csometimes the issue is whether the transaction actually occurred. But often it\u2019s not about that, and instead is about what the people were thinking at the time that they made that exchange.\u201d\n\nThe mayor said at the time that Mr. Rechnitz\u2019s account was untrue; the case, against the labor leader Norman Seabrook, ended in a mistrial, in part because Mr. Rechnitz seemed an unreliable witness.\n\nBut in Mr. Singh\u2019s case, the charges to which he pleaded guilty, detailed in a court document, amounted to more than just his admissions that he had received benefits from Mr. de Blasio\u2019s administration in return for his contributions; they were the conclusions not only of the prosecutors handling the matter, but also of their boss, Robert L. Capers, then the United States attorney for the Eastern District, who signed the document.\n\nThat included a July 2015 meeting in which Emma Wolfe, a top aide to Mr. de Blasio, met with Mr. Singh to negotiate a settlement, which contained more favorable terms than he had previously been offered.\n\n\u201cNothing that he described as having happened, happened, period,\u201d Mr. de Blasio said on WNYC. But the meeting did happen, and so did City Hall\u2019s other efforts on behalf of Mr. Singh, which have emerged.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnthony M. LaPinta, Mr. Singh\u2019s lawyer, disputed the mayor\u2019s assertion. \u201cMr. Singh pleaded guilty to his crimes because he is, in fact, guilty of those crimes,\u201d Mr. LaPinta said in a emailed statement.", "title": "2 Donors Plead Guilty, but the Mayor Is Not Charged. For instance, Bill O\u2019Reilly, then the top-rated host in cable news, was forced out in April after a New York Times investigation found that he and Fox had paid a combined $13 million in settlements to women who had accused him of sexual harassment.\n\nSimilar allegations extended all the way up to Roger Ailes, the chairman of Fox News, who died in May. While the choices may sometimes seem overwhelming, they also present a wonderful opportunity for pleasure and experimentation.\n\nOn a recent expedition through a handful of Manhattan shops, I found these 20 excellent bottles, all under $20. They come from eight different countries, and even more regions. Most of these are red, in deference to the season, when most people gravitate toward heartier dishes. But in winter I still eat foods that call for white wines, and I always like sparkling wines, so both are represented as well.\n\nThe $20 price is crucial. Budget-minded shoppers may recoil, believing they can find plenty of bottles under $10. That\u2019s true, and most of those wines will be technically sound. They will also be boring, the scourge of mass-market wines today.\n\nBy contrast, most of these are from small producers who work traditionally and sometimes iconoclastically. Wines like these cost a little more, from $15 to $25, but for that price, the level of interest and pleasure in the wines increases exponentially.", "title": "20 Wines Under $20: Touring the World, Familiar to Obscure", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "A few weeks ago we gave you the Golden Globes red carpet with its many black dresses, black tuxes and political statements.
