(Let us not forget this was the event that gave us Jennifer Lopez\u2019s plunging green Versace dress in 2000, Kanye West\u2019s lilac tuxedo and gloves in 2006, Lady Gaga\u2019s giant egg in 2011 and Nicki Minaj and her papal date in 2012.)\n\nThis year, the style was slightly more staid, but no less fun to look at.. See many of the looks from the 2018 Grammys red carpet right here.", "title": "2018 Grammys Red Carpet Photos: Cardi B, Lady Gaga and More", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Reporters from The New York Times checked the facts, falsehoods and statements in need of context from President Trump\u2019s first State of the Union address. Watch a replay along with real time analysis here, and read an annotated transcript of the speech.\n\neconomy\n\n\u201cSince the election, we have created 2.4 million new jobs, including 200,000 new jobs in manufacturing alone.\u201d\n\nThe math is correct, but context matters.\n\nThe economy has added about 169,000 jobs a month since the 2016 election, but that is somewhat less than the 185,000 jobs per month that the economy added over the previous seven years.\n\n\u2014 Binyamin Appelbaum\n\neconomy\n\n\u201cAfrican-American unemployment stands at the lowest rate ever recorded.\u201d\n\nTrue, but needs context.\n\nIt\u2019s true that the black unemployment rate in December, 6.8 percent, was the lowest recorded, but that is also the culmination of a longer-term trend. Moreover, it\u2019s an open question how much credit a president, especially in his first year, can take for the economy.\n\n\u2014 Linda Qiu\n\neconomy\n\n\u201cAfter years of wage stagnation, we are finally seeing rising wages.\u201d\n\nFalse.\n\nWages are, in fact, rising \u2014 but at a slower rate than they were at the end of President Obama\u2019s second term.\n\n\u2014 Jim Tankersley\n\nhealth care\n\n\u201cWe eliminated an especially cruel tax that fell mostly on Americans making less than $50,000 a year \u2014 forcing them to pay tremendous penalties simply because they couldn\u2019t afford government-ordered health plans. We repealed the core of disastrous Obamacare \u2014 the individual mandate is now gone.\u2019\u2019\n\nTrue, but needs context.\n\nIn the newly passed tax law, Congress eliminated penalties for people who go without health insurance, starting in 2019. An estimated 4.5 percent of taxpayers paid the penalty in 2015, and nearly 60 percent of those who did earned less than $50,000 in 2015 \u2014 though the Kaiser Family Foundation found that a sizable amount of low-income Americans paying the penalty could find coverage for less.\n\nPeople could, in many cases, obtain exemptions from the penalties that were indeed a major element of the Affordable Care Act. Other elements of the health care law remain intact.\n\n\u2014 Robert Pear\n\neconomy\n\n\u201cApple has just announced its plans to invest a total of $350 billion in America, and hire another 20,000 workers.\u201d\n\nThis needs context.\n\nThe technology giant Apple did, indeed, say after the tax cut passed that it would \u201cinvest\u201d $350 billion domestically over the next five years. But at least $275 billion of that was simply continuing the company\u2019s past spending trends. The actual amount of new investment appears to be roughly $37 billion.\n\n\u2014 Jim Tankersley", "title": "2018 State of the Union Fact Check", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Did you feel like you were breaking ground when you made it?\n\nI do feel like it was maybe a little bit ahead of its time. It was difficult just to get a black woman on the poster by herself.\n\nHow does it feel to be back at Sundance?\n\nI feel like this is the place to be right now because there\u2019s change.\n\nWere there movies you had seen that represented your experience before you decided to make your film?\n\nI\u2019m a fan of Gordon Parks and I thought \u201cThe Learning Tree\u201d was a great coming-of-age story. But I love Diana Ross in \u201cLady Sings the Blues\u201d because that was her story. It wasn\u2019t an ensemble piece.\n\nPhoto\n\nI studied film in France and I\u2019m a big international film buff. I love Godard, Ousmane Semb\u00e8ne, Mizoguchi. These filmmakers often focused on a woman\u2019s story. Also Spike\u2019s film \u201cShe\u2019s Gotta Have It.\u201d I liked that it was about one woman\u2019s journey. But, it was from a male\u2019s point of view. Still good though.\n\nSo you\u2019re saying that although Spike Lee\u2019s film stars a woman character, you feel the character is written more like how a man would see her?\n\nYep.\n\nHow did you get your movie made?\n\nI actually submitted my script to some of the mini majors [studio divisions]. One person said, \u201cWe love the script, we think it\u2019s great. But could you make her boyfriend, Tyrone, a drug dealer?\u201d I said no, I wouldn\u2019t change it. So I ended up starting a company and raising money myself through grants.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut we ran out of money in post. I sent a script to the writer Terry McMillan. She sent a check to help. Also Michael Moore saw a rough cut of the film and he helped, too.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2015, you asked Michael Moore a question during a Q&A at the New York Film Festival and offered him a role in your next movie.\n\nAnd he said yes.\n\nYou also asked him about what the mostly male, white Hollywood execs could do to help open doors for more people of color.\n\nYes, and I\u2019m glad I spoke up. I don\u2019t know if this had anything to do with it, but it was the next year that Ava DuVernay\u2019s movie opened the New York Film Festival.\n\nWhat\u2019s happening with the film you said you\u2019d give Michael Moore a role in?\n\nWe\u2019re still trying to get financing. It\u2019s still rare to have a black director, writer and producer making a film with a black lead female character. This one is about a cinema professor. It\u2019s called \u201cI Love Cinema.\u201d\n\nHas this been the case ever since \u201cJust Another Girl?\u201d\n\nYes. After I did that movie, I wrote several screenplays but little happened. I did a short for Showtime about Bessie Coleman, the first African-American pilot. I went around pitching that for a feature and people would say, the story\u2019s not that important. I wrote a movie about a female hip-hop artist. People said they loved the script, but I couldn\u2019t get that financed. I tend to write films that deal with one black woman\u2019s story. That\u2019s where it becomes a little tricky in the film industry. And I think it does a disservice to the black women who aren\u2019t getting that kind of role.\n\nHow do you think more change will happen?\n\nWell I think art really reflects our society. And maybe now with more women speaking up and having their voices be heard, we can see a shift. Maybe if we had more black executives, they would see the importance of these stories. I mean, how can you not do a film about Bessie Coleman?", "title": "25 Years After a Breakthrough at Sundance, Trying to Break Through Again", "authors": ["Mekado Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDocuments released on Tuesday revealed that police investigating the mass shooting last October in Las Vegas were seeking to question a second man in connection to the attack.\n\nThe identity of the man has not been previously reported. It is unclear whether the man who was identified in the documents as a person of interest remains under investigation. The authorities have said that Stephen Paddock was the sole gunman responsible for the attack, but that there was one additional person of interest still under investigation whom they declined to identify.\n\nOn Tuesday, a Nevada court unsealed hundreds of pages of search warrants, including an affidavit filed less than a week after the shooting that identifies the gunman\u2019s longtime girlfriend as a person of interest. The authorities subsequently said the girlfriend, Marilou Danley, was not considered a suspect and that she had continued to cooperate with local and federal investigators.\n\nThe records also included another person of interest, Douglas Haig, whose name the judge ordered redacted. The Las Vegas Review-Journal used an unredacted copy and identified Mr. Haig.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Haig\u2019s whereabouts was unknown and he could not be reached for comment.\n\nA Douglas Haig in Mesa, Ariz., who is an engineer at Honeywell Aerospace, also operated a company called Specialized Military Ammunition, a limited liability corporation his wife opened in 2012. In October, Mr. Haig told Newsweek that he had been interviewed by agents with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. He said that he did know Mr. Paddock and had not sold ammunition \u201cfor a long time.\u201d On Tuesday, a website for the company noted \u201cWe Will Be Closed Indefinitely. Check back to see if/when we are up and running again.\u201d", "title": "2nd Person of Interest Was Identified in Days After Las Vegas Shooting, Documents Show", "authors": ["Jennifer Medina", "Mitch Smith"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "MANILA \u2014 The Philippine Justice Department filed murder charges on Monday against three police officers in the death of a 17-year-old boy last year, a case that strengthened opposition to President Rodrigo Duterte\u2019s brutal war on drugs.\n\nThe officers \u2014 Arnel Oares, Jeremias Pereda and Jerwin Cruz \u2014 were charged in a lower court in Caloocan City, north of Manila, along with an informant who had erroneously identified the boy, Kian Loyd delos Santos, as a drug pusher.\n\nWitnesses had described seeing Mr. delos Santos being dragged away by the officers and finding his body slumped over near a pigsty. That contradicted statements by the police officers, who said the boy had pulled a gun, setting off a shootout in which he died.\n\nThe teenager\u2019s death in August ignited public anger, and his funeral procession became a protest led by the influential Catholic Church and activists who denounced Mr. Duterte\u2019s drug crackdown.", "title": "3 Philippine Officers Charged in a Killing That Spurred Outrage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "In his will, Edward Kleban, the Tony Award-winning lyricist of \u201cA Chorus Line,\u201d made provisions to underwrite two cash prizes for musical theater writers whose work shows great potential: one to a lyricist and one to a librettist.\n\nThis year, however, there are three winners of the Kleban Prize, each of whom will receive $100,000, payable over two years.\n\nAlan Schmuckler and Amanda Yesnowitz were given the lyricist prize, while Christian Duhamel is the recipient of this year\u2019s librettist award.\n\nMr. Schmuckler wrote, along with Michael Mahler, the music and lyrics of \u201cDiary of Wimpy Kid: The Musical,\u201d which premiered at the Children\u2019s Theater Company in Minneapolis in 2016. Ms. Yesnowitz wrote the lyrics for \u201cSomewhere in Time,\u201d a 2013 musical adaptation of the 1980 film starring Christopher Reeve and Jane Seymour. She is currently working on a musical inspired by the life of Margaret Bulkley, an Irish woman who lived as a man in the 19th century.", "title": "3 Promising Musical Theater Writers Receive $100,000 Prizes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Watching is The New York Times\u2019s TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.\n\nI Want to Believe\n\nGillian Anderson and David Duchovny in \u201cThe X-Files.\u201d Shane Harvey/Fox\n\n\u2018The X-Files\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Wednesday at 8 p.m., on Fox.\n\nWednesday at 8 p.m., on Fox. Save To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nThis week\u2019s episode of \u201cThe X-Files,\u201d \u201cThe Lost Art of Forehead Sweat,\u201d is one of the most fun episodes of the show ever, revival or original. It explores the Mandela Effect, which is when large groups of people misremember the same wrong information. (It\u2019s named for the shared memory some people apparently have of Nelson Mandela\u2019s dying in the 1990s. He died in 2013.) Is it just the fallibility of the human brain? Or \u2026 is it some kind of eerie conspiracy?\n\nWhile there are many fabulous Easter eggs for longtime fans of the show, this episode is still worth a go even if you\u2019ve only seen a handful of episodes or mostly know Mulder and Scully through cultural osmosis \u2014 it\u2019s as clever and snappy an hour as you\u2019re likely to see on network television. Bonus points for brilliant use of Vancouver\u2019s A-maze-ing Laughter sculpture park, where 14 bronze statues are equal parts cheerful and intimidating.\n\nI Want Something Fun\n\nCatherine O\u2019Hara in \u201cSchitt\u2019s Creek.\u201d Pop TV\n\n\u2018Schitt\u2019s Creek\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Wednesday at 8 p.m., on Pop.\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\n\u201cSchitt\u2019s Creek\u201d returns for its fourth season this week, and while I typically say, \u201cJust jump in!,\u201d especially for comedies, this show really won\u2019t make much sense unless you\u2019ve seen at least some of Season 3. Fear not, though: The first three seasons are all streaming on Netflix.\n\n\u201cSchitt\u2019s\u201d is about a wealthy family whose fortune ran out, so the parents (Eugene Levy and Catherine O\u2019Hara) and their two adult children (Daniel Levy and Annie Murphy) find themselves living in a run-down small town. Season 1 is decent, but Season 2 is where it really takes off. It\u2019s very bingeable, so if you have a cold or depression, give yourself permission to give the day over to a \u201cSchitt\u2019s Creek\u201d marathon. If you are one of the many people who have asked me what to watch now that they\u2019ve burned through \u201cYounger,\u201d the answer is \u201cSchitt\u2019s Creek.\u201d\n\n0\n\nI Want to Cry But Be O.K.\n\nPeter Engler and Ann Curry in \u201cWe\u2019ll Meet Again.\u201d Blink Films, via PBS\n\n\u2018We\u2019ll Meet Again\u2019\n\nWhen to watch: Tuesday at 8 p.m., on PBS (check local listings).\n\nSave To Watch Ribbon Save to Watch Like Heart Shape Like\n\nAnn Curry hosts this new series that reunites people whose paths unexpectedly diverged after historical events. This week\u2019s episode brings together people whose lives were fractured by World War II: In one segment, it\u2019s a Japanese-American woman who was forced into an internment camp as a little girl and is looking for the white classmate who stood up for her; in the other, it\u2019s a German Jewish man looking for the descendants of the family friends who nurtured him when he was a child refugee in the Shanghai Ghetto. Poignancy abounds!\n\nI Don\u2019t Know What I Want, Give Me All My Choices\n\nTiffany Haddish in \u201cDrunk History.\u201d Comedy Central\n\nOn Monday, we have two new shows: \u201cThe Alienist,\u201d at 9 p.m. on TNT, and \u201cMosaic,\u201d at 8 p.m. on HBO. \u201cThe Alienist\u201d is a historical drama based on Caleb Carr\u2019s 1994 novel, which follows a psychiatrist and his pals as they track a serial killer. If you like moody thrillers, this is a decent one, though it is so darkly shot that it\u2019s almost impossible to see what\u2019s happening. (What\u2019s happening is little-boy sex slaves are being murdered.)\n\n\u201cMosaic,\u201d starring Sharon Stone and directed by Steven Soderbergh, is a six-episode mini-series that airs every night this week (with two episodes airing on Friday). It was released as an app late last year, but here it is packaged as a traditional murder-mystery mini-series, complete with Soderbergh\u2019s signature ice-cold stare. Stone is terrific, and the show absolutely scratches the \u201crich people\u2019s fancy houses\u201d itch.\n\nTuesday things are certainly breezier, with Tiffany Haddish appearing on \u201cDrunk History,\u201d in a solid episode all about heroines (10 p.m. on Comedy Central). \u201cThe Detour\u201d is back on TBS for its third season, starting at 10:30 p.m. I loved Season 1 of this family-on-the-lam comedy starring Jason Jones and Natalie Zea, but I was significantly less into Season 2. Luckily, Season 3 seems to be back on track. And \u201cBaskets\u201d is also back on FX at 10 p.m., if you are looking for sad-clown stories.\n\nOn Wednesday, if you didn\u2019t want to watch \u201cThe X-Files\u201d or \u201cSchitt\u2019s Creek,\u201d there\u2019s a new mini-series on Paramount Network (nee Spike) called \u201cWaco,\u201d starring Taylor Kitsch as David Koresh, the infamous cult leader whose standoff with the government in 1993 left nearly 80 people dead. Michael Shannon plays the F.B.I. hostage negotiator, and while the performances are all strong, the series on the whole feels a little spiritless, as if it were preserved behind glass. It starts at 10 p.m.\n\nFinally, on Thursday, \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race\u201d is back on VH1 at 8 p.m. with another all-star season. It\u2019s a 90-minute episode, so plan accordingly. Thursdayalso features new episodes of \u201cTop Chef\u201d and \u201cProject Runway\u201d (Bravo at 10 p.m.and Lifetime starting at 7:54 p.m.), as well as this season\u2019s penultimate episode of \u201cThe Good Place,\u201d at 8:30 on NBC. Options!", "title": "3 Shows to Watch This Week. And Also a Bunch More.", "authors": ["Margaret Lyons"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSHANGHAI \u2014 The Chinese and South Korean authorities on Sunday were searching for 32 crew members who went missing after their oil tanker collided with another ship off China\u2019s east coast the night before.\n\nThe site of the collision, which happened roughly 160 miles off the coast of Shanghai at 8 p.m. Saturday, according to China\u2019s Ministry of Transportation, is in the middle of seas with heavy shipping traffic between China and South Korea.\n\nThe oil tanker, registered in Panama, collided with a bulk freighter registered in Hong Kong. The government said that all 21 crew members of the bulk freighter had been rescued, while the 32 missing were from the oil tanker.\n\nOf those missing, 30 are Iranian citizens and two are from Bangladesh, according to the Chinese government. The 21 rescued are all Chinese citizens.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA photo posted by China\u2019s state news media showed a large plume of black smoke rising from the waters behind a single ship amid low, overcast clouds.\n\nIn an article, Xinhua, the Chinese state-run news agency, said China had sent eight search and rescue vessels while Shanghai\u2019s fire department sent experts to advise on combating the fire. South Korea sent a fixed wing plane and Coast Guard vessel to help with the efforts.\n\nWhile the extent of the fire or any spillage of oil is not clear, China\u2019s state news media said that the oil tanker, which is owned by an Iranian company, is about 900 feet long and was carrying 136,000 metric tons of oil.", "title": "32 Sailors Missing After Ships Collide Off China\u2019s East Coast", "authors": ["Paul Mozur"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "2) How big will it really be?\n\nThe effort focuses on the United States employees of JPMorgan Chase, Amazon and Berkshire Hathaway. Together, the companies have nearly one million employees (a portion of those, though, are outside of the United States.) That\u2019s a lot of employees but relatively small when compared with 157 million people who had employer health care plans at the end of 2016, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation. Would the venture be able to scale up? Some experts are skeptical about that. Ben Gomes-Casseres, a professor of international business at Brandeis, wrote: \u201cMy bet is that JPMorgan and Amazon\u2019s employees have pretty good health coverage, with plans that rank among the richest that the industry has to offer. If so, will these lead users be anxious to find a more cost-effective model? Will they even be willing to experiment with their coverage? And, beyond that \u2013 if they do develop a new approach, will it be helpful to the masses of employees at lesser companies, or, worse, the unemployed and uninsured?\u201d\n\n3) Do these companies bring valuable expertise to providing health care at a lower cost?\n\nIt\u2019s not clear how much more expertise Amazon, Berkshire and JPMorgan have than companies that have been operating in health care for decades. Amazon could have gotten into pharmacy services years ago, if it had wanted, which means it might have seen complexities and risks that don\u2019t exist in other sectors. Berkshire brings a strong insurance specialization, but not in providing health insurance directly to the consumer. What is more, Berkshire\u2019s point man in the joint health care effort will be Todd Combs, an investor who does not come from the insurance operations of the company.\n\n4) If the high cost of health care is the main problem, what can this venture do to cut costs?\n\nMuch depends on whether the effort can address the main reason that health care spending has gone up in the United States versus other countries. A recent Upshot column showed how much of the rise is a result of more being done for patients during hospital stays and doctor visits, or that they are charged more for those services. One way to assess the brash new initiative from Jeff Bezos, Warren Buffett and Jamie Dimon is whether it does anything to address this dynamic.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\n\u2018A hungry tapeworm on the American economy.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s how Warren Buffett referred to the nation\u2019s \u201cballooning costs of health care\u201d Tuesday.\n\nMr. Buffett\u2019s Berkshire Hathaway announced it is teaming up with JPMorgan Chase and Amazon to form an independent health care company to serve their employees in the United States.\n\nThe three companies provided few details about the new entity, other than saying it would initially focus on technology to provide simplified, high-quality health care for their employees and their families, and at a reasonable cost. They said the initiative, which is in the early planning stages, would be a long-term effort \u201cfree from profit-making incentives and constraints.\u201d\n\nMr. Buffett\u2019s concern about rising health care costs is not new, nor is his use of \u201ctapeworm\u201d to describe them. Mr. Buffett\u2019s statement Tuesday echoes other recent comments he has made on the subject. He trotted out the tapeworm metaphor to describe rising medical costs during television interviews in 2010 and 2012, MoneyBeat\u2019s Ben Eisen and Erik Holm point out.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt Berkshire\u2019s annual meeting in May, he said: \u201cMedical costs are the tapeworm of American economic competitiveness.\u201d\n\nIn fact, Mr. Buffett use of the tapeworm metaphor to describe drags on the economy dates back more than three-and-a-half decades at least.\n\nMr. Buffett wrote in his 1981 shareholder letter: \u201cInflation acts as a gigantic corporate tapeworm.\u201d\n\nThen in his 2013 letter to Berkshire shareholders, he wrote: \u201cCitizens and public officials typically under-appreciated the gigantic financial tapeworm that was born when promises were made that conflicted with a willingness to fund them.\u201d\n\nTurbulence ahead?\n\nThe smooth glide higher for U.S. stock markets may be hitting a bumpier stretch.\n\nVolatility, as measured by the widely followed C.B.O.E. Volatility Index, or VIX, jumped nearly 30 percent in recent days as investors paused to consider the ongoing sell-off in the United States dollar and rising yields on United States government debt.\n\nThe S.&P. 500 stock index dropped roughly 0.7 percent early Tuesday and could notch its second consecutive decline, something that hasn\u2019t happened since mid-December.\n\nLow interest rates have been a key ingredient in the almost relentless rise in U.S. equity markets. But with the yield on the benchmark U.S. 10-year Treasury now above 2.70 percent, its highest level in four years, that backdrop could be changing.\n\n\u2014 Matt Phillips\n\nPhoto\n\nFrom Amex to venture capital to help start-ups mature\n\nDespite being inundated by post-American Express job offers, Ken Chenault has chosen an interesting path: becoming chairman and managing partner of General Catalyst Partners, which has invested in Airbnb, Warby Parker and Stripe, among others.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore interesting is why he\u2019s taking the job, Andrew writes in his latest DealBook column. He\u2019s hoping to be the adult in the room for the next generation of start-ups, after the troubles at Uber, SoFi and more.\n\nHere\u2019s what he told Andrew:\n\n\u201cGiven their age and the scale and size and impact that they can have on our society, unless they make a step up, we are going to have some serious problems,\u201d Mr. Chenault said. \u201cAnd we do have serious problems.\u201d \u201cCompanies are starting to realize that they are growing up, and in growing up, they have to assume some broader responsibilities,\u201d he added. \u201cCompanies are at different stages, from a self awareness standpoint, in accepting that reality.\u201d\n\nOch-Ziff has picked a new C.E.O.\n\nIn selecting Rob Shafir \u2014 previously the head of Credit Suisse\u2019s American operations \u2014 as the successor to Daniel Och, the hedge fund has apparently laid to rest questions about its leadership planning.\n\nA reminder: Before Mr. Shafir, Mr. Och\u2019s chosen successor was James Levin. Then the two men had a falling out.\n\nMr. Och\u2019s statement:\n\n\u201cRob is a world-class executive who will be a great asset to Oz as we continue our evolution as a firm. His distinguished career of over 30 years leading global financial institutions and asset management businesses brings unique experience that will benefit Oz significantly.\u201d\n\nAnd a statement by Mr. Levin, who had weighed quitting \u2014 but was identified in today\u2019s statement as still being Och-Ziff\u2019s co-chief investment officer:\n\n\u201cOz is a tremendous firm with a talented and creative team that works each day to identify and execute on the most compelling investment opportunities around the world. I am excited about the future and look forward to welcoming Rob.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nWho will succeed Jamie Dimon?\n\nThe JPMorgan Chase chief said yesterday that he plans to stick around another five years. So who will eventually pick up the baton?\n\nIn the short term: It could be Daniel Pinto, the head of JPMorgan\u2019s investment bank, or Gordon Smith, the head of its consumer bank. They were named co-presidents yesterday \u2014 but Mr. Pinto is 55 and Mr. Smith is 59.\n\nIn the longer term: It could be one of the other executives named in the firm\u2019s statement:\n\n\u2022 Mary Erdoes, 50, who runs the asset and wealth management arm\n\n\u2022 Doug Petno, 52, who runs the commercial banking division\n\n\u2022 Marianne Lake, 48, the C.F.O.\n\n\u201cThe board and Dimon both believe that under all timing scenarios, whether today or in the future, the company has several highly capable successors in place,\u201d JPMorgan said in its statement. But the firm has had trouble holding onto potential successors over the years.\n\nThe political question: Mr. Dimon has said publicly that he isn\u2019t going to run for president. (There\u2019s been speculation, and friends are still encouraging him to try.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Antony Currie writes, \u201cJPMorgan has given Jamie Dimon the freedom to outstay his welcome.\u201d (Breakingviews)\n\n\u2022 Lex writes, \u201cAs murky as the future is, the situation at JPMorgan is probably preferable to Goldman, where there is a ferocious thinly-disguised competition between the two co-presidents for the top job.\u201d (FT)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat will Trump talk about in his first State of the Union?\n\nSurely jobs and the economy, given how often he has spoken on those topics (including at the World Economic Forum in Davos). Politico also suggests infrastructure, immigration, trade and national security.\n\nBut here are the big questions:\n\n\u2022 Will President Trump stick to the script and focus on issues like spending $1 trillion on infrastructure?\n\n\u2022 How hard will he press the White House immigration proposal? Democrats are opposed, and the next shutdown deadline is Feb. 8.\n\n\u2022 Will he touch on health care, given that Republicans have so far rolled back only a small portion of the Affordable Care Act?\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee voted to release a contentious memo alleging improprieties in the surveillance of a Trump campaign associate. The Justice Department had wanted it kept secret. (NYT)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. (Axios)\n\n\u2022 Congressional Republicans are hoping to tame President Trump\u2019s stances on trade. (Politico)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Businesses and investors are starting to focus on a little-noticed provision in the tax overhaul: \u201copportunity zones\u201d to draw investment in economically disadvantaged areas. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The F.B.I.\u2019s deputy director, Andrew McCabe, is stepping down after months of criticism by Mr. Trump. (NBC News)\n\nPhoto\n\nDon\u2019t expect nationalized 5G\n\nBoth the F.C.C. and the telecom industry are against a plan created at the National Security Council and reported by Axios.\n\nHere\u2019s what Ajit Pai of the F.C.C. said:\n\n\u201cAny federal effort to construct a nationalized 5G network would be a costly and counterproductive distraction from the policies we need to help the United States win the 5G future.\u201d\n\nThe White House itself backed away from the proposal and appears to prefer focusing on building secure networks using 5G tech.\n\nWhat\u2019s behind the controversy, from Cecilia Kang and Mark Landler of the NYT:\n\nIt lays bare the differences between two camps in the administration that have been present since Mr. Trump\u2019s inauguration: economic nationalists and China hawks. Among those officials aggressively pushing the 5G network are two China hard-liners: Gen. Robert S. Spalding II, the senior director for strategic planning at the National Security Council, and Peter Navarro, the director of the White House national trade council.\n\nElsewhere in tech\n\n\u2022 Facebook will promote local news, Mark Zuckerberg says. And pediatric and mental health experts are asking him to discontinue a children\u2019s messaging service.\n\n\u2022 How committed is Kodak to virtual currency? (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Microsoft issued an update to Intel\u2019s update mitigating the Spectre security flaw. (CNBC)\n\n\u2022 Strava users in the U.S. military have inadvertently disclosed their locations and habits, including in sensitive areas in Iraq and Syria. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nAntonio Weiss is back in the deal business, thanks to Keurig\n\nListed in the phalanx of bankers and lawyers behind the $18.7 billion Dr Pepper Snapple deal is a name you might easily miss, \u201cAFW LP.\u201d It\u2019s short for \u201cAntonio Francesco Weiss,\u201d the former Lazard banker and Treasury Department official \u2014 and an adviser to Keurig.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe recap\n\nMr. Weiss was one of Lazard\u2019s biggest deal makers, eventually becoming the firm\u2019s global head of investment banking. He worked on InBev\u2019s takeover of Anheuser Busch and Reynolds American\u2019s takeover of Lorillard. (He also sold D.E. Master Blenders to JAB, the investment firm that later bought Keurig.)\n\nBut Mr. Weiss left Lazard to become a counselor at the Treasury Department under the Obama administration, taking on issues like Puerto Rico\u2019s debt crisis and new lending marketplaces.\n\nSince then\n\nHe\u2019s become a senior fellow at the Mossavar-Rahmani Center for Business and Government at Harvard\u2019s Kennedy School, and a director at the Volcker Alliance.\n\nHe has considered getting back into investment banking, and has been courted by many a bank. And he might yet start his own shop.\n\nWho\u2019s afraid of an I.P.O.?\n\nCompanies want to go public. But recent news suggests that many want to avoid the initial public offering process.\n\n\u2022 Exhibit A: Keurig\u2019s $18.7 billion deal with Dr Pepper Snapple Group, which would let JAB take the coffee maker public.\n\n\u2022 Exhibit B: Dell is contemplating a reverse merger with VMware, according to CNBC. (That\u2019s one of several options, we\u2019ve been told.)\n\n\u2022 Exhibit C: Spotify.\n\nOf course, there will still be I.P.O.s.: Uber, Dropbox and Airbnb are all working toward offerings. But if some companies can avoid the process, it appears they will.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Blackstone is in advanced talks to buy about 55 percent of Thomson Reuters\u2019 Financial and Risk business, valuing the unit at about $20 billion, including debt, according to unnamed sources. The editor, Tim Herrera, emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nThis week I\u2019ve invited Kenneth R. Rosen from the Smarter Living team to share some great tips about working from home, with a little help from readers. Last fall he wrote a guide to working from home, and below is even more advice for people who are either starting out or looking to stay motivated at home. What\u2019s your advice for staying productive (or beating boredom)? Let Ken know on Twitter @kenneth_rosen or at kenneth.rosen@nytimes.com.\n\nTake it away, Ken!\n\n***\n\nAfter I published \u201cHow to Work From Home,\u201d tons of readers wrote in wanting to know the steps to building a career around working from home, whether that meant finding jobs and gigs or balancing a family on top of a workload. Others felt that success \u201cat working from home doesn\u2019t require a magic checklist of dos and don\u2019ts, but instead a focused desire to perform and succeed.\u201d\n\nHere are some tips for making it work for you.\n\nFinding Remote Work\n\nThere are many companies and websites that connect freelancers with employers, but they can be sparse depending on your specific trade and industry. Upwork is a wonderful platform that I have used for small projects.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou set up a profile based on your area of expertise \u2014 it\u2019s open to writers, programmers and developers, administrative support workers, translators, financial professionals, marketers and more \u2014 and then browse available jobs and postings. After placing bids, you can be awarded short- or long-term contracts. A nifty desktop app tracks and logs your daily hours and sends them directly to your employer.", "title": "4 Simple Tips for Working From Home", "authors": ["Tim Herrera"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think I had everything else on my r\u00e9sum\u00e9,\u201d Wozniacki said later, the trophy glittering by her side. \u201cNo. 1, year-end championships, big tournaments, 27 titles. I basically have beaten any player that has been playing that is on tour right now. This was the only thing missing, and it means something extra even that it took a little longer, but I still made it here.\u201d\n\nHalep, a Romanian, will lose her No. 1 ranking to Wozniacki on Monday, and knows all too well about delayed gratification. She is now 0-3 in major single finals and has lost all of them in three sets.\n\n\u201cMaybe the fourth time will be with luck,\u201d she said in remarks to the crowd at Laver Arena, before leaving the court.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s fine,\u201d she said later. \u201cI cried, but now I\u2019m smiling. Is just a tennis match in the end. But yeah, I\u2019m really sad I couldn\u2019t win it. It was close again, but the gas was over in the end. She was better. She was fresher. She had actually more energy in the end.\u201d\n\nThis much-anticipated final was tight and tense from the beginning. The spectators sounded as divided as tennis fans in general, with roughly equal support being expressed for \u201cCaro!\u201d and \u201cSimona!\u201d\n\nThe match turned into a grueling fitness test, with both finalists breathing hard, even on the changeovers. Eventually each took a medical timeout.\n\nExtended rallies were the rule. There were 50 exchanges that lasted nine shots or more, 50 others that lasted from five to eight shots.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis was no surprise in light of the speed and defensive skills that both women possess, but it made for quite a challenge.\n\nMomentum shifted repeatedly. Wozniacki took a 3-0 lead to start before Halep reeled her in to force a tiebreaker that Wozniacki \u2014 playing aggressively, particularly down the line \u2014 was able to dominate.\n\nPhoto\n\nHalep won the second set despite taking a medical timeout when leading, 3-2, because of dizziness and a headache. She looked woozy even while closing out the set.\n\nBoth players were able to cool down before the third set, with a 10-minute off-court break allowed because of the heat.\n\nThe match kept tossing and turning. Wozniacki went up, 3-1, in the third set only to lose three straight games. But just when it seemed that Halep might definitively have the edge, Wozniacki, down, 3-4, took a medical timeout to have her left leg taped below the knee.\n\nAfter play resumed, she did not lose another game.\n\nNeither Halep nor her coach, Darren Cahill, cried foul over Wozniacki\u2019s break, even though Halep had to wait longer than usual to serve.\n\n\u201cMaybe those three minutes were a little bit tough,\u201d Halep said. \u201cBut you know the rule is the rule. I don\u2019t complain.\u201d\n\nWith Halep serving at 4-5, 30-30, Wozniacki won one of the match\u2019s best rallies: an 18-shot duel that forced her to sprint from corner to corner and come up with a tightly angled backhand on the run that allowed her to take control and finish the point with a forehand winner.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThat was a crazy point,\u201d Wozniacki said.\n\nIt gave her match point, and in light of the way this tournament had gone, the big surprise was that Halep did not find a way to save it.\n\nWhen Halep\u2019s backhand hit the net, Wozniacki hit the deck, immediately throwing her racket in the air and then crying as she lay on her back with her hands covering her face.\n\n\u201cI never cry, but today is a very emotional moment,\u201d Wozniacki said to the crowd as she cradled the Cup that she was already calling Daphne.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShe spared a word for Halep, too.\n\n\u201cI know today is a tough day,\u201d she said, turning to face her opponent. \u201cI\u2019m sorry I had to win today, but I\u2019m sure we\u2019ll have many matches in the future. It was an incredible match, incredible fight, and again, I\u2019m sorry.\u201d\n\nShe sounded as if she meant it.\n\nSuch a happy ending for Wozniacki looked highly unlikely in the second round of the tournament, when she faced two match points and a 1-5 deficit in the final set against unseeded Jana Fett of Croatia.\n\nWozniacki escaped and went on to win six consecutive games.\n\n\u201cI think that match really helped Caroline with the feeling that she was playing a little bit with house money \u2014 that\u2019s how we kept putting it,\u201d said her fianc\u00e9, David Lee, a retired N.B.A. player who was courtside for all of her matches in Melbourne. \u201cI was sitting there planning what I was going to say to her after the match to help cheer her up, and next thing you know you are moving on \u2014 so it was really, really special.\u201d\n\nWozniacki and Lee became engaged in Bora Bora in November. Both she and her father and coach, Piotr Wozniacki, have said that feeling happy and settled in her personal life has helped her on the court.\n\n\u201cObviously sport and life are all connected,\u201d Lee said. \u201cWhen you\u2019re happy off the court, I think that makes a difference, and she\u2019s got that stability. She knows that whatever happens in tennis, she\u2019s got a great support system, and I\u2019m happy to be a part of that.\u201d\n\nSaturday was, perhaps above all, a father-daughter moment. High-profile coaches have come and gone in the Wozniacki camp, but Piotr has been a constant in her tennis career.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think we both deserve this,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s just special that when I started playing tennis at 7 years old, he was there. It was training at 11 p.m. or 10 p.m. when I was 10 years old. My dad was there. When it was raining. When it was hot. He was always there by my side, and I think this means a lot to both of us.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHalep had saved match points of her own, five in total over two matches: her third-round victory over the American Lauren Davis and her semifinal victory over the former No. 1 Angelique Kerber.\n\nShe also sprained her left ankle in her first-round victory. It all took a physical toll, and she said she had been unable to practice for more than \u201c15 minutes\u201d between matches during the tournament. Cahill said much of the pain ended up in Halep\u2019s right foot because she was compensating for her left ankle.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s swollen, my right one,\u201d Halep said. \u201cBoth of them are dead. That\u2019s why I need a break.\u201d\n\nThis was the first Grand Slam final in the Open era between women who had both faced match points in the tournament.\n\nWozniacki and Halep had also both lost their previous two major finals. But Wozniacki is now the first player from Denmark to win a major singles title.\n\nShe lost the 2009 United States Open final to Kim Clijsters and the 2014 United States Open final to Williams. Both opponents were aggressive base liners, with power in abundance, and they took the initiative against the more defensive-minded Wozniacki.\n\nShe said she briefly considered retirement in 2016 when recurring physical problems, particularly a severe ankle injury, contributed to her drop in the rankings. Wozniacki was at No. 74 before the 2016 United States Open, but reached the semifinals and has now made it all the way back to the top.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe has changed her game in recent seasons and improved her serve and forehand. Wozniacki still relies on her outstanding coverage and consistency from the baseline, but she has added a dose of risk to the mix.\n\nIt helped her win the WTA Finals \u2014 the elite, eight-women, season-ending championship \u2014 last year. That was her most significant title until Saturday\u2019s.\n\nIt has been quite a process. Though Wozniacki is just 27, this was her 43rd appearance in a Grand Slam singles tournament. Flavia Pennetta, Marion Bartoli and Jana Novotna are the only women to have played in more before winning a first major trophy.\n\nThe first time Wozniacki played the Australian Open, as a 17-year-old in 2008, she reached the fourth round. She rose to No. 1 in October 2010 and \u2014 with the exception of one week \u2014 held the top spot until January 2012.\n\nShe faced questions all through that run about her inability to win a Grand Slam title.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m No. 1 in the world. I\u2019m 20 years old, so I think I\u2019m doing fine,\u201d she said in an interview in May 2011. \u201cObviously, of course, I\u2019d like to win a Grand Slam, but I don\u2019t put pressure on myself. Next year. This year. In three years.\u201d\n\nIt took nearly seven, and it was sweet. No one else will ask her whether she will ever be able to win a Grand Slam singles title \u2014 a question she joked on Saturday night that she had heard \u201ca hundred thousand times.\u201d (Or maybe she wasn\u2019t joking).\n\n\u201cI think that\u2019s one of the most positive things about all this: I\u2019m never going to get that question again,\u201d she said. \u201cI\u2019m just waiting for the question, When are you going to win the second one?\u201d", "title": "43rd Time\u2019s the Charm: Caroline Wozniacki Wins Her First Major Title", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "PASADENA, Calif. \u2014 Too many TV shows to choose from?\n\nYou\u2019re not alone.\n\nAt least 487 original scripted programs aired in 2017, the latest record-breaking figure for the TV industry, according to data released Friday by the cable network FX.\n\nThat was more than the 455 shows that broadcast in 2016, more than the 288 in 2012 and far more than the 182 from 15 years ago.\n\nThe staggering growth largely comes from the seemingly endless budget lines that help produce new shows for streaming services. Netflix, for example, has said it will spend a $8 billion on content this year.\n\nIn 2013, the year that Netflix\u2019s \u201cHouse of Cards\u201d premiered, online services distributed only 24 original programs. In 2017, that number skyrocketed to 117.", "title": "487 Original Programs Aired in 2017. The editor, Tim Herrera, emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nIt\u2019s not just you: Yes, everyone you know really is sick.\n\nThis year\u2019s flu season is the worst in nearly a decade \u2014 the most intense since 2009\u2019s swine flu pandemic \u2014 and it\u2019s only going to get worse. (If you\u2019re curious why it\u2019s so bad this year, read this.)\n\nThere are a few things you can do to protect yourself from the flu, like washing your hands frequently and disinfecting shared spaces, but sometimes you will catch it despite your best efforts.\n\nIf you\u2019re among the unlucky millions who will get the flu this year, this is the most important advice: If you\u2019re able to stay home, please stay home. Going into work while you\u2019re sick doesn\u2019t prove anything, and you\u2019re putting your co-workers at risk. Really \u2014 just stay home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPhew, glad we got that out of the way.
