The New York theater is obligingly presenting a host of deliberately disorienting productions from an international array of artists this month, in works designed to rearrange your mind and shake up your senses. Fixed notions of nationality, gender and race are being deconstructed and detonated in one of the liveliest lineups of brave new plays in many a season. Here, a quintet of iconoclastic eye-openers to help you focus on the future.\n\nPanorama\n\nFor the Italian troupe Motus, boundaries aren\u2019t made for crossing, but for erasing altogether. Two years ago, this genre-blending company confounded and elated downtown audiences with \u201cMDLSX,\u201d a mixed-media meltdown of gender-specific identity. Motus returns to one of its favorite haunts, La MaMa in the East Village, to consider the possibility of a world unfettered by nationalism \u2014 and, heck, even nationhood \u2014 in the sprawling performance piece \u201cPanorama,\u201d which suggests that to migrate is simply to do what comes naturally. (Don\u2019t expect to see Donald J. Trump in the audience.)\n\nTickets: publictheater.org/Under-the-Radar/\n\nPhoto\n\nBallyturk\n\nFew people fall apart as energetically, or as entertainingly, as the characters created by the Irish dramatist Enda Walsh. The author of such exhilarating spectacles of self-destruction as \u201cThe Walworth Farce,\u201d \u201cPenelope\u201d and \u201cMisterman\u201d is once again occupying St. Ann\u2019s Warehouse in Brooklyn with a shaggy tale of Gaelic disharmony. In \u201cBallyturk,\u201d two nameless friends swap stories of the rural village of the title, which may well exist only in their feverish, mutually dependent fantasies. (Those hungry for more of Mr. Walsh\u2019s brand of narrative mayhem can see a first-rate, London-born revival of his \u201cDisco Pigs,\u201d in which two marauding hedonists come of age, at the Irish Repertory Theater.)\n\nTickets: stannswarehouse.org\n\nPhoto\n\nMiles for Mary\n\nA guaranteed cure for the perverse nostalgia for the 1980s that seems to be creeping into American culture these days. This inspired group portrait of high school teachers planning a fund-raising telethon brings back all the self-help-seeking klutziness of the decade, with a jargon-laden vocabulary (and wince-making cultural references) to match. Created by the Mad Ones and first staged at the Bushwick Starr in 2016, \u201cMiles for Mary\u201d crosses the river into Manhattan with its original director, the excellent Lila Neugebauer, and blissfully bonded ensemble, which fans the frictions that emerge during a seemingly endless series of conferences into a bonfire to remember.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTickets: playwrightshorizons.org\n\nPhoto\n\nHe Brought Her Heart Back in a Box\n\nNow there\u2019s an evocative title for you, conjuring dread, romance and a tragic surrealism all at once. Such is the distinctively poetic and terrifying universe of Adrienne Kennedy, a playwright\u2019s playwright of slender output and immense influence. Which makes this latest offering, her first new play in nine years, an event for theater cognoscenti. A Theater for a New Audience production, directed by Evan Yionoulis at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn, Ms. Kennedy\u2019s phantasmagoric drama takes a treacherous sentimental journey into the Georgia and New York City in the 1940s, when the specters of Nazism and Jim Crow cast Jacobean shadows on an interracial romance.\n\nTickets: tfana.org\n\nAt Home at the Zoo\n\nEdward Albee was one of the great pioneers of the drama of melting identity, starting with \u201cThe Zoo Story,\u201d his reputation-making portrait from 1958 of the feral darkness beneath civilized surfaces. In the early 21st century, Albee wrote an enriching companion piece to \u201cThe Zoo Story\u201d called \u201cHomelife,\u201d and the two works were staged in tandem at Second Stage Theater a decade ago. They return to New York at the Signature Theater to probe and poke anew at the beast within. Ms. Neugebauer directs a cast led by Robert Sean Leonard as the unraveling soul at its center.", "title": "5 Shows to See if You\u2019re in New York in January", "authors": ["Ben Brantley"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "1. Embrace the New Pink\n\nIt\u2019s official: Fuchsia has supplanted millennial pink as the rose du jour. Don\u2019t save it for accents. Take counsel from a prefall collection like Pucci and wear as much of it as possible, ideally in streamlined shapes that defy any notion of Barbie-dom.\n\nStaud silk organza trench coat, $350 at staud.clothing; Altuzarra stretch wool blazer, $1,695, and flared pants, $695, at Neiman Marcus, neimanmarcus.com; Calvin Klein cotton logo turtleneck, $295 at Saks Fifth Avenue, saksfifthavenue.com.", "title": "5 Styling Tweaks to Make Right Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Rural lawmakers and farm groups revolted when the Obama administration tried to tighten some child labor rules to keep children away from manure pits and block them from driving tractors and other heavy equipment. They pilloried the move as a big-government intrusion that would outlaw children from doing their chores. The proposals \u2014 which would have exempted children on their parents\u2019 farms \u2014 were quickly dropped.\n\nThese days, researchers say, it is even hard to know how many children are getting hurt, and how and where. Some public health groups and universities collect news clippings of farm accidents, but the federal government stopped running its own surveys in 2015.\n\nOn the Schachtschneider farm, the boys started learning early. Their father, Caleb Schachtschneider, 36, said he taught his two older sons, Maric and Kholer, by letting them sit in his lap as he drove the tractor or skid steer across the farm.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like an extension of you,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you\u2019re around it, you\u2019ve got to teach them. They need to know because they\u2019re there. Otherwise, they\u2019d get hurt worse.\u201d\n\nRunning the equipment became second nature to the older boys, their father said. But accidents still happened. Two years ago, when Kholer struck Maric with the skid steer, Maric spent a week in the hospital and came home in a wheelchair, said the boys\u2019 mother.\n\nMs. Smith, 34, said she hated seeing her children drive the yellow machine squatting beside the barn. Sometimes she fantasized about ramming it with her car or maybe selling it off. But she also defended allowing the boys to do work that would otherwise require hiring help the family could not afford. Seeing her children bottle-feed calves and milk full-grown cows was a source of pride. Farmwork taught them how to take care of themselves, she said.\n\n\u201cIf we were to just leave and not let our kids continue to grow up like this, what are they going to have?\u201d she asked. \u201cWhat are they going to learn? Just to quit?\u201d", "title": "5-Year-Olds Work Farm Machinery, and Injuries Follow", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe West Wing\u201d met \u201cThe Apprentice\u201d on Tuesday when President Trump presided over an extraordinary meeting, later broadcast on television, of lawmakers from both parties debating policy in the cabinet room. On the table: immigration.\n\nOver the course of about 55 minutes, members of both the House and the Senate discussed how best to protect undocumented immigrants who arrived as children, and whether to embrace a path to citizenship for millions of other immigrants. President Trump gave his endorsement to a plan for broad changes, even as the lawmakers debated a narrower deal that could be reached sooner.\n\nHere are some dramatic moments from the meeting.\n\nFirst of all, take a look at who was around the table.", "title": "6 Dramatic Moments in Trump\u2019s Unusual Immigration Session", "authors": []} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "Well, at least it\u2019s not 2017 anymore.\n\nI expect that future historians will look back on it as one of the darker non-war years in the country\u2019s history \u2014 a year when the president lied constantly, America\u2019s global influence suffered and Congress used its mighty powers to enrich the rich. Yet the long view of American history still offers reason for optimism. We usually figure out how to emerge from our darker periods.\n\nIn the hope that 2018 represents at least the start of a turning point, I offer seven New Year\u2019s wishes:\n\nRepublicans stand up for the rule of law. The country\u2019s most urgent problem is the possibility that the president will impede an investigation into illegal behavior by his aides and possibly himself.\n\nPresident Trump clearly wants to do so. His allies are defaming Robert Mueller even though Mueller is a longtime Republican, a successful F.B.I. director and a decorated Marine who\u2019s now pursuing matters of national interest, such as: Does a hostile foreign power have influence over American officials? And did the president use illegal tactics in his campaign?\n\nRepublicans in Congress can make sure that the country gets answers. They can refuse to tolerate any disruption of Mueller\u2019s investigation, including the firing of him or his boss, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein. If Trump tries to go there, his fellow Republicans can tell him that his presidency would effectively be over. Privately and publicly, they should be saying so now.", "title": "Opinion | 7 Wishes for 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "And the \u201cTrump effect\u201d seems to have worn off at the southern border. Illegal crossings are up again. Above, an arrest in San Diego.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. President Trump was asked whether he would be interviewed by Robert Mueller, the special counsel in the Russia inquiry, without preconditions. \u201cI\u2019ll speak to my attorneys,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ll see what happens.\u201d\n\nThe response came after Senate Democrats issued a new report concluding that Russia\u2019s interference in the 2016 election fits into a nearly two-decade pattern of meddling \u2014 and that the U.S. response was being hindered by the White House. Above, Vladimir Putin in Moscow last month.\n\nIn a Times Op-Ed, Ben Smith, the editor in chief of Buzzfeed News, defended his decision to publish the salacious \u2014 and largely unsubstantiated \u2014 dossier on links between the Trump campaign and Russia.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. DJT Holdings, a corporate entity owned by President Trump, is embroiled in a court battle with a Manhattan condominium over whether it can remove his name from the building. The company argues that it cannot.\n\nAnd the president is due for a physical on Friday. It will be the first formal check on his personal physician\u2019s claim that he\u2019d be the \u201chealthiest individual ever elected\u201d to the office. But what he discloses about it is up to him.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. In Southern California, at least 15 people have been killed and more than two dozen injured by huge mudslides unleashed by heavy rain. The authorities said two dozen people were still missing and 300 were stuck in their homes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe disaster was a direct result of recent wildfires, which left the land vulnerable to mudslides.\n\n\u201cIt sounded like a freight train,\u201d one resident said. See the aftermath in this video.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. Imagine being trapped in a Winter Wonderland.\n\nThat was the situation for 13,000 tourists in a resort village at the foot of the Matterhorn, one of the most famous peaks in the Swiss Alps. Heavy snow and rain left them stranded there for two days, with only one option out: an airlift.\n\n\u201cEven if you can\u2019t ski, there is always something to do, like eating fondue or chocolate in the village,\u201d one visitor reported.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Myanmar charged two Reuters journalists detained last month with obtaining state secrets. They face up to 14 years in prison if convicted.\n\nU Wa Lone, center front, and U Kyaw Soe Oo, center back, had been investigating the existence of a mass grave in Rakhine State, where a military campaign against the Rohingya has sent hundreds of thousands of people fleeing into Bangladesh.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. We found a secret shelter for homeless men like William Arroyo, above, in the basement of a Brooklyn bodega.\n\nThe owner, Candido Arc\u00e1ngel, has been quietly taking in men in need of help for the last 14 years, allowing them to stay in the store\u2019s cellar. He can\u2019t bear the idea of anyone out in the cold.\n\n\u201cThis is not a personal mission; it\u2019s a mission for the good of society,\u201d he said.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. Tonya Harding isn\u2019t sorry. In fact, she thinks she deserves an apology.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOur reporter spent time at a skating rink with Ms. Harding, discussing the new movie \u201cI, Tonya,\u201d the Nancy Kerrigan scandal and Ms. Harding\u2019s struggles to tell her side of the story. She says that she had to overcome poverty and abuse and that the deck was always stacked against her.\n\n\u201cI was always told I was fat. I was ugly. I wouldn\u2019t amount to anything,\u201d she said. \u201c\u2018If you don\u2019t smile and follow through they\u2019re not going to give you the marks. If you wear that ribbon they\u2019re not going to give you the marks. If you wear that dress they\u2019re not going to give you the marks.\u2019\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s our review of \u201cI, Tonya.\u201d\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. Finally, it\u2019s here: our annual list of 52 places to inspire travelers. The list includes popular spots like New Orleans and lesser-known gems like Gansu, in China, and S\u00e3o Tom\u00e9 and Principe, on Africa\u2019s West Coast. Here\u2019s how we chose the locations.\n\nThis year we are sending one writer to visit each and every place. We got 13,000 applications for the job. And now, please meet the lucky traveler: Jada Yuan, above. You\u2019ll have all of 2018 to get to know her.\n\nHave a great night.\n\n____\n\nYour Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.\n\nAnd don\u2019t miss Your Morning Briefing, posted weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern, and Your Weekend Briefing, posted at 6 a.m. Sundays.\n\nWant to catch up on past briefings? You can browse them here.\n\nIf photographs appear out of order, please download the updated New York Times app from iTunes or Google Play.\n\nWhat did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "7-Eleven, California, Tonya Harding: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing", "authors": ["Karen Zraick", "David Scull"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Bekir Bozdag, the deputy prime minister of Turkey, said on Twitter that Turkey would respect Syria\u2019s territorial integrity and sovereignty, and would pull out of the region once the target was achieved.\n\nHe added that the military campaign was not against the Syrian government or its people but against terrorist organizations. He named the Kurdish Y.P.G. and P.K.K. groups, as well as the Islamic State, as the targeted organizations.\n\n\u201cThe only target of the operation is the terrorist groups and the terrorists as well as their barracks, shelters, positions, weapons, vehicles and equipment,\u201d he said. \u201cCivilians are never targeted. Every kind of planning has been done to avoid any damage to civilians.\u201d\n\nThe Russian Foreign Ministry expressed concern at the assault and called for restraint. The Russian Defense Ministry said in a statement that it was withdrawing its troops and military police from the enclave to avoid any conflict.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a later statement Russia blamed the United States for the clashes.\n\n\u201cProvocative actions by the U.S., aimed at isolating regions with predominantly Kurdish population, were the main factors that contributed to the development of a crisis in this part of Syria,\u201d the statement read.\n\nYet despite Russian reservations, it appears there was high level communication between Turkey and Russia on the operation. The chief of staff of Turkey\u2019s army, Hulusi Akar, who is commanding the operation, visited Moscow on Thursday with the head of Turkey\u2019s National Intelligence Organization, Hakan Fidan.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd despite its expression of concern, Russia cooperated on deconfliction efforts by allowing Turkish jets into Syrian airspace and by removing its troops form Afrin, Turkish analysts said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Turkish Army announced Saturday evening that 72 fighter jets had returned safely to their bases.\n\nThe general command of the Syrian Democratic Forces, the mainly Syrian Kurdish rebel force that has led the United States-backed fight against the Islamic State, appealed to Turkey to cease its operation in Afrin, calling it an unjustifiable aggression against the Syrian people that would undermine the fight against the Islamic State.\n\n\u201cIf attacked, we will have no choice but to defend ourselves and our people,\u201d the command said in a statement, \u201cbut we state in front of the world that we harbor no hostile intent towards Turkey.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSyrians in the region expressed alarm, as the aerial bombardment hit outlying villages along the Turkish border.\n\nCivilians were fearful and were leaving Afrin and the villages along the border, a resident of Afrin said. He asked that his name be withheld from publication out of concern for his safety.\n\nA lawmaker in Syria\u2019s Parliament expressed concern that Turkey was looking to create strife among Syrians by using Arab members of the rebel Free Syrian Army to fight Syrian Kurds.\n\nThe Syrian government and some Kurdish militias were negotiating to raise Syrian government flags over public buildings in Afrin to try to avert the Turkish bombing, the lawmaker said. The lawmaker added there was a split among Kurds about whether to accept the Syrian government\u2019s retaking of Afrin, in a bid to end the Turkish offensive, or whether Kurds should maintain control and resist the offensive.\n\nBassam Barabandi, a former Syrian diplomat who defected during the early days of the crisis, sent out a forlorn appeal to all parties to abide by an agreement forged in March between American-backed Kurdish rebels and Turkish-backed Syrian opposition fighters on the control of villages around Afrin.\n\n\u201cGiven previous discussions about this settlement to reduce further bloodshed and lives lost on both sides,\u201d he wrote in an email, \u201cit is important to consider a return to this agreement to reduce tensions.\u201d", "title": "72 Turkish Jets Bomb U.S.-Backed Kurdish Militias in Syria", "authors": ["Carlotta Gall"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Get some physical activity daily.\n\nThe experts we spoke to disagreed on which comes first, but all agreed physical activity and sleep are the two most important components of good health.\n\n\u201cPhysical activity is almost magical in its ability to improve quality of life,\u201d Dr. Freedhoff said. It reduces risks of nearly every physical and mental condition there is. \u201cIf you can only do one thing in terms of improving your diet or fitness, I\u2019d improve fitness first.\u201d\n\nIt doesn\u2019t need to be fancy, long or boring. Ten-minute blocks of playing with your kids, dancing or even taking the stairs makes a difference.\n\n\u201cWhat sinks a lot of people\u2019s efforts is they take on more than they can do, find it\u2019s impossible to maintain and then quit,\u201d Dr. Freedhoff said. \u201cThe best activity is the one you enjoy the most and can see yourself continuing the most.\u201d\n\nDr. M. James Lenhard, medical director of Christiana Care Health System\u2019s Diabetes & Metabolic Diseases Center in Wilmington, Del., agreed that making it fun is paramount.\n\n\u201cSome people like to chop wood, others like walking, others like peeling vegetables,\u201d Dr. Lenhard said. \u201cI don\u2019t care what it is, find something you really like so you can stick with it.\u201d\n\nAnd don\u2019t get discouraged if you fall off the wagon.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019ll have good weeks and bad weeks,\u201d Dr. Freedhoff said. \u201cDo as much as often as you can enjoy. Some is good, more is better, everything counts.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGet enough sleep.\n\nOne third of Americans don\u2019t get enough sleep, but it\u2019s impossible to overstate how essential sleep is to good health. It affects your immune system, hormones, appetite, weight, thinking, energy, concentration, temper, mood \u2026 even life expectancy. Luckily, there are ways to get a better night\u2019s sleep.\n\nConsider the effects of poor sleep on mental health: \u201cPeople who have impaired sleep or insomnia symptoms are significantly more likely to develop clinical depression,\u201d said Dr. Britney Blair, a licensed clinical psychologist and adjunct clinical faculty at Stanford University. If you are coping with depression and impaired sleep, you are much more likely to have thoughts of suicide. In fact, several studies have shown how just treating sleep problems in those with depression can improve the depression symptoms too, she said.\n\nHow much sleep each person specifically needs varies \u2014 \u201cit\u2019s as unique as your fingerprint,\u201d Dr. Blair said \u2014 but it ranges from seven to nine hours for most people. But quality matters too. If you\u2019re feeling tired or having disrupted sleep, find out if you have a sleep disorder and treat it if you do.\n\nSleep apnea is an extremely underdiagnosed condition that increases the risk of obesity, diabetes, heart disease and early death, such as Carrie Fisher\u2019s. Take the STOP-BANG questionnaire to see if you have the symptoms. For those with insomnia, a specific cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment. Following good \u201csleep hygiene habits\u201d can actually make insomnia worse for some people, Dr. Blair said, so find a provider who specializes in insomnia through the Society of Behavioral Sleep Medicine.\n\nDon\u2019t smoke.\n\nThis one is a no-brainer, and not just because smoking can cause lung cancer, emphysema and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.\n\n\u201cSmoking is associated with virtually all diabetes complications,\u201d Dr. Lenhard said, and it\u2019s a leading cause of heart disease. \u201cCigarette smokers with diabetes are virtually certain to get cardiovascular disease,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s not if they get it, it\u2019s when they get it.\u201d\n\nMost smokers don\u2019t need reminders of these facts.\n\n\u201cAbout 80 percent of smokers want to quit and about half have tried to quit in the last year, but success is low,\u201d Dr. Hurst said. \u201cIf people will use nicotine patches and medications with a behavioral plan, they can increase their chances of quitting five or six times. There are more effective treatment options when you use all the tools.\u201d\n\nAnd e-cigarettes or vaping? We just don\u2019t have the evidence yet on their toxicity or ability to help people quit.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe bulk of evidence is that they are less toxic than cigarettes, though the bar is low there,\u201d Dr. Hurst said. \u201cBut long-term effects are less well known.\u201d And data on whether it actually helps people quit is contradictory. Anecdotal evidence shows they definitely help some people, but it\u2019s not clear who, why, how or how often.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNurture your relationships.\n\nHumans are social creatures, so our attachment to others is \u201ccore to who we are as human beings,\u201d Dr. Blair said. \u201cWe are biologically hard-wired to attach to one another.\u201d\n\nHow you nurture personal relationships depends on you. Does it mean you add a weekly lunch with a friend to your schedule? Join a local club or sports team? Plan a monthly date night with your partner? Eat meals at the dinner table with your family more often? Make Saturdays family days without distractions?\n\nYou decide, but don\u2019t underestimate the importance of those activities to good health and well-being. The need for attachment starts in infancy and never goes away.\n\n\u201cIt transitions from a parent or primary caregiver to our spouse, our children, our friends,\u201d Dr. Blair said. \u201cFostering loving, connected attachment and close relationships is the single most important thing you can do for happiness.\u201d\n\nEat more fruits and vegetables.\n\nVegetables offer more benefits than fruits in terms of vitamins and minerals with fewer calories, but fruits are a place to start if you don\u2019t get much of either. The best way to get more fruits and veggies is to cook more meals at home with unprocessed foods. This also decreases sodium, sugar and calorie intake, said Dr. Freedhoff. \u201cIf you focus on cooking more with fresh whole ingredients, that will lead to an increase in fruits and vegetables,\u201d he said.\n\nStart with cooking just one more meal a week than you do now. If time, finances or other reasons make home cooking difficult, add an extra vegetable to dinner each night or replace a snack with an apple or orange. Frozen vegetables are time savers with the same benefits as fresh ones, and canned fruits are fine if they\u2019re not packed in syrup, Dr. Freedhoff said.\n\nJust don\u2019t drink your fruits or rely on dried fruits. \u201cAny concentrated form of fruit sugars is not as helpful,\u201d he said. \u201cThose both pack a lot more calories and add up faster.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCooking at home also offers benefits beyond healthier meals, Dr. Freedhoff added. It can save you money, gives you a skill to pass on to children and grandchildren and encourages family meals at the table.\n\nGet vaccinated.\n\nA hundred years ago, the top 10 causes of death in the United States were nearly all infectious diseases that vaccines can prevent today.\n\nA major reason cancer, heart disease, diabetes and other chronic conditions top today\u2019s list is that people now live long enough for those to develop. Before vaccines, thousands of children never reached adulthood. Even today, thousands of adults die from the flu.\n\nSo the advice here is straightforward: Vaccines can save lives, so keep up with and follow the recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nSpend time in the sun, but not too much.\n\nNot everyone has this option year-round, especially in northern latitudes, but take advantage of what you can. Light helps your sleep and mood, being out in the sun increases your likelihood of physical activity and sunlight is the only natural way to get vitamin D.\n\n\u201cBright light is incredibly important for healthy sleep,\u201d said Dr. Blair. \u201cOur sleep system evolved when we were sleeping outside,\u201d so not getting enough light during the day can hinder sleep. And again, healthy sleep helps mental health too.\n\nIt\u2019s no coincidence that those in higher latitudes have lower vitamin D levels, but how much vitamin D people need, how to measure it and how it affects health remain unanswered questions. It\u2019s an essential vitamin nonetheless.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s almost no disease state that has not been associated with vitamin D deficiency,\u201d Dr. Lenhard said, \u201cbut association is not cause and effect.\u201d We don\u2019t know how much vitamin D contributes to or prevents certain health problems, but we know many people don\u2019t have enough, especially if they\u2019re overweight or have diabetes, Dr. Lenhard said. If your levels are low, raising them with more sunlight exposure or supplements has few downsides if you don\u2019t go overboard.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf course, too much sun isn\u2019t good either. The sun\u2019s UV light is a leading cause of skin cancer, so protect yourself with sunblock, hats and clothing too.\n\nEat and drink less sugar.\n\nThis recommendation is controversial given existing research, said Dr. Lenhard, but there are still reasons to watch how much you consume.\n\n\u201cThe data on how sugar consumption affects the body and development of diabetes is still unclear, but there\u2019s a fair amount of calories in it,\u201d he said. Whether the culprit is sugar or increased calories isn\u2019t known, but both decrease when you cut out extra sugar. The easiest place to start? Drinks. Switch that soda or sugary drink to water instead.\n\nStaying hydrated maintains your energy and prevents headaches and other dehydration effects. But don\u2019t go overboard: No evidence supports the \u201ceight glasses of water a day\u201d claims, Dr. Freedhoff said. \u201cThe notion that there\u2019s a magical amount that will improve your health is mythology,\u201d he said. But evidence does support choosing water over soft drinks, alcohol and other calorie-dense beverages.\n\n\u201cIf you drink when you\u2019re thirsty and you drink water preferentially, you\u2019re good,\u201d Dr. Freedhoff said. \u201cIt\u2019s about limiting drinks you love the most thoughtfully. What\u2019s the smallest amount that will satisfy me?\u201d\n\nDecreasing your alcohol intake not only reduces calories, it also reduces the risks associated with excessive alcohol use.\n\nAnyone of any age, size or gender can begin working on these back-to-basics behaviors. And focusing on adding one or two small, daily positive habits to your routine removes the intimidation of otherwise lofty New Year\u2019s goals. If you miss a day, start fresh the next day. Everyone falls off sometimes. What matters most is jumping back on.", "title": "8 Easy, Meaningful New Year\u2019s Resolutions for Better Health", "authors": ["Tara Haelle"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain every week with Marc Stein\u2019s weekly newsletter. Sign up here and we\u2019ll send Marc\u2019s expert insights directly to your inbox.\n\n\u2014\n\n\u2022 LeBron James may not be moving to Los Angeles after all.\n\nMy best advice when it comes to the looming third installment of the LeBron Sweepstakes: Don\u2019t just assume he\u2019s going to the Lakers in free agency \u2026 and don\u2019t write off the Cavaliers yet. King James\u2019 free agency choice is the story line that will lord over the whole league in 2018, but I tend to believe he\u2019s still months away from knowing what he wants to do, despite the persistent chatter that he\u2019s Hollywood-bound.\n\nAs his longtime business partner and confidante Maverick Carter stated rather clearly in a November radio interview with Rich Eisen: \u201cWhen you win as an athlete, that matters the most.\u201d Consider that a pretty decent hint that James is liable to take a long look around to see which franchise can offer him the best hope of challenging Golden State and adding to his three championship rings, whether that\u2019s the Lakers, Houston, Philadelphia, Team X that hasn\u2019t even been mentioned as a possible destination \u2014 or, yes, his hometown Cavs.\n\n\u2022 Markelle Fultz won\u2019t play another game in his rookie season.\n\nThis is the old reverse jinx trick sportswriters love. That\u2019s right: I\u2019m openly hoping I\u2019m wrong here, that just writing this leads to a Fultz comeback after the All-Star break and a stream of I-told-you-sos from angry Philadelphians. (He adds: \u201cAs a kid, I looked like Mowgli,\u201d the \u201cJungle Book\u201d protagonist.) He has already walked for Topman and booked the corresponding campaign, and posed for an Alexander McQueen look book; fall 2018 is his first full runway season. \u201cMy favorite way to pass time backstage is just talking to other people and stuff,\u201d Lessore says. \u201cMy pastimes in general are thoroughly uninteresting, as all I do is stay in bed and watch series.\u201d\n\nRepresented by Supa Model Management.\n\nImage\n\nIhor Liubchenko\n\n19, Ukraine\n\nLiubchenko made his debut during the spring/summer 2018 shows as a Prada exclusive, and then walked a handful of runways in Paris \u2014 Balenciaga, Valentino and Acne Studios, among them.
