Well, almost exclusively bad news, at least in terms of subject matter. These picks cover the devastation of tsunamis, earthquakes and wildfires; the Spanish flu epidemic of 1918; mass extinctions; the potential for nuclear annihilation. Even the work of fiction included here is a fantasy about imminent catastrophe. The good news is the eloquent and haunting way in which these books are written.\n\nJohn Williams\n\nDaily Books Editor and Staff Writer\n\nGHOSTS OF THE TSUNAMI: Death and Life in Japan\u2019s Disaster Zone, by Richard Lloyd Parry. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) A British journalist, long resident in Tokyo, probes the emotional and spiritual effects of the catastrophe that killed thousands of men, women and children in 2011.\n\nTHE DOOMSDAY MACHINE: Confessions of a Nuclear War Planner, by Daniel Ellsberg. (Bloomsbury, $30.) When the Cold War ended in 1991, nuclear weapons vanished from the minds of most Americans. But Ellsberg, the former Defense Department analyst who leaked the Pentagon Papers, sounds an impassioned alarm, warning that the dangers of nuclear conflict remain.\n\nMEGAFIRE: The Race to Extinguish a Deadly Epidemic of Flame, by Michael Kodas. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $28.) An account of the misguided history and dire results of America\u2019s wildfire management policy that also captures the Sisyphean struggles of the men and women who battle blazes for a living.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPALE RIDER: The Spanish Flu of 1918 and How It Changed the World, by Laura Spinney. (PublicAffairs, $28.) The Spanish flu tends to be overshadowed by World War I in our cultural memory, but Spinney, a novelist and science writer, draws on medical mysteries and haunting vignettes to give the pandemic its due.", "title": "9 New Books We Recommend This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Even if you don\u2019t follow financial markets closely, if you have money in those markets it is worth considering, every so often, where you have been and where the currents may be taking you.\n\nIn a nutshell, the stock market in the United States has generated enormous wealth for investors, and in recent months it has roared ahead with scarcely a setback, raising questions about how sustainable those gains really are.\n\nBonds haven\u2019t performed as spectacularly as stocks. There have been signs that fixed-income markets just may be ready for a long-awaited shift in direction.\n\nWe\u2019ve selected nine articles with reporting and analysis on where the markets have been and some clues on where they may be heading. Together the selection provides an introduction to investing. We hope that at least some of these articles will entertain you as well.\n\nIs the Stock Market Too Quiet for Its Own Good?\n\nA rare calm has settled over the stock market, which has been prospering with barely any downturns. That condition is highly unusual, and some fear that it raises the odds that share prices will descend.\n\nRead more \u00bb\n\nCutting Carbon Emissions While Earning Cash\n\nGreen bond funds seek securities with clear environmental benefits. Their managers chase the promise of a double bottom line: growing returns and falling carbon emissions.", "title": "9 Points to Guide Your Investments in 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The Ferragamo Vara pump has stood the test of time. Introduced in 1978, the polished shoe has the magic ability of going with practically everything, from frayed denim to a throwback skirt suit.\n\nSalvatore Ferragamo patent leather pumps, $575 at Saks Fifth Avenue, saksfifthavenue.com.\n\nImage\n\nThese stacked-heel loafers in navy patent leather put a fashion-forward spin on the masculine style. Slip them on and walk straight up that corporate ladder.\n\nSies Marjan patent leather loafers, $590 at Barneys New York, barneys.com.", "title": "9 to 5 Dressing, Updated for 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt is a truth universally acknowledged that the first two months of the year are desolate times for movie lovers who prefer to gorge on new releases. Once the holiday season\u2019s tidal wave of blockbusters and prestige pictures has receded there\u2019s not much action beyond the awards season itself. Releasing only chaff during the first two months of the year has been a studio tradition so longstanding that nobody seems to remember the rationale. But even for awards mavens, now is a good time to catch up and explore.\n\nDuring the last week of 2017 I was out of New York, visiting relatives, and one evening circumstances left me alone in their house with a few hours to kill. I ended up using my phone to watch \u201cS\u00e9rie Noire,\u201d a grimy 1979 French crime thriller that I saw maybe 20 years ago, via a pretty grimy-in-itself 16 -millimeter print, and had no expectation to see again. Directed by Alain Corneau, the movie is an adaptation of the novel \u201cA Hell of a Woman,\u201d by the American genre writer Jim Thompson. (Mr. Corneau wrote the screenplay with Georges Perec, the French literary genius who wrote \u201cLife: A User\u2019s Manual.\u201d)\n\nThe story line of \u201cS\u00e9rie Noire\u201d is jaw-droppingly squalid \u2014 less than 10 minutes into the movie an abusive aunt is pimping her young niece (Marie Trintignant) to a feckless traveling salesman (Patrick Dewaere) \u2014 and the movie\u2019s setting, an impoverished Paris suburb in the depths of a drippy winter, is depicted with such rigor that you suspect the film stock itself of carrying mold. Not everyone\u2019s cup of tea, obviously, and not to make light of trigger warnings, but this movie could conceivably be eligible for at least a dozen of them. But I\u2019ve long found it unnerving and fascinating, and when a friend on social media mentioned that it was available on FilmStruck, I was genuinely surprised.\n\n[ See the best 100 movies currently on Netflix. ]\n\nOne comes to expect at least a certain amount of the unexpected on a carefully curated site like FilmStruck. That\u2019s less true of Netflix. Still, I\u2019ve always thought the commonly propagated complaint about the dearth of \u201cclassic\u201d films on Netflix something of a straw man. The streaming service has never advertised itself as a curated haven of greatness. People perhaps confuse Netflix\u2019s DVD rental service, which offers a wide variety of older and critically elevated films, with the streaming service, on which you cannot watch \u201cCitizen Kane\u201d or \u201cCasablanca.\u201d\n\nMy own complaint about the service is more about the presentation of the movies they have than the quality of the movies themselves. It\u2019s no secret that Netflix doesn\u2019t do a great job letting consumers know what more recent critical favorites are available, so if you\u2019re on that site and looking for hidden gems, you\u2019re not going to find them gathered under a category. Nor is it a sure thing that the site\u2019s algorithm is going to recommend them to you.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut they\u2019re there. A few weeks back Bilge Ebiri, the lead film critic for the Village Voice, placed \u201cMy Happy Family,\u201d a drama from Tblisi, Georgia, at the top of his 2017 best films list. Mr. Ebiri had first seen it at the Sundance Film Festival in early 2017, and after that it dropped from sight. As it happens, it is on Netflix. Another 2017 Sundance favorite, \u201cI Don\u2019t Feel at Home in This World Anymore\u201d turned up on Netflix very shortly after it played the festival. But these streaming premieres were hardly big Netflix events. A big Netflix event is \u201cBright,\u201d a sci-fi fantasy film widely mocked by reviewers that garnered sufficient viewership on the service to justify a sequel. I understand the relations of scale between indie films and blockbusters, but in the streaming world there ought to be a middle ground between \u201cBright\u201d-style exposure and zero public awareness.", "title": "The Hidden Gems of 2017 Movies Are on ... Netflix?", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Colbert said that as long as he uses this kind of speech, Mr. Trump probably shouldn\u2019t accuse other world leaders of being divisive.\n\n\u201cNow, at one point Donald Trump said that North Korea might be trying to drive a wedge between the U.S. and South Korea, but assured us that \u2018I know more about wedges than any human being that\u2019s lived.\u2019 Oh, sir, you are a wedge. The simplest of tools.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrump and F.I.S.A.\n\nTweeting Thursday about the House\u2019s vote on warrantless surveillance, Mr. Trump seemed to contradict the Republicans\u2019 party line \u2014 and then himself.\n\n\u201cWe need to get smart? You\u2019re the only one live-tweeting a debate with yourself \u2014 that you\u2019re losing.\u201d \u2014 STEPHEN COLBERT\n\nAbdul-Jabbar Takes a Shot at Trump\n\nIt would seem no one can dismiss presidential hostility quite like Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the N.B.A.\u2019s all-time leading scorer and the inventor of the famous \u201cskyhook\u201d jump shot. He talked to Mr. Noah about the time Mr. Trump sent him a nasty letter.\n\nNOAH: You wrote an op-ed in and around Donald Trump, comparing him to Bernie Sanders, explaining the differences and trying to show how different their worldviews were. And the president then wrote you a personal letter on your own column. I think we have the picture here, what he wrote. It reads, \u201cDear Kareem, Now I know why the press always treated you so badly. They couldn\u2019t stand you. The fact is that you don\u2019t have a clue about life and what has to be done to make America great again. Best wishes, Donald Trump.\u201d What do you do with a personal note like that from the president? Do you frame it or do you burn it? ABDUL-JABBAR: Actually, when I got that I crumpled it up in a ball and I skyhooked it into a wastebasket.\n\nThe Punchiest Punchlines (Circuit City Edition)\n\n\u201cAfter being out of business for years, Circuit City announced that they\u2019re opening stores again. Yeah, they said they couldn\u2019t wait to fax their employees the news.\u201d \u2014 JIMMY FALLON \u201cVermont could become the first state to legalize recreational marijuana through the state legislature. Yeah, then the state full of Ben & Jerry\u2019s and snowboarders said, \u2018Oh, good, we can finally start smoking weed. Finally. Wonder what that\u2019ll be like.\u2019\u201d \u2014 JIMMY FALLON \u201cAccording to NBC News, former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon has hired a lawyer to help him prepare to testify before the House Intelligence Committee. I\u2019d say Bannon\u2019s starting to sweat \u2014 but I\u2019m pretty sure he never stopped.\u201d \u2014 SETH MEYERS\n\nThe Bits Worth Watching\n\nJames Corden played \u201clive Tinder\u201d with a writer on his show, and it looked a lot like a classic dating show.\n\nMr. Colbert\u2019s audience learned some things. One of them: It\u2019s probably not a great idea to invite him to your party.\n\nEnjoy the Weekend\n\nConan O\u2019Brien is back next week after a long break. The Times Late-Night Comedy Committee will be here again on Tuesday morning to tell you about it.\n\nAlso, Check This Out\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter Fifth Harmony broke up acrimoniously, Camila Cabello \u2014 singer of the hit song \u201cHavana\u201d \u2014 has come out on top.", "title": "Trevor Noah Pans Trump\u2019s Vulgarity, a Bleep for Other Hosts", "authors": ["Giovanni Russonello", "Best Of Late Night"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The suit charges the Port Authority with failing to enforce his lease, which gives the Ark \u201cexclusive rights\u201d to handle the animals coming to the airport from overseas. The lease requires that the Port Authority \u201cmust use reasonable efforts to cause other providers to cease their provision of the exclusive services.\u201d\n\nThe project was financed with a combination of conventional loans and tax-free bonds, with Ark responsible for all payments.\n\nThe heart of the Ark\u2019s business is supposed to be horses coming from Europe, which must be quarantined for at least three days in order to prevent the spread of equine diseases.\n\nThe Ark\u2019s primary competitor is the U.S. Department of Agriculture\u2019s 40-year-old operation in Newburgh, N.Y., about 90 miles north of Kennedy Airport.\n\nPhoto\n\nMost of the hundreds of birds and more than 3,500 horses that enter the United States at Kennedy every year are still put onto trailers for the 2-\u00bd-hour ride to Newburgh, even though the cargo planes could practically pull alongside the Ark, where the horses could be transferred to a dolly and wheeled into a stall moments after landing.\n\n\u201cI watch them go by my door every day,\u201d Mr. Cuticelli said, \u201ctrucked up to Newburgh.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt makes no sense to me why the Port Authority, the U.S.D.A. and all the other agencies involved in the creation of this facility are not supporting its use,\u201d Mr. Cuticelli said. \u201cI entered into a technically, legally binding contract with exclusivity. Otherwise, I never would have done it.\u201d\n\nThe Port Authority and the Department of Agriculture declined to discuss the lawsuit.\n\nJoelle Hayden, a spokeswoman for the U.S.D.A., did say that her agency \u201cdoes not mandate use of any one import quarantine facility, airline or animal handling service. We support the use of all approved entities and services.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd a spokesman for the Port Authority said in a statement that the \u201climited exclusivity provision enables the private veterinary clinic to provide the first-class facility and services that J.F.K. requested.\u201d\n\nCritics, mostly shipping agents and transporters, said that the privately owned Ark was too expensive and unnecessary, given the existence of the Newburgh operation.\n\nBut Dr. Scarlette Gotwals, a veterinarian and director of flight operations for Horse America, a shipping agent, said she was mystified as to why Ark has not been embraced by the horse industry.\n\n\u201cThis is exactly what we\u2019ve been looking for,\u201d said Ms. Gotwals, the first shipper to bring horses to the Ark in September. \u201cIt\u2019s a world-class facility. It\u2019s an indoor, climate-controlled facility. In Newburgh, you\u2019re using outdoor barns.\u201d\n\nShe said the price difference, which amounted to a couple of hundred dollars, was \u201cnot cost prohibitive.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuticelli, who described himself as a \u201cbroken down real estate investor,\u201d got involved with the project at the urging of Ken Rotondo, a veterinarian and a former member of the advisory council at Cornell University\u2019s veterinary college.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 2010, the Port Authority solicited companies willing to build a first-class animal facility at Kennedy Airport.\n\n\u201cI proposed moving quarantine\u201d to Kennedy, instead of going to Newburgh, Dr. Rotondo recalled.\n\nThe Port Authority awarded the contract to Dr. Rotondo\u2019s group, he said, \u201cwithout going to bid.\u201d After Dr. Rotondo retired, Mr. Cuticelli took over.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRon Marsico, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said the former airport facility \u201cfell far below the minimum appropriate standards.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Ark contract was tailored,\u201d he said, \u201cto enable the private contractor to make the necessary investment to build and operate a world-class facility.\u201d\n\nAfter three years of negotiations, the Ark signed a 310-page lease in 2014.\n\nHowever, in 2015, the Port Authority signed a 20-year lease with the U.S.D.A. operation in Newburgh, on the grounds of Stewart Airport. Thomas Bosco, then director of aviation for the Port Authority, recommended that the authority\u2019s board approve the lease, saying that the \u201cArk does not provide quarantine services.\u201d It was a puzzling statement given that Ark had signed a lease requiring it to provide that service.\n\nBefore construction could begin, Ark had to wait for the Port Authority to remove the heart of the airport\u2019s Perimeter Intrusion Detection System, a high-tech system of cameras, radar and sensors.\n\nArk also had to comply with various regulations and requirements imposed by the Port Authority, the U.S.D.A., the Center for Disease Control, state and local health departments and the Department of Homeland Security.\n\nThe delays and requirements drove the cost of the project from $48 million to $65 million, Mr. Cuticelli said. He obtained private financing, put up $12 million of his own money and New York City provided a $35 million bond.\n\nArk opened in January 2017, although the U.S.D.A did not approve the equine quarantine for imported horses until September. Business was slow.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Cuticelli said he does not know whether he has stumbled into some bureaucratic nightmare with the Port Authority, a turf war between government agencies, or is the object of a boycott by livestock shipping agents and transporters.\n\n\u201cThere are two big issues,\u201d said Matt Haug, general manager for IRT Transport, which transports livestock internationally. \u201cPeople aren\u2019t acquainted with them. The other issue is the traffic difficulties at Kennedy Airport. Newburgh is situated near the interstates.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cNobody asked for an import facility,\u201d said a shipper, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he did not want to become embroiled in the litigation. \u201cI don\u2019t know how this became a $65 million facility. They\u2019ll never recoup their money.\u201d\n\nA Port Authority official, who also spoke on the condition of anonymity, blamed federal officials. \u201cIt\u2019s no secret that the U.S.D.A. has not been friendly to this facility,\u201d he said.\n\nThe official said the Port Authority was trying to work out the issues with the U.S.D.A.\n\nArk\u2019s lease does appear to give it exclusivity, which is also generating friction with the horse racing industry.\n\nThe New York Racing Association, which operates several tracks including Aqueduct and Belmont Park near Kennedy Airport, has built its own U.S.D.A.-approved quarantine barns for international horse races, enabling the horse to compete right after it leaves quarantine. The 40 or so racehorses a year that fly into Kennedy from Europe, Japan and elsewhere for races within two weeks of landing represent only a fraction of the total expected volume.\n\nIn December, Dora J. Delgado, a senior vice president of racing and nominations for the Breeders Cup, sent a letter to the U.S.D.A. expressing its concerns about the Port Authority\u2019s plans to require \u201cinternational equine athletes\u201d to use Ark, rather than the U.S.D.A.-approved quarantine barn at Belmont.\n\nAlison McGowan, who runs Ternary Performance Horses on Long Island, was importing two show horses from Belgium and Holland in September. She said she told her shipper \u2014 whom she declined to name \u2014 on numerous occasions that she wanted the horses taken to Ark.\n\nThe day before the horses were to leave Amsterdam, she discovered that the shipper planned to take them to Newburgh.\n\nShe canceled the flight and hired a new shipper, Ms. Gotwals, who brought the horses to Ark.\n\n\u201cFor me as a horse owner,\u201d Ms. McGowan said, \u201cI would never ship horses halfway across the world on a long flight and then put them on a trailer for 2.5 hours to quarantine. The Ark is outstanding. I\u2019d rather have a state-of-the-art facility providing the best care.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuticelli said he may not be able to wait much longer.\n\n\u201cWhat sense does it make to build a multi-, multmillion-dollar state-of-the-art facility to, among other things, mitigate the risk of hoof-and-mouth disease contamination, and then do what they are doing,\u201d said his lawyer, Stephen B. Meister. \u201cIt\u2019s totally insane.\u201d", "title": "A $65 Million \u2018Animal Terminal\u2019 at Kennedy Airport Sits Empty", "authors": ["Charles V. Bagli"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "You\u2019d think they would have a good chance at winning business on the basis of lower prices, but that\u2019s not how the warped title insurance market works.\n\nWe now move from the galling to appalling, as reported by Shane Goldmacher this week in The New York Times.\n\nTo get people to buy one identical product over another, the title companies spend enormous amounts of the premiums they collect from home buyers on lavish entertainment.\n\nThey are not entertaining the home buyers, but the intermediaries \u2014 like real estate lawyers \u2014 who steer business to members of the title cartel.\n\n\u201cSports tickets. Nobu. Strip clubs. Hooters. Wining and dining,\u201d Maria Vullo, the superintendent of the state\u2019s Department of Financial Services, said. \u201cThey even give gift cards! That\u2019s cash. Why would they give a referral source cash?\u201d\n\nNo mystery about any of it.\n\nThe consumer pays for the title insurance, but rarely chooses the title agent. \u201cThat\u2019s why you have this very problematic situation where you have meals and entertainment being lavished on the real estate professionals,\u201d Ms. Vullo said.\n\nWhatever you might think about health insurance companies, 82 percent of the money they take in gets paid out in claims for medical care.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe title insurance industry in New York pays out less than 5 percent of its premiums in losses, Ms. Vullo said. Of $1.1 billion in annual premiums, 95 percent goes for salaries, bonuses and expenses. That, includes, of course, buying the actual insurance (which, Ms. Vullo said, is 15 percent of the cost) and the research on the titles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlso driving the premiums are gimmicks like renting Citi Field and paying Mets players for a meet-and-greet with real estate lawyers. One title insurer spends millions each year on luxury boxes at Madison Square Garden, baseball stadiums and the U.S. Open.\n\nThe state plans to enact a regulation this week that bars much of this spending. In response, lobbyists besieged the legislature in hope of extinguishing the new rules. They are making some headway. A bill sponsored by Sen. James L. Seward, a Republican from the Ithaca area, was passed by the State Senate. The Assembly insurance committee is considering a version sponsored by its chairman, Assemblyman Kevin A. Cahill, a Democrat who represents parts of Ulster and Dutchess counties.\n\nIt says that no matter which rules are enacted, nothing prohibits the companies \u201cfrom undertaking any usual and customary marketing activity aimed at acquainting present and prospective customers with the advantages of using a particular title insurer or title insurance agent.\u201d\n\nThe core language reads like a 96-word loophole, but Ms. Vullo put it in stronger terms. \u201cIt would give a license to bribery,\u201d she said.\n\nAt a hearing earlier this month, representatives of the industry argued that their practices were essential to building relationships with the people they described as their \u201cclients\u201d \u2014 the real estate intermediaries, not the home buyers.\n\nMr. Cahill suggested that marketing directly to the consumers would hurt home buyers inexperienced in shopping for title insurance. \u201cIs it ethically appropriate to go over the head of the experts?\u201d Mr. Cahill asked. His office said Tuesday that the bill remains in the committee. Industry representatives have said they are considering litigation to fight the new regulation, and have retained a former counsel to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.\n\nTitle insurance costs often look small compared to the price of the home. In New York, for a house costing $500,000, the average title insurance fee is around $2,700.\n\nMany people just roll that cost into their mortgage, which at current rates, winds up adding about $13 a month.\n\nJust a tiny nick from a shaving cut.\n\nOne that bleeds for 30 years.", "title": "A 96-Word Law Would Be a \u2018License to Bribery\u2019 for Insurers", "authors": ["Jim Dwyer", "About New York"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "We may as well impose a fee to walk through our city\u2019s beautiful Central Park, or to view our city\u2019s architecture, or perhaps even charge for a glimpse at the Statue of Liberty for that matter. Art is to be appreciated by every human being no matter where on our planet they hail from and no matter their economic status. NOO YAWKA\n\nAmerican children up to the age of 18 should have free access. In France, I bought yearly passes for myself to all museums. My daughters could get in free because they were French citizens. Kids need more than videos! MO FRANCE\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCharging a Fee Is Fair\n\nI have a feeling that many of the people complaining willingly spend hundreds of dollars for a ticket to a Broadway show and/or then visit MoMA and other museums that are charging $25 with no complaints. And a $25 ticket that includes admittance to the Met\u2019s three museums is a huge bargain. LOLA\n\nAlthough I agree, in theory, with almost every argument against mandatory admission fees for out-of-town visitors, budget constraints are real. This policy tries to \u201churt the fewest\u201d of many alternatives. The Met is a world treasure and should be kept open and accessible to all. Charging out-of-town visitors a modest fee so that it remains operational is fair. AMYF\n\nThe Met is a city museum with a national focus. It is fair to say that the taxpayers of New York already shoulder a large part of the costs for the Met and deserve a better break. I have maintained an out-of-town membership for more than a decade, and, when in town, I visit as much as I want. Prorated, it is not a bad deal. Cut these guys a break. They have to make the books balance. ARVEY\n\nWhat About a Flat Rate or Other Fees?\n\nThe Met is fabulous, and $25 is reasonable considering what you see. But $25 is high for many people, especially families. I wonder if the Met ever considered different pricing, such as a flat rate of $10 for everyone or surge pricing? By appearing to lower the price, the Met could actually make a lot more money. PADRAIG LEWIS\n\nLiving in Hoboken, I can get to the Met just as fast as those in some of the boroughs. That said, I do want to continue to have the Met in existence and be better than the institution it currently is, so I support the need for a mandatory admission. I just wish it was applied to all visitors and perhaps at a lesser cost. CJFILM\n\nThe Cleveland Museum of Art \u2014 one of the best in the country \u2014 does not charge admission, but it does charge for special exhibits. I think that is a better option for the Met \u2014 I would have gladly paid extra to see the current Michelangelo exhibit. KAREN", "title": "A Barrier or a Fair Fee? Readers React to the Met\u2019s New Admission Policy", "authors": ["Maira Garcia"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "One of the most effective ways to back up photos on smartphones is by using one of several well-known cloud services, such as Apple iCloud, Google Photos, Amazon\u2019s Prime Photos, and Dropbox. One reason you should use them is that they all share an important feature: automatic backups. (Note: You\u2019ll find this feature on other services, as well.) \u201cYou can never predict when a crash will happen or your phone will be stolen,\u201d says Jill Duffy, a contributing technology editor who covers productivity for PCMag.com.\n\nEach also offers free versions to back up your photos, although it\u2019s generally just a small amount of storage space. You\u2019ll also want to be sure to drill down and examine the details of each service to find additional pros and cons. For example, the pricing model is very different on just these four services (not to mention other photo backup apps). Take Apple iCloud. It\u2019s very well known, but it provides just five gigabytes of free storage to start for those with Apple devices, and just one GB if you don\u2019t own one. For more space, you\u2019ll pay a monthly fee: $0.99/month (50 GB), $2.99/month (200 GB), or $9.99/month (two terabytes). Apple lets you share storage space on the 200-GB and two-TB plans with your family. If you\u2019re accustomed to Apple devices (and the service integrates nicely with Apple products) and are willing to splurge for a monthly fee, iCloud might serve your needs. But if you own an Android device, it might not be the best solution.\n\nBy contrast, you get free, unlimited photo storage on Google Photos, allowing you to automatically back up all images from your phone, computer and other devices. Google also recently updated its app for desktop computers, which now can automatically upload photos directly into Google Photos when transferring images from your camera to your computer, which is very convenient.\n\nHowever, Google Photos has limitations as well. If you shoot photos with a resolution larger than 16 megapixels, they\u2019ll be downsized, which some photographers find unacceptable. At this time, smartphones mostly capture 12- or 16-megapixel photos, which won\u2019t be affected, but some models already exceed that limit, as do many digital cameras.\n\nBoth Amazon Prime Photos and Dropbox have their pros and cons, too. If you have an Amazon Prime account, Prime Photos can be a great option, since, like Google Photos, you get free, unlimited storage, which includes the ability to store RAW images, which are those high quality files for photo editing on an image editor. But you need to pay for an Amazon Prime account.\n\nDropbox has long been a popular backup option for many photographers; it is easy to use and works well on many platforms, but you get only two GB of free storage, and additional storage is pricey ($9.99/month or $99/year for one TB).\n\nFor serious photographers who shoot lots of photos, there are additional options: Some shutterbugs splurge for robust photo-organizing software packages, including apps by ACDSee, Mylio and Adobe, which, for a fee, include online cloud storage. In fact, Adobe recently updated its professional photo organizer, Lightroom, and expanded its cloud-storage plans, which are available at various prices.", "title": "A Beginner\u2019s Guide to Backing Up Photos", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Opinions, though, differ significantly from those who are familiar with the countries.\n\n\u201cOf all the amazing places I lived in during my 18 years as a diplomat \u2014 including highlights like Paris and New York \u2014 Haiti is the place that sticks in my mind the most, because of its beauty and the character of its people,\u201d said Peter Kujawinski, a writer who, as an American diplomat, lived in Haiti for a total of four years since 2000.\n\nAvid readers of travel journalism may have also noticed many of these same countries on a number of prominent 2018 \u201cbest of\u201d destination lists.\n\nOur own 52 Places to Go in 2018 featured several African destinations, including Kigali, Rwanda; Liuwa Plain National Park, Zambia; Tangier, Morocco; and S\u00e3o Tom\u00e9 and Pr\u00edncipe. Elsewhere, Harar and Addis Ababa in Ethiopia were recommended by National Geographic and Cond\u00e9 Nast Traveler, respectively, and Forbes flagged destinations in Haiti, Tanzania and Senegal as \u201cBest Budget Travel Destinations for 2018.\u201d And Tanzania\u2019s Ruaha National Park was chosen by National Geographic as one of its \u201cPlaces You Need to Visit in 2018.\u201d", "title": "A Beginner\u2019s Travel Guide to Haiti, El Salvador and Africa", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "From the street, the well-lit room with white-brick walls and pale oak floorboards can resemble a minimalist stage set. Once inside, though, it feels more like a friend\u2019s dinner party where everyone is hanging out in the kitchen. An initial visit just a month after Mrs Robinson\u2019s opened revealed an early taste of what Mr. Zviel aspired to: a lively kitchen where he could play and riff with Asian-inspired, umami-rich dishes directly inspired by New York City chefs like Mr. Dufresne and David Chang: a bowl of crispy charred brussels sprouts served with crunchy toasted rice and loads of fresh chopped cilantro; shrimp noodles in a buttery sake-saffron broth, loaded with little salty bombs of fish roe and caviar; a fried soft-shell crab served on a fluffy white bao bun with homemade spicy mayo and a thin slice of kohlrabi. (Because Mrs Robinson\u2019s encourages both sharing and indulging, there is little difference between appetizers and mains.)\n\nDuring another visit in December, over some obscure and upbeat \u201970s music, a guest and I perused the menu, which had clearly evolved since my last visit. We started with an off-menu special: two spicy deviled eggs with fried oysters, which were messy but delicious. There were hits and misses: A generous and gutsy sandwich of aged beef tartare, fried sweetbreads, shiso b\u00e9arnaise and hot sauce was a standout; the octopus Bolognese had great potential but the ratio of sauce to pasta overwhelmed.\n\nThe biggest surprise at Mrs Robinson\u2019s is the desserts. Unlike most Berlin restaurants, Mr. Zviel treats it as a grand finale. A thick, creamy popcorn soup is poured around passion fruit ice and a swirl of sweetened black tahini cream, under which are obscured sweet crunchy bits of caramelized popcorn and peanuts. A rum banana cake was served with a nondairy amazake (traditionally a sweet, non- or low-alcoholic Japanese beverage) ice cream and like the popcorn soup, kept revealing new flavors and textures with every bite \u2014 hidden at the bottom was a layer of toasted puffed quinoa and amaranth. Like a catchy tune, the dish replayed in our minds days later.\n\nMrs Robinson\u2019s, Pappelallee 29; 49-152-0518- 8946 ; mrsrobinsons.de. An average meal for two, without drinks or tip, is 100 euros, about $120.", "title": "A Berlin Restaurant That Cooks Without Compromise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "New Yorkers like to brag about their tap water. Not only is it safe to swill, but it has even been called the \u201cchampagne of drinking water.\u201d\n\nNow, New York City has committed $1 billion to protect the nation\u2019s largest municipal water system as part of a far-reaching 115-page agreement with state health officials that makes New York one of the few cities in the country that can provide nearly all of its tap water without being forced to rely on expensive filtration plants.\n\n\u201cThe city\u2019s water system could well be its single most important capital asset \u2014 or at least on par with the subway system,\u201d said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an advocacy group. \u201cImagine living without clean running water in New York City for even a single day. Life as we know it would grind to a halt.\u201d\n\nNew York\u2019s immaculate water supply is backed by science, lots of it. Every day, dozens of scientists monitor the quality of the city\u2019s drinking water, collecting samples by hand that are tested no less than 600,000 times a year for more than 250 variables, including pollutants. They are augmented by a growing army of robotic monitors that have been plunged into far-flung reservoirs, testing the water another 1.6 million times a year.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis enormous monitoring apparatus is one critical part of New York City\u2019s drinking water supply, ensuring the safety of more than a billion gallons of water flowing daily through a sprawling network of three pristine lakes, 19 reservoirs, and mile after mile of aqueducts and tunnels. About 90 percent of that water never sees the inside of a filtration plant, flowing from huge reservoirs as far as 125 miles away in the rural Catskill Mountains.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew York has spent more than $1.7 billion to protect this unfiltered water supply since the early 1990s, in return for being granted a succession of federal and state waivers exempting it from costly filtration requirements. It is one of only five cities nationally \u2014 along with Boston, San Francisco, Seattle, and Portland, Ore. \u2014 that have an unfiltered water supply. This marvel of water engineering has attracted visits from scientists and government officials from Australia, China, India, Singapore and Colombia.", "title": "A Billion-Dollar Investment in New York\u2019s Water", "authors": ["Winnie Hu"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "But Ms. Barzee Flores said Democrats should not treat impeachment as a singular issue in 2018, over matters like health care and immigration. \u201cThere are other issues that are pressing,\u201d she said. \u201cMore pressing, even.\u201d\n\nFor Mr. Steyer, however, impeachment is a singular cause. And he is no easy character for Democrats to ignore: From his headquarters in a San Francisco office tower, Mr. Steyer, 60, has built a sprawling political operation with more than 200 staff members around the country, mostly employed by his flagship group, NextGen America, which focuses on climate change.\n\nMr. Steyer has amassed a mixed win-loss record over the years, along with a mercurial reputation among Democratic strategists. But he is nearly alone among Democratic donors in his willingness to spend money on a titanic scale. In 2016, Mr. Steyer spent more than $90 million supporting Democrats, and his checkbook may be critical to their efforts to capture Congress.\n\nSeparate from the impeachment drive, Mr. Steyer, who made his fortune as a hedge fund investor, announced this month that he would spend $30 million on mobilizing young voters in 2018. He has already quietly funneled nearly $2 million into a union-backed effort to capture seven Republican-held seats in California, three strategists directly involved in the campaign said.\n\nBut on impeachment, Democrats in Congress have made no secret of their skepticism. Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer, the Democratic minority leaders in the House and Senate, have called it a premature proposal. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a hero of the left, said Democrats should avoid \u201cjumping the gun\u201d on such a drastic action. And the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has urged candidates to use more measured language, endorsing investigations of Mr. Trump but avoiding an impeachment pledge.\n\nMs. Pelosi, who has a longstanding relationship with Mr. Steyer and hosted him in her private box at the Democrats\u2019 2016 convention, conveyed her concerns to him directly. She told Mr. Steyer in a phone call last fall that impeachment was a profoundly divisive issue and stressed that other matters, like the Republican-backed tax overhaul, were more urgent, according to four people briefed on the conversation.\n\nBut Mr. Steyer insisted that Mr. Trump had more than met the standard for being removed from office, and said his ads were electrifying the Democratic base. The conversation was cordial, according to associates of both Democrats, but neither gave ground.", "title": "A Billionaire Keeps Pushing to Impeach Trump. Democrats Are Rattled.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "In 1921, following the Irish War of Independence, the British Army withdrew from southern Ireland and Monto lost a big chunk of its customer base. The new Irish Free State, overwhelmingly Roman Catholic, fell under the social control of the bishops, and prostitution was driven underground. On March 12, 1925, the police raided Monto and closed down what remained, aided by volunteers from a Roman Catholic relief agency, the Legion of Mary.\n\nSince then, almost all the old Monto buildings have been demolished and replaced with public housing or private developments. According to a local historian, Terry Fagan, who does walking tours of the old Monto, the Gloucester Street site is among a handful of buildings left from that era. Even the street names have mostly been changed \u2014 Gloucester Street is now Sean MacDermott Street, named after a hero of the 1916 uprising.\n\nWhile poverty has been greatly reduced, the area remains relatively deprived, the center of a heroin epidemic that exploded in Dublin in the 1970s. Addicts and dealers haunt corners and squares where prostitutes once plied their trade.\n\nToday, the Monto area has faded into folklore, along with the names and lives of its women. One half-remembered streetwalker, Lily of the Lamplight, used to sing to herself under the streetlight where she waited for custom. Long after she was gone, her name passed, by some strange osmosis, into the English version of a wartime German love song, \u201cLili Marlene.\u201d", "title": "A Blot on Ireland\u2019s Past, Facing Demolition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Even so, pollution levels fell less precipitously or rose elsewhere, suggesting that a concerted effort last fall to shift heating to natural gas from coal may have simply shifted the harmful effects to regions far from the capital.\n\nIn the northern province of Heilongjiang, on the border with Russia, pollution levels rose 10 percent. In a statement with its analysis, Greenpeace argued that the results demonstrated the need for more government action, noting that nationwide the drop in pollutants was only 4 percent.\n\n\u201cChina\u2019s national air pollution action plan has brought massive reductions in pollution levels and associated health risks, but policies favoring coal and heavy industry are holding back progress,\u201d Huang Wei, one of the organization\u2019s campaigners, said in the statement.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut in Beijing, where pollution levels are tracked as closely as property prices are in Hong Kong, London or New York, the respite from eye-watering, throat-scratching smog has nonetheless been welcomed. Only a year ago the pollution was so bad on some days that schools were closed and flights were canceled.\n\nAir quality is measured by the concentration of PM2.5, or particulate matter of a size deemed especially harmful; such pollutants contribute to a variety of health conditions. Anything under 50 is considered good.\n\nFor a couple of days at the end of December, levels nearly reached 300, which is considered hazardous, but those were, for this winter so far at least, the exceptions. (On Thursday evening, as this article was being written, the level was 29, according to the China Environmental Monitoring Station index.)\n\nBut beyond the health risks, pollution also poses a political risk for the government of President Xi Jinping as he moves to promote the country\u2019s rise on the world stage.\n\nThe government does not seem to be resting on its laurels in the fight against pollution. The Ministry of Environmental Protection warned in a statement on Wednesday that clearer skies were caused in part by favorable weather conditions, and that conditions could worsen in late January and early February.\n\n\u201cLocal governments need to strengthen pollution controls to further cut emissions and make sure they reach their goals on air quality improvement,\u201d the ministry was quoted as saying in China Daily.", "title": "A Blue Sky in Beijing? It\u2019s Not a Fluke, Says Greenpeace", "authors": ["Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Rates\n\nFrom $209\n\nBasics\n\nWhile most visitors to New Orleans want to be in the heart of the city\u2019s dynamic French Quarter, there\u2019s no denying that its boisterous vibe doesn\u2019t appeal to all travelers. Fortunately, there\u2019s a more relaxing option a streetcar ride away in the Garden District. The 18-room Henry Howard Hotel, a historic double-gallery townhouse, was built by the acclaimed architect Henry Howard in 1867 as a mansion for Edward Conery, a steamship owner and ship chandler, that he later bestowed to his two daughters. After years as a rundown inn, the New York-based Fitzgerald Hotel Group modernized the property while maintaining structural elements for its opening in February 2016. Local culture is tastefully celebrated throughout, from snare drums used as coffee tables in the ground floor parlor to the second line brass instruments hanging above beds in each guest room. The designer Lauren Mabry of Hunter Mabry Design pulled inspiration from both the building and the city\u2019s past for a stunning interior overhaul that is both fun and elegant, and unlikely to date itself.\n\nLocation\n\nLocated in the lower Garden District, only a 10-minute taxi ride from the French Quarter, the hotel sits a block away from St. Charles Street (also known as the Mardi Gras route). The restaurants, bars and antique shops of Magazine Street are a short walk away, as are several of Henry Howard\u2019s other architectural projects that are worth checking out.\n\nImage The parlor at the Henry Howard Hotel. Credit Kathleen Fitzgerald\n\nThe Room\n\nOur Queen Superior room was located in the north wing, accessible from an outdoor covered corridor, overlooking a nearby parking lot. It was smartly decorated, with red pine hardwood floor, custom toile wallpaper featuring New Orleans icons like the steamboat and the St. Charles streetcar, an iron bed canopy, a mounted trumpet, vintage chairs done up in a black and white stripe fabric, and oil portraits by the local artist Hayley Gaberlavage. But it was a cramped fit for two people. The dressing table was small but helpful in the absence of a closet large enough to properly store our luggage (there was only hanging storage).\n\nThe Bathroom\n\nThe bathroom was perched on the mezzanine level of our room, which was a nice separation from the main living space, but given its small size, there was limited room to place our toiletries. The standout feature was the goat-milk bath and body products from Beekman 1802.", "title": "A Boutique Hotel in New Orleans\u2019s Garden District", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Pierson\u2019s passion for his brand of cinema is a palpable thread throughout. It\u2019s infectious, and the segments produced by other film folk that Mr. Pierson picked up along the way testifies to that; their work has the same informed, fervent quality.\n\n\u201cI had to cobble the first 10 episodes on my own, for the most part, with my wife, Janet, helping,\u201d he said. (Janet Pierson is now the chief programmer of the film section of South by Southwest, the annual festival in Austin, Tex.)\n\n\u201cMost of the ideas were things I myself was wildly enthusiastic about,\u201d he continued. \u201cBut there was a pool of larger people coming to me with their ideas, and the point of the whole show was to spread that enthusiasm around \u2014 I\u2019ve sometimes described myself as the Johnny Appleseed of this world. So when people who were capable came to me with ideas they loved, but I might not have had the same personal attachment to, I was beholden to give them opportunities to create segments around stuff they loved.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter years of pursuing the Criterion Collection about putting together a DVD or Blu-ray package of the show, Mr. Pierson eventually had to accept that TV content was, with one or two exceptions, not something that Criterion did. That changed when Criterion teamed up with Turner on the FilmStruck site. \u201cThe show fits really well with what the site does; it\u2019s a very happy home for it,\u201d he said.\n\nOnce the determination was made, Mr. Pierson was slightly surprised that the site insisted on putting up all 66 episodes over a period of time.\n\nWhile the show is, by definition, of a certain age, it\u2019s not as dated as it might have seemed, in part because Mr. Pierson rarely did segments based entirely on time-specific pegs. And almost all the individual films and filmmakers he focused on turned out to have staying power. (In this sense, the series is a good companion to \u201cCin\u00e9astes de Notre Temps,\u201d the French TV documentary series that ran from 1964 to 2009; right now three episodes of that show are on FilmStruck\u2019s Criterion site.)\n\nWhen I spoke to Mr. Pierson on the phone from his home, where he says he\u2019s keeping busy cooking for his wife while she prepares the slate for the next SXSW, I asked his veteran\u2019s view of what streaming is doing for indie movies today. He expressed some skepticism. \u201cAs someone who began as a sales agent, I\u2019m an empiricist. So I find it frustrating to have no idea of how many people are watching anything across the streaming spectrum. Back in the day, if someone said, \u2018Hey my film\u2019s doing great,\u2019 you could verify if they were delusional or right. Now, who knows?\u201d\n\nStreaming services don\u2019t gauge their success according to ratings, or box office numbers, because they don\u2019t need to. But Mr. Pierson sees in this business model not just great potential for exposure, but great potential for anonymity. \u201cWhat\u2019s notable to me, too, is that you once could gauge things to the degree by which they got traction in the general cultural conversation,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen you could have any newspaper in America riffing in headlines on \u2018sex, lies, and videotape\u2019 or \u2018Slacker,\u2019 and \u2018Do the Right Thing,\u2019 you could feel how those filmmakers are penetrating the culture. You can tell that it had gotten outside the indie community echo chamber. In the current landscape, I find myself in the dark, but thinking maybe the cultural impact has been lessened.\u201d\n\nMy own feeling is it\u2019s too soon to tell, and that\u2019s one thing I\u2019ll be exploring in future columns.", "title": "A Brief History of American Independent Film: \u2018Split Screen\u2019 on FilmStruck", "authors": ["Glenn Kenny"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "It begins with the patriarch, Jitu Weusi, a basketball and community legend from Bedford-Stuyvesant. He was a fearless and hyperactive educational activist who founded Uhuru Sasa Shule, one of New York City\u2019s first black private schools, and co-founded the East, a cultural center and jazz venue.\n\n\u201cHard-core progressive institutionalism,\u201d Fruster called it. \u201cThis was organized, intentional, systemic. He was doing it in such a way that racists could not even bother him. He was the guy you cannot arrest.\u201d\n\nBorn Leslie R. Campbell, Weusi \u2014 a 6-foot-10 center \u2014 played on scholarship at Long Island University. He wore No. 44, the same one Johnson wears now. He was also the father to eight children and stepfather to two more. One of those was Keith Fruster, Clarence\u2019s father. Weusi renamed him Pamoja, Swahili for \u201ctogetherness.\u201d In the Cage \u2014 the cramped basketball courts at West Fourth Street \u2014 they called him something else.\n\n\u201cHe was 6-5, slender, muscular, could definitely finish above the rim,\u201d Clarence Fruster said of his father, who died when Clarence was young. \u201cWhen he was coming through, you got out the way. He\u2019d part the lanes.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s why they called him Moses.\n\nWhile Weusi was busy consulting with activists and politicians, like Al Sharpton and David N. Dinkins, the former mayor, it was up to Pamoja to pass the game on to his brothers and sisters. He would sign them up for three-on-three tournaments, cajole them on weekend mornings to run laps around the high school track and have them practice layups for hours at a time.\n\nPhoto\n\nKojo Campbell, another of Weusi\u2019s sons, played on scholarship at Stony Brook and \u201cwas a freakishly good street ball legend in his own right,\u201d Fruster said. At Rucker Park and the city\u2019s other legendary courts, Campbell became known as Slomotion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI guarded whoever the best scorer was: Lance Stephenson, Kemba Walker, Ron Artest \u2014 I guarded all those guys,\u201d said Campbell, who was quite possibly the only Larry Bird fan in 1980s Bed-Stuy.\n\n(He would never scuff anyone\u2019s Jordans, though.)\n\nThree of Pamoja\u2019s sisters also landed college scholarships. One was Makini Campbell, Johnson\u2019s mother. At 6-5, she had become a defensive-minded center for L.I.U., her father\u2019s alma mater. \u201cShe would ball out,\u201d Fruster said. \u201cThat was just plain old mind-blowing.\u201d\n\nIn her last year of eligibility, Campbell became pregnant with Johnson. \u201cI always tell him, \u2018You were inside the womb playing basketball,\u2019 \u201d she said.\n\nJohnson was the prodigy. By 8, he was playing for the Gauchos, the famed New York A.A.U. club, and spending his summers zipping across the country for high-level camps. He played his high school ball at two powerhouses, St. Patrick High School in New Jersey, which produced Kyrie Irving, and Florida\u2019s Montverde Academy, before playing at Kentucky. He declared for the N.B.A. draft after two years and was drafted by the Thunder in the second round. It was a joyous moment, but not yet the summit: Johnson was contracted to the Oklahoma City Blue, the Thunder\u2019s development league team, where he shined for two years.\n\nIn the summer of 2017, he got the call he was waiting for: The Thunder were offering a two-year N.B.A. contract. \u201cYour heart starts pounding,\u201d Kojo Campbell said. \u201c \u2018This is big. This is exciting.\u2019 But even at that point it\u2019s like, \u2018O.K., O.K. \u2014 ink\u2019s not on the paper yet.\u2019 \u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJohnson would indeed be on the Thunder\u2019s 2017-18 opening day roster in October. And a month later, he landed that first N.B.A. start against the Clippers. \u201cI\u2019m at the animal hospital with his dog who\u2019s about to have surgery for eating a corn cob,\u201d his mother recalled. \u201cWe\u2019re making decisions. I\u2019m texting him. He says: \u2018Mom, I can\u2019t talk right now. I have media.\u2019 I\u2019m like: \u2018Media? Boy, what do you have media for? You lucky you get in!\u2019 Then I find out, oh my gosh, he might start tonight!\u201d\n\nIn Johnson\u2019s telling, everyone had a part in helping him develop. \u201cMy uncles, they\u2019d beat up on me,\u201d he said. \u201cThat created the love because I wanted to compete. From my mom, what I learned was patience.\u201d Around his sophomore year, he said, everyone \u201cstarted faking injuries, started coming up with excuses\u201d to get out of playing against him.\n\nHe also had his \u201cbig cousin,\u201d Michael Murray, to fend off. Murray played at Coppin State and now plays professionally in Spain. \u201cHe\u2019s the one I was honestly trying to catch up to my whole life,\u201d Johnson said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWeusi died while Johnson was at Kentucky. The funeral was held in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and the overflow poured onto the streets. Amiri Baraka, the poet and playwright, attended. Pharoah Sanders, the jazz saxophonist, played. John Calipari, Johnson\u2019s coach, was there. \u201cMy dad would be over the moon knowing Dakari is playing in the N.B.A.,\u201d Nandi Campbell, one of Weusi\u2019s eight children, said. \u201cI can see him walking down the street telling everybody. Even strangers.\u201d\n\nJohnson has yet to crack the Thunder rotation and play regular, significant minutes. His big goals remain unfulfilled. His presence in the league is, for his family, a wonder. But they know there will be more hard work to come.\n\n\u201cIt has been generations of cultivating skills,\u201d Kojo Campbell said. \u201cBut it\u2019s not, \u2018Oh, we needed somebody in the N.B.A. \u2014 we can breathe easy now.\u2019 The legacy of this family is about being able to validate ourselves. It\u2019s the focus on the process. It\u2019s: \u2018You know what? We can do this ourselves.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "A Brooklyn Family\u2019s Journey Finally Reaches the N.B.A.", "authors": ["Amos Barshad"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Dark chocolate is one of the ingredients in the poblano mole at La Morada.\n\nCredit Stephen Speranza for The New York Times", "title": "A Brunch Where the Mole Flows", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "The role of the press isn\u2019t to applaud politicians but to provide accountability, so here\u2019s my on-the-fly commentary and fact-checking of President Trump\u2019s State of the Union address to a joint session of Congress tonight. Hang on!", "title": "Opinion | A Brutal Fact-Check of President Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt\u2019s no challenge to find Manchego, the popular Spanish cheese. But Mah\u00f3n has only recently become widely available in the United States. The pale yellow cheese, from the island of Minorca, is versatile. Typically a squarish loaf, it is buttery mild with a fruity aroma after three months of aging. Paprika gives the rind its bright orange hue. At six months, the rind darkens to brown, the texture firms up and the cheese becomes more robust. There is another six-month-old version, made from raw milk, with a more intensely fruity flavor. All are excellent melters: Mah\u00f3n, Whole Foods and Gourmet Garage stores, $16 to $24 per pound, depending on the variety and the store.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Buttery Spanish Cheese for Melting", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Go visit NYT Cooking for more recipes and instruction on how to make them.
