Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Gosar\u2019s fellow Arizona Republican, Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona, took to Twitter in response, \u201cThis is why we can\u2019t have nice things.\u201d\n\nTo that, Mr. Gosar jabbed back, referencing Mr. Flake\u2019s pending retirement at the end of the year, \u201cThis is why you got forced out of office.\u201d\n\nThe powers that be on Capitol Hill did not take appear to take Mr. Gosar as seriously as he took himself. A spokeswoman for the Capitol Police did not return an email request for comment, and AshLee Strong, a spokeswoman for House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, dismissed Mr. Gosar\u2019s suggestion with six succinct words.\n\n\u201cClearly, the speaker does not agree,\u201d Ms. Strong said.\n\nBut, this being Washington, Democrats did not miss an opportunity to pounce.\n\n\u201cWhat he said is outside the circle of decency in terms of members of Congress,\u201d Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, told reporters. She added: \u201cWe believe that we\u2019re children of God, and we all have a spark of divinity in us, and for him to make that statement is to dishonor the God who made us. It\u2019s just shameful.\u201d\n\nMr. Reyes came to the United States from Mexico when he was 10 with his mother, who was escaping an abusive relationship. She worked in canneries and in the fields, he said; today Mr. Reyes works as a \u201cbilingual eligibility specialist,\u201d helping elderly and disabled people figure out if they qualify for government services like Medicaid and food stamps. In his spare time, he is an immigration advocate.\n\nHe never expected Congress to roll out the red carpet for him. But he did not expect anyone to suggest that he be arrested either. He has been in the United States legally since 2012, when he applied for protection from deportation under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, known as DACA.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI refuse to be intimidated,\u2019\u2019 Mr. Reyes said, adding: \u201cI\u2019m not just here representing myself. I\u2019m here representing my family back at home, representing my friends, individuals I\u2019ve met along this journey whose life is in the balance, who are every day waking up with uncertainty.\u201d", "title": "A Congressman Suggests \u2018Dreamers\u2019 Be Arrested. Capitol Hill Rolls Its Eyes.", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Perhaps Mr. Noll\u2019s identity shouldn\u2019t have mattered. His historical evidence and the power of his arguments would be worth considering even if he were Catholic, Jewish or secular. But his identity did matter. It mattered because my evangelical students could not simply assume bad faith on the author\u2019s part. They knew Mr. Noll cared about evangelicals as a group of people. Instead of dismissing Mr. Noll as a bigot, my students thoughtfully engaged with his work.\n\nSince then, I have taken identity into account every time I have assigned new books for one of my courses. I currently teach a course called Black Intellectuals, which is focused on debates around racial inequality in the post-civil rights era. It tends to attract progressive students who, in analyzing racial inequality, are drawn to arguments that stress structural obstacles to equality and the enduring power of white racism, especially in our criminal justice system. The course features black authors who do defend that view, but I also teach the work of others who depart from it in some measure, including heterodox thinkers like Thomas Chatterton Williams and conservatives like Jason Riley. Much like my conservative evangelical students at Cornell, my progressive students at Claremont McKenna College are less likely to assume these contrarian black thinkers are acting in bad faith or are motivated by bigotry \u2014 even when the thinkers criticize hip-hop culture or defend white police officers. So the students engage the challenging arguments and ideas instead.\n\nAs conservatives have long observed and psychologists have since confirmed, human beings are hive-minded animals whose moral judgments are shaped more by sentiments than by reason. Thus, when we are confronted by arguments we disagree with, we can easily find reasons to reject them. The search for disconfirming evidence, however, can sometimes be short-circuited, especially when we feel close to the person making an argument we disagree with. As the social psychologist Jonathan Haidt concluded in his 2012 book, \u201cThe Righteous Mind,\u201d if we have \u201caffection, admiration, or desire to please\u201d other people, we lean toward them and attempt to \u201cfind the truth\u201d in their arguments. Social proximity matters.\n\nIf we want our students to consider the work of authors they\u2019re inclined to disagree with, we professors must take the identity of those authors into account. This doesn\u2019t mean scrubbing all white men from our syllabuses. But when we design an education for our students, we should remember that humans are partial, tribal beings \u2014 not rational automatons.\n\nSome readers \u2014 especially those on the right \u2014 may suspect that embracing identity in this way will only embolden campus radicals. But that objection ignores an important truth: Practicing the new identity politics in the right way can subvert the dogmas that drive its excesses. When students read books by a broad intellectual range of evangelical or female or black authors, for example, they learn that there is no single evangelical or female or black perspective. Disagreements about ideas transcend these social categories.\n\nThe left has often placed too much faith in the power of human reason. Conservatives make the same error when they insist that the identities of intellectuals should never matter. The fact is, they do. And they would, even absent new movements on campus.", "title": "Opinion | A Conservative Case for Identity Politics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTRUMPOCRACY\n\nThe Corruption of the American Republic\n\nBy David Frum\n\n301 pp. HarperCollins. $25.99.\n\nDonald Trump is the oddest president America has ever elected. He lived in a gilded tower on New York\u2019s Fifth Avenue but nevertheless became the voice of the left-behind. He made his public reputation as a reality-TV star but nevertheless defeated one of the most experienced politicians in the land. Trump has done so many extraordinary things in his first year in office, from tweeting about nuclear war to conducting public business in sight of paying guests in a resort he owns, it\u2019s easy to forget that, unless impeachment intervenes, he still has another three years \u2014 and perhaps seven \u2014 to go.\n\nTrump\u2019s election has set off a furious competition among America\u2019s pundits to explain what is going on: The most depressing political story of our time is also the most exciting. David Frum has usually been at or near the front of the pundit pack with a succession of articles in The Atlantic, where he is a senior editor. Most commentators are dyed-in-the-wool liberals who exhausted the language of fulmination during George W. Bush\u2019s presidency. Frum worked for Bush and even had a hand in writing his \u201caxis of evil\u201d speech. Most commentators regard conservative America as an alien land inhabited by monsters. Frum has been writing sharp but sympathetic books on that land since his first, \u201cDead Right,\u201d on the weaknesses of Reaganism, in 1994. The central theme in Frum\u2019s excellent new book, \u201cTrumpocracy,\u201d which draws on his Atlantic articles, is what Trump\u2019s career tells us about the deeper structural problems of America in general, and conservative America in particular.\n\nFrum argues that Trump\u2019s greatest talent \u2014 his genius really \u2014 is spotting and exploiting weaknesses. The Republican establishment spent $100 million to put the crown on Prince Jeb Bush\u2019s head. Trump incinerated Bush (and all that cash) with his gibe about \u201clow energy.\u201d He then proceeded to incinerate \u201clittle\u201d Marco Rubio and \u201clyin\u2019\u201d Ted Cruz. Trump\u2019s campaign against Hillary Clinton was in some ways a model of how not to run campaigns \u2014 he lurched from crisis to crisis and never bothered to enumerate any detailed policies. But he understood her great limitation: that she represented the nexus between meritocracy and plutocracy, indebted to Big Money and divorced from millions of heartland Americans.\n\nTrump\u2019s political operatics worked because he understood deeper weaknesses in American society. The white working class is suffering from two great hammer blows. The first is to its economic well-being: A group that thrived during the golden years of the 1950s and 1960s has seen its incomes stagnate and its job security disappear. Great swaths of white America now suffer from maladies that are all too familiar to black America: broken homes, drug addiction, listlessness, early death. The second hammer blow is to its psychological well-being: Even as their economic position has declined, members of the white working class \u2014 particularly white working-class men \u2014 have seen themselves denounced, often by people who spend more on college education in one year than they earn shoveling dirt, as agents of privilege and oppression. What better way to respond to being defined as a problem than to vote for a man who promises to punch back?\n\nTrump grasped that America is suffering from an epistemological weakness as well as economic ones: The line between truth and falsehood is becoming dangerously blurred. Again, America\u2019s knowledge elite is partly responsible for this: Armies of postmodern academics had prepared the way for Trump by arguing that truth is a construct of the power elite. But the biggest culprit is technological progress. Digitalization is not only creating a deafening cacophony of voices. It is also making it harder to finance real journalism while simultaneously making it easier to distribute tripe.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Manhattan-based playboy who has had life handed to him on a silver platter might look like a strange vehicle for the pain of the American heartland. But Trump is a winner with the soul of a loser: He is consumed by imagined slights to his fragile ego, hypersensitive to the pretensions of smarty-pants liberals, a man who spends many hours a day watching cable news and seething with anger. He is also an anti-intellectual with the soul of a postmodernist: He believes that reality is something that can be bent into any shape you choose provided that you have enough power.\n\nWhat does Trump want to do with all his power? The answer, Frum argues, certainly does not lie in helping the white working class that put him in the White House. His tax cuts will widen America\u2019s already high levels of inequality. It lies instead in \u201cthe aggrandizement of one domineering man and his shamelessly grasping extended family.\u201d The essence of Trumponomics is running a country just as you run your family business: appointing people with whom you have strong personal ties, ideally ties of DNA, directing business to your properties, using public resources to avenge private grudges. Trump\u2019s appointments to the White House staff included his former bodyguard, Keith Schiller, and a former contestant on \u201cThe Apprentice.\u201d Perhaps the most telling moment in his first year was when he asked his daughter Ivanka to sit in his seat at a G-7 meeting, thereby reducing a great republic to the level of a family property.\n\nPhoto\n\nFrum thinks the combination of Trump\u2019s drive for self-aggrandizement and America\u2019s current weaknesses is nothing less than a threat to the democratic order. \u201cThe thing to fear from the Trump presidency is not the bold overthrow of the Constitution, but the stealthy paralysis of governance; not the open defiance of law, but an accumulating subversion of norms; not the deployment of state power to intimidate dissidents, but the incitement of private violence to radicalize supporters.\u201d Any supposed solutions to Trump\u2019s behavior, however, may be worse than the disease: American liberals have found themselves investing extraordinary hopes in the generals who now surround the president.\n\nTrump isn\u2019t alone in the weakness-exploitation business. Some of the most eye-catching investors in his real estate empire since he won the Republican nomination hail from countries where there is a faint line between business and politics. And some of Trump\u2019s biggest ideological backers have an almost apocalyptic sense that America needs to be purged in order to be saved. Hanging over everything is the figure of Vladimir Putin, a man who has devoted his career to accumulating information on weaknesses, both personal and political, and turning that information into power. Rather than Russia turning into America, as America\u2019s policymakers argued in that great age of illusion, the 1990s, America seems to be turning into Russia.\n\nThe immediate task facing the American republic is to limit the damage that Trump can cause: Here the checks and balances are already playing the role that the founders intended. But the bigger task is to eliminate the weaknesses that have produced Trumpism. Frum rightly points out that these are broad as well as deep. The travails of the white working class are symptoms of a bigger problem: the concentration of wealth in a narrow range of industries and companies. Likewise, the corruption embodied in Trump Inc. is the product of a broader corruption of America\u2019s governing class, which has allowed Bill and Hillary Clinton to transform themselves into public-service millionaires and Barack and Michelle Obama to negotiate a reported $65 million book deal for their autobiographies. Getting tough on Trump is going to be a picnic compared with getting tough on the causes of Trumpism.", "title": "A Conservative\u2019s Case Against Donald Trump", "authors": ["Adrian Wooldridge", "David Frum"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The key part of Simpson\u2019s testimony, as The Plum Line\u2019s Greg Sargent notes: The F.B.I. was already investigating the Trump campaign\u2019s relationship with Russia when it received additional information from Christopher Steele, a former British intelligence officer working with Simpson\u2019s firm, Fusion GPS. (Various Fox News commentators and others have tried to spin a tale in which the Clinton campaign effectively started the F.B.I. investigation, via Steele and Fusion.)\n\nWe still don\u2019t know how much of the information in Steele\u2019s infamous Trump dossier is accurate. Either way, Steele and Fusion are only supporting players in this story. The main questions are about Trump\u2019s campaign and Russia \u2014 not the people trying to figure out what was happening between the campaign and Russia.\n\nRelated: In The Times, Ben Smith, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed News, defends its decision to publish the Steele dossier one year ago today.\n\nPerspective. The story of Russian collusion is devilishly complicated. Susan Hennessey \u2014 a legal expert whose work I\u2019ve often cited in this newsletter \u2014 offered an especially clear summary in a recent podcast with Vox\u2019s Ezra Klein. She described two scenarios \u2014 one more innocent, one less so. Here are the basics:\n\nThe innocent explanation: Amateurish Trump officials unwittingly blundered into a campaign by Russia to influence American policy and create chaos. The Trump officials cooperated with Russian nationals because they didn\u2019t know they shouldn\u2019t. They then lied about their contacts because those contacts were embarrassing, not because they were part of a sophisticated conspiracy. As Hennessey puts it, \u201cthe cover up is worse than the crime.\u201d\n\nThe less-innocent explanation: Top Trump officials understood that they were doing something wrong. Perhaps they were trying to help their campaign with tactics they understood were wrong. Or perhaps they were working to advance the interests of a foreign power, because of financial entanglements between those officials \u2014 maybe including Trump \u2014 and Russia. These officials, and others who were aware of the entanglements, then lied about the contacts. In that case, Hennessey explains, \u201cthe decision making at the top of the executive branch is not in any meaningful way being guided by the best interests of the American people.\u201d\n\nLast year, I walked through five possible motivations for the Trump team\u2019s strange friendliness with Russia, including some of the possibilities mentioned here. If you\u2019re a podcast fan, you may enjoy the full Hennessey-Klein discussion.", "title": "Opinion | A Counter-Conspiracy, Debunked", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The decision by the Department of Homeland Security not to renew Temporary Protected Status, for almost 200,000 migrants from El Salvador is President Trump\u2019s latest attempt to restrict both legal and illegal immigration. This comes on the heels of the same rulings last year regarding Haitians and Nicaraguans. Salvadorans, however, are by far the largest group of T.P.S. recipients \u2014 approximately two-thirds of the remaining beneficiaries.\n\nJust like the decision to end the DACA program for nearly 800,000 undocumented childhood arrivals, the T.P.S. announcement is politically motivated and is probably an attempt to satisfy President Trump\u2019s anti-immigrant base. Although the choice to end a supposedly temporary program that has nonetheless lasted for 17 years may sound rational, the real-world consequences of such a wide-reaching move will be immediate and severe \u2014 and may even contribute to a new cycle of illegal immigration.\n\nMany, if not most, are unlikely to voluntarily return to a country that they no longer call home and instead may seek to stay illegally. The widespread fear instilled by this ruling, and the possible deportations to come, will tear apart families and communities. In effect, as of September 2019 there will be a group of newly unauthorized migrants living in the United States equivalent to the population of Salt Lake City. After almost two decades in the United States, Salvadoran T.P.S. recipients have built lives, communities and businesses. In many cities \u2014 above all Washington and Los Angeles \u2014 they are an important part of the economic and social fabric. They are parents to approximately 192,700 United States-born citizens.\n\nIronically, if T.P.S. recipients are deported, a primary beneficiary will be one of President Trump\u2019s most-stated enemies: the MS-13 gang, which he has accused of turning United States communities \u201cinto bloodstained killing fields.\u201d The criminal organization, which is active in both the United States and El Salvador, traces its roots to instability after a wave of deportations from the United States in the 1990s, which El Salvador was ill equipped to receive. It didn\u2019t take long for the resulting instability to bounce back to the United States in the form of increased criminal activity and illegal immigration.", "title": "Opinion | A Counterproductive Approach to a Broken Immigration System", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Usually, Mr. Echigoya produces about 25 pairs a month, which sell for $480 and $580 each from his website, boweryblue.com, and for as much as $650 at shops in Brooklyn, Tokyo, Hong Kong and Bangkok.\n\n\u201cYou said straight leg, right?\u201d Mr. Echigoya asked Mr. Mosholder, handing him two pairs and leading him to a makeshift dressing room in a hallway. He pulled shut a gray curtain.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re really perfect,\u201d said Mr. Mosholder, who came out wearing the jeans. \u201cThere\u2019s so much twist,\u201d he said, pointing to fabric near the cuff.\n\nThe doorbell rang again. Pat Prasong Kanhasura, 45, entered with Bobby Narin Mungkay, 37.\n\nMr. Kanhasura sported a pair of Bowery Blues that he said he wore \u201calmost every day.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kanhasura owns Bangklyn East Harlem, on Second Avenue between 105th and 106th Streets, a clothing store that sells Bowery Blue jeans and serves what he calls \u201cSoutheast Asian soul food.\u201d\n\nThe two came to talk business with Mr. Echigoya, who is looking for a Manhattan showroom for his line.\n\n\u201cI think he is the best denim maker,\u201d Mr. Kanhasura said. \u201cIf you look, the fabric isn\u2019t straight, because of the machines he uses. It has more charm than the ones made with a computer.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI cannot use new machines,\u201d Mr. Echigoya said. \u201cCannot. The old machine makes denim more by hand, more uneven.\u201d\n\nMr. Mungkay leaned against a beam and pulled out his phone. He flipped through photos of himself in a dark mine shaft. Mr. Mungkay works for Mr. Kanhasura, but he started talking about his recent side gig with Brit Eaton, a vintage-denim hunter who is known in the trade as Indiana Jeans. Mr. Eaton traverses the American West looking for \u201cGold Rush\u201d denim: actual jeans from the 1840s and 1850s.\n\nMr. Mungkay would say only that the most recent expedition was in Colorado. \u201cIt\u2019s kind of secret,\u201d he explained.\n\nMr. Echigoya aims to duplicate classic American jeans by using only American cotton, along with his own \u201cunique cotton thread.\u201d\n\n\u201cJeans are like humans,\u201d Mr. Echigoya said. \u201cThey need their own character.\u201d", "title": "A Craftsman\u2019s Passion: American Jeans", "authors": ["Lisa M. Collins", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "It was time to head to the island\u2019s wild south, a jigsaw of protected landscapes informally called the Siguanea Nature Reserve where caves are filled with pre-Colombian carvings, sea turtles lounge by the beaches and reptiles bask in the swamps. My plan was to visit the evocatively named village of Cocodrilo (crocodile) with Dr. Guggenheim, who since 2015 has worked with a local group there called Red Alerta to protect its pristine coral reefs. It is a singular Cuban-American joint venture. His Washington-based N.G.O., Ocean Doctor, provides equipment and trains villagers to work as guides instead of fishing illegally \u2014 a standard ecotourism model in other parts of the world, but a radical departure in Cuba, where the economy is still mostly state-run and grass-roots activism is discouraged.\n\n\u201cAs fearful as we are of thousands of Americans going down to Cuba and recreating the mass tourism model that destroyed much of the Caribbean,\u201d he told me in Nueva Gerona, \u201ctourism has to be part of the solution.\u201d (Because it is research-based, the Red Alerta program has been unaffected by recent changes to travel for American citizens, but visits have to be arranged through an authorized travel agency or Ocean Doctor.)\n\nBut La Isla has not shaken off its Cold War past. The Cuban military monitors the various southern nature reserves, and we soon discovered that the whole area had been declared off-limits \u2014 no explanation given. The word on the street in Nueva Gerona was that the military was conducting antidrug sweeps along the coast. True or not, there would be no Cocodrilo for us. Time for Plan B. We decided to head to El Colony, the island\u2019s only real hotel, which had the misfortune to open the week before the revolution in 1959, and somehow managed to survive the following decades on the dribble of tourism to Cuba, mostly from the Eastern bloc. At the small marina there, we hired a boat to take us to the reserve\u2019s limits.\n\nSoon we were motoring south with a dive master and a cook. Our first mission was to snorkel off a popular beach called Punto Franc\u00e9s, where two years ago Dr. Guggenheim had seen intact expanses of elkhorn coral, a barometer of reef health. Even an amateur like me could tell that all was not well below the waves. \u201cThat is a wonderful example of a reef that is 90 percent dead,\u201d Dr. Guggenheim said with a sigh, as we dried off back on board. There had been some bleaching from climate change, he explained, but the main culprit was overfishing, which led to the coral being slowly covered in slimy green algae. \u201cWe treat fish like crops to be harvested,\u201d he said, \u201cbut they have important jobs to do in the ecosystem. One of them is grazing on algae, which keeps reefs clean.\u201d", "title": "A Cuban Island That Has Played Both Paradise and Prison", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "It took two eagle-eyed historians to track down the plane that led hundreds of Allied aircraft into Normandy during World War II.\n\nA few years ago, the historical treasure was languishing in an aircraft bone yard in Wisconsin.\n\nThe plane, a twin-engine C-47 called \u201cThat\u2019s All, Brother,\u201d carried American paratroopers into German-occupied France on June 6, 1944, or D-Day. It led the main formation that dropped thousands of men into what became a bloody but decisive battle, paving the way for the liberation of northern France from the Nazis.\n\n[UPDATE: A D-Day Plane Is Flying Again; With Photos]\n\nLike many other World War II planes, \u201cThat\u2019s All, Brother\u201d was sold for private use after the fighting ended. It cycled through a series of owners and its historical significance was in danger of being forgotten.\n\nBut in 2007, the two historians started following a paper trail.\n\nFrom Normandy to Oshkosh\n\nAt the Air Force Historical Research Agency in Montgomery, Ala., Matt Scales, then a member of the Air National Guard, was researching John M. Donalson, who piloted the plane on the day it soared over the beaches of Normandy.", "title": "A D-Day Plane Lost for Years Is About to Fly Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 When a federal judge in California ordered a stop last week to a key plank of President Trump\u2019s immigration agenda, he revived a debate that has simmered in this age of partisanship: the role of the impartial judiciary in American democracy.\n\nThe judge, William Alsup of the Northern District of California in San Francisco, used a local case to impose a nationwide stop on Mr. Trump\u2019s order to end a program that protects young undocumented immigrants in the United States.\n\nThe tactic has gained popularity among federal judges as a tool to combat perceived executive overreach. But legal scholars say it is helping to erode the idea of an impartial judiciary, and Judge Alsup\u2019s decision opened him to critiques that he overstepped his boundaries by applying national orders in a regional case.\n\nThe possibility of obtaining a comprehensive injunction that impedes, or even thwarts, the opposition has legal scholars worried that more plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers will take cases to sympathetic judges.", "title": "A DACA Question: Should Judges Use Local Cases to Halt National Orders?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cSerbs have to remain and survive in their homes in Kosovo,\u201d Mr. Vucic told the skeptical audience of ethnic Serbs in the village of Banjska in northern Kosovo. \u201cWe cannot allow our numbers to dwindle in the land we\u2019ve lived in since ancient time.\u201d\n\nStill, he made clear that it was imperative that both sides act in good faith in the wake of Mr. Ivanovic\u2019s killing in the northern city of Mitrovica, not far from the monastery. The investigation is an opportunity for the ethnic Albanian institutions to \u201cshow what they will do,\u201d he said in a statement. On the Serb side, he said, \u201cThere will be no mercy for the perpetrators nor for those who ordered it, no matter whether their name is Serbian or Albanian.\u201d\n\nThe war ended nearly two decades ago, but tensions remain high and all sides are aware how quickly violent episodes in one ethnic community can morph into a conflict with another. Mr. Vucic\u2019s arrival was precipitated by the death of Mr. Ivanovic, 64, who was shot five times in the chest on a street, his body splayed out on the sidewalk just steps from the office of the political party he led.\n\nAs Mr. Vucic\u2019s motorcade sped from the north to a Serbian enclave in the south of the country, hundreds of officers lined the highway, standing guard in a blinding snowstorm.\n\nThe Serb leader tried to walk a fine line on his visit, working to satisfy different audiences \u2014 the Serbian people, and the Western leaders he is courting as he seeks to join the European Union.", "title": "A Death in Kosovo Stokes Fears and Threatens Peace", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE FLOATING WORLD\n\nBy C. Morgan Babst\n\n370 pp. Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $26.95.\n\nFollowing a grim hurricane season, C. Morgan Babst\u2019s powerful debut novel, \u201cThe Floating World,\u201d revives our memory of what seemed at the time like the mother of all storms.\n\nThe novel follows the members of a New Orleans family immediately after Hurricane Katrina, alternating among their perspectives. There is Tess, a white doctor who comes from money, and her husband, Joe, a Creole artist. They have two grown daughters, the distressed Cora and the willful Del. Cora is the only one to stay for the storm; Del is away in New York and the others evacuate. Though Tess will eventually come to her daughter\u2019s aid, and Del will return, Cora sees something in the 25 days she\u2019s without her family that leaves her even more frazzled than before.\n\nUnlike Jesmyn Ward\u2019s powerful Katrina novel, the National Book Award-winning \u201cSalvage the Bones,\u201d most of this story takes place after landfall. And with visions of the storm sneaking into even the most discordant scenes, inescapable loss permeates each page. At one point, the perfection of a Tollhouse cookie in the imperfect city brings tears to Tess\u2019s eyes. At another, Del gets a \u201cfeeling in her chest like water straining against a door\u201d when her friend-turned-lover says I love you. Sometimes \u2014 especially in Tess\u2019s, Del\u2019s and Joe\u2019s sections \u2014 the sense of loss becomes almost oppressive. In reality the storm\u2019s impact was unrelenting, no doubt, but Babst is most effective at conveying the emotional weight of the tragedy when she presents it alongside vibrant characters and story lines.\n\nPhoto\n\nOne of the most vibrant is the family patriarch, Vincent, whom Babst brings to life in a portrayal that\u2019s impressively unrestrained, even Faulknerian. Because of his memory limitations, we see his whole life stream forward as if in the present tense, outside of the storm\u2019s temporal confines. We taste the stuffed crab and pocket pies he ate on a street the city has since replaced with an interstate he doesn\u2019t remember. We feel the comfort of his mother\u2019s rocking chair, the relief of his dog come back to assure him everything will be O.K.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBabst also shines in her depiction of Cora. The book\u2019s short middle section ingeniously tracks back to before the storm, and Cora glimmers on the page: a fragile, na\u00efve yet thoughtful woman reminiscent of Laura in \u201cThe Glass Menagerie.\u201d\n\nAny novel of the South has to grapple with race at least implicitly, and \u201cThe Floating World\u201d doesn\u2019t shy from the subject. Cora is romantically involved with Troy, an African-American restaurant worker whose sister, Reyna, is mentally ill. Though Joe identifies as Creole, and Cora and Del are biracial, they are economically privileged. So it was wise on Babst\u2019s part to introduce the poorer Troy and Reyna to a book about Katrina \u2014 a storm that touched so many poor African-American lives, after all. Unfortunately, Reyna rarely rises above stereotype, either sentimentalized by Cora or demonized by Troy. And her fate is too often and too superficially linked to Cora\u2019s story, without recognizing her independent significance as a mother of two, or just as a complex character. She feels like a missed opportunity to pay authentic attention to the plight of the people who arguably saw the worst of the storm.", "title": "A Debut Novelist\u2019s Elegy for Post-Katrina New Orleans", "authors": ["Margaret Wilkerson Sexton", "C. Morgan Babst"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In his research, Cajal\u2019s two tools were the most powerful microscope he could find and one of the oldest art techniques known to mankind: drawing, for which he had great talent. Looking through the lens he saw with such acuity and drew so precisely (freehand) that some of his renderings still appear in text books. And yet he also drew with such delicacy and vivacity that his drawings stand on their own as wonders of graphic expression, both mysterious and familiar.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe drawings are at once fairly hard-nosed fact if you know your science. If you don\u2019t they are deep pools of suggestive motifs into which the imagination can dive. Their lines, forms and various textures of stippling, dashes and faint pencil circles would be the envy of any modern artist. That they connect with Surrealist drawing, biomorphic abstraction and exquisite doodling is only the half of it.\n\nThese small works evoke enough things you already know \u2014 landscape, weather systems, trees, marine life \u2014 that they bring you back around to reality, implying the multiple purposes if not universality of certain natural structures. Root systems, functioning in different ways, are found in trees, turnips and the pyramidal neuron, which Cajal called \u201cthe noble and enigmatic cell of thought.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBorn in Navarra, the son of a doctor, Cajal was a rebellious artistic child, with an innate distrust of authority and an obsessive-compulsive proclivity. At 8, according to the catalog, he drew everything around him and then set out to collect everything pertaining to birds. He taught himself photography, making carefully posed self-portraits throughout his life. And he trained as an artist, but his father cajoled him toward medicine by enlisting him to make anatomical drawings as teaching aids. The son then went to medical school and eventually found his calling in researching the extremely refined, nearly invisible workings of the brain. It was an exciting area of study at that time and it perfectly fused his various interests and talents.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis show, the first exhibition of Cajal\u2019s drawings in this country, originated at the University of Minnesota and continues in May to the MIT Museum in Cambridge, Mass. It was selected from the 2,900 or so drawings that Ram\u00f3n y Cajal made in his lifetime; all come from the Cajal Institute in Madrid, which organized the show with the university\u2019s Weisman Art Museum and three neuroscientists on its faculty \u2014 Eric A. Newman, Janet M. Dubinsky and Alfonso Araque. The catalog is an absolute treasure, jargon-free, with excellent reproductions and an illuminating biographical essay by Larry W. Swanson, a neurobiologist and author of \u201cBrain Architecture\u201d (2002). The outliers of the group are Lyndel King, director and chief curator of the Weisman and Eric Himmel, editor in chief at Abrams Books (the catalog\u2019s publisher), who contribute a riveting essay detailing Cajal\u2019s artistic sensibility and working processes.\n\nThe drawings will elicit stupefied awe from art enthusiasts, who use their brains without knowing how they work, and excited chatter from visiting neuroscience types. I asked one loquacious, evidently knowledgeable viewer if \u201cgray matter\u201d was a colloquialism or a term of science. I learned that it\u2019s a term of science that became a colloquialism: the brain has gray matter, which contains cells, and also white matter, which is fibrous.\n\nThe 80 drawings here were made between 1890 and 1933, and are divided into four sections. \u201cCells of the Brain\u201d presents some of the basics, beginning with pyramidal neurons, and including the pericellular nests that surround them like pointy hats, or Eva Hesse sculpture, and proceeding to the coral-like Purkinje neurons (from the human and pigeon cerebellum).\n\nIn \u201cSensory Systems,\u201d you\u2019ll find several of the show\u2019s masterpieces: \u201cCells in the retina of the eye,\u201d a vertical stack of textures and intersecting lines and shapes, suggests a wall hanging by a very ambitious fiber artist of the 1950s. Drawings for the retina of the lizard and sparrow evoke espaliered trees. Blue ink added to the peninsular forms of \u201cThe labyrinth of the inner ear,\u201d renders them solid. And the Wagnerian \u201cEnding of the vestibular nerve\u201d is swept with diagonal streams of lines and rising neurons.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDevelopment and Pathology\u201d is rife with strange aberrant forms and a sense of agitated circuitry; also several outstanding drawings in a purely visual sense. Cajal samples the brain cells of a drowned man and one suffering from paralysis and in \u201cTumor cells of the covering membranes of the brain,\u201d he achieves tangled skeins that conjure William Blake and Louise Bourgeois. Things quiet down in \u201cNeuronal Pathways,\u201d which I recommend for the strange little landscape that is \u201cConnections within the hippocampus.\u201d\n\n\u201cSeeing the Beautiful Brain Today,\u201d a section on contemporary renderings usually in jolting bright colors, presents animations as well as detailed microscopic photographs that are juxtaposed with reproductions of Cajal drawings of the same subject. Nothing here compares to Cajal artistically, but the animations have their own kind of wonder and should not be missed.", "title": "A Deep Dive Into the Brain, Hand-Drawn by the Father of Neuroscience", "authors": ["Roberta Smith"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cIn Reply, a Bilingual Salvo From Kennedy\u201d (news article, Jan. 31):\n\nWhat do Democrats desperately need? If you pair Joe Kennedy up with one of the female Democratic politicians like Heidi Heitkamp, Claire McCaskill or Tammy Duckworth, the Democrats will have a winning ticket in 2020.\n\nJOE MCCAFFREY, PHILADELPHIA\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nJoseph Kennedy\u2019s rebuttal to the State of the Union was spot on. Not on the side, so I didn\u2019t have to deal with opening it and squeezing it out and all that.\u201d She\u2019d then read The Daily News and possibly head to the gym for an anxiety-ridden run on the treadmill, always in corduroy cutoffs (Mullin doesn\u2019t \u201cdo workout clothes,\u201d she says) and \u201cgym shoes, in the elementary-school way.\u201d\n\nAs Mullin, 47, has settled into adulthood, she\u2019s made some adjustments \u2014 she now regularly swims laps at the YMCA and practices yoga, both at home and in a studio. \u201cI did, for the first time, self-consciously go to the grocery store with yoga clothing on \u2014 O.K., I covered my leggings with gauchos,\u201d she says, \u201cthen I realized, everyone wears yoga clothes to the grocery store and nobody is looking at me, so get over it.\u201d In terms of diet, Mullin\u2019s bacon, egg and cheese has become a \u201cMorning bruschetta.\u201d She shares the recipe for that, as well as her version of a breakfast taco, below.", "title": "A Designer\u2019s Healthy Answer to Bacon, Egg and Cheese", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The recipe was packed with protein from chickpeas (rather than red meat) along with vitamins and fiber from the rustic vegetables. When feeling depleted, James says this cleaner, lighter version of the traditionally heavy dish makes her feel balanced and \u201cmore whole.\u201d Having done a number of detoxes over the years, James realized that she would rather not eliminate foods from her diet. Instead, she says, \u201cIt\u2019s not about stripping away \u2014 but adding in what you\u2019re missing.\u201d With its aromatic blend of spices, the chili was also a step above \u201ctakeout food and all that jazz, which I didn\u2019t want.\u201d\n\nImage James at home in Brooklyn. Credit Gabriela Herman\n\nThroughout her two years at Ryerson University, James adapted her mother\u2019s chili recipe and kept a pot of it on the stove, or a container in the fridge, which her friends and roommates would huddle over. \u201cIt didn\u2019t feel like college food,\u201d she says. \u201cIt felt like a warm hug.\u201d\n\nNow the 33-year-old James regularly makes the chili for an energizing winter fix. Though she is no longer a vegan, she explains, \u201cIt just makes you feel warm and enriched.\u201d After recently moving into a new apartment in Bed-Stuy, Brooklyn, James has more space to share the chili with others \u2014 gatherings often include her boyfriend, the stylist Browne Andrews, the editor Elaine Welteroth and Adeline, the front woman of the band Escort. \u201cIt\u2019s an easy crowd pleaser, and you can always infuse your own thing \u2014 take out the broccoli or add more corn to customize it,\u201d she says. The dish takes about two and a half hours to make but James, who frequently travels to Ethiopia and South Africa to produce her line of sustainable shoes and bags, considers cooking a form of meditation. \u201cWe have to make time for ourselves and nourish ourselves \u2014 and this chili is pretty perfect for that.\u201d\n\nHere, James shares the wholesome recipe, which she serves in vintage wooden bowls from her mother. She recommends making up a large batch, noting that the chili tastes even better the second day. \u201cThat\u2019s when the flavors really come together.\u201d", "title": "A Designer\u2019s Plant-Based Chili Recipe for Cold Winter Days", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "There\u2019s a world of hospitality contained in the tiny cups of black tea that greet you \u2014 along with a dainty plate of Welsh rarebit-flavored crackers \u2014 when you sit down to eat at Lady of the House, a nominally Irish, decidedly welcoming restaurant that opened last September in Detroit\u2019s Corktown neighborhood.\n\nThe lady in charge of this particular house is Kate Williams, a Detroit native whose family roots run deep in Corktown: her great-grandparents met at the neighborhood\u2019s Gaelic League after emigrating from Ireland. Ms. Williams, who previously cooked at other restaurants around town, had long wanted to open her own in Detroit, where \u201cas much as we can,\u201d she said, her business is now \u201cgetting the money back into a city that needs to grow the tax base.\u201d\n\nAnd, indeed, her focus is local: Much of Ms. Williams\u2019 produce comes from urban farms, her house gin was created in collaboration with Detroit City Distillery and her tables and bar shelves were made by a local artist. A sense of resourcefulness pervades her cooking, which incorporates so-called ugly foods \u2014 ingredients that would have otherwise been discarded for purely aesthetic reasons \u2014 and whole-animal butchery. \u201cChef is passionate about no waste,\u201d our server informed us. \u201cYou\u2019ll notice at the end of the night that we only have one compost bucket.\u201d", "title": "A Detroit Restaurant With Deep Local Roots", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The author began the diary in 1941 \u2014 the date written on the first page \u2014 while she was working at a weather station that served the farming operations of the sprawling Karlag labor camp in Kazakhstan.\n\nThe diary features the misadventures of camp life experienced by the stick figure called the \u201cLittle Weather Devil.\u201d Drawn in the style of pre-revolutionary comics, each page depicts a theme, like hunger or fear, or illustrates specific, often emotional moments, from the tragedy of losing a coat in a harsh climate to the joy of finding a she-wolf for a pet. On some pages, the figure contemplates existential questions or the vagaries of fate.\n\nThe diary frequently references Russian literature, including the poets Pushkin and Lermontov, as well as Latin axioms. The title of the diary, \u201cWork and Days,\u201d came from the epic poem of Hesiod, a Greek poet, from around 700 BC, which discussed corruption, honesty and justice.\n\nThe couplets are difficult to translate, particularly the more philosophical musings. They are often word plays or otherwise ambiguous.\n\n\u201cIt reveals a very good knowledge of the language and literature, but it is often hard to tell what she means,\u201d said Dmitri A. Belanovsky, who translated parts of the diary into English. He thinks the ambiguity was insurance in case the guards found the diary.\n\nThe Gulag History Museum published a copy of the diary in a small, handsome volume that also includes reproductions of newspaper articles about its discovery, the record of Ms. Ranitskaya\u2019s interrogation when she was arrested and some longer poems that she wrote later. It took some eight years to pull it all together.", "title": "A Diary From a Gulag Meets Evil With Lightness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSLOW MEDICINE\n\nThe Way to Healing\n\nBy Victoria Sweet\n\n289 pp. Riverhead Books. $27.\n\nDoctors today often complain of working in an occupational black hole in which patient encounters are compressed into smaller and smaller space and time. You can do a passable job in a 10-minute visit, they say, but it is impossible to appreciate the subtleties of patient care when you are rushing.\n\nEnter \u201cSlow Medicine: The Way to Healing,\u201d a wonderful new memoir by Dr. Victoria Sweet. The term \u201cslow medicine\u201d has different interpretations. For some it means spending more time with patients. For others it means taking the time to understand evidence so as to avoid overdiagnosis and overtreatment. For Sweet, it means \u201cstepping back and seeing the patient in the context of his environment,\u201d and providing medical care that is \u201cslow, methodical and step-by-step.\u201d\n\nAt the beginning of her book, she relates how her 93-year-old father was mistreated after being hospitalized for a seizure. He is put in 4-point restraints and sedated. Bloody urine drains from his bladder because it has been injured by a catheter insertion. Worse, his rushed doctors don\u2019t know that this isn\u2019t his first seizure but rather the latest in a long line that can be managed at home.\n\nThe steamroller of inpatient care takes over. Every day Sweet\u2019s father sees a different doctor. He isn\u2019t allowed to eat or get out of bed because he is on tranquilizers. He becomes septic. His symptoms are misdiagnosed as a stroke. Doctors eventually prepare to insert a feeding tube into his stomach because he cannot swallow. Sweet and her sisters get him out of the hospital just in time. When he gets home, he has a steak and a beer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSweet writes, \u201cIf I, as a physician, couldn\u2019t get appropriate care for a family member in a lovely community hospital with well-trained staff \u2014 who could?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nShe yearns for a different kind of medical care \u2014 one that is not \u201ca commodity, bought and sold on Wall Street.\u201d", "title": "A Doctor Argues That Her Profession Needs to Slow Down, Stat", "authors": ["Sandeep Jauhar", "Victoria Sweet"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Video\n\nSYDNEY, Australia \u2014 A practice session for Australian lifeguards who were testing a new drone turned into a real rescue when the drone helped save two swimmers at a beach in New South Wales.\n\nOn Thursday morning, Jai Sheridan, a lifeguard supervisor who was operating the drone, was alerted to two young men caught in turbulent surf with 10-foot swells. Mr. Sheridan then steered the drone toward the swimmers.\n\nIn video of the incident taken from the drone, it can be seen releasing a yellow \u201crescue pod\u201d that inflates in the water. The two swimmers grabbed the pod, and with its support they made their way to shore. They were fatigued, but not hurt, Surf Life Saving New South Wales, a volunteer organization, said in a statement.\n\nThe rescue took just 70 seconds. \u201cOn a normal day that would have taken our lifeguards a few minutes longer,\u201d Mr. Sheridan said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe drone used for the rescue, known as a Little Ripper unmanned aerial vehicle, is also part of a shark-spotting program being rolled out across Australian beaches this summer. It uses an algorithm to automatically recognize sharks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Of the five families who lost loved ones, by count, the Stewarts lost the most.\n\nThe coffins inside the funeral home proved too much to bear for the relatives who filed in on Monday under an ominous sky. Loud cries and deep moans pierced the chill inside Chapel A, as relatives wondered how something so unfathomable could possibly be real.\n\n\u201cGod, what my children does do that you just wipe out the page, nothing left, not even a line?\u201d Ms. Stewart pleaded. \u201cJesus, where do I go from here?\u201d\n\nIn the vestibule, her daughter Shevan Stewart, who lived on the first floor of the building, fainted, then woke up shouting, \u201cThe fire, the fire, the fire!\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nHer brother Rudolph said she was having flashbacks: \u201cShe tried to save them. She\u2019s taking it very hard.\u201d\n\nThe funeral was a ritual that other families \u2014 the Donkors, the Sarkodies, the Mensahs \u2014 will endure over the coming weeks as they say goodbye to those who died in the fire. A funeral was held Sunday for the youngest victim of the fire, 7-month-old Amora Batiz, and her grandmother, Maria Batiz, 65.\n\nAndrene Paul, Ms. Stewart-Francis\u2019s sister, set up a GoFundMe page to send the bodies back to Jamaica for burial. Ms. Stewart-Francis wanted to be buried with her father, with whom she was \u201cjoined at the hip,\u201d Ms. Paul said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor the Stewarts, the outcome could have been even worse: They occupied five units in the Prospect Avenue building and everyone was home when the fire started.\n\nMs. Young, who lived on the basement floor with her parents, had been visiting her aunt Karen\u2019s fifth-floor apartment. The pair were known as the family divas, stylish and never ones to miss a nail appointment.\n\nThey died with Kelesha and Kylie after being overcome by smoke in the bathroom where they sought shelter. Mr. Francis died last week after he was taken off life support.\n\nMs. Young was \u201clike a model,\u201d Ms. Paul, her aunt, said, miming the way her niece walked, with a sassy swish in her hips. The couple married in May, Ms. Paul said.\n\nMr. Francis found work hard to come by in Jamaica, his brother said, and he believed he would have better prospects in the United States \u2014 and at least he would be with his young family. His departure was bittersweet for his family, which included eight other brothers and eight sisters, his twin brother said.\n\n\u201cWe understood that he was going away for a better life, but we also didn\u2019t want him to leave us,\u201d Iholt Francis said. \u201cIt was a mixed feeling.\u201d\n\nA few weeks before he died, Mr. Francis started a job sorting recyclables at Action Environmental Services, a waste-management company in the Bronx. But it was a means to an end, his brother said. Holt was saving money to go to vocational school to become an electrician.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s a hands-on person, so anything that involves using hands, building stuff, that\u2019s what he was good at,\u201d Iholt Francis said.\n\nDuring the funeral, he paid tribute to his brother and said that the loss left him struggling with suicidal thoughts.\n\nMourners in the crowd pleaded, \u201cThere is hope, brother,\u201d and \u201cMercy.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, he went to Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx to give doctors permission to let his brother, who had been declared brain dead, die. Kissed him. And in that moment I just wished that it would be enough, that it would be the miracle that he needed to come back to this world.
