How are you feeling heading into the trip?\n\nElated and terrified \u2014 but I keep coming back to elated, which is a good thing. I\u2019ve only been to five of the places on the list, and those are mostly in the United States. I\u2019m so grateful to The Times for picking me to go on this crazy adventure.\n\nI\u2019m sure I\u2019m like a lot of people from middle- and working-class backgrounds in that I\u2019d certainly dreamed of traveling around the world \u2014 I just never thought it would happen. I grew up in a part of New Mexico where herds of cattle would just wander into our backyard. I went straight from college to working as an editorial assistant at New York magazine, and at the time I was just throwing ideas at the wall, ready to take whatever job came my way. I never thought I\u2019d spend 17 years falling in love with journalism and learning from some of the smartest people I\u2019ve ever met. (Or that I\u2019d get to hang out with Stevie Nicks.) But I also knew when I saw the 52 Places listing, that I\u2019d found the one thing that I wouldn\u2019t be able to turn down if I were lucky enough to get it.\n\nTell us a little about how your professional background will be an asset.\n\nThe initial job posting said The Times was looking for someone with \u201cthe ability to parachute into a place and distill its essence,\u201d and I remember thinking, I\u2019ve done that for years! (Had I known that 13,000 people were going to have the same reaction, I\u2019m not sure I would have felt so confident, but it helped in the moment.)\n\nMy first writing job at New York magazine was running our party coverage. That meant going to up to four events a night, walking into a strange room and trying to get interviews with whatever celebrities happened to be there. You have to think fast and you can\u2019t have any kind of fear factor, which I hope will come in handy on the road.", "title": "A Few Questions for Our 52 Places Traveler", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "JAIPUR, India \u2014 After months of controversy, weeks of threats and days of fiery protests, a contentious new Bollywood film hit the theaters in India on Thursday, and the reaction was:\n\nWhat\u2019s the big deal?\n\nMoviegoers streamed out of heavily guarded movie theaters saying they liked the sets, the music and the grand Bollywood style of \u201cPadmaavat,\u201d a lavish saga about a legendary Hindu queen who may never have existed. But they couldn\u2019t understand why so many people had violently objected to it.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s silly, it\u2019s sad, it\u2019s ironic because actually the movie presented the Rajputs in a very good light,\u201d said Preeti Sharma, who saw the film with her husband in New Delhi on Thursday afternoon.\n\nThe Rajputs, historically a caste of warriors, have been the ones most offended by the movie; Rajput activists said the movie was historically inaccurate and disrespectful. Hundreds of Rajput women even threatened to kill themselves over it (their elders eventually talked them down).\n\nOn Thursday, protests erupted in different cities in India, with some tire-burning and stone-throwing, but nothing major. It seems that Rajput activists may have won this battle because their campaign of threats and intimidation succeeded in terrifying many cinema owners.", "title": "A Film Has Inflamed Indians. But Moviegoers Mostly Say It\u2019s Fine.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Ferris manages to do a lot within the confines of its small space in the basement of the new Made hotel, south of Herald Square. At times it reminded me of one of those Leatherman tools that unfolds to reveal not just a knife and screwdriver but also a spoke wrench, fish scaler, eyelash curler, olive pitter, tuning fork and eel skinner.\n\nOne recent night I sat at Ferris\u2019s seven-seat kitchen counter. I didn\u2019t realize that I was also sitting at Ferris\u2019s bar until the bartender standing in front of me had measured my drink, strained it into a stem glass and set it on a napkin, all without moving more than one step to the right or left.\n\nShe had whipped up a citrus-sheathed gin number with a rustle of Chartreuse called a 388 C, and it was about as cheerful a kickoff to the dinner hour as anything I\u2019ve come across lately. In fact, almost all the drinks that Ferris\u2019s bartenders stir up in about four square feet of space are smarter and more bracing than what typically comes out of a full-size bar, and often they are poured into vintage etched glasses that any neo-speakeasy would envy.\n\nThe cocktails encapsulate Ferris\u2019s most likable traits. It\u2019s a modest restaurant that overdelivers, cares about little details and has a personal, handmade sensibility. It doesn\u2019t quite give you the feeling of showing up at a friend\u2019s place for dinner, but it comes closer than a lot of places where that\u2019s the explicit aim.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe illusion is aided by the carpentered interior. The single dining room, clad in raw two-by-eights, could be a suburban basement finished over the weekend by a couple with a table saw. A long cushioned bench built into one end of the room provides about half the seating, along with the stools at high tables and the counter.", "title": "A Firecracker of a Beef Rib and Other Surprises at Ferris", "authors": ["Pete Wells", "Restaurant Review"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Updated on March 19.\n\nJudges in a number of states have recently thrown out election maps, saying that they have been gerrymandered to the point of being unconstitutional, effectively dooming one party to permanent underrepresentation.\n\nThe decisions are certain to have drawn the Supreme Court\u2019s interest as it mulls a resolution to the question of extreme partisan gerrymanders. The justices are expected to decide this spring whether the practice violates the Constitution, and if so, how to determine whether an electoral map is fairly drawn.\n\nHere are the basics of the major contested cases.\n\nPennsylvania: Congressional districts\n\nHow many seats does each party hold?\n\nRepublican candidates received 54 percent of the vote in 2016, and won 13 of the state\u2019s 18 seats. Democratic candidates received 46 percent of the votes and won five seats.\n\nWhat\u2019s happened so far?\n\nThe State Supreme Court ruled on Jan. 22 that the map \u201cclearly, plainly and palpably\u201d violated the State Constitution and ordered the map redrawn. The Republicans who control the State Legislature asked the United States Supreme Court to block the state court\u2019s order, but were turned down.", "title": "A Flurry of Courts Have Ruled on Election Maps. Here\u2019s What They\u2019ve Said.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "American intelligence officials and Iran watchers say the protests appear to have started organically.\n\nThe demonstrations, which are widespread and amorphous, do not match the playbook that Western intelligence agencies have used to mount covert operations in Iran \u2014 namely, sustained resource-intense operations that focus on the narrowly defined and measurable goal of sabotaging the alleged nuclear weapons program, they say.\n\nVideo\n\nFor now, they say, the evidence points to one catalyst of the unrest: widespread discontent with the government.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t need Americans or Israeli or British intelligence to convince people in Iran that there is a small ruling elite that is controlling the country\u2019s economy and ruining it,\u201d says Meir Javedanfar, a lecturer on Iranian studies at the Interdisciplinary Center in Herzliya, Israel.\n\nA former American intelligence official said it was implausible that a foreign agency could organize protests in dozens of cities without the Iranian government catching wind of it beforehand. Additionally, Western spy agencies are leery of operations that rely on mass demonstrations, which have a high risk of failure and cannot be easily controlled, the official said.\n\n\u201cCertainly, the West doesn\u2019t have the ground game to engage in that kind of activism, nor do Iran\u2019s regional adversaries,\u201d said Suzanne Maloney, the deputy director of the foreign policy program at the Brookings Institution and a former adviser to senior State Department officials on Iran.\n\nThat logic has not stopped Iranian officials from pointing fingers outside their borders.\n\nOn Wednesday, the government announced the arrest of an unidentified citizen of an unidentified European country who \u201chad been trained by espionage organizations in Europe,\u201d the Tasnim news agency reported.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIran has also accused Saudi Arabia, its main regional rival, of fomenting unrest. On Tuesday, the head of Iran\u2019s National Security Council, Ali Shamkhani, told a Lebanese television station that the Saudis were responsible for 27 percent of all anti-Iran hashtags on Twitter.\n\n\u201cThe hashtags and social media campaigns cornering the situation in Iran are all in fact being guided by Saudi Arabia, U.K., Israel and U.S.,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Shamkhani offered no evidence to support his claim. Iran and Saudi Arabia are openly hostile to each other and are embroiled in opposite sides of regional power struggles in Syria, Yemen and Lebanon. Saudi Arabia has leveled similar accusations against Iran, accusing its Shiite Muslim government of stirring up Shiite dissidents in Sunni Muslim-governed Bahrain and in eastern Saudi Arabia.\n\nAn American intelligence official disputed the Iranian claim of a Saudi hand in the protests, saying that it would be difficult for the Saudis, or their allies in the United Arab Emirates, to organize an uprising in Iran. Neither Arab country has a coterie of Persian speakers, links to a proxy opposition force, or the depth of personnel needed for such an operation, the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.\n\nOnce protests begin, however, any number of countries could try to funnel aid to the protesters.\n\nIranian fears of foreign intervention run deep, as far back as to Alexander the Great, who conquered what was then the Persian Empire around 330 B.C. Modern Iran\u2019s security establishment has long held that the biggest threats to the country come from abroad; the belief that the United States wants a change in government is axiomatic. The evidence, as every Iranian schoolchild knows, is the 1953 plot by the Central Intelligence Agency, code-named Operation Ajax, that overthrew Iran\u2019s prime minister and re-installed the shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSince at least 2006, the United States and its allies have undertaken a series of cyberattacks and more traditional strikes against Iranian targets to try to derail the nation\u2019s nuclear program. The American operations, code-named Olympic Games and Nitro Zeus, succeeded in taking offline hundreds of Iranian centrifuges needed to purify uranium.\n\nIn 2012, Iran\u2019s most senior atomic energy official, Fereydoon Abbasi, said separate explosions, which he attributed to sabotage, had targeted power supplies to the country\u2019s two main uranium enrichment facilities. Mr. Abbasi himself narrowly escaped what Iranian officials described as a foreign assassination attempt in 2010 when unidentified motorcyclists riding through downtown Tehran attached a bomb to his car.\n\nThe attackers killed one scientist, a project manager for the country\u2019s Atomic Energy Organization, Iran\u2019s nuclear chief said at the time. Mr. Abbasi and his wife were wounded.\n\nIran blamed the United States and Israel for those attacks. The United State denied responsibility, and Israel did not respond to the accusation.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen Iran was confronted with its last major protest movement, the so-called Green Movement of 2009, the government arrested thousands of anti-government activists as well as political leaders, accusing many of them of being foreign spies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSecurity forces have applied the same charge to rebel groups.\n\nJundullah, a Sunni Muslim group from Iran\u2019s ethnic Baluch minority that has claimed responsibility for bombings that have killed dozens of people, has been accused of having ties to the Taliban, Al Qaeda and the United States.\n\nIn 2010, Iranian state television broadcast a statement by a captured Jundullah leader who said he had been promised military support from the United States. The American government has denied having links with the group.\n\nThe Iranian opposition group Mujahedeen Khalq, known as the MEK, leveraged its relationship with several former high-ranking Americans \u2014 such as R. James Woolsey and Porter J. Goss, former C.I.A. directors; Louis J. Freeh, the former F.B.I. director \u2014 to help overturn its listing by the State Department as a terrorist organization. Other American officials have called for Washington to support the group.\n\nSuch statements fan the suspicion in Iran that any foreigner may be a spy. Dual nationals in particular have traveled to Iran to visit family members, conduct academic research or expand their businesses only to end up in jail on espionage charges.\n\nIn 2017, Siamak Namazi, an oil executive, and his octogenarian Iranian-American father, Baquer, lost their appeal of a conviction for \u201ccollaborating with enemy states.\u201d A Chinese-American student from Princeton University, Xiyue Wang, was arrested in 2016 and charged with \u201ccollaborating with foreign governments,\u201d a charge he denies.\n\nWhether or not there is any truth to the charges, the consequences are quite real. Omid Memarian, an Iranian political analyst based in New York, says that labeling the protesters as foreign agitators and spies serves as a warning to the working-class and rural citizens who make up a large proportion of the demonstrators.\n\n\u201cIt sends the signal that it will be very costly for you to join,\u201d he said. \u201cIt could mean years of prison, or worse.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut it is na\u00efve to put the blame on outside enemies,\u201d he added. \u201cThe grievances are real. The protests are real. It shows that people have little left to lose.\u201d", "title": "Iranians, Like Their Leaders, See Foreign Hand in Protests", "authors": ["Margaret Coker"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The kitchen was equipped with a tiny fridge, so to supplement the daily shopping, Punyaratabandhu carried a basket through the garden, picking out just enough food for the day from a tangle of edible shoots, leaves and tubers. There was neem and basil growing, chiles and mint, six kinds of eggplant, along with trees full of mangoes, bananas, papayas and jackfruit. The kitchen was traditional, which meant that it was outdoors, with a large clay stove built right into the ground. It was lit in the morning, when all the day\u2019s cooking took place. A heavy wooden bench, about the size of a king bed, was where everyone gathered to prep the ingredients, grating coconut flesh, pounding aromatic pastes in a mortar and pestle and chopping. The kitchen belonged to Punyaratabandhu\u2019s maternal great-grandmother, who grew up outside the city, in central Thailand. \u201cWhen she married my great-grandfather, she brought a lot of traditions from up country,\u201d said Punyaratabandhu, who sometimes found it a little embarrassing when her friends from school came over and saw the clunky, old-fashioned stove.\n\nWhen Punyaratabandhu broke with tradition and moved to Chicago to study philology, her mother shipped over a steady supply of Thai cookbooks, persuading friends and relatives who were making the trip to carry a few with them. \u201cPart of her was afraid of losing her daughter, culturally,\u201d Punyaratabandu said. \u201cSo she tried to lure me back to my roots using the thing she knew would be most powerful: food.\u201d Over time, Punyaratabandhu became a food blogger, an author and an authority on Thai food, not only cooking but also tracing dishes through different eras, meticulously tracking their changes. What she found, time and time again, was that cooking wasn\u2019t static. That it didn\u2019t make sense to stubbornly romanticize a single past version. \u201cThere\u2019s no such thing as authenticity, at least not as most people understand it,\u201d she said. Instead, Punyaratabandhu thought of each dish as having a core set of ingredients that defined its identity, and even those sets could shift.", "title": "A Garlicky Stir-Fry With Basil Leaves From Bangkok", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Television would never do that, of course, but McGregor does. Over 13 chapters, each marking a year, he traces the lives of more than two dozen of the town\u2019s inhabitants. There is birth, death, marriage, divorce, sex, romances kindled and snuffed out. And this is only half the action, because the turn of the seasons, the weather and the life cycles of plants and animals occupy almost as much of the narrative as the activities of the human characters do.\n\nImage\n\nMcGregor is a beautiful, controlled writer, who can convey the pathos of a life in a few lines. Despite the large cast of characters, each feels specific and real, from the vicar, Jane Hughes, who is the closest thing this reticent town has to a therapist, to Gordon Jackson, the town\u2019s Casanova, who, in a sympathetic twist, often seems more hopeful than his bedmates do about the possibility of a lasting relationship.\n\nMcGregor captures a village culture that is simultaneously gossipy and reserved. We are frequently told a character \u201cwas seen\u201d doing this or that, but not by whom. When a single mother moves to town with her children, we learn that \u201cthere were questions\u201d \u2014 about her background and where the father is \u2014 \u201cbut nothing was said to her face.\u201d When one character\u2019s mentally ill sister is taken away in an ambulance, \u201cnobody thought it appropriate to ask questions and he didn\u2019t volunteer.\u201d A widow, covered with bruises from her developmentally disabled son, flinches when anyone gently tries to probe what is going on.\n\nThe only flaw in this unconventional but affecting novel is that its central metaphor \u2014 the girl\u2019s disappearance \u2014 remains obscure. So does the symbolism of the village\u2019s 13 reservoirs, which figure in the search and in the title, and are echoed in the girl\u2019s age and the number of chapters.\n\nWe learn that the reservoirs were created, many years before, by flooding valleys; at their bottoms are the ruins of old villages. Perhaps McGregor means for the drowned villages, like the missing girl, to represent the secrets beneath the surface of any life. Or perhaps he means for them to gesture toward the sweep of history, reminding us that the struggles that seem so momentous to one group of people will someday be forgotten.\n\nThe book ends, quietly, at the close of the 13th year. A character who is bedridden by a stroke listens from his house to his neighbors singing \u201cSilent Night\u201d in the church, with his granddaughter performing a solo. The town takes a breath. Theirs is the calm not of life\u2019s big questions having been answered, but of putting them temporarily aside.", "title": "A Girl Vanishes. But in This Novel, Time Is the Real Mystery.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "KANDEL, Germany \u2014 It happened between neatly stacked rows of shampoo and organic baby food: A teenage boy walked up to his ex-girlfriend in the local drugstore, pulled out a kitchen knife with an eight-inch blade and stabbed her in the heart.\n\nThe death in Kandel, in southwestern Germany, on Dec. 27 has traumatized this sleepy town of barely 10,000 inhabitants, not just because both the suspect and the victim were only 15 years old and went to the local school, but also because the boy is an Afghan migrant and the girl was German.\n\nFrom the moment Germany opened its doors to more than a million migrants two years ago, prominent episodes like the Berlin Christmas market attack and the New Year\u2019s molestation and rapes in Cologne have stoked German insecurities.\n\nBut the case of the two teenagers, Abdul D. and Mia V., has struck a special nerve because the killing happened in such a quiet and provincial setting and the two people involved were so young. It became national news, was debated over dinner tables, on talk shows and on social media sites, and reinforced fears that Germany is becoming ever less safe.", "title": "A Girl\u2019s Killing Puts Germany\u2019s Migration Policy on Trial", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The flagship store also sells binoculars and telescopes, which is a remnant from an earlier era. Though this part of the business has grown smaller over the years, Scott said that some shoppers still request telescopes for their apartments or binoculars if they are going on a safari.\n\nHelping whoever enters the store, even if the person is not buying, is an ingrained part of the work ethic here.\n\n\u201cWe can have 10 interactions in a row that are not revenue generating,\u201d Scott said. \u201cNobody works on commission.\u201d\n\nAs a tourist was leaving who had been given a replacement contact lens case after losing one, Babette Sommer, of Forest Hills, Queens, entered. She was greeted with a chorus of hellos from the staff.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen it comes to any of my eyeglass needs, this is the only place,\u201d Ms. Sommer, a customer of four years, said. But it seemed as if she mostly wanted to chat, sharing the stories of her stressful kitchen repairs and the tooth she had recently lost. She visits regularly, she said, for eyeglass adjustments and other needs. But \u201cI also come whenever I need cheering up.\u201d", "title": "A Glasses Menagerie", "authors": ["Shivani Vora", "Neighborhood Joint"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "At first, Mr. Sinha only sold a small selection of goods from India, such as lentils and spices, but he expanded his offerings over the years to include products from the Middle East and South Asia, as well as Mexico, England and Australia.\n\nBy the time current co-owners Mohammed Alam, 52, and Hakim Khan, 64, bought New Foods of India from Mr. Sinha in 2012 (Mr. Sinha still owns the building), there were more than 50 kinds of teas from around the world, at least 10 varieties of basmati rice, including aged and extra-long, and well over 70 types of lentils. Several shelves in the front are filled with hot sauces and pickles, while others offer Indian toiletries such as sandalwood soap and coconut hair oil.\n\nThere also sell homemade rotis, made by Indian women in Queens. Using their own kitchens, the women make the flatbreads daily \u2014 fenugreek, potato, plain and corn are among the options \u2014 and then deliver the rotis to the store. The same women also make Indian sweets, called mithais, which you can find behind the glass case near the door.", "title": "A Go-To Grocery for Indian Cooks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Seth Meyers, hosting the Globes, turned directly to what he called \u201cthe elephant not in the room\u201d when he opened the NBC broadcast by saying, \u201cGood evening, ladies and remaining gentlemen.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a new era underway,\u201d he continued, \u201cand I can tell because it\u2019s been years since a white man was this nervous in Hollywood.\u201d\n\nMr. Meyers prompted the booing of Mr. Weinstein with a joke about the deaths section of the Oscars telecast. \u201cHarvey Weinstein isn\u2019t here tonight because, well, I\u2019ve heard rumors that he\u2019s crazy and difficult to work with,\u201d Mr. Meyers said. \u201cBut don\u2019t worry, he\u2019ll be back in 20 years when he becomes the first person ever booed during the \u2018In Memoriam.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe Globes soon moved on to celebrating films and television series about women. \u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri,\u201d about a mother (Frances McDormand) who takes her daughter\u2019s murder investigation into her own hands, emerged as the movie to beat in the coming Oscar race, winning four Globes, including ones for best drama and Ms. McDormand\u2019s acting. Greta Gerwig\u2019s \u201cLady Bird,\u201d a coming-of-age tale set in Sacramento, was honored with prizes for best comedy and Saoirse Ronan\u2019s acting.\n\nThe major TV winners were the HBO series \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d which received four Globes, including awards for Nicole Kidman and Laura Dern; \u201cThe Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,\u201d a new Amazon series that collected two prizes, including best TV comedy; and \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale,\u201d which received two Globes, including best TV drama.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cA new day is on the horizon!\u201d Oprah Winfrey, accepting the Cecil B. DeMille lifetime achievement award, shouted toward the end of her eight-minute speech, which focused mostly on the #MeToo movement, noting that it was brought forth by the \u201cinsatiable dedication\u201d of journalists and women, like the recently deceased Recy Taylor, who have spoken up to tell their stories.\n\n\u201cWhen that new day finally dawns, it will be because of a lot of magnificent women, many of whom are right here in this room tonight, and some pretty phenomenal men,\u201d Ms. Winfrey said. She received multiple standing ovations \u2014 some people stayed standing as she spoke \u2014 and finished her comments with an assertion of hope, looking forward to \u201cthe day when nobody ever has to say \u2018Me too\u2019 again.\u201d\n\nAfter Ms. Winfrey exited the stage, Natalie Portman arrived to present the award for best director. \u201cHere are the all-male nominees,\u201d Ms. Portman said. (Guillermo del Toro won for \u201cThe Shape of Water.\u201d)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor some people watching at home, the pronouncements struck a hypocritical note. Weren\u2019t some of these people the same ones who had been silent about Mr. Weinstein\u2019s behavior for decades?\n\nAnd Ms. Winfrey, of course, was accepting an award named for a man who had helped cement a culture of male domination in Hollywood. It was also notable that many of the men who won awards did not mention the current reckoning that Hollywood is undergoing regarding sexual harassment and the role of women in entertainment.\n\nThe awards get spread around.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe foreign journalists who bestow the Globes are known for spreading their awards far and wide, and that was the case on Sunday. Gary Oldman won best actor in a drama, for playing Winston Churchill in \u201cDarkest Hour.\u201d Pixar\u2019s \u201cCoco\u201d was named best animated film. And the figure-skating dark comedy \u201cI, Tonya\u201d was recognized with Allison Janney\u2019s win for best supporting actress.\n\nBut several movies received nothing, most notably Steven Spielberg\u2019s newspaper drama \u201cThe Post,\u201d which was nominated for six prizes. \u201cCall Me by Your Name,\u201d \u201cGet Out,\u201d \u201cMudbound\u201d and \u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d were also ignored.\n\nJames Franco won best actor in a comedy for \u201cThe Disaster Artist,\u201d a biopic about Tommy Wiseau, an eccentric Hollywood figure best known for his cult film \u201cThe Room.\u201d Mr. Wiseau, who had been sitting in the ballroom in wraparound blue sunglasses and looking at his phone, sauntered to the stage, where a hoarse Mr. Franco was espousing his love for his brother, Dave Franco, who also stars in \u201cThe Disaster Artist.\u201d Standing nearby, the younger Franco got a little teary.\n\n\u2018Marvelous Mrs. Maisel\u2019 is a big winner in TV.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe night\u2019s first award went to Ms. Kidman, who won best actress in a television movie or limited series. \u201cPower of women!\u201d she said, holding up her Globe and name checking her female co-stars. Ms. Kidman won for her role in \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d in which she plays a battered wife who summons the courage to leave her husband. Her co-star Alexander Skarsgard won for best supporting actor, and the show won for best limited series or TV movie.\n\nAs expected, Hulu\u2019s adaptation of Margaret Atwood\u2019s dystopian novel about the repression of women, \u201cThe Handmaid\u2019s Tale,\u201d matched its best drama win last year at the Emmy Awards. Elisabeth Moss, who stars in that series, also repeated her Emmys win, collecting the trophy for best actress in a drama. The \u201cThis Is Us\u201d star Sterling K. Brown was named best dramatic actor, the first time in Globes history that a black man had won that prize.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou wrote a role for a black man that could only be played by a black man,\u201d Mr. Brown said in his speech, thanking the \u201cThis Is Us\u201d creator, Dan Fogelman, for creating his part. \u201cI am being seen for who I am, and being appreciated for who I am, and it makes it that much more difficult to dismiss me or dismiss anybody who looks like me.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n(It was a reminder of how much has changed in Hollywood in recent months. Kevin Spacey won the category at the 72nd ceremony for his performance in \u201cHouse of Cards,\u201d a series that fired him late last year after men came forward to accuse him of unwanted sexual advances.)\n\nThe Amazon series \u201cThe Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,\u201d about a perfectionist 1950s housewife who becomes a stand-up comic, won the Globe for best TV comedy, and its star, Rachel Brosnahan, collected the trophy for best actress in a comedy.\n\n\u201cTheir support was completely unwavering,\u201d Amy Sherman-Palladino, the show\u2019s creator, said of Amazon from the stage while wearing a top hat festooned with feathers. She made no mention of Roy Price, who had helped push forward the series before resigning in October following accusations of sexual harassment.\n\nA night draped in black\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Globes were draped in black, quite literally, with actresses and some actors vowing to use their attire to make a statement about sexual harassment in Hollywood and other spheres. Winners were expected to use their moments of glory to rail against the systemic sexism and silence that allowed the behavior of men like Mr. Weinstein, James Toback, Louis C.K. and Mr. Spacey to fester for decades.\n\nOn the red carpet, eight actresses walked hand in hand with activists who focus on sexual harassment and gender inequality.\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t want to create hierarchies \u2014 saying that women in Hollywood are more important than other women,\u201d Marai Larasi, the executive director of Imkaan, a British network of organizations dedicated to ending violence against black women, said on the E! arrivals special. \u201cWe have a platform, and we\u2019re trying to use it in the best way we possibly can.\u201d Ms. Larasi attended as Emma Watson\u2019s guest.\n\nBut the tone on the red carpet was not entirely serious. Smiles abounded. Along with discussion about women\u2019s rights came lighthearted banter by nominees about butterflies (the stomach variety) and some of the usual fashion chitchat. Alexis Bledel carried a black crystal clutch from Onna Ehrlich; Gucci dressed Margot Robbie and Dakota Johnson.\n\nAnd inside the ballroom, the ceremony in many ways felt like business as usual. Stars, producers and studio executives schmoozed in frantic fashion during the commercial breaks and straight through some awards. The vibe even approached easygoing and carefree \u2014 as if Hollywood felt it had exculpated itself with all of the serious talk on the red carpet and the sharp-edged jokes Mr. Meyers cracked during his monologue.", "title": "A Golden Globes Draped in Black Addresses #MeToo", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes", "Cara Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSATURDAY PUZZLE \u2014 A crossword with this much wide-open white space might be intimidating to some solvers, but here\u2019s a tip for forging ahead: Ignore the longer entries for now (unless you know them outright, of course), and focus on the shorter entries.\n\nLooking for a way in? Try BMI at 34A, clued as \u201cSong royalties org.\u201d It can\u2019t be ASCAP, because we have only three squares. So salt that in. At 37A, the editors show us some mercy with \u201cStandard & Poor\u2019s.\u201d That gave me BONITA and SMOOTHS. Skipping up to the top of the grid, I got ON TV, ODIST, ALKALIS (I knew to think of chemical bases primarily because of the question mark in the clue), and OTTER. You could also write in SITU at 39A, if you know that one.\n\nWhat surprises me about Alex Vratsanos\u2019s grid is the amount of material that can be considered \u201colder,\u201d like the comic strip character Blondie\u2019s maiden name (BOOPADOOP), Howdy Doody and other MARIONETTES. Even SISTER SOULJAH\u2019s recording days \u2014 she continues to be a community activist \u2014 were more than 20 years ago. But that\u2019s the thing about late week puzzles. You will dive deep into pop culture, history, science, theater and many other subjects. No need to worry about shallowness here.\n\nSo, we have some good stuff in here \u2014 I liked BOOP A DOOP, BIG TICKET ITEM, MAJORITY RULES, TEXAS SIZE, PACHINKO, SISTER SOULJAH, BOSTON CREAM and PANNED OUT \u2014 and some very tough stuff in here. Mr. Vratsanos\u2019s puzzle gave me quite a run for my money, but I stuck with it and eventually completed the puzzle. But it wasn\u2019t easy. Did you stick with it, or are you putting it aside until you can reboot your brain?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTricky Clues\n\nThere is a lot of general knowledge in here today and that\u2019s hard enough, but I\u2019m going to go through the ones that really took me down. In my opinion, these were wordplay on crack.", "title": "A Great Fear of Shallow Living", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Entering the offices of CookFox architects in Manhattan, you can almost leave the city behind.\n\nThe horseshoe-shaped work pods are plant-fringed havens, warmly lit by the late afternoon light. Terraces on three sides of the office are planted with native trees, vines and grasses and replete with bee apiaries that are tended by the employees, who are encouraged to work outdoors in season.\n\nThis unusual Midtown workplace, at 250 West 57th Street, was designed to be a showcase for a new kind of green building inspired by what architects call \u201cbiophilic design.\u201d\n\nThe term, from the Greek for \u201clove of living things,\u201d was popularized by the Harvard biologist E.O. Wilson, who argues that humans are hard-wired by our evolutionary biology to be emotionally attracted to the natural world. Advocates of biophilic design say that to be called green, a building needs to do more than just use energy efficiently and have a minimal carbon footprint. Rather, it needs to be a health-promoting place for the people who live and work there.\n\nCookFox projects have included the iconic Bank of America Tower at One Bryant Park, which incorporates features like planted green walls and a wealth of natural materials. But the point is not just to spruce up urban offices with splashes of green, says the firm\u2019s co-founder, Richard Cook. It is to use principles of natural design to help bring the health benefits of the outdoors indoors.", "title": "A Greener, More Healthful Place to Work", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Whether or not you\u2019re waiting for the Super Bowl to tackle your next batch of guacamole, there\u2019s a new gadget that will improve the results. The Guac-Lock is a bowl that effectively eliminates exposure to air, preventing the oxidation that discolors the avocados. With my test batch, the color stayed true for two days and was far superior to that of guacamole sealed with a sheet of plastic wrap placed on the surface. The bowl was invented by a couple of entrepreneurial home cooks, and though it\u2019s a little complicated to use, it\u2019s worth the effort. It comes with a recipe that\u2019s simple but good: Casabella Guac-Lock, $19.95, thegrommet.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Guacamole Keeper, Peas Not Included", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJames Lee Burke is what fellow writers call a wordsmith. He can make your eyes water with a lyrical description of tropical rain falling on a Louisiana bayou: \u201cI love the mist hanging in the trees,\u201d he tells us in ROBICHEAUX (Simon & Schuster, $27.99), \u201ca hint of wraiths that would not let heavy stones weigh them down in their graves, the raindrops clicking on the lily pads, the fish rising as though in celebration.\u201d But in the next breath, he\u2019ll offer a comprehensive account of an excruciating death by torture: \u201cThe guy who did him took his time.\u201d And to satisfy our appetite for Southern eccentricity, he\u2019ll introduce us to great characters like Baby Cakes Babineau and Pookie the Possum Domingue.\n\nDave Robicheaux, the narrator of this robust regional series, is an Iberia Parish sheriff\u2019s detective with the melancholy air of a man who occasionally sees the hollow-eyed ghosts of the Confederate dead. Haunted by his own violent past, Robicheaux keeps trying to redeem himself through good works; but when he falls off the wagon, as he does here in a spectacular way, he thinks he might be capable of committing murder. But he\u2019s not in the same class as a contract killer named Chester Wimple (\u201cSometimes people call me Smiley\u201d).\n\nLike most of Burke\u2019s plots, this one has roots in Louisiana history, a gumbo of \u201cmisogamy and racism and homophobia,\u201d not to mention \u201cdemagoguery\u201d and \u201cself-congratulatory ignorance.\u201d Mob figures like Fat Tony Nemo look tough, but they have nothing on up-and-coming politicians like Jimmy Nightingale, eager to follow in the footsteps of his flamboyantly crooked predecessors. Burke has no inclination to romanticize gangsters, no matter how well groomed: \u201cThey were brutal, stupid to the core, and had the visceral instincts of medieval peasants armed with pitchforks.\u201d Rather, he pays homage to the fallen dead like Lt. Robert S. Broussard, a Civil War hero whose sword gets into the hands of a crime boss. In rescuing this artifact, Robicheaux bares his bleeding heart for \u201cLa Louisiane, the love of my life, the home of Jolie Blon and Evangeline and the Great Whore of Babylon, the place for which I would die.\u201d\n\n\u2666\n\nWitty, stylish and a bit of a rogue \u2014 that\u2019s what people said about Richard Nash, known as Beau, the notorious dandy who transformed the English city of Bath into \u201cthe 18th-century equivalent of Vegas.\u201d The same might be said of Peter Lovesey, whose elegant mysteries pay tribute to the past glories of this beautiful city. In BEAU DEATH (Soho Crime, $27.95), a demolition crew unearths the remains of a bewigged gentleman in period dress, setting off gossip that Nash has been found \u2014 murdered. Detective Superintendent Peter Diamond accepts this theory until he discovers the desiccated corpse was wearing modern-day underwear.\n\nThere\u2019s always a whiff of Restoration comedy about Lovesey\u2019s cunning plots, which make a point of featuring shrewd women like the drolly named Georgina Dallymore, whose ample comedic gifts make her a figure fit for a Congreve comedy and the perfect companion for Diamond.\n\n\u2666\n\nIf you find it significant that tortellini can be easier to eat than linguine or fettuccine, THE BODY IN THE CASKET (Morrow, $25.99) is your kind of mystery. Katherine Hall Page, who has written almost two dozen culinary mysteries, has come up with another smart twist on her cozy formula featuring Faith Fairchild, a minister\u2019s wife and keen-eyed amateur detective from suburban Massachusetts. Faith\u2019s catering firm, Have Faith in Your Kitchen, has been hired for a weekend party by Max Dane, a once-famous Broadway producer celebrating his 70th birthday. But what he really wants to hire is Faith\u2019s sleuthing talent, because he strongly suspects that one of his guests wants to kill him. The mechanics of the murder mystery are well set up and executed, but what you\u2019re hungry for is what\u2019s on the menu. This time, Faith is starting off with \u201cFallen Angel\u201d cocktails, then moving along to deviled eggs and an apple-potato dish called \u201cHimmel und Erde.\u201d The main course, lobster pasta fra diavolo, is followed by an angel food cake, from a recipe that calls for \u201cnine large eggs\u201d and a mountain of sugar. Sounds divine.\n\n\u2666\n\nWhere better to set a gangster novel than big, bad, brawling Chicago during Prohibition? The way Ray Celestin tells it in DEAD MAN\u2019S BLUES (Pegasus Crime, $25.95), everyone in the city was corrupt, from the mayor, Big Bill Thompson, to the 25,000 soda shop owners who ran speakeasies in their back rooms. The most colorful characters were mobsters like Al Capone and his rival, Bugs Moran, so-called because he was certifiably \u201cbuggy, crazy, homicidally violent and not very clever.\u201d As he did in his first novel, \u201cThe Axeman,\u201d which was set in New Orleans, Celestin perfectly captures the jazzy street rhythms of this proudly pugnacious city and its peculiar characters. His authorial gaze encompasses everything from a flower-festooned gangster\u2019s funeral (with \u201ca casket costing more than most people\u2019s houses\u201d) to a golf game featuring Capone; his hit man, Machine Gun Jack McGurn; and the mayor of suburban Burnham. Which is a lot funnier than the funeral.", "title": "A Gumbo of Crime: From the Bayou to Britain", "authors": ["Marilyn Stasio"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think they\u2019re looking out for everybody\u2019s well-being and truly thinking about the words that they say as a brand,\u201d Ms. Egbuchulam said. \u201cThey\u2019re providing opportunities for people to take care of their whole self. This is one way that they\u2019re choosing to do that as a company.\u201d\n\nBut Bryan Sieve, a member for more than 10 years, said the change hurt his ability to manage his time and had stirred up \u201ca hornet\u2019s nest\u201d at the branch he goes to in Maple Grove, Minn. As a businessman with a full schedule, he said, it is important for him to multitask during his morning workout, and he enjoyed the large selection of channels on his gym\u2019s TV screens.\n\nThe company gave no public notice before making the change, he added.\n\nMr. Sieve said that he would switch to a competitor if the cable news channels were not restored by the end of the month, and that he had told the Maple Grove manager as much.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.
