Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never seen anybody complain about this, none ever in our club,\u201d he said. \u201cWho are these faceless people that all of a sudden have huge sway over changing a policy at Life Time Fitness without member input, consent or even fair warning?\u201d\n\nMs. Bushaw, the company spokeswoman, declined to say how many members had requested the change, but wrote: \u201cSuffice it to say, this has been a growing issue over years, not weeks or months. Ultimately, we believe this change is consistent with the desires of the overall membership.\u201d\n\nShe noted that the channels in question were still available on smaller screens installed in some cardio machines \u2014 a feature she said was being added at more clubs. Members can also use their gym\u2019s Wi-Fi to watch shows on personal devices, she said.\n\nJennifer Berlanga, a Life Time member in Dallas, called that a reasonable balance.\n\n\u201cI think giving members the choice to watch it on their cardio station or personal devices is a great way to compromise between those who want nonstop news and those who don\u2019t,\u201d Ms. Berlanga wrote on Twitter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor her, she said, \u201cit will be nice to enter the cardio room without the barrage from both sides.\u201d\n\nAsked about this option, Mr. Sieve called it \u201chogwash.\u201d He does not want to carry his iPad or phone around the gym, he said, and none of the cardio machines at the Maple Grove facility have built-in screens. Even if they did, he added, those screens would not be useful when he lifts weights or uses noncardio machines.\n\nIn a video message on Twitter, Irene Kistler, a school librarian in Texas, criticized the decision in much grander terms.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t be afraid of democracy,\u201d Ms. Kistler said. \u201cPut the news back on. Banning the news is really kind of un-American.\u201d\n\nFew, if any, other major fitness chains in the United States have taken similar steps.\n\nRepresentatives of several companies did not respond to requests for comment on Tuesday afternoon. But McCall Gosselin, a spokeswoman for Planet Fitness, said the issue had \u201cnever come up.\u201d No Planet Fitness members have complained about the presence of cable news in their gyms, she said.", "title": "A Gym Chain Is Banning Cable News. It\u2019s for Your Health.", "authors": ["Maggie Astor"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Neza, as it is known, is gritty and working class, a sprawl of short concrete buildings. But it is a quiet success story. As crime and corruption skyrocket nationally, especially in surrounding areas, they\u2019ve remained stable or even declined here.\n\nWhen we asked Neza locals and officials how they did it, they pointed to Jorge Amador, the police chief who looks and talks as if he wandered into the job after getting lost on his way to a faculty meeting.\n\nMr. Amador, whose background is in sociology and water management, imposed policy changes that, sweeping and sometimes eccentric, might be impossible elsewhere. He set up literature programs and chess classes. He restructured the force to emphasize community engagement. He fired 100-plus officers suspected of corruption or brutality.\n\nSo was Mr. Amador the key to Neza\u2019s success? After some time in Neza (and a lot of time with Mexican academics), we came to a different conclusion. Or, at least, a broader one. Neza\u2019s secret was breaking from the Mexican party system, which is what made Mr. Amador\u2019s hiring and reforms possible.\n\nPhoto\n\nMexico\u2019s establishment political parties are beyond troubled. They are a dangerous combination of superstrong \u2014 they are tightly controlled institutions that have few career civil servants \u2014 and super-weak. They are riven with corruption, patronage and nepotism. They have the power to enforce internal loyalty but not to perform basic institutional functions.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t have any institution or agency that is capable of forcing the parties to cooperate and forcing them to be honest and fair. And that is a huge problem,\u201d said Joy Langston, a political scientist at the CIDE, a Mexico City university.\n\n\u201cThey are very much able to negotiate reforms that make them even stronger and give them even more distance from voters,\u201d she said, adding that this means parties have shrinking incentive to think about policies that will help voters, or to think about policy at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNeza is different; it is run by the left-wing P.R.D. party, rather than either of the establishment parties.\n\nMost P.R.D. holds are not like Neza. They, too, see upticks in crime and corruption. But because the P.R.D. exists outside of the mainstream party system, an official like Mr. Amador is at least freer to root out corruption or experiment with unorthodox reforms.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the same time, however, he cannot turn for help or policy expertise from state or federal institutions. So he is walking a tightrope without a net. And not all of his policies have worked.\n\nAfter years of relatively undisturbed experimentation, Neza has become something like an open-air experiment in social engineering. The goal is to so enamor the police of their civic responsibility that they will decide to refuse the money they could make extorting civilians or aiding drug gangs, as is common in much of Mexico.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn August, we attended one of the twice-annual awards ceremonies that Mr. Amador holds for the police. Of the 700 officers in attendance, half would receive some sort of prize and cash reward. Family members in the audience waved supportive signs. In an Oprah-style twist, and to cheers even she might envy, six officers were each granted bonuses worth four months pay. It felt like a pep rally.\n\n\u201cAt the beginning, people don\u2019t trust you, they are very defensive,\u201d said Diana Hernandez, one of the community officers assigned to monitor a small patch of streets \u2014 another experiment.\n\nShe understands, she said. Growing up, her family rarely called the police, seeing them as bound to bring more trouble. Now, she said, \u201cPeople recognize me on the street. That they know me really makes me feel good about this.\u201d\n\nNeighborhood watch groups, set up to coordinate with police, are provided with police cameras, alarm systems and direct lines to the patrol cars.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut their longer-term purpose, Mr. Amador said, is to create public buy-in for his reforms \u201cso that it doesn\u2019t matter who\u2019s in the mayor\u2019s office.\u201d\n\nIn a way, he is seeking to replicate the functions of a political party: grass-roots mobilization, civil society allies and institutionalized policies. It\u2019s a big idea, but a reminder that trying to reform the police and society without real institutional support is a bit like writing in the sand.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s fragile, this experiment,\u201d Guillermo Vald\u00e9s, a former head of the national intelligence agency, said. Establishing it \u201chas been a long process and a slow one,\u201d requiring time and freedom that doesn\u2019t exist for most Mexican officials constrained by the party system.\n\nPolicing experts we spoke to generally gave Neza high marks, as did Mr. Vald\u00e9s.\n\nJuan Salgado, also with the CIDE, said the city had achieved \u201cgreat successes,\u201d in part by sidestepping civil society organizations, which, like so much in Mexico, tend to dominated by the establishment parties.\n\nStill, not everyone has been sold. Antia Mendoza, a Mexico City-based security expert, said Neza\u2019s officials had not proven a link between Mr. Amador\u2019s reforms and the crime rate. And she saw little proof the community networks were working.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd Neza is hardly an oasis of safety. The day before the police awards, our photographer visited Neza to find the main traffic circle shut down by a public brawl. When we spent some time in the police command center, which includes dozens of new-looking TV screens displaying feeds from hundreds of street cameras, the officers watched helplessly as a car chase zipped across the screens.\n\nStill, in a way, the most important thing may not be how well Mr. Amador\u2019s reforms worked but the fact that he had space to try them at all, and for years at a time. That level of freedom, particularly to purge corruption, is rare in Mexican policymaking. It\u2019s a major problem for Mexico, constricting officials in a time of national crisis.\n\nThat, for us, was Neza\u2019s lesson: not the presence of reforms, but the absence of party-imposed constraints. It made us look differently at the rest of Mexico, where those constraints can be suffocating.\n\nIt made us think about Europe\u2019s mainstream parties, which are the least popular they\u2019ve been in years, giving rise to smaller and less professionalized fringe parties. It made us think about the global rise in populist parties, which often reject policy expertise and institutions as untrustworthy \u201cdeep state\u201d elites. And it made us think about American parties that have been hollowed out by polarization and other factors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMexico\u2019s political parties are, in many ways, particular to Mexico and its history. They are legacies of the country\u2019s revolutionary past and its recent emergence from single-party rule. The degree to which they are failing is exceptional. But the ways that they are failing are not.", "title": "A Haven From Mexico\u2019s Political Parties Hints at Their Decline", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "Amanda Taub", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s sort of a double whammy,\u201d said Dr. Donald Lloyd-Jones, a cardiologist at the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine who helped write the American Heart Association\u2019s cholesterol guidelines. \u201cBiologically, lp(a) both gets into the artery wall and causes damage there more easily.\u201d\n\nStudies suggest that the threshold for high lp(a) begins around 30 milligrams per deciliter of blood. Heart disease risk jumps for those in the 80th percentile, with lp(a) levels above 60, and climbs sharply for the 5 percent of the population with lp(a) levels between 150 and 300, according to Dr. Ginsberg at Columbia. \u201cThose people can be disasters in terms of cardiovascular risk,\u201d he said.\n\nYet many people at high risk do not fit the typical profile of a person with heart disease. Sandra Revill Tremulis was a health-conscious medical device executive who moonlighted as an aerobics instructor, followed a strict diet, and maintained 16 percent body fat, equivalent to that of an elite athlete. Her LDL and total cholesterol levels were low, and at age 39, her Framingham risk score, which gauges heart disease risk, put her odds of having a heart attack in her 40s at just 1 percent.\n\nBut when she started experiencing extreme fatigue and struggled to finish her workouts, she went to an interventional cardiologist and asked for a thorough work-up \u2014 which revealed that she had a 95 percent blockage in one of her coronary arteries.\n\n\u201cI was imminent to have a widow-maker heart attack at age 39,\u201d she said.\n\nFurther testing showed she had high lp(a), which she believes she inherited from her father, who died of a heart attack at age 50. Determined to raise awareness, Ms. Revill Tremulis started a nonprofit, the Lipoprotein(a) Foundation, and now travels the globe advocating for wider testing.\n\n\u201cOnly a small percentage of physicians know about this,\u201d she said. \u201cThe biggest challenge for patients is finding knowledgeable physicians who know about this and can help them.\u201d\n\nDr. Lloyd-Jones at Northwestern said that testing for lp(a) should be considered for people with early-onset cardiovascular disease \u2014 which means younger than age 50 for men and age 60 for women \u2014 or a strong family history of it. Since high lp(a) is hereditary, those who have it often have a parent, sibling or grandparent who suffered a premature heart attack or stroke. When one person has it, it\u2019s important to test other family members too.", "title": "A Heart Risk Factor Even Doctors Know Little About", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I recently moved into a renovated apartment in Hell\u2019s Kitchen that is heated with steam. The valve on the radiator wakes me up most nights, intermittently making one of the loudest hissing sounds I have ever heard. Think of a teakettle whistling so loud that the noise interrupts conversations in the living room when my bedroom door is closed. I contacted my landlord, who sent a plumber, but the plumber said there were no solutions. Is there any way to fix this? And, if not, what are my options? I am desperate for a good night\u2019s sleep.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA. Radiators can be noisy things that clang and hiss as steam heats a room. But one that functions properly should not sound like a wailing teakettle. Your radiator may have a problem with an air valve. Air valves, also known as air vents, open and close as steam flows through the radiator. (Unlike a control valve, you cannot turn an air valve on or off.)\n\nThese valves come in different sizes and are easily replaceable. \u201cYou could probably put a different type of air valve on the radiator that expels the air a little slower,\u201d said Philip Kraus, the president of Fred Smith Plumbing and Heating in Manhattan. \u201cIt\u2019s not complicated at all. You just unscrew it and put another one on.\u201d\n\nAsk Real Estate Submit your questions, share your stories and tell us what topics interest you most. Post a comment or email us at realestateqa@nytimes.com.\n\nAssuming this is the problem, your landlord should address it. \u201cThe landlord is shirking his or her legal obligations here,\u201d said Lucas A. Ferrara, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. Because the condition violates the warranty of habitability, a state law that protects tenants, you are entitled to a rent abatement and if the problem cannot be fixed, may be allowed to terminate your lease, Mr. Ferrara said.\n\nYou could write the landlord a letter, including these points, sent by certified mail, demanding that the problem be addressed. You could also call 311 to report the matter.\n\nYour fastest route to a good night\u2019s sleep, however, may be through your superintendent. Ask the super to replace the valve, something that Mr. Kraus said a handyman could do. While you should not have to pay for such work, offering a tip may get the job done faster.", "title": "A Hissing Radiator and Sleepless Nights", "authors": ["Ronda Kaysen", "Ask Real Estate"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "In 1967, 6-year-old David Santiago and his family were forced out of their tenement apartment on Delancey Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan to make way for what was supposed to be a massive urban renewal project. At the time, they were promised when the new buildings were finished they would be able to return.\n\nLast month, after 50 years in which the land sat empty as factions battled over what the neighborhood should look like, Mr. Santiago, now 57, finally opened the door of his promised new home, on the eighth floor in the first of nine buildings in a complex called Essex Crossing, on the south side of Delancey, near the entrance to the Williamsburg Bridge.\n\nThere were tears in his eyes when he walked in, he said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s weird,\u201d Mr. Santiago said as he looked at the glassy condominiums to the north and the changing face of the neighborhood. \u201cWhen I walk down the street I don\u2019t see the new buildings out there. I see the marble pillars of the old Seventh Precinct, the shop on Delancey that was known for the best cuchifritos, Ratner\u2019s restaurant, the Apollo Theater, and The Spot, a bar where the Jewish gangsters hung out and I shined shoes.\u201d\n\nClose to 1,800 families, most of them Puerto Ricans, lost their homes all those years ago. Between the first and second building \u2014 a total of 310 apartments \u2014 at Essex Crossing, 14 families with ties to the neighborhood dating to 1967 will be moving back. Others may come as the remaining 769 apartments are completed.", "title": "A Homecoming 50 Years in the Making", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Sufia Hossain, a native of Bangladesh who worked in fashion in New York, turned a career corner and decided to make hot sauces. Months of experimentation led to her company, Silly Chilly Hotsauce, which makes sauces in Englewood and Bloomfield, N.J., from chiles grown at Rutgers University\u2019s farm in New Brunswick, among other sources. Each of the three sauces is agreeably thick: mellow mustard-yellow mango and sweet pepper; musky, smoky mahogany serrano and chipotle; and weaponized neon-orange habanero. Ms. Hossain also teaches classes in making hot sauces, $45 per person for 90 minutes in Manhattan and Brooklyn: Silly Chilly Hotsauce, $10.95 for five ounces, sillychillyhotsauce.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Hot Sauce With a Fashionable Pedigree", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think it was more that there\u2019s a stereotype about centers,\u201d he said, alluding to the rare giants who have wound up in coaching. \u201cPeople tend to attribute thinking on the basketball court to guards. It\u2019s a fallacy because, you know, there have been a lot of dumb guards.\u201d\n\nIn recent years, Thompson said, with the pro game more perimeter-dominant than ever, Ewing\u2019s case became even harder.\n\nAs he did when John III coached the Hoyas, Thompson attends Georgetown home games at the downtown Capital One Arena. But as Ewing\u2019s team ran off a string of victories against lower-profile programs to begin the season, Thompson largely stayed out of sight and reporters\u2019 range, giving his prot\u00e9g\u00e9 space.\n\nFor the Butler game, though, Thompson occupied a baseline seat that was only a firm bounce pass away from the Georgetown bench, indicating he thought Ewing had aced his initiation. Approached at halftime, he snapped, \u201cWhat do you want?\u201d Then he offered an adjacent seat and said, \u201cIf I wasn\u2019t mean, you wouldn\u2019t know it was me, would you?\u201d\n\nThis veneer of crankiness was a playful reference to the early-to-mid-1980s, when the Ewing-powered Hoyas reached three Final Fours and Thompson\u2019s program had an air of unapproachability that even had a name: Hoya Paranoia.\n\n\u201cA lot of things we did was attributed to paranoia, but it wasn\u2019t,\u201d Thompson said. \u201cIt was the decisions we made as an educational institution. And in Patrick\u2019s case, it was because of his talent and the demand being so much higher on him. Listen, Patrick has never been an antisocial person \u2014 he\u2019s been a private person. He\u2019s always been very unselfish, and a lot of those times he didn\u2019t want to do things it was because he wanted other people to get some attention.\u201d\n\nThompson made the initial call to Ewing after his son\u2019s dismissal last year, suggesting he declare his candidacy to the university\u2019s administration, though Thompson bristled at the notion of extended family nepotism.", "title": "A Hoya Again, Patrick Ewing Learns Value of Knowing When to Pivot", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "In 2003 at a Kurdish investment seminar in Erbil, Mr. Schute met Douglas Layton, an American who came to Kurdistan in 1992. Mr. Layton, whose round spectacles and woolen cap lend him the air of a paperback spy, had survived a $1 million bounty on his head, courtesy of Saddam Hussein. After the dictator\u2019s capture and execution, Mr. Layton journeyed to Hussein\u2019s palace in Baghdad, where he found his outlandish throne and sat in it. \u201cYou\u2019re gone,\u201d Mr. Layton whispered to Saddam\u2019s ghost, \u201cand I\u2019m still here.\u201d\n\nMr. Schute and Mr. Layton, who had been working for the Meridian Health Foundation, both knew of Kurdistan\u2019s cultural riches and friendly people, so they joined forces to create what eventually became Kurdistan Iraq Tours, the only inbound tourism operator in Kurdistan. The idea seemed absurd.\n\n\u201cEveryone said no one will come to Iraq, and I said but they\u2019ll come to \u2018the other Iraq!\u2019\u201d Mr. Layton recalled. \u201cI believed, and I still believe, that tourism is the future.\u201d\n\nFor their main local guide, they hired and trained Balin Zrar, a charismatic, chain-smoking Kurd. Mr. Zrar had spent seven years running an Italian restaurant in London after he smuggled himself to Europe \u2014 an epic tale that involved time in an Iranian prison camp and riding for days curled atop a spare tire under a tractor-trailer. After the London bombings, Mr. Zrar returned to Kurdistan to dabble in real estate. For the guide-position interview, Mr. Layton asked him if he liked history. \u201cI hate history,\u201d replied Mr. Zrar, now in his early 40s, and the candor landed him the job. No one believed he\u2019d be busy.\n\nIn 2008, though, things took off. The company landed a contract with California-based Distant Horizons to run its Kurdistan cultural trips and soon others followed. Momentum built. By 2011 The New York Times put Iraqi Kurdistan on its annual list of places to go. National Geographic Traveler did the same. \u201cTop Gear,\u201d the British television show, filmed a special there. In 2012 tourism arrivals surged 30 percent, year-over-year, to about 2.2 million visitors. Copycat inbound companies sprang to life. Starwood, Kempinski and Marriott lined up to manage new luxury hotels. By spring 2014, Kurdistan Iraq Tours had 15-person groups booking 11-day itineraries and was actually making some money.\n\nPhoto\n\nThen, ISIS showed up.\n\nThe militants steamrolled down the Tigris and pushed into Kurdistan. They got so close to Erbil\u2019s city gates that even Mr. Schute was worried. Tourism companies shut down. Seventy hotels closed. Many flights ceased. \u201cWe were the last guys standing,\u201d Mr. Layton said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut all through those awful years the men worked behind the scenes, speaking to lawmakers and publishing a gorgeous, comprehensive guidebook to the region. As soon as ISIS was gone they knew travelers would come wandering back.\n\nTHE RED-EYE FROM AMMAN touched down just before dawn in Erbil where Mr. Zrar waited. He had a slim build and black hair flecked with gray. He fidgeted, as most Kurdish men do, with a string of beads called a tasbih. Outside the air was hazy and cool.\n\nOur contingent of five North Americans had pretty much spent a lifetime traveling. Even so, only one of us, the head of an adventure travel trade association, had visited Kurdistan before. This time he\u2019d brought along his son, who\u2019d turn 17 on the trip. A Canadian expat living in Hong Kong and a photographer from Los Angeles who had been to North Korea 10 times rounded out our group.\n\nWe piled into a mini bus and rolled into the city. Rows of half-finished skyscrapers rose from the earth like the picked-over rib cage of a great steely beast. Barbershops, bookstores, mosques and carts laden with wild cucumbers and cigarettes scrolled by the window. Unlike Iraqi Arabs, few Kurdish women wore head scarves. If you ignored the road signs pointing to Baghdad, you could mistake this for Turkey.\n\nTURKEY Amedi Duhok Lalish iraqi kurdistan IRAN Mosul Erbil Dukan Lake Tigris Sulaymaniya Area of detail Halabja IRAQ Baghdad 50 miles\n\nThe plan was to spend a week traveling in a clockwise loop that started and ended in Erbil, taking in cities like Duhok and Sulaymaniyah along the way. We\u2019d hike in the Zagros Mountains, paddle kayaks on Lake Dukan, and eat kebabs and flatbread. Often we\u2019d pause over sugary tea outside noisy bazaars and linger in museums highlighting Kurdish traditions and history. Mr. Layton, who now lives in Connecticut, could not join us, but Mr. Schute, still in Erbil, would spend time with us.\n\nImmediately it became clear that this would be unlike any other trip. Mr. Schute also serves as a senior security adviser to the Kurdish interior ministry and works closely with the Peshmerga, which means \u201cthose who face death.\u201d More than 100,000 of these Kurdish soldiers \u2014 our allies against Saddam Hussein and ISIS \u2014 manned a nearly impenetrable front riddled with tank ditches and checkpoints that has kept Kurdistan an enclave of comparative security while much of the rest of Iraq remains too dangerous for tourists. The Peshmerga, coalition forces and the Iraqis had cornered the last of ISIS\u2019s fighters in Mosul\u2019s old city along the Tigris. The effort to root them out for good was being coordinated through the Zerevani Peshmerga headquarters outside Erbil. Mr. Schute arranged to take us there.\n\nC-17s roared overhead as we arrived. In the distance you could see a dome that the South Koreans had built for a gym and several squat metal buildings. Guards led us into a room with a long table set with bananas and apricots and cold cans of Pepsi. United States Army Lt. Col. Darin E. Huss, the center\u2019s director, and Iraqi and Kurdish generals, came in to answer our questions about the fight. \u201cIn 10 days it will be finished, inshallah,\u201d Staff Major Gen. Saad Khalid Yasin told me. (It would be more like six weeks.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMost eye-opening of all, though, was the base\u2019s Mad Max junkyard of captured ISIS vehicles. The militants had welded thick armored plates around old Soviet personnel carriers and attached grids of rebar along their sides to disperse incoming rocket blasts. Some rigs had heavy metal prows to better ram a checkpoint. Others had been reduced to mangled heaps of metal. I climbed inside one that had been scorched beyond all recognition. On the floor lay a chalky white bone. Lamb. Someone\u2019s lunch had ended poorly.\n\nOVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS we took in more mainstream sites. We strolled around Erbil\u2019s citadel, a fortress on a mound, that dates to 6000 B.C., and mingled with Arab Iraqis from the south who seemed overjoyed to friend an American on Facebook. I stuck my nose in sacks of za\u2019atar and sumac in the city\u2019s frenetic bazaar and watched two teen lovebirds \u2014 she in a hijab, he in jeans \u2014 kiss behind a tree in a park where no one could see but God.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe next morning our driver headed north toward the Mar Mattai monastery. We slipped past wheat fields, gas stations with knockoff names like \u201cShall\u201d and \u201cNobil,\u201d and a refinery \u2014 a reminder of Kurdistan\u2019s agricultural economy and the fact that Iraq controls some of the richest oil fields in the world, a quarter of which lie in Kurdistan. Kids played on the banks of the Greater Zab River where earthen bunkers once shielded Iraqi tanks during the 2003 invasion. This was the Green Line, the point behind which Saddam withdrew his forces after the creation of a no-fly zone over Kurdistan following his defeat in the 1991 Gulf War.\n\nThe air turned hair-dryer hot as we wrapped up our time at the monastery. From there we drove to a field just outside a village called Amian. A lone cow stood in the grass. A kid in a yellow shirt rode by, waving, on a bike. In the distance rose a gumdrop-shape dollop of earth. It was a tell, or a man-made hill formed when ancient villages are built and rebuilt atop one another over thousands of years until they\u2019re abandoned and the grass reclaims them.\n\nKurdistan is littered with these. Very few of them have been excavated, Hashim Hama Abdullah, the director of the Slemani Museum in Sulaymaniyah, would tell me later after I\u2019d spent a morning studying the museum\u2019s ancient stelae, tablets and other artifacts. \u201cNo excavating happened at all under Saddam,\u201d he said. \u201cNow teams are coming in.\u201d\n\nKurdistan has no real budget for tourism projects, which means few attractions have basic things like interpretive signs. This field, which also has never been excavated, would be just a field without Mr. Schute to explain it. In 331 B.C. the Persian king Darius III picked this now peaceful place to face Alexander the Great of Macedonia once and for all. The ensuing fight, the Battle of Gaugamela, saw Darius\u2019s far greater force suffer such horrific losses that soon the Macedon kingdom would stretch from Greece to Pakistan. The battle counts as one of the most important military victories of all time, Mr. Schute said.\n\n\u201cCan you feel it?\u201d he asked, as he imagined the war elephants, the scythed chariots and the tens of thousands of soldiers lining up to hack each other to bits. \u201cI get here and I can feel it.\u201d", "title": "A Journey Into Iraqi Kurdistan", "authors": ["Tim Neville"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Nadal\u2019s team announced on Wednesday that a magnetic resonance imaging exam indicated that he had strained the iliopsoas, an inner hip muscle, on his right side. Nadal still plans to follow his planned schedule, his team said, by playing a hardcourt event in Acapulco, Mexico, which begins on Feb. 26, followed by events in Indian Wells and Miami.\n\nThat would give Nadal more than a month to recover (he already had announced he would not play in the Davis Cup next week when Spain faces Britain).\n\nIn the semifinals, Cilic will face Kyle Edmund, an unseeded surprise from Britain who upset the No. 3 seed Grigor Dimitrov, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, earlier in the day in Rod Laver Arena.\n\nIt has been a tournament of big surprises. In her first Australian Open, the unseeded Elise Mertens of Belgium has reached the semifinals in women\u2019s singles. In his first Australian Open, 97th-ranked American Tennys Sandgren has reached the quarterfinals in men\u2019s singles.\n\nNadal\u2019s retirement means there will be no rematch with Roger Federer in this year\u2019s final. Federer beat Nadal in a five-set thriller in 2017 to win the Australian Open, but Federer, who will face Tomas Berdych in the quarterfinals on Wednesday, is now the only member of the so-called Big Five who is still in contention at Melbourne Park.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe years of competing at the highest level are taking their toll on that elite group. Andy Murray, 30, underwent hip surgery this month in Australia after withdrawing from this tournament. Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka managed to play after taking six-month breaks from competition because of injuries, but they were diminished in Melbourne.\n\nWawrinka, returning from knee surgery at age 32, lost in the second round to Sandgren. In a fourth-round loss to the 21-year-old South Korean Hyeon Chung, Djokovic, now 30, was frequently wincing in pain, his right elbow still not sufficiently healed after his extended break. Djokovic has acknowledged that elbow surgery is a possibility.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSandgren and Chung will play each other for a spot in the semifinals on Wednesday.\n\nNadal expressed concern about the series of injuries to leading players in the last year.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not the right moment to say for me, but somebody who is running the tour should think a little bit about what\u2019s going on,\u201d he said. \u201cToo many people getting injured.\u201d\n\nNadal, 31, said tennis authorities need to think about the long-term health of the players.\n\n\u201cThere is life after tennis, so I don\u2019t know if we keep playing in these very, very hard surfaces, what is going to happen in the future with our lives,\u201d he said.\n\nThroughout Nadal\u2019s remarkable career, as he has won 16 Grand Slam singles titles and two Olympic gold medals, he has often lobbied for more tournaments to be played on natural surfaces like grass and clay \u2014 his best surface.\n\nNadal has a spectacular but punishing playing style, full of abrupt changes of direction as he covers court like few men in the long history of tennis.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhen he was part of the ATP Player Council, he pushed unsuccessfully to base the ranking system on two years of results instead of one. In an interview in September, he complained that the top players had mandatory tournament commitments that stretched from January to November, although veteran players become exempt from some mandatory events as they accrue years of service.\n\nChris Kermode, the executive chairman and president of the ATP, has said that the tour has conducted research that shows the overall injury rate is not climbing for all players but only for the elite, which could be explained by the fact that much of that group is aging.\n\nFederer, the oldest of the Big Five by far at age 36, has long argued that it is important to take long breaks within the season. And though Cilic, 29, was sympathetic to Nadal\u2019s injury, he was not ready to ring the alarm bells as loudly.\n\n\u201cIn the end, it\u2019s on all of us to try to take care of our bodies, to try to pick the right schedule, to listen to our body, how it feels,\u201d said Cilic, the 2014 United States Open champion and the only man outside the Big Five to win a Grand Slam singles title since the beginning of 2010.\n\nPhoto\n\nNadal had a triumphant 2017 season, winning his 10th French Open and third United States Open. But his knee troubles returned by season\u2019s end, forcing him to withdraw from the Paris Masters and depart the ATP World Tour Finals after one match.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRecovery was slower than Nadal hoped or expected, and at the start of 2018 he withdrew from a planned exhibition event in Abu Dhabi and an official tournament in Brisbane, Australia.\n\nThis was the first time Nadal had arrived at the Australian Open without playing a warm-up event, but he successfully navigated the first week, dropping just one set, to Diego Schwartzman in the fourth round.\n\n\u201cI worked hard to be here,\u201d Nadal said. \u201cWe did all the things that we believed were the right things to do to be ready. I think I was ready. I was playing O.K.\u201d\n\nBut his body \u2014 his strength and his weakness \u2014 began to break down again in the third set Tuesday.\n\n\u201cStart to feel the muscle a little bit tired in the third, but playing normal, no limits, no limitation,\u201d Nadal said. \u201cThen in the fourth at one movement, one drop shot I think, I felt something. At that moment, I thought something happened, but I didn\u2019t realize how bad.\u201d\n\nIt would soon become clear, and the capacity crowd in Laver Arena began to groan and gasp as they watched him hobble and miss routine shots.\n\n\u201cYou never want to accept it. You want to wait and see if something happens that helps it go away and get better,\u201d said Nadal, who took anti-inflammatory medication during the match. \u201cI was waiting to see if that had any effect and improved anything. But I couldn\u2019t move, and without being able to move, I\u2019m not going to win. I couldn\u2019t keep going because I was totally lame, and I didn\u2019t know either if I continued like that whether I would do more damage.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nInjuries have spoiled Nadal\u2019s chances at the Australian Open before. He has retired from matches at eight tour events during his career but only two at the Grand Slam level, both at Melbourne Park. (He also withdrew from the 2016 French Open before the third round because of a wrist injury.)\n\nIn 2010, Nadal stopped his Australian Open quarterfinal against Murray because of a knee problem. In 2011, when Nadal was trying to become the first man since Rod Laver in 1969 to win four straight major singles titles, he sustained a hamstring injury in the opening set of his quarterfinal against his Spanish compatriot David Ferrer and lost in straight sets.\n\nIn the 2014 final here, Nadal lost to Wawrinka in four sets when hampered by a back problem.\n\nDespite his retirement on Tuesday, Nadal will retain the No. 1 ranking after the tournament. But \u2014 as with Djokovic \u2014 it is unclear when Nadal will be able to play again.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sad because once again I\u2019ve had a problem in my career,\u201d he said. \u201cBut in the end, when these things happen, you have to look in the mirror and see all the good things that have happened, too. It\u2019s true that I\u2019ve perhaps had more injuries than most of my competitors, but it\u2019s also true that I\u2019ve won more than nearly all of them.\u201d", "title": "A Leg Injury Takes Rafael Nadal Out of the Australian Open", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Of all the glaciers in retreat throughout the world, those in this part of South America are the most likely to disappear first. Scientists call them the tropical glaciers, ice caps found in places as warm as Ecuador and Indonesia, where high mountain peaks have shielded them for thousands of years from the heat of the jungle below.\n\nCOLOMBIA COLOMBIA ECUADOR ECUADOR PERU Amazon River BRAZIL Huaraz CORDILLERA BLANCA ANDES MTS. Pacific Ocean 300 Miles\n\nYet now, even these high perches have become precarious. Climate scientists say the ice cap here has been reduced by nearly a quarter in the past 40 years because of rising temperatures. With the rate of melting increasing each year, some scientists predict that within 50 years many of the peaks here will no longer have glaciers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not Antarctica, where you have a rupture of a mile and everyone notices,\u201d said Justiniano Alejo Cochachin, a glaciologist who works for the Peruvian government. \u201cIt\u2019s 19 meters a year; it is bit by bit.\u201d\n\nOn his many journeys, Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez has spent decades looking over the shoulders of scientists like Mr. Cochachin, shaping his own intimate view of a landscape altered by climate change.\n\nHe watched the expanding rocky fields around the Pastoruri Glacier, where the melting ice uncovered fossils that had not seen daylight in ages, including those of ferns and other plants. He has seen rivers turn red as other glaciers melted and exposed heavy metals that poison the water downstream.\n\n\u201cIf there is no water, there is no life,\u201d Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez said.\n\nHis work begins early, well before sunrise, when he packs crampons used to walk atop the glaciers, large boring drills and topographical instruments, helmets, gloves and the gear to build a shelter, all in a backpack nearly as large as he is.\n\nThe food often goes on a mule \u2014 provided the mule can make the climb. If not, Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez carries that, too, on several trips in and out of the camp over the course of several days.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Gonz\u00e1lez said the path on a recent climb to a glacier called Yanamarey would not be so taxing, by his standards \u2014 a round-trip journey of 10 hours. And so we headed out one morning with Rolando Cruz, a researcher in the nearby town of Huaraz who came to take some measurements at the base of the glacier.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe long hours up are often quiet ones, where Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez searches for what he calls the \u201cperfect route\u201d through the unmarked boggy landscape of mist and fog where jagged peaks rise up on either side and hawks soar above. Vast plains stretch for miles, former lake beds from the ice age, where cows graze.\n\n\u201cThe cows weren\u2019t here before,\u201d noted Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez, saying they now graze at higher altitudes than before, as they follow the grasses as the temperatures have warmed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe route was one that Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez has crossed countless times over the decades, since he first visited the Yanamarey glacier in the early 1990s. His descriptions of it from that time vary. At times he evokes a building \u2014 it had \u201cblue walls,\u201d he said. Sometimes he spoke of the glacier\u2019s \u201cbeautiful long tongue,\u201d and it sounded more like an animal.\n\n\u201cYes, it is alive,\u201d he said, describing the glacier\u2019s slow movement below his feet.\n\nIn the 1990s, the hikes could be an escape from the conflicts taking place below, when the Shining Path, the Maoist rebel group that terrorized Peru for decades, attacked politicians in Huaraz and planted three car bombs. Despite the unrest, American researchers would come each year, and Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez would lead them up as the ice sheet continued to melt.\n\n\u201cWhen you go out into the field, your mind clears,\u201d he said.\n\nIt was the sound of the cracking, heard on nearly every ice sheet the scientists came to study, that bothered him most. \u201cTac,\u201d he said, \u201clike a huge sound.\u201d And every year he came, Yanamarey was farther away than it had been the last time.\n\nPhoto\n\nOur climb continued. The landscape turned into a rocky stretch of boulders. Then the glacier came into view.\n\nIt looked very different that day from the place Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez had described. The ice sheet, having once spilled into the lake below it, had retreated halfway up a rocky mountainside, a small spit peeking behind the rocks. There were no \u201cblue walls,\u201d no \u201ctongue,\u201d just a thin coat of ice over a bare rocky stretch.\n\n\u201cIt looks gray, like the color of lead,\u201d Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez said several times.\n\nMr. Cruz climbed up, took his measurements in the distance and returned some time later. The two men looked at each other with the same resigned glance, then headed back down the hill.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt his age, Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez knows these journeys will not continue forever. His knees have begun to give out, particularly as he walks downhill with large amounts of gear. \u201cYou don\u2019t have the same strength,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Gonz\u00e1lez looked over at his son \u00c1lvaro, an 18-year-old who had joined us that afternoon back at the hostel in Huaraz. The boy told me he would soon study climate science in college, inspired by his father who had taken him to see the ice sheet for the first time some years ago.\n\nWho had shown Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez the glaciers first? It was his mother, he said, on a chilly day when the two were looking out at the peaks from a nearby farm.\n\n\u201cYou could see those white glaciers in the distance,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd our mother pointed to them and said in her language \u2018raju,\u2019 which is the Quechua word, which means ice.\u201d\n\nBack then, the ice seemed as permanent as the mountains themselves.\n\n\u201cNo, I never imagined this,\u201d said Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez, describing the ice today. \u201cAs a child, you can never picture the things which might happen.\u201d", "title": "A Lifetime in Peru\u2019s Glaciers, Slowly Melting Away", "authors": ["Nicholas Casey", "The Saturday Profile"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The Monday shift was in stark contrast. The phone was silent. Mr. Aston browsed the internet to pass the time, made cups of tea, stretched. But then, around 11:30 p.m., an email arrived. It was from an electronic musician experiencing a host of problems, including anxiety and depression.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a huge step for someone just to send that,\u201d Mr. Aston said. \u201cThey clearly need to talk.\u201d\n\nHe quickly wrote a reply, saying, among other things, they could call anytime. Four hours later, the phone still hadn\u2019t rung. The help line received an average of 25 inquiries a week in December. Some nights are busy, others quiet.\n\nMental health is a high-profile issue in the music industry, with stars like Zayn Malik talking about anxiety and the suicides of Chris Cornell of Soundgarden and Chester Bennington of Linkin Park. Yet the Music Minds help line is one of few public initiatives trying to improve matters.\n\nRichard Robinson, Help Musicians\u2019 chief executive, said the idea had been brewing for several years. The \u201cfinal shove,\u201d he said, came in 2016, when the group commissioned the University of Westminster in London to research mental health issues in the industry.\n\nOf the roughly 2,200 people who participated in the survey, from aspiring violinists to folk singers, 71 percent said they had experienced anxiety or panic, and 68.5 percent depression. That compares with a nationwide average of 17 percent of people ages 16 or over having anxiety or depression in Britain, according to the Office of National Statistics. More than half of those in the music industry said they had found it difficult to get help. The report on the survey results is blunt: \u201cMusic making is therapeutic, but making a career out of music is destructive.\u201d\n\nOther studies have shown similar numbers. In 2016, researchers in Norway found that musicians there were three times more likely to be in therapy than the general work force.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s a unique environment,\u201d Mr. Robinson said. \u201cSomeone who\u2019s putting their creative brain on show is saying, \u2018Look, I can either succeed or fail here.\u2019 And it\u2019s horrific.\u201d\n\nThe daily calls to the help line show it is needed, he added. Calls from electronic musicians, composers and people in music theater have dominated so far.\n\nIt is easy to find musicians who welcome such efforts. \u201cI\u2019m totally fine to admit I\u2019ve rung Samaritans before,\u201d said Matthew Johnson, the frontman of the Leeds-based rock band Hookworms, referring to Britain\u2019s best-known suicide-prevention hotline. \u201cThe problem I\u2019ve had is, when I\u2019ve tried to explain my problems, and I\u2019ve had it with therapists too, they say, \u2018Oh, your life must be wonderful.\u2019 They don\u2019t particularly understand the pressures you might be under.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Johnson has had depression, on and off, since he was a teenager. Being a musician has sometimes made things worse, he said, even though Hookworms has released two critically acclaimed albums. The profession comes with financial precariousness, but he said he also hated being onstage, and found coping with reviews and online sniping difficult.\n\n\u201cI found myself the other day looking through YouTube comments, and I found one \u2014 one! \u2014 where someone said they didn\u2019t like it,\u201d Mr. Johnson said, referring to their latest single. \u201cThat\u2019s the one I\u2019ll take to heart. I\u2019ll ignore all the ones saying it\u2019s brilliant.\u201d\n\nThe artist says he feels lucky that his band signed with Domino, a London-based label that he said had been supportive. \u201cWhen I feel bad, they always reach out to check I\u2019m O.K. They\u2019ve gone out of their way to move stuff, cancel stuff.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIf our record absolutely tanked, I don\u2019t think they\u2019d stop supporting us,\u201d he added. \u201cI\u2019ve seen it with friends who\u2019ve made one record on a big label then been dropped, and they\u2019ve totally spiraled to a terrible place.\u201d\n\nNone of the large record labels contacted for this article would comment on the industry\u2019s actions on mental health.\n\n\u201cThe help line is great, but it is not the total solution in any shape or form,\u201d said Sally Gross of the University of Westminster, who conducted the survey for Help Musicians. \u201cMental health is very much a hot topic, and everyone\u2019s saying they\u2019re doing something about it. I don\u2019t know what that is though.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is not just the music industry that needs to act, she added. Mental health services require increased government funding, she said, and there is a need for better education on the realities of life as a musician.\n\nMusicians themselves are calling for more action. \u201cFootball clubs have someone attached to them to deal with all forms of health of their players,\u201d said Neil Barnes, better known as Leftfield, a dance act who have had several platinum albums. \u201cI think that record companies should employ therapists as part of their payroll, to offer that service to bands.\u201d\n\nMr. Barnes has long had depression, and found it worsened after the band split up, in 2002, and later when he was under pressure to write new music. He was lucky to be able to afford private therapy, he added.\n\nThe help lines, though, are an important first step. Mr. Robinson, the Help Musicians chief executive, urged the global music industry to support the Music Minds Matter endeavor or replicate it.\n\n\u201cMental health is clearly becoming a much talked about subject, but we need to make sure it doesn\u2019t become a cause c\u00e9l\u00e8bre or a fad,\u201d he said. \u201cWe are losing people.\u201d", "title": "A Listening Ear for Musicians in Need", "authors": ["Alex Marshall"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "In his annual State of the State address today, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, of New York, spoke about New York City\u2019s transit crisis. Here are three books in which writers explore the politics and complications involved in building the nation\u2019s first subways and provide suggestions for improving public transportation in the United States overall.\n\nImage\n\nTHE RACE UNDERGROUND\n\nBoston, New York, and the Incredible Rivalry That Built America\u2019s First Subway\n\nBy Doug Most\n\n416 pp. St. Martin\u2019s Press. (2014)\n\nIn this Gilded Age saga, Most recounts the politics, engineering challenges and competition behind the creation of the United States\u2019 first subway systems in Boston and New York. His narrative centers on two brothers, Henry and William Whitney, who were instrumental in the construction of both systems. The idea of a subterranean train was first floated in the late 1800s by the then publisher of Scientific American, Alfred Beach, but it was dismissed. It would take decades for more politicians and engineers to get on board. This book delivers a lively account of a transformational time in American history.\n\nImage\n\nMOVE\n\nPutting America\u2019s Infrastructure Back in the Lead\n\nBy Rosabeth Moss Kanter\n\n325 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. (2015)", "title": "A Literary Journey Underground", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "In a release issued on Dec. 20, the foundation compiled a list of factual errors from the book, among them, Ms. Stevens\u2019s claim that she was by Avedon\u2019s side when he died (he was attended only by his family when he died in San Antonio, while Ms. Stevens was in New York City at the time, according to the foundation); that Avedon was paid $1 million a year to join Vogue as a fashion photographer (he signed a contract with Cond\u00e9 Nast that awarded him $1 million over 20 years); and that Avedon photographed his terminally ill father \u201crelentlessly,\u201d taking 50 portraits of him during \u201cfraught\u201d sittings (according to foundation, there were just six portrait sessions).\n\nThe foundation also claims that Ms. Stevens based parts of the book on an unfinished, semiautobiographical novel that Avedon was working on for years before his death, in which he blended elements of his past with fiction. \u201cStevens appears to be lifting various stories out of this fictional work, lightly editing and rewriting them, and then presenting them as both her own work and as biographical fact,\u201d James Martin, the executive director of the Richard Avedon Foundation, said in a statement.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Martin said he read parts of Avedon\u2019s novel in progress after his death, when he was sorting through his files and packing them up. He said he asked Ms. Stevens what she wanted him to do with the manuscript, and she said she would take care of it, and took the box and put it under her desk. (When asked to provide examples of overlapping passages from the novel and the biography, the foundation declined to do so.)\n\nSpiegel & Grau rebutted the foundation\u2019s claim. \u201cNorma Stevens did not copy or use a Richard Avedon novel in any way in writing \u201cAvedon: Something Personal,\u201d the company said in a statement. \u201cThe Avedon Foundation has made loose, unsubstantiated allegations of copyright infringement without presenting any documented instances of substantial similarity between our book and another work.\u201d\n\nMs. Stevens was not available to comment for this article, a spokeswoman for Spiegel & Grau said, but the publisher defended the work: \u201cThe book is an important and meaningful account by the person who was in a privileged position to observe and know Richard Avedon as well as anybody else and to reflect on him.\u201d\n\nMs. Stevens worked with Avedon closely for nearly 30 years, and had a front-row view of his celebrated, glamorous career. Before he died, Avedon indicated that he wanted to name Ms. Stevens as the executive director of his foundation, and she ran it for five years. Ms. Stevens notes in the book that Mr. Avedon often urged her to write about him, and to make it an honest and unsparing portrait. \u201cThe best portrait is always the truth. Make me into an Avedon,\u201d she said he told her.\n\nIn a career that spanned nearly six decades, Avedon revolutionized fashion photography and took revealing portraits of some of the biggest cultural giants of the modern era, including Ezra Pound, Charlie Chaplin, Bob Dylan, Marilyn Monroe and Allen Ginsberg. His works were exhibited in museums around the world and collected in books and exhibition catalogs, including \u201cObservations,\u201d which featured text by Truman Capote, and \u201cNothing Personal,\u201d with text by James Baldwin.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut while his portraits of others were often shockingly intimate, Avedon himself kept much of his private life, including questions about his sexuality, shielded from public view. His archives are closely held by the foundation, and 13 years after his death, no one had published a significant book about his life before Ms. Stevens and Mr. Aronson.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome of Avedon\u2019s close friends, family members and collaborators have expressed doubt that Avedon urged Ms. Stevens, who is not an author, to write about him and include scandalous revelations about his private life.\n\n\u201cI think he\u2019d be horrified,\u201d the actor and director Andre Gregory, a close friend of Avedon, said in an interview. \u201cHe was one of the most discreet men I\u2019ve ever met.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJohn Avedon, the photographer\u2019s son, called the biography a \u201ccollection of either half-truths, or outright falsehoods, embellished into often salacious stories,\u201d and cited two specific passages in which he is referred to \u2014 including a macabre one in which he prepared a meal containing his deceased father\u2019s ashes, mistaken for oregano \u2014 as false.\n\nHe said that his father, who was famously controlling over the way his work was presented, had never seemed keen on the idea of a biography.\n\n\u201cOn the one occasion in which I raised the topic my father made it abundantly clear that he had no desire to participate in, or be the subject of, a biography,\u201d Mr. Avedon said in an email. \u201cThe whole idea was anathema. My father wanted to be remembered for his life\u2019s work \u2014 his photographs.\u201d\n\nOther friends of Avedon were livid at how their relationship with him was portrayed. Nicole Wisniak, the founder and editor of the French-language magazine Egoiste, said in an email that Ms. Stevens \u201chas chosen to completely lie about the nature of my relationship with Dick.\u201d\n\nAdam Gopnik, a writer for The New Yorker and a close friend of Avedon who was interviewed by Ms. Stevens and Mr. Aronson, said that Ms. Stevens \u201cmisrepresented\u201d her project and told him that she was writing an oral history of the Avedon studio, not a biography. He also said that the words attributed to Avedon in the book sound out of character for him.\n\n\u201cIt would be a source of grief to Dick to find himself the subject of a posthumous tell all, a genre he loudly, and often, despised,\u201d Mr. Gopnik said in an email.\n\nThe most reliable source on whether Avedon would have approved of the book is, of course, no longer alive. But Avedon addressed questions of truth, fiction and accuracy when discussing his own photographs, in ways that suggest he was skeptical that any art form, even photography, could fully capture its subject.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThere is no such thing as inaccuracy in a photograph. All photographs are accurate,\u201d he said. \u201cNone of them is the truth.\u201d", "title": "A Literary Portrait of Richard Avedon Causes Controversy", "authors": ["Alexandra Alter"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Not so long ago, such a dense revival of Eastman\u2019s work would have been impossible. Destitute and mentally ill in the late 1980s, he fled New York City and made his way to Buffalo, his former home, where he died in a hospital of causes that remain vague.\n\nBy then he was so distant from the artistic scene of which he was once a vibrant member that it was only when The Village Voice published an obituary in January 1991, eight months later, that his old friends and collaborators found out he was gone. His scores had years before been destroyed or vanished; recordings of them were more or less nonexistent, and none released commercially.\n\nA vital career seemed entirely lost. First in Buffalo, whose state university campus was a new-music hotbed, and then in another hotbed, the downtown New York of the \u201970s, Eastman had been the charismatic center of the party \u2014 sweet-natured, arrogant, exuberantly provocative. His compositions radiated confidence; his solo-piano improvisations balanced conviction and meditation; his bass voice, in music by Meredith Monk, Peter Maxwell Davies and Frederic Rzewski, was a formidable mixture of reverberation and clarity.\n\nAll that was stilled, long before he died.\n\nIt was because of the determination of a small circle of advocates \u2014 particularly the composer and performer Mary Jane Leach, who had worked with Eastman in the 1980s \u2014 that material began to reaccumulate. Archival recordings and scores were discovered and released; transcriptions were created. The past decade has seen a trickle, and then a relative flood, of performances.", "title": "A Long-Lost Composer Is Raised From the Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The death of the composer and performer Julius Eastman in 1990 went largely unobserved, even in the artistic circles he had long traveled in. By then, after a string of misfortunes, documentary evidence of his music had withered nearly to nothing. For those who cherished the work of this inventive firebrand \u2014 a conceptualist steeped in dance, Minimalism and jazz-informed improvisation \u2014 a restoration seemed deeply implausible.\n\nYet that is what has transpired. The diligent research of scholars like Mary Jane Leach has resulted in the discovery and release of multiple recordings, as well as a 2015 collection of essays called \u201cGay Guerrilla,\u201d after one of Eastman\u2019s politically pointed pieces.\n\nMore is still being uncovered. The Kitchen in Chelsea, where Eastman had important performances, has begun a three-week festival, \u201cJulius Eastman: That Which Is Fundamental.\u201d Modeled after a similar presentation in Philadelphia last year, it is organized by the artist Tiona Nekkia McClodden and by Dustin Hurt of Bowerbird, a Philadelphia arts organization, along with members of the Kitchen\u2019s curatorial team.\n\nAlong with newly unearthed biographical material from the Kitchen\u2019s archives, the festival will also include a performance of a riotous Eastman work, \u201cTrumpet\u201d \u2014 written in the early 1970s for seven trumpeters (ideally), or (barring that) seven soprano instruments. While the library at the State University of New York at Buffalo has a recording of a 1971 performance, no part of the score was thought to have survived.", "title": "A Long-Lost Score, Rebuilt With the Help of a Photo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The shiny new cars get all the attention. More than 3,000 refugees and migrants died in the Mediterranean last year while trying to make their way to Europe.\n\nThe deaths on Saturday focused attention on the dangerous central Mediterranean crossing between Libya and Italy, where most of those deaths took place, and prompted calls from the United Nations migration agency for a comprehensive policy to address the humanitarian crisis.\n\n\u201cThis is the beginning of the year, and this is quite dramatic after only eight days,\u201d said Flavio Di Giacomo, an agency spokesman.", "title": "A Look Inside a Rescuer\u2019s Struggle to Save Migrants from Sinking Dinghy", "authors": ["Megan Specia"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "In 1900, the Manhattan philanthropist Jacob H. Schiff received a surprise gift from some people he had helped: a silver trophy the size of a punch bowl. Officially known as a loving cup, it is inscribed with text in ruffled and blocky typefaces, thanking him for financing the Young Men\u2019s Hebrew Association building on Lexington Avenue at 92nd Street. In 2016, the trophy surfaced unexpectedly at M.S. Rau Antiques in New Orleans, and in March, it will go on public view in a mirrored hall at the facility Mr. Schiff helped found, now known as the 92nd Street Y.\n\nJo Frances Brown, who runs the 92nd Street Y\u2019s programs for seniors, spotted the trophy at the store, and the Y bought it for about $25,000. One side is etched with an image of the original four-story Neoclassical building, which was razed and replaced with the current structure in 1928. Henry Timms, the executive director of the 92nd Street Y, said the upcoming display of the object is timed for celebrations of a fund-raising campaign for $180 million worth of renovations, additions and other upgrades.\n\nNo one knows who designed or made the trophy; the only prominent mark on its base is a cryptic \u201c3154.\u201d Joseph P. Brady, a silver historian and appraiser in Atlanta, said he suspects the maker was the Whiting Manufacturing Company, a New York business known for applying elaborate fonts on custom vessels. He added that it is not unusual for forgotten trophies emerging on the market to be repatriated by the families or institutions that had originally commissioned them.\n\n\u201cThey do end up back where they belong,\u201d he said.", "title": "A Loving Cup Comes Home, to the 92nd Street Y", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 There were 218 communities whose proposals did not reach the second round in Amazon\u2019s well-publicized search for its second headquarters. For those ambitious but unlucky folks, there were no \u201cthanks for entering\u201d gift baskets or any consolation prizes.\n\nTom Hall, town manager of Scarborough, Me., had just returned from a meeting about the clam harvest when he heard the bad news from a reporter. He took it philosophically. The town\u2019s proposal to convert a 500-acre harness racing track in the center of Scarborough was, he knew, \u201cthe longest of long shots.\u201d\n\nIn Oklahoma, there were more regrets.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m certainly disappointed,\u201d said Scott Phillips, who ran a development team called Day 1 that promoted a proposal to build an entirely new 50-square-mile city for Amazon between Oklahoma City and Tulsa, equidistant from each.", "title": "A Maine Racetrack Didn\u2019t Lure Amazon. Multiply That Disappointment by 218.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "So does the rebuttal from the governor\u2019s camp: that the mayor already has the power to veto big transit spending.\n\nStill, does the governor really need to micromanage the streets of Manhattan when he already has under his jurisdiction 55,000 square miles of New York State, from the Canadian border to the tip of Montauk? Is any public good served by not talking to the mayor when you want to change taxes and transportation in the city?\n\nThe governor\u2019s command of detail has given him a portfolio of accomplishments throughout his public life. But micromanaging can curdle. It turns out that last summer, the governor\u2019s office fiddled with statistics on the reasons for transit delays, as Dan Rivoli reported in The Daily News. In a cache of emails, senior officials struggled to blame more delays on Con Edison than the utility was genuinely responsible for, which an analyst had put at 3,422 annually.\n\n\u201cHow would you massage that language?\u201d a press secretary for the governor wrote to a transit official. \u201cCould we say \u2018power-related issues caused more than 32,000 delays?\u2019\u201d\n\nSure, you could say that. It would be no less than 99 percent dishonest, but you could say it.\n\nIf someone fell or jumped on the track and the power was turned off, the trains that could not run on time would be categorized as \u201cpower-related delays.\u201d If a piece of track equipment failed and the power had to be shut off while repairing it, that, too, could be counted as a \u201cpower-related delay\u201d \u2014 and not the fault of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBy this logic, people who kick out the cord to the television in their living rooms could curse Con Edison, rather than blame their own clumsiness.\n\nThanks to this abuse of language and arithmetic, the figure of 3,422 Con Edison delays was swollen beyond recognition when the governor walked the tracks and spoke to reporters on Aug. 9 in the Columbus Circle station.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re looking at the largest single cluster of delays, which are 32,000 power-related delays,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said that day. \u201cWhat people tend to forget is the M.T.A. runs on power.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked about this on Monday, after The News\u2019s expos\u00e9, Mr. Cuomo said he had relied on figures sent to him by the M.T.A. Thereafter, transit officials did back flips trying to say that the naked manipulation of data was not naked manipulation of data. It was. It is. Andy Byford, the new president of the subway system, declined to endorse the counting techniques used by his agency.\n\nWhen Mr. Byford was introduced as the transit leader in November, I asked him what he thought about the governor\u2019s practice of bypassing the chain of command to directly call superintendents within the system. \u201cThat\u2019s the governor\u2019s prerogative,\u201d Mr. Byford said. \u201cHe\u2019s the governor.\u201d\n\nBut he\u2019s not the mayor.\n\nNew York City\u2019s wealth, and its role as an economic engine for the state and the nation, depend on mobility.\n\nA show of hands, please, from all those who believe that it is possible to improve, or at least passably fix, New York\u2019s transit system if the governor and the mayor cannot figure out how to work together.\n\nAnyone?", "title": "A Mayor, a Governor, and the Feud That Keeps New York Down", "authors": ["Jim Dwyer", "About New York"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI call him the Wizard of Oz,\u201d Ms. Yuskavage said. \u201cHe does have all of these people running Oz.\u201d\n\nFor prominent artists and estates like those in Mr. Zwirner\u2019s fold \u2014 Dan Flavin, Donald Judd \u2014 that means having a presence in the most important art centers, which increasingly includes Asia. And it also means having the most impressive headquarters in New York, which is what Mr. Zwirner seems to be going for with his new building by Mr. Piano \u2014 the architect\u2019s first commercial gallery.\n\n\u201cIt will upgrade the quality of my spaces, and that is something attractive for all these people that I need in my life \u2014 the artists and the people who work here,\u201d Mr. Zwirner said.\n\nThe new gallery will be at 540 west 21st Street, part of a project that is being developed by the investor Uri Chaitchik of Casco Development. The gallery will be connected to Casco\u2019s residential tower, but it will be a separate structure, with three floors of galleries.\n\nThe precise design has yet to be determined \u2014 Mr. Piano is in the early stages of the process. But it is likely to have a similarly spare aesthetic to Mr. Zwirner\u2019s current spaces, by Annabelle Selldorf. Although he loves his Selldorf spaces \u2014 and the architect is a friend \u2014 he went with Mr. Piano on this project, Mr. Zwirner said, because he was the developer\u2019s choice.\n\nSo far, Mr. Zwirner said, he has enjoyed working with Mr. Piano, whom he described as \u201cone of my great heroes,\u201d having admired his designs for museums like the Menil Collection in Houston, the Morgan Library & Museum renovation and the Beyeler Foundation in Basel, Switzerland.\n\nBecause this is Mr. Piano\u2019s first commercial gallery, Mr. Zwirner said, \u201cI have to remind him we don\u2019t need coat checks, we don\u2019t need ticket booths and the size of the lobby doesn\u2019t have to be quite that large.\u201d", "title": "A Mega-Dealer Expands: David Zwirner Plans a New Art Gallery", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Another study found that people who took pictures of artwork in a museum were less able to recall the artwork and their locations than those who visited the museum without snapping photos. Those of us old enough to remember life before smartphones used to memorize important phone numbers. Few do so now or even try. We could, but why bother?\n\nThere\u2019s another type of memory extension that is even more mindlike. We routinely extend our memories by using other people\u2019s minds, and our minds serve as memory extenders for others. Anyone with children is constantly remembering things for them \u2014 what time they need to be at soccer practice, where it is, what they need to bring. My children know the names of many other children and their parents, a resource I draw on regularly at family social events because I often forget \u2014 or never knew \u2014 them.\n\nPaying close attention to this kind of external memory is of some professional value. A few years ago, my work demands began to overwhelm my ability to remember important information. Using some mental tricks helped, but I still couldn\u2019t keep up.\n\nSo I switched strategies. Recognizing that there was some redundancy in remembering certain things that others knew, I gave up trying. Instead, I made more of an effort to keep track of the areas in which each of my colleagues was expert. If they have the information stored in their minds, and if I can access those minds relatively easily \u2014 for instance with a quick email or even a tweet \u2014 there\u2019s no need for me to remember that information.\n\nFor example, if I need to know about which nutrition studies to trust, I could simply ask my colleague Aaron Carroll, who just wrote a book on the topic.\n\nBut what if I encounter a colleague using the same approach, and we both think the other is doing the remembering? When I worry that might be the case, I ask: \u201cAm I keeping track of this or you?\u201d That settles it. In fact, I end many meetings or email exchanges at work just this way. Once a plan of action or a solution to a problem is worked out, I make it clear who has ownership of it and will make sure crucial information isn\u2019t lost.\n\nAt home, my wife and I are explicit about who is handling which follow-up to the myriad demands associated with my children\u2019s school and extracurricular activities. Whatever is on her plate (i.e., in her head), I largely forget about. Whatever is on mine, I better remember!", "title": "A Memory Shortcut, With a Little Help From Friends", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Rates\n\nDoubles start at $159.\n\nThe Basics\n\nThe handsome red brick warehouses that cluster north of downtown Minneapolis near the Mississippi River speak to peak 19th-century commercial traffic on the waterway and nearby rail lines. Many have more recently been reclaimed by some of the city\u2019s most buzzed-about restaurants (including the Bachelor Farmer) and stylish shops (MartinPatrick3). Now the Hewing Hotel, opened in 2016 in a prominent warehouse that once stored farm equipment, pays homage to one of those trades \u2014 logging \u2014 in six stories of wood-framing, flooring and paneling. Channeling the spirit of an urban lumberjack, massive, rough-hewed posts picket the sunny lobby filled with low-slung leather couches. Patterned wallpaper featuring fish and moose and retro accessories on library shelves including vintage hockey gloves mirror Minnesota\u2019s affinity for the outdoors. Minnesotans have returned the love, crowding the hotel\u2019s ground-floor restaurant and bar Tullibee, which champions the bounty of the region with a Scandinavian accent. Fittingly, there\u2019s a sizable sauna and outdoor hot tub on the rooftop, as well as a bar.\n\nLocation\n\nThe Hewing resides in the gentrifying North Loop neighborhood, part of the Minneapolis Warehouse Historic District. Target Field, home to the Minnesota Twins, is within a few blocks. The Guthrie Theater, just over a mile downriver, is a quick Uber ride away. This year\u2019s tournament won\u2019t feature the best, but there are plenty of fascinating stories to follow. Few of them ever expected to have an Olympic opportunity, and for most, this will be their one and only shot.\n\nTeam U.S.A. will come in with heavy hearts but plenty of inspiration after the team\u2019s general manager, Jim Johannson, the longtime national program executive, died unexpectedly on Sunday at age 53. And while the roster he built isn\u2019t quite the ragtag squad of underdogs that won the hearts of Americans in 1980, they\u2019re not far off.\n\nThe captain is 39-year-old Brian Gionta, the diminutive forward last seen finishing out his N.H.L. career on some miserable Sabres teams. There\u2019s Chris Bourque, son of the Hall of Fame Bruins defenseman Ray, and several college players, including Boston University\u2019s Jordan Greenway, who\u2019ll become the first African-American to represent the United States in Olympic hockey. And there\u2019s Bobby Butler, a minor leaguer and former N.H.L. winger who warmed hearts when a video of him telling his dad he would be playing for Team U.S.A. went viral.\n\nThat\u2019s not Auston Matthews or Patrick Kane. But maybe it doesn\u2019t have to be.\n\nTeam Canada fans hoping to see Sidney Crosby or Connor McDavid will have to settle for names like former N.H.L.ers Derek Roy and Mason Raymond. Or they can root for the defenseman Chay Genoway: An undrafted long shot, he dreamed of making the N.H.L., and he did \u2014 for just a single game, in 2012. That\u2019s one better than Mat Robinson, who never made it at all, and neither did the team\u2019s oldest player, 37-year-old Chris Lee.\n\nThen there\u2019s goaltender Ben Scrivens, an undrafted Cornell graduate who spent almost his entire five-year N.H.L. career playing in three of Canada\u2019s most high-pressure markets \u2014 Toronto, Edmonton and Montreal. He built a devoted fan base through a thoughtful social media presence, and his wife, Jenny, was a goaltender for the New York Riveters of the National Women\u2019s Hockey League.\n\nUnlike the members of previous Team Canada rosters, these guys don\u2019t have N.H.L. playoff races to return to when it\u2019s over. Instead, they\u2019ll be playing in easily the most important games of their careers.
