In a way, that feels like what the Olympics should be.\n\nThe Czech team will be captained by Martin Erat, a veteran forward who played almost 900 N.H.L. games. But he\u2019s probably best remembered by the league\u2019s fans for something he had no control over \u2014 a disastrous 2013 trade in which the Washington Capitals gave up their best prospect to acquire him. That prospect, Filip Forsberg (no relation to Peter), is now one of the league\u2019s best young forwards, while Erat has been out of the league for almost three years. As a 24-year-old in 2006, Erat was on the last Czech team to win a medal. Now, at 36, he gets one last bid for glory.\n\nAnd if you really can\u2019t get excited about Olympic hockey without the presence of genuine N.H.L. star power, there\u2019s always Team Sweden. Their roster will feature the teenage phenom Rasmus Dahlin, a ridiculously skilled defenseman expected to go first overall in the next N.H.L. draft. At 17 years old, he\u2019ll be the fifth youngest player to ever appear in the men\u2019s Olympic tournament.", "title": "Opinion | A Minor Miracle on Ice at the Olympic Games?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Until his dying day, my dad\u2019s Uncle Bern was a communist sympathizer. I remember him as an affable old man with a gracious wife who made a modest living selling antique lace. He probably wouldn\u2019t have hurt a fly. Yet he found much to admire in the most murderous ideology of the 20th century, responsible for tens of millions of deaths from the killing fields of Cambodia to the gulags of Murmansk.\n\nIf you\u2019re Jewish in America, chances are there\u2019s at least one Uncle Bern somewhere in your family tree. As the scholar Ruth Wisse noted last year in Tablet magazine, Jewish intellectual life in the 1930s and 40s was largely defined by one\u2019s stance toward one thing: The Party. Historians reckon that Jews accounted for nearly half the Communist Party\u2019s total membership in those years, while many other Jews were close fellow travelers.\n\nMost of these people, like my great-uncle, were deeply misguided idealists who otherwise led quiet and decent lives. A tiny handful of others \u2014 including atomic spies Julius Rosenberg, David Greenglass, Harry Gold and Morton Sobell \u2014 betrayed America\u2019s most important military secrets to Stalinist Russia and did incalculable damage to the country and the world.\n\nHere\u2019s a thought experiment: Would the United States have been better off if it had banned Jewish immigration sometime in the late 19th century, so that the immigrant parents of Rosenberg and Sobell had never set foot here? The question is worth asking, because so many of the same arguments made against African, Latin-American and Muslim immigrants today might have easily been applied to Jews just over a century ago.", "title": "Opinion | A Modest Immigration Proposal: Ban Jews", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "In their midst now lies one badly overgrown and dilapidated minor-league ball field. Greer Stadium has sat empty since the Nashville Sounds departed at the end of the 2014 season. As part of a preserved Civil War site, the stadium\u2019s location has long been designated as public parkland, going back to 1928, when the city bought it from the descendants of John Overton, a longtime crony of President Andrew Jackson. That parcel was always meant to revert to parkland once the Sounds decamped.\n\nThe actual fort at Fort Negley Park was dismantled after the Union Army withdrew in 1867, but history set its hand on the site a second time during the Depression, when a facsimile of the fort was rebuilt there by 800 laborers funded by the Works Progress Administration. That reproduction ultimately fell into ruin and for decades was closed to the public, but 1996 brought a plan to restore the site again. Fort Negley reopened in 2004, on the 140th anniversary of the Battle of Nashville. The next year it was designated a National Historic Landmark District.\n\nThree years after the Sounds left, Mayor Megan Barry released a request for proposals related to the site of the old stadium. The request was not for Metro Parks to create a plan for desperately needed green space in an already overpaved urban core. The request was not for the Metro Historical Commission to create a plan to preserve the legacy of African-Americans who gave their lives to preserve the Union. It was not a request for the Friends of Fort Negley, an advocacy group, to create a plan to expand the educational reach of the site.\n\nThe plans the mayor requested were for private development under a land-lease arrangement much like the one that allowed Greer Stadium to be built there in the first place.\n\nLet\u2019s call what happened next the second Battle of Nashville.\n\nFor years this city has been undergoing rapid, unchecked growth, and it desperately needs affordable housing and subsidized work spaces for artists and innovators. That much everyone agrees on. When the mayor\u2019s office approved a plan by the Cloud Hill partnership, headed by the developer Bert Mathews and the music producer T Bone Burnett, for a mixed-use private development that would include music and art studios, retail space and housing at three price points \u2014 affordable, work force and market rate \u2014 it made a kind of sense.", "title": "Opinion | A Monument the Old South Would Like to Ignore", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Doctors were panic-stricken, and nurses were crying, Ms. Matthias said. She recalled the callousness of some of the staff members, who tried to reassure her that she could try again if Franklin did not survive.\n\nPhoto\n\nHer family, including Franklin\u2019s father, kept constant vigil in the neonatal intensive care unit. Ms. Matthias wrote in a journal every day her son was there. The most brutal entry came on Day 12, when Ms. Matthias was told her son was unlikely to survive the night.\n\nThe family gathered in the hospital chapel to pray, with one exception. Ms. Matthias\u2019s mother paid a private visit to Franklin, telling him: \u201cYour mother\u2019s waited a long time for you. If you pull through for her, she\u2019s going to stick with you.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFranklin survived the night. And after more than 100 days in the hospital, 73 of them on an incubator, he was released on Sept. 24 and taken home with his parents.\n\n\u201cWe got Frankie,\u201d Ms. Matthias said. \u201cThere\u2019s nothing and nobody that can take him away from us now. It\u2019s a matter of just keeping him healthy, as healthy as possible.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Matthias remains a ceaselessly doting mother to Franklin, who is largely nonverbal and legally blind. His various disabilities are the source of many challenges, and in the years after his birth, Ms. Matthias also endured two miscarriages.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2008, Ms. Matthias learned she was pregnant again, this time with Nevaeh, which came with its own conflicting emotions.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI thought I was being selfish to take any time or any more of my heart away from Franklin and give it to somebody else,\u201d she said.\n\nNevaeh was brought home from the hospital five years to the day from Franklin\u2019s discharge date. Ms. Matthias gushes about her daughter\u2019s compassionate, spunky soul, calling her the \u201cultimate big sister\u201d to Franklin, despite her younger age.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s my glue,\u201d Ms. Matthias said.\n\nOn the walk from school, Nevaeh displayed equal care for Franklin, at one point lifting his book bag back onto his shoulders after its straps slipped down, loosely binding his arms behind him.\n\nHardship struck in late 2013. The family lost their Section 8 apartment, forcing Ms. Matthias, her children and their father into a homeless shelter. The unfamiliar surroundings affected Franklin\u2019s mental health, causing him great anxiety. Ms. Matthias feared that Nevaeh felt ashamed. And the stress reignited a dormant vice for Ms. Matthias: shoplifting.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt gave me a high that I couldn\u2019t find anywhere else,\u201d she said. \u201cWhen you\u2019re doing it, you just think you\u2019re being mischievous.\u201d\n\nWhenever Ms. Matthias stole, she said, the item was frivolous, the action done solely for a momentary rush. In spring 2014, the habit sent the family careening into disarray. After a court appearance related to a shoplifting charge, Ms. Matthias bought a birthday present for her nephew and then went to a Walmart, where she stole baby formula, which she had no need for. She was arrested on the spot.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen she returned to court, she was charged with petty larceny. The judge accused her of endangering her children, which sent Ms. Matthias into hysterics. The city\u2019s Administration for Children\u2019s Services took Franklin and Nevaeh into custody.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was mush,\u201d Ms. Matthias recalled. \u201cFor the first time, I felt totally helpless.\u201d\n\nShe served 56 days in Westchester County Correction, during which she missed Franklin\u2019s birthday and Nevaeh\u2019s kindergarten graduation. Her guilt and shame were so overwhelming that she refused to have her children visit.\n\nAfter Ms. Matthias\u2019s release, she sought immediate help from Children\u2019s Aid, one of the eight organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Social workers helped her regain custody of the children less than two months after her release.\n\nMs. Matthias and her children\u2019s father separated around the same time, though he is still involved in their lives. She and the children re-entered the shelter system.\n\nIn late 2014, Ms. Matthias began attending Cleptomaniacs and Shoplifters Anonymous meetings. Receiving Nevaeh\u2019s forgiveness was a huge boost to her willpower, she said, but the meetings were vital to understanding that she was not the only one battling such a compulsion. They also pushed her to stay mindful of her actions\u2019 consequences.\n\n\u201cI know the right direction is to always look for the help that I need,\u201d Ms. Matthias said. \u201cIf I don\u2019t know what direction I\u2019m going, I know where to go to get the help.\u201d\n\nMs. Matthias\u2019s support network has a hole since her mother, who used to call Ms. Matthias and her children every day, died in March 2016.\n\n\u201cI miss that lady,\u201d Ms. Matthias said in a pained whisper.\n\nIn late 2016, the family secured a new apartment in the Bronx. Finances remain tight. Ms. Matthias, who does not work, receives $735 in Social Security disability for Franklin, $100 in welfare and $180 in food stamps each month. Social workers at Children\u2019s Aid used $1,500 in Neediest Cases funds to buy the family new furniture.\n\nMs. Matthias says Nevaeh is thriving in school. Franklin recently transitioned into a specialized high school, and Ms. Matthias says she has few worries about his development.\n\nWhen she cries, the tears she sheds are for her mother. She knows one day her children will face the same loss and takes comfort in her belief that Nevaeh will never leave her brother\u2019s side.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI know she\u2019s going to be there for him,\u201d Ms. Matthias said. \u201cWhen I\u2019m gone, they got each other.\u201d", "title": "A Mother\u2019s Determination Withstands Years of Tumult", "authors": ["John Otis", "The Neediest Cases Fund"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The mummified child, who died at two years old, was buried in the Basilica of Saint Domenico Maggiore in Naples during the 16th century. The researchers who have worked there acknowledge some of the emotional challenges to studying the toddler\u2019s remains.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s this hollowness yet this ghostlike pain still there which is fascinating from a scientific perspective but horrific from a parental perspective,\u201d said Hendrik Poinar, an evolutionary geneticist at McMaster University in Ontario and an author of the recent paper.\n\nIn the crypt, the child\u2019s coffin rests near dozens of other wooden burial boxes, some of which held the bodies of Aragonese princes and Neapolitan nobles. Their corpses were clothed in decorated woven fabrics and precious silk. Many were embalmed but some were naturally mummified by the dry conditions of the basilica.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe mummies of San Domenico Maggiore are unique in Italy not only for the antiquity and excellent state of preservation of the bodies,\u201d Gino Fornaciari, a paleopathologist at the University of Pisa and an author of the paper, said in an email, \u201cbut also for the fame of the personages, whose lives and causes of death are well known.\u201d\n\nDr. Fornaciari first studied the child mummy in the 1980s. Using an electron microscope he found what he thought were traces of smallpox, also known as variola virus, in its remains. Since then the child has served as a quintessential example of early European smallpox. That made it a prime target for Dr. Holmes and his colleagues who have tried to map out the timeline and diversity of the smallpox virus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2016, Dr. Holmes and his team had found traces of smallpox in a 17th century Lithuanian mummy. By re-examining the Naples mummy with molecular tools, they expected to push back the timeline of smallpox in Europe another hundred years.\n\n\u201cThat was the hope, that this would be a slam dunk,\u201d Dr. Poinar said. \u201cBut it\u2019s never a slam dunk when you think it\u2019s a slam dunk.\u201d\n\nInstead, when they sequenced the genome of the child mummy and performed their molecular analysis they found no trace of the smallpox virus. But they did find evidence of the hepatitis B virus.\n\nMore Reporting on Archaeology\n\nAt first they did not pay much attention to the finding. Then they realized that a symptom of hepatitis B infection in children is a facial rash called Gianotti-Crosti syndrome. They thought perhaps the hepatitis B virus caused the dots on the child\u2019s mummified face.\n\nThey performed another molecular analysis and found that the genetic information they extracted from the ancient hepatitis B virus resembled that of a modern-day hepatitis B virus genome. To the researchers, that was a red flag for contamination.\n\nThey spent the next year and a half trying to figure out whether they had actually found traces of ancient hepatitis B virus, or whether instead the virus they found was a contaminant from one of the researchers who uncovered the mummy in the 1980s. As hepatitis B infections were common in Italy at that time, Dr. Poinar said it was possible that the virus signals they saw were from contamination.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFurther analysis showed that the genetic material from the hepatitis B virus they found on the mummy was damaged in much the same way that genetic information from the mummy itself was damaged. That indicated that it was similarly as old. But to further corroborate their hunch, the team performed an evolutionary analysis using several other old strains of hepatitis B virus, and found that the virus itself evolves very slowly. That suggests that in a period of about 500 years, the hepatitis B virus has not changed much.\n\nDr. Poinar and Dr. Holmes said they are confident that they found perhaps the earliest evidence of hepatitis B infection in Italy, but would not completely rule out the possibility of contamination.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m 80-20 at this point, or maybe 90-10, that it\u2019s not contamination,\u201d Dr. Poinar said.", "title": "A Mummified Child\u2019s Remains Show Signs of a Modern Scourge", "authors": ["Nicholas St. Fleur"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "It also assumes a fair amount of familiarity with Judaism; unlike the previous presentation, it declines to enumerate basic facts about the religion, from the nature of monotheism to the demographics of the diaspora. Walking away from a \u201cmaster narrative,\u201d in favor of discrete \u201cscenes\u201d (as an introductory text here states), the Jewish Museum now offers a nimbler and lighter perspective on art and faith. In places, this feels exciting; in others, the curators may have scrapped too much and added too little.\n\nIn \u201cConstellations,\u201d a grab bag of an opening gallery, artworks and Jewish ceremonial objects play off one another in aesthetically pleasing, if historically nebulous, counterpoint. A papier-m\u00e2ch\u00e9 costume of a golem (a mythical creature brought to life from clay) designed by Robert Wilson for a stage production stands next to an ornate dress of the sort worn by Sephardic brides in 19th-century Morocco, garlanded with gold ribbons and passementerie. A vitrine of chanukkiyot, or nine-stemmed menorahs, is smaller and more judiciously curated than one from the previous collection display, and includes examples from baroque Germany, 18th-century Venice and big-hair Los Angeles of the 1980s, where the Memphis designer Peter Shire crafted a cantilevered candelabra of pastel steel. Early paintings by Mark Rothko and Eva Hesse reveal two young refugees, one from imperial Russia and one fleeing Nazi Germany, feeling their way to new visual languages.\n\nThere are fluffed notes. A Torah ark from Sioux City, Iowa, dating to 1899 and featuring a profusion of carved lions, eagles and flora, stands next to an equally ornate but far more rigid portrait of an Ethiopian Israeli by Kehinde Wiley that, as so often in this painter\u2019s work, drowns complex political and historical circumstances in formulaic ornament. This is an example of what nonchronological hangs get wrong: favoring easy visual rhymes \u2014 in this case carved wood and floral embellishments \u2014 over deep engagement with time, place and method. Beyond the ruptured timeline, this is actually quite a conservative way of displaying art \u2014 closer to a 17th-century princely collection than a modern scientific museum.", "title": "A Museum\u2019s Fresh Take on the Whole Megillah", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Henrietta Red, a restaurant in the Germantown neighborhood of Nashville that opened last February , has many of the telltale trappings of Instagram clickbait. While there\u2019s no millennial pink, the black sandwich board and expanse of marble at the bar, coupled with the wishbone chairs and tile-framed wood-burning oven in the dining room, fit a certain envy-inducing aesthetic. But unlike other places that hit those idealized notes, Henrietta Red lives up to its image as a place you actually want to be.\n\nStart your meal with something fun \u2014 a craft cocktail Jell-O shot, perhaps. The potent, jiggly cubes offer reassurance that, despite the restaurant\u2019s cool interior, it\u2019s O.K. to relax. They come are offered in flavors like Fernet and Coke, are served skewered, and, like liquid cocktails, come with a garnish.\n\nNext up are more things to slurp. One of the goals of Julia Sullivan, the chef and an owner, who opened the restaurant with the general manager and sommelier Allie Poindexter, was to fill the void in Nashville\u2019s oysterscape. A small, perfectly nice selection hailing from both coasts, Canada and the Gulf, comes with a seasonal mignonette (in our case, juicy watermelon) in addition to the usual condiments. The best oysters, though, come out of the wood-burning oven, slathered with a grassy pesto-like green curry then cooked until custardy.", "title": "A Nashville Restaurant That Tastes as Good as It Looks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "ESSEN, Germany \u2014 The mood among the comrades was restive.\n\nTwo dozen members of the local chapter of the Social Democratic Party patiently sat through the order of the day \u2014 public toilets, the closure of a slaughterhouse \u2014 until discussion finally turned to agenda item No. 8.\n\nIt was the question all were waiting for: Should their proud but ailing party join Chancellor Angela Merkel in another coalition government \u2014 despite having categorically ruled it out for most of last year?\n\n\u201cComrades,\u201d Matthias Vollstedt, the jovial bow-tie-wearing leader of the local party chapter, asked the eclectic group of workers, students, civil servants and pensioners, age 22 to 82, \u201cis there anyone in the room who actually wants this?\u201d\n\nNot a single hand went up.\n\nTherein lies a potentially major stumbling block not only for Ms. Merkel, but for all of Europe, which has been waiting for Germany to form a government for three and a half months since its inconclusive September election.", "title": "A New Coalition With Merkel? Not So Fast", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "AT 2 MINUTES 44 SECONDS\n\nMusical Paradise\n\nThe first sex scene in Gregory Spears and Greg Pierce\u2019s opera \u201cFellow Travelers,\u201d which had its New York premiere last weekend, begins with vacation plans. \u201cI should take you to Bermuda,\u201d Hawk, a State Department employee in Washington, D.C., says to Tim, an idealistic newcomer from New York. As the men slowly remove their clothes, Hawk (the baritone Joseph Lattanzi) describes tree groves and \u201csand as white as milk\u201d and repeatedly tells Tim (the tenor Aaron Blake) \u201cI\u2019ll show you.\u201d Once they are finally in bed together, the music swells as they sing \u201cBermuda!\u201d The music here is beautiful, if a bit wistful. This is a gay romance in the time of McCarthy and the \u201clavender scare,\u201d and they know that their paradise is \u201cas far away as it sounds.\u201d JOSHUA BARONE\n\nRead our review of \u201cFellow Travelers.\u201d", "title": "A New Gay Opera: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments of the Week on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "But as he stood next to his two choices to fix the state\u2019s infrastructure \u2014 Mr. Corbett and Diane Gutierrez-Scaccetti, his choice to lead the Department of Transportation \u2014 Mr. Murphy noted that New Jersey Transit would not be turned around overnight.\n\n\u201cI ask for your patience as we start to rebuild this agency,\u201d he said.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Corbett said that since word of his nomination leaked last week, he has been hearing from friends wishing him well, but also sharing their grievances.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve had people calling me that\u2019s just like a therapy session,\u201d he said, promising that once he takes charge, \u201cthe right kind of people are going to feel like they just had a heavy backpack taken off their back.\u201d\n\nMr. Corbett, whose nomination needs to be approved by the transit agency\u2019s board of directors, said his immediate focus would be on hiring and safety.\n\nThe deadly crash at the Hoboken Terminal, which killed a woman and injured over 100 people, brought attention to New Jersey Transit\u2019s delay in installing positive train control, an emergency-braking system that Congress said had to be completed by 2015 (the railroad was later granted a three-year extension).\n\nBut as of last September, only 7 percent of the hardware necessary for new system had been installed, just 125 of the 2,200 components. And of the 1,100 workers who need to be certified for the new system only 137 had completed the process, according to the Federal Railroad Administration\n\nThe likelihood that the agency can finish everything by the end of this year seems remote. The agency was already fined $12,000 this month for failing to meet deadlines.", "title": "A New Leader for a Troubled New Jersey Transit", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI am going against normal protocols,\u201d Sheriff Lombardo said, adding that he hoped the preliminary report would \u201cquell the zest for information.\u201d\n\nThe report offers extensive details about Mr. Paddock\u2019s actions and planning in the time leading up to the attack. Here are some of the key takeaways:\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Mr. Paddock \u201clived a seemingly normal life,\u201d the investigators wrote, based on numerous interviews with relatives and acquaintances. He began traveling internationally \u2014 usually alone \u2014 in 2012, going to Europe, Asia and South America, and he took cruises to the Bahamas, Mexico and Alaska.\n\n\u2022 Mr. Paddock complained often to friends and family members about pain and fatigue. But the doctor who had been his primary care physician since 2009 said that the only major ailment he had was from a slip and fall at a casino in 2013, when he tore a muscle. The doctor told investigators that Mr. Paddock was \u201codd\u201d and showed \u201clittle emotion.\u201d While he believed Mr. Paddock may have had bipolar disorder, Mr. Paddock refused to discuss it or take antidepressants, though he did accept anti-anxiety medication. Mr. Paddock often refused to take medication, he said.\n\n\u2022 Over more than three decades \u2014 from 1982 through the fall of 2016 \u2014 Mr. Paddock bought 29 firearms, including handguns, shotguns and one rifle. Such purchases accelerated beginning in October 2016: He bought more than 55 firearms in less than a year, mostly rifles. He also bought more than 100 firearm-related items such as scopes, ammunition and bump stocks in the year before the attack.\n\n\u2022 Ms. Danley told investigators that Mr. Paddock\u2019s demeanor changed during the last year \u2014 he became \u201cdistant\u201d and \u201ctheir relationship was no longer intimate.\u201d He became \u201cgermaphobic\u201d and had strong reactions to smells. During a stay at the Mandalay Bay in early September, Ms. Danley said he had behaved strangely, and constantly looked out the windows of the room and at the concert venue below from different angles.\n\n\u2022 Mr. Paddock appeared to begin thinking about a mass shooting last May, searching on Google for \u201csummer concerts 2017\u201d and \u201cbiggest open air concert venues in USA.\u201d In early September he searched for \u201cLas Vegas high rise condos rent\u201d and \u201clife is beautiful expected attendance,\u201d a reference to another large outdoor concert in Las Vegas that month. Two weeks later, he looked for \u201cswat weapons,\u201d \u201cballistics chart 308,\u201d \u201cSWAT Las Vegas,\u201d and \u201cdo police use explosives.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Mr. Paddock stayed in a room at the Ogden condominium complex on Sept. 17, during the Life is Beautiful music festival, requesting rooms that overlooked the downtown outdoor venue there. In video surveillance, Mr. Paddock could be seen taking several suitcases from his vehicle to his rooms. He was always alone and investigators so far \u201chave been unable to determine if Paddock intended an attack during this festival or if he used it as a means to plan a future attack,\u201d the report said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 On Sept. 25, Mr. Paddock checked into room 32-135 at the Mandalay Bay and checked into the room next door four days later, under Ms. Danley\u2019s name.\n\n\u2022 On his first night at the hotel, Mr. Paddock had dinner at a sushi restaurant inside the hotel and returned to the front desk with five suitcases. The next day, he took seven more suitcases up to his room with the bellman.\n\n\u2022 On Sept. 27, Mr. Paddock spent the entire night gambling, not stopping until 7 the next morning. The next day, he went to Mesquite and purchased a .308 bolt-action rifle, deposited $14,000 into a Wells Fargo account and transferred $50,000 to an account in the Philippines. He stopped at a gun range before going back to the hotel. He gambled through the night again. On Sept. 30, he brought four more suitcases to his room just before 6 a.m. and two additional one at 3:20 p.m.\n\n\u2022 On Oct 1., at about 10 p.m., a hotel security guard named Jesus Campos arrived on the 32nd floor to respond to an alarm set off by an open door to another room. He was shot a few minutes later, just after Mr. Paddock opened fire on the crowd below.", "title": "A New Report on the Las Vegas Gunman Was Released. Here Are Some Takeaways.", "authors": ["Jennifer Medina"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "At the International Culinary Center in California and New York, known for turning out acclaimed pastry chefs like Christina Tosi, of Milk Bar, and Melissa Weller, the founder of Sadelle\u2019s bakery in SoHo, architecture plays a significant role in the curriculum, thanks to Mr. Chan, 42, and his architectural background.\n\nSince 2015, the second half of the school\u2019s six-month pastry program has incorporated lessons on sketching, making timelines and project planning. Mr. Chan added a chapter called \u201cElements of Design\u201d to the school\u2019s textbook; it teaches students about architectural principles like dynamism and scale in relation to dessert.\n\nMr. Chan said a number of students have recently come to the school from the architecture world. \u201cThey have a much easier time at adapting because they are used to being asked questions. They are better able to express their creative ideas,\u201d he said. \u201cPastry students with no design backgrounds will be the ones to draw a tall chocolate structure with nothing holding it up.\u201d\n\nMr. Chan has also introduced technology into pastry education \u2014 tools like lasers, which can be used to bake and pipe batter at the same time, and water-jet cutters, used by architects to slice through sheet metal and by large-scale patisseries and hotels for cutting cakes into precise, programmed shapes in the half the time it would take a person to complete.\n\nNot everyone endorses this approach, though. \u201cArchitecture and pastry are both very human schools of thought,\u201d said Ms. Yee, who makes the un-strudel-like strudel. \u201cYou are always thinking about what people will like. This kind of technology, to me, dehumanizes food. You\u2019re taking away the personal aspect of cooking.\u201d\n\nSome blame technology for the glorification of social-media oddities like clear pumpkin pie, or ice cream wrapped in a cloud of cotton candy.\n\nMr. Chan recalled encountering a red velvet cake at a bakery in Thailand on a recent trip.\n\n\u201cIt resembled a red velvet cake,\u201d he said, \u201cbut it didn\u2019t have any cocoa. Someone had seen it online but didn\u2019t take the time to look up what, actually, is in a red velvet cake. That\u2019s the problem with social media. You lose context. Architects are the opposite \u2014 we\u2019re invested in the process.\u201d\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A New School of Pastry Chefs Got Its Start in Architecture", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE MANNEQUIN MAKERS\n\nBy Craig Cliff\n\n325 pp. Milkweed Editions. Paper, $16.\n\nMuch has been written and sung about the way distance and the isolation it breeds have shaped the identities of those Europeans who settled in New Zealand. From the music of Split Enz to Eleanor Catton\u2019s novel \u201cThe Luminaries,\u201d stories of colonizers who crossed perilous seas to carve out a facsimile of an old society in a strange land are more than familiar. In his debut novel, the New Zealand writer Craig Cliff adds to the canon, but with such ambition, creativity and sheer energy that he shows there\u2019s still something new to say about a national narrative that can seem, at times, to hold no surprises.\n\nIn \u201cThe Mannequin Makers,\u201d Cliff makes real a desolate, windswept country at the turn of the early 20th century and beyond, a place populated by men and women who have learned that life is hard, and that it can be borne only by keeping one\u2019s feelings carefully trammeled. It is the preoccupation of many a New Zealand novel and at the beginning of this one, things seem to fall into a familiar pattern. In the small town of Marumaru on the North Island\u2019s east coast, Colton Kemp\u2019s wife dies while pregnant and, unable to acknowledge what has happened, he goes about his business in town that day without divulging the news to anyone, pretending she is still alive.\n\nBut there is already an inkling that this will be more than another story about a quiet man: Kemp is a carver of department store mannequins, and not an especially good one. In another establishment across town, his rival, known as The Carpenter, does not have Kemp\u2019s imagination, but his mannequins are startlingly lifelike, incurring Kemp\u2019s bitter jealousy.\n\nFrom there, the tale takes flight in a way that comes close to magic realism, with the characters and events falling into a gothic swoon. In his grief over the loss of his wife, Kemp commits an act so heinous that it sets in motion a story almost Shakespearean in scope. To divulge more would spoil a rollicking plot, but it isn\u2019t revealing too much to say that Cliff\u2019s background as a short story writer gives him a rare skill with the minutiae of structure and characterization. The book is split into four entwined narratives, each from a different point of view, with Kemp\u2019s just the first. A headstrong teenage girl and a man who cannot speak are rich standouts of the book\u2019s second and third acts; Cliff paints the 16-year-old girl as kind and resilient while never overplaying her innocence. It\u2019s one of several tightropes he steps onto with quiet assurance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLater, in mute, elderly Gabriel Doig, the reader is delivered an immensely satisfying account of shipwreck and survival. That the tale is conveyed in writing to another character, because Doig cannot speak, and that it arrives obviously laden with Cliff\u2019s own research of the historical context, could easily have resulted in unwieldy storytelling. Instead, the book soars.\n\nIn the final section, another change of narrator and a jump forward to 1970s Australia bring about the denouement. This is the only place Cliff seems to falter; he has much to reveal about his new storyteller while also needing to wrangle a sprawling plot. Events unspool perhaps a little slowly in the beginning of this section and then rather too quickly toward the end, leaving the characters\u2019 motivations, and the truths we are eager to learn, somewhat occluded.", "title": "A New Zealand Novel Full of Taciturn Men and Wooden Dolls", "authors": ["Charlotte Graham-Mclay", "Craig Cliff"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nJennifer Finney Boylan (\u201cThat\u2019s What Ze Said,\u201d Op-Ed, Jan. 10) argues that English needs a non-gender-specific pronoun, and that we should therefore accede to any person\u2019s demand to be called by any personal pronoun of choice, as she does for her students at Barnard.\n\nI can accept the first part of this argument, but not the second. English, an evolving language, can accommodate a new, standard, non-gendered personal pronoun, and is capable of settling on one after a period of experimental usage, as it did with \u201cMs.\u201d But to accept anyone\u2019s requested vanity pronoun is to invite chaos, strain the limits of memory and elevate narcissism above consensus communication. It is also to normalize something more dangerous: the deployment of extreme individualism in the service of political power over institutional and linguistic conventions.\n\nJESSE LARNER, NEW YORK\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nIn a 1947 reader competition, published in the magazine Alphabet and Image, Ian Fleming proposed the idea of a 27th letter of the alphabet. Given today\u2019s gender and identity fluidity, perhaps it\u2019s time to reopen the notion, so that the letter would represent those who eschew \u201che\u201d or \u201cshe,\u201d or as Jennifer Finney Boylan might add, \u201chir,\u201d \u201cze\u201d or \u201cxem.\u201d\n\nJEFFREY J. SUSLA\n\nWOODSTOCK, CONN.\n\nThe writer teaches writing at the University of Hartford.", "title": "Opinion | A Non-Gendered Pronoun", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The friendship/hateship between Susan and Ro, the ways in which each experiences the mere existence of the other as both a reproach and a criticism, is one of the great delights of this lyrical and beautifully observed reflection on women\u2019s lives. Ro cannot stop thinking of Susan\u2019s offhand remark that \u201cyou don\u2019t truly become an adult until you have kids.\u201d Susan is preoccupied with the thought of Ro\u2019s questioning her reasons for changing her surname: \u201cHow come nobody\u2019s allowed to criticize a woman\u2019s decision to give up her name for a man\u2019s name? Just because it\u2019s her choice? I can think of some other bad choices that\u2014.\u201d Both women keep lists: Ro\u2019s is a self-flagellating inventory of reasons it\u2019s a bad idea for an unwed 42-year-old to raise a child; Susan\u2019s is a lengthy accounting of the unrelenting and grindingly dull routine of raising children: \u201cHerd crumbs into palm. Spray table. Wipe down table. Rinse cups and bowls,\u201d and on and on. Susan\u2019s resentment of Ro\u2019s rich intellectual life means the exhausted mother can\u2019t empathize with the single teacher\u2019s loneliness. But Ro\u2019s corresponding resentment of Susan\u2019s full family life means she can\u2019t empathize, either, with her friend\u2019s boredom and despair. These carefully chosen details feel urgent in our present moment, when women are constantly encouraged to compete with one another to attain an unattainable ideal of our gender.\n\nIf there is a criticism to be made of this highly absorbing novel, it is that it feels perhaps a shade too contemporary, and never quite reveals the horrors that would surely follow if the pre-Roe v. Wade days were to repeat themselves. The one disaster that has occurred \u2014 to Mattie\u2019s friend Yasmine \u2014 is elided from the action of the novel, and rendered soft-focus and ambiguous. The reader is left to wonder what it would be like to be a pregnant teenager of color under these new laws. Mattie\u2019s journey to try to terminate her pregnancy is far less demeaning and terrifying than the hardships endured by some women living in states with few legal, safe abortion clinics. Gin stands trial, but it\u2019s clear from early on that the forces conspiring against her would have seen her accused of a crime with or without the new laws. Having read one\u2019s Paley, one feels while reading Zumas\u2019s book that yes, this imagined dystopia is terrible, but the reality would be far worse.\n\nMaybe, though, it is almost impossible to write the truth about these things without seeming \u2014 how like a woman! \u2014 hysterical. As with the return of fascism and the measles outbreak, it\u2019s difficult to believe that mere foolishness and complacency could return us to the bad old days until we actually see it happen. And the novel gives the reader much to enjoy in the meantime. Zumas is a skillful writer, expertly keeping each of her characters in balanced motion, never allowing one to dominate the rest. Her cunning device of not revealing the name of each character in the sections she narrates grants us a multidimensional perspective on all four women, highlighting their roles in one another\u2019s stories. It\u2019s a beautiful metaphor for the interdependence of women\u2019s lives \u2014 for the way that, as Paley would remind us, the laws that imprison or criminalize one of us narrow the options for all of us.\n\nFloating over the narrative of \u201cRed Clocks,\u201d too, is the figure of Eivor Minervudottir, the subject of Ro\u2019s biography. This Arctic explorer\u2019s fierce yet cool interest in the natural world provides Zumas\u2019s suggested answer to the question: What is a woman when she is by herself? If, as Virginia Woolf posited, \u201ca woman must have \u2026 a room of her own\u201d \u2014 and, one is tempted to add, a womb of her own \u2014 to be able to create, then why are we so fearful of what nonsexual, nonreproductive passions could emerge from female solitude? And, if Minervudottir\u2019s tale never quite coheres, never quite touches the rest of the book, then her very ice-floe remoteness becomes a stark reminder of our society\u2019s detachment from a world in which a woman could simply and happily be left alone.", "title": "A Novel That Asks, What if Abortion Were Again Illegal?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA STATE OF FREEDOM\n\nBy Neel Mukherjee\n\n278 pp. W.W. Norton. $25.95\n\nNeel Mukherjee likes to keep his titles a bit abstract, suggesting a mood or even an ethical choice, but conveying nothing about a book\u2019s characters or setting or plot. His first novel, \u201cA Life Apart,\u201d published in 2010, could be about almost anything; in practice it begins with an Indian student at Oxford and then moves in on the London sex trade. His 2014 novel, \u201cThe Lives of Others,\u201d shares its name with an earlier Oscar-winning German film, but those words fit beautifully onto its complex story of political and familial turmoil in Bengal. Both books have a 19th-century plenitude of detail, but it\u2019s the 19th century of Zola rather than Dickens. They\u2019re works of rub-your-nose-in-it naturalism, unforgiving and emotionally draining, books that make you squirm, and think. That\u2019s especially true of his latest novel, \u201cA State of Freedom.\u201d Except this title is less open-ended than it seems, and in using it Mukherjee has something very specific in mind: He has his eye on one crucial literary predecessor.\n\nV. S. Naipaul\u2019s \u201cIn a Free State\u201d won the Booker Prize in 1971, just a few years after it was established to recognize the year\u2019s best fiction from Britain and its former colonies. The award has had a better record than most: Many of its winners have stood the test of time and their tally includes remarkably few embarrassments. But \u201cIn a Free State\u201d stands out, even in a list that includes \u201cDisgrace\u201d and \u201cPossession,\u201d \u201cMidnight\u2019s Children\u201d and \u201cWolf Hall.\u201d It is dark and bitter and grand, and its prose mixes despair with a sense of majesty. Naipaul divides the book into five sections, each about people in motion from one continent to another, and frames its different narratives with a prologue and an epilogue whose cadences match his own autobiographical writing. No character reappears from one part to the next, but the book is unified by its sense of freedom as a disruptive force, as though its people were unmoored in something other than a physical sense.\n\nCalcutta-born and London-based, Mukherjee has twice been a finalist for the now-renamed Man Booker Prize, and this new novel stands as an echo of Naipaul\u2019s great work. The first of its five semi-independent sections concerns an expatriate Indian academic, a man bent on showing the Moghul remains of northern India to his American son: the Taj Mahal over lunch and then an hour\u2019s drive to the abandoned 16th-century capital of Fatehpur Sikri. He\u2019s a worried father, concerned that he \u201cmight have imposed too much on a 6-year-old,\u201d but he drags the boy along just the same, and grows irritated at his inattentiveness. He\u2019s also horrified at their driver\u2019s breakneck pace and dismayed by the beggars and touts, for whom his guidebook marks him as prey. America has made him soft; he\u2019s lost \u201cthe easy Indian ability to bark at people considered as servants.\u201d In other hands this might be comic, but Mukherjee begins on a foreboding note, and so as we read we wait for something to happen, something bad.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the way back from Fatehpur Sikri the car passes a fox-faced man with \u201ca mustache that seemed alive,\u201d leading a trained bear along the roadside. While Mukherjee\u2019s unhappy professor will vanish from the book, the bear\u2019s owner, Lakshman, reappears in its third section, as though the novelist had decided to imagine a life for a man glimpsed from the window of a moving car.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLakshman finds the cub near his village in the mountains and saves it from the cruelty of the local children, only to inflict a further cruelty of his own. The keepers of dancing bears are traditionally Muslims, known as \u201cqalandars\u201d; Lakshman, a Hindu, doesn\u2019t so much train the animal as beat it into submission, having first gotten its canines knocked out. Nevertheless the bear soon acquires a name, Raju, and a character, and when Lakshman runs away from the cares of village life, from his family and his debts, Raju becomes his only companion. This is the hardest of Mukherjee\u2019s narratives to read, but it\u2019s also the most original and the most beautifully written. (On a morning when \u201cthe heat is beginning to bare its teeth,\u201d the man and his bear must \u201ccleave to the shaded areas.\u201d)", "title": "A Novel That Echoes Naipaul, Exploring the Limits of Freedom", "authors": ["Michael Gorra", "Neel Mukherjee"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "KING ZENO\n\nBy Nathaniel Rich\n\n386 pp. MCD/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $28.\n\nA street preacher, perhaps the most minor of characters in Nathaniel Rich\u2019s ambitious and metaphorically dense third novel, \u201cKing Zeno,\u201d hangs moralistic signs on the back of his church wagon. One is about John Barleycorn. Another \u2014 we\u2019re in New Orleans in 1918 \u2014 reads, \u201cJAZZ KILLS.\u201d This is a tiny, atmospheric touch, viewed through the window of a police captain\u2019s office while prominent characters discuss an investigation into serial ax murders, but like nearly every detail in this novel of digging and questing, it has figurative resonance. The novel makes clear that jazz does indeed kill \u2014 not by its decadence, as the proselytist suggests, but by its novelty, its ingenuity. Jazz kills the old art forms, rag and swing. Jazz enacts violence on a song \u2014 one band is shown \u201cteasing apart the \u2018Tiger Rag\u2019 like an old sweater until it unraveled into something unrecognizable and frightening.\u201d And jazz assaults the listener \u2014 \u201cSlaughter me dead!\u201d one audience member screams during a show. In its diabolical innovation jazz is dangerous, and as such it is an ideal subject for a novel that roils with the inseparable energies of creation and destruction.\n\nJazz is but one of numerous intricate subjects that Rich admits into the novel. Others include World War I, the Spanish flu epidemic, serial murder, police procedures, race relations, the New Orleans Mafia, and the construction of the Industrial Canal, which links Lake Pontchartrain to the Mississippi River (and whose catastrophic breach during Hurricane Katrina looms meaningfully over the book: PROGRESS KILLS). Rich, a resident of New Orleans, throws his arms wide open to history and to the city, and \u201cKing Zeno,\u201d particularly in its first half, is as unruly and laterally active as a big urban novel ought to be. And the novel, like a city, somehow coheres, as Rich never loses control of the riotous raw material. The close third-person point of view rotates among three central figures, providing pattern and the promise of convergence; the mysterious ax murders serve as a narrative through-line; the canal exerts centripetal and allegorical force; and the extraordinary American yearning of the characters, as in Stephen Millhauser\u2019s \u201cMartin Dressler\u201d or E. L. Doctorow\u2019s \u201cThe Waterworks,\u201d is a constantly propulsive force.\n\nDespite his large canvas, Rich is a gifted portraitist of his three main characters. One is William Bastrop, a detective in the New Orleans Police Department who is haunted by recent experiences in the war. Bastrop has not been forthright to his wife, Maisie, nor to himself, about what happened in a besieged dugout in France, where many of his fellow soldiers died. One of the ghosts from his past turns out to be real \u2014 an eye-patched, trench-coated fellow soldier seeking revenge for Bastrop\u2019s cowardice \u2014 and Bastrop must escape harm and then confront his own trauma and fraudulence. Maisie (or Maze), after learning the truth about France, moves out. To save his marriage and to regain a sense of purpose and integrity, Bastrop decides, roughly midway through the novel, that he must solve the ax murder case. \u201cThis was no longer police work, at least not only police work. By solving this unsolvable case, he would solve Maze. He would prove his courage, regain his confidence.\u201d At this point his character achieves velocity and direction \u2014 he becomes a dramatic vector, a supersleuth.\n\nImage\n\nThe second central character is a Creole musician named Isadore Zeno. Isadore is a startlingly original cornet player who longs to be the king of New Orleans jazz, to make a new music that \u201cwould live forever, flowing from one generation to the next down the river of time into the sea of immortality.\u201d But listeners are not quite ready for Isadore\u2019s sound, and he is frustrated by his lack of good gigs. Zeno has a pregnant wife and he needs steady work. He dabbles in armed robbery, but ultimately goes straight, working as a canal digger and a cooper. For a time he forsakes the cornet, but eventually he resolves, roughly midway through the novel, to be both a family man and a jazzman. (As the son of a trumpet player, I was perhaps inordinately curious about how Zeno achieves and maintains his brilliance without seeming to practice.) When the hysteria surrounding the Axman gives Zeno an odd opportunity to take the stage, he very creatively capitalizes on the widespread fear. This daring and desperate move \u2014 somewhat convenient, dramatically speaking \u2014 furthers Zeno\u2019s music career, and also puts him on a dangerous course toward both the Axman and Bastrop.", "title": "A Novel of 1918 New Orleans, With Murder and All That Jazz", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "THE NOTHING\n\nBy Hanif Kureishi\n\n167 pp. Faber & Faber. $22.\n\n\u201cOne night, when I am old, sick, right out of semen, and don\u2019t need things to get any worse, I hear the noises again,\u201d is the arresting first sentence of Hanif Kureishi\u2019s new novel, \u201cThe Nothing.\u201d The man hearing noises is Waldo, a Bafta-winning filmmaker now staring down his 80s, in a wheelchair and in terminal physical decline, who sits at the window of his Victoria flat, like Jimmy Stewart in \u201cRear Window,\u201d observing the goings-on of his neighbors through binoculars. \u201cThere is a world within this London mansion block,\u201d he notes, and later: \u201cDinner parties are more riveting than wars, and are always an occasion for a close-up. But there\u2019s no sex.\u201d\n\nHang on. I thought you said this was a Hanif Kureishi book? I want my money back. Kureishi is the Londoner (of Pakistani descent) who wrote the 1985 Daniel Day Lewis film \u201cMy Beautiful Laundrette\u201d and arrived on the literary scene with the 1990 novel \u201cThe Buddha of Suburbia,\u201d a bi-curious picaresque whose wily mixed-race hero bed-hopped his way out of the London suburbs. \u201cAlways put your penis first,\u201d a wise old writer tells the main character in \u201cThe Last Word\u201d (2014), a directive every Kureishi protagonist has done his best to heed, with Waldo no exception. A once studly young buck in flares, love beads, shoulder-length black hair and \u201can ass you\u2019d pay to bite,\u201d he now lives with his wife, Zee, 22 years his junior, who feeds and washes his failing body. \u201cI am, I\u2019ve realized at last, the sort of fool who wants to be loved exclusively,\u201d he says.\n\nBut Waldo\u2019s imagination is not going quietly into the night. Convinced Zee is having an affair with a longtime pal of his, a down-at-the-heels film critic and Soho gadfly called Eddie who spends nights at their flat under the pretext of helping Zee with her nursing duties, Waldo goes to bed, feigns sleep, turns up his hearing aid and lets his mind run wild: \u201cWorking with sound and my imagination, I envisage the angles and cuts, making the only substantial films I can manage these days, mind movies.\u201d\n\nImage Credit Sonny Figueroa/The New York Times\n\nThe idea of a celibate Hanif Kureishi hero tormented by the very urges he once indulged is an excellent one \u2014 think Philip Roth in a chastity belt. Given the current cultural and political climate, in fact, that idea may have even more than usual appeal. The unfettered license that male writers have enjoyed when it comes to holding up every stain in the sheets as a palimpsest of their smarting, solipsistic souls is due for an overhaul. Sexual jealousy has produced many a major and minor classic, from Saul Bellow\u2019s \u201cHerzog\u201d to Patrick Hamilton\u2019s \u201cHangover Square\u201d and Julian Barnes\u2019s \u201cBefore She Met Me,\u201d but the trick of these books lies in the skill with which the writer evokes, through the heat haze of the protagonist\u2019s obsession, the bobbing horizon line of reality, however fleetingly glimpsed. There must be more to \u201cLolita\u201d than just Humbert Humbert\u2019s lust.", "title": "A Novel of the Horndog in Winter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cPentagon Plan Would Expand Nuclear Policy\u201d (front page, Jan. 17):\n\nAs we expand the circumstances that could precipitate nuclear war, the importance of a prudent, experienced president and government officials who influence his decisions becomes more apparent.\n\nWe should heed the warning of Andrew C. Weber, an assistant defense secretary in the Obama administration, who is quoted as saying, \u201cAlmost everything about this radical new policy will blur the line between nuclear and conventional.\u201d If adopted, he said, the new policy \u201cwill make nuclear war a lot more likely.\u201d\n\nIn the past, miscalculation has brought us to the precipice of war, as with the Cuban missile crisis, or actual war, as with the events that led up to World War I.\n\nThe recent false alarms in Hawaii and Japan should cause greater concern that misjudgment or rash judgment could result in nuclear catastrophe.", "title": "Opinion | A Nuclear Plan in Dangerous Times", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Multiple dance forms of the United States were on view last week at the Joyce Theater. As a rule, this dance theater presents one company a week \u2014 but here it featured eight, in four programs, under the aegis of American Dance Platform, an annual fixture and part of the big early-January dance splurge across New York, with presenters coming in from around the country to sample as many troupes as possible.\n\nFor New Yorkers, it\u2019s also a valuable opportunity to sample new or unfamiliar dance. It proved a truly American platform, too, with idioms including Hawaiian hula, Irish footwork, Spanish dance, tap, Lindy, ballet and modern.\n\nI saw six of the Platform\u2019s eight companies. Good dancers abounded; good programming was rarer. Every troupe took me somewhere I hadn\u2019t been before, though not all had the secret of making me feel they had more to offer than what they had performed.\n\nBest of all was a dancer-choreographer I\u2019d seen before, Caleb Teicher: His spell keeps growing. Lean and lithe, he\u2019s immediately memorable for the Diaghilev/Susan-Sontag streak of white hair amid his black locks, but his looks soon become less striking than his character. I used to find him sly, but what is far more striking now is his impulsive, elusive eccentricity. He\u2019s engaging, and yet you watch him with perpetual curiosity: Who and what is he?\n\nPhoto\n\nHe\u2019s a tap dancer who is equally at home in other American folk forms \u2014 jazz, soft-shoe, the Lindy \u2014 and he\u2019s funny, charming, elusive, seeming always to resist categorization. In \u201cVariations,\u201d he and two colleagues, Brittany DeStefano and Gabe Winns Ortiz, bring off marvels to excerpts from Bach\u2019s Goldberg Variations, mostly tying a footfall to every keyboard note and yet always revealing fresh resources of pressure, idiom, physicality. In \u201cMeet Ella,\u201d Nathan Bugh and Mr. Teicher bring a wider lexicon to several of Ella Fitzgerald\u2019s most crazy live improvisations; her inspired lunacy brings out the same in them. The more I see of Mr. Teicher & Company, the more I want to see.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI\u2019d also seen Philadanco before. One of several important troupes in Philadelphia, it has terrific performers, with high energy and marvelous fullness of physical texture. A pity then that the two items the group danced here \u2014 Francisco Gella\u2019s \u201cBetween the Lines\u201d and Ray Mercer\u2019s \u201cSuper B!\u201d \u2014 were just formulaic modern soft-shoe ballet.", "title": "A Pan-American Dance Sampler at the Joyce", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "For all its successes, Los Angeles has not developed the political, cultural and philanthropic institutions that have proved critical in other American cities. The turmoil at The Times comes just months after Eli Broad, who has been the city\u2019s biggest philanthropist, announced he was retiring.\n\nThere are many reasons for this problem. Los Angeles County is made up of 88 different cities, including the City of Los Angeles, rolling across 4,571 square miles that stretch from the ocean to the desert. People here are more likely to identify themselves with the city or neighborhood where they live \u2014 be it Glendale, Compton, Beverly Hills or Whittier \u2014 rather than Los Angeles. The worsening traffic has encouraged people to stay close to the places where they live and work.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s so vast,\u201d said William Deverell, a historian of California at the University of Southern California. \u201cL.A. was self-consciously designed to be a decentralized place. What we call sprawl in the 21st century was part and parcel of the decentralized nature of the place.\u201d\n\nThere has been an exodus of Fortune 500 companies to other parts of the country from Los Angeles over the past 20 years \u2014 among them, Occidental Petroleum, which moved to Houston in 2014 \u2014 and with it the loss of business leaders who in other cities fill key civic roles. There were three Fortune 500 companies here in 2017, compared with seven in the City of Los Angeles in 1987. Many Hollywood executives and actors have homes in other parts of the country, and with some notable exceptions, have not played a major role in civic life here.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). Sign up to get it by email. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe region has become increasingly economically and ethnically diverse, a challenge for any political or civic leader looking to unify a community. And this is a relatively young city, filled with recent arrivals who do not have the history of the kind of old-line families who have defined civic foundations in established cities like Boston and Philadelphia.\n\nThe overlapping maze of governments works against the emergence of a single powerful political leader, such as an Edward I. Koch, the former mayor of New York City. The mayor here has little control over the school board or the health system.\n\nUnlike New York, which has two feisty daily tabloids and a 24-hours news station devoted only to New York news, The Los Angeles Times has stood increasingly alone as other news organizations have gone out of business, such as The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, which closed in 1989. That has meant the absence of different voices and the kind of competition that can ensure a live civic debate, particularly since Los Angeles does not have the prodding that comes with an aggressive tabloid culture.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMarylouise Oates, who was an influential society columnist for The Times in the 1980s, writing closely followed columns that covered every aspect of life here \u2014 politics, Hollywood, culture, along with events in the Jewish, Latino and African-American community \u2014 said she was distressed that there were few journalistic voices in the community today.\n\n\u201cThis city is so silo-ized,\u201d Ms. Oates said. \u201cI covered everything. At the time it was all one city. Otis Chandler made that possible. He decided it was a good thing to do.\u201d\n\nAntonio R. Villaraigosa, a former two-term mayor, said the lack of these kinds of forces was a constant obstacle to accomplishing anything ambitious when he was in City Hall.\n\n\u201cRallying the city around big challenges becomes more difficult when you don\u2019t have the broad cross-section of institutional players,\u201d said Mr. Villaraigosa, a Democrat who is running for governor. \u201cWe don\u2019t have anything like that here. We\u2019ve been struggling for 50 years with weakened institutions.\u201d\n\nBut he said he thought that was changing. \u201cWe are a global city,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need to see ourselves as a global city.\u201d\n\nThe other factor is the lack of philanthropy. There is no shortage of wealth in Los Angeles, but leaders of cultural institutions have long struggled to raise money or solicit contributions of art. Los Angeles ranked 14th in charitable giving in 2017, according to The Charity Navigator; San Diego ranked first. The Walt Disney Concert Hall, by any measure a landmark work of architecture in this city and the world, almost did not get completed; Richard Riordan, a former mayor, made a personal plea to Mr. Broad to help come up with the needed financing.\n\nMr. Broad said he was not worried that no one would step up to fill the shoes he has left since retirement. For example, he suggested, David Geffen, the Hollywood mogul who lives in Beverly Hills and New York, pledged $150 million last year for the construction of a new Los Angeles County Museum of Art building.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a changing city,\u201d Mr. Broad said. \u201cIt\u2019s a younger city. We\u2019re growing up.\u201d\n\nGeography may be seen as an impediment to strong institutions, but it is also a central piece of Angeleno identity \u2014 a landscape of beaches, mountains, valleys, open skies and clusters of buildings. \u201cGeography is part of our values,\u201d said Zev Yaroslavsky, a former member of the county board of supervisors and a professor at the Luskin School of Public Affairs at the University of California, Los Angeles. \u201cWe don\u2019t want to live on top of each other, like in New York or Philadelphia.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSouthern Californians, he said, \u201cwant to be independent.\u201d\n\nBill Boyarsky, a former editor at The Los Angeles Times and the author of \u201cInventing L.A.: The Chandlers and Their Times,\u201d a book on the newspaper, described the idea that people in Los Angeles \u201ccan\u2019t see beyond their block\u201d as an East Coast stereotype.\n\n\u201cI always thought geography was an unusual but true way of binding the city together,\u201d he said.\n\nThe developments come as Los Angeles \u2014 by many other measures \u2014 is on an upswing. The economy is humming. Its youthful mayor, Eric M. Garcetti, is traveling the country, a potential presidential candidate in 2020, which in some circles provokes eye-rolling, but is also a source of pride, particularly at a time when political activism in this relatively apolitical city has risen since the election of President Trump.\n\nThe city now has two professional football teams \u2014 after 20 years when there were none \u2014 and was chosen as the site of the 2028 Olympic Games. And a raft of new museums are opening or are being renovated, including one financed by the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures and another by George Lucas in downtown Los Angeles.\n\n\u201cWe are a trendsetting city,\u201d Ms. Bojarsky said. \u201cAnd we look much more like what cities of the future are going to look like. We have the diversity of the economy, the diversity of the people. There are no all-white cities or single-economy cities anymore.\u201d\n\nStill, the absence of progress on big issues \u2014 homelessness, education and battered streets, to name a few \u2014 is a source of frustration and embarrassment for many civic leaders.\n\n\u201cLos Angeles plays small ball really well,\u201d said Austin Beutner, a former deputy mayor who served briefly as the publisher of The Times. \u201cWhat\u2019s missing oftentimes is the ability to bring the entire community together on behalf of issues or opportunities that will benefit the community as a whole.\u201d\n\nThe contrast with the era when Otis was a power at his newspaper and in the city is striking. Upon arriving here, Otis, through subterfuge, conspired to steal water from the Owens Valley and bring it to Los Angeles, making rapid growth possible. The newspaper\u2019s power helped secure funding for a new harbor, opening the city to global trade.\n\nWith special sections, the newspaper marketed Los Angeles to the rest of the country, attracting waves of striving migrants with the promise of sunshine, cheap land and abundant opportunity. In politics, the newspaper bent City Hall to its will, and along the way propelled the rise of favored leaders, including Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan. The Chandlers sold the family-controlled Times Mirror Company to the Tribune Company in 2000.\n\nThe newspaper developed from being less a political player and more a civic leader \u2014 a paper with international prestige that helped set the conversation every morning here. \u201cIt proved to be the golden age for an organization like The L.A. Times to engage citizens of Los Angeles,\u201d Mr. Beutner said. \u201cWith everything going on here today you\u2019d expect it to be a leader in the conversation. Meanwhile, it is being pummeled from above.\u201d", "title": "A Paper Tears Apart in a City That Never Quite Came Together", "authors": ["Tim Arango", "Adam Nagourney"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere is nothing that will ever lift the burden of Michael\u2019s tragic death from the hearts of his mother and father and their entire family,\u201d she added. \u201cBut in speaking with Michael\u2019s mother following the verdict, she reiterated for us what she has consistently wished from this case \u2014 that another young person isn\u2019t subjected to such perverse conduct merely for wanting to belong.\u201d\n\nOne of the earliest and highest-profile cases of prosecutors charging a fraternity came after the death, in 1997, of Scott Krueger, an 18-year-old freshman at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who was pledging to join the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity. He fell into a coma after binge drinking, his blood-alcohol level reaching 0.40, five times the legal limit to drive, prosecutors said. The fraternity was indicted on homicide and hazing charges, while no individual members were charged. The case fell apart after the fraternity dissolved its chapter at M.I.T.\n\nAnother fraternity, Sigma Alpha Epsilon, was found guilty in 2012 of hazing and other charges after George Desdunes, a Cornell University sophomore from Brooklyn, died after drinking excessive amounts of alcohol. However, in that case, the fraternity did not present a defense; three students who were charged were acquitted.\n\nProsecutors routinely pursue criminal cases against institutions, often for white-collar crimes involving allegations of corporate malfeasance. Charges alleging violent offenses are less common. Legal experts said the situation with fraternities is analogous to workplace cases, such as in mines or on construction sites, where prosecutors believe an employer\u2019s negligence or wrongdoing contributed to a worker\u2019s injury or death.\n\nIn such cases, prosecutors have to show that the death was \u201cmuch more than pure possibility,\u201d said David LaBahn, the president of the Association of Prosecuting Attorneys. \u201cThis was a death that was preventable.\u201d\n\nIn the Baruch case, Pi Delta Psi has contended that the initiation rituals were unsanctioned. During the trial, the fraternity claimed that prosecutors had unfairly conflated the students\u2019 actions with organization\u2019s in a way that was \u201cmisleading and directly prejudices the national fraternity.\u201d\n\n\u201cA corporation can only act through a person,\u201d the fraternity argued in court documents, adding that there was \u201cno evidence presented\u201d showing that the national fraternity had representatives at the retreat, was involved in its planning or \u201cexhibited an intent to cause the tragic result.\u201d", "title": "A Partial Win for Prosecutors Who Targeted Fraternity After Student\u2019s Death", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "It is a play that will haunt the New Orleans Saints and their fans for a long time. They needed one stop against the Minnesota Vikings. They needed to tackle a defenseless wide receiver in bounds. Do that, and they would be headed to the N.F.C. Championship. But caught up in the moment, a rookie missed a tackle, and it cost his team everything. Here is what went wrong:\n\nThe Setup\n\nIt was 3rd-and-10 at Minnesota\u2019s 39-yard line. There were 10 seconds remaining, the Vikings had no timeouts, and New Orleans was clinging to a one-point lead. A play of any kind that did not get out of bounds would almost certainly end the game, since the Vikings would not be able to stop the clock in time to try a game-winning field goal.\n\n\u201cWe knew that all we needed was a field goal,\u201d receiver Adam Thielen said. \u201cObviously, we knew it was going to be tough because all they had to do was stay back and not give up the big play. I don\u2019t think anybody in the huddle was down. We were just trying to make a play.\u201d", "title": "A Pass. A Catch. A Missed Tackle. What Went Wrong for the Saints?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "The latest example of cooperation has been in framing \u2014 the language political actors use to describe their causes. For social scientists, the more actors manage to frame an issue to resonate for multiple constituencies, not just the core constituency, the more likely they are to influence politics.\n\nIn Latin America, both Catholic and evangelical clergymen have come up with an effective frame for their conservatism: opposition to what they have baptized the \u201cideology of gender.\u201d\n\nThis term is used to label any effort to promote acceptance of sexual and gender diversity. When experts argue that sexual diversity is real and gender identity is a construct, evangelical and Catholic clergies respond that this is just ideology, not science.\n\nEvangelicals are keen on stressing the word \u201cideology\u201d because this gives them the right, they argue, to protect themselves, and especially their children, from exposure to these ideas. Ideology of gender allows them to call for the protection of children as cover for homophobia.\n\nThe political beauty of \u201cideology of gender\u201d is that it has given clergymen a way to recast their religious stand in secular terms: as parents\u2019 rights. In Latin America, the new Christian slogan is, \u201cDon\u2019t mess with my kids.\u201d It is one of the results of this evangelical-Catholic collaboration.\n\nPolitically, we may be witnessing a historic truce between Protestants and Catholics in the region: Evangelicals agree to embrace the Catholic Church\u2019s strong condemnation of abortion, the Catholic Church embraces evangelicals\u2019 strong condemnation of sexual diversity, and together, they can confront rising secularism.\n\nThis truce poses a dilemma for Pope Francis, now on tour in Latin America. On the one hand, he has expressed rejection of extremism, and a desire to connect with the most modern, even liberal groups in the church. On the other hand, this pope has made \u201cChristian encounters\u201d a hallmark of his papacy, and he himself is not entirely allergic to the cultural conservatism of evangelicals.", "title": "Opinion | A Perfect Marriage: Evangelicals and Conservatives in Latin America", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The second ominous possibility lurking on Mexico\u2019s horizon is the end of Nafta, or, at best, the indefinite postponement of renegotiation, perpetuating uncertainty. Talks are scheduled through March or April. But given Mexican presidential elections on July 1, and a United States midterm vote in November, it would be impossible for a hypothetical agreement to be ratified by both Congresses, and perhaps the Canadian Parliament, before early 2019.\n\nThis would deter foreign investment at least until the new rules are determined and also allow the Trump administration to continue to threaten a Nafta blowup to obtain concessions from Mexico on other issues.\n\n\u201cHypothetical\u201d is a big word. Such little progress has been made on America\u2019s stringent demands that there is no agreement in sight.\n\nThe Trump administration wants the so-called rules of origin renegotiated, requiring, for example, that at least 50 percent of a Nafta-produced car be made of American parts. Washington also wants disputes settled in American courts (and not in the more neutral arbitration bodies set up by the treaty), limits on the export of some agricultural products from Mexico to the United States, and the entire agreement revisited every five years.\n\nWith these sticking points hanging over the talks, President Trump\u2019s negotiators may any day invoke Nafta\u2019s Article 2205, which provides for a signatory\u2019s exit from the treaty in six months.\n\nWhile Mexico will survive without Nafta, the impact on foreign investment, much more than on trade, would be devastating for the first few years. This is not good news for an economy that is expected to grow less than 2 percent in 2018, and has expanded recently at an average rate of barely 2 percent per year. Lower growth means less employment, which, among other things, could prompt greater emigration from Mexico to the United States.\n\nThe third squall ahead lies in the presidential election. This will be the fifth consecutive democratic vote for Mexico: a first in its history. That in itself is a major achievement. And the election promises to be fundamentally free and fair: another accomplishment. But the outcome, at least according to most current polls, promises to be problematic. The reason is Andr\u00e9s Manuel L\u00f3pez Obrador, the left-wing politician and presidential candidate better known as AMLO.", "title": "Opinion | A Perfect Storm Is Coming to Mexico", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Zizka could easily have stayed on cruise control; instead, she decided to \u201cbring fresh air into the city,\u201d as she put it.\n\nFrustrated by her experience on that play a few years back, she put on her scouting hat. \u201cI started to reconnect with my European origins and went back to Berlin, to festivals in Amsterdam and Antwerp,\u201d she said. \u201cI admired the fearlessness of some of the European company actors, which I did not \u2014 do not \u2014 see in productions in the United States.\u201d\n\nAmong her first moves was to organize acting workshops led by Jean-Ren\u00e9 Toussaint, a French coach and actor who emphasizes a vocal training he dubs \u201cprimitive voice.\u201d\n\nMs. Zizka also trawled YouTube for inspiration and in 2011 discovered a video of the Greek director Theodoros Terzopoulos, from the Attis Theater in Athens, teaching an acting class in Poland. A few years later, she brought him over to present his production of \u201cAjax, the Madness\u201d at Philadelphia\u2019s FringeArts festival. He also conducted a four-day workshop that would plant the seed of HotHouse, the Wilma\u2019s \u201cartistic incubator\u201d and acting company, and a key element in Ms. Zizka\u2019s plan.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile many regional theaters once had resident companies, that model has evaporated over the past two decades or so. Trinity Repertory Company, in Providence, R.I., has a 16-member troupe and is one of the few theaters left to guarantee its group between 30 and 40 weeks\u2019 worth of work a year.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYet Curt Columbus, Trinity\u2019s artistic director, is optimistic \u2014 perhaps overly so, considering long-term trends \u2014 that change may be on the horizon. He uses the locavore food movement for comparison.\n\n\u201cWhat you\u2019re seeing is a little bit of a return to the land, where people look around and go, \u2018What are we doing for our local community?\u2019\u201d Mr. Columbus said by telephone. \u201cIf I\u2019m bringing in actors from New York or Los Angeles, they don\u2019t have any investment in the people who are here.\u201d\n\nOf course, with seven productions per season and an annual budget just over $9 million, Trinity Rep has more breathing room than the Wilma, which usually puts on four shows on an annual budget of $3.7 million. (There were only three in 2017-18 because the Wilma presented Opera Philadelphia\u2019s \u201cWe Shall Not Be Moved\u201d in the fall slot, and also worked on a new lobby cafe around that time.)\n\nThe Wilma must also be aware of the ominous shadow cast by the neighboring Philadelphia Theater Company, which had to repurchase its own venue after the bank foreclosed and severely curtailed its 2017-18 season to pay off debt.\n\nSo for now, at least, the Wilma\u2019s effort remains financially modest: The HotHouse actors get paid when they are cast in a show, and they receive a stipend for attending the communal training Ms. Zizka has instituted to build esprit de corps.\n\nPhoto\n\nThree Mondays out of the month between September and June, the 12 company members participate in five-hour sessions filled with exercises drawn from Mr. Terzopoulos\u2019s techniques.\n\nThey did not go down easily at first.\n\n\u201cThere is a rigorous collectivity to this work that is strenuously un-American in a way that is both exciting and disturbing,\u201d said Ross Beschler, a HotHouse member.
