At first, he questioned the idea. \u201cIt pushed my ideas of myself and what I could do in terms of my flexibility, my depth, my strength. But after a day thinking about that, I was, \u2018Oh that\u2019s a good thing!\u2019 \u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTraining takes place at the Wilma\u2019s studio, in a slightly grungier neighborhood a half-hour walk from the theater. Before entering the space, the participants leave their shoes at the door, along with their inhibitions and self-consciousness. Mr. Terzopoulos\u2019s approach emphasizes breathing, with the diaphragm the gateway to feeling, and it starts with an extended vocal and physical warm-up.\n\n\u201cThis is the idea of the vertical voice, in which you find emotions inside your body,\u201d the wiry, soft-spoken Ms. Zizka said. \u201cPeople are blocked in their bodies, so this is a way to generate emotions by opening up the back of the bodies. You want to have emotion, body, voice, all in a fluid expression.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe process then moves on to a \u201cdeconstruction\u201d stage.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about, How do I take apart the function of the breath, and how do I look at different parts of the body?\u201d said Justin Jain, among the handful of HotHouse actors who have traveled to Greece to train at Attis. \u201cIt\u2019s all in service of excavating what Terzopoulos calls the capital-B Body. That includes not only your physicality but your memory, your history, your imagination \u2014 everything about the human experience.\u201d\n\nThat phase can last three or four hours, according to Mr. Jain. Next comes \u201cthe infinite improvisation,\u201d he said, when \u201cyou start to marry a text or a concept or an idea to that form.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThis requires the actors to be comfortable with themselves and with one another \u2014 at a November session, some cried, others got into a trance-like state. \u201cIt\u2019s better than therapy,\u201d Ms. Zizka said, chuckling.\n\nAs her experiment evolves, Ms. Zizka must balance artistic daring with pragmatic considerations that American nonprofit institutions inevitably face.\n\nOne question mark is the future of WynTix, which keeps tickets for a show\u2019s initial run at an affordable $30 ($10 for students). A grant from the Wyncote Foundation in Philadelphia funded the initiative, which was extended by one year and is now slated to conclude at the end of the season; the Wilma is exploring ways to continue it.\n\nMeanwhile, on Jan. 10, the Wilma begins five-week run of the Stew and Heidi Rodewald musical \u201cPassing Strange,\u201d which will mix HotHouse members and others. The Wilma had to partner with a commercial producer to bring the Tony-nominated show\u2019s revival to fruition.\n\nThat show\u2019s director, Tea Alagic, has worked with HotHouse and attended the strenuous Monday sessions. So has Kate Tarker, who has been commissioned to write a play in the Wilma\u2019s 2018-19 season.\n\n\u201cThey have a warm-up ritual that they do on Mondays where it\u2019s like they\u2019re excavating this sadness from their bones,\u201d Ms. Tarker reported. \u201cSo I wrote them a piece that\u2019s a tragedy but also kind of a comedy about tragedy. I was interested in bringing them a challenge.\u201d", "title": "A Philadelphia Theater Heading, and Sweating, in a New Direction", "authors": ["Elisabeth Vincentelli"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "AT 2 MINUTES 47 SECONDS\n\nFragile Sincerity\n\nAhead of her performances with the New York Philharmonic this week, the cellist Alisa Weilerstein joined us for a Facebook Live concert and interview. She closed with the two bourr\u00e9es from Bach\u2019s Suite No. 3 in C, which she has been touring as part of a three-hour marathon of all six of Bach\u2019s cello suites. I asked when we could expect a recording; alas, likely not this year. But this led me back to her other albums, including her impassioned recording of Dvorak\u2019s Cello Concerto with the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra in 2014. Her playing has the expressive power of human voice \u2014 especially in the second movement, in which Dvorak borrows the melody from his lied \u201cLasst mich allein.\u201d The song\u2019s opening line, \u201cLeave me alone in my dreams,\u201d comes through in Ms. Weilerstein\u2019s playing, with the fragile sincerity of a pleading heart. JOSHUA BARONE\n\nWatch Alisa Weilerstein on Facebook Live and read our review of her concert with the Philharmonic.", "title": "A Pianist\u2019s Big Prize: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments of the Week on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "One frigid morning in December, a modest Revolutionary War-era wooden house in the center of Kent, Conn., was abuzz with activity. In the rear of the building, home to the newly opened restaurant Swyft, employees were tidying and prepping the night\u2019s menu of wood-fired pizzas, fresh pastas and small plates. In a front extension, carpenters were banging away amid the elegant, putty-colored walls of Ore Hill, a fine-dining restaurant that will open early this summer.\n\nNimbly presiding over it all was chef Joel Viehland, who crisscrossed the space, gesticulating to builders on the Ore Hill side, then darting over to Swyft\u2019s prep stations and nudging his staff to \u201cfeed Sour Girl\u201d\u2014 a term of endearment for his prized long-fermented sourdough starter.\n\nViehland\u2019s schedule for the past year has been a balancing act, preparing for the unveiling of his two distinct yet interconnected restaurants. In many ways, the concept, a combination of the casual and the formal, is not unlike the working relationship behind it, between Viehland and the philanthropist Anne Bass. After the James Beard\u2013nominated Viehland, who has cooked at Noma and Gramercy Tavern, left his most recent post at the acclaimed Community Table in New Preston, he began brainstorming ideas with Bass, a longtime local resident, who just happened to be purchasing this building in Kent. \u201cWe started asking questions,\u201d Viehland explained. \u201cDo we need a casual restaurant, or do we need a fine-dining restaurant?\u201d They decided that Litchfield County \u2014 with its growing number of quietly chic shops (including Plain Goods, George Home and Privet House) and its roster of marquee fashion- and art-world residents (Jasper Johns, Agnes Gund, Diane von Furstenberg) \u2014 could use both.", "title": "A Pizzeria and Fine-Dining Restaurant \u2014 All in One", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cJust because you\u2019re invited doesn\u2019t mean you\u2019re welcome,\u201d said Mare Young, 25, known as \u201cTurb0,\u201d who has been skating since the age of 7. Like many others who have since found Unity, Young mostly skated solo as a way to enjoy the sport but avoid the typical skate scene.\n\nMae Ross, a 20 year old transgender woman, skated alone post-transition. \u201cSkating was really hard for me for a second there, adjusting to my newly developing body and trying to skate and maintain relationships with people I skated with before,\u201d said Ross, who relocated from Bakersfield, Calif., to the San Francisco area a year ago, in part to find like-minded people in a city long known for its L.G.B.T.Q. population, but struggled to find skating companions before Unity.\n\n\u201cI thought I would meet more girl skaters or something, but even if I did, they wouldn\u2019t really talk to me,\u201d Ross said. \u201cNone of those hesher bro skaters liked me anyway, even before I transitioned.\u201d\n\nMr. Valdez also opted to skate alone after growing tired of the macho skate scene he\u2019d grown up in. The melded athletic evolution of Cazzie Russell, Dave Stallworth, Bill Bradley and Dave DeBusschere.\n\nIt\u2019s also fair to wonder: In the increasingly glitzy, superstar-driven N.B.A., could the Spurs have even been the Spurs in a market like New York, with its itinerant night life temptations and news-media-induced ego inflations?\n\n\u201cWhen you\u2019re winning, I think you could do it,\u201d Popovich said in the coaching office of the visitors\u2019 locker room before Tuesday\u2019s game. \u201cI think they could have survived here. As far as the invasiveness, they\u2019re also pretty open to people. They talk. But they\u2019re pretty selfless in that it\u2019s never been about the camera. So I think the solid, fundamental play and the individual personalities would have been appreciated by the Knicks fans, who are the most sophisticated \u2014 at least that\u2019s what\u2019s in my head.\u201d\n\nThe question becomes more relevant now that the Knicks have moved on from their failed Hail Carmelo experiment and are building a foundation with a Spurs-like international flavor, beginning with the Latvian big man Kristaps Porzingis, the promising French rookie point guard Frank Ntilikina and the charismatic Turkish center Enes Kanter.\n\nThe Knicks may not be ready to beat the still formidable Spurs, but can they \u2014 operationally and stylistically, at least \u2014 become the Spurs?\n\nPhoto\n\nA comically caustic voice of experience, Popovich is often asked what he thinks of pretty much all things N.B.A., and more. He will typically respond by saying, \u201cLast I checked, we were still turning the ball over, so until I get all of that stuff straight, I don\u2019t have to worry about anybody else.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the Knicks \u2014 and Ntilikina, in particular \u2014 did leave an impression on him in San Antonio last week with their attitude and their commitment to ball movement.\n\n\u201cThey came into the timeouts and walked back onto the court and they played, and whether something went well or wrong for them, they just played, just competed,\u201d Popovich said. \u201cSo I was just impressed with the operation.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Ntilikina, he said: \u201cIt was the first time I watched the point guard, and he was calm and cool the entire game. Didn\u2019t say anything, just did what they asked him to do.\u201d\n\nNoting Ntilikina\u2019s mental approach, size, reach, court vision and defensive tenacity, Popovich nodded when it was suggested that the 19-year-old could be a nightly stat-line filler.\n\n\u201cHe might be special,\u201d he said.\n\nPopovich had to deal with a 19-year-old French kid with a different body type and playing approach when Parker was a rookie in 2001. Popovich\u2019s first workout impression of Parker was \u201ca skinny kid\u201d who struck him as \u201csoft\u201d and \u201ctoo cool for school.\u201d He was inclined not to draft him, but a second look convinced him otherwise, and Parker was so impressive in training camp that he wound up starting 72 games as a rookie \u2014 and that was for a team with championship aspirations.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know if rolling the dice makes you brave, but the insanity was certainly there,\u201d Popovich said.\n\nParker, he agreed, paved the road for Ntilikina and others. As did the Spurs, in a larger sense, for latecomers like the Knicks to the mining of international talent.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just not an oddity, success through other people\u2019s success, just knowing it could happen,\u201d Popovich said. \u201cWe\u2019ve all got \u2019em, and it\u2019s made the N.B.A. better.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nImporting talent is different from nurturing it and blending it with homegrown talent, as the Spurs have done for nearly two decades with uninterrupted excellence. The challenge for the Knicks\u2019 management team headed by Steve Mills and Scott Perry is how to tune out the daily news media dissections, balance long-term ambitions with short-term rewards, while hoping that the owner James Dolan doesn\u2019t resort to his past chaos-inducing intrusions.\n\nAll with the understanding that Porzingis and his canny older brother and agent, Janis, are watching closely to see if the Knicks can behave more like the Spurs before the time comes to recommit long-term.\n\nEver the defender of the smaller and less-fussed-over market, Popovich nonetheless said he hoped they could.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always believed that the N.B.A.\u2019s better if it has good teams in New York, L.A., Chicago,\u201d he said. \u201cIt raises everybody\u2019s boat.\u201d\n\nAt least the case can be made it did the last time the Knicks won a title, when Popovich was touring the world while serving in the Air Force, 45 years ago this spring.", "title": "A Plan for the Knicks\u2019 Future? Look to the Spurs\u2019 Past", "authors": ["Harvey Araton", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "At intermission, they are encouraged to walk through the History Center\u2019s Civil War exhibition and admire its extensive collection of rifles and ordnance, with words from Ms. Trethewey\u2019s imagined monologue by a black Union soldier still fresh in their ears: \u201cSome names shall deck the page of history/as it is written on stone. Some will not.\u201d\n\nThe wrongs Ms. Trethewey describes have not been easily righted. As calls for the removal of Confederate symbols have mounted, particularly around the South, the backlash from neo-Confederates and other whites concerned that their own history is being erased has been occasionally ugly, and even deadly. Though many see the public memorials to the breakaway Southern states as little more than celebrations of white supremacy, President Trump has lamented the removal of \u201cour beautiful\u201d Confederate statues.\n\nAt the same time, amid the shoving, shouting and violence, a more measured conversation is being had about the recalibration of American history and the rethinking of historical symbols, one in which the art world has played a central role.\n\nPhoto\n\nArtists, art historians and preservationists have weighed in on what to do with the decommissioned Confederate statues, and on questions of their artistic merit. In Baltimore, a statue of a pregnant black woman with a raised fist, created by the artist Pablo Machioli, briefly occupied a space where the city\u2019s Lee-Jackson memorial had stood before its removal in August. Good-natured petitions calling for alternative monuments to the African-American hip-hop artists OutKast and Missy Elliott have appeared in their respective hometowns of Atlanta and Portsmouth, Va.\n\nThis is the context in which the Alliance seeks to interject its revival of \u201cNative Guard.\u201d Ms. Trethewey\u2019s celebrated 2006 book is itself a kind of literary monument to her experience growing up in Mississippi as a biracial child, to her African-American mother, and to the Louisiana Native Guards, the black Union soldiers who fought on the Mississippi coast and guarded a prison camp for captured Confederates at Ship Island, south of Biloxi.\n\n\u201cThe book is trying, in many ways, to talk about those things that have been forgotten or erased or somehow left out of the historical record, and I\u2019m very concerned with trying to inscribe, or reinscribe, those things,\u201d Ms. Trethewey, an English professor at Northwestern University, said in a recent phone interview.\n\nThe Alliance\u2019s artistic director, Susan V. Booth, approached the Atlanta History Center with the idea of staging the play alongside its collection of Civil War artifacts. It was enthusiastically embraced by F. Sheffield Hale, the center\u2019s president and CEO. \u201cI said, \u2018Hell yeah,\u201d recalled Mr. Hale, who said he was already a fan of the book. \u201cIt fits into our new strategic plan of working with other institutions and getting different people from different ZIP codes and different interests in here,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Hale is not a historian but a history buff, an Atlanta native with a law degree from the University of Virginia. Since taking the helm of the museum in 2012, he has helped raise $65 million for the center, bringing glossy upgrades to its main campus in the affluent Buckhead neighborhood, but also a fresh emphasis on diversity and historical nuance.", "title": "A Play About Race and Memory, With Fresh Wounds All Around", "authors": ["Richard Fausset"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cU.S. Eliminates a Protected Visa for Salvadorans\u201d (front page, Jan. 9):\n\nI am saddened by many things done and said in the Trump administration. But no act has been as cruel as the decision to end Temporary Protected Status for the nearly 200,000 Salvadorans living in the United States, many of whom have been living, working and raising families here for more than 20 years.\n\nWhat possible good can it do for the United States to send a hard-working, taxpaying people back \u201chome,\u201d a place devastated by a long civil war where gang violence reigns?\n\nThe Temporary Protected Status program was not meant as a pathway to citizenship, but what better way to judge a person\u2019s worthiness for citizenship? What more proof do we need that a person who enters the country illegally out of fear for his life (or a life of utter poverty) will make a good citizen than over 20 years of being gainfully employed and paying taxes?\n\nERIKA BERRY, BALTIMORE", "title": "Opinion | A Plea on Salvadorans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "When the plot of a dystopian novel and the daily churn of the news cycle start overlapping, admiration for a given author\u2019s prescience may make way for alarm.\n\nTake Octavia E. Butler\u2019s 1993 \u201cParable of the Sower.\u201d Set in the 2020s, it describes an America where climate change is a menace, conflicts erupt over scarce water supplies, private armies protect corporate interests and the well-to-do wall themselves off in gated communities from the chaos surrounding them. A charismatic politician even promises to \u201cmake America great again.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not that Octavia predicted him,\u201d the musician Toshi Reagon says of a current-day politician who, you may have heard, rode the same slogan to the White House. \u201cIt\u2019s that she knew us so well and knew we would allow it to happen. That\u2019s chilling. It gives me bumps on my arms.\u201d\n\nMs. Reagon, whose musical adaptation of the novel is the centerpiece of the Public Theater\u2019s Under the Radar festival, is the granddaughter of a Baptist minister. Her parents became musical luminaries of the civil rights era and beyond: the late Cordell Hull Reagon founded the Freedom Singers, while Dr. Bernice Johnson Reagon performed with that group as well as with another a cappella ensemble Sweet Honey in the Rock.", "title": "A Prescient Sci-Fi \u2018Parable\u2019 Gets Set to Music", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 When President Trump mused last year about protecting immigrants brought to the United States illegally as children, calling them \u201cthese incredible kids,\u201d aides implored him privately to stop talking about them so sympathetically.\n\nWhen he batted around the idea of granting them citizenship over a Chinese dinner at the White House last year with Democratic leaders, Mr. Trump\u2019s advisers quickly drew up a list of hard-line demands to send to Capitol Hill that they said must be included in any such plan.\n\nAnd twice over the past two weeks, Mr. Trump has privately told lawmakers he is eager to strike a deal to extend legal status to the so-called Dreamers, only to have his chief of staff, John F. Kelly, and senior policy adviser, Stephen Miller, make clear afterward that such a compromise was not really in the offing \u2014 unless it also included a host of stiffer immigration restrictions.\n\nAs the government shutdown appeared to near an end on Monday, one thing was clear to both sides of the negotiations to resolve it: The president was either unwilling or unable to articulate the immigration policy he wanted, much less understand the nuances of what it would involve.", "title": "A President Not Sure of What He Wants Complicates the Shutdown Impasse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The Central Park Five, as they were called, were later exonerated and were paid a $41 million settlement, but Mr. Trump has never accepted that outcome. As late as 2016, he insisted that they were still guilty and that the settlement was \u201coutrageous.\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Obama was in office, Mr. Trump was a leader of the so-called birther movement, promoting the conspiracy theory that Mr. Obama had been born in Kenya, a false claim he did not abandon until 2016. During the campaign, Mr. Trump also generated criticism for describing illegal immigrants from Mexico as \u201crapists\u201d; proposing to ban all Muslims from entering the nation; and being slow to disavow the support of David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klansman.\n\nSince taking office, he has asserted that there were good people on both sides of a white supremacist rally and counterprotest in Charlottesville, Va., and repeatedly lashed out at black football players he deemed insufficiently patriotic for kneeling during the national anthem to protest racial injustice.\n\nIn a closed-door meeting on immigration with advisers in June, described last month in The New York Times, Mr. Trump complained that Haitians \u201call have AIDS\u201d and that Nigerians who visit would never want to \u201cgo back to their huts\u201d in Africa.\n\nPeople close to Mr. Trump have long insisted that he is not racist and that his often crude language is applied across the board. Omarosa Manigault Newman, a former \u201cApprentice\u201d contestant who was one of the few African-Americans on his senior staff until her departure last month, bemoaned various racially charged moments during his administration, but insisted that \u201che is not a racist.\u201d\n\n\u201cYes, I will acknowledge many of the exchanges, particularly in the last six months, have been racially charged,\u201d she said in an interview with ABC News. \u201cDo we then just stop and label him as a racist? No.\u201d\n\nKatrina Pierson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign who now works for America First Action, a pro-Trump \u201csuper PAC,\u201d said that as an African-American she found the president to be colorblind and empowering. The criticism of his words and actions, she said, owed more to partisanship.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re on the left, then everything he says or does, you\u2019re going to find a racist or sexist tone to it, period,\u201d she said on Friday. \u201cEven if you\u2019re on the right but you\u2019re an establishment person that is used to politically correct way of doing things, you might cringe when he says something that\u2019s not politically correct. He says things people say at their dinner table. He\u2019s just very bold and very honest, and a lot of people have been conditioned not to deal with people that way.\u201d", "title": "A President Who Fans, Rather Than Douses, the Nation\u2019s Racial Fires", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE OUTSIDER: Presidential endorsements can help writers bigly. President Kennedy declared his love of the James Bond spy series, and brought Ian Fleming to this country\u2019s attention. President Reagan enthused about the first novel to be published by the Naval Institute Press \u2014 an obscure submarine technothriller called \u201cThe Hunt for Red October\u201d \u2014 and turned Tom Clancy into a star.\n\nIt\u2019s less usual for a presidential cease-and-desist letter to propel a book\u2019s sales. But then, part of the point of Michael Wolff\u2019s \u201cFire and Fury\u201d (new at No. 1 in hardcover nonfiction) is that nothing about President Trump is usual. Wolff\u2019s behind-the-scenes look at Trump\u2019s first year in office draws heavily on interviews with aides and staffers, and the picture it paints is as grim as anything by Hieronymus Bosch. \u201cNothing contributed to the chaos and dysfunction of the White House as much as Trump\u2019s own behavior,\u201d Wolff writes in a passage claiming that the president, afraid of poisoning, won\u2019t let housekeepers touch his toothbrush and barks at them even for tidying up: \u201cIf my shirt is on the floor, it\u2019s because I want it on the floor.\u201d In Wolff\u2019s telling, his subject \u2014 used to the home comforts of Trump Tower \u2014 finds the White House \u201cvexing and even a little scary.\u201d\n\nVilifying the commander in chief is itself a proud tradition on the lists (Dinesh D\u2019Souza, take a bow), and Wolff\u2019s scorching portrayal would probably have done well even had Trump not threatened an injunction. For his part, though, Wolff maintains that he set out with no preconceptions. \u201cI would have been delighted to write a contrarian account here: \u2018Donald Trump, this unexpected president, is actually going to succeed,\u2019\u201d he told \u201cMeet the Press\u201d this month. \u201cThat is not the story. He is not going to succeed. This is worse than everybody thought.\u201d\n\nTHE INSIDER: \u201cThe Woman in the Window,\u201d A. J. Finn\u2019s debut thriller about a possible murder and an unreliable witness, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. This book arrives with sky-high expectations courtesy of a reported seven-figure advance, rave early reviews and \u2014 maybe \u2014 the fact that Finn, in real life, is Dan Mallory, vice president and executive editor of William Morrow. (As it happens, Morrow is also publishing the novel.) \u201cI knew that the market was ripe,\u201d he told The Houston Chronicle recently. \u201cBut you have to have a story, and I wasn\u2019t going to publish a novel until I felt comfortable with the narrative. \u2026 In the end, I think it was a happy confluence of my instinct as a writer and my expertise as a publisher.\u201d", "title": "A Presidential Fury Propels Wolff Book to No. 1", "authors": ["Gregory Cowles", "Inside The List"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "How much money for mass transit might this scheme yield? The task force\u2019s estimates run as high as $1.5 billion a year \u2014 roughly 10 percent of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority\u2019s operating budget. But much will depend on how the fees are structured, including in which hours and on which days they\u2019re imposed.\n\nQuestions of fairness are inevitable. For instance, toll-free East River bridges would stay as they are. This is one way perhaps to make the plan more palatable to Brooklyn and Queens politicians. Drivers crossing the Brooklyn Bridge could circumvent the congestion zone by zipping onto the F.D.R. Drive. But that\u2019s not possible for those who use other East River bridges, which feed directly into streets within the zone.\n\nThen, too, some people will see the proposals as a burden on less affluent New Yorkers. Mr. de Blasio, who prefers a \u201cmillionaire\u2019s tax,\u201d has been among the objectors. But if the task force\u2019s numbers are right, that argument is weakened. The panel says that of those who commute to jobs in Manhattan from other boroughs, a mere 4 percent do so by car \u2014 118,000 people. Fewer than 5,000 of them are said to qualify as the working poor. (And aides to the governor suggest some sort of tax credit might be created to ease their pain, as perhaps would lowering tolls on bridges that don\u2019t link to Manhattan, like the Throgs Neck, Whitestone and Verrazano-Narrows.)\n\nThe simple fact is that mass transit needs the money and the central city needs relief from snarled traffic that, according to some estimates by business groups, costs the New York metro economy $20 billion a year. It\u2019s long past time to discourage the many motorists who drive into Manhattan every day as a matter of choice, not necessity.", "title": "Opinion | A Pricing Scheme to Unclog New York\u2019s Arteries", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Representative Duncan D. (If Mr. Hunter did step aside, that would probably increase Republican chances of holding the seat, given his party\u2019s registration advantage there.)\n\nThe turmoil comes as California has emerged as the front line in Democratic efforts to win back the House. Seven of the 14-member Republican congressional delegation represent districts that Hillary Clinton won against Mr. Trump in 2016, including Mr. Issa and Mr. Royce. The party needs to capture 24 Republican seats to win back power. Democrats began recruiting candidates, raising money and setting up field operations here nearly six months ago.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s disapproval rating among independent voters, whose support is critical for any Republican hoping to win, shot up 20 percentage points from the week after his inauguration to the end of last year, from 48 percent to 68 percent, according to the Public Policy Institute of California. Independents make up 25 percent of the California electorate, a decimal point less than Republicans.\n\nThe president had a 73 percent approval rating among California Republicans in a poll last month by the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California, Berkeley, which, while high, was still considerably below what Barack Obama enjoyed among Democratic voters when he was president.\n\nMr. Trump and congressional Republicans have championed a tax bill widely assailed as punishing to California homeowners, dismantled policies aimed at fighting climate change and pushed tough and restrictive immigration policies. Last year, Californians voted to legalize recreational marijuana by a hefty margin of 57 percent to 42 percent; days after the law took effect on Jan. 1, the Justice Department announced it would aggressively enforce federal strictures against the drug.\n\nThe Interior Department moved last week to allow offshore oil drilling, a policy that has a long history of bipartisan opposition among Californians. The next day, it exempted Florida from the policy in response to pleas from Rick Scott, the Republican governor running for Senate, drawing accusations that the Trump administration was punishing this state.\n\n\u201cMost days for California Republicans in Congress are days spent on defense,\u201d said Bill Whalen, a research fellow at the Hoover Institution and a former senior adviser to Pete Wilson, a Republican governor. \u201cDefense spent on why Donald Trump wants to pull the country out of the Paris accords. Defense trying to explain why the president won\u2019t give the same offshore drilling waiver to California as it did to Florida. And defense trying to explain the latest thing Donald Trump said that he\u2019s now denying that he said.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Ch\u00e1vez said he would not have voted for the tax bill and opposed the tough immigration policies backed by some Republicans in Congress. \u201cOffshore drilling \u2014 I don\u2019t support it,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019ve been in California my whole life. I remember the Santa Barbara spill.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor all that, Republicans have some reason to hope they can withstand any Democratic wave. The fact that Mrs. Clinton won districts represented by these seven Republicans does not mean that voters will necessarily support a Democratic candidate for Congress in November. Although Republican enrollment in this state has been on a steady decline, the party continues to have a registration edge in these districts. Historically, Democratic turnout drops in nonpresidential years \u2014 especially in California.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAs a 34-year resident of Irvine in Orange County and as someone who has long been active at a variety of levels in political and policy debates, I am also reluctant to conclude that Democrats in a midterm election will be able to turnout a sufficient number of voters to overcome the current advantages Republicans still have in the districts,\u201d said Mark P. Petracca, a professor of political science at the University of California, Irvine.\n\nJim Brulte, the California Republican leader, said voters made their decision based on the candidates, not the party. He said he did not think Mr. Trump was an albatross on his candidates.\n\n\u201cLook, Republicans lost every statewide race in California in 2002, 2010 and 2014, before Donald Trump even announced he was running for president,\u201d Mr. Brulte said. \u201cSo anybody who wants to blame Donald Trump for the problems of the Republican Party, which began 20 years ago, is a revisionist historian.\u201d\n\nIt has long been a tough climb to get elected as a Republican in California. But Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency has pushed a party already struggling closer to the brink. Republicans and Democrats said that the level of anger at Mr. Trump could very well push up Democratic turnout in these districts.\n\n\u201cIt was already difficult,\u201d said Rob Stutzman, a Republican political consultant in Sacramento. \u201cBut he\u2019s made it more difficult.\u201d\n\nMark Baldassare, the president of the Public Policy Institute of California, said Mr. Trump\u2019s stand on issues \u201chas been at odds even with many Republicans\u201d in the state, \u201cespecially on immigration.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn our polling, we have seen majorities of Republicans saying they want a path to citizenship,\u201d he said. \u201cThey support DACA,\u201d the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which protects so-called Dreamers from deportation.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe offshore drilling policy was the latest complication for Republican candidates. In a poll taken in 2017 by the Public Policy Institute, 69 percent of respondents said they opposed opening up offshore sites for drilling. Republicans were more supportive \u2014 50 percent said they backed it \u2014 but majorities of Republicans who live near the coast opposed it. Mr. Issa\u2019s district runs along the coast.\n\nLast week, moderate Republicans, including Arnold Schwarzenegger, the former governor, announced they were creating an organization intended to try to save the state party, in part by differentiating it on issues like immigration and climate change.\n\n\u201cWhat works nationally doesn\u2019t work in California,\u201d said Chad Mayes, a State Assembly member and one of the founders of the group. \u201cWe are in a death spiral. We have to get out of this death spiral.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump is a historically weak political figure here. He drew 31.5 percent of the vote against Hillary Clinton, an even poorer showing than Herbert Hoover posted when he ran against Franklin D. Roosevelt in the midst of the Depression.\n\nAnd he poses a challenge to Republican candidates for state and federal office who need the votes of the Republican base, who support Mr. Trump. The result: Candidates have spoken warmly about Mr. Trump at forums where they need to win Republican support.\n\n\u201cCalifornians are waking up to one of the best economies we have seen in decades, since Ronald Reagan was president,\u201d said Travis Allen, a Republican State Assembly member who is running for governor. \u201cThe Trump effect on the economy is being felt across the country \u2014 even in California. I fully expect this to continue and to be a huge benefit for every Californian.\u201d\n\nMr. Whalen of the Hoover Institution said that Mr. Trump \u201cis not the person with whom you are going to identify the future of the party.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut what do you do?\u201d he said. \u201cYou can\u2019t walk away from him.\u201d\n\nMr. Stutzman, the political consultant, said it would be difficult for the state party to recover as long as Mr. Trump is in the White House: \u201cThe degradation of the Republican brand in California cannot be reversed with Trump as president.\u201d", "title": "A Problem for Republicans Fighting to Keep California House Seats: Trump", "authors": ["Adam Nagourney"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Some were alphabetical: Four Laurie Colwin novels shared a shelf with Evan S. The library of the legendary former Random House publisher Howard Kaminsky, who died last summer, contained books by friends and mysteries he wrote with his wife, Susan, under the pseudonym Brooks Stanwood. In a high, far corner: \u201cThe Art of the Deal,\u201d by Donald Trump, which he came to regret publishing. We asked some of Kaminsky\u2019s friends and colleagues to share their thoughts on his collection.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a weird thing about book obsessives: We\u2019re kind of like thieves, and certainly voyeurs. We go into people\u2019s houses and immediately want to scope out their books, to see what sort of creatures they are. I knew Howard pretty well, but one book or another would still catch me by surprise. As in, Wow, how\u2019d he get hold of that? Like his copy of Joy Williams\u2019s \u2018State of Grace\u2019 \u2014 the Paris Review edition. Hell, she\u2019s been a dear pal for 40 years, and I\u2019m her publisher, but I don\u2019t have that.\u201d\n\n\u2014GARY FISKETJON, editor of Alfred A. Knopf\n\n\u201cWe were often competitive readers. Once I confidently tried to outdo him on plot details in \u2018The Brothers Karamazov\u2019 and \u2018Crime and Punishment,\u2019 but I should have realized he owned them. He had a phenomonal memory for pretty much every volume on those beautiful mahogany shelves.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2014ALEXANDRA PENNEY, author and journalist\n\n\u201cHoward was a passionate and discerning reader. He pulled it off the shelf and said, \u2018I know you\u2019re going to love this one.\u2019\u201d", "title": "A Publisher\u2019s Life and Library", "authors": ["Maria Russo"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "But the office of Mayor Muriel E. Bowser, who must sign the bill into law, has some reservations.\n\n\u201cI would say, we\u2019re listening hard,\u201d said Brian T. Kenner, deputy mayor for planning and economic development. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to see what the cost is and how much revenue that can create and be put to affordable housing,\u201d a key priority of the Bowser administration. The district requires 8 to 12 percent of housing to be lower-cost units. Still to come is an essential statement of the bill\u2019s fiscal impact from the city\u2019s chief financial officer.\n\nAn estimated 89,000 people work in the so-called Golden Triangle, an area of prime real estate that extends from the White House to Dupont Circle. The hope is that conversions will give it more of a 24-hour neighborhood feel.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe only conversion underway involves the renovation of the former Planned Parenthood headquarters, on 16th Street Northwest, four blocks north of the White House. To be known as the Adele, the high-end project will have 13 condos ranging from $859,000 to $2.4 million.\n\nThe situation is not yet dire: Washington\u2019s office vacancy rate is lower than the region\u2019s, which is 16.3 percent and expected to rise to nearly 17 percent by late 2019, according to Newmark Knight Frank, a New York-based real estate services firm. But the fear is, with more office buildings being built, the overall commercial vacancy rates in the district will also climb, leading to lower office rents.\n\nProponents hope that the conversion bill will help both the market and the neighborhood.\n\n\u201cWe believe this bill will strengthen city\u2019s tax base while adding residents and ensuring the longtime economic vitality of our downtown,\u201d said Leona Agouridis, executive director of the Golden Triangle Business Improvement District. \u201cIt is a policy question: Do we want to have residents in the downtown area? If so, what are we willing to do to help realize it? This is a catalyst.\u201d\n\nGerry Widdicombe, a consultant to the DowntownDC Business Improvement District, said the idea behind the legislation was to \u201ceducate the market on how this can be done\u201d without hurting the city\u2019s tax base or the building owner\u2019s bottom line. \u201cIt\u2019s working in the suburbs because their office markets are really, really weak.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nJack Evans, a Democratic member of the Council and the bill\u2019s sponsor, said the bill would enable a \u201cManhattanizing of the District of Columbia,\u201d bringing more vitality to the city\u2019s core by encouraging an influx of full-time residents who could walk to work while patronizing nearby shops and restaurants. \u201cBut for the city\u2019s involvement, we would not get what they are looking for.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the Golden Triangle, 77 percent of the office buildings were erected from 1960 to 1990. Ms. Agouridis suggested that owners must soon decide whether to demolish and rebuild or renovate them to the higher Class A or premium Trophy building standards.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s natural in the cycle of buildings,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s like your home, you get to certain point, you need to replace major systems. But with renovation comes opportunity. From a neighborhood perspective, it makes a lot of sense to get that conversion going.\u201d\n\nIn Washington, some owners have sought to upgrade older buildings to Class A by \u201cre-skinning\u201d the facades, giving them a more modern look and reducing energy costs. So far, building owners in Washington continue to favor such cosmetic face-lifts over more substantial conversions.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother factor contributing to rising office vacancy rates, according to Mr. Widdicombe, is that some companies, notably law firms, are relocating to newer buildings, where they are leasing less space per employee, a workplace trend known as densification.\n\nA new concept in Washington, conversions have been implemented elsewhere. More than 37.5 million square feet of \u201colder office space that has reached functional obsolescence\u201d in the nation has been converted to residential use over the last decade, according to JLL.\n\nIn Washington\u2019s Maryland and Virginia suburbs, for instance, higher office vacancy rates have resulted in more conversions of older buildings without the use of government incentives.\n\nIn Old Town, a neighborhood in Alexandria, Va., the former offices of the Sheet Metal Workers International Union are now the Oronoco, a 60-unit luxury condominium on the Potomac River waterfront, with prices ranging from $1.3 million to $2.8 million. In Fairfax County, Washington\u2019s most populous suburb, the county government recently voted to streamline rezoning for the \u201crepurposing\u201d of commercial buildings.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. But they have a mixed zoning history. They long housed commercial tenants, but the buildings were converted in 2006 into condos, ranging from $499,000 for a one-bedroom to $2 million for three-bedroom units.\n\nAccording to the DC Condo Boutique website, the townhouse row \u201ccombines historic details with modern conveniences.\u201d A one-bedroom, one-bath unit there \u2014 the only residence currently for sale and available for immediate occupancy in the entire Golden Triangle district \u2014 is on the market for $650,000. \u201cIncredible location,\u201d the listing says.", "title": "A Push to Make Washington\u2019s Downtown More Livable", "authors": ["Eugene L. Meyer", "Square Feet"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Name Julien Turner\n\nAge 20\n\nHometown Pickerington, Ohio\n\nNow Lives In a dormitory suite at Morehouse College in Atlanta, where he is a second-year student.\n\nPhoto\n\nClaim to Fame In addition to being a straight-A student and a linebacker for his college football team, Mr. Turner is a budding filmmaker with a knack for making homespun content that ricochets across the web. Photos of his high school prom proposal (a goofy re-creation of a Jell-O mold gag from \u201cThe Office\u201d) melted over 13,000 hearts on Twitter. He also runs Dreadhead Films, a indie movie studio he started with his 15-year-old brother, Justen, that has landed choice slots at the 2015 White House Student Film Festival and the Pan African Film and Art Festival. \u201cEverywhere we go, we are always the youngest filmmakers there,\u201d Mr. Turner said.\n\nBig Break In November, Mr. Turner uploaded a homemade rap video on cell division as extra credit for a biology class. Set to the Lil Uzi Vert song \u201cXO Tour Llif3,\u201d the low-fi video takes place on campus and features lyrics like \u201cif my genes go left unread/ all my cells are dead.\u201d Once the activist Shaun King retweeted the video, a media firestorm took off, including an article in The New York Post, an appearance on \u201cGood Morning America\u201d and nearly 370,000 likes on Twitter. Mr. Turner also passed the course. \u201cMy professor said she loved it,\u201d he said.\n\nLatest Project The Turner brothers recently became two of the youngest directors to produce a segment for \u201cSesame Street.\u201d They\u2019re currently putting together a live-action short that will spotlight the number 6. Shot last month in Columbus, the clip features local children. Mr. Turner hopes to find roles for Bert and Ernie down the line. \u201cWe\u2019re not at that level yet,\u201d he said. \u201cHopefully, we get to work with them next.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNext Thing The brothers are developing a television pitch about a black female superhero. \u201cThe gist is that some of the extreme environments that we\u2019ve dealt with in our communities are actually giving people abilities,\u201d he said.\n\nFamily Affair Mr. Turner\u2019s father, Kevin, is a jazz professor at Ohio State University and his mother, Cynthia, is an accounting professor there who moonlights as a manager for her two sons. He and his younger brother used to ask for video equipment for Christmas and taught themselves techniques from watching YouTube. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to soak in these experiences as young people and brothers, and use our youth and our blood connection to our advantage,\u201d he said.", "title": "A Rap Video for a Biology Class Was His Demo Reel", "authors": ["Alex Hawgood", "Up Next"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Neutrons from the source, slowed down by the water, would penetrate the uranium atoms in the cans and induce fissions. If the fissioning atoms released more neutrons, those \u201csecondary\u201d neutrons would irradiate the manganese. Measuring the radioactivity induced in the manganese would tell Fermi if the fissions were multiplying. If so, then a chain reaction might be possible, one bombarding neutron splitting a uranium atom and releasing two neutrons, those two splitting two other uranium atoms and releasing four, the four releasing eight, and so on in a geometric progression that could potentially produce vast amounts of energy for power \u2014 or for an atomic bomb. The experiment worked.\n\nIn 1941, President Franklin D. Roosevelt authorized a program to build atomic bombs, hoping to defeat a Germany that was potentially a year or more ahead in the deadly race. Fermi, working now at the University of Chicago, undertook the building of a full-scale reactor to demonstrate that a chain reaction could be achieved and controlled. By then it was known as well that a nuclear reactor would breed a newly discovered element, plutonium, an alternative nuclear explosive. Fermi\u2019s reactor would also demonstrate the breeding of plutonium.\n\nInstead of water, which absorbed too many neutrons, the demonstration reactor would use graphite, the form of carbon found in pencil lead, to slow the neutrons. Graphite blocks the size of planter boxes, drilled with blind holes to house slugs of uranium metal, would be stacked layer by layer to form a spherical matrix. Fermi, who loved American idioms, called his creation a \u201cpile.\u201d\n\nAcross the month of November 1942, Fermi supervised the building of Chicago Pile No. 1 on a doubles squash court under the west stands of the university football stadium. It was ready on the frigid morning of Dec. 2, 1942. Through the morning and early afternoon, wielding his slide rule, Fermi slowly took the pile critical, with a characteristically Fermian break for lunch. It worked, which meant a bomb would almost certainly work as well.\n\nHistorically, no other development in Fermi\u2019s life ranks as high as the nuclear reactor, mighty versions of which produce more than 11 percent of the world\u2019s electricity today. Fermi continued to contribute original scientific work throughout the war and postwar at the University of Chicago. He advised the United States government on atomic energy and worked on weapons problems during summer stints at Los Alamos. He opposed the development of the hydrogen bomb more vehemently than J. Robert Oppenheimer but escaped the ruination visited upon Oppenheimer by the vindictive chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, Lewis L. Strauss. He went on to help build the first hydrogen bomb.\n\nI kept wishing this biography were livelier, lit with more surprises, but Schwartz, working with limited sources, tells the story well. A few infelicities are distracting. \u201cDisinterested\u201d doesn\u2019t mean \u201cuninterested.\u201d \u201cFulsome\u201d still means \u201coffensively flattering,\u201d not \u201cgenerous,\u201d though the meaning is changing. Brig. Gen. Leslie R. Groves of the United States Army Corps of Engineers, not Oppenheimer, held \u201cauthority over the entire Manhattan Project.\u201d Oppenheimer was the director of the Los Alamos Laboratory, one part of the project, where the first bombs were designed and built.\n\nStill, these are minor mistakes. All in all, Schwartz\u2019s biography adds importantly to the literature of the utterly remarkable men and women who opened up nuclear physics to the world.", "title": "A Remarkable Man Among Remarkable Men and Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI like to get a bit of a surprise when I go to the bathroom at a restaurant,\u201d the Danish chef Adam Aamann explains when asked why he has taken a hands-on approach \u2014 quite literally \u2014 to the restrooms in his new restaurant. Diners freshening up at Aamanns 1921 \u2014 which opened in Copenhagen in August and offers a modern take on classic Danish cuisine \u2014 are given a choice of two liquid soaps. One smells of lemon, cedar, bergamot and thyme; the other carries notes of lemon, bergamot, orange and rosemary. Both were handmade by Aamann himself.\n\n\u201cI like to throw myself at things I haven\u2019t tried before,\u201d he says, standing in the kitchen of his three-story house in Osterbro, one of Copenhagen\u2019s smartest neighborhoods. \u201cI also thought it would be an extraordinary way of tickling people.\u201d\n\nIn particular, Aamann wanted to \u201ccreate the full experience\u201d at Aamanns 1921: for diners to return to the table with \u2014 one hopes \u2014 clean hands that smell like the herbs used in the kitchen. In other words, the soap should provide a \u201creference\u201d to the food. At Aamanns 1921 that means smorrebrod \u2014 Denmark\u2019s traditional open-faced sandwich, adorned with fixings that include marinated herring, matured cheese, kohlrabi and pickled onions. Aromatic herbs adorn most dishes.", "title": "A Restaurant Where the Bathroom Soap Complements the Meal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nEverything you might need to know about chocolate, from bean to bar, as they say, will be covered during an all-day conference at the Institute of Culinary Education. It will be the first time the school has drawn on its many resources \u2014 most notably its chocolate lab, run by the school\u2019s creative director, Michael Laiskonis \u2014 to offer such a presentation for professionals and amateurs. Talks, demonstrations, panel discussions and tastings will be held, with experts like the chefs Bill Yosses and Marc Aumont, and historians including Maricel Presilla and Alexandra Leaf participating: \u201cRoots of Cacao,\u201d Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., $100 per person plus fee, $60 for students plus fee, eventbrite.com, Institute of Culinary Education, 225 Liberty Street (West Street), ice.edu.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "A Rich Day of Chocolate Talks", "authors": ["Florence Fabricant", "Front Burner"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Under the state of emergency imposed by Mr. Erdogan since the attempted coup, public gatherings are prohibited and freedom of expression and the media are tightly constrained. Most of those joining Ms. Aksener\u2019s movement are young people chafing under the restrictions, she said.\n\nMs. Aksener and Mr. Erdogan both represent the center right of the political spectrum, but she opposes him on almost every aspect of his politics, from his increasingly autocratic form of government to his anti-Western diatribes that have damaged relations and scared off foreign investment.\n\nMr. Erdogan remains Turkey\u2019s most popular politician by far, but last year\u2019s referendum showed that the country is deeply divided. Ms. Aksener says she is uniquely placed to draw support from right-wing nationalists and more liberal centrists who are disenchanted with Mr. Erdogan.\n\n\u201cWe saw in the referendum the country is split in half,\u201d she said. \u201cThe Good Party is the only party that can get votes from both camps.\u201d\n\nStill, her path ahead will be anything but easy. Although Mr. Erdogan\u2019s Justice and Development Party has slipped slightly in the polls, there is little sign that Ms. Aksener is the cause, said Kemal Can, a prominent political writer.\n\n\u201cMost of the polls show that she cannot draw the vote away from A.K.P.,\u201d he said, using the party\u2019s Turkish initials. \u201cShe may sway 1 or 2 percent from A.K.P., but these are already estranged voters who most probably already voted No in the referendum.\u201d\n\nSince she occupies some of the same political space as the president, Ms. Aksener is in many ways campaigning as the anti-Erdogan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe says she wants to re-establish freedom of expression, reverse draconian measures that have imprisoned journalists and closed down newspapers and media outlets, and restore a nonpartisan justice system and constitutional court.\n\nShe also says she wants to reverse Mr. Erdogan\u2019s April referendum, which will introduce an executive-style presidency after the next elections, regardless of who wins.\n\n\u201cWe are going to return to a parliamentary system,\u201d she said. \u201cThe second thing is to restore trust in the economy.\u201d\n\nThe daughter of a civil servant, Ms. Aksener grew up in a small rural village in western Turkey. Her family was among the hundreds of thousands resettled from Greece in the population exchanges between Greece and Turkey in 1923.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cDespite limited education, I managed to go to university and became a lecturer,\u201d she said. She gained her doctorate in history in Istanbul and taught at several universities.\n\nYet Ms. Aksener said the possibility of moving up a class through education had become elusive in Turkey, where employment has become partisan, depending on whether a person is connected to the governing party. \u201cThe opportunity I got 45 years ago, you cannot receive today,\u201d she said.\n\nEducation and the economy are the two things people are most concerned about on the campaign trail, she said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThousands of families were affected when Mr. Erdogan scrapped the national high-school entrance exam in September, ordering students instead to attend their closest neighborhood school, many of which have been transformed into religious academies.\n\n\u201cPupils were preparing for the exam for four years,\u201d Ms. Aksener said, \u201cand you change it overnight?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMobility between the social classes will be diminished,\u201d she added. \u201cChildren will not be able to dream about their future, and this is the saddest thing.\u201d\n\nAlthough Mr. Erdogan has overseen a period of impressive economic growth, allowing many in Turkey to climb out of poverty and join the middle classes, Ms. Aksener noted that the growth has been built on a construction boom rather than industrialization.\n\nPointing to high youth unemployment, she said research conducted by her party had found that 18- to 25-year-olds from middle-income families felt trapped in a triangle of unhappiness, despair and fatalism. \u201cThe Good Party will give hope to these people,\u201d she said.\n\nShe entered politics in 1994, joining the True Path Party of Suleyman Demirel and serving as interior minister for nine months until a military coup replaced the government in 1997. She joined the Nationalist Movement Party in 2007 and became deputy speaker of Parliament for eight years.\n\nAlthough the Nationalist Movement Party has a history of extreme right-wing elements, Ms. Aksener has avoided nationalist rhetoric and describes herself as center-right. Her party manifesto is carefully worded, supporting a strong defense against terrorism, immigration and outside cultural influences.\n\nSenior members of her new party have been more outspoken, though. Umit Ozdag, the vice chairman of the Good Party, caused an outcry in November with derogatory comments about Syrian refugees.\n\nMs. Aksener remains focused on attacking Mr. Erdogan\u2019s policies.\n\nShe broke with the Nationalist Movement Party leader, Devlet Bahceli, over his support for Mr. Erdogan\u2019s new presidential system, which she criticizes for lacking checks and balances.\n\nShe is also campaigning for women\u2019s rights, hoping to win over female voters. \u201cIn the cities, women are harassed based on their gender,\u201d she said. \u201cIn the villages they are beaten up or even killed.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe describes her 24 years in politics as a \u201cvery rough political life.\u201d During the 2015 parliamentary election campaign, supporters of Mr. Erdogan alleged on television that a video showed her cheating on her husband, a mechanical engineer.\n\nIn the furor that followed, both Mr. Erdogan and his wife called her in sympathy, as did Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu and his wife \u2014 although Ms. Aksener said that amid that sympathy they also encouraged her to drop out.\n\n\u201cI noticed there was an expectation that I should end this fight,\u201d she said. \u201cI went in the opposite direction. I continued the fight and I sued those people.\u201d\n\nHer accusers backed off somewhat, but were later acquitted.\n\nThe battle taught her a lesson, she says. \u201cI saw them up close,\u201d she said. \u201cI am not afraid of Erdogan, not as much as a grain of dust.\u201d", "title": "A Rival Steps Up to Challenge Turkey\u2019s President Erdogan", "authors": ["Carlotta Gall", "The Saturday Profile"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "And she has indeed been highly deferential. She fell in line after Mr. Trump insisted last month that the Republican National Committee put resources back into the Senate race in Alabama to aid Roy S. Moore, who had been accused of preying on girls as young as 14.\n\nAlabama rejected Mr. Moore and elected a Democrat to the Senate for the first time in a generation. But even now, Ms. McDaniel will not say whether she believes the committee\u2019s move was a mistake. \u201cI understand why the president did what he did,\u201d she said. \u201cHe wants to keep that majority.\u201d\n\nShe stressed that disputes in the party were an unwanted distraction. \u201cIf you\u2019re spending more time attacking your fellow Republicans, you\u2019re not helping us win in November,\u201d she said. \u201cI would prefer,\u201d she added, \u201cthat we don\u2019t always air those differences. I used to say if you have a fight within your family, you don\u2019t go on \u2018Jerry Springer.\u2019\u201d\n\nSo far, Ms. McDaniel has managed to hold together the factions of the party that are split over their feelings about Mr. Trump but united, for now, in pursuit of conservative policy goals. A relentless fund-raiser who spends up to six hours a day on the phone wringing money from donors, she has helped put the party in a formidable financial position. The Republican National Committee has nearly $40 million in the bank, compared with the Democratic National Committee\u2019s $6.3 million.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not been easy for her for a lot of reasons,\u201d said Ron Kaufman, who represents Massachusetts on the Republican National Committee. \u201cThe good news is Ronna understands totally the downside of where we are, as well as the upside. And she understands that our job is to make whatever potential wave there is a ripple.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThat \u201cshe\u2019s raised a ton of dough\u201d only helps her position in the party and with the president, he added.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe has a close relationship with the president that is perhaps unlikely for a Mormon from suburban Detroit. She has delivered something Mr. Trump intuitively understands: quantifiable results. Not only has she raked in money, but his narrow victory in her home state also helped put him over the top in the Electoral College. \u201cShe won,\u201d he has told people. He has also been known to refer to her as \u201cmy Romney.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe president has a pretty sterile view of results,\u201d said Reince Priebus, the former White House chief of staff and party chairman who pushed Mr. Trump to pick Ms. McDaniel as his successor. \u201cAnd if the results are the money is being raised and the apparatus is running well, the president is going to be pretty happy.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPolitics being in her blood, Ms. McDaniel worked her way up through various positions in the Michigan Republican Party before being elected as the state chairwoman in 2015.\n\nMs. McDaniel remained neutral throughout the 2016 primary races even as her uncle spoke out against Mr. Trump, denouncing him as \u201ca phony, a fraud.\u201d And when it became apparent that Mr. Trump would probably be the nominee, she enthusiastically embraced his campaign.\n\nAs for her own surname, she insisted that the president had never asked her to drop it outright. He raised the issue, she said, only lightheartedly, in front of her husband. And she said she liked the brevity of her name without it. \u201cMy husband and the president joked about it,\u201d she said. \u201cMy husband likes it, too.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRepublicans said that she appeared to have accepted the reality that party committee leaders in her position are generally not afforded much leeway, and that under Mr. Trump that seemed especially true.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re not the party\u2019s chairman, you\u2019re the president\u2019s chairman,\u201d said Saul Anuzis, a former chairman of the Michigan Republican Party. \u201cAs a Romney, she accepted the role of being a Trump person. And if she is going to do a good job, then she\u2019s going to have to be a Trump person.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump has often given Ms. McDaniel credit for telling him he could win Michigan \u2014 a prediction that few Republicans or Democrats were willing to make.\n\n\u201cI told Ronna for two years this state was competitive, and she listened to me much more than Democrats did,\u201d said Representative Debbie Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who is old friends with Ms. McDaniel\u2019s family. \u201cI was in union halls talking to people who were scared about trade, who were scared about their pensions. And she was hearing it, too,\u201d Ms. Dingell added.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI get it,\u201d Ms. McDaniel said. \u201cI was at the ground level when the movement came through my state.\u201d\n\nAs she looks to her backyard now, a movement of a very different kind seems to be building. Peters"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The authorities said 28 people were injured, four of them critically.\n\nAt least 300 houses were damaged in the Montecito area and many more were listed by the authorities as \u201cthreatened.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe are still in the hopeful, optimistic mode that we can find survivors,\u201d said Mike Eliason, a spokesman for the Santa Barbara County Fire Department, which has rescued six people since the hillsides gave way.\n\nCanine units worked their way along the Montecito and San Ysidro Creeks, where a large number of houses were swept away. The area near the creeks was the most treacherous, Mr. Eliason said, as creeks swelled with the sudden torrents of water mixed with ash from the fires, rocks and dirt.\n\n\u201cSome single-story homes were obliterated, just wiped off the foundation,\u201d he said. \u201cOthers had holes blown through from boulders.\u201d\n\nThe mud also hid some dangers from rescue workers.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve gotten multiple reports of rescuers falling through manholes that were covered with mud, swimming pools that were covered up with mud,\u201d Anthony Buzzerio, a Los Angeles County fire battalion chief, told The Associated Press. \u201cThe mud is acting like a candy shell on ice cream. It\u2019s crusty on top but soft underneath, so we\u2019re having to be very careful.\u201d", "title": "A Rush to Find Survivors Amid the Mud of Southern California Enclave", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "On a recent afternoon at Soho Rep, a welder sent sparks arcing past a dressing room strewn with metal bars and twin vises holding lengths of steam pipe. Lumber and sprinkler system components packed the upstairs hallway; in the theater itself, a lighting team wearing cloth masks crowded around a table. It was good to be home.\n\nIn September of 2016, Soho Rep, a downtown company with audacious taste in plays, announced that it would immediately vacate its 73-seat theater at 46 Walker Street, which it had rented for 25 years. A round of lease negotiations had revealed building regulations at variance with the company\u2019s use of the space, resulting in what Sarah Benson, Soho Rep\u2019s artistic director since 2007, described as a moral obligation to leave.\n\nMaybe a legal obligation, too. As Cynthia Flowers, Soho Rep\u2019s executive director explained, \u201cIf something, God forbid, were to happen, there could potentially be huge ramifications.\u201d\n\nBut after nearly a year and a half in exile, Soho Rep has returned to Walker Street, and is kicking off its 43rd season with a typically startling play, Aleshea Harris\u2019s \u201cIs God Is,\u201d which begins previews Feb. 6. \u201cIt was inconceivable that we would ever find our way back into the space,\u201d Ms. Benson said. But here they are.", "title": "A Safer Home for Dangerous Plays", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSome soups are delicate, light and refreshing, served as the prelude to a meal. Others, like this one, are hearty and nourishing meals in themselves. It is not precisely a soup, but a soupy concoction of potatoes and pasta, known throughout Italy as pasta e patate.\n\nThis is an example of the country\u2019s bare-cupboard cuisine, la cucina povera, in which inexpensive basics are transformed with small jolts of flavor from aged cheese, dried chiles, herb pastes and the like. Thrifty but flavorful, its principal aim is to feed a family during times when funds are tight. (If no potatoes were in the pantry, you could make a similar soup with beans or lentils.)\n\nHumble, but not spartan, many dishes from this tradition are also exceedingly delicious.\n\nHere, you soften an onion in a hot pan with a generous glug of olive oil, then add chopped potatoes, salt, a garlic clove, a rosemary sprig and water. When the potatoes are done, a handful of pasta goes in, and when the pasta is al dente, you ladle this steaming, chunky marvel of a soup into bowls. Pass the grated pecorino and Parmigiano, a cruet of oil, the pepper mill and crushed red pepper.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat\u2019s the bare-bones version. There are any number of regional variations, of course, and every cook is at liberty to customize according to whim. Some might add, for example, more vegetables, like celery and carrot; some tomato, a little or a lot; bacon or pancetta or ham; beef or chicken broth; or, as in my recipe, a large quantity of chopped kale.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough the soup could be made from start to finish and served right away, you can make it several hours, or even a day, in advance. This allows for the flavors to meld and for the potatoes to break down a bit. But since you don\u2019t want the pasta to be overcooked, cook it separately, and stir it in as a final step. Small, textured pasta shapes, like pennette, orecchiette or rigatoncini are the best choice. For potatoes, I like yellow-fleshed ones like Yukon or German Butterball, but russets will suffice.\n\nAs for the double-carbohydrate, starch-on-starch nature of this soup, I regard it as a satisfying win-win.", "title": "A Satisfying Soup From the Italian Pantry", "authors": ["David Tanis", "City Kitchen"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "In Toutiao\u2019s case, one of the accounts that were suspended this week had posted a saucy video of a woman in a short skirt. It got 57,000 views. Another suspended account had recently put up a post titled \u201cThe World\u2019s Ugliest Celebrities, Michael Jackson Is Ranked First, You Won\u2019t Want to Eat After Reading This.\u201d\n\n\u201cOnce you have more people watching, then you want to be more cautious,\u201d Wei-Ying Ma, who heads Toutiao\u2019s artificial intelligence lab, told a conference in Beijing last month.\n\nAs Toutiao\u2019s popularity has skyrocketed, Bytedance has become a darling of Silicon Valley investors such as Sequoia Capital. The company, which is currently valued at $20 billion, has been in talks with existing backers to raise new financing that would value the company at more than $30 billion, according to a person familiar with the discussions who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the details are not public.\n\nThat price tag would make Bytedance among the most valuable privately held technology companies in the world, not just in China. Airbnb is said to be valued at around $30 billion. SpaceX, the rocket maker founded by Elon Musk, is valued at $21 billion.\n\nBytedance has big plans for overseas expansion, too. It recently spent between $800 million and $1 billion to purchase Musical.ly, a video-based social network popular with teenagers in the United States and Europe. At the Beijing conference last month, a top Bytedance executive, Liu Zhen, said the company hoped to be earning half its revenue from outside China within the next five years.\n\nJinri Toutiao, whose name means \u201ctoday\u2019s headlines\u201d in Chinese and is pronounced JING-er TOE-tee-yow, aggregates content from various sources and looks much like Facebook\u2019s newsfeed. But instead of displaying articles and videos based on what your friends have shared, the app does so based on what you have previously read and watched on the app.\n\nIf you click on articles about iPhones, then Toutiao will feed you more tech coverage. After you watch a few cooking videos, the app will fetch you more clips of people wrapping dumplings and braising chicken\u2019s feet.", "title": "A Saucy App Knows China\u2019s Taste in News.
