Was this Instagram tribute to her posted earlier in the day with the knowledge that he would have to excuse himself for about 15 minutes at 9 p.m.?\n\nIt was the only thing that the HQties of Twitter wanted to know.\n\nEven Scott Rogowksy, the game\u2019s cult hero host, acknowledged Mr. Obama\u2019s image, though he seemed to take the president\u2019s presence in stride.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe salute you, sir,\u201d he said. \u201cThank you for your service.\u201d\n\nOf course, the 44th president is famously competitive, whether it be over the tastiness of his chili recipe or the number of push-ups he can pump out. For his birthday each year, he competes in a round-robin of athletic competitions with some of his closest friends.", "title": "A Savage Question About Obama and HQ, Answered", "authors": ["Jonah Engel Bromwich"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSPACE CRAFT: Fans of Pierce Brown\u2019s swashbuckling sci-fi adventure series won\u2019t be surprised to learn that he loved world-building from an early age. \u201cWhen I was a kid, we moved around, and I was forced to grow up in lots of places. I spent a lot of time alone. I\u2019d go into the woods and build forts and create these huge imaginary scenes.\u201d When he wrote the first volume in his best-selling \u201cRed Rising\u201d series, \u201cI started with the main character and shaped my world around him,\u201d he says. \u201cI was inspired by the plight of Irish immigrants in the 19th century and by the disenfranchisement of working classes.\u201d He\u2019s still dissecting social hierarchies in the fourth book in the series, \u201cIron Gold,\u201d which debuts on this week\u2019s hardcover fiction list at No. 3: \u201cI\u2019m exploring the lives of people who become casualties despite the best intentions of the story\u2019s heroes.\u201d\n\nPICTURE THIS: Two new historical biographies appear this week on the children\u2019s hardcover picture-book list: Brad Meltzer\u2019s \u201cI Am Harriet Tubman,\u201d which enters the list at No. 4, and Margot Lee Shetterly\u2019s \u201cHidden Figures,\u201d at No. 8. Shetterly \u2014 whose 2016 book about black female mathematicians at NASA during the early years of the space race has already been made into a movie and a young-reader chapter book \u2014 says she relished bringing her narrative to the 3-to-7 set. \u201cThese are the ones who need the story the most,\u201d she explains. \u201cTo encourage women and minorities to enter STEM fields, you need to start early.\u201d She adds, \u201cDistilling the story for them in no way means you dumb it down. You simplify concepts, but you don\u2019t assume children can\u2019t understand.\u201d\n\nPALACE POLITICS: David Cay Johnston\u2019s \u201cIt\u2019s Worse Than You Think\u201d debuts at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list, where it sits with three other titles about President Trump or his administration. Johnston, a veteran journalist, is not surprised by the appetite for such books. \u201cDuring the campaign, Donald Trump was like an accident on the other side of the highway, complete with fireworks and a marching band and dancing girls,\u201d he says. \u201cPeople were not paying attention to who he is; they were too busy watching the spectacle. But now people are saying, \u2018Wait a minute. What\u2019s going on here?\u2019\u201d In his book, Johnston says he is trying to show what members of Trump\u2019s administration have been doing for the last year, \u201cundermining rules on things like job safety, food safety, and air and water quality.\u201d", "title": "A Sci-fi Writer Inspired by the Plight of Irish Immigrants", "authors": ["Tina Jordan", "Inside The List"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Such questions were raised recently in connection with reports linking the Sackler family, prominent cultural donors, to the company that produces OxyContin, the powerful painkiller that has been involved in opioid overdoses. And some objected to the renaming of the Metropolitan Museum of Art\u2019s fountain plaza after the conservative philanthropist David H. Koch in 2014 (he gave $65 million).\n\n\u201cA political litmus test for who should serve can be very destructive to a nonprofit institution,\u201d said Reynold Levy, the former president of Lincoln Center. \u201cAs long as the mission and important portions of the program are supported by the trustee, what they do in the political world shouldn\u2019t be relevant.\u201d\n\nA similar effort by scientists, in 2015, called on the museum to cut ties with Mr. Koch, then a trustee. Less than a year later, having served on the board for 23 years, Mr. Koch resigned. At the time, both Mr. Koch and the museum said that the resignation was unrelated to the pressure campaign.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn March last year, a group of employees filed complaints with the museum\u2019s human resources department in an attempt to spur an internal conversation about Ms. Mercer\u2019s role on the board, but nothing came of it, according to one person involved in the effort who declined to be identified for fear of repercussions.\n\nThe museum emphasized that scientists and educators at the museum make decisions about scientific and educational content, not trustees and donors.\n\n\u201cWe believe that human-induced climate change is well-supported by scientific evidence and is one of the most serious issues currently facing our planet,\u201d the statement said. \u201cWe are deeply committed to presenting evidence-based, scientific information about climate change to a broad public.\u201d\n\nThe latest push to oust Ms. Mercer from the museum board was spearheaded by the Natural History Museum, a nonprofit traveling museum that also led the 2015 drive to remove Mr. Koch.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMuseums are among the most trusted sources of information in society,\u201d the organization\u2019s co-founder and director, Beka Economopoulos, said in an email. \u201cHaving a science denier and top funder of climate science denial campaigns in a leadership position at a science museum undermines the institution\u2019s credibility.\u201d\n\nMs. Mercer, a daughter of the hedge fund magnate Robert Mercer, has been on the museum\u2019s board since 2013. The Mercer Family Foundation has long supported a variety of conservative causes, including Breitbart News, the influential right-wing website founded by Andrew Breitbart and until recently run by Stephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trump\u2019s former chief strategist.\n\nThe Mercer family publicly distanced itself from Mr. Bannon this month after Mr. Bannon\u2019s provocative remarks about Mr. Trump were reported in Michael Wolff\u2019s book, \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House.\u201d\n\nTax records show that the Mercers have given a little over $19 million to a variety of conservative groups, including at least three that reject the scientific consensus around fossil fuel-driven climate change: the Heartland Institute in Illinois, as well as the CO 2 Alliance and the Center for the Study of Carbon Dioxide and Global Change. The foundation has given nearly $5.9 million to the Heartland Institute since 2008, compared to about $4 million to the museum since 2012.\n\nThe Mercer Family Foundation has also donated to New York City hospitals as well as the National Youth Science Foundation, which runs summer camps. But most of its money goes to conservative causes.\n\nThe foundation\u2019s 2016 return is not yet available on the Internal Revenue Service website. It was shared with The Times by the Climate Investigations Center, which tracks funding for organizations that reject established climate science. It is based in Washington and is supported by anonymous donors seeking to limit the risks of climate change.", "title": "A Science Denier at the Natural History Museum? Scientists Rebel", "authors": ["Robin Pogrebin", "Somini Sengupta"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 A winter storm in Lebanon has resurfaced a longstanding national problem, in the form of a swirling sea of garbage.\n\nPiles of trash began washing up Monday on the beaches of Zouk Mosbeh, a town 10 miles north of Beirut, leaving the shore littered with refuse. An earlier storm surge had dragged trash from a landfill out to sea, later depositing it along the coastline and up to 100 feet inland.\n\nPrime Minister Saad Hariri on Tuesday ordered a cleanup of the beaches in the Kaserwan district, home to Zouk Mosbeh and a region filled with beach resorts.", "title": "A Sea of Trash on Lebanon\u2019s Beaches", "authors": ["Nada Homsi"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "How else to describe a Lilliputian rendition of a photograph that\u2019s so realistically detailed, one subject called it \u201ccreepily accurate\u201d? A personal action figure? Mini-Me, like the character in the Austin Powers movies?\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPeople use the term \u20183-D selfie\u2019 a lot. It really isn\u2019t that,\u201d said Michael Anderson, the chief executive of Doob USA. \u201cWe refer to them as 3-D-printed replicas.\u201d\n\nDoob, which was founded five years ago and whose headquarters are in D\u00fcsseldorf, Germany, is betting big that people want to see themselves made small: smiling alone; hugging their spouses in an eerily perfected version of the old wedding-cake topper; astride a Harley-Davidson, tattooed arms naked to the wind. Whether you consider them cute or creepy, they are perhaps the most currently relatable example of the much buzzed-about, yet perplexing, 3-D printing.\n\nTo visit the SoHo store and be in the presence of so many real New Yorkers looking exactly like they do on the city\u2019s streets, only shrunken and displayed on tables and shelves, is, initially, surreal. You have stepped into some version of the new Alexander Payne movie, \u201cDownsizing,\u201d or that old Lily Tomlin-Charles Grodin flick \u201cThe Incredible Shrinking Woman.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOne 10-inch figurine of a man dressed fashionably in a tan blazer, scarf and black-frame architect\u2019s glasses, his dog lying obediently at his feet, was so lifelike that it captures his expression of self-satisfaction.\n\n\u201cAll that detail is integral,\u201d Mr. Anderson said. \u201cIf it\u2019s you, but it\u2019s small and blurry, it\u2019s just a trinket. But sometimes, on the larger figures, you can see the time on a person\u2019s watch.\u201d\n\nThe more thought given to one\u2019s appearance before the doobing process, the better the results, generally. Patterns and contrasting colors show up well, for instance. And a good pose can capture the inner you.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne family gathered three generations together for a group doob. A musician stood knees bent, blowing his horn. Then there\u2019s the bodybuilder who took his shirt off, showing his waxed six-pack abs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHeather Stern first got doobed in 2014, when she was eight months pregnant with her daughter, Rosie. She has celebrated Rosie\u2019s birthday every year since by getting doobed together. The naturalistic figures have made her think about \u201cthe toys we give to our daughters,\u201d Ms. Stern said, like American Girl dolls.\n\n\u201cFor your daughter to have an image of a normal female body is a positive thing,\u201d she said.\n\nBut what to do with a doob? They aren\u2019t sturdy enough to play with. Displaying them in your house or office may seem narcissistic. Ms. Stern keeps her doobs on a bookshelf at home with the Legos she builds (she is a mechanical engineer), though \u201cit\u2019s not like a centerpiece of the house,\u201d she said.\n\nShe added: \u201cPeople are shocked by it: \u2018Oh my God, that\u2019s amazing, what is it?\u2019\u201d\n\nOne fitting use is to advance the self-referential digital culture from which doobs sprung. That\u2019s what Ashley Holt did. A custom cake maker in Brooklyn, Ms. Holt had a doob made of herself posing mouth wide open, midbite. After she received the finished figurine, which takes about two to three weeks, she made a cake in the form of a peach. Then she posed her doob with the cake, took a picture and posted it to Instagram \u2014 \u201cto make it look like a tiny little person eating a giant peach,\u201d Ms. Holt said. \u201cI wanted to bring a doob into a cake design, rather than the standard cake topper.\u201d\n\nFor a finale, Ms. Holt returned to the Doob store weeks later and got a doob of herself holding her tiny cake-eating doob.\n\n\u201cI was wearing the same outfit,\u201d she said. \u201cThey call that a \u2018Meta Doob.\u2019\u201d", "title": "A Selfie for Your Shelf", "authors": ["Steven Kurutz"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "To try to steer the political narrative, the president took to Twitter on Friday with a vague account of the meeting, saying his remarks at the meeting were \u201ctough, but this was not the language used.\u201d\n\nBut Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, who also attended the meeting on immigration, told reporters on Friday that the president had used the expletive several times, and had said \u201cthings which were hate-filled, vile and racist.\u201d\n\n\u201cI cannot believe that, in the history of the White House in that Oval Office, any president has ever spoken the words that I personally heard our president speak yesterday,\u201d Mr. Durbin said.\n\nSenator Tim Scott, Republican of South Carolina, told The Post and Courier of Charleston that Mr. Graham had related Mr. Trump\u2019s remarks to him after the meeting, and he called news reports about them \u201cbasically accurate\u201d based on that account.\n\nAccording to three people briefed about the meeting, it featured a dramatic moment between the president and Mr. Graham, who referred to Mr. Trump during the 2016 presidential campaign as a \u201crace-baiting, xenophobic, religious bigot,\u201d but who has recently grown close to the president and has advised him on immigration policy.\n\nAfter Mr. Trump disparaged African nations in foul terms, they said, Mr. Graham answered with an impassioned defense of immigrants and immigration as essential to the American ideals of diversity and inclusion.\n\nMr. Graham has not responded to repeated requests for comment on the president\u2019s remarks or his own. But on Friday, he released a statement that appeared to confirm the tenor of both.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cFollowing comments by the president, I said my piece directly to him yesterday,\u201d Mr. Graham said. \u201cThe president and all those attending the meeting know what I said and how I feel. I\u2019ve always believed that America is an idea, not defined by its people but by its ideals.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Twitter posts on Friday, Mr. Trump charged that Democrats had fabricated parts of the exchange even as he defended the sentiment that prompted them.\n\nMr. Trump said he \u201cnever said anything derogatory about Haitians other than Haiti is, obviously, a very poor and troubled country,\u201d and denied that he had asked to remove them from the immigration proposal, adding: \u201cMade up by Dems.\u201d\n\nIn a joint statement released on Friday, two Republican senators who also attended the session, Tom Cotton of Arkansas and David Perdue of Georgia, charged that Democrats were acting dishonorably, claiming that they could not remember whether Mr. Trump used the words attributed to him.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump brought everyone to the table this week and listened to both sides, but regrettably, it seems that not everyone is committed to negotiating in good faith,\u201d the senators said. \u201cIn regards to Senator Durbin\u2019s accusation, we do not recall the president saying these comments specifically, but what he did call out was the imbalance in our current immigration system, which does not protect American workers and our national interest.\u201d\n\nAlso present at the meeting were the House majority leader, Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California; Representative Robert W. Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia and the chairman of the Judiciary Committee; and Representative Mario Diaz-Balart, Republican of Florida.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists.
