There is no excuse for it.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nThe bipartisan backlash to the president\u2019s comments intensified on Friday as Mr. Trump signed a proclamation at the White House for Martin Luther King Jr. Day, ignoring a question from a reporter about whether he is a racist.\n\nThe current debate about Mr. Trump\u2019s anti-immigrant talk unfolded one week before funding for the government is set to be exhausted without action from Congress, where Democrats have pressed to include an immigration plan to preserve protections for roughly 800,000 undocumented immigrants that Mr. Trump has moved to rescind. Under Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, a program created by President Barack Obama that is commonly known as DACA, they have obtained temporary, renewable work permits. Mr. Trump announced in September he was ending the program, setting a six-month clock before the first permits would begin expiring and calling on Congress to enact legislation to create a permanent solution in the meantime.\n\nA federal judge in San Francisco this week issued a nationwide injunction, putting that action on hold and ordering the Trump administration to continue the program pending a legal challenge.\n\nWhile lawmakers had been closing in on a bipartisan deal on the matter and Mr. Durbin and Mr. Graham had been hopeful that Mr. Trump was on the brink of endorsing it, the furor surrounding his remarks appeared to deepen the divisions surrounding any such plan, prompting the president to discount the chances of an agreement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nConceding only that his language was \u201ctough,\u201d Mr. Trump said on Twitter, \u201cWhat was really tough was the outlandish proposal made - a big setback for DACA!\u201d\n\nThe president\u2019s comments on Thursday came during a session in which senators were describing a plan to end the diversity visa lottery and allocate some of the visas instead to vulnerable populations from places including El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti that have had Temporary Protected Status in the United States. The measure under discussion would also provide legal status for DACA recipients and work permits for their parents, bar the children from sponsoring their parents for citizenship, and include $2.5 billion in border security funding.\n\nMr. Trump had responded approvingly to the proposal after hearing Mr. Graham and Mr. Durbin describe it over the phone on Thursday morning, according to people familiar with the conversations, but the pair arrived at the White House to brief the president about it not long after to find several Republicans they were not expecting sitting in on the session. Attendees were startled by the tone Mr. Trump took during the meeting, and by Friday morning, Mr. Trump was listing his objections to the measure on Twitter and working preemptively to shift blame if the dispute led to a government shutdown.\n\n\u201cUSA would be forced to take large numbers of people from high crime countries which are doing badly,\u201d Mr. Trump said of the immigration plan. \u201cThe Dems will threaten \u2018shutdown,\u2019 but what they are really doing is shutting down our military, at a time we need it most.\u201d", "title": "A Senior Republican Senator Admonishes Trump: \u2018America Is an Idea, Not a Race\u2019", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cGuilty of Not Being a Mind Reader\u201d (Op-Ed, Jan. 17):\n\nBari Weiss brushes aside the problematic behavior of the comedian Aziz Ansari in a sexual encounter to advance her notion that his actions are commonplace and therefore no big deal.\n\nNobody is expecting Mr. Ansari or anyone else to be a mind reader in the bedroom. But he didn\u2019t need to be, because, according to the account in the website Babe, which Mr. Ansari didn\u2019t dispute, Grace, his accuser, made it clear that she didn\u2019t want to proceed. She did this when she repeatedly removed her hand from his penis and when she said \u201cI don\u2019t want to feel forced\u201d and \u201cno, I don\u2019t think I\u2019m ready to do this.\u201d It\u2019s on him that he ignored those actions.\n\nGrace\u2019s ideas aren\u2019t \u201cretrograde\u201d; she was simply asking Mr. Ansari not to continue to push her for sex. She was asking him to treat sex as something that happens between two people, not something one does to the other. He may indeed have considered the encounter consensual, but that doesn\u2019t make it so.\n\nMs. Weiss makes it sound as if Grace didn\u2019t voice any objections. Whatever other sexual acts she consented to are irrelevant to his ignoring her direct statements. That\u2019s the issue.", "title": "Opinion | A Sexual Encounter, and a Dispute", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe End of Maine Shrimp?\u201d (Food, Dec. 27), about the species\u2019 disappearance from the state\u2019s warming waters:\n\nSome of my fondest childhood memories are of sitting on seaside rocks, eating fried Maine shrimp dipped in tartar sauce or slathered with ketchup. My father, a native-born Mainer, knew how to avoid the tourist lines and the high prices that came along with them. But those traditions I came to know and love are threatened by climate change.\n\nIn a state where our environment and economy are bound together, it\u2019s not just our favored traditions that are threatened, but our very way of life. We need action on climate at the federal level and an Environmental Protection Agency administrator who is up to the task. The current administrator, Scott Pruitt, is dismantling the agency, and it\u2019s time we replace him.\n\nKRISTIN JACKSON, PORTLAND, ME.\n\nThe writer is federal outreach coordinator for the Natural Resources Council of Maine.", "title": "Opinion | A Shrimpless State", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "DAVOS, Switzerland \u2014 On the campaign trail, Donald J. Trump the candidate denounced what he called \u201cthe false song of globalism.\u201d A year after taking office, President Trump came on Friday to tell the elites at Davos, who composed the song, that maybe they could still perform in harmony.\n\nIn an encounter that might have surprised even him two years ago, Mr. Trump reassured the world\u2019s political and financial leaders that his \u201cAmerica First\u201d agenda was not a rejection of international cooperation. The combative nationalist gave way to the let\u2019s-make-a-deal businessman, as he invited them to invest in what he called a resurgent United States.\n\n\u201cI believe in America,\u201d Mr. Trump told a jampacked auditorium on the last day of the annual World Economic Forum in Davos. \u201cAs president of the United States, I will always put America first, just like the leaders of other countries should put their country first also. But America first does not mean America alone. When the United States grows, so does the world.\u201d\n\nThat did not mean Mr. Trump has joined the globalism chorus. He has spent much of the last year trying to dismantle the international political and economic system represented by the Davos consensus \u2014 ripping up or renegotiating trade agreements, threatening or imposing tariffs on imports and working to curb the flow of immigration. In his speech on Friday, Mr. Trump insisted that cross-border trade had to be made fairer and vowed to take action against predatory practices.", "title": "A Sober Trump Reassures the Davos Elite", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "This was not the case last December with the Gulf Cup, a biennial tournament featuring eight national teams from the region that was scheduled to be played in Qatar. Ten days before the opening match, with Saudi Arabia, the U.A.E. and Bahrain refusing to participate, Qatar agreed to allow the tournament be switched to Kuwait. (The U.A.E. soccer association said that, in that case, its reasons for boycotting were not political.)\n\nThe tournament went off without major incidents: Saudi Arabia and the U.A.E. were placed in a different group from Qatar\u2019s, and their national teams never met on the field. But with no resolution to the diplomatic crisis, concern quickly shifted to this year\u2019s Champions League, a tournament featuring 32 of Asia\u2019s top clubs from various countries, set to begin its group stage in February.\n\nThe problem was that the tournament is split into eight groups of four teams, and with four clubs from Qatar, four from the Emirates and two from Saudi Arabia in the field, a collision of at least two of them seemed inevitable. (Iran, which has sided with Qatar in the political dispute, also has teams in the tournament and has its own diplomatic impasse with Saudi Arabia.) In the end, half of the eight groups contain at least one team from Qatar and one from Saudi Arabia or the U.A.E. (or both).\n\nIn January, the A.F.C. sent a delegation to the region to investigate the situation. But on Saturday it announced the games would be played at home sites after all, according to the event\u2019s regulations.\n\n\u201cThe regulations are clear, and matches must be played in home-and-away format, especially in club competitions,\u201d said Dato\u2019 Windsor John, the A.F.C.\u2019s general secretary. \u201cNow we need to think from an operational point of view. We need to sit down with them and see what is needed. In terms of venues, kickoff times and all the rest, there is a lot to do.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBoth the Saudi and U.A.E. federations expressed surprise at the decision but quickly indicated their participating clubs would not withdraw. The first tests arrive Feb. 12, when the group stage begins.\n\n\u201cIn view of U.A.E. F.A. keenness to cooperate with A.F.C., it announces the participation of its affiliated clubs in A.C.L. 2018,\u201d the U.A.E. federation said a statement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDorsey said that he saw compliance as a practical recognition by Saudi Arabia and the U.A.E. of the popularity of soccer in their countries, and an acknowledgment of the risks of denying fans access to prestigious games.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think it shows that there is a change in attitude so much as the need for domestic maneuvering,\u201d he said.\n\nThat does not mean there will be no trouble. During the Gulf Cup in December, a Saudi delegation walked out of a news conference to protest the presence of Qatari journalists. In September, Saudi authorities ejected a reporter from the Qatari-owned network beIN Sports from a crucial 2018 World Cup qualifier in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, despite the network\u2019s status as the broadcast rights-holder for the event.\n\nThe A.F.C. has yet to comment on the prospect of neutral venues when Iranian and Saudi clubs meet. Those two countries cut diplomatic ties in January 2016, and a year later that dispute led to a Champions League semifinal between Al Hilal of Saudi Arabia and Iran\u2019s Persepolis being held in U.A.E. and Oman. Instead of games attracting as many as 150,000 fans combined in Riyadh and Tehran, only 14,000 people actually attended the two neutral-site matches.\n\n\u201cTaking the matches to a third country is a temporary solution, or should be,\u201d said Steve Kim, a former head of club competitions at the A.F.C. \u201cThe games need to be played home and away. But in Asia, that can be difficult.\u201d\n\nAll this sporting drama and tension is playing out against the backdrop of the 2022 World Cup, to be hosted by Qatar. The tournament is central to the country\u2019s efforts to become an influential player on the global stage, and disrupting it \u2014 or forcing its cancellation \u2014 could be seen as a coup for its rivals.\n\nIn October, a leading U.A.E. security official wrote on Twitter that the blockade would end if Qatar gave up hosting rights to the tournament. \u201cIf the World Cup goes out of Qatar, the crisis in Qatar will end because the crisis was made to break it,\u201d said the official, the Dubai security chief Dhahi Khalfan.\n\nThe recent decision by the Champions League, then, is encouraging, according to Dorsey. \u201cIf the Gulf crisis is to last into 2022, then this breach of the blockade means that an even more significant breach would occur at the World Cup,\u201d he said.\n\nFor John and the A.F.C., the issue was much simpler.\n\n\u201cWe haven\u2019t thought about that,\u201d he said of the World Cup. \u201cWe have obligations to fans, media and sponsors, and we are focused on making sure that our fixtures are completed.\u201d", "title": "A Soccer Tournament Breaks Through the Boycott of Qatar", "authors": ["John Duerden"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "TOMS RIVER, N.J. \u2014 The hulking figure lay on its side in the long grass, partially mummified by a tarp and some bubble wrap. Brian Hanlon recognized it as soon as he saw the face.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s Shaq!\u201d he cried.\n\nIndeed, there was Shaquille O\u2019Neal, even larger than life, frozen mid-dunk. Hanlon rapped on the copper-toned torso. It was hollow as a PVC pipe.\n\nThis was just a polymer cast of the real statue of O\u2019Neal \u2014 that 900-pound monument of bronze and granite stands proudly outside the Pete Maravich Assembly Center in Baton Rouge, La., where O\u2019Neal played his college games for L.S.U. It didn\u2019t bother Hanlon that the cast was covered in snow, resting ignominiously outside an old chicken coop like a fallen oak. He\u2019d actually had forgotten it was out here. He\u2019d been busy.\n\nLast year, in fact, was Hanlon\u2019s busiest to date. He is a sculptor by trade, the creator of the kinds of statues that stipple the stadiums, plazas and rotundas celebrating our sports icons. In 2017, he unveiled 30 new monuments, from Charles Barkley at Auburn to Evander Holyfield in Atlanta to Jackie Robinson as a football player at the Rose Bowl. At Indiana University, 12 new statues of Hoosier basketball icons went up in the lobby of Assembly Hall; each was designed by Hanlon. And after the conclusion of this year\u2019s Winter Olympics, Hanlon could soon be adding skiers and figure skaters to his impressive roster of honorees.", "title": "A Sports Rodin Works in Bronze, and in Volume", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "That is what Ms. Brown, 38, has been trying to do, in many ways, since she started her company in 2006, and in the works she has made for other troupes, including Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. But it\u2019s especially true of the last three pieces she has created for her group, a series that reveals her growing trust in her own art.\n\n\u201cMr. TOL E. RAncE\u201d (2013) took on the stereotypes of blacks in entertainment, past and present, using film footage and spoken dialogue. \u201cBlack Girl: Linguistic Play\u201d (2015) looked at the experience of girlhood, making a dance out of playground games. Both had educational components: post-show conversations, study guides in the programs.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe first one was about other people\u2019s perceptions of black people,\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cAnd \u2018Black Girl\u2019 was more about the inside \u2014 my childhood, my perspective. Where is the black girl joy that I don\u2019t see in the media? How can we bring that to the stage?\u201d\n\n\u201cInk\u201d extends that idea \u2014 its brotherhood duet is a kind of male counterpart to \u201cBlack Girl\u201d \u2014 and also the method, turning everyday gestures into dance. Ms. Brown said there were more to investigate, like the handshakes known as dap. \u201cAnd I wanted to tie them to the African tradition and show how the gestural language keeps coming around.\u201d\n\nIn an opening solo, Ms. Brown \u2014 an exceptionally precise and powerful dancer \u2014 looks like she is stirring a pot, introducing gestures that recur with different meanings throughout the work. One second, she\u2019s an African griot miming stories, the next she\u2019s a hip-hop D.J. spinning records. \u201cI wanted it to be pops and flashes, not chronological,\u201d she said. \u201cSo that people see the different gestures but not in a particular place and time.\u201d\n\nThe mash-up continues through the other parts of \u201cink.\u201d But the live music is centered on percussion, on drums, and in a climactic section called \u201cMigration,\u201d the African element gains force in communal dance like a spiritual explosion.\n\nMs. Brown explained: \u201cIt\u2019s to say, \u2018This is what\u2019s been underneath the whole time, the thing that\u2019s carrying us through, the African spirit.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe idea of cultural continuity, that the present always contains the past, is itself a running theme in her work. It\u2019s the explicit message of her 2016 TED video \u201cA Visual History of Social Dance in 25 Moves,\u201d a four-minute survey course on African-American social dances, which has been viewed more than a million times online.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn \u201cink,\u201d the concept is presented more abstractly. Ms. Brown said she and the dancers worked on stripping the gestures down so that they didn\u2019t look \u201cdancey,\u201d then on building them back up so that they became alive in a theatrical sense. She gives her dancers the freedom to make choices, the way actors do.\n\n\u201cI almost look at my dancers as actors,\u201d she said, which isn\u2019t surprising, since she is one of the rare concert dance choreographers who sustains a high-level career in theater, too. Most recently, she did the choreography for the current Broadway revival of \u201cOnce on This Island.\u201d (In his review of the show for The New York Times, Jesse Green called her work \u201celectric.\u201d)\n\nPhoto\n\nFor Ms. Brown, there is no hard separation between her work in musical theater and her work for her company. The Double-Dutch jump-rope moves in \u201cBlack Girl\u201d had their origin in something she created for \u201cFortress of Solitude,\u201d the musical version of the Jonathan Lethem novel at the Public Theater in 2014.\n\n\u201cWorking in both worlds has helped me be a better choreographer,\u201d Ms. Brown said. \u201cBecause theater is all about the story, the story, the story. And as a choreographer in concert dance, I want to be a storyteller.\u201d\n\nTo Theresa Ruth Howard, a writer and former dancer who has followed Ms. Brown\u2019s career closely, \u201cink\u201d demonstrates how musical theater has contributed to Ms. Brown\u2019s artistic growth.\n\n\u201cThe work has become more and more abstract,\u201d Ms. Howard said, \u201cbut Camille has learned how to tell a story so well that she can now tell it in a purer concert dance form.\u201d\n\nMs. Howard \u2014 who described Ms. Brown\u2019s work as a love letter to black people, \u201cshowing things we want to see\u201d \u2014 also noticed another progression. \u201cCamille has always been concerned that people would miss or misunderstand things,\u201d she said. \u201cShe practically wrote a textbook in the program for \u2018Black Girl,\u2019 but now she\u2019s more willing to let the work speak for itself.\u201d\n\nMs. Brown agrees. \u201cWhen I was creating \u2018Black Girl,\u2019 I wanted it to be a piece that was recognizable for everyone,\u201d she said. \u201cI wanted it to be culturally specific, but with universal themes. But this new work is not about being universal.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe gestures are a language,\u201d she continued, \u201cand some people will recognize it, and think \u2018I know that\u2019 or \u2018I know that guy,\u2019 but other audience members won\u2019t be familiar with it.\u201d Similarly, references in the rhythms \u2014 reggae, dancehall, the beat from Mary J. Blige\u2019s \u201cReal Love\u201d \u2014 will carry strong associations for some people, but not for everyone.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI like that,\u201d Ms. Brown said, \u201cbecause it forces some audience members to think past what they think they know about black people.\u201d", "title": "A Storytelling Choreographer Who Listens to Her Audience", "authors": ["Brian Seibert"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u2193\n\nA Mystified Allergist\n\nThe specialist spent nearly two hours going over everything the woman had been exposed to \u2014 food, plants, toxins, anything that might have triggered this nearly fatal allergic reaction. There were no new exposures that day, nothing she hadn\u2019t eaten or touched many times before and after this latest attack. The most common cause of severe allergic reactions in adults is food, but the allergist couldn\u2019t identify any likely suspects. He was mystified. He asked her to share her diagnosis when she got one.\n\nFor months after returning to her home on Long Island, the woman was anxious about everything she ate, and she worried every night when she went to bed. She always kept a bottle of Benadryl and an EpiPen with her, but still she was terrified about what might happen if she was too far from a hospital the next time.\n\n\u2193\n\n\u2018I Need a Nurse!\u2019\n\nWhen her next attack happened \u2014 just 10 months later \u2014 she was already in Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in East Patchogue, N.Y. She was being treated with antibiotics for a devastating case of gastroenteritis due to salmonella. Her first meal, after days of nothing but clear liquids, was beef brisket with potatoes and carrots. It smelled good, but she had no appetite. She made herself eat a few bites anyway, knowing it was her first step toward going home.\n\nPhoto\n\nA couple of hours later, she felt a strange itch on the top of her head. She scratched reflexively. Then the recognition hit her like a slap: Not now, she thought. She grabbed the IV pole, still dripping fluids into her system, and ran out into the hallway. \u201cI need a nurse,\u201d she shouted. Her heart was pounding, and she knew what was coming next. Hospital staffers in scrubs descended on her. Was she having a panic attack? No, an allergy attack, she told them.\n\nThey helped her back into bed and gave her oxygen, Benadryl and steroids. \u201cWhat happened?\u201d someone asked. She told the whole story, plus something she now realized \u2014 every one of her attacks seemed to come a few hours after she ate beef. She didn\u2019t go through this every time she had a hamburger or steak; meat was a regular and much-loved part of her diet. But she was pretty sure that she had steak \u2014 or beef brisket, this time \u2014 before each episode.\n\nHer doctors were dubious. New food allergies \u2014 especially severe ones like hers \u2014 are uncommon in adults. This was much more likely to be an allergic response to one of the antibiotics they were giving her. The patient, though, found that theory hard to swallow. It might explain this episode, but what about the earlier ones? She hadn\u2019t been on antibiotics then. The doctors had no answer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2193\n\nWas a Tick to Blame?\n\nA nurse had a different theory about what happened, one the patient had heard before but never believed. There was some kind of tick, the nurse told her, whose bite could make you allergic to meat. She didn\u2019t know much about it. But, the nurse suggested, she should check it out.\n\nThe woman had been bitten by ticks before \u2014 who on Long Island hasn\u2019t? But was it really possible for a bite to produce this crazy reaction? Indeed it was, she discovered, when she got home and began doing some research. The bite of the lone star tick \u2014 named for a white spot shaped like Texas on the arachnid\u2019s back \u2014 could cause an allergic reaction to mammalian meat. The trigger was a sugar, identified as galactose-\u03b1-1,3-galactose and more casually known as alpha-gal, a carbohydrate found in the flesh of all nonprimate mammals.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow the tick bite triggers this allergy is not yet known. The link between the tick \u2014 whose range extends from southern Florida to Maine and as far west as Iowa \u2014 and the resulting alpha-gal allergy was first described in 2009 by Thomas Platts-Mills, a professor at the University of Virginia, who himself developed the disorder. Unlike most food allergies, in which symptoms occur within minutes of consuming the allergen, the alpha-gal reaction is delayed. The symptoms \u2014 ranging from a rash to nausea to shortness of breath and even anaphylaxis \u2014 can appear four to six hours after a meal containing meat. Stranger still, the reaction doesn\u2019t occur after every exposure.\n\n\u2193\n\nA Diet Changed Forever\n\nThe diagnosis of mammalian meat allergy (M.M.A.) can be confirmed with a blood test that identifies antibodies to alpha-gal. The patient contacted Diane Cymerman, an allergist she had seen years earlier for seasonal allergies. Cymerman asked her to list all the foods she consumed before her last episode in the hospital and had her blood tested for antibodies to everything on the list, down to the black pepper and parsley seasoning. And to alpha-gal.\n\nThe first results came back the following week: She had a moderate allergy to beef, but everything else was normal. The following month, the test results for alpha-gal antibodies came back. She was wildly allergic to galactose-\u03b1-1,3-galactose. Cymerman called the patient with the news. She had to avoid eating meat from mammals \u2014 and everything derived from them, including Jell-O and other foods and medications made from gelatin. Even safe foods cooked on a grill that has also been used for meat can be contaminated with enough alpha-gal to trigger a reaction.\n\nThe patient contacted the allergist back in Iowa and told him what she had. He was amazed. He had only recently heard a lecture on this phenomenon. He had never seen it before her case.\n\nIt hasn\u2019t been easy for this Iowa transplant to give up beef and other meat that comes from mammals. Some days, she tells me, just thinking about a juicy hamburger or steak makes her stomach growl. But she remembers her terror and that long drive to the Iowa hospital and sticks to chicken, fish and vegetables.", "title": "A Strange Itch, Trouble Breathing, Then Anaphylactic Shock", "authors": ["Lisa Sanders"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201chearth, home and parish, towards\n\n\u201cthe wider world beyond\n\n\u201cway beyond.\u201d\n\nOr a memory of existential awareness (upon receiving his daughter\u2019s birth certificate) might suddenly turn mundane: \u201cthere was a metaphysical reality to her now \u2014 she had stepped into that political index which held a space for her in the state\u2019s mindfulness \u2026 this document which did not tag or enumerate her but freed her into her own political space, our citizen daughter who\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201care we ever going to leave this car park or are you going to sit all day gawping at that certificate\n\n\u201cMairead called from the back seat.\u201d\n\nMcCormack is a pleasure to read on everything from King Crimson \u2014 \u201cmusic for engineers, all those dissonant chords laid down at right angles\u201d \u2014 to picking out eyeglasses \u2014 \u201ceach made me look foolish in one way or another, too comic or too odd or too obviously chasing something I no longer possessed\u201d \u2014 but it\u2019s the connections that the book keeps coming back to, the way one story relates to another, the whole greater than its parts.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSticklers for verisimilitude might rightly point out that nobody really \u201cthinks\u201d in such articulate well-cadenced paragraphs (Molly Bloom\u2019s mind is a rat\u2019s nest by comparison), but the coherence McCormack has opted for is more than stylistic. In some ways, it\u2019s what the whole book is about. More than once Marcus counts himself \u201cone of those men who had always structured his days around radio news bulletins,\u201d and his struggle against a fractured worldview fed by media saturation is the novel\u2019s most compelling and recurring theme. The stories he dwells on longest involve a water contamination catastrophe that makes Mairead very ill (\u201chistory and politics were now a severe intestinal disorder, spliced into the figure of my wife who sweated along the pale length of her body\u201d) and a case of political graft sabotaging a public construction project he\u2019d overseen as an engineer. Meanwhile, his own \u201cchildhood ability to get ahead of myself and reason to apocalyptic ends\u201d he sees reinvented in his son, Darragh, as a \u201ckind of apocalyptic riffing,\u201d the media-age glibness of the young. It\u2019s in this context that a memory of something as innocuous as a video chat with Darragh (who was bumming around Australia, calling intermittently in the middle of the night) leads Marcus to imagine the world\u2019s end: \u201cstanding hollow-eyed in the middle of some desolation with the wind whistling through your skull, just before the world collapses\n\n\u201cmountains, rivers and lakes\n\n\u201cacres, roods and perches\n\n\u201cinto oblivion, drawn down into that fissure in creation where everything is consumed in the raging tides and swells of non-being, the physical world gone down in flames\n\n\u201cmountains, rivers and lakes\n\n\u201cand pulling with it also all those human rhythms that bind us together and draw the world into a community, those daily\n\n\u201crites, rhythms and rituals.\u201d\n\nMcCormack\u2019s sense of Armageddon is at once familiarly contemporary and blessedly contentious. Marcus\u2019s gloominess is tempered by his own self-skepticism and struggle, but the true counterpoint is an agnostic sort of spirituality that accumulates over the course of the novel, a sense of the connectedness of humanity, the world in all its parts, \u201cthat harmonic order,\u201d as Marcus imagines, \u201cwhich underlay everyone and everything.\u201d It is this same sense of order he identifies earlier, \u201cupholding the world like solar bones, that rarefied amalgam of time and light whose extension through every minute of the day is visible from the moment I get up in the morning and stand at the kitchen window with a mug of tea in my hand, watching the first cars of the day passing on the road.\u201d\n\nFor all its apparent stylistic complexity, \u201cSolar Bones\u201d is a beautifully simple book. Death has not solved Marcus\u2019s worldly problems, only offered a shift of scope, and this is what McCormack\u2019s novel offers as well. Where modernism took a world that appeared to be whole and showed it to be broken, \u201cSolar Bones\u201d takes a world that can\u2019t stop talking about how broken it is, and suggests it might possibly be whole.", "title": "A Stylistically Daring Novel Considers Fundamental Questions", "authors": ["Martin Riker", "Mike Mccormack"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Their wedding, which took place less than a year after they met, was highlighted in a Vows column on July 12, 1992. Now, more than 25 years later, they have not grown more alike, only more tolerant. \u201cI don\u2019t think there\u2019s a day that goes by when we don\u2019t view the world differently,\u201d Ms. London, 56, said.\n\nThey live in Flemington, N.J., in a house overflowing with her oil paintings and pastel drawings; Mr. Sirota has numbered and cataloged each piece.\n\nWhen their two children \u2014 Julia Sirota, 22, and Craig Sirota, 20 \u2014 were growing up, Ms. London would sometimes turn the kitchen into an art studio and forget about making dinner. Mr. Sirota, who has been a research scientist at Exxon Research and Engineering (now ExxonMobil) in Annandale, N.J., for more than 30 years, would just order takeout for everyone. He is also the one who makes sure the fire extinguishers in the house are working.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s technical, and my abilities are much more hands-in-the-dirt kind of thing,\u201d Ms. London said. \u201cI\u2019m the one bringing home the animals, adding more pets, much to his consternation. He\u2019ll say, \u2018What? This wasn\u2019t what we planned!\u2019\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cWe have things we don\u2019t see eye to eye on but there\u2019s never been a doubt that overall, we are a team. I think marriage is constantly choosing to be a team. It\u2019s a conscious decision \u2014 this is a priority. This is home base.\u201d\n\nOver the years, Mr. Sirota has continued working on \u201cFrankenstein,\u201d now the official title of his musical. In fact, as Julia and Craig got older, it became a family project. While some families work on puzzles together, the Sirotas huddled around the piano, revising \u201cFrankenstein.\u201d \u201cI needed to find Cara, get married and have children so they could help me with the lyrics,\u201d Mr. Sirota said. \u201cMy daughter did a lot of the editing. She said, \u2018You can\u2019t have this verse, it\u2019s heteronormative.\u2019 I said, \u2018What?\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt one point in the musical, an older couple warns a younger one about marriage. \u201cAll days won\u2019t be so sunny,\u201d they say, and, \u201cHis lips won\u2019t always taste like honey.\u201d Also: \u201cYoung bride, the man whose ring you wear will one day start to lose his hair.\u201d\n\nAfter many years together, Mr. Sirota and Ms. London agreed, the real stuff somehow becomes the romantic stuff. \u201cYou grow to love the imperfections,\u201d Mr. Sirota said. \u201cIn fact, the longer and longer you are in a marriage, the less you even want perfection.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Sirotas are empty nesters now (\u201cWe can eat anything, anytime!\u201d Ms. London said), and \u201cFrankenstein\u201d has found a larger audience. After a short break for the holidays, performances of \u201cFrankenstein\u201d resume Jan. 15 at St. Luke\u2019s Theater on West 46th Street in New York and continue every Monday night.\n\nIn recent years, Mr. Sirota said, their marriage has entered new territory. Each year seems to bring a strange mix of graduation ceremonies, opening nights, college acceptances and funerals, of \u201ccongratulations and condolences.\u201d\n\nIn 2011, Ms. London\u2019s father died of brain cancer and last March, Mr. Sirota\u2019s father died of Alzheimer\u2019s disease. Toward the end of his life, he could not remember the names of his children but he could perfectly recall the lyrics to his favorite songs. Whenever Mr. Sirota and Ms. London visited him, they would all sing together. \u201cWith gusto,\u201d Mr. Sirota said.\n\nAfter Mr. Sirota\u2019s mother died in 2015, he found a stash of letters she had secretly written to him when he was a teenager. In one, she outlined \u2014 more like conjured, it turns out \u2014 the type of woman she hoped he would marry.\n\n\u201cIt described Cara,\u201d he said, his voice cracking with emotion. \u201cIf she had to invent a daughter-in-law, it would have been Cara.\u201d", "title": "A Successful Marriage Is Never as Easy as A, B, C", "authors": ["Lois Smith Brady", "State Of The Unions"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Iceye-X1 has limitations. The satellite\u2019s instrument can take only two snapshots every hour and a half; it spends the rest of the time recharging its batteries. It also sends just one wavelength of radar pulses.\n\nOn the other hand, shuttle flights at the time cost hundreds of millions of dollars each and lasted a couple of weeks at most. Mr. Caro\u2019s radars spent most of the time on the ground, turned off. Development took years, and proposals to NASA to send another radar satellite into orbit never came to fruition.\n\nMr. Modrzewski said his company is already developing more capable successors \u2014 each one is designed to last only about three years \u2014 and a constellation of small satellites could provide world coverage. The next version of the satellite will more than double the ground resolution, Mr. Modrzewski said.\n\nBut the single satellite now in orbit could provide valuable information on sea ice, even at night or when the region is obscured by clouds.\n\n\u201cIf you\u2019re on an icebreaker and you wanted to know the best way to navigate, a SAR image can really help you with that,\u201d Mr. Caro said.\n\nThe dream of a bigger, more advanced synthetic aperture radar mission also continues with Nisar, a collaboration between NASA and India\u2019s space agency. \u201cAll the bells and whistles you can imagine,\u201d said Mr. Caro, who is participating in the design review. But that mission may not launch until 2021.", "title": "A Suitcase-Size Satellite\u2019s Big Image of Frozen Earth Below", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "After that, Ms. Butrus contacted Mr. Buck via prepaid cellphones she picked up at a Walgreens drugstore. Every six months or so, she flew to Zurich to withdraw money directly from Mr. Buck. She would return to the United States secretly carrying just under $10,000 in cash \u2014 the cutoff for having to make a customs declaration.\n\nThe setup allowed Ms. Butrus to avoid paying tens of thousands of dollars in income taxes. And it wouldn\u2019t have been possible without Mr. Buck and Bank Frey.\n\nAs much as chocolate and watches, Switzerland is known for bank secrecy. That made the country a destination for money that the wealthy wanted to hide. Last decade, it also made Swiss banks targets for an assault by the United States government, which was tired of Americans escaping taxes on money in offshore accounts.\n\nMany banks came clean, divulging their clients to American authorities. Many Americans, including Ms. Butrus, searched for new places to park their money.\n\nBank Frey was among the very few to defy the legal onslaught. And Mr. Buck, a clean-cut and self-confident 28-year-old at the time he met Ms. Butrus, was the bank\u2019s public face, responsible for landing and then managing American accounts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat put Mr. Buck in the government\u2019s cross hairs. In 2013, a federal grand jury indicted him for conspiring to help Americans avoid taxes. It seemed like another blow against Swiss bank secrecy.\n\nBut things didn\u2019t go as prosecutors had planned \u2014 and the chain of events could have big consequences for America\u2019s fight to keep people from evading taxes using offshore bank accounts.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Small Outfit\n\nMr. Buck was raised in Germany. His parents had been championship ice dancers; his mother competed in figure skating for Switzerland in the 1972 Olympics in Japan.\n\nHis father ran an insurance company, and Mr. Buck figured that one day he would take it over. But an acquaintance from business school offered him a job in early 2007 at Bank Frey. The bank was tiny, with about 20 employees. Mr. Buck shared an office with four people, including the bank\u2019s receptionist. \u201cWe all got along well,\u201d he said.\n\nThe business revolved around clients that the bank\u2019s founder, Markus Frey, had accumulated over the years, according to Mr. Buck and the court testimony of another former bank employee. At first, there wasn\u2019t a focus on Americans.\n\nThen, in 2008, a legal earthquake shook the foundations of Swiss banking. American prosecutors started filing criminal charges against bankers and executives who had set up accounts for Americans. In 2009, UBS, the huge Swiss bank, admitted helping Americans hide money from the Internal Revenue Service and agreed to provide authorities with the names of its tax-dodging clients.\n\nSoon Swiss banks were expelling American clients.\n\nNot Bank Frey. It didn\u2019t have offices in the United States, and executives didn\u2019t see it as their responsibility to police whether their clients were paying taxes.\n\n\u201cWe decided there\u2019s no reason not to maintain business with American clients,\u201d Mr. Buck said in an interview. Executives consulted with legal experts to ensure they weren\u2019t crossing any lines. \u201cWe really tried to make sure that how we did the business is correct.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOpening accounts for desperate Americans seemed like a golden opportunity. \u201cThe positioning of Bank Frey as a solely Swiss private bank is now considered as a competitive advantage by the market,\u201d the bank\u2019s chief executive, Gregor Bienz, said at a board meeting in late 2008, according to records of the meeting. Mr. Bienz didn\u2019t respond to requests for comment.\n\nOver the next few years, hundreds of millions of dollars in American deposits flowed from Swiss banking stalwarts \u2014 institutions like Credit Suisse and Julius Baer \u2014 to Bank Frey. Its number of American clients roughly tripled, according to court records. By September 2012, nearly half of the bank\u2019s $2.1 billion in assets was held on behalf of American taxpayers.\n\nThe Matterhorn Debit Card\n\nMs. Butrus was one of them. C. Richard Lucy, a former Goldman Sachs and Bank of America executive in New York, was another.\n\nIn late 2009, Mr. Lucy\u2019s contact at Julius Baer, where he\u2019d had an account for many years, told him he had to move it elsewhere. Mr. Lucy traveled to Zurich and met with about 15 banks. None would take his money, according to his court testimony.\n\nThere was one exception. \u201cA couple of times the name Bank Frey came up as a bank that was new and aggressively seeking out accounts,\u201d he testified. (He didn\u2019t respond to requests for comment.)\n\nSure enough, when Mr. Lucy showed up at Bank Frey\u2019s offices, Mr. Buck said he would open him an account.\n\nMr. Lucy was impressed by Mr. Buck\u2019s assurances that his bank had nothing to worry about in the American tax-evasion investigations. \u201cI had found what I was looking for,\u201d Mr. Lucy said.\n\nMr. Lucy said that Mr. Buck arranged for him to get a Matterhorn-emblazoned debit card that didn\u2019t have Bank Frey\u2019s or Mr. Lucy\u2019s names on it. Mr. Lucy was told that, when he needed money, he should call Bank Frey and ask them to load money onto the debit card. He could use it at any ATM.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Lucy wanted to bring some account documentation back to New York. He said Mr. Buck advised him not to take anything with Bank Frey\u2019s name on it. (Mr. Buck denies giving that advice.) Mr. Lucy took a pair of scissors and snipped Bank Frey\u2019s name and logo off the paperwork.\n\nBack in Manhattan, Mr. Lucy bought a prepaid phone card for his calls to Zurich. He made them from a pay phone outside his apartment building. When that phone was damaged, the only other functioning pay phone he could find nearby was inside the kitchen of a boutique hotel. Surrounded by the kitchen\u2019s hubbub, he chatted on the phone with his Swiss banker.\n\nBy the turn of the decade, other Swiss banks were booting their American customers \u2014 and handing them glossy Bank Frey brochures on the way out the door.\n\nMr. Buck, who eventually rose to be Bank Frey\u2019s head of private banking, said he felt he wasn\u2019t doing anything wrong. All the same, he warned one client, Christine Warsaw, against sending banking instructions through the United States Postal Service, she said in court. \u201cNo USPS, use fax,\u201d she wrote in a note to herself. Mr. Buck said he didn\u2019t tell her not to send materials through the mail.\n\nBy 2011, it was dangerous for Americans to keep their money in undeclared offshore accounts. More banks were handing over client lists to the Justice Department. If you showed up on a list, prosecutors might pursue you.\n\nA safer option was to turn yourself in to the I.R.S. through a voluntary self-disclosure program. It allowed taxpayers to pay back taxes, cooperate with investigators and move on with their lives.\n\nMs. Butrus closed her Bank Frey account and eventually declared the money to the I.R.S. She paid her taxes and a stiff penalty and pledged to help the I.R.S. and prosecutors. Mr. Lucy did, too. On disclosure forms, both identified Mr. Buck as their relationship manager.\n\nPhoto\n\nProsecutors were hunting for bankers to hold accountable. The theory was that bankers knew they were enabling Americans to break the law and therefore were part of a conspiracy to defraud the United States government. Prosecutors turned to people including Ms. Butrus and Mr. Lucy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy 2013, more than 20 employees of Swiss financial institutions had been criminally charged. At least a dozen pleaded guilty and received a fine, probation or both. Several hunkered down in Switzerland, which refused to extradite its citizens to the United States for actions that weren\u2019t illegal in Switzerland.\n\nNone had actually gone on trial.\n\n\u2018Do It Now\u2019\n\nAt 5 o\u2019clock one morning in April 2013, Mr. Buck was awakened by a phone call. Bank Frey\u2019s chief executive was on the line. \u201cGo look at Bloomberg,\u201d Mr. Buck recalls him saying, referring to the business-news service.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sleeping,\u201d Mr. Buck said he replied.\n\n\u201cDo it now,\u201d his boss ordered.\n\nMr. Buck pulled out his cellphone. There it was: an article saying he had been indicted.\n\nTerrified, Mr. Buck skimmed the indictment. The indictment made clear that his former clients were assisting the government. \u201cIt was surreal,\u201d Mr. Buck said.\n\nMr. Buck, 32 years old at the time and single, went to work to hand in his I.D. card and cellphone. He was placed on paid leave; the bank would cover his legal expenses.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThen Mr. Buck headed to his sister\u2019s house. It was her husband\u2019s birthday, and they were hosting a barbecue.\n\nHis sister, Sylvia Muther, was nearly nine months pregnant. \u201cWe were scared he\u2019d go to jail,\u201d she said. \u201cWe tried not to think about that.\u201d\n\n\u201cI got hammered,\u201d Mr. Buck said.\n\nMr. Buck spent months weighing his options. He could plead guilty and be done with it. He could spend the rest of his life in Switzerland, which wouldn\u2019t extradite him. Or he could fight the charges.\n\nThat third road was perilous. If Mr. Buck won at trial, he would be free \u2014 and the Justice Department\u2019s fight against bankers who enable tax evasion would be dealt a serious blow. If he lost, he was looking at up to five years in prison.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn October 2014, one of UBS\u2019s top executives, Raoul Weil, went on trial in Florida. Federal prosecutors accused him of helping clients hide billions. Mr. Weil\u2019s lawyers argued he had no knowledge of or responsibility for what had happened. The jury deliberated for barely an hour before acquitting him.\n\nThe same week, a Los Angeles jury acquitted an Israeli banker who faced similar accusations. The Americans\u2019 pursuit of foreign bankers no longer looked invincible.\n\nA few months later, on a cloudy morning in January 2015, Mr. Buck was skiing with friends in the Swiss Alps. Above the tree line, they started their descent.\n\nA sign on the slope marked the boundary between France and Switzerland. Mr. Buck realized he was crossing an international border \u2014 and that meant he theoretically could be picked up on an American arrest warrant in France. \u201cI was scared,\u201d Mr. Buck said.\n\nHe told his friends to continue without him. He snapped off his skis, trudged back up the slope and skied down the Swiss side of the mountain.\n\nMr. Buck realized he couldn\u2019t spend the rest of his life fearful of crossing a border. \u201cThere was no way I was just going to stay in Switzerland,\u201d he said.", "title": "A Swiss Banker Helped Americans Dodge Taxes. Was It a Crime?", "authors": ["David Enrich"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Yes, the United States has a role to play in holding Mr. Assad accountable for the crimes he has committed against his own people and preventing him from committing more. But the president doesn\u2019t have the power to unilaterally make the decision to commit American troops to stop Mr. Assad by force. He needs to make his case to Congress and the American people, as well as the international community. Inserting American troops into this situation on his own is not just bad policy, it is illegal under both the Constitution and international law.\n\nStart with the Constitution. The founders created a system in which the power to declare war rests with Congress, not the president. The 1973 War Powers Resolution requires the president to notify Congress within 48 hours of introducing armed forces into hostilities in the absence of a declaration of war. The president must then terminate the use of armed forces within 60 days (with 30 days for withdrawal) unless Congress has declared war or otherwise authorized the use of military force.\n\nThe Trump foreign policy team has made clear that it does not think it must abide by any of these rules, and the new commitment announced by Secretary Tillerson shows that it is ready to break them. Clearly and lamentably, the president is prepared to flout constitutional limits on his authority to commit our troops on his own.\n\nThe Trump administration might argue that the troops are already in Syria, so keeping them there isn\u2019t \u201cintroducing them.\u201d But that would make a mockery of the statute. The Obama administration explained in 2015 that the authorizations for the use of military force that Congress agreed to in 2001 and 2002 provided the legal basis for operations against the Islamic State because they were broadly aimed at terrorism as a threat. That justification was tenuous, but surely nothing in the statutes could plausibly be said to extend to an American military presence in Syria after the Islamic State has been credibly debilitated.\n\nWe\u2019re not the first ones to point out such concerns. Senators Tim Kaine, a Virginia Democrat, and Jeff Flake, an Arizona Republican, have worked for years to draw attention to the absence of legal authorization for military operations in the Middle East. And Bob Corker of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, made clear at a recent committee hearing that if the United States were to remain in Syria to fight Iranian proxies, \u201cthe authorizations are not there for that kind of activity.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | A Syria Plan That Breaks the Law", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Always Big\n\nBobroczkyi said the day he met Porzingis, while visiting a basketball academy in Seville, Spain, was the first time in a long while that he stood eye-to-eye with somebody other than his father. Porzingis was 7-foot-1 at the time. Bobroczkyi was 14.\n\nBobroczkyi was always tall, even when he was little. He passed six feet before his ninth birthday. He dunked at age 12. His father, Zsigmond, is 7-1, and his mother, Brunhilde, a former volleyball player, is 6-1. Still, their boy\u2019s size raised concerns. At the Cleveland Clinic, doctors ruled out Marfan syndrome, a genetic condition of the connective tissue that can lead to life-threatening heart trouble. Other tests over the years eliminated other, potentially worrisome, conditions.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe made all kinds of tests through the years to ensure everything was all right,\u201d the father wrote in an email. \u201cWe made them everywhere, every year, once including Rome, Seville, Washington, Vitoria, Budapest. Everything was fine.\u201d\n\nIn Bobroczkyi\u2019s hometown, Arad, in western Romania, he was known mostly because of his father, who had played professionally with the Romanian clubs Elba Timisoara and West Petrom Arad, and even with Muresan on Romania\u2019s national team, forming what might have been the world\u2019s tallest frontcourt at the time. But he began to garner attention when, in middle school, he surpassed his father\u2019s height.\n\nHe went to Italy to play for an amateur club, A.S. Stella Azzurra, but took a year off from basketball to work on his frame, which was struggling to support his long limbs. Around that time, Bob Bossman, director of the basketball program at Spire, discovered a YouTube video of Bobroczkyi coolly knocking down 3-pointers and making passes.\n\n\u201cI saw he has potential,\u201d Bossman said. \u201cYou don\u2019t get to work with a kid like that often.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBossman reached out to Bobroczkyi on Facebook. The conversation began: Bossman told him about the facilities, the chance to play on a team with some of the nation\u2019s top recruits, to attend a small boarding school down the road, to practice at an Olympic training site. When Bobroczkyi and his family visited the campus in 2016, he packed a bag and did not return to Italy.\n\nHe first lived in a dorm at Grand River, a 187-year-old preparatory academy with 80 students. School officials brought in an eight-foot bed for his room and custom desks in his classrooms. He has since moved into a house with his basketball teammates at Spire; the bed could not fit in the door there, he said, so Bobroczkyi props two suitcases at the end of his twin with a pillow on top to support his feet.\n\n\u201cYou have to get used to it,\u201d he said of his height, a sizable understatement given the challenges that come with it. Doorways are perpetually too low. Pants need to be custom-ordered. Shirts are XXXXXL.\n\nHis team once flew him to Hartford for a game, but forgot to reserve a seat for him in an exit row.\n\n\u201cNever flying again, Coach,\u201d Bobroczkyi told Bossman when he landed. On the bus ride back to Ohio, he sat in the back row, his legs splayed out down the aisle.\n\nDeveloping Game\n\n\u201cYes, Rob! Thirties! You\u2019re on them!\u201d\n\nThe voice of Brandon Strausser, the strength and conditioning coach at Spire, echoed around the cavernous performance center. Bobroczkyi lay on a bench with 30-pound dumbbells on either side of him, ready for his first rep of 10 presses.\n\nStrausser and John Wallace, Spire\u2019s performance director, had tailored a workout plan for Bobroczkyi that was like nothing they had ever attempted. It was arguable that nobody had created anything like it. After all, whose body could compare?", "title": "A Teenager\u2019s Basketball Dream Is Size XXXXXL", "authors": ["Zach Schonbrun"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Within two years, her appetite for the sport had returned. She returned to the tour and continued to study. She would not crack the top 200 again or reach the WTA Tour level, but she found herself enjoying tennis more than ever as part of a balanced life.\n\nThen came the violent episode in 2011. At a small tournament in Versmold, Germany, Tamaela was watching her friend Danielle Harmsen compete in a qualifying match against Karen Barbat. With Harmsen up a break at 4-2 in the first set, Barbat\u2019s father, Mihai, became enraged.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe screamed racial insults at Tamaela, whose father was born in the Netherlands to immigrants from the Maluku Islands in Indonesia, and struck her in her temple. She collapsed to the ground and was unconscious for several minutes.\n\n\u201cHe started talking to me and I didn\u2019t even know what was happening,\u201d Tamaela said.\n\nWhen she regained consciousness, she went to a police station to file a report, but later, according to news media reports, she began to vomit continuously and was taken in an ambulance to a nearby hospital. She was diagnosed with a concussion and kept overnight, Tamaela said.\n\nMihai Barbat was banned from the tournament, and his daughter was disqualified from both singles and doubles. In Danish news media reports, Barbat and his daughter claimed that he acted in self-defense after being provoked by Tamaela, which she denies. The Barbats had returned to their home in Denmark before the German police could contact them. Mihai Barbat was not arrested.\n\nHe had a history of erratic behavior on tour, including an arrest one year earlier for attempted drunken driving in a parking lot outside a tournament in Copenhagen. The International Tennis Federation ultimately banned him from its events for two years.\n\n\u201cThis is the truth in tennis: There are parents that are just nuts,\u201d Tamaela said. \u201cI feel sorry for their kids.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKaren Barbat apologized to Tamaela the next year.\n\n\u201cShe came to me, she apologized, but I haven\u2019t seen him,\u201d Tamaela said. \u201cI don\u2019t think I would even recognize him if I see him. It was quick.\u201d\n\nEager to shake off the episode, Tamaela entered a tournament in Rotterdam one month after the attack. It would be her last.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI recovered and I wanted to play a little bit, but then I got unwell on court,\u201d she said. \u201cI started playing a little bit too early. I was feeling bad on court, so I thought, O.K., I\u2019m just going to finish. I had been thinking of finishing before.\u201d\n\nTamaela\u2019s concussion symptoms faded after three or four months, though she said, \u201cever since then I still have sometimes a tough time remembering things.\u201d Her decision to stop playing stuck.\n\nShe began full-time work as a physiotherapist and savored the stability and security of a normal job and work schedule.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTennis came calling again in the form of a friend from tour: Krunic, a talented, diminutive Serbian. Though nearly a decade apart in age, the pair shared a close bond. Krunic had been the first person outside Tamaela\u2019s family to contact her when she was hospitalized.\n\nAt first Krunic asked for only a few weeks at a time when her normal coaches were unable to travel with her. But in the summer of 2016, Krunic asked Tamaela if she would join her on the tour as her primary coach.\n\nTamaela was reluctant.\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Alex, come on, I have my life here, my family, a full-time job with a contract,\u2019\u201d she recalled. \u201cIt\u2019s quite a big step for me to take, and I always like security. I love to be home with my family. I had to give it some thought.\u201d\n\nTamaela said her boss told her: \u201c\u2018Elise, if you want to do it, you\u2019ve got to do it. And if you don\u2019t like it, come back.\u2019 So I had my security there, and I was just going to try, and I\u2019d go back if I didn\u2019t like it. But I\u2019m still here.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe pair have made great strides. Krunic finished 2016 ranked 147th, and has climbed over 100 spots to her current spot at 45th, a career high.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKrunic, who lost in the first round of the Australian Open last week, opened her season with a run to the quarterfinals at the Brisbane International. She beat the top-seeded Garbi\u00f1e Muguruza, who retired in the third set because of cramping in the stiflingly humid summer weather.\n\nThat Krunic earned an impressive upset on the strength of her conditioning is not incidental. Tamaela pulls double duty as a coach with tennis experience and a credentialed physiotherapist, giving her a dual insight few others have.\n\n\u201cI worked a lot with professional athletes, and I know a lot of injuries are just overuse,\u201d Tamaela said. \u201cAlmost every injury is overuse, unless it\u2019s a trauma like in soccer. But in tennis, it\u2019s most of the time overuse. So that\u2019s what we\u2019re trying to find, this balance.\u201d\n\nTamaela is also uncommon as a female coach, a rare cohort even on the women\u2019s professional tour. According to the WTA\u2019s most recent index of coaches, there are only eight players in the top 100 who list a woman as a coach or co-coach.\n\nKrunic had previously worked with another female coach, Biljana Veselinovic.\n\n\u201cMaybe the tour is still not really familiar with female coaches, but I tried it for myself, I loved it and I\u2019m pretty sure if some other girls tried it they would love it too,\u201d Krunic said.\n\nWorking with Tamaela gave her newfound trust and connection with a coach, Krunic said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s about the energy, and I\u2019m a pretty tough person to deal with because I have an opinion for everything,\u201d she said. \u201cOf course sometimes I\u2019m right, sometimes I\u2019m wrong, but sometimes with guys it can get heated because not a lot of guys will allow some girl to say whatever she thinks. But with Elise, we\u2019re really good friends and she knows me really well. She knows when to ignore me, when to listen to me, or when I\u2019m searching for something.\u201d\n\nThe two know each other well enough that Tamaela can correctly guess what Krunic will order at restaurants. Krunic, too, knows to stop talking when Tamaela picks up her current book. Tamaela reads voraciously, finding it the best way to seek calm on the rocky ride of the tour on which she remains a somewhat reluctant passenger.\n\n\u201cThis is not something I ever wanted to do in my life \u2014 and after Alex, no more,\u201d Tamaela said. \u201cI think she\u2019s going to be the only person I ever coach, and after her I\u2019ll go back to my normal life at home.\u201d", "title": "A Tennis Coach Is a Reluctant Passenger on the Road", "authors": ["Ben Rothenberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "That meeting may come much sooner than any of the South Koreans expected. On Wednesday, officials from North and South Korea agreed to field a joint women\u2019s hockey team and march under the same flag at the Olympics, which begin Feb. 9. The International Olympic Committee, which had been pressing for the two countries to cooperate during the Games, is expected to ratify the agreement at a meeting Saturday in Switzerland.\n\nSo far, the only North Korean athletes to qualify for the Pyeongchang Games are a pairs figure skating team but it is not clear if they will be among North Korea\u2019s delegation, which would number about 550 people and may also include a pop orchestra and supporters.\n\nThe move to field a joint hockey team, supported by President Moon Jae-in of South Korea but met with some criticism by the public, has created uncertainty for the South Korean team, which has trained as a core group over the last four years and already is something of a hybrid.\n\nTo fill out its roster and compete at the highest level, the Korean Ice Hockey Association recruited a handful of women\u2019s hockey players of Korean heritage from the United States and Canada. With their counterparts from South Korea, the women have established a familial bond while pushing to earn a reputation as a strong team, not just as one gifted a berth into their first Olympic appearance as the host nation.\n\nAmong the greatest unknown is who from the North will be joining their team.\n\nSarah Murray, the Canadian-born coach of the South Korean team, fielded those questions as she arrived in South Korea on Tuesday, facing a horde of reporters with a sudden, elevated interest in women\u2019s hockey and North Korean players.", "title": "A Tricky Reunion on the Ice for North and South Korean Hockey", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Members of Utah\u2019s congressional caucus, not content with eviscerating two national monuments in the state, have unleashed a new assault on public lands, proposing legislation that hides an agenda of deregulation behind the shield of the National Park Service and the beloved park system it oversees.\n\nOn Dec. 6, two days after President Trump radically reduced the size of the Grand Staircase Escalante and Bears Ears National Monuments by some two million acres, the largest reversion of federal land protections in the nation\u2019s history, Representative Chris Stewart, Republican of Utah, introduced legislation to establish the Escalante Canyons National Park and Preserve.\n\nOn its face, the bill might seem like something for advocates of preserving iconic Western landscapes to embrace in the face of Mr. Trump\u2019s rollback. The new park would incorporate a small portion of the original 1.9-million-acre Grand Staircase area that the president\u2019s proclamation fractured. The other three members of the state\u2019s House delegation, all Republicans, signed on as co-sponsors.\n\nBut a reading of the bill, H.R. 4558, reveals it as a Trojan horse, appearing as a gift to the public while eroding federal environmental protections on public lands. If it becomes law, the bill could set a precedent with enormous consequences nationally, all of them bad for the national parks and the park service, which celebrates its 102nd birthday this August. It is, in fact, a model for the piecemeal unraveling of the more than 400 national parks, monuments, battlefields, historic sites, recreation areas and other places in the park system.", "title": "Opinion | A Trojan Horse Threatens the Nation\u2019s Parks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "HOW TO BEHAVE IN A CROWD\n\nBy Camille Bordas\n\n319 pp. Tim Duggan. $26.\n\nImage\n\nIsidore Mazal, known as Dory, the 11-year-old protagonist of Bordas\u2019s novel, is the youngest of an eccentric genius-cluster of brothers and sisters. He perceives himself to be strikingly dull compared with his precocious family members, some of whom are writing dissertations while others are composing experimental music and planning to be distinguished in ways yet to be determined. The clan of six is both close-knit and dissociated by the privacy of their individual obsessions. Together, their collective erudition and oddness isolate them from their small French town, which is still intrigued by their precocity. But as a series of losses throws into sharp, sometimes devastating, light the limits and loneliness of the life of the mind, it is Dory \u2014 observant, feeling, open to others and to new experiences \u2014 who becomes, as his brother observes in an ethnographic treatise on their unique \u201cfamily system,\u201d \u201cthe one the other subjects turn to for comfort and hope.\u201d\n\n\u201cHow to Behave in a Crowd,\u201d Bordas\u2019s third novel and her first written in English, joins the league of novels about adolescence persuasively told by adolescent narrators. \u201cWho would care for a novel about us?\u201d asks one of Dory\u2019s siblings. The answer is: everyone.\n\nYIZA\n\nBy Michael K\u00f6hlmeier\n\nTranslated by Ruth Martin\n\n111 pp. Haus Publishing. Paper, $15.95.\n\nImage\n\nThe reader never feels safe in the world of this short novel, first published in Germany in 2016 as \u201cDas M\u00e4dchen mit dem Fingerhut\u201d (\u201cThe Girl With the Thimble\u201d). In an unnamed country, a trio of homeless children of unspecified nationalities negotiates the vicissitudes of their imperiled circumstance with a mix of innocence, preternatural canniness and an empathy that transcends the limits of language. Like many tragedies and fairy tales (\u201cOedipus Rex,\u201d \u201cJane Eyre,\u201d \u201cHansel and Gretel\u201d), K\u00f6hlmeier\u2019s dark gem of a story takes its English title from its protagonist, Yiza, a 6-year-old girl who escapes with two older boys from a home for migrant children. Yet this is no typical fall-from-power-through-hubris narrative or fabulist cautionary tale. Yiza, we learn, is not even a real name, and for a while the only vocabulary the three have in common is the names by which they call themselves. The mendicant world they wander through \u2014 stalked by starvation, illness, prejudice and evil \u2014 is all too real to anyone attuned to the predicament of displaced children. The engine of this simply told but important text (narrated in a stripped-down vocabulary, as though K\u00f6hlmeier and Martin have selected only words that can be easily translated into any language) is the resiliency of the children themselves. Despite privation and a lack of means to express to each other the staggering uncertainty of their situation, they nonetheless exchange talismanic gifts (the thimble) and are capable of loyalty and protectiveness that evince a humanity greater than any shown to them by society.\n\nLEA\n\nBy Pascal Mercier\n\nTranslated by Shaun Whiteside\n\n292 pp. Grove. $25.\n\nImage\n\nTwo middle-aged Swiss men \u2014 Martijn van Vliet and Adrian Herzog \u2014 meet by chance outside a Provence cafe. Herzog, a retired surgeon, is in town to visit his daughter; for van Vliet, the trip is part of an endgame pilgrimage in the wake of sad events involving his dead wife and his mercurial, extraordinarily talented daughter, Lea, a renowned violinist who is eventually hospitalized in the same asylum in St.-R\u00e9my that once sheltered Vincent van Gogh.", "title": "A Trove of Continental Fiction Explores Loss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "HER Nope. I say beating up the new guy is a waste of time and energy that could be used to solve real problems like the ones you talk about.\n\nA few days later, we kept the conversation going, with her arguing that the president was subject to excessive scrutiny.\n\nHER He is not the first to have bad form. Sadly the powers that be overturn every rock, scab, and snicker he makes to make him seem worse. Not even Obama could withstand such scrutiny. All the time! For months at a time. That was his job as a businessman. WTH?! He made money. Why hate on that? He wasn\u2019t Madoff!\n\nME Obama HAD such scrutiny ALL THE TIME. You\u2019re in some alternate reality now if you\u2019re suggesting otherwise. His birth certificate, his fist bump with his wife, his tan suit, his salute with coffee in his hand, his golfing, his wife not covering her head in Saudi. Then more criticism when she did cover it in a mosque (protocol like meeting the pope), her shorts, their daughters\u2019 expressions and skirt lengths, his bowing to Saudis and I could go on!\n\nMany times she urged me to calm myself, ignore the words and focus on the policies. In the summer, after John Kelly was appointed as the chief of staff, I wrote to ask what she thought of him and whether he would be able to manage a boss who seemed to prefer chaos and infighting. Her response: \u201cDunno.\u201d That wasn\u2019t quite good enough for me. I responded:\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t know your own reaction? None of us know how it will turn out of course. Are you on tranquilizers or anything? I know it\u2019s been a year of change for you.\u201d Luckily, I got an \u201cLOL\u201d back.\n\nIn August, we were discussing a friendship that had been under strain because of her vote and support for the president. I tried to explain how it looked to me \u2014 and perhaps to her friend. To many people, this president\u2019s sloppy speech about nuclear weapons, his failure to promptly condemn violence by white supremacists, his lack of ethics and so on was particularly troubling. Supporting him meant condoning that. \u201cI thought them mostly angry and misguided,\u201d I wrote. \u201cYou knew you were among the reviled.\u201d\n\nShe wrote back, in defense:\n\n\u201cIt means I thought (think) he has the right idea. I believe Congress could implement his ideas humanely \u2014 his articulation is lacking. He is not a one-man show. I want him to do the job. I pray, every day, that God gives those around him the strength to DO SOMETHING for the people they\u2019re here to support. Mr. Kim\u2019s mention in his annual New Year\u2019s Day speech of a \u201cnuclear button\u201d on his desk prompted Mr. Trump to respond Tuesday on Twitter: \u201cI too have a Nuclear Button, but it is a much bigger & more powerful one than his, and my Button works!\u201d\n\nIn addition to his predictable bombast, Mr. Kim unexpectedly proposed opening bilateral negotiations between his country and South Korea. The offer was immediately accepted by President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, whose administration fears that the North might disrupt the upcoming Winter Olympics in the South. As a confidence-building measure, Pyongyang reactivated a hotline with Seoul that had been dormant for nearly two years.\n\nWhile the Moon administration is open to dialogue with the North, Mr. Trump has yet to show a clear willingness to embrace diplomacy as a means to break the impasse over Pyongyang\u2019s nuclear program. Mr. Kim\u2019s offer presents an opportunity for Washington and its longtime ally South Korea to unite behind a strategy to freeze the North\u2019s nuclear program at its current level and prevent a bad situation from getting worse.\n\nThe diplomatic track has been blocked by Washington\u2019s insistence that North Korea commit to denuclearization as a precondition to talks. A line of four is showing up in dairy cases and online. The milk is pressed from raw nuts grown on a family farm in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales, Australia, the macadamia\u2019s native habitat. The farm cultivates the trees in a manner said to promote healthy soil. There are four varieties, all nicely creamy: original (lightly sweetened), unsweetened and unsweetened vanilla (both pleasant), and latte de barista (designed for coffee shops, fairly sweet, foams well): Milkadamia, $4 to $5.50 per quart, depending on the store, milkadamia.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. One month later, he flew to Los Angeles (accompanied by his mother) to star in a Saint Laurent campaign photographed by Hedi Slimane. \u201cI honestly didn\u2019t know who Hedi was, so I ended up having fun and joking around with him,\u201d Mr. Lang said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use.
