And He\u2019s Only 19.", "authors": ["Alex Hawgood", "Up Next"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. View more of his work, visit his website or follow him on Twitter.\n\nFollow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion), and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.", "title": "Opinion | A Very Stable Genius-in-Chief", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "For the past three years, I have spent the majority of my days moving through the world doing an impression of Donald Trump. I have coifed, combed and caressed a gravity-defying pompadour, teetered over my own midsection in a Pisa-like lean and narrowed my eyes into a leering squint.\n\nMost of the time, I did this on Comedy Central\u2019s \u201cThe President Show,\u201d and I hope I don\u2019t sound too much like my avatar when I say I portray both his body and his mind with relative accuracy. I\u2019ve studied our president\u2019s bizarrely lyrical speech patterns and his unconsciously betraying body movements. I have learned that he is speaking with his body language as much as he is with his mouth.\n\nAs you prepare to watch our 45th president deliver his first State of the Union on Tuesday night, you can refer to this primer as a means of reconciling his body language and speech patterns. It should provide insight into what the president is really saying.\n\nSlopes, Stairs and Inclines\n\nWhen the sergeant-at-arms barks our president into the House chamber, I can promise you that Mr. Trump\u2019s mind is mostly focused on getting down the slight slope leading toward the podium. I\u2019ve watched hundreds of hours of him managing inclines and declines and even after 70-plus years on the planet, he still struggles with that. He never seems particularly steady, and I\u2019ll leave you to make the associations between his instability and his lack of a moral center.", "title": "Opinion | A Viewer\u2019s Guide to Donald Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Around two million Chinese enter the zone each year, far more than the number of Kazakhs, but they mostly stay on the Chinese side. Traffic across the barely marked border, at least in winter, flows almost entirely one way. Only a trickle of Chinese pass into Kazakhstan as throngs of Kazakhs pour in the other direction to shop for clothing, toys and electronic goods, many of them counterfeit, in Chinese shops.\n\n\u201cIt is not Hong Kong or Shanghai, but it is a great chance for us to see what China is like,\u201d said Aidos Sarym, a Kazakh political analyst who has visited. The experience, he added, will help calm a widespread fear felt by many Kazakhs of China and its people.\n\nWhile there is not much to see yet on the Kazakh side other than snow, Mr. Ivanov, the deputy director, thinks his desolate domain can still attract waves of Chinese tourists in the future. \u201cEighty percent of Chinese don\u2019t have passports, and this is the only chance they have to visit a foreign country,\u201d he said.\n\nKazakhs who cross the border into Horgos are greeted by a giant screen displaying Chinese political slogans that sing the praises of President Xi Jinping of China and his recent 19th Communist Party congress. But all are written in Chinese, so virtually nobody from Kazakhstan has a clue to the exultant message.", "title": "A Visa-Free Zone Welcomes Your Wallet. But Maybe Not Your Beard.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "GUINOBATAN, Philippines \u2014 Mount Mayon, one of the Philippines\u2019 most active volcanoes, is as renowned for its beauty as it is feared for its destructiveness.\n\nAdmired for its symmetry and classic cone shape, the volcano was named for a mythological fairy. But its smooth slopes and cute name belie its deadly nature: Inside is an enormous chamber, churning with molten rock and toxic gas.\n\nAnd it is ready to blow.\n\nFor two weeks Mayon has rumbled, belched plumes of ash and smoke and lit up the night sky with an eerie orange glow.\n\n\u201cIt is very hard to sleep at night when you start to hear the explosions,\u201d said Ed Esquivel, 60, a retired police inspector from the village of Bogna, five miles from the crater. \u201cIt is like five big airplanes flying around the village.\u201d", "title": "A Volcano Known for Its Beauty Is Also a Killer", "authors": ["Jes Aznar", "Russell Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "BYRON BAY, Australia \u2014 The Great Barrier Reef is literally being eaten alive.\n\nDeadly starfish are feasting on parts of the world\u2019s largest reef system, which is already threatened by rising ocean temperatures, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority said on Friday.\n\nCrown-of-thorns starfish, a native species whose numbers occasionally grow so out of control they endanger the reef, have been detected on 37 sections of the southerly Swain Reef, more than 60 miles offshore, according to the park authority.\n\n\u201cWhenever coral in any location in the Great Barrier Reef is threatened or stressed, it is of concern,\u201d said Fred Nucifora, a spokesman for the authority.\n\nThe reef is one of the planet\u2019s largest living structures \u2014 big enough to be seen from space \u2014 and is home to thousands of species, including sharks, turtles and whales. Australia relies on it for about 70,000 jobs and billions of dollars annually in tourism revenue.", "title": "A Voracious Starfish Is Destroying the Great Barrier Reef", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cAfter more than 20 years of building a reputation working hard in the public and private sectors, all it took was one false claim to cost me my job and the ability to walk my kids to school without getting accusatory stares on the street,\u201d Mr. Ford, 47, said.\n\n\u201cMorgan Stanley fired him, and defamed him, without ever figuring out what happened,\u201d said Beth Wilkinson, one of his lawyers.\n\nLong before his termination, Mr. Ford had become a polarizing figure within Morgan Stanley. While some executives liked him, he had been accused of padding his expense account and mistreating his assistants, according to people close to both the bank and Mr. Ford. Mr. Ford acknowledged that he had faced flak over those issues, but said his conduct had always been appropriate.\n\nPhoto\n\nNow Mr. Ford is fighting to salvage his reputation. He has publicly threatened legal action, and his lawyers are negotiating with Morgan Stanley over a possible settlement, according to people on both sides of the talks.\n\nThe chain of events preceding Mr. Ford\u2019s ouster provides insight into how companies are dealing with human-resources issues in an era of unprecedented scrutiny.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe son of a longtime Tennessee congressman, Mr. Ford was elected to Congress in 1996 at the age of 26, entering as its youngest member at that time.\n\nMr. Ford, a moderate Democrat, occasionally crossed party lines during his five terms in the House. He was regarded as a potential future White House contender.\n\nBut his political career was derailed in 2006 when he lost a Senate race. The next year, Mr. Ford landed at Merrill Lynch. His job was to woo companies and individuals who might become clients. In 2008, he married Emily Threlkeld, a Hollywood fashion stylist whose stepfather was once a prominent Morgan Stanley executive. Three years later, Mr. Ford joined that firm.\n\nHe worked closely with Gregory Fleming, who ran Morgan\u2019s wealth-management division. He frequently spoke at industry events and became a common presence on cable talk shows. He earned millions a year.\n\nIn early 2014, a Reuters reporter, Lauren Tara LaCapra, was working on an article about Mr. Fleming.\n\nShe sought Mr. Ford\u2019s help. They met for coffee, and the next night they had dinner at the \u201c21\u201d Club in Manhattan. Some of Mr. Ford\u2019s behavior made Ms. LaCapra uncomfortable, according to emails reviewed by The New York Times.\n\nNonetheless, the two shared a taxi after dinner to their homes. \u201cHad fun tonight!\u201d Ms. LaCapra emailed him later that night. \u201cThanks for inviting me out.\u201d\n\nThe email banter continued over the following days, touching on topics including travel plans and Valentine\u2019s Day. Despite the friendly veneer, Ms. LaCapra forwarded one of Mr. Ford\u2019s emails to another person with the word \u201cCreeper\u201d atop his note.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Feb. 20, Mr. Ford invited Ms. LaCapra to another dinner.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to have further interactions after dinner with your friends at the 21 Club on Feb 11,\u201d she responded. \u201cI felt that some of your conduct was inappropriate and it made me uncomfortable. I tried to be polite, but also to make it clear that I don\u2019t veer outside the normal boundaries of a source-reporter relationship. It seems like your recent overtures are on a path outside of those boundaries.\u201d\n\nMr. Ford responded that he was \u201cvery sorry\u201d and that \u201cmy overtures are strictly professional.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor nearly four years, the issue seemed to go away.\n\nBut during that time, Mr. Ford\u2019s support at Morgan Stanley was weakening. Some regarded him as a celebrity banker who hadn\u2019t earned his seven-figure paydays, according to several executives.\n\nIn early 2016, Mr. Fleming left, and Mr. Ford felt he had lost a senior ally, three people familiar with his thinking said.\n\nBefore long, he was moved from an office on the 39th floor, one level below top executives, to a smaller one on the sixth floor. He cycled through executive assistants, and some complained that he was difficult to work for, according to people close to both Mr. Ford and Morgan Stanley.\n\nMr. Ford felt he was being marginalized in the downsized office, and he regarded some assistants assigned to him as incompetent, the people familiar with his thinking said.\n\nMorgan Stanley officials also accused him of misusing his expense account, which Mr. Ford denied. He received a written warning about his conduct, according to the Morgan Stanley officials and one of Mr. Ford\u2019s lawyers, John Singer.\n\nLast fall, reporters began asking about the \u201c21\u201d Club dinner.\n\nMorgan Stanley executives contacted Ms. LaCapra. She told them that Mr. Ford had behaved provocatively at dinner and that an altercation had broken out after she declined to join him for an after-dinner drink.\n\n\u201cMr. Ford tried to pull me into an elevator to go to a cocktail lounge, despite my verbal and physical resistance,\u201d Ms. LaCapra said in a statement to The Times.\n\nWhen Morgan Stanley interviewed Mr. Ford about the evening, he said he had behaved properly.\n\n\u201cI never pulled or grabbed her,\u201d he said in a statement to The Times. \u201cHer story is totally inconsistent with the reality that she voluntarily got in a cab with me after a group dinner, dropped me off and sent me an unsolicited email later that night saying she had fun and thank you.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe existence of the harassment allegation was too much for Morgan Stanley, especially since Mr. Ford was already in a precarious position, the bank officials said. Executives also felt he had misled them about some of the evening\u2019s events.\n\nOn Dec. 6, the day after its interview of him, Morgan Stanley fired Mr. Ford. The next day, the firm said in a statement that he had been \u201cterminated for conduct inconsistent with our values and in violation of our policies.\u201d\n\nNews articles linked his firing to the harassment allegation. \u201cEx-lawmaker fired by Morgan Stanley over sexual misconduct claims,\u201d a New York Post headline declared.\n\nA month later, settlement negotiations between Mr. Ford\u2019s lawyers and Morgan Stanley are continuing. A person close to Mr. Ford said he was seeking a public statement from the bank that he hadn\u2019t been fired specifically because of sexual harassment.", "title": "A Wall St. Executive\u2019s Downfall Seemed Sudden. It Was Years in the Making.", "authors": ["Kate Kelly", "Andrew Ross Sorkin"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Philosophy, he added, \u201chas made a huge difference both to my life outside business, in terms of adding a great degree of richness and knowledge, and to the actual decisions I\u2019ve made in investing.\u201d\n\nMr. Miller gift may seem modest compared with the $1.5 billion that Michael Bloomberg has given to Johns Hopkins over his lifetime, including a $300 million gift to its School of Public Health in 2016.\n\nBut Ronald Daniels, the president of Johns Hopkins, said Mr. Miller\u2019s gift would give a much-needed boost to the beleaguered humanities, at a moment when many universities, and the governments that support them, are heavily focused on the so-called STEM fields: science, technology, engineering and math.\n\n\u201cThis gift is so wonderfully contrarian,\u201d Mr. Daniels said. \u201cTo have someone of Bill\u2019s stature who is willing to lend an imprimatur to philosophy, this most ancient of disciplines, and to the idea of its continuing relevance as an end in itself, is simply spectacular.\u201d\n\nMr. Miller, 67, is not the only old-guard Wall Street figure with a background in philosophy. George Soros was heavily influenced by the Austrian philosopher Karl Popper. Carl Icahn was a philosophy major at Princeton, where he wrote a senior thesis titled \u201cThe Problem of Formulating an Adequate Explication of the Empiricist Criterion of Meaning.\u201d (On the watchdog side of the street, Sheila Bair, the former chair of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, was also a philosophy major.)\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Miller, whose father worked as a terminal manager for a trucking company, said he had essentially talked his way into the Ph.D. program at Hopkins, despite having taken only one six-week course in philosophy at the very end of his senior year.\n\n\u201cThey wanted to see three examples of your philosophical work,\u201d he recalled. \u201cI didn\u2019t have any, so I took 30 days off the Army and wrote three papers.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Miller, who worked part-time in accounting during graduate school, completed the coursework and qualifying exams. But when it came time to start a dissertation, he looked at the difficult prospects of getting a teaching job, and left for (much) greener pastures.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPhilosophy is often derided as useless and impractical, and not always in as fond a way as in the classic Monty Python sketch \u201cMrs. Premise and Mrs. Conclusion Visit Jean-Paul Sartre.\u201d But when Marco Rubio, on the campaign trail in 2015, said America needed \u201cmore welders and less philosophers,\u201d defenders of Sophia rushed to note that postsecondary philosophy teachers earned nearly twice as much as welders, while former philosophy majors outearned most other liberal arts majors by midcareer.\n\nOn Wall Street, Mr. Miller, an old-fashioned stock picker who focused on identifying undervalued companies, is famous for his 15-year streak beating the S.&.P 500, from 1991 to 2006, while at Legg Mason, where he spent most of his career. He was an early believer in Amazon, investing heavily at a time when most analysts were highly skeptical.\n\n\u201cThere was a huge amount of confirmation bias going on with Amazon,\u201d he said. \u201cThere was an inability to do what Wittgenstein talked about in his \u2018Philosophical Investigations\u2019: crisscrossing the landscape from many angles, investigating in many different ways.\u201d\n\nThe more general public may recall his brief depiction in \u201cThe Big Short,\u201d where he was the guy blustering on about the fundamental strength of Bear Stearns stock (which in real life Mr. Miller rode toward the bottom) in a public debate with Steve Carell\u2019s character even as it was shown plummeting on BlackBerry screens.\n\nThe scene, based on a real exchange, \u201cmade the person seem quite a bit more pompous than I think of myself as being,\u201d Mr. Miller said.\n\nIn recent years Mr. Miller, who said his firm currently has $2.5 billion under management (considerably less than the funds he oversaw at Legg Mason, with which he ended ties in 2016), has invested heavily in Bitcoin.\n\nThe cryptocurrency has inspired a nascent philosophical literature, to complement more in-flight friendly reading like Bitcoin Magazine. In addition to books on the history and sociology of money, Mr. Miller said he had been reading the Berkeley philosopher John Searle\u2019s 1995 book \u201cThe Construction of Social Reality,\u201d which looks at how objective social realities form, grow and change.\n\n\u201cIt is particularly insightful when trying to understand new social facts and structures such as crypto assets,\u201d Mr. Miller said.", "title": "A Wall Street Giant Makes a $75 Million Bet on Academic Philosophy", "authors": ["Jennifer Schuessler"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Democrats fare best when they fight Trump on policy grounds that can win over swing voters. That ground tends to be economic. Trump favors government cuts and corporate deregulation that would hurt many Americans. He has also failed to deliver on his promises to bring back factory jobs. \u201cIf you are a Democrat, and you are not talking about this every day,\u201d Ronald Klain, the longtime Democratic operative, wrote, referring to Trump\u2019s broken promises to Carrier workers in Indiana, \u201cyou are not using the most effective argument we have.\u201d\n\nA focus on economic issues will almost certainly be more effective than a focus on personality. But the question isn\u2019t just personality versus policy. It\u2019s also which kinds of policy Democrats emphasize. And economic issues are much more likely to be effective than cultural issues, even if Democrats rightly feel passionate about cultural issues like immigration and Trump\u2019s racism. Matthew Yglesias made this point well in Vox yesterday, also citing the recent Republican uptick in polls.\n\n\u201cThe question isn\u2019t whether Trump is racist (he is),\u201d Yglesias tweeted, summarizing his piece, \u201cit\u2019s whether harping on that is a good way to defeat racism.\u201d His answer \u2014 which I agree with \u2014 is no. \u201cIf you want to help the people most severely victimized by Trumpism, you need to beat Trumpism at the polls,\u201d he wrote.\n\nAs for the potential shutdown: Democrats are absolutely right to insist on protection for the so-called Dreamers \u2014 immigrants brought to the United States illegally as children. And I understand why Senate Democrats view a potential government shutdown as their best leverage.\n\nBut Democrats would also be wise to be honest with themselves about the political downsides here. Notably, Claire McCaskill of Missouri \u2014 who represents a state Trump carried in 2016, the kind of area the party will need to win to retake control of Congress \u2014 seems concerned about a high-profile fight over immigration. It\u2019s not the subject most likely to drive Trump\u2019s approval rating back down into the 30s.\n\nThe best question for Democrats to ask themselves may be: Can we protect the Dreamers without turning immigration into the country\u2019s highest-profile political topic?\n\nTrump\u2019s agenda. Jane Williams, denied that such an understanding existed, and questioned the role of the federal government in financing a \u201clocal project where nine out of 10 passengers are local transit riders.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s talk that this might just be a ploy to get New York and New Jersey senators to back the yet-to-be-revealed Trump infrastructure plan, and perhaps there are negotiations to be pursued. But where does this leave the region? The clock is ticking on the useful life of the tunnels, and the second phase of the Gateway plan \u2014 in which long-suffering New Jersey Transit commuters would get double the number of trains and direct service to Manhattan on more lines \u2014 recedes into the future.\n\nThe city depends on those commuters to keep its economy growing. New York State gets a big slice of nonresident income tax revenue from them. And for northern New Jersey\u2019s economy, jobs in Manhattan are, by far, the largest \u201cindustry.\u201d\n\nNew Jersey ranks third in per capita personal income among the states, and New York fourth. They are big net contributors to the federal budget. Unfortunately, the lesson of the recent past \u2014 with respect to taxes and transit both \u2014 is that the two states can\u2019t count on their taxes making a round trip back from Washington.\n\nThe states and the city have too much at stake to sit on the sidelines while the Trump administration ignores their needs. They need to evaluate how they can proceed without a federal partner. That means considering new revenue sources, as well as pushing for more efficient construction management and reordering other capital spending to emphasize transportation. I would suggest a new tax on real estate pass-through entities, exactly offsetting the cuts in the recent tax legislation passed by Congress.", "title": "Opinion | A Way Forward for New York-New Jersey Commuters", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThere are \u201cfishy\u201d fish, and then there are non-fishy fish. And with its mild, milky flesh, cod is one of the least fishy of them all.\n\nUsually, I\u2019m drawn to the more robust varieties \u2014 the mackerels, sardines, anchovies and swordfish in the market, which have enough personality to take whatever seasoning I feel like throwing at them. This gives me the kind of fridge-clearing, spice-sprinkling latitude I need to get really creative.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut milder fish can also be appealing, especially cod, which has a fresh, saline taste that can also be sweet. To fully appreciate its subtle flavor, it\u2019s best to keep things simple when preparing it.\n\nThe good thing about this kind of simplicity is that it can also mean speed. The fewer things you have to chop, peel, squeeze, seed, grind or otherwise deal with when cooking, the faster your dinner will come together. Minimalism is your friend on any given weeknight.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn this recipe, the only ingredients to prepare are shallots, garlic and some fresh herbs: It\u2019s labor you can do while your skillet heats up. Once it\u2019s hot, you\u2019ll quickly braise the cod fillets and shallots in butter, white wine and a handful of herb sprigs.\n\nPhoto\n\nThen, while the fish firms up in the pan, you\u2019ll have ample time to mix the sauce: a swirl of garlic, yogurt and whatever those herbs were that you just chopped. Or you can make the sauce ahead. It will keep for a week in the fridge, and it is so good on roasted or raw vegetables that you might even consider a double batch.", "title": "A Weeknight Dish for Lovers of Non-Fishy Fish", "authors": ["Melissa Clark", "A Good Appetite"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Among saiga antelopes, the month of May ought to be about new life. But in 2015, it was just the opposite for the Betpak-Dala saiga population in central Kazakhstan.\n\nIn only three weeks, about 220,000 of the critically endangered antelopes, most of them newborns and mothers that had gathered to calve, dropped dead across an area the size of Britain.\n\nIn a study published today in Science Advances, researchers presented a preliminary account of the cause of the mysterious die-off: Bacteria called Pasteurella multocida, which seem normally to exist harmlessly in saigas\u2019 tonsils, somehow invaded their guts, poisoning their blood and breaking down their organs, leading to death within a few hours.\n\nThe mechanism that allowed the bacteria to become so harmful is still unclear, but the scientists believe it had something to do with a peculiarly wet and warm period before the outbreak.", "title": "A Wet and Warm Spring, Then 200,000 Dead Saigas", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "R.O. Blechman is an artist and animator, and the illustrator, most recently, of \u201cGOD: 48 Famous and Fascinating Minds Talk About God.\u201d\n\nFollow New York Times Books on Facebook and Twitter (@nytimesbooks), and sign up for our newsletter.", "title": "A Writer\u2019s State of Mind", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "When the American Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons surveyed its members, it found that virtually all of them prescribed opioids. Harold Tu, the director of the division of oral and maxillofacial surgery at the University of Minnesota School of Dentistry, realized that this is really important, because the first exposure to opioids of many young people is when they get their wisdom teeth removed.\n\nSo he instituted a new protocol at his school: Patients now get ibuprofen and acetaminophen instead \u2014 a combination that studies have found works better than opioids to control pain and inflammation after this surgery. In part because of Dr. Tu\u2019s work, the association now recommends that ibuprofen, not opioids, be the first-line pain medicine.\n\nGo bipartisan. Republicans and Democrats don\u2019t disagree about everything, although it might seem that way from looking at Congress. Tennessee\u2019s work on college completion is one example of a solution to a problem of national proportions that\u2019s being embraced in red and blue states.\n\nAnother area where this is happening is criminal justice reform. Many states are drastically reducing or even getting rid of the costly, unfair and harmful system of money bail. Alaska is the latest. Other national leaders include Kentucky, the District of Columbia, Arizona and New Jersey (under former Gov. Chris Christie, a Republican).\n\nReducing mass incarceration is another bipartisan cause, endorsed by Newt Gingrich and Bernie Sanders, the Koch brothers and Black Lives Matter. (Attorney General Sessions is unfortunately an exception.) Leaders among the states include California, New York, New Jersey, Texas, South Carolina, Georgia and Mississippi.\n\nStrengthen democracy. The Trump administration\u2019s attacks on basic constitutional guarantees and American values present a singular danger to our nation, and history will judge the willingness of most Republicans in Congress to join President Trump\u2019s cult of personality.\n\nBut some good has come of it. Americans have responded with a tidal wave of activism \u2014 certainly the most important new trend in social change last year. Much of it is partisan, beginning with the record-breaking Women\u2019s March a year ago, on Jan. 21 (a march that organizers hope to repeat this Jan. 20 and 21). Then activists plunged in locally, many guided by the organizing advice of the resistance organization Indivisible \u2014 visit your own member of Congress and tell him or her your views on particular issues \u2014 and the history of successful protest campaigns.", "title": "Opinion | A Year of Pushback to Save Social Innovation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "BURNING QUESTION: Would you want to know the date of your death? That\u2019s the premise of Chloe Benjamin\u2019s captivating family saga \u201cThe Immortalists,\u201d which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 7. It begins in the late 1960s, when all four Gold children \u2014 at loose ends on Manhattan\u2019s Lower East Side during a steamy, sticky summer vacation \u2014 decide to visit a fortuneteller famous for predicting when people will die. As Benjamin, 29, explained in an interview with NPR, \u201cthe novel follows each of the siblings over about 50 years as they reckon with their prophecies. Some of them fight against it. Others claim they don\u2019t believe in it. Some use it to push them to pursue their wildest dreams. And others are surprisingly limited by it even if their date of death is quite far out.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the whole idea, \u2018Can you change your destiny?\u2019\u201d Putnam\u2019s editorial director, Sally Kim, says. \u201cThe novel gives you a way to think about that, to examine the idea up close with characters you spend a lifetime with. It forces you to think about your own life.\u201d In the months before publication, the hallways at Putnam began to thrum with staffers discussing the novel. \u201cI mean, would you want to know the day you\u2019re going to die?\u201d Kim asks. \u201cThe second you finish this book, you want to talk to someone about it. When I was done reading the manuscript it was the middle of the night, and I wanted to shake my husband awake.\u201d\n\nCRIME TIME: The latest book vying for the \u201cGirl on the Train\u201d crown is \u201cThe Wife Between Us,\u201d a fiendishly smart cat-and-mouse thriller by Greer Hendricks and Sarah Pekkanen that debuts at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list. The authors met when Hendricks, then a Simon & Schuster editor, acquired Pekkanen\u2019s first novel back in 2008. \u201cWhen she left publishing, she told me a secret, which was that she wanted to try to write fiction,\u201d Pekkanen told The Washington Post. \u201cI had just finished a book, and she was struggling to figure out what she wanted to write. So I suggested [a joint project] to her.\u201d\n\nBuzz began building for the novel last October when Steven Spielberg\u2019s production unit, Amblin Partners \u2014 which made \u201cThe Girl on the Train\u201d \u2014 snapped up the movie rights in a splashy deal. These days \u201cThe Wife Between Us\u201d is drawing comparisons to another hot January title, A. J. Finn\u2019s \u201cThe Woman in the Window,\u201d which sits at No. 1: Both pulled in big advances, both feature unreliable narrators and both were written by publishing insiders.", "title": "A Young Novelist Grapples With Matters of Life and Death", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Is your room at home a \u201cfeel-good\u201d space? Does it bring you positive feelings, help you be productive or relax?\n\nHow have you designed it to support your well-being? What colors do you use? How is your furniture arranged? Is it clean? Is it filled with nostalgic items or is it more minimalist? What kinds of decorations do you have and how do they make you feel?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out more tips on how to design a \u201cfeel-good\u201d space.", "title": "A \u2018Feel-Good\u2019 Room", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "I sometimes use a service called Relationship Science, which is a fascinating way to understand the connections between the people I cover. Think Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon, or in this case, Six Degrees of Jamie Dimon.\n\nDespite being an unabashed Apple aficionado \u2014 I also have an Apple Watch \u2014 I happen to use Google apps for much of my life since it\u2019s so easy to collaborate on documents with colleagues and coordinate calendars. (And yes, Google Maps is still better than Apple Maps.) I use Slack to communicate with everyone at work, especially when I\u2019m traveling and not in the office.\n\nI\u2019m on airplanes too much, so I\u2019m also a devotee of Bose noise-canceling headphones. Other key pieces of travel technology: Hearos Xtreme earplugs for overnight flights are the best on the market (trust me, I\u2019ve tried them all); if you need to block out light to sleep on a flight or you\u2019re stuck in a hotel room that has terrible shades, get yourself a Lonfrote sleep mask, which is so much better than the freebie on your flight. I carry a handful of extra portable power packs to charge devices on the road. And I always keep a stash of RxBars (blueberry, pumpkin or peanut) with me; they're about as healthy as you can get when it comes to packaged and packable food.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhat could be better?\n\nI still want a bigger, longer lasting battery on the iPhone. I can never get enough battery life \u2014 and I have battery anxiety looking at the percentage icon dwindle throughout the day if I haven\u2019t found a place to plug in. Same for the AirPods, though I\u2019ve found that\u2019s less of an issue for me.\n\nOn my Apple Watch, I desperately want to be able to adjust the sensitivity that activates the screen when I turn my wrist to look at it. (Hey, Apple Watch team: I\u2019d make it a bit more sensitive so it turns on more frequently, even at the cost of battery life.)\n\nIn your years of writing about deals, which tech merger do you think has had the most significant impact on people\u2019s lives?\n\nGoogle\u2019s acquisition of YouTube in 2006 was game changing. It was the single biggest accelerant of the use of video online. It's probably the most underappreciated deal of all time in any industry. The price tag was $1.65 billion and YouTube was losing money at the time, so it seemed crazy for Google. But today, the deal looks like a brilliant heist.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYou also appear on CNBC\u2019s \u201cSquawk Box.\u201d How has technology changed live broadcasting and your experience as an anchor?\n\nPhoto\n\nIt has probably changed the most on the production side of TV. It used to be that you needed a truck and satellite hookup wherever you\u2019d go. We\u2019d travel with an army of production and technical personnel. But these days you can use services like LiveU, which basically puts an entire satellite truck in a shoe box that connects to the internet or wirelessly using cellular towers. I was just in China and Saudi Arabia, and we broadcast entire three-hour live shows with only a handful of people and no satellite connection.\n\nWhat tech product are you currently obsessed with using in your daily life?\n\nSonos is pretty great. We have a handful of Sonos speakers in our home for music and TV. We also have an Echo and Google Home speaker. I\u2019m thinking about getting the Sonos One, which is supposed to incorporate Alexa, Google Assistant and ultimately access to Apple all in one device.\n\nI read magazines on an app I love called Texture; it\u2019s like Netflix for magazines. If you\u2019re a magazine junkie, it is so worth it.\n\nI\u2019m into sleep trackers like Autosleep on the Apple Watch, but I want to find a device that tracks sleep without wearing anything on my wrist or body. (Or keeping a phone in bed, which I refuse to do.) I also use Nokia\u2019s Withings wireless scale, which is a pretty good way to keep you honest about food consumption \u2014 and much easier than constantly entering what you eat in MyFitnessPal or LoseIt, though I\u2019ve used both and they're good. And I have a Braun Series 7 electric razor that for years I\u2019ve told every male friend is the best thing I use daily, though Braun came out with a new one last year so I don\u2019t know if I\u2019m right about that anymore.\n\nApple has more than $250 billion in cash. Which companies do you think it should buy, and why?\n\nI used to think they should make a big deal, but these days I\u2019m less certain. The next big thing in computing is clearly going to be artificial intelligence and health care. I imagine I\u2019d be investing in those spaces aggressively \u2014 but the potential takeover targets are less obvious.", "title": "A \u2018Gadget Junkie,\u2019 Wearing His Tech and Covering Deals", "authors": ["The New York Times", "Tech We Re Using"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "The Jaguars have been such a punchline for so long that their incompetence is a plot point on the television show \u201cThe Good Place.\u201d Almost no one expected them to get this far \u2014 and judging by the betting line, few people expect them to get any farther \u2014 but they are one of four teams left competing for the two spots in Super Bowl LII, and they will need to get through the five-time champion Patriots to get there.\n\nHere is what you can expect in the A.F.C. Championship game:\n\nNo. 3 Jacksonville at No. 1 New England\n\n3:05 p.m. Eastern, CBS\n\nLine: Patriots by 9\n\nLaugh all you want, but the Jaguars (10-6) got to this point by earning every win. It was not always pretty, but Jacksonville scored the fifth-most points in the N.F.L., and allowed the second-fewest, regularly confounding opponents who expected the other shoe, hanging precariously from one of Blake Bortles\u2019 toes, to drop.\n\nSo what type of team, exactly, are the Patriots (13-3) facing? First and foremost, the Jaguars are a weaponized secondary. Jalen Ramsey and A.J. Bouye are both Pro Bowl cornerbacks, with Ramsey having become a shutdown defender who cuts the field in half. Anyone trying to cheat over the middle will find that Tashaun Gipson and Barry Church are two of the league\u2019s finest, and most aggressive, safeties.\n\n\u2014-\n\nN.F.C. Championship Game Preview: Eagles or Vikings?\n\n\u2014-\n\nTom Brady is obviously capable of handling a top-notch secondary, but he will have almost no time to process his reads thanks to a Jacksonville pass-rush led by Calais Campbell and Yannick Ngakoue. That duo combined for 26.5 sacks, and the team as a whole had 55. It gets no easier behind Campbell and Ngakoue, where Brady will find Telvin Smith, who was rated by Pro Football Focus as the N.F.L.\u2019s fourth best linebacker.", "title": "A.F.C. Championship Game Prediction: Patriots or Jaguars?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Machines are starting to take the place of the people who flip burgers, drive across town and, lately, manage stock portfolios.\n\nArtificial intelligence is taking on a bigger role in making investment decisions.\n\nA.I., including an ability to analyze data and actually learn from it, is considered useful in executing certain investing models, such as high-frequency trading, and in helping fund managers with tasks that rely on gathering and interpreting reams of information. Going a step further, an exchange-traded fund introduced in October uses A.I. algorithms to choose long-term stock holdings.\n\nIt is to early to say whether the E.T.F., A.I. Powered Equity, will be a trendsetter or merely a curiosity. Artificial intelligence continues to become more sophisticated and complex, but so do the markets. That leaves technology and investment authorities debating the role of A.I. in managing portfolios. Some say it will only ever be a tool, valuable but subordinate to its flesh-and-blood masters, while others envision it taking control and making decisions for many funds.\n\n\u201cWe are just beginning to see a rise of the machines in investment management,\u201d said Campbell Harvey, a professor of finance at Duke University. Although, he said, \u201cit\u2019s hard to define what the markets will look like\u201d if human judgment is usurped, he predicted that \u201cin the end, it will be a good thing for investors.\u201d", "title": "A.I. Has Arrived in Investing. Humans Are Still Dominating.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Historically we have tended to shy away from this kind of social planning and job matching, perhaps because it smacks to us of a command economy. No one, however, is suggesting that the government should force workers to train for and accept particular jobs \u2014 or indeed that identifying these jobs and skills gaps needs to be the work of the government. The point is that we now have the tools to take the guesswork out of which jobs are available and which skills workers need to fill them.\n\nSecond, we can bring what is known as differentiated education \u2014 based on the idea that students master skills in different ways and at different speeds \u2014 to every student in the country. A 2013 study by Indian researchers found that nearly 40 percent of medical students held a strong preference for one mode of learning: Some were listeners; others were visual learners; still others learned best by doing.\n\nOur school system effectively assumes precisely the opposite. We bundle students into a room, use the same method of instruction and hope for the best. A.I. can improve this state of affairs. Even within the context of a standardized curriculum, A.I. \u201ctutors\u201d can home in on and correct for each student\u2019s weaknesses, adapt coursework to his or her learning style and keep the student engaged.\n\nToday\u2019s dominant type of A.I., also known as machine learning, permits computer programs to become more accurate \u2014 to learn, if you will \u2014 as they absorb data and correlate it with known examples from other data sets. In this way, the A.I. \u201ctutor\u201d becomes increasingly effective at matching a student\u2019s needs as it spends more time seeing what works to improve performance.\n\nThird, a concerted effort to drag education and job training and matching into the 21st century ought to remove the reliance of a substantial portion of the population on government programs designed to assist struggling Americans. With 21st-century technology, we could plausibly reduce the use of government assistance services to levels where they serve the function for which they were originally intended.", "title": "Opinion | A.I. and Big Data Could Power a New War on Poverty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "While the letter did not mention AT&T, its pending deal to sell the Huawei smartphone in the United States had been widely reported.\n\nFletcher Cook, a spokesman for AT&T, declined to comment.\n\nHuawei, a private company, has long denied that it presents security risks. In a statement, Huawei said it had delivered \u201cpremium devices with integrity globally and in the U.S. market\u201d over the past five years, adding that it would introduce new products for the American market on Tuesday.\n\nThe last-minute disruption is the latest in a long line of setbacks for Huawei, which has struggled for years with political opposition to its efforts to tap the hugely valuable United States market. More broadly, it underscores a deepening political rift over issues of technology, user privacy and security \u2014 a rift that adds to a brewing trade dispute between the world\u2019s two largest economies.\n\nJust a week ago, an affiliate of the Alibaba Group in China dropped a $1.2 billion proposal to acquire MoneyGram, after a United States panel that reviews foreign takeovers did not endorse it. The deal drew heavy criticism from lawmakers over the possibility of Chinese access to American user data, despite assurances from the Chinese company that it would take steps to make the data more secure.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAT&T, meanwhile, faces its own challenges in the United States. The Justice Department in November sued to block the company\u2019s $85.4 billion bid for Time Warner, a merger that would create a media and telecommunications behemoth with the ability to reach consumers through a wide variety of means.\n\nHuawei has been counting on the Mate 10 to compete with Apple\u2019s high-end iPhones, in a test of the potential appeal of a Chinese brand in the American market. While Huawei has long sold budget phones, some Mate 10 versions cost $900 or more without subsidies from phone carriers.\n\nHuawei sells smartphones in the United States, but it does not have smartphone deals with any of the major wireless carriers in the country. Those carriers \u2014 Verizon, AT&T, Sprint and T-Mobile \u2014 dominate the market, making it more difficult for Huawei to get a foothold in the country. The AT&T deal was supposed to cement the company\u2019s status as a top maker of the devices, alongside Apple and Samsung Electronics of South Korea.\n\nCongressional misgivings about the company\u2019s close relationship with the Chinese government have long plagued Huawei. Already, other major telecommunications companies refuse to buy the equipment Huawei makes for telecommunications networks \u2014 its core business \u2014 because of worries in Washington over security.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the letter, the lawmakers said Huawei had ties to the Chinese Communist Party, as well as to the country\u2019s intelligence and security services, and they accused Huawei of disregarding intellectual property. In particular, the letter implies that the deal with AT&T could more firmly establish Huawei phones in the United States, and ultimately open up the possibility of American government officials using them.\n\nAnalysts said the political opposition to Huawei was not surprising. Leaders in China and the United States view technology made in the other country with suspicion. In policy guidance and speeches, Chinese officials have repeatedly called for technology made by American companies to be replaced by locally produced ones. Beijing has also widely blocked major American internet companies from offering products in the country.\n\nAmerican lawmakers have stated their suspicions before. In 2012, a House Intelligence Committee report said two Chinese companies, including Huawei, were a threat to United States national security.\n\nFor a Chinese company that has pushed hard to become a recognized multinational player, the setback is only one of many in the United States. Huawei is also under investigation by the Treasury and Commerce Departments over whether it broke American trade sanctions against countries including Iran and North Korea. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania.", "title": "Abigail Darby, Clayton Robinson", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Battle for Poland\u201d (Op-Ed, Jan. 11):\n\nIt is striking that, in his analysis of the illiberal forces steering Poland away from the European Union and democratic values, Charles A. Kupchan does not mention the early attacks by the Catholic hierarchy on women\u2019s rights in post-Communist Poland, resulting in severe restrictions on abortion rights in 1993. They were the canary in the coal mine.\n\nNot long after taking office in 2015, Poland\u2019s ruling Law and Justice Party took further aim at women\u2019s rights, seeking to ban all abortions. This blanket ban \u2014 which could have imprisoned thousands of women and their doctors \u2014 was halted when tens of thousands of women took to the streets over many days in protest, forcing the government to withdraw the bill.\n\nToday as in 1993, a majority of Poles reject restrictions on abortion rights. The Polish women\u2019s rights movement, then and now, has been both a target of ultraconservatives and a vibrant counterforce, crucial to upholding democratic principles and human rights. Europe should stand by these brave activists.\n\nFRAN\u00c7OISE GIRARD, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is president of the International Women\u2019s Health Coalition.", "title": "Opinion | Abortion Rights in Poland", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The streets of San Francisco have always smelled of marijuana. Yet it\u2019s worth noting that the city doesn\u2019t seem to have gotten much smellier in the new year, after the recreational use of marijuana became legal in California under a law approved by voters in 2016.\n\nWell, obviously: because nobody smokes marijuana anymore. Everyone\u2019s vaping it. Or eating, drinking, sipping, dabbing, sucking on lozenges, chewing on gum, applying unguents or administering a drop or two of a cannabis-infused tincture under one\u2019s tongue, where it is absorbed into the sublingual artery, within minutes producing an invisible, odorless, private high.\n\nThese are a few of the inventions of an increasingly sophisticated set of marijuana start-ups, which argue that by pushing the industry past smoke, they can make cannabis convenient and ubiquitous \u2014 the drug of the future, and the next great American bonanza.\n\nEight states and the District of Columbia have legalized marijuana for recreational use, and it is legal for medicinal use in 29 states. The drug remains illegal under federal law, and the Justice Department has signaled a crackdown on the business. Yet growth of the legal marijuana industry keeps beating even its biggest boosters\u2019 expectations; customers in North America will spend more than $10 billion on legal marijuana in 2018 and nearly $23 billion by 2021, projects the ArcView Group, a cannabis-focused research and investment firm.", "title": "About That Joint: Marijuana Start-Ups Pass", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "An auction of vintage watches is scheduled for Jan. 18 in the ballroom of the Monaco Yacht Club, an event that ordinarily would not be considered unusual. The vintage watch scene is traditionally a male domain, with most sale catalogs containing only a few offerings for women.", "title": "About Time: An Auction Dedicated to High-End Watches for Women", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cPortrait Artist Apologizes After Accusations of Sexual Harassment\u201d (news article, Dec. 21):\n\nAs a supporter of the #MeToo movement, I must take issue with the article about Chuck Close\u2019s alleged harassment of women. I read nothing to indicate that these women were forced into compromising positions, threatened, physically assaulted or contacted repeatedly. If his admittedly frank, and sometimes puerile, approach to talking about the nude body made them uncomfortable, the women had every right to set limits or walk away.\n\nIf their expectations or assumptions about a studio visit with the artist were disappointing, then perhaps they should examine their own opportunistic hopes for such a meeting.\n\nMr. Close has generously helped many artists and championed recognition of women in the field. We need to be careful not to smear the reputation of an esteemed artist by suggesting habitual predatory behavior by a man who may be guilty of no more than creating decidedly awkward moments in delicate situations.\n\nCAROL WAX, PEEKSKILL, N.Y.\n\nThe writer is an artist.", "title": "Opinion | Accusations Against Chuck Close", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency issued a stinging response, in which it called Mr. Ragbir \u201can aggravated felon\u201d in reference to his wire fraud conviction in 2000. It said it was \u201cactively exploring\u201d an appeal.\n\n\u201cThe agency is deeply disturbed by the harmful personal attacks some Congress members have leveled against career law enforcement personnel, whose sworn duty is enforcing laws enacted by Congress itself,\u201d the statement read.\n\n\u201cThe agency is similarly concerned with the tone of the district court\u2019s decision, which equates the difficult work ICE professionals do every day to enforce our immigration laws with \u2018treatment we associate with regimes we revile as unjust.\u2019\u201d\n\nFederal prosecutors asked Judge Forrest, who was nominated by President Barack Obama in 2011, to keep Mr. Ragbir in detention. Judge Forrest rejected the request.\n\nStephen Yale-Loehr, a professor at Cornell Law School, called the decision \u201cgroundbreaking.\u201d He said, \u201cIt holds that the Constitution requires the government to give people subject to a final deportation order time to arrange their affairs.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Yale-Loehr cautioned: \u201cToday\u2019s decision was long on rhetoric and short on careful legal analysis. I worry that a higher court may reverse.\u201d\n\nThe judge acknowledged that the government\u2019s labyrinthine statutes allowed for the detention of people with what are known as final orders of removal, meaning that they have no further appeals in the immigration courts and may be deported. But that did not mean that the government could deny due process, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTaking such a man, and there are many such men and women like him, and subjecting him to what is rightfully understood as no different or better than penal detention, is certainly cruel,\u201d Judge Forrest said. \u201cThe Constitution commands better.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Ragbir came to the United States in 1991 from Trinidad and Tobago. He had been a lawful permanent resident when he was convicted of wire fraud in 2000. After he served his sentence, Mr. Ragbir was ordered deported in 2006 and detained by immigration officials, then released on an order of supervision while his case moved through the immigration courts.\n\nIn 2011, the New York field office of the ICE granted him a stay of removal, allowing him to remain in the country. He was given several extensions of the stay, the last set to expire on Jan. 19. But ICE decided to detain him eight days early, at a Jan. 11 check-in.\n\nFederal prosecutors argued they did so because ICE had obtained travel documents from Trinidad. The agency flew him to a detention facility in Miami without initially notifying his lawyer and wife; the court later ordered him back to the New York area.\n\nBecause Mr. Ragbir was not a flight risk or a danger to the community, his lawyers argued that he should not have been detained.\n\nThe decision from the district court comes after several nationally prominent immigrant activists were detained in recent weeks. Mr. Ragbir\u2019s legal team from New York University Law School\u2019s Immigrant Rights Clinic, led by Alina Das, argued that officials from ICE detained him in order to silence and punish him.\n\nThey said that Scott Mechkowski, the assistant field director of ICE who ordered him deported, had resented Mr. Ragbir for his activism against the agency.\n\nDuring oral arguments, Jeremy Cutting, a legal intern for Ms. Das, said that Mr. Mechkowski had at one point referred to the Jan. 11 check-in as \u201cD-Day.\u201d After Mr. Ragbir was detained and taken away in an ambulance, it turned into a showdown; 18 people, including two City Council members, were arrested during protests outside the federal building.\n\nBrandon Waterman, a lawyer for the government, said that claims that government was targeting Mr. Ragbir was \u201cpure speculation,\u201d adding, \u201cwe have no information to support that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Das said that Mr. Ragbir has a separate lawsuit pending in New Jersey challenging his original criminal conviction. A judge there has issued a temporary stay of deportation so that the court can hear the case, and the next hearing is on Feb. 9.\n\nAmy Gottlieb, Mr. Ragbir\u2019s wife, called Judge Forrest\u2019s decision gratifying. \u201cWe\u2019ve all seen that our immigration system is not treating people fairly,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd the judge saw that and called it out.\u201d\n\nBefore the decision, Representative Nydia Velazquez, a Democrat from New York, had invited Ms. Gottlieb to be her guest at the State of the Union on Tuesday. Ms. Gottlieb said that she wanted her husband to accompany her to Washington.", "title": "Activist Entitled to \u2018Freedom to Say Goodbye,\u2019 Judge Rules", "authors": ["Liz Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "An escalating legal battle played out on Friday in the case of Ravi Ragbir, an immigrant rights activist whose detention on Thursday by federal immigration authorities sparked protests that led to the arrest of 18 people, including members of the New York City Council.\n\nMr. Ragbir, 53, the executive director of the New Sanctuary Coalition of New York City, had shown up for a check-in with Immigration and Customs Enforcement on Thursday morning, at the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building in Lower Manhattan. When officials told him that he was going to be detained and deported, Mr. Ragbir fainted, his wife, Amy Gottlieb, said.\n\nThat is when events turned chaotic.\n\nHis lawyer from New York University Immigrant Rights Clinic, Alina Das, said that as he was regaining consciousness she argued that she was still pursuing legal remedies for Mr. Ragbir. She said that Scott Mechkowski, the assistant field office director for ICE, dismissed her arguments and had officers handcuff Mr. Ragbir.", "title": "Activists and ICE Face Off Over Detained Immigrant Leader", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf Procter & Gamble were sponsoring a 2018 advertisement for avoiding activists, it might include an in-house remedy for removing corporate stains. Investors seeking new strategies, more dividends, executive changes or board seats aren\u2019t going away. If anything, the siege of P.&G. by Nelson Peltz, whose Trian Partners gained a director\u2019s seat after a 10-month campaign, will embolden others to take up the cause. Resistance isn\u2019t futile, but it needs to be more carefully considered.\n\nFrom General Motors to Whole Foods, no company was off limits in 2017. P.&G. proved size is no defense; the $230 billion conglomerate was the largest ever target for a proxy fight. Companies with a market capitalization of over $10 billion made up 21.4 percent of targets in the first 11 months of 2017, up more than two percentage points from the previous year, according to Activist Insight. Expect that trend to continue in 2018 even though activists went home empty-handed in more cases than not in those 11 months, which wasn\u2019t the case the previous year.\n\nFor companies, the best defense is a good offense. G.M.\u2019s Mary Barra handily fended off David Einhorn\u2019s attempt to split the stock. It helped that she had already begun to address the stock\u2019s discount by selling off the automaker\u2019s European brands before Mr. Einhorn launched his campaign, and that she carefully outlined the company\u2019s long-term strategy. Automatic Data Processing sent Bill Ackman packing by pointing out its efforts to transform its technology and the hedge-fund manager\u2019s comparatively poor performance.\n\nFor activists, sharp instincts and finely honed demands hold the key to success. Mr. Peltz made clear he wasn\u2019t seeking to break up P.&G. and sought a single board seat to push for new blood in management and greater emphasis on new products and mergers and acquisitions. The defiant 10-month defense by the chief executive, David Taylor, seemed out of proportion to the activist\u2019s ask and ultimately undercut Mr. Taylor\u2019s credibility. Look for more executives to follow the example of General Electric\u2019s John Flannery, who enlisted Mr. Peltz as an ally by giving Trian a board seat without a proxy fight.\n\nP.&G.\u2019s boardroom makeover offers companies an opportunity to wash their dirty laundry. Entrenchment, egocentricity and poor performance without a clear plan are a checklist for activist success. Chief executives and board members looking to fend them off need to add softener to their pride and starch to their corporate plans.", "title": "Activists\u2019 Guide to 2018: The Best Defense Is a Good Offense", "authors": ["Lauren Silva Laughlin"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Pamela Anderson walks down a city street and uses her cellphone to book a ride. Along the way, she passes a newspaper and street signs that say, \u201cHollywood Sexual Harassment Scandal Reaches New Lows\u201d and \u201cU.S. Senator Accused of Groping.\u201d When she gets into the car, she sees another sign that says, \u201cRide-Hail Drivers Suspected of Rape.\u201d The car doors lock, and the driver turns around and suggestively asks, \u201cShall we?\u201d Just then, \u201c#MeToo\u201d pops up on her phone\u2019s screen.\n\n\u201cWhen you accept a ride from a ride-hail app, you also accept the risks that come with it,\u201d Ms. Anderson says in a voice-over. \u201cMany ride-hail companies consider their drivers third-party providers, so they don\u2019t have to accept any responsibility or accountability for their actions. Always ride responsibly.\u201d\n\nThe 60-second ad, to be released Monday, is the third in a campaign introduced in 2015 by the National Limousine Association to promote Ride Responsibly, an initiative that encourages riders to \u201cthink before you app.\u201d\n\nIt is an attempt by the association to focus on allegations of attacks by drivers for ride-hailing companies like Uber and Lyft, which happen to be its competitors. In November, for instance, two women sued Uber, claiming their drivers raped them in separate cases in Florida and California. And last month an Uber driver in Beirut, Lebanon, was arrested in connection with the killing of Rebecca Dykes, a British diplomat.", "title": "Ad Warns Riders About Uber and Lyft, but Some Call It Alarmist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "You tweeted that you\u2019re putting your career in jeopardy with \u201cCardinal.\u201d Why?\n\nI think my career is in trouble because all careers are always in trouble. It\u2019s an ebb and flow of stuff. You\u2019ve got to take a realistic look at the stuff that you\u2019ve done and made and not all my things have been super successful, so that\u2019s where the joke comes from.\n\nSeriously, what is your level of nervousness right now?\n\nMy level of nervousness is high. I\u2019m not a super nervous guy in general. I don\u2019t live a ton of my life in my head. Every day, working on this is like being in Europe. Things are just slightly off and you have an intuition of how it would work but you don\u2019t know. You still know how to exist but it\u2019s just everything is a little bit different. \u2018The outlets are different. O.K., I just have to get a new adapter.\u2019 Everything takes a little more time, so it makes me nervous.\n\nYou\u2019ve focused primarily on sitcoms and indie films in the last several years, so why suddenly turn to theater?\n\nI\u2019m turning 36 and I really want to be good. I really want to be good at what I do. I\u2019ve been doing this for like 10 years and when you start out it\u2019s a passion and it\u2019s fun and it\u2019s kind of loose, the way I viewed it. Jobs would come and go and I knew that stuff would be there and not be there. And I just hit this point where I felt like I really wanted to be really good. And I didn\u2019t know how to do that.\n\nYou don\u2019t think you were good on \u201cHappy Endings\u201d and \u201cThe Mindy Project\u201d?\n\nI think I am good but I think I can be better. You only have a short time to do all this stuff because of your age. Everything is constantly changing. I really wanted to make sure that I was thought of as one of the best. I think the only way to do that is to start making sure that you\u2019ve touched everything.", "title": "Adam Pally Is Very, Very Nervous", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I have my account set up in the Mail app, but how do I find my Gmail contacts list on my iPad?\n\nA. If you cannot find the address book you use with your Gmail on the web, it may be because your Gmail contacts are not set to sync with your iPad. Once you configure the settings, you should see your Gmail connections listed when you open the iPad\u2019s standard Contacts app.\n\nTo sync Gmail contacts to an iOS device running iOS 11, go to the iPad\u2019s home screen and tap open the Settings icon. Select Accounts & Passwords. On the next screen, under Accounts, tap Gmail, Google or whatever you nicknamed the mail account when you first set it up on the iPad.\n\nOn the Gmail settings screen, go to the Contacts line and tap the button to the On position. In addition to mail and contacts, you can sync your Google Calendar and Notes to your iPad; the information then appears in the iPad\u2019s default Calendar and Notes apps. Press the Home button when you are finished. Because the contacts list is now set to synchronize, changes you make \u2014 like updating an address or phone number for someone on your list \u2014 should update across all your devices.", "title": "Adding Gmail Contacts to an iPad", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "There comes a time when everyone wants a little more space \u2014 whether it is because a child is on the way, a home office has become a necessity or for some other reason. I see posts in my Twitter feed that have \u201csensitive content\u201d labels in place of the message. What counts as sensitive content, and how can I unblock it?\n\nA. Twitter\u2019s media policy generally does not allow images or videos depicting graphic violence, pornography or hate-group imagery to be attached to posts. Twitter users can report material they find objectionable by selecting the menu icon on the message and using the Report option.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHowever, the company makes exceptions when the posted material is deemed to be \u201cartistic, medical, health or educational\u201d content. To shield users who do not wish to see such things popping up in their feeds, Twitter blocks those posts from view with the \u201csensitive content\u201d label.\n\nIf you prefer to judge the posts yourself, you can adjust your settings. Log into your account at twitter.com, click your profile icon on the right and select \u201cPrivacy and safety settings\u201d on the left. In the Safety area of the page, turn on the check box next to \u201cDisplay media that may contain sensitive content.\u201d (Those using the Twitter for Android app can also do this in the app\u2019s settings.)\n\nPhoto\n\nLikewise, you can make potentially sensitive content visible in Twitter searches by turning off the \u201cHide sensitive content\u201d check box in the Search area. Click Save Changes when you are finished.\n\nAfter years of a rather hands-off approach to policing its users, Twitter announced last month that it will enforce its new restrictions against abusive behavior and other hateful conduct. Last year, prosecutors brought a man suspected of belonging to Al Qaeda to Philadelphia to face charges in federal court. The suspect, Ali Charaf Damache, a dual Algerian and Irish citizen, was transferred from Spain. If the administration had tried to send him to the military prison in Cuba, then Spain probably would have refused to cooperate.\n\nAdministration officials have said that Mr. Sessions still believes in the value of the Guant\u00e1namo facility. And in this fight against terror, we have gotten results.\u201d\n\nAfter a driver killed eight people by plowing his truck down a crowded Manhattan bike path in November, Mr. Trump has signaled that he recognized the reality of prosecuting people at Guant\u00e1namo Bay.\n\n\u201cWould love to send the NYC terrorist to Guantanamo,\u201d he wrote on Twitter, \u201cbut statistically that process takes much longer than going through the Federal system.\u201d\n\nMany Republicans who were most vocal in their criticism when President Barack Obama made that same argument were silent in response to Mr. Trump\u2019s decision.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEmirati officials had agreed to hand over Mr. Khabyar for federal prosecution. Some officials say he is a better candidate to face charges from the Emirati government. And even assuming he served time in an American prison, he could argue after his release that he should not be deported to Yemen or Sudan because he would be tortured.\n\nMr. Khaybar was captured in mid-2016 by United Arab Emirates forces during a raid. Officials said Mr. Khaybar, who is about 40, was cooperative and provided valuable information to his interrogators. His willingness to talk was viewed as a sign that he would have helped prosecutors once he was in American custody.\n\nHis case inside the intelligence community has been likened to that of Ahmed Abdulkadir Warsame, a Somali terrorist who was captured in 2010 and brought back to New York, where he was successfully prosecuted. Yet Gonzalez never reached the World Series, and when his Los Angeles Dodgers finally made it last fall, he watched most of it on television in a suite. A back injury had knocked him out of the postseason.\n\n\u201cSomewhat of a scout,\u201d he said on Wednesday, describing his role for the World Series, which the Dodgers lost to the Houston Astros. \u201cIt was fun, it was exciting, and I enjoyed it. I wish the team would have won Game 7, but some things don\u2019t always go perfect.\u201d\n\nGonzalez had already lost his first-base job to Cody Bellinger, a slugging rookie, and the Dodgers had no use for a scout making $21.5 million. They dumped his salary last month in a trade with the Atlanta Braves, who persuaded Gonzalez to approve the deal by agreeing to release him once it became official.\n\nFree agency led Gonzalez to the Mets, whose one-year, $545,000 deal with the team became official on Thursday. If he does not, they will have assumed almost no risk.", "title": "Adrian Gonzalez Is Officially a Met, With Plans to Tutor Dominic Smith", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "WILLIAMSBURG, Va. \u2014 The playwright Adrienne Kennedy never wanted to move to Virginia. She spent 30 years living on the fourth floor of a brownstone on West 89th Street \u2014 her \u201clittle Victorian palace,\u201d she called it. But the rent went higher. Her breath on the stairs came shorter. Just before she turned 80, she traveled down to Williamsburg, Va., to visit her younger son, Adam Kennedy, and she stayed.\n\n\u201cUnfortunately, I\u2019ve been here six years,\u201d she said of her new city. \u201cI hate it.\u201d\n\nThe move to Virginia cost Ms. Kennedy her shelves of books and her walks down Broadway. But it has given her a poem, a memoir and a play, \u201cHe Brought Her Heart Back in a Box,\u201d which begins performances at Theater for a New Audience on Jan. 18. It is her first new play in nearly a decade and the first that she has written without a collaborator in 20 years.\n\nMs. Kennedy, one of the American theater\u2019s greatest and least compromising experimentalists, was speaking at a table in a genteel hotel lounge near the Colonial Williamsburg living history site. Her dramas are sites of living history, too, where personal stories of racism\u2019s unhealed wounds mingle with dark tales thieved from the Brothers Grimm and 1940s Hollywood.\n\nOn a morning just after Christmas, the hotel was still decorated for the holidays and so was Ms. Kennedy, in a brocade coat, a purple scarf and a black broderie anglaise dress. One hand clutched an asthma inhaler.", "title": "Adrienne Kennedy, Playwright: Still Quiet, Still Bold, Still Furious", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Rossell\u00f3 said he intends to try and harness the political power of about 5 million Puerto Rico-born citizens scattered around the country to help the statehood push by pressing and evaluating candidates on their support for that effort.\n\nThere is no chance that Congress will accept the credentials of the shadow delegation and seat them as representatives of Puerto Rico, which currently has a nonvoting resident commissioner who can participate in congressional debates. But it is a way of making a point. It is also following a well-traveled historical path to statehood.\n\nIn 1796, the residents of Tennessee decided to force the issue of statehood by holding a convention, drafting a constitution, electing members of the House and Senate and then demanding that the other states let Tennessee in. The state eventually prevailed, and that hardball path to statehood came to be known as the Tennessee Plan. It has been copied by others, most recently Alaska, and Puerto Rico is now utilizing the technique.\n\nWith an eye toward worries about political realignment, the shadow delegation includes three Democrats, three Republicans and an independent. While they may not share the same view when it comes to assessing the quality of the federal response to the hurricane, they would agree that Puerto Rico\u2019s recovery would have been handled differently if it was a full-fledged state.\n\nThe new tax law, coming on the heels of the hurricane and a debilitating financial crisis, seemed to Puerto Ricans to be an especially cruel step. The legislation instituted a new tax on intellectual property held by foreign corporations that Puerto Ricans say will eliminate a main incentive for businesses to locate on the island and puts Puerto Rico on the same level as a foreign nation. \u201cWe are American citizens and these are American jobs,\u201d the governor said. \u201cIt just doesn\u2019t make sense.\n\nHe and other statehood backers say the island of nearly 3.5 million people \u2014 it would be the 30th largest state by population \u2014 would have fared much better with full representation in Congress and the right of residents to vote for president.\n\n\u201cBecause we don\u2019t have political power, because we don\u2019t have representatives, senators, no vote for president, we are treated as an afterthought,\u201d said Mr. Rossell\u00f3. \u201cWhen it is time to vote, there is not accountability.\u201d", "title": "Advocates of Puerto Rico Statehood Plan to Demand Representation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "The Times article also cited the suspicious death of Lance Cpl. Gregory Buckley Jr., a United States Marine who was killed at a checkpoint where he was stationed with a notorious commander who had a retinue of bacha bazi boys. Corporal Buckley had complained about that commander and was killed, along with two other Marines, by one of the commander\u2019s boys.\n\nThe Sigar report made no mention of the cases of Corporal Buckley, Captain Quinn or Sergeant Martland, and it appeared to have interviewed only three unnamed American soldiers who reported being aware of the practice, which many soldiers and Afghan officials have told journalists they know to be widespread.\n\nAs of Aug. 12, 2016, the Defense Department was investigating 75 instances of gross human rights violations, seven involving child sexual assault, but even Defense Department officials acknowledged that that was a small portion of the total, the Sigar report said.\n\nUnder the Leahy Law, United States military aid funds must be cut off to any foreign military unit implicated in gross human rights violations, which includes the practice of bacha bazi, with its enslavement and rape of young boys. But another provision of American law, called the \u201cnotwithstanding clause,\u201d says that Afghan military aid should be available \u201cnotwithstanding any other provision of law.\u201d\n\nThe Sigar report said that the \u201cnotwithstanding clause\u201d had been used repeatedly to evade cutting off military aid to Afghan units.\n\n\u201cDOD\u2019s continuing to provide assistance to units for which the department has credible information of a gross violation of human rights undermines efforts by U.S. government officials to engage with the Afghan government on the importance of respect for human rights and rule of law,\u201d the report said. Le Guin, 88, a feminist science fiction author known for books such as \u201cThe Left Hand of Darkness\u201d and the Earthsea series.\n\n\u2022 Finally, \u201cI\u2019ll Drink to That,\u201d a podcast by a former sommelier, is an indispensable resource on wine and its history.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nIn honor of Australia Day, Friday\u2019s holiday marking the anniversary of Britain\u2019s arrival Down Under in 1788, we\u2019re looking at one of the country\u2019s most recognizable exports: \u201cG\u2019day, mate!\u201d\n\nAustralian National University points to an early use of the greeting in \u201cThe Romance of a Station,\u201d a novel from 1889:\n\n\u201cHe pulled up, nodding to Alec\u2019s \u2018Good-day, Tillidge\u2019, and replying in a short, morose manner, running his words one into the other, as a bushman does, \u2018G\u2019d-day, sir.\u2019\u201d\n\nA century later, the phrase was popularized the world over in a tourism ad campaign featuring Paul Hogan, the Australian actor who would later gain international fame as Crocodile Dundee.\n\nAustralians have a long tradition of abbreviating and slackening words and phrases, particularly by adding \u201cie\u201d to the end.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAussie\u201d appears in references from World War I. A book by Gertrude Moberly, recounting the experiences of a nurse, described a \u201cfarewell dance for the boys going home to \u2018Aussie\u2019 tomorrow.\u201d\n\nAnd Australians always have their \u201cmates.\u201d The nation\u2019s unique camaraderie, known as mateship, is especially evident during commemorations of the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps (or Anzacs), the World War I-era fighting force.\n\nAdam Baidawi contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.
