Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSeeking Justice in Oakland\n\nThe path forward appears rockier in Oakland, where several former employees of restaurants owned by the chef Charlie Hallowell described a pattern of sexual propositions and a near-constant stream of sexual innuendo to The San Francisco Chronicle in December.\n\nMr. Hallowell, 44, who began his cooking career at Chez Panisse, employs about 150 people at three restaurants with his business partner, Richard Weinstein. His first, Pizzaiolo, has been a hub of local left-leaning politics, art and community projects since it opened in 2005.\n\nMr. Hallowell has been the most public about his personal and professional efforts to navigate the scandal. \u201cI have stepped aside and indefinitely left the day-to-day operations of the restaurant,\u201d he wrote this week in response to several questions for this article. \u201cI have stopped taking my salary and stopped taking any owner distributions.\u201d\n\nListening to people\u2019s experiences and hearing their anger and frustration \u201chas been pretty brutal, and it has really illuminated the massive blind spot I had,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Hallowell said he is in the process of hiring a new chief executive with input from the staff, and is staying out of the restaurants as an independent investigation arranged by his legal counsel is underway. He has hired a human resources consultant, and said he wants to bring on a coach with expertise in management training and organizational psychology.\n\nHe is also working with Restorative Justice for Oakland Youth, an organization founded by Fania Davis, the sister of the author and political activist Angela Davis, which aims to bring victims and perpetrators together to work toward reconciliation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI feel like we are digging so deep into this place of blame that we can\u2019t find a place of healing,\u201d said Teiahsha Bankhead, a co-director. The goal, she said, is to recognize that people are taught to behave in certain ways \u2014 and to change that culture, both for women and men.\n\nIt may not be enough. The seven-person management team at one restaurant, Boot and Shoe Service, has threatened to resign if Mr. Hallowell does not divest from the restaurant by Saturday. (At other restaurants, the staff is staying on and not joining in that fight.)\n\nMolly Surbridge is a former employee who told The Chronicle that Mr. Hallowell had once stopped her during an interview for a promotion to say he wanted to have sex with her. She and others said they think he is convinced that the scandal will eventually blow over.\n\n\u201cRight now, it\u2019s just public shaming, which doesn\u2019t work,\u201d she said in an interview last week. \u201cIt needs to be a real consequence. Because it is a business, it needs to be about money.\u201d\n\nSilence and Conversation in New York\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Friedman, 56, who owns seven restaurants in New York and California with the chef April Bloomfield, has dropped out of public sight since The New York Times reported in December that he had created a pervasive culture of sexual predation and harassment, especially at the Spotted Pig in the West Village, where some employees referred to a celebrity-studded private dining room as \u201cthe rape room.\u201d\n\nSince making some initial apologies, Ms. Bloomfield has not spoken publicly about the state of the restaurants or her business relationship with Mr. Friedman. She has taken over operations.\n\nMr. Friedman has sought treatment, according to former employees who said he had sent them apologies and the phone number of a Connecticut rehabilitation center in case they wanted to contact him.\n\nKelly Berg, the group\u2019s recently hired human resources manager, issued a statement on Monday that said the company was working with consultants and \u201crolling out a forceful action plan to elevate and empower our managers and enact our standards throughout the organization.\u201d The plan includes increased training and better monitoring to ensure \u201ca supportive and caring environment.\u201d Mr. Friedman, the statement said, has not been involved in day-to-day management since The Times\u2019s article appeared.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s heartbreaking to see your icons taken down,\u201d said Kerry Diamond, a founder of Cherry Bombe, a media group dedicated to women and food that features Ms. Bloomfield on the current cover of its twice-yearly magazine \u2014 a feature that Ms. Diamond said had been developed long before the revelations.\n\n\u201cAt the same time,\u201d she added, \u201cthese are important conversations we\u2019re finally having about harassment and abuse, so you can\u2019t be too sad. It\u2019s going to be painful and messy if we want real change to occur.\u201d\n\nA Quandary for Customers\n\nThe dining public appears to be divided. At first, many reservations and holiday parties scheduled for Mr. Batali\u2019s and Ms. Bloomfield\u2019s restaurants were canceled. But business doesn\u2019t appear to have suffered terribly. Babbo was packed on Sunday night. At the Spotted Pig, the wait for a 7 p.m. table on Friday was an hour long.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Ms. Bloomfield has been trying to steady the Hearth & Hound, which opened just as the Friedman expos\u00e9 was published. Reservations aren\u2019t hard to get, but last weekend tables were filled.\n\nSamantha Martin, a customer who ate there last week, said she hadn\u2019t heard about the accusations against Mr. Friedman. \u201cI try to do everything right and be careful where my money goes, but I can\u2019t keep track of everything,\u201d she said. \u201cEven if I heard it, I\u2019m not sure I would have skipped coming here. The food is incredible.\u201d\n\nFor some diners, though, the taint may never go away. Brian Gresko, a Brooklyn writer who addresses themes of gender and masculinity in his work, was recently casting around for a new place to eat near Union Square because he could not bring himself to go to Otto, a Batali restaurant.\n\nMr. Gresko used to meet friends there regularly, and even chose it to celebrate his birthday. Now he vows to show support for the #MeToo movement by \u201cnot consuming the art or the products that these guys have created,\u201d he said. \u201cTo my stomach\u2019s dismay.\u201d", "title": "After the Apologies, Restaurants Struggle to Change", "authors": ["Kim Severson"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "First, more than 800 guests made their way by candlelight across glittering grass to a giant chessboard, complete with robotic chess pieces that did their best to block the doors of the giant mirrored marquee.\n\nInside, the huge plaster casts of body parts that had been suspended from the ceiling for the show were still there, and Champagne accompanied edible fondant fancies shaped like Magritte-inspired apples or scarlet dice. All around were go-go girls in playing-card tutus, and a hostess worked the room with a lit candelabrum balanced on her head.", "title": "After the Couture Show, Dior\u2019s Surrealist Ball", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "But Mr. Cotton said the Port Authority was \u201cnot stepping away from responsibility.\u201d Instead, it was making changes now while awaiting the recommendations of Mr. LaHood, who is now a senior policy adviser to the DLA Piper law firm.\n\nMr. LaHood said his team would look at everything and talk to everyone, including airline and airport employees and passengers. \u201cWe will get to the bottom of this,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. LaHood said he understood how frustrated many travelers were, especially those who had not been reunited with their luggage for a week or more. He admitted that he had received a few emails from people asking if he could help them find their bags. He said he could not.\n\nOne of the investigators\u2019 first interviews will be with the Federal Aviation Administration next week, Mr. LaHood said. The F.A.A. sent a letter this week to Kennedy\u2019s managers demanding an explanation of how they handled the removal of snow and ice during and after the storm, which struck on Jan. 4.\n\nKeeping the runways clear is the Port Authority\u2019s job. But the big problems that weekend emanated from terminals shared by foreign airlines and operated by private companies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe airlines and terminal operators are responsible for getting planes to and from gates to load and unload passengers and luggage. Most of them hire contractors to handle the bags and clean and stock the planes.\n\nAt Terminal 1, which is shared by a roster of foreign carriers, the workers on the ground could not keep pace with the steady flow of arrivals. The frigid weather also disabled some equipment, said Huntley Lawrence, the Port Authority\u2019s director of aviation.\n\nPlanes were stuck between the runways and the terminal for hours before the Port Authority was called in to rescue the passengers with buses. Many of those passengers wound up leaving the airport without their bags.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo add mishap to misery, a water main burst in the ceiling of Terminal 4 on Jan. 7, gushing water through an arrivals area still crowded with stranded travelers. As a response, Mr. Cotton said the Port Authority had ordered all of the terminal owners and operators to inspect all of their pipes and plumbing to make sure that it is protected from extreme weather.\n\nMr. Cotton said that there had been no management changes at the Port Authority or at Kennedy. He said he was not aware of any changes at airlines or terminal operators either.\n\n\u201cThere are plenty of failures to go around and I think everyone has acknowledged that,\u201d Mr. Cotton said. He said the airlines and terminal operators had been very cooperative and had willingly agreed to a new spirit of mutual aid.\n\nMr. Lawrence said that the newly created emergency operations center had been convened for two minor storms in the two weeks since the chaos. He said it was the first to be set up for storms at Kennedy, though he said Newark Liberty International Airport has had one.\n\nMr. Lawrence said that about 100 pieces of luggage still had not been returned to their owners, a failure that Mr. Cotton called \u201cunconscionable.\u201d\n\nAfter apologizing again for the collective lapses, Mr. Cotton promised improvement. \u201cWe simply have to assure that J.F.K. performs better and performs better starting now,\u201d he said.", "title": "After the Storm, Port Authority Plots Changes at J.F.K. Airport", "authors": ["Patrick Mcgeehan"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "The scandal began when Catherine Corless, an amateur historian, dug into the history of the old mother-and-baby home in Tuam that was managed by the Sisters of Bon Secours from 1925 to 1961. It was one of more than a dozen homes throughout Ireland that were often run by Catholic religious orders, but were funded and supposedly regulated by the government.\n\nMs. Corless came across the death certificates for nearly 800 children who had died at the home, often of contagious disease. But there were virtually no burial records, an absence in the public record that neither the Bon Secours nor the local government could explain.\n\nAfter further sleuthing, she wrote an article in the local journal in 2012 that strongly suggested that the remains of hundreds of children, all born to unwed mothers and all baptized in the Catholic faith, had not been buried in consecrated ground, but in parts of a disused septic system dating to when the home was a 19th-century workhouse.\n\nThose suspicions were confirmed last March by forensic investigators working for the Commission of Investigation Into Mother and Baby Homes, which had been established by the chastened government in response to Ms. Corless\u2019s work. The commission is charged with examining the social and historical reasons for these institutions, to which Irish society had long relegated vulnerable, unwed mothers and their children.\n\nMs. Zappone, meanwhile, dispatched a panel of technical experts who eventually developed the five options. They reported that the considerable complications included the amount of juvenile remains and their commingling, which would make individual identifications difficult, and the potentially limited yield of DNA tests. The experts emphasized the importance of communicating \u201crealistic expectations,\u201d given the need to match extracted samples with those of living relatives and the likelihood that samples taken from infants would be of poor quality.", "title": "Agonizing Question for Irish: What to Do With Children\u2019s Remains?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nYou report that three months after Hurricane Maria, half of Puerto Ricans are still without power (news article, Dec. 30). How can we allow our fellow citizens to suffer and even die?\n\nAfter Hurricane Irma, my house in Florida was without power for three weeks. Before spending hundreds of dollars at a hotel, a luxury many do not have, I spent a week without power between my house and a friend\u2019s.\n\nWhat people fail to recognize are the dangerous conditions a lack of electricity creates for families, especially those already struggling. It\u2019s not the lack of TV or decent food or light that is so problematic, but the lack of proper air-conditioning in a hot climate.\n\nStaying hydrated is a huge struggle, and a cold shower is the only moment of relief you can get. Sadly, a lack of running water and questions about water safety have also been issues. This is simply unacceptable, and Congress must step up aid to the island. We cannot sit by while our citizens die.", "title": "Opinion | Aid to Puerto Rico: An Appalling Lapse", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Aileen Eve Silbert and Shai Vichness were married Jan. 27 at the Liberty Warehouse, an events space in Brooklyn. Rabbi David Ellenson officiated, with Rabbi Suri L. Krieger participating.\n\nThe bride, 36, is a licensed mental health counselor in private practice in Manhattan. She graduated summa cum laude from Barnard College and received a master's degree in mental health counseling from N.Y.U.\n\nShe is the daughter of Dr. Janys Gelberg of Tenafly, N.J., and Dr. Glenn R. Silbert of White Plains. The bride\u2019s father is an ophthalmologist in private practice in Hackensack, N.J., and an associate clinical professor of ophthalmology at New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, part of the Mount Sinai Health System in Manhattan. He is on the board of the Society of Columbia Graduates, an alumni group that annually rewards excellence in teaching at the university. Her mother is a cosmetic and holistic dentist, with offices in Englewood, N.J., and Manhattan.\n\nThe groom, 35, is a managing director of Nuveen Investments in Manhattan. He graduated from Baruch College.", "title": "Aileen Silbert, Shai Vichness", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Homeowners, take comfort: Even the appliances on Air Force One break down.\n\nMore than a quarter-century after they were installed, two of the refrigerators on the president\u2019s plane need to be upgraded, and these specially designed \u201cchillers\u201d aren\u2019t cheap.\n\nThe Boeing Company was awarded a nearly $24 million contract in December to engineer the refrigerators for Air Force One, the Defense Department said.\n\nThe two units being replaced came with the aircraft in 1990 and are no longer able \u201cto effectively support mission requirements for food storage,\u201d the Air Force said in a statement on Saturday.\n\n\u201cThe units were based on the technology at the time and designed for short-term food storage,\u201d the statement said. \u201cAlthough serviced on a regular basis, reliability has decreased with failures increasing.\u201d", "title": "Air Force One Needs 2 New Refrigerators. Together, They Cost $24 Million.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Another of Silicon Valley\u2019s biggest unicorns appears to be slowly edging toward the public stock markets \u2014 even if only by baby steps.\n\nAirbnb announced on Thursday that it had named its first independent board member \u2014 Kenneth I. Chenault, the departing chief executive of American Express. Naming an outside board member is often an early step by a company that will eventually seek an initial public offering.\n\nAt the same time, Airbnb\u2019s chief executive, Brian Chesky, wrote in a letter to the online room-rental service\u2019s top hosts that he was building a company with an \u201cinfinite time horizon.\u201d\n\nThe moves are the latest sign that another of the biggest privately held companies in the technology universe may be preparing to go public. These companies, typically valued at more than $1 billion by private investors, are known as unicorns. Dropbox, the file-storage provider, which was most recently valued at $10 billion, recently filed confidentially for an initial offering. Spotify, the music streaming giant, is pursuing an unconventional \u201cdirect listing\u201d of its shares on the public markets.", "title": "Airbnb, Edging Toward Possible I.P.O, Names Ken Chenault to Board", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "As Samantha Wilson wrote on Hollywood Life by Bonnie Fuller at the time, \u201cThere\u2019s Photoshop, and then there\u2019s Photoshop.\u201d\n\nIn addition to pledging not to alter its own imagery, CVS is also asking all of the brands it sells (companies like L\u2019Or\u00e9al, Maybelline and Coty) to do the same, or to label retouched images clearly and visibly as \u201cmodified.\u201d The company has created what it is calling a \u201cbeauty mark\u201d (catchy, that), which looks kind of like a heart within a broken circle. It will be applied to all images to signal truth in advertising. CVS will start phasing in the new system in April and is hoping it will be complete by 2020.\n\nGet ready for crow\u2019s feet! Laugh lines! The occasional age spot and dark under-eye circle or two. It\u2019s hard to imagine, right? We have lived in an airbrushed world for so long, the sight of a visible pore really would be something shocking.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe felt it was important to be as transparent and authentic as possible with the women who come into our stores,\u201d Ms. Foulkes said. \u201cWe want to be clear about the issue and make beauty something that makes women feel good, as opposed to not good enough.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s an awfully good \u2026 well, sound bite, but it does raise the question of what \u201cmaterially altered\u201d means? After all, not \u201caltered at all\u201d creates something of a loophole for those taking part. Erasing a pimple here and a worry line there may not seem material to one brand, but it could be material to an individual. There\u2019s a sliding scale of what constitutes transparency for most of us, and we aren\u2019t the ones selling skin care.\n\nAccording to the official statement from CVS, the company is defining \u201cmaterially altered\u201d as \u201cchanging or enhancing a person\u2019s shape, size, proportion, skin or eye color, wrinkles or any other individual characteristics.\u201d Not, however, taming a flyaway hair (to suggest one example that might sneak through).\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a conversation we are having now with our partners,\u201d Ms. Foulkes said. \u201cIf a famous actress shows up for a shoot and she\u2019s had a very late work night and has dark circles under her eyes, is cleaning them up materially altering her image? I think it is, but other people might not.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe actress question is, as it happens, not just any old example. In 2011, Lanc\u00f4me, part of L\u2019Or\u00e9al, got in trouble with the Advertising Standards Authority in the United Kingdom for a Julia Roberts ad for its Teint Miracle foundation that showed Ms. Roberts miraculously lit from within, with not a visible line or spot. The problem was, said the authority, which banned the ad, her glow was probably due more to digital postproduction work than to the actual product.\n\nSimilarly, in 2014, Diane Keaton made a speech at the Golden Globes in all her 68-year-old glory, only to appear with the skin of a twentysomething in a L\u2019Oreal commercial that same evening, a contrast that was widely mocked.\n\nWhile we most often complain about the negative effects airbrushing can have on the body images of young girls \u2014 the American Medical Association has identified it as health issue \u2014 the impact of Keaton-esque treatment can be just as detrimental for us more mature women, even if theoretically we are supposed to know better (or at least be able to recognize the impossible, or implausible, when we see it).\n\nHaving been at many fashion shows where older models are trotted out onto the catwalk, I have been struck by the discrepancy between reality and representation. No matter how great they look (and many of them are amazingly beautiful women in their 40s), their bodies and their faces generally look nothing like they do in the pages of glossy magazines. They have back fat. They even have the occasional pimple. They have what my middle child once called \u201cthose holes in your face\u201d (pores).\n\nOnly, of course, in their photographs, they do not. But maybe they will soon.\n\nThere have been anti-airbrushing movements before. Last November, Lupita Nyong\u2019o publicly criticized Grazia UK magazine for erasing her ponytail. In 2016, Pirelli published a non-airbrushed calendar for the first time and got women like Nicole Kidman, Julianne Moore and Helen Mirren to pose unfiltered. But the CVS news takes the initiative to a new level, thanks to its size: 7,900 stand-alone stores in the United States selling beauty, with an average of 571 square feet per store devoted to the sector, and five million people passing through the stores daily, 80 percent of whom are women.\n\nThat\u2019s a lot of eyeballs. Hey, wait \u2026 are yours bloodshot and squinty today? Me, too.", "title": "Airbrushing Meets the #MeToo Movement. Guess Who Wins.", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "While it would be premature to write the A380\u2019s obituary, there is little doubt that the double-decker plane \u2014 once touted as the future of aviation \u2014 has been an enormous disappointment and a financial disaster for Airbus, the most formidable competitor to Boeing in the passenger airplane market.\n\nWhen Airbus started delivering the A380 a decade ago, after spending $25 billion to develop it, the company based near Toulouse, France, saw the plane as the solution to airport congestion and to increased demand for air travel. Only so many planes can land at an airport in any given day, so Airbus reasoned that planes carrying more people would allow airports to absorb more passengers.\n\nThe A380 can carry more than 500 passengers while also offering amenities like showers, first-class suites and a bar.\n\nBut the airline industry responded by increasing traffic to smaller airports, a change that favored Boeing and its 787 Dreamliner, a midsize, wide-bodied plane that can carry a maximum of 330 passengers. The Dreamliner has two engines, making it much less expensive to maintain than the four-engine A380.\n\nMr. Aboulafia of Teal Group noted that it is now possible to fly directly to Spain from Washington, D.C., without passing through a large hub like London or Frankfurt.\n\n\u201cAs smaller, more efficient planes flood the market,\u201d he said in an email, \u201cnew city pairs are being created almost every day, killing the case for larger aircraft.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAirbus did not book any orders for the A380 last year, the company said on Monday. In fact, orders for two planes were canceled.\n\nThe superjumbo\u2019s poor performance overshadowed an otherwise decent year for Airbus, which said on Monday that it delivered 718 aircraft in 2017, a 4 percent increase from the previous year. The company said it had a backlog of orders worth $1.1 trillion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAirbus could further benefit from a general upswing in commercial air travel, and it may profit from a trade dispute between its archrival Boeing and Bombardier of Canada.\n\nThe United States Commerce Department imposed punitive tariffs on Bombardier last year after Boeing accused it of receiving unfair subsidies from the Canadian government. Bombardier is challenging the tariffs, but has also struck a deal to build its new CSeries midrange planes at an Airbus factory in Alabama. That could allow Bombardier to avoid the penalties.\n\nAirbus\u2019s best-seller by far in 2017 was the A320 line, versions of which can carry up to 240 passengers, or about half as many as the A380.\n\nMr. Leahy, the Airbus chief operating officer, said on Monday that the A380\u2019s best days were ahead. Passenger traffic is doubling every 15 years, he said, meaning that the original rationale for the model still holds.\n\nAirbus, as a result, is still betting that airlines flying between large, highly congested hubs in London or New Delhi will have no choice but to buy larger planes if they want to continue to grow.\n\n\u201cIf people want to fly, they need to fly in bigger aircraft,\u201d Mr. Leahy said. \u201cThis is an airplane whose time will come.\u201d\n\nBut he acknowledged that, until that day arrives, Airbus needs a minimum of six to eight orders a year to keep production alive at the A380\u2019s final assembly plant near Toulouse. For the moment, he said, the only likely customer for those planes is Emirates.\n\n\u201cThey are probably the only one who has the ability right now,\u201d Mr. Leahy said.", "title": "Airbus A380, Once the Future of Aviation, May Cease Production", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The United States has also stepped in, saying it opposes such unilateral changes by China, according to Taiwanese media. In response to a question from Taiwan\u2019s government-run Central News Agency, Brian Hook, a policy adviser to Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, said China should have consulted with Taiwan first.\n\nPhoto\n\nTensions between Taiwan and China force the United States to engage in a difficult geopolitical balancing act. While Washington has joined most of the rest of the world in keeping Taiwan at diplomatic arm\u2019s length for fear of angering China, it also obligated by treaty to provide the means for the island to defend itself.\n\nAccording to Taiwanese media reports, Taiwan has asked friendly nations to raise concerns about the new route with the International Civil Aviation Organization, the U.N. body that oversees international air routes. Taiwan cannot directly appeal to the organization because it is not a member of the United Nations. Taiwan also has no formal ties with the aviation body itself, which is headed by Fang Liu, a Chinese citizen who since 2016 has denied Taiwan observer status.\n\nThe establishment of the new air route comes as China has been stepping up efforts to isolate Taiwan, which broke away when the Communist Party took control of China in 1949. Earlier this month, Chinese authorities forced big multinational corporations that do business in China, including the Marriott hotel chain and Delta Air Lines, to remove Taiwan from lists of countries on their websites.\n\nChina began raising the pressure on Taiwan after Ms. Tsai\u2019s election in 2016. The government of President Xi Jinping of China cut off official communications channels, citing her unwillingness to subscribe to the notion that Taiwan belongs to \u201cone China.\u201d Mr. Xi, who has pledged to restore China to international greatness, has issued stern warnings to Taiwan, saying China will never relinquish control of any part of its territory, even though the Communist government has never ruled Taiwan.\n\nIn a New Year\u2019s statement last month, Zhang Zhijun, minister of China\u2019s Taiwan Affairs Office, put blame for the current tensions on the Tsai administration, accusing it of \u201cindulging and conniving with \u2018Taiwan independence\u2019 forces pushing forward with \u2018desinification\u2019, \u2018progressive Taiwan independence\u2019 and all kinds of backwards policies.\u201d\n\nThe failure to consult with Taiwan before establishing the air route is seen as a slap in the face aimed at Ms. Tsai. In 2015, when Taiwan was governed by the more China-friendly administration of Ms. Tsai\u2019s predecessor, Ma Ying-jeou, Beijing and Taipei negotiated an agreement for China to use a similar air route over the Taiwan Strait for Chinese airliners flying the opposite direction, from north to south.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement on Wednesday, China\u2019s Taiwan Affairs Office said the route was an internal affair of China. It also said that the safe use of the earlier, 2015 route proved that there was no safety risk in flights in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe use of airliners also follows a Chinese strategy of relying on nonmilitary means to assert its sovereignty in other disputes in the region while avoiding a full-blown, armed confrontation.\n\nChina has dispatched coast guard vessels to challenge Japanese control of islands in the East China Sea that China also claims. In the South China Sea, China has used commercial fishing boats and ships from its fisheries management agency to demonstrate its presence in areas also claimed by Southeast Asian nations.\n\nTaiwan also has a history of viewing Chinese airliners as a Trojan horse for military threats against the island. Up until the early 2000s, Taiwan resisted opening direct flights by commercial airliners between China and Taiwan partly out of fear that Chinese military aircraft could evade radar detection by sneaking in behind civilian jets.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTaiwanese officials and security experts said that they think China is growing bolder as its People\u2019s Liberation Army has narrowed the military imbalance with the United States. China\u2019s move \u201chas caused a lot of concern and discussion on our side,\u201d said a Taiwanese government official speaking on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the subject. He also praised the United States for speaking out against China\u2019s move.\n\nThe new air route has alarmed some security experts because it increases China\u2019s ability to launch a surprise attack on the Taiwanese island groups of Kinmen and Matsu, which are near the Chinese coast and thus on the front line of Taiwan\u2019s defense, by allowing Chinese aircraft to get closer before they can be detected.\n\nBy making it easier for China to launch a first strike, the new air route risked further destabilizing an already tense region, said Ian Easton, a research fellow at the Project 2049 Institute, an Arlington, Va.-based think tank, who has done research on Chinese war plans for Taiwan.\n\n\u201cGiven the close-in nature of the standoff, early warning time is vital for stability,\u201d he said, \u201cand it\u2019s being further constricted.\u201d", "title": "Airliners Have Become China\u2019s Newest Means of Pressuring Taiwan", "authors": ["Chris Horton"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "After Alabama drove to a first down at the Clemson 1-yard line, Payne re-entered the game \u2014 presumably to add another big body for blocking purposes. He spent nine seasons as an assistant to Saban at Alabama before taking over at Georgia two years ago, and on Monday he became the sixth former Saban assistant to lose to him (they are 0-12 over all).\n\n\u201cWe told everybody at halftime there was no question they were going to him because they were struggling and they needed some momentum,\u201d Smart said. \u201cHe provided them some juice.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTagovailoa went on to outshine the other freshman quarterback on the field, Jake Fromm of Georgia, who had led the Bulldogs to 13 wins this season and who fell just short of bringing the Bulldogs their first national title since the 1980 season.\n\nAnd after watching Tagovailoa engineer the stunning comeback, even Hurts had to applaud his coach\u2019s move.\n\n\u201cIt was an executive decision and it was a good one,\u201d said Hurts, who was 25-2 as a starter going into the game. \u201cWe\u2019re national champs, so you can\u2019t say anything about it.\u201d\n\nBut that outcome was still uncertain just before the final play. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBefore the next play, Smith looked at his quarterback in the huddle and said, \u201cTrust me.\u201d Saban had already shown faith in Tagovailoa, and the second-down play called for four receivers to go deep.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSmitty was wide open,\u201d said Tagovailoa, who attended the same high school as Marcus Mariota in Honolulu. \u201cSo I hit him, and here we are now, thank God.\u201d\n\nThe Tide had overcome enormous odds to even reach overtime. Trailing by 7 points with just under four minutes remaining in the fourth quarter, Alabama had marched down the field but stalled and faced 4th down deep in Georgia territory. Tagovailoa rolled out to his left, avoided pressure and threw a 7-yard touchdown pass that sizzled past two defenders and into the arms of Calvin Ridley. The extra point by Andy Pappanastos tied the score, 20-20.\n\nAfter Alabama\u2019s defense forced Georgia to punt, Tagovailoa led the Tide back down the field and a victory seemed likely in regulation. They just needed Pappanastos to hit a winning field goal from 36 yards out with just a few seconds remaining.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Pappanastos\u2019s kick hooked severely to the left, just like a 40-yard attempt he had missed in the first half, and the Georgia fans, granted a reprieve, roared in delight and relief.\n\nThose emotions did not last long. Georgia (13-2) did take a brief lead in overtime on Rodrigo Blankenship\u2019s 51-yard field goal after Fromm, too, was sacked for a 13-yard loss. But Tagovailoa followed with perhaps the throw of the season to Smith, and Alabama (13-1) had its second title in three years. Both saw crafty coaching from Saban, who used an unexpected onside kick two years ago to help the Tide beat Clemson in that championship game.\n\nThis victory gave Saban six national titles and added to his stature as one of the most accomplished coaches in college football history. He matched Bear Bryant, who won six national titles at Alabama. Saban has five at Alabama and one at Louisiana State, and the wild victory on Monday helped ease memories of a crushing loss to Clemson in last year\u2019s championship game.\n\nSoon after Monday\u2019s victory, someone tried to stuff a game ball in Saban\u2019s hands to commemorate the latest accomplishment. He may have deserved it, but so, too, did Tagovailoa, Smith, Ridley, the members of the offensive line, and the entire defense, which held Georgia scoreless in the fourth quarter.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think you give anybody a game ball,\u201d Saban said, noting the remarkable nature of the game. \u201cIt has to be a team ball, and that\u2019s exactly what we\u2019ll do with it.\u201d", "title": "Alabama Wins National Championship With a Halftime Twist", "authors": ["David Waldstein"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Alan Bleviss, a ubiquitous voice-over artist who could be heard in everything from presidential campaign ads to blockbuster film trailers and television commercials, died on Dec. 30 at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.\n\nHis death was announced by his daughter Sarah Bleviss. He had lung cancer, she said.\n\nThe Canadian-born Mr. Bleviss\u2019s warm, sonorous voice was heard in countless commercials for companies like AT&T, Heinz, Pampers, Enterprise Rent-a-Car and MasterCard, as well as in trailers for films, including \u201cScarface,\u201d \u201cDirty Dancing\u201d and \u201cRagtime.\u201d He was the voice of the Democratic Party in campaigns for Bill Clinton, Joseph R. Biden Jr. and others.", "title": "Alan Bleviss, Veteran Voice-Over Artist, Is Dead at 76", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Alan Sagner, a prodigious fund-raiser for liberal candidates and causes who served as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, died on Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 97.\n\nThe cause was cardiac amyloidosis, his daughter Deborah said.\n\nAfter serving as the finance chairman for Brendan T. Byrne\u2019s successful 1973 campaign for New Jersey governor, Mr. Sagner was appointed state transportation commissioner by Mr. Byrne, who died the day after Mr. Sagner did.\n\nA Democrat and a homebuilder by profession, Mr. Sagner headed the Corporation for Public Broadcasting in the mid-1990s. He was the unsalaried chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from 1977 to 1985.\n\n\u201cAlan was one of the strong, fair public servants of our time,\u201d said Peter C. Goldmark Jr., who was the Port Authority\u2019s executive director during Mr. Sagner\u2019s tenure, when it was transformed from a sluggish agency into an energetic vehicle for regional economic development.", "title": "Alan Sagner, Who Revitalized the Port Authority, Dies at 97", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "When a public radio reporter asked Mr. Cuomo last month about the allegations against Mr. Hoyt and what he could have done differently to address such behavior in state government, Mr. Cuomo told the reporter, Karen DeWitt, that her question did a \u201cdisservice to women.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen you say it\u2019s state government, you do a disservice to women, with all due respect, even though you\u2019re a woman,\u201d he told Ms. DeWitt.\n\nAfter Mr. Cuomo\u2019s comments attracted widespread criticism, his aides scrambled to clarify that he had meant to convey the prevalence of sexual harassment across sectors.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo said the past year had brought a \u201clong overdue reckoning.\u201d\n\n\u201cThis year, we saw brave men and women across the nation shatter this silence and create a moment of reckoning that through these reforms we seek to turn into permanent protections,\u201d he said.\n\nMany of the various proposals wade into the private as well as the public domain. Mr. Cuomo\u2019s planned legislation would require any companies with state business to disclose the number of sexual harassment cases they had faced each year, and would bar employers from forcing their employees into private arbitration. One of the Democrats\u2019 bills would expand protections for employees of small businesses.\n\nMs. Young said the focus on harassment by celebrities and public officials, both in New York and nationwide, threatened to overshadow victims of sexual harassment whose accused abusers were less well known. She said her proposal to allow independent contractors, in industries ranging from hair styling to real estate, to sue their employers for sexual harassment could ensure protections for up to 40 percent of New Yorkers, the percentage she said work on a freelance or contract basis.\n\n\u201cThis tackles the serial sexual predators of the rich and famous but also helps everyday New Yorkers who may find themselves in terrible situations,\u201d Ms. Young said.", "title": "Albany Lawmakers Signal Consensus on New Sexual Harassment Policies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "New York, which has had no shortage of child sex-abuse scandals, should be on that list. In fact, it should be leading the nation on this issue. Instead it, along with Mississippi, Georgia, Alabama and Michigan, is one of the states with the least victim-friendly reporting laws in the country. New York requires most child sex-abuse victims to sue by the age of 23, 19 years before the average age at which such victims report their abuse.\n\nLawmakers have had the solution in their hands for more than a decade. The Child Victims Act would extend the statute of limitations to age 50 in civil cases, and to age 28 in criminal cases. It would also establish a one-year window in which anyone would be permitted to bring a lawsuit, even if the statute of limitations had already expired.\n\nThe bill enjoys widespread and bipartisan support in Albany \u2014 it passed the State Assembly once again in 2017, by a vote of 139 to 7 \u2014 and from Gov. Andrew Cuomo. And yet it keeps failing to become law.\n\nWhy? The Senate majority leader, John Flanagan, a Republican, has refused to let the bill come to the floor for a vote. The bill\u2019s opponents, which include the Catholic Church, Orthodox Jewish groups and the Boy Scouts of America, are concerned primarily with the one-year window, which they believe would cause a wave of claims that could drive churches, schools and hospitals into bankruptcy. That hasn\u2019t happened in other states, even those that opened the window for longer. In Minnesota, which created a three-year window for a population a little more than a quarter of New York\u2019s, just under 1,000 civil claims have been filed.\n\nBut even if it did, we should be less concerned with protecting the bank accounts of institutions that might harbor sexual predators, and more concerned with bringing justice to the victims \u2014 whether their abusers are clergy members, teachers or, as in a majority of cases, a family member.\n\nThe Child Victims Act should have passed on its merits long ago. Since it hasn\u2019t, Mr. Cuomo needs to step up and demonstrate the leadership he has shown on many other divisive issues in recent years, like same-sex marriage. If Mr. Cuomo includes the bill\u2019s provisions in the 2018-19 state budget, which he is scheduled to present on Tuesday, he will make it extremely tough for Mr. Flanagan and other Republican leaders to say no to protecting New York\u2019s most vulnerable victims.", "title": "Opinion | Albany, Pass the Child Victims Act", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Apple popularized the virtual assistant concept in 2011 when it introduced technology called Siri in its iPhones. About three years later, Amazon debuted the Echo, a speaker packed with microphones to capture and decipher what we\u2019re saying to Alexa. Soon, various technology companies were betting that speaking to machines through virtual assistants would be an essential way for consumers to interact with devices and services in the future.\n\nThere is a reason tech companies think virtual assistants are so important: They want to control an indispensable \u201cplatform\u201d \u2014 a crucial piece of technology other services or devices must rely upon.\n\nSome believe virtual assistant technology can be that sort of platform, and the company with the most useful assistant will gain an advantage for their other services \u2014 like internet search or online shopping. Lose that competition, however, and a company could be at the mercy of its rivals.\n\nWith those stakes in mind, tech giants have been scrambling to make their assistants omnipresent. Since smart speakers are the main way for people to deal with virtual assistants, Amazon and Google stoked holiday sales with heavy discounts, dropping the price of their entry-level models to $30, from $50. At the same time, tech companies have been putting their assistants inside products of all shapes and sizes.\n\nBefore last week\u2019s International CES tech conference in Las Vegas, Amazon announced a string of new Alexa partnerships. Hisense will put the assistant into its television sets, while Kohler said a new bathroom mirror will have built-in microphones so people can use Alexa to dim the lights and fill a bathtub using voice commands. PC makers like HP, Asus and Acer said they were integrating Alexa into their computers, while Panasonic, Garmin and other electronics makers will do the same for devices that go into cars.\n\nAmazon also announced an agreement with Toyota to integrate Alexa into some Toyota and Lexus vehicles. Ditto for a new smoke alarm from First Alert. Google said LG Televisions, headphones from Sony and smart displays from Lenovo will tap into its Assistant.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor now, consumers\u2019 satisfaction with their smart speakers \u2014 and by extension, the onboard assistants \u2014 is helped in part by the fact they didn\u2019t pay a lot to get them into their homes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJustin Hosseininejad, an engineering consultant from Medina, Ohio, said he bought his first Amazon Echo Dot for $50 last year and got a second one free a few months ago with another internet-connected device, the Nest thermostat. He uses them to listen to news in the morning and play music throughout the day. He recognizes that he\u2019s not asking Alexa to do a lot, but considering how little he paid, he is fine with that.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s only certain things I use it for, but I\u2019m happy with it,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m not doing my taxes with it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPaul Erickson, a senior analyst at the research firm IHS Markit, said the next step for these devices will be to become the hub of a connected home, controlling internet-connected lights, thermostats and other basic home appliances.\n\n\u201cThe more interesting functionality is yet to come,\u201d Mr. Erickson said. \u201cPart of that will come as more integration happens this year and next year. This is the first year we\u2019re going to see real advances with the assistants because of competition in the marketplace.\u201d\n\nCompetitors of Google and Amazon are also spreading their assistants far and wide. Apple now has Siri running across its universe of devices, along with an upcoming smart speaker called HomePod. Samsung has its own assistant, Bixby, available in its phones and televisions, and Microsoft has Cortana as a feature built into its Windows software.\n\nAmazon has turned its Echo family of products and the Alexa assistant that powers them into the unlikeliest of success stories \u2014 although it is hard to say exactly how successful because it shrouds its disclosures about devices sales in fuzzy language.\n\nAmazon would say only that it sold \u201ctens of millions\u201d of Alexa devices during the recent holiday season, millions more than the same period last year. Analysts estimate that Echo accounts for over 70 percent of sales in the smart speaker category, with Google a distant second.\n\nGoogle was also coy about revealing exact sales of Google Home. In a statement on Jan. 5, Google announced it has sold one Google Home smart speaker every second since it started shipping a smaller version of voice-controlled device on October 19 \u2014 or about 79 days. That works out to roughly seven million units.\n\nIn the 20 months since it first started making the Google Assistant available as part of its Allo messaging app, Google said its Assistant is now accessible on more than 400 million devices including washing machines, dryers, air-conditioners, refrigerators and dishwashers from LG, headphones from Bose and a range of speakers from 15 different companies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGoogle said the Assistant can now accomplish more than one million tasks, or \u201cactions,\u201d such as asking for photos from Halloween or adding events to a calendar. It created a directory \u2014 searchable, of course \u2014 to highlight these capabilities, hoping to remind users that the Assistant can do more than set a timer.\n\nThere are signs that some consumers are starting to recognize the value of virtual assistants even if they aren\u2019t interested in smart speakers. Mr. Hosseininejad\u2019s friend Stephen Melik, also an engineer from Ohio, said he uses Siri on his Apple Watch and iPhone to control his lights and power switches. But the notion of a stand-alone smart speaker that remains in one place doesn\u2019t make sense to him.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve always viewed these smart speakers as a solution searching for a problem,\u201d he said. \u201cBut the voice assistants, potentially there are a lot of benefits to it.\u201d", "title": "Alexa, We\u2019re Still Trying to Figure Out What to Do With You", "authors": ["Daisuke Wakabayashi", "Nick Wingfield"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The safety and security concerns become more challenging when tools like Alexa are used to make car-to-home connections. While cruising down I-95, a driver can open a garage door back at home or shut off the living room lights, for example. Ford already offers such car-to-home capabilities that, using its Ford+Alexa app, can tap into some 25,000 Alexa skills in vehicles that have the company\u2019s Sync 3 in-dash system. Ford has also added a new feature that allows the driver to forgo the push-to-talk button and trigger Alexa by uttering a wake-up phrase.\n\nSuch convenience does allow for the possibility that restive children could prank Alexa from the back seat simply by calling out for, say, Rick Astley songs. Timur Pulathaneli, Ford\u2019s supervisor of connected vehicles and services, said that if it proved to be a nuisance, drivers could turn the feature off in the app so that Alexa would respond only after a button was pushed on the steering wheel.\n\nFord\u2019s setup also limits what a car thief or a parking attendant can do behind the wheel. A person wouldn\u2019t automatically be able to unlock a home\u2019s front door from the car because such functions work only in conjunction with the owner\u2019s smartphone (which they\u2019d have to steal, too).\n\nAdding voice assistants to vehicles may make cars seem like just another device on the so-called Internet of Things, but it raises the stakes significantly.\n\n\u201cWhat gets added with the car is your specific location,\u201d Mr. Wang said. \u201cYou can track where the car goes and at what times.\u201d\n\nIf compromised, Alexa could provide a criminal with details about a user\u2019s purchases, driving habits and travel routines. And to make it easier to connect different smart devices, Alexa can scan for compatible gadgets. All that information is sent back to Amazon\u2019s servers and then shared with other companies, Travis Witteveen, chief executive of the security firm Avira, pointed out. The sharing of such information increases the system\u2019s \u2014 and the car\u2019s \u2014 security vulnerabilities.\n\nNevertheless, the conveniences that digital assistants offer may make them an ineluctable part of the next generation of cars. Nuance, a leading speech-recognition company involved in the automotive business, is already working on voice systems for cars that would be even easier to use. Eric Montague, Nuance\u2019s senior director of product marketing and strategy, said the company would introduce a system this year that did not require the driver to use a wake-up word or push a button to talk.\n\nUltimately, the car will simply understand when it\u2019s being spoken to.\n\n\u201cPeople will expect to be able to have a conversation with their car,\u201d said Martyn Humphries, a vice president at NXP, whose sensors are used extensively in automotive applications. \u201cSo security is going to have to continue to evolve with it.\u201d", "title": "Alexa, What Happened to My Car?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "New York Fashion Week is losing another designer. Starting this summer, Alexander Wang \u2014 he of late-night-party-in-Bushwick-post-bus-tour-fashion-show fame (at least last season) \u2014 has decided to move his shows from the regular February and September schedule to June and December. Which is to say, precollection time. Which is a kind of insider fashion season that no one else (especially not consumers) actually understands and with which fashion itself has an ambivalent relationship.\n\nAccording to the company\u2019s announcement, the move, which will also include combining the precollection and main collections into one, and dividing the label\u2019s products into monthly deliveries (spread out between October-March and April-September), \u201cis widely considered to be a transformative solution for the global industry, breaking out of the conventional fashion calendar.\u201d It\u2019s not specified who is doing all that considering, but let\u2019s go with it for now.\n\nIn terms of real world benefit, this shortens the gap between initial product reveal and initial product delivery from six months to four, thus making consumers wait slightly less time for at least some purchasing satisfaction. It also means that if you follow the entertainment juggernaut that the ready-to-wear shows have become, there soon won\u2019t be any #Wangfest to amuse you.", "title": "Alexander Wang Is Leaving New York Fashion Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Both feature extended and sympathetic give and take between young and quite old people. In each, Smith finds a way to consider the work of a lesser-known English female artist. In \u201cAutumn\u201d it was the painter Pauline Boty; here it is the artist and sculptor Barbara Hepworth.\n\nFinally, each of these books has an elastic structure, one that allows Smith the freedom to write as if improvising a bedtime story. The combination of dreaminess and acuity is what gives these books their tang.\n\nI\u2019ve never seen one of Smith\u2019s plays, of which she has written several. But I\u2019d like to. Her dialogue is a series of pine cones flung at rosy cheeks. Her characters take aim with disastrous candor. Here\u2019s a snippet of Sophia and Iris\u2019s talk, as overheard by Art:\n\n\u201cSelfish. (His mother.)\n\nSophist. (His aunt.)\n\nSolipsist. (His mother.)\n\nSwotty little show-off. (His aunt.)\n\nI know what you did with your life. (His mother.)\n\nI know what you did with my life too. (His aunt.)\u201d\n\nNot long after this, Art, perhaps after drinking a jeroboam of eggnog, is reported to be shouting about landscaping and then \u201chis head hit the table with a thud.\u201d This is Pinter by way of Annie Baker.\n\nSmith does not wear her politics as lightly in \u201cWinter\u201d as she did in \u201cAutumn.\u201d There is perhaps one speech too many about how we are all in this world together. This novel takes more patience than did \u201cAutumn\u201d; it\u2019s slower to rake its themes into a coherent pile. My advice: Read it anyway.\n\nThere\u2019s a moment around its midpoint when Lux explains why she came to England to study. It\u2019s because of \u201cCymbeline,\u201d the Shakespeare play. She declares, in one greedy sentence:\n\n\u201cI read it and I thought, if this writer from this place can make this mad and bitter mess into this graceful thing it is at the end, where the balance comes back and all the lies are revealed and all the losses are compensated, and that\u2019s the place on earth he comes from, that\u2019s the place that made him, then that\u2019s the place I\u2019m going, I\u2019ll go there, I\u2019ll live there.\u201d\n\nI read \u201cWinter\u201d and thought something similar: Yes, I could build an igloo here. All the same, I\u2019ll be looking forward to Smith\u2019s spring thaw.", "title": "Ali Smith\u2019s Seasonal Cycle Turns to a Dreamy \u2018Winter\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "At a moment when the old titans like Cond\u00e9 Nast and Time Inc. are contracting, shape-shifting and anxiously hashtagging, herein lies a museum of real magazine making, testament to the old glossy solidity. The price of admission, however, is stiff: visitors can do research with a staffer\u2019s aid for 75 pounds per hour (about $100), with negotiable day rates (and a student discount of 20 percent), or gingerly borrow a magazine for three working days for \u00a350.\n\n\u201cI always knew it was a cultural resource and that there was value in it,\u201d Mr. Hyman said of the archive. But having the collection verified by Guinness was about validation, he said, \u201cbecause then people might take it more seriously than just thinking: \u2018Some lunatic\u2019s got a warehouse full of magazines.\u2019\u201d\n\nMs. Turk has a knack for repackaging Mr. Hyman\u2019s animated monologues into what in the trade are called sound bites. \u201cI maintain that James always had the foresight that this was going to be something else, more than just a sort of collector\u2019s dream,\u201d she said. \u201cThe archive is all about preserving and documenting the history of print.\u201d\n\nMr. Hyman has kept magazines in various storage spaces since the late \u201980s, and had many, many magazines at home, in his spare room. But in 2010 his wife was expecting a baby. \u201cI wasn\u2019t given any ultimatums,\u201d he said, \u201cbut it was like, \u2018You\u2019re going to have to sort this out.\u2019\u201d (At that time, Ms. Turk also helped Mr. Hyman pare down his collection of about 40,000 compact discs, like a scene out of the Nick Hornby novel \u201cHigh Fidelity.\u201d)\n\nFrom 2012 the magazines sat nearly untouched in storage, including at an idle meat factory in Islington, during which time Mr. Hyman said he acquired another 30,000 to 40,000 magazines. Some 90,000 were shelved in alphabetical order at Cannon House in 2015, but the collection is too big to shift when, say, they get a set of 60 rare Playboys or a camper van full of issues of Athletics Weekly from the 1970s, as they recently did. Instead, another area of the archive is dedicated to magazines that have been acquired since the move.", "title": "All Good Magazines Go to Heaven", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "SATURDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Wordplay is fortunate to have a very large and close community, with new people joining us every day. The more, the merrier, I say, because it\u2019s more fun to solve together. We\u2019re all learning, and one thing I absolutely love to see here is Wordplayers helping others through their solve. EACH ONE TEACH ONE, as yesterday\u2019s puzzle said.\n\nAnother thing some of our newer Wordplayers have said is that the empty white space in a late week puzzle grid is somewhat intimidating to them, and that\u2019s perfectly natural. A blank piece of paper or an empty page on a computer is intimidating to writers, so why shouldn\u2019t an empty grid without the security of shorter words be intimidating to solvers?\n\nHere\u2019s the thing. We feel intimidated because the emptiness makes the task ahead feel huge and insurmountable. But if we break this huge task into manageable chunks, it\u2019s not so scary, is it? If we slow our roll and decide to just focus on our gimmes for now, we can fill those in without being overwhelmed. If we\u2019re facing a stack of grid spanners, we don\u2019t have to look at those; we can focus on filling in as many of the crossings as possible, until we can take an educated guess at those long entries.\n\nAnd when you just can\u2019t get something, don\u2019t beat yourself up. Come to Wordplay, because you will not be alone. We are an alliance here, a UNITED FRONT against the puzzle, in a way. Solving together means more success. And that\u2019s not scary at all, is it?", "title": "Alliance of Groups", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "One thing is clear: The United States, which has relied heavily on Kurdish fighters to push the Islamic State out of northeastern Syria, has consistently understated the complexities of its alliance with the Kurds, a policy some analysts call willful ignorance.\n\n\u201cObviously the U.S. chose to look the other way, out of what it deemed to be the necessity of building an alliance to quickly capture territory from Daesh,\u201d said Noah Bonsey, a Syria analyst with the International Crisis Group, using the Arabic acronym of the Islamic State.\n\n\u201cThe U.S. has sound reasons to continue to support the Y.P.G.,\u201d he said, \u201cbut doing so while the P.K.K. maintains an active insurgency against its NATO ally is an unsustainable situation.\u201d\n\nThe United States military\u2019s official partner in Syria is a militia known as the Syrian Democratic Forces, which includes Arab and Assyrian fighters but is dominated by the Y.P.G. The Americans de-emphasize such details.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the cooperation with the Y.P.G., including arming and training the fighters and providing them with air support, has put the United States on a collision course with Turkey.\n\nLast weekend Turkey launched a military operation against the Kurdish enclave of Afrin in northwestern Syria and it is now threatening to expand the operation to the east, into areas where Kurdish forces are directly backed by the American military.\n\nThe United States has sought to differentiate between the Kurds it supports and those in Afrin, whom it does not, a distinction the Kurds themselves do not recognize.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey are not different parts at all, and they cannot be divided in any way, not politically, not economically, not militarily,\u201d said Newaf Xelil, a Kurdish political analyst in Germany and a former spokesman for the party affiliated with the Y.P.G. \u201cFor us, it is all Kurdistan and we are now defending Afrin with all we have.\u201d\n\nOn Wednesday, President Trump urged his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, to use restraint and avoid any situation that could lead to clashes between the Turkish and American militaries. Disputing the White House\u2019s description of the call, Turkish officials denied that Mr. Trump had made such a request.\n\nY.P.G. leaders say theirs is a homegrown movement that sprang up to defend civilians in the early days of Syria\u2019s war and against offensives by the Islamic State.\n\nThat role, and the backing of the United States, has transformed the group into the most prominent political and military force in northeastern Syria.\n\nFormerly an impoverished and marginalized minority, Syria\u2019s Kurds now administer substantial territory, where they are teaching Kurdish in schools and setting up local administrations. Critics have accused them of displacing Arabs.\n\nAmerican officials have long sought to minimize the Y.P.G.\u2019s ties to the P.K.K., but Turkey is enraged that the United States is giving military support to a group that idealizes Mr. Ocalan, the sole inmate of an island prison in the Sea of Marmara.\n\nMany Y.P.G. leaders speak openly of their history with the P.K.K., and Kurds from Iraq, Iran and Turkey have joined the movement in Syria.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Bonsey said there had been hope among the Americans that they could pull the Y.P.G. away from the P.K.K.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut such a prospect appears unlikely \u2014 especially with the Kurds now uncertain that they have solid support from the United States, which has sent mixed messages about how strongly it would back them against a Turkish onslaught.\n\nThe American ambivalence was clear on Wednesday in comments by Thomas P. Bossert, Mr. Trump\u2019s homeland security and counterterrorism adviser, at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not in any way critical of the Turkish decision, but I\u2019m just praying for their longer-term strategic patience,\u201d Mr. Bossert told reporters.\n\nAsked if the Turks should withdraw, Mr. Bossert said, \u201cI would prefer it if for now they would remove themselves from the capital of Afrin.\u201d\n\nThe United States effectively gave a green light to the current Turkish offensive against Afrin, urging restraint but emphasizing that it does not work with the Y.P.G. there.\n\nThe enclave is in northwest Syria, not connected to a larger territory held by the Syrian Democratic Forces in the country\u2019s northeast, where several small American military bases and several thousand American advisers are.\n\nBut Mr. Erdogan has threatened to attack that larger area, beginning with the town of Manbij. The Turks say the Americans promised that the Syrian Democratic Forces would withdraw from such majority-Arab areas after taking them from the Islamic State, but it has not.\n\nThe ingredients for this clash have been brewing since Syrians rose up against the authoritarian rule of President Bashar al-Assad in 2011. Within a few years, the northeastern province of Hasaka, with a large Kurdish population as well as Arabs and Assyrians, was effectively ruling itself.\n\nAs it became the area\u2019s dominant force, the Y.P.G. tried to implement its vision of a utopian society, inspired by Mr. Ocalan. Influenced by Murray Bookchin, an American anarchist, Mr. Ocalan has called for autonomous rule by local committees unbound by national borders. Proponents say they do not seek to break up Syria but are leading a long-term social revolution that will ensure gender and minority rights.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen the Islamic State began sweeping across northeastern Syria, its first defeat was in the Kurdish border town of Kobani. The Y.P.G., with help from American airstrikes, repulsed Islamic State fighters at great cost.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter that, facing Turkish criticism, the United States began calling its partner the Syrian Democratic Forces. There was a scramble to enlist Arabs and members of other ethnic groups.\n\nThe Y.P.G. remains the predominant part of the Syrian Democratic Forces and provides its most effective fighters. But the Kurds do have local allies.\n\nThey have built local councils with representatives from various ethnic groups, each required to have a chairman and a chairwoman. While they are still largely overseen by the Y.P.G., locals have begun to engage with them in significant ways.\n\nHassan Hassan, a Syrian analyst and author, said that the Americans repeatedly had broken promises to Turkey about the alliance: They said the Syrian Democratic Forces would not cross the Euphrates River. It did. They said it would withdraw. It stayed.\n\nThe Americans also said that the Y.P.G. would refrain from promoting P.K.K. ideology outside Kurdish areas. But Y.P.G. fighters hoisted a huge poster of Mr. Ocalan in the center of the city of Raqqa after wresting it from the Islamic State last year, a huge embarrassment to the United States.\n\nMr. Hassan said the local councils are vetted by the Y.P.G. and cannot be seen as fully democratic. But he said that in some areas, Arab residents nonetheless had welcomed the Syrian Democratic Forces, particularly in the eastern province of Deir al-Zour, the area of Mr. Hassan\u2019s family roots.\n\nAmerican officials have told the Kurds that the United States will not fight Turkey for them. With a diminished need to fight the Islamic State in Syria, Mr. Hassan said, American support for the Kurds could dwindle.\n\nBut Mr. Xelil, the Kurdish analyst, said the Americans would need the Kurds for their other objectives in Syria, like pushing back on Iranian influence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe think that it is surely possible that the Americans will find real reasons to deepen their relationship with the Kurds in a strategic sense,\u201d he said.", "title": "Allies or Terrorists: Who Are the Kurdish Fighters in Syria?", "authors": ["Anne Barnard", "Ben Hubbard"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Allison Shearmur, a studio executive and independent producer who helped bring a string of box-office hits to the screen, including the \u201cBourne\u201d franchise, the \u201cHunger Games\u201d series and the yet-to-be-released \u201cSolo: A Star Wars Story,\u201d died on Jan. 19 in Los Angeles. She was 54.\n\nThe cause was lung cancer, said her husband, Edward Shearmur.\n\nMs. Shearmur, who died at U.C.L.A. Medical Center, had received the diagnosis in 2016 but disclosed it only to her family and closest associates as she continued working on movie projects, including \u201cRogue One\u201d (2016), an earlier installment in the Star Wars Anthology series (set before the events of the original \u201cStar Wars\u201d blockbusters), as well as \u201cSolo.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe didn\u2019t want to be defined by her disease,\u201d Mr. Shearmur said. \u201cShe felt that if people knew of this very difficult detail, it would overshadow everything else.\u201d\n\nFor 20 years Ms. Shearmur maintained a high profile in Hollywood. She helped to oversee feature film production at Universal Pictures before moving on to Paramount Pictures, where she was co-president of production, and Lionsgate, as president of motion picture production, and then setting out as an independent producer. Among the other prominent films she helped shepherd along were the Julia Roberts hit \u201cErin Brockovich\u201d (2000); \u201cThe Curious Case of Benjamin Button\u201d (2008), with Brad Pitt; and the raucous \u201cAmerican Pie\u201d sex comedies.", "title": "Allison Shearmur, 54, \u2018Star Wars\u2019 and \u2018Hunger Games\u2019 Producer, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Although some new buildings along the waterway went up as far back as 2000, and several condo towers were built near its mouth more than a decade ago, most construction ground to a halt during the recession. With few impediments now, a burst of fresh projects are either being planned, under construction or completed, their crowns blending into the skyline of downtown and the Brickell neighborhood.\n\nJust beyond the south side of the river, the $1 billion Brickell City Center \u2014 a massive complex that includes a shopping center, offices, luxury condos and a hotel \u2014 opened in November 2016 and inspired a slew of projects in its vicinity.\n\nAcross the river, the New York developer Shahab Karmely spotted a large empty lot, once a shipyard, while he was prospecting in the area in 2013. The result will be One River Point, a two-tower, 60-story condominium designed by the Uruguayan architect Rafael Vi\u00f1oly that will be topped off by a pair of 14,000-square-foot \u201csky villas\u201d costing about $30 million each. Spanning the gap between the towers, 800 feet in the air, a three-level private club will be encased almost entirely in glass. Construction is scheduled to start in early 2019.\n\nMr. Karmely, the principal at KAR Properties, said he had seen similar growth along rivers in London, Frankfurt and other cities, and regretted not diving in. \u201cI didn\u2019t take advantage of it,\u201d he said while cruising the Miami River in a motorboat. \u201cBut I said to my partner: \u2018This is undiscovered country. You can\u2019t go wrong with a river. It\u2019s dilapidated, but filled with potential.\u2019\u201d\n\nPaul S. George, a history professor at Miami Dade College and the author of \u201cAlong the Miami River,\u201d which begins its narrative with Spanish troops being entertained by Tequesta Indians on the river\u2019s banks in 1568, said the development in recent years was nothing short of astonishing.\n\n\u201cThis was a dormant area, completely, for over 50 years,\u201d Professor George said. \u201cThere was nothing going on here for decades, but people have just taken to this river. It\u2019s been a long time coming.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAmong the newcomers is the New York fashion designer Naeem Khan, who has dressed the Duchess of Cambridge, Michelle Obama, Beyonc\u00e9 and Taylor Swift and who plans to move his headquarters to a site just east of the 12th Avenue Bridge. He also intends to build a factory and a 26,000-square-foot school for aspiring fashion designers there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew developments and businesses along the waterway northwest of downtown are interspersed with boat sheds, fishing piers and modest dwellings. Tugboats tow freighters, ferries and yachts to repair yards like the century-old RMK Merrill-Stevens, which is undergoing a $30 million renovation. At some docks, the decks of cargo ships bound for Haiti and the Dominican Republic are stacked with mattresses, kitchen appliances and secondhand vehicles.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the charm of the river \u2014 it\u2019s unique,\u201d said Roman Jones, who made his name as a nightclub impresario in Miami Beach and opened Kiki on the River, an upscale restaurant with a Greek flavor, in April.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn a recent afternoon outside the restaurant, on North River Drive, a pair of Lamborghinis and a Ferrari awaited their owners, a sight that would have been unthinkable in the area just a few years ago. Inside, customers dined on, among other delicacies, a dish called Seafood Towers, which combined Alaskan king crab, Maine lobster, jumbo shrimp, oysters and New Zealand green-lipped mussels and was priced at $229 a plate.\n\nAt both Kiki and a similarly chic restaurant next door, Seaspice, yacht owners docked their vessels alongside the outdoor dining areas and stepped ashore for drinks and meals under the shade of large, cream-colored parasols.\n\nOn the other side of Kiki, the owner of a ramshackle boat repair dock, marine-supplies store and snack bar said he was the last of a dying breed. \u201cI\u2019m the only bait-and-tackle store left on the Miami River,\u201d Pedro G\u00e1ndara said in Spanish, noting that he had spent 10 years operating where the Kiki restaurant is now, before he was pushed out two years ago into the much smaller space next door.\n\n\u201cThere were a lot of places here that serviced boats, and more than half no longer exist,\u201d said Mr. G\u00e1ndara, a 60-year-old boat mechanic who came to Miami from Cuba in 1987. \u201cSoon, this one will no longer exist. This is the last place on the river for humble people like me.\u201d", "title": "Along Miami River, Derelict Bait Shops Give Way to Luxury Condos", "authors": ["Nick Madigan", "Square Feet"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Winter snow is typically welcomed in the Alps, an area well-equipped to cope with the several inches of the white stuff.\n\nBut recent thaws followed by heavy rainfall have upended travel and led to evacuations in much of the region, as thick packs of snow dislodge and trigger avalanches.\n\nIt has been a winter of extreme weather on Europe\u2019s highest peaks, with avalanches, flooding and biting cold threatening homes and causing trouble on roads and railways.", "title": "Alps Avalanches Prompt Evacuations and Upend Travel", "authors": ["Palko Karasz"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "According to the C.D.C.\u2019s FluView index, which is updated each Friday, this season\u2019s infection rate is closely echoing that of the 2014-15 season, which was also a predominantly H3N2 year and also rated \u201cmoderately severe.\u201d\n\nHowever, the hospitalization rate is already only half that of 2014-15, Dr. Jernigan said, so he expects fewer deaths.\n\nFlu has been ticking up again in the wake of several mild seasons that followed the 2009-10 \u201cswine flu\u201d pandemic. In that year, an H1N1 virus with a mix of human, bird and pig genes that had never been seen before struck in the spring of 2009, disappeared over summer and returned in the fall. Although millions caught it, it turned out to be relatively mild, and few died.\n\nThe H3N2 component of Australia\u2019s flu shot was reported to be only 10 percent effective at preventing infection and is the same as in North American shots. But both Dr. Jernigan and Dr. Fauci said they expected to see roughly 30 percent effectiveness when data is collected at season\u2019s end, in part because more healthy people get their shots.\n\nThe vaccine mismatch was not caused by a genetic shift in the circulating flu, as happens in some years, but by changes in the \u201cseed virus\u201d used in the vaccine;
