View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Clinton Foundation dismissed the investigation as politicized.\n\n\u201cTime after time, the Clinton Foundation has been subjected to politically motivated allegations, and time after time, these allegations have been proven false,\u201d Craig Minassian, a spokesman for the foundation, said in a statement.\n\nNick Merrill, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton, added: \u201cLet\u2019s call this what it is: a sham. This is a philanthropy that does life-changing work, which Republicans have tried to turn into a political football. It\u2019s disgraceful, and should be concerning to all Americans.\u201d\n\nThe foundation, which was formed in 1997 during Bill Clinton\u2019s presidency and has raised roughly $2 billion, has been a repeated target for Republicans. In 2015, the conservative author Peter Schweizer published \u201cClinton Cash: The Untold Story of How and Why Foreign Governments and Businesses Helped Make Bill and Hillary Rich,\u201d an investigation of donations to the foundation made by foreign entities.\n\nMr. Schweizer is the president of the Government Accountability Institute, where Stephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trump\u2019s former chief strategist, was a founder and the executive chairman.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Justice Department, in a letter sent in November to the House Judiciary Committee, said prosecutors would examine allegations that donations to the Clinton Foundation were tied to a 2010 decision by the Obama administration to allow a Russian nuclear agency to buy Uranium One, a company that owned access to uranium in the United States, as well as other issues.\n\nThe letter appeared to be a direct response to Mr. Trump\u2019s statement days earlier that he was disappointed with Mr. Sessions for not investigating Mrs. Clinton. An administration official said the F.B.I. had taken investigative steps related to the foundation inquiry before the Justice Department sent the letter to the judiciary committee.\n\nIn the letter, the Justice Department wrote that the attorney general had directed \u201csenior federal prosecutors to evaluate certain issues.\u201d Those prosecutors would make \u201crecommendations as to whether any matters not currently under investigation should be opened, whether any matters currently under investigation require further resources, or whether any matters merit the appointment of a special counsel.\u201d\n\nSeveral F.B.I. offices, including those in New York and Little Rock, Ark., had been investigating the foundation. At the direction of Mark F. Giuliano, then the deputy director of the F.B.I., the investigations were consolidated at F.B.I. headquarters in Washington and placed under the supervision of career public integrity prosecutors.\n\nThe decision by senior F.B.I. officials and prosecutors not to move forward with the case angered some agents while others believed there was little evidence to support more aggressive steps during a presidential campaign.", "title": "Amid Calls from Trump, F.B.I. Renews Questions Over Clinton Foundation", "authors": ["Adam Goldman", "Matt Apuzzo"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights and the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights in Honduras have called on security forces to stop what they called the \u201cillegal and excessive use of force\u201d to break up protests. This past week, both organizations reported that human rights activists, journalists and others continue to face threats and harassment.\n\nIn addition to the disputed results, the opposition also argues that Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez never should have been on the ballot in the first place.\n\nWhat put him there was a ruling by the Supreme Court, which lifted the Constitution\u2019s ironclad ban on presidential re-elections in a circuitous ruling two years ago. The five judges who made the decision all owed their positions to Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez.\n\nThe president has steadily taken control over much of the government, filling independent institutions, including the Supreme Court, with his allies. Critics said a law passed by Congress this month showed that the postelection turmoil has not dissuaded him from continuing to amass power.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe law targets the attorney general\u2019s office, which has been pursuing high-level corruption cases, working with an international panel that Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez was forced to accept after months of antigraft protests in 2015. On Jan. 18, Congress all but shut down those cases, effectively pulling the attorney general\u2019s authority to investigate the theft of public funds destined for social projects.\n\nJuan Jim\u00e9nez Mayor, a former prime minister of Peru, who leads the anticorruption panel, denounced the law and said it would block investigations into as many as 60 current and former Honduran legislators, as well as high-ranking officials in the government. Among them, Mr. Jim\u00e9nez said, is the powerful president of Congress, Mauricio Oliva, a close ally of Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cPolitically, they picked the worst moment to approve this law,\u201d said Ra\u00fal Pineda Alvarado, a political analyst, calling it \u201can illegal monstrosity.\u201d \u201cFor all the effort the government may make, citizens understand that this law is made to favor the corrupt.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAlready a judge has dismissed cases against five former legislators who were charged with embezzling government funds, citing the new law. Mr. Jim\u00e9nez said the law could lead to the release of Mario Zelaya, the former head of Honduras\u2019s main public health agency, who is accused of stealing as much as $300 million. Some of that money found its way to Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez\u2019s 2013 presidential campaign, though he has denied that he knew the source of the funds.\n\nHeide Fulton, the charg\u00e9 d\u2019affaires at the United States Embassy, called the law a \u201cmonumental step backward in the fight against corruption.\u201d\n\nMr. Hern\u00e1ndez has not commented on the law, but few in Honduras believe that he played no role in its approval. \u201cThis is a decision taken at the highest political levels of the country and it is irreversible,\u201d said Edmundo Orellana, a former attorney general and professor of constitutional law at the National Autonomous University of Honduras.", "title": "Amid Protests, Honduran President Is Sworn In for 2nd Term", "authors": ["Jeff Ernst", "Elisabeth Malkin"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Corrupt government agents and the black market happily provided transport documents to draw a veil of fictitious legality over whatever came floating down the river from the Amazon forest. Or as one exporter shipping timber on the Yacu Kallpa put it to an undercover investigator from the nonprofit Global Witness, \u201cThis tree miraculously becomes legal timber, just because of a piece of paper.\u201d Exporters could point to that piece of paper and claim to be merely \u201cbuyers in good faith.\u201d\n\nThat make-believe mind-set sufficed until Peru\u2019s customs service and its forest watchdog agency, together with investigators from the nonprofit Environmental Investigation Agency, tried to connect export shipments back to their reported harvest sites and found that almost none of the timber came from anyplace legal.\n\nActing on that information, United States federal agents met the Yacu Kallpa at the dock in Houston in September 2015 and seized 71 shipping containers of timber worth more than $1 million. Investigators would later determine that 92 percent of the timber on that shipment was illegal. The Yacu Kallpa then simply turned around and tried to do it again.\n\n\u201cPeople are doing these things because they know they can,\u201d said Laura Furones, leader of the Peru campaign at Global Witness. \u201cThe level of impunity is astonishing.\u201d\n\nIndeed, on that next and final Yacu Kallpa shipment, 96 percent of the timber was illegal, according to investigators in Peru, putting the Iquitos-to-Houston connection out of business. That was also the basis for the trade representative\u2019s barring of the Peruvian exporter La Oroza. Federal prosecutors in this country and Peru are now conducting criminal investigations against more than 100 people in the Yacu Kallpa case, including American importers that also relied on the \u201cbuyer in good faith\u201d fiction.", "title": "Opinion | Amid the Plunder of Forests, a Ray of Hope", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nUpdated on Feb. 26, 2018.\n\nHas the flu season peaked?\n\nYes, it appears to have. About 6.4 percent of Americans visiting doctors in the week ending February 17 had flu symptoms, down from a peak of 7.7 percent two weeks before.\n\nFlu activity was rated \u201chigh\u201d in 39 states, as well as in New York City, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Five states reported \u201cmoderate\u201d activity. Six states are experiencing only \u201clow\u201d or \u201cminimal\u201d activity: Florida, Idaho, Washington, Maine, Montana and North Dakota.\n\nHow bad is this season?\n\nIt has been as bad as any since the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention adopted stringent surveillance methods in the early 2000s. The peak infection rate equaled that of the 2009 \u201cswine flu\u201d pandemic. (The rate is a measure of what percentage of all patients visiting doctors in a particular week had flulike symptoms, including a fever of at least 100 degrees.)\n\nHow This Flu Season Compares With Recent Ones This chart shows percentage of outpatient visits for flu-like symptoms in this and previous flu seasons. % 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0 10 20 30 40 50 2017\u20132018 flu season 2013\u20132017\n\nflu seasons\n\nWeeks from the early October start of flu season % 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0 5 10 15 20 25 30 35 40 45 50 2017\u20132018\n\nflu season\n\n2013\u20132017\n\nflu seasons\n\n\n\nWeeks from the early October start of flu season % 7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0 5 10 15 20 25 30 35 40 45 50\n\nWeeks from the early October start of flu season\n\n2013\u20132017\n\nflu seasons\n\n2017\u20132018\n\nflu season\n\n\n\nEven more worrying, the hospitalization rate for flu at one point was the highest the C.D.C. has ever recorded. It substantially surpassed that of the lethal 2014-2015 season, during which 710,000 Americans were hospitalized and 56,000 died.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Anne Schuchat, acting director of the C.D.C., said on Feb. 9 that the season was \u201con track to break some recent records.\u201d (History\u2019s worst influenza pandemics \u2014 in 1918, 1957 and 1968 \u2014 all occurred before the C.D.C.\u2019s new surveillance standards were rolled out in the early 2000s and modified in 2010.)", "title": "The Flu Outbreak Has Peaked but Still Has Weeks to Go", "authors": ["Donald G. Mcneil Jr."]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Now, the future seems less promising. The giants of multilevel marketing have come under a dual assault, from regulators here and in the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\nTwo companies, Herbalife and Usana Health Sciences, disclosed last year that they faced investigations in the United States for their operations in China under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which prohibits American companies from bribing foreign officials. Another, Nu Skin, settled a similar case with the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2016, while Avon Products pleaded guilty in 2014, resulting in a $135 million fine.\n\nAmway, which is not public, has not disclosed any inquiries by American regulators. In one Chinese province, however, the conduct of some Amway sales distributors prompted an investigation, one that the victims say was squelched by local officials, including at least one with ties to the company.\n\n\u201cThis industry is absolute chaos for China,\u201d said You Yunfan, a former Amway distributor who wrote a scathing memoir under the pen name Xiao Fei.\n\nNoting that Chinese law prohibits many of the worst practices associated with multilevel marketing, he added, \u201cThe root problem is that the government is riddled with corruption and not doing its job.\u201d\n\nThat may be changing. Four government agencies last year announced a crackdown on the marketing model, which critics denounce as a pyramid scheme.\n\nTurbulence in the Chinese market could be devastating for Amway, which has relied on China for much of its growth over the last decade.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt is now, by far, the largest of the multilevel marketing companies here, with 1.5 million distributors, more than all the others combined, according to the Ministry of Commerce\u2019s records. China is now Amway\u2019s largest market, accounting for $2.6 billion in revenue, or about 30 percent of its worldwide sales, the company\u2019s president, Doug DeVos, told Reuters last year.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn a statement, an Amway vice president, Scott Balfour, said the company welcomed the crackdown, saying it would distinguish pyramid schemes from legitimate direct selling.\n\nAmway has not been singled out in the campaign, and it has built an impressive brand here, operating gleaming showrooms in Beijing and elsewhere and sponsoring the Chinese Olympic team. Yet it has been dogged by accusations like those it has faced elsewhere.\n\nFormer Amway distributors have organized online to warn others of the company\u2019s model. Amway\u2019s name in Chinese, an li, has entered the vernacular to mean to \u201cpromote heavily\u201d or to \u201cbe brainwashed.\u201d\n\nAmway and others faced skepticism from the authorities nearly from the moment they entered the market in the early 1990s. Multilevel marketing was officially denounced as an \u201ceconomic cult,\u201d and in 1998 the government banned all direct selling.\n\nOnly when negotiating entry into the World Trade Organization did China agree to American demands to allow the companies in. Direct selling has been legal since 2005, though with restrictions intended to discourage the endless recruiting of new distributors, a component of Amway\u2019s model.\n\nEnforcement of the laws, however, remains uneven. \u201cIt\u2019s a gray area,\u201d said Liu Kaixiang, a professor at Peking University\u2019s School of Law who conducts research at the university\u2019s industry-affiliated direct-selling research center. \u201cThe majority of these direct-selling companies are right on the edge. If they were to completely follow the law, there would be no market at all.\u201d\n\nThe vagaries of Chinese regulations and an avaricious bureaucracy have already ensnared others, like Avon, once the top direct seller here. In 2014, it admitted to providing $8 million in cash and gifts like Gucci purses to Chinese officials.\n\nPhoto\n\nSimilar troubles caught up with Nu Skin, which settled a case by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2016 by admitting that it paid the equivalent of $154,000 to \u201ca charity to obtain the influence of a high-ranking Chinese Communist Party official\u201d to resolve a potential fine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHerbalife disclosed in a stock filing that it, too, was under investigation, while Usana Health Sciences announced that it had alerted the Department of Justice about questions over \u201cexpense reimbursement policies\u201d of its subsidiary in China.\n\nAmway said in its statement that it had not faced questions from American regulators about its practices in China. Its business has nonetheless raised questions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn Amway\u2019s Beijing center, a reporter with The New York Times listened as Big Brother Feng detailed sales tactics that would violate Chinese law if used, promising that new recruits could earn more as they recruited others.\n\nA few days later, one of the recruits was out on the streets repeating the pitch as he handed out fliers for the XS energy drink. The fliers said new distributors could ultimately earn the equivalent of $75,000 a year.\n\nIn fact, 96 percent of direct sellers make less than $750 a year, roughly the average monthly wage for private-sector workers, according to government statistics.\n\nIn some regions, Amway in particular has come under focus.\n\nIn Lanzhou, a city of nearly 3.7 million along the Yellow River and the ancient Silk Road in Gansu Province, dozens of former distributors have accused the company of abetting extortionate practices that left them in debt. They accused those above them of conning them into buying products they could not realistically sell.\n\nOne of them, Liu Gang, said he had been persuaded to give up a job as a teacher in 2009 to pursue an Amway fortune.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn training sessions, some of which he recorded and played for The Times, he was told that the way to achieve success was by working under pressure. He took out loans \u2014 first mortgaging his home, then borrowing from unofficial lenders working, he and others said, with the local Amway staff \u2014 to load up on vitamins, water filters and soaps. By 2014, he could not unload his merchandise and faced $600,000 in debt.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was brainwashed,\u201d Mr. Liu said.\n\nThe provincial office of the State Administration for Industry and Commerce, which regulates businesses, took the accusations seriously. In May 2016, the office sent a letter to complainants saying that there was evidence of wrongdoing and that the region\u2019s top two distributors, a husband-and-wife team, Tang Jinsong and Zhao Yufang, \u201care suspected of operating a pyramid scheme.\u201d\n\n\u201cTo climb to the top, you need a team of distributors under you,\u201d said Liu Jianhong, another former distributor, who provided the letter to The Times. \u201cIt forms a pyramid. We were at the very bottom.\u201d\n\nMr. Balfour, the Amway vice president, said that the Lanzhou situation had \u201cinvolved a number of serious violations of our rules of conduct, as well as violations of Chinese lending laws\u201d by sales distributors, but that the company itself had not been accused of wrongdoing.\n\nIn a second statement, Amway said that it did not endorse exaggerated claims of distributors and that company policy prohibited obtaining loans to buy products. Mr. Balfour said the company would investigate specific claims brought to its attention.\n\nThe regulatory office in Lanzhou gave enough credence to the complaints that it referred the findings to the local branch of China\u2019s main law enforcement agency, the Public Security Bureau.\n\nThen the investigation stalled.\n\nWang Xingwei, the administration official in charge of the initial investigation, said in a telephone interview that he had been transferred off the case.\n\nThe former distributors said they believed that regional officials sympathetic to Amway had quashed their complaints. They cited an instance when the state television channel in Gansu, after interviewing them, received a directive not to report on their case.\n\nAccording to a journalist at the station, Gao Zenglei, the directive came from the Communist Party\u2019s provincial propaganda department. At the time, it was headed by Liang Yanshun, who once participated in an Amway program that enrolled officials in classes at Tsinghua University and Harvard University, according to Harvard and his online biography. Mr. Liang did not respond to requests for comment.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Zhao, one of the top distributors, dismissed the accusations and said she and her husband, Mr. Tang, had done everything \u201centirely in accordance with the company\u2019s system, according to the company\u2019s operating model and under the oversight of the company.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe aggrieved distributors, she added, were responsible for any debts they built up.\n\n\u201cEveryone should be responsible for their own actions,\u201d she said. \u201cIf they don\u2019t know this, they won\u2019t last in this world.\u201d\n\nMr. Balfour said Amway had punished individuals involved, though he did not disclose names or sanctions. Amway\u2019s website still counts Mr. Tang and Ms. Zhao as among its top handful of sales distributors, and their photo is on display at Amway\u2019s big Beijing conference hall.\n\nThe former distributors, by contrast, face financial ruin.\n\nLiu Jianhong amassed $300,000 in debt. In China, that means she has been put on a government list that prohibits her from flying, taking trains or acquiring new credit cards.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m going to be dealing with this the rest of my life,\u201d she said.", "title": "Amway Made China a Billion-Dollar Market. Now It Faces a Crackdown.", "authors": ["Ryan Mcmorrow", "Steven Lee Myers"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Later, he guided brands and colleagues through the heydays of MSN and Yahoo and the rise of platforms like YouTube, Facebook, Snapchat and streaming TV. Along the way, Mr. Norman became known for sharing his insights at industry events and in trade publications, always with a healthy dose of dry British wit.\n\nMr. Norman recently spoke with The New York Times about where the media and advertising worlds are now and where he thinks they are going. The interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.\n\nThere is a huge focus on how dominant Google and Facebook are in digital advertising, where they are often referred to as the \u201cduopoly.\u201d Some people have a hard time seeing that change.\n\nThe people who are most stuck in the world are those who see hegemonic positions now and don\u2019t believe that now can be disrupted \u2014 despite the fact that what exists now only exists because everything\u2019s been disrupted.\n\nAt the beginning of my career, the hegemonic position was held by ITV and the big commercial broadcasters. Then it was held by this display triumvirate of Yahoo, MSN and AOL and, separately, search by Google. And it took quite a long time to get here.\n\nIf you asked anyone in 2009, \u2018Guess what the combined market shares of Google and Facebook will be in 2017,\u2019 I\u2019m not sure there would have been anyone that would have come close.\n\nHow long do you think will they maintain that position?\n\nIt kind of depends on what Google and Facebook allocate their resources to, and like everybody else, it depends on how they manage to navigate actual and potential regulatory environments going forward. I think if they were both worried about a thing today, it would be what regulators think about them, because they\u2019re not at the peak of their popularity with those folks at the moment, it would seem to me.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI think that\u2019s why people are so interested in the Amazon story and were so interested in the Snap story and were so interested in Twitter\u2019s story \u2014 because everyone\u2019s looking for the next one to break through.\n\nWhat\u2019s the next thing that\u2019s going to look and feel completely different that disrupts how people interface with the world around them? My guess is that five to seven years from now, there will be at least one company that people will think of in the top five most important enterprises in advertising that simply doesn\u2019t exist now.\n\nPhoto\n\nLast month, the Walt Disney Company said that it had reached a deal to buy most of 21st Century Fox, which would fit into its plans to introduce two Netflix-style streaming services and give the company a majority stake in Hulu. (Comcast and Time Warner have the minority stakes.) What do you think?\n\nImagine a massively emboldened Hulu.\n\nIf Disney decides to put the Fox assets in entertainment and movies into Hulu, and Comcast decides to put Universal and NBC studio assets into Hulu, too, then certainly from a domestic point of view, you end up with a product that looks pretty fantastic if people watch television.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYou could have things like day-after episodes of new drama of the Hulu model and then the entire movie libraries of Universal, Fox, Disney, Pixar and all of the other stuff with it.\n\nThen what happens if that same group of people says to the broadcasters of the world: \u201cWhat we have here is a working business model of what the studio system plus the broadcast system can look like in a new world, with a tiered-option model based on some combination of live, day-after, on-demand, paid, ad-funded and so forth, and basically you could slice it whichever way you\u2019d like for your market. We\u2019ve got the content block and the technology license block so that everyone can build their own castle in all these markets.\u201d\n\nDisney has BamTech, remember. [Disney has a majority stake in BamTech, the company that built HBO Go in time for the fifth season of \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d and will build Disney\u2019s new streaming services.]\n\nIt may not be owned 100 percent by one company, but it could be a new phenomenon that could be a kind of distributed monopoly, which I don\u2019t think anyone\u2019s really thought about.\n\nAnd this could potentially run ads?\n\nBecause you\u2019re using the same underlying systems, you suddenly have a data pool that crosses all of that content, all of those users and potentially all of those markets. People are asking the question about what\u2019s the third force? That would probably be the answer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s another way that could go?\n\nI think if I learned one thing over my career, it is that Newton was right: The objects that are in motion stay in motion, and that motion tends to accelerate, hit plateaus and reaccelerate.\n\nGiven the asymmetry of certain enterprises in the world, you kind of wonder as to whether or not new Disney, with all of its IP, has in fact become the juiciest peach in the world to be consumed by Apple.\n\nIf Apple was going to make a \u201cone bound and you\u2019re serious\u201d move into the video content business globally, and the provision of video service business globally, it could make sense. You then have most of Hulu and all of the IP in Pixar, Marvel and all of the other things that Bob Iger has been assembling over the years, and you have ESPN. That wouldn\u2019t be a terrible place to start, and they could do it for 30 percent of their market cap.\n\nWhat do you make of Facebook\u2019s plans to prioritize \u201cmeaningful interactions\u201d between friends and family while showing less news to its users?\n\nYou can on one hand take it at face value and say that Facebook is taking a step back to their roots. The other way you could argue this is that Facebook has decided that there is a degree of toxicity which comes from being overtly an economic participant in a news-based value chain, and that the economics of it are not worth the perceived risks of association.\n\nThe one thing that\u2019s kind of disturbing about all of this to me and potentially The New York Times is: Are we moving into a world where the dominant platforms of media consumption are basically getting close to a point where they\u2019re blacklisting the monetization of news?\n\nWhat have you seen that makes you think they\u2019re getting close to that?\n\nIt seems that there is no huge demand in Google\u2019s program commissioning to commission news. I don\u2019t see there\u2019s a big appetite for Facebook saying, \u201cWe would like 20 news organizations to provide news bulletin programming for Facebook Watch.\u201d\n\nWe know there are dozens and dozens of news organizations around the world, or at least a dozen or two that include The Times, Reuters, Bloomberg, the BBC and so on, who are, for the most part, the keepers of truth in news and the people who keep the public informed.\n\nAnd it seems odd to me that if you have aspirations to take up a very significant part of the media consumption time of the public that you do not have an overt policy for the dissemination of news and to participate in the funding of news for your audience.", "title": "An Ad Executive Often in the Vanguard Peers Into the Future", "authors": ["Sapna Maheshwari"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "In the bathroom at Public School X811 that day, officers continued looking for clues surrounding his death, but instead found articles of a full and vibrant life. There were the keys to Mr. Azimi\u2019s car parked outside, the one he drove to work each morning, leaving the Putnam County town of Carmel by 6 a.m. for a commute that could take more than an hour. His house in Carmel was warm and worn, with a heap of toys visible through the windows on the porch. There were two children, 8 and 4, a girl and a boy.\n\nOn his left hand was a wedding band. His bride, Rachel Azimi, had pushed it up over his knuckle on their wedding day almost 10 years ago. In recent weeks, she had been ill, pregnant with their third child.\n\nMr. Azimi had texted her just that morning: \u201cThese next few months will probably be difficult because I know you\u2019re sick. Everything is going to work out and we\u2019re going to have a good future.\u201d By nightfall that day, she would be frantic, calling her husband 37 times with no response. A strange car would pull up to the house as midnight approached. Police detectives.\n\n\u201cIt can\u2019t be him!\u201d she shouted.\n\nSome addicts die in plain view, their years of drug use ravaging their bodies and upending their lives, like a long siege. Mr. Azimi\u2019s addiction was more like a sleeper cell. It took seed as a teenager, and those around him sought to stomp it dead, but it loomed, largely dormant. It hid behind the broad smile he flashed for photographs, the ones of the family man with the house and the yard.\n\n\u201cI believed he was sober for the vast majority of our marriage,\u201d Ms. Azimi said. \u201cI never saw drug paraphernalia. I don\u2019t even know what heroin looks like.\u201d\n\nHe shared his past addiction sparingly to new friends, telling them only some of his troubles as a teenager in Bedford, N.Y., when he began drinking and using drugs.\n\nHis parents had taken a decisive measure to end the habit, sending him to a small alternative high school two hours away in Hancock, N.Y., called the Family Foundation School. The school sought to curb bad behavior by limiting student contact with the outside world and exacting what alumni described as a system of punishments that could be severe. Mr. Azimi was there from 1997, when he was 16, to 2000. The school closed in 2014.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA classmate there, Christopher Lont, 35, befriended Mr. Azimi, and the two stayed in touch. Mr. Lont said his friend came to define himself as the substance user he had been when he was a young teenager, an identity that never wavered: \u201c\u2018I have this problem,\u2019\u201d Mr. Lont recalled him saying. \u201c\u2018This is my problem. I\u2019ll never get over this problem.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Azimi would prove himself right. While in his 20s, he returned to his native Brewster and began hanging around with fellow former classmates. Someone introduced heroin into the mix, said Grace Cole, 35, a friend from the Hancock school.\n\nMr. Azimi was living with his father and mother. \u201cShe\u2019d call me when Matt would vanish,\u201d Ms. Cole said of his mother. \u201cShe would be flipping out on the phone: \u2018He showed up last night in his bare feet and can\u2019t find his car. He thinks it\u2019s in the Bronx, but he can\u2019t remember driving there.\u2019\u201d\n\nThen he seemed to straighten up again. He wanted to teach. He told friends he had a plan. \u201cBeing happy meant being married, having kids, the white picket fence,\u201d Mr. Lont said.\n\nMs. Cole remembered the urgency in this goal. \u201c\u2018I want to get married,\u2019\u201d she remembered Mr. Azimi telling her. \u201c\u2018It has to happen as soon as possible, and I want kids. I want it now.\u2019\u201d", "title": "An Addict Dies in a School Restroom. He Was a Teacher.", "authors": ["Michael Wilson"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Students at the University of Wisconsin-Madison had gathered last spring to consider a resolution calling on the university to divest in companies and countries that abuse human rights, profit from the \u201cmilitary-industrial complex\u201d and promote fossil fuels when the debate jumped the rails.\n\nSoon, the students were in a full-scale battle over whether the resolution should cover Israel, with charges of anti-Semitism and racism rattling the room. A student representative who was Jewish said that the last-minute inclusion of Israel \u201ccrossed the line from legitimate conversation to a point where I consider it malicious.\u201d The student government chairwoman, who is black, suggested the opposition to the resolution amounted to \u201cwhite supremacy,\u201d which she condemned with a four-letter expletive.\n\nIn the aftermath, Kenneth L. Marcus, the founder and president of the Louis D. Brandeis Center for Human Rights Under Law, decided to enter the fray, writing to university administrators to denounce calls for divestment from Israel as anti-Semitic, and to assail the meeting as hostile toward Jewish students. He urged that the black student leader be disciplined.\n\nOn Thursday, Mr. Marcus received the approval of the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee to be President Trump\u2019s assistant secretary for civil rights in the Education Department, a prestigious post known more for policing racial bias and sexual violence in schools than refereeing the battles over Israel and Palestinian rights on the nation\u2019s university campuses.", "title": "An Advocate for Israel Draws Fire as He Nears Confirmation to Civil Rights Post", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The day after the establishment embraces the Taliban, it says to America: \u201cYou can use our bases to bomb the Taliban, but hush, please, because we have told our people that the Taliban are our true friends. And please don\u2019t hold it against us if we tell some Taliban, the good ones, to take cover as your planes take off.\u201d\n\nAnd then some Taliban who attack the state say they\u2019ll stand behind the army if Pakistan comes under attack by America or India. This ideological confusion was at its peak after American soldiers killed Osama bin Laden in 2011: We still haven\u2019t decided if it was Bin Laden who violated our sovereignty by hiding in Pakistan, or the Americans by killing him there. People wonder if the Pakistani army was complicit or just incompetent. Why can\u2019t it be both?\n\nBut Pakistanis who have asked questions like that have been hounded. The military has whipped the nation into jumping through so many hoops of fire that we have almost internalized the logic of a war without end.\n\nThe Pakistani Army believes America can\u2019t win the war in Afghanistan without its assistance. The security establishment is committed to the age-old fantasy of controlling Afghanistan through proxies, even though it is clueless about what to do with its proxies, past and present.\n\nLike Pakistan, America is addicted to this conflict. Here\u2019s a permanent Vietnam, another war essential to America\u2019s existence as a world power. Whenever Pakistan and the United States have squabbled over the years, it has been about the amount of dollars paid versus the number of bad guys killed. In this accounting from hell, what are a few mass murders between friends?\n\nAlthough some American pundits say that Trump is bonkers when it comes to his domestic policies, they expect the rest of the world to believe that he is O.K.-ish when it comes to Afghanistan and Pakistan. Just another American president, like a half-dozen before him, who is going to fix this part of the world.\n\nSome experts\u2019 solution to the current tensions is that Trump, that stable genius, should ask his new Saudi friends to use their influence over Pakistan to play broker. A one-bedroom, he knew, would be helpful when he had overnight guests from out of town, but it would also mean a downgrade. And he didn\u2019t have all that many guests.\n\n\u201cFor my day to day, a studio is not bad,\u201d he said.\n\nSo he returned to the Murray Hill Marquis, now satisfied that he was making the right choice. He moved into the studio apartment in August, paying $3,005 a month, with one month free.\n\nThe building was formerly the Affinia Dumont, \u201ca boutique hotel with unusually large hotel rooms for New York,\u201d said Richard Wernick, managing director of residential leasing for the LeFrak Organization, which bought the property last spring and began the conversion to rentals.\n\nMr. Opong-Owusu\u2019s apartment faces busy 34th Street, but \u201cI don\u2019t mind the rambunctiousness of this area,\u201d he said. \u201cI like it more than being in a quiet area.\u201d\n\nHe is impressed that the building is cleaned throughout, and often. Moreover, hundreds of thousands of Syrians have died or have been displaced, including 200,000 who arrived over the years in the town of Afrin, where they found safety. Now thousands more lives are in danger because of a tyrannical and unprovoked attack by Mr. Erdogan on this peaceful region.\n\nIf the United States is to truly stand for democracy as it claims, it must be decisive in protecting Afrin as well as the other two Kurdish regions in Syria. To abandon the Kurdish people now is to once and for all forsake any historical claims America has as a defender of democracy.", "title": "Opinion | An Appeal to the U.S.: Don\u2019t Abandon the Kurds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "There are good reasons to be wary of impeachment talk. Congressional Republicans show zero interest, and they\u2019re the ones in charge. Democrats, for their part, need to focus on retaking Congress, and railing about impeachment probably won\u2019t help them win votes.\n\nBut let\u2019s set aside realpolitik for a few minutes and ask a different question: Is serious consideration of impeachment fair? I think the answer is yes. The evidence is now quite strong that Donald Trump committed obstruction of justice. Many legal scholars believe a sitting president cannot be charged with a crime. So the proper remedy for a president credibly accused of obstructing justice is impeachment.\n\nThe first article of impeachment against Richard Nixon argued that he had \u201cprevented, obstructed and impeded the administration of justice.\u201d One of the two impeachment articles that the House passed against Bill Clinton used that identical phrase. In both cases, the article then laid out the evidence with a numbered list. Nixon\u2019s version had nine items. Clinton\u2019s had seven. Each list was meant to show that the president had intentionally tried to subvert a federal investigation.\n\nGiven last week\u2019s news \u2014 that Trump has already tried to fire Robert Mueller, the special counsel investigating the Trump campaign \u2014 it\u2019s time to put together the same sort of list for Trump. Like my apartment. From the books, to the sketch board, to the bed, to the refrigerator \u2014 everything is authentic, in 1962, what an artist would have, and what a movie buff would have. But it\u2019s in this otherworldly room that is a piece of art. I felt like Spencer Tracy could walk around the corner at any moment. I was as close as I could to being in a \u201940s Hollywood classic.\n\nHow would you describe Giles?\n\nHe\u2019s very lost. He probably lies. But he\u2019s got a great heart. He exaggerates, but he\u2019s an artist. He\u2019s insecure. He always says, \u201cI think this is some of my best work, don\u2019t you?\u201d He\u2019s looking for that compliment. He needs someone to tell him that he\u2019s O.K., that he\u2019s, you know, worthy.\n\nThere\u2019s that thread in your characters that thinks that, too.\n\nA thread in me thinks that, too.\n\nI think we all have it, but maybe you\u2019re more able to \u2014\u2014\n\nI was an only child, and I understand loneliness. You\u2019re a glorified backup,\u2019\u201d he recalled. \u201cWhatever romance was left in commercial aviation, the jet engine killed.\u201d\n\nHe was not interested in stunt flying or becoming a military pilot, so he abandoned aviation and found a job managing a branch of a courier company in Silicon Valley. Jobs at a consulting firm that handled transportation planning issues and at another trucking firm followed.\n\nThen it was on to law school at Boston University and a summer job as a volunteer law clerk, drafting opinions for administrative law judges from the National Transportation Safety Board. \u201cNone of the judges were pilots,\u201d he said. \u201cI understood the facts better than they did, no offense. They said they wanted to hire me on a paid basis during law school.\u201d So they did, and also after he finished law school.\n\nThe slowest part of a conversation with Mr. Avedisian is the tell-us-all-about-it part, because he will not discuss details of his idea for the subway while the contest is still going on.\n\nThe transit agency said he was a finalist in a category called \u201cRapidly Deploy Modernized Subway Cars to the Subway System.\u201d (The other categories involve modernizing the antiquated signal system and improving the communications infrastructure.)\n\nThe transit authority said Mr. Avedisian had proposed \u201cadding up to four cars to trains currently in operation to increase both train capacity and passenger comfort.\u201d The agency said Mr. Avedisian\u2019s longer trains would stop at every station, but not every car would open. \u201cSome cars at the front and back of a train will not platform at every station,\u201d the authority said, \u201cbut generally will platform at alternating stations.\u201d\n\nIn plainer terms, using an existing 10-car train as an example, the first four cars would open at one station, leaving the last four beyond the platform with the doors closed. At the next station, the train would in effect overshoot the platform, allowing the last four cars to reach the platform and open while the first four stayed shut. Six cars in the middle would open on the platform at every stop.", "title": "An Einstein for the Subways? And it wasn\u2019t.\n\nIn his last years, Mr. Leedom broke his hip, but also danced at a holiday party in the building. He was matter of fact about some of his infirmities, like needing help cleaning himself, but frustrated by declines in his hearing and vision. He rejected hearing aids because they squealed with feedback, then complained that he could not follow movies or plays, or make new friends.\n\n\u201cIf you asked him, he had no infirmity,\u201d said Craig Weltha, 49, who visited regularly and helped manage Mr. Leedom\u2019s care. \u201cThe problem was always outside of him. He didn\u2019t have a hearing problem \u2014 the problem was that people were speaking gibberish.\u201d\n\nOne aide called him \u201cMy Kenneth, my lovely,\u201d and he liked that.\n\nHe was firmly decisive. You can\u2019t blink. The cold stabs your face and numbs your earlobes to rubber.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an icy hell,\u201d said Amy Loughlin, 50, who was visiting from Austin, Tex., and scaling the mountain, the highest in the Northeast, in the back of a SnowCoach \u2014 a van retrofitted with tanklike treads to handle the blowing snow and treacherous roads.\n\nWith much of the Northeast and Midwest feeling like a block of ice, the temperature here in the high peaks of New Hampshire\u2019s White Mountains was forecast to drop to 40 degrees below zero overnight Friday. The wind chill could make the air feel as cold as 100 below zero. That is not a typo. Negative. 100.\n\n\u201cWe should end up being the coldest location tonight in the lower 48,\u201d said Mike Carmon, senior meteorologist at the Mount Washington Observatory, who was one of a handful of scientists and others huddled at the top of one of the most dangerous and forbidding places in the country. \u201cWe basically just start saying it\u2019s stupid cold outside.\u201d", "title": "An Eyelash-Freezing \u2018Icy Hell\u2019: The One Spot That Could Feel Like Minus 100", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMost people say toffee, but I grew up knowing it as buttercrunch. That\u2019s what Loft, a New York brand started by William Loft in 1860, called it. Loft\u2019s went out of business in the 1990s, but up in Manchester, Vt., Mother Myrick\u2019s Confectionery makes similar buttercrunch. Ron Mancini, an owner of the company, grew up in Queens eating Loft\u2019s candies. He uses Cabot Creamery butter and coats his buttercrunch with milk or dark chocolate and chopped nuts: $18.95 for 7 ounces to $68.95 for two pounds, Mother Myrick\u2019s Confectionery, 888-669-7425, mothermyricks.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "An Opera About Mexico, With a Side of Guacamole", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Part of that history was made by Hodge\u2019s ancestors. He is a seventh-generation Texan from a state in which phrases like \u201cseventh-generation Texan\u201d are humble-brag gold. His great-grandfather had the distinction of surviving the Galveston hurricane of 1900, the worst natural disaster (perhaps as many as 8,000 dead) in the history of the United States. A great-granduncle operated a ranch at the base of the Window, a gap in the mountain ramparts of the Big Bend country that is a beloved hunk of geology to scenery-starved Texans.\n\nHodge begins his book with an atmospheric prelude (\u201cThe boy wears a cowboy hat and boots, his jeans tucked in. He carries a gun, and a knife, and sometimes a sword\u201d) that to my ear echoes the opening of Cormac McCarthy\u2019s \u201cBlood Meridian\u201d (\u201cSee the child. He is pale and thin, he wears a thin and ragged linen shirt. He stokes the scullery fire\u201d). Lest you suspect me of overexplication, Hodge himself takes time out, a little past the midway point of his book, for a 14-page appreciation of McCarthy\u2019s fiction, particularly his Texas-set novel \u201cNo Country for Old Men.\u201d Caution: Writing about Cormac McCarthy while simultaneously writing about the immemorial violence of the Texas borderlands can lead to sentences like this:\n\n\u201cAnd everywhere are the ruins of those ancient and not so ancient peoples who were slaughtered in those places and whose lives left no articulate testament to bear witness to the joys and hopes and dreams and sorrows that they shared before pale riders the color of dust swooped down and spilled their blood onto the thirsty ground.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nIf Hodge is susceptible every now and then to the hypnotic Bible rhythms of McCarthy\u2019s language, for the most part he writes with an earnest, stripped-down clarity. He\u2019s smart, observant and skeptical. He has no interest in adding another volume to the library shelves of rousing Texas hoohah. \u201cAs I reread the conventional histories,\u201d he writes, \u201cI remained dissatisfied by their generalizations and hoary meditations on Texas \u2018character.\u2019 Much of it struck me as self-congratulatory nationalistic rubbish. I read those fat tomes mostly for the footnotes, the infinite forking paths of primary sources and archives.\u201d Even \u201cLone Star,\u201d T. R. Fehrenbach\u2019s venerable history of the state (so massive and self-confident its first words are \u201cIn the beginning\u201d), makes Hodge a little queasy, because \u201csuch epic histories sweep high above the hard ground of lived experience.\u201d\n\nHard ground and lived experience are what \u201cTexas Blood\u201d is all about. Hodge reminisces about his own background as a young ranch hand \u2014 loading livestock into trailers, rounding up sheep on muleback, crossing the Rio Grande to Ciudad Acu\u00f1a every weekend for flaming tequila shots at famous watering holes like Ma Crosby\u2019s. He traces the history of the region through the Jumano and Apache Indians who had at one time or another considered themselves in possession of it. He writes about Spanish explorers like Cabeza de Vaca and notorious scalp hunters like the Irish-born James Kirker, or the former Texas Ranger John Joel Glanton, who went on to assume toxic literary immortality as a character in \u201cBlood Meridian.\u201d\n\nIn other chapters Hodge follows the trail of his long-ago Texas-bound ancestors through Missouri and Kansas, hangs out with the Border Patrol in the Rio Grande Valley, explores the ancient rock art along the Pecos, and takes part in a pilgrimage to the top of Mount Cristo Rey across the New Mexico border from El Paso, where Indian dancers known as matachines perform a centuries-old dance depicting Hern\u00e1n Cort\u00e9s\u2019s conquest of Mexico, \u201cthe ancient drama of conquest, love, betrayal and conversion.\u201d", "title": "An Unconventional History of Texas, From a Writer With the State in His Veins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Pompeo has shown a similar eagerness to express his views in public forums, making clear his skepticism of the Obama administration\u2019s deal to limit Iran\u2019s nuclear weapons program, playing down talk of Russian interference in the election last year, and talking at length about the need to stop North Korea\u2019s nuclear program, even if that means using military force.\n\nThose issues all came up in Mr. Pompeo\u2019s appearances this week. But his focus was on talking about how he has reshaped the C.I.A. In an appearance on Tuesday at the American Enterprise Institute, a think tank in Washington, Mr. Pompeo boasted that he had pared back bureaucracy at the agency, reducing the decisions that had to be personally approved by the director \u201cby 40 percent.\u201d\n\nThe United States\u2019 list of rivals and enemies is long \u2014 it includes global powers as well as international criminal networks \u2014 and \u201cwe need to have a bias toward being as nimble as our adversaries,\u201d Mr. Pompeo said.\n\nHe made his point with an anecdote: \u201cI was sitting in a very long meeting with some very senior officials and I was asked, \u2018Boy, if we did X, what would our adversaries do?\u2019\u201d Mr. Pompeo recounted. \u201cAnd I responded by saying, \u2018They sure as heck won\u2019t have a meeting like this.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe audience laughed. \u201cThat\u2019s exactly what happened in the meeting, too,\u201d he said.\n\nThe changes he has made at the C.I.A. have resulted in substantive achievements, though few could be discussed publicly, Mr. Pompeo said. He did offer one example, saying that the C.I.A.\u2019s work had helped stop the flow of supplies vital to North Korea. But he provided no other details.\n\nMr. Pompeo has given only a handful of speeches and interviews since taking over the C.I.A. Most of his appearances have been at forums familiar to neoconservatives, where he tends to find receptive audiences and his assertions about the inner workings of the Trump administration are rarely challenged.\n\nThe audience\u2019s questions on Tuesday focused largely on North Korea, Iran and the other issues that tend to occupy the Washington national security establishment, including the fight against the Islamic State. Mr. Pompeo\u2019s assertions about the president\u2019s handling of the daily intelligence briefings went unchallenged, even though they run counter to accounts from other administration insiders. There was no talk about whether the president\u2019s Twitter messages, such as calling North Korea\u2019s ruler, Kim Jong-un, \u201cLittle Rocket Man,\u201d affected the C.I.A.", "title": "An Unexpectedly Smooth First Year for Trump\u2019s C.I.A. Director", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "PASADENA, Calif. \u2014 It was a critical moment for the Georgia Bulldogs. Playing Oklahoma in the College Football Playoff semifinals at the Rose Bowl, they had erased what seemed a devastating halftime deficit only to fall behind again, 45-38, late in the fourth quarter. But they had marched down the field and, with 55 seconds left, running back Nick Chubb had scored on a 2-yard dash.\n\nAt that moment, they had a decision: Should they go for a 2-point conversion and try to win the game right there?\n\nIt would not have been a crazy trigger for Georgia Coach Kirby Smart to pull. The rushing game is his offense\u2019s hallmark and was their most effective weapon Monday night, with their three running backs averaging 11.4 yards per carry. The bet would have been that a short running play would have given the Bulldogs a better chance than kicking the extra point and then trying to beat Oklahoma \u2014 statistically college football\u2019s best offense, helmed by the Heisman Trophy winner Baker Mayfield \u2014 in overtime.\n\nInstead, Smart elected to take the extra point. Georgia held Oklahoma on the final drive in regulation. After the teams traded field goals in the first overtime, Georgia blocked Oklahoma\u2019s field-goal attempt in the second and then scored a touchdown to win, 54-48, and head to the national championship game next Monday, where the Bulldogs will face Alabama.", "title": "An Unrelenting Georgia Wears Down Oklahoma in a Clash of Styles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "But Namdar\u2019s deeper subject isn\u2019t contemporary patriarchy and its discontents. Some critics have mistaken the book as continuing the tradition of Saul Bellow, Philip Roth and Bernard Malamud \u2014 whose names Namdar strategically drops, as red herrings \u2014 with Andrew just another Kepesh, Silk, Levin or Herzog. Namdar actually has less in common with those novelists, whose imaginations were largely secular, than with Cynthia Ozick, who has grappled with religious prohibition, or with the young Leonard Cohen, who harangued an audience in Montreal in 1964, telling them: \u201cThere is an awful truth which no Jewish writer investigates today.... It is this truth: We no longer believe we are holy.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAs if in response to that howl, in \u201cThe Ruined House\u201d ancient Jewish holiness bleeds, insistently, horrifically, into the present. The connection is hinted at from the start, in the Hebrew dates given in the chapter headings, which count \u201cfrom the creation of the world\u201d: The novel begins on Elul 6, 5760 (\u201cwhich happened to fall on Wednesday, Sept. 6, 2000\u201d), and ends on \u201cThe 1st of Tishrei, 5762\u201d or \u201cSept. 18, 2001.\u201d This indicates that Andrew\u2019s story is being narrated, unusually, as part of the trajectory of the long Jewish past.\n\nUneasy links between that past and the present animate the visions that begin, over the course of the novel, to flood Andrew\u2019s senses and invade his dreams, frightening and finally paralyzing him. He\u2019s overtaken by the sights and smells of fires, bulls, golden candelabra and massacres; he watches as \u201cred, boiling blood runs in the streets,\u201d hears \u201cwails of terror and sorrow\u201d and has no idea why.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn explanation, eventually available to the reader but not to Andrew, appears in a pseudo-Talmudic narrative set during the Roman rule of Palestine and involving the High Priest and one of his many assistant priests. This ancient back story appears on pages styled to evoke the commentary-laced text of the Talmud.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn that fine print, it turns out that Andrew\u2019s breakdown \u2014 his visions, the attendant writer\u2019s block and uncontrollable urges, as well as a protracted, bizarre battle he wages with a \u201ccut of Black Angus beef tenderloin, dry aged for 21 days and weighing seven and a half pounds, at $39.99 a pound\u201d \u2014 reflects the strictures that governed the ancient High Priest\u2019s conduct leading up to the moment, during Yom Kippur, when he would speak the name of God and attain atonement for all the world\u2019s Jews.\n\nSuch a conceit \u2014 a projection of a perspective from ancient Judea onto the lifestyle of a contemporary secular New York Jew \u2014 might strike some readers as tendentious or random, but it\u2019s not.\n\nFirst, it should be noted, it\u2019s only natural that Namdar, as a Hebrew speaker and teacher of classical Jewish literature, should perceive strange crossings of the ancient and the modern that English-speaking Americans would miss. Many such echoes, present in Namdar\u2019s Hebrew original, could not be conveyed even in Hillel Halkin\u2019s extraordinary translation, but some do manage to peek through. For example, apropos of not much, on a jaunt out of the city, Andrew happens to notice \u201cthe opaque, misplaced names on the road signs \u2014 Goshen, Rehoboth, Bethel,\u201d which are noteworthy only if you\u2019ve been thinking about the old Canaan, the one that\u2019s not in Connecticut.\n\nAndrew\u2019s surname, Cohen, functions in the same way, as a portal between past and present. It means \u201cpriest,\u201d and the people who bear it \u2014 every songwriter, model, television host, comedian, Trump lawyer, baseball announcer, novelist and figure skater \u2014 all trace their roots, knowingly or not, to the functionaries who performed ritual sacrifices (slaughtering animals, burning incense) in the Temple in Jerusalem, before A.D. 70. Don\u2019t be embarrassed if you didn\u2019t know this: Since the days of vaudeville, in America \u201cCohen\u201d has meant nothing at best, and at worst it\u2019s been the punchline of a cruel joke. Namdar\u2019s protagonist, sophisticated and brilliant as he may be, hasn\u2019t the slightest inkling of his inheritance.\n\nAs the novel carefully reminds us, though, the sacrifices performed by priests in the Temple have always been the not-so-thoroughly repressed core of religious Judaism. It\u2019s not just the Orthodox, but also Conservative Jews, all across America, who still pray constantly for the Temple to be rebuilt. Before the advent of political Zionism in the 19th century, that dream of rebuilding was the reason Jews even cared about Zion: They believed the only thing that could purify them or secure their atonement was ritual sacrifice, possible nowhere but on that highly contentious scrap of land, the Temple Mount.\n\nSo it\u2019s no caprice on Namdar\u2019s part to take seriously the legacy of the destroyed temple, the \u201cruined house\u201d whose fall sent the Israelites into exile and elevated the rabbis over the priests as Jewish authorities. On the contrary, his is an attempt to recover the mythic foundations of the present.\n\nNamdar has no thesis, and the novel does not suggest that the return of the repressed would be easy or even productive. At times dripping in gore and effluvia, steeped in sacred texts and apocalyptic visions, \u201cThe Ruined House\u201d cannot be recommended lightly. But it is a masterpiece of modern religious literature, exactly as deep, disturbing and unresolved as is necessary to remind us, habituated as we are to the shallows of contemporary Jewish life, what still lurks beneath \u2014 primitive, raw and exacting.", "title": "An Unusual Jewish Novel, Full of Blood and Incense", "authors": ["Josh Lambert"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The photographer Jamel Shabazz is known for his photographs of diverse communities that serve as social commentary to broaden perspectives. In a Lens piece, \u201cJamel Shabazz\u2019s 40 Years of Sights and Styles in New York,\u201d Maurice Berger writes:\n\nMr. Shabazz uses his camera predominantly to challenge stereotypes and negative perceptions about urban life \u2014 and especially about New York\u2019s black and brown residents \u2014 by focusing on the vitality, diversity and dignity of his subjects.\n\nPeople are the main focus of Shabazz\u2019s work, and the concept and emotional intention of his photographs are supported by the use of value and contrast to create emphasis. Subjects stand out when contrasting with their environment, drawing the eye to the person captured in the image.\n\nIn \u201cStyle,\u201d Lower East Side, Manhattan, 2002,\u201d the black-and-white image that begins the slide show above, there are many tonal values (shades from the gray scale). Which parts of the image are low contrast, and which are high contrast? What stands out? What\u2019s the first thing you see? What\u2019s the next thing you notice? Is your eye drawn to the high contrast or low contrast areas first?\n\nIn highlighting his community, Jamel Shabazz plays with value and contrast to make them stand out, emphasizing fashion and community aesthetics as a way to honor and document his New York neighbors. His memorable photographs communicate successfully in part because of his skilled approach to using value to create emphasis and meaning.\n\nClick through the entire slide show and repeat the same exercise for each image. Which photos have high contrast colors? Which have low contrast colors, or a mix of both? Which areas are emphasized with high contrast shades? What do you think Mr. Shabazz wanted to reveal about his subjects?\n\n_________\n\n2. Value Creates Illusion\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen colors have similar value and low contrast, they create the illusion of vibration or movement, as in the paintings of Agnes Martin, whose color choice often stays within the realm of a certain value to create subtle variation with a puzzling effect for the eye. In \u201cThe Joy of Reading Between Agnes Martin\u2019s Lines,\u201d Holland Cotter writes about the visual exercise of differentiating color and value in her work:\n\nView her paintings from several feet away, and their surfaces \u2014 whitish, pinkish, grayish, brownish \u2014 look hazily blank, as if they needed a dusting or a buffing. Move closer, and complicated, eye-tricking, self-erasing textures come in and out of focus.\n\nHow does Martin use value to trick the eye and create subtle texture variation? Which of her paintings have a high contrast between colors, and which have colors of similar value? Look through the images shown in \u201cThe Joy of Reading Between Agnes Martin\u2019s Lines\u201d and analyze her use of color value.\n\nThen, compare and contrast Agnes Martin\u2019s use of contrasting color values with the work of the painter Julian Stanczak, known for his Op Art style that also boldly plays with the eye. Op Art is a type of visual art that creates optical illusions. In his Times review of the exhibition \u201cJulian Stanczak Master of Op Art: Highlights of the Past 40 years,\u201d Kenneth Johnson writes:\n\nMr. Stanczak has been steadfastly devoted to using pattern and color to create striking and confounding illusions of movement and luminosity. In his neatly made abstractions nothing stays fixed: lines appear to vibrate, waver, rotate and undulate; color glows and throbs as if electrically generated; hovering, gridded squares seem to fade in and out of visibility. The effects are retinal but they feel almost hallucinatory.\n\nIn the Times writer Roberta Smith\u2019s recent obituary about the abstract painter Julian Stanczak, Ms. Smith detailed how the artist achieved these optical illusions and became a leader in the Op Art style.\n\nHe produced some of the most emotionally gripping paintings associated with the Op trend. This was achieved partly by his delicately textured paint surfaces and partly by the soft light that often infiltrated his forms and patterns, the result of an infinitesimal adjustment of the shades of one or two colors.\n\nBrowse through the Times slide show embedded above on \u201cThe Art of Julian Stanczak\u201d and answer the following questions:\n\n\u2022 Can you identify the techniques used to create optical illusions of depth, dimension and light?\n\n\u2022Which paintings have the most subtle adjustments between shades?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022Which have a higher contrast?\n\n\u2022Which kinds of value variants create the strongest texture?\n\n\u2022How do you describe the effect each image has on your eye?\n\n_________\n\n3. A Times Scavenger Hunt\n\nPhoto\n\nNow that you\u2019ve explored how value is used to emphasize subjects in art and creates the illusion of dark and light, and gained an understanding of the value of colors and how they affect each other, browse through features in The New York Times\u2019s Art & Design section; Lens, the Times site for photojournalism; or anywhere else on NYTimes.com, and challenge yourself to a scavenger hunt.\n\nSee if you can find photographs or images of artwork with the following characteristics:\n\n\u2022A high contrast photograph.\n\n\u2022A low contrast photograph.\n\n\u2022An image of a painting with colors of highly contrasting values.\n\n\u2022An image of a painting with colors of similar value.\n\n\u2022A photograph in which the level of value contrast affects the mood of the image.\n\n\u2022A photograph in which the value contrast creates texture.\n\n\u2022A photograph in which the value contrast emphasizes the focus of the image.\n\n4. Your Turn: Photo Portraits and Op Art\n\nHere are two ideas for experimenting with value in your own creative work.\n\na. Portraits With Varied Values\n\n\n\nSlide Show\n\nIn 2014, The Times invited students to submit creative selfies that express who they are, and received hundreds, from college students to first graders. Marci Beene, who teaches digital photography at J.T. Hutchinson Middle School in Lubbock, Tex., turned the solicitation into an assignment for her seventh and eighth graders: \u201cDo a selfie that goes beyond your face,\u201d she instructed, \u201cand that represents something.\u201d Click through the photos above to see the results.\n\nTake a portrait of a friend, or a self-portrait using the timer on your camera. Use an editing app on your phone like Instagram or Snapchat to create different versions of the portrait with filters. Create one black-and-white version with high contrast and one with low contrast. Do the same with a full-color version.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhich filters create the strongest value contrast and which flatten the photo with low contrasting light and color? Arrange the four versions of your portrait into one image and compare the mood of each. How does value bring about the feeling portrayed?\n\nb. Op Art Collage\n\nPhoto\n\nTo create an Op Art collage, choose two colors of construction paper with similar values, like red and orange, or light yellow and light pink. Cut one color into thin strips or small shapes, and glue onto the other sheet with a glue stick. Consider the abstract compositions of Julian Stanczak for inspiration. Next, choose two colors that have a strong contrast, like blue and orange. Create another cut-paper collage using the same technique.\n\nSol LeWitt is another artist who experimented with color values to whom you can look for inspiration. View the Times slide show \u201cSol LeWitt at Mass MoCA,\u201d as well as the image above.\n\nHang your two paper collages side-by-side and critique the visual effect of each. Do they vibrate or create dimension? Which has a stronger effect? Which is your eye drawn to more?\n\nConsidering value in your own artwork will help you emphasize the focal points, create depth and texture and help determine the experience you want your viewer to have. Do you want to create a calming or jarring feeling? Value can help evoke an emotional response from your audience.\n\n_________\n\nWant to read the whole series? Here are our lessons on shape, form, line, color, texture and space. How do you teach these elements?", "title": "Analyzing the Elements of Art: Four Ways to Think About Value", "authors": ["Kristin Farr"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nToday, Aldabra Atoll, an island in the Indian Ocean near Madagascar and Tanzania, is a predator-free paradise for more than 100,000 giant tortoises. Gone are the seafarers who over-hunted them to near extinction in the 18th and 19th centuries. Gone too are the large crocodiles that may have preyed upon them in prehistoric times, as a new study suggests.\n\nDennis Hansen, an ecologist from the University of Zurich, was exploring the coral atoll and its azure lagoon, part of the Seychelles, when he came across fossils that intrigued him. They included parts of a giant tortoise shell with circular bite marks and the jaw of an ancient crocodylian. From the finds, he and a colleague concluded that some 90,000 to 125,000 years ago, the ancient crocodiles may have feasted upon the giant tortoises of Aldabra.\n\nThe finding, which was published Tuesday in the journal Royal Society Open Science, may offer new insights into the ancient past of the world\u2019s most numerous giant tortoise and the threats it once faced from predators.\n\nMore Reporting on Paleontology\n\nMeasuring more than 3 feet long and 550 pounds on average, the Aldabra giant tortoise is behind only the Galapagos tortoise in size. It has a thick, domed shell which protects its soft body. It also has a long neck and stout legs covered in scales.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Hansen found about 180 fossils near a pond on the atoll. One was a jawbone of an ancient crocodile that he first thought was a tortoise longbone. But when he turned it over he saw it had holes where teeth could fit. He sent some of the fossils to his colleague Torsten Scheyer, a paleontologist also at the University of Zurich, for further examination.", "title": "Ancient Crocodiles Once Feasted on Giant Tortoises on This Island", "authors": ["Nicholas St. Fleur"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn January 2011, the musician Dane Terry packed up his earthly possessions and drove from his native Ohio to New York, reaching his destination in a blizzard. \u201cI parked my car with all my things in a snowbank,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen it melted out, I sold it.\u201d\n\nSelling your car is a true sign you are here to stay, and Mr. Terry has since embedded himself in a downtown scene that joyfully straddles the worlds of theater, pop music, performance art and cabaret. The 34-year-old (\u201cI don\u2019t lie on my Grindr profile,\u201d he quipped) has appeared at genre-hopping venues like La MaMa and Joe\u2019s Pub, and his new musical show, \u201cJupiter\u2019s Lifeless Moons,\u201d running Jan. 12 to 17 as part of the 13th Annual Coil Festival, is helping reopen Performance Space 122.\n\nGrowing up in Columbus, Mr. Terry wanted to be a magician. \u201cI was interested in the idea of performing tricks, but what I actually wanted was real magic,\u201d he said at a cafe in Park Slope, Brooklyn, a few subway stops from his home in Kensington. \u201cWhen I found music, I realized that was the closest thing you could get.\u201d\n\nAt age 12, he taught himself to play the piano, practicing for hours on end, and at 17, he started making money noodling away in lounges and at weddings. In his twenties, he toured the country with his friend Jordan O\u2019Jordan, playing punk basements and D.I.Y. venues, and he has recorded a handful of albums and EPs.\n\nYet when this admirer of Jerry Lee Lewis-style boogie-woogie and musical narrative \u00e0 la Laurie Anderson moved to New York, he joined the theater community. \u201cThe music people in New York, I think, still don\u2019t know who I am, largely,\u201d Mr. Terry said, not sounding regretful in the least.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cJupiter\u2019s Lifeless Moons,\u201d which also features three guest musicians, is Mr. Terry\u2019s most narratively structured outing yet, with a plot inspired by his stay in Cleveland last winter. (The show will be expanded into a multi-episode podcast for Night Vale Presents.) The ride-hailing service had been doing the deliveries for Ando, so it\u2019s a natural fit.\n\nIn a statement, Jason Droege, the vice president of Uber Everything, the umbrella under which Uber Eats operates, said, \u201cWe are committed to investing in technology that helps consumers and restaurant partners alike.\u201d\n\nThis is not Mr. Chang\u2019s first attempt to create a food delivery service that goes beyond simply picking up pizzas and burgers from a nearby restaurant. The service was eventually sold to the London-based company Deliveroo.", "title": "Ando, David Chang\u2019s Meal-Delivery Business, Ends Service", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis medium, which we, for official purposes like passports and school IDs, trust to be an accurate picture of the world, has always been something that can be lent to fiction as well as to fact,\u201d he explained. \u201cAndreas is not a journalist doing reportage.\u201d\n\nOther specialists expressed a preference for Mr. Gursky\u2019s earlier work.\n\nQuentin Bajac, the chief curator of photography at the Museum of Modern Art in New York \u2014 where Mr. Gursky\u2019s retrospective in 2001 gave the photographer a major career boost \u2014 said his signature pieces of the \u201990s came \u201cat a perfect moment,\u201d just as globalization was gathering pace. Mr. Gursky represented the spread of multinationals and the explosion of financial markets, as they were striking \u201cthe right balance between something that is neither critical nor apologetic,\u201d Mr. Bajac said. That \u201cabsence of narrative\u201d mirrored the contemporary mood.\n\nMr. Gursky\u2019s work also embodied the shift from analog to digital, from \u201ctaking images\u201d to \u201cmaking images,\u201d said Mr. Bajac \u2014 initially doing both but now doing more of the latter.\n\nMr. Gursky was born in Leipzig (then in East Germany) and left when he was 1 year old. His father set up a successful commercial photography studio in D\u00fcsseldorf, in the West, so the little boy grew up surrounded by a lab and camera equipment. Though initially determined not to follow in his father\u2019s footsteps, he ended up getting a photography degree from the Folkwang University of the Arts, in nearby Essen, because \u201cto be honest, I didn\u2019t know what I could do.\u201d\n\nIn 1980, he enrolled at the D\u00fcsseldorf Art Academy to study with the pioneering teacher Bernd Becher, whose other disciples \u2014 Thomas Struth, Thomas Ruff, Candida H\u00f6fer \u2014 also went on to become prominent photographers. While there, Mr. Gursky started taking color panoramas of mountains, camping sites and swimming pools featuring tiny human beings.\n\nA switch to digital photography in the early \u201990s allowed Mr. Gursky to take large-format photographs and to manipulate the images in digital postproduction \u2014 by \u201cpumping up the color sometimes or combining several different images in order to get this really even perspective, where you can see everything and details that aren\u2019t available from just one perspective are suddenly made available to you,\u201d Mr. Rugoff explained.", "title": "Andreas Gursky Is Taking Photos of Things That Do Not Exist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "1.
