At the 2015 Academy Awards, he won best supporting actor for his part in Steven Spielberg\u2019s \u201cBridge of Spies.\u201d Mr. Holland played a supporting role in \u201cMoonlight,\u201d which won best picture at the Oscars in 2017; he also starred in \u201cSelma.\u201d\n\nThe new season opens at the Globe on April 25 with a production of \u201cHamlet.\u201d Other plays in the season include \u201cAs You Like It,\u201d \u201cThe Winter\u2019s Tale,\u201d \u201cLove\u2019s Labour\u2019s Lost\u201d and \u201cThe Two Noble Kinsmen.\u201d", "title": "Andr\u00e9 Holland and Mark Rylance in New Season at Shakespeare\u2019s Globe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Andy Dalton, the quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals, is an unlikely hero for Buffalo Bills fans.\n\nBut Dalton\u2019s improbable last-minute touchdown pass against the Baltimore Ravens on Sunday cleared the path for Buffalo\u2019s first playoff appearance since the 1999 season, and grateful Bills fans responded by channeling their excitement into charity. Dalton said that by Wednesday evening, 10,000 people had donated almost $250,000 to his foundation since the game, enough to cover most of the charity\u2019s goals for all of 2018.\n\nMany of the Bills fans donated $17 as a tribute to breaking their 17-year postseason drought.\n\nThe Andy & Jordan Dalton Foundation, named for the Bengals quarterback and his wife, provides money and experiences for seriously ill children and their families in Cincinnati and Fort Worth, Tex. Before the Bills fans\u2019 support, the foundation aimed to give six families each month grants averaging $2,000, for an annual budget of about $144,000. The money helps with medical bills and needed supplies.\n\nBut after exceeding the entire year\u2019s fund-raising goals in just two days, the foundation will be able to increase the number of grants it gives or to fund other programs, said Andrea Baker, a spokeswoman. The organization typically receives more applications for help than it\u2019s able to provide, she said.", "title": "Andy Dalton Saved the Bills, and Fans Flocked to His Charity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "MELBOURNE, Australia \u2014 Andy Murray underwent surgery on his right hip on Monday and said he hoped to be back playing in time for Wimbledon.\n\nMurray, a three-time major winner and former No. 1, has not played a competitive match since a quarterfinal exit at Wimbledon last July. He decided last week to withdraw from the Australian Open, which begins next week.\n\nMurray has been told to expect a 14-week recovery period and he is targeting a return to the court by June.\n\n\u201cI underwent successful right hip surgery at the St Vincent Hospital in Melbourne,\u201d Murray wrote on his Facebook page. \u201cI\u2019d like to thank Dr John O\u2019Donnell and all of the staff for looking after me. I look forward to returning to competitive tennis during the grass court season. Thanks to everyone for all the well wishes and support over the last few days. I\u2019ll comeback from this.\u201d", "title": "Andy Murray Has Hip Surgery and Hopes to Return in June", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Before his withdrawal, Murray had said he was ready to settle for less than his best if need be.\n\n\u201cI just want to be able to play tennis,\u201d he said in a news conference on Sunday. \u201cI don\u2019t mind if it\u2019s No. 30-in-the-world level. I would love it to be No. 1-in-the-world level, but I just want to play. When that\u2019s kind of taken away from you, you know, you kind of realize how important it is.\u201d\n\nMurray is not alone in being plagued by an injury. The other four men who started 2017 ranked in the top five \u2014 Novak Djokovic, Milos Raonic, Stan Wawrinka and Kei Nishikori \u2014 were also forced to abbreviate their seasons. None played the United States Open, and only Raonic played a tournament after it, retiring one game into his second match in Tokyo.\n\nBecause of a lingering elbow injury, Djokovic withdrew from an exhibition match in Abu Dhabi as well as a tournament this week in Doha, Qatar. Nishikori, also struggling with his right wrist, pulled out of Brisbane and next week\u2019s tournament in Sydney. Wawrinka, who is managing a chronic knee injury, did not enter any warm-up tournaments.\n\nAll five are still entered in the Australian Open, but only Raonic is scheduled to play a warm-up tournament, with his first match in Brisbane set for Wednesday.\n\nRaonic said he thought the casualties among elite players were possibly coincidental, but did point to correlation between injury and the previous year\u2019s workload.\n\n\u201cIf you look at it from just a purely numbers standpoint, you see the guys that play a lot the year before, a lot of matches \u2014 65-plus, maybe even over 70 matches \u2014 those guys struggle the following year,\u201d Raonic said.\n\nTop-ranked Rafael Nadal, who played a full schedule last year after an injury-shortened 2016 season, withdrew from Brisbane before the draw was made.", "title": "Andy Murray\u2019s Australian Open Is in Doubt Because of Lingering Hip Problem", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "BONN, Germany \u2014 Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany escaped political disaster on Sunday, at least for now, and inched a step closer to forming a new government after the Social Democrats voted in favor of entering formal coalition talks with her conservative camp.\n\nThis latest episode in Germany\u2019s agonizing saga of political uncertainty raised cautious hopes that a new administration might be sworn in by Easter. But a major wild card remains: The Social Democrats\u2019 grass roots \u2014 rebellious after sharing power with Ms. Merkel led to their worst election result in more than 80 years \u2014 must approve any final coalition deal. Sunday\u2019s vote, backed by 56 percent of party delegates, was tight.\n\n\u201cThe fight is not over!\u201d warned the bright-red banner of one activist outside the party congress in the western city of Bonn.\n\nStill, Sunday\u2019s vote met with a collective sigh of relief in the corridors of power in Berlin and neighboring countries, which have been impatient for the continent\u2019s most influential country to turn its attention back to the world.", "title": "Angela Merkel Spared Disaster, and German Coalition Talks to Continue", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Ponzi\u2019s scheme was eventually exposed, and he later died in a charity hospital in Brazil, with only $75 to his name.\n\nRemy Tumin contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online. Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Angela Merkel, Brexit, Winter Olympics: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Williams, 36, should be back in the game soon. Her coach, Patrick Mouratoglou, told me that Williams, who gave birth to a daughter in September, was still planning to return to the circuit at the tournament in Indian Wells, Calif., in March.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut for now, Kerber, who turned 30 on Thursday, is the veteran champion working her way back in a sunlit place. She is also, after beating Sharapova, the last major singles women\u2019s champion left heading into the round of 16. Kerber, a German, will face Hsieh Su-wei, a 32-year-old from Taiwan who is known best for her doubles prowess.\n\n\u201cAngie is already one step ahead of everybody else because nobody else knows what it\u2019s like to win a Grand Slam,\u201d said the Australian Rennae Stubbs, a television analyst and former player. \u201cIt\u2019s bloody hard to do it. It\u2019s nerve-racking and it\u2019s stressful and it\u2019s out-of-this-world different, and she\u2019s already won two and won here and she\u2019s playing great. She\u2019s nails right now. She\u2019s 2016 all over again.\u201d\n\nSharapova, who will turn 31 in April, has farther to go to crank back her clock. Since returning last season from a 15-month suspension for an antidoping violation, she has not gotten past the fourth round in the two major tournaments she has played.\n\nOnce No. 1, she is closing in on the top 40 again. It would be quite a surprise if Sharapova, a Russian, were not one of the 32 seeds at the French Open, the next major tournament, which begins in Paris in May.\n\nBut her first serve was a liability on Saturday night, when she put just 38 percent into play. And though she generated plenty of her signature pace and acoustic fury, she was not nearly steady enough or acrobatic enough to keep up in this match. Kerber kept her off balance as a rule and countered her flat power effectively when Sharapova was able to deliver groundstrokes from more solid platforms.\n\n\u201cAngie knew it would be a tough one mentally, but if she plays like that, with aggression, she\u2019s just a better player than Maria right now because of her movement,\u201d Barbara Rittner, the German Fed Cup captain, said after chatting with Kerber as she warmed down from the match on a stationary bike.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKerber\u2019s new coach, Wim Fissette, was also part of the debriefing and is again having a quick impact on a new pupil. Fissette, a Belgian who started his WTA Tour coaching career working with Kim Clijsters, has since experienced success with Halep, Victoria Azarenka and Johanna Konta.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut he split with Konta last year, and when Kerber split with her longtime coach Torben Beltz, she recruited Fissette \u2014 in part because of his r\u00e9sum\u00e9 and in part because he speaks German.\n\nKerber said Fissette was her first choice, and they are now off to a flying start. She has won 12 straight matches to start the season: four of them unofficial at the Hopman Cup team event and eight of them on tour.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a different voice,\u201d Kerber said. \u201cIt\u2019s a little bit different than with Torben, but you know, I think I needed the change, and that\u2019s why I decided to change everything. I think it was a good decision to do it.\u201d\n\nShe won the title in Sydney the week before the Australian Open after saving two match points in the first round against Lucie Safarova and then rallying to defeat Venus Williams in the second.\n\nStubbs was courtside for those matches.\n\n\u201cVenus was playing well, and Angie digs out the second set and then runs away with it and has not looked back after that,\u201d Stubbs said. \u201cIt was like: \u2018I remember how to win again. I have to dig deep, and digging deep wins me matches and then that gives me confidence and that reminds me I\u2019m really good.\u2019 And then everybody starts talking, \u2018Angie\u2019s back!\u2019 \u201d\n\nThe risk, of course, is that Kerber starts hearing that chorus so often that she begins to think too hard again instead of just reacting and hustling and letting her beautiful game flow.\n\n\u201cI think she plays extremely well when she has a lot of matches behind her back,\u201d Sharapova said. \u201cI always thought she\u2019s a confidence player.\u201d", "title": "Angelique Kerber Is Learning How to Win Again", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey", "On Tennis"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. There\u2019s a lot of exciting reading in the Food section we sent to the printing plants last night and delivered to the vicinity of front doors and driveways this chilly morning. Ligaya Mishan takes us all on vacation to Hawaii, where she\u2019s from, to eat poke and experience it in its indigenous form, far superior to anything you\u2019ll ever find on the mainland. For \u201cBeers of The Times,\u201d Eric Asimov and his merry band of tasters dive deep into the pleasures of brown ale. Pete Wells reviews Ferris, a new New American restaurant in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan.\n\nAnd Tejal Rao brings forth a delightful profile of Angie Mar, the chef and an owner of the Beatrice Inn in Manhattan, which includes a recipe of Ms. Mar\u2019s for an impressively large English-style meat pie with potatoes and brown gravy, with a marrow bone roasted right into it. Some, like me, will want to make that as soon as this weekend, a kind of cry against winter in place of a flight to Kailua. (Though we\u2019d take that flight if we could, for sure. You ever see how they fish for giant trevally there?)\n\nTonight, though, I think most will want to cook simply, get some grub on the table soon as possible. That is the way of the world in the middle of the week, and, though we ache to change many things about our state of affairs, that is not one of them. You won\u2019t even need a recipe! Just cook some pasta \u2014 ziti, for instance, for that\u2019s what is on the shelf \u2014 in salted water, and drain it just before it is done, reserving a cup of the cooking water.\n\nWhile the pasta cooks, melt a honking big knob of unsalted butter in a pan large enough to hold the pasta and cook some diced onions or shallots in it until they\u2019re translucent. Add some slivered sage leaves and finish cooking the pasta in all of that, making a kind of sauce with around a half-cup of the cooking water and a healthy shower of grated Parmesan \u2014 like, at least a cup. Season liberally with kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper and \u2014 here\u2019s a twist \u2014 serve the whole thing on a bed of raw baby greens, which will melt a little in the heat, while still retaining some crunch. Dinner is served.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat\u2019s one idea, anyway. You could make burgers instead. Or smothered chicken. Or rice noodles with spicy pork and herbs. You ever try a weeknight omelet mousseline for supper? Oh, buddy. It\u2019s a classic French technique in which the egg whites are whipped before you fold in the yolks, which are mixed with cream. It all results in a lighter, fluffier specimen than the classic. You can play down the fanciness by serving it with hot sauce or ketchup, with buttered toast, and get your \u201cNighthawk\u201d on.", "title": "Angie Mar Is a Badass", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "Melissa Clark", "Tejal Rao"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMr. de la Rosa,\u201d she said to a server, holding up the shard on her fingertip, \u201cWould you like to take this downstairs and show it to them?\u201d\n\nMs. Mar\u2019s earliest cooking jobs were at Diner and Marlow & Sons in Brooklyn. She helped open Reynard, where she learned to butcher, then became a sous-chef at the Spotted Pig (where the owner, Ken Friedman, has been accused of sexual harassment by several current and former employees).\n\nHer aim, she says, is to provide her team with the training, support and guidance she couldn\u2019t always find for herself as a young cook. For restaurant culture to shift in a meaningful way, Ms. Mar believes it is just as vital for her to mentor men as women.\n\n\u201cWe need to focus on bringing the next generation up,\u201d said Ms. Mar, who refers to her staff, half-jokingly, as her kids. \u201cBecause what really matters is where my cooks are in 10 years, and who they\u2019re mentoring in 10 years.\u201d\n\nMs. Mar sometimes uses honorifics \u2014 Mr. and Ms., ladies and gentlemen \u2014 to address her team, with the archaic formality of a professor. She and her managers also carve out time each day to discuss an informal curriculum of books, films and restaurant reviews, as well as techniques and inspirational quotations, with the entire staff.\n\nOn a recent evening, they talked about \u201cJiro Dreams of Sushi,\u201d the 2011 documentary about the Japanese chef Jiro Ono, marveling at his craftsmanship.\n\nAfterward, Ms. Mar met with her wine consultant, Nathan Wooden, to test dishes under development. The staff seated her, as if she were a guest, and Ms. Mar took notes on the back of her menu, writing down questions and ways to improve not only on flavors and presentations, but also on the introductory monologue a server gives to each table (which she determined to be a smidgen too long).\n\nPhoto\n\nJust a few weeks earlier, she had tapped a 19-year-old server, Emma Arango, to train as a chef de salon, adding tableside service to her responsibilities. Tonight Ms. Arango was in a black suit, shaving truffles over hamburgers, flamb\u00e9ing whole ducks, carving lamb.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cLook at her go,\u201d Ms. Mar said with pride. \u201cShe\u2019s going to run one of my restaurants one day.\u201d\n\nMs. Mar had asked the kitchen to plate two versions of a langoustine cocktail she was fine-tuning \u2014 one with the sharp shell still on, the other ready to eat.\n\n\u201cThe problem is, do most people want to go through all this?\u201d Ms. Mar asked, cracking open a shell-on one with her hands, with ease, dipping the meat in butter, and then tipping it back for a taste of the brains. No, she decided, and went with the version that would require more work in the kitchen, but less in the dining room.\n\nThe langoustine had been developed, like all new dishes, through a series of weekly workshops that Ms. Mar runs with her sous-chef, Nicole Averkiou, and head chef, Ed Szymanski.\n\nIn the earliest stages of a new dish, Ms. Mar draws out a word web in Sharpie, on printer paper, throwing words out, circling them, squashing them together in different sequences, discussing all the possible variations out loud.\n\nAt the center of a blank page, she wrote: Hare. This dish, she said, was inspired by Madame de Pompadour, one of Louis XV\u2019s mistresses, whom she had been reading about recently.", "title": "Angie Mar\u2019s Menu: Red Meat and Respect", "authors": ["Tejal Rao"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHouston guard Chris Paul\u2019s return to the Staples Center to face the Los Angeles Clippers took a contentious turn late in the game on Monday, with several heated exchanges and two ejections in the final minutes. And it apparently did not stop after the final whistle, as several Rockets players reportedly tried to enter the Clippers\u2019 locker room seeking a confrontation.\n\nThe game, a 113-102 Clippers win, unraveled with about three and a half minutes to go. The Rockets reacted furiously after a foul call against Paul, playing against his former team for the first time since being traded last summer, and Clippers center Blake Griffin appeared to exchange angry words with Rockets Coach Mike D\u2019Antoni near the sideline. D\u2019Antoni later accused Griffin of making contact with him along the sideline on his way downcourt before the call on Paul, which led to the confrontation. A relative has been arrested.\n\nAs an indication of the widespread attention and concern the case has prompted, one major television station, NDTV, ran regular updates at the bottom of the screen on Tuesday:\n\n\u201cBaby in I.C.U.; Condition stable.\u201d\n\nAccording to police officials, the infant\u2019s parents were working Sunday morning and had asked a cousin to watch their two girls, the 8-month-old and a 2-year-old. The family lives in a poor neighborhood in the northwest corner of New Delhi.\n\nWhen the baby\u2019s mother, a maid, returned in the afternoon, she found the infant bleeding profusely between her legs. Her father, speaking to television reporters with his face obscured to protect the family\u2019s identity, said the bed the baby had been lying on had been smeared with blood.\n\nThe mother asked the cousin what had happened and he could not give her a clear answer.\n\nShe then called the police. After questioning, investigators arrested the cousin, a day laborer in his late 20s, who admitted to inserting his finger inside the infant girl\u2019s vagina, police officials said.", "title": "Anguish in New Delhi at Rape of an 8-Month-Old Girl", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Anna Mae Hays, a front-line nurse who was named the United States military\u2019s first female general after serving in three wars \u2014 in the jungles of India during World War II, in Korea and in Vietnam \u2014 died on Monday in Washington. She was 97.\n\nThe cause was a heart attack, a niece, Doris A. Kressly, said.\n\nGeneral Hays, who grew up mostly in Pennsylvania as the daughter of Salvation Army officers, had enlisted in the Army Nurse Corps during World War II. She was shortly deployed to a field hospital in northeastern India, where she treated construction workers and Army engineers building a road to China, sometimes assisting in amputations.\n\nIn South Korea, she helped establish the first military hospital in the coastal city of Inchon, the scene of a decisive victory for United Nations forces in 1950.\n\nDuring her three decades in the military, which culminated in her appointment to chief of the nurse corps, General Hays witnessed extraordinary medical advances, from the introduction of lifesaving antibiotics and painkillers to helicopter airlifts of wounded soldiers.", "title": "Anna Mae Hays, 97, U.S. Military\u2019s First Female General, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor nearly five years, Brooklyn\u2019s criminal-justice system has been engaged in an unprecedented project as prosecutors, judges and lawyers have pored over scores of cases connected to the former star detective Louis Scarcella looking for evidence of misconduct. After all this time, the investigation has become a kind of episodic drama, a real-life police procedural that has so far cleared the names of a dozen people convicted of murder.\n\nOn Thursday, in the latest installment of the inquiry, a judge threw out the guilty verdict in another murder case that Mr. Scarcella worked on, saying that if the jury that considered the matter had known about the allegations against him at the time, it might have come to a different conclusion.\n\nThe ruling by the judge came in the case of Sundhe Moses, a Brooklyn man found guilty in 1997 of killing a 4-year-old girl who roller-skated into a hail of bullets meant for members of a street gang operating at a public-housing project. Mr. Moses served 18 years in prison for killing the girl, Shamone Johnson, but was released on parole in 2013 after an eyewitness at his trial recanted his testimony.\n\nSince he was released, Mr. Moses has been trying to get his verdict formally reversed, in part by arguing, as he did at trial, that Mr. Scarcella choked and hit him to coerce a confession. In her order on Thursday, Justice Dineen A. Riviezzo said that while some of the claims against Mr. Scarcella \u201cseem far-fetched,\u201d the accumulation of accusations that he used \u201cimproper tactics\u201d to send people to prison could have proved persuasive to the jury that convicted Mr. Moses.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhen Justice Riviezzo announced her decision from the bench, spectators in the courtroom in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn applauded. Mr. Moses, now 42, embraced his lawyer, Ronald L. Kuby. His mother, Elaine Hill, sitting behind him, hid her face and started weeping.", "title": "Another Brooklyn Murder Conviction Linked to Scarcella Is Reversed", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mayor Bill de Blasio\u2019s recent declaration of war on Big Oil for its contribution to climate change inspired, as is often the case with this mayor, some skepticism that he was once again seizing a big issue to propel himself into the national spotlight. Some also suggested that if he truly cared about the carbon emissions that cause global warming, he would mothball at least part of the fleet of SUVs that ferry him around the city.\n\nAll partly true, perhaps, but Mr. de Blasio\u2019s decision to confront some of the world\u2019s biggest polluters is possibly transformative and certainly timely. It comes just when the Trump administration is moving in the opposite direction, opening up America\u2019s coastal waters to drilling and removing regulatory obstacles to oil exploration, and generally giving fossil fuel companies pretty much what they want. It follows a year of extreme weather events, including three major hurricanes, that collectively caused $306 billion in damage \u2014 the most expensive year on record for natural disasters in this country. And it comes as climate scientists are growing increasingly confident about linking these events, or at least their severity, to global warming.\n\nThe mayor\u2019s attack is two-pronged. First, he intends to divest the city\u2019s $189 billion pension fund of an estimated $5 billion invested in fossil fuel companies. This puts the city on the same page as a number of other cities, New York State and many colleges, where the divestment movement first took root.\n\nSecond, of potentially more consequence, he announced that the city was suing five big oil companies \u2014 ExxonMobil, Chevron, BP, Royal Dutch Shell and Conoco Phillips \u2014 to hold them accountable for emissions that have helped drive up global temperatures and to force the companies to fork over billions of dollars in damages to help cope with the effects of climate change, steps like fortifying coastal protections against flooding and upgrading sewer systems.", "title": "Opinion | Another Day of Reckoning for Big Oil\u2019s Role in Climate Change", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI noticed him as I transferred from the Q train to the L on my way to a beer garden in Brooklyn.\n\nI sat across from him. He had headphones on and was unaware of the world around him, eyes wide open without looking anywhere in particular. He was not especially attractive, nor did he have any distinct features to draw my attention. Yet he did.\n\nOther riders left the car, new ones got on. Nothing seemed to alter his state of mind, not even my occasional but piercing stare.\n\nSuddenly, something \u2014 or, rather, someone \u2014 caught his eye. She was not particularly attractive, nor did she have any distinct features to attract his attention. Yet she did.\n\nI was looking at him. He was looking at her.", "title": "Another Missed Connection", "authors": ["Estefan\u00eda Michel", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "BANGKOK \u2014 The government of Malaysia and an American ocean exploration company began a new effort on Wednesday to solve one of history\u2019s greatest aviation mysteries: the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 nearly four years ago.\n\nOcean Infinity, a Houston-based company, could receive as much as $70 million if it finds the plane\u2019s debris field or two data recorders within 90 days, Transportation Minister Liow Tiong Lai said Wednesday at a signing ceremony with company officials at Putrajaya, Malaysia\u2019s federal administrative center.\n\nBut under the agreement, the company will receive nothing if it does not find the missing Boeing 777, which disappeared over the Indian Ocean on March 8, 2014, with 239 people aboard.\n\nMr. Liow called it a \u201cno cure, no fee\u201d agreement.\n\nUnder the contract, Malaysia will pay Ocean Infinity $20 million if it finds the wreckage or data recorders early in the search. The potential fee rises in staggered amounts to as much as $70 million, depending on how large an area the vessel searches before locating the plane.", "title": "Another Search Begins for Long-Missing Malaysian Airliner", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "This article was updated on Feb. 2, 2018. For further coverage of the memo, read here \u00bb\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 House Republicans released a secret Intelligence Committee memo on Friday that accuses senior officials at the F.B.I. and the Justice Department of abuses in the early stages of the special counsel\u2019s Russia investigation.\n\nDemocrats say the memo is a partisan attempt to undermine the inquiry, and an assistant attorney general, Stephen E. Boyd, said that releasing it without an official review process would be \u201cextraordinarily reckless.\u201d In an unusual public statement, the F.B.I. said it had \u201cgrave concerns\u201d about releasing the memo.\n\nHere are answers to some basic questions.\n\nWhat does the memo say?\n\nThe memo is a short summary of some of the intelligence used to support a government request to secretly surveil Carter Page, the former Trump campaign associate.\n\nIn order to obtain the warrant, the F.B.I. and the Justice Department had to show a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court judge that they had probable cause to believe that Mr. Page was acting as a Russian agent. The memo describes four applications to surveil Mr. Page. The original request was made on Oct. 21, 2016; investigators have to seek approval to extend the surveillance every 90 days.", "title": "Answers About the Secret Memo on the Trump-Russia Inquiry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Using antacids during pregnancy is linked to asthma in offspring, a systematic review of research has found.\n\nResearchers pooled data from eight observational studies and concluded that the risk of asthma in childhood increased by 34 percent when the mother used proton pump inhibitors and by 57 percent with the use of histamine-2 receptor antagonists. The study is in Pediatrics.\n\nP.P.I.s and H2 blockers are considered safe and effective prescription drugs for treating gastroesophageal reflux disease, or GERD, a common complication in pregnancy. They are also available over the counter.\n\nNo observational study can establish causation, and genetic or environmental factors could explain the association. Yet even after controlling for maternal asthma, use of other drugs during pregnancy, age of the mother at birth, smoking and other variables, the association persisted.", "title": "Antacids During Pregnancy Tied to Asthma in Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLarge crowds rallied on Saturday in Bucharest, Romania\u2019s capital city, the latest in ongoing mass demonstrations against revisions to the country\u2019s corruption laws that have gripped the country since last year.\n\nBraving snowy conditions and freezing temperatures, protesters gathered in the city\u2019s University Square before marching to the Parliament. Once outside the building, the crowd, whose numbers were estimated to be in the tens of thousands, sang the national anthem, and people waved their cellphones in the air, creating an impressive display of light, according to the national press agency Agerpres.\n\nPhoto\n\nThose gathered were protesting against new legislation, passed by Parliament in December and currently waiting to be signed into law, that critics say weakens the country\u2019s judicial system and makes it harder to prosecute high-level corruption crimes.\n\nOther demonstrations were held in smaller cities around the country on Saturday, according to Agerpres, including in Cluj-Napoca, Timisoara and Sibiu where thousands also rallied.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThose gathered in Bucharest chanted anticorruption slogans, denounced the current government and called for early elections, according to several local reports.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe controversial new legislation still needs to be signed into law by President Klaus Iohannis, who has long been a critic of the amendments. He wrote to the country\u2019s Constitutional Court on Friday, saying one amendment that would allow public officials to own businesses \u201cdiminished the standards of integrity\u201d expected from public officials, according to The Associated Press.\n\nSome fear the new legislation, if signed into law, would mark a step backward for the country.\n\nLast year, Romania saw its largest protests in decades after the government moved to decriminalize some corruption offenses, galvanizing the masses to denounce the move.", "title": "Anti-Corruption Protest Draws Tens of Thousands Across Snowy Romania", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Many people take antioxidants before or after exercise in the belief that this prevents muscle soreness. A thorough review of the scientific literature has found no solid evidence that it works.\n\nResearchers pooled data from 50 randomized placebo-controlled trials involving 1,089 participants. Some studies looked at antioxidant supplements taken before exercise, some after. The type of antioxidant studied varied \u2014 cherry juice, pomegranate juice, vitamins C and E, black tea extract and others in various doses. The studies used supplements as powders, tablets and concentrates.\n\nThe pooled data, in the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, showed some small advantage for using antioxidants, but none that would add up to a meaningful difference from taking a placebo at any time after exercise. None of the trials measured recovery time \u2014 that is, the time it took to being able to exercise again without soreness. Two trials found antioxidants caused mild gastrointestinal problems in a small number of participants.\n\n\u201cMuscle soreness is something you get from unaccustomed or high-intensity exercise, and there are some ways to reduce it \u2014 hot baths, cold baths, massage,\u201d said the lead author, Mayur K. Ranchordas, a senior lecturer at Sheffield Hallam University in England. \u201cBut the evidence for antioxidant supplements is pretty poor. The effect was so small that in practical terms they really didn\u2019t make any difference.\u201d", "title": "Antioxidants Don\u2019t Ease Muscle Soreness After Exercise", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Apple is selling out. It\u2019s not about the latest version of the iPhone, but the huge cache of personal data that will be going directly to the largest, and one of the harshest, authoritarian regimes in the world: the Communist government of China.\n\nGiven the Chinese government\u2019s continuing crackdown on human rights and freedom of speech under President Xi Jinping, as well as its deepening reach into Western democracies, Apple\u2019s policies in China have far-reaching implications for us all.\n\nLast summer, Apple announced that it would be partnering with Guizhou-Cloud Big Data, a state-owned company with Communist Party connections, to build Apple\u2019s first data-storage center in China. Beginning Feb. 28, the iCloud content of Apple ID users registered in China will be sent to and managed by Guizhou-Cloud Big Data.\n\nCustomers registered in China, according to Apple\u2019s new terms and conditions agreement for the country, must \u201cunderstand and agree that Apple and G.C.B.D. will have access to all data that you store on this service, including the right to share, exchange and disclose all user data, including content, to and between each other under applicable law.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Apple Can\u2019t Resist Playing by China\u2019s Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nApple has taken another step toward becoming a power in the entertainment business by scooping up the rights for a TV project from Damien Chazelle, the Oscar-winning writer and director of \u201cLa La Land,\u201d the unlikely critical and box office hit from 2016.\n\nThe tech giant announced the new series on Thursday. It marks the latest television entry from Mr. Chazelle, who signed a deal with Netflix in September to make \u201cThe Eddy,\u201d an eight-episode musical series set in Paris.\n\nApple said that Mr. Chazelle would direct and write each episode of the new series\u2019 first season. His involvement in the Netflix show has him directing only its first two episodes.\n\nAnother difference from the Netflix deal: Apple is being mum on the details.\n\nHow many episodes will it be?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhere will it take place?\n\nWhat\u2019s it about?\n\nApple would not answer any of those questions.\n\nIn a very short period of time, with competition so intense, TV networks have begun committing tens of millions of dollars to projects without so much as seeing a script. Rarer still is an announcement of a coming series without a public disclosure of what was purchased.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor the mysterious new assignment, Mr. Chazelle will reunite with the producers Jordan Horowitz and Fred Berger, both of whom worked on \u201cLa La Land.\u201d MRC, which produced \u201cHouse of Cards,\u201d is the studio behind the show. Show business fans will recall Mr. Horowitz as the man who stood on the Academy Awards stage to claim the Oscar for best picture after Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway had mistakenly announced \u201cLa La Land\u201d as the winner. After realizing the error, Mr. Horowitz revealed that \u201cMoonlight\u201d was the true winner and called the rival film\u2019s team to the stage.\n\nThe untitled Chazelle project is the eighth one to be made public by Apple. The Cupertino, Calif., company entered the streaming wars last year when it announced that it would spend more than $1 billion on a slate of original programming.", "title": "Apple Goes Deeper Into La La Land With Damien Chazelle Project", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA pair of investors who say they hold about $2 billion in Apple stock are pushing the company to do more to protect its youngest users from the effects of digital technology.\n\nIn an open letter to Apple, the investors, the activist hedge fund Jana Partners and the California State Teachers\u2019 Retirement System, voiced concerns that such technology might be hurting children and said Apple could help ease the damage even as it generates business.\n\n\u201cWe believe that addressing this issue now will enhance long-term value for all shareholders, by creating more choices and options for your customers today and helping to protect the next generation of leaders, innovators, and customers tomorrow,\u201d they wrote in the letter, dated Saturday.\n\nThe investors, whose combined holdings are small compared with Apple\u2019s approximately $900 billion market value, cited research suggesting that the prevalence of digital devices, such as the laptops, tablets and smartphones Apple makes, may be negatively affecting children.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne survey of teachers in Alberta, Canada, found that about two in three believed that digital technology was increasingly distracting their students, according to the letter. And research by Jean Twenge, a professor of psychology at San Diego State University, suggests that the rise of digital technology may be linked to an increase in mental health problems among teenagers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAddressing the issue now could help Apple avoid an impending reckoning as unease grows over the role technology and social media play in our daily lives, the shareholders wrote.", "title": "Apple Investors Warn iPhones and Other Technology May Be Hurting Children", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Apple is one of several multinational giants that have kept a total of roughly $3 trillion in global profits off their domestic books to sidestep the previous 35 percent federal corporate tax rate. Under the new tax law, companies that make a one-time repatriation of cash will be taxed at a rate of 15.5 percent on cash holdings and 8 percent on nonliquid assets. That is lower than the new 21 percent corporate rate. And under the new tax code, Apple would also have been taxed whether it brought the money back or not.\n\nBy shifting the money under the new terms, Apple has saved $43 billion in taxes, more than any other American company, according to the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, a research group in Washington.\n\nOther tech giants are set to follow suit in the coming months. Companies like Microsoft, Alphabet and Cisco also shifted their profits into offshore shell companies, avoiding billions of dollars in taxes, and are now in a better position to bring the money back.\n\nAlthough Republican supporters of the tax law argued that the influx of international profits would create jobs and increase wages, many economists disagreed that a one-time repatriation would have any substantial impact on real investment.\n\nApple\u2019s announcement, couched as a major investment in the United States instead of a massive financial windfall, followed years of criticism that the company did not do enough for the American economy because it makes most of its products in China and parked its profits abroad.\n\nDuring the 2016 presidential campaign, Apple was a frequent target of Mr. Trump, who pledged that as president he would force the company to start making iPhones and Macs in the United States. While that hasn\u2019t happened and is unlikely to, Apple has since gone on a charm offensive to demonstrate its value to the American economy.\n\nThe company has highlighted the number of jobs created by the so-called app economy, an ecosystem of software and services that run on the iPhone and other Apple products. Last year, Apple also said it was creating a $1 billion fund to invest in advanced manufacturing in the United States. On Wednesday, Apple said it was increasing the size of that fund to $5 billion and noted that it was already backing projects from manufacturers in Kentucky and Texas.", "title": "Apple, Capitalizing on New Tax Law, Plans to Bring Billions in Cash Back to U.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In the latest indication of Apple\u2019s growing ambitions in the digital health market, the tech giant on Wednesday unveiled a new feature that would allow users to automatically download and see parts of their medical records on their iPhones.\n\nThe feature is to become part of Apple\u2019s popular Health app. It will enable users to transfer clinical data \u2014 like cholesterol levels and lists of medications prescribed by their doctors \u2014 directly from their medical providers to their iPhones, potentially streamlining how Americans gain access to some health information.\n\nA dozen medical institutions across the United States \u2014 including Johns Hopkins Medicine in Baltimore and Cedars-Sinai in Los Angeles \u2014 have agreed to participate in the beta version of the new feature. Apple plans to open the beta test to consumers on Thursday.\n\nApple said it will not see consumers\u2019 medical data, which is encrypted and stored locally on the iPhone, unless the user chooses to share it with the company.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really strange to me that you can easily pull up all of your spending record on your credit card going back a long way in every detail, yet your health is way more important and you don\u2019t have easy access to your health information,\u201d said Jeff Williams, Apple\u2019s chief operating officer. \u201cWe want to make sure that consumers are empowered with information about their health.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTech giants including Apple, Microsoft and Alphabet, Google\u2019s parent company, are going head-to-head to obtain a larger slice of American health care spending, which amounts to more than $3 trillion annually.", "title": "Apple, in Sign of Health Ambitions, Adds Medical Records Feature for iPhone", "authors": ["Natasha Singer"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Here\u2019s what Apple plans to do:\n\n\u2022 Invest about $30 billion in capital expenditures in the United States over the next five years.\n\n\n\n\u2022 Create more than 20,000 new jobs in the United States, a 24 percent increase from the roughly 84,000 employees in the country currently.\n\n\u2022 Issue stock-based bonuses worth $2,500 to employees, according to Bloomberg.\n\nCould antitrust law fell the tech giants?\n\nThat\u2019s the provocative question posed by Greg Ip of the WSJ. And it reflects governments\u2019 growing wariness toward the tech industry.\n\nGoogle, Amazon and Facebook aren\u2019t like the Standard Oil or AT&T of old, gouging consumers on price. (Indeed, many of their services are free.) But if the question is \u201cAre consumers better off?\u201d then could there be an opening for regulatory action?\n\nMore from Mr. Ip:\n\nIf market dominance means fewer competitors and less innovation, consumers will be worse off than if those companies had been restrained. \u201cThe impact on innovation can be the most important competitive effect\u201d in an antitrust case, says Fiona Scott Morton, a Yale University economist who served in the Justice Department\u2019s Antitrust Division under Barack Obama.\n\nWhere tech has support: In its efforts to keep net neutrality regulations, with a lawsuit against the F.C.C. by 22 state attorneys general and a bill by Senate Democrats to undo the repeal using the Congressional Review Act.\n\nGoldman posts first quarterly loss in six years.\n\nGoldman once seemed invincible. Its trading business was a profit machine.\n\nThis morning it posted a quarterly loss in part because of the poor performance in its trading unit.\n\nThe numbers:\n\n\u2022 $1.9 billion. Goldman\u2019s fourth-quarter loss.\n\n\u2022 $4.4 billion. The charge Goldman took related to the new tax law, which wiped out nearly half of Goldman's earnings for the year, according to the WSJ.\n\n\u2022 $5.68. The Wall Street firm\u2019s profit per share excluding the tax-related charge, beating the consensus estimate of $4.90 from Wall Street analysts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022$7.8 billion. Goldman\u2019s revenue for the quarter, down 4 percent. Goldman is the only big bank to report a decline in revenue so far.\n\n\u2022 $2.37 billion. Goldman\u2019s trading revenue for the fourth quarter, down 34 percent from a year ago. That was the steepest decline of any of banks reporting so far. Citigroup, JPMorgan and Bank of America have reported declines in trading revenue of 19 percent, 17 percent and 9 percent.\n\n\u2022 $1 billion. Goldman\u2019s revenue from buying and selling bonds, commodities and currencies, half of what it generated a year ago. To put that in perspective: Goldman\u2019s fixed-income division at its peak churned out nearly a billion dollars every two weeks.\n\nIn unrelated Goldman news...\n\nFederal prosecutors in Manhattan unsealed an indictment charging Nicolas De-Meyer, 40, with stealing $1.2 million worth of rare wine from a former employer. The former employer in question was Mr. Solomon, who employed Mr. De-Meyer as a personal assistant, according to two sources familiar with the matter.\n\nAccording to the indictment, the wine was stolen from around October 2014 to around October 2016, when Mr. De-Meyer had been asked to transport it from his former employer\u2019s Manhattan apartment to his wine cellar in East Hampton, N.Y.\n\nMr. De-Meyer was arrested in Los Angeles on Tuesday, according to a spokesman for the Los Angeles federal prosecutor\u2019s office. He could not immediately be reached for comment.\n\n\u201cThe theft was discovered in the fall of 2016 and reported to law enforcement at that time,\u201d a Goldman spokesman said.\n\nExcluding tax hit, BofA posts biggest profit in more than a decade.\n\nBank of America reported $2.4 billion in fourth-quarter profit, after taking a $2.9 billion charge tied to the new tax law.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe numbers:\n\n\u2022 $5.3 billion, or 47 cents a share. BofA\u2019s profit in the fourth quarter excluding the tax-related charge. Analysts had expected the bank to report earnings of 44 cents per share.\n\n\u2022 $21.1 billion. BofA\u2019s earnings for 2017, excluding the tax-related charge. That matches its biggest annual profit since 2006.\n\n\u2022$20.4 billion. The bank\u2019s revenue for the fourth quarter, up from $19.99 billion a year ago.\n\n\u2022$2.66 billion. BofA\u2019s fourth-quarter trading revenue, down about 9 percent from a year ago.\n\n\u2022 $11.46 billion. The bank\u2019s net-interest income, up 11 percent.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe new tax code and banks: short-term pain, long-term gain\n\nLet\u2019s recount the hits that U.S. banks took from the tax overhaul:\n\n\u2022 Citigroup: $22 billion\n\n\u2022 JPMorgan Chase: $2.4 billion\n\n\u2022 Goldman Sachs: $4.4 billion\n\nWe\u2019ll ignore Wells Fargo for now (it gained). The bigger point is that, thanks to lower corporate rates and preferential treatment for pass-through entities, financial institutions are some of the new code\u2019s biggest winners.\n\nMore from Jim Tankersley of the NYT:\n\n\u201cThe good news is that tax reform has produced both current and future benefits for our shareholders,\u201d PNC\u2019s president and chief executive, Bill Demchak, told analysts on Friday. He said the bank\u2019s preference would be to divert the tax savings \u201ctoward dividend\u201d \u2014 which is to say, to return a higher dividend to shareholders.\n\nPhoto\n\nG.E.\u2019s problems have investors thinking \u2018breakup\u2019\n\nThe conglomerate itself isn\u2019t planning on going that far just yet.\n\nHere\u2019s John Flannery, its chief, on a conference call yesterday:\n\n\u201cWe are looking aggressively at the best structure or structures for our portfolio to maximize the potential of our businesses. Our results, over the past several years, including 2017 and the insurance charge, only further my belief that we need to continue to move with purpose to reshape G.E.\u201d\n\nThe context\n\nMr. Flannery didn\u2019t say anything out of line with his past remarks. It\u2019s just that he said it as G.E. announced an unrelated $6.2 billion charge connected to its legacy insurance portfolio.\n\nOther conglomerates, from Honeywell to United Technologies to Tyco, have explored restructuring to varying degrees, as Wall Street analysts question the viability of the model.\n\nG.E. and its advisers are still thinking about how to reshape the 125-year-old group, whose complexity may mask yet more problems. The company promises an update in spring, and is unlikely to announce something that only fiddles around the edges. But don\u2019t expect plans for it to become three or four fully separate companies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCritics demand more boldness\n\n\u2022 Lex writes, \u201cOnce a paragon of management acumen, it is now a rolling train wreck of unexpected and expensive blunders.\u201d (FT)\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Some Republicans are irked by a stream of temporary funding resolutions, rather than a full agreement that would permit more military spending.\n\nHouse Speaker Paul Ryan\u2019s proposal for a continuing resolution \u2014 which includes delays to several health care taxes in addition to CHIP funding \u2014 has support among many, but not all, Republicans. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 G.M.\u2019s chief, Mary Barra, urged Mr. Trump to be cautious about withdrawing from Nafta. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 How Michael Wolff got into the White House. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nForget the Bitcoin frenzy\n\nThe biggest thing about virtual currencies isn\u2019t how much their prices rise (or fall). It\u2019s the technology that makes them work, argues Steven Johnson in the NYT Magazine.\n\nMore from Mr. Johnson:\n\nWhat Nakamoto ushered into the world was a way of agreeing on the contents of a database without anyone being \u201cin charge\u201d of the database, and a way of compensating people for helping make that database more valuable, without those people being on an official payroll or owning shares in a corporate entity.\n\nWe\u2019ll count him as a skeptic: Dick Kovacevich, the former Wells Fargo C.E.O., told CNBC that he thinks Bitcoin is \u201ca pyramid scheme\u201d that \u201cmakes no sense.\u201d\n\nBeware cryptoheists: North Korea looks to be using the same malware found in the Sony Pictures hack and the Wannacry assault against digital currency investors.\n\nVirtual currency quote of the day, from Bloomberg:\n\n\u201cI have a Zen philosophy that you just go with the flow,\u201d said George Tasick, a part-time cryptocurrency trader in Hong Kong whose day job is making fireworks. \u201cI\u2019m not really changing my behavior in any way.\u201d\n\nThe issues in selling the Weinstein Company\n\nIssue one: Some potential buyers may want to pick up the troubled studio through the bankruptcy process, to cleanse it of legal liabilities.\n\nIssue two: Advocates for women who have brought allegations against Harvey Weinstein worry that could deny them justice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Jonathan Randles and Peg Brickley of the WSJ:\n\nA Chapter 11 filing would halt lawsuits brought by women against the studio, forcing them to line up with low-ranking creditors to await their fate. Once the money from a sale comes in, bankruptcy law dictates who gets paid first \u2014 the banks that kept Weinstein Co. in business \u2014 and who gets paid last \u2014 women claiming that Weinstein Co. was part of Mr. Weinstein\u2019s pattern of alleged sexual misconduct.\n\nBut it\u2019s complicated. A bankruptcy filing could provide legal structures for Mr. Weinstein\u2019s accusers, like a judge\u2019s supervision of sales and settlements.\n\nA suitor from the past: Among the bidders is the previous studio founded by the Weinstein brothers, Miramax, according to Bloomberg.\n\nWhat about RICO? DealBook\u2019s White Collar Watch takes a look at using the racketeering law against Mr. Weinstein and his company:\n\nRICO lawsuits are tempting. They allow a plaintiff to sue a variety of defendants by claiming that they acted together and seek an award of triple damages, a bonanza in some business disputes that can run into millions of dollars. But these cases should also come with a bright red warning sign: Tread lightly or see your case thrown out of court before it even gets started.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe M. & A. flyaround\n\n\u2022 Nestl\u00e9 finally struck a deal to sell its U.S. confectionary business, with Ferrero paying $2.8 billion. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Apple\u2019s Big Plans: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cDerailed Infrastructure\u201d (editorial, Dec. 25): The rail tragedy near Tacoma, Wash., was preventable. Why did it happen?\n\nCongress is the primary culprit. For many decades, it has appropriated billions to develop, implement and operate our air traffic control system, and it has spent even more trying to make an inherently unsafe mode of transportation \u2014 highways \u2014 a little less unsafe. But railways are essentially told to \u201cfix the problem with your own dollars.\u201d\n\nRailroads in Europe began to focus on \u201ccrash avoidance\u201d back in the 1930s, and today most rail systems throughout the world manage to prevent such accidents. In Japan, the high-speed Shinkansen system has operated since 1964 without a single significant-injury accident.\n\nIn the United States, we pay far too little attention to crash avoidance. Congress and the Federal Railroad Administration are responsible. And the media is guilty of failing to educate.", "title": "Opinion | Apportioning Blame for the Amtrak Tragedy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "On a typical Friday in Washington, lawmakers might be returning home, the president might be visiting one of his golf clubs and tour groups might be roaming an otherwise empty Capitol. This week, only the tours went according to plan.\n\nNegotiations between President Trump and members of Congress in both parties over a deal to fund the government while protecting the young undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers fell apart in recent days. The House passed a stopgap spending bill on Thursday with predominantly Republican support to keep the government open for a month, but the Senate needed more than a dozen Democratic votes for it to pass.\n\nJust after midnight Saturday, the government shut down.", "title": "Approaching Shutdown: Scenes From the Capital", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "TUESDAY PUZZLE \u2014 So there I was, on the bus to work the other day \u2014 minding my own business, in my own seat \u2014 when a man boarded and sat down next to me. We exchanged pleasantries (\u201cGood morning, oh yes, very cold today \u2026\u201d) and I turned back to checking my email on my phone.\n\nThose of you who use public transportation probably know what happened next. He closed his eyes, sighed and proceeded to widen what seemed to be his entire being. His shoulders slumped, his arms fell to his sides and his knees fell open. Into my space, so that I was crushed against the frosty window. And since I am both a lady and a delicate flower, I huddled selflessly against that window for the rest of my ride and let the poor man get his beauty rest.\n\nNo, that\u2019s what we\u2019d like to think happened, but we all know me better than that. A series of gradually louder \u201cExcuse me!\u201ds followed, until he had retreated back behind the invisible boundary between seats and dared not expand his knees even an inch farther.\n\nBecause I have no tolerance for MAN SPREADing, which, by way of a segue, would have been a spiffy theme entry in today\u2019s puzzle by Jim Hilger.", "title": "Apt Word to Follow", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "DEARBORN, Mich. \u2014 Nabil Mousa\u2019s first solo art exhibition was a joyous occasion, but it still brought tears to his eyes when he introduced his husband to the audience.\n\nMr. Mousa was born in Syria and immigrated to the United States with his conservative Christian parents. In 2000, when he came out, they soon cut off contact and disowned him.\n\nNow, he was melding his two identities \u2014 gay and Arab \u2014 in a show of paintings here. And what was more surprising was where his work was being displayed: the Arab American National Museum, which was focusing for the first time on a gay artist\u2019s exploration of discrimination.\n\nMr. Mousa, 51, is among a small but growing number of L.G.B.T. artists of Arab descent incorporating their sexual identity into their work. In doing so, they confront their own apprehensions, along with censorship and surveillance in the Arab world, and what educators and curators say is a reluctance by some institutions in the United States to exhibit their work on its artistic rather than political merit.", "title": "Arab and Coming Out in Art That Speaks Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe world will be saved by intelligence and the humanity of generous people, and possibly love,\u201d Miuccia Prada told reporters after her men\u2019s fall/winter 2018 show, held in a Milan warehouse on Sunday. \u201cBut of course the aesthetic helps.\u201d As ever, the designer remained focused on the state of society in her collection. She sent models down the runway in workers\u2019 uniforms and armloads of bags, all in the key of Prada: padded, artfully cut and in the shiny black pocone nylon that first established the designer\u2019s reputation as a contrarian oracle of fashion.\n\nIn the years after Prada took over the luggage-making company her grandfather had founded in 1913, she introduced radical new offerings: a line of clothing, a collection of shoes and then bags recast in the unlikely anti-luxury material of nylon. Eventually her Vela nylon backpack came to define the cerebral, minimalist style of the \u201990s. \u201cI am in love with black nylon,\u201d Prada announced backstage, expressing passion for its \u201cutilitarian tone and industrial aspect.\u201d\n\nIn her latest interpretation of the material, Prada asked the architects Rem Koolhaas and Herzog & de Meuron \u2014 with whom she collaborates regularly \u2014 to design something in nylon for the show, and to select another talent from their field to do the same. They chose, respectively, the German designer Konstantin Grcic and the French designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec. T spoke to each of them about their designs.", "title": "Architects and Designers Reinterpret a Prada Classic: Nylon", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 In October, the WSJ reported that the two companies have a standstill agreement that blocks Glencore from buying Bunge\u2019s stock and from making a hostile bid. The agreement expires in the coming weeks.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nLowe\u2019s will put a veteran activist shareholder on its board.\n\nAmong the three directors that the home retailer is adding is David Batchelder of Relational Investors, who has long prodded for change at companies like Hess.\n\nThe other two incoming directors are:\n\n\u2022 Lisa Wardell of Adtalem Global Education\n\n\u2022 Brian Rogers of T. Rowe Price\n\nBehind the move: D.E. Shaw, which had quietly built up a stake at Lowe\u2019s and planned to call for change at the retailer. The company has long trailed Home Depot in the market for selling hammers, lumber and power tools to homeowners and professional contractors.\n\nHere\u2019s what Robert Niblock, Lowe\u2019s chairman, said of the appointments in a statement:\n\n\u201cWe are pleased to welcome David, Brian and Lisa as new independent directors to the Lowe\u2019s board and especially value the constructive discussions we have had with the D.E. Shaw Group.\u201d\n\nBacking the move is Quentin Koffey of D.E. Shaw, who was part of the team at Elliott Management who scored a victory over Hess five years ago along with Mr. Batchelder. Mr. Koffey moved over to D.E. Shaw last summer\n\nHere\u2019s what he said of today\u2019s announcement:\n\n\u201cLowe\u2019s is an excellent company with tremendous value creation opportunities in front of it, and we believe the new directors will be significant assets to the board. We believe the refreshed board and the management team are committed to achieving outstanding performance and maximizing shareholder value.\u201d\n\nThe activist investor flyaround\n\n\u2022 Elliott Management continued to press Qualcomm into raising its offer for NXP Semiconductor well above $135 a share, which the hedge fund says is NXP\u2019s value on a standalone basis. (Elliott)\n\n\u2022 Carl Icahn wants Xerox, of which he owns a 9.7 percent, to renegotiate a joint venture with Fujifilm. And if the board won\u2019t do it, he wants those directors replaced. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Lex writes of Bill Ackman\u2019s plan to more than double the management stake in his firm\u2019s publicly traded investment vehicle: \u201cA champion of shareholder rights should be beyond reproach in his treatment of his own shareholders. That is not consistent with getting a board waiver to breach a 4.9 percent ownership limit, even if other investors can apply as well.\u201d (Lex)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nIs a sale of Vice less likely in this era?\n\nIn the wake of the #MeToo movement and the media empire\u2019s problems with allegations of misconduct \u2014 most comprehensively chronicled by Emily Steel of the NYT \u2014 some in the industry are speculating that Vice may have a harder time selling itself.\n\nMore from Joe Pompeo of Vanity Fair:\n\nLuckily, Vice secured its latest cash infusion several months before its #MeToo moment. But, with potential buyers like Disney and 21st Century Fox now wrapped up in their own mega-mergers, there\u2019s a sense that a sale has begun to seem like a less likely outcome, at least anytime soon. And despite Smith\u2019s track record of hinting in interviews that a public offering is just around the corner, a person with knowledge of the matter told me there are currently no such plans for 2018. John Chachas, an investment banker who founded the media-focused firm Methuselah Advisors, told me Vice has \u201cbuilt a great offering of content that reaches a highly coveted core audience of young males. But whether the business model appeals to a public institutional investor is a different question\u2014not to mention all the requirements and headaches of being public that don\u2019t matter when you are privately owned.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s working in Vice\u2019s favor\n\n\u2022 The company isn\u2019t as dependent on digital advertising as peers like BuzzFeed.\n\n\u2022 It also has a number of sources of revenue, from its HBO shows to its branded content studio to its subscription service in Asia.\n\n\u2022 And it has a presence in 40 countries.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nThe investor J. D. Vance isn\u2019t going to run for the Senate\n\nMr. Vance, a venture capitalist and the author of \u201cHillbilly Elegy,\u201d had been courted by Republicans as a potential candidate for the Senate. Specifically, to run against Senator Sherrod Brown, the incumbent Democratic senator who\u2019s up for re-election this year.\n\nBut Mr. Vance squelched that talk today:\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nADT\u2019s I.P.O. is failing to impress\n\nThe tale of the tape\n\nWhere ADT hoped to price its stock: $17 to $19 a share\n\nWhere ADT priced its shares: $14 per share\n\nWhere ADT is trading now: About $12.75 a share\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nOverstock jumps on deal speculation\n\nShares of Overstock.com briefly rose 4.5 percent Friday after the NY Post, citing people familiar with the matter, reported Kroger may be eyeing a deal for the e-commerce company.\n\nThe report comes a little more than a month after Patrick Byrne, Overstock\u2019s chief executive, told CNBC that \u201che expects to have a deal in the next three months on selling or reorganizing the company\u2019s retail business to focus on blockchain.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOverstock was recently up 2.6 percent.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nAre the stars aligning for wage growth?\n\nOne of the great mysteries of the recovery is why wage growth has remained lackluster as the labor market has tightened. Average hourly earnings rose just 2.5 percent last year, below the Fed\u2019s target and in line with recent years.\n\nBut there has been some optimism that wage growth might pick up this year because: 1) The unemployment rate should continue to fall; 2) Companies are doling out one-time bonuses and pay raises in response to the new tax law; 3) Several cities and states raised the minimum wage on Jan. 1.\n\nThe economists at BofA Merrill Lynch took a closer look these dynamics, and here\u2019s their take away:\n\n\u201cWage increases by companies and higher state and local minimum wages should provide a slight bump to wage growth in the next few months...Once the initial boost to wage growth fades, we think the trajectory for wage growth should be a function of the degree of tightening in the labor market. The descent in the unemployment rate should be able to boost wages to a high-2% pace by year-end and to 3% by the middle of 2019. The trajectory is still gradual, but clearly higher.\u201d\n\nDo investors care about a government shutdown?\n\nSo far, the markets don\u2019t seem bothered. S. & P. 500 futures were up this morning.\n\nWill that change as the Senate looks deadlocked over the House\u2019s stopgap funding bill? Democrats so far appear united on wanting a permanent shield for the young immigrants known as Dreamers (something C.E.O.s like Tim Cook and Steve Schwarzman support), and Senate Republicans need 60 votes to pass the funding bill.\n\nWhat\u2019s in the House measure: Money to keep the government open for a month, six years\u2019 funding for the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program, and the delay or suspension of several taxes tied to the Affordable Care Act.\n\nDemocrats\u2019 reaction: House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said, \u201cThis is like giving you a bowl of doggy doo, put a cherry on top and call it a chocolate sundae.\u201d\n\nWhy businesses should care: If Democrats force a shutdown and win the escalating political battle, they could have more clout to push back against President Trump\u2019s agenda, including further deregulation of industries. If Republicans win, they could add to legislative momentum from their tax overhaul victory.\n\nThe Washington gossip: How Mr. Trump butted heads with his chief of staff, John Kelly.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow Government Sachs 2.0 fell apart\n\nDina Powell is gone. So is Steve Bannon. Anthony Scaramucci was barely there. And soon, Gary Cohn is expected to leave. What was expected to be a big contingent of Goldman Sachs alumni in the Trump administration is down to, primarily, Steven Mnuchin.\n\nHere\u2019s what Newt Gingrich told Jim Stewart of the NYT:\n\n\u201cEveryone was wondering who would dominate the White House: Steve Bannon or the Manhattan mafia,\u201d Mr. Gingrich told me this week, referring to the Goldman alumni. \u201cIt turns out Donald Trump dominated the White House. Surprise! That should have been obvious to anyone who knows anything about Trump.\u201d\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 The Senate is weighing whether to clamp down on Chinese acquisitions of U.S. tech companies. In an email later circulated among employees and directors, Ting said he was deeply disturbed by what he saw. He told people he called his own father to seek moral counsel.\n\nStill, Mr. Kalanick is doing OK in some respects. He\u2019s officially a billionaire after a consortium led by the SoftBank closed its $9.3 billion investment in Uber yesterday.\n\nSoftBank is already questioning Uber\u2019s direction\n\nA senior executive at the Japanese tech giant, who is set to become an Uber director, is already challenging the ride-hailing giant\u2019s strategy of worldwide domination. It should focus on its core markets in the U.S., Europe, Latin America and Australia, Rajeev Misra told the FT.\n\nMr. Misra insisted that his suggestion wasn\u2019t about cutting losses but about focusing on promising areas for growth. On Twitter, our colleague Mike Isaac had, shall we say, a toughly worded assessment.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat\u2019s next in the race for Amazon\u2019s HQ2\n\nTwenty cities got a rose from Amazon and are advancing to the next stage of the competition for its second headquarters.\n\nWhat New York City, Atlanta, Toronto, Denver and the others can expect, according to Nick Wingfield of the NYT:\n\nThe process will now shift into a new phase, with Amazon representatives communicating more directly with the finalist cities as they prepare to select a winner later this year \u2014 and perhaps with cities being even more outspoken about why they should be chosen. Emissaries from Amazon are expected to visit the finalist locations in person.\n\nSome observations\n\nIt\u2019s notable that three contenders are in the D.C. area. The tax collector regards virtual currencies as property, not money.\n\nPhoto\n\nHow does a business move on after a harassment scandal?\n\nIn the restaurant industry, it\u2019s involved women stepping up. Here\u2019s what Shannon White, the C.O.O. of John Besh\u2019s restaurant group in New Orleans, said of taking over after the eponymous restaurateur left amid scandal:\n\n\u201cIt was like we were in the eye of the hurricane,\u201d she said. She persuaded Mr. Besh and his business partner, Octavio Mantilla, to make her chief executive. \u201cI think it\u2019s a women\u2019s problem, and women have to take the lead,\u201d she said. \u201cA man is not going to understand it.\u201d\n\nMeanwhile, a study by McKinsey & Company found that companies with more diverse executive teams tended to be more profitable than their peers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe creator of the Shitty Media Men list speaks: Moira Donegan said that the conversation about harassment will continue. \u201cI think that every time we get a little louder, and we get a little closer to making the changes that actually need to be made,\u201d she told the NYT in a video interview.\n\nPhoto\n\nWeekend reading: Redfin\u2019s I.P.O. diary\n\nFrom a LinkedIn post by Glenn Kelman, the online real estate brokerage\u2019s C.E.O.:\n\nWe had two SUVs, one carrying two bankers and three or four Redfin folks, one driving behind us empty. I asked our bankers if the empty SUV was carrying spare human organs in case of a medical emergency; they laughed. Maybe it was available as a rolling panic room in case any of us ever needed personal space or private reassurance? We asked many times to have it sent home but its purpose was unfathomable and implacable.\n\nRead the whole thing.
