The gallery had four confirmed sales at the private view, ranging in price from \u00a310,000 to \u00a335,000, according to Ms. Sutton.\n\nFeiler was part of the St. Ives School of artists, based in Cornwall, England, whose works have been popular with modern-minded British art collectors. In November, a similar but smaller abstract by the artist sold for \u00a3125,000 at a London auction, according to the Artnet database. That was the highest auction price achieved for the artist since 2008.\n\n\u201cA lot of people have accumulated money in this country, they want to buy art and they\u2019re drawn to their own national school of artists,\u201d said Robert Upstone, a private dealer, who was visiting the fair. \u201cThey\u2019re undervalued in international terms,\u201d added Mr. Upstone, a former director at the Fine Art Society, a gallery that stopped exhibiting at the London Art Fair in 2010.\n\nBy that time, the Islington fair had lost its reputation for being a place where City of London bankers spent their bonuses, according to Ms. Sutton of Osborne Samuel.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a different market now and bonuses are paid differently,\u201d she said. Ms. Sutton did say, however, that Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, visited her gallery\u2019s booth on Tuesday (he didn\u2019t buy anything).\n\nFor the Modern British market to expand significantly, either a lot more British collectors will have to buy more works \u2014 which looks problematic with Brexit, or Britain\u2019s withdrawal from the European Union, threatening to put a brake on the economy \u2014 or more of the sector\u2019s \u201cundervalued\u201d artists, such as Burra and Feiler, will need to gain wider international recognition. At the moment, such artists are more likely to be siphoned into Impressionist and Modern auctions, as happens with other British artists, like Henry Moore and Barbara Hepworth.", "title": "As Brexit Looms, London\u2019s Art Dealers Cater to Divided Tastes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Mnuchin\u2019s request to raise the debt limit stems from the simple fact that federal spending is far outpacing revenue. The Treasury must borrow money from private investors but needs congressional approval to go above the $20.5 trillion debt limit that caps the United States debt load.\n\nFiscal hawks warn that mounting federal debt will ultimately slow economic growth, but Washington shows no signs of paying heed. Congress is poised to dole out billions of dollars for a host of different priorities, and the spending spree is being embraced across party lines.\n\nMr. Trump and Republicans are pushing for a big increase in military spending, warning that the nation\u2019s security is at stake. The president wants $25 billion for border security, including his promised wall on the border with Mexico. Mr. Mnuchin also said on Tuesday that infrastructure would be an administration priority this year. Mr. Trump has suggested that rebuilding roads and bridges is something that could garner bipartisan support, and White House has signaled that it will seek $200 billion from Congress to jump-start an infrastructure investment program.\n\nOn top of that spending, the party is still celebrating its sweeping overhaul of the tax code, casting aside expectations of how it will impact the national debt.\n\nAfter loudly bemoaning that the tax overhaul would swell the national debt, Democrats are pressing to secure a sizable boost in spending on domestic programs, including billions of dollars to address the opioid crisis. And lawmakers from both parties are looking to approve at least about $80 billion in additional aid in response to last year\u2019s hurricanes and wildfires.\n\n\u201cThe deep dark secret is Republicans like to spend money just as much as Democrats,\u201d said Representative Jim Costa, Democrat of California and a co-chairman of the centrist Blue Dog Coalition. \u201cThey just want to spend it on something different.\u201d\n\nJust last week, lawmakers approved a stopgap spending bill to end a government shutdown and keep agencies funded until Feb. 8 while also extending funding for the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program for six years. But the fine print of the bill also suspended or delayed a handful of taxes imposed by the Affordable Care Act, which will cost the government $31 billion, according to the congressional Joint Committee on Taxation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe deficit is now projected to reach $1 trillion in the 2019 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a fiscal watchdog group.\n\nThat could grow even larger if, as expected, congressional leaders from both parties can reach an agreement to raise strict caps on military and domestic spending that were imposed in 2011.\n\nRepublicans are pushing for a big increase to the cap on military spending, while Democrats are insisting on an equal increase in nonmilitary spending. All told, lawmakers could reach a two-year agreement to raise the spending caps by more than $200 billion over that period.\n\nFor Democrats, the firm posture in spending talks does not perfectly harmonize with their outcry during the battle over the Republican tax overhaul. Senator Roy Blunt of Missouri, a member of the Senate Republican leadership, recalled that just recently, during the fight over taxes, Democrats were \u201cabsolutely outraged at what potential deficit impact there might be.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAnd then we immediately get into a tens and hundreds of billion dollars of discussion about how we now raise the spending caps,\u201d Mr. Blunt said. \u201cSo I think there\u2019s plenty of inconsistency.\u201d\n\nWith the tax overhaul now law and with lawmakers pushing to increase spending, fiscal watchdogs have been left reeling.\n\n\u201cEven just to keep the government open for a few weeks, for some reason it was necessary to add to our debt,\u201d said Michael A. Peterson, the president and chief executive of the Peter G. Peterson Foundation, which advocates reining in federal budget deficits.\n\nThe tax overhaul approved in December \u201cclearly dug the hole deeper,\u201d Mr. Peterson said. The bill is projected to add $1.5 trillion to the deficit over a decade, or about $1.1 trillion if the effects of economic growth and interest rates are taken into account, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation.\n\nMr. Mnuchin dismissed that idea on Tuesday, reiterating his position that if economic growth can be sustained at an annual rate of 3 percent, the tax cuts will pay for themselves. (Macroeconomic Advisers, an economic forecasting firm, expects growth in the first three months of 2018 to fall to 2.3 percent.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile Democrats tried to draw attention to how the tax cuts would worsen the government\u2019s finances, few Republicans expressed similar concerns. One who did, Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee, vowed to oppose the tax rewrite if it added \u201cone penny\u201d to the deficit, but even he ended up voting for it.\n\nAt the hearing on Tuesday, Mr. Corker praised the tax bill for bringing better results than he expected, noting that the International Monetary Fund had raised its global economic growth projections in response to the tax cuts.\n\n\u201cIt seems to be having an impact far beyond what we thought it would have just on our own country,\u201d Mr. Corker said.\n\nIn conversations about the deficit, Republican lawmakers are quick to talk about the need to rein in the cost of entitlement programs, such as Social Security and Medicare, which make up a big portion of federal spending. But there is little expectation that Congress will take any significant action in those areas any time soon.\n\n\u201cThis is out of control,\u201d complained Senator David Perdue, Republican of Georgia, as he lamented that lawmakers were set to approve disaster aid without finding a way to pay for it.\n\n\u201cEvery dime that we\u2019re talking about for disaster relief is borrowed,\u201d Mr. Perdue said. \u201cWe have to go to China and borrow that money to give disaster relief to farmers in Texas and people in Florida.\u201d\n\nAt the Senate hearing on Tuesday, Mr. Mnuchin said that Mr. Trump has been focused on initiatives that will spur economic growth as a way of generating additional revenue for the government.\n\n\u201cHis first priority was to create economic growth,\u201d Mr. Mnuchin said. \u201cThat\u2019s the single most important thing that will create revenues.\u201d\n\nSome Republicans are not so sure.\n\n\u201cAt some point we\u2019re going to have to change the name of the Department of Treasury to the Department of Debt, because there\u2019s not going to be any treasury left,\u201d said Senator John Kennedy, Republican of Louisiana. \u201cIt would seem to me that we need to have an adult discussion at some point about how we\u2019re going to get control of that.\u201d", "title": "As Deficit Soars Toward $1 Trillion, Congress Shrugs and Keeps Spending", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport", "Thomas Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe right timing of this debate is really now because the U.S. economy has fully recovered from this recession,\u201d Mr. Williams said.\n\nPatrick Harker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, told attendees at the economics gathering in Philadelphia that there was an urgent need for more and better research on the available alternatives.\n\n\u201cThe most important issue on the table right now is that we need to consider the possibility of a new economic normal that forces us to re-evaluate our targets,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is a question for the profession itself, and we do need people thinking about this.\u201d\n\nThe Fed\u2019s current approach is known as inflation targeting. It works in large part by training the public to expect a certain level of inflation, disciplining the pricing decisions of businesses and the wage demands of workers. It is, in other words, a self-fulfilling prophecy.\n\nThe Fed announced in January 2012 that it would seek to keep inflation at a 2 percent annual pace, formalizing its implicit target since the mid-1990s.\n\nThe rise of inflation targeting reflected a consensus among academics and policymakers that central banks did not have direct control over broader economic performance but did exercise direct control over inflation, and that keeping inflation low and stable was the best way to support growth.\n\nMost central banks in developed nations similarly target a low rate of inflation, taking the view that unpredictable increases in prices are economically disruptive. The European Central Bank, for example, aims to keep inflation \u201cbelow, but close to\u201d 2 percent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the Fed\u2019s focus on inflation in the real economy did not prevent asset prices like mortgage-backed bonds from soaring to unsustainable heights before 2008, and concern about keeping inflation low limited the scope of its post-crisis stimulus campaign.\n\nMoreover, the combination of low inflation and modest growth has left the Fed with very little room to respond to future downturns by reducing interest rates. During past downturns, the Fed lowered rates by an average of five percentage points. But the Fed\u2019s benchmark rate currently sits in a range between 1.25 percent and 1.5 percent. That would make cutting the rate a less effective tool than in previous firefights.\n\nJanet L. Yellen, the Fed\u2019s outgoing chairwoman, has emphasized that the Fed has other weapons in its arsenal. After 2008, the Fed bought large quantities of Treasuries and mortgage bonds and promised to keep interest rates low for years at a time, encouraging borrowing by businesses and consumers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Yellen is expected to be succeeded by Jerome H. Powell, a Fed governor who is awaiting Senate confirmation as the next Fed chairman.\n\nSome outside economists say the Fed is putting a brave face on a bad situation.\n\n\u201cWe are living in a singularly brittle context in which we do not have a basis for assuming that monetary policy will be able as rapidly as possible to lift us out of the next recession,\u201d said Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard economist and former Treasury secretary.\n\nThe proposed alternatives to inflation targeting can be sorted into two categories. The first contains one simple idea: The Fed should permanently embrace higher inflation. The second is full of complicated ideas for temporarily embracing higher inflation during downturns.\n\nOlivier Blanchard, a fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics who began his term as president of the American Economic Association at the Philadelphia meeting, said the choice of a 2 percent target had no particular economic logic to recommend it. Raising the target to 4 percent would give the Fed more room to operate without significantly larger economic costs, he said.\n\nMany economists, however, are wary of the simple solution.\n\nBen S. Bernanke, the former Fed chairman, has warned that the costs of dropping a new anchor would be significant. On Monday, at a Brookings Institution conference convened to discuss alternatives to the 2 percent target, Mr. Bernanke dismissed a 4 percent target as politically untenable.\n\n\u201cThe Fed is not going to adopt a 4 percent inflation target,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s just not going to happen.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Bernanke has added his name to the list of those seeking an alternative to the current system. Last year, he proposed that the Fed should announce that it would temporarily tolerate higher inflation during future economic recoveries.\n\nA mechanized version of that idea, popular in some academic circles, would instruct the Fed to target an alternative economic measure, nominal gross domestic product, or N.G.D.P., which sums inflation and real economic growth. Under a 4 percent N.G.D.P. target, for example, the Fed would aim for a combination of inflation and growth that equaled 4 percent, such as 2 percent inflation and 2 percent growth. During a period of lower inflation, like the last decade, such a target would require the Fed to dictate more aggressive stimulus.\n\nSome are skeptical that the Fed can improve the economy by trying harder. Atif Mian, an economist at Princeton University, has argued in his research that high levels of household debt are limiting the impact of monetary policy because many households cannot or will not continue borrow.\n\n\u201cThere is this implicit assumption that things will have traction if you just push hard enough,\u201d Mr. Mian said. \u201cBut what is the mechanism through which this will raise actual G.D.P.?\u201d\n\nIndeed, the Fed and other central banks have not even succeeded in hitting their 2 percent targets in recent years, for reasons that remain unclear. Inflation in the United States has been below that level for the last six years, although most Fed policymakers continue to predict that higher inflation is around the corner.\n\nMs. Romer said more ambitious targets might encourage central banks to try harder to stimulate inflation.\n\nIn practice, she said, the Fed could have purchased more Treasuries and mortgage bonds as part of its response to the crisis, or even engaged in direct lending to businesses.\n\n\u201cWe should not just assume that what we\u2019ve done for the last 25 years is right,\u201d she said.", "title": "As Economy Strengthens, Fed Ponders New Approach", "authors": ["Binyamin Appelbaum"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The Japanese government has made managing the shift to next-generation vehicles a priority, but critics say its approach lacks focus. It has bet big on hydrogen fuel cells, an alternative technology to plug-in rechargeable batteries that is struggling to win widespread support.\n\nThe fear is that once again, Japan will miss a big technological shift.\n\nIn the consumer electronics sector, the transition to new products like flat-screen televisions and digital music players undermined once-ubiquitous Japanese brands. Innovation in the digital era became the domain of Silicon Valley, while mass production shifted to China.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs a result, some storied names in the world of technology \u2014 Sharp, Toshiba, Sanyo \u2014 have disappeared or no longer resonate with the world\u2019s consumers the way they once did.\n\n\u201cWhat really puts Japan on the defensive is the idea that the tech revolution is coming to the car industry,\u201d said James Kondo, a visiting professor at Hitotsubashi University in Tokyo who has worked with technology companies in the United States and Japan.\n\n\u201cThe industry is at the center of everything, not just economically but psychologically, and it\u2019s facing fundamental change,\u201d he added.\n\nCars that don\u2019t burn gasoline or diesel account for a tiny sliver of the world market today, but their prospects are looking brighter.\n\nBatteries are becoming more powerful even as their prices tumble. China, the world\u2019s biggest automobile market, is betting big on electric cars. France and Britain have announced they will phase out fossil-fuel-burning vehicles in an effort to fight climate change.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the annual Tokyo Motor Show this autumn, some of Japan\u2019s biggest carmakers sought to dispel concerns that they had underinvested in electric vehicles.\n\nToyota and Honda prominently displayed new electric prototypes. Previously, they had expressed doubt that cars relying entirely on rechargeable batteries would prove reliable enough, or able to travel far enough, that consumers would embrace them.\n\nPhoto\n\nTheir focus has instead been on developing cars that extract energy from onboard hydrogen fuel cells. Enthusiasm for that technology has faded in other countries, in part because it would require huge and expensive new infrastructure for delivering hydrogen to drivers.\n\nJapan is becoming an increasingly isolated hydrogen booster.\n\nToyota displayed a new fuel-cell prototype at the show alongside its plug-in model. And the government remains committed to pouring money into transformative \u201chydrogen society\u201d projects, with plans to build 320 hydrogen stations for cars by 2025.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe trend toward electric vehicles is growing, and sales are increasing, but we can\u2019t suddenly jump to E.V.s,\u201d Hiroshige Seko, Japan\u2019s industry minister, said in September, defending the government\u2019s commitment to hydrogen.\n\nNot all of Japan\u2019s carmakers have been avoiding electric vehicles. Nissan was an early advocate of battery-only cars, introducing its Leaf all-electric model in 2010.\n\nOther automakers are now starting to branch out more widely. This month, Toyota announced a battery-development partnership with Panasonic, which supplies lithium-ion batteries to Tesla, the upstart American maker of electric cars. Toyota said it would introduce 10 new electric models by the early 2020s, with the aim of selling one million all-electric vehicles a year by 2030.\n\nThe Toyota-Panasonic tie-up shows how some nontraditional auto suppliers in Japan stand to gain from the shift to electric. Panasonic, which lost billions of dollars over the last decade as its television business shriveled, has turned auto parts into its fastest-growing division, selling sensors and cockpit consoles as well as batteries.\n\nSome in the industry, pointing to Tesla\u2019s problems in expanding production, say big companies like Toyota are ultimately better positioned to take electric vehicles to the mass market.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut the rapid shifts in the landscape have unnerved many in the industry. Like the phones and televisions of today, the cars of tomorrow may be distinguished less by how solidly they are built than by the software that runs them, and how cleverly they are designed and marketed. Already, Apple and Google \u2014 technology companies with a knack for giving people what they want \u2014 are exploring getting into the auto industry.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn the future, mobility won\u2019t belong only to carmakers,\u201d Akio Toyoda, Toyota\u2019s chief executive, said last year.\n\nMr. Nakatsuka, the Jatco chief executive, understands the danger as well as anyone. His company is pushing a simplified transmission system that he says could be installed in electric vehicles to reduce stress on their motors and batteries.\n\nBut he says Jatco\u2019s best hope is that takeup of electric vehicles will be slow.\n\n\u201cCountries are moving very fast, and carmakers are moving faster, too, but consumers are still not convinced,\u201d he said, citing unresolved questions about electric vehicles\u2019 range, safety and durability.\n\nFor now, Jatco, which is jointly owned by Nissan, Mitsubishi and Suzuki, is focused on nearer-term threats, like Japan\u2019s worsening labor shortage and price competition from rivals.\n\nIt is automating its factories as fast as it can. Transmissions contain about 400 separate parts, which must be precisely assembled, and their production is hard to leave to robots. But Jatco says its next assembly line will be 70 percent automated, up from 40 percent for its most recently completed line.\n\nEventually, it wants robots to do 100 percent of the work \u2014 meaning that by the time electric cars turn transmissions into museum pieces, there may be few human jobs left to lose.\n\nMr. Nakatsuka said he did not expect transmission-less, battery-powered cars to take a big chunk of the market until at least 2030.\n\n\u201cAfter that,\u201d he said, \u201cI\u2019ll be retired.\u201d", "title": "As Electric Cars\u2019 Prospects Brighten, Japan Fears Being Left Behind", "authors": ["Jonathan Soble"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "She offered her account during the second day of testimony in the trial of Mr. Percoco, once one of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s closest friends and advisers before he left the governor\u2019s office in January 2016, several months before the search of his house.\n\nIn September 2016, Mr. Percoco was charged in a wide-ranging corruption case that included two overlapping schemes that involved bribery and fraud. He and three co-defendants went on trial this week; a second trial is scheduled in June.\n\nMr. Percoco, the former executive deputy secretary to Mr. Cuomo, has been accused of taking more than $300,000 in bribes in return for official actions on behalf of an energy company and a developer seeking lucrative deals with the state. Prosecutors have charged that the bulk of the bribe money was funneled by one of the companies to Mr. Percoco through a \u201clow-show\u201d job for his wife, who has not been charged.\n\nProsecutors have not accused the governor, a Democrat, of any wrongdoing, and Mr. Cuomo\u2019s office has declined to comment. When the charges were announced, Mr. Cuomo publicly distanced himself from Mr. Percoco, saying he had \u201czero tolerance for abuse of the public trust from anyone,\u201d and \u201cif anything, a friend should be held to an even higher standard.\u201d\n\nYet, in the government\u2019s opening statements on Tuesday, it became clear that Mr. Cuomo would loom large over the trial because of his longstanding relationship with Mr. Percoco.", "title": "As F.B.I. Closed In, Joseph Percoco Called an Ally: Gov. Cuomo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Facebook makes most of its money from online ads \u2014 posting a net profit of $10.2 billion in 2016 \u2014 and has made it clear that it believes its future lies in video and video ads. Wall Street analysts regularly ask the company about its progress in attracting the hefty ad budgets that remain locked up in television despite cord cutting and the emergence of streaming platforms.\n\nStill, Facebook\u2019s video tab, Watch, which was introduced in August, has been met with some skepticism.\n\n\u201cOne of the things that Facebook has done here that it hasn\u2019t necessarily done so much in the past is they let the ad model lead the consumer behavior versus the other way around,\u201d said Sarah Hofstetter, the chief executive of the agency 360i. \u201cWatch was built with the premise that ad dollars were coming to video and it would be smart for Facebook to have a video platform.\u201d\n\nMs. Hofstetter noted that Watch could potentially benefit if publishers that had relied heavily on Facebook traffic started making fewer videos now. \u201cThis, in turn,\u201d she said, \u201ccould lead to less inventory and push advertisers towards the more premium videos within Facebook Watch.\u201d\n\nPublishers could also respond by migrating their videos to Watch, where Facebook could sell more of the pre-roll ads with sound that run before YouTube videos, said Ben Hovaness, executive director of digital activation at Omnicom\u2019s Hearts & Science agency.\n\n\u201cYou can think of the Watch tab as Facebook trying to have its own YouTube inside of it,\u201d he added.\n\nRight now, said Mike Dossett, who leads digital strategy at the agency RPA, most Facebook video ads \u201cshow up as a sponsored video from a brand like any other post in your feed.\u201d\n\nMr. Dossett said he anticipated a broader transformation of what appeared on Facebook as the company focused on videos that inspired the active participation of its users, like live sports.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s interesting to see what that might turn into for the type of content Facebook is buying,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s going to pretty radically shift the type of video that is populating the platform.\u201d", "title": "As Facebook Changes Its Feed, Advertisers See Video Ambitions", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "And since President Trump was elected, college administrators say, his rhetoric and more restrictive views on immigration have made the United States even less attractive to international students. The Trump administration is more closely scrutinizing visa applications, indefinitely banning travel from some countries and making it harder for foreign students to remain in the United States after graduation.\n\nWhile government officials describe these as necessary national security measures, a number of American colleges have been casualties of the policies.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAs you lose those students, then the tuition revenue is negatively impacted as well,\u201d said Michael Godard, the interim provost at the University of Central Missouri, where 944 international students were enrolled in the fall, a decline of more than 1,500 from the previous year. \u201cWe\u2019ve had to make some decisions, budgetary decisions, to adjust.\u201d\n\nInternational students pay double the $6,445 tuition of Missouri residents, and the lost revenue amounts to $14 million, according to Roger Best, the chief operating officer for the school, in Warrensburg, Mo. Dr. Best said that the university has been forced to cut instructors in computer programs, where many of the foreign students were enrolled, as well as defer maintenance and shave money from other departments, such as the campus newspaper.\n\nNationwide, the number of new foreign students declined an average of 7 percent this past fall, according to preliminary figures from a survey of 500 colleges by the Institute of International Education. Nearly half of the campuses surveyed reported declines.\n\nNow that the revenue stream appears to be diminishing, the financial outlook may be dire enough to weigh down the bond ratings of some schools, making it more expensive for them to borrow money, according to Moody\u2019s Investors Service. Last month, Moody\u2019s changed its credit outlook for higher education to \u201cnegative\u201d from \u201cstable.\u201d\n\n\u201cGrowing uncertainty for international student enrollment stems from immigration policies that are in flux,\u201d Moody\u2019s said, warning that universities without global brand recognition would be hit hardest. While some flagship public and elite private colleges have been affected, the Institute of International Education said, the biggest impact will be felt by second-tier institutions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe shift comes just as some states also are experiencing a drop in domestic students, partly the result of a decline in birthrates two decades ago. This year, the number of domestic undergraduate students dropped 224,000, or 1 percent, according to the National Student Clearinghouse Research Center.\n\nAn increasingly diverse population in that age group means that more of the students come from low-income families in which no one has ever gone to college, also presenting recruitment challenges for universities, according to Doug Shapiro, the organization\u2019s executive research director. \u201cAffordability issues are the biggest hurdles,\u201d Mr. Shapiro said. \u201cThere\u2019s only so much you can do with recruiting if the families can\u2019t afford the tuition.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOfficials at Kansas State University in Manhattan, Kan., reported an overall enrollment decline of more than 900 students, including 159 fewer international students. One official cited a \u201cperfect demographic storm.\u201d Budget cuts are underway.\n\nFaced with a demand from the university that it trim its budget, faculty in the school\u2019s modern languages department picked Italian as the language to cut, a decision that will save the university the salary of its only Italian professor, which one faculty member said was about $47,000. A final decision is still pending.\n\n\u201cThis definitely undermines that idea of diversity many U.S. universities proclaim to promote across the country,\u201d said Alessia Salamina, the professor whose job is in jeopardy. \u201cThis is in fact a national emergency, not only a K-State one.\u201d\n\nAccording to the institute\u2019s survey, enrollment is falling from a broad range of countries, including China and India, the two biggest sources of students. Among countries covered by Mr. Trump\u2019s travel ban, Iran is the largest, though it can still send students to the United States.\n\nBut many administrators believe the president\u2019s views on immigration have made applying to United States colleges more of a gamble today. Officials said that other reasons for the decline in enrollment include increased competition from schools in other countries, cuts in scholarship programs in Saudi Arabia and Brazil, and a currency crisis in India caused when the government decided to swap widely used notes for new bills.\n\nFor years, American colleges had been staking their futures on continued growth in foreign students, and after the recession a decade ago, those students were a lifeline for colleges that had poured money into new buildings and amenities. In just the past six months, the University of Akron opened an international center in an existing building and hired 10 employees to work in international programming. The president, Matthew Wilson, said that students from India were reporting increased scrutiny of their visa applications, one of the reasons for a drop of about 200 international students.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEven a marketing campaign featuring Akron\u2019s favorite son, LeBron James, who is wildly popular in China, hasn\u2019t been enough to stave off declines.\n\nBut Mr. Wilson said he remained optimistic. \u201cInternational isn\u2019t something where I\u2019m thinking this is going to result in budgetary cutbacks,\u201d he said. \u201cSome folks are scaling back. We\u2019re actually scaling up.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAkron is one of several public universities in Ohio reporting drops in enrollment, including of international students.\n\nAt Wright State, near Dayton, the cuts have been deep and broad. Moody\u2019s has already downgraded Wright State three notches, citing among other factors a notable drop in international enrollment, nearly 800 students over two years.\n\nWright State has decided to eliminate Italian, Russian and Japanese, part of more than $30 million in budget cuts.\n\nThe swimming team will cease to exist this spring, even after five of its members recently competed at the U.S.A. Winter Nationals. The team\u2019s elimination prompted at least two members to decide to leave the university, according to Trevor Keriazes, who specializes in the breaststroke.\n\nOther cuts included the full-time French horn and tuba professors, both one year short of tenure protection.\n\nThe school had asked both to remain as adjunct professors with reduced pay. Instead, they landed other jobs, and adjuncts have taken their positions at Wright State.\n\n\u201cIt was a contentious thing for a lot of people,\u201d said Jonas F. Thoms, who had developed a vibrant French horn studio at Wright State, and recently joined West Virginia University. The trumpet and trombone still have full-time professors, but with the loss of the horn and tuba jobs, Mr. Thoms said, \u201cthey cut half of the brass faculty.\u201d", "title": "As Flow of Foreign Students Wanes, U.S. Universities Feel the Sting", "authors": ["Stephanie Saul"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Hayley Fisher, a senior lecturer at the University of Sydney, said pent-up demand will result in a \u201cpop of weddings\u201d over the next few years. But while it was too early to tell, Dr. Fisher cautioned that the long-term economic effects are likely to be modest.\n\n\u201cThere is going to be a whole new market, but there will be a stabilization,\u201d she said.\n\nMany suppliers in the wedding industry have proactively begun changing their marketing strategies. Some, like Katsu Nojiri, who photographed Thursday\u2019s wedding, are experimenting for the first time with Google ads.\n\nOthers, like Raphael Kahn, managing director of Zest, which hosts 120 weddings annually at two venues, have begun advertising in same-sex friendly wedding directories.\n\n\u201cIt definitely is good for the industry, and we certainly want to be there when it all happens,\u201d Mr. Kahn said.\n\nBusiness listing sites supportive of same-sex marriages say they have seen a burst of suppliers wanting to be included. Alexander Ross, the founder of the wedding guide Mr. Theodore, estimated a 200 percent increase in inquiries for listing requests since November.\n\n\u201cAustralia\u2019s not going to see weddings the way we\u2019ve seen weddings in the past,\u201d Mr. Ross said. \u201cThat traditional structure is evolving.\u201d\n\nThose changes are affecting all aspects of the industry. What has two thumbs and created ISIS? This guy.\u201d\n\nReviewing a chart that showed the decline of the stock market during Mr. Bush\u2019s presidency, Mr. Ferrell said, \u201cI\u2019m no economer, but even I know, that was no bueno.\u201d Going on to compare vice presidents, he added: \u201cSome say Mike Pence is heartless. But remember, Dick Cheney was literally heartless. At this point, it\u2019s just Legos in there.\u201d\n\nAnd if Mr. Trump thinks the news media is tough on him, Mr. Ferrell reminded viewers that an Iraqi reporter had once thrown a pair of shoes at Mr. Bush.\n\n\u201cBut you know what they say: \u2018Shoe me once, the shoe\u2019s on you,\u2019\u201d Mr. Ferrell said. \u201c\u2018Shoe me twice, I\u2019m keeping those shoes.\u2019\u201d\n\nReassuring viewers that he was \u201cnot a Trump synthesizer or anything,\u201d Mr. Ferrell noted that Presidents Bush and Trump had \u201ca lot in common.\u201d They are the same age, for example, and they both won presidential elections while losing the popular vote.\n\n\u201cThough, back in my day, we didn\u2019t let Russians rig our elections,\u201d he added. \u201cWe used the Supreme Court, like Americans.\u201d\n\nIn other memorable moments from this episode:\n\n\u2018Weekend Update\u2019 Riffs of the Week\n\n\u201cWeekend Update\u201d carried most of the weight this week when it came to topical, headline-driven humor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOn Monday, Chuck Schumer saw his shadow, which means we have three more weeks of government,\u201d Colin Jost, the \u201cWeekend Update\u201d co-anchor, said of the deal to end a three-day government shutdown.\n\nThe deal keeps the government operating through Feb. 8, Mr. Jost said, meaning Mr. Trump, Mr. Schumer and his Republican counterpart, Senator Mitch McConnell, \u201chave 12 days left to solve all of immigration.\u201d\n\nMr. Jost continued, referencing legislation to protect young undocumented immigrants from deportation:\n\nI\u2019m not that confident. I wouldn\u2019t even trust them to get out of an escape room in 12 days. Also, Schumer only agreed to this temporary deal because Mitch McConnell promised to finally address the issue of DACA. But trusting Mitch McConnell to keep a promise is like trusting Stevie Wonder to perform a bris.\n\nMr. Jost\u2019s co-anchor, Michael Che, addressed a conspiracy theory advanced and then played down by Senate Republicans about a so-called secret society within the F.B.I. said to be plotting against Mr. Trump:\n\nRepublicans have begun blaming a secret society within the F.B.I. for undermining the Trump presidency. And you know what? I believe it. That\u2019s why hating on Donald Trump is so frustrating for me. Because he constantly reaffirms all of my black paranoia. Just when I think he\u2019s insane, he\u2019ll say something that makes perfect sense, like \u2018The media\u2019s lying, the F.B.I.\u2019s trying to do me like they did Tupac.\u2019 And I\u2019m like, \u2018They did kill Tupac, didn\u2019t they?\u2019\n\n#MeToo Sketch of the Week No. 1\n\nMr. Ferrell appears as one of the spokesmen for Next, \u201cthe only antiperspirant for men who are feeling the heat because their #TimesUp\u201d \u2014 a reference to an anti-harassment campaign led by women in Hollywood.\n\nMaking his way through the office, where he is about to be fired for some kind of sexual misconduct, Mr. Ferrell explains: \u201cI work hard. I play hard. And something\u2019s coming out about me real soon. Because I\u2019m \u2026 Next.\u201d\n\n#MeToo Sketch of the Week No. 2\n\nThree couples (played by Mr. Ferrell and Kate McKinnon, Aidy Bryant and Kenan Thompson, and Heidi Gardner and Beck Bennett) find that their meal comes to a crashing halt when they attempt to discuss an unspecified New York Times Op-Ed about Aziz Ansari, the comedian and actor who has been accused of sexual misconduct by a woman who went on a date with him.\n\nIt is hardly an easy topic in which to find humor, but \u201cS.N.L.\u201d seemed to find the right tone by focusing on the awkwardness of the dinner guests, which escalates to absurd proportions. \u201cCan\u2019t we just go back to the dog?\u201d Mr. Ferrell pleads. \u201cWe were happy when we were talking about the dog!\u201d\n\n#MeToo Sketch of the Week No. 3\n\nIn the final segment of the night, Mr. Ferrell played Chucky Lee Byrd, a Jerry Lee Lewis-style pop singer of a bygone era (though perhaps not as bygone as one might think). To the increasing chagrin of a TV pitchwoman played by Ms. McKinnon, all of his songs \u2014 \u201cCruisin\u2019 in My Windowless Van,\u201d \u201cGirl Scout Cookie,\u201d \u201cI Left My Heart Across State Lines\u201d \u2014 appear to be about dating underage girls.\n\nInternet Culture Callback of the Week\n\nIf you were left slightly puzzled by the sketch in which Mr. Ferrell and Ms. McKinnon played a silver-haired couple who struggle to correctly say the catchphrase in an advertisement for chicken potpies (\u201cbaked in a crispy pastry crust\u201d), allow us to explain: It\u2019s a parody of this viral video from a few years back, in which a real-life husband and wife, Jack and Sonja Palmer, could not quite say that the potpies being advertised were \u201cbaked in a buttery flaky crust.\u201d\n\nNot to worry: The Palmers became internet celebrities and, according to anecdotal reports from social media, their mere presence is enough to leave people awe-struck.", "title": "As George W. Bush on \u2018S.N.L.,\u2019 Will Ferrell Wants to Remind You: \u2018I Was Really Bad\u2019", "authors": ["Dave Itzkoff"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Then there is the matter of the investigations into possible collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign. What began as a bipartisan effort to get to the bottom of Russia\u2019s brazen meddling in the 2016 presidential election has devolved in recent weeks into partisan warfare, particularly in the House. House Republicans on the Intelligence Committee have assembled a memo said to accuse officials from the F.B.I. and the Justice Department of improperly spying on a Trump campaign adviser. Democrats are crying foul play, and even the Justice Department is warning that a Republican push to declassify the memo could dangerously compromise American intelligence.\n\nOne of the year\u2019s most crucial questions is shaping up to be whether Republican control of Congress can withstand all this dysfunction, or whether it will lead to a sweeping realignment of power in the midterm elections in November. The outcome will undoubtedly shape the second half of Mr. Trump\u2019s term.\n\n\u201cWhat we find in every state in the country is that people want Congress to hold the Trump administration accountable,\u201d said Senator Chris Van Hollen, Democrat of Maryland, who leads the committee charged with electing Democrats to the Senate. He added, \u201cCongress has been totally AWOL.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFor Democrats, the dysfunction has made the quest to regain power more urgent. They argue that outside of a few moments of independence \u2014 the passage last summer of a Russia sanctions bill opposed by Mr. Trump, for example, and statements by a few Republican senators like Jeff Flake of Arizona and Bob Corker of Tennessee \u2014 Republicans have shown themselves unwilling to challenge Mr. Trump and his administration.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAmong the gravest disappointments of this year was not finding out how awful a president Donald Trump has turned out to be, but rather how docile the Congress has been,\u201d said Representative Adam Schiff of California, the top Democrat on the Intelligence Committee. \u201cThe most important thing people can do right now who are concerned about the direction of the Congress is change the majority in Congress. That\u2019s the single most important thing we can do right now for the health of the democracy.\u201d\n\nRepublicans fiercely contest Democrats\u2019 assessment. They take pride in having passed a tax overhaul written by lawmakers \u2014 as opposed to the White House \u2014 and say they have continued to investigate the election meddling despite Mr. Trump\u2019s clear opposition. There is nothing wrong, they argue, with Republicans\u2019 advancing an agenda they share with the White House and have long waited to enact.\n\n\u201cIf we were really in the tank for Trump, we wouldn\u2019t even be doing this investigation,\u201d said Representative Tom Rooney, Republican of Florida, who is helping to lead the Intelligence Committee\u2019s Russia-related work. \u201cIt would have been much easier not to.\u201d\n\nFor the moment, Congress simply needs to show it can perform its most basic function: controlling the government\u2019s purse. The fiscal year began on Oct. 1, but for four months, the government has been functioning on short-term stopgap spending bills that provide no reordering or new direction to government programs.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s nothing more basic than the power of the purse, and there\u2019s no more systemic failure than what we\u2019ve had for years: not to exercise that power in an orderly and prescribed way,\u201d Mr. Price, the North Carolina Democrat, said.", "title": "As Gridlock Deepens in Congress, Only Gloom Is Bipartisan", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg", "Nicholas Fandos"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "More police officers have been sent into the New York City subway to address the large number of homeless people sleeping on trains during cold winter nights, the police said.\n\nThe officers\u2019 objective is to offer services to the homeless people, from shelter to hospitalization, but their task is a daunting one. In the wee hours of Sunday morning, officers entered an E train while it was held at the last stop, World Trade Center. There were 70 homeless people aboard.\n\nThe increase in police officers followed a report last week in The New York Times that found dozens of homeless people taking refuge on trains, particularly the E, which for decades has been the line most-used by the homeless because it is subterranean for its entire ride, keeping it warm at night.\n\n\u201cThere have been dozens and dozens of additional officers added to the subway to ensure the safety of our transit system as well as to help with outreach to the homeless \u2014 particularly in the overnight hours,\u201d said J. Peter Donald, the assistant commissioner in the Police Department\u2019s public relations office.", "title": "As Homeless Take Refuge in Subway, More Officers Are Sent to Help", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "There have been some gatherings, but relatively few and drawing only a few hundred at a time, a lack of interest that has confounded many residents. About 500 people have been arrested in Tehran, a figure that pales in comparison to 2009.\n\nTo some extent, some say, the difference may reflect a divide between Iran\u2019s urban and rural populations, with more sophisticated city dwellers dismissing the leaderless provincial protests as too violent and undisciplined.\n\nOthers see the chaos and violence in nearby Syria, and worry about what could happen if Iran suffered a similar breakdown in authority. Still others, having gone through the 2009 protests and the brutal repression that finally contained the uprising, say they are willing to work patiently to wring economic and political concessions from the clerical government.\n\nIn a series of interviews, Tehran residents said they were just as upset as anyone else over the country\u2019s widespread corruption, high unemployment and lack of freedoms, but most also said they did not know anyone who had joined a protest in recent days.\n\n\u201cMaybe it\u2019s the presence of security forces,\u201d said Farhad, a 33-year cybersecurity expert who refused to give his surname for fear of reprisals by the authorities. \u201cOr maybe Tehranis are just not interested.\u201d\n\nIn 2009 they were interested. Millions marched in protest against the state, holding up green ribbons and posters asking, \u201cWhere is my vote?\u201d Young people, women and intellectuals were all furious over President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad\u2019s re-election, which they said was fraudulent. Led initially by two defeated opposition presidential candidates, Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi, they took to the streets, facing heavily armed security forces.\n\nThe protests rocked the Islamic republic to its core. Around 150 people were killed, thousands were arrested, and intellectuals, journalists and politicians were tried in Stalinist-type mass proceedings, many of them forced to make humiliating public confessions of wrongdoing. Two protesters were executed.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn those days, Ali Sabzevari, now 33, joined every protest. \u201cWe were fighting for our rights and our future, but we had structure and a plan,\u201d he said. But this time around, older, a bit heavier and wiser, he said the protests held no attraction for him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThose people do not know what they want. They have no clear idea, and I don\u2019t like their slogans,\u201d he said. \u201cI want our society to open up, more democracy, but I don\u2019t see how violent protests will achieve that.\u201d\n\nOthers shared that view, and worried about playing into the hands of widely detested Western leaders like President Trump and Israel\u2019s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. \u201cThese people definitely have the right to protest,\u201d Shervin Bashari, 32, said of the Iranian demonstrators, \u201cbut I do not want to join something and have Trump and Nethanyahu exploit it for their own purposes.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Trump has posted several Twitter messages supporting the protesters, saying the United States will come to their aid at the right time.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t want to support chaos either,\u201d said Mr. Bashari, who sells imported heating equipment. \u201cProtest should be peaceful and with minimal costs. Now 21 people, including two children, have died, and for what?\u201d\n\nThe Green Movement and the security clampdown that followed left a deep scar on all those involved. Many protest leaders spent years in jail under harsh conditions, and Tehran endured a heavy police presence.\n\nIn 2011, the leaders of the protest \u2014 Mr. Moussavi, his wife, Zahra Rahnavard, and Mr. Karroubi \u2014 were placed under house arrest without a trial. They have remained there since, and have only recently been allowed to receive selected visitors.\n\nThe election of a moderate president, Hassan Rouhani, in 2013, \u2014 celebrated with huge street parties in Tehran and other middle-class cities \u2014 was seen by many as an end to that period.\n\nThe subsequent signing of the nuclear agreement and the lifting of international sanctions was similarly celebrated by educated urbanites, who in many ways set the cultural and social norms in the country.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMany have since grown disillusioned with Mr. Rouhani, even after his re-election this year. He has failed to fulfill election promises like appointing three women as ministers (so far, none have been named), and the nuclear pact has not produced the economic boom he promised. Yet, no matter how sour their feelings about Mr. Rouhani, most reform-minded people in Tehran are sticking by him.\n\nLeili Rashidi, a prominent Iranian actress, is typical of this group. One of the best-known figures to join the 2009 protests, a potentially career-threatening decision, Mrs. Rashidi says she has no interest in joining the current protests.\n\nHaving campaigned for Mr. Rouhani\u2019s re-election in May, she says she is not ready to desert him. \u201cHe is not perfect,\u201d she said, \u201cbut he is the only way forward.\u201d\n\nShe said her friends all agreed with her that efforts to overthrow the system would lead nowhere. \u201cI sympathize with the problems of the protesters who want a better standard of living, jobs and less economic hardship,\u201d she said. \u201cBut change must come gradually, I\u2019ve learned. With least pain, peacefully, not through violence.", "title": "As Iran Erupts in Protest, Tehran Is Notably Quiet", "authors": ["Thomas Erdbrink"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Meghen Yeadon, a recruiter for Stoughton, found part of the solution: a Wisconsin Department of Corrections work-release program for minimum-security inmates.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWork-release programs have often been criticized for exploiting inmates by forcing them to work grueling jobs for pay that is often well below minimum wage. But the Wisconsin program is voluntary, and inmates are paid market wages. State officials say the program gives inmates a chance to build up some savings, learn vocational skills and prepare for life after prison.\n\nMs. Yeadon initially encountered skepticism from supervisors. But as the local labor pool kept shrinking, it became harder to rule out a group of potential \u2014 albeit unconventional \u2014 workers.\n\nLess Education, but Still Gaining In the past five years, employment rates have grown the most among those who have not earned a high school diploma. +4.0 pct. points Less than high school Change in employment rates +3.5 Some college or associate\u2019s degree +3.0 Ages 25-54 +2.5 High school diploma or G.E.D. +2.0 Bachelor\u2019s degree or higher +1.5 +1.0 +0.5 \u201912 \u201913 \u201914 \u201915 \u201916 \u201917\n\n\u201cOur company is looking for new ways to find pools of people just because of our hiring needs being so high,\u201d Ms. Yeadon said. \u201cIt just took them to hear the right sales pitch.\u201d\n\nOther companies are making similar choices. Officials in Wisconsin and other states with similar inmate programs say demand for their workers has risen sharply in the past year. And while most companies may not be ready to turn to inmate labor, there are signs they are increasingly willing to consider candidates with criminal records, who have long faced trouble finding jobs.\n\nThe government doesn\u2019t regularly collect data on employment for people with criminal records. But private-sector sources suggest that companies have become more willing to consider hiring them. Data from Burning Glass showed that 7.9 percent of online job postings indicated that a criminal-background check was required, down from 8.9 percent in 2014.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMike Wynne has seen the change in employer mind-set firsthand. Mr. Wynne runs Emerge Community Development, a Minneapolis nonprofit that helps people with criminal records or other difficulties find jobs. In the past, Mr. Wynne said, companies saw working with Emerge mostly as a form of public relations. But with the unemployment rate in the Minneapolis area at 2.1 percent, companies have increasingly turned to Emerge as a source of labor.\n\n\u201cWe see employers really knocking on the door of our organization in a way that we haven\u2019t seen in probably 20 years,\u201d Mr. Wynne said.\n\nAs employers dip deeper into the pool of available labor, workers are coming off the economy\u2019s sidelines. The participation rate for what economists call prime-age workers \u2014 those ages 25 to 54 \u2014 hit a seven-year high in December. Employment gains have been especially strong for groups that often face discrimination \u2014 unemployment for African-Americans fell to 6.8 percent in November, the lowest rate on record.\n\nAmy Glaser, a senior vice president for Adecco, a staffing firm, said that especially during the recent holiday season, there was a surge in demand for warehouse workers, creating opportunities for people who might have struggled to find work earlier in the economic recovery. Two years ago, Ms. Glaser said, companies required warehouse workers to have high school diplomas and experience with the scanners used to track merchandise. Now, increasingly, they require neither, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve seen an extreme escalation in the past 12 months,\u201d Ms. Glaser said. \u201cIf someone applies for a job and you don\u2019t get to them within 24 hours, that person will already have taken another job.\u201d\n\nEven during the strong economy that accompanied the housing boom of the mid-2000s, the unemployment rate never dropped below 4.4 percent, and the United States has never reached the point at which everyone who wanted a job could get one. Perhaps as a result, incomes were stagnant for many middle-class families, and many groups that have historically faced discrimination or other disadvantages in the labor market never experienced the full benefits of the strong economy.\n\nMany economists say the recovery still has a ways to go before rivaling that of the late 1990s and early 2000s. The unemployment rate has fallen nearly as far as it did in 2000, when it hit 3.8 percent. But millions of Americans still have part-time or temporary jobs, or are out of the labor force entirely. And parts of the country still bear the scars of the recession that officially ended nearly a decade ago.\n\n\u201cI think of the late \u201990s as having been a very healthy labor market,\u201d said Narayana Kocherlakota, the former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. \u201cWhen I look at the United States today, I think it has some room to grow in terms of achieving that kind of health.\u201d\n\nStill, household incomes have risen rapidly in the past two years, with the strongest gains coming for those in the poorest families. And there are signs that the tightening labor market is at last beginning to shift bargaining power from companies to workers. Ahu Yildirmaz, an economist who helps lead the research arm of the payroll-processing company ADP, said her firm\u2019s data showed more people switching jobs, and getting bigger bumps in pay for doing so.\n\nFor Mr. Forseth, the job at Stoughton Trailers was an opportunity to save money and prove his value. He even earned the Employee of the Month award \u2014 although, because he was still incarcerated, he couldn\u2019t take advantage of the parking spot that came with it.\n\nNow, however, he is thinking bigger. Other jobs in the area pay higher wages, and his freedom has opened up more options. He has been talking to another local company, which is interested in training him to become an estimator \u2014 a salaried job that would pay more and offer room for advancement.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re saying they\u2019re willing to teach someone that wants to learn,\u201d Mr. Forseth said. \u201cThat\u2019d be an actual career.\u201d", "title": "As Labor Pool Shrinks, Prison Time Is Less of a Hiring Hurdle", "authors": ["Ben Casselman"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s an unprecedented time in our radio history when we have so many stations getting on the air at the same time,\u201d said Jennifer Waits, the social media director at Radio Survivor, a group in San Francisco that tracks and advocates for noncommercial radio.\n\nWeird Is Good\n\nLow-power FM stations can typically be heard for about three and a half miles if a bigger station or obstacle does not block the signal. Of the nearly 2,500 low-power stations in some stage of licensing, construction or active broadcast across the nation, more than 850 have a license holder with a religious affiliation.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany bigger stations, by contrast, are being programmed far from the cities they serve, with corporate budgets to buy transmitters that can then boost a signal beyond its home base. The low-power licenses are exclusively local, restricted to nonprofit groups that might have a civic cause \u2014 the South Philadelphia Rainbow Committee, for example \u2014 or were formed solely for the sake of a station and the dreams that fuel its existence.\n\nWashington has the second-highest concentration of them among the nation\u2019s 15 most populous states, with 68 stations for 7.4 million people, according to the Federal Communications Commission, second only to Florida. New York, by contrast, has 54 stations, but nearly three times Washington\u2019s population. Oregon \u2014 while not among the 15 most populous states, with 4.1 million people \u2014 is even more saturated than Washington and Florida; it has 80 low-power stations, most in rural areas.\n\nYou want weird? Just turn the dial. One station in Seattle invites listeners to phone their dreams and fantasies into a recorded line, then puts them on the air, at least the ones that don\u2019t raise concerns about F.C.C. indecency rules.\n\nRussian-speaking residents in Portland, Ore., have their own tiny station.\n\nAnd if you want be charmed by a 5-year-old boy chatting with his father at bedtime about dinosaurs, music and his sometimes bothersome sisters, you can find that at Tristan\u2019s Bedtime Radio Hour, broadcast on Sunday nights on KBFG in Northwest Seattle, where Tristan lives. It also streams on the web.\n\nHelp From Community Groups\n\nWhat low-power urban radio creates, believers say, is a sense of community, a defined physical stamp of existence that goes only as far as it can be heard. So new licensees and programmers are knocking on doors near their antennas and holding fund-raisers at the local brewpub. That\u2019s a stark contrast to the amorphous everywhere-but-nowhere world of the web, and the web-streaming radio or podcasts that a few years ago seemed most likely to take center stage in low-budget community communications.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen you start broadcasting, it\u2019s like you have a storefront,\u201d said Rebecca Webb, founder of the Portland Radio Project, KSFL 99.1, which broadcasts from two rooms above a closed silent-movie-era theater built around 1915. The station promises to play a Portland-area music group every 15 minutes, and in a time of media consolidation, Ms. Webb said, that\u2019s a political act.\n\n\u201cThe fact that we have gathered ourselves up by our bootstraps and created a community radio station is in direct response to the ownership concentration of large media companies,\u201d she said.\n\nMany community groups with no money and often no experience in radio got help in starting their stations. A Seattle-based event ticketing company with a social mission in working with nonprofits allowed a staff organizer, Sabrina Roach, to help people manage the F.C.C. process with seminars, training and advice.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn Oregon and California, a group called Common Frequency jumped in, especially in rural regions, helping people get licenses as they came available. In Philadelphia, the Prometheus Radio Project led a fight to get the F.C.C. to relax rules to allow more low-power FM stations, especially in urban markets, which big broadcasters had opposed.\n\nThe recent F.C.C. vote to end so-called net neutrality, under which internet users were guaranteed equal speed and access, might not directly affect small radio broadcasters that do not livestream. But advocates said the decision amplified the importance of small voices, however they are expressed.\n\n\u201cIf it gets harder for independent media to stream online, the low-power FM stations will become even more important,\u201d said Todd Urick, a radio engineer who helped lead Common Frequency.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nVoices From the Trenches\n\nClara Pluton, a stand-up comedian in Seattle who pays the bills by waiting tables, hosts a radio show with Val Nigro, who also does comedy, every other Tuesday night on Hollow Earth Radio, KHUH 104.9. The station began broadcasting in the Central District of Seattle in September, and Ms. Pluton and Ms. Nigro are now in their second month of \u201cqueer talk,\u201d as they describe their show. There\u2019s no salary, no fame, no certainty of an audience of any kind, the women said in an interview at the station, but deep rewards nonetheless in knowing that they speaking out about their lives and their city.\n\nWhen things go wrong, she said, and they do \u2014 a curse word slipping out, or a bad, skipping CD \u2014 it\u2019s part of the experience for volunteers and listeners alike. Lack of polish is part of the authenticity.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like members of the community broadcasting to members of their community,\u201d Ms. Pluton said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome volunteer D.J.s, like Bob Knowles in Portland, found a place in local radio after 25 years fishing for halibut in Alaska. He tuned in one day to KSFL, the Portland Radio Project, and liked it so much that he went in and got his own show, \u201cThrowin\u2019 it Back Thursdays,\u201d playing obscure or forgotten musical tracks as one of the station\u2019s 40-odd volunteers.\n\nGary Dunn, a 17-year-old junior at Ballard High in Seattle who was helping to broadcast the varsity basketball game, said he liked the surprise that KBFG offered of not knowing what might come next, a song he has never heard, a perspective in politics or in life that is unfamiliar. He also likes the fact that radio is an old technology, one his great-grandparents would have known. \u201cOld devices still help us,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Muhs, the physics teacher, ultimately got his software back up and running in time for Ballard Beavers\u2019 tip-off against the Franklin High Quakers. But it wasn\u2019t the Beavers night, and they lost 39 to 70.", "title": "As Low-Power Local Radio Rises, Tiny Voices Become a Collective Shout", "authors": ["Kirk Johnson"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s very frustrating that he seems to make time for everyone else except us,\u201d said Geraldine Sanchez, 19, a nanny, as she walked outside Francis\u2019s childhood home in the middle-class neighborhood of Flores. The otherwise nondescript spot is now marked with a plaque: \u201cPope Francis was born in this house.\u201d\n\nThe pope has not spoken at length about why he has not visited Argentina, which analysts attribute at least in part to a reluctance to get swept up in the country\u2019s polarized politics.\n\nIt is not that Francis has ignored South America, a region where the Roman Catholic Church\u2019s influence has been waning steadily in recent years.\n\nBy the end of his coming trip, the pontiff will have visited every country that borders Argentina, with the exception of Uruguay, plus three additional countries on the continent. He traveled to Brazil in 2013, Bolivia, Paraguay and Ecuador in 2015, Colombia last year and now Chile and Peru during a six-day trip that starts Monday.\n\nMany in Argentina have interpreted the pope\u2019s apparent snub as a decision to avoid contact with President Mauricio Macri. Francis did not crack a smile when he posed for a photo at the Vatican with the center-right politician in February 2016, shortly after Mr. Macri was sworn in.\n\nFrancis also had a tense relationship with former President Cristina Fern\u00e1ndez de Kirchner and her late husband and predecessor, N\u00e9stor Kirchner, while he was archbishop of Buenos Aires, often making thinly veiled criticisms about poverty and corruption. Ms. Kirchner and the pontiff appeared to reconcile after he moved to the Vatican.\n\nBut while he may avoid any awkward encounters with leaders in Argentina, the coming trip will still put the pontiff in some uncomfortable situations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn Santiago, Francis is expected to face demonstrations for keeping Bishop Juan Barros as head of the Diocese of Osorno, 570 miles south of the capital, despite allegations he helped cover up a notorious case of clerical sexual abuse. Francis appointed him in January 2015 even though he was part of the inner circle of the Rev. Fernando Karadima, whom the Vatican found guilty of sexual abuse in 2011.\n\nFrancis called \u201cdumb\u201d the lay and religious organizations protesting in Osorno at the time.\n\n\u201cWe are not convinced that the pope has really assumed this zero tolerance policy on sexual abuses,\u201d said Juan Carlos Claret, 24, one of the organizers of the demonstrations. \u201cHe has showed infinite tolerance. Having all the power to do something, he prefers to remain ambiguous.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPeru will be no less thorny. Francis will almost certainly be asked to weigh in on President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski\u2019s politically explosive Christmas Eve pardon of former president Alberto Fujimori, which sparked nationwide protests. Besides that, the pope on Wednesday ordered a Vatican takeover of a Peruvian Catholic society, following claims that its founder sexually and physically abused members.\n\nSex abuse scandals are among the reasons millions of Latin Americans have turned away from the Catholic Church in recent years. In prosperous nations, including Chile and Uruguay, societies have become increasingly secular. In countries in the region troubled by violence, stark inequality and entrenched poverty like Brazil, evangelical denominations have cut deeply into the historical base of the Catholic Church.\n\nThe number of Chileans who described themselves as Catholic dropped from 74 percent in 1995 to 45 percent last year, according to a poll by Latinobar\u00f3metro.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
