View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe decline of Catholicism in Argentina, from 87 percent in 1995 to 65 percent last year, has also been significant, according to the Latinobar\u00f3metro poll.\n\nYet, the church got a lift across the region with Francis\u2019 ascension, which was celebrated with the type of joy that is sparked by a soccer World Cup victory.\n\nIn Argentina, local church authorities acknowledge that people are frustrated that Francis has not come home, but they urge patience. Jorge Oesterheld, the spokesman for Argentina\u2019s bishops\u2019 conference, told a local radio station recently that the pope is \u201clooking for the moment\u201d to return home.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a little painful for him to pass over us and land on the other side,\u201d Mr. Oesterheld said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAny return is unlikely to come soon. In 2016, Francis released an 11-minute video to the Argentine people explaining he would not return home in 2017. \u201cThe world is bigger than Argentina,\u201d he said. The Vatican confirmed there would not be a trip to Argentina this year, either.\n\n\u201cI really want the pope to come to Argentina, but I agree this is not the right time,\u201d said Lautaro Baz\u00e1n, 20, who was set to board the same bus to Chile as Ms. Cartes. \u201cThere is too much social tension,\u201d he added, referring to violent protests last month after Congress overhauled pension and welfare programs.\n\nYolanda Sotoa, 50, who will be among those traveling to Chile as part of a delegation of social organizations, said she does not begrudge the pope\u2019s decision to stay away.\n\n\u201cThe pope is someone who has always fought for the poorest members of society,\u201d said Ms. Sotoa, who recycles cardboard for a living, as she stood in a workshop in the Parque Patricios neighborhood of Buenos Aires, surrounded by goods made almost entirely from material recovered from trash. \u201cHe\u2019s the polar opposite of our president, who represents high society.\u201d\n\nOther Argentines, however, are indignant.\n\n\u201cI really don\u2019t like that he has not returned,\u201d said Luisa Fern\u00e1ndez, 73, as she left Francis\u2019 childhood church, less than half a mile from his first home, after Mass. \u201cIt reflects badly on the country.\u201d There is no question, Ms. Fern\u00e1ndez added, that Francis does not come home for \u201cideological\u201d reasons and as a \u201cprotest\u201d to the president.\n\nThe government has been pushing back against the political interpretations of the pope\u2019s actions.\n\n\u201cWe need to remove some of the drama from the issue,\u201d said Alfredo Miguel Abriani, a senior foreign ministry official who oversees religious affairs. \u201cThe pope is a prudent and wise man and will know when will be the best time to travel to Argentina. We must be patient.\u201d\n\nJuan Grabois, who leads the Movement of Excluded Workers and organized a 700-person committee of social organizations to see the pope in Chile, said that the obsession with when the pontiff will visit Argentina is part of the \u201cnavel-gazing attitudes\u201d common in Argentina.\n\n\u201cHe was in Argentina for 76 years,\u201d added Mr. Grabois. \u201cHe now has to prioritize the rest of the world.\u201d", "title": "As Pope Francis Heads to Chile and Peru, Argentina Feels Snubbed, Again", "authors": ["Daniel Politi"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 President Trump\u2019s incendiary words about immigration have dampened the prospects that a broad spending and immigration deal can be reached by the end of the week, raising the possibility of a government shutdown with unknown political consequences for lawmakers in both parties.\n\nDemocrats facing re-election in states that Mr. Trump carried in 2016 fear that a government funding crisis, precipitated by an immigration showdown, could imperil their campaigns. And they are growing increasingly uneasy that liberal colleagues eyeing White House bids are demanding that any spending bill beyond a stopgap measure that expires on Jan. 19 include protections for undocumented immigrants brought to the United States illegally as children.\n\n\u201cWelcome to our world,\u201d said Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, who is running for re-election in a state that Mr. Trump carried by 19 percentage points.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve got people running for president all trying to find their base, and then you\u2019ve got people from Trump states that are trying to continue to legislate the way we always have \u2014 by negotiation,\u201d Ms. McCaskill said. \u201cAnd never the twain shall meet.\u201d", "title": "As Shutdown Talk Rises, Trump\u2019s Immigration Words Pose Risks for Both Parties", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s moving very fast,\u201d Mr. Dayton said. \u201cIt\u2019s also unlike other markets because there is this federal-state conflict. Every state has different rules. There are so many layers of complexity.\u201d\n\nHis group offers tips for new investors. Some apply to any private investment \u2014 like looking at enough deals and properly vetting a promising deal. But others are specific to the industry, like navigating the different state laws, understanding the robust competition from illegal producers and mitigating the risk of federal prosecution.\n\nPutting money into growers or dispensaries requires investors to sign documents that are going to be filed with state regulators, putting investors at odds with federal law, Mr. Dayton said. \u201cWith the exception of things that are going through the F.D.A. approval process,\u201d he said, referring to the Food and Drug Administration, \u201cany business that touches cannabis in the United States violates federal law.\u201d\n\nBut warnings aside, there are opportunities for investors. The safest investment is in legal businesses like pharmaceutical companies using cannabis in their treatments as well as companies that make devices to consume cannabis, create sales and tracking software, develop or manage the real estate related to cannabis, or even provide human resources to the industry. Companies that grow or distribute marijuana are considered riskier.\n\nOne of the best known in the medical marijuana field is GW Pharmaceuticals, a multibillion-dollar company developing a cannabis-based drug, known as a cannabinoid, for multiple sclerosis. Others include Zynerba Pharmaceuticals, which makes cannabinoids for neuropsychiatric conditions; Insys Therapeutics, for pain-management in cancer patients; and Therapix Biosciences, for central nervous system disorders.\n\nThese drugs were created to harness certain components of cannabis that react with receptors in the body. \u201cWhat\u2019s unique about cannabinoids is they\u2019re very safe,\u201d said Dr. Ascher Shmulewitz, the interim chief executive of Therapix. \u201cWith most drugs, the question is safety, and the issue is causing harm. With cannabinoids, the issue we have to show is efficacy.\u201d\n\nTherapix took an approved drug called Marinol, which is used to treat nausea in cancer and H.I.V. patients, and improved how it is delivered to the body. It is in F.D.A. trials now.", "title": "As States Legalize Marijuana, Investors See an Opportunity", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis is the first visit by the British leader since the Brexit referendum, and for both sides the primary aspect is reaffirming the status of that Sino-British \u2018golden era,\u2019\u201d said Cui Hongjian, the director of European studies at the China Institute of International Studies, a state institute in Beijing.\n\n\u201cSino-British trade has felt some impact from Brexit,\u201d Mr. Cui said. \u201cWe\u2019ll see whether this time there can be better communication to resolve some problems.\u201d\n\nMrs. May\u2019s own political fate is also weighing on the visit. On her flight to her first stop in China, Wuhan, an industrial city on the Yangtze River, she was peppered with reporters\u2019 questions about calls for her resignation from within her own Conservative Party.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI\u2018m not a quitter and there is a long-term job to be done,\u201d she said, according to Reuters. \u201cThat job is about getting the best Brexit deal, about ensuring that we take back control of our money, our laws, our borders, that we can sign trade deals around the rest of the world.\u201d\n\nChina, the world\u2019s second-biggest economy, could become a more important source of customers and investment for Britain as its scheduled March 2019 departure from the European Union looms. After her meetings in Beijing, including with Mr. Xi, Mrs. May will visit Shanghai to promote trade and investment.\n\nIn 2016, China was the destination for 3.1 percent of British exports of goods and services, while 43 percent went to other European Union member countries. Chinese officials are eager to talk up prospects for more business, and British exports to China have been growing. Representatives of more than 40 companies, universities and trade groups are accompanying Mrs. May on her trip.\n\nIn a press appearance with Mr. Li, Mrs. May said that she had won China\u2019s agreement to take steps toward lifting a ban on British beef imports, which dated back to the crisis over mad cow disease during the 1990s.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut China also bristles with policies and practices that protect many domestic industries from foreign competitors, and Mrs. May has sounded a more guarded note about prospects for cooperation than did Mr. Cameron and his Labour Party predecessors, Gordon Brown and Tony Blair.\n\nMr. Cameron and George Osborne, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, courted Chinese investment aggressively, placing less emphasis on contentious issues like democracy, human rights and the future of Hong Kong, a former British colony. In 2015, Britain also bucked the United States by joining China\u2019s fledgling Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Mrs. May, who took office in 2016, has taken a cooler approach to Beijing, delaying for several months a decision to build a nuclear power plant with Chinese investment. Her government ultimately approved the project, but promised conditions that it said would protect the security of critical infrastructure.\n\n\u201cIt was a very marked shift from the moment she came to power,\u201d said Rosemary Foot, a senior research fellow at the University of Oxford who studies Chinese foreign relations.\n\nChinese interest in investing in some sectors of the British economy, like infrastructure, technology and even financial services in London, probably will not be seriously dampened by Britain\u2019s departure from the European Union, said Paul C. Irwin Crookes, a senior lecturer at Oxford University who is studying the consequences of Brexit for the countries\u2019 ties.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut in other sectors, Chinese companies\u2019 willingness to invest could depend greatly on the terms of Britain\u2019s new relationship with Europe, he said.\n\nIn theory, after it leaves the bloc, Britain \u201ccould design a relationship with China that could move away from the model currently being put forward in the E.U.-China relationship,\u201d Dr. Irwin Crookes said by email. But in practice, the European Union may demand that Britain avoid policies that undercut European trade positions, he said.\n\n\u201cThis then is also a matter of high politics, and it is unclear in what direction it could move,\u201d Dr. Irwin Crookes said.\n\nThis is not Mrs. May\u2019s first visit to China; she and Mr. Xi met during the Group of 20 summit meeting in the eastern city of Hangzhou in 2016. But this time, Mrs. May faces the dilemma of whether to endorse Mr. Xi\u2019s \u201cBelt and Road\u201d initiative \u2014 his expansive vision of ports, roads, railways and other infrastructure to spread Chinese trade and influence.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat project has unsettled some American and European policymakers, who worry it will be a vehicle for one-sided Chinese influence and interests. Britain has been cautious, but Mr. Xi has made it one of his signature international undertakings. Mrs. May said in Beijing that Britain would work with China on deciding how to cooperate on the initiative, while ensuring that it \u201cmeets international standards.\u201d\n\n\u201cObviously, China knows that Britain is pretty desperate for trade deals, so maybe she\u2019s trying to generate a bit of leverage of her own,\u201d said Dr. Foot of Oxford. \u201cSecondly, there\u2019s a genuine concern that involvement in \u2018Belt and Road\u2019 is not going to be open, essentially, to other companies and to other countries.\u201d\n\nMrs. May has also been pushed to raise what Chris Patten, the last British governor of Hong Kong, called \u201cincreasing threats to basic freedoms\u201d in the city, which Britain returned to China in 1997 under a promise that Beijing would let it keep its civil liberties and legal autonomy for 50 years. Mr. Xi\u2019s government has tightened its grip on Hong Kong politics, publishing and news media, especially since the 2014 protests there over China\u2019s refusal to allow fully democratic elections in the city.\n\nIn a letter to Mrs. May this week, Mr. Patten and Paddy Ashdown, former leader of the centrist Liberal Democrats, asked for assurances that Britain\u2019s growing commercial relationship with China would not \u201ccome at the cost of our obligations\u201d to the people of Hong Kong.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been very difficult to build up a broad base of interest in the subtle changes that have been going on in Hong Kong,\u201d Dr. Foot said. \u201cIt\u2019s a long time since the handover of 1997, so it\u2019s been very difficult against the weight of China\u2019s economic and political prominence.\u201d", "title": "As Theresa May Pursues Deals in China, Her Own Troubles Follow", "authors": ["Chris Buckley", "Stephen Castle"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cWhat we often see communicated about rural America is that there are these isolated pockets of despair that are beyond hope or recovery,\u201d Ray Starling, the special assistant to the president for agriculture, agricultural trade and food assistance on the National Economic Council, said in a briefing Friday. The report makes clear that \u201cthat\u2019s not what we believe.\u201d\n\nYet some of the president\u2019s economic policies could actually harm the farm industry. New analyses of the tax law by economists at the Department of Agriculture suggest it could actually lower farm output in the years to come and effectively raise taxes on the lowest-earning farm households, while delivering large gains for the richest farmers.\n\nAnd the administration\u2019s trade policies continue to be a concern for farmers, who benefit from access to other markets, including by exporting their products. Mr. Trump continues to threaten to withdraw from trade pacts if other countries do not grant the United States a better deal, a position that has put him at odds with much of the farm industry.\n\n\u201cTrade has become an increasingly important and substantial part of the ag economy. So anything that causes a ripple in that can have not just little effects but significant effects,\u201d said Dale Moore, the executive director for public policy at the Farm Bureau.\n\nIndeed, part of the White House report Monday is expected to discuss global markets\u2019 importance to rural America.\n\nAgriculture has been the biggest beneficiary of pacts like the North American Free Trade Agreement, which have allowed the United States to export grains and meat. In April, when the president came to the brink of withdrawing the United States from the pact, Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue helped to dissuade him by showing him a map of the part of the country that would be hardest hit \u2014 farming states that also helped to elect Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cIt creates a lot of anxiety across all of agriculture, particularly the U.S. pulling out of Nafta,\u201d said Kevin Kester, a rancher in California and the president-elect of the National Cattlemen\u2019s Beef Association.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFarmers and ranchers like Mr. Kester worry that they are losing ground to foreign competitors, as major markets like Japan, Europe and Mexico push ahead with their own trade pacts. Although Mr. Trump has talked about forging new bilateral deals, the United States does not appear to be close to forming any.\n\nAmerican beef exporters are now at a big disadvantage in Japan, Mr. Kester said, after Mr. Trump withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a deal that would have included Japan, and Japan signed a free-trade agreement that cut tariffs for Australian beef. \u201cWe\u2019re continuing to talk to the Trump administration and urge them to get on the horse and get going with talks with Japan in particular,\u201d Mr. Kester said.\n\nNations like Canada are also beginning to export goods that have long been a staple of United States exports, such as lobster.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFarmers have lobbied the president in recent months to preserve free trade agreements with Canada, Mexico and South Korea. On Thursday, a group of six Republican senators visited the White House to lobby the president on trade.\n\nPat Roberts, the senator from Kansas who led the delegation, said the president had \u201creally listened to our concerns\u201d and \u201cunderstands the difficulty farm country is going through.\u201d\n\n\u201cI delivered the message that farmers and ranchers need to grow export markets and maintain our status as a reliable supplier, more especially with Canada and Mexico in Nafta renegotiations,\u201d Mr. Roberts said.\n\nTrade analysts said these visits from farm state representatives and the president\u2019s trip to the Farm Bureau meeting were most likely the product of Nafta supporters inside the White House, who are trying to influence the president\u2019s views on trade. Yet there is no sign yet that these meetings have altered the president\u2019s long-held skepticism of Nafta.\n\n\u201cThe reports we\u2019re hearing is the message is being delivered,\u201d said Michael Dykes, the president of the International Dairy Foods Association, an industry lobbying group. However, he said, \u201cwe haven\u2019t seen anything visible to see that they\u2019re taking it on and changing course.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithout existing free trade agreements, many agricultural products would face prohibitively high tariffs as they cross borders. Food is still one of the most protected products under global rules. Without free trade agreements, Mexico could raise its tariffs to up to 75 percent on American chicken and Idaho potatoes. South Korea could raise its tariffs to 40 percent on beef and 36 percent on cheese.\n\n\u201cI believe the president is genuine when he says he wants to take care of the folks in rural America. I think he\u2019s also hearing from rural America that, hey, Nafta is critical to agriculture,\u201d Mr. Dykes said. \u201cNafta is woven into the fabric of our business.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump has positioned his tax overhaul, which lowers individual and corporate rates, as an economic salve for rural America, including farmers. The new law won support from farmers, but many warn that its benefits could be blunted by a protectionist approach to trade.\n\nStanley H. Ryan, the chief executive of Darigold, said the tax bill was \u201chelpful and supportive\u201d for businesses like his, a century-old dairy producer in Washington State. However, \u201cto get the full benefits of it, you\u2019ve got to have market access,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Farm Bureau endorsed both the House and Senate versions of the bill, and Mr. Trump signed a compromise measure into law in December. The final version included several provisions the bureau had championed, such as the ability for businesses to immediately deduct the cost of new investments. It also narrowed the number of households affected by the estate tax, a move the bureau praised even though it had pushed to eliminate the tax entirely.\n\nBut research presented on Friday in Philadelphia, at America\u2019s annual mega-gathering of economists, suggests the bill contains downsides for the industry in general and particularly for lower-income farmers.\n\nA model of the law\u2019s effects on farm households by Siraj G. Bawa and James M. Williamson, of the Agriculture Department\u2019s Economic Research Service, projects that 70 to 80 percent of the law\u2019s benefits will flow to the top 1 percent of farm households by income.\n\nThe law actually shrinks tax refunds for the lowest-earning 20 percent of farm households, Mr. Bawa said in a session hosted by the Agriculture and Applied Economics Association. The reason stems from a combination of changes in the bill, including its elimination of a tax break for domestic production.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe lowest quintile is actually getting a tax raise under this,\u201d Mr. Bawa said.\n\nA second paper, from Jayson Beckman and Munisamy Gopinath of the Agriculture Department and Marinos Tsigas of the United States International Trade Commission, projects that the law will reduce American farm production nearly 1 percent for primary agriculture, even though it reduces tax rates on farmers.\n\nThe reason, in part, is that the tax bill\u2019s favorable treatment of other sectors, such as construction and factories, could draw investment away from agriculture.\n\nThe authors suggest those reductions could be offset \u2014 if America could secure better access to foreign consumers through trade negotiations.", "title": "As Trump Appeals to Farmers, Some of His Policies Don\u2019t", "authors": ["Ana Swanson", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Screening requests by the White House are commonplace in modern administrations but are generally kept under wraps if the film is shown during presidential downtime. The news that the White House would screen \u201cThe Post\u201d was first reported by The Hollywood Reporter.\n\nOn Friday, the representative for Fox Movies said that the administration had also secured permission to screen a second movie, \u201cThe Greatest Showman,\u201d a musical about P. T. Barnum \u2014 a man who, as the film\u2019s website indicates, created a \u201cmesmerizing spectacle that became a worldwide sensation.\u201d\n\nThere is no guarantee that the president will be in the room if, when or even where either movie is screened. Mr. Trump, who is described in Mr. Wolff\u2019s book as, among other attributes, having a tiny attention span, has said that he has trouble sitting through movies and knows in the first five minutes whether he will enjoy a film. He will get up and leave if he realizes he will not.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Friday afternoon, Mr. Trump\u2019s focus was set to stray briefly from the news media; the president traveled to Camp David to meet with Republican congressional leaders over more pressing matters, which include figuring out how to keep the government running. Mr. Trump has long toyed with the idea of clamping down on the First Amendment, going so far as to suggest at a 2016 campaign rally that he would \u201copen up those libel laws.\u201d\n\n\"So when The New York Times writes a hit piece which is a total disgrace,\u201d Mr. Trump told the crowd at the time, \u201cor when The Washington Post, which is there for other reasons, writes a hit piece, we can sue them and win money instead of having no chance of winning because they\u2019re totally protected.\u201d\n\nIndeed, Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyer sent an 11-page letter this week to Mr. Wolff\u2019s publisher, warning that the book might \u201cgive rise to claims for libel\u201d that could result in \u201csubstantial monetary damages and punitive damages.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s low regard for reporters has not found favor with the stars of \u201cThe Post,\u201d who have grown increasingly vocal after the film\u2019s premiere.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Nixon administration accused The Times of violating the Espionage Act, and won a temporary court order in 1971 that blocked the newspaper from publishing more of what became known as the Pentagon Papers. That is when The Washington Post, led by the publisher Katharine Graham, stepped in.\n\nMr. Hanks, who plays Ben Bradlee, the former editor of The Post, told The Hollywood Reporter in December that he would not attend a White House screening of his own movie.\n\n\u201cThis is the moment where, in some ways, our personal choices are going to have to reflect our opinions,\u201d Mr. Hanks said. \u201cWe have to start voting, actually, before the election. So, I would probably vote not to go.\u201d\n\nThis White House has demonstrated a knack for scheduling movie screenings to match \u2014 or clash with \u2014 the news cycle it perpetuates: Last January, aides screened \u201cFinding Dory,\u201d about a family\u2019s efforts to reunite, as protests against the administration\u2019s immigration ban roiled the country.", "title": "As Trump Targets the Press, His White House Is Screening a Journalism Tribute", "authors": ["Katie Rogers"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 When President Trump met with Turkey\u2019s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, at the United Nations last September, he embraced him as a friend and declared, \u201cWe\u2019re as close as we\u2019ve ever been.\u201d Five months later, Turkey is waging an all-out assault against Syrian Kurds, America\u2019s closest allies in the war against the Islamic State.\n\nThe Turkish offensive, carried out over the protests of the United States but with the apparent assent of Russia, marks a perilous new phase in relations between two NATO allies \u2014 bringing their interests into direct conflict on the battlefield. It lays bare how much leverage the United States has lost in Syria, where its single-minded focus has been on vanquishing Islamist militants.\n\nAs Turkish troops advanced Monday on the Kurdish town of Afrin, in northwest Syria, the White House warned Turkey not to take its eye off the campaign against the Islamic State. But it stopped short of rebuking Turkey, and acknowledged its security concerns about the Kurds, whom Turkey considers terrorists and a threat to its territorial sovereignty.\n\nThe inherent conflict of the United States using the Kurds as its on-the-ground partner in fighting the Islamic State could be overlooked as long as that group remained a threat. But with the militants now in retreat, the White House is groping for a way to maintain relations with the Kurdish fighters without further alienating the Turks.", "title": "As Turkey Attacks Kurds in Syria, U.S. Is on the Sideline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In July, Japan signed a wide-ranging new trade deal with the European Union \u2014 a step the Japanese prime minister, Shinzo Abe, referred to as hoisting \u201cthe flag of free trade high amidst protectionist trends.\u201d The European Union pushed ahead with a major update to its agreement with Mexico, while China pursued a pan-Asian agreement, among other deals.\n\nBusiness interests in the United States are watching with alarm as other countries strike agreements that exclude American exporters. For example, ranchers in Canada and Australia will be able to sell beef at lower prices in Japan than their American competitors, who will be subject to higher tariffs because the United States is not party to the Trans-Pacific Partnership.\n\nKent Bacus, the director of international trade and market access for the National Cattlemen\u2019s Beef Association, said Tuesday that the United States\u2019 withdrawal was \u201ca missed opportunity for the United States to gain greater access to some of the world\u2019s most vibrant and growing markets.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis one was really about America\u2019s role in the Pacific, and I think pulling out was a signal we\u2019re not as interested,\u201d said William Reinsch, the Scholl Chair in International Business at the Center for Strategic and International Studies and a former Clinton administration official. \u201cThe president can say whatever he wants, but the way this is being perceived is as a pullback of American influence.\u201d\n\nThe Trump administration has pushed back against claims that the America First doctrine is isolationist and it is ceding global leadership. While advisers have continued to criticize global institutions, they insist their goal is to improve, not destroy, them.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to the World Economic Forum to share President Trump\u2019s economic story and to tell the world that America is open for business,\u201d Gary D. Cohn, who heads the White House National Economic Council, said in a briefing on Tuesday. \u201cAmerica First is not America alone.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump and his advisers say that the United States will be pushing ahead with new trade deals \u2014 ones that will ultimately be better for American companies and their workers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll be doing other trade deals,\u201d Mr. Trump said Monday as he signed an order imposing tariffs on imports of washing machines and solar modules. \u201cWe\u2019re in the process of negotiating with other countries, also, all of which have treated us very unfairly.\u201d\n\nYet the willingness of countries to engage with the United States is unclear. For many, a relationship with the Trump administration has been a delicate dance: They do not want to risk access to the American market, or raise the ire of the American president.\n\nBut global leaders are warily watching the Trump administration\u2019s take-it-or-leave-it approach to renegotiating its trade pacts with Canada, Mexico and South Korea. They have seen Mr. Trump scrap the global climate change accord, withdraw the United States from the United Nations compact on migration and refugees and criticize global institutions that the United States largely designed, like the United Nations, the World Trade Organization and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.\n\nIn Davos, at a forum long considered the center for globalization, the administration\u2019s America First message has not been entirely well received. On Wednesday, comments by Wilbur Ross, the commerce secretary, that American troops were \u201ccoming to the ramparts\u201d in what he called a continuing global trade war prompted blowback from other state leaders.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nChancellor Angela Merkel of Germany warned on Wednesday that \u201cprotectionism was not the answer\u201d and called right-wing populism a \u201cpoison,\u201d in a speech largely seen as a rebuttal to Mr. Trump before his expected speech on Friday. \u201cWe think that shutting ourselves off, isolating ourselves, will not lead us into a good future,\u201d Ms. Merkel said.\n\nCanada has also contrasted its approach with that of the United States. Chrystia Freeland, the Canadian foreign minister, said she was worried about movements around the world that have blamed trade and immigration for the hollowing out of the middle class, and that Canada was \u201cdoubling down\u201d on its openness to trade and immigrants. \u201cIt\u2019s partly a statement about our values. But we also think it is a really great economic benefit to us as well,\u201d she said.\n\nSo far, it is unclear which countries the United States could be courting to create new trade deals. Britain has expressed interest in a bilateral deal with United States, but talks could not begin until it finishes extricating itself from the European Union, which does not look likely to be resolved soon.\n\nJapan, the preferred partner for many American businesses, appears to have spurned the United States\u2019 offer to forge a trade deal one on one, after Mr. Trump pulled the United States out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd China has tried to position itself as a global leader \u2014 a sharp change from the early 1990s, when the leader at the time, Deng Xiaoping, cautioned his countrymen to \u201chide your strength and bide your time.\u201d\n\nChina has set about building its own vision of an international order, including an Asian investment bank to rival the World Bank, and its global infrastructure project, One Belt One Road. At last year\u2019s meeting in Davos, President Xi Jinping of China portrayed his country as a global leader and vigorously defended free trade \u2014 a position some considered ironic for a country that maintains sharp controls on many industries.\n\nThe Trump administration\u2019s more aggressive stance toward allies and adversaries may shift this balance in China\u2019s favor. At an event on Tuesday in Washington, Juan Gabriel Vald\u00e9s, the Chilean ambassador to the United States, contrasted Chile\u2019s now warm relationship with China with the United States\u2019 more combative stance on trade, especially in its negotiations over Nafta.\n\n\u201cIn the history of the region, we have never had a partner that is so willing, so open, so dedicated to listen to what are our needs than what we have now with China,\u201d Mr. Vald\u00e9s said.\n\n\u201cThe United States continues to be, and will probably be in the next 10, 20 years, the main partner of the Latin American region,\u201d he said. \u201cBut change is there. It\u2019s written on the wall, if this continues like it is.\u201d", "title": "As U.S. Trumpets \u2018America First,\u2019 Rest of the World Is Moving On", "authors": ["Ana Swanson", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "JERUSALEM \u2014 The Israeli right, emboldened by President Trump\u2019s recognition of Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital, is not the only faction arguing for a single state between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea.\n\nThe Palestine Liberation Organization has also begun to ask whether that might not be such a bad idea, though it has a radically different view of what that state would look like.\n\nAs momentum ebbs for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, both sides are taking another look at the one-state idea. But that solution has long been problematic for both sides.\n\nFor the Israelis, absorbing three million West Bank Palestinians means either giving up on democracy or accepting the end of the Jewish state. The Palestinians, unwilling to live under apartheid-like conditions or military occupation, have also seen two states as their best hope.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow, for the first time since it declared its support for a Palestinian state side-by-side with Israel in 1988, the P.L.O. is seriously debating whether to embrace fallback options, including the pursuit of a single state.", "title": "As a 2-State Solution Loses Steam, a 1-State Plan Gains Traction", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Later Tom observes one of the members of the medical team: \u201cI can\u2019t see if Sax is yelling at the staff in Room 2 or into a telephone: Extraordinary doses of vasoconstrictors, acute circulatory instability, multiorgan failure, extensive bleeding from all orifices, membranes, infarcts, come on people, the patient is basically dying on us here.\u201d As another doctor tells Tom, \u201cWe\u2019re in proper hell now, you\u2019re right in the middle of it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe reader is dropped into this abyss with little guidance. There\u2019s almost no hierarchy of detail or information because Tom doesn\u2019t know what\u2019s significant and what isn\u2019t. Everything is important, not only because the action is unspooling in real time but because in the first moments after his daughter\u2019s birth and the final moments of his partner\u2019s life, the most mundane detail is precious: \u201cHer ears, eyebrows, eyelashes, nose, and that little indentation in her skin by her right nostril, that\u2019s the only thing that\u2019s still the same, but it\u2019s enough, it\u2019s Karin.\u201d\n\nThis is narrative as raw material. In a powerful translation by the novelist Henning Koch, there are sentences of precise and subtle lyricism. Describing Tom\u2019s newly born daughter, Malmquist writes: \u201cThe consultant is holding Livia by the legs, as if she\u2019s bleeding prey.\u201d Elsewhere the prose is unadorned, even blunt, particularly in the sections where the opaque languages of medicine and bureaucracy flood \u2014 infiltrate would be too weak a word \u2014 Tom\u2019s voice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA novel about permeability, \u201cIn Every Moment We Are Still Alive\u201d captures the jumbled sensory experience of being profoundly, catastrophically overwhelmed. Malmquist achieves much of this through style. The linguistic contagion results in moments of deep pathos, as when Tom struggles to locate the language to tell her parents that Karin is dead, only to fall back on medical terminology: \u201cI don\u2019t know how to articulate it so I just repeat what Nygren said to me: The electrical activity in Karin\u2019s heart has stopped.\u201d\n\nBook Review Rose McGowan on \u2018Brave\u2019 McGowan talks about her new memoir, and Katie Kitamura discusses Tom Malmquist\u2019s new novel, \u201cIn Every Moment We Are Still Alive.\u201d Audio\n\nTom is left with his grief and his newborn daughter. \u201cJersey Girl,\u201d a heartwarming 2004 movie about death starring Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez, uses more or less the same setup. The comparison illustrates the degree to which this material risks clich\u00e9 and sentimentality. But if sentiment is emotion\u2019s easily digestible expression, simple to contain and designed not to trouble, it\u2019s clear that Malmquist is explicitly interested in what can\u2019t be contained, what continues to trouble.\n\nThis novel travels off the map and into that territory. It exchanges the schematic ease of the sentimental for the uncharted depths of the emotional. Toward the end, Tom says, \u201cI miss Karin,\u201d but until this point there\u2019s virtually no mention of his feelings. At its conclusion, Tom hasn\u2019t recovered, isn\u2019t even bereaved, but instead exists in a pit of emotion so acute as to be without \u201cmeaning.\u201d Watching his child at play and asleep, he confesses: \u201cI have never hated as I hate now, it has no direction, no meaning, and every time I try to understand it, attach words to it, define it, control it, I start crying so violently that I am afraid of waking her even if I am in a different room.\u201d\n\nWhat kind of emotional experience do we expect from a work of art? Once upon a time, we turned to art in search of catharsis, submitting to a rite of terror and purification, the workings of which were beyond our comprehension. But in the age of psychology and self-help, our expectations have shifted. Increasingly, we seek narratives that guide us through our fear, language that diagnoses and renders transparent, a timeline of redemption and resolution that\u2019s legible and coherent.\n\nPhoto\n\nMalmquist denies us that timeline. Even as he depicts the unpromising start of Karin and Tom\u2019s relationship, he utilizes the present tense: \u201cKarin has a friend with her when we meet that weekend in a bar on Odengatan. Helena is as tall as Karin, but slender. \u2026 Karin is unremarkable in comparison, and when they stand next to each other at the horseshoe-shaped bar and I can see their hips, Karin looks ungainly.\u201d\n\nOver the course of the novel, Karin emerges as a complex character, and the representation of her relationship with Tom is undistorted by either hindsight or nostalgia. This temporal collapse captures the nature of acute grief and trauma: It\u2019s not simply that Tom is unable to imagine a future without Karin, it\u2019s that he\u2019s unable to process the past as past. The effect is often jarring as disordered fragments from past and present are set against one another without signposts or connective tissue. In contemporary fiction, this technique is used infrequently enough for it to feel radical here, particularly in this sustained form.\n\nOnly in the novel\u2019s final pages does time regain its full dimensions. Tom allows himself to address Karin directly and to dream of Livia\u2019s future: \u201cWe\u2019ll move away from Lundagatan to another street, another city, another country, she falls in love with an older boy or girl \u2026 over long periods she does not ask about you, she calls home while on a trip abroad, she misses home, I meet her at the airport, she says she thought she saw you, she loves your clothes, she finds a receipt in the pocket in your duffel coat from a shop that no longer exists. \u2026 She says: Sssh. And she says: I often dream about my mother.\u201d\n\nThat a shift to the second person and a change in tense should feel so expansive and create such a rush of emotion is a testament to Malmquist\u2019s extraordinary skill. As with \u201cMy Struggle,\u201d it\u2019s tempting to label this novel \u201cauthentic,\u201d and therefore \u201cartless.\u201d The two are not always bedfellows, and, among other things, \u201cIn Every Moment We Are Still Alive\u201d is a tremendous feat of emotional and artistic discipline. The novel doesn\u2019t feel remembered, though of course it is. That\u2019s where its craft lies, and its triumph \u2014 in the suspension of hindsight, in an act of recollection whose hand is perpetually guiding the text, but can\u2019t be seen.", "title": "As a Daughter Is Born, a Young Mother Dies", "authors": ["Katie Kitamura", "Tom Malmquist"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Singapore \u2014 In high school, my friends and I spent many afternoons discussing how our lives would change once we went to college. Lounging around coffee shops or our parents\u2019 apartments, we\u2019d fantasize aloud about prospective friends, future boyfriends and the careers we hoped to have after graduation.\n\nWe all saw our lives as single-handedly within our control, but one of my friends was more eager than the rest of us to make a total transformation. She said she wanted to be someone entirely new in college and do everything she couldn\u2019t do back home in Singapore, our large city that was somehow made small by our tight-knit Indian community. Among our families, everyone always seemed to know everything about everybody.\n\nAt the time, her desire to reinvent herself upset me. I felt like she was proposing a drastic and strikingly unnatural step. It seemed inauthentic, like a rejection of her true self.\n\nNow I think about how funny that seems. I\u2019m only halfway through my first year at Durham University, in northeast England, and already I see that we are shaped by the new spaces we inhabit, whether we plan on changing or not. College is entirely about reinvention, and it\u2019s not always in our control.", "title": "Opinion | As a Freshman, You Can\u2019t Avoid Reinvention", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mechanics was a passion, though, as well as music, and his first creation actually was a subwoofer speaker (\u201cI couldn\u2019t find one that I liked and could afford, so I built my own\u201d), which he still uses today. But perhaps the biggest departure from his fellow watchmakers was getting a master\u2019s degree in business administration in 2002 from the Business School Lausanne, which he completed part time while working for a local maker of watch parts. Mr. Gauthier\u2019s graduation thesis was a business plan for his own brand, which he started three years later.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis focus was the creation of top-quality watches in very limited quantities, an orientation he has maintained as the business developed. Today, the Romain Gauthier brand makes only about 50 watches a year.\n\nMr. Gauthier introduced his first watch, the 41-millimeter Prestige HM (\u201chour, minute\u201d), at the 2007 Baselworld watch fair. Along with a movement made in-house, the watch had a flat winding crown on the back rather than the traditional location on the side of the case. Its placement made it easy to wind and suited both left- and right-hand wearers. The more traditional aspect of the watch was its off-center time indicator, set on a gold guilloch\u00e9 dial.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSuch finishes \u2014 like hand-beveled bridges that require 20 hours of work or tiny screws topped with a special insignia \u2014 are Mr. Gauthier\u2019s signature, earning him something of a reputation in the industry. William Asprey, chairman of the London retailer William & Son, Mr. Gauthier\u2019s only British outlet, lauded the brand for its \u201cextraordinary finishing\u201d and \u201crare pieces that appeal to our clients.\u201d\n\nThe watchmaker also supplies high-end parts to outside houses, including Chanel. That relationship began in 2011, and included an investment that both businesses still decline to detail. (The relationship became public knowledge at the 2016 Baselworld fair, during Chanel\u2019s introduction of Monsieur, its first men\u2019s watch with an in-house movement.)\n\nMr. Gauthier\u2019s third watch, Logical One, won a Grand Prix d\u2019Horlogerie de Gen\u00e8ve award in 2013; the model addressed the longtime horological challenge of transferring constant energy via a chain-and-fus\u00e9e mechanism, a part that the watchmaker reconfigured for optimal reliability and consistency. The watch, now offered in white gold and in titanium, originally was produced in platinum and in red gold for 139,000 Swiss francs ($142,580 today) each, but those 20-piece limited editions sold out. (\u201cI have to borrow some Logical Ones from friends to show at S.I.H.H.,\u201d Mr. Gauthier said).\n\nPhoto\n\nDespite such accolades, Mr. Gauthier said that introducing his own brand would have been impossible without his M.B.A., something he says would be valuable for any of his peers in the independent watchmaking world. \u201cThe biggest challenge for a niche brand is to be professional,\u201d he said. \u201cThe big companies succeed because they take care of all points \u2014 not only developing and producing a watch but also promotion, communication, traveling the world and meeting clients. I\u2019ve had to learn about balancing my passion with business.\u201d\n\nInterest in such watches has been rising, driven by two key factors, said Sky Sit, who last summer established Skolorr, a website that sells only watches made by independents (it does not stock Romain Gauthier).\n\nOne is the so-called flight to quality, spurred by the recent industry downturn that created overstocks and led to heavy discounting of some big brands. \u201cWhen people saw discounts of 30 to 50 percent on watches, they began to question the value of major mainstream pieces,\u201d Ms. Sit said. \u201cIt was a light bulb moment: Watches by independents, with their exclusivity and smaller-scale production, have more intrinsic value.\u201d (Independents generally make from 30 to 300 pieces a year, compared with the hundreds of thousands produced by the largest brands.)\n\nAnd millennial buyers are the other factor. \u201cThey want something that not everyone has and which is more personal,\u201d Ms. Sit said. \u201cIt\u2019s the psychology of wanting to stand out. Social media is everything.\u201d\n\nThe industry seems to be taking note, too. S.I.H.H. has a space dedicated to independents, with the number of Carr\u00e9 des Horlogers exhibitors rising to 17 this year (there were nine in 2016). For small houses, the fair \u201cis a better way to efficiently and quickly target the most important actors in fine watchmaking worldwide,\u201d said Fabienne Lupo, the fair\u2019s managing director. And, she added, their presence \u201cbrings in some fresh air \u2014 and fresh air is always a benefit for everyone.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor his S.I.H.H. debut, Mr. Gauthier is introducing a women\u2019s watch (he has done feminine designs but as private commissions) drawn from the Insight Micro-Rotor collection he introduced at Baselworld last year. The models, at a unisex-sized 39.5 millimeters (about 1.5 inches), include the maison\u2019s first automatic movement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe red-gold women\u2019s watch features a visible bidirectional micro-rotor in 22-karat gold, and sparkles with 45 diamonds in different sizes. It also has a layered dial that is available in white mother-of-pearl from Australia or black, from Tahiti, paired with either a satin or rubber strap.\n\nThe watch, the Insight Micro-Rotor Lady, is priced at 83,000 Swiss francs and will be produced in limited editions of 10 pieces with each dial. Mr. Gauthier called it the \u201cperfect luxury daily watch\u201d as it doesn\u2019t need winding. \u201cYou just need to wear and enjoy it, and see beautiful things on your wrist.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Gauthier, who said his brand is too small to have created a caliber just for women, noted that his production capacity is 80 to 100 watches a year. More than that would require not only more staff but also would compromise his vision to keep creating what he calls \u201clittle stars\u201d for collectors \u2014 small-quantity watches made of parts that take hours to craft and, when done, reflect knowledge and sophistication. \u201cThat is the real meaning of haute horology,\u201d he said.\n\nThat\u2019s not to say that growth is entirely off the agenda. Here Mr. Gauthier\u2019s business training rises, producing terms like ROI, investment, manufacture and R&D. \u201cIndependent means controlling your business \u2014 and risk \u2014 from the inside,\u201d he said. \u201cMy thinking was always to take the small road, not the highway.\u201d\n\nMr. Gauthier did hint that he may have his own boutique someday (he\u2019s stocked in only 11 retailers worldwide) and noted that the United States now accounts for about 40 percent of his sales. While I may still view him as an aberration, they simply assume that his antics define the office, lending an entirely new, inverted context to the age-old adage that in the United States, anyone can become president.", "title": "Opinion | As the Trump Presidency Enters Year 2", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cRequest to Check Citizenship Stirs Fears for Census\u201d (news article, Jan. 3):\n\nIt is with questionable motivation that the Justice Department is seeking to add a question on citizenship to the 2020 census. But even giving the Trump administration the benefit of the doubt, whatever good intentions may underlie this request \u2014 acquiring more information, in theory, can be a good thing \u2014 a likely result is that many immigrants will fear participating in the census because of this administration\u2019s words and deeds thus far addressing this group.\n\nIn turn, this lower participation among immigrants will significantly affect both the redistribution of seats across states in the House of Representatives and the allocation of much federal spending that occurs every decade based on the most recent census.\n\nClearly, here the practical considerations outweigh any theoretical benefits. There is a reason that the professionals at the Census Bureau have chosen to exclude a question of this sort, and the administration should not impose its political agenda on the bureau and compromise the accuracy of the census.\n\nNEIL G. BENNETT, NEW YORK\n\nThe writer is the director of the CUNY Institute for Demographic Research.", "title": "Opinion | Asking About Citizenship", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Q. On my Amazon Echo at home, I can ask \u201cWhat\u2019s new?\u201d and get a briefing from sources I\u2019ve selected for news, business, sports and so on. Is there anything similar to that for an iPhone so I can get this type of information read to me while I\u2019m in the car?\n\nA. Along the lines of Amazon\u2019s Alexa flash briefing feature, Apple\u2019s Siri virtual assistant has a new skill to help users keep up with current events. (Apple\u2019s own Echo competitor, the HomePod speaker, arrives next month.) In response to the command, \u201cHey, Siri, give me the news,\u201d the software plays the latest newscast from National Public Radio. D-Sol for throngs of partygoers.\n\nFor a more tranquil evening, Mr. Solomon enjoys fine food and fine wine, and is known to arrive at steakhouses with a rare vintage from his cellar. For years, Mr. Solomon, a co-president at Goldman Sachs, tasked his personal assistant with helping manage a world-class collection of wine.\n\nBut his assistant, Nicolas De-Meyer, was doing much more than simply stocking his boss\u2019s wine cellar in the Hamptons, federal authorities said. Mr. De-Meyer stole some of the most coveted French vintages \u2014 worth more than $1.2 million \u2014 in Mr. Solomon\u2019s collection and sold them, according to an indictment unsealed on Wednesday in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. De-Meyer, 40, was arrested on Tuesday night at Los Angeles International Airport and was charged with one count of interstate transportation of stolen property, the authorities said. The Cleveland Orchestra, which many consider one of the finest ensembles in the nation and the world, turns 100 this year.\n\nBut don\u2019t necessarily expect the orchestra, which plays two soberly sensible programs at Carnegie Hall this week, to join the clamor. There is no major commissioning project, such as you might see from other orchestras; no nationally televised gala.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s kind of an understated celebration,\u201d said Gary Hanson, the ensemble\u2019s executive director from 2004 to 2015, \u201cand that is absolutely true to the Cleveland Orchestra\u2019s character. It would rather not make noise. The quality of the performances is always supposed to be the loudest voice.\u201d\n\nFranz Welser-M\u00f6st, music director since 2002, elaborated: \u201cWe shouldn\u2019t be celebrating ourselves. He was making sure that uninvited player agents or scouts did not harass members of his team on the eve of the 16-team African Nations Championship, a competition for national teams with rosters made up solely of players who play club games in their birth countries.\n\nFor coaches and other team officials like Koivogui, the top priority is making sure the teams excel, with distractions kept to a minimum. But for many players present, the biennial tournament, now in its fifth edition, represents a rare opportunity for a life-changing event: the chance for previously unheralded players to make their way onto national teams or into better-paying leagues in Europe, Asia and the Middle East.\n\n\u201cI can spot them,\u201d Koivogui said, suspiciously watching the hotel\u2019s revolving door for agents. \u201cNo agents can come here without permission.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKoivogui\u2019s effectiveness is debatable. With about $6 billion spent on soccer\u2019s transfer market every year, and billions more spent on salaries, the most intrepid deal brokers make sure to find out what rooms players are staying in and then phone them directly. The father said he had some papers that he wanted to copy. Would the son help?\n\n\u201cI said, \u2018Yes, sure,\u201d the son recalled. Off they went to a Xerox machine that was big, clunky and, by today\u2019s standards, very, very slow.\n\nIt was the first time anyone had let the son run such a monster. He was thrilled.\n\nSaying that the father wanted to copy \u201csome papers\u201d is like saying that the Vatican is \u201ca church.\u201d The papers \u2014 which the father was smuggling out of his office, a briefcase-full at a time \u2014 would become known as the Pentagon Papers, the sprawling, classified history of the Vietnam War. The father was Daniel Ellsberg, a former Defense Department official who by then was deeply discouraged about the conflict.\n\nThe son, Robert Ellsberg, may have had a cameo role in history as his father\u2019s helper, but not in the film \u201cThe Post,\u201d Steven Spielberg\u2019s drama about the newspaper that played catch-up after another newspaper \u2014 this one \u2014 broke the story of the Pentagon Papers.", "title": "At Age 13, Creating the Pentagon Papers. When the beignets arrived, they came with sugar on the side, in a bowl, two inches deep.\n\nIndigenous to New Orleans, beignets are of the same genus as doughnuts but a separate species: pieces of puffed-up fried dough with an airiness somewhere between buoyancy and levitation. They leave drifts of confectioners\u2019 sugar in their wake.\n\nMatt Pace, who grew up in New Orleans East and moved to New York a decade ago to make a life as a painter, started frying up his hometown treat at outdoor food markets in 2014 under the name Booqoo Beignets. Ms. Duma, a media entrepreneur and fashion tech investor, posted the card on Instagram, and the public reaction was swift and furious. Charges of racism flew.\n\nPhoto\n\nBy Tuesday, when Chanel day dawned, apologies were made, but badly. Then a video of Ms. Duma making homophobic and transphobic statements six years ago during an internal business meeting was released. Cue more apologies. But by Wednesday and the Valentino show, both women were metaphorically gone from the front row.\n\nIt was a potent reminder that while fashion likes to consider itself part of the front lines of social consciousness, it is still in many ways a hidebound industry. And nothing symbolizes that like the couture: stratospherically expensive clothes made by hand for the ivory tower few, just as it has been for decades.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven though Violet Chachki, the winner of the seventh season of \u201cRuPaul\u2019s Drag Race,\u201d was the ubiquitous celebrity guest of the week; Clare Waight Keller added a powerful female designer voice to the mix; and there was more diversity on the runways, the shows can still resemble the inside of a snow globe, like scenes from a soft-focus fairy tale, frozen in place.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOr, in Chanel\u2019s case, the inside of a French garden. Karl Lagerfeld had recreated one in the confines of the Grand Palais, down to the trellises twined with climbing roses and urns spilling blooms. A burbling fountain in the midst of it all provided background music for a bouquet of pastel boucl\u00e9 suits with matching boucl\u00e9 bootees (also some boucl\u00e9 knickerbockers, but let\u2019s forget those), berry-hued cocktail dresses twinkling with flower fairy lights and feathers, and little sheaths that shimmered under the airbrushed scrim of a silk chiffon overdress and allowed for a bigger stride.\n\nPhoto\n\nIt was awfully pretty \u2014 and his bride did wear the trousers \u2014 as were Giambattista Valli\u2019s trademark little lace 1960s dresses embroidered in three-dimensional peonies, black bows and rhinestones. But is that enough? Along with Murray Colpman, he had traveled hundreds of miles by train, then walked for 45 minutes, to reach this obscure transportation outpost in northeastern England.", "title": "At England\u2019s Loneliest Rail Station, a Train Comes Just Once a Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Under Mr. Flannery\u2019s predecessor, Jeffrey R. Immelt, the industrial giant drastically cut back GE Capital after the financial crisis began in 2008. The unit has now largely been pared back to its original purpose: financing for G.E. customers to buy the company\u2019s jet engines, power turbines, medical-imaging machines and other industrial equipment.\n\nOnly a few nonindustrial finance businesses remain within GE Capital. The newly disclosed trouble surfaced in one of those, a reinsurance unit, North American Life and Health, mainly because of the higher-than-expected cost of reinsuring long-term care policies sold by other insurers.\n\nAfter examining the trend in claims tied to such policies, G.E., working with the reinsurer\u2019s primary regulator, the Kansas Insurance Department, decided it needed to substantially increase its reserves for future payouts. Many of the policyholders are now 80 and older, an age when claims rise substantially.\n\nG.E. has agreed to add $15 billion to reserves for the business over the next seven years.\n\n\u201cThis is deeply disappointing,\u201d Mr. Flannery said in the conference call. He added that the anticipated costs were manageable, would be \u201ccontained within GE Capital\u201d and would have no effect on investment in the company\u2019s industrial businesses.\n\nStill, G.E. said, GE Capital would suspend dividend payments to the parent company for the \u201cforeseeable future.\u201d To conserve cash, Mr. Flannery cut G.E.\u2019s dividend last year, only the second time since the Depression that had happened.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Flannery did say on Tuesday that G.E. would explore different potential ownership structures for the remaining units, as it did with its oil-field equipment business last year. In July, the company completed a merger of its oil and gas division with Baker Hughes into a separate company in which G.E. holds a 62.5 percent stake.\n\n\u201cOur results, over the past several years, including 2017, and the insurance charge only further my belief that we need to continue to move with purpose to reshape G.E.,\u201d Mr. Flannery said.\n\nThe scope of the insurance problem, and its seemingly sudden emergence, were reflected in sharp questions from analysts about the performance of G.E.\u2019s outside auditor, KPMG, and possible lapses by G.E. managers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nG.E. said it had used two outside auditors to assess the insurance obligations, and Jamie Miller, the company\u2019s chief financial officer, said that the G.E. board reviewed the selection of the company\u2019s auditor every year.\n\nThe company\u2019s scrutiny of its finance unit and other businesses is continuing. \u201cWe\u2019ve been scrubbing deeply,\u201d Mr. Flannery said.\n\n\n\nThe circumstances surrounding the insurance problem echoed those that cropped up in the company\u2019s power-generation business last year. Problems in long-term-care insurance are not startling, as the population ages and claims pile up. Similarly, a slowdown in demand for gas turbines was to be expected, with energy efficiency improving and utilities steadily switching to renewable sources of electricity.\n\nIn both cases, it was the magnitude and suddenness of the problems that unsettled investors and, apparently, Mr. Flannery himself. Questioned by analysts, he said, \u201cI share your surprise and disappointment of this coming out of a legacy business.\u201d\n\nThe problems at G.E. were brewing well before Mr. Flannery took over, and analysts said he had moved swiftly to take corrective action. But the two announcements of deeper-than-anticipated troubles, they said, added to the uncertainty surrounding the company.\n\n\u201cThe good news is that Flannery seems to have cleared the deck,\u201d said Scott Davis, an analyst at Melius Research, an independent financial analysis firm. \u201cThe bad news is how do you trust anything now?\u201d", "title": "At G.E., $6.2 Billion Charge for Finance Unit Hurts C.E.O.\u2019s Turnaround Push", "authors": ["Steve Lohr", "Chad Bray"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "On every table at Happy Stony Noodle sits a bowl of suan cai, pickled mustard greens, dark and minerally, fermented and then flopped in a wok with sesame oil, garlic, dried onion and a flick of sugar. The chef, Chih Shen Hsu, calls it \u201cChinese kimchi.\u201d It\u2019s a condiment, to be spooned into soup or over meat, lending a sour frisson and crunch. But I ate it straight and was, as the restaurant\u2019s name promised, happy.\n\nMr. Hsu, 65, was born in Hsinchu City in northern Taiwan under martial law. As a child, he often lingered over soup at Happy Beef Noodle, a no-frills storefront opened by veterans of the Kuomintang\u2019s Nationalist Army who had fled to Taiwan after the Communists\u2019 victory in mainland China. When he grew up, he took over the noodle shop and ran it for two decades with his wife, Yu Lan Hsu, while they watched the transformation of their country from rural society to megalopolis.\n\nThey moved to the U.S. in 1997 and brought Happy Beef Noodle with them, trying out iterations of the restaurant in Flushing, Queens, then Edison, N.J. (Both have shuttered.) Two and a half years ago, they settled on this quiet side street off Broadway in Elmhurst, Queens. The \u201cStony\u201d now on the awning is Mr. Hsu\u2019s English nickname, bestowed on him by a professor in his college days.", "title": "At Happy Stony Noodle, a Childhood Favorite Anchors the Menu", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "But interviews with experts familiar with Kennedy\u2019s operations this weekend, as well as with scores of passengers both inside that jampacked airport and others far away, hint at the complicated story to someday come, and offer a view from within the chaotic scene.\n\nThe arrival of a severe winter storm on Thursday was not a surprise.\n\nWith a snowstorm ominously described as a bomb cyclone bearing down on the New York area, the Port Authority started warning about airport disruption and flight cancellations on Wednesday afternoon. On Thursday, as the snow piled up and winds strengthened, the Port Authority announced that Kennedy would temporarily shut down. At 1 p.m., it was telling travelers that it intended to resume flight activity later that day.\n\nAround the world, airlines were reading that forecast as a green light to take off for long hauls to New York City. As late as 6:20 p.m., the Port Authority was still sending out tweets that it expected to reopen Kennedy that night. But an hour later, close to 7:30 p.m., the Port Authority decided to keep Kennedy closed until Friday morning. That meant that all of the flights bound for Kennedy had to divert to other airports or turn around.\n\nThe sudden, unplanned detouring of all of those planes set off a chain reaction that stretched to various continents and left Kennedy tied in knots for the next few days, with passengers stranded in overcrowded terminals and on planes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cVirtually no foreign airline canceled any flights into J.F.K.\u201d on Thursday, said Jason Rabinowitz, a freelance aviation blogger who tracked the cascading pileup as it played out. \u201cThey all launched their aircraft, but by the time they got halfway over the Atlantic, they found out they couldn\u2019t land at J.F.K.\u201d\n\nAs an example, Mr. Rabinowitz cited Iberia Flight 6253, which got halfway to New York from Madrid before making a U-turn and going back to Spain: an eight-hour fight to nowhere. Norwegian Air Flight 7019 made a similar journey Thursday night en route to New York from France. \u201cThat was kind of weird,\u201d said Mona Bismuth, 27, a passenger. \u201cWe turned around at the southern tip of Greenland.\u201d A passenger on a different flight was sent back to Moscow \u2014 twice \u2014 because of what was happening in New York.\n\nWhen Kennedy gradually reopened on Friday, the airlines started sending their diverted planes on to Kennedy. The airport\u2019s runways could handle the traffic, but some of its terminals were quickly overwhelmed with planes arriving faster than gates could be cleared for them.\n\nThat mismatch continued into Saturday, as the airlines played catch-up on the flights they had sent elsewhere or had canceled.", "title": "At J.F.K. Airport, the Planes Just Wouldn\u2019t Stop Coming", "authors": ["Michael Wilson", "Patrick Mcgeehan"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In a Michigan court, dozens of parents have sobbed, wiped away tears or stood silently in a grim backdrop as young women and teenagers testify about being molested by Lawrence G. Nassar, the former Olympic gymnastics team and sports medicine doctor.\n\nMany of the parents heard that they were present when Dr. Nassar abused their children, using his body to block their view as he leaned over the examining table. One mother was looking at her phone during the treatment, the court heard. Others did not watch Dr. Nassar closely, sold by his reputation as a doctor for elite gymnasts and his easygoing manner.\n\nOver the last week, as more than 150 young women have read statements about Dr. Nassar\u2019s abuse, one element has stood out: the role of the parents who sent their children to him. Many stood next to their daughters in court, and some spoke, offering yet another glimpse into how a predator can enter the lives of a family eager to fulfill the ambitions of their children, some of them dreaming of Olympic gold.\n\n\u201cI willingly took my most precious gift in this world to you, and you hurt her,\u201d said Anne Swinehart, who was allowed to directly address Dr. Nassar in court after her daughter Jillian spoke on Tuesday. \u201cPhysically, mentally and emotionally, and she was only 8.\u201d", "title": "At Larry Nassar\u2019s Sentencing, Parents Ask: \u2018How Did I Miss the Red Flags?\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere is no expedited processing for deferred action under DACA,\u201d he said in a statement. \u201cThese DACA requests will be processed in accordance with standard procedures. An individual\u2019s deferred action under the DACA policy begins the day U.S.C.I.S. approves the request and is generally valid for two years from the date of issuance.\u201d\n\nThe delayed applications were reported by The New York Times in November. Officials initially said that nothing could be done for the rejected applicants, and said the number was small. But as elected officials complained and the extent of the problem became clear, the agency reversed its position.\n\nSome applications sat for weeks without being delivered by the Postal Service, others arrived on time at designated collection centers in Chicago, Dallas and Phoenix, but were not processed on time because of courier problems.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis week, U.S.C.I.S. said it sent letters to more than \u201c1,700 individuals,\u201d and that more than 200 applicants resubmitted their renewals before the government invited them to do so.\n\nPart of the problem, immigration activists say, was that the agency imposed a \u201creceived by\u201d deadline, instead of relying on a postmark as it does with most other immigration-related applications. In September, the Trump administration announced that it planned to end DACA on March 5 but urged Congress to find a legislative solution before then. Anyone whose permit expired before March could renew by Oct. 5.\n\n\u201cThe fact that that many individuals were affected shows that the deadline they imposed \u2014 which we always said was too short and too arbitrary \u2014 was too short even for the government to perform its functions properly,\u201d Camille Mackler, the director of legal initiatives for the New York Immigration Coalition.\n\nAccording to U.S.C.I.S., 154,000 people were eligible to apply for renewal and 132,000 applications were received on time. According to an Oct. 18 deposition of an immigration official conducted as part of a federal lawsuit in Brooklyn, 4,000 DACA applications arrived late and were rejected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe government is taking the blame for nearly half of those.\n\nHasan Shafiqullah, a lawyer for the Legal Aid Society of New York said he thought the number might even be higher.\n\nOne of his clients whose application was rejected lost his DACA protections on Dec. 1, another lost them on Dec. 23, and two more will lose theirs soon. Without DACA permits, the immigrants cannot legally work and may not be eligible for college scholarships.\n\nAccording to the Center for American Progress, a liberal think tank, about 122 people have been losing their DACA permits per day, a number calculated before the extent of the mail delays were known. The full effect of the mail delays may be felt for months \u2014 or even years.\n\nIf an immigrant lives in the country illegally for any amount of time, it could have harmful repercussions, Ms. Mackler and Mr. Shafiqullah said. It could make it especially difficult for those who have turned 18 after their DACA permits expire to get green cards from employers.\n\n\u201cTypically DACA folks are low income, and for anyone, the inability to work is difficult, especially people living paycheck to paycheck \u2014 it can be devastating,\u201d Mr. Shafiqullah said.", "title": "At Least 1,900 Immigrants Were Rejected Because of Mail Problems", "authors": ["Liz Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "On the street outside, the men\u2019s boss, Minister of Telecommunications Shahzad Aryobee, was frustrated that the police would not let him get close to the building, which was partially in flames, as occasional explosions broke out. Mr. Aryobee tried to reach by phone the 105 staff members he said were inside to reassure them. \u201cI\u2019m here, I won\u2019t leave you, help is coming,\u201d he said.\n\nThere was little the minister could do but look on helplessly as the night wore on, with temperatures well below freezing, until morning came and authorities claimed they had retaken control of the hotel.\n\nIt was the latest in a series of serious attacks on the Afghan capital that have alarmed residents and undermined confidence in the government\u2019s ability to cope with a worsening security situation.\n\nThere were fears of a much larger death toll, in part because similar attacks have proven more deadly. But in the morning, the security official said only five bodies had been found, with half of the building still uncleared.\n\nHowever, officials indicated they did not have yet have full control of the hotel.\n\n\u201cOur special forces are entering the building,\u201d said Gen. Afzal Aman, commander of the Kabul Garrison, an elite unit of police and soldiers that is responsible for security in the capital, who was reached by cellphone at the scene. \u201cThe attackers are at one side of the building. There are guests trapped in their rooms. We do not know who are the attackers.\u201d\n\nHotels in Kabul have long been a favored target of various insurgents, and Saturday\u2019s attack was the second time gunmen forced their way inside that hotel; in a 2011 attack, they went room to room, executing anyone they found.\n\nThe Intercontinental is one of the most heavily guarded places in the capital and benefits from sitting on a fortified hilltop. It is also a symbol of the Afghan state. Built in the 1970s as part of the Intercontinental Hotels chain, it was seized by the government after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. During the ensuing civil war it was heavily damaged in shelling by rival mujahedeen factions, then rebuilt after the Taliban were defeated.", "title": "At Least 5 Killed in Afghan Hotel Attack That Trapped Hundreds of Guests", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Reaves, 31, a graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design whose work was shown at the Whitney Biennial last year, has made a name for herself with raw, deconstructed artworks that can also function as furniture. The commission is the first time that Mr. Galliano has asked an artist to present new work alongside a Margiela collection.\n\n\u201cI think what drew us to one another was a similarity in our approach to technique, and an interest in making the ordinary somehow extraordinary,\u201d Ms. Reaves said. \u201cTo find a shared understanding between artists is quite rare. But in John\u2019s work, I see the identity of Margiela constantly coming together with his own. That it\u2019s so easy to get lost in the maze of pavilions has certain unexpected advantages.\n\nMake a wrong turn at Urban Panorama, and you might bumble into Unconventional and find yourself chatting with a first-time exhibitor like Ben Wayenberg, a hedge fund trader from Belgium who impulsively threw over finance for fashion.\n\nMr. Wayenberg prefers to be known as Ben Spleen and calls his fledgling label Spleen Unconventional.
