Given his age, 23, and dwindling eligibility, however, it is unlikely he will ever play for the Golden Gophers again, unless a related ruling is overturned on appeal.\n\nThe decision to suspend Lynch stems from an incident in April 2016 in which he allegedly sexually assaulted a Minnesota woman in his dormitory.\n\nThe university\u2019s Office of Equal Opportunity and Affirmative Action issued a decision on Thursday, ruling that Lynch was responsible for violations of the university code regarding sexual misconduct and sexual assault, stalking and relationship violence, and would be suspended from the university early next week, according to documents reviewed by The New York Times.", "title": "At Minnesota, Another Athlete Is Suspended in a Sexual Assault Case", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The retail industry is doubling down on digital to keep its unexpectedly strong holiday performance from becoming a fluke.\n\nThe floor of the National Retail Federation\u2019s annual trade show in New York this week was crowded with alert systems primed to recognize heavy-spending customers, so-called smart shelves fitted with real-time inventory trackers and robots for every step of the supply chain.\n\nIt was a conference about shopping that looked more like an expo for tech, as if the electronics trade show CES had decamped from Las Vegas and moved to the Javits Center in Manhattan.\n\nThe retail federation said last week that total sales in November and December made their largest leap since 2008, surging 5.5 percent from a year earlier. Participants take classes, attend performances, take part in workshops and contribute to a theatrical production. Four sister projects now exist in Dallas, Detroit, Seattle and London.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Mr. Eustis will join Mr. Kwei-Armah to share directing duties, and four actors from the original production will reprise their roles.\n\nThe free Shakespeare in the Park season will start in May with \u201cOthello,\u201d directed by the Tony Award winner Ruben Santiago-Hudson. It is slated to run from May 29 to June 24.", "title": "At Shakespeare in the Park, Everyday New Yorkers Will Take the Stage", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "PARK CITY, Utah \u2014 The world has finally gotten with the Sundance Film Festival. For years, thousands have flocked here sometimes for the love of movies, though at other times just because it seemed like a cool place to spend time and money. Each January, they would be met by high-minded reminders that the festival also nurtured talent, believed in story (a Sundance mantra) and embraced diversity. Those paying attention would notice that it generally made good on its principles with a slate that \u2014 good, dutiful or mediocre \u2014 was striking for its plurality of voices.\n\nAnd so this year, women were hot (not in a sexist, demeaning way, of course!) along with black filmmakers (again). Except that the festival and its parent organization, the Sundance Institute, have been pushing and advocating for filmmakers who are not white men for much of their history. In 1979, the year Robert Redford floated his plans for the institute, he spoke about diversity; he did so again this year. For the most part, the festival has been more invested in diversifying its filmmaker population than the kinds of movies it programs. Sundance invariably includes work that\u2019s somewhat off-center, like \u201cHale County This Morning, This Evening,\u201d a drifty, beguilingly elliptical documentary from RaMell Ross about everyday life in Alabama\u2019s Black Belt.\n\nYet for the most part, Sundance remains committed to character-driven tales about lost, besieged, oppressed, searching and triumphant outsiders of one type or another. All these were in evidence again at this year\u2019s festival, where some of the strongest, most memorable titles included \u201cLeave No Trace,\u201d a deeply affecting story from Debra Granik (\u201cWinter\u2019s Bone\u201d) about a veteran and his teenage daughter \u2014 movingly played by Ben Foster and Thomasin Harcourt McKenzie \u2014 living precariously off the grid in the Pacific Northwest. A different outsider emerges in \u201cThe Kindergarten Teacher,\u201d a remake of an Israeli film about a woman who comes to believe that one of her students is a prodigy. Directed by Sara Colangelo, this version doesn\u2019t have the merciless political bite of the original, but it does star an excellent Maggie Gyllenhaal.", "title": "At Sundance, Films Filled With Fury, Propelled by Outsiders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 The evening before President Trump arrived in Davos, Switzerland, to hobnob with the global elite and throw down the gauntlet of America First \u2014 and maybe nail down a date with President Emmanuel Macron of France for his first state dinner \u2014 Pierpaolo Piccioli, creative director of Valentino, stood atop an ornate iron staircase in the H\u00f4tel Salomon de Rothschild here and brought the couture shows to a close with a meditation on the subject of dreams.\n\nIt\u2019s a popular word when it comes to couture, which pretty much everyone involved likes to refer to as \u201cthe dream\u201d (in part to justify that it is out of reach for 99.9 percent of consumers).\n\nBut, like so many other words (Sad! Huge!) and language elements (the exclamation point) in the past year \u2014 and especially the past few weeks \u2014 it has been Trumpified.\n\nIt\u2019s almost impossible to hear \u201cdream\u201d and not think \u201cDreamers\u201d instead.", "title": "At Valentino, a Dream Ending: Couture for the Casual Era", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Fewer patients meant fewer chances of bad outcomes and better scores for a ranking system that grades all veterans hospitals on a scale of one to five stars. In 2016, administrators began cherry-picking cases against the advice of doctors \u2014 turning away complicated patients and admitting only the lowest-risk ones in order to improve metrics, according to multiple interviews with doctors and nurses at the hospital and a review of documents.\n\nThose metrics helped determine both the Roseburg hospital\u2019s rating and the leadership\u2019s bonus checks. By denying veterans care, the ratings climbed rapidly from one star to two in 2016 and the director earned a bonus of $8,120.\n\nCurrent and former staff members say the practice may reach well beyond Roseburg. Recent government reports also challenge the reliability of the department\u2019s metrics, casting doubt on a key tool that it says it relies on for reforming its beleaguered health care system.\n\nThe hospital\u2019s director, Doug Paxton, acknowledged that being more selective had improved ratings, but denied that the hospital was turning patients away to improve scores. Tightening admissions, he said, benefited patients, not metrics, because Roseburg\u2019s hospital lacks the resources for acute patients, so many need to be sent to larger hospitals in the community.\n\n\u201cThe numbers are indicators of the quality of care for the veterans, so, sure, we\u2019re worried about the numbers,\u201d he said. \u201cBut if you improve the care to veterans, in turn your numbers are going to improve. That\u2019s the bottom line.\u201d\n\nBut five emergency room doctors strongly disagreed. In a letter in response to questions from The New York Times, they said they had warned about the arrangement at Roseburg, where physicians are repeatedly overruled by administrators. \u201cWhen we voice concern that a process is dangerous and not good for patient care,\u201d they wrote, \u201cwe are met with the response that \u2018this is what the director wants.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cWe cannot express strongly enough how detrimental this process has been for patient care and how unacceptable it would be anywhere else,\u201d the letter noted.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe day after Mr. Savage was turned away, he showed up again asking for help. Again, he was denied. He waited for hours in the emergency room until a doctor finally admitted him against the wishes of the administration, his son-in-law said. The administration, ever mindful of metrics, moved him to a nursing home in less than 24 hours.\n\nThe Department of Veterans Affairs began grading hospitals about four years ago based on 110 performance indicators such as wait times, infection rates and nurse turnover at its 1,200 hospitals and clinics.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd on the surface, the scrutiny appears to have paid off. In 2016, according to the department, 82 percent of facilities improved.\n\nEven Roseburg. For years, the hospital in this logging town, which had no intensive care unit and limited surgery facilities, has struggled with the challenges many rural hospitals face. It was hard to attract new doctors. A small staff meant that just one open position could create a pileup of delays. Doctors constantly left for higher-paying jobs outside the system.\n\nBut as more patients were sent away in recent years, Roseburg was recognized by the Department of Veterans Affairs as one of the rising stars of its health care system.\n\nHowever, interviews with staff at the hospital suggest that some improvements were pure manipulation. And in some cases efforts to improve the rating actually made care worse.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a numbers game. The leadership has figured out the hospital can actually do better by seeing less patients,\u201d said Dr. Steven Blum, a hospitalist there who said he has seen patients regularly turned away or transferred to private hospitals. \u201cThese numbers show up on the director\u2019s report card, so it is very important they look good.\u201d\n\nOn average, more than half the hospital\u2019s beds now sit empty, he said, while patients are either sent home or transferred to private hospitals at government expense. Costly transfers don\u2019t come out of the Roseburg budget, but they do protect the hospital by moving risk to other facilities\u2019 books.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor the few patients who are admitted to Roseburg, other tactics are used to further improve the ratings. The hospital is penalized when patients are hospitalized with congestive heart failure, because it counts as a sign of poor preventive care. So, doctors said, they are told to list it as hypervolemia, a condition that occurs when there is too much fluid in the blood, a diagnosis that isn\u2019t tracked and hides the problem.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnother penalty is assessed for deaths in the hospital or within 30 days of discharge. To avoid counting these, doctors and nurses say, the administration regularly persuades veterans to be admitted only as hospice patients, signaling they are terminal and don\u2019t want treatment. Often neither is true. Doctors said some veterans were switched to hospice without their knowledge.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s extremely unethical, extremely,\u201d Dr. Blum said. \u201cI was asked to do it and so were the emergency department doctors. And we refused, so the administration just did it.\u201d\n\nThe focus on improving scores overshadowed deep-seated problems, staff said, including crippling turnover in primary care doctors.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn 2015, 17 of 23 primary care doctors left, according to Laura Follett, who oversaw scheduling for Roseburg\u2019s primary care clinic.\n\n\u201cTeams would have no doctors, and we\u2019d have to just cancel appointments,\u201d Ms. Follett said. She resigned in 2016.\n\nDangerous gaps appeared when doctors ordering critical tests were no longer around to review the results and alert patients. Several nurses said they saw positive cancer screening alerts and other critical lab results languish for weeks or even months.\n\n\u201cAlerts go into Neverland,\u201d said Treva Moss, a nurse who works in the medical center\u2019s specialty clinic in Eugene, Ore.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis fall, a number of employees complained to their congressman, Peter DeFazio, who blasted the hospital management on the floor of the House of Representatives as \u201cdysfunctional.\u201d At his request, the department is conducting an investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRoseburg\u2019s decision to cloak deficiencies by manipulating metrics is part of a persistent problem that reaches beyond one rural hospital, said Dr. Michael Mann, a professor of surgery at the University of California, San Francisco who led the thoracic surgery program at the San Francisco veterans hospital for eight years.\n\nAttempts to track performance in the veterans health care system have repeatedly created perverse outcomes, he said. He pointed out that the 2014 scandal exposing hidden wait times for veterans arose only after the department began tracking whether medical appointments were scheduled within 14 days, and veterans hospitals across the country that could not meet the goal began keeping off-the-books lists to hide actual wait times.\n\nDuring Dr. Mann\u2019s tenure, the veterans department began ranking hospitals on surgical complications. Remarkably, complications across the nationwide system dropped steadily, decreasing 47 percent between 1997 and 2007.\n\n\u201cOf course quality had not really improved by that much,\u201d Dr. Mann said. \u201cPeople had just learned to make it appear that it had.\u201d\n\nMany hospitals simply stopped performing surgeries on high-risk patients, or cut high-risk procedures all together, Dr. Mann said. \u201cI\u2019m very ashamed. I colluded. I was told not to operate and pulled back, and at least one of my patients died because of it.\u201d\n\nThe vast health care system has little choice but to rely on metrics, said David J. Shulkin, the veterans affairs secretary.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWithout it we\u2019re like an airport with no air traffic control,\u201d he said in an interview. \u201cWe don\u2019t know where our hospitals are, we don\u2019t know where they are headed. All we can do is respond to the crashes. I\u2019d rather be able to look ahead and prevent them.\u201d\n\nThe department regularly audits hospitals, he said. But the Government Accountability Office raised doubts in a report this fall noting in many cases the data seems inaccurate but the central office \u201chas not determined the extent to which these problems exist.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn 2014, when Mr. Paxton took over Roseburg, he vowed to turn around a hospital that had long ranked one of the worst in the system. He added staff, tried to cut inefficiencies, and tapped his new chief of mental health, a social worker by training named Paul Beiring, to figure out how to improve metrics.\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Beiring said focusing on hospital admissions was strategic because it accounted for a big slice of the rating.\n\n\u201cIt is weighted really high, so we knew we had to optimize that measure,\u201d he said.\n\nThe medical center created an \u201cexclusion list\u201d of conditions deemed too severe for Roseburg and put in place a \u201cutilization management team\u201d of administrators to approve hospital admissions using a risk analysis score.\n\nDoctors were required to call an off-site nurse to ask permission to admit a patient. Patients who had a high risk of death \u2014 usually because of advanced age \u2014 were routinely transferred to other hospitals or sent home. Even low-risk patients that Roseburg could easily have cared for, such as people with pneumonia, were denied, doctors said.\n\nIn a statement, the Department of Veterans Affairs said Roseburg was not manipulating data, adding: \u201cAll admission decisions are based on the hospital\u2019s ability to provide the care patients require and are made by clinicians, including the facility chief of staff and her clinical chiefs of service \u2014 nonclinical administrators have nothing to do with these decisions.\u201d\n\nThe hospital has no plans to change its admitting practices. In November, Roseburg was demoted to one star, because of what Mr. Beiring called \u201ca death or two\u201d but he said it was a temporary setback and the hospital had already \u201cdeployed counter measures\u201d that would soon send its ratings up again.\n\nOne of those measures, doctors said, appears to be that admissions have become ever more strict.", "title": "At Veterans Hospital in Oregon, a Push for Better Ratings Puts Patients at Risk, Doctors Say", "authors": ["Dave Philipps"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "The Rangers and Henrik Lundqvist came into Monday\u2019s Winter Classic unbeaten in outdoor games \u2014 and despite below freezing temperatures and a gritty performance by the last-place Buffalo Sabres, the Rangers prevailed again.\n\nThe temperature was 20.5 degrees at Citi Field for the opening face-off at 1:27 p.m. with Lundqvist bathed in sunlight in front of a sellout crowd of 41,821. J.T. Miller scored in overtime a little after 4 p.m. to give the Rangers a 3-2 win as the freeze deepened.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t play that many times outside \u2014 so obviously every game means a lot to you, you want to make the most of it,\u201d said Lundqvist, now a perfect 4-0-0 in outdoor games. \u201cYou want to make sure you can be able to sit down in a week or this summer or look back at this as a great memory. So you need to win. And we did.\u201d\n\nPaul Carey and Michael Grabner scored first-period goals, and Lundqvist made 31 saves.", "title": "At a Frigid Winter Classic, the Rangers Hold Off the Sabres", "authors": ["Allan Kreda"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "South High School is Denver\u2019s designated school for non-English-speaking students whose educations have been disrupted. Here, teenagers uprooted by war, violence and deprivation meet the most generous of Americans. Nice people from churches, synagogues and Goodwill all appear in their lives, brought together by a generously funded public school system and a dedicated English Language Acquisition teacher, Eddie Williams.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA Mexican-American whose own mother hid her roots out of shame and fear, Williams presides over a miniature United Nations of survivors of conflicts across the planet. There\u2019s Hsar Htoo, born in a refugee camp in Thailand to a Karen family from Myanmar. For him, everything in Denver is new: \u201crunning water, appliances, grocery stores, snow.\u201d\n\nWilliams worries about Iraqi sisters Jakleen and Mariam, daughters of a Christian father and Muslim mother; their father worked for the Americans, and then disappeared in Baghdad as sectarian violence erupted during the American troop drawdown. With their mother and a third sister, the girls spent six years in a Damascus suburb, missed a year of school because of car bombs and are now barely able to get to school on time.\n\nMethusella and Solomon, teenage boys from the Democratic Republic of Congo, were driven out of Goma with their family. The brothers show up at South High School on time every day, \u201calways nicely dressed,\u201d bending over their work with laser focus.\n\nThorpe gets to know some of the parents, like Methusella and Solomon\u2019s father, a dignified man wearing a collared shirt and navy trousers, working as a dishwasher and studying English out of a creased pocket dictionary he bought at Goodwill for a dollar. He speaks four languages including French, and when he sees dents in American houses, he must remind himself they are not caused by bullet holes, like the dents in houses back home.\n\nThorpe went deep, hiring 14 translators to conduct repeated interviews. Jakleen shares a letter she wrote to her father. Thorpe runs her hands over the Arabic letters on the page, and it\u2019s \u201clike reading Braille inversely,\u201d because the girl pressed so hard with her pen. Still, some of their sad secrets stay buried. Hsar Htoo asks Thorpe before she interviews him not to ask him about his father\u2019s death. She also never really unravels how the unaccompanied Salvadoran children, fleeing one of the hemisphere\u2019s most violent nations, survived harrowing cross-border trips and made their way from federal detention facilities to Denver.\n\nA year is a long time in teenage years, and frustration mounts. Some of the students are multilingual, and feel smarter than their lack of English allows. The Iraqi girls are so depressed they barely show up for school in the winter, racking up absences. The school encourages them with success stories. Thorpe\u2019s Arabic translator tells the girls that she raised her three children in America, and that they too hated it when they first arrived. Today, one is an engineer, another is a pediatric dentist, and the third is studying medicine.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThorpe makes fascinating linguistic discoveries. At first, the newcomers can\u2019t even communicate with one another. As the weeks pass, they resort to Google Translate, sometimes bypassing English altogether. Watching them translate Swahili to Arabic and Portuguese, Thorpe notices cognates between Arabic and the African languages, remnants of ancient connections between two regions that to many Americans are as unfamiliar as the dark side of the moon.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cAs the kids discovered these commonalities, I began to feel as though I were watching something like the living embodiment of a linguistic tree,\u201d Thorpe writes. \u201cThe classroom and the relationships forming inside of it were an almost perfect map of language proximity around the globe.\u201d\n\nThorpe has an epiphany of sorts when she learns that the word for \u201cbook\u201d is \u201cvirtually identical\u201d in the African languages and in Arabic. \u201cThat was the moment when I first grasped my own arrogance as an English speaker,\u201d Thorpe writes. \u201cI mean, the arrogance harbored by someone who knew only European languages, which rendered the well-laced interconnectedness of the rest of the world invisible.\u201d\n\nIn class, the teenagers are like teenagers everywhere. They are dramatic, they preen, they get depressed, they fall in love. One day, the students teach Thorpe a word \u2014 qalb \u2014 meaning \u201cheart\u201d in Farsi and Arabic. When Thorpe puts qalb into Google Translate, Arabic to English, something surprising happens. She is given a flood of meanings. \u201cI got heart, center, middle, transformation, conscience, core, marrow, pith, pulp, gist, essence, quintessence, topple, alter, flip, tip, overturn, reversal, overthrow, capsize, whimsical, capricious, convert, change, counterfeit. \u2026 My own concept of heart did not include flip, capsize or reverse.\u201d She concludes: \u201cOur two cultures did not have the same idea of what was happening at the core of our beings. \u2026 The idea of heart that these kids possessed appeared to have a lighter, more nimble quality.\u201d\n\nBut no matter how nimble and light their hearts might be, the students can\u2019t help noticing the rising resentment aimed their way. \u201cXenophobia was not something that was listed formally as a factor that inhibited learning among E.L.A. students,\u201d she writes, \u201cbut as the weeks slipped by and the cacophony of the presidential election ratcheted up, elevating all kind of sentiments in the voting populace, including a virulent dislike of people from other countries, I came to think of the fear some people in my own country felt toward foreigners as an issue that itself inhibited the newcomers\u2019 learning. They were acutely sensitive and could detect when they were misunderstood.\u201d\n\nOr hated.\n\nRight after Trump\u2019s election, the long commutes to and from school on Denver\u2019s public transit system become an obstacle course of shame and fear. People call the students \u201cdirty\u201d and tell them to \u201cgo home.\u201d A passenger on a bus tells one girl, \u201cWe are going to kick your ass out of this country.\u201d\n\nThe faculty at South High School struggles to help the students grapple with the new social climate, treating it like an emergency akin to a shooting or an outbreak of flu. The principal brings on nine temporary counselors to help, because the number of children seeking counseling \u201creached levels that nobody had ever seen before.\u201d Two students had attempted suicide.\n\nNevertheless, Thorpe\u2019s book is a reminder that in an era of nativism, some Americans are still breaking down walls and nurturing newcomers, the seeds of the great American experiment.", "title": "At a Public School in Denver, Refugee Children Find Hope and Frustration", "authors": ["Nina Burleigh", "Helen Thorpe"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Some political observers have also added Corey Johnson, who was also at the ceremony and is beginning his final term as a council member and is expected to be elected speaker of the City Council on Wednesday.\n\n\u201cI think Quinn is in the minds of most electeds looking to 2021,\u201d said Christina Greer, a professor of political science at Fordham University, who attended the inauguration Monday. Christine C. Quinn, the former City Council speaker, was seen as aligned with the policies of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, which hurt her Democratic primary bid in 2013. In other words, the mayoral hopefuls will quite likely spend much of the next four years as foils to Mr. de Blasio.\n\nIt is a familiar dynamic.\n\n\u201cI guarantee you in the next four years, we\u2019re going to agree on everything!\u201d Mr. de Blasio said sardonically of Ms. James and Mr. Stringer during his inaugural address.\n\nMr. Stringer, who privately toyed with the idea of mounting a primary challenge to Mr. de Blasio in 2017, begins the competition ahead in the money game. Because he did not accept matching funds for his re-election campaign for comptroller \u2014 a race in which he faced no strong competition \u2014 he can roll over much of his campaign cash into his 2021 mayoral campaign account, a sum that his aides put at more than $1.3 million.\n\nMr. Diaz had about $900,000 after his re-election race, though only about $600,000 of it could be rolled over into a campaign account because he took public funds for his campaign that he will have to return, according to a spokesman. So did Ms. James for her largely carefree cruise back to the public advocate\u2019s office; she also has far less in her account \u2014 about $39,000 \u2014 and the unspent funds would have to be paid back.\n\nBut there is a lot of time to make up ground.\n\n\u201cTish James!\u201d a man at the inauguration, wearing a pair of blankets over his wool coat, yelled out several times, whenever her name came up. He left after Ms. James spoke.\n\nBefore the inauguration, several council members in attendance joked that whoever gave the shortest speech would be the early favorite for 2021.\n\nIn that, Mr. Stringer, prevailed. While Ms. James\u2019s remarks stretched to 13 minutes, his ended in less than six.", "title": "At de Blasio Inaugural, Speeches by Two Who Might Replace Him", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "But why? To appreciate true genius is to see it uninhibited by exterior circumstances, to see it in its purest natural element. Sports are entertainment, and part of that entertainment is to see athletic genius at work. Why would we want to see a wonderful athlete unable to be his or her best because it\u2019s absurdly hot or cold outside? The beauty is in the performance, not what surrounds it.\n\nWould you appreciate, say, a Daniel Day-Lewis performance more because it was done in a storage freezer, or in the middle of a blazing desert? (Never mind that, knowing him, he\u2019d probably still win an Oscar.) Isn\u2019t the art itself enough?\n\nThe N.F.L. has constructed a whole cottage industry out of \u201cfrozen tundra\u201d as spectacle, all born from the infamous Ice Bowl of 1967, the N.F.L. Championship Game in which the Packers outlasted the Cowboys at Lambeau Field in conditions where the wind chill reached about minus 36 degrees Fahrenheit. But that game is compelling only as lore. In the moment, it was virtually unwatchable and barely even resembled football. During the game, the Packers quarterback Bart Starr got frostbite in his fingers; the linebacker Ray Nitschke\u2019s frostbite was so awful, his toenails fell off. The marching band in attendance couldn\u2019t play because the woodwinds froze.\n\nAfter whistling for kickoff, the referee Norm Schachter realized that his whistle was stuck to his lips; when he tried to remove it, the skin ripped from his mouth. (The refs stopped using their whistles after that and communicated by screaming for play to stop.) A fan in the stands died. This was not football. This was simply a bunch of men trying not to freeze to death. And yet the game is still talked about as a classic decades later, to the detriment not just of the men and women who play, but of the pleasure of the fans who watch them.\n\nWeather does not enhance the enjoyment of sports; it stands in the way. We watch sports to see a great quarterback throw a perfect pass to win the big game; we do not watch the ball hit a stiff wind and flutter like a wounded duck. Would anyone want to watch a basketball game where jump shots could be blown off course? What would that tell us about who was the better team?\n\nTo watch the Monfils-Djokovic match was to watch two men wilting and withering away; neither looked like even close to the star tennis players we\u2019ve seen them both be for years. Closing the roof and providing a climate-controlled environment \u2014 to play every sport in optimal conditions for athletes to thrive \u2014 wouldn\u2019t just be more humane to the players, it would be far more enjoyable to watch.\n\nWe want to see athletes do incredible things that we cannot. We do not want to see them begging for a break so that they do not collapse. Sports aren\u2019t endurance tests. They\u2019re entertainment. What\u2019s best for the athlete is, helpfully, also what\u2019s best for us.", "title": "Opinion | At the Australian Open, Too Hot to Be Good", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "All Things Cobo\n\nOnce you\u2019ve made it to Detroit, the Cobo Center (1 Washington Boulevard) will likely become your second home while in the city. The center is on the Detroit River shoreline, directly across from Windsor, Ontario. From public transportation to ride-hailing, there are several solid options for accessing the center.\n\nThe Detroit People Mover, an almost three mile, 13-stop monorail system, has a station on the third floor of the center. The fare is 75 cents, and the system normally runs from 6:30 a.m. to midnight on Monday through Thursday; 6:30 a.m. to 2 a.m. on Friday; 9 a.m. to 2 a.m. on Saturday; and noon until midnight on Sunday. There will be extended hours on select dates, including Sunday, Jan. 14, when the People Mover will run from 11 a.m. to midnight, and Friday, Jan. 19, when the system will run from 6:30 a.m. until 2:30 a.m. On the weekends during the public viewing of the auto show (Jan. 20 to 21 and Jan. 27 to 28), the People Mover will begin operations at 8 a.m. The system connects visitors to some of Detroit\u2019s most well-trafficked areas and notable attractions, including the Renaissance Center, the world headquarters of General Motors, Greektown, Campus Martius Park, Grand Circus Park and the Detroit Opera House.\n\nFrom Jan. 20 to 28, Canadian visitors can take an express bus from the Windsor International Transit Terminal in Windsor to the auto show. A round-trip ticket from the terminal to the Cobo Center costs $10 and can be purchased at the terminal. Proof of citizenship is mandatory.", "title": "At the Auto Show in Detroit, a Sneak Peek at What\u2019s New", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "These of course were the Globes for which most women dressed in black, not in mourning but in solidarity, as a way to mark a raised consciousness about sexual abuse and harassment and the fresh determination to fight them.\n\nBut the sartorial departure didn\u2019t pack quite the punch that it was intended to, partly because a monochromatic palette didn\u2019t change the plunging necklines, gaudy jewelry and glamorous fillips of every other awards show. This was more simplification than sacrifice.\n\nAnd one effect was that on the red carpet, interviewers asked women about sexual harassment and men about their recent professional achievements. The battle against inequality begat more inequality.\n\nOprah Winfrey redeemed that, with a gorgeous speech about how a yesterday of discrimination becomes a tomorrow of hope. One of the best routes, she noted, are role models. She recalled what it meant to her, when she was younger, to see Sidney Poitier receive Hollywood\u2019s highest accolades. And she wondered aloud what it might mean for little girls Sunday night to see her getting the Cecil B. DeMille Award for outstanding contributions to the world of entertainment.\n\nAs I listened to her, I thought about something that Saoirse Ronan said last week when, as part of the TimesTalks series, I interviewed her and Greta Gerwig in an auditorium in Manhattan about the movie \u201cLady Bird,\u201d which Ronan starred in and Gerwig wrote and directed. (It won the Globe on Sunday night for best motion picture, musical or comedy, and Ronan won for best performance by an actress in a motion picture, musical or comedy.)\n\nRonan told me that since making \u201cLady Bird,\u201d she found herself wanting not just to act but to direct, because she\u2019d watched Gerwig and actually seeing a woman in that job, right in front of her, had make it seem possible in a new way. It had put that aspiration into her vocabulary.\n\nHollywood at its best puts more aspirations in more people\u2019s vocabularies. It did that last year, and the Globes were a reminder. As a recent story in The Times noted: \u201cThe three most popular movies at theaters in the United States and Canada in 2017 \u2014 \u2018Star Wars: The Last Jedi,\u2019 \u2018Beauty and the Beast\u2019 and \u2018Wonder Woman\u2019 \u2014 were each driven by female characters, something that has not happened in at least 37 years, as far back as full box office data is available. The top comedy of the year, \u2018Girls Trip,\u2019 was also anchored by women, as was the top film to play in limited release, \u2018Lady Bird.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Opinion | At the Golden Globes, Hollywood Does What Washington Won\u2019t", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFarmworker women pick and plant the food that we eat and have a long history of combating sexual violence,\u201d said Ms. Ram\u00edrez, who fights sexual violence against farmworkers and pushes for Latina empowerment. Of the women working in Hollywood, she said, \u201cWe stand with them and we lend them our power and strength. Part of our work as an organization is to fight for gender equality across all lines.\u201d\n\n\"50/50 by 2020,\u201d said Ms. Dern, who is a nominee for her performance in \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d referring to a key goal of Time\u2019s Up: to have gender parity at talent agencies and studios in two years.\n\nSusan Sarandon and Rosa Clemente", "title": "At the Golden Globes, Stars and Their Activist Guests Talk About Why They Fight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "As a result, most, like Kelly Clarkson and Miley Cyrus, ended up carrying their roses in their hands. Ms. Cabello, the young Cuban-American singer whose affecting speech about Dreamers and her own history, made after Kesha\u2019s appearance, was another powerful moment, attached hers to her handbag. And they seem to have largely disappeared by the time the women entered the auditorium. Presumably, there were a lot of dead flowers left behind, which is probably not exactly the symbol the organizers were going for.\n\nThe Golden Globe Awards, with its surprisingly effective call for the women attending to wear all black in support of Time\u2019s Up, not only raised our expectations of what clothes can say on the red carpet, but created the expectation that they should be used to say something in the first place.\n\nPinning on a point of view is no longer enough. We\u2019ve been there, done that. And now the bar has been raised. If women (and men) really want their point of view on change to be seen as well as heard, they need to follow through on the idea. And that includes changing what they wear. Clothes are an expression of culture.\n\nWithout that kind of added dimension, the fashion, even the most glamorous, dream-inducing kind, seems less compelling. It doesn\u2019t have the same staying power, because it doesn\u2019t have the same substance, no matter how much material is involved.\n\nWith the Oscars looming, the final exclamation point to this awards season, it\u2019s an important lesson. The pressure will probably be high for nominees and other attendees to put aside politics and play the old game, but the stakes have changed.\n\nIf they are smart, they will start planning the red carpet revolution now.", "title": "At the Grammy Awards, White Roses Paled in Comparison to Kesha Rose", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "His models always look en route to or from a blissed-out music festival somewhere \u2014 here, a few came wrapped in blankets. They mash up textures, fabrics and sizes; they bounce beads and gummy-bear pendants; their clothes are plastered with monkeys or chairs or beakers or keys. (There was not, according to a Marni spokesman, any fur.)\n\nWhen his men wear suits, the garments are rumpled and wrinkled, small in the jacket and long in the leg, sleeves trailing, like a parody of working men \u2014 kids playing dress up.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s how I would like to live my whole life,\u201d Mr. Risso said backstage. \u201cThinking as a child thinks, how he lives.\u201d What he really wanted was fun.\n\nFun is in short supply these days, in fashion and out of it. It has become a clich\u00e9 of fashion writing to note the contrast between the grim world pressing in at the door and the blithe carrying-on inside, but here was the literal end: the rage outside, playtime within.\n\nIn difficult times, some designers offer armor; Mr. Risso offers fun. After more than a year at Marni, Mr. Risso has begun to seem a bit stuck in that gear, but that\u2019s not to say that fun is an illegitimate response. It\u2019s a finger plugged into the ear, or as the Flower Children once did, a bloom stuck in a barrel of a gun.", "title": "At the Men\u2019s Shows, Fun and a Sweater for Formal Wear", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 Militants attacked an army unit near Afghanistan\u2019s main military university early Monday, killing at least 11 Afghan soldiers and wounding 16 others in what has been an intense period of violence in Kabul, the capital.\n\nGen. Dawlat Waziri, a spokesman for the Ministry of Defense, said five militants were involved in the attack on a unit of the army\u2019s 111th Capital Division, which is based next to the university.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know how they entered, but two of them blew themselves up after entering, the third and fourth were gunned down by security forces, and a fifth attacker was arrested,\u201d General Waziri said.\n\nThe Islamic State\u2019s local affiliate in Afghanistan claimed responsibility in a message distributed by the group\u2019s Amaq news agency.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the group\u2019s foothold in eastern Afghanistan has come under sustained military pressure, it has increasingly claimed responsibility for urban attacks. But in those urban attacks, Afghan and Western officials see an overlap between the Islamic State and the Haqqani network, a brutal arm of the Taliban long behind complex urban operations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese type of attacks are always carried out by the Haqqani network \u2014 I think this attack is also carried out by Haqqani, but ISIS is claiming credit,\u201d General Waziri said. \u201cFor us there is no difference between Taliban, Haqqani and ISIS \u2014 all of them are terrorist groups.\u201d", "title": "Attack Near Kabul Military Academy Kills 11 Afghan Soldiers", "authors": ["Mujib Mashal", "Fahim Abed"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt\u2019s 2018, and there are young men and women now being sent over there who were literally in diapers when we first sent troops to Afghanistan,\u201d said Will Fischer, a former Marine lance corporal who served in Iraq.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re fighting the same battle over and over again,\u201d Senator Tammy Duckworth, Democrat of Illinois and a veteran of the Iraq war. \u201cOur troops are losing their friends, they are shedding blood, over the same patch of ground, over and over again.\u201d\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis, visiting Kabul in September, was quickly hustled to waiting helicopters for the brief flight to NATO headquarters instead of driving downtown on the harrowing roads from the international airport on the capital\u2019s outskirts. The Taliban still fired off some obligatory rockets at the airport to welcome him.\n\nStill, American officials insist that change is just around the corner.\n\n\u201cLooking ahead to 2018, as President Ghani said, he believes we have turned the corner and I agree,\u201d Gen. John W. Nicholson Jr. told Pentagon reporters on Nov. 28, referring to Afghanistan\u2019s president, Ashraf Ghani. \u201cThe momentum is now with the Afghan Security Forces.\u201d\n\nHe would know. He is the latest in a string of commanders in Afghanistan, and he said the same thing a year before. \u201cWe are stabilizing what was once a deteriorating situation and have the international support to progress even further in the coming years,\u201d he told the same group of reporters in December 2016.\n\nSix months later, a truck bomb devastated a central area of Kabul near the presidential palace and foreign embassies in one of the war\u2019s deadliest strikes. Some 150 people were killed and 300 more injured.\n\nAmerican optimism goes all the way back to Nov. 17, 2001, when Laura Bush, then the first lady, said the Taliban \u201cis now in retreat across much of the country, and the people of Afghanistan, especially women, are rejoicing.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAt the time, American troops had been in Afghanistan for a month. And just days into 2002, Sgt. First Class Nathan Ross Chapman of San Antonio became the first American soldier killed by hostile fire, during an ambush in eastern Afghanistan.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSergeant Chapman\u2019s death would be followed by those of 2,215 more American troops in Afghanistan, according to the Pentagon\u2019s most recent count.\n\nThree months after Sergeant Chapman\u2019s death, Condoleezza Rice, then the White House national security adviser, declared that \u201cthe Taliban regime has been routed.\u201d\n\n\u201cAfghanistan,\u201d she said, \u201chas been transformed from a terrorist-sponsored state into a country led by people who are trying to create a better future.\u201d\n\nA year later, on May 1, 2003, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said the main war effort was ending. \u201cWe\u2019re at a point where we clearly have moved from major combat activity to a period of stability and stabilization and reconstruction activities,\u201d he said of a conclusion by the United States, NATO and the Afghan government.\n\nHe called most of Afghanistan \u201csecure.\u201d Troops were still dying: Four German soldiers who were heading home that June at the end of their NATO deployment were killed in a suicide bombing on the way to the airport in Kabul.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut by then, the United States\u2019 attention had turned almost completely to Iraq. American forces would soon be battling insurgents in gritty urban warfare that played out on television screens around the world. Afghanistan, and the Taliban\u2019s resurgence there, receded from the national conscience.\n\nAs he was running for president in 2008, Barack Obama presented Afghanistan as the war the United States should be fighting, not the \u201cdumb war\u201d in Iraq. Still, days before he left office, President George W. Bush visited Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan on Dec. 16, 2008, to tell troops that \u201cthe Taliban is gone from power, and it\u2019s not coming back.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExcept the Taliban had already returned. In July 2008, the group bombed the Indian Embassy in Kabul, killing 58. Nine American troops died the same month in an attack on a NATO base. And that August, the Taliban killed 10 French soldiers in the country\u2019s eastern Uzbin Valley.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut American commanders were still predicting victory.\n\n\u201cThe insurgency is not going to win in Afghanistan,\u201d said Gen. David D. McKiernan, who was the top commander on Feb. 18, 2009, when he briefed reporters. \u201cThe vast majority of the people that live in Afghanistan reject the Taliban or other militant insurgent groups. They have nothing to offer them. They do not bring any hope for a better future.\n\n\u201cThe insurgency will not win in Afghanistan.\u201d\n\nAbout the same time, President Obama authorized sending in 17,000 more troops. His national security adviser, Gen. James L. Jones, promised in March to deploy an additional 4,000 Americans to train Afghan national security forces.\n\nAnd by December, Mr. Obama agreed to a surge of an additional 30,000 troops in Afghanistan.\n\n\u201cIt will be clear to the Afghan government, and more importantly to the Afghan people, that they will ultimately be responsible for their own country,\u201d Mr. Obama said in a speech at West Point on Dec. 1, 2009. But he indicated that he would begin withdrawing troops in 2011.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Taliban kept up its onslaught. Among other violence, military bases at Bagram and Kandahar were attacked in 2010 and a NATO convoy in Kabul was bombed, killing 18.\n\nStill, on March 16, 2011, Gen. David H. Petraeus, the war\u2019s commander at the time, said he was preparing to hand off responsibility for security operations to Afghan forces, given \u201chard-fought achievements\u201d that he said had reversed the Taliban\u2019s momentum in key areas.\n\nOn May 27, 2014, Mr. Obama announced that the bulk of American forces would head home. An estimated 100,000 United States troops were in Afghanistan at the peak of war operations; that number would dwindle to 10,000 under Mr. Obama\u2019s strategy.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s time to turn the page on more than a decade in which so much of our foreign policy was focused on the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq,\u201d he said.\n\nThat was before the Islamic State arrived on the scene. In 2015, the extremist group rooted in Iraq and Syria marked its arrival in Afghanistan with a suicide bomb attack in Jalalabad, killing more than 30 people and injuring more than 100.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNot to be outdone, the Taliban soon after overran Kunduz \u2014 the first time the group had managed to take over a major city since 2001. Afghan government troops, backed by the United States, eventually wrested back control.\n\nBy the end of 2016, General Nicholson, the current war commander, said the United States\u2019 support \u201csends a clear message to the enemies of peace and stability in Afghanistan, and the world, frankly, that they will not win.\u201d Four months later, he ordered the dropping of the \u201cmother of all bombs\u201d \u2014 the most powerful conventional bomb in the American arsenal \u2014 on an Islamic State cave complex in the Achin district of eastern Afghanistan.\n\nIn November, General Nicholson delivered another bright update from Kabul. \u201cThe Taliban cannot win in the face of the pressures that I outlined,\u201d he said on Nov. 28. \u201cAgain, their choices are to reconcile, live in irrelevance or die.\u201d\n\nThe extremists chose a different option.\n\nThe Taliban launched a bloody 15-hour siege on a major hotel in Kabul last week, killing 22. On Saturday, at least 95 people died when an ambulance packed with explosives blew up on a busy street in the capital. And the Islamic State claimed responsibility for an attack on an Afghan military base on Monday. At least 11 Afghan soldiers were killed.", "title": "Attacks Reveal What U.S. Won\u2019t: Victory Remains Elusive in Afghanistan", "authors": ["Helene Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on Australia, news of the world and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Want to receive it by email? Sign up here.\n\n______\n\nJournalism often relies on serendipity.\n\nEarlier this week, for example, I went out to Parramatta, one of western Sydney\u2019s most vibrant and diverse areas, to talk to people about Australia Day. And within minutes of arriving, I saw a familiar face walking toward me: Acuoth Achol.\n\nA gentle giant with a smile that makes you want to talk to him, he\u2019s one of the coaches of the Savannah Pride, the South-Sudanese-Australian basketball team I wrote about soon after arriving in Australia. His office, where he works on refugee resettlement, was just a block away.\n\n\u201cThings have been going really well,\u201d he said as we shook hands. Want to receive it by email? Sign up here.\n\n______\n\nA few newsletters ago, I asked for your help. Could we, together, vanquish Canada?\n\nCould we add more new sign-ups to the Australia Letter than my colleague, Ian Austen, could add to his newsletter, the Canada Letter?\n\nSince Canada had more than double our subscriber base to pull from, it was an epic challenge. Not quite like trying to reach the third round of the Australian Open when you\u2019re only 15 years old. But sort of.\n\nAnd you did it.\n\nMarta Kostyuk became the youngest woman to reach the third round of a Grand Slam in 21 years this week; and as of Thursday night, 1,921 people signed up for the Australia Letter since my plea at the end of November, compared to 1,334 for the Canada Letter.", "title": "Australia vs. Canada. The Results Are In.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "He was 32-3 on outdoor hard courts in 2017: his only losses coming against Evgeny Donskoy in the second round in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Alexander Zverev in the final in Montreal and Juan Martin del Potro in the quarterfinals of the United States Open.\n\nNadal won that U.S. Open to claim his first hardcourt singles title in nearly four years. But Nadal has never won a Grand Slam tournament without playing in an official event at least three weeks before it and has rarely won a Grand Slam tournament without winning a lead-in tournament.\n\nThis year, ongoing pain in his right knee forced him to withdraw from his planned warm-up tournament in Brisbane. Despite being No. 1, Nadal is thus an outsider in Melbourne. So of course is Djokovic, a six-time Australian Open champion who has not played an official match since retiring at Wimbledon in July against Tomas Berdych because of a damaged right elbow that is still a concern and was encased in a sleeve during exhibition play on Wednesday.\n\nIn short, there is ample room for an ambush in the men\u2019s draw with a gifted, unpredictable outsider like Australia\u2019s Nick Kyrgios in fine form and talents like Zverev, Del Potro, Dimitrov and David Goffin lurking. There is even more room on the women\u2019s side with the 2016 Australian Open champion Angelique Kerber back on target and with a new coach, Wim Fissette, after slumping in 2017.\n\nUnseeded women have won two of the last three majors: Ostapenko at the French Open and Sloane Stephens at the U.S. Open. An extension of the trend is not out of the question with Maria Sharapova unseeded in Melbourne. But it seems more likely that the winner will come out of the Top 10, seven of whom have yet to win a major singles title: Simona Halep, Caroline Wozniacki, Elina Svitolina, Karolina Pliskova, Caroline Garcia, Johanna Konta and CoCo Vandeweghe.\n\nWilliams remains, at 23 Grand Slam singles titles, one short of Court\u2019s record. But their mutual absences in Melbourne do not remove Court from the conversation in Melbourne.\n\nCourt, a Pentecostal pastor, has strong views on homosexuality. Her public stance against same-sex marriage, which is now legal in Australia after a vote last year, has led to renewed calls that Margaret Court Arena should be renamed. Martina Navratilova, who, like Court, is a member of the International Tennis Hall of Fame, is one of the more prominent figures who have called for a change.", "title": "Australian Open Begins a Challenging Season in Tennis", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "MELBOURNE, Australia \u2014 Angelique Kerber had already proved that she could handle the biggest moments in tennis. Madison Keys had not, and a one-sided women\u2019s quarterfinal at the Australian Open on Wednesday did not resolve that disparity.\n\nKerber, who just turned 30, is back on a high in Melbourne: reading the flow of play beautifully, bending low and slapping straight-line winners off ill-considered shots from her opponents.\n\nEven on a very good day for Keys, beating this version of Kerber would have been difficult. But on another tough day for Keys in the Grand Slam spotlight, this match quickly turned into a mismatch.\n\nIt was 4-0 Kerber in 14 minutes, 6-1 Kerber in 22 minutes. And, ultimately, despite all of Keys\u2019s ball-striking talent and earnest off-season efforts, it was 6-1, 6-2, Kerber, in 51 minutes.", "title": "Australian Open: Angelique Kerber and Simona Halep Advance to Semifinals", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think game-wise, my level was good,\u201d he said. \u201cI think I should have won in four sets.\u201d\n\nZverev acknowledged, though, that Chung, 21, had dramatically improved in the last year and that he was playing better than his current ranking, No. 58, would suggest.\n\n\u201cThis was a top-10 level match from the start till the end of the fourth set, and for him until the end,\u201d Zverev said. \u201cWhen he plays like that, there are very, very few people who will beat him.\u201d\n\nChung went undefeated last November to capture the title at the NextGen ATP Finals, a tournament for the best eight players who were 21 and younger. (Zverev didn\u2019t take part because he qualified for the ATP Finals in London.)\n\nAnd with his run in Melbourne, Chung became the first South Korean man ever to reach the fourth round at the Australian Open and just the third Korean player (male or female) to go so far at a Grand Slam.\n\nPhoto\n\nHis next opponent is not ranked as high as Zverev, but presents just as daunting a challenge \u2014 the six-time champion Novak Djokovic. Seeded 14th this year, Djokovic beat Chung in straight sets in the first round two years ago.\n\n\u201cI have one more chance to play with a great player in the world,\u201d Chung said. \u201cI\u2019m just happy to share the court with Novak.\u201d\n\nWhen a downcast Zverev was asked after the match whether his problem in best-of-five-set matches was physical or mental, he replied, \u201cDefinitely not physical.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI have some figuring out to do, what happens to me in deciding moments in Grand Slam,\u201d he said. \u201cIt happened at Wimbledon. It happened in New York. It happened here.\u201d\n\nZverev\u2019s Grand Slam record is a meager 14-11. Among those who have beaten him are Borna Coric (second round, 2017 United States Open), Dan Evans (second round, 2016 U.S. Open) and Fernando Verdasco (first round, 2017 French Open).\n\nDjokovic continued his comeback from six months out with an injured right elbow, beating No. 21 Albert Ramos-Vinolas, 6-2, 6-3, 6-3.\n\n\u201cI obviously have to be more humble this time with my expectations because I haven\u2019t played for six months,\u201d Djokovic said.\n\nFederer entered last year\u2019s Australian Open under similar circumstances, coming off an extended break for a knee injury, and went on to win the title. His defense moved through another round Saturday with a 6-2, 7-5, 6-4 win over No. 29 Richard Gasquet.\n\nFederer, the No. 2 seed, will next face the former world junior No. 1 Marton Fucsovics, who beat Nicolas Kicker in straight sets.\n\nAngelique Kerber routed Maria Sharapova, 6-1, 6-3, in their third-round match on Saturday night, meaning she will be the only Grand Slam champion in the fourth round of the women\u2019s draw.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSharapova, a five-time major winner, was back at Melbourne Park for the first time since 2016, when a failed doping test led to a 15-month ban from tennis.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe had comfortable wins in the first two rounds and was growing in confidence, but she had no answers for Kerber, who is on a 12-match winning streak in a kind of comeback of her own after a sliding down the rankings last year.\n\n\u201cI learned a lot from the last 12, 24 months. I had a great 2016, and last year was a little tougher,\u201d Kerber said, reflecting on how her year-end ranking dropped from No. 1 to 21 when she failed to defend her Australian or U.S. Open titles. \u201cAnybody who knows me knows I never give up.\u201d\n\nHer match with Sharapova was over in 1 hour 4 minutes, a vast contrast to top-ranked Simona Halep\u2019s 4-6, 6-4, 15-13 win over Lauren Davis in 3 hours 44 minutes.\n\nDavis, an American ranked 76th in the world, needed two medical timeouts for foot treatment in the third set, which lasted 2 hours 22 minutes. The Romanian Halep is playing in her first major tournament since ascending to No. 1. She has yet to win a Grand Slam; her best finishes have been two trips to the final at the French Open.\n\nHalep\u2019s next opponent will be Naomi Osaka, who beat 18th-seeded Ash Barty, 6-4, 6-2.\n\nWhen No. 20 Barbora Strycova beat the American-Croatian qualifier Bernarda Pera, 6-2, 6-2, Madison Keys, the runner-up at the 2017 U.S. Open, became the only American woman to reach the fourth round.\n\nKeys advanced, 6-3, 6-4, over Ana Bogdan and will next play No. 8 Caroline Garcia, who beat Aliaksandra Sasnovich, 6-3, 5-7, 6-2. Her assignment will get tougher, with Kerber up next.\n\nTomas Berdych ended Juan Martin del Potro\u2019s return to Melbourne Park \u2014 his first visit since 2014 \u2014 with a 6-3, 6-3, 6-2 win.\n\nFifth-seeded Dominic Thiem beat Adrian Mannarino, 6-4, 6-2, 7-5, to set up a fourth-round match against Tennys Sandgren, who continued his career-best run by beating Maximilian Marterer, 5-7, 6-3, 7-5, 7-6 (5).", "title": "Australian Open: Another Early Exit for Alexander Zverev", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "As temperatures soared toward 104 degrees, it was a sizzling demolition of an opponent who had taken Sharapova to three sets in both their previous meetings.\n\nSharapova needed more than three hours to defeat Sevastova when the pair played in Beijing four months ago, and she was in no mood to take her time again as the temperatures rose.\n\nShe broke Sevastova to open the second set, but Sevastova broke back immediately. The jolt to the Sharapova juggernaut was evident, and she began to make unforced errors as service holds and breaks were exchanged.\n\nAt 4-4 a backhand winner got Sharapova to break point, and she converted on a follow-up screaming shot. But, once again, Sevastova broke back, and wound up forcing a tiebreaker.\n\nSharapova regathered herself and hit a scarcely believable forehand crosscourt winner on the run to get to 5-2. After squandering a pair of match points, she secured her victory.\n\nSharapova endured a string of defeats early in her comeback but she has been working her way back up the rankings. Davis held up well through the grueling battle but needed two medical timeouts for foot treatment in the third set. One involved tending to a problem more common among ultrarunners: A toenail began to fall off. After Davis received medical attention for it, her movement appeared unimpeded.\n\nPhoto\n\nHalep had badly rolled her left ankle during her first-round victory over the Australian wild card Destanee Aiava, but she surprised herself by moving with relative ease in her second-round win over Eugenie Bouchard.\n\nAgainst Davis, Halep was more aggressive early in rallies and dominated their shorter exchanges, while the American consistently prevailed in longer rallies.\n\nFor better or worse, Halep said, she could not feel her ankle, which was tightly taped and numbed by painkillers.\n\nDarren Cahill, who has coached Halep for several years, said she prevailed because she had \u201creally toughened up over the past couple of years.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe\u2019s battling out every single match,\u201d Cahill said. \u201cWhoever won that match, I thought it was a minor miracle to go through the ups and downs of that, the roller coaster. I said to her, \u2018I\u2019m not sure I\u2019ve sat through a more emotional tennis match, in all my years of coaching.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s one for the ages, and a credit to both ladies,\u201d he added. \u201cI thought they were magnificent.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHalep\u2019s survival came three days after second-seeded Caroline Wozniacki saved two match points to keep herself in the tournament, and two days after third-seeded Garbi\u00f1e Muguruza was eliminated in the third round. Altogether, three of the top seven seeds in the women\u2019s draw have departed.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd Halep survived only by battling through one of the toughest matches in the tournament\u2019s history. It tied the record for most games in a women\u2019s match at this event, but was not the longest in time spent. That was played in 2011, when Francesca Schiavone beat Svetlana Kuznetsova, 16-14, in the third set of a match that lasted a full hour more than Halep\u2019s win over Davis.\n\nHalep\u2019s next opponent will be Naomi Osaka, who defeated 18th-seeded Ashleigh Barty, 6-4, 6-2. Osaka, ranked 72nd in the world, had 12 aces and 24 winners. Barty was the last Australian woman remaining in the singles draw.\n\nMadison Keys, a United States Open finalist, also moved through to the fourth round, with a 6-3, 6-4 win over Ana Bogdan at Margaret Court Arena.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. She then played only one match after the U.S. Open before shutting down her season early to let the wrist heal. It has helped her start the new season feeling mentally fresh, as well.\n\n\u201cI finished the U.S. Open and I was exhausted,\u201d she said. \u201cSo as amazing as that run was, the combination of being exhausted from that and having a wrist that still wasn\u2019t 100 percent perfect, I just needed to kind of shut it down, calm down, and then I was really excited to start the new season.\u201d\n\nKeys is the only one of the four American women who reached the semifinals at the U.S. Open last September still in contention in Melbourne \u2014 Stephens, Venus Williams and CoCo Vandeweghe were all eliminated in the first round.\n\nKeys will next play Caroline Garcia, a 6-3, 5-7, 6-2 winner over Aliaksandra Sasnovich.", "title": "Australian Open: No. 1 Simona Halep Survives a Nearly 4-Hour Thriller", "authors": ["Ben Rothenberg"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "He is no longer a candidate for a record seventh Australian Open men\u2019s singles title. Instead, the quarterfinal in his section of the draw will match the unseeded Chung against the unseeded American Tennys Sandgren, whose five-set upset of No. 5 seed Dominic Thiem was arguably the bigger surprise on Monday.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know if this is a dream or not,\u201d Sandgren said to the crowd in his on-court interview after his 6-2, 4-6, 7-6 (7-4), 6-7 (7-9), 6-3 victory. \u201cAll you guys are here, and I\u2019m not in my underwear, so maybe it\u2019s not a dream.\u201d\n\nOne could understand Sandgren\u2019s uncertainty. At 26, he has spent most of his career in tennis\u2019s minor leagues: the satellite and challenger circuits. He had yet to win a match at a Grand Slam tournament when he arrived in Melbourne this year. (Sandgren\u2019s given name is a family name and has nothing to do with tennis, even though he ended up excelling at it, playing at the University of Tennessee.)\n\nBut he is now in the final eight with Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer, the defending champion, who has yet to lose a set this year and defeated Marton Fucsovics, 6-4, 7-6 (7-3), 6-2, on Monday. Federer will face Tomas Berdych in the other quarterfinal in the bottom half of the men\u2019s draw.\n\n\u201cI definitely had a real pinch-me moment,\u201d said Sandgren, describing his internal dialogue after match point as: \u201cWow, this is hopefully real. If I wake up now, I\u2019m going to be real upset.\u201d\n\nLast week Sandgren surprised No. 9 seed Stan Wawrinka in the second round, winning by 6-2, 6-1, 6-4. Wawrinka was returning from a six-month break of his own after knee surgery and was visibly struggling to find his rhythm and form.\n\nBut Thiem, a powerful Austrian, said he was in perfect health, and he appeared to have the edge when he forced a fifth set after saving a match point at 5-6 in the fourth-set tiebreaker with a bold backhand winner down the line from what appeared to be a compromised position.", "title": "Australian Open: Novak Djokovic Falls to Hyeon Chung", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Nadal, with his spot in a 10th Australian Open quarterfinal secure, draped an arm around his Argentine friend Schwartzman and patted him on top of the head after they met at the net.\n\nNadal called it \u201ca great battle\u201d and said it had given him \u201cconfidence I can resist for four hours on court at a good intensity.\u201d\n\nNadal lost last year\u2019s Australian Open final to Roger Federer, but went on to regain the No. 1 ranking and win the French and United States Open titles before bringing his season to a premature end because of an injured right knee.\n\nHe didn\u2019t play a competitive match before the Australian Open, and he advanced through three rounds without dropping a set.\n\nThat streak finished when Schwartzman took the second set, rebounding three times after dropping serve to break back against Nadal and level the match.\n\nNadal lifted his play to win the third, but Schwartzman didn\u2019t relent.\n\nThe second game of the fourth set lasted 20 points and almost 13 minutes, with Nadal finally holding after saving five break points.\n\nHe broke again in the next game and withstood more break points \u2014 seven in all in the last set and 15 of 18 in the match \u2014 before clinching it in 3 hours 51 minutes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt was a good test for me,\u201d Nadal said. \u201cIt was a lot of hours on court. Moments under pressure.
