She tried a between-the-legs shot for the first time in a tour-level match.\n\n\u201cI think you can tell my confidence is high,\u201d Wozniacki said in an on-court TV interview. \u201cI tried a tweener today and it went in.\u201d\n\nWozniacki next plays Carla Su\u00e1rez Navarro, who came back from a set and 4-1 down to beat No. 32 Anett Kontaveit, 4-6, 6-4, 8-6.\n\nElise Mertens reached the quarterfinals in her Australian Open debut, beating Petra Martic 7-6 (5), 7-5, to extend her winning streak to nine matches, including a title run at the Hobart International. \u201cIt\u2019s been amazing \u2014 good start of the year,\u201d Mertens said. \u201cThis is really a bonus.\u201d\n\nMertens\u2019s next opponent is fourth-seeded Elina Svitolina, who started her fourth-round match just before midnight and was finished within an hour. She beat the Czech qualifier Denisa Allertova, 6-3, 6-0, to reach the quarterfinals here for the first time.", "title": "Australian Open: Rafael Nadal Survives Marathon Match", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "There is no dishonor in any of that. Chung has years ahead of him to become a more complete threat, and his movement dropped off after the opening games, when he was sliding, Djokovic-style into the corners.\n\nMeanwhile, the second-seeded Federer continues to bust through mental and physical barriers and will face another member of the tennis establishment, the No. 6 seed Marin Cilic of Croatia, in Sunday\u2019s final. Federer said it was bittersweet to reach the final in the way he did.\n\nIt was surely bittersweet for the Australian Open organizers as well. This is the only Grand Slam tournament that stages the men\u2019s semifinals on separate days, and Friday\u2019s abbreviated match made for a very short main event.\n\n\u201cI knew he was having issues with his feet going into it,\u201d Federer said of Chung. \u201cBut I knew he also had issues going into the match against Novak.\n\n\u201cHe handled that very well, the same against Sandgren,\u201d he added, referring to Chung\u2019s four-set victory over the American Tennys Sandgren in the quarterfinals.\n\n\u201cFor me, I was trying to block that away and just play Chung himself,\u201d Federer said. \u201cIf he had no issues, well, that\u2019s normal. If he has issues, well, bad luck for him, and I\u2019ll take advantage of it.\u201d\n\nNeville Godwin, Chung\u2019s coach, said the problem began in earnest in the quarterfinals of the tournament in Auckland, New Zealand, earlier this month when Chung lost to David Ferrer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHyeon always has calluses on his feet, which is normal, all the players have that,\u201d Godwin said. \u201cHe just hadn\u2019t shaved them down far enough, so in Auckland they started blistering and bruising underneath.\u201d\n\nGodwin said that when Chung arrived in Melbourne, he held up well for the first week, but that he required anesthetizing injections in both feet before each of his last three matches. At this stage, he essentially had open wounds that were wrapped for play.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThese are serious injections,\u201d Godwin said. \u201cEach one lasts like a minute. The guy is biting into a towel for a minute, and you have to do it pretty close to match time otherwise it wears off. So 45 minutes before a match, and he\u2019s biting into a towel having someone jabbing his feet.\u201d\n\nGodwin said that it was Chung\u2019s decision to take the injections and that the problem was a new one.\n\n\u201cWe just basically ran out of time,\u201d Godwin said. \u201cHe\u2019s young, and he had a great run, and it\u2019s a very unfortunate time for it to happen, but he managed it the best that he could actually. He had three doctors, a podiatrist and five trainers running around after him the, sort of, last 10 days.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGodwin said he believed there was no other good option except to retire from the match.\n\n\u201cIt was starting to look messy, where he couldn\u2019t move,\u201d he said. \u201cFor someone who laid his foundation for the whole tournament on his movement, it\u2019s not the right thing. There was obviously something wrong.\u201d\n\nIt is unclear how long recovery will take.\n\n\u201cEvery human being is different in their healing protocol,\u201d Godwin said. \u201cNow he really has to do nothing for five days to seven days. He\u2019s entered into some tournaments coming up, so we literally have to take it day by day and see. Luckily he\u2019s had a good result, so it does buy us a little more time.\u201d\n\nOn Monday, Chung will climb to No. 29 from 58th in the rankings; that is the highest singles ranking ever for a Korean player.\n\nFederer said he believed Chung was \u201cgoing to be a very good player,\u201d but he resisted making predictions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t like to put too much pressure on players by saying they\u2019re going to win everything, because I don\u2019t think it\u2019s fair,\u201d he said. \u201cA lot of experts, such-called experts, said I was going to be world No. 1 and win everything. In a way it\u2019s funny and cool, but it\u2019s not so cool in hindsight. Afterwards, anything you achieve is normal. I find it disappointing. Getting to No. 1, winning Grand Slams, winning Masters 1000s, it ain\u2019t normal. It\u2019s extraordinary.\u201d\n\nThe pundits do deserve credit in this instance for getting it right, however. Federer has indeed become one of the greatest players of all time.\n\nSunday\u2019s duel with Cilic will be a rematch of last year\u2019s Wimbledon final, which, like Friday night\u2019s semifinal, also turned into an anticlimax because of foot blisters: Cilic began crying on a changeover at the frustration of not being able to perform his best.\n\nCilic has beaten Federer just once in nine matches, but it was a significant victory, coming in the semifinals of the 2014 United States Open en route to Cilic\u2019s first and only major singles title.\n\nHe presumably will need his top gear again on Sunday to trouble Federer, who has yet to drop a set as he defends the surprising title he won last year by prevailing in a series of tense five-setters.\n\nHis return visit has been much shorter on drama but not on statistical import. This will be Federer\u2019s seventh Australian Open final, a men\u2019s Open era record. It will be his 30th Grand Slam singles final, building on his own men\u2019s record.\n\nIf he beats Cilic, Federer will have 20 major singles titles, increasing his record total among men to a nice round number that seemed all but unreachable when Djokovic was dominating the game in the first half of 2016.\n\nDjokovic has fallen back because of an elbow injury, but Federer glides on \u2014 thoroughly in his element.", "title": "Australian Open: Roger Federer Eases Into Final as Chung Retires", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "MELBOURNE, Australia \u2014 Hyeon Chung became the first South Korean man to reach the semifinals of a Grand Slam singles tournament, beating Tennys Sandgren, 6-4, 7-6 (5), 6-3, on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nChung will seek his next milestone against a far more experienced foe: second-seeded Roger Federer, who reached his 14th Australian Open semifinal with a 7-6(1), 6-3, 6-4 win over 19th-seeded Tomas Berdych.\n\nChung, 21, won a showcase for young ATP talent last November in Milan, and has solidified himself as the leader of his generation with each successive win at this tournament. He beat Mischa Zverev, a quarterfinalist here last year, in the first round; the Sydney International champion Daniil Medvedev in the second round; fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev in the third round; and six-time champion Novak Djokovic in the fourth round.\n\nChung said his victories had kept him energized.\n\n\u201cWhen I win the match against top player, never tired,\u201d he said, adding that he was \u201cmentally happy.\u201d", "title": "Australian Open: Sandgren Loses to Chung, Then Targets the News Media", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "MELBOURNE, Australia \u2014 The first two rounds of the Australian Open have let the outsiders in.\n\nTennys Sandgren, ranked 97th, said he watched Stan Wawrinka win the 2016 United States Open final in a bar.\n\n\u201cI was having a few beers,\u201d Sandgren said of Wawrinka\u2019s third major win. \u201cI was watching the tennis, thinking: That\u2019s insane \u2014 an inhuman level of tennis.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, an undaunted Sandgren beat ninth-seeded Wawrinka with some ease, 6-1, 6-2, 6-4. He was able to dominate Wawrinka\u2019s signature backhand with his own, hitting eight winners to Wawrinka\u2019s two.\n\nWawrinka was far from his glimmering best, but Sandgren still had to contain his composure over the best-of-five match against an experienced champion who could have roared back at any point.", "title": "Australian Open: Tennys Sandgren Takes Down Stan Wawrinka", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cTennis is definitely a roller coaster,\u201d Stephens said at her alternately downbeat and upbeat news conference. \u201cBut I have learned to just not panic. It will be O.K. There\u2019s always going to be times when it\u2019s really tough, and there will be times when you\u2019re on an extreme high. I think for me now it\u2019s not that great, but it\u2019s nothing to panic about, guys.\u201d\n\nNext to lose was Williams, the 37-year-old who had one of her finest seasons last year in the major tournaments but had perhaps the most daunting opening-round assignment here of any top women\u2019s player: the unseeded Belinda Bencic, who defeated Williams, 6-3, 7-5.\n\nBencic, a former top 10 player from Switzerland, has come back convincingly from left wrist surgery last year and was fresh off winning the Hopman Cup team event with Roger Federer. On Monday, she took the initiative from the baseline repeatedly and returned serve with aplomb to defeat Williams for the first time in five matches.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think I played a bad match,\u201d Williams said. \u201cShe just played above and beyond.\u201d\n\nThe next high-profile American to lose was CoCo Vandeweghe, the No. 10 seed and a semifinalist here last year, who was upset, 7-6 (4), 6-2, in Hisense Arena by Timea Babos, a Hungarian veteran with a serve nearly as big as Vandeweghe\u2019s.\n\nVandeweghe later said she had been suffering from the flu, which had affected her preparation for the tournament\n\n\u201cIn women\u2019s tennis, I think we see it: Anything can happen when there is no Serena Williams,\u201d Babos said.\n\nEven without Serena Williams, the American women have had considerable success in the past year. On Monday, however, they were 1-9 collectively, with the only victory coming in the hinterlands of Court 22 from Nicole Gibbs, the former Stanford star who was also the last direct entry into the main draw.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSome of the girls who had tough matches earlier today were kind of ribbing me in the locker room before I went on, saying \u2018You need to hold it down for our country today,\u2019 so no pressure,\u201d Gibbs said.\n\nShe went on to defeat Viktoriya Tomova, a Bulgarian who made it into the tournament as a lucky loser, by 6-1, 6-1.\n\nReferring to the three U.S. Open semifinalists who lost before she took the court, Gibbs said, \u201cObviously that speaks volumes to the depth, especially on the WTA Tour, so I think it\u2019s just a tough game, and it\u2019s tough to stay on top repeatedly.\u201d\n\nTwo of the three top-ranked American men \u2013 Jack Sock and John Isner \u2013 also lost on Monday. Sock, who broke into the top 10 last year and qualified for the elite ATP World Tour Finals in London, was upset, 6-1, 7-6 (4), 5-7, 6-3, by the Japanese veteran Yuichi Sugita.\n\nPhoto\n\nSock said his surprising late-season surge has played a role in his downbeat start to 2018 (he also lost a lopsided opening match in Auckland, New Zealand where he was defending champion).\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just a weird feeling because you are on the highest of highs after making it,\u201d he said of London. \u201cYou go home, and you\u2019re all excited and it\u2019s Thanksgiving with your family and then in your head, you\u2019re like, \u2018Well I only have a couple weeks to train and get ready and then it\u2019s kind of back to reality and the grind of it.\u2019\u201d\n\nKevin Anderson, a surprise finalist at last year\u2019s U.S. Open, was also defeated on day one, losing in five sets to Kyle Edmund of Britain. Last year has been a long, very good but long season. So let\u2019s start another one and try to don\u2019t think much about what happened the year before.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat is also the challenge for Stephens, whose tennis roller coaster has been one of the wildest rides imaginable. After an 11-month injury layoff, she roared back to win her first major singles title in New York shortly after returning to action. Since then, Stephens has lost eight straight matches.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not going to dwell on it just because I lost eight matches in a row and say, \u2018Oh winning the U.S. Open, it\u2019s haunting me now,\u2019\u201d Stephens said. \u201cIt\u2019s the best thing that ever happened to me.\u201d\n\nShe added: \u201cYou know, before I would get so upset about what people would write and say things about me on TV and blah, blah, blah \u2014 and now it\u2019s like, yeah, who cares? I won a Grand Slam. I\u2019m going through a tough time. Who cares?\n\n\u201cNo one cares about my life. I\u2019m just having fun. I\u2019m enjoying it. There\u2019s too much emphasis on the bad things that happen after something really great happens.\u201d\n\nSix other American women also lost on Monday: the youngsters CiCi Bellis, Taylor Townsend, Sofia Kenin and Jennifer Brady, as well as the veterans Alison Riske and Irina Falconi.\n\nBut the most prominent American to fall was the fifth-ranked Venus Williams, who last year reached the finals of the Australian Open and Wimbledon. She was defeated in Melbourne last year by her sister Serena Williams, who was two months pregnant at the time.\n\nSerena Williams, who gave birth to a daughter in September, has not played another tour-level match since that victory, while Venus Williams has continued to excel and even talk about playing until the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo.\n\nBut Bencic, 17 years Venus Williams\u2019s junior, is a remarkable talent. She was not yet born the last time no Williams sister reached the second round of the Australian Open. That was in 1997, but Bencic ensured it happened this year by playing a poised and aggressive match. She is now one of the few to have defeated both Williams sisters in singles (she upset Serena Williams in the final of the Rogers Cup in 2015 before experiencing injury issues).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cObviously yeah, the first reaction of everyone was like, \u2018Oh bad luck, bad luck,\u2019\u201d said Bencic of being drawn to face Venus Williams.\n\nBut she said she adopted a different approach than in her previous defeats to Venus. \u201cFor the first matches, I think I had a little bit too much respect, played a little bit careful and safe,\u201d Bencic said. \u201cThis time I really tried to come out and hit it big, also tactically be smart on the court. It\u2019s really tough to play her. You really have to be on the limit of your game. You have to come out with everything you have.\u201d\n\nStephens has been troubled by a knee issue, but her confidence also has seemed to be a factor. And though she served for the match at 5-4 in the second set on Monday, she was unable to close it out.\n\nIt all amounted to a major mood swing from September in New York: a shift also represented by Stephens\u2019s coach, Kamau Murray, normally a gifted and expansive communicator who walked out of Margaret Court Arena wearing a pained expression before delivering a series of remarkably curt answers to questions.\n\nIs the issue more mental or physical for Stephens at the moment?\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll see; we\u2019ll see,\u201d Murray said, as he headed for the staircase.", "title": "Australian Open: Within Hours, Top Americans Fall", "authors": ["Christopher Clarey"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Victoria crime statistics show that Sudanese immigrants are overrepresented in criminal arrests. About 1.5 percent of offenders in Victoria are Sudanese, though Sudanese and South Sudanese immigrants make up about half a percent of the state\u2019s population, according to a parliamentary inquiry last year.\n\nThe vast majority of crimes in Victoria are committed by Australian-born offenders. Between June 2016 and June 2017, 1,462 serious assaults were committed by Australian-born youth offenders, compared to 45 for those born in Sudan. Data from the same period shows that 98 aggravated burglaries were committed by Sudanese youth offenders, compared to 540 by those born in Australia.\n\nPhoto\n\nThough crime in Victoria has risen by nearly 20 percent in the past five years, the government\u2019s Crime Statistics Agency reported a 4.9 percent drop in overall crime there in 2017.\n\nBoth police officials and Victorian citizens balked at Mr. Dutton\u2019s characterization of the issue. Lisa Neville, Victoria\u2019s acting police minister, described the home minister\u2019s comment as \u201ca new low.\u201d On social media, a number of Victorians ridiculed Mr. Dutton, posting photos of themselves eating in restaurants with the hashtag #MelbourneBitesBack.\n\nMany have pointed out that the attacks on Mr. Andrews, the Victorian premier, coincide with an upcoming election, which Mr. Turnbull hopes will swing the state back under the control of his Liberal Party.\n\nStephane M. Shepherd, a forensic psychology professor working at Johns Hopkins and Swinburne University, said that the demography of the Sudanese population in Victoria was crucial to understanding the recent crimes.\n\n\u201cIt goes back to the migration,\u201d Dr. Shepherd said. \u201cThere\u2019s a disproportionate amount of young males coming over, as part of the humanitarian intake. Half of the Sudanese population in Australia is 25 or under.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Shepherd said the state\u2019s Sudanese population represented broad family fragmentation that could explain the disproportionate crime data.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCommunity leaders said they were disappointed in Mr. Turnbull and Mr. Dutton\u2019s comments.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m really disappointed in the media coverage, but particularly appalled by the way this issue has become partisan,\u201d said Carmel Guerra, chief executive for the Center for Multicultural Youth in Victoria. \u201cRather than scapegoating these young people, we should try to work out what\u2019s going on.\u201d\n\nMs. Guerra, who also sits on the Youth Parole Board of Victoria, said there were similar anxieties and political efforts when Australia previously experienced large migrations from Vietnam and the Middle East.\n\n\u201cWe have seen situations before when new communities struggle initially, then tend to integrate into the broader community,\u201d she said. \u201cI don\u2019t want to downplay it: there are some real issues that we have to deal with. But that can be done without the hysteria and the racial profiling.\u201d", "title": "Australia\u2019s Prime Minister Warns of \u2018Gang Violence\u2019 by African Migrants", "authors": ["Adam Baidawi"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe market is pretty saturated right now,\u201d said Jessica Caldwell, an analyst with Edmunds.com. She noted that there were now 1.26 vehicles on the road for every licensed driver, more than ever.\n\nThe downward sales trend is the latest challenge for the industry. Tariffs could be imposed on cars made in Mexico and Canada if the Trump administration negotiates major changes to the North American Free Trade Agreement. Manufacturers are also trying to push ahead with self-driving and electric vehicles even as it remains unclear how many they will be able to sell, and when.\n\nThe effect of rising fuel prices is also a question mark. Though still low by the standards of recent years, prices at the pump were $2.49 a gallon for regular gas on Wednesday compared with $2.35 a year ago, according to AAA.\n\nThe seven-year stretch of growth from 2010 to 2016 is the longest since the infancy of the automobile nearly a century ago, according to the automotive publisher WardsAuto. It was born out of one of the industry\u2019s darkest periods: the deep recession that prompted federally backed bankruptcy reorganizations of General Motors and Chrysler. At the low point, 2009, new-car sales plunged to fewer than 11 million a year.\n\nAs sales climbed over the past seven years, carmakers had to worry little about keeping their plants humming. Now they are faced with the prospect of trimming production and finding ways to entice customers to buy the vehicles that are rolling off the assembly line.\n\nSlowdown Last Year Domestic sales of light vehicles declined in 2017 for the first time since the financial crisis to 17.2 million from 17.6 million in 2016. U.S. annual car sales 18 million 16 14 12 10 8 6 4 2 0 \u201909 \u201917\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s challenging for every company,\u201d said Ray Mikiciuk, assistant vice president for sales at American Honda. \u201cIt\u2019s a lot easier to operate in a rising market.\u201d\n\nLast year\u2019s drop in sales was mitigated by increased discounts and other incentives, which now equal 11.5 percent of sticker prices, up from about 7 percent a few years ago, said Mark Wakefield, global co-head of automotive and industrial at AlixPartners, a consulting firm. At some point, further increases in sales incentives could hurt manufacturers\u2019 profits, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe are deep into a push market,\u201d in which consumers have to be lured with deals rather than driven by a strong need or desire for a new car, Mr. Wakefield said.\n\nDespite last year\u2019s decline, domestic auto sales remain at a historically healthy level. And worldwide sales are still on the rise: The research firm IHS Markit estimated that global light vehicle sales rose 1.5 percent in 2017, to 93.5 million cars and trucks.\n\nAmericans tend to favor cars when gas prices are high, and trucks when prices are low, but this time the shift to trucks has been compounded by an increasing preference for taller, roomier vehicles. That has forced carmakers in recent years to shift the production mix rapidly to emphasize sport-utility vehicles, minivans and light trucks.\n\nThe December Sales Picture DECEMBER 2017 SALES CHANGE MARKET SHARE % 308,539 240,910 222,985 171,946 149,317 138,226 63,594 63,342 57,652 43,039 \u2013 3.3 + 1.3 \u2013 8.3 \u201310.7 \u2013 7.0 \u2013 9.5 + 2.1 \u2013 0.3 \u2013 5.4 \u201320.8 % 19.2 15.0 13.9 10.7 9.3 8.6 4.0 4.0 3.6 2.7 GENERAL MOTORS FORD MOTOR TOYOTA FIAT CHRYSLER HONDA NISSAN HYUNDAI SUBARU VOLKSWAGEN KIA\n\nIn December, passenger cars made up just one-third of the market. \u201cIn 2012, cars were over 50 percent,\u201d said Ms. Caldwell, the Edmunds analyst. \u201cThat\u2019s a big shift in a short period of time.\u2019\u2019\n\nSales at General Motors last month reflected that shift. The company had a strong December in trucks, selling more than 94,000 full-size pickups between its Chevrolet and GMC brands, almost one-third of its total sales. But its overall sales still fell 3.3 percent from the previous December, as cars like the Chevy Malibu and Impala languished on dealer lots.\n\nFor the full year, G.M.\u2019s sales declined 1.3 percent, to 3 million vehicles. At the Detroit auto show, which kicks off later this month, G.M. will unveil redesigns of its full-size pickups.\n\nFiat Chrysler Automobiles also had a tough month, with sales declining 10.7 percent. Fiat Chrysler has stopped making small and mid-sized cars, and trucks account for 85 percent of its sales total. But a push to cut back on incentives and sales to rental fleets have slowed the company. Total sales for 2017 dropped 8 percent, to 2.1 million vehicles.\n\nFord Motor, the second largest American automaker after G.M., was one of the few manufacturers to report a rise for December, with sales increasing 1.3 percent. Like G.M., Ford had a big month in pickups, selling more than 89,000 of its F-series models.\n\nBut for the full year, Ford couldn\u2019t buck the market\u2019s trend. Its 2017 sales slipped almost 1 percent, to 2.6 million vehicles.", "title": "Car Sales End a 7-Year Upswing, With More Challenges Ahead", "authors": ["Neal E. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDENVER \u2014 Nathan MacKinnon, Erik Johnson and Mikko Rantanen had a goal and an assist each, Jonathan Bernier made 27 saves and the streaking Colorado Avalanche beat the Rangers, 3-1, on Saturday afternoon for their ninth straight win.\n\nThe Avalanche have won eight straight at home and haven\u2019t lost since Arizona beat them on Dec. 27. Colorado has outscored opponents, 37-15, in the last nine games and has not trailed during the winning streak.\n\nColorado has won nine in a row for the first time since Oct. 10 to 28, 2000, the last season it won the Stanley Cup.\n\nPavel Buchnevich scored and Henrik Lundqvist stopped 34 shots for New York.\n\nColorado took a 2-0 lead with goals by Johnson in the first period and MacKinnon early in the second. MacKinnon used Rangers defenseman Steven Kampfer as a screen to beat Lundqvist.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMacKinnon has goals in five straight games and has recorded at least one point in each game of Colorado\u2019s streak. He is second in the N.H.L. in scoring with 59 points (23 goals, 36 assists).\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. It was just the third power-play goal the Avalanche have allowed in the last 18 games.", "title": "Avalanche Beat Rangers for Ninth Straight Win", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was a rejection of his governorship,\u201d said Patrick R. Miller, a political-science professor at the University of Kansas in Lawrence. \u201cThen the ambassadorship happened and people thought, \u2018This will go quick. Then he won\u2019t have to suffer the humiliation of serving out the rest of his term.\u2019 \u201d\n\nEven his critics in Kansas conceded that the job as ambassador was well suited to Mr. Brownback, a convert to Catholicism who frequently speaks of his faith. Announcing the nomination last July, he wrote on Twitter: \u201cReligious Freedom is the first freedom. The choice of what you do with your own soul. I am honored to serve such an important cause.\u201d\n\nThe governor seemed to begin gradually handing control over to Mr. Colyer last fall. In November, it was Mr. Colyer, not Mr. Brownback, who appointed a new leader of Kansas\u2019 beleaguered child welfare agency. Mr. Colyer began to appear more frequently in public than his role as lieutenant governor typically required, lawmakers said. He was a prominent voice at luncheons and legislative meetings to discuss the 2018 session. The next budget, Mr. Colyer\u2019s spokesman said in November, would be handled by Mr. Colyer \u201cto ensure a smooth transition.\u201d\n\nThroughout the fall, legislators said they kept hearing rumors that Mr. Colyer\u2019s inauguration would be happening in the next week or two. But as 2017 drew to a close, so too did the chance for Mr. Brownback to get a confirmation vote.\n\nLast week, Mr. Brownback addressed the uncertainty about his role in Kansas by saying on Twitter: \u201cLooking forward to another great legislative session. I will remain Governor until confirmed by the U.S. Senate.\u201d\n\nIn the State Capitol for the first day of the new legislative session, Mr. Colyer smiled politely on Monday when asked if he was any closer to knowing when he would succeed Mr. Brownback.\n\n\u201cNope, no \u2014 we believe he\u2019ll be renominated here shortly,\u201d Mr. Colyer said several hours before the White House announced the renomination of Mr. Brownback on Monday.", "title": "Awkward: Brownback Said He Was Leaving as Kansas Governor. He Hasn\u2019t.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The single most distressing thing to me about this story is that the only person with any agency in the story seems to be Aziz Ansari. The woman is merely acted upon.\n\nAll of this put me in mind of another article published this weekend, this one by the novelist and feminist icon Margaret Atwood. \u201cMy fundamental position is that women are human beings,\u201d she writes. \u201cNor do I believe that women are children, incapable of agency or of making moral decisions. If they were, we\u2019re back to the 19th century, and women should not own property, have credit cards, have access to higher education, control their own reproduction or vote. There are powerful groups in North America pushing this agenda, but they are not usually considered feminists.\u201d\n\nExcept, increasingly, they are.\n\nThe article in Babe was met with digital hosannas by young feminists who insisted that consent is consent only if it is affirmative, active, continuous and \u2014 and this is the word most used \u2014 enthusiastic. Consent isn\u2019t the only thing they are radically redefining. A recent survey by The Economist/YouGov found that approximately 25 percent of millennial-age American men think asking someone for a drink is harassment. More than a third of millennial men and women say that if a man compliments a woman\u2019s looks it is harassment.\n\nTo judge from social media reaction, they also see a flagrant abuse of power in this sexual encounter. Yes, Mr. Ansari is a wealthy celebrity with a Netflix show. But he had no actual power over the woman \u2014 professionally or otherwise. And lumping him in with the same movement that brought down men who ran movie studios and forced themselves on actresses, or the factory-floor supervisors who demanded sex from female workers, trivializes what #MeToo first stood for.\n\nI\u2019m sorry this woman had this experience. I too have had lousy romantic encounters, as has every adult woman I know. I have regretted these encounters, and not said anything at all. I have regretted them and said so, as she did. And I know I am lucky that these unpleasant moments were far from being anything approaching assault or rape, or even the worst night of my life.\n\nBut the response to her story makes me think that many of my fellow feminists might insist that my experience was just that, and for me to define it otherwise is nothing more than my internalized misogyny.\n\nThere is a useful term for what this woman experienced on her night with Mr. Ansari. It\u2019s called \u201cbad sex.\u201d It sucks.\n\nThe feminist answer is to push for a culture in which boys and young men are taught that sex does not have to be pursued as if they\u2019re in a pornographic film, and one in which girls and young women are empowered to be bolder, braver and louder about what they want. The insidious attempt by some women to criminalize awkward, gross and entitled sex takes women back to the days of smelling salts and fainting couches. That\u2019s somewhere I, for one, don\u2019t want to go.", "title": "Opinion | Aziz Ansari Is Guilty. Of Not Being a Mind Reader.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "In 2008, Jessica Valenti and Jaclyn Friedman edited the anthology \u201cYes Means Yes!: Visions of Female Sexual Power and a World Without Rape,\u201d seven years before Ansari released his own book, \u201cModern Romance: An Investigation,\u201d in which he explores dating and sex in the digital age.\n\nIn the summer of 2014 (perhaps as Ansari was writing his own book), the California Legislature passed a bill requiring \u201caffirmative, conscious, and voluntary agreement to engage in sexual activity,\u201d unleashing a debate on the efficacy of \u201cyes means yes\u201d that consumed the blogosphere for months. \u201cLack of protest or resistance does not mean consent, nor does silence mean consent,\u201d the bill stated. Feminist publications covered the issue exhaustively. In October 2014, Ansari appeared on \u201cThe Late Show With David Letterman\u201d and declared himself a feminist.\n\nIn 2015, two years before Ansari stuck his fingers in a woman\u2019s mouth who\u2019d just told him \u201cno, I don\u2019t think I\u2019m ready to do this,\u201d according to the woman\u2019s account, which was published this past weekend, Kate Harding published \u201cAsking for It: The Alarming Rise of Rape Culture \u2014 and What We Can Do About It,\u201d in which she described sexual assault as \u201cnot a \u2018mistake\u2019 but a deliberate decision to treat another person like a soulless object.\u201d The same year, Rebecca Traister of New York Magazine argued for the need to look beyond consent to systems of power in an essay titled \u201cThe Game Is Rigged: Why Sex That\u2019s Consensual Can Still Be Bad.\u201d\n\nThere is a reflexive tendency, when grappling with stories of sexual misconduct like the accusations leveled at Ansari this past weekend \u2014 incidents that seem to exist in that vast gray area between assault and a skewed power dynamic \u2014 to point out that sexual norms have changed. This is true. The line between seduction and coercion has shifted, and shifted quickly, over the past few years (the past few months, even). When I was in my 20s, a decade ago, sex was something of a melee. \u201cNo means no\u201d was the only rule, and it was still solidly acceptable in mainstream social circles to bother somebody until they agreed to have sex with you. (At the movies, this was called romantic comedy.)\n\nWhat\u2019s not true is the suggestion that complex conversations about consent are new territory, or that men weren\u2019t given ample opportunity to catch up.", "title": "Opinion | Aziz, We Tried to Warn You", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Tony Hall, the BBC\u2019s director general, noted the broadcaster\u2019s \u201cspecial role\u201d in the broader debate. \u201cThat is why we need to be and want to be an exemplar on gender pay, and equal pay,\u201d he said in a statement on Tuesday.\n\nBut lawmakers questioned the BBC\u2019s commitment, given that Ms. Gracie had earned tens of thousand of pounds less than men doing similar jobs.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re telling us nothing about what you\u2019re going to do with this historic \u2014 this huge, historic \u2014 problem you\u2019ve got with these huge inequities in pay,\u201d said Julie Elliott, a Labour lawmaker.\n\nFran Unsworth, the BBC\u2019s director of news and current affairs, acknowledged that the organization put a higher value on some jobs, like North America editor, than on others such as China editor. Ms. Unsworth maintained that Ms. Gracie\u2019s pay was on par with male editors when she took the job, and that managers had overlooked adjustments that could have been made since.\n\n\u201cIf you take the North America job, this is on-air three times a week at the moment,\u201d Ms. Unsworth said. The China job, she said, is \u201cnot the relentless treadmill that something like the North America job is.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Gracie said the grievance process, which attributed part of the pay discrepancy to her need for professional \u201cdevelopment,\u201d had added \u201cinsult to injury.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s the first time I\u2019ve ever been in development at 55,\u201d she said dryly.\n\nMs. Gracie was \u201cthe perfect example of a woman who was asking and not getting,\u201d said Amanda Goodall, a senior lecturer at Cass Business School in London and an author of a paper that found that women ask for pay raises as often as men do, but do not receive them as frequently.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDiscontent about pay has often simmered at the BBC, which is funded by a license fee paid by British households. The row deepened last summer when the broadcaster disclosed the salaries of on-air employees earning more than \u00a3150,000.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe data revealed startling gaps in the pay of its most senior male and female journalists, prompting demands for change. Though two male international editors appeared on the list, neither Ms. Gracie nor Katya Adler, the broadcaster\u2019s Europe editor, reached that level.\n\nA follow-up report commissioned by the BBC identified no \u201csystemic gender discrimination among rank-and-file employees,\u201d a finding challenged by female journalists. In November, Samira Ahmed, a BBC presenter, described in an journalists\u2019 union newsletter how it felt to be paid less than male colleagues.\n\n\u201cI can only describe the feeling of being kept on much lower pay than male colleagues doing the same jobs for years as feeling as though bosses had naked pictures of you in their office and laughed every time they saw you,\u201d Ms. Ahmed wrote. \u201cIt is the humiliation and shame of feeling that they regarded you as second class, because that is what the pay gap means.\u201d\n\nThe National Union of Journalists lodged an official grievance in December on behalf of 121 members; more joined the grievance later. When the BBC asked all employees with complaints to come forward, it resulted in 298 cases in all.\n\nMr. Hall said the BBC had resolved 117 of those cases, most of them involving pay for women.\n\nLast week, the BBC said it was reducing the salaries of several male journalists. Then on Tuesday, it published a further review, of the salaries of 824 on-air staff, which also found no evidence of gender bias in pay decisions.\n\nStill, the report noted that there were more men than women in the upper half of pay distribution, and that pay for the highest-profile employees, most of them men, needed to be adjusted.\n\nThe BBC said that it would address these issues and institute \u201csubstantial pay cuts\u201d for some men, while increasing pay for some male and female presenters.\n\nA group of 170 women at the BBC said in a submission to Parliament that they had \u201cno confidence\u201d in the review\u2019s conclusions, saying they had not been consulted.\n\nSome of these women detailed their experiences in the document, which was submitted to the parliamentary group, the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee. The summary said that women had \u201cexperienced veiled threats made against them when they raised the subject of equal pay.\u201d", "title": "BBC Managers Face Barrage of Criticism in Gender Pay Dispute", "authors": ["Amie Tsang"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Her letter also magnified the pressure the BBC has recently faced internally and externally to fix a significant pay gap between men and women throughout its ranks, even among its top television and radio stars.\n\nMs. Gracie\u2019s letter was met with statements of support from several high-profile figures at the BBC, and she expressed her gratitude on Monday while hosting the flagship news program \u201cToday\u201d on BBC Radio 4.\n\nThe BBC did not respond to a request for comment on Sunday night but in a statement to BBC News, a spokeswoman, citing a salary audit, said there was \u201cno systemic discrimination against women\u201d and that \u201ca significant number of organizations have now published their gender pay figures showing that we are performing considerably better.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Gender Letter A weekly newsletter on women, gender and society. Ms. Gracie did not make the list. On average, men made about 10 percent more than women, the report found.\n\nMs. Gracie said she learned in that report just how severely she had been underpaid despite her high-ranking position in its news division. While she did not reveal her salary, she said that of the four international news editors, the two men earned 50 percent more than the two women.\n\nShe wrote that she believed her promotion to China editor, which required her to move to Beijing and leave her children in the United Kingdom, meant she would be paid the same as her male colleagues.\n\n\u201cLike many other BBC women, I had long suspected that I was routinely paid less, and at this point in my career, I was determined not to let it happen again,\u201d she wrote about accepting the China editor position in 2014. \u201cBelieving that I had secured pay parity with men in equivalent roles, I set off for Beijing.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Gracie said that after the salaries were made public, she asked for pay matching her male counterparts\u2019. On Wednesday, law enforcement authorities from Munich raided the homes of former employees of Audi, Volkswagen\u2019s luxury car unit. Some Audi vehicles also contained the emissions-masking software.\n\nAndrea Mayer, a Munich prosecutor, said the homes that were raided belonged to middle managers and were searched as part of an investigation into emissions cheating. Prosecutors have identified 13 suspects, Ms. Mayer said, but have not yet filed criminal charges against any of them.\n\nThe monkey experiments were paid for and overseen by the European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector, known by its German initials, E.U.G.T. BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen financed the organization and all three companies had representatives on its board.\n\nWhy Diesel Became So Popular in Europe Over the last 20 years, diesel cars have taken a strong hold on the European market, thanks in large part to regulations that made them cheaper to fill up than gasoline-powered cars.\n\nThe research took place at the Lovelace Respiratory Research Institute in Albuquerque in 2014. Researchers there exposed one group of the monkeys to exhaust from a late-model diesel Volkswagen; a second group was exposed to exhaust from an older Ford diesel pickup truck.\n\nUsing monkeys as experiment subjects was not illegal, but it has angered animal-rights advocates and others who say the tests lacked the usual justification for research on primates, which is to advance medical science and protect human lives. In this instance, the monkeys were being used to try to help the companies sell diesel cars by showing that emissions were less harmful than many scientists had maintained.\n\nThe research suffered from procedural flaws and had not been published by the time the E.U.G.T. folded last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA separate project financed by the carmakers subjected human volunteers to doses of nitrogen dioxide, one of diesel\u2019s most noxious byproducts. The research, in 2015, was authorized by an ethics commission at the RWTH Aachen University in Aachen, Germany, where it took place.\n\nDaimler said Wednesday it had suspended its representative on the E.U.G.T. board. The company did not disclose his name, but a report by the organization summarizing its activities from 2013 to 2015, said the carmaker was represented by Udo Hartmann, whose title was head of Daimler\u2019s group environmental protection and energy management.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Hartmann could not be reached for comment late Wednesday.\n\nDaimler continued to try to distance itself from the monkey testing, in which Volkswagen employees took a leading role.\n\n\u201cEven though Daimler did not have influence on the study\u2019s design, we have launched a comprehensive investigation into the matter,\u201d the company said in a statement Wednesday. \u201cWe will fully investigate the facts, and make sure that such things do not happen again.\u201d\n\nBMW said its representative on the E.U.G.T. board had been \u201crelieved of his current tasks\u201d while the company conducted an internal investigation. The man remains a BMW employee, the company said.\n\nAccording to the E.U.G.T. report about the organization\u2019s activities from 2013 to 2015, BMW\u2019s representative on the board at the time of the monkey research was Frank Hansen, a member of a company team that works on car-sharing and other new forms of urban transportation.\n\nMr. Hansen did not immediately respond to a request for comment. BMW implicitly defended his conduct on Wednesday, saying in a statement that the employee has provided credible assurances \u201cthat he critically called into question the commissioning of animal tests during his mandate on the board.\u201d", "title": "BMW and Daimler Move Against Executives Over Diesel Tests on Monkeys", "authors": ["Jack Ewing"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The energy giant BP said on Tuesday that it expected to take an additional charge of $1.7 billion in the fourth quarter for claims related to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster, which killed 11 people and caused the worst oil spill in American history.\n\nThe company also said that it now anticipated cash payments related to the disaster to be about $3 billion this year, up from an estimate issued in the third quarter of more than $2 billion.\n\n\u201cWith the claims facility\u2019s work very nearly done, we now have better visibility into the remaining liability,\u201d Brian Gilvary, BP\u2019s chief financial officer, said in a news release. \u201cThe charge we are taking as a result is fully manageable within our existing financial framework.\u201d\n\nThe explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig was one of the worst environmental disasters in United States history, spilling millions of gallons of crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico. It badly damaged BP\u2019s reputation and has cost the company tens of billions of dollars in fines and settlements.", "title": "BP to Take $1.7 Billion Charge Over Deepwater Horizon Spill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "This film was born out of another film that fell through because I couldn\u2019t fund it. When you have a camera but no money, you make do with what you can. Often, that means looking around for what\u2019s closest to you. Call it \u201cproximity cinema,\u201d a type of cinema for the poor. This film, about my younger brother\u2019s experiences moving back to our family\u2019s home in Missouri, is a good example.\n\nFilming a family member can be tricky, but luckily, my brother is a joy to be around. Following him for this film, I found him to be rambunctious and fun, brimming with energy and honesty. The camera naturally gravitates toward these traits, and watching him through my lens, I was enthralled. Ultimately I was able to turn the footage into this film structured around the framework of him moving back in with our parents. That framework wasn\u2019t a naturally interesting topic for me, since I and all of my brothers have done this at one point as adults. But it did seem the best way to structure the material.", "title": "Opinion | Baby Brother", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "When someone tells you who they are, believe them.\n\nIn his State of the Union address, Donald Trump told us exactly who the modern-day abortion opponents are \u2014 and exactly what they think of women.\n\nThis revelation came more than halfway through the speech Tuesday, and probably by accident, when President Trump told a story that was, at least nominally, about human kindness as a cure for the opioid epidemic. As Mr. Trump described it, a 27-year-old Albuquerque police officer, Ryan Holets, happened upon a pregnant woman who was homeless and was \u201cpreparing to inject heroin.\u201d The president continued: \u201cWhen Ryan told her she was going to harm her unborn child, she began to weep. She told him she did not know where to turn, but badly wanted a safe home for her baby.\u201d\n\nThe president said that Officer Holets \u201cfelt God speak to him,\u201d that he took out a picture of his wife and their four children, and \u201cwent home to tell his wife Rebecca. In an instant, she agreed to adopt. The Holets named their new daughter Hope.\u201d\n\nYou might have been wondering \u2014 I know I was \u2014 what happened to that homeless woman? Was she offered treatment? Was she given a chance to reunite with her newborn baby, which could have been a powerful incentive to get clean? Can she be part of the baby\u2019s life? Where is she now? Is she O.K.?", "title": "Opinion | Baby Hope\u2019s Birth Mom Has a Name", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "ESPN executives had some nervous moments during halftime of Monday night\u2019s college football national championship. It appeared that a Georgia blowout, which looked likely, might lead fans to turn the game off.\n\nThey needn\u2019t have worried. The network announced Tuesday that Alabama\u2019s thrilling 26-23 comeback was watched by 28.4 million people; 27.4 million on the flagship channel, and another 1 million on ESPN2 and ESPNU as part of its \u201cMegaCast\u201d production. Last year\u2019s game was watched on ESPN by 24.4 million viewers, with 25.7 million watching in 2016. Monday\u2019s contest was the fifth-highest-rated college football game ESPN has ever broadcast, and second-highest if the MegaCast is factored in, behind only Ohio State\u2019s victory over Oregon in the 2015 championship game in the inaugural College Football Playoff.\n\nThe game capped a hugely successful college football bowl season for ESPN, as viewership was up for both its New Year\u2019s Day slate of high-profile games and its entire 35-bowl-game season.\n\n\u201cWhen I look across the landscape of sports properties, it\u2019s hard to argue that, from beginning to end, anything is as compelling as college football,\u201d Burke Magnus, an ESPN executive, said before the game.", "title": "Back in Traditional Time Slots, College Football Thrives on ESPN", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The small Bronx Museum of the Arts regularly hits above its weight. It is doing so again with \u201cGordon Matta-Clark: Anarchitect,\u201d a streamlined exhibition of the work of this insurrectionary artist. The show creates a remarkably full picture of an irrepressible and unfailingly D.I.Y. maverick who is revered as one of the prime movers in the juggernaut of Conceptual, Process and Performance art that emerged in the late 1960s and \u201970s. With a range that few of his peers equaled, Matta-Clark contributed to all of these genres.\n\nHe and his twin brother, John Sebastian, were born in New York to the Chilean Surrealist painter Roberto Matta and Anne Clark, an American artist and fashion designer. The parents separated shortly after their birth, and the boys were raised primarily in Greenwich Village by their mother. Matta-Clark (1943-1978) studied architecture at Cornell University, and evolved into a kind of urban land artist who used his skills to reshape and transform architecture into an art of structural explication and spatial revelation. He is best known for cutting up derelict buildings scheduled for demolition, turning them into giant temporary installations or extracting fragments from them that he then exhibited as sculpture.", "title": "Back in the Bronx: Gordon Matta-Clark, Rogue Sculptor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The petition for Mr. McCrary generated some publicity, and on Tuesday, he was released after an anonymous donor posted his bail.\n\nMs. Geraghty and her allies are now pressuring Atlanta to embrace a national wave of bail reform that has already taken hold in places like Chicago, Houston, New Jersey and, most recently, Alaska. Those who support reform argue that detaining the working poor over small bail amounts can ruin careers and disrupt families. They note that jail time racked up while waiting for a case to be resolved can sometimes exceed the jail time prescribed for the offense itself. They argue that such detentions violate the 14th Amendment\u2019s equal protection clause, because it denies arrestees \u201cthe pretrial freedom made available to those who can pay for release for the same offense,\u201d as Ms. Geraghty wrote in her petition.\n\nAnd, they say, bail does nothing for public safety, using access to money rather than potential for danger to determine who goes free. \u201cThis is the right time for Atlanta to move away from wealth-based detention,\u201d Ms. Geraghty said.\n\nEarlier this month, the Southern Center for Human Rights in Atlanta joined Civil Rights Corps, based in Washington, in sending a letter to Atlanta\u2019s new mayor, Keisha Lance Bottoms, asking her to lead a change in the city\u2019s bail system. The groups noted that they had forced changes in other Georgia cities by suing them.\n\nBut Atlanta already appears ripe for change. Ms. Bottoms has spoken candidly, and movingly, about the conviction of her father, the R&B singer Major Lance, on cocaine charges in the 1970s. \u201cI learned very early on that good people sometimes make bad decisions,\u201d she said in a biographical campaign video. Ms. Bottoms has pledged, in her agenda for her first 100 days in office, to create a criminal justice reform commission.", "title": "Bail Was $500, Money He Didn\u2019t Have. Atlanta Faces Calls for Change.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Ballet, which began life in Western Europe during the Renaissance, is danced all over the globe with many accents. The many ways in which it can be (and seem) American often occupied the mind of the Russian-born choreographer George Balanchine, who moved to New York in 1933 and became an American citizen in 1939. The very title of his ballet \u201cSquare Dance\u201d tells you that he was thinking of America.\n\nYet here, as so often, Balanchine\u2019s thoughts were indirect. His music was from the European Baroque, Vivaldi and Corelli, but this ballet tells everyone that these composers are now American property too. The steps and manners combine those of ballet and those of American square dancing; so do its patterns and structures.\n\n\u201cSquare Dance\u201d returns this week (Feb. 2-10) to the repertory of New York City Ballet, the company for which it was made. It is informally formal, polite and virtuoso, sweet and outgoing. I\u2019m especially fond of a passage in the finale when the men and women, holding hands, in couples, kick the air behind them with one foot: not an academic ballet step at all, just a folk moment, and wonderfully fresh. When the ballet was new, Balanchine clinched the connection by having a caller onstage whose rhyming lines included \u201cSee those feet go wickety-whack!\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe ballerina role remains one of the peaks of allegro bravura. In one passage, she does gargouillades (sideways jumps in which each foot writes rings in the air). Then the six corps women do them too. Gargouillades, originally an 18th-century step, occur in many Balanchine ballets (and in a few by other choreographers), but these are the most high-exposure and isolated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter them, the ballerina\u2019s footwork gets faster and more intricate, with phrases of the most intoxicating brio. Balanchine later wrote, \u201cThe American style of classical dancing, its supple sharpness and richness of metrical invention, its superb preparation for risks, and its high spirits were some of the things I was trying to show in this ballet.\u201d He had spent years forging that very style.", "title": "Balanchine\u2019s \u2018Square Dance\u2019 Speaks Ballet With an American Accent", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThese boards are often populated with private-sector leaders who would never tolerate such bad behavior in the companies they run,\u201d said Darren Walker, the president of the Ford Foundation, who recently stepped off City Ballet\u2019s board. \u201cBecause they\u2019re volunteers, they often yield to management and particularly to charismatic artistic leaders. When presented with evidence to the contrary, they sometimes look the other way.\u201d\n\nSome board members occasionally tried to challenge Mr. Martins, including the prominent longtime benefactor Anne Bass, who finally left the school\u2019s board in 2005. In her resignation letter, recently obtained by The New York Times, Ms. Bass expressed dismay that Mr. Martins \u201cand those who report to him are operating with no oversight or appropriate review and are answerable to no one.\u201d\n\nNow, as the boards prepare to replace Mr. Martins, many former dancers \u2014 about two dozen of whom have complained in interviews about his treatment \u2014 are concerned that board leaders and others at City Ballet are not examining their own responsibility for allowing a powerful leader to go largely unchecked. Jennifer Desaulniers, who spent three years in the school in the late \u201990s, said Mr. Martins openly berated ballerinas if they gained weight and discounted them if they got hurt \u2014 and no one stepped in to stop him.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re injured, you\u2019re out; you\u2019re fat, next person,\u201d Ms. Desaulniers said, adding that instructors were also coldhearted. \u201cIt goes way beyond Peter \u2014 they\u2019re protecting one another, and they\u2019re protecting Balanchine\u2019s legacy.\u201d\n\nAsked to respond, City Ballet said in a statement: \u201cWhen the current board and management received the anonymous letter suggesting inappropriate actions by Peter Martins, they immediately engaged an independent outside counsel to begin an investigation into the allegations. The board and management take these allegations very seriously. Since the investigation began Mr. Martins has announced his retirement but the investigation into the allegations surrounding him is continuing.\u201d", "title": "Ballet Leaders Allowed Peter Martins to Act With Impunity, Dancers Say", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The tentative agreement, reached between Ballet Theater and the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents roughly 90 company dancers and stage managers, will raise the salaries of the lowest-paid dancers the most. Those dancers, in the corps de ballet, will get raises of 4 percent in the first year, 3 percent in the second year and 3 percent the third year under the agreement. (Corps members currently get paid from a little more than $1,000 a week to $1,900 a week, depending upon seniority.) The company\u2019s better-paid soloists will not get raises in the first two years, and will get a 1 percent raise in the third year of the contract.\n\nThe agreement will also lead to increased payments to retirement plans \u2014 a major sticking point in the talks. The company eliminated payments to defined contribution retirement plans for a year after the recent recession hit, and then restored them at half their previous level \u2014 3.75 percent of income, down from 7.5 percent, the union said. The new agreement calls for the company to increase its contribution to 4 percent in the third year of the new contract.", "title": "Ballet Theater Choreographs a Labor Deal, and the Show Goes On", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Besieged by the nation\u2019s highest big-city murder rate, Baltimore named a new police commissioner for the third time in five years on Friday, with the mayor saying she was \u201cimpatient\u201d for change. The surprise move came as the city struggles to control the violence that took the lives of almost 900 residents during the two-and-a-half-year tenure of the last chief, Kevin Davis, who was fired on Friday.\n\nThe new commissioner, Darryl De Sousa, 53, inherits a long list of problems that have proved intractable for predecessors, including a near-total lack of trust of the police in many neighborhoods and stunning levels of privation along the city\u2019s most violent streets, even as employment rates have improved and areas like the Inner Harbor have become gleaming tourist destinations.\n\n\u201cWe need the numbers to go down faster than they are,\u201d Mayor Catherine Pugh, who has been in office for a year, said at a news conference announcing the change.\n\nFor its long-troubled police force, the city has tried an outsider from California via Harvard, who was seen as an agent of change, then a Marylander who was chief of police in a neighboring county. It was recorded on Jan. 24, 2017, and seems to show the officer, Richard A. Pinheiro Jr., placing a bag of white capsules inside a can in an alley. The officer can then be seen walking back to the street, at which point he appears to switch on his body camera and announce that he is going to search the alley.\n\nThe video shows him returning to the alley to find the bag he had just placed there.\n\nThe body cameras used by the Baltimore Police Department retain visual recordings beginning 30 seconds before the cameras are manually switched on.\n\nIt remains unclear whether the Jan. 24 footage shows an attempt to plant evidence or a re-enactment of an event that had already occurred off-camera.\n\nVideo\n\nDuring the episode, a man was arrested on drug dealing charges. But they were dropped after the video became public, and Officer Pinheiro was suspended with pay from the Police Department.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Tuesday, the officer was indicted by a grand jury on charges of tampering with or fabricating physical evidence, a misdemeanor, and common law misconduct in office. A spokeswoman for the Baltimore state\u2019s attorney\u2019s office said that an arraignment was scheduled for February.", "title": "Baltimore Police Officer Charged With Fabricating Evidence in Drug Case", "authors": ["Jacey Fortin"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The department noted that the book was used by the New Jersey Scholarship and Transformative Education Program, which allows inmates to enroll in college-level courses.\n\nAsked why the ban was lifted, Matthew Schuman, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Corrections, said it was because \u201cofficials determined that the book should not have been banned, as evidenced by the fact that it is being utilized as a teaching tool for NJ-STEP students.\u201d\n\nMr. Schuman did not answer questions about why the book was banned in the first place.\n\nSince its publication in 2010, Ms. Alexander\u2019s book has become a well-known and frequently cited work on the subject of mass incarceration in the United States, which, it argues, has systematically devastated black America.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe book traces how the government\u2019s war on drugs became a means of racial discrimination, and the way that African-American men in particular had been the victims of harsh sentencing policies.\n\nThe book reached the best-seller lists in 2012, after it was published in paperback, galvanizing prison reform activists as well as readers who were less aware of what Ms. Alexander argued was a crisis of injustice. (The book was informed by Ms. Alexander\u2019s work as the director of the A.C.L.U.\u2019s racial justice project in Northern California.)\n\nAccording to data from The Sentencing Project, a prison reform advocacy group, New Jersey has the highest disparity between black and white inmates of any state, with 12.2 black inmates for every white inmate.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn response to emailed questions on Monday, Ms. Alexander said that she was \u201cnot terribly surprised\u201d and forwarded emails indicating that the book had been banned from other prisons.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m glad N.J. has lifted the ban, but it shouldn\u2019t have existed in the first place,\u201d she wrote. \u201cI hope this experience will inspire people to continue to challenge unreasonable regulations and conditions of confinement. And I hope the media will pay more attention to the oppressive rules and regulations governing the lives of people who are incarcerated.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe said that the ban had reinforced one of the key themes of the book: that mass incarceration was not at its core a system of crime prevention but instead \u201ca system of racial and social control.\u201d\n\nTess Borden, a staff lawyer for the A.C.L.U. of New Jersey, who drafted the letter with Alexander Shalom, a senior supervising lawyer, said she has spoken to people in other states who said reading Ms. Alexander\u2019s book in prison changed their lives. It helped them see the role of racial injustice in imprisoning so many black and brown people, she said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s flatly unconstitutional under the First Amendment,\u201d she said of the ban in an interview. \u201cIt\u2019s also really flawed policy, especially so in New Jersey, which leads the country in racial disparities in incarceration.\u201d\n\nThe A.C.L.U. of New Jersey applauded the lifting of the ban, but said it would continue working to address \u201cendemic racial discrimination in the criminal justice system.\u201d\n\nFederal courts have allowed prisons to censor books and it is common practice for states to keep lists of texts it considers dangerous. All told, those institutions account for about half of the companies that have promised raises or bonuses since President Trump signed the bill into law, according to a running list by Americans for Tax Reform, a group that advocates low taxes.\n\nThe payouts to workers reflect a small slice of the windfall that banks large and small are in line to receive. The law includes a reduction in the corporate rate to 21 percent from a high of 35 percent last year, as well as a 20 percent deduction for income from pass-through companies. One-third of all community banks are organized as pass-throughs, according to the Independent Community Bankers of America, which represents those firms and was among the groups pushing for a lower pass-through rate.\n\nAnalysts projected the financial industry would reap some of the largest benefits from that reduction given that banks typically paid much higher effective tax rates in the past than many other industries, like manufacturing.\n\nThe boon for banks comes as the industry begins to regain some of its swagger in the wake of the financial crisis and as it seeks to roll back some of the post-crisis regulations put in place by the Obama administration under the 2010 Dodd-Frank law.\n\nOfficials at top banks have mostly showered Mr. Trump with praise for his economic policy agenda, which they say is expanding growth. Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, called the new tax law a \u201csignificant positive outcome for the country\u201d in a news release accompanying the bank\u2019s earnings on Friday.\n\nThe gains come despite a one-time hit of $2.4 billion that JPMorgan Chase reported in the fourth quarter, the result of a provision in the law that forces companies to pay a one-time tax on profits that are held overseas.\n\nOther large banks will report earnings on Tuesday and are expected to similarly reveal large savings from the tax overhaul.", "title": "Banks Are Big Winners From Tax Cut", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump\u2019s former chief strategist, will be interviewed by investigators working for the special counsel in the Russia investigation instead of testifying before a grand jury, according to a person familiar with the matter, a sign that Mr. Bannon is cooperating with the inquiry.\n\nThe special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, had subpoenaed Mr. Bannon to appear before a grand jury this week. But Mr. Bannon has agreed to cooperate with Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigation and will be interviewed in the less formal setting of the special counsel\u2019s offices in downtown Washington.\n\nIt was not clear why Mr. Mueller subpoenaed Mr. Bannon and did not first ask him to sit for an interview, as Mr. Mueller had done with more than a dozen current and former White House officials who were questioned in recent months. Mr. Mueller could still call Mr. Bannon to appear before a grand jury after he meets with investigators.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Schmidt"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "After the interview, Democrats on the committee accused the White House of exerting influence over Mr. Bannon to keep him from expounding about his time in the West Wing. A senior administration official insisted that the White House had not told Mr. Bannon to exert executive privilege. Mr. Bannon did not address reporters, and a spokesman for Mr. Mueller did not respond to messages seeking comment.\n\nMr. Mueller issued the subpoena after Mr. Bannon was quoted in a new book criticizing Mr. Trump, saying that Donald Trump Jr.\u2019s 2016 meeting with Russians was \u201ctreasonous\u201d and predicting that the special counsel investigation would ultimately center on money laundering.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Breaking News Emails Get the latest on the special counsel investigation \u2014 and other major news \u2014 delivered to your email inbox. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter excerpts from the book, \u201cFire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House,\u201d were published this month, Mr. Trump derided Mr. Bannon publicly and threatened to sue him for defamation. Mr. Bannon was soon ousted as the executive chairman of the hard-right website Breitbart News.\n\nSome legal experts said the subpoena could be a sign that the investigation was intensifying, while others said it might simply be a negotiating tactic to persuade Mr. Bannon to cooperate with the investigation. The experts also said it could be a signal to Mr. Bannon, who has tried to publicly patch up his falling-out with the president, that despite Mr. Trump\u2019s legal threats, Mr. Bannon must be completely forthcoming with investigators.\n\nProsecutors generally prefer to interview witnesses before a grand jury when they believe they have information that the witnesses do not know, or when they think they might catch the witnesses in a lie. It is much easier for a witness to stop the questioning or sidestep questions in an interview than during grand jury testimony, which is transcribed, and witnesses are required to answer every question.\n\n\u201cBy forcing someone to testify through a subpoena, you are providing the witness with cover because they can say, \u2018I had no choice \u2014 I had to go in and testify about everything I knew,\u2019\u201d said Solomon L. Wisenberg, a prosecutor for the independent counsel that investigated Bill Clinton when he was president.\n\nSignificant grand jury activity may undermine the case that White House officials have made for months: that they believe the inquiry is coming to an end and are convinced that the president will be cleared. Mr. Mueller has told Mr. Trump\u2019s lawyers that he will probably want to question the president before the investigation concludes, but no interview has been scheduled.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Bannon has limited firsthand knowledge about two key issues within Mr. Mueller\u2019s purview \u2014 the president\u2019s firing of James B. Comey as F.B.I. director, a decision made without Mr. Bannon present, and the drafting of a misleading statement about the subject of the June 2016 meeting with Russians, in which they promised damaging information about Hillary Clinton.\n\nBut even Mr. Bannon\u2019s secondhand knowledge could be used to draw a contrast with statements from people with firsthand knowledge whom Mr. Mueller has already interviewed. And Mr. Bannon was directly involved in a number of other major moments, including the decision-making around the firing of Michael T. Flynn, the president\u2019s first national security adviser, who was dismissed after he lied to Vice President Mike Pence about phone calls with the Russian ambassador during the presidential transition.\n\nMr. Bannon also helped run the transition after Chris Christie, now the former governor of New Jersey, was fired as head of that team. And he was the chief executive of the Trump campaign in October 2016 when WikiLeaks began releasing thousands of stolen personal emails from the hacked account of Mrs. Clinton\u2019s campaign chairman, John D. Podesta.\n\nVideo\n\nIn \u201cFire and Fury,\u201d Mr. Bannon was quoted by the author, Michael Wolff, as suggesting that Donald Trump Jr.; the president\u2019s son-in-law and senior adviser, Jared Kushner; and Paul Manafort, his campaign chairman at the time, were \u201ctreasonous\u201d and \u201cunpatriotic\u201d for attending the meeting with Russians at Trump Tower. Mr. Bannon said he believed there was \u201czero\u201d chance that the younger Mr. Trump did not take them to meet his father, who has said he knew nothing about the meeting.\n\n\u201cThe three senior guys in the campaign thought it was a good idea to meet with a foreign government inside Trump Tower in the conference room on the 25th floor \u2014 with no lawyers,\u201d Mr. Bannon said in the book.\n\nMr. Trump erupted in anger after the excerpts were published, calling Mr. Bannon \u201cSloppy Steve\u201d on Twitter and saying he had \u201ccried when he got fired and begged for his job.\u201d\n\n\u201cNow Sloppy Steve has been dumped like a dog by almost everyone,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote. \u201cToo bad!\u201d\n\nDays after the excerpts were published, a statement was issued in Mr. Bannon\u2019s name in which he tried to back away from his assertions in the book. He said that his reference to treason was aimed at Mr. Manafort, not the president\u2019s son. Mr. Bannon did not apologize, however, and though he had approved the statement, an associate sent it to reporters without his knowledge.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe president appeared to ease his anger toward Mr. Bannon at the end of last week. When asked in an interview with The Wall Street Journal whether his break with Mr. Bannon was \u201cpermanent,\u201d the president replied, \u201cI don\u2019t know what the word \u2018permanent\u2019 means.\u201d\n\nPeople close to Mr. Bannon took the president\u2019s comments as a signal that Mr. Trump was aware that his fired strategist would soon be contacted by investigators.\n\nMr. Trump has a history of reaching out to people he has fired, including those under investigation, directly or indirectly, as he did with Mr. Flynn after he was dismissed and before he struck a plea deal with Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigators.\n\nMr. Bannon has hired William A. Burck of the Washington office of the Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan law firm to represent him in the defamation threats from Mr. Trump and the congressional inquiries. Mr. Burck also represents several current and former administration officials who have been interviewed as witnesses by Mr. Mueller\u2019s investigators. Among them are the White House counsel, Donald F.
