Experts say a White House spending plan submitted to Congress last week shifts funds away from more effective ways to patrol the border, like high-tech surveillance, to build that wall.", "title": "Bannon, North Korea, El Salvador: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you can buy a well-diversified equity portfolio with a P/E of 10, you\u2019re getting an awful lot of earnings for each dollar of price you\u2019re paying,\u201d said Chris Brightman, chief investment officer for the asset management firm Research Affiliates.\n\nArjun Jayaraman, head of quantitative research and a portfolio manager at Causeway Capital Management, says emerging market value stocks are the only major asset class trading at a discount to their pre-global-financial-crisis levels. This explains why many value investors think these stocks will outperform in the coming years.\n\nFind Your Fund Explore Fund Results \u00bb See how the largest, leading and lagging funds compare. Search by Category \u00bb Find funds by their type, performance, risk or expenses. For more fund information, search morningstar.com.\n\nThe asset management firm GMO, for example, forecasts that over the next seven years, emerging market equities in general will gain only 2 percent a year on an inflation-adjusted basis but value stocks will return nearly 7 percent annually.\n\nThere are risks, though, to the strategy of emphasizing value stocks in emerging markets. \u201cWhen most people think about the demographic trends driving the emerging markets and the high growth rates of India and parts of China, these things are all favorable to growth\u201d stocks, Mr. Jayaraman said \u2014 but not necessarily to value-oriented shares.\n\nBut, he says, \u201cThe rubber band can only stretch so far\u201d when it comes to the rising prices of growth stocks.\n\nErnest C. Yeung, manager of the T. Rowe Price Emerging Markets Value Stock Fund, notes that in the low-inflation, low-interest-rate climate that much of the emerging markets have been mired in recently \u2014 where investors worry that growth will be hard to come by \u2014 \u201cpeople are willing to pay up for future growth.\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s why in this environment, high-quality growth stocks \u2014 names like Tencent and Alibaba \u2014 have done so well,\u201d he said. But that should start to shift, he said. \u201cWhen the macroeconomy recovers, value stocks normally begin to work.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn particular, value stocks in the financial industry stand to benefit.\n\n\u201cFinancials are a driven by the health of the macroeconomy and the direction of interest rates,\u201d Mr. Yeung said. And they\u2019re cheap.\n\nTake Standard Chartered. While technically based in London, this $30 billion commercial and retail bank operates primarily in Asia, Africa and the Middle East, where the economy is growing at a much faster rate than in Britain.\n\n\u201cThe bank has been through some rough times,\u201d Mr. Yeung said. It posted losses in 2016, thanks partly to its holdings in the energy industry during a commodity slump.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs a result, the stock now trades at just 0.7 times the bank\u2019s book value, which represents the net asset value of the company, compared with a price-to-book-value ratio of 1.5 to 2 before the global financial crisis. \u201cSo we are nowhere back to historical norms,\u201d Mr. Yeung said.\n\nThe steel industry is another place that should thrive as the economy improves.\n\n\u201cThe common perception is that China keeps dumping cheap steel into the global markets,\u201d Mr. Yeung said. That may have been true several years ago, but the Chinese government recently carried out supply-side reforms that have reduced China\u2019s steel supply more than 20 percent, he said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs a result, Chinese exports have fallen more than 40 percent, creating breathing room \u2014 and opportunities \u2014 for other emerging market steel producers.\n\nMr. Yeung\u2019s T. Rowe Price Emerging Markets Value fund owns shares of the South Korean steel producer Posco. The company gets about 90 percent of its revenue from developing economies in Asia. So the reacceleration of global growth in that part of the world is likely to be a tailwind for the stock.\n\nCatherine LeGraw, a member of the asset allocation team at GMO, notes that investors need not limit themselves to staid industries to gain exposure to attractively priced emerging market stocks.\n\n\u201cThink information tech based in Taiwan instead of China,\u201d she said.\n\nWhy? A number of Taiwanese tech companies are regarded as old tech because they are involved in the manufacturing and supply chain that propels new economy tech products and services.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThese are companies like Hon Hai, whose subsidiary the Foxconn Technology Group helps manufacture Apple iPhones and Amazon Kindles, among other popular consumer devices.\n\nPartly because Hon Hai is not regarded as a new economy name, the stock trades at a modest price-to-earnings ratio of around 10, compared with around 60 for Tencent Holdings, one of China\u2019s largest internet and social media companies.\n\nBut Mr. Jayaram says that \u201cif we see better sales for iPhones in the first quarter, that could be a big catalyst\u201d to move Hon Hai\u2019s stock, too. And that creates a buying opportunity for bargain hunters right now.", "title": "Bargain Hunters Turn to Emerging Market Stocks", "authors": ["Paul J. Lim"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nAbout a year ago, I was hired as a permanent home-based employee of a company expanding into new countries, including the one I live in. There are four home-based workers in my group, and others in satellite offices away from headquarters. We communicate primarily via email and text messages, or sometimes by phone. Six months ago, the manager who hired me was abruptly transferred. A few months after that, her replacement announced with great fanfare that our unit would now have monthly team meetings, which we remote workers would attend by videoconference. But an hour before the first meeting, the new manager told each of the home-based workers that an emergency had arisen and she had to cancel the meeting. There was no word about rescheduling \u2014 until two days later, when we received minutes to a team meeting that had happened in the interim, and listed us as absent! When I emailed about dial-in information for the next meeting (with copies to my home-based colleagues) I got no answer. Finally, an email I sent to a different manager at the start of the meeting, including the entire team, resulted in me getting patched in \u2014 and scolded by my manager for several minutes about my email. I managed to get another left-out home worker included, too. What should we remote workers do under these circumstances? The project managers I deal with day to day seem to appreciate my work. In fact, I thought I was headed toward a promotion based on their feedback. I\u2019ve changed jobs a lot in the last few years and I don\u2019t want to abandon this one too quickly. But I feel home-based workers like me are threatened now. BETH\n\nYour new supervisor doesn\u2019t seem to be on board with the whole remote-worker idea. The question is whether she is out of step with broader company practices \u2014 or if her lukewarm attitude reflects some big-picture strategic shift.\n\nBeing a remote worker almost always means making an extra effort to remind bosses and colleagues that you exist, and that you\u2019re doing useful work. That means making sure the lines of communication are as open as possible. Since digital communication can be so susceptible to misunderstanding, it\u2019s important to make direct, human contact from time to time. So schedule a one-on-one phone chat.\n\nGet a clear sense of what she needs from you, and ask directly how she wants you to keep in touch. But also make sure you convey how you\u2019ve successfully collaborated with various project managers and make clear your contributions to the company\u2019s goals. You want to make her life easier, not more complicated.\n\nIf it doesn\u2019t violate company norms, contact the transferred boss who hired you, and perhaps some of those project managers. Don\u2019t criticize the new boss, but seek advice on how to make sure your work remains on point and appreciated.", "title": "Based at Home, and Excluded from the Action in the Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat story could this image tell?\n\nUse your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo and post it in the comments.\n\nThen read the related article to find out what this picture is all about.", "title": "Basketball", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "A Basquiat is coming back to Brooklyn.\n\nStarting Jan. 26, the Brooklyn-born graffiti artist Jean-Michel Basquiat\u2019s 1982 skull painting \u201cUntitled\u201d will be on view at the Brooklyn Museum through March 11.\n\nThe work caused something of a stir when the Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa paid $110.5 million for it at Sotheby\u2019s last year, making the painting the sixth most expensive work ever sold at auction at the time.\n\n\u201cAs I explained when I successfully bought the work, my hope is that art becomes more accessible to a wider audience, and not just enjoyed by a select few,\u201d Mr. Maezawa said in a statement to The New York Times. \u201cTherefore, it is with great excitement that I begin the journey of sharing this masterpiece \u2014 particularly with young people who will carry us forward into the future.\u201d\n\nMr. Maezawa is supporting the show, \u201cOne Basquiat\u201d \u2014 billed as the first museum exhibition of the painting \u2014 as well as public programming around it.", "title": "Basquiat Skull Painting Is Coming to the Brooklyn Museum", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Whatever the merits of the suit, Mr. de Blasio and his predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, are the very embodiment of a possible line of defense by the oil companies. Namely, that it wasn\u2019t the oil companies that created the greenhouse gases, but society in general \u2014 companies and individuals who used oil to generate electricity, or for transportation.\n\nMany mornings, Mr. De Blasio is driven 11 miles to his gym in Park Slope, Brooklyn, from the official mayor\u2019s residence on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, Gracie Mansion.\n\nFormer Mayor Bloomberg, a billionaire, rode the subway most days. On the other hand, Mr. Bloomberg routinely splurged on carbon usage by deploying his personal fleet of carbon-inefficient private jets and helicopters for long-distance travel. He would use them to fly to a weekend home in Bermuda, for instance, or to Europe. In an episode so rich you could choke on it, Mr. Bloomberg brought an entourage aboard his personal Falcon 900 to Copenhagen, at a cost in carbon emissions that was 37 times more than if the group had flown commercial.\n\nThe reason for the trip? Mr. Bloomberg was speaking at a conference on climate change.\n\nIn New York, the police regard S.U.V.s as the most prudent for moving and protecting the mayor, and no one should begrudge any officials the security they need to carry out the work they do on behalf of the public. That goes for their recreation, at least for mayors, who put in long hours. At some point, every last one of them winds up splutteringly frayed or fried, so getting to a favorite gym probably helps keep Mr. de Blasio from losing his mind.\n\nJust because it is easier to deplore hypocrisy in others than in ourselves does not make any of us immune to it. Hypocrisy is more widely practiced by humans than any creed. Mr. Bloomberg\u2019s health department wanted restaurants to cut sodium from their recipes but he was known to shake salt on slices of pizza and saltine crackers.", "title": "Battling Climate Change from the Back Seat of an S.U.V.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "They were held at a nearby nature center that we work with. They take them out, along with other hatchlings that have been mis-oriented that people bring to the nature center. Actually, they get a ride out on a boat when some of the local dive masters volunteer, and they take them out all at once and basically drop them off in the Gulf Stream.\n\nHow did you make such a small treadmill?\n\nIt\u2019s a belt sander. We put a power coupling on it so that we could slow it down. Obviously, we don\u2019t really want to be sanding the turtles. The crawling surface is actually hair scrunchies, so it would be soft and give them some traction.\n\nIt was tough on the graduate students, because they had to watch them the entire time. When the turtles were crawling, we\u2019d have the treadmill on, but as soon as they stopped, you had to turn the treadmill off. And then as soon as they started crawling, you had to turn it on again. So it was very labor intensive to do the experiment.\n\nWhat do the hatchlings do when they get to the Gulf Stream?\n\nThey settle into the weed lines, that\u2019s what they\u2019re aiming for. They can eat all the amphipods and things that are hanging out in the sargassum, and they just live there for the next several years.\n\nDo your results mean we don\u2019t have to worry about human lights?\n\nThey end up spending a lot longer on the beach than they otherwise would, both because they\u2019re disoriented and because they\u2019re stopping all the time. That makes them very vulnerable to predators.\n\nThere\u2019s a lot of things out on the beach that like to eat baby sea turtles. Night birds, raccoons, foxes. And then also, they can end up being still on the beach in the morning when the sun comes up, which means they pretty much would just overheat and die.\n\nThere are some people who don\u2019t think that turning off the lights, really, is going to do any good. But I can say from being out on the beach doing the study, it\u2019s very clear that we would have one house that had a porch light on in the back or something like that, and the turtle would head straight for it.", "title": "Beach Crawling Doesn\u2019t Tire Out Baby Sea Turtles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Lord Jones, which is based in Los Angeles, is not the only brand to market a pain-relieving CBD body lotion, but it is one of the chicest. Founded in 2016 by Robert Rosenheck, who has a branding background, and his wife, Cindy Capobianco, who has led public relations for Banana Republic and marketing for Gap, it is a leader in a movement to make marijuana more attractive to a mainstream audience. The packaging, with a baronial crest and gold accents, would look at home in a fashionable department store. That celebrities use the products adds additional cachet.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe closer we get to de-stigmatizing cannabis, the better it is for all,\u201d Ms. Capobianco said.\n\nThat sentiment is shared by upstarts including Cannuka, a line of topical products containing CBD and manuka honey; Khus & Khus, a skin- and body-care line by the ayurvedic specialist Kristi Blustein; and Vertly, a line of lip balm by Claudia Mata, a former W magazine accessories editor, which is introducing body care this year. And beauty lines, including Malin & Goetz and Boy Smells, make reference to cannabis in their products purely for the scent.\n\nFor example, Boy Smells has a cannabis-scented candle called Kush. \u201cWe\u2019re aware that having a cannabis candle is a little provocative, but I personally love the flavor and smell of cannabis,\u201d said Matthew Herman, a founder, who previously worked for the fashion labels Giles Deacon, Proenza Schouler and Zac Posen. \u201cIt has a wet earth smell that is very attractive.\u201d\n\nMr. Herman also noted that the cannabis industry is undergoing a makeover. \u201cA lot of my friends have been getting their products from more \u2018luxury\u2019 cannabis suppliers who are focusing on packaging and branding,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s not like pot is new, but for a long time you had to go to a head shop and buy a cheesy pipe. It was always a little gnarly. Now it\u2019s fun to see modern, minimal, elevated designs.\u201d\n\nBut looks are one thing, efficacy is another. As CBD oil seeks to go mainstream, it\u2019s tough to tell which products hold up to scrutiny. \u201cI get sent a million different brands saying they have CBD, and the stuff doesn\u2019t work,\u201d Ms. Richards said.\n\nThat\u2019s because there is confusion in the marketplace, said Verena von Pfetten, a onetime Lucky digital editor and a founder of Gossamer, a publication dedicated to the chic side of cannabis culture. \u201cThe cannabis plant is complex with many compounds,\u201d Ms. von Pfetten said. \u201cCBD is one of them, and THC is one of them.\u201d\n\nThere are studies, she said, showing that for pain relief, CBD works best within the plant\u2019s cannabinoid system, meaning that combinations of compounds are more effective than isolated ones. That\u2019s termed the \u201centourage effect,\u201d and Lord Jones, for one, has sought to compensate for it by using CBD rendered from the entire hemp plant.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve found CBD isolate, or crystals of pure CBD, to not work,\u201d Ms. Capobianco said.\n\nSpeaking of hemp, there\u2019s debate there, too. Hemp is a type of cannabis that has had the THC largely bred out of it. It\u2019s legal across state lines, so only CBD derived from hemp can be distributed nationally. There is a lot less CBD and other cannabinoids in hemp than in cannabis strains that contain THC.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe reality is that the levels of active ingredient in hemp are so low that, though CBD definitely offers benefits, there might not be a wake-up-and-feel-it moment,\u201d Ms. von Pfetten said.\n\nNone of that is stopping companies from expanding beyond wellness into skin care. Lord Jones is introducing a face care line based on CBD early this year. Ildi Pekar, a facialist in Manhattan who has tended to Miranda Kerr and Irina Shayk, said that sales of her CBD facial oil are up and she plans on investing more in the ingredient, which she calls \u201cthe argan oil of the future.\u201d Both cite reports that say CBD has anti-inflammatory qualities when applied topically.\n\nBut Shereene Idriss, a dermatologist in Manhattan, said that those papers are vague. \u201cThere was one study in 2014 that said CBD can help reduce oil production and thereby have anti-acne and anti-inflammatory attributes,\u201d Dr. Idriss said. \u201cIt wasn\u2019t a perfectly well-rounded study, but it does have merit.\u201d The other study, from 2017, addressed cannabinoids in dermatology in general, including THC, but didn\u2019t deal with risks.\n\n\u201cI would need more, a randomized clinical trial, before I could with full-fledged belief recommend CBD oil as something more than just offering regular hydration,\u201d she said.\n\nIf you\u2019re using CBD lotions for pain relief, Dr. Idriss said, there are better studies demonstrating efficacy but that more needs to be done.\n\n\u201cCBD lotion that also has THC in it, it\u2019s going to help you much more with pain relief,\u201d she said. \u201cBut the ones from hemp, are they going to help as much? It\u2019s hard to tell because we don\u2019t have the data and studies. Also, the problem is you often don\u2019t know how much you are getting \u2014 it\u2019s completely unregulated.\u201d", "title": "Beauty\u2019s New High: CBD Oil", "authors": ["Bee Shapiro", "Skin Deep"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGently cooked onions, simmered in butter or oil until they collapse in a golden-brown heap, need very little help to become a meal.\n\nAdd broth and some toasted bread, and they become a soothing soup. Scoop them onto pizzas or stir them into risotto or pasta, and they shine sweetly against the plainer carbs.\n\nAnd in this hearty, warming stew, they melt into a soft-textured sauce for brawny cubes of beef.\n\nPound for pound, there\u2019s nearly as much onion in the pot as there is meat, with the two flavors melding into each other. Bite into a strand of onion without any meat attached, and you\u2019ll emphatically taste the beef, while the meat absorbs all the oniony broth that surrounds it, becoming redolent as it falls apart on your fork.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor a simple stew like this one, you could use any meat. Pork, lamb or even venison would provide ballast for the mellowness of the allium. But beef cooked with copious onions is a classic. You\u2019ll see it in Greek stifado, flavored with red wine vinegar; in Ugandan Bunyoro stew, scented with curry powder; and in ale-spiked Flemish carbonnade, on which this recipe is very loosely based.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe ale here is essential. It adds a restraining note of bitterness to counter the onions, which can become overwhelming depending on their natural sugar content and how long you cook them. The longer and slower they go, the sweeter they become. A shot of ale keeps them in check.", "title": "Beef and Onions, Made Better With Beer", "authors": ["Melissa Clark", "A Good Appetite"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Treadwell Park on the Upper East Side looks like any other sports bar. On game days, it can get packed with young business-casual types gathering to cheer at oversize screens, play foosball, and eat burgers and fries at communal wooden tables.\n\nDownstairs, however, is a hidden lair for less rowdy types: a tasting room, dedicated to the best beer in the world. A former storage space, it can accommodate only about 10 people. This detail, however, didn\u2019t stop the Samuel Smith Brewery, a prestigious beer-making family in England, from choosing the cellar to host one of the first-ever tastings in the United States of its oatmeal stout.\n\n\u201cIt might be the most utilized space in the city,\u201d said Sean Ellwanger, the New York City sales manager for Merchant du Vin, a beer importer.\n\nAnne Becerra, the city\u2019s first female certified cicerone (basically a beer sommelier), who oversees the beer program at Treadwell Park\u2019s two New York locations, had the idea for the exclusive room, called the Cellar. \u201cI love being upstairs. I think it\u2019s fun. I love playing the games,\u201d she said. \u201cBut sometimes you want to talk quietly and share a great beer somewhere private.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Becerra filled the Cellar with artifacts from breweries around the world. There is an old clock from a Trappist brewery in Belgium and a panel etched with the Reinheitsgebot, the German beer purity law of 1516. Mugs and glasses from traditional English pubs are on display.\n\nPhoto\n\nA leather-bound book listing the beers available, along with their vintages, ingredients and back stories, sits on the one table in the room. In the corner a mounted screen will often show reruns of \u201cThe Beer Hunter,\u201d a 1990 television series about the English beer critic Michael Jackson, who went on a global quest for the finest ales, porters, stouts, malts and lagers. \u201cWhen I took the cicerone test it was new, and there weren\u2019t study guides or classes,\u201d Ms. Becerra said. \u201cI learned a lot of what I know from that guy.\u201d", "title": "Beer Cellars, Whiskey Tastings and the Women Bringing Them to Life", "authors": ["Alyson Krueger"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Consider his description of the making of the traditional wooden fence called a wattle hurdle. It starts not as you\u2019d expect with the assembly of the required materials, but with the planting and tending of the hazel trees that will eventually provide the timber necessary for the process to begin 10 or so years later. His subsequent account of the (literally) Neolithic process by which horizontal branches are woven together with upright rods into a lattice goes on for a half-dozen painstakingly detailed pages. If Langlands were providing instructions for how you too could make your own wattle, the effect would be unendurably boring, not to mention borderline incomprehensible. Instead, his genuine passion for the activity at hand makes his account hypnotic. To watch a hurdle maker at work, he says, is \u201calmost like watching a concert pianist at one with her instrument.\u201d He is clearly addicted to that place where labor is transformed through mastery into art.\n\nExploring this unfamiliar territory requires navigating a deliciously unfamiliar vocabulary: hafting (attaching an arrowhead to the tip of a spear); laying, pleaching and plashing (all required to nurture a hedgerow); carding, retting, scotching (for textile production); stooking (for thatched roofs); stocking and scudding (for leather); panning, marling and mattocking (for working the earth); flushing (for sheep farming); puddling (for cisterns); and pugging and wedging (for pottery). Of course, we no longer need these words, because most of us no longer participate in the activities these words describe. For Langlands, this loss is tragic. His obsession with successfully learning to make a thatched roof, he says, \u201cproved to me most forcefully that it\u2019s not that we have lost these ancient skills, it\u2019s worse than that. It\u2019s that we have lost the conception of those skills and what they can do for us.\u201d Ironically, the residue of these lost skills persists today in turns of phrase like \u201cmake hay while the sun shines,\u201d \u201cby hook or by crook,\u201d or having \u201cbeen through the mill.\u201d Once operating instructions, these are used by people who will never clear a field, tend a herd of sheep or qualify as a master weaver.\n\nGiven Langlands\u2019s background, it\u2019s no surprise that he consistently locates true craeft in the years \u2014 the millenniums, really \u2014 before the Industrial Revolution. Is it really gone? As a first-year student in design school, I remember the endless hours spent doing something as simple as drawing a capital letter A, the attention to detail that blurs and vanishes before your eyes, that moment when you lose track of time. Langlands describes the sensation as being \u201ctamed into the work.\u201d \u201cYou resign yourself to it. Your breathing moderates as you become methodical, more controlled. This is a marathon, not a sprint.\u201d Practicing craeft is an experience so universal there\u2019s even a song about it, Stephen Sondheim\u2019s \u201cFinishing the Hat.\u201d Making things is hard but satisfying. Langlands is talking about digging a hole in the ground, but is it so very different from staying up all night writing code?\n\nImage Credit Nicole Natri\n\nBut perhaps I\u2019m giving us too much credit. Beyond the mastery of specialized skills, Langlands is talking about something more holistic: a way of looking at the world. In reconnecting with craeft, he begins to see not just the beauty of an object or a building or a landscape, but the deeper purpose for which each has been created. And he understands, too, the environment they shape and upon which they depend. \u201cArchaeology became so much more than just stuff in the ground,\u201d he says about his own journey. \u201cIt became an exploration of what it was to be human, not only because we are makers but because we are resourcers, gatherers with an inveterate knowledge of the natural world around us.\u201d How comparatively helpless are the rest of us as we contemplate the featureless mirror of the computer screen or the smooth sheen of the smartphone.\n\nIt is a deflating irony, of course, that in a marketplace dominated by mass production, it is the handcrafted item that commands a premium. Wicker baskets, made by our ancestors the same way since 5,000 B.C., are beautiful, versatile and resilient. Langlands cites a 1926 survey that listed more than 200 varieties of them in production in England and Wales.", "title": "Before Glitter and Glue Sticks, \u2018Craeft\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "ABC: The crime novelist Sue Grafton, who died on Dec. 28, often seemed like a permanent fixture of the best-seller lists. Her alphabetically titled mysteries about the private eye Kinsey Millhone spent something like 400 weeks on the lists over all, and 10 of those books (beginning with \u201cL Is for Lawless,\u201d in 1995) entered at No. 1. So it comes as a surprise to learn that Grafton didn\u2019t have a best seller until the series was eight years old and six books along, when \u201cF Is for Fugitive\u201d finally cracked the paperback list in 1990. \u201cWhen I started writing the series, who even knew this was going to work?\u201d Grafton told the critic and editor Sarah Weinman in a 2009 interview for The Los Angeles Times. That was the year that \u201cU Is for Undertow\u201d came out, and Weinman asked whether Grafton felt any pressure to make it all the way to Z. \u201cFor the first half of the alphabet, people bet I couldn\u2019t,\u201d Grafton replied. \u201cNow, they are rooting for me.\u201d\n\nIn the end, cancer claimed Grafton before she could embark on that final book, which she had planned \u2014 poignantly, it turns out \u2014 to call \u201cZ Is for Zero.\u201d So Kinsey Millhone\u2019s last stand will remain in \u201cY Is for Yesterday,\u201d which was released in August and went straight to the top of the hardcover fiction list. \u201cAs far as we in the family are concerned,\u201d Grafton\u2019s daughter Jamie Clark wrote, announcing the death online, \u201cthe alphabet now ends at Y.\u201d\n\nJ.K.: \u201cGood Night Stories for Rebel Girls,\u201d by Elena Favilli and Francesca Cavallo, is still going strong on the middle grade hardcover list, at No. 4 in its 27th week. And now there\u2019s a sequel: Like the original, \u201cGood Night Stories for Rebel Girls 2\u201d (which hit No. 5 last week) offers brief inspirational biographies of 100 women across a range of disciplines. That includes literature \u2014 one profile in the new book is of J. K. Rowling. \u201cAt 6,\u201d it begins, \u201cJoanne wrote a short story about a rabbit and titled it \u2018Rabbit.\u2019\u201d Success was preordained.\n\nPS.: There aren\u2019t typically a lot of debuts on the list at this time of year. People crave the comfortable more than the new, and resolutions haven\u2019t kicked in yet. But these lists also reflect last-minute holiday shopping \u2014 so earlier best sellers reappear, as gift givers turn to the books they loved. This week sees the return of Jesmyn Ward\u2019s \u201cSing, Unburied, Sing\u201d (last on the list in October) at No. 15; and Lisa Wingate\u2019s \u201cBefore We Were Yours\u201d (last on the list in November) at No. 13; as well as the continued presence of Jennifer Egan\u2019s \u201cManhattan Beach,\u201d which climbs a spot to No. 14 after returning last week for the first time since November.", "title": "Before Sue Grafton Was a Star", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "During the 2016 campaign and his first year in the White House, Mr. Trump and Mr. Miller have developed an easy working approach to the president\u2019s speeches, according to a former campaign adviser. Their process, which a White House official said began last fall and in earnest in mid-December for this speech, usually involves Mr. Trump telling Mr. Miller what direction he wants to take with the speech. He will then talk out some lines.\n\nThen Mr. Miller, who drafts the material with a keen ear for applause lines he has heard during the president\u2019s previous speeches, usually revamps the speech and hands it back to Mr. Trump.\n\nOn at least one occasion, the president has noticed that Mr. Miller struck a line he had said he wanted in. It is usually restored.\n\nMr. Trump took at least a few minutes out of his day for a photo op, posing in the Oval Office with the guests who are expected to be seated near the first lady, Melania Trump, during his address. In photographs released by the White House, Mr. Trump shook hands with some guests and flashed his trademark thumbs-up sign while standing next to others.\n\nIf tradition is any indication \u2014 and at least for today, it was \u2014 the last minute back-and-forth between Mr. Trump and his speechwriters could continue until the moment the president departed the White House for the Capitol.\n\nMr. Clinton was known to agonize over the details in his speeches until the last minute. He was also able to speak extemporaneously at times, including during the first minutes of his September 1993 address to a joint session of Congress on health care, when a speech from earlier that year was accidentally fed to a teleprompter.\n\nCody Keenan, a speechwriter for Mr. Obama, said Mr. Obama tried to lock up speeches the evening before, though things didn\u2019t always go according to plan: Once, Mr. Obama called him back at the last minute to tack on a paragraph to his final State of the Union address.", "title": "Before Trump\u2019s Speech, a Chaotic White House Follows Tradition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cComplicit\u201d traces back to the French complice (a partner or associate), which derives from the Latin complex \u2014 which means \u201cfolded together,\u201d as in the ingredients of a cake. It also means \u201ccomplex.\u201d There are so many ways to be complicit that you could make trading cards and never collect them all. You can be complicit through action or inaction, speech or silence, association or omission. You can engage in outright collusion, aiding in wrongdoing and lying your way through the cover-up. You can take advantage of an immoral situation to promote your book or your brand. But you can also feel coerced into complicity, intimidated or brainwashed. You can look the other way because you fear for your job or your reputation, or because you refuse to feel responsible for the systems around you.\n\nComplicity can be synonymous with collusion, but where collusion describes an action, complicity describes a state of being. It is buttery and passive, a path of least resistance. Complicity often calls for pretending not to know what you know, not to see what you see: playing dumb for the sake of getting along, preserving the comforts of the status quo. As a moral (non) stance, it clears the way for everything from bad manners to genocide. Take, for example, the opioid crisis, which we learn from a recent Washington Post article is a result of a corrupt system peopled with \u201crogue doctors\u201d and \u201ccomplicit\u201d pharmacists. The Flint water crisis, lawsuits claim, is a result of the complicit state of Michigan trying to save money by switching the city\u2019s water source and the complicit city of Flint failing to act as corroded pipes leached lead into the water.\n\nIn November, Dictionary.com selected \u201ccomplicit\u201d as its Word of the Year. Its number of searches had spiked in April, when Ivanka Trump told \u201cCBS This Morning\u201d that \u201cI don\u2019t know what it means to be complicit.\u201d For a moment, it was unclear whether she didn\u2019t know what the word meant or whether she was skirting the issue. It\u2019s possible she was simply rejecting the concept itself. Early in the year, some Democrats looked to her to be a voice of moderation \u2014 to keep her father at least marginally connected to the values of the socially liberal cosmopolitan women to whom she had carefully positioned herself as a peer. By March she was the subject of a \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d parody commercial for a scent called \u201cComplicit: the fragrance for the woman who could stop all this, but won\u2019t.\u201d Could, but won\u2019t, is where complicity lives.", "title": "Behind Every Villain Stands Someone \u2018Complicit\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJake Silverstein, editor in chief: \u201cFor this story we wanted a very straightforward and immediate cover. So we used a simple image and abandoned the typical conventions of display language \u2014 headline and subhead \u2014 for a more direct, conversational approach.\u201d\n\nRead the cover story, \u201cWhy Are Our Most Important Teachers Paid the Least?\u201d See all past covers here.", "title": "Behind the Cover: 1.14.18", "authors": ["The New York Times Magazine"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: \u201cTo harmonize with the display language, which hints at something mysterious \u2014 and wonderful \u2014 that the networks underlying cryptocurrencies might achieve, we wanted to leave readers wondering what was at the end of the golden balloons\u2019 strings.\u201d\n\nRead the cover story, \u201cBeyond the Bitcoin Bubble.\u201d See all past covers here.", "title": "Behind the Cover: 1.21.18", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJake Silverstein, editor in chief: \u201cThe notion of reinvention is fundamental to the personal philosophy of RuPaul Charles, the most famous drag performer in the world and the host of the show \u2018Drag Race.\u2019 He styled himself for this shoot and had very specific ideas about everything from wardrobe to lighting. The door closed before I could get on, snagging my foot.\n\nI pulled my foot out, but the beige mule that was on it got stuck. It teetered a moment before slipping between the train car and the platform, and then falling onto the tracks.\n\nI reported my loss to a station attendant and learned that it might be some time before the shoe could be rescued. I left my phone number and got on the next train, tucking my bare foot under the seat and casually gazing upward.\n\nAfter reaching my stop, I left the station in one shoe and my bare foot on tiptoes. I found some footsie socks at a Duane Reade and walked on, dodging the puddles on Park Avenue where building superintendents had hosed down the pavement.", "title": "Beige Mule on the Tracks", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFor many mammals, a busy social life can be an important contributor to a long life. But some animals need more alone time than others, and failure to get it could be lethal, according to new research.\n\nConsider the marmot. After spending 13 years tracking their interactions and life spans in Colorado, Daniel T. Blumstein, a biologist at the University of California, Los Angeles, and his colleagues found in a study published Wednesday in Proceedings of the Royal Society B that yellow-bellied marmots with more active social lives tended to die younger than those that avoided interactions.\n\n\u201cThe difference in life span between the most social and the least social marmot was about two years,\u201d said Dr. Blumstein. That\u2019s significant considering that the average life span of a yellow-bellied marmot is about 15 years.\n\nMarmots are a genus of large, squirrel-like rodents with sharp claws and furry ears. They are known as socially flexible animals: They prefer to live solitary lives, but will peacefully coexist with each other if the habitat demands it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe yellow-bellied marmot is more social than other marmots, like the groundhog, but it doesn\u2019t really want to be social,\u201d said Dr. Blumstein.", "title": "Being Antisocial Leads to a Longer Life. For Marmots.", "authors": ["Douglas Quenqua"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou hear people talking about it like it\u2019s something new,\u201d Mr. Evans said in an interview on Thursday. \u201cYou want to say: \u2018Heck, we were writing about this two years ago and it didn\u2019t get much traction.\u2019\u201d\n\nThe newspaper was shut out of most of the industry\u2019s prominent awards in 2016, and the national news media paid the story moderate attention at best. But this week, The Star has gotten its retroactive due.\n\nPhoto\n\nJake Tapper, a CNN anchor, said Wednesday that the newspaper was \u201cdeserving of huge praise in bringing about this day of reckoning.\u201d\n\nAngela Povilaitis, Michigan\u2019s assistant attorney general who prosecuted Dr. Nassar, gave The Star direct credit on Wednesday at his sentencing.\n\n\u201cWhat finally started this reckoning and ended this decades-long cycle of abuse was investigative reporting,\u201d she said. Without The Star\u2019s reporting, she said, \u201che would still be practicing medicine, treating athletes and abusing kids.\u201d\n\nAt first, the reporters hardly knew of Dr. Nassar. The first story in their investigative series, published on Aug. 4, 2016, did not mention him, instead focusing on the failure of U.S.A. Gymnastics officials to notify the authorities after abuse allegations against coaches. Following leads, the reporters \u2014 Ms. Kwiatkowski, Mr. Evans and Mark Alesia, along with the photographer Robert Scheer \u2014 traveled to 12 states and gathered public records from 23 states. Lawyers helped to unseal additional records in Georgia.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter the story was published, their phone lines and email inboxes were immediately flooded with tips from former gymnasts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cAmong them were three people in three different states who gave us the name, Larry Nassar,\u201d Steve Berta, the editor of the investigations team, said in an interview on Thursday.\n\nOne of those women was Rachael Denhollander, a former gymnast who, in an email to The Star on the day their first story was published, said Dr. Nassar had abused her when she was 15. She was willing to go on the record, a turning point the journalists said was essential.\n\nMr. Alesia and Mr. Scheer traveled to Louisville to meet her. The second major story in the series, which was published on Sept. 12 and focused entirely on Dr. Nassar, quoted Ms. Denhollander and reported accusations of another, anonymous, woman. (The other woman wasn\u2019t ready to go on the record or speak with the authorities, but the reporters looked into her account.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe three stories were so remarkably similar: no chaperone, no gloves, digital penetration,\u201d Mr. Alesia said in an interview on Thursday. \u201cIt was clear something was up that needed to be pursued and investigated.\u201d\n\nThe reporters and their editor said their investigative work was not finished. In addition to Dr. Nassar\u2019s sentencing, the scandal has led to the ouster of top officials at U.S.A. Gymnastics and Michigan State University, where Dr. Nassar was employed.\n\nSuddenly besieged by interview requests from the national news media in recent days, they said they were hopeful that the attention would reflect well on the need for local journalism.\n\n\u201cAt the end of the day, none of this would have happened if not for those women coming forward and sharing their stories with the public,\u201d Ms. Kwiatkowski said.", "title": "Belatedly, The Indianapolis Star Gets Its Due for Gymnastics Investigation", "authors": ["Daniel Victor"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "BRUSSELS \u2014 A Belgian official\u2019s decision to expel several Sudanese migrants late last year \u2014 several of whom say they were tortured when they went back home \u2014 has roiled Belgium\u2019s politics, reflecting not only the fraught migration debate in Western Europe but also the divisions that have made the country notoriously difficult to govern.\n\nThe official, Theo Francken, is a 39-year-old Flemish nationalist who in 2014 was appointed secretary of state for asylum and migration. He is known for making incendiary comments about migrants; in September, he apologized for using the term \u201ccleaning up\u201d about a police operation in which several undocumented immigrants were arrested. The term was condemned as xenophobic.\n\nSupporters and critics alike have called Mr. Francken \u201cthe Flemish Trump.\u201d\n\nLast September, Mr. Francken invited several Sudanese officials to Belgium to review the cases of dozens of Sudanese people who were in the country without authorization. The decision outraged advocates for the migrants, who pointed to Sudan\u2019s abysmal human rights record and the fact that its president, Omar al-Bashir, is wanted by the International Criminal Court for trial on war crimes and genocide charges.\n\nRepresentatives of the Belgian government were present during most of the interviews, but were not always accompanied by Arabic-language interpreters, raising the possibility that they did not follow all of what was said. In the final silent seconds before the cameras started rolling, a mischievous gleam crossed his eyes as he used an Italian double entendre to recall that, back in his old television days, people used to have sex on the studio floor.\n\nYes, Mr. Berlusconi, 81, is back. Again. His smile is brighter, his cheeks are Silly Putty-toned and tauter, his waistline is slimmed and his hair has regenerated into a Ken-Doll helmet. But despite his waxworks appearance, pre-Weinsteinian penchant for priapic innuendo and lingering criminal trials, Mr. Berlusconi, a former Italian prime minister, is no longer the joke of European politics.\n\nInstead, political analysts agree that the only sure bet in Italy\u2019s coming and critical March 4 elections is that Mr. Berlusconi will return as a major force in Italian, and possibly European, politics. Even if he will not be prime minister immediately (he is barred until next year following a fraud conviction), he is likely to be the kingmaker.\n\nHis resurrection is both astonishing and entirely unsurprising when one considers that Mr. Berlusconi has over the decades conditioned and desensitized an electorate that has picked him as prime minister three times despite, well, everything.", "title": "Berlusconi Is Back. Again. This Time, as Italy\u2019s \u2018Nonno\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe theater critic of The New York Times I do believe wields power,\u201d she was quoted as saying in Nicholas Coleridge\u2019s book \u201cThe Fashion Conspiracy\u201d (1988). \u201cBut not the fashion editor. It\u2019s too diffuse. The most I can do, if I\u2019m really enthusiastic, is get a buyer to go see the collection.\u201d\n\nMany designers might have disagreed. They hung on her every printed word as she roamed through Europe and the United States, sometimes covering four fashion shows a day for two weeks and also choosing the illustrations (by Antonio Lopez and Maning Obregon, among others) and photographs (by Don Hogan Charles, Bill Cunningham and others) that would accompany her articles and reviews.\n\nIn 1970, she recalled in a 2003 review of Michael Gross\u2019s \u201cGenuine Authentic: The Real Life of Ralph Lauren\u201d on the fashion website lookonline.com, Bloomingdale\u2019s opened its Polo Shop, which featured Ralph Lauren\u2019s radical four-inch-wide ties. It was the first time the store had sponsored a name designer in its men\u2019s department.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cMarvin Traub, the head of Bloomingdale\u2019s, had invited me to his office to see the revolutionary work of a new men\u2019s wear designer, which was entirely different from what conservative, traditional-minded men were wearing,\u201d she wrote. \u201cThe ties were an instant success.\u201d\n\nHer fashion reviews rarely equivocated.\n\nIn 1982, when Chanel tinkered with its classic suit, Ms. Morris concluded: \u201cQuiet, unassuming clothes have been transformed into fairly arrogant styles. The Chanel look has been vulgarized.\u201d\n\n\u201cBut,\u201d she added, \u201cnot everyone is troubled by it.\u201d\n\nShe described Norman Norell as \u201cthe dean of American fashion designers\u201d and championed Claire McCardell\u2019s comfortable sportswear, the wearable elegance of Calvin Klein\u2019s women\u2019s styles and the collections of Geoffrey Beene, Halston and Donna Karan, among others.\n\nMs. Morris was something of a trendsetter herself \u2014 she wore patterned stockings before they were fashionable \u2014 but she typically favored practical, unpretentious sportswear.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Morris wrote several books, including \u201cThe Fashion Makers\u201d (1978) and \u201cScaasi: A Cut Above\u201d (1996).\n\nBernadine Taub was born on June 10, 1925, in Harlem. She graduated from Hunter College in the Bronx in 1945 with a bachelor\u2019s degree in journalism. While working at Millinery Research, a fashion weekly, she earned a master\u2019s in English from New York University.\n\nBefore joining The Times, she worked at the magazine Fashion Trades and at The New York Journal-American.\n\nMs. Morris gravitated to fashion coverage because it was among the relatively few reporting specialties that welcomed women.\n\nShe married Jesse Morris, a businessman who had sold locomotives and became the director of financial services at the American Natural Soda Ash Corporation. He died in 2011. In addition to their daughter, she is survived by their son, Michael; a brother, Harvey Taub; and two granddaughters.", "title": "Bernadine Morris, Veteran Observer of Fashion, Dies at 92", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Beth Heslowitz and Matthew Hayes are to be married Jan. 14 at the iPic Theaters in Boca Raton, Fla. He graduated from Kansas State University.\n\nHe is the son of Linda Hayes Schroeder of Los Altos, Calif., and Larry Hayes of Virginia Beach.\n\nThe groom\u2019s mother is a business partner in Aplat, a company in San Francisco that designs and manufactures culinary tote bags.
