When asked whether he would stick around, the governor-elect said he could not.\n\n\u201cNo statement being made,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m trying to still put the team together.\u201d\n\nBut for Mr. Christie, it was the final time he would grip the ornate wooden lectern under the giant golden arch in the packed Assembly chamber, lean forward forcefully on his right elbow and proclaim the world as he sees it.\n\n\u201cI ran to be different,\u201d he said. \u201cI ran to speak bluntly. I ran to shine lights on all of New Jersey\u2019s real problems.\u201d\n\nToward the end of his speech, Mr. Christie offered a slight departure from his usual approach. The governor whose love for all things New Jersey, especially Bruce Springsteen, is never far from the surface, instead chose to quote Alfred Tennyson\u2019s poem \u201cUlysses.\u201d\n\n\u201cThough much is taken, much abides,\u201d Mr. Christie said, reciting the poem. \u201cAnd though we are not now that strength which in old days moved heaven and earth, that which we are, we are. One equal temper of heroic hearts, made weak by time and fate, but strong in will. To strive, to seek, to find and never to yield.\u201d", "title": "Boastful and Unabashed, Christie Gives Final State of the State Address", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "His father, Thomas, was a state trooper, and his mother, the former Sue Corey, was a homemaker. He frequently mined his youth for material for his stand-up routines and his books, as he did in \u201cOpenly Bob,\u201d a 1997 volume of essays that included one on sex education.\n\n\u201cWhile talking about sex with your parents is difficult for straight teenagers, it\u2019s even more trying for gay teenagers,\u201d he wrote. \u201cIt takes considerable maturity, when your parents are attempting to tell you the facts of life, to interrupt and inform them of the facts of your life.\u201d\n\nMr. Smith graduated from the University at Buffalo with a degree in English. He made his Manhattan stand-up debut at Comedy U. Grand, a club in SoHo, in July 1986, a time when being openly gay was fraught with risks, especially in the world of comedy, where heterosexual men dominated and gay-bashing was still good for laughs.\n\n\u201cI was determined to be an out comic in New York,\u201d Mr. Smith wrote in \u201cLove, Christopher Street: Reflections of New York City,\u201d a 2013 book of essays by more than two dozen writers, \u201csince it was the right thing to do, both artistically \u2014 a closeted artist is still an oxymoron to me \u2014 and politically.\u201d\n\nIn 1988 he, Jaffe Cohen and Danny McWilliams formed Funny Gay Males, each man performing his own material in an evening-length show. The act caught on, playing at places like the Ballroom and Town Hall in New York and touring as well.\n\n\u201cIt was a show that anyone could enjoy,\u201d Paul Delean wrote in The Gazette of Montreal, describing the men\u2019s 1991 performance at the Just for Laughs comedy festival there, \u201cand very different from much of the mainstream comedy heard in the previous 10 days. There was less profanity, for one thing. More humility, less aggression. Not a single joke demeaning to women or racial minorities.\u201d", "title": "Bob Smith, Groundbreaking Gay Comedian, Is Dead at 59", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI went on YouTube,\u201d said Mr. Groff, speaking before an early rehearsal at the Y, where \u201cThe Bobby Darin Story\u201d will kick off the new \u201cLyrics\u201d season from Jan. 20 to 22. \u201cI watched all these TV performances, from the beginning to the end of his career, and I was blown away by his versatility. The rock & roll and the standards, the dancing, the folk songs. The duets with George Burns and Judy Garland. His life was insane.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Groff \u2014 also known for his cheekily effete, Tony-nominated performance of King George III in \u201cHamilton,\u201d and TV roles in \u201cGlee,\u201d \u201cLooking\u201d and \u201cMindhunter\u201d \u2014 was discussing his new \u201cobsession\u201d with the show\u2019s director Alex Timbers, the music director Andy Einhorn and Mr. Chapin.\n\nMr. Timbers, the director of \u201cBloody Bloody Andrew Jackson\u201d and \u201cHere Lies Love,\u201d was brought into the project by Mr. Groff. The two had met last spring to discuss another collaboration, but couldn\u2019t coordinate their schedules.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Timbers said he was intrigued by the chance to reconsider the performer\u2019s career. \u201cIt\u2019s interesting to ask if Bobby Darin\u2019s legacy has been negatively impacted by the fact you couldn\u2019t put him in a box,\u201d said Mr. Timbers. \u201cHe was always chasing the next wave in music. In one of our first conversations, we were talking about people like Madonna, how she was ahead of the whole EDM thing with \u2018Ray of Light.\u2019 Or U2, when they released \u2018Pop.\u2019 \u201d\n\nIf Darin\u2019s singing could seem slicker and less distinctive than that of his more celebrated contemporaries, his range was indeed expansive, encompassing rock (\u201cSplish Splash\u201d), lush and jazzy pop (\u201cDream Lover,\u201d \u201cBeyond The Sea\u201d) and show tunes and songbook staples (\u201cMack the Knife,\u201d most famously).\n\nHe also ventured into film acting, founded a record label and music publishing company, and, as his political awareness grew, crafted \u201cSimple Song of Freedom,\u201d a pacifist anthem for the Vietnam era.\n\nDarin pursued goals like he was running out of time \u2014 \u201clike he had a stopwatch on his life,\u201d noted Mr. Timbers. And with good reason: childhood bouts with rheumatic fever had left the performer\u2019s heart severely weakened; he would die at 37. He nonetheless proceeded at a breakneck pace: marrying movie sweetheart Sandra Dee; collecting an Oscar nomination; holding court at the Copacabana and in Las Vegas; campaigning for Bobby Kennedy before returning to nightclubs.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an extraordinary trajectory for a guy who was told he\u2019d be dead by the age of 15,\u201d said Mr. Timbers.\n\nWhile Darin was prolific in the studio, evidence suggests his live performances could be looser, and swing harder. In the \u201cMack the Knife\u201d captured on \u201cDarin At the Copa,\u201d his voice sounds grittier than on the hit single, and his syncopation is more playful.\n\n\u201cAs with so many great performers,\u201d said Mr. Einhorn, \u201cthere was clearly something about being in the room with him, this great kinetic energy. That\u2019s often where you discovered what he could really bring to the music.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile in Australia in 2016, Mr. Chapin caught the jukebox outing \u201cDream Lover: The Bobby Darin Musical\u201d and began to think that Darin\u2019s work might an attractive subject for the \u201cLyrics\u201d series. \u201cThere was so much about his story I didn\u2019t know,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough \u201cLyrics\u201d shows have focused more on writers known for their work in theater \u2014 the new season will include tributes to Irving Berlin, Frank Loesser and Lynn Ahrens \u2014 Mr. Chapin said he thought, \u201cWell, Bobby Darin did write his own songs, so there is that aspect to it.\u201d\n\nAfter getting the blessing of the \u201cDream Lover\u201d producers (who hold worldwide rights to Darin\u2019s story, via his estate), Mr. Chapin assembled his team and hunkered down. Getting rights to the songs Darin had written, of which there are 160 titles, proved tougher than expected: \u201cI could get my hands on only 25 of them. One piece I actually bought on eBay for $35.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLike previous installments of the \u201cLyrics\u201d series, \u201cThe Bobby Darin Story\u201d will not be a book musical. (Nor are the creators banking on a fuller production.) But there will be something of a narrative line, written by Mr. Chapin, as well as other performers joining Mr. Groff to tell the story of Darin\u2019s roller coaster life, which included a \u201cmidlife meltdown,\u201d in Mr. Chapin\u2019s words, precipitated by the late-in-life discovery that the woman he thought was his older sister was actually his mother.\n\n\u201cThere aren\u2019t characters speaking dialogue, having conversations on stage,\u201d Mr. Timbers said. \u201cIt will show emotion through music, and narration. That section toward the end of Darin\u2019s life, this sort of downward spiral, could have been tricky in musical theater, where it can become less exhilarating when you don\u2019t have a protagonist making choices, taking positive action. But Ted has been able to focus on the coolest, juiciest stuff about Bobby Darin.\u201d\n\nMr. Groff\u2019s own research has included \u201cDream Lovers,\u201d an unsparing account of Darin and Ms. Dee\u2019s lives together written by their son, Dodd Darin.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s this quote that basically says that after all the things Bobby Darin did, in the end, he felt most powerful and most alive and most himself performing in a nightclub setting,\u201d Mr. Groff said.\n\nMr. Timbers added: \u201cHe lived a gritty, driven life. He hurt people along the way and people hurt him.\n\n\u201cIt would be easy to do a hagiography, a scrubbed-clean look at the meteoric rise of a pop sensation who bottoms out in midcareer and then has a resurgence. But I think this will be more ornery and strange and idiosyncratic. As befits Bobby Darin.\u201d", "title": "Bobby Darin Who? Jonathan Groff Gets It Now", "authors": ["Elysa Gardner"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "MONTREAL \u2014 The United States International Trade Commission on Friday struck down a Commerce Department recommendation that America place steep duties on imported Canadian jets, bringing an end to a trade dispute that has stoked tensions between normally close allies.\n\nThe case was brought by Boeing, which accused the Canadian jet maker Bombardier of subsidizing its products and selling them at unfairly low prices in the United States in violation of American trade rules. As is its usual practice, the commission did not explain the factors behind its decision.\n\nThe dispute \u2014 one of several trade conflicts to erupt between the two countries over lumber, newsprint and other goods \u2014 flared up amid wrangling over the Trump administration\u2019s plan to drastically rework the 24-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement. The trade commission\u2019s decision seemed likely to ease that strain.\n\nThe Commerce Department had decided that duties of nearly 300 percent should be placed on Bombardier\u2019s new CSeries aircraft. But the trade commission, a quasi-judicial body of trade experts, disagreed.", "title": "Boeing Denied Bid for Tariffs on Canadian Jets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "DAKAR, Senegal \u2014 A video released in Nigeria on Monday by Boko Haram purports to show girls among those abducted in 2014 from a school in the town of Chibok vowing to stay with their captors and never go home.\n\nAbout a dozen girls, some with faces covered, appear in the video, one of several released in recent days by Boko Haram, the Islamist group terrorizing northern Nigeria in a war that has spilled across borders and raged for nearly nine years.\n\n\u201cWe are the Chibok girls,\u201d one of the girls said in the video, according to translations by new agencies. \u201cWe are the ones you are crying about for us to come back. By the grace of God we are never coming back.\u201d\n\nIt was unclear if the girls in the video were in fact among the nearly 300 who in April 2014 were kidnapped by fighters from their school in northeastern Nigeria as they were preparing for exams. Allen Manasa, a spokesman for the village of Chibok, said he could not verify the identities of anyone in the video. The girls\u2019 families have not yet seen the video, he said.", "title": "Boko Haram Video Is Said to Show Captured Girls From Chibok", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Morales\u2019s determination to continue governing his landlocked country has echoes elsewhere in the region, where a stable grid of democracies suddenly looks a lot less solid. Corruption scandals have rocked Ecuador, a successful impeachment brought down a president in Brazil and an attempt to remove Peru\u2019s president from office failed by only a slim margin.\n\nIn Venezuela, President Nicol\u00e1s Maduro\u2019s leftist government recently banned the three biggest opposition parties from running in a presidential election this year, following a deadly crackdown against protesters. In Honduras, judges overturned a constitutional ban against re-elections, allowing the right-wing incumbent, President Juan Orlando Hern\u00e1ndez, to run again. After widespread protests of the results and calls by the Organization of American States for a new election after allegations of vote-rigging, Mr. Hern\u00e1ndez declared victory last month, with the support of the United States.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s undeniable that you\u2019re starting to see authoritarian tendencies in parts of Latin America, leaders that are struggling to let go,\u201d said Oliver Stuenkel, an international relations professor at the Get\u00falio Vargas Foundation in S\u00e3o Paulo, Brazil. \u201cIt\u2019s not limited to the right or left now.\u201d\n\nBen Raderstorf, an analyst at the Inter-American Dialogue, a policy group based in Washington, said recent economic troubles, in an area suffering from stagnant commodity prices, is one factor leading to incumbents trying to hold onto power in Latin America.\n\n\u201cWhen economies started to turn downward, political machines started to grasp what they could,\u201d Mr. Raderstorf said.\n\nBefore telling Mr. Morales, 58, in the referendum that it was time he retired, voters had repeatedly backed him, in three consecutive elections, bringing stability to a country that some politicians had considered ungovernable. Five presidents had served in the five years before the swearing in of Mr. Morales in 2006.\n\nWhen he first entered office, Mr. Morales, part of a group of leftist leaders in Latin America who rose to power at a time of high commodity prices, sought to tackle a history of inequality in Bolivia. He strong-armed foreign energy companies to share more profits with the state, investing the proceeds in education and health care while rewriting the country\u2019s Constitution to speed his reforms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA former union leader for coca farmers, Mr. Morales toured the country wearing traditional clothes and touting his indigenous roots. He built a web of aerial cable cars in the capital, La Paz, connecting the city\u2019s poorer periphery to places of employment. By 2012, the poverty rate had dropped by more than half from a decade before.\n\nThis momentum has top officials in La Paz arguing that now is not the time to cut short a productive presidency on what they argue are the mere technical grounds of term limits.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s historic leadership, it doesn\u2019t work in short cycles,\u201d said Gabriela Monta\u00f1o, the head of Bolivia\u2019s Chamber of Deputies and a member of the president\u2019s Movement Toward Socialism party. \u201cThere is simply no leader in Bolivia like Evo Morales.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFrom her office in the Legislature, Ms. Monta\u00f1o noted that nearly half of the country\u2019s senators are women and added that her own rise to power would have been impossible under any other president. She then brought up the case of Germany, a democracy where the current chancellor, Angela Merkel, entered office before Mr. Morales and is now trying to form a coalition government after her fourth election.\n\n\u201cI think as Bolivians we have the right to re-elect people as we please,\u201d she said.\n\nIt is an argument that has gained traction among some economists on the left.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe question of term limits isn\u2019t as simple as it\u2019s often portrayed,\u201d said Mark Weisbrot, the co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research, a left-leaning think tank in Washington, noting that Americans elected Franklin Delano Roosevelt for four terms as he sought to overhaul the economy in the 1930s and lead America\u2019s World War II allies in the 1940s.\n\n\u201cLeaders who are trusted enough and have the skills to get elected and preside over serious transformations can be quite rare,\u201d he said.\n\nYet in Bolivia, the argument that a leader like Mr. Morales needs to be allowed to run again is being countered by an adage: That power corrupts those who hold it.\n\nWhile Mr. Morales\u2019s initial years in power were notable for reductions in inequality and increased rights for indigenous people, the more recent news about his government has focused on the misuse of public funds and attacks on the news media.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne scandal involved a woman, Gabriela Zapata, with whom the local news media said Mr. Morales had a romantic relationship. Ms. Zapata, 31, an executive at a Chinese-owned construction company that received large government contracts, was tried and sentenced in 2017 for influence peddling.\n\nThough Mr. Morales has denied any connection to the case, the allegations that he had a relationship with a corrupt businesswoman still follows the president.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI think he is a villain,\u201d said Gabriela de Carpio, 34, an unemployed mother in La Paz, saying that the increasing frequency of corruption scandals involving the president\u2019s confidantes was one reason she voted against the referendum to let him run a fourth time.\n\nThe term limits that Mr. Morales wants to jettison were part of a Constitution he had promoted in 2009. Late last year, the country\u2019s highest court, which critics say is packed with judges loyal to Mr. Morales, ruled that term limits had violated an international human rights treaty from the 1960s, a ruling many legal experts consider dubious.\n\n\u201cIn Bolivia the executive is now the only power and directs all others,\u201d said V\u00edctor Hugo C\u00e1rdenas, a former vice president, and now an opposition politician. He said he fears attacks against opposition parties in coming years similar to those in Venezuela.\n\nBut even though Mr. Morales has said he will run again, that does not mean he will necessarily win in a walkover.\n\nIn judicial elections in December, a majority of Bolivians voiced their anger at the government by nullifying their ballots rather than picking from a list of judges that had been preselected by leftists.\n\nBut some analysts point out that while many voters are willing to express their anger against the president in referendums and judicial elections, far fewer may be willing to reverse his course by sending an untested opposition politician to the presidential palace.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe have the perhaps weakest opposition in Latin America,\u201d said Jorge Lazarte, a columnist for Bolivian newspapers and political scientist, saying few candidates stand a chance against Mr. Morales\u2019s power and charisma.\n\nAs Julio Eguino, a 42-year-old psychologist, put it, \u201cthe question is, if not Evo, then who?\u201d\n\nWhile Mr. Eguino is keeping an open mind about who he will vote for next year, he said he has little interest in the opposition and so far has always given Mr. Morales his vote.\n\nHe added that the changes in Bolivia begun by Mr. Morales still have a long way to go.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not a question of even five terms for Evo,\u201d Mr. Eguino said recently at his home in the capital\u2019s middle-class neighborhood of Calacoto. \u201cIt might be a question of a century to see the change we need.\u201d", "title": "Bolivia Tells President His Time Is Up. He Isn\u2019t Listening.", "authors": ["Nicholas Casey"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "But as soon as elected officials in Hoboken learned of the purchase, they began plotting to block New York Waterway\u2019s move there. Hoboken\u2019s City Council approved the use of the power of eminent domain to take the property from the ferry company if a deal could not be worked out.\n\nTo thwart that possible Council action, New York Waterway persuaded New Jersey Transit, the state-run operator of commuter trains and buses, to move to buy the site and lease it back to the ferry company. Hoboken would not have been able to force a state agency to sell the land.\n\nNew Jersey Transit\u2019s board had scheduled a vote on the purchase in the waning days of the administration of former Gov. Chris Christie, a Republican. But a last-gasp attempt to approve the deal on Martin Luther King\u2019s Birthday \u2014 Mr. Christie\u2019s last full day as governor \u2014 failed.\n\nMr. Christie\u2019s successor, Philip D. Murphy, a Democrat, criticized New Jersey Transit\u2019s involvement in the matter. The agency\u2019s board is now led by Mr. Murphy\u2019s transportation commissioner, Diane Gutierrez-Scaccetti. On Tuesday, Mr. Murphy announced that Kevin Corbett would be the agency\u2019s executive director.\n\nNearly three-fourths of the 2,447 respondents to the unscientific survey on the city\u2019s website said they would prefer that the property be converted to open space, even if doing so would cost the city \u201ctens of millions of dollars.\u201d Fewer than one-fourth of the respondents said they would prefer a combination of the maintenance facility and open space. There was no requirement that the respondents live in Hoboken, but about 77 percent of them said that they lived within 10 blocks of the site.", "title": "Bolstered by Survey, Hoboken Again Says No to Ferry Yard", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Who knew trade wars were so complicated? A United States trade agency on Friday surprisingly rejected calls by Boeing and the Trump administration to impose duties on Bombardier\u2019s CSeries jet. It shifts the regional-airplane dogfight back to the marketplace, where it belongs, raising the pressure on Boeing to seal a tricky merger with Embraer.\n\nChicago-based Boeing\u2019s decision to file a trade complaint against Bombardier was unusual, as it doesn\u2019t make a direct competitor to the 100-to-150-seat aircraft. Delta Air Lines, whose order for 75 Bombardier planes triggered last year\u2019s grievance, said Boeing didn\u2019t make a serious bid of its own but merely offered to sell it some secondhand Embraer jets.\n\nYet as Bombardier and Embraer extend the size of their flagship regional airliners, they have closed the gap with Boeing\u2019s 737 and Airbus\u2019s A320 models. The threat of potential Chinese competition has made both the American and European giants eager to buttress their flanks.\n\nCommerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said $1.5 billion in Canadian government subsidies for Bombardier would damage United States industry. The 300 percent duties he tentatively approved would have effectively closed the American market to the company. That prompted Bombardier to sell a majority stake in its CSeries program to Airbus. Boeing countered that the deal wasn\u2019t sure to go through and that a promised CSeries assembly plant in Alabama was \u201cyears away,\u201d at best.", "title": "Bombardier\u2019s Win Adds Pressure on Boeing to Strike Embraer Deal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Bank of America\u2019s bonuses will cost the bank $145 million in 2018, or about 5 percent of the nearly $2.7 billion in savings it is expected to reap in 2018 from a lower, 21 percent corporate tax rate. Apple\u2019s bonuses will cost $300 million, a fraction of the $40 billion, at least, that the tech giant is saving from a single provision in the law, which allows it to return earnings held overseas at less than half the rate it would have paid under the old system.\n\nAnd two days before Walmart snagged glowing headlines for handing out $400 million in bonuses and lifting its minimum wage at a cost of $300 million, the nation\u2019s largest retailer by sales unveiled a plan to buy back company-issued debt. The cost of the buyback: $4 billion.\n\nThe gap between what companies are saving and how they are, so far, rewarding workers, doesn\u2019t mean that the new law won\u2019t eventually lead to substantial wage increases. Economists across the political spectrum agree it\u2019s simply too soon to tell whether \u2014 and to what degree \u2014 that will happen.\n\nThe flurry of high-profile bonus announcements \u201care hard to interpret,\u201d said Mihir Desai, an economist at Harvard Business School and Harvard Law School whose research supports the idea that corporate tax cuts lead to at least modest wage increases. \u201cThey may well be evidence for these gains, but just as well may be an example of savvy public relations. The reality is we\u2019ll have to wait for a few years and good empirical work to really know the answer.\u201d\n\nBefore Mr. Trump signed the tax bill in December, few companies had committed to rewarding workers if it passed. Since then, more than 200 have pledged bonuses, wage increases or other benefits for employees that are specifically tied to the new law, which includes deep cuts to business tax rates. The new law lowers the corporate rate to 21 percent, from a previous high of 35 percent, and it includes a 20 percent deduction for many owners of so-called pass-through companies, who pay taxes on their profits at individual income tax rates.", "title": "Bonuses Aside, Tax Law\u2019s Trickle-Down Impact Not Yet Clear", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "But one thing is certain: The president and his allies on Capitol Hill will almost certainly reject any proposal that does not include funding for the \u201cbig, beautiful wall\u201d that Mr. Trump promised to build along the southern border, though he had said Mexico would pay for it.\n\nLate Tuesday night, Mr. Trump reiterated his request for tougher border security. He posted on Twitter that \u201cCryin\u2019 Chuck Schumer fully understands, especially after his humiliating defeat, that if there is no Wall, there is no DACA.\u201d\n\nThe administration has asked Congress for $18 billion to build the wall; Mr. Cornyn said that in negotiations with the White House before the shutdown, Mr. Schumer had offered the president $25 billion. A spokesman for Mr. Schumer declined to comment but did not dispute the figure.\n\nBut Mr. Schumer said he rescinded the offer because Mr. Trump had rejected the rest of the immigration package.\n\n\u201cThe wall offer was made as part of a broader deal. The president rejected that broader deal, so the offer is off the table,\u201d Mr. Schumer said.\n\nMr. Graham said he had a message for the administration. \u201cTo my friends at the White House: You\u2019ve been all over the board,\u201d he said. \u201cYou haven\u2019t been a reliable partner, and the Senate is going to move. Just ask Boris Johnson.\n\nMr. Johnson, the British foreign secretary, raised the notion in a summit meeting with French officials on Thursday, according to people briefed on the talks. The two nations agreed to convene a panel to explore big projects, and Mr. Johnson wrote on Twitter: \u201cOur economic success depends on good infrastructure and good connections. Should the Channel Tunnel be just a first step?\u201d\n\nThe idea generated extensive news coverage and even more ample mockery on social media, where the hashtag #BorisBridge quickly gained popularity.\n\nThe same Mr. Johnson who is advocating a stronger physical tie to the Continent is also a leading proponent of Brexit, as Britain\u2019s political uncoupling from the European Union is known. But he has, in the past, proposed adding a second Channel Tunnel for road traffic, in addition to the one that opened a generation ago for trains.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe idea of a bridge more than 20 miles long may be no more than a trial balloon by Mr. Johnson. He is a good boy.\n\nRiley, a 12-week-old Weimaraner, is hardly the first pup to have job responsibilities far beyond \u201cfetch\u201d and \u201csit\u201d and \u201cget off the couch.\u201d\n\nBut he appears to be the first to be trained specifically to detect moths and other pests that could damage high-value artwork in a museum.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really a trial, pilot project. It advocates ceaselessly for the notion that every problem \u2014 from climate change to joblessness to terrorism to cybersecurity \u2014 requires international cooperation and multilateral solutions.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s derisive rejection of such ideas as the woolly-headed notions of the global elite is central to his identity. He used his inaugural address a year ago to declare the dawning of a new \u201cAmerica First\u201d era. He has since pulled the United States out of a sprawling Pacific trade deal, while renouncing American participation in the Paris climate accord. He has spurned the modern sensitivities to race and gender.\n\nWhile many here are poised to recoil at Mr. Trump\u2019s arrival \u2014 diplomats, heads of state and members of human rights organizations \u2014 much of the moneyed elite who pay the bills for many Davos festivities are willing to overlook what they portray as the American president\u2019s rhetorical foibles in favor of focusing on the additional wealth he has delivered to their coffers.", "title": "Bottom Line for Davos Elite: Trump Is Good for Business", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Also on the list are other American groups like the Quakers\u2019 American Friends Service Committee, the feminist group Code Pink and the United States Campaign for Palestinian Rights. Organizations in Chile, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Norway, Sweden and South Africa are also named.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThese people are trying to exploit the law and our hospitality to act against Israel and to defame the country,\u201d Interior Minister Aryeh Deri, who is responsible for enforcing the ban, told Ha\u2019aretz.\n\nSpokesmen for the two ministries did not respond to requests for interviews.\n\nRebecca Vilkomerson, who heads Jewish Voice for Peace, which embraced the boycott movement in 2005, called the blacklist an effort \u201cto bully and intimidate us.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s emotional, and it\u2019s hard,\u201d said Ms. Vilkomerson, who lives in Brooklyn. \u201cMy husband was flying home from Israel yesterday. Both his parents are 80, he was born and raised there, we\u2019re all close. It\u2019s the sort of classic conundrum between political principle and personal impact. I really don\u2019t know how it\u2019s going to play itself out.\u201d\n\nMs. Vilkomerson said that while the movement\u2019s supporters outside Israel would be affected, the biggest victims could be Palestinians living in Israel under temporary permits, including spouses of Israelis who are citizens or hold permanent residency. Under the law, citizens and permanent residents cannot lose that status for supporting the movement, but those with temporary-stay permits could have them revoked, she said.\n\nLast March, Israel amended its Entry Law to bar anyone who actively promotes a boycott of the country. In a statement, the Ministry of Strategic Affairs said the 20 groups named on Sunday had \u201cundertaken ongoing, consistent and significant action to promote and advance a boycott of Israel.\u201d\n\nThe ministry said the blacklist \u201cexplicitly excludes political criticism of Israel\u201d as a criterion for inclusion on the list and was aimed at \u201ccentral figures in key boycott organizations.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nYousef Munayyer, the director of the Campaign for Palestinian Rights, called the group\u2019s inclusion a \u201cbadge of honor.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhen Israel, which aims to portray itself to the world as liberal and democratic, blacklists activists dedicated to nonviolent organizing and dissent, it only further exposes itself as a fraud,\u201d he said.\n\nThe blacklist\u2019s publication shed some light on a policy that has been shrouded in secrecy and confusion.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn July, five members of an interfaith delegation were kept off their Lufthansa flight to Israel from Dulles International Airport. The five, who included a rabbi and two other members of Jewish Voice for Peace, along with members of Presbyterian and Muslim groups, were told that the Israeli government had ordered the airline not to allow them to board.\n\nA lawyer, Eitay Mack, pressed under public-records law for copies of Israel\u2019s instructions to Lufthansa and other foreign companies or governments.\n\nMr. Mack said he believed that there may be more groups on the blacklist than the 20 named on Sunday, and that the government may also be compiling a blacklist of individuals to be barred from entry.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe law is being challenged on constitutional grounds, under Israel\u2019s version of the Bill of Rights, its Basic Law on Human Dignity, adopted in 1992.\n\nShachar Ben Meir, a lawyer representing the plaintiff in that case, which will have its first hearing next month, said the amended Entry Law violated the Basic Law\u2019s assurance of intellectual freedom and the freedoms of speech and conscience.\n\nIsrael and its allies are fighting the boycott movement on a number of fronts worldwide. Two years ago, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu budgeted more than $25 million annually to that fight, but little has been divulged about how the money is being spent. A report in Ha\u2019aretz uncovered more than $1 million in government contracts with law firms in Europe and the United States to oppose the movement, but details were redacted on national-security grounds.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the United States, the billionaire Sheldon Adelson is underwriting a variety of initiatives to fight the movement, including on college campuses, as polls show the Palestinian cause rapidly gaining support among young people while support for Israel is eroding.\n\nJust how much economic damage is being done to Israel by the boycott movement is a matter of considerable debate.\n\nRight-wing politicians and activists routinely speak of it as \u201ceconomic terrorism,\u201d but Dahlia Scheindlin, a liberal Israeli pollster, said her surveys showed that Israelis see few effects aside from the occasional celebrity canceling an appearance in Israel, as the singer Lorde did last month.\n\n\u201cSo perhaps paradoxically, they also feel resilient \u2014 there\u2019s a \u2018no one can really hurt us\u2019 attitude,\u201d Ms. Scheindlin said. \u201cSo far, it\u2019s not so much the boycott itself that feels like an existential threat, but what they\u2019re demanding and who they are.\u201d", "title": "Boycott Drive Put Israel on a Blacklist. Now Israel Has One of Its Own.", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "In the movie, Mr. Dillman portrayed Artie Straus (a stand-in for the real-life Richard Loeb), an arrogant law student from a socially prominent family who persuades a classmate (Mr. Stockwell) to help him commit the perfect crime as a demonstration of their superior intellect.\n\nIt would become one of his best-known performances.\n\n\u201cBradford Dillman emerges as an actor of imposing stature as the bossy, over-ebullient and immature mama\u2019s boy, Artie,\u201d A. H. Weiler wrote in a Times review.\n\nMr. Dillman, Mr. Stockwell and Mr. Welles shared best actor honors at the Cannes Film Festival.\n\nIn an interview with The Times shortly after \u201cCompulsion\u201d was released, Mr. Dillman gave some insight into his acting philosophy, criticizing what he called \u201c \u2018the beat\u2019 acting style.\u201d He said it made a mockery of the Actors Studio and Lee Strasberg\u2019s Method.\n\n\u201cTo me this much-touted new \u2018technique\u2019 is a reversion to the animalistic, a declaration of spiritual bankruptcy, a shedding of hard-won civilized sentiments like tenderness, honor, self-respect, loyalty, friendship, love,\u201d he said. \u201cAll this glaring out at the world from beneath furrowed brows, these shufflings and shamblings and evasivenesses, the self-hate projections, the affected stammerings and word repetitions and vowel swallowings. To me these are ridiculous, infantile.\u201d\n\nThe Times\u2019s Lawrence J. Quirk quoted him approvingly and wrote: \u201cDillman is an individualist and a breaker of rules. He dares to dress neatly. He dares to be a gentleman. He scorns white buckskins, clean or dirty. He doesn\u2019t scratch. He doesn\u2019t mumble. He doesn\u2019t spout phrases like \u2018gas it, man!\u2019 He doesn\u2019t hate himself. He isn\u2019t lonely.\u201d", "title": "Bradford Dillman, Star of Broadway and Hollywood, Dies at 87", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "Six weeks ago, few considered her a contender for the Olympic team. But she took third place at Skate America. And she followed on Friday with a composed, nearly flawless performance as Cinderella to finish first at the United States national championships.\n\nOn Saturday, Tennell, of Carpentersville, Ill., was named to the Olympic team, along with Mirai Nagasu, 24, of Montebello, Calif., and Karen Chen, 18, of Fremont, Calif.\n\n\u201cComing into this year, my main goal was to stay healthy,\u201d Tennell said. \u201cI knew it was an Olympic year and somebody had to go. I just kind of kept it in the back of my mind.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSelf-possessed and unexcitable, Tennell handled the immense pressure of Olympic qualification with no outward sign of nervousness on her face or in her performances.\n\nShe landed her triple Lutz-triple toe loop combination jump here with metronomic precision. According to the skating website Ice Network, Tennell has not missed any triple jump in her last three competitions.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never been a nervous competitor,\u201d Tennell said. \u201cI\u2019ve always really enjoyed competing in the energy of the arena.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA redemptive performance by Nagasu returned her to the Olympics after she was left off the team for the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, in a controversial decision by American skating officials. She is the most mature and elegant of the American women and possesses the most difficult jump \u2014 a triple Axel, which requires a takeoff from a forward position and three and a half revolutions in the air.\n\nPhoto\n\nNagasu has been alternately brilliant and erratic in her career, sometimes troubled by self-doubt. But she finished fourth at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, British Columbia. And if she can land the triple Axel in South Korea and skate consistently, she might have a chance to win a medal in a sport now dominated by Russian teenagers. No American woman has won an Olympic skating medal since Sasha Cohen took silver at the 2006 Winter Games in Turin, Italy.\n\n\u201cI wasn\u2019t going to let a decision that wasn\u2019t mine keep me from my dreams,\u201d Nagasu said of being left off the 2014 Olympic team. \u201cIt\u2019s like getting into university. If you don\u2019t get in the first time, what are you going to do, not apply again? No, you keep applying until you make it happen.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nChen, the 2017 national champion and an airy jumper, battled what she believed to be a virus during these championships. She was bedridden part of the time and visited her sports psychologist and acupuncturist to help her perform, telling herself: \u201cI trained so hard for this moment; I don\u2019t want to regret it. I can\u2019t let this cold or virus win.\u201d\n\nAshley Wagner, 26, a three-time national champion who had been placed on the 2014 Olympic team ahead of Nagasu in a disputed decision, finished fourth at these championships and was left off the 2018 Olympic team.\n\nWagner said on Friday night that she was \u201cfurious,\u201d feeling the judges had underscored her on marks for artistry. But Wagner, who won a silver medal at the 2016 world championships, has struggled throughout this season. And as her highly regarded career may have come to an end, Tennell\u2019s has begun its unlikely rise.\n\nTo lessen the chance of back injuries, Tennell has begun performing Pilates and attempting fewer jumps in training. Wearing a back brace was \u201cvery tough,\u201d she said, adding that her mother \u201creally helped me put things in perspective and not give up on myself.\u201d\n\nAnd now she is headed to the Olympics.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s incredible,\u201d Tennell said. \u201cI\u2019m so extremely proud of myself and how far I\u2019ve come.\u201d", "title": "Bradie Tennell Lands an Unlikely Spot on the Olympic Figure Skating Team", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "SAN JOSE, Calif. \u2014 With a nearly perfect free skate on Friday, the rising star Bradie Tennell won her first national title and almost certainly earned a spot on the American team for next month\u2019s Olympics.\n\nTennell was spotless in the short program on Wednesday, then as the final skater in the long program she didn\u2019t miss a trick under tremendous pressure. Her top competitors, Mirai Nagasu and Karen Chen, already had done superb routines.\n\n\u201cI just had to keep calm and focus on what I knew I could do,\u201d Tennell, 19, said. \u201cThere\u2019s the initial butterflies, but I kind of start to lose myself and keep going.\u201d\n\nNagasu, 24, who won a national title 10 years ago and finished fourth at the 2010 Olympics, capped a sweet comeback with a flowing performance to finish second, virtually assuring a spot in next month\u2019s Games in South Korea \u2014 four years after being denied a berth by the selection committee. That position for Sochi was given to Ashley Wagner, who finished fourth in the 2014 national championships, one spot behind Nagasu, but had a better overall record.", "title": "Bradie Tennell Wins Her First U.S. Figure Skating Title", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Bob S. Carter, chief of neurosurgery at the Massachusetts General Hospital, said using the Orbeye was like having \u201cSuperman eyes,\u201d but added that his hospital was also evaluating other devices and had not yet decided which to buy. The technology, he said, is \u201cthe way of the future.\u201d\n\n\u2018I Just Feel Good\u2019\n\nMs. Roy, a retired administrative assistant who lives in the Bronx, first noticed troubling symptoms in 2015: episodes of weakness in her right hand, and trouble speaking. Tests at a local hospital ruled out a stroke. But the occasional episodes continued, and in July 2017, while recovering from heart surgery at Lenox Hill, she had a seizure.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA battery of tests found she had moyamoya disease, a rare condition first identified in Japan. The name means \u201cpuff of smoke,\u201d and describes patients\u2019 X-rays, which show a cloud of fragile blood vessels that sprout in the brain where normal vessels are blocked.\n\nThere are probably various causes, which are not well understood. Many patients are children. The condition can progress and lead to multiple strokes, mental decline and, in adults, death from brain hemorrhage.\n\nMs. Roy had no doubts: Hoping to avoid a major stroke that could cripple or kill her, she wanted brain surgery.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer operation, on Dec. 15, was the first bypass Dr. Langer performed with the Orbeye, though he and his colleagues had used it for other operations. This type of bypass is one of the most difficult neurosurgical operations, and requires stitching together arteries that are only a millimeter or so in diameter. Colleagues say Dr. Langer is one of the few surgeons in the world with the skill and experience to perform it well.\n\nA vessel in Ms. Roy\u2019s scalp \u2014 one that Dr. Langer called \u201cthe Michael Jordan artery,\u201d because his can be seen pulsing at his temple \u2014 would be rerouted to feed a deeper artery whose blood supply had been cut off.\n\nThe cut end of one branch of the scalp artery would be sewn to a hole cut in the side of the deeper vessel. Another branch of the scalp artery would simply be laid atop Ms. Roy\u2019s brain, with the expectation that branches would grow into the nerve tissue, because oxygen-deprived cells secrete substances that can stimulate the growth of blood vessels.\n\nThe procedure started with assistant surgeons touching an ultrasound probe to Ms. Roy\u2019s temple to detect the pulse of the scalp artery, and then marking the vessel\u2019s path with purple ink so that Dr. Langer would know precisely where to cut. Then he would begin the painstaking process of freeing the two branches of the artery from their surrounding tissue.\n\nWhen the scalp artery was free, the surgeons took a drill and a saw to Ms. Roy\u2019s skull, removing a disc of bone about three inches in diameter. Magnified 15 times on the monitor, her brain, webbed with bright red blood vessels, gleamed in the light and pulsated with each heartbeat.\n\nIt took about 10 stitches to sew the scalp artery to the artery in the brain, using a curved needle about the size of an eyelash and fine thread barely visible to the naked eye.\n\n\u201cThe first two stitches are the hardest,\u201d Dr. Langer said. \u201cThey set the whole thing up. I\u2019m sewing vertically, but I have no trouble seeing. It\u2019s high magnification.\u201d", "title": "Brain Surgery in 3-D: Coming Soon to the Operating Theater", "authors": ["Denise Grady"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn Germany, calling your fashion label GmbH is so inconspicuous, it\u2019s almost a joke: The acronym stands for a word that means corporation or company.\n\nBut there is nothing ordinary about the subversive Berlin-based fashion collective GmbH, lead by Benjamin Alexander Huseby and Serhat Isik. \u201cWe wanted to be somewhat nameless,\u201d said Huseby, sitting at a cutting table in GmbH\u2019s studio which, reminiscent of an underground club, is hidden within a massive L-shaped industrial building in Kreuzberg, a neighborhood populated with artists, activists and Turkish immigrants. Isik nodded and added, \u201cWe collaborate with our team, with other artists. That\u2019s how it works in Berlin.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor years, despite the city\u2019s reputation as a progressive creative capital, Berlin has launched few noteworthy fashion designers onto the international stage. Both Huseby and Isik admitted that they were attracted to the city because of \u2014 not despite \u2014 its anti-fashion scene. Their first collection (called Collection Zero) took traditional workwear, like German carpenter pants, and made them fitted, using vintage, deadstock or club-friendly fabrics such as vinyl. When Collection Zero launched in 2016, it was immediately picked up by Opening Ceremony; last year GmbH was shortlisted for the LVMH Award.\n\nPhoto\n\nMany designers in the collective (there are between \u201c10-15 of us on any given day,\u201d says Huseby) are the children of immigrants: Huseby was born to a Pakistani father and a Norwegian mother and grew up among pine forests in the Norwegian countryside. Isik is a first-generation German of Turkish descent; he was born in Herne, a small former mining city in the industrial Ruhr district. When they met on Berlin\u2019s clubbing circuit in 2015, Isik was designing a line of tailored men\u2019s wear and teaching at the Academy of Fashion and Design in Berlin; Huseby was a fashion photographer who had recently completed a photographic series about edible urban plants and weeds. \u201cI was interested in the migration of plants as it relates to humans and as weeds as a symbol of migrant workers in Europe,\u201d Huseby says. He eventually turned the series into a book, titled \u201cWeeds & Aliens.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nNow, along with Isik and the GmbH collective, he continues to weave these ideas and political statements into the clothes: In some of the knit pieces featured in the brand\u2019s third collection, for fall/winter 2018, a pattern of abstract stinging nettles has been woven or embroidered into the fabric. \u201cThe stinging nettle is our coat of arms,\u201d explained Isik. Huseby added, \u201cIt\u2019s a plant that is not considered beautiful but grows everywhere in this city. It\u2019s a survivor plant.\u201d Isik brought out a sample fabric of jacquard knit with nettle leaf forms woven into it, which would soon be part of a tightly fitted long-sleeve shirt, like a modern compression top. \u201cDuring World War I there was a shortage of cotton in Germany, so many army uniforms were made of stinging nettle fiber,\u201d Isik says.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFighting uniforms and armor were major sources of inspiration for the current fall/winter 2018 collection \u2014 which they presented on Tuesday in Paris at their first runway show, in a sprawling factory in the 18th Arrondissement \u2014 as were Viking and medieval Islamic history. Against the backdrop of modern-day Europe \u2014 where some of the big political discussions involve the integration of refugees and the closing of borders \u2014 Huseby and Isik are interested in stories about how Islamic thought and customs have shaped Western society. \u201cThe starting point for this collection came from a recent BBC article,\u201d says Huseby, who grabbed his laptop from another table to look up the link to the story. \u201cA Swedish textile archaeologist found Arabic characters woven into Viking burial costumes that were found in ninth- and 10th-century graves in Scandinavia.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe designers say they are interested in taking apparel associated with a certain group \u2014 and turning it on its head. For example, Isik says, \u201cwe like to take a Turkish oil wrestling trouser and put it on a woman. Or take apart vintage Scandinavian sweaters and piece them back together with the kind of brown zip-up sweater that our migrant fathers used to wear.\u201d Huseby shows me images of two sleeveless tops made of chain mail that are part of their fall/winter 2018 collection. It\u2019s also an example of a GmbH collaboration: They worked with the London-based designers Alan Crocetti and Fannie Schiavoni on the designs. Unsurprisingly, Berlin\u2019s club scene is also a strong influence on their aesthetic. The name of their current collection, \u201cMy Beauty Offends You,\u201d comes from a line by the vocalist Bobo Secret in the song \u201cAlkahhaf,\u201d by Fatima Al Qadiri, a Kuwaiti\u2013raised composer and artist who often deals with issues of gender, queer culture and race in her music.\n\nGmbH frequently casts their shows with friends from the Berlin underground. For their last offering, spring 2018, the models were all from immigrant backgrounds, many of whom were friends from the club scene. The collection was inspired by Huseby and Isik\u2019s migrant fathers \u2014 and the German expression \u201cGastarbeiter\u201d which translates as \u201cguest worker.\u201d Huseby himself shot that campaign. \u201cWe grew up not even considering that we could be fashion models,\u201d said Isik. \u201cSoutheast Asians or Muslims or transgender people were rarely represented in the fashion world.\u201d Huseby added, \u201cWe can only shift society\u2019s idea of what beauty is by strong representation.\u201d", "title": "Brand to Know: The Fashion Collective Making Modern Armor", "authors": ["Gisela Williams", "On The Verge"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "S\u00c3O PAULO, Brazil \u2014 Nine inmates were killed, 14 were injured and dozens escaped in a prison riot on Monday, the national news media reported. It was the latest example of Brazil\u2019s difficulties maintaining control over its notoriously violent penal system.\n\nAccording to a newspaper, O Estado de S\u00e3o Paulo, 106 prisoners escaped the prison in the city of Goi\u00e2nia, near the capital, Bras\u00edlia. The authorities recaptured 27 of the escapees, but the rest remained at large.\n\nOne of the inmates killed in the mayhem was decapitated, news organizations reported, recalling a prison riot that occurred one year ago in the Amazon in which 56 people died. Several were decapitated and thrown over prison walls.\n\nThat riot, which was rooted in a longstanding gang rivalry, came at the beginning of a January marred by widespread prison violence, with 130 prisoners dying in the first 20 days of 2017.\n\nBrazil\u2019s prisons, which suffer endemic violence, are often severely overcrowded. Rights group call prison conditions medieval, with food scarce and cells often so packed that inmates have no space to lie down.\n\nIn comments on Monday the newspaper Folha de S\u00e3o Paulo, the head of Brazil\u2019s prison guard union, Jorimar Bastos, criticized the resources allocated for oversight at the Goi\u00e2nia prison, saying only five guards were assigned to watch over 900 prisoners.", "title": "Brazil Prison Riot Leaves 9 Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "But this scanty evidence was enough for Judge Moro. In something that Americans might consider to be a kangaroo court proceeding, he sentenced Mr. da Silva to nine and a half years in prison.\n\nThe rule of law in Brazil had already been dealt a devastating blow in 2016 when Mr. da Silva\u2019s successor, Ms. Rousseff, who was elected in 2010 and re-elected in 2014, was impeached and removed from office. Most of the world (and possibly most of Brazil) may believe that she was impeached for corruption. In fact, she was accused of an accounting maneuver that temporarily made the federal budget deficit look smaller than it otherwise would appear. It was something that other presidents and governors had done without consequences. And the government\u2019s own federal prosecutor concluded that it was not a crime.\n\nWhile there were officials involved in corruption from parties across the political spectrum, including the Workers\u2019 Party, there were no charges of corruption against Ms. Rousseff in the impeachment proceedings.\n\nMr. da Silva remains the front-runner in the October election because of his and the party\u2019s success in reversing a long economic decline. From 1980 to 2003, the Brazilian economy barely grew at all, about 0.2 percent annually per capita. Mr. da Silva took office in 2003, and Ms. Rousseff in 2011. By 2014, poverty had been reduced by 55 percent and extreme poverty by 65 percent. The real minimum wage increased by 76 percent, real wages overall had risen 35 percent, unemployment hit record lows, and Brazil\u2019s infamous inequality had finally fallen.\n\nBut in 2014, a deep recession began, and the Brazilian right was able to take advantage of the downturn to stage what many Brazilians consider a parliamentary coup.\n\nIf Mr. da Silva is barred from the presidential election, the result could have very little legitimacy, as in the Honduran election in November that was widely seen as stolen. A poll last year found that 42.7 percent of Brazilians believed that Mr. da Silva was being persecuted by the news media and the judiciary. A noncredible election could be politically destabilizing.\n\nPerhaps most important, Brazil will have reconstituted itself as a much more limited form of electoral democracy, in which a politicized judiciary can exclude a popular political leader from running for office. That would be a calamity for Brazilians, the region and the world.", "title": "Opinion | Brazil\u2019s Democracy Pushed Into the Abyss", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "A data breach at the company that develops New York State\u2019s third-through-eighth grade reading and math tests allowed an unauthorized user to access information about 52 students who took the tests by computer last spring, the state\u2019s Education Department said on Thursday. The data that was viewed included students\u2019 names, New York State Student Identification numbers, school names, grade levels and teacher names.\n\nNew York State officials said that the company, Questar Assessment, believed a former employee gained access to the information.\n\nThe 52 students attended five schools in different parts of the state. In total, roughly 88,000 students around the state took tests by computer last spring, including those who took field tests, which allow the test developer to try out new questions.\n\nIn response to the breach, the State Education Department said that it had required Questar to reset passwords on all user accounts and close accounts of former employees, which the department said the company had done. The department said it had also demanded that Questar submit a plan detailing how it will prevent such breaches in the future and commissioned an independent audit of its systems and security policies. The department said it had referred the matter to the office of state Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, and a spokeswoman for Mr. Schneiderman said the office had opened an investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re working very hard to hold the responsible parties accountable and, most importantly, to make sure this never happens again in New York,\u201d the state education commissioner, MaryEllen Elia, said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
