She tried to quit several times, twice entering rehabilitation programs, but she always resumed her habit.\n\n\u201cIt felt like it would be never-ending,\u201d Jessica Darlington said. \u201cEvery time she said she would get help, she tried. But then she fell.\u201d\n\nIn 2001, in what she acknowledged was a cry for attention, Ms. Darlington sliced one of her wrists. She was taken to a hospital, which prompted the city\u2019s Administration for Children\u2019s Services to intervene.\n\n\u201cMy rock bottom was when my kids got taken from me,\u201d Ms. Darlington said. Her children entered kinship foster care with their grandmother while Ms. Darlington went to a drug-treatment program at the Addicts Rehabilitation Center in Manhattan. She entered on the birthday of her daughter Janice Wright, now 23.", "title": "Breaking the Hold of Drugs to Earn the Embrace of Her Children", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBreast-feeding may reduce a woman\u2019s risk for Type 2 diabetes, a new study reports.\n\nResearchers followed 1,238 women, average age 24 at the start, for up to 30 years. Each delivered at least one baby, and none had diabetes before the study began. The scientists collected data on health and lifestyle at interviews and physical examinations conducted seven times over the course of the project. The study is in JAMA Internal Medicine.\n\nThere were 182 cases of diabetes, and after adjusting for physical activity, smoking and other factors, the researchers found that breast-feeding for up to six months was associated with a reduced risk for diabetes of 25 percent; breast-feeding for six to 12 months was tied to a 48 percent reduced risk; and breast-feeding for 12 months or more with a 47 percent risk reduction. The associations held for obese women and for those who had had gestational diabetes, both strong risk factors for Type 2 diabetes.\n\nThere are several plausible mechanisms, the researchers say. For example, lactating women have lower circulating glucose, and lactation may help preserve the function of the cells that produce insulin.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve known for a long time that breast-feeding has major benefits for child health,\u201d said the lead author, Erica P. Gunderson, an epidemiologist with Kaiser Permanente in Oakland, Calif. \u201cThe specific benefits for women\u2019s health have been less recognized.\u201d", "title": "Breast-Feeding Tied to Reduced Risk of Diabetes", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "He confounded the so-called experts again and again, at no time more dramatically than in 1977. That April, a poll by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers found that only 17 percent of New Jerseyans approved of his performance.\n\nImage Mr. Byrne in 2007 during a panel discussion in Princeton, N.J. Credit Mj Schear/Associated Press\n\nHis very vulnerability may have helped him: Nine Democrats were emboldened to challenge him in the primary. They consumed one another, allowing Mr. Byrne to be renominated with just 30 percent of the vote.\n\nMr. Bateman had also survived a bruising primary, after which he led the incumbent governor by as many as 10 percentage points in several reputable polls. But Mr. Byrne campaigned relentlessly.\n\nHe insisted that his Republican opponent had essentially no platform, except his condemnation of the income tax. Mr. Byrne never retreated from his stance that the income tax was not only right but also essential, and that its burden on homeowners would be offset by rebates on property taxes.\n\nHe underscored some conspicuous first-term accomplishments, like his successful backing of a referendum to bring casino gambling to Atlantic City, at the time a shabby resort community, to revitalize it. He reminded voters of his support for building the Meadowlands Sports Complex, which lured the football Giants from New York City.\n\nHe soon closed the gap in Truman-like fashion and won convincingly over the man who had been his adversary in squash as well as in politics.\n\n\u201cI knew I\u2019d get re-elected when people started waving at me using all five fingers,\u201d he reflected, perhaps only half-jokingly.\n\nMr. Byrne began his public career in the mid-1950s as an adviser to Gov. Robert B. Meyner. In 1959, Governor Meyner named him Essex County prosecutor. He was reappointed by Gov. Richard J. Hughes in 1964.", "title": "Brendan Byrne, Former New Jersey Governor, Is Dead at 93", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 Emilie K\u00f6nig, 33, spent the past five years living in Syria, where she was a prominent propagandist and recruiter for the Islamic State. Now she wants to return home \u2014 to France.\n\nThe quandary her case poses is an increasingly common problem for European countries: What should they do when citizens, who are also militants, want to return?\n\nMeanwhile, fighting rages in Idlib Province, the last major insurgent stronghold in Syria. The U.N. expressed alarm over assaults by Russian-backed Syrian forces, which it said had put tens of thousands of civilians at risk.", "title": "Brexit, Facebook, Julian Assange: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "GREEN\n\nBy Sam Graham-Felsen\n\n301 pp. Random House. $27.\n\n\u201cGreen,\u201d the debut novel from Sam Graham-Felsen, who was chief blogger for Barack Obama\u2019s 2008 presidential campaign, chronicles the middle school travails of an anomalous variety of minority student. \u201cI am the white boy at the Martin Luther King Middle,\u201d is how 12-year-old David Alexander Greenfeld, nicknamed Green, introduces himself in the novel\u2019s opening line. Martin Luther King Middle is a Boston public school \u2014 \u201cmad ghetto,\u201d in Green\u2019s estimation \u2014 where his progressive parents have sent him for sixth grade. He\u2019s not the only white boy in the school, but the other one \u2014 his friend Kev, who\u2019s got lip scruff and spiky black hair along with prowess on the basketball court \u2014 often passes for Puerto Rican. There\u2019s no mistaking Green, though: not with his blue eyes and blond curls and constantly flushed cheeks, not with his monogrammed L. L. Bean backpack, not with his weakness for blurting the word \u201cawesome\u201d (\u201ca Caucasian catastrophe,\u201d he notes). Almost all 12-year-olds are confused about who and what they are, but for David Greenfeld, at school, one conspicuous facet of his identity defines him: not his Green-ness, but his whiteness.\n\nHewing to the classic coming-of-age-novel formula, \u201cGreen\u2019s\u201d Green experiences a variety of awakenings \u2014 sexual, religious, familial, moral and not surprisingly racial \u2014 during the course of his sixth-grade school year (1992-93), all of which get relayed in first-person, present-tense, slanged-up narration. The alarm clock for some of these awakenings is the friendship Green strikes with Marlon Wellings, a pious, studious black classmate who lives near Green in the Robert Gould Shaw Homes, a.k.a. \u201cthe projects.\u201d Marlon, unlike Green, is mostly immune to social tensions, sitting by himself at lunchtime studying for the entrance exam to Boston Latin, the city\u2019s elite public school, where Green also aims to transfer. Green\u2019s first impression is that Marlon \u201clooks pretty soft,\u201d and thus approachable: \u201ccreased khakis, pilled-up flannel, boxy black shoes and a short, unkempt flattop, more like a clumpy cloud.\u201d He has a gap in his front teeth, just as Green does, but the similarities don\u2019t end there. The bond they form is based partly upon a clandestine love for the Boston Celtics \u2014 \u201cno one openly admits they feel the Celtics anymore,\u201d Green says \u2014 and partly upon their shared desire for an upward move to Boston Latin. At Martin Luther King Middle they\u2019re outsiders, and both of them are desperate to get even farther outside.\n\nImage\n\nThe similarities do, however, bear some obvious endpoints. Green\u2019s Birkenstock-shod parents went to Harvard before embarking on a life of bobo activism (\u201cPops gives mad loot to Greenpeace\u201d); Marlon\u2019s father is somewhere down South while his grandmother cares for him along with his mentally ill mother. Green and his 8-year-old brother, Benno, spend summers helping their parents tend a community garden plot; Marlon eats asparagus for the first time at Green\u2019s house and the resultant urine smell triggers a cancer panic. Green is a secular Jew, confounded by what that even means, while Marlon sings in the choir in a storefront church near the Roxbury border. Green\u2019s parents, if they would relax their principles, could conceivably send him to a safer private school (brother Benno, who recently stopped speaking, attends one such school \u201cfor sensitive kids\u201d); Marlon\u2019s grandmother is absent that option. And Marlon is black, while Green, glaringly, is white.\n\nThis dynamic \u2014 the white boy adrift in the urban and predominantly black school, the fraught cross-racial friendship that blooms there \u2014 isn\u2019t new to fiction. Jonathan Lethem probed it, with exquisite grace, in his 2003 novel \u201cThe Fortress of Solitude.\u201d (A line from Lethem\u2019s novel, in fact, could serve as a 10-word summary of Green: \u201cA white boy in sixth grade, squirming in the glare.\u201d) Graham-Felsen isn\u2019t reaching for the same lofty heights as Lethem did (few novelists dare to), but he is reaching in the same general direction: toward the terribly thorny beauty at the heart of cross-racial friendships, which constitutes, per Leslie Fiedler and others, one of our essential American stories. These thorns keep getting denser and sharper as \u201cGreen\u201d progresses, as when Green discovers that the pair\u2019s snow shoveling business is successful only when he approaches potential customers without Marlon in sight. What we call racism Green apprehends as \u201cthe force\u201d: its energies everywhere, \u201cworking on everyone,\u201d himself included. When Green copies a couple of answers from Marlon during the fated entrance exam, the white proctor takes notice but lets it slide. \u201cA sickening mix of relief and shame sweeps over me,\u201d says Green. \u201cMar knows it and I do, too: I\u2019ve been saved by the force.\u201d", "title": "Bridging the Racial Divide in a Middle School Friendship", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cTrump\u2019s Idea for Unclogging Congress: Pork\u201d (front page, Jan. 11):\n\nMy organization, Taxpayers for Common Sense, coined the term \u201cbridge to nowhere,\u201d referring to a bridge in Alaska, never built, that became a symbol of pork-barrel spending.\n\nWe created databases for all earmarks in all appropriations bills from 2003 until the earmark moratorium in 2010, even before Congress created a system of disclosure.\n\nWe saw trends as well as specific patterns of favoritism and instances of self-dealing. But we saw no evidence that earmarks were critical to make legislative progress. The last time all appropriations bills were passed in regular order and on time precedes the explosive growth of earmarks.\n\nEarmarks sound like a quick fix, but bringing them back would relaunch a pay-to-play system that picks winners and losers based on political muscle rather than on project merit.", "title": "Opinion | Bring Back Earmarks? Two Opposing Views", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Change comes slowly to the ballet world.\n\nOne popular style of pointe shoes, used by ballerinas who perform on their toes, was designed more than a century ago and is made of paper, glue and fabric. To improve the fit of the shoes, dancers swathe their toes in lamb\u2019s wool or household items such as paper towels and makeup pads.\n\nBut now, some dancers are embracing custom-molded shoe inserts made from silicone putty, a distinctly modern product from a Bay Area start-up called PerfectFit Pointe. The inserts are meant to help distribute dancers\u2019 weight more evenly and prevent skin abrasions like blisters and corns.\n\nKelly Schmutte, the PerfectFit Pointe founder, initially marketed her product to dance stores and ballet studios. When some elite studios expressed reluctance, she decided to take a different tack: She approached professional dancers directly through Instagram.\n\nSeveral agreed to try her product. Principal dancers at the New York City Ballet, American Ballet Theater, San Francisco Ballet and Royal Danish Ballet now use the inserts in their pointe shoes. (The name comes from \u201cen pointe,\u201d a French ballet term that means on the point of the toe and is often denoted as \u201con pointe\u201d in English.)", "title": "Bringing Ballet Pros Relief, Down to the Tips of Their Toes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "On Tuesday, Chase Finlay\u2019s tall and statuesque Apollo and the muses Sterling Hyltin (Terpsichore), Ashley Bouder (Polyhymnia) and Lauren Lovette (Calliope) were utterly lucid exponents of the Balanchine vision. Many who remember City Ballet\u2019s \u201cApollo\u201d during Balanchine\u2019s lifetime would still like improvements, but they\u2019re the same we\u2019ve wanted for years. Mark Stanley\u2019s lighting is too tepid, and several aspects of the choreography are misaccentuated. Andrew Litton\u2019s conducting, though it elicited wonderful orchestral playing, was insufficiently propulsive. When Terpsichore placed her finger onto Apollo\u2019s at the start of the pas de deux, the emphasis was overdone: What should matter more is the line that follows as she turns away.\n\nSo today\u2019s \u201cApollo\u201d lacks playfulness, excitement, naturalness. (Balanchine once described Apollo as \u201ca country boy,\u201d the muses as \u201cthree broads who happen along.\u201d) But its formal qualities remain thrilling: The lines of Mr. Finlay\u2019s dancing open out vastly into the surrounding air.\n\nBalanchine\u2019s \u201cApollo\u201d was an open-sesame. Its revelatory meeting of ancient and modern became the hallmark of his work. Classicism and modernism also coexist in many of his ballets, not least the five others on Tuesday\u2019s and Wednesday\u2019s programs.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Wednesday, \u201cThe Four Temperaments\u201d (1946), one of the peak ballets of the 20th century, was vivid in all its facets, from Lydia Wellington\u2019s gleamingly cool, sure delivery of the opening duet onward. Teresa Reichlen has long been the definitive exponent of Choleric\u2019s thunder-and-lightning steps, while Anthony Huxley, sometimes too contained in the past, broke through as Melancholic to a new fervor, his torso powerfully showing the conflicts embodied here. No conflicts for Tiler Peck\u2019s incisive Sanguinic: She was all full-throttle, outward-bound momentum.\n\nMaria Kowroski, the company\u2019s senior ballerina, and her partner Tyler Angle brought a greater wealth of nuance to \u201cMozartiana\u201d (1981) than they\u2019ve previously achieved. Sara Mearns, the troupe\u2019s most dramatic stylist, firmly steered \u201cCort\u00e8ge Hongrois\u201d (1973) from severity to jubilance, and \u201cChaconne\u201d (1976) from elusive spirituality through to rococo brilliance. She was handsomely partnered by Russell Janzen (\u201cCort\u00e8ge\u201d) and Adrian Danchig-Waring (\u201cChaconne\u201d). Both these men were admirable: More authority will come with more experience. Mr. Janzen seems unnecessarily anxious, as if not knowing how good he is.\n\nWednesday\u2019s account of \u201cDivertimento No. 15\u201d (1956), a celestial work featuring five ballerinas and three cavaliers, was both bold and clear. My cavil here is not a new one: Some of these ballerinas (Megan Fairchild, Abi Stafford) stepped out eagerly into space without illuminating the air around them; they were bubbly but not radiant. But it was good to see Ashley Laracey back from a six-month injury. Could this lovely but often self-absorbed soloist become an exemplar of classical style?\n\nOutside the auditorium, the David H. Koch Theater looked distinctly festive. Jihan Zencirli\u2019s large installation of primary-color balloons in the upstairs foyer is the latest, brightest and merriest of the six art installations the company has presented in the past years; Ms. Zencirli is the first female artist to have been commissioned. Even though I prefer this beautiful foyer in an unadorned, pristine condition, I enjoy these balloons: They hang like huge grapes from a pergola.", "title": "Bringing It All Back Home: City Ballet Begins Again With Balanchine", "authors": ["Alastair Macaulay"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Nitsche represents something of a U-turn herself. She spent the last 23 years at Maison Margiela, many of them alongside Martin Margiela, the Belgian ur-conceptualist who helped set the direction for high fashion for years. Brioni, by contrast, represents a retreat into the wardrobe. But Ms. Nitsche found them in many ways parallel.\n\n\u201cFor me, at Margiela, in the middle of the interest was also the original garment, the stereotype,\u201d she said. \u201cOf course, it was much more about concepts, in a certain way, and Brioni for me today is not so much about fashion.\u201d Brioni, she said, was not for any one particular man, age or type but for people who \u201cwant a little bit more, how do you say, \u2018spezzato\u2019?\u201d The word means broken, but she meant its more popular sartorial definition, mismatched, or as she put it, \u201cunexpected.\u201d\n\nThere is something a little broken, a bit winningly off-kilter, about Ms. Nitsche\u2019s Brioni; it even has a touch of humor not always in evidence when a label is turning out $163,000 alligator jackets. (Ms. Nitsche suggested throwing one on under a suit jacket.) Her beautifully tailored tuxedos come in black, but also almost black: a dark chocolate brown and an almost imperceptibly fir green, a private joke on the black-tie circuit for the man who wears it. The jackets alone can require 220 to 230 steps of construction at the hands of Brioni tailors in Penne, in the Abruzzo region of Italy, whom the label recruits from the tailoring school it supports.\n\nMs. Nitsche\u2019s three-piece suits come classic and correct, but also in versions that are, as it\u2019s said, spezzato: in checks that, on inspection, turn out to be subtly mismatched piece to piece. (One of her waistcoats: Surprise! It\u2019s a cardigan.)\n\nThese are minor upsets in the grand scheme, but they speak not only to a Margielian sense of mischief, but also to a commendable desire to speak small, to the man who wears the clothes rather than to the public that recognizes them at 50 paces.", "title": "Brioni Redefines Itself, With a Whisper and a Smirk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe polluter should pay for it,\u201d Simon Ellin, chief executive of the Recycling Association, said in an interview. \u201cIt shouldn\u2019t be the public that should pay for it, but we\u2019d still be in favor because it will change behavior.\u201d\n\nBut Ian Fisher, 49, who was taking his breakfast at Costa, a major coffee chain, found the tax proposal \u201cunacceptable,\u201d adding, \u201cCoffee is expensive enough, and it\u2019s not going to cure the problem of people littering.\u201d\n\nMost coffee chains currently offer small discounts when drinks are served in reusable cups.\n\nStarbucks on Friday said it was looking to test a 5-pence paper cup charge in 25 stores across London starting in February. \u201cWe will investigate the impact of a 5 pence charge on a paper cup, coupled with prominent marketing of reusable cups,\u201d the coffee giant said.\n\nCaffe Nero, another prominent coffee retailer, said it was committed to increasing \u201cthe sustainable recovery and recycling of paper cups.\u201d Costa, the biggest coffee chain in Britain, said it had collected more than 12 million cups for recycling over the past year, though it was not clear how many of those were recycled.\n\nMembers of Parliament behind the report dismissed the efforts made by coffee shops and cup manufacturers. They have \u201crecently made voluntary commitments or provide in-store recycling, some of which were introduced during the course of the inquiry,\u201d the report said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cHowever, despite having spent years talking about the problem, industry\u2019s voluntary commitments have been inconsistent and ineffective.\u201d\n\nA 2011 consumer survey cited by the lawmakers found that eight in 10 consumers were laboring under the misconception that disposable cups were being recycled, and that most consumers tried to discard their cups in recycling bins. The report found that fewer than one cup in 400, or 0.25 percent, gets recycled.\n\nThere are alternatives to the latte levy. Two facilities in Britain have the capacity to recycle disposable cups, having invested in the multimillion-dollar machinery needed to strip the plastic away from the paper.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe tricky part is taking the plastic from the fiber,\u201d said Richard Burnett, market development manager at James Cropper, a fine-paper manufacturer that recycles the paper into upscale shopping bags for department stores like Selfridges.\n\nThe operation has the capability to recycle half a billion paper cups a year, he said by telephone, but they were not being collected properly and sent to the manufacturer, based some 260 miles north of London, to be recycled. \u201cThat\u2019s the missing part of the jigsaw puzzle,\u201d he said.\n\nSince paper cups only make up less than 1 percent of total packaging waste in Britain, most paper mills have not invested in specialized machinery, Mr. Burnett said. Paper recyclers also generally reject packaging that has been \u201ccontaminated,\u201d or come into contact with food or drink.\n\nOn the other end of the spectrum, some companies are starting to develop cups that can be recycled more easily. Frugalpac\u2019s \u201cFrugal Cup\u201d contains a plastic liner that is glued only lightly so that it separates quickly and easily when the cup is re-pulped, lawmakers said.\n\nHannah Baines, 16, who was studying one morning at a Costa shop and drinking coffee out of a cup, welcomed the bid for a latte tax. But in the long run, she said, \u201cit\u2019s probably just better to make the cups recyclable.\u201d", "title": "Britain Considers a \u2018Latte Levy\u2019 to Cut the Use of Coffee Cups", "authors": ["Kimiko De Freytas-Tamura"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Last Monday Carillion, a Wolverhampton-based infrastructure and facilities management company, went into liquidation. The company has become an emblem of Britain\u2019s public sector reforms over the last two decades, and its collapse represents a signal moment for the country.\n\nThe result of a demerger in 1999, the company became Britain\u2019s second-biggest construction company with high-profile building projects including the Tate Modern, the Royal Opera House \u2014 and even the Channel Tunnel. But its operations did not stop there: Through a succession of mergers, Carillion moved into services and management. Rail tracks, hospitals, schools, prisons and military homes all fell within its capacious purview.\n\nCarillion\u2019s reach across the British economy is tentacular. Now, as it falters, the consequences of the government\u2019s reliance on companies like it are plain for all to see. All 20,000 of Carillion\u2019s British employees stand to lose their jobs, and the economic effects could prove potentially devastating. With up to 90 percent of Carillion\u2019s work subcontracted out, as many as 30,000 businesses are potentially at risk.\n\nAs the fallout from the last week\u2019s collapse continues to reverberate, in hindsight it\u2019s obvious that the company\u2019s business model, which mistook the temporary construction boom at the start of the millennium for something more enduring, died in the teeth of the Great Recession. In 2009 its market capitalization was half of what it was just two years earlier, a clear sign that investment had outstripped capacity.", "title": "Opinion | Britain Isn\u2019t Working", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "During his election campaign, Mr. Macron suggested renegotiating or scrapping the 2003 Le Touquet agreement that established British border controls in Calais, but that question has receded for now. On Thursday the two leaders reached an additional accord that aims to reduce the time spent by migrants in Calais, particularly unaccompanied minors. Britain is under pressure to accept more of them, though Mrs. May\u2019s statement made no mention of the numbers that could be admitted.\n\nUnderscoring the importance of defense cooperation, Thursday\u2019s meeting was held at the Sandhurst military academy, and Mrs. May said that three British military helicopters would support French operations against Islamist insurgents in the Sahel region of Africa. France will commit troops to a British-led NATO force in Estonia \u2014 one of four such groups deployed to Eastern Europe \u2014 in 2019, she said.\n\nWelcoming the agreements, Mrs. May said they illustrated her argument that Britain \u201cmay be leaving the European Union, but we are not leaving Europe.\u201d For Mr. Macron, cooperation on defense with Britain \u2014 Western Europe\u2019s only other significant military power \u2014 is important to bolster the credibility of European foreign policy. For both sides, antiterrorism and intelligence cooperation is vital.\n\nYet analysts say there is a limited area of common interest, and even that is shrinking because of Brexit. Mrs. May\u2019s hopes of achieving a favorable trade deal with the European Union have so far won little sympathy in France, which is keen to lure banks and other businesses from Britain.\n\nPhoto\n\nParis has already won the right to host the bloc\u2019s banking authority, which will move from London. In recent months the mayor of the struggling northern French city of Lille and the presidents of two French regions, Hauts-de-France and \u00cele de France, have traveled to London to promote the advantages of moving to France, according to the French newspaper Le Monde.\n\nWith Mrs. May leading a weak and divided government that is preoccupied by Brexit, and with Germany\u2019s chancellor, Angela Merkel, still trying to assemble a new coalition government, Mr. Macron has emerged as Europe\u2019s leading political player on the international stage.\n\nMoreover, Mr. Macron has branded himself as a centrist pro-European, a fierce opponent of the populist right and a critic of many of the ideas behind Brexit, Mrs. May\u2019s defining political objective.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThat means that on the one thing Mrs. May needs most \u2014 help in securing a favorable post-Brexit trade deal with the European Union \u2014 Mr. Macron made no concessions. He said his aim was \u201cneither to punish nor reward\u201d Britain\u2019s decision to quit the bloc. And, asked about access to Europe\u2019s single market for Britain\u2019s financial services, Mr. Macron said, \u201cBe my guest\u201d \u2014 while adding pointedly that this would require accepting single-market rules that Mrs. May has rejected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cMacron is part of a generation that has a sort of indifference to the United Kingdom,\u201d said Vivien Pertusot, an expert on Franco-British relations at the Institut Fran\u00e7ais des Relations Internationales, a research organization. \u201cHe\u2019s young. He hasn\u2019t known the fraternity and rivalry that animated relations for an earlier generation.\u201d\n\nMr. Macron has rarely mentioned Britain in speeches. Despite the various initiatives discussed on Thursday, Mr. Pertusot said, \u201cThere\u2019s a sort of distance in Franco-British relations, and a desire to re-center relations around the Franco-German partnership.\u201d\n\nThursday\u2019s summit meeting, which began with lunch in an upscale pub, was Mr. Macron\u2019s first visit to Britain since his election. But in the meantime the French president has managed his international diplomacy with aplomb, hosting successful meetings with President Trump and with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.\n\nMr. Trump, by contrast, who last winter accepted an invitation for a state visit to Britain, still has not set a date. Last week he canceled plans to attend the opening of the new United States Embassy in London, facing the prospect of protests. The lack of a visit by Mr. Trump is a growing embarrassment for a British government that not only prides itself on its \u201cspecial relationship\u201d with Washington, but also hopes for a post-Brexit trade deal with the United States.\n\nAs close neighbors with interlinked histories, Britain and France have a long-running rivalry. While there was genuine excitement about the likely loan of the Bayeux Tapestry, there were also some less positive reactions ahead of the summit meeting.\n\nThe right-leaning Daily Telegraph expressed concerns that Britain would be \u201cseduced\u201d by the French president, and the pro-Brexit Sun newspaper published a reimagined Bayeux Tapestry \u2014 renamed the BYE-EU Tapestry \u2014 in which \u201cBrexit frees us from continental shackles.\u201d", "title": "Britain and France Agree on Deals to Limit Brexit Fallout", "authors": ["Stephen Castle", "Adam Nossiter"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 In the post-Harvey Weinstein era, every institution and public company in Britain has been piously claiming to be concerned with how women are viewed, heard, treated and paid. And yet last week, 360 rich and powerful men in Britain were happy to pay \u00a32,000 a head (about $2,800) to attend an evening fund-raiser hosted by the Presidents Club Charitable Trust, during which their female peers and partners were excluded, and the only women in the room were there as miniskirted sex objects whose explicit duty was to serve \u2014 and stroke the egos of \u2014 the men.\n\nYou didn\u2019t need to see or expect the harassment that followed to find this arrangement deeply suspect. The invitation promised gleefully that this would be \u201cthe most un-P.C. event of the year.\u201d Half the tables were taken by men in the real estate industry; others on the guest list were financiers, restaurateurs, celebrities.\n\nThe fund-raising \u2014 for a children\u2019s hospital \u2014 was just a fig leaf. This was a bonding and networking experience, bringing men together to exult in male dominance and sexual power, barring any women who might question or challenge them, and reducing women to decorative, accommodating, humiliating subservience.\n\nThe details of the dinner, exposed by the Financial Times, have undermined the organizers\u2019 and guests\u2019 claims not to have understood or noticed what the event was about. The evening began with the servers paraded across the stage, two by two. The brochures on every table had an entire page asking the men not to harass the women. That\u2019s an extraordinary plea to have to make at a supposedly civilized event.", "title": "Opinion | Britain\u2019s Handsy Old Boys\u2019 Club", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Britain\u2019s National Health Service, put in place by the country\u2019s post-World War II Labour government, holds a unique place in the country\u2019s psyche as both source of constant frustration, object of affection and \u2014 somehow \u2014 a central pillar of arguments both to leave and remain in the European Union. In a country riven over Brexit, at least most people can agree on the importance of the N.H.S.\n\nWhat its future should be is less clear.\n\nThe N.H.S. suffered from staff shortages and tight budgets long before Brexit, but in the year following the referendum almost 10,000 nurses quit. In November, Simon Stevens, the chief executive of the service in England, said that after seven years of budget constraints \u201cthe N.H.S. can no longer do everything that is being asked of it.\u201d\n\nAmid a flu outbreak, colder weather and the continuing shortages of beds and staff this winter, some hospitals declared \u201cblack alerts,\u201d meaning they were unable to deliver comprehensive care. Nonurgent surgeries were postponed and patients waited more than 12 hours in emergency wards before being tended to \u2014 undergraduate medical students were reportedly asked to volunteer to ease some of the strain.\n\nIn early January, Prime Minister Theresa May was asked if the service was in crisis, and responded that it was better prepared for winter than \u201cever before.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Britain\u2019s N.H.S. in Crisis: \u2018We Might Break\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Items auctioned included a night at a strip club.\n\nThe group that held the event, the Presidents Club Charitable Trust, announced late Wednesday that it would disband.\n\n\u201cThe trustees have decided that the Presidents Club will not host any further fund-raising events,\u201d it said in a statement. \u201cRemaining funds will be distributed in an efficient manner to children\u2019s charities and it will then be closed.\u201d\n\nOutrage had been widespread and reached the floor of Parliament, where Jess Phillips, a Labour lawmaker, said, \u201cWhat happened was women were bought as bait for men, who were rich men.\u201d\n\n\n\nAnne Milton, an education minister in the Conservative government, said that David Meller, co-chairman of the group that had held the dinner, had stepped down as a member of the board of the Department for Education. Maria Miller, another Conservative lawmaker and chairwoman of the Women and Equalities Committee, said the law against sexual harassment should be toughened.\n\nOpposition lawmakers said that a government minister who attended the event, Nadhim Zahawi, should resign, though Mrs. Milton said in Parliament that he had left the dinner early.\n\n\u201cI know he found the event extremely uncomfortable,\u201d she said. \u201cHe left and he was truly shocked by the reports that have emerged.\u201d\n\nMr. Zahawi, the under secretary of state for children and families, wrote on Twitter: \u201cI do unequivocally condemn this behavior. The report is truly shocking. I will never attend a men only function ever.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOne of the prizes auctioned at the event included tea with Mark Carney, the governor of the Bank of England. The National Council for Voluntary Organizations told its members not to accept contributions from the trust.\n\nThe Presidents Club reported that it had raised more than 20 million pounds ($28 million) over the past 33 years. Last year, it raised \u00a31.6 million and spent nearly \u00a3600,000, leaving a net profit of \u00a31 million (about $1.4 million).\n\nWPP, one of Britain\u2019s largest advertising and public affairs companies, which bought a table for the event this year and in years past, said it was unaware of the conduct described in the article, but that it would not take part in the dinner again.\n\nMr. Meller\u2019s company, the Meller Group, declined to comment on the report. The other chairman of the charitable trust, Bruce Ritchie, is the owner and chief executive of a large real estate firm, Residential Land, which also declined to comment.\n\nThe host of this year\u2019s dinner, the British comedian and writer David Walliams, said on Twitter that he had been there \u201cin a strictly professional capacity and not as a guest,\u201d and that he had left immediately after appearing on stage.\n\n\u201cI did not witness any of the kind of behavior that allegedly occurred and am absolutely appalled by the reports,\u201d he added.\n\nThe Presidents Club said in a statement that \u201cthe organizers are appalled by the allegations of bad behavior at the event asserted by the Financial Times reporters. Such behavior is totally unacceptable. Anyone working at an event should be treated professionally and with respect at all times.\u201d\n\nThe article said that Ms. Dandridge had warned the hostesses that men might get \u201cannoying\u201d and that \u201csome girls hate it.\u201d It also said the women were encouraged to drink and were required to sign a nondisclosure agreement. The more reticent ones were urged to interact more with the men, including being prodded not to spend much time in the restroom.\n\nThe Financial Times reported that one woman said a man had shown her his penis, one said a guest had asked if she was a prostitute, one said a man had suggested she remove her underwear and dance on a table, and others said that men touched them or invited them to rooms upstairs.\n\nIn a BBC interview, the reporter who wrote the article, Madison Marriage, said she had been groped.", "title": "Britain\u2019s \u2018Most Un-P.C.\u2019 Charity Will Shut Down", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Broadway San Diego, a touring production group, announced on Friday that it had cut ties to the actor Ben Vereen, whose name was on an awards program rewarding outstanding local high school performers. The total box-office gross reached $50.3 million, edging out the record set at the end of last year. But attendance was higher the same week last year, with 359,495 theatergoers. Higher ticket prices and the increased use of premium pricing models meant that more money came in last week, despite roughly 50,000 fewer tickets being sold.\n\nNineteen shows hit 100 percent capacity. Ten shows cleared $2 million. In what is now becoming routine, \u201cHamilton\u201d once again broke the box office record it had set just a week before, raking in $3.8 million over eight performances. The show\u2019s average ticket price hit $358.\n\nLongstanding shows popular with tourists did particularly well. The revival of \u201cCats\u201d saved its biggest week for last, pulling in $1.8 million over nine performances (adding an extra show is common for holiday weeks) before closing on Dec. 30. \u201cChicago,\u201d which has been on Broadway for 21 years, had the highest-grossing week in its history, making $1.2 million over nine performances. Donoghue, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York.\n\nMs. Harris, 57, a retired New York City correction officer who was elected in a special election in 2015, was arraigned on Tuesday afternoon before a United States magistrate after prosecutors released a lengthy dissection of her alleged crimes.\n\nIn one scheme, authorities accused Ms. Harris of trying to capitalize on a natural disaster, improperly receiving nearly $25,000 in federal funds by falsely claiming that she had been displaced from her Coney Island home by Hurricane Sandy in 2012.
