To test the waters for a lieutenant governor run, Mr. Williams is planning to travel the state in the coming weeks.\n\nBut there are already strong headwinds. Supporters have yet to rally around his effort. Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council speaker, Corey D. Johnson, have so far declined to offer support, as has the progressive Working Families Party, which backed his early political career. Proxies for Mr. Cuomo, including one of his top advisers, have already launched attacks.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve spoken to him and I\u2019ve told him that I\u2019m not supporting him for the position,\u201d said Charlie King, a former campaign adviser to Mr. Cuomo who twice ran unsuccessfully for lieutenant governor. Mr. King brought up Mr. Williams\u2019s failed bid to become the City Council speaker, a race that officially ended this month.\n\n\u201cI told him, \u2018Look, you\u2019re going to have to address the question: Why should a million Democratic voters, who don\u2019t know you, want you to lead the state, when 50 of your colleagues, who do know you, didn\u2019t want you to lead their conference?\u2019\u201d he said.\n\nYet Mr. Williams\u2019s desire for the state\u2019s No. 2 post appears to already have had an effect. Even as the current lieutenant governor, Kathy Hochul, vows to run for re-election, alternatives have been floated behind the scenes, including the Rochester mayor, Lovely Warren, who like Mr. Williams is black.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m glad the governor is finally understanding the importance of diversity,\u201d Mr. Williams said sardonically. He brushed off the concern that running against Mr. Cuomo\u2019s lieutenant during the governor\u2019s own re-election year would jeopardize his future in politics, and contrasted his own reputation as a vocal and sometimes intransigent advocate for police reform and progressive housing policy with the sorts of positions taken in Albany.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think you can change your beliefs based on a political race. I think you can adjust your tactics, your strategy, but if you don\u2019t have a core, I don\u2019t know what you\u2019re doing,\u201d he said. \u201cOften times I\u2019ve felt from the governor\u2019s mansion that there isn\u2019t a core. There is, \u2018What is best to achieve power?\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAsked for comment, the governor\u2019s office pointed to earlier remarks by a top adviser, Melissa DeRosa, who observed that 2018 is an election year and \u201cpeople are going to run for things for all different reasons.\u201d\n\nGrowing up a first-generation New Yorker whose parents immigrated from Grenada, Mr. Williams, 41, said he longed to be an actor. In theatrical roles, the symptoms of his Tourette\u2019s syndrome \u2014 evident in normal conversation \u2014 would often dissipate completely, he said. But even before graduating from Brooklyn College, he began thinking of politics: He ran for student body president, but narrowly lost, a defeat that stuck with him.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAfter a time on a local community board, as a tenant organizer and as executive director of New York State Tenants and Neighbors, a tenant advocacy group, he ran for what he believed would be an open Council seat in the Flatbush area of central Brooklyn in 2009. But the rules for term limits changed, giving the Democratic incumbent a third term and a shot at re-election. Still, Mr. Williams, who has struggled to raise money, succeeded in a tight six-way race.\n\nIn his first term, Mr. Williams became one of the Council\u2019s most prominent critics of the Police Department\u2019s stop-and-frisk tactics, co-sponsoring legislation with Councilman Brad Lander that created an inspector general for the police and expanded the prohibitions on profiling. The bills passed after midnight on a summer day in 2013, each with enough votes to survive a mayoral veto. Applause greeted their passage.\n\nFor Mr. Williams, it was a signature moment and an example of the lifelong activist who sticks to principle while engaging in one of the most difficult of political tasks: shepherding contentious legislation over the vehement objections of City Hall. In the years since, crime has gone down, not up.\n\n\u201cHe took an unpopular stance because he knew it was right,\u201d said Joo-Hyun Kang, the director of Communities United for Police Reform, an advocacy group that pushed for the legislation.\n\nMore recently, on Jan. 11, Mr. Williams found himself again facing down the police as he and other demonstrators tried to block an ambulance carrying Ravi Ragbir, an immigrant rights leader detained by federal authorities. No stranger to civil disobedience \u2014 which, in activist jargon, he refers to as \u201cC.D.\u201d \u2014 Mr. Williams expressed shock and disappointment at his and others\u2019 harsh arrests. He said he had been \u201cflung\u201d by officers several times.\n\n\u201cThe type of violence that occurred there should not have occurred,\u201d he said. At least 15 complaints have been filed with the city\u2019s Civilian Complaint Review Board over the episode, which Mr. de Blasio has said is under review.\n\nHis longtime friend, the civil rights activist Kirsten John Foy, called Mr. Williams \u201ca fighter\u201d and the \u201cideal vehicle\u201d for expanding the role of lieutenant governor and using it for advocacy. \u201cI think it is something the state needs,\u201d said Mr. Foy, who was detained along with Mr. Williams by the police at the 2011 West Indian American Day Parade.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Mr. Williams\u2019s commitment to principles has caused him political problems, particularly as he has tried to reconcile his personal religious beliefs \u2014 he worships at St. Paul Community Baptist Church \u2014 with liberal Democratic policies on abortion and gay marriage, leaving himself open to attacks that he is too conservative on the issues. Ms. DeRosa, the secretary to Mr. Cuomo, said in a radio interview that what she had read about Mr. Williams\u2019s views \u201ctroubles me tremendously.\u201d\n\n\u201cI support marriage equality and I support a woman\u2019s right to access safe and legal abortions. Period,\u201d he said, tapping the table for emphasis.\n\nBut, he added: \u201cI was honored to see them respond like that. That means that immediately they\u2019re taking my discussion about this seriously.\u201d", "title": "Brooklyn Councilman Took on the Police. Next Up: The Governor.", "authors": ["J. David Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAs he begins his first full term in office, Eric Gonzalez, the Brooklyn district attorney, has formed a committee of more than 50 criminal justice experts, hoping to sustain his predecessor\u2019s legacy of reform by turning his agency \u2014 one of the country\u2019s largest prosecutors\u2019 offices \u2014 into a laboratory for new ideas.\n\nKnown as Justice 2020, the committee will bring together a coalition of pastors, police officials, public defenders, former inmates and social-justice advocates to help shape Mr. Gonzalez\u2019s policies on a diverse array of issues: mass incarceration, wrongful convictions, gender violence, immigration and the use of big data in guiding prosecutions. The committee intends to issue a report by the spring, officials said, and Mr. Gonzalez plans to implement its recommendations in stages over the next two years.\n\n\u201cJustice 2020 is going to be the road map this office is going to follow,\u201d he said on Monday, while speaking to his staff at a private meeting at Long Island University. \u201cIt will give us a blueprint for what the criminal justice system will look like.\u201d\n\nMr. Gonzalez was inaugurated in Williamsburg on Sunday, and in his speech he mentioned the committee, which will take the place of a traditional transition team. Having worked in the office for more than 20 years \u2014 taking over when the last district attorney, Ken Thompson, died in the middle of his term \u2014 Mr. Gonzalez was not expected to significantly shake up his closest circle of aides after his election in November. But the committee will allow him to imprint his own vision on the office he now leads.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat vision \u2014 one that seeks to balance public safety with ensuring fairness to all of Brooklyn\u2019s residents \u2014 has, at times, been questioned by activists and lawyers who have said the office\u2019s progressive policies on bail reform and minor drug arrests have not always lived up to its promises. During his campaign, Mr. Gonzalez was also criticized for not holding his prosecutors accountable when they worked on cases that led to wrongful convictions.", "title": "Brooklyn District Attorney Turns to Experts for Ideas on Reform", "authors": ["Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "As calzones are to the Naples area, panzerotti \u2014 another filled half-moon turnover \u2014 are to Apulia, the heel of Italy. Though panzerotti ooze similar fillings, they are made from a thinner dough than calzones and deep-fried, not baked. Now they\u2019re available in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, at Panzerotti Bites. Vittoria Lattanzio and her husband, Pasquale De Ruvo, who are from Apulia, fry them with a dozen fillings, including mortadella, tomato, roasted vegetables and tuna. Sweet ones are filled with ricotta and Nutella. They are quite light, miraculously greaseless, and if you take them home to serve, they need but five minutes in a 350-degree oven to come back to life. A few with fancy fillings like smoked salmon are folded into a heavier casing: Panzerotti, $7 to $12, Panzerotti Bites, 235 Smith Street (Douglass Street), 347-720-0269, panzerottibites.com.\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Brooklyn Gets a Bite of Panzerotti", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Brooklyn\u2019s real estate market continued its ascent in the fourth quarter of 2017, even as the markets in Manhattan and surrounding areas stumbled, according to recent industry reports.\n\nThe median sales price in Brooklyn rose to $770,000, up 2.7 percent from a year earlier, the third highest price ever recorded in the borough, according to a report from Douglas Elliman. The record was set in the second quarter of 2017, when the median sales price reached $795,000.\n\nJonathan J. Miller, president of the appraisal firm Miller Samuel, which prepared the report, said that while price growth has slowed, tight inventory suggests the upward trend will continue. There were 1,711 homes for sale in the fourth quarter, down 23 percent from the previous year, making it the 10th straight quarter of declining inventory.\n\n\u201cNormally, when you go that low, sales taper off,\u201d Frank Percesepe, who oversees Brooklyn sales for the Corcoran Group, said about buyer tendencies. \u201cBut they\u2019re buying anything they can get their hands on.\u201d", "title": "Brooklyn Real Estate Prices Climb Higher", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "When they married, Ms. Blichfeld, now 39, was a network casting director for \u201c30 Rock\u201d and other shows, while Mr. Sinclair was a struggling actor getting cast as \u201chomeless man\u201d and \u201cwild-eyed guy,\u201d freelance editing and making attention-seeking videos, including one in which he dances naked through the city to electro-pop. They created \u201cHigh Maintenance\u201d in part to showcase his intelligent, funny, charming side. Soon they became a poster couple for successful work-life partnerships.\n\nIt wasn\u2019t clear if that relationship, or the critically beloved show, could survive their uncoupling.\n\n\u201cIf we were not contractually obligated for Season 2, I do wonder what our creative or personal life would be,\u201d said Ms. Blichfeld, who has since come out as lesbian and is dating a woman. \u201cI\u2019m sort of impressed that we were able to work together this year.\u201d\n\nIn what Mr. Sinclair likened to \u201cexposure therapy,\u201d they worked side by side after their breakup for up to 15 hours a day, almost every day, for months, writing, shooting and editing the new season. He was also adjusting to the increased workload, responsibilities and stakes of an HBO series. \u201cThis year was, like, Season 2 of our show and the Trump administration and our breaking up and giving each other space while still working together,\u201d Mr. Sinclair said. \u201cIt was intense.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThus, the R.V.\n\nAn Almost Midlife Crisis\n\nMaking a wide turn onto Atlantic Avenue, cuing up a music podcast called \u201cChances With Wolves\u201d and heading for the expressway, Mr. Sinclair said he was at loose ends in other ways. The day before, his landlord had informed him that he had to vacate the apartment he once shared with Ms. Blichfeld. The building was being sold.\n\n\u201cThat apartment is the last part of my relationship with Katja,\u201d he said with a hint of melancholy. But seeking to put a positive spin on his eviction, he added: \u201cI\u2019m welcoming the forced change. My luck has been impeccable. If I take anything from my life, it\u2019s that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHigh Maintenance\u201d has benefited from lucky timing, too. It debuted as a Vimeo web series the same month that Washington State and Colorado passed measures to legalize marijuana for recreational use, when every media outlet was doing think pieces about changing attitudes toward pot. America was ready for a kindhearted weed dealer.\n\nBut it also resonated because of the writing, which has the subtlety and surprise of great fiction, and because it refuses to mine stoner culture for cheap laughs of the \u201cUp in Smoke\u201d variety. The Guy\u2019s clients run the human spectrum: an agoraphobe starved for connection; a woman fighting cancer; bougie married swingers; a father retired from corporate life living below his high-strung daughter \u2014 all of them turning to pot in anxious times to \u201cfind equilibrium,\u201d as a New Yorker review put it.\n\nWhat\u2019s more, every episode is chock-full of Tom Wolfe-ian status details recognizable to anyone living in modern Brooklyn or places like it. The Elena Ferrante book that shows up in three different apartments; the vintage film cameras on a hipster bachelor\u2019s shelf; the precious baby names like Persimmon; the references to intersectionality and illegal Airbnbs. The mellow way these cultural signifiers are treated, however, results not in an acid satire of progressive boho urbanites, but in an affectionate sendup.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn real life, Mr. Sinclair will utter a statement like \u201cMy ayahuasca shaman says New York shrinks your aura,\u201d and then, as the show would, do a little eye roll to acknowledge the absurdity.\n\nGiven all the emotional turmoil in his personal life, Mr. Sinclair said it was hard this past year to keep the light tone and \u201cnot to put some of that bummer feeling on my character.\u201d\n\nBut, he said, \u201cpeople didn\u2019t want to see The Guy in pain.\u201d\n\nTo do so would both upset the central conceit of \u201cHigh Maintenance,\u201d which has always focused on the lives of the clients \u2014 not the dealer \u2014 and puncture a fantasy. The Guy spends his days cruising around on his bike, having aimless conversations, toking on the job. He doesn\u2019t appear to have problems, only to soothe the problems of others, with his case of goodies and friendly, nonjudgmental patter.\n\nFor viewers living in brutally competitive, increasingly unaffordable, class-stratified New York (or Los Angeles, or San Francisco, or wherever), a throwback slacker offers escapist joy.\n\nWhich is why it came as a shock when The Guy got robbed and locked out of his apartment in the Season 1 finale, and, intruding on the woman with whom his ex-wife is now living, chucked his phone in frustration over his bad night. Whoa. The Guy has an ex-wife? Someone in his life not thrilled to see him? Angry outbursts?\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Blichfeld said she later heard from fans who were surprised. They told her, \u201c\u2018It was such a different representation of The Guy. I don\u2019t know how I feel about seeing him break down.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Sinclair said that the realities of being a 35-year-old, low-level weed dealer are catching up with his character. He thinks the show has \u201cearned a little window into his life,\u201d which the new season offers, along with story lines about breakups and changed relationship dynamics that echo the creators\u2019 lives.\n\n\u2018Me at My Best\u2019\n\nMr. Sinclair is so naturalistic in his acting that many people assume he is playing a version of himself, or that he is The Guy. Charlie Gruet, a cinematographer on the show since its web days, recalled being on set one day when a bike messenger spotted Mr. Sinclair and yelled, \u201cI\u2019m doing what you\u2019re doing\u201d \u2014 though it wasn\u2019t clear if he meant delivering weed.\n\n\u201cBen has that quality where you just want to hang out with him,\u201d Mr. Gruet said. \u201cThe Guy has that similar quality.\u201d\n\nMr. Sinclair is likewise rough around the edges in his personal grooming, though driving the R.V. he looked stylishly rumpled in a green sweater and millennial-pink pants. And he belongs to the same liberal, diverse, woke milieu as the show\u2019s characters. He attended Oberlin College, claims to have had his life changed at Burning Man and says he is trying to check his power and white privilege.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut where The Guy is a chill cipher who doesn\u2019t say much, Mr. Sinclair is talkative and disclosing, even intensely intimate. Five minutes after meeting, he said that he\u2019s reading a book called \u201cBoundaries and Relationships\u201d because \u201cthat\u2019s been an issue in my life.\u201d Then he underscored the point by oversharing that he\u2019s seeing a therapist but trying not to sabotage the process with his authority issues.\n\n\u201cHe is me at my best,\u201d Mr. Sinclair said of The Guy, adding that, like the character, \u201cI\u2019m able to achieve a feeling of intimacy with someone quickly. It\u2019s been my blessing and curse.\u201d\n\nSomething else he and The Guy have in common: They both own a \u201977 Travco.\n\nMr. Sinclair wound up with the R.V. because he saw a moon lamp made of fiberglass, and then became fascinated by fiberglass as a building material, and then while researching on the web came across the fiberglass-bodied R.V. How The Guy ends up with it on \u201cHigh Maintenance\u201d is for now a secret, although one assumes the story will also follow a meandering, pot-head logic.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was not surprised one bit when he showed me a photo of this R.V. and said he was buying it,\u201d Ms. Blichfeld said. \u201cBen has a flair for drama. He likes big gestures.\u201d\n\nShe added, \u201cHad we been together, I don\u2019t know if that would\u2019ve happened. I\u2019m the one who would have been asking for inspections and things and projecting all the ways the R.V. would complicate our life.\u201d\n\nThe motor home, like a fiberglass boat, bobbed and weaved and rocked up the Taconic State Parkway for three hours all the way to Germantown. But Mr. Sinclair looked content behind the wheel. When part of the roof blew off beside a farm on a back road a few miles from the destination, he pulled over, tossed the shards into the back and rolled on. He even arrived at his buddy\u2019s house in time to roll the joint.\n\nIn a few days, Mr. Sinclair was scheduled to leave for a monthlong solo trip to Indonesia, to go scuba diving in Bali and Raja Ampat. When he returned, it would be to a new season of his show, a new apartment, a new New York. He was excited about the trip but also nervous, he said, because he doesn\u2019t like to be alone.\n\nHe thought out loud: \u201cIs it worth being alone for the sake of being alone because you think you should be alone, or to find solitude just because it\u2019s good for you? Or if you like being around people and that\u2019s just what you like, maybe that\u2019s O.K., too?\u201d\n\nSounding like one of the endearingly searching New Yorkers who call upon The Guy, Mr. Sinclair said, \u201cI\u2019m trying to answer those questions for myself.\u201d", "title": "Brooklyn\u2019s Favorite Pot Dealer Returns", "authors": ["Steven Kurutz"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Teddy Roosevelt wore Brooks Brothers to his inauguration. So, too, did Woodrow Wilson, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Ulysses S. Grant. Forty of the 45 United States presidents have patronized America\u2019s oldest maker of men\u2019s wear, the most famous among them surely Abraham Lincoln, who was dressed in a custom-made Brooks Brothers wool coat for his inauguration in 1865 to a second presidential term.\n\nDouble-breasted with trim tape outlining hem, lapel and a small ticket pocket, that coat had a lightly padded lining that was embroidered with an eagle motif and a motto. Had history played out differently, we would have little cause to remember what seems like a singularly Lincoln-esque detail about this simple garment: \u201cOne Country, One Destiny\u201d stitched inside, to be worn against his narrow frame and known only to a few besides Lincoln\u2019s tailor and the Great Emancipator himself. But, of course, it was that same Brooks Brothers coat that Lincoln selected one month later for an outing to Ford\u2019s Theater, where he was assassinated by John Wilkes Booth.\n\nHere, amid the splendor of a gallery inside the Palazzo Vecchio, a replica of Lincoln\u2019s coat hangs in a small vitrine, part of a modest exhibition culled from the Brooks Brothers extensive archive and brought to Florence to kick off a yearlong celebration of the brand\u2019s 200th anniversary.", "title": "Brooks Brothers Celebrates 200 Years With a Party \u2014 in Florence", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "I cannot say I share the taste for these I.P.A.s, which, with their emphasis on the imperious flavors of American hops, are the equivalent of oaky California chardonnays of the 1990s.\n\nBrown ales and like-minded styles \u2014 including straightforward lagers, pilsners and porters \u2014 to name a few, are very different sorts of beers. They occupy subtler realms, quenching thirst with pure flavors and perhaps a snappy zestiness in the case of pilsner and a rich depth in the case of porter. They are not flamboyant styles that wow with complexity or make themselves the centers of attention. They simply satisfy.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the kind of beer that gets left behind in our I.P.A. culture,\u201d Orr said.\n\nClay had a more charitable explanation. \u201cIn the \u201990s, everybody made brown ales or porters,\u201d he said. \u201cIt makes sense that a new generation would want to do something different.\u201d\n\nIn the 1970s and \u201980s, early craft brewers were motivated by what seemed lost. Back then, American beer culture was dominated by the insipid lagers of the big brewers. Dozens of classic styles, developed over centuries of brewing, had largely been abandoned. Porters, amber ales, India pale ales, brown ales \u2014 English styles mostly \u2014 had been read about more than tasted.\n\nInspired by England\u2019s Campaign for Real Ale movement, many American craft brewers set about resurrecting these styles first. Their success, coupled with similar efforts in other countries, encouraged further experimentation, with German and Belgian styles and beyond, as well as a fair amount of creative boundary-pushing.\n\nSome of the results were augmented styles, in which characteristics were exaggerated, sometimes to good effect, but often beyond balance. Hoppy I.P.A.s, for example, became double or even triple I.P.A.s.\n\nOver time, the trend toward amplification spawned a counter-movement promoting session beers, brews that toned down the volume and alcohol without sacrificing flavor. American brown ales, which tend mostly to be in the range of 5 to 6 percent alcohol, do not quite fit the definition of session beers, which typically are around 4 percent. They also have more discernible hop flavors than their classic English counterpart, and occasionally are brewed with additions like nuts or seeds. But brown ales are relaxed and easygoing, pure and pleasing, with flavors that are subtle rather than flamboyant.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOur favorites in the tasting all leaned toward the textbook style: malty, with flavors of chocolate, coffee or, sometimes, dried fruit. Mostly these brown ales were dry and nutty, although sometimes they left an impression of sweetness \u2014 Clay found that some had a surprising flavor of strawberry candy.\n\nWe also noted a few examples of experimentation, some more successful than others. Dogfish Head\u2019s Indian Brown Ale, as its name indicates, combines the characteristics of brown ale with those of an I.P.A., quite successfully in our opinion. It was fuller bodied with more alcohol and hoppy bitterness than in a classic brown ale, but it also had discernible malt and chocolate flavors. Over all, it was well integrated enough to be No. 5 among our favorites.\n\nOther similar efforts were so dominated by hops that we had no clue to the style of the beer in the glass.\n\nNow, I should point out that beer tastings, particularly with styles like brown ale, have gotten complicated for us. For these blind tastings, we include only beers that we have purchased from retail outlets.\n\nSome craft beers are distributed nationally, but many of the best are available only in various local markets. In previous years, we could order beers from different parts of the country. But a recent crackdown on interstate shipping of wine applies to beer as well. So for this tasting, we were restricted to those American brown ales that were available in the New York market.\n\nEven so, our No. 1 beer was the Humboldt Brown Hemp Ale, from Arcata, Calif., which was brewed with hemp seeds. The hemp supposedly adds an herbal component, but for us the beer seemed quite classic, dry with a creamy texture and flavors of malt, chocolate and dried fruits.\n\nNo. 2 was Brooklyn Brown Ale, brewed in Utica, N.Y., which had pure, grainy flavors, while No. 3, Bell\u2019s Best Brown Ale from Comstock, Mich., was balanced and subtle. Black Hog\u2019s Granola Brown Ale, from Oxford, Conn., No. 4 on our list, was actually brewed with granola. It was slightly tart, with a tobacco flavor and a refreshing bitterness that prompts the next sip.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOthers worth mentioning in the tasting include the rich and creamy Maduro Brown Ale from Cigar City in Tampa, Fla., which was brewed with oatmeal, and the smoky, textured Georgia Brown from SweetWater in Atlanta.\n\nWe also had three outliers at the bottom of our top 10, including the Nut Brown Lager from Kelso in Brooklyn \u2014 which as a lager rather than an ale really did not fit the category \u2014 but we liked its malty, cola flavors; the Durty Mud Season Hoppy Brown Ale from Smuttynose in Hampton, N.H., which was full-bodied and strong at 8.4 percent alcohol but balanced and delicious despite its assertiveness; and the Hazelnut Brown Nectar from Rogue in Newport, Ore., which was on the edge of sweetness, with flavors of buttercrunch candy and hazelnuts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAware that our choice was limited and that our tasting was more of a local cross-section than a complete look, Orr mentioned three beers that he wished had been in our tasting: Boffo Brown Ale from Dark Horse in Marshall, Mich., Brown Ale from Newburgh in Newburgh, N.Y., and Brown Ale from Duck-Rabbit in Farmville, N.C.\n\nWe all found the tasting stimulating, even if the style supposedly does not inspire much excitement among beer nerds. Well-made, subtly delicious and refreshing are high accolades, as far as I am concerned, and brown ale fits that bill. Fortunately, many brewers still seem to feel the same way.\n\nTasting Notes\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605\u00bd HUMBOLDT BROWN ALE BREWED WITH HEMP SEEDS ARCATA, CALIF., 5.7 PERCENT ($1.75, 12 ounces)\n\nDry, creamy and well balanced with lingering flavors of malt, chocolate and dried fruits.\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605 BROOKLYN BROWN ALE UTICA, N.Y., 5.6 PERCENT ($2, 12 ounces)\n\nRelaxed and pure with flavors of grain, coffee and chocolate.\n\n\u2605\u2605\u2605 BELL\u2019S BEST BROWN ALE COMSTOCK, MICH., 5.8 PERCENT ($2.25, 12 ounces)\n\nBalanced, subtle and easy to drink, with flavors of coffee and chocolate.\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd BLACK HOG GRANOLA BROWN ALE OXFORD, CONN., 5.7 PERCENT ($3, 12 ounces)\n\nSlightly tart, with flavors of coffee and tobacco, and a bitterness that lingers pleasantly.\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd DOGFISH HEAD INDIAN BROWN ALE WILMINGTON, DEL., 7.2 PERCENT ($2.50, 12 ounces)\n\nFull-bodied and rich, with flavors of chocolate and malt, well-integrated hop bitterness and a touch of heat.\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd CIGAR CITY MADURO BROWN ALE TAMPA, FLA., 5.5 PERCENT ($2, 12 ounces)\n\nRich, creamy aromas, with flavors of chocolate, toffee and grain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2605\u2605\u00bd SWEETWATER GEORGIA BROWN, ATLANTA, 5.8 PERCENT ($2.25, 12 ounces)\n\nRich and thickly textured, with smoky flavors of chocolate and grain.\n\n\u2605\u2605 KELSO NUT BROWN LAGER BROOKLYN, N.Y., 5.75 PERCENT ($2.50, 12 ounces)\n\nWell balanced, with flavors of malt, cola and dried fruits.\n\n\u2605\u2605 SMUTTYNOSE DURTY MUD SEASON HOPPY BROWN ALE, HAMPTON, N.H., 8.4 PERCENT ($2, 12 ounces)\n\nStrong and full-bodied, with flavors of malt, dried fruits and sourdough bread.\n\n\u2605\u2605 ROGUE HAZELNUT BROWN NECTAR, NEWPORT, ORE., 5.6 PERCENT ($2.50, 12 ounces)\n\nNot quite sweet, but on the edge, with flavors of buttercrunch, spice cake and hazelnuts.\n\nWHAT THE STARS MEAN Ratings, up to four stars, reflect the panel\u2019s reaction to the beers, which were tasted with names concealed. The beers represent a selection generally available in good retail shops and restaurants and on the internet. Prices are those paid in the New York region. Tasting coordinator: Bernard Kirsch.\n\nRecipe Pairing: No-Smoker Pastrami\n\nA few months ago an intriguing recipe landed among my emails: pastrami made at home without a smoker. It came from La Bo\u00eete, a spice emporium in Hell\u2019s Kitchen. The tasting of straightforward, eminently quaffable brown ales provided an opportunity to try my hand at pastrami. The recipe, which takes almost a week, mostly unattended, turned out extremely well. The essential ingredients are smoked salt and Prague powder (the curing salt sodium nitrite). Both are sold online. With the beer along for the ride, the result \u2014 reheated and served with warm sauerkraut, or sliced on rye with mustard and sauerkraut \u2014 made for superb cold-weather feasting. Keep the pastrami in mind as you plan for the Super Bowl. FLORENCE FABRICANT\n\nFollow NYT Food on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.", "title": "Brown Ales May Be Unfashionable, but the Style Is Timeless", "authors": ["Eric Asimov", "Florence Fabricant"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The price was $750,000, with maintenance in the $1,100s. The couple planned to make an offer, but on a subsequent visit they noticed a buzz coming from the bathroom vents. \u201cIt was like being on a prop plane,\u201d Mr. Trabucco-Campos said.\n\nThe problem seemed to be the rooftop fans, but while the management company brought in engineers and maintenance workers to fix it, the buzz persisted. The couple decided to move on, and the apartment later sold for the asking price.\n\nSoon after, though, another apartment in the same line, with an identical floor plan, came on the market.\n\nThis one, listed at $715,000, was on a lower floor and in especially bad condition. Each room was painted a different bright color, and Ms. Bondy declared it \u201ca disaster zone.\u201d But it had the same open view and no buzz.\n\nExcited to renovate, the couple bought it for $710,000 in midsummer, and then moved in with Ms. Chock-Goldman\u2019s parents in Westchester for six months.\n\n\u201cIt was unrealistic for us to continue paying rent and renovate an apartment,\u201d Ms. Chock-Goldman said. They commuted to work by train, often rising before dawn to meet the contractor at 7 a.m.\n\nIn December, they moved in. Since then, Ms. Chock-Goldman said she has been noticing small flaws, \u201cthings I didn\u2019t think about before,\u201d like the awkward placement of a toilet-paper holder in one bathroom and a power outlet on the kitchen island.", "title": "Brownstone Charm on a Budget", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nBruce T. Halle, who founded Discount Tire in Michigan with an inventory of only six tires in 1960 and built it into the largest independent tire dealer in North America, died on Thursday. He was 87.\n\nOfficials at company headquarters, in Scottsdale, Ariz., announced the death but did not specify the cause or say where he died.\n\nMr. Halle, Discount Tire\u2019s chairman, had been ranked by Forbes magazine as the richest person in Arizona for several years. According to the magazine, his net worth is more than $5 billion.\n\nBorn in Springfield, Mass., on May 27, 1930, Mr. Halle started his first tire store in Ann Arbor, Mich., four years after he graduated from Eastern Michigan University with a degree in business administration.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe rented an old plumbing supply building, built countertops, repainted the sign outside and was the store\u2019s only employee, serving as tire technician, cleaning crew, salesman and accountant.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was three days before Mr. Halle had his first customer and a week before he made a sale. His original inventory consisted of two new tires and four retreads.", "title": "Bruce Halle, Founder of Discount Tire, Is Dead at 87", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Multiple Grammys for \u201824K Magic.\u2019\n\nMr. Mars, who has earned the respect of the industry as an all-around entertainer, capable of repeatedly scaling the pop charts and entertaining the nation at the Super Bowl, won album of the year for \u201c24K Magic,\u201d as well as record of the year for the title track and song of the year \u2014 a songwriters\u2019 award \u2014 for \u201cThat\u2019s What I Like.\u201d (His album also claimed an engineering prize.)\n\nSong of the year went to Mr. Mars and the seven other writers of \u201cThat\u2019s What I Like,\u201d a slice of 1980s-throwback funk. Accepting the award, Mr. Mars was surrounded by what looked like an entourage, but they were the credited writers of the song, reflecting the new production model of pop music in which huge teams of specialized writers collaborate.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been knowing these guys for over a decade,\u201d Mr. Mars said. \u201cAll the music-business horror stories you\u2019ve seen in the movies, we\u2019ve been through all of them.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an honor to share this with you all tonight,\u201d he told them.\n\nIn addition to Mr. Mars, they were Christopher Brody Brown, James Fauntleroy, Philip Lawrence, and the quartet known as the Stereotypes: Ray Charles McCullough II, Jeremy Reeves, Ray Romulus and Jonathan Yip.\n\nVideo\n\nKesha and a #MeToo moment.\n\nIn the days leading up the awards, the Grammys faced questions how the show \u2014 and the music industry at large \u2014 would respond to the #MeToo movement and the show of solidarity at the Golden Globes this month, when the women of Hollywood, wearing black, presented a united front.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a forceful speech, Ms. Mon\u00e1e spoke for the women of the music industry, calling for a unified response of the women in music against sexism and sexual harassment, saying, \u201cWe come in peace but we mean business.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nThen Kesha sang \u201cPraying,\u201d her ballad of anger and redemption, surrounded by women all in white, including the singers Cyndi Lauper, Camila Cabello, Julia Michaels and Andra Day and the Resistance Revival Chorus, a collective of women who sing protest songs. Kesha became pop\u2019s symbol of the fight against sexual assault when, in a 2014 lawsuit, she accused her producer, Dr. Luke, of inflicting years of abuse. (Dr. Luke, whose real name is Lukasz Gottwald, in turn accused Kesha of fabricating the story in an attempt to escape her recording contracts.)\n\nHer voice breaking, Kesha sang \u201cYou brought the flames and you put me through hell,\u201d and \u201cWhen I\u2019m finished, they won\u2019t even know your name.\u201d\n\nAs she finished, she held back tears and the choir gathered around her in a group embrace.\n\nImmediately afterward, Ms. Cabello, a young Cuban-Amerian singer who had been part of Kesha\u2019s performance, introduced a segment highlighting immigration, with the cameras turning to a view of the Statue of Liberty and Emma Lazarus\u2019s poem \u201cThe New Colossus\u201d (\u201cGive me your tired, your poor/Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free\u201d). Then U2 performed its song \u201cGet Out of Your Own Way\u201d on a barge in New York harbor. (The performance had been taped two nights before.)\n\nPhoto\n\nA striking opening.\n\n[ Never miss a pop music story: Sign up for our weekly newsletter, Louder. ]\n\nThe 60th annual Grammy Awards opened with a striking conceptual performance by Kendrick Lamar and by Bono and the Edge of U2, with Dave Chappelle serving as a one-man Greek chorus. It walked a fine line between confrontational political commentary and grounding comedy.\n\nMr. Lamar began surrounded by phalanxes of soldiers in camouflage fatigues as he began his song \u201cXXX\u201d with images of the American flag waving behind him on digital screens. After the words \u201cThis is a satire by Kendrick Lamar\u201d flashed behind him, and a brief appearance by Bono and the Edge, the camera cut to Mr. Chappelle, who said: \u201cThe only thing more frightening than watching a black man be honest in America is being an honest black man in America.\u201d\n\nThe show then alternated again between Mr. Lamar and Mr. Chappelle, before ending with Mr. Lamar standing among men in red hoodies who were gunned down one by one.\n\nPhoto\n\nLady Gaga then took the stage to sing her ballads \u201cJoanne\u201d and \u201cMillion Reasons\u201d at a white piano draped with the wings of a bird or an angel. \u201cTime\u2019s up,\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Lamar next won the first prize of the night, for best rap/sung performance, for \u201cLOYALTY.,\u201d featuring Rihanna, who told him: \u201cCongrats. You deserve this, man.\u201d\n\nAccepting the award for best rap album for \u201cDAMN.,\u201d Mr. Lamar delivered a paean to hip-hop itself, which, he said, had \u201cshowed me the true definition of what an artist was.\u201d\n\n\u201cFrom the jump I thought it was about the accolades, and the cars and the clothes,\u201d Mr. Lamar said. \u201cBut it\u2019s really about expressing yourself, putting that paint on the canvas for the world to evolve for the next listener, the next generation after that.\u201d\n\nThen he paid tribute to his artistic heroes, including Jay-Z, Nas and Puff Daddy, and added, as the ultimate obeisance: \u201cJay for president.\u201d\n\nThere were other notable performances. Dressed in a glowing white suit, Childish Gambino \u2014 the musical persona of Donald Glover, who has won Golden Globes and Emmys as an actor \u2014 performed \u201cTerrified\u201d as a slithery erotic fantasy fully of falsetto and a gentle funk groove. Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee played their monster Latin pop hit \u201cDespacito,\u201d surrounded by grinding couples, the women in ultrashort shorts or nude-colored showgirl get-ups.\n\nRihanna sang \u201cWild Thoughts\u201d with Bryson Tiller and DJ Khaled, fully in character as a big-voiced hype man. Elton John played his \u201cTiny Dancer\u201d with Miley Cyrus. And Sting, strangely ubiquitous in the show, played his 1987 song \u201cEnglishman in New York\u201d as a Police-style smooth groove.\n\nPhoto\n\nAlessia Cara wins best new artist.\n\nAlessia Cara, a 21-year-old Canadian pop singer who has songs of empowerment like \u201cScars to Your Beautiful,\u201d took home one of the ceremony\u2019s big four awards. After the microphone was lowered reach her, Ms. Cara said: \u201cHoly cow, I\u2019m shaking. I\u2019ve been pretend-winning Grammys since I was a kid, like in my shower.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAll but nine of the 84 awards were given out at a nontelevised ceremony in the afternoon.\n\nDuring the preshow ceremony, Mr. Lamar won best rap performance, best rap song and best music video, all for \u201cHUMBLE.\u201d Mr. Mars won best R&B performance and R&B song for \u201cThat\u2019s What I Like,\u201d and best R&B album for \u201c24K Magic.\u201d\n\nDespite 21 past wins, Jay-Z has never taken home a Grammy in the top categories, and that did not change at Sunday\u2019s ceremony. The rapper, who was feted as an \u201cindustry icon\u201d at Clive Davis\u2019s glittery annual pre-Grammy party, was shut out.\n\nEd Sheeran, who was snubbed in the top categories, was awarded best pop vocal album, in absentia, for \u201c\u00f7,\u201d one of last year\u2019s biggest hits. He also won best pop solo performance for \u201cShape of You.\u201d Childish Gambino won best traditional R&B performance for his song \u201cRedbone,\u201d a 1970s funk throwback that was a surprise hit at radio last year.\n\nThe country singer-songwriter Chris Stapleton won two awards in the preshow ceremony: best country solo performance for \u201cEither Way,\u201d and best country song for \u201cBroken Halos,\u201d which Mr. Stapleton wrote with Mike Henderson.\n\nJason Isbell also won two: best Americana album, for \u201cThe Nashville Sound,\u201d and best American roots song, for \u201cIf We Were Vampires.\u201d Carrie Fisher won a posthumous Grammy \u2014 her first \u2014 in the best spoken word album category, for \u201cThe Princess Diarist.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nChris Stapleton wins and victims of violence are honored\n\nAfter Mr. Stapleton won best country album for \u201cFrom A Room: Volume 1,\u201d the country singers Eric Church, Maren Morris and the Brothers Osborne offered a tribute to the victims of violence at music events.\n\nMs. Morris began the introduction drawing a connection between the bombing in Manchester, England, last May and the shooting at a country music festival in Las Vegas in October.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAll country music was reminded in the most tragic way,\u201d Mr. Church said, the connection we share with our fans and the healing power of music will always provide.\u201d\n\nAs they played a quiet and stripped-down version of Eric Clapton\u2019s \u201cTears in Heaven,\u201d the names of individual victims were displayed on glowing panels behind them, as if electronic votive candles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA night of questions new and old.\n\nThe Grammys, like most awards shows, have been wrestling for years with issues of diversity: ethnic, gender and, in the Grammys\u2019 case, musical. Not so long ago, the show drew eye rolls for over-rewarding elder heroes at the expense of pop\u2019s younger, more vital mainstream. (Think Ray Charles beating Green Day and Kanye West in 2005, or Herbie Hancock defeating Amy Winehouse and, ahem, Mr. West in 2008.)\n\nThe Grammys have generally gotten much better at recognizing the pulse of contemporary music. A diverse crop of nominees this year made it likely that the winners of the four most prestigious categories \u2014 album, record and song of the year, and best new artist \u2014 would not be white men.\n\nAt the same time, gender remained very much still an issue. Lorde was the only woman up for album of the year; she did not perform at the ceremony. Julia Michaels and Ms. Cara have credits in the song of the year category (which recognizes songwriters). Otherwise, the top nominees were predominantly male. As a new report indicated, gender diversity at the Grammys \u2014 and in the music industry at large \u2014 has been abysmal.\n\nVideo\n\nThe white roses.\n\nAs the Grammys approached, it became clear that aside from the performance by Kesha, the industry had no organized response to the #MeToo movement planned along the lines of the Time\u2019s Up campaign that was front and center at the recent Golden Globes.\n\nThat changed just days ago, when a small group of midlevel female music executives called for artists to wear a white rose to the show, as a sign of \u201chope, peace, sympathy and resistance.\u201d By Thursday, a handful of stars including Lady Gaga and Kelly Clarkson had pledged their support. On Sunday, the group circulated a list of music-industry professionals and artists who had signed on to the effort, adding Pink, Dua Lipa and Lil Uzi Vert, among others.\n\nAt the preshow ceremony, several artists wore white roses, although their comments about it were muted. Reba McEntire, the country star, was asked about the white rose on her dress after she won best roots gospel album for \u201cSing It Now: Songs of Faith & Hope.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy message is, I want to treat you like I want to be treated,\u201d Ms. McEntire said. \u201cIt\u2019s the golden rule. I think if we did that more often, a lot of these problems would be nonexistent. Let\u2019s just treat people kindly.\u201d\n\nLisa Loeb, who won best children\u2019s album, said, only half in jest: \u201cI know some people are saying the music industry took a little while to catch up with some of the other industries. But we haven\u2019t had as many awards ceremonies.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA preshow controversy.\n\nHours before the show began, it already had a Trump controversy. On Saturday night, CNN aired an interview with Jay-Z as part of the inaugural episode of \u201cThe Van Jones Show,\u201d in which Jay-Z commented on the president\u2019s reported denigration of Haiti and African countries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt is disappointing and it\u2019s hurtful,\u201d Jay-Z said. \u201cBecause it\u2019s looking down at a whole population of people and it\u2019s so misinformed because these places have beautiful people and beautiful everything. This is the leader of the free world speaking like this.\u201d\n\nBy 8:18 a.m. Sunday, the president fired off his response on Twitter.\n\nA little more than an hour later, Mr. Jones \u2014 who is managed by Jay-Z\u2019s company, Roc Nation \u2014 wrote on Twitter in response, noting that he did ask Jay-Z about the president\u2019s record on reducing black unemployment, and Jay-Z responded that the issue was about treating people with respect and not, as he put it: \u201cTreat me really bad and pay me well.\u201d\n\nSome of the stars at the preshow ceremony seized the opportunity to make political or personal statements.\n\nResidente, a Puerto Rican rapper who founded the influential group Calle 13, won best Latin rock album (for \u201cResidente\u201d). Dedicating his prize \u201cto my country, Puerto Rico,\u201d he spoke about the need to seek out reliable sources of news about the island.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s happening in Puerto Rico is horrible,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019ve been without electricity for six months now. Some people are dying because they are not eating well. All of that, I had it in my heart when I won this a moment ago.\u201d\n\nC\u00e9cile McLorin Salvant, a Haitian-American singer who won best jazz vocal album, addressed President Trump\u2019s comments about Haiti and Africa. \u201cAt some points you have to either laugh or cry,\u201d she said. \u201cI choose to laugh.\u201d\n\nThe political material was also played for laughs. In one segment, Mr. Corden had celebrities audition for the job of reading the audiobook of Michael Wolff\u2019s \u201cFire & Fury,\u201d the much talked about look inside the Trump White House. John Legend, Cher, Snoop Dogg and Cardi B \u2014 a Bronx-born former stripper who has instantly become one of the music industry\u2019s most beloved figures \u2014 all incredulously read excerpts aloud. The winning reader turned out to be Hillary Clinton.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bit drew laughs throughout the arena, but not everyone was pleased.\n\n\u201cI have always loved the Grammys but to have artists read the Fire and Fury book killed it,\u201d Nikki Haley, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, wrote on Twitter. \u201cDon\u2019t ruin great music with trash. Some of us love music without the politics thrown in it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPaying tribute to stars.\n\nFor a year that saw the losses of Chuck Berry, Fats Domino, Tom Petty, Chris Cornell, Chester Bennington of Linkin Park, Malcolm Young of AC/DC and Walter Becker of Steely Dan, there were several tributes.\n\nAfter the annual \u201cin memoriam\u201d montage, the rapper Logic, in a hoodie with \u201cYou are not alone\u201d on the back, performed his \u201c1-800-273-8255,\u201d whose title is the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. As on the recording, he was joined by Ms. Cara and Khalid.\n\nSome also happened out of sight of the cameras. After a 40th anniversary edition of the Voyager Golden Record \u2014 the gold discs sent into space containing the sounds of the earth, including Chuck Berry\u2019s \u201cJohnny B. Goode\u201d \u2014 won best box set package, Lawrence Azerrad, one of the album\u2019s art directors, commented on the everlasting life of Berry\u2019s music.\n\n\u201cLong after the earth is gone, swallowed up by the sun,\u201d he said, \u201cChuck Berry\u2019s record will still be floating in space.\u201d\n\nAbsent from the stage.\n\nWhile many stars will pack the stage, the Grammys were also notable for who wasn\u2019t there. Besides Mr. Sheeran, neither Taylor Swift nor Justin Bieber were in attendance.\n\nJay-Z and Lorde were in the audience but did not perform.\n\nScheduling, limitations of time and space, and the whims of performers and producers may well account for many of these absences. But in recent years, the Grammys have also faced boycotts from some artists who feel that not enough of the top prizes go to black artists. Frank Ocean stated that in regards to last year\u2019s show.\n\nAnd while Drake has said that the reason he is not performing is that the Grammys asked him to cancel one of his own shows to appear, he also did not submit his latest \u201cplaylist\u201d album, \u201cMore Life,\u201d for award consideration.\n\nPhoto\n\nNew York, New York.\n\nThe Grammys were being held in New York for the first time since 2003, when the city was still struggling to attract business and tourism after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The New York mayor\u2019s office lobbied hard to bring the awards back.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut aside from a handful of segments with heavy-handed New York themes, the broadcast seemed little different from its recent ones at the Staples Center in Los Angeles. In one, James Corden, the host, brought Sting and the reggae singer Shaggy into the subway for a vaudevillian version of Mr. Corden\u2019s \u201cCarpool Karaoke,\u201d with tough New Yorkers telling the three men to shut up or, after taking out earbuds, waving them away with \u201cSorry, I don\u2019t have any cash on me.\u201d\n\nBruno Mars and Cardi B sang Mr. Mars\u2019s \u201cFinesse\u201d as a costumed nod to 1980s hip-hop, with b-boy outfits and moves that seemed pulled from the Rosie Perez book of choreography.\n\nLater in the show was a reverent tribute to the musical traditions of Broadway, with Ben Platt from \u201cDear Evan Hansen\u201d singing Leonard Bernstein\u2019s \u201cSomewhere\u201d from \u201cWest Side Story,\u201d accompanied on a dark platform by cello and acoustic guitar, his voice filling Madison Square Garden at the song\u2019s climax. (Earlier in the day, \u201cDear Evan Hansen\u201d won best musical theater album.)\n\nAnd Patti LuPone, backed up by an orchestra and with a full set behind her, sang \u201cDon\u2019t Cry for Me Argentina\u201d from \u201cEvita,\u201d a reprise of her performance from the Grammys in 1981, when that show won best cast show album.", "title": "Bruno Mars Sweeps Top Prizes at the 2018 Grammy Awards", "authors": ["Ben Sisario"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "With all its flaws, \u201cto that extent the European Union is the world\u2019s avant-garde, the world\u2019s future,\u201d while the United States, especially under President Trump, \u201cis retro, even if they don\u2019t know it,\u201d he said. \u201cBelieve me, the nation state will die, but we have to find the institutional system to handle it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nBrussels may be the capital of Belgium, but matters most because it is the symbolic capital of the European Union, a bloc of (still) 28 states and nearly 510 million people. (The United States, by contrast has about 323 million.)\n\nRather like Washington, Brussels is an administrative, political and lobbying center, chosen not for its political geography or history but because Belgium came first in the alphabet of the founding six nations and so first hosted the new institutions. Except for the Parliament, it evidently was too much trouble to rotate.\n\nBut for all its importance, Mr. Menasse mused in 2010, he didn\u2019t really know much about how the European Union functioned, or for that matter, about the functionaries who ran it. So he rented an apartment in the center, on the Rue du Vieux March\u00e9 aux Grains \u2014 not in the dull European quarter where the Union institutions are. For a writer who loves cities, cigarettes and wine, that would have been a step too far.\n\nHe set about exploring the place, meeting officials, reading the histories, digging into the archives. \u201cThe European Union is man-made, and everything done by man contains a story,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat they do all day, what are their biographies, nationalities, coming together with all these different languages and mentalities, and suddenly the institution has a face.\u201d\n\nThe result is a traditional novel, broad-shouldered, omniscient, almost Balzac-ian, but with terrorism part of a plot centered satirically around an all-too-plausible Brussels idea. An unhappy Greek Cypriot eurocrat, Fenia Xenopoulou, \u201cpromoted\u201d to the underfunded, despised department of culture, is charged with revamping the tarnished image of the European Commission, the bureaucracy that administers the bloc, with a big \u201cJubilee Project\u201d to mark its 50th anniversary.\n\nShe is bitter, and thinks: \u201cWhen the Commissioner for Trade or for Energy, yes, even when the Commissioner for Catching Fish had to leave and go to the bathroom, the discussion was interrupted and people waited until he or she returned. But if the Culture Commissioner had to leave, people kept right on talking, no one even noticed whether she was sitting at the table or on the toilet.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Xenopoulou decides on the perfect project \u2014 given that the European Union emerged from the atrocities of the Nazis, she proposes to proclaim Auschwitz as the birthplace of the European Commission.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNeedless to say, the member nations that actually run the European Union are horrified, each for its own reasons. Poland argues that Auschwitz was a solely German crime; Germany says that Muslims, now a part of German and European culture, were innocent; Austria says that a Polish horror must not be used to undermine the foundations of the Austrian state. And so on.\n\nBut Mr. Menasse wants to capture the other Brussels as well, including the headquarters of NATO, so there is another thread \u2014 a police detective whose politically sensitive investigation is frustrated and a Polish hit man who kills the wrong person but escapes amid a chaotic protest by pig farmers (and their pigs), demonstrating against an E.U. regulation blocking the export of pigs\u2019 ears to China. The novel ends, eerily enough, with a terrorist bombing of the Maalbeek subway station, in the European quarter.\n\nOver Austrian white wine and cigarettes in a long interview, partly in English, partly in German, at the Savoy Hotel cigar bar in Berlin, he recalled that day in March 2016, when the station and the airport were hit by suicide bombers, killing 32 people.\n\n\u201cWhen I planned the novel I knew it would end with an attack on the Maalbeek metro station, and then it happened,\u201d he said. \u201cI was in Brussels then and in the beginning I really couldn\u2019t believe it.\u201d\n\nBrussels might have been an historical accident as the capital of the bloc, but it was inevitable for Mr. Menasse. \u201cBrussels is the capital of a nation-state without a national idea,\u201d he said. \u201cIt has three official languages and 19 mayors\u201d of individual communes \u2014 \u201cit\u2019s like a lab situation for what\u2019s going on in Europe.\u201d It has no national \u201cleitkultur,\u201d or guiding culture, he said. \u201cIts variety is its richness.\u201d\n\nBut it is the very persistence of nationalism, and the increase in power in the European Union of the Council of nation states, that creates the real democratic deficit felt by Europeans toward the Brussels institutions, Mr. Menasse argues. \u201cThe deficit is the result of defending the national democracies within the European system.\u201d\n\nMr. Menasse seems an archetypal European. But his history has all the echoes of a terrible past. His father was Jewish, and in 1938, he was one of the 10,000 or so Jewish children brought to Britain in the \u201cKindertransport.\u201d Mr. Menasse\u2019s uncle also came to Britain and volunteered for the British Army. He fought the Nazis, helping to liberate Vienna. But when he wanted to remain home, Mr. Menasse recounted, his British commanding officer reminded him that \u201cthe British Army was not a club, and he ordered my uncle to go to Burma, where he had to fight the Japanese.\u201d\n\nMr. Menasse\u2019s father also returned to Vienna, and became something of a national hero as a professional football player. \u201cBut anti-Semitism was not over in Austria just because the war was over,\u201d Mr. Menasse said astringently. \u201cBut they liked my father because he was such a great football player.\u201d\n\nThe success of this novel was a complete surprise, he said. He had spent painful years on another novel into which he had poured his soul, \u201cExpulsion From Hell,\u201d published in 2001, which did badly, he said. \u201cWhen I finished that novel I was full of hopes, that I\u2019d get the Nobel Prize, or else I would die unknown.\u201d He smiled ruefully, lighting another cigarette. \u201cUnknown was right, and I was depressed for two or three years \u2014 if you put five, six, seven years of all your emotional and intellectual capacity into one project and no one looks, you can get depressed.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe worked hard on \u201cDie Hauptstadt,\u201d \u201cbut when I gave it to the publisher I had no expectations,\u201d he said. \u201cI was numb in my soul.\u201d And when nominated for the German Book Prize, \u201cI didn\u2019t care. But I went with this attitude and suddenly I had it!\u201d he said. Normally the next day the German press is full of critical, carping articles about the winning book. \u201cBut what really touched me,\u201d he said, \u201cwas that this time, there were no complaints.\u201d", "title": "Brussels, E.U. Capital, Gets a Novel, Both Tart and Empathic", "authors": ["Steven Erlanger"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The other day my barber asked me whether he should put all his money in Bitcoin. And the truth is that if he\u2019d bought Bitcoin, say, a year ago he\u2019d be feeling pretty good right now. On the other hand, Dutch speculators who bought tulip bulbs in 1635 also felt pretty good for a while, until tulip prices collapsed in early 1637.\n\nSo is Bitcoin a giant bubble that will end in grief? Yes. But it\u2019s a bubble wrapped in techno-mysticism inside a cocoon of libertarian ideology. And there\u2019s something to be learned about the times we live in by peeling away that wrapping.\n\nIf you\u2019ve been living in a cave and haven\u2019t heard of Bitcoin, it\u2019s the biggest, best-known example of a \u201ccryptocurrency\u201d: an asset that has no physical existence, consisting of nothing but a digital record stored on computers. What makes cryptocurrencies different from ordinary bank accounts, which are also nothing but digital records, is that they don\u2019t reside in the servers of any particular financial institution. Instead, a Bitcoin\u2019s existence is documented by records distributed in many places.\n\nAnd your ownership isn\u2019t verified by proving (and hence revealing) your identity. Instead, ownership of a Bitcoin is verified by possession of a secret password, which \u2014 using techniques derived from cryptography, the art of writing or solving codes \u2014 lets you access that virtual coin without revealing any information you don\u2019t choose to.", "title": "Opinion | Bubble, Bubble, Fraud and Trouble", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "A woman in a silky burgundy sari bustled up and demanded 10 buckets.\n\nTen? I thought, but the shop owner didn\u2019t flinch. He turned to count off the pails from the tower of shiny red, yellow and blue plastic behind him.\n\nI plunked my rupees down on the counter, grabbed the massive pulleys and, as best I could under the weight with a floppy infant tied to my chest, ran.\n\nThe pulleys really were for the baby. Little Liam had a bad case of insomnia.\n\nThe first three months of his life, he was colicky. I had memorized the American Academy of Pediatrics sleep guidelines, but every time we put Liam down on his back, he rolled around like a panicked, upturned turtle and howled. His only sleep, day or night, happened face down on my reclined chest or my husband\u2019s with one of our thumbs plugging his mouth like a pacifier. If we tried to give our arms a break by switching out a pruney thumb for a real pacifier, Liam\u2019s eyelids popped open. He scrunched up in a hot, red ball and wailed like a tiny fire engine.\n\nAfter three mind-numbing months of failed sleep, Rani, Liam\u2019s blessed Tamil nanny, intervened. She tied an old, green cotton sari to a wooden ax handle, added a spring at the top for a bit of bounce, suspended the contraption from a branch of the magnolia tree in our front yard, and laid the baby inside, hammock style.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI spied through the leaded glass windows of our front door as Rani gripped the rope suspending the hammock \u2014 called a totil \u2014 and swung it forward and back. As the momentum built, she flung Liam up, perpendicular to the ground in front of her, and then plunged him back down on alternating sides of her body. Rani reminded me of skiers dodging moguls in the Olympics, only this athlete wore a daisy-print sari and hurled a tiny, green cocoon around her in a blur of centripetal force.\n\nWhen I suddenly remembered the little larva inside that cocoon was my baby, I gripped the door handle, ready to intervene, but then I heard something I had never heard from Liam when he was exhausted: Silence. Only the cicadas hummed in the yard.\n\nFrom that day forward, Liam was a certified hammock sleeper. Rani insisted that totils were only for daytime naps \u2014 certainly not to be used at night when, in her view, babies should be snuggled safely in bed with their parents \u2014 but having failed at her prescription, not to mention back sleeping, we were desperate. So, instead of listening to Rani, we showered her with unwanted praise and rigged up a hook in our bedroom where we could hang the magical sleep machine at night. Our baby would finally sleep like a baby.\n\nWell, kind of. For a while, Liam agreed to one nap a day with Rani, because she was willing to swing him in the totil for over an hour until he fell asleep. But our nights were punctuated with regular nursing breaks every two hours, after which Liam expected to be agitated back into unconsciousness.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAround five months of age, Liam started waking up for the day at 4 a.m. I realized we were in bad shape, that we were just conditioning our kid to associate sleep with perpetual oscillation. Moving him to the terra firma of his unused crib and letting him cry it out was the obvious solution, but with my nerves so frayed from exhaustion, I couldn\u2019t take a full night of screaming. So, I caved. Halfway through each night, I relocated from my bed to a comforter on the cold floor under Liam\u2019s totil. I alternately dozed and batted at the baby hammock when he whistled every 20 minutes for rocking service.\n\nThus humbly situated and desperately sleep deprived, one morning I hallucinated that we had installed a pulley system in our bedroom rafters to swing our addicted child from the comfort of our flannel sheets.\n\nAt breakfast, I told Tim about my dream, and within two hours I was at the hardware shop. When I got home, Tim climbed up the ladder and installed one pulley above Liam\u2019s totil and one above our bed, connecting them with rope. As a finishing touch, we tied one of Liam\u2019s rejected pacifiers to our end of the rope as a handle.\n\nThat night, when the boy cried, we yanked on the rope and the room filled with the sounds of a small factory: metal groaning, rope rubbing over hardware. Liam fell silent. Tim and I smothered anxious giggles under the warmth of our down comforter and smiled up at the pacifier dangling above our heads. We knew it wouldn\u2019t last, but in that moment we were so desperate for a reprieve from the exhaustion that suspending our baby in midair from a Rube Goldberg machine felt like the perfect sleep solution.", "title": "Building a Baby Sleep Machine in India", "authors": ["Katie Quirk"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "There is something intoxicatingly utopian about the story of Tanc\u00edtaro.\n\nThis small town has succeeded at self-rule in a part of Mexico \u2014 the state of Michoac\u00e1n, drug war ground zero \u2014 where so many similar experiments have failed. It is free of the drug cartels as well as the Mexican police and politicians who are widely seen as part of the problem. It has homegrown institutions. It is safe.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a nice town. You can walk around at day or night. It\u2019s very nice,\u201d Guillermo Vald\u00e9s, a former head of Mexico\u2019s national intelligence agency, told us this August. \u201cThey take care of themselves.\u201d\n\nMr. Vald\u00e9s told us about Tanc\u00edtaro at the end of a long interview at a Mexico City cafe, where we had met him to discuss towns that were seceding in subtler ways. It was the sort of comment sometimes made after the formal questions have ended and the notebooks have closed, the casual aside that changes the whole story.\n\nHe\u2019d recently visited Tanc\u00edtaro for a book he was writing on the drug war and found its experiment in self-rule intriguing. It\u2019s a global center in avocado production, exporting about $1 million worth every day. The orchard owners use that money to fund militias that guard and police the town.", "title": "Building a Mini-State With Avocados and Guns", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "A second concourse of 477,00 square feet will be constructed at a cost of $545.5 million to the north between the runways. One existing 990-foot tunnel, and a second, new one of the same length, will link the two concourses at a cost of nearly $140 million. The airport is spending more than $90 million to construct 14 miles of new roadway. A station for the light-rail line connecting the airport to downtown Salt Lake City will be moved closer to the new terminal.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen the facilities are finished in 2023, they will provide this fast-growing metropolitan area, home to 80 percent of Utah\u2019s three million residents, with improved efficiency at one of the country\u2019s busiest airports, serving nine airlines with 329 daily flights. Traffic has climbed to more than 23 million travelers annually in an airport designed to serve fewer than half that number.\n\nTo ease congestion, Delta Air Lines, which serves 70 percent of the airport\u2019s passengers, agreed to help finance the reconstruction.\n\n\u201cPlanning for this project goes back to the early 2000s master plan, when we were thinking about how to make the existing airport layout work,\u201d said Bill Wyatt, the airport\u2019s executive director. \u201cDelta sat down and also tried to think how they could make that work operationally. They concluded they couldn\u2019t make it work operationally. Everybody began to focus on this new concept, which we\u2019re building.\u201d\n\nDelta, which earned $39.6 billon in total revenue in 2016, uses the hub principally as a link between coastal and mountain cities. Delta\u2019s investment in the airport is a share of the $1.2 billion the airline is spending annually over the next decade to expand and modernize air transport facilities around the country, according to company figures. The money would be spent on airport projects in Atlanta, Los Angeles, New York, Salt Lake City and Seattle, Morgan Durrant, a company spokesman, said in an email message.\n\nMike Williams, the program director for the airport\u2019s Terminal Redevelopment Program, said the nationwide airport reconstruction effort started in 2008, as the country was in the grip of the Great Recession. Three years after a downturn in the American airline industry pitched Delta into bankruptcy in 2005, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport started to build its $1.4 billion, 1.2 million-square-foot Maynard H. Jackson Jr. International Terminal.\n\nThe Atlanta terminal opened in 2012 just as fuel prices moderated, the national economy recovered and Americans began filling airline seats and overcrowding the country\u2019s old airports.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
