Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the same period, Los Angeles International Airport began a $14 billion project to upgrade runways and safety facilities, improve escalators and elevators and renovate four terminals. The project included a $2.1 billion remodeling and expansion of the international terminal and the addition of a $1.6 billion, 750,000-square-foot midfield terminal.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExpansion is needed. In 2016, 823 million passengers boarded airliners in the United States, 25 million more than in the previous year. Airport and airline executives, mindful of criticism about old facilities and responsive to the growing demand, have escalated construction projects into a nationwide building boom, with New York-area airports leading the way.\n\nLaGuardia is spending $8 billion to replace four terminals with one, build a new parking structure, connect the airport more efficiently to public transit and gain more space for taxiways. Newark Liberty International Airport just broke ground on a $2.4 billion project, much of the money to be spent replacing 44-year-old Terminal A with a one-million-square-foot facility and a 3,000-space parking deck. And Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced a $10 billion project this year to renovate and expand passenger terminals and improve ground transportation at Kennedy International Airport.\n\nOther big airport construction projects include an investment of nearly $800 million at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport to build a 450,000-square-foot international terminal to replace one that dates to the 1970s. Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport broke ground almost two years ago on a $807 million, 760,000-square-foot terminal. And Orlando International Airport is in the midst of a $1.1 billion renovation and expansion of its North Terminal, as well as improvements to other facilities.\n\nRebuilding the Salt Lake City airport has attracted broad support from residents, not only because it is financed almost entirely without taxpayer funds but also because the new terminals will enhance one of the most conveniently situated major airports in the country. From almost anywhere in the city or its outskirts, the airport is less than a half-hour car or train ride away.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nTwo features of design and construction distinguish the reconstruction: its linear layout, and the lack of disruption to the airport\u2019s operation.\n\nWhen the project is finished, the airport will consist of an airy central terminal flanked by the two wings of its 3,700-foot-long South Concourse. In front of that will be the 3,400-foot-long North Concourse.\n\nThe unbent concourses, designed by the architecture and engineering firm HOK, are characteristic of airport reconstruction projects to accommodate big planes. The three old terminals, dating to the 1960s, are connected by an outdoor sidewalk and were upgraded sporadically through the decades with clusters of gates served by fans of tightly spaced jet bridges.\n\nThe project can occur without disruption because the 7,800-acre airport has enough room to build all the new facilities, including the first wing of the South Concourse. When gates in the new concourses are ready to serve passengers, the airport will close and demolish the old terminals, then build the rest of the South Concourse.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a very flexible and efficient design,\u201d Mr. Wyatt said. \u201cIf we need more space after the initial phase of construction, you can add capacity as far as the eye can see, virtually without any disruption at all.\u201d", "title": "Building a Modern Airport in Salt Lake City From One Well Past Its Prime", "authors": ["Keith Schneider", "Square Feet"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "A review of Ms. Ma\u2019s case \u2014 involving interviews with officials, diplomats and others, as well as searches in corporate registries \u2014 underscored China\u2019s deep ambivalence as it has come under increasing pressure to enforce sanctions against North Korea. While China is on the record opposing the North\u2019s pursuit of nuclear weapons, it is wary of being seen imposing punishments at the bidding of the United States, especially against its own citizens.\n\nImage Ms. Ma in a company photo. Since China announced an investigation in 2016, her whereabouts has been shrouded in mystery.\n\nNorth Korea\u2019s agreement on Tuesday to send athletes to the Winter Olympics in South Korea next month, and to hold talks and other exchanges with the South, may have been symbolic and perhaps a cynical effort to bide time. Yet it suggested that the rising diplomatic and economic pressure, meant to deny it the financial and material resources needed to develop nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles, may have had some effect on the North\u2019s leader Kim Jong-un.\n\nMr. Kim has given no signal that he would give up his nuclear ambitions, but after the North\u2019s initial overtures, Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter that the talks were evidence that \u201csanctions and \u2018other\u2019 pressures are beginning to have a big impact on North Korea.\u201d\n\nChina has shown a willingness to support tougher sanctions at the United Nations Security Council over the last year, but it has done so grudgingly. The reasons for that are historical and strategic. North Korea has long counted on China as its only real ally, for example, but some analysts argue that economic factors also play a part.\n\n\u201cThe Chinese don\u2019t want to have to be doing this,\u201d said Ken E. Gause, an expert on North Korea with CNA, a research organization in Arlington, Va. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot of money to be made on that border, and there are a lot of connections between the operators on the border and their patrons back in Beijing.\u201d", "title": "Businesswoman\u2019s Fate a Test of China\u2019s Resolve on North Korea", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "You might make Ruth Reichl\u2019s recipe for chicken diavolo this week, get your Italian on. You could try a brussels sprouts salad with apples and walnuts. Or, if you\u2019re feeling peckish, you might brew a big pot of Tamar Adler\u2019s health soup, which many readers say is improved greatly by not boiling the miso, but whisking it in at the end.\n\nOr, if you\u2019d like to join us for our weekly Wednesday enterprise of cooking without a recipe, try this simple fried-egg quesadilla, which makes for as fine a light supper as it does breakfast. You\u2019ll need only butter, corn tortillas, some Cheddar or jack, a slice of ham or cooked bacon if you want it, some chopped cilantro if you have any, and salsa or hot sauce to drizzle over the top. Easy work: Melt some butter in a pan and gently cook a tortilla in it. Top the tortilla with cheese, the meats if you want them, and another tortilla. Cook, flipping the quesadilla a few times, until it is crisp and golden and the cheese within it has melted. Use a spatula to pull it out of the pan, and place it onto a cutting board to rest. Fry an egg in the now-empty pan with a little more butter, then cut the quesadilla into quarters and slide the egg on top. Top with cilantro and hot sauce or salsa. Nice.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. (You will need a subscription to do all of that, it\u2019s true. If it annoys, you can take it out on me: foodeditor@nytimes.com.)\n\nAnd we\u2019ll be standing by if something goes awry, either with your cooking or our technology. Just write: cookingcare@nytimes.com. One of us will get back to you.\n\nNow, far from the precincts of cutting boards and paella pans, my friend Capt. David Berson of the electric launch Glory, in Greenport, N.Y., turned me on to Clancy Sigal\u2019s excellent \u201cA Woman of Uncertain Character,\u201d a memoir about life with his mother, an itinerant labor organizer. (Sigal himself was quite a figure, a novelist whose life reads like fiction: Read his obituary in The Times.)\n\nThe language is sometimes salty, in keeping with the ethos of the day, but this report on cooking the pizza-cinnamon roll recipe that Mario Batali mysteriously appended to his letter of apology about sexual misconduct, by Geraldine DeRuiter, is dark and hilarious.\n\nFinally, Dolores O\u2019Riordan, the lead singer of the Cranberries, died on Monday in London. She was 46. Listen to her sing \u201cZombie,\u201d live on Letterman in 1994, and follow it with \u201cSalvation,\u201d live at the MTV Music Awards in 1996. That\u2019s a great voice of Irish music stilled. I\u2019ll be back on Friday.", "title": "Butter Tarts!", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "Sara Bonisteel", "Kim Severson", "Alison Roman", "Tamar Adler"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cMost of these things were developed by housewives, and it wasn\u2019t deemed important,\u201d said Lenore Newman, the author of \u201cSpeaking in Cod Tongues: A Canadian Culinary Journey.\u201d \u201cNow that we\u2019re actually interested in it, we go back, and we find there are a lot of holes in this knowledge. I think we can safely say they\u2019re Canadian and that they\u2019re definitely still popular.\u201d\n\nBy the 1910s, the butter tart was all the rage in the farming regions of Ontario. Three recipes for tart filling and six recipes for butter tarts appear in the \u201cCanadian Farm Cook Book\u201d of 1911. \u201cJunia,\u201d a columnist for The Farmer\u2019s Advocate, shared reader recipes in early 1913 to answer a question from N.W. of Ontario who longed for a butter tart recipe \u2014 \u201cthe crust and all, as I am a new beginner.\u201d Readers responded with tart recipes plain and with currants, proof perhaps that the filling debate over plain or dried fruit is more than a century old.\n\nThat same year, the Lake of the Woods Milling Company published \u201cFive Roses Cook Book,\u201d with recipes from its customers; it spread the butter tart across the Dominion. At one point, there was one \u201cFive Roses\u201d cookbook for every four Canadian households, said Ms. Driver, the bibliographer.\n\nBy midcentury, Eaton\u2019s department store in Toronto included a butter tart in its boxed picnic lunches, and Canadian Betty Crockers like Edith Adams (the fictional home economist of The Vancouver Sun) and Rita Martin (also fictional, with a name pronounceable in French and English) evangelized the tart, along with real-life home economists like Kate Aitken.", "title": "Butter Tarts, Canada\u2019s Humble Favorite, Have Much to Love", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "The Marley catalog is unusual. During his lifetime, he had few chart hits, but his music has achieved steady, far-reaching popularity that has lasted for decades. According to Nielsen, Marley\u2019s songs have been streamed more than 1.7 billion times in the United States alone, and his fame permeates deep into emerging markets like Africa and India.\n\n\u201cThere isn\u2019t a crevice of the world,\u201d Mr. Mestel said, \u201cwhere Bob Marley isn\u2019t a god.\u201d\n\nUnlike most publishers, Primary Wave sees itself as a branding house and an asset manager, exploiting song catalogs on behalf of investors that have contributed to an acquisition fund. The company, Mr. Mestel said, has about $400 million to invest in music on behalf of those investors, a group that includes BlackRock, the world\u2019s largest money manager.\n\nOver the past year, hundreds of millions of dollars have changed hands in music-publishing transactions. In June, Concord paid almost $600 million for Imagem, which includes the Rodgers & Hammerstein catalog. In December, Kobalt bought Songs (Lorde, the Weeknd) for $160 million, and this month Round Hill Music closed a $240 million deal for Carlin Music, which includes standards like \u201cFever.\u201d\n\nMoney managers, lawyers and music executives say that a confluence of factors, including low interest rates and a roaring stock market, has created an especially frothy market for alternative investments like music rights. And the success of streaming has quickly given a boost to catalog valuations, pointing to the possibility of steady growing returns for years to come.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re experiencing growth from multiple sources simultaneously,\u201d said Barry M. Massarsky, an economist who specializes in valuing music catalogs. \u201cIt\u2019s a perfect storm of value for music publishing assets.\u201d\n\nIn a competitive market, Primary Wave\u2019s pitch to songwriters is that it can find new ways to market old material. For Mr. Robinson, who signed a $22 million deal with Primary Wave in 2016, the company did a deal with American Greetings to promote a new holiday, Father-Daughter Day, using Mr. Robinson\u2019s song \u201cMy Girl.\u201d When he was looking for a new home for his songs, Mr. Robinson said in an interview, those ideas sold him.", "title": "Buying a Piece of Bob Marley\u2019s Song Catalog, and His Enduring Legacy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Though called the Australian Open, it is effectively the Grand Slam of the Asia Pacific Region.\n\nWhen Paul McNamee became the tournament\u2019s director in the 1990s, his mandate was to lift the Australian Open from a junior to equal partner of the four Grand Slam events of the year.\n\n\u201cWe needed to be ourselves, which was a sun-drenched nation that needs to have a big casual outdoor party,\u201d said McNamee, who no longer runs the tournament. \u201cThe Australianization was absolutely the key for this tournament to find its identity.\u201d\n\nThe three Northern Hemisphere tournaments had long-held identities. Wimbledon has always been a beautiful display of British tradition and ceremony. The French Open is chic and Parisian. And the United States Open is as big, loud and grand as its host city, New York.\n\nBut it was only in the 1990s when Australia began struggling with its place in the world \u2014 even flirting with the idea of severing ties with Britain to become a republic \u2014 that the Australian Open really found its stride.\n\nOpen officials knew they needed to embrace Asia in order to expand and grow. They hired a full-time manager to work on the Asia strategy. On the court were not only more players from Asia, but ball boys and girls from there, as well.\n\nKia Motors of South Korea took over as the tournament\u2019s major sponsor. Ganten Water, a Chinese company, has the exclusive concession on selling bottled water \u2014 imported from China \u2014 at the Open this year.", "title": "By Looking to Asia, the Australian Open Found Itself", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "B\u00e9n\u00e9dicte Pesle, a Frenchwoman who was so impressed with the stage performances she saw during visits to the United States that she devoted herself to bringing the adventurous works of Merce Cunningham, Robert Wilson and other American artists to European audiences, died on Jan. 17 in Paris. She was 90.\n\nHer death was announced by the culture services division of the French Embassy in the United States.\n\nMs. Pesle (pronounced pell) did her work behind the scenes, eschewing labels like \u201cproducer\u201d and \u201cpresenter\u201d while performing a wide array of functions \u2014 go-between, convincer, fund-raiser and more \u2014 that might in fact have fallen under those job descriptions.\n\nWhen pressed, she would use a humble term to characterize her role, said Denise Luccioni, who worked with her: \u201csecr\u00e9taire d\u2019artistes\u201d \u2014 secretary of artists.\n\n\u201cShe did whatever needed to be done,\u201d Ms. Luccioni said by email. \u201cBut before that, she had had the idea for it, the clear vision of how it should be done, and she had transmitted her passion and enthusiasm and convinced whoever needed to be convinced that that was the way to go. Then she did all the practical things, because nobody thought of all the things she thought of.\u201d", "title": "B\u00e9n\u00e9dicte Pesle Dies at 90; Introduced American Stage Artists to France", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has decided to postpone its session on nuclear attack preparedness next week. Much attention had been drawn to the timing of the agency\u2019s session, which was publicized just days after President Trump touted the size of his nuclear button compared with North Korea\u2019s.\n\nLate Friday afternoon, the C.D.C. announced that it had changed its mind about next Tuesday\u2019s topic, making a last-minute revision to reflect concerns about cases of severe flu.\n\n\u201cTo date, this influenza season is notable for the sheer volume of flu that most of the United States is seeing at the same time, which can stress health systems,\u201d the agency said. \u201cThe vast majority of this activity has been caused by influenza A H3N2, associated with severe illness in young children and people 65 years and older.\u201d\n\nKathy Harben, a spokeswoman for the agency, said the Tuesday session would now address guidance for health professionals on trying to reduce the spread of the flu and to help with shortages of antiviral medicines in some hard-hit areas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n[READ: Questions and Answers About This Year\u2019s Flu Season]\n\nThe C.D.C.\u2019s announcement that it was holding a nuclear preparation workshop drew widespread media coverage and embarrassed the public health agency. with funding for six years.\n\nExpanding the scope of nuclear retaliation\n\n\u2022 A Pentagon plan that has been sent to President Trump for approval would permit the use of nuclear weapons to respond to a wide range of devastating but non-nuclear assaults, including cyberattacks.\n\nThe document casts a bleak picture of U.S. national security threats, citing not only Russian and Chinese nuclear advances but also ones by North Korea and, potentially, Iran.\n\n\u2022 Separately, Japan\u2019s public broadcaster accidentally sent news alerts on Tuesday that North Korea had launched a missile \u2014 just days after the government of Hawaii sent a similar warning.\n\nKoreas to march as one at Games\n\n\u2022 North and South Korea agreed today to field a joint women\u2019s ice hockey team at the Winter Olympics next month, and to have their athletes march under one flag at the opening ceremony.\n\nThe Games, which begin on Feb. 9 in Pyeongchang, South Korea, will be the first time the countries have a joint Olympic team.\n\nSeoul has said in the past that it hoped such a move could contribute to a political thaw after years of high tensions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading being used as a state-approved school.\n\nThe case raises questions about whether California is too lenient in its approach to home schooling, and whether it should have been monitoring David Turpin, the father and supposed principal, more closely.\n\n\u2022 The parents, both arrested on nine counts of torture and child endangerment, remain in jail.\n\nTrump is declared of sound mind and body\n\n\u2022 The White House physician said on Tuesday that President Trump\u2019s overall health was \u201cexcellent,\u201d and that the president had received a perfect score on a test to screen for neurological impairment.\n\nThe physician, Dr. Ronny Jackson, said that Mr. Trump, 71, had asked for the cognitive test to try to quell questions about his mental abilities.\n\n\u2022 Dr. Jackson also said that the president weighed 239 pounds and was too sedentary.\n\nStephen Bannon to testify\n\n\u2022 President Trump\u2019s former chief strategist was subpoenaed last week by the special He\u2019s more enthusiastic about the diet part than the exercise part, but we\u2019re going to do both.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Dr. Ronny Jackson, the White House physician, on President Trump.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\n\u201cColor,\u201d said Louis Comfort Tiffany, \u201cis to the eye what music is to the ear.\u201d\n\nTiffany, who died on this day 85 years ago, was the son of the founder of Tiffany & Co., the famous jeweler. But the younger Tiffany found his own success as an artist and designer, most famous for his work with stained glass.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1881, he helped redesign the interior of a house in Hartford, Conn., owned by Mark Twain, who was making his name after the publication of \u201cThe Adventures of Tom Sawyer.\u201d\n\nThe work was followed a year later by a commission with a much higher profile: redecorating the White House.\n\nChester Arthur had been thrust into office after the assassination of President James Garfield in 1881. He hired Tiffany to remodel the Executive Mansion to suit his refined tastes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTiffany redecorated several rooms, and he also installed a large stained-glass screen in the Entrance Hall.\n\nBut his mark on the White House did not last. Twenty years later, in 1902, President Theodore Roosevelt ordered a major renovation that swept away the building\u2019s Victorian touches \u2014 including Tiffany\u2019s screen.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. The race between Amazon and Google to be the go-to service for integration of consumer products was on full display. In many booths, signs prominently advertised that products worked with Google Assistant or Amazon\u2019s Alexa. The smart home, car and TV all seemed to have been touched by Amazon or Google.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s the year of A.I. and conversational interfaces,\u201d said J. P. Gownder, an analyst for Forrester Research.\n\nPhoto\n\nZipping along the convention floor were robots yielding a host of skills. Chen"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Thick cable-knit sweaters may call to mind blustery fishing towns, coarse sheep\u2019s wool and Irish folklore \u2014 but this season, several designers have put a fresh spin on the age-old style. On his fall/winter 2018 runway in Paris, the Belgian designer Walter Van Beirendonck showcased variants of the textured sweater such as sleeveless shapes in bold primary blues. The Japanese label Sacai also explored the pattern, segmenting cable knit patches together to create contrast. For more modern takes on the style \u2014 including gleaming Lurex and soft cashmere \u2014 here are six others you can buy now.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto", "title": "Cable Knit Sweaters Get a Fresh Twist", "authors": ["Kelly Harris", "Market Report"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Caitlin Elizabeth Field and Julia Elizabeth Sullivan were married Jan. 20 in their apartment in Brooklyn. Zachary Aidala, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.\n\nDr. Field (left), 34, is the manager for science and research development for Staten Island\u2019s Freshkills Park of the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation. She is based in Manhattan. She also works part time as a commercial sailing captain at Classic Harbor Line in Manhattan. She graduated from Vassar, and received a master\u2019s degree in psychology focusing on animal behavior and conservation from Hunter College. She also received a doctorate in biopsychology and behavioral neuroscience from the CUNY Graduate Center.\n\nShe is the daughter of Christine E. Bysheim and Scott C. Field, both of Islip, N.Y. Her father is an independent painting contractor in Islip. Her mother retired as a fourth-grade teacher from South Country School in Bay Shore, N.Y. She is also the stepdaughter of William T. States.\n\nMs. Sullivan, 33, is the associate director of quality management for New York City and a nurse practitioner in Manhattan for Planned Parenthood of New York City. She graduated from Hampshire College. She also received a master\u2019s degree in nursing specializing in reproductive and sexual health from Columbia and a Master of Public Health from Emory University.", "title": "Caitlin Field, Julia Sullivan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cStarfire\u201d is what Ms. Smith wants to say as herself. She released a seven-song EP in 2014, \u201cEverything to You,\u201d that, true to its title, was a showcase for how generalized her songwriting could be. Although \u201cStarfire\u201d is by no means the bare-bones radio-unfriendly confessional she hints at in \u201cThis Town Is Killing Me,\u201d it is far more personalized, and more dramatic.\n\nThe album offers some biographical particulars. \u201cSt. Paul\u201d is named after the Minnesota city Ms. Smith regularly drove through \u2014 playing Wilco songs in her \u201cbeat-up Wrangler\u201d \u2014 on her way to Nashville. The slow-building \u201cDon\u2019t Give Up on My Love,\u201d the one song on the album written by Ms. Smith alone, grapples with the toll of career ambitions on a relationship: \u201cYou said underneath your breath/That you didn\u2019t really know, didn\u2019t really know if this is worth it.\u201d\n\nThe music, produced by Paul Moak (who has produced the Christian-rock bands Third Day and Leeland), takes some format-defying turns \u2014 notably in \u201cEast Side Restaurant,\u201d a waltz that begins as something like a French chanson and builds to a string-orchestra climax, treating a breakup as a grand tragedy. (Those strings are on call for other songs, too.) Most importantly, the album presents Ms. Smith as someone more wounded, stubborn and complicated than the people-pleasing country-gal image she accepted on her EP.", "title": "Caitlyn Smith, a Hitmaking Nashville Songwriter, Sings Her Own on \u2018Starfire\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "For example, at 44A, if you add OM to the phrase IT\u2019S NO JOKE, you get OMITS NO JOKE, clued as \u201cMakes an unabridged humor book?\u201d\n\nThere are three more theme entries for you to solve. Be mindful as you solve, and you will probably get them.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n13A: Anyone out there who hasn\u2019t seen \u201cFerris Bueller\u2019s Day Off\u201d? Anyone? Anyone? The teacher, played by Ben Stein, DRONES ON:\n\n17A: These \u201ccommand\u201d clues are tough to decipher, but they add fun to the solve, in my opinion. \u201cHit it!\u201d could be a command from an orchestra leader, but it could also be a directive on how to enjoy a PI\u00d1ATA.\n\n29A: Hand up if you thought this was going to be ZIT. No? Just me? The answer to \u201cExtraction target, often\u201d is ORE.\n\n61A: Some readers ask why certain misdirected clues get a question mark and some don\u2019t. There are multiple reasons, but in this case, \u201cKept on the down-low?\u201d could mean keeping a secret or keeping quiet about something, yet that\u2019s not quite where this clue is going. It\u2019s stretchy to use that clue for a word like SIMMERED (which is typically clued straight to cooking, so kudos for the fresh clue), yet it works, because simmering something on the stove occurs when you keep the temperature relatively low.\n\n8D: Richard Gorelick, the former restaurant critic for The Baltimore Sun, has taken it upon himself to tweet at me almost every day that the singer and popular crossword entry ENYA has not yet appeared in The New York Times crossword puzzle in 2018. We have a lot of fun, but just between us, I\u2019m starting to worry about him.\n\nPhoto\n\n15D: Here\u2019s one clue that I think could have been better. \u201cLads\u2019 loves\u201d is meant to hint at LASSES, and should be no trouble for those who think primarily in cis-heterosexual terms. It\u2019s probably not even hard for those who aren\u2019t cis-heterosexual, but the clue\u2019s wording is not very inclusive to them. From a strictly language point of view, it\u2019s zippy and alliterative, but not all lads love LASSES, and vice versa. An alternative clue could have been something like \u201cPartners of lads?\u201d because the words lads and LASSES are often partnered as a phrase, but it doesn\u2019t quite make the assumptions \u201cLads\u2019 loves\u201d does.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n28D: Quirky wordplay here. \u201cExtremely fancy?\u201d means really posh on the surface, but in today\u2019s puzzle, it means to fancy someone extremely. The answer is covets.\n\n31D: This one had me going for a while. It\u2019s very cleverly worded. \u201cCourt officials whose jobs have now been replaced by technology\u201d made me think of judges in a court of law. I had enough letters at that point to write in JUDGES, but then I was stymied. ROBOJUDGES? No, too many letters. It turns out that we\u2019re supposed to be thinking about a tennis court, and the answer is NET JUDGES.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nJeff Chen: Very cool to get a chance to work with Josh! My wife had just listened to a podcast about meditation in which he was featured, so that sparked conversation. Somehow, meditation got linked to premeditation \u2014 or PREmeditation \u2014 and off we went. OM! I really like one of his quotes: \u201c\u2018How I Met Your Mother\u2019 might be my great popular success, I mean, it might be. I hope it\u2019s not. I suspect I\u2019ll have some other things that will be seen and noticed, [but] I\u2019m just going to keep making things that light me up.\u201d Love that attitude. I\u2019m looking forward to hearing a lot more about Josh\u2019s projects in the future.\n\nMr. Radnor did not have a chance to write his own notes, but he did tweet about it:\n\nPhoto\n\nA lovely, calming collaboration to get us over the hump of the week, Mr. Radnor and Mr. Chen.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Calculated", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "He also became the first director of the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity and the founder of the African Center for Technology Studies in Nairobi, Kenya, a pioneering group that married government policy with science and technology to spur sustainable development and foster distinctly African perspectives on science.\n\nProfessor Juma died on Dec. 15 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 64. His wife said the cause was cancer. At his death he was widely credited as having been an important force in ensuring that biotechnology would play a critical role in improving economic life in many developing countries, especially in sub-Saharan Africa.\n\n\u201cCalestous understood that people often resist the changes that come with innovation, and that overcoming this resistance can be very important in enabling societies to move ahead,\u201d said Douglas W. Elmendorf, dean of the Kennedy School. \u201cSo he tried to understand why people resist innovation, and what can be done to make them feel comfortable with change.\u201d\n\nProfessor Juma\u2019s latest book, \u201cInnovation and Its Enemies\u201d (2016), described how technological change is often greeted with public skepticism. Beneath such opposition, he argued, is the belief that only a small segment of society will benefit from potential progress, while the much broader society bears the greatest risk.\n\nSuccessful policymaking must take into account people\u2019s feelings, he believed. When Professor Juma helped design a stove for use in developing countries, its metallic cylinder was replaced with a clay lining to improve efficiency. But the prototype caused less smoke \u2014 attracting more mosquitoes \u2014 and villagers worried that metal workers could lose their jobs. A later model used metal and clay.\n\n\u201cUltimately, all development is experimental; no one knows what they are doing,\u201d Professor Juma said with a laugh in 2014. \u201cAfricans need the chance to experiment as well. They will make mistakes, but they can learn from them, too.\u201d\n\nProfessor Juma could be lighthearted in the classroom or in public in order to make his points. With more than 100,000 followers on Twitter, he shared with them cartoons that teased skeptics of science and innovation. One of his last posts featured a game show called \u201cFacts Don\u2019t Matter.\u201d In it, a contestant is told: \u201cI\u2019m sorry, Jeannie, your answer was correct, but Kevin shouted his incorrect answer over yours, so he gets the points.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cCalestous was very serious about getting his work right, but he was not serious about himself,\u201d Mr. Elmendorf said. \u201cHe shared his enjoyment of the research and teaching, though he was working on life-or-death issues for many people. He was incredibly optimistic.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nProfessor Juma was born to John Kwada Juma and Clementina Nabwire Juma in the village of Busia, in western Kenya, on June 9, 1953. He grew up nearby in Port Victoria.\n\n\u201cPort Victoria was as remote as it gets \u2014 a small fishing village on Lake Victoria at Kenya\u2019s westernmost point,\u201d said Ken Kobe, who taught Professor Juma while serving as a Peace Corps volunteer there in 1969-70.\n\nAfter graduating from Egoji Teachers\u2019 Training College in central Kenya in 1974, Professor Juma became a science teacher in Mombasa, a port city on the Indian Ocean. He went on to write so many letters to the editor of the Nairobi-based newspaper The Daily Nation that it hired him in 1978 to be its first full-time science and environment correspondent.\n\nWangari Maathai, the environmentalist who became the first African woman to win a Nobel Peace Prize, hired Professor Juma to work at a nonprofit in Nairobi. Encouraged by Ms. Maathai, he won a scholarship and earned a doctorate in science and technology policy studies in 1987 from the University of Sussex in England.\n\nHe met his wife, who also works in sustainable development, at a conference in Montreal. They married in 1987 and moved to Kenya.\n\nProfessor Juma experienced two major ecological disruptions in his childhood, Ms. Field-Juma said. One was the introduction of Nile perch to Lake Victoria to help the fishing industry. Though it did benefit the area economically for a time, it also contributed to the depletion, to near-extinction, of stocks of many other types of fish in the lake.\n\nThe second change was the British colonial government\u2019s deforestation of much of the Port Victoria region, which dried out what had been a wet and fertile area. \u201cThe microclimate of that region was irreversibly changed,\u201d Ms. Field-Juma said.\n\nOn his return to Kenya with his wife, he sought a scientific solution to the agricultural crisis.\n\n\u201cI started to run into all the people who had collected seeds of fruits and vegetables, mostly fruits, that had disappeared,\u201d he said in an interview in 2003. \u201cAnd some of them explained to me that those fruits have disappeared because the area had dried up. And they would pose this question to me: \u2018You scientists, are you able to grow these fruits in places where there is less water?\u2019 \u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nProfessor Juma recognized the potential of genetic modification to address such issues and to help solve Africa\u2019s broader agricultural problems, distilling his thinking in the 1989 book \u201cThe Gene Hunters.\u201d\n\nThe book helped pave the way for the Convention on Biological Diversity, a United Nations treaty signed by more than 150 governments in 1992 to protect the survival of diverse species and ecosystems.\n\nBesides his wife, he is survived by his son, Eric, and his sister, Roselyda Nanjala.\n\nUntil he was hospitalized, Professor Juma had planned to host about 20 international students for Thanksgiving in Cambridge. Instead, he joined them from the hospital by Skype, sharing stories and discussing development with them.\n\n\u201cIt was just what he wanted,\u201d Ms. Field-Juma said, \u201cand he wasn\u2019t even there.\u201d", "title": "Calestous Juma, 64, Dies; Sought Innovation in African Agriculture", "authors": ["Adeel Hassan"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "The memo reminded prosecutors that \u201cmarijuana activity is a serious crime.\u201d Mr. Sessions said in a statement that \u201cstricter enforcement by prosecutors will help tackle the growing drug crisis, and thwart violent crime across our country.\u201d\n\nLeading voices in California\u2019s marijuana industry said Thursday that while the announcement by Mr. Sessions might have punctured some of the excitement surrounding legalization, it did not change their plans to take part in what is the world\u2019s largest legal market for recreational pot.\n\n\u201cThis has changed zero on the ground for us,\u201d said Steve DeAngelo, the executive director of Harborside, a company with dispensaries in Oakland and San Jose.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think this is going to result in any serious attempt to shut down the legal cannabis industry,\u201d Mr. DeAngelo said. \u201cIt\u2019s more of a delaying tactic than a knife to the throat of the industry.\u201d\n\nCalifornians approved Proposition 64, which allowed for recreational use of the drug, by a 57 percent to 43 percent margin in a November 2016 ballot initiative.\n\nCarla Lowe, the Northern California director for the advocacy group Citizens Against Legalizing Marijuana, said she hoped the Sessions memo would focus attention on a drug that was being produced at much higher levels of potency than in previous decades.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019m concerned what this is doing to developing brains in young people,\u201d she said.\n\n\u201cI would hope this would get the attention of some of the people who are law-abiding citizens,\u201d Ms. Lowe said. \u201cBut I don\u2019t know that there\u2019s much hope in California.\u201d\n\nLawyers who specialize in cannabis said they were skeptical that federal prosecutors would be more aggressive in California for several reasons, including a perceived reluctance of jurors in the state to convict marijuana cases, especially small-scale ones, that do not involve other crimes. Lawyers also point out that the Trump administration has not yet appointed its own federal prosecutors in California.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAdditionally, lawyers said the Justice Department is constrained by the Rohrabacher-Farr amendment, which has been attached to congressional budget bills in recent years, and prohibits the Justice Department from spending money on the implementation of state medical cannabis laws.\n\n\u201cThe message to the industry is that nothing has really changed,\u201d said Sean McAllister, a lawyer who specializes in cannabis cases in California and Colorado. \u201cThe industry has flourished in an environment of uncertainty for the past 20 years. Sessions\u2019s memo does not create any additional uncertainty that did not already exist.\u201d\n\nBut the uncertainty is nonetheless substantial. The Sessions announcement may give further pause to large companies that have been reluctant to invest in the marijuana business because of fear of retaliation by federal authorities. And small-scale veterans of the industry \u2014 the cottage marijuana businesses in the famed Emerald Triangle of Northern California, among others \u2014 face potential threats of forfeiture, as they always have. If prosecutors were to crack down, sellers and anyone caught in possession of the drug could go to jail.\n\nYet as a practical matter, officials from the federal Drug Enforcement Administration have said that combating opioid trafficking is much more important than cracking down on marijuana given the agency\u2019s stretched resources.\n\nRuss Baer, a spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Administration, said in an interview last year that most of the agency\u2019s resources were being spent on combating opioids. \u201cWe are spread thin,\u201d he said.\n\nLocal law enforcement is also stretched. Thomas D. Allman, the sheriff of Mendocino County, one of the three counties in the Emerald Triangle, said Thursday that investigating marijuana cultivation was not a high priority, unless it was \u201cout of control\u201d or involved other crimes, such as the environmental damage.\n\n\u201cIf somebody is obeying state law, I\u2019m going to say there are not many local law enforcement agencies who are going to be rushing out to do an investigation,\u201d Sheriff Allman said. \u201cThere are many other crimes we can focus on that impact the safety of the community.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHezekiah Allen, the executive director of the California Growers Association, a cannabis industry group, says while marijuana growers are concerned about the more aggressive federal posture, longtime growers have seen it before.\n\n\u201cFolks that have been at this for a few generations remember that this is a cycle,\u201d Mr. Allen said. \u201cFederal enforcement ebbs and flows and it has for decades. This is another enforcement cycle but this time we have a state government that is working with us. And frankly enforcement wasn\u2019t all that effective in the past.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, among customers at the Berkeley Patients Group, a dispensary that sells recreational marijuana, there was defiance and eye-rolling among those asked about the Sessions memo.\n\n\u201cTo me, they\u2019ve always wanted to destroy everything Obama did. It\u2019s all in that vein,\u201d said Barry Alexander, 61, a supervisor at a Whole Foods supermarket. Mr. Alexander was skeptical that the Trump administration could do much to change legalization in California. \u201cWe\u2019re like Texas, we\u2019re our own country,\u201d he said.\n\nIan Carr, 23, a construction worker who bought cannabis at another dispensary in Berkeley, the Cannabis Buyers Club, shrugged off the prospect of a federal crackdown.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been using marijuana since before it was legal,\u201d he said. \u201cSo I\u2019d just go back to that.\u201d", "title": "California Defiant in Face of Federal Move to Get Tough on Marijuana", "authors": ["Thomas Fuller"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "With disheveled hair and ill-fitting black suits provided by the public defender\u2019s office, they both looked dazed as they sat in the courtroom packed with reporters. Their hands rested in their laps, shackled with a chain around their waists and another around each of their ankles. Bail was set at $12 million each.\n\nMr. Hestrin said that many of the children appear to have cognitive deficiencies and show evidence of nerve damage from \u201cextreme and prolonged physical abuse.\u201d None of the siblings, ages 2 to 29, have seen a doctor in four years and they have never seen a dentist.\n\nForced to stay up all night and sleep during the day, they were given only a tiny amount of food on a strict schedule, Mr. Hestrin said. A 29-year-old daughter weighed just 82 pounds and a 12-year-old sibling was the size of a 7-year-old. The 2-year-old child did not appear to be abused, Mr. Hestrin said.\n\n\n\nThe daughter who escaped did not understand what the officers meant when they asked if there was medication in the home. Many of the children did not know what a police officer was.\n\n\u201cThey lack a basic knowledge of life,\u201d Mr. Hestrin said.\n\nMr. Hestrin also recounted how the children were allowed to bathe only once a year \u2014 if they washed their arms above their wrists, they were accused of \u201cplaying in water\u201d and chained to their beds as punishment, Mr. Hestrin said.\n\n\u201cThe victims were often not released from their chains to go to the bathroom,\u201d he said.\n\nBefore Sunday, neither law enforcement nor child protective services had any contact with the Turpin family. The couple hid the abuse in part by registering the residence as a private school, which prevented government officials from ever coming into contact with the children, the authorities said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut it had been going on for years. Before coming to California, the family lived in Fort Worth, Tex., where, Mr. Hestrin said, the parents used rope and \u201chogtied\u201d the children. When one escaped, they began using chains and padlocks, he said. The most intensive abuse, he said, appeared to be targeting the oldest children, who were also \u201cfed very little on a strict schedule.\u201d There was \u201cfrequent beating and even strangulation,\u201d he added.\n\n\u201cWhat started off as neglect became severe, pervasive, prolonged abuse,\u201d Mr. Hestrin said.\n\nHe pleaded with anyone who knew the family to contact his office.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cSomeone must have seen something, someone must have noticed something,\u201d Mr. Hestrin said. \u201cWe need your help.\u201d\n\nWhile several neighbors have said they thought of the family as clannish and reclusive, they were never worried enough to call the police.\n\nRoberto Gomez, 45, who lives in the house behind the Turpins, said on Tuesday that the family appeared to leave lights on 24 hours a day and seemed to be more active at night. But neither Mr. Gomez, nor his son, ever saw the people who lived there, which struck them as strange in a neighborhood where families are often outside.\n\n\u201cI thought they were doing something like drugs,\u201d the elder Mr. Gomez said. \u201cBut I never, ever expected there to be 13 kids back there.\u201d\n\nKimberly Milligan, who moved to the neighborhood two and half years ago, said on Thursday that she rarely saw the children.\n\n\u201cI would say, are we sure 13 kids live there? Because it just doesn\u2019t make sense,\u201d she said in a phone interview.\n\nOne recent night, Ms. Milligan said, she and her son were outside, and her son suddenly asked, \u201cWhat is he doing in the trash can?\u201d It was one of the Turpins\u2019 three sons, she said. She did not think much of it at the time. But now, based on conversations with neighbors who saw similar episodes, she thinks the boy may have been rummaging for food.\n\nMr. Turpin appeared to be employed and earning a regular income, Mr. Hestrin said. He and his wife ate well. The police found several toys scattered through the four-bedroom home, but they were all unopened. The only thing the children were permitted to do was to write in journals \u2014 the authorities found hundreds of them in the home.", "title": "California Girl\u2019s Escape From \u2018Human Depravity\u2019 Led to Rescue of 12 Siblings", "authors": ["Jennifer Medina"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Why do the researcher say we\u2019ve never seen this before in California?\n\nMark A. Finney, an expert in fire behavior for the U.S. Forest Service and an author of the study, says California forests are much more vulnerable now because, paradoxically, they have been better protected. In their natural state, forests were regularly thinned by fire but the billions of dollars that the state spends aggressively fighting wildfires and restrictions on logging have allowed forests to accumulate an overload of vegetation.\n\n\u201cWe had forests that were very resilient to weather variations and insect disturbances in the past \u2014 maintained by frequent fire on the order of every year, or every few years at the most,\u201d Mr. Finney said. By putting out fires, \u201cwe\u2019ve changed completely the fire component of these ecosystems,\u201d he said.\n\nHow might the dead-tree forests affect California? One of the most striking concerns is the damage the fires might do to watersheds. Intense, hot-burning fires could disrupt forests\u2019 ability to channel water into the Sierra reservoirs that provide cities like San Francisco with drinking water. That\u2019s a scenario that could nudge the state into rethinking its forest management.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: 100 Million Dead Trees Prompt Fears of Giant Wildfires", "authors": ["Thomas Fuller", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nIf history is any guide, the State of the State speech Gov. Jerry Brown will deliver in Sacramento on Thursday \u2014 his last one \u2014 won\u2019t be very long. It probably won\u2019t be overly sentimental. And it will probably include a tribute to his home state.\n\nBut here are a few things we will be listening for:\n\n1. How much will he talk about perhaps his biggest bit of unfinished business \u2014 the bullet train, plagued by cost overruns and delays? Mr. Brown\u2019s strategy is to keep building, hoping to buy time until a (presumably) sympathetic Democratic administration takes office. His real audience on Thursday, should he use the moment, will be the next governor, whose support will be crucial.\n\n2. This will be one of the final opportunities for the famously frugal governor to return to a favorite topic: warning lawmakers and his successor against excessive spending, particularly if a recession is coming.\n\n3. Will Mr. Brown use his platform to push for reforms in California\u2019s notoriously dysfunctional tax system, hamstrung by Proposition 13 and a heavy reliance on volatile capital gains tax revenues? (Don\u2019t bet on it).", "title": "California Today: A Final State of the State From Jerry Brown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Q. You\u2019ve spent a lot of your career focusing on and writing about Latino issues. Are you going to continue to do so?\n\nA. Latinos are a huge part of California, so of course I am going to write about them. But it will not be the only thing. \u201cAsk a Mexican\u201d is over. I don\u2019t like replicating myself. My beat is going to be California. I like challenges and feel like, \u201cLet\u2019s see if I can pull this off.\u201d If I can\u2019t, at least I tried.\n\nQ. Were you surprised about the backlash, with people calling you racist and homophobic?\n\nA. No, there have been people who have been targeting me for a while. There\u2019s always going to be people who don\u2019t like what you write. If you don\u2019t have haters you are not doing your job correctly. The people accusing me of being racist, they don\u2019t take my career in perspective. We covered these communities better than anyone else in Orange County. What seems to be the issue right now, is that in this country if you don\u2019t have the same thoughts as other people you are immediately marked as the enemy. I\u2019ve always been about throwing stories out there, and I\u2019ll defend them.\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Last year, the fights were largely rhetorical. But 2018 has brought a full-fledged fight between the conservative Trump administration and liberal California \u2014 over issues like immigration, the environment and marijuana. So few knew what to expect on Jan. 8, 1966, when the Grateful Dead took the stage at the Fillmore Auditorium in San Francisco. The band had only recently changed its name from the Warlocks and had nowhere near the notoriety it soon would achieve.\n\nThe show is now the earliest fan-recording of the band, which relied largely on such recordings and word of mouth to gain popularity. The recording includes nearly as much banter as it does music and gives a glimpse into the wild-eyed commotion of the day. In the words of Jerry Garcia: \u201cIn the end, it\u2019s nothing but mindless chaos.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. [The New York Times]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Hollywood Farmers\u2019 Market is one of the most popular in Los Angeles: Every Sunday, dozens of farmers drive in from across Southern California to set up stands along a two-block stretch of Ivar Avenue.\n\nOn any given Sunday, there is an abundant selection of strawberries, flowers, lettuce, avocados and vegetables. Although this is what is known as \u201cwinter\u201d in Los Angeles, the market is always crowded with people and produce, and is a big source of revenue for many farmers.\n\nThis past Sunday, the market offered another way to measure the disruption caused by the mudflows in Montecito: Empty spaces. The closing of two miles of the 101, because of mud and debris, blocked farmers north of Los Angeles from driving their wares to market. Among the farmers who were unable to get there were Tutti Frutti Farms and The Garden Of\u2026.\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nBrian P. Kelly, the head of California\u2019s State Transportation Agency, was appointed this week to run the state\u2019s High-Speed Rail Authority, the organization charged with overseeing construction of what would be America\u2019s first high-speed train system. This week a consultant to the authority reported that the cost of the first segment under construction, a 119-mile span in the Central Valley, has risen to $84 million per mile from $66 million per mile. Mr. Kelly spoke to us on Wednesday. (Our chat has been edited and condensed below.)\n\nQ. You\u2019re going from what appeared to be a secure and prominent role at the State Transportation Agency to the head of an organization that faces a lot skepticism from the general public and fierce opposition from Republicans. Why did you take the job?\n\nA. In 23 years of doing transportation policy in California I have never seen a single project that would have such a transformative impact as this one. You are right. This project has mammoth opposition. I\u2019d rather get in the fight than stand on the sidelines.\n\nQ. The High-Speed Rail Authority was established 23 years ago. During that time China has built 16,000 miles of high-speed rail. We are still working on the first 119 miles. Smith, a Santa Rosa real estate agent.\n\nLast month the neighbors put up for sale all that remains of their property \u2014 blackened dirt \u2014 for $199,000 and are in negotiations with a buyer.\n\n\u201cIt was a beautiful house, a two-car garage, a nice backyard,\u201d Mr. Smith said. \u201cThey had done a lot of remodeling.\u201d\n\nThe owners studied what it would take to rebuild the house and decided to take the insurance money, cut their losses and move out of town, Mr. Smith said.\n\n\u201cThey are going to take their money and run,\u201d he said.\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The Trump administration is requesting that the 2020 census include questions about immigration status. The declaration means that the federal government may cover 75 percent of firefighting costs, which approached $200 million. The federal government may also cover costs of recovering from the blaze, including the removal of vast amounts of debris in fire-denuded areas. McCarthy, an armament expert for the U.S. War Department, lived in San Francisco during the first half of the 20th century. An avid and able photographer, Mr. McCarthy documented his travels around California with his wife, Grace. The result is a collection of photographs that give us a remarkably diverse record of the key moments in the state\u2019s history \u2014 the devastation of the Great Fire in San Francisco after the 1906 earthquake; the construction of the Golden Gate Bridge \u2014 and historical street views of Los Angeles, Yosemite and the Mexican border, among many other places. The collection, preserved by the California State Archives, is available here. Here\u2019s a small sampling:\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Taco]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nIts exact origins are debated, but one historian traced it back to the silver mines of 18th century Mexico.\n\nAnother researcher argued that it spread across America as a \u201cform of exoticism\u201d springing from \u201cwithin the segregated landscape of 1950s Los Angeles.\u201d\n\nWe are talking, of course, about the taco. And if the theory that California, with its large Latino population, represents the future demographics of America is correct, then the taco is likely to continue to undergo reinvention in this country for a long time to come. Although perhaps not as inventively as in California, where varieties proliferate, and different cuisines collide to create new takes on an old staple. (One famous example is the Los Angeles chef Roy Choi and his \u201cKorean Mexican taco movement.\u201d)\n\nIt\u2019s even a subject of academic study, the history and meaning of the taco, with classes just having started in the spring semester for the course, \u201cTaco Literacy,\u201d at St. John\u2019s University in New York.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut to capture the current state-of-play in the world of tacos, Daily Meal has published its list of the best tacos in each of the 50 states. And No. 1 in California is the carnitas taco at La Taqueria, in San Francisco.\n\nAnd being the best in California, means being No. 1 in the nation: La Taqueria topped an earlier list of best tacos in the country.\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nRescue crews on Thursday continued digging through the muddy aftermath of devastating mudslides in Montecito, Calif., where dislodged boulders, fallen trees and thrashed vehicles were still strewn across the landscape.\n\nThe scale of the wreckage was staggering: about 100 homes were completely destroyed and another 300 were badly damaged. Seventeen people have been declared dead. And crews continued searching for more than 40 people who had been unaccounted for or declared missing by their families.\n\nJosie Gower was one of the victims.\n\nJust before 3 a.m. on Tuesday morning, she and her boyfriend heard a loud noise downstairs in their home. They went to investigate. When she opened the back door, Ms. Gower was sucked out of her house by the mud, which overpowered her grip on the doorframe.\n\n[Read The Times\u2019 full story about the victims here.]\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t make sense. I kept thinking the worst case would be a few inches of flooding,\u201d her son, Hayden Gower, said. \u201cI keep thinking over and over about what we could have done different. Why did she go down there then? What could have stopped her from dying this way? It\u2019s too hard to imagine.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). [The Sacramento Bee]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nMonica Ramirez, an activist and lawyer, said she never expected to one day walk the red carpet at the Golden Globes alongside Hollywood\u2019s brightest stars. Her fight for Hispanic farmworkers, and in particular women in those jobs who face harassment, isn\u2019t the clearest path to a celebrity awards ceremony.\n\nBut the #MeToo moment has formed new friendships and alliances, between powerful actresses seizing the moment and empowered activists who have given decades of their lives to fight for change.\n\nMs. Ramirez, who accompanied the actress Laura Dern, began working on behalf of women farmworkers decades ago, first in college and then later as a lawyer; she co-founded and is president of the Alianza Nacional de Campesinas. She praised Ms. Dern and others for using their platform to shine a light on women\u2019s advocacy across industries.\n\n\u201cIt was an incredible and very powerful experience. That was a lot of love in the room, on the red carpet, for our community, for what we represent,\u201d Ms. Ramirez said. \u201cBut this is not just one moment that happened on the red carpet. It\u2019s a movement that\u2019s built on the work we\u2019ve been doing for decades in this country.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Shrug.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEvery day we think about what happened in 2005,\u201d Mr. Bell said on Tuesday. \u201cWe know what Montecito is going through because we lived through exactly the same thing. It was a mud flow, it was rapid-moving, it buried people.\u201d\n\nA number of articles have been published recently about people pondering the wisdom of living in California, fire-prone and seismically volatile as it is, not to mention bank-account-emptying expensive.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhen heavy rain comes, Mr. Bell plows mud flows off the streets with the town\u2019s tractor the way Americans farther north do with snow.\n\nI asked him if he had a message for the grieving residents of Montecito.\n\n\u201cWork together as a community, as a team,\u201d he said.\n\nBut the words of a 2005 United States Geological Survey report on La Conchita are equally apt.\n\n\u201cThis was not the first destructive landslide to damage this community,\u201d the report said, \u201cnor is it likely to be the last.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story California Today The news and stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state). Regulators are telling the utilities to pass on those savings to their customers. [San Francisco Chronicle]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Geologists and officials in Santa Barbara say it is still too early to know precisely how and why last week\u2019s mudslides became so lethal. But they are already studying satellite imagery to help determine the path of the deadly debris, in the hopes that understanding what happened will prevent similar calamities in the future. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Some insurers required people who lost their homes to the recent wildfires to compile a list of all their destroyed belongings, a tedious and often traumatic process. A bill in the State Legislature would automatically provide policy holders with 80 percent of their contents coverage if a state of emergency is declared. It\u2019s one of a number of proposed insurance reforms related to disaster coverage. [The Press Democrat]\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The discovery of 13 emaciated siblings this week in Perris brings new scrutiny to home schooling in California, where almost anyone can open a private school by filing an affidavit with the state. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The backyard shed gets an upgrade: Bay Area homeowners are taking advantage of changing laws and an intense demand for housing by building, and renting out, small dwellings known as granny flats or in-law units in their backyards, converted basements or garages. [Mercury News]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nOn New Year\u2019s Day, when California began legal sales of recreational marijuana, the cannabis map of America looked decidedly lopsided. The entire West Coast plus Nevada and Colorado had gone green. The East Coast? Only Massachusetts and possibly Maine are on track to allow recreational sales this year.\n\nBut there were signs on Tuesday that the scales might eventually even out a bit. Gov. Phil Murphy of New Jersey, who was sworn in on Tuesday, repeated his promise to legalize cannabis. \u201cA stronger and fairer New Jersey embraces comprehensive criminal justice reform comprehensively, and that includes a process to legalize marijuana,\u201d he said.\n\nIn New York, Gov. Andrew Cuomo, outlined his budget priorities, saying he would fund a study of a \u201cregulated marijuana program.\u201d\n\nWhere does that leave us? According to one theory, the rest of the country lags California politically by around 15 years. So set your watch for 2033.\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Berkeley.", "title": "California Today: Lessons From Montecito\u2019s Neighbor", "authors": ["Thomas Fuller", "California Today"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Chief Beck was essentially a rookie when Daryl F. Gates \u2014 a hard-liner with an aggressive approach to law enforcement \u2014 took over the department decades ago; he was a sergeant during the riots that burned the city in 1992 and forced Chief Gates\u2019s resignation; and he was chief when the once-beleaguered department got out from under a consent decree that had been aimed at battling corruption in one of the department\u2019s divisions.\n\n\u201cMy goal has always been to not only restore the city\u2019s faith in its police department, but to restore the police department\u2019s faith in itself,\u201d Chief Beck said. \u201cAnd I think I\u2019ve been a big part of doing that.\u201d\n\nAs the leader of one of the nation\u2019s largest police departments, Chief Beck has had to contend with crippling budget cuts, a deadly, days-long rampage by a former officer who targeted the police and their families, and heavy, sustained criticism of police shootings.\n\nPerhaps more than anything, though, Chief Beck has had to keep the Police Department on the path of reform as it tries to escape the shadow of its checkered past and regain the community\u2019s trust.\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s been inside the department for 42 years,\u201d Steve Soboroff, the president of the Los Angeles Police Commission, said of Chief Beck. \u201cIf you\u2019re a reformer over that period of time that means you have to change because policing has changed \u2014 and he has.\u201d\n\n\u201cWill you find 200 people wearing T-shirts that say \u2018Fire Charlie Beck\u2019? Sure,\u201d Mr. Soboroff added. \u201cBut I\u2019ll show you 3.8 million people who think he\u2019s done a heck of a job.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Online\n\n(Please note: We regularly highlight articles on news sites that have limited access for nonsubscribers.)\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Janet Napolitano, the University of California president, is considering a sweeping overhaul of her office, which has been sharply criticized for being too big and too costly to operate. [The New York Times]\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nBeing a San Diego sports fan is not easy.\n\nThe Clippers left long ago. The Padres have not made the playoffs in more than a decade. And the Chargers bolted for Los Angeles last year.\n\nSo it\u2019s with a combination of joy and relief that Padres fans are celebrating some good news: Their lights-out closer, Trevor Hoffman, was recently voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame; he will be just the third player to enter wearing a Padres cap, joining Tony Gwynn and Dave Winfield.\n\nHoffman helped the Padres win the National League pennant in 1998 \u2014 something that has happened only one other time in the franchise\u2019s history. With a changeup that left hitters flailing, he became the first pitcher to reach 600 saves and retired in 2010 as the career saves leader.\n\nHoffman\u2019s dramatic entrances to AC/DC\u2019s \u201cHells Bells\u201d routinely sent excited shivers through the stands; as he would jog in from the bullpen, screens would flash \u201cTREVOR TIME.\u201d\n\n\u201cTo give joy to the city, knowing that I\u2019ve been backed by so many, so well, for so long, there\u2019s a lot of pride there,\u201d Hoffman said at a news conference last week. \u201cI think people are going to be able to stick their chest out a little bit, and say, \u2018He\u2019s one of ours.\u2019\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. What direction has Yosemite been heading in recent years?\u201d reads the Change.org petition. \u201cWhere will this development take the trend? When will it stop?\u201d\n\nNot so fast, says the Aramark corporation, which posted the job listing that sparked the angst.\n\nThe company is the park\u2019s primary concessionaire. Aramark said it is making Starbucks available in the existing Yosemite Valley Lodge as part of an effort to \u201cupgrade\u201d the food offerings with familiar products. An Aramark spokesperson assured that \u201cno new structures or free-standing stores are being built as part of this renovation,\u201d which appears to be the petition\u2019s central concern.\n\nBy Monday evening, more than 10,000 individuals had signed the petition, which was created by anonymous user named \u201cConcerned Citizen.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays. Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nOn his first day as the new editor in chief of the Los Angeles Times, Jim Kirk held a meeting. His newsroom had suffered through several months of turmoil \u2014 and staff members had many questions.\n\nOne of the most poignant came from a columnist, Robin Abcarian: Had Mr. Kirk ever been a defendant in a sexual harassment lawsuit?\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d he replied, which Ms. Abcarian said prompted a round of applause.\n\nHer question, Ms. Abcarian said in a telephone interview on Tuesday, was an earnest one. It came less than two weeks after Ross Levinsohn, who was named The Times\u2019s publisher in August, was put on leave after a National Public Radio article detailed sexual harassment allegations made against him while he worked at other companies. (The New York Times reported this week that Tronc \u2014 the parent company of the Los Angeles Times \u2014 vetted Mr. Levinsohn before he was hired, but the company was not aware that he had twice been a defendant in sexual harassment lawsuits.)\n\nMr. Kirk, who had recently served as the interim executive editor of the Los Angeles Times, replaced Lewis D\u2019Vorkin.", "title": "California Today: The Los Angeles Times Has (Another) New Editor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nAcross Los Angeles, they sleep in tents, under tarps or out in the open air, and their numbers are growing. Last year the population of homeless people on the streets of Los Angeles increased 23 percent, and officials believe the numbers have continued to rise.\n\nThis week the city will start to find out just how much.\n\nStarting Tuesday night in the San Fernando, Santa Clarita and San Gabriel Valleys, thousands of volunteers fanned out to neighborhoods to count the homeless, an annual three-day exercise that in recent years has confirmed an alarming crisis in Los Angeles County.\n\nThe count, along with demographic surveys, will help policymakers decide how to spend public money: $355 million per year raised by Los Angeles county from a special sales tax, and a $1.2 billion city bond issue to build housing for the homeless.\n\nOnce mostly associated with Skid Row, the vast tent encampment in downtown Los Angeles, the homeless are now spread out across the city, setting up tents under highway overpasses and moving into affluent neighborhoods like Bel-Air, where a wildfire that threatened the area\u2019s mega-mansions was sparked last year by a cooking fire at a homeless encampment.", "title": "California Today: Thousands of Volunteers Count the Homeless in Los Angeles", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nLast weekend, as the federal government was shutting down amid partisan squabbles over immigration, President Trump\u2019s re-election campaign released an ad featuring an undocumented immigrant from Mexico accused of murdering two Sacramento police officers.\n\nDemocrats, the ad stated, are \u201ccomplicit in every murder committed by illegal immigrants.\u201d\n\nOn the same day, a group of California Republicans put out their own ad about immigration. It featured the sunny disposition of Ronald Reagan, and words he spoke form the Oval Office in 1989, as he prepared to leave office. In the address, President Reagan defined what he meant when described, as he often did, America as a \u201cshining city.\u201d\n\nIt is a country, he said, \u201cteeming with people of all kinds living in harmony and peace.\u201d\n\nThe contrasting tone of the two ads \u2014 one dark and ominous, the other bright and optimistic \u2014 say a lot about the divergence between the national Republican Party and the party in California. In California, the party is fighting for relevance in a state whose diversity \u2014 Latinos are a plurality in the state \u2014 and progressive values have placed it at the forefront of opposition to the Trump administration.\n\n\u201cIn California we have a problem,\u201d said Chad Mayes, a former Republican leader in the California State Assembly, who was pushed out of his leadership position last year after a backlash within his party because he negotiated with Democrats on climate change.", "title": "California Today: Two Immigration Ads, One Dark, the Other Sunny", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning.\n\n(Want to get California Today by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nMudslides wreaked havoc in Southern California Tuesday amid intense rainfall across the state, demolishing homes in Santa Barbara County and killing at least 15 people. Just weeks ago, many of those areas hardest hit by mudslides were battling wildfires.\n\nFirefighters waded through debris, over piles of fallen trees and around displaced boulders in the aftermath of the storm, scouring for survivors after several homes were swept away. In one dramatic rescue, the Santa Barbara fire department pulled a 14-year-old girl from the remains of her destroyed home in Montecito. In another instance, a boy was found under a freeway overpass and rescued by firefighters; mud had carried him for hundreds of yards.\n\n[Follow The Times\u2019 reporting here.]\n\nAs rain pounded down, parts of the 101 Freeway were flooded by water from the overflowing Montecito Creek.\n\n\u201cThis is not a river. See a full listing here.\n\n\u2022 The California Historical Society in San Francisco is hosting a screening of an episode of \u201cLost L.A.\u201d this Wednesday that explores the state\u2019s colonial history. The screening will be followed by remarks and a question-and-answer session with the show\u2019s host and producer, Nathan Masters.\n\n\u2022 A new exhibit showcasing work by Rico Lebrun opens this week at Jack Rutberg Fine Arts in Los Angeles. The exhibit focuses on his impact on Mexican art and artists.\n\n\u2022 The Professional Bull Riders Invitational in Sacramento kicks off this Friday, and runs until Sunday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Finally ...\n\nPhoto\n\nA new study released last week brings some bitter clarity to an old mystery as California suffers one of the worst flu seasons on record: The flu can be transmitted simply by breathing, according to a team of researchers that included Sheryl Ehrman, an expert in aerosol science and droplets and the dean of engineering at San Jose State University.\n\nResearchers invited students at the University of Maryland who were suffering from cold symptoms to breathe normally into a cone. Nearly 40 percent of the samples they collected had infectious virus.\n\n\u201cThe findings suggest that if you just keep the surfaces around you clean and you wash your hands all the time and you avoid having people cough on you \u2014 that may not provide you complete protection,\u201d Professor Ehrman said in an interview.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s really important for people who are sick to stay home,\u201d Professor Ehrman said. \u201cIf they are really sick they should go to the hospital. Please don\u2019t come to work. Please don\u2019t get on public transportation. Please don\u2019t go to the grocery store.\u201d\n\nCalifornia Today goes live at 6 a.m. Pacific time weekdays.
