President Trump, meeting with lawmakers on immigration, said he\u2019d like to see immigrants from Norway, not \u201cshithole countries\u201d like Haiti.\n\nElsewhere in Washington, the House voted against restricting a surveillance program that permits the government to collect, without a warrant, the emails and other communications of foreigners abroad \u2014 even when they are talking to Americans. The vote was a victory for the intelligence community and the Trump administration.\n\nThere was some bad news for the White House too: Mr. Trump\u2019s approval rating has fallen across a range of demographic groups, including among white voters, evangelical Christians and rural Americans.", "title": "California, Walmart, Eric Greitens: Your Thursday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSATURDAY PUZZLE \u2014 We welcome back Mark Diehl, who offers us the kind of Saturday that gets your hopes up with a very doable northwest and southeast, and then breaks your heart with the rest of the puzzle. Especially that center, staggered stack.\n\nThere are a few easy ways to start this puzzle. My first gimme was SHANIA Twain, because the entry is six letters, so a \u201cTwain of note\u201d can\u2019t be Mark, and SHANIA is the only other noted Twain I know. From there, the rest of the southeast wasn\u2019t too hard: I salted in JOB for \u201cLinkedIn listing,\u201d JANEANE Garofalo (although I had to think about the spelling of her name), BLADES for the barbershop and FM STEREO for that high quality radio sound.\n\nUp in the northwest, we know that St. Patrick\u2019s Day is celebrated in MID-MARCH, yes? Somewhere in the recesses of my brain I remembered that home runs are sometimes called DINGERS. We traveled back in time to call our pal an ACE, and we remembered the spooky visual of the CROW in Hitchcock\u2019s \u201cThe Birds.\u201d\n\nSo, now that you\u2019re in, what did you think?\n\nMr. Diehl introduces 11 entries to The New York Times Crossword, and I liked TRASHMOUTH (although I had not heard the term; I\u2019ve heard \u201cpotty mouth\u201d and \u201ctrash talker\u201d), CLAM JUICE, BLOODBORNE, ERRATA PAGE, TEAM EVENTS and STEADY DIET.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat made this one tricky for me were some of the general knowledge required and some of the clues, which seemed a bit off once I solved them. Maybe it was a case of my overthinking things, and I\u2019ll get into that in the next section.", "title": "Call of the Wild", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": For many of the capital\u2019s largest projects, Chinese are now viewed as the target market.\n\n\u201cHistorically, Chinese investment in Cambodia has mainly been in infrastructure,\u201d Ross Wheble, the country manager for Cambodia for the real estate consultant Knight Frank, said in an email. \u201cIt is only within the past 18 months that we have started to see the entry of Chinese developers and individual investors.\u201d\n\nThis year is going to be a big one in terms of high-end residential property coming on line, Mr. Wheble said.", "title": "Cambodia Finds New Target for Real Estate: Chinese Investors", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The girl group Fifth Harmony has made three albums, none of which has risen higher on the Billboard chart than No. 4. Those charges were not previously made public.\n\nThe federal information describes Mr. Singh\u2019s negotiations with an unnamed New York City agency to renew a lease for one of his businesses. The details in the indictment match Mr. Singh\u2019s efforts to renew a lease with the Department of Citywide Administrative Services for his Water\u2019s Edge restaurant, which operated on city property in Queens.\n\nMr. Singh started raising campaign contributions for the unnamed official in 2010, ultimately raising tens of thousands of dollars, according to the records. Mr. Singh was one of the earliest large donors when Mr. de Blasio began his mayoral campaign in 2010, and he, his family members and other associates ultimately raised a total of about $33,000 for the mayor.\n\nThe information also refers to several actions by Mr. Singh and city officials that contributed to the conspiracy. It refers to an Oct. 12, 2013, fund-raiser that Mr. Singh hosted at his restaurant. On that date, campaign finance filings indicate, the de Blasio campaign held a fund-raising event at Water\u2019s Edge.\n\nIn December 2014, Mr. Singh sent an email to an aide to \u201cOfficial #2\u201d \u2014 the mayor \u2014 saying that he needed help with the agency involved in his lease renewal, according to the unsealed documents.", "title": "Campaign Donor Pleaded Guilty to Trying to Bribe Mayor de Blasio", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Health care is a business that requires a lot of regulatory compliance and negotiation with established players. A new entrant could bring innovative approaches to old problems, but it may also become stymied by the industry\u2019s complexity. The entrepreneurs who launched Oscar Health, one of the insurance start-ups to sell policies under the Affordable Care Act, wanted to create something radically different from the competition. But it has had a difficult time living up its initial hopes and has lost substantial sums in what has proved to be a very challenging business.\n\nClassic disruption rarely applies in health care\n\nMost disruptive companies enter a market with a product that is lower in value than that of market incumbents, but much lower in cost. That\u2019s the model for classic disrupters, like Southwest Airlines, MP3s or Japanese carmakers. Health care tends to be different, because consumers don\u2019t usually want to settle for a lower-quality product, even if it is substantially cheaper.\n\nAmitabh Chandra, a health economist at Harvard, said that perhaps the easiest way to squeeze a lot of dollars out of the health care system would be to reduce what he called \u201clow-value services\u201d \u2014 health care treatments that are expensive, but only slightly more effective than cheaper options.\n\nBut reducing their use is hard because many people still want the better therapy, even if it\u2019s not a particularly good value. Highly compensated employees, like those at Chase or at Amazon headquarters, may be particularly attracted to cutting-edge cancer treatments or the latest prescription drugs, he noted. A health plan that cut out such services might hurt the ability to recruit and retain workers needed to succeed in other parts of the business.\n\n\u201cIf there was pure inefficiency, I think it would be a lot easier to make progress,\u201d he said. \u201cThe problem is that all of this stuff has some small benefit.\u201d\n\nThere are some ways that a smart company might seek to wring real inefficiencies out of health care. It could, say, lower the prices paid to monopoly hospitals, eliminate services that have no value or tighten the supply chain for drugs. Optimists about the venture say, if the company succeeds, it will most likely do so by finding strategies that improve care and reduce cost.\n\nThese are really different companies, with different priorities\n\nThe three companies are each large but also very different, and they may have different priorities about how to structure their health benefits.", "title": "Can Amazon and Friends Handle Health Care? There\u2019s Reason for Doubt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The stronger first act plays out during a church service at which Lauren attempts to voice her concerns. The parishioners sing a few bars of \u201cWe Shall Not Be Moved.\u201d Lauren\u2019s mordant response: \u201cWe\u2019ll be moved, all right. It\u2019s just a matter of when, by whom, and in how many pieces.\u201d\n\nMs. Reagon leans into the microphone to say that she never liked that part of the book. But she and her mother have movement on their minds. They want to prod us, prompt us, push us out onto the sidewalk ready to take action. Less a straightforward adaptation than a passionate dialogue with the novel, this \u201cParable of the Sower\u201d uses its plot to warn against what will happen if we don\u2019t stand up. As Butler said of her novel, \u201cIf it\u2019s true, if it\u2019s anywhere near true, we\u2019re all in trouble.\u201d\n\nIn the show\u2019s highlight, \u201cDon\u2019t Let Your Baby Go to Olivar,\u201d Ms. Reagon sings about how easily complacency might tip us into a world like the novel\u2019s. And she makes us sing with her. (To my fellow ticketholders: I\u2019m sorry. And nice harmonies!) The song concludes in a chant: \u201cFight, fight, strategize/ Say it together: Equal rights.\u201d Maybe this sounds corny. Maybe it is. But in that theater, it felt vital, even sacred. If you want to change the world, convincing a few hundred people to voice your call isn\u2019t a bad place to start.\n\nWhere to start with \u201cPursuit of Happiness,\u201d a spaghetti Western with extra sauce that climaxes in a shaggy dog story so hirsute it will upset pet groomers everywhere.\n\nThe set is a minimalist saloon dotted with old-timey signifiers \u2014 a bleached skull, a rifle, a couple of wanted posters. Various cowboys and cowgirls with blacked eyes and lousy dentistry mosey up to the bar to drink and fight and discourse on human misery. \u201cI began to feel ashamed of making art. It\u2019s a pastime, totally unnecessary, useless,\u201d one cowpoke wails.\n\nPhoto\n\nFreighting everyday conversation with life-or-death importance has always been the style of Nature Theater of Oklahoma, a company best-known for its ambitious 10-part project, \u201cLife and Times,\u201d which started with an astounding bang and fizzled to a multimedia whimper.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt first, \u201cPursuit of Happiness,\u201d created by Pavol Liska and Kelly Copper, seems like more of the same, with declamatory speech and antic choreography underlying each throwaway line. The six terrific performers are from EnKnapGroup, a Slovenian dance company with a Pan-European core, so a lot of the comedy comes from watching a foreign troupe deconstruct a beloved genre, but it also comes from hearing them mangle American idioms in terrible oater accents. (Supertitles are needed and supplied.) They\u2019re in on the joke, but the joke is also on them, which can feel ugly.\n\nAt least until Bence Mezei, dressed in a mariachi suit, steps out from behind the whiskey-soaked bar and begins an outlandish, Burroughs-esque monologue about how he and the troupe decided to bring their unique form of modern dance to an insurgent zone somewhere outside of Baghdad. Drunk on missionary zeal and military grade Red Bull, the dancers re-enact an absurd swing-yer-partner performance that just might bring peace to the Middle East. Or get everyone killed.\n\nThe surreal story is weird and gross and dumb. It\u2019s inappropriately sexual and way, way, way too long. It is also hilarious and one of the wildest things you\u2019ll see at the theater this year. \u201cPursuit of Happiness\u201d won\u2019t change the world. It will change your night.", "title": "Can Art Change the World? With Song, Dance and Cowboy Clich\u00e9s Two Shows Offer Different Answers", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "A third reason offered for affirmative action is to make sure that all the major social groups and points of view are represented in the academic community. The idea here is both that we can learn from one another and that we want educated people in all the social groups. This could be a reason for wanting more people with autism. They could be rare enough that we need to oversample them (assuming we aren\u2019t already doing so).\n\nSo while I\u2019m not finding a strong case for affirmative action for academics on the autism spectrum, I can see a weak one. In the present political climate, though, I doubt that a category of this kind is likely to gain practical support. I don\u2019t know whether you would help your employment prospects by announcing yourself as someone with autism-spectrum disorder (presumably after receiving a formal diagnosis), but under the Americans With Disabilities Act, it would be illegal to discriminate on that basis.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI have a 40-year-old son who is severely autistic; he has limited verbal ability and the mentality of a 4-year-old. He has never voted. But because so many of the issues contested in elections affect him, would it be ethical to request an absentee ballot and cast votes for those people and programs that most benefit him? My wife thinks it\u2019s a bad idea, but I believe it would give him a voice, however small, in his future. Name Withheld\n\nIn a typical election, the outcome isn\u2019t going to depend on one vote. What you\u2019re doing in voting, then, is expressing your individual preference. A vote taken on behalf of someone else \u2014 someone who has interests, for sure, but doesn\u2019t actually have a preference \u2014 doesn\u2019t serve that function. What you\u2019re proposing isn\u2019t to give your son a voice; it\u2019s to give yourself two.\n\nA colleague of mine is running for public office. I think he would do a fantastic job, but given the current political climate, I think he has no chance of winning. I\u2019ve been asked to donate to his campaign, but I\u2019m reluctant to do so because I feel I\u2019d be throwing my money away and making it more likely that my party loses the election. I would rather donate to an inferior candidate who might win. Some friends have argued that it\u2019s unethical for me to donate to a candidate I think would do a worse job. They also argue that my view contributes to the dysfunction in our electoral system. Do I have an obligation to support the candidate I think is best, even if I\u2019m convinced he\u2019ll lose? Name Withheld\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGiving money to a campaign is, like voting, an expressive act. Like voting, it isn\u2019t going to change the outcome, although, also like voting, it\u2019s a contribution to the outcome; your money, like your vote, will be a part of the campaign\u2019s success or failure. So the key question is what your political aim is. Is it to gain a seat with the best candidate your party can win with, or is it to lose nobly? If those are the options, you can reasonably express your support for a strategy that would minimize the chances of the worst outcome. It sounds as if your friends simply disagree with your assessments of the probabilities, but you\u2019re not obligated to defer to their judgment. You certainly don\u2019t have an obligation to support a candidate without regard to her prospects; otherwise, you could write in the name of that marvelous political-science professor you had in freshman year, knowing that she will end up with one lambent, heartfelt vote. In our very divided country, it clearly makes a difference which party has more people in office.", "title": "Can Autism Make Me a Diversity Hire?", "authors": ["Kwame Anthony Appiah", "The Ethicist"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThat to me is more about internet bullying than freedom of expression,\u201d said Mr. Hope, who said he had been offended to be cast as an enemy of free speech, given that his father, Christopher Hope, had been forced to leave South Africa because of his anti-apartheid writings, which he said were banned for years.\n\nMr. Hope said that he was satisfied that the video had been taken down, and that he had asked his lawyers to stop further legal proceedings. He acknowledged sending the video to the head of the Konzerthaus, but said that he had not asked them to take Mr. L\u00fccker\u2019s work away next season. (A spokesman for the Konzerthaus did not respond to an email seeking comment.)\n\nA lawyer for Mr. L\u00fccker, Roman Ronneburger, said in an email that the video had been intended as \u201ca satirical and funny joke,\u201d aimed not only at Mr. Hope but at the musician he was playing with in the video, Ludovico Einaudi, a pianist and composer. He said that Mr. L\u00fccker had been informed that the program he has presented at the Konzerthaus since 2011 would not be renewed as a result of the video.\n\nThe shred is no longer available. Van, which viewed it, described it as \u201cgenuinely funny, if you can stomach the average American stand-up comedy routine\u201d and noted that the words of Mr. Hope\u2019s concert introduction had been substituted with \u201cprecisely timed poop jokes and masturbation gags.\u201d\n\nIn the absence of the Hope shred, here are some older, more strictly musical shreds:\n\nThis one notes that it is \u201cdefinitely NOT the life-affirming and glorious sound of The Mormon Tabernacle Choir\u201d:", "title": "Can Classical Music Take a Joke? A Violinist Is Shredded", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "So what\u2019s Israel\u2019s strategy to keep its conflict with Hezbollah and Iran on a low flame? First and foremost, it\u2019s been to reinforce to Hezbollah and Iran, through many channels, that they can\u2019t out-crazy Israel. That is, if Hezbollah and Iran think they can place rocket launchers in densely populated Lebanese and Syrian villages and towns \u2014 and expect that Israel will not take them out if it requires large collateral civilian casualties \u2014 they are as wrong today as they were in 2006.\n\nIsraeli military planners are more convinced than ever that the key reason Hezbollah has avoided major conflict with Israel since the big Israel-Hezbollah war in Lebanon in 2006 is that Israel\u2019s Air Force \u2014 without mercy or restraint \u2014 pounded Lebanese infrastructure, Hezbollah offices and military targets in the southern suburbs of Beirut \u2014 not to kill civilians but not to be deterred by them, either, if they were nested amid Hezbollah weapons or headquarters.\n\nYes, it was ugly and brutal, say Israeli planners, but it worked. This is not Scandinavia. \u201cThe reality here starts where your imagination ends,\u201d said one Israeli officer. Sometimes only crazy can stop crazy. And Hezbollah\u2019s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, definitely got the message. He declared after the 2006 war that he never would have set off that conflict had he known beforehand that Israel would inflict that much damage on his Shiite supporters and their property \u2014 \u201cabsolutely not,\u201d he said.\n\nIsraeli military planners hope he remembers that, and that Iran does, too. They say that if Tehran thinks it can launch a proxy war against Israel from Lebanon and Syria \u2014 while the Iranian home front is untouched \u2014 it should think again. Israel has not purchased Dolphin-class submarines that can operate in the Persian Gulf, and armed them with cruise missiles, for deep-sea fishing.\n\nBut Iran is a determined and wily foe. It has been perfecting its ability to convert dumb surface-to-air missiles, with 1970s technology, into smart, precise surface-to-surface rockets, by reconfiguring them with GPS links, inertial navigation systems, dynamic wings and smart cards. Iran\u2019s ally in Yemen, the Houthis, has used these types of rockets in recent months.\n\nThe Israelis told Putin that they would not allow Iran to build such rocket facilities in Lebanon or to transfer such precision missiles to Hezbollah in Lebanon via any depots or factories in Syria, and that Russia should not interfere with Israeli operations against them. It\u2019s not clear Putin made any promises.\n\nThis is no small matter. Today, if Hezbollah, with its less-precise area rockets, wanted to hit a specific Israeli military building or high-tech factory from Lebanon, it would probably have to launch 25 dumb missiles. By deploying the Iranian upgrades it would have to fire only one \u2014 with a very high probability of hitting the target within 30 meters, meaning it could inflict heavy damage on Israel\u2019s infrastructure in a very short period of time.", "title": "Opinion | Can Crazy Still Keep the Peace Between Israel and Iran?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "In an email, Alex Castellanos, a veteran Republican media consultant and Trump loyalist, put forward his view of why Trump and his supporters are immune to the attacks of the #MeToo movement:\n\nTrump displays unalloyed masculine strength. His supporters do not care if he is predatory, insulting, or offensive as long as he is never in doubt, especially if he is kicking the limp Washington establishment around. Trump\u2019s instinct-driven behavior confirms that he is the archetypal alpha-male, the unfiltered reptilian brain, concerned only with sustenance, survival or sex. If anything enters his world, they know he must either eat it, kill it, or mate with it. That\u2019s why they like him. For about half of America, that is terrifying. For the other half, Trump\u2019s strength is the only thing they can count on to protect them from return of the elite bloodsuckers who would devour them.\n\nCastellanos continued, heating up his rhetoric:\n\nTrump\u2019s supporters don\u2019t expect his unrestrained id to ponder the details of briefing papers before he eats the red meat in front of him. As long as Trump displays strength and grabs the media, the establishment and America\u2019s adversaries by the pussy, he\u2019s the T Rex many of his supporters want.\n\nMusa al-Gharbi, a fellow in sociology at Columbia, sees the possibility of backlash from voters \u2014 such as those Castellanos describes \u2014 who are angered or offended by the #MeToo movement. Al-Gharbi emailed me:\n\nIf the idea is that Democrats can win over and mobilize people who did not vote for them last cycle by calling Trump a sexist, and Roy Moore a predator \u2014 even if many voters agree and are disturbed by Moore and Trump \u2014 many of them can also sympathize with Trump in a sense. The same people who are bashing Trump have also disparaged them (Trump supporters) as misogynistic, racist, homophobic, ignorant, etc. \u2014 to their minds, unfairly. So they don\u2019t put a lot of stock in those messengers, and indeed, hearing Democrats sling these kinds of labels around will probably just stir up resentment against the left.\n\nIn an essay in Salon in May 2016 that contended that Trump\u2019s path to victory was much easier than conventional wisdom had it, Al-Gharbi argued that Democrats and\n\nprogressives have done a great job framing racial inequality, feminism and LGBTQ rights as part of the same basic struggle. However, this association works both ways. Accusations of misogyny, for instance, are often heard in the context of a fundamentally anti-white, anti-Christian culture war \u2014 a zero-sum campaign waged against ordinary hard-working Americans by condescending and politically-correct liberal elites.\n\nThe issue of sexual harassment is a useful tool to mobilize Democratic voters in liberal states and districts, according to Leonie Huddy, a political scientist at Stonybrook, but, like Al-Gharbi, Huddy thinks that such tactics should be deployed with caution:\n\nFeminism and anti-feminism are essentially baked into the political parties at this point and it is difficult to believe that there are many people left for the parties to capture on the basis of gender-linked issues including sexual harassment.\n\nHuddy warned specifically against Democrats adopting \u201ca singular focus on harassment and gender issues\u201d given the 2016 election outcome:\n\nGender issues were front and center in Clinton\u2019s campaign and that had something of a polarizing effect that likely contributed to weaker support for Clinton among white working class men.\n\nMore important, according to Huddy,\n\nDemocrats need to figure out how to combine issues linked to gender/feminism, race, and immigration \u2014 identity politics \u2014 into a more coherent economic framework that reduces the sense that one group wins at another group\u2019s expense.\n\nIn a recent paper, \u201cTrending Towards Traditionalism? Changes in Youths\u2019 Gender Ideology,\u201d two sociologists, Joanna Pepin, of the University of Maryland, and David Cotter, of Union College, found evidence of a retrenchment on key gender issues among the young.\n\nUsing polls of high school seniors over the past 40 years \u2014 conducted by the Monitoring The Future project at the University of Michigan\u2019s Survey Research Center \u2014 Pepin and Cotter documented a shift on two key questions: \u201cIt is usually better for everyone involved if the man is the achiever outside the home and the woman takes care of the home and family\u201d and \u201cthe husband should make all the important decisions in the family.\u201d The accompanying chart shows the trend line on both of those questions.", "title": "Opinion | Can Democrats Follow #MeToo to Victory?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cArt is at the very top of the luxury pyramid,\u201d said Sebastian Cwilich, co-founder of Artsy, an American online platform for learning about and collecting art, which this month expanded by opening an office for 20 workers in London.\n\nMr. Cwilich makes the obvious but inescapable point that paintings and drawings are unique items that are a lot more expensive than mass-produced songs and books. A six-figure price tag tends to deter digital impulse buys. Prints, photographs and design objects, which generally exist in multiples, are better suited to online sales platforms, but even here, concerns about condition, authenticity and provenance can be a deterrent.\n\n\u201cThe online space is most active in the sub-$100,000 category,\u201d Mr. Cwilich said. \u201cThe art market is opaque and intimidating, but the internet does give more people a chance to participate.\u201d The internet also gave trading more \u201cvelocity,\u201d he said.\n\nArtsy, which is based in New York, hopes to speed things up even more by opening a 3,500-square-foot hub in the Whitechapel district of London. The team in the British capital will oversee the company\u2019s partnerships with galleries in Africa, Europe and the Middle East.\n\nMore than 2,000 galleries pay monthly subscriptions of, typically, $400 to $1,000 a month, to advertise works on Artsy, according to Mr. Cwilich, who started the company in 2012 with Carter Cleveland. Artsy generates further revenue by arranging and administering online bids at live auctions, for which it receives a 5 percent commission on successful sales. Privately owned, the company doesn\u2019t report revenues, profits or losses.\n\nPrices remain a major hurdle for the expansion of the digital art trade, not just because they are often so high, but because of their lack of availability. Consumers looking to buy, say, a shirt online can browse numerous fashion websites where thousands of items are clearly labeled and priced. But all too often, prices on art dealers\u2019 websites \u2014 and in their galleries and booths at fairs \u2014 are \u201con application,\u201d a process that can be both laborious and forbidding.\n\nThat remains the norm at Artsy, but some dealers are becoming more open. Mr. Cwilich said that about a third of the works on the site carried prices. Even Gagosian, an international gallery giant that is traditionally secretive about how much its art costs, is now showing prices for works selling for less than $100,000 by artists such as Damien Hirst and Ed Ruscha.\n\nPhoto\n\nLarry Gagosian, the gallery\u2019s founder, was an investor in a $50 million Artsy fund-raising round that closed in July 2017. Other investors include Joe Gebbia, co-founder of Airbnb; and Sky Dayton, founder of the digital services company, EarthLink.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Indian collector Saloni Doshi, who runs the Space 118 artists\u2019 studio project in Mumbai, India, said she read articles on Artsy to find out what was going on. But, she added, \u201cI don\u2019t buy through them.\u201d\n\nMs. Doshi said she preferred to purchase contemporary art online from Paddle8. \u201cYou see the price, then you just bid,\u201d she said. \u201cArtsy isn\u2019t very buyer-friendly. All the numbers aren\u2019t there.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFrom a consumer perspective, dedicated online-only auctions, with clear price structures, enjoy a definite edge over dealer transactions in the digital sphere. Since May, Christie\u2019s website has listed results from its online-only auctions, which last year had an average lot price of $7,305, up from $6,047 the year before. Competitors such as Sotheby\u2019s and Paddle8 do not make this information available.\n\nAccording to Marc Sands, Christie\u2019s chief marketing officer, \u201cAs a potential consignor or buyer, it\u2019s important to look at what has happened to interpret value.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt aids transparency,\u201d he added.\n\nResults achieved for artworks resold at live auctions can be viewed at subscription websites such as Artnet and Artprice. But the \u201cprimary market\u201d prices that galleries charge for new works by contemporary artists remain offline, with many dealers regarding them as trade secrets available only to insiders.\n\nA free app, Magnus, which started in 2016, aims to rip through this veil of exclusivity. Smartphone users simply point their device at an artwork in a gallery or fair and visual recognition technology (most times) quickly supplies dealer and auction prices for the relevant artist. In that way, Magnus works for art in a similar fashion to that in which Shazam, the popular song-identifying app, works for music.\n\nMagnus\u2019s database contains about 10 million prices, compiled through crowdsourcing. About 10 percent of those are from the primary market, according to the app\u2019s founder, Magnus Resch, a German entrepreneur based in New York.\n\n\u201cWe are disrupting the art market by making it more transparent,\u201d Mr. Resch said in an email. \u201cMy generation wants all information immediately, and not go through a beauty contest while waiting for the director of the gallery to come and check me out.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNot surprisingly, some in the art world have resented those efforts. Late in 2016, Magnus was withdrawn for five months from the Apple app store, after accusations that data had been taken from rival platforms and from individual galleries. But the app, with contested information removed from its database, is now available again and is still free, although Mr. Resch said he was \u201cin the process of developing innovative features and additional services for professional users for which we can charge.\u201d\n\nMr. Resch said the app was \u201cparticularly strong\u201d at art fairs, estimating that it revealed around 80 percent of the prices at events such as Art Basel. But for the moment, business at those fairs continues to be dominated by an older generation of market-savvy buyers who have cultivated personal relationships with gallerists.\n\n\u201cWhy would I use Artsy or Magnus? I have access to the prices,\u201d said one of those, Alain Servais, 54, a Brussels-based collector who attends at least 20 contemporary art fairs per year. \u201cIf you bring too much transparency to the market, you risk harming the mythmaking machine that makes the prices so high,\u201d Mr. Servais added. \u201cYou are not longer part of a clique. Art becomes a common thing.\u201d\n\nMyths and mystique might be keeping prices high at the moment. But sooner or later, the art business is going to have to find a way of engaging the next generation of buyers. And that generation is digital, not analog.", "title": "Can Digital Technology Open Up the Art World?", "authors": ["Scott Reyburn"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Successful fast food restaurants have to be clean, efficient and consistent. As far as I can tell, though, it\u2019s never been necessary for the people who run them to care about food. How would you even tell? It would be like watching a porn film to assess the work of the dialect coach.\n\nMark Ladner was the chef at Del Posto for a decade, steering it to a four-star review from The New York Times in 2010, and at Lupa for five years before that. Leaving all that behind, in October he opened Pasta Flyer, a restaurant in Greenwich Village where pasta in a compostable sugar-cane-fiber bowl costs between $7 and $8.75 and is cooked in less than a minute while you watch.\n\nIf you tasted the fusilli with pesto, say, or the fettuccine Alfredo, and didn\u2019t know Mr. Ladner\u2019s history, you probably wouldn\u2019t guess that it had been made by one of the city\u2019s greatest pasta cooks. But you\u2019d be able to tell in a second that it was made by somebody who cared about food.\n\nThe texture is the first thing most cheap pasta places screw up. Pasta Flyer doesn\u2019t screw it up. The noodles are firm and chewy, with a happy little bounce. Partly this is because they\u2019re not overcooked, but Mr. Ladner is also buying excellent dry pasta from Italy. It\u2019s similar to the imported stuff I like to buy when I cook at home, which costs almost as much by the pound as a bowl does at Pasta Flyer. The rigatoni is made with whole grain and the penne is gluten free; they\u2019re both as supple and smooth as the three shapes made from semolina.", "title": "Can Fancy Chefs Excel at Fast, Cheap Food? Two Case Studies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nMy sister-in-law is friends with a woman I see socially about three times a year. She is a high-functioning alcoholic: She doesn\u2019t drink during the day but becomes a slurry obnoxious mess at parties. I avoid her, and eventually her husband steps in. But recently, my teenage stepdaughter witnessed her \u201cdrunk show\u201d and helped the woman\u2019s daughter through tears of anger and shame. Now I feel complicit. My sister-in-law won\u2019t intervene. So, I would like to tell this woman she needs help. Can you suggest a diplomatic approach?\n\nANONYMOUS\n\nRemember that ancient party trick Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon? Its premise: Any two people, but particularly actors, are separated by fewer than six others who link them. It was utterly charming until its ubiquity made it insufferable. But if Six Degrees proved what a small, small world we inhabit, it never argued that folks at the far poles of separation should intervene in our most personal problems.\n\nI admire your helping impulse. But you are a near-stranger, not complicit. You see this woman about three times a year and avoid her when you do. You have no idea what goes on during the other 362 evenings (or any of the days). And denial is common among people with substance problems. Many report that when they do seek help, it is thanks to the intervention of loved ones \u2014 not in-laws of uninterested pals.\n\nYou are not the right messenger, but you still have a big opportunity: You (and your spouse) should speak with your stepdaughter about what may have been an upsetting experience at the party. Praise her for her kindness to the woman\u2019s daughter; sketch out the limits of helpfulness (for example, no getting into cars); and answer her questions. The most valuable dialogue to begin is with someone close to you.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSiblings Only\n\nMy boyfriend\u2019s niece is getting married in Colorado. His brother suggested a pre-wedding trip and invited us along. After the wedding, this brother wants his wife and me to leave, so that the brothers and their sister can have some time alone. (The brother\u2019s wife has no problem with this.) The siblings live in different states, so I get that time together is precious. But being asked to leave early rubs me the wrong way. I would never ask this of anyone. Is the brother being rude, or am I too sensitive?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use.
