If he wants a few days alone with his siblings after the two of you enjoy a high-altitude mini-break, I would go along with him.", "title": "Can I Stage an Intervention for a Near-Stranger\u2019s Alcoholism?", "authors": ["Philip Galanes", "Social Q S"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Jaroussky hopes to change that, beginning on a small scale. His new institute, the Acad\u00e9mie Musicale Philippe Jaroussky, provides free weekly music lessons to 23 children from working-class or immigrant backgrounds.\n\nHalf of those who attend classical music concerts in France are executives or managers, and their average age is 54, according to a 2015 study commissioned by the French Association of Orchestras.\n\nImage The French countertenor Philippe Jaroussky, right, performing at the Volksb\u00fchne in Berlin this month. Credit Clemens Bilan/European Pressphoto Agency\n\n\u201cWhether in Hamburg, in New York or in Paris, I sing before the same kind of people,\u201d Mr. Jaroussky said in an interview. \u201cAnd as much as I love my audience, I\u2019m worried that if we don\u2019t bring more diversity onto the stage, we won\u2019t get a younger and more diverse audience either.\u201d\n\nThe children in the academy, ages 7 to 12, were given the choice of learning the piano, violin or cello, and receive instruments to keep throughout the three-year program.", "title": "Can Philippe Jaroussky Help Fix Classical Music\u2019s Diversity Problem?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "There is not strong evidence for that contention.\n\n\u201cHigher earnings are positively correlated with longer lifespan,\u201d says a guidance document published by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services on Thursday.\n\nOne comprehensive review of existing studies found strong evidence that unemployment is generally harmful to health, including higher mortality; poorer general health; poorer mental health; and higher medical consultation and hospital admission rates. Another academic analysis found strong evidence for a protective effect of employment on depression and general mental health. A 2013 Gallup poll found that unemployed Americans are more than twice as likely as those with full-time jobs to say they currently have or are being treated for depression. Other community engagement activities such as volunteering are also associated with improved health outcomes, and it can lead to paid employment.\n\n(One citation in that passage is to a health insurer\u2019s survey that asked people who volunteer how it made them feel.)\n\nBut it is not at all clear how much work or income alone improve health. In fact, there\u2019s quite a lot of evidence that causality can move in the opposite direction, since health problems can make it difficult to work or go to school. It might be, as the guidance document suggests, that people who don\u2019t work become depressed. Or it could be that some people who are depressed have a harder time getting or keeping a job. Treating their depression might ease their symptoms and improve their employment prospects. \u201cHaving the medical coverage helps people to get a job,\u201d said LaDonna Pavetti, a vice president at the liberal Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, who has studied work requirements extensively.\n\nSome research does suggest that a boost to income can improve people\u2019s health. Yet a study that examined the earned-income tax credit, a program established specifically to raise the incomes of low-wage workers, wasn\u2019t able to find any clear health benefit.\n\nMore crucially, a work requirement does not guarantee that Medicaid beneficiaries will have an increased income or even find a job. Some people may be nudged by a work requirement into work they wouldn\u2019t have done otherwise. But others may simply be kicked out of the health insurance program because they aren\u2019t able to meet the requirement. States will be allowed to cut off Medicaid benefits to people who can\u2019t demonstrate that they\u2019ve completed the required number of work or activity hours or who don\u2019t qualify for an exception related to a health problem or having a young child. Others might meet the work requirement rule and keep their Medicaid, but still remain poor, because they are able to get only a volunteer or part-time job that keeps their income low.\n\nStudies of the Medicaid population suggest that most of them work already or would qualify for exceptions. The guidance says that states will need to carve out exceptions for people who are medically frail and for people with opioid addictions, so they won\u2019t lose their benefits. But anyone who fails to complete or document their required work and loses benefits won\u2019t get the health benefits of Medicaid coverage or any of the described health benefits that the administration says come from work. States that have asked for work requirements \u2014 10 have submitted applications already \u2014 have estimated reductions in Medicaid enrollment, and not all because of people finding other kinds of health coverage.", "title": "Can Requiring People to Work Make Them Healthier?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The authors are far from the first to raise questions about Compas\u2019s role in judicial decision making.\n\nIn one high-profile case, a Wisconsin man charged with evading the police said that his due process rights were violated when a judge used Compas in sentencing him to six years in prison. (He appealed the case to the United States Supreme Court, but it declined to weigh in last year.)\n\nAnd, in 2016, the investigative journalism nonprofit ProPublica concluded that the software was unfair to black defendants.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhile some academics disputed the certainty of that finding \u2014 arguing that it depends on how fairness is measured \u2014 the report inspired Ms. Dressel and Mr. Farid to conduct their own study.\n\nIn addition to their main finding, the authors also found evidence of racial bias from both Compas and the humans, even though neither considered race in the predictions. Compared with their white peers, a larger share of black defendants was falsely predicted to reoffend, while a smaller share was falsely predicted not to.\n\nEquivant disputed the findings. In a statement on Wednesday, it said that the authors overstated the number of variables Compas uses to predict future crimes \u2014 it is six, the company said, not the 137 that the authors cited. Equivant also said that the conclusions were limited by the small data sample used, the same data behind the ProPublica report.\n\nMs. Dressel and Mr. Farid based their analysis on a database of more than 7,000 pretrial defendants in Broward County, Fla., from 2013 to 2014. For each, the database included demographic information, criminal history, Compas risk scores and arrest records for the two years following the scoring.\n\nA subset of 1,000 defendants was then used to collect predictions from 400 people, recruited through Amazon\u2019s Mechanical Turk, a marketplace for online labor. Those participants were presented with paragraphs about each of 50 defendants and asked to rate the likelihood that each would commit a crime in the following two years.\n\nThe descriptions the individuals were presented with included the defendants\u2019 sex, age, crime they were charged with, the type of crime and their arrest history.", "title": "Can Software Predict Crime? Maybe So, but No Better Than a Human", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Moon Jae-in, South Korea\u2019s new and immensely popular president, is a progressive from a camp that favors so-called sunshine policies, and fervently aspires to reconciliation with North Korea through d\u00e9tente, economic engagement and increasing interdependence. But those policies have a checkered track record.\n\nIn 2000, their first major proponent, the former president and Nobel Peace laureate Kim Dae-jung, secretly and illegally paid Kim Jong-il, North Korea\u2019s leader at the time, hundreds of millions of dollars to secure a summit. Roh Moo-hyun, the next South Korean president, later strained relations with the United States by trying to take on a balancing role between Washington and Pyongyang \u2014 playing arbiter, in other words, between the ally committed to Seoul\u2019s military protection and the regime committed to Seoul\u2019s destruction.\n\nTo his credit, in his short time in office Mr. Moon \u2014 who, by the way, was one of Mr. Roh\u2019s top advisers during those troubled years \u2014 has leavened his own sunshine yearnings with a strong dose of realpolitik. He has pushed for missile defense, for example, as well as for close coordination over international sanctions with the United States despite new strains with President Trump. Last week, Mr. Moon is reported to have said of the upcoming talks with North Korea, \u201cI will not just na\u00efvely push for dialogue as in the past.\u201d\n\nStill, Pyongyang seems to have kept in reserve the option of going on a charm offensive with him. It has already dismissed President Trump as a \u201cdotard.\u201d It called Barack Obama a \u201cwicked black monkey.\u201d It cursed Park Geun-hye, the previous president of South Korea, as an \u201cold, insane bitch.\u201d But it has had nothing bad to say about Mr. Moon (yet).\n\nMeanwhile, the urgency of the North\u2019s diplomatic drive can be explained by both recent wins and menacing losses ahead. Over the past several years, Pyongyang has tested atomic bombs \u2014 and, it claims, one hydrogen device \u2014 and has launched intercontinental missiles. According to Mr. Kim, the United States mainland is now \u201cwithin range of our nuclear strike\u201d and his defense sector is moving to \u201cmass produce\u201d nuclear warheads and ballistic missiles.\n\nAll the same, the North\u2019s military rests on an economic base that is not only tiny, but also notoriously dysfunctional and desperately dependent on foreign resources and so uniquely vulnerable to serious sanctions. The United Nations Security Council has voted for new and potentially crippling penalties. China \u2014 North Korea\u2019s main financial backer \u2014 appears finally ready to reconsider, and reduce, its support.\n\nTo date, at least by outward appearance, the North Korean economy has not been much fazed by international sanctions. But we do not know how fast the North is spending down its reserves. Only Mr. Kim does.\n\nIf Mr. Kim is indeed in a race against the clock to forestall economic disaster at home, importuning Seoul to help lift (or at least ignore) international sanctions, relax nuclear counter-proliferation efforts and revive sunshine economic programs could be the most expeditious way to get out of a bind.", "title": "Opinion | Can South Korea Avoid Getting Played by the North?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "There are three approaches state officials could use to undercut the tax law. First, they could encourage families to donate money to the state government by offering them a credit for those gifts against state income taxes. The idea would be to turn state taxes into charitable donations that are deductible against the federal income tax. This might sound like a gimmick that the Internal Revenue Service could easily shut down. But David Kamin, a law professor at New York University, says there is precedent supporting such a policy. For example, some states offer tax credits to people who donate money to private schools, and these donations also qualify for the federal charity deduction.\n\nUnder the second approach, which is advocated by the economist Dean Baker, state governments would replace their income taxes with payroll taxes paid by employers. Those kinds of taxes \u2014 like the one for unemployment insurance coverage \u2014 are deductible for businesses under the Republican tax law. That switch would mean that employers could pay their workers less, but take-home pay would stay the same because employees wouldn\u2019t be on the hook for paying state income taxes.\n\nBut other experts warn that switching to a payroll tax would be complicated and could have unintended consequences if states don\u2019t put in place other safeguards. For example, it might not be possible for employers to reduce the wages of workers who are covered by union contracts or who earn the minimum wage. A switch to a payroll tax might also tempt some businesses to move to nearby states that do not have such a tax.\n\nThe third approach is for states to file a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the tax law. Mr. Cuomo said on Wednesday that he would file such a suit, claiming that the provision limiting deductibility of state and local taxes amounts to double taxation. Other officials, including the governor-elect of New Jersey, Phil Murphy, are considering similar legal action. But experts say that such lawsuits are unlikely to succeed because they ask courts to read the 16th Amendment, which authorized the federal income tax, very broadly. Further, Congress already restricts the use of the state and local tax deduction through the alternative minimum tax, says Kim Rueben of the Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center. The new law will reduce the number of people who end up paying the alternative minimum tax.\n\nIt is hard to say if any of these maneuvers would be successful. But they could potentially cost the federal government billions of dollars in tax revenue. No doubt Republicans in Washington would be peeved and might try to pass legislation that seeks to outlaw or reduce the effectiveness of these state policies. But that might not be an option if Democrats gain House seats or take control of one or both chambers of Congress in the November election \u2014 an outcome that has probably become more likely thanks to the tax law.\n\nNone of this should come as a surprise. Republican leaders invited taxpayers and state governments to play tax avoidance games by rushing through an unpopular mess of a tax bill that, over time, will benefit few and hurt many.", "title": "Opinion | Can States Fix the G.O.P. Tax Law?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Sweatcoin\u2019s \u201cfirst premise is that physical movement has economic value,\u201d Anton Derlyatka, a Sweatcoin co-founder, told me.\n\nMr. Derlyatka said the app aims to overcome our human tendency to choose immediate gratification \u2014 like doughnuts or binge-watching videos \u2014 over activities like daily exercise that offer long-term benefits. By giving consumers points that can buy goodies, Sweatcoin hopes to incentivize couch potatoes to become more active.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a tool, a hack, to help all of us, not just the select few, to remain fit,\u201d said Oleg Fomenko, another Sweatcoin co-founder.\n\nCould the app change me, a book nerd who innately favors reading over running? Cautiously optimistic, I downloaded Sweatcoin on an iPhone over the holidays.\n\nIn theory, the app awards one sweatcoin for every 1,000 outdoor steps. But I quickly learned that users often get credit for fewer steps than they expected.\n\nPhoto\n\nFor one thing, Sweatcoin immediately shaves your sweatcoin earnings by 5 percent \u2014 in the fine print, the app calls it a commission \u201cto keep our lights on.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor another thing, the app counts only the steps it thinks you took outside. Bummer. I would get no credit for Zumba, spinning \u2014 or listening to music playlists and dancing around my kitchen while cooking.\n\nTo help it distinguish outdoor steps, Sweatcoin collects and analyzes GPS signals and motion data from your phone. To improve accuracy, it instructs users to turn off the app\u2019s battery-saver mode and keep the app running in the background.\n\nAnd Sweatcoin gets bossy about it. The first time I swiped the app off, a notice popped up on my phone: \u201cYou killed me! Do not force quit me if you want to generate sweatcoins.\u201d I complied, and my battery paid the price.\n\nFrictionless this app was not.\n\nBut then I noticed that Sweatcoin seemed to frequently skimp on points, too. On a recent day I went for a walk with my sister in the snowy Massachusetts countryside, the app counted less than half my steps as outdoor activity.\n\nFrustrated, I turned to reviews on Reddit, Twitter, and app stores where missing points are a common theme.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201c Where are my missing 3000 steps!\u201d Ian Wynne, a sports performance consultant in Britain, wrote on Twitter. \u201cThis is happening a little too often.\u201d\n\nTo commiserate, I called Mr. Wynne, who won a bronze medal in kayaking at the Athens Olympics in 2004.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a little frustrating when you are outside and you are sure that you have taken 1,000 more steps than it claims,\u201d Mr. Wynne said. Nevertheless, he planned to continue using Sweatcoin. He regularly exercised, he said, and liked the idea of getting extra credit for the outdoor activities he was already doing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Fomenko, the Sweatcoin co-founder, told me that the app\u2019s \u201cdraconian algorithm\u201d is meant to deter cheating techniques like, say, strapping a phone to a pet dog. And that fraud-deterrence system may verify fewer steps than users expect, he said.\n\nIn practice, according to the app\u2019s help section, that means the Sweatcoin algorithm typically verifies 65 percent of a user\u2019s total steps. It also means that some frequent consumer behaviors \u2014 using a protective smartphone cover, walking while connected to public Wi-Fi, walking slowly with small children \u2014 could reduce your step count.\n\nIn a follow-up email, Sweatcoin\u2019s co-founders said that they would soon hire a data science team \u201cto help us improve the speed and accuracy of this algorithm.\u201d They also said they were working on a verification algorithm to count indoor activity.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe current system seemed preposterous to me. What\u2019s the point of an unpredictable fitness app?\n\nNevertheless, after about two weeks of intermittent use, I had earned 47.52 sweatcoins. I was feeling pretty good \u2014 a Fitbit could soon be mine.\n\nThen I learned that the rewards could also be fickle.\n\nSweatcoin generates revenue by marketing other companies\u2019 products to its users. When a user redeems reward points for a product through Sweatcoin, the maker of that product pays Sweatcoin a fee.\n\nBut the Fitbit and some other fitness devices on offer when I signed up had disappeared from the app before I could earn one. Now the reward choices included a workout app for 30 sweatcoins that didn\u2019t interest me \u2014 or the iPhone X for a whopping 20,000 sweatcoins. I calculated that, if I took 13,000 total steps every day, it would take me more than five years to get that iPhone.\n\nI felt like Sweatcoin, by offering rewards that seemed near impossible to obtain, could end up demotivating the very people it was trying to nudge to walk more.\n\nAs a reporter who regularly covers data privacy, I also couldn\u2019t help being troubled by the possibility that the app could share or sell the trove of location and motion data it collects from users.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSweatcoin\u2019s founders said they would never do such a thing. \u201cLet me make it very, very clear,\u201d Mr. Derlyatka said, \u201cwe never, ever sell anybody\u2019s user data to any outside parties.\u201d If the fitness start-up were ever acquired by another company, however, the app\u2019s privacy policy states that \u201cpersonal data held by it about its customers will be one of the transferred assets.\u201d\n\nBut the biggest downside for me was feeling like Sweatcoin\u2019s behavioral engineering cheapened important experiences. When I used the app, instead of concentrating on the friends I was walking with, I kept checking to see how close I was to being able to redeem my sweatcoins for that Fitbit.\n\nNo trinket or gift card is worth that distraction.", "title": "Can Sweatcoin, a Hot Fitness App, Keep You Off the Couch?", "authors": ["Natasha Singer"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "John Hughes\u2019s movie \u201cThe Breakfast Club\u201d (1985) is a classic movie of its genre precisely because it captures this feature of the teenage experience. Five teenagers from different cliques (\u201ca brain, an athlete, a basket case, a princess and a criminal\u201d) bond during enforced Saturday detention. Over the hours together, they discover a common humanity that transcends the social roles into which each had been slotted.\n\nHaving made themselves vulnerable to one another, they ask themselves, in the movie\u2019s climactic scene, whether they will acknowledge one another in school on Monday. Claire (\u201cthe princess\u201d) answers in the negative and is consequently accused by Bender (\u201cthe criminal\u201d) of being nothing more than what she initially seemed: \u201cYou just stick to the things that you know: shopping, nail polish, your father\u2019s BMW \u2026.\u201d Claire in turn, accuses Bender of being unwilling to face the facts. She says, \u201cI\u2019m telling the truth.\u201d The eventual romantic resolution of this dispute \u2014 the two characters kiss \u2014 is a cinematic way of signaling that the correct attitude to their future lies somewhere in the middle.\n\nClaire is wrong to be so cynical: If she believes that their association was merely temporary or convenient, then what has happened between them is insignificant and each character is truly trapped in his or her pigeonhole. Consider this line from the New Yorker critic Pauline Kael\u2019s correspondingly cynical review: \u201cThe movie is about a bunch of stereotypes who complain that other people see them as stereotypes.\u201d Kael is not wrong that the characters are stereotypes. But the point of the movie is to give us a glimpse of them trying to be more than that.\n\nNotice, however, that the antidote to cynicism cannot be Bender\u2019s na\u00efve conviction that everything is different now. A person cannot, in a day, do the work needed to transcend years of internalized stereotyping. At the end of the movie, detention ends and the five teenagers part ways with a fragile, doubt-filled faith in the connections they have forged. They have tasted enough of the value of true friendship to know that they have not plumbed its depths and are therefore liable to ignore one another in the halls on Monday morning; their attitude toward the goods of friendship is not one of possession but one of aspiration.\n\nLacking the grounds to conclude that they will greet one another, they can nonetheless have aspirational faith \u2014 try to believe \u2014 that they will do so. The movie suggests that it is possible to see something in the prospect of stereotype-transcending friendship without taking oneself to have seen all that there is to see. What keeps aspirational faith honest is its provisional character, the aspirant\u2019s recognition that she still has a long way to go.\n\nThe problem with Pascal\u2019s wager is that it is a wager, and so the stakes are fixed in advance. Betting is about winning some value you are already aware of, not learning that there is something new out there to be valued. If you set out to acquire beliefs without learning, you are cheating: gaining epistemic ground without doing epistemic work. By contrast, in the cases of aspirational faith, coming to believe that, e.g., we will still be friends on Monday, is part and parcel of a bigger project of learning to become a different kind of person. The project is intellectual, involving a change in beliefs, but it is not only intellectual \u2014 and its intellectual character is inseparable from its affective and motivational character.\n\nPascal may have been making a related point, to the effect that the mind does not have a monopoly on wisdom, when he famously proclaimed that \u201cthe heart has its reasons, which reason does not know.\u201d But that sentiment, however beautifully expressed, leaves the crucial questions unanswered. Because suppose that Pascal is right, and someone\u2019s heart has reasons that her reason does not know. Do things have to stay that way? Couldn\u2019t her reason learn those reasons? And wouldn\u2019t that, in turn, be her heart\u2019s opportunity to grow?", "title": "Opinion | Can We Learn to Believe in God?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Farrow, in an email to The Times, replied: \u201cIf Woody Allen and his surrogates\u2019 response to this is that I\u2019m capitalizing on a moment in which it is in vogue to carefully look at the facts, rather than rely on thin defenses from powerful men without question \u2014 a moment in which the truth is in fashion \u2014 I\u2019d say they\u2019re right.\u201d\n\nMs. Farrow\u2019s claim was investigated in 1992 and 1993 by authorities in Connecticut, where the alleged assault took place, and in New York. The investigations concluded there was no abuse. A state\u2019s attorney in Connecticut said he had probable cause to prosecute Mr. Allen but would not, to spare Ms. Farrow the pain of a court appearance at a young age.\n\nThe recent fallout tilted against Mr. Allen has extended past Hollywood. On Thursday a Connecticut theater canceled a production of Mr. Allen\u2019s \u201cBullets Over Broadway,\u201d based on his 1994 movie, citing \u201cthe current dialogue on sexual harassment and misconduct.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe majority of Mr. Allen\u2019s stars have not weighed in. But a handful of performers, without directly addressing guilt or innocence, have expressed regret over working with Mr. Allen, or vowed not to again. Ms. Farrow\u2019s statements, in which she detailed her alleged abuse as a 7-year-old, and how she felt let down by the film community, \u201cmade me realize that I increased another woman\u2019s pain, and I was heartbroken by that realization,\u201d said Greta Gerwig, who appeared in Mr. Allen\u2019s \u201cTo Rome With Love\u201d in 2012.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA top Hollywood strategist who spoke on the condition of anonymity to protect her professional relationships said that she would advise her clients not to work with Mr. Allen. She said a role in an Allen film would be too hard to justify \u2014 a career choice over a possible moral stand.\n\nOthers pointed to the trajectory of artists like Roman Polanski as an example of the entertainment industry\u2019s longstanding moral leniency. In the decades since Mr. Polanski fled the United States to avoid sentencing after pleading guilty to unlawful sex with a 13-year-old girl, he has enjoyed a flourishing career in Europe, where audiences have been conditioned to separate the art from the artist. He continued casting top Hollywood stars and won an Oscar in 2003 for directing \u201cThe Pianist.\u201d (Mr. Allen has long had devoted fans, and more box office fortune, in Europe. \u201cWonder Wheel,\u201d which has taken in $9 million overseas thus far, is due to open in France this week.)\n\nAlec Baldwin, a repeat star of Mr. Allen\u2019s films, has come to his defense, writing on Twitter that \u201cthe renunciation of him and his work, no doubt, has some purpose. But it\u2019s unfair and sad to me.\u201d He called working with Mr. Allen \u201cone of the privileges of my career.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Aronson and other partisans of Mr. Allen\u2019s contend that the efforts of the Farrow family to discredit Mr. Allen are burnished by Ronan Farrow\u2019s role, through his investigative reports in The New Yorker, in exposing Harvey Weinstein\u2019s years of alleged abuse. Mr. Farrow, Dylan\u2019s brother, has also publicly supported her. \u201cRonan is in a good position now,\u201d Ms. Aronson said. \u201cHe\u2019s traveling around with a halo. Unfortunately, he\u2019s wrong\u201d about Mr. Allen. (Mr. Farrow declined to comment.)\n\nMr. Allen is continuing on the creative path he has followed for decades: always writing \u2014 in addition to a screenplay, Ms. Aronson said he may be working on short stories or possibly a book \u2014 and playing clarinet at his regular Monday-night gig at the Carlyle on the Upper East Side. \u201cHis life hasn\u2019t changed,\u201d she said.\n\nBut his artistic vision may be out of step with the times. His last four films have flopped at the North American box office, taking in a cumulative $26.9 million \u2014 roughly half of which goes to theater owners \u2014 while carrying a collective $85 million in estimated production costs, not including marketing.\n\nPoor reviews have played a role. But box office analysts say that women, in particular younger women, have grown increasingly determined to boycott his films since 2013, when Dylan Farrow first spoke in detail about her claims of abuse in an interview with Vanity Fair.\n\nBefore Amazon\u2019s largess, Mr. Allen, like most indie filmmakers, financed his movies by preselling distribution rights. Even as his box office results faltered, he was able to attract continued interest from distributors by casting major stars. And he was able to cast major stars (and often persuade them to work for reduced salaries) because of his reputation as a film legend and because awards sometimes followed. But pull out one element \u2014 the stars \u2014 and the model could collapse.\n\nDespite signs of wavering support in Hollywood, Ms. Aronson was still defiantly confident that Mr. Allen could make any movie he wants. Financing is already in place for the script he\u2019s working on now, she said, outside the Amazon deal. And as for casting, actors are a renewable resource. \u201cI have no doubt,\u201d she said, \u201cthat he\u2019ll be able to find new talent.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThough prolific, at 82, Mr. Allen may be nearing his closing chapter as a filmmaker. Some industry observers suggested that if he continued working quietly, the controversy would blow over, as it has before \u2014 because, until #MeToo, Hollywood always had a short memory.", "title": "Can Woody Allen Work in Hollywood Again?", "authors": ["Melena Ryzik", "Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I am a senior living in a rent-stabilized apartment in Elmhurst, Queens. As precious as my rent is, it has become extremely difficult for me to continue living in New York because of my limited income and increasing lack of mobility. So, I would like to approach the management company, which owns more than 200 buildings in the city, about buying me out of my lease. How do I start this conversation? Do I need to provide historical rent prices or market-rate comparisons? Would a letter explaining my situation move their hearts?\n\nA. A rent-stabilized lease in New York is a valuable asset for a renter \u2014 such leases come with protections like tenancy for life and regulated rent increases. In some cases, landlords are willing to pay a pretty penny to buy a tenant out of it. If landlords think they can fetch substantially more money for the apartment after renovating it, they have an incentive to make a deal.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Real Estate Newsletter Every week, get updates on residential real estate news, covering the five boroughs and beyond. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut in New York, location is everything. An apartment on the Upper East Side would be worth much more than one in Elmhurst, Queens, for example. So, before you approach your landlord, figure out how much your home is worth so that you know what you could reasonably demand.\n\nStart by looking at market-rate apartments in your building or neighborhood. What do they rent for? On StreetEasy, the average asking rent for one-bedrooms in Elmhurst was roughly $1,970 per month in early January. Remember, your landlord would probably need to renovate your apartment once you leave. Would the profit margin be wide enough to warrant buying you out at the price you need to find a suitable home elsewhere?\n\nAsk Real Estate Submit your questions, share your stories and tell us what topics interest you most. Post a comment or email us at realestateqa@nytimes.com.\n\n\u201cYou have to understand the leverage that you have,\u201d said David Rozenholc, a Manhattan lawyer who has won seven- and eight-figure buyouts for tenants.\n\nFigure out your own bottom line. You will have to pay taxes on whatever payout you get \u2014 it needs to be enough to give you good options. \u201cWhere are you going? You need to get enough money to replace the apartment that you have now,\u201d Mr. Rozenholc said.\n\nIf you approach your landlord, you do not need to share any information that you\u2019ve learned \u2014 the landlord knows what the asset is worth. Instead, hold your cards to your vest. \u201cThe minute you approach the landlord with this question, the landlord thinks you\u2019re going to move anyway and won\u2019t give you any money,\u201d Mr. Rozenholc said. So, \u201cyou have to make it very clear to them that unless you get a fair settlement, you have no ability to move, you don\u2019t have enough money to move anywhere and therefore you\u2019re not going to be moving.\u201d", "title": "Can You Convince a Landlord to Buy You Out of an Apartment?", "authors": ["Ronda Kaysen", "Ask Real Estate"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHow good are you at detecting someone else\u2019s lie? Have you heard about the ways professionals can spot a lie when they see one?\n\nDo you know any ways \u2014 body language, for example \u2014 that are supposed to help you know when another person is lying?\n\nIn the Times interactive quiz \u201cCan You Spot the Liar?,\u201d the producers Jeffery DelViscio and Brittany Storoz write:\n\nPoker players might call it the \u201ctell\u201d \u2014 it\u2019s the idea that your body language tells your questioners if the words you\u2019re saying are actually true or false. These subjects in a University of Chicago study on body language and lying were asked several general questions \u2014 and then told off camera to lie or tell the truth when answering. Can you tell truth from falsehood?\n\nStudents: Take the quiz, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 How did you do on the quiz? Did you feel confident in detecting the truthtellers from the liars? Why?\n\n\u2014 What did you learn about yourself when taking the quiz, if anything, and why?\n\n\u2014 How difficult or easy is it to detect a lie? Why did you answer the way you did?\n\nIn related Times coverage, see \u201cAt Airports, a Misplaced Faith in Body Language.\u201d", "title": "Can You Spot a Liar?", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Metal hips are far from the only devices with catastrophic consequences. In October 2007, Medtronic, a leading medical device manufacturer, recalled the lead wires in its Sprint Fidelis defibrillator after they were found to fracture and misfire, harming or even killing patients. The devices had not been clinically tested and were approved for sale by the F.D.A. through the supplement pathway. But in this case, the \u201cminor change\u201d was a fatal one; the new wire was thinner and prone to fracture.\n\nBy the time of the recall, 268,000 leads had been implanted in patients worldwide, the majority in the United States. After the recall, many patients rushed to have the devices removed, but removal posed its own dangers, causing major complications in 15 percent of patients.\n\nEven when devices are subjected to trials, the F.D.A. sometimes ignores danger signs detected by those studies. In 1997, during the approval process of the vagus nerve stimulator, a device made by Cyberonics to treat epilepsy, an F.D.A. adviser voiced concerns about a high death rate noted in patients with the device. But the agency didn\u2019t stop the device from going to market. Instead, it awarded conditional approval, meaning that Cyberonics would have to conduct safety studies after the device was on the market.\n\nThe agency didn\u2019t even require Cyberonics to inform patients that there was concern about the death rate, or that they were effectively being made unwitting guinea pigs. When Cyberonics finally submitted five studies that it said proved the device was safe, it failed to include death data for any of the studies, a move the F.D.A. defended, saying the agency hadn\u2019t asked the company to count deaths, only to \u201ccharacterize\u201d deaths.\n\nHow it\u2019s possible to characterize deaths without including any actual data on deaths is anyone\u2019s guess.\n\nWith such shockingly lax regulations, it\u2019s no surprise that device recalls have risen over the years; in 2003, there were eight Class 1 device recalls, which the F.D.A. defines as indicating \u201ca reasonable probability\u201d that a device will \u201ccause serious adverse health consequences or death.\u201d In 2016, that number rose to 117, affecting hundreds of thousands of patients.\n\nLoose oversight of devices poses a threat to public health. Yet the Trump administration\u2019s picks to lead the Department of Health and Human Services and the F.D.A. are advocates of deregulation, which they insist will speed the march of \u201clifesaving\u201d devices to market. This presumes that such speed and innovation is actually lifesaving or life-enhancing. The number of device-related deaths shows how dangerous that presumption is.", "title": "Opinion | Can Your Hip Replacement Kill You?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "France failed to make good for my grandfather on the promissory cultural note of the Alliance Isra\u00e9lite Universelle. The organization\u2019s purpose was to lift Jews out of their benighted surroundings and offer them the tools to make a go at life in Europe. It was the promise of a country that took pride in being more civilized than the ones that would eventually expel all of their Jewish populations.\n\nToday such distinction feels more blurred and more difficult to defend than at any point since World War II.\n\nWhat hurts most about this realization is that it directly contradicts what Jews like me feel must also necessarily be true: France is our home, as if somewhere in the universe there is a real France, and the one in Europe is just a facsimile that keeps falling off the anti-Semitism wagon.\n\nFrench-speaking Jews may have celebrated this year when Emmanuel Macron\u2019s party, La R\u00e9publique En Marche!, defeated the frighteningly far-right and anti-Semitic National Front, but this supposedly new France has done nothing to curb its Jewish problem. Every year in France Jewish storefronts are vandalized, including arson in kosher supermarkets this past week.\n\nThe general feeling of unrest is not unlike the one felt over 100 years ago during the Dreyfus Affair, when it became clear to many that Jewish life in France was ultimately unsustainable. For many, the situation has started feeling untenable again today. Anti-Semitism, as it turns out, is a flat circle.\n\nAnd yet, despite all the betrayal and heartbreak, I cannot bring myself to renounce France, as if after more than a century of love for this country, the love itself has become part of my genome. Generations removed from the work of the Alliance, its effects continue to exist in me.\n\nI feel as ridiculous admitting that I am not French as I do saying that I am. I know all the transfer points of the Paris Metro. Like my father, I studied French literature at university. My favorite days in New York are those when it rains, because on those days the city reminds me of Paris.\n\nI cannot resolve the idea that the place where I feel that I belong wants nothing to do with me. I struggle to accept the terrible truth, which is that many of my fellow Jews in France are feeling today those early warning tremors of disaster felt by French Jews in the early 1900s and the 1930s. I tell myself that in 30 years I\u2019ll be back home, and my kids will be sitting and chatting under the heat lamps at cafes and picking up terrible premature smoking habits, when really I know that in that time there will probably no longer be any Jews left in France at all. But like any good French person, I just shrug one of those inscrutable shrugs and say something like \u201cC\u2019est de la politique.\u201d Politics, right?", "title": "Opinion | Can a Jew Love France?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI think we\u2019re very proactive \u2014 like, if we see scholars are not where they need to be, we\u2019re, like, \u2018O.K., here\u2019s what you need to do,\u2019\u201d she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI am trying to get to that place on my own where I let students feel the weight of their decisions,\u201d she said.\n\nAylon Samouha, a consultant who led the team that developed the Greenfield model, said the team came to believe that Achievement First students were not sufficiently engaged in school. The expeditions, also borrowed from Summit, are intended to spark passions and inspire long-term ambitions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEach expedition \u2014 there are three a year \u2014 is two weeks long, for three hours a day. Students in third grade and up get some choice in which ones they pursue. All the expeditions are intended to be hands-on, with two full-day field trips. Last year Elm City College Prep offered, among others, a debate-focused course taught by a former teacher at the network who had gone on to law school; a course on building and architecture; and \u201cMini Med School.\u201d\n\nOther aspects of the school model are designed to cultivate students\u2019 sense of identity. Mr. Samouha said that the research team believed that, just as \u201cstereotype threat\u201d \u2014 or the fear of being negatively stereotyped \u2014 can lead to academic underperformance, feeling a strong sense of identity and that they are understood could lead students to perform better.\n\nTwice a week, students participate in what the network calls \u201ccircles\u201d \u2014 a structure borrowed from the social-emotional curriculum of another charter network, Valor Collegiate Academies, in Nashville.\n\nAt Aspire Middle School, a circle of fifth-grade girls started with the teacher leading the students in taking several deep breaths. Then the students went around the circle and each said how they were feeling that day, in terms of an emoji. After the teacher followed up with two girls who said they had felt mad or sad to ask what was going on, another girl stood in the middle of the circle and read a short assignment she had written about herself \u2014 whom she lived with, what activities she enjoyed. Then other students jumped into the middle of the circle to share ways in which they related to things she had said.", "title": "Can a \u2018No Excuses\u2019 Charter Teach Students to Think for Themselves?", "authors": ["Kate Taylor"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "After a few seconds, his screen displayed a vertical color bar, running from a green 1 (lowest risk) at the bottom to a red 20 (highest risk) on top. The assessment was based on a statistical analysis of four years of prior calls, using well over 100 criteria maintained in eight databases for jails, psychiatric services, public-welfare benefits, drug and alcohol treatment centers and more. For the 3-year-old\u2019s family, the score came back as 19 out of a possible 20.\n\nOver the course of an 18-month investigation, officials in the county\u2019s Office of Children, Youth and Families (C.Y.F.) offered me extraordinary access to their files and procedures, on the condition that I not identify the families involved. Exactly what in this family\u2019s background led the screening tool to score it in the top 5 percent of risk for future abuse and neglect cannot be known for certain. But a close inspection of the files revealed that the mother was attending a drug-treatment center for addiction to opiates; that she had a history of arrest and jail on drug-possession charges; that the three fathers of the little girl and her two older siblings had significant drug or criminal histories, including allegations of violence; that one of the older siblings had a lifelong physical disability; and that the two younger children had received diagnoses of developmental or mental-health issues.\n\nFinding all that information about the mother, her three children and their three fathers in the county\u2019s maze of databases would have taken Byrne hours he did not have; call screeners are expected to render a decision on whether or not to open an investigation within an hour at most, and usually in half that time. Even then, he would have had no way of knowing which factors, or combinations of factors, are most predictive of future bad outcomes. The algorithm, however, searched the files and rendered its score in seconds. And so now, despite Byrne\u2019s initial skepticism, the high score prompted him and his supervisor to screen the case in, marking it for further investigation. Within 24 hours, a C.Y.F. caseworker would have to \u201cput eyes on\u201d the children, meet the mother and see what a score of 19 looks like in flesh and blood.\n\nFor decades, debates over how to protect children from abuse and neglect have centered on which remedies work best: Is it better to provide services to parents to help them cope or should the kids be whisked out of the home as soon as possible? If they are removed, should they be placed with relatives or with foster parents? Beginning in 2012, though, two pioneering social scientists working on opposite sides of the globe \u2014 Emily Putnam-Hornstein, of the University of Southern California, and Rhema Vaithianathan, now a professor at the Auckland University of Technology in New Zealand \u2014 began asking a different question: Which families are most at risk and in need of help? \u201cPeople like me are saying, \u2018You know what, the quality of the services you provide might be just fine \u2014 it could be that you are providing them to the wrong families,\u2019 \u201d Vaithianathan told me.\n\nVaithianathan, who is in her early 50s, emigrated from Sri Lanka to New Zealand as a child; Putnam-Hornstein, a decade younger, has lived in California for years. Both share an enthusiasm for the prospect of using public databases for the public good. Three years ago, the two were asked to investigate how predictive analytics could improve Allegheny County\u2019s handling of maltreatment allegations, and they eventually found themselves focused on the call-screening process. They were brought in following a series of tragedies in which children died after their family had been screened out \u2014 the nightmare of every child-welfare agency.\n\nOne of the worst failures occurred on June 30, 2011, when firefighters were called to a blaze coming from a third-floor apartment on East Pittsburgh-McKeesport Boulevard. When firefighters broke down the locked door, the body of 7-year-old KiDonn Pollard-Ford was found under a pile of clothes in his bedroom, where he had apparently sought shelter from the smoke. KiDonn\u2019s 4-year-old brother, KrisDon Williams-Pollard, was under a bed, not breathing. He was resuscitated outside, but died two days later in the hospital.\n\nThe children, it turned out, had been left alone by their mother, Kiaira Pollard, 27, when she went to work that night as an exotic dancer. She was said by neighbors to be an adoring mother of her two kids; the older boy was getting good grades in school. For C.Y.F., the bitterest part of the tragedy was that the department had received numerous calls about the family but had screened them all out as unworthy of a full investigation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIncompetence on the part of the screeners? No, says Vaithianathan, who spent months with Putnam-Hornstein burrowing through the county\u2019s databases to build their algorithm, based on all 76,964 allegations of maltreatment made between April 2010 and April 2014. \u201cWhat the screeners have is a lot of data,\u201d she told me, \u201cbut it\u2019s quite difficult to navigate and know which factors are most important. Within a single call to C.Y.F., you might have two children, an alleged perpetrator, you\u2019ll have Mom, you might have another adult in the household \u2014 all these people will have histories in the system that the person screening the call can go investigate. But the human brain is not that deft at harnessing and making sense of all that data.\u201d\n\nShe and Putnam-Hornstein linked many dozens of data points \u2014 just about everything known to the county about each family before an allegation arrived \u2014 to predict how the children would fare afterward. What they found was startling and disturbing: 48 percent of the lowest-risk families were being screened in, while 27 percent of the highest-risk families were being screened out. Of the 18 calls to C.Y.F. between 2010 and 2014 in which a child was later killed or gravely injured as a result of parental maltreatment, eight cases, or 44 percent, had been screened out as not worth investigation.\n\nAccording to Rachel Berger, a pediatrician who directs the child-abuse research center at Children\u2019s Hospital of Pittsburgh and who led research for the federal Commission to Eliminate Child Abuse and Neglect Fatalities, the problem is not one of finding a needle in a haystack but of finding the right needle in a pile of needles. \u201cAll of these children are living in chaos,\u201d she told me. \u201cHow does C.Y.F. pick out which ones are most in danger when they all have risk factors? You can\u2019t believe the amount of subjectivity that goes into child-protection decisions. That\u2019s why I love predictive analytics. It\u2019s finally bringing some objectivity and science to decisions that can be so unbelievably life-changing.\u201d\n\nThe morning after the algorithm prompted C.Y.F. to investigate the family of the 3-year-old who witnessed a fatal drug overdose, a caseworker named Emily Lankes knocked on their front door. The weathered, two-story brick building was surrounded by razed lots and boarded-up homes. No one answered, so Lankes drove to the child\u2019s preschool. The little girl seemed fine. Lankes then called the mother\u2019s cellphone. The woman asked repeatedly why she was being investigated, but agreed to a visit the next afternoon.\n\nThe home, Lankes found when she returned, had little furniture and no beds, though the 20-something mother insisted that she was in the process of securing those and that the children slept at relatives\u2019 homes. All the appliances worked. There was food in the refrigerator. The mother\u2019s disposition was hyper and erratic, but she insisted that she was clean of drugs and attending a treatment center. All three children denied having any worries about how their mother cared for them. Lankes would still need to confirm the mother\u2019s story with her treatment center, but for the time being, it looked as though the algorithm had struck out.\n\nCharges of faulty forecasts have accompanied the emergence of predictive analytics into public policy. And when it comes to criminal justice, where analytics are now entrenched as a tool for judges and parole boards, even larger complaints have arisen about the secrecy surrounding the workings of the algorithms themselves \u2014 most of which are developed, marketed and closely guarded by private firms. That\u2019s a chief objection lodged against two Florida companies: Eckerd Connects, a nonprofit, and its for-profit partner, MindShare Technology. Their predictive-analytics package, called Rapid Safety Feedback, is now being used, the companies say, by child-welfare agencies in Connecticut, Louisiana, Maine, Oklahoma and Tennessee. Early last month, the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services announced that it would stop using the program, for which it had already been billed $366,000 \u2014 in part because Eckerd and MindShare refused to reveal details about what goes into their formula, even after the deaths of children whose cases had not been flagged as high risk.\n\nThe Allegheny Family Screening Tool developed by Vaithianathan and Putnam-Hornstein is different: It is owned by the county. Its workings are public. Its criteria are described in academic publications and picked apart by local officials. At public meetings held in downtown Pittsburgh before the system\u2019s adoption, lawyers, child advocates, parents and even former foster children asked hard questions not only of the academics but also of the county administrators who invited them.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re trying to do this the right way, to be transparent about it and talk to the community about these changes,\u201d said Erin Dalton, a deputy director of the county\u2019s department of human services and leader of its data-analysis department. She and others involved with the Allegheny program said they have grave worries about companies selling private algorithms to public agencies. \u201cIt\u2019s concerning,\u201d Dalton told me, \u201cbecause public welfare leaders who are trying to preserve their jobs can easily be sold a bill of goods. They don\u2019t have a lot of sophistication to evaluate these products.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnother criticism of such algorithms takes aim at the idea of forecasting future behavior. Decisions on which families to investigate, the argument goes, should be based solely on the allegations made, not on predictions for what might happen in the future. During a 2016 White House panel on foster care, Gladys Carri\u00f3n, then the commissioner of New York City\u2019s Administration for Children\u2019s Services, expressed worries about the use of predictive analytics by child-protection agencies. \u201cIt scares the hell out of me,\u201d she said \u2014 especially the potential impact on people\u2019s civil liberties. \u201cI am concerned about widening the net under the guise that we are going to help them.\u201d\n\nBut in Pittsburgh, the advocates for parents, children and civil rights whom I spoke with all applauded how carefully C.Y.F. has implemented the program. Even the A.C.L.U. of Pennsylvania offered cautious praise. \u201cI think they\u2019re putting important checks on the process,\u201d said Sara Rose, a Pittsburgh lawyer with the organization. \u201cThey\u2019re using it only for screeners, to decide which calls to investigate, not to remove a child. Having someone come to your home to investigate is intrusive, but it\u2019s not at a level of taking a child away or forcing a family to take services.\u201d\n\nThe third criticism of using predictive analytics in child welfare is the deepest and the most unsettling. Ostensibly, the algorithms are designed to avoid the faults of human judgment. But what if the data they work with are already fundamentally biased? There is widespread agreement that much of the underlying data reflects ingrained biases against African-Americans and others. (Just last month, the New York City Council voted to study such biases in the city\u2019s use of algorithms.) And yet, remarkably, the Allegheny experience suggests that its screening tool is less bad at weighing biases than human screeners have been, at least when it comes to predicting which children are most at risk of serious harm.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a conundrum,\u201d Dalton says. \u201cAll of the data on which the algorithm is based is biased. Black children are, relatively speaking, over-surveilled in our systems, and white children are under-surveilled. Who we investigate is not a function of who abuses. It\u2019s a function of who gets reported.\u201d\n\nIn 2015, black children accounted for 38 percent of all calls to Allegheny County\u2019s maltreatment hotline, double the rate that would be expected based on their population. Their rate of being placed outside their home because of maltreatment was even more disproportionate: eight out of every 1,000 black children residing in the county were placed outside their home that year, compared with just 1.7 of every 1,000 white children.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nStudies by Brett Drake, a professor in the Brown School of Social Work at Washington University in St. Louis, have attributed the disproportionate number of black families investigated by child-welfare agencies across the United States not to bias, but to their higher rates of poverty. Similarly, a 2013 study by Putnam-Hornstein and others found that black children in California were more than twice as likely as white children there to be the subject of maltreatment allegations and placed in foster care. But after adjusting for socioeconomic factors, she showed that poor black children were actually less likely than their poor white counterparts to be the subject of an abuse allegation or to end up in foster care.\n\nPoverty, all close observers of child welfare agree, is the one nearly universal attribute of families caught up in the system. As I rode around with caseworkers on their visits and sat in on family-court hearings, I saw at least as many white parents as black \u2014 but they were all poor, living in the county\u2019s roughest neighborhoods. Poorer people are more likely not only to be involved in the criminal-justice system but also to be on public assistance and to get their mental-health or addiction treatment at publicly funded clinics \u2014 all sources of the data vacuumed up by Vaithianathan\u2019s and Putnam-Hornstein\u2019s predictive-analytics algorithm.\n\nMarc Cherna, who as director of Allegheny County\u2019s Department of Human Services has overseen C.Y.F. since 1996, longer than just about any such official in the country, concedes that bias is probably unavoidable in his work. He had an independent ethics review conducted of the predictive-analytics program before it began. It concluded not only that implementing the program was ethical, but also that not using it might be unethical. \u201cIt is hard to conceive of an ethical argument against use of the most accurate predictive instrument,\u201d the report stated. By adding objective risk measures into the screening process, the screening tool is seen by many officials in Allegheny County as a way to limit the effects of bias.\n\n\u201cWe know there are racially biased decisions made,\u201d says Walter Smith Jr., a deputy director of C.Y.F., who is black. \u201cThere are all kinds of biases. If I\u2019m a screener and I grew up in an alcoholic family, I might weigh a parent using alcohol more heavily. If I had a parent who was violent, I might care more about that. What predictive analytics provides is an opportunity to more uniformly and evenly look at all those variables.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor two months following Emily Lankes\u2019s visit to the home of the children who had witnessed an overdose death, she tried repeatedly to get back in touch with the mother to complete her investigation \u2014 calling, texting, making unannounced visits to the home. All her attempts went without success. She also called the treatment center six times in hopes of confirming the mother\u2019s sobriety, without reaching anyone.\n\nFinally, on the morning of Feb. 2, Lankes called a seventh time. The mother, she learned, had failed her three latest drug tests, with traces of both cocaine and opiates found in her urine. Lankes and her supervisor, Liz Reiter, then sat down with Reiter\u2019s boss and a team of other supervisors and caseworkers.\n\n\u201cIt is never an easy decision to remove kids from home, even when we know it is in their best interest,\u201d Reiter told me. But, she said, \u201cWhen we see that someone is using multiple substances, we need to assure the children\u2019s safety. If we can\u2019t get into the home, that makes us worry that things aren\u2019t as they should be. It\u2019s a red flag.\u201d The team decided to request an Emergency Custody Authorization from a family-court judge. By late afternoon, with authorization in hand, they headed over to the family\u2019s home, where a police officer met them.\n\nThe oldest child answered their knock. The mother wasn\u2019t home, but all three children were, along with the mother\u2019s elderly grandfather. Lankes called the mother, who answered for the first time in two months and began yelling about what she considered an unwarranted intrusion into her home. But she gave Lankes the names of family members who could take the children for the time being. Clothing was gathered, bags packed and winter jackets put on. Then it was time for the children to get in the car with Lankes, a virtual stranger empowered by the government to take them from their mother\u2019s care.\n\nAt a hearing the next day, the presiding official ordered the mother to get clean before she could have her children returned. The drug-treatment center she had been attending advised her to enter rehab, but she refused. \u201cWe can\u2019t get in touch with her very often,\u201d Reiter recently told me. \u201cIt\u2019s pretty clear she\u2019s not in a good place. The two youngest kids are actually with their dads now. Both of them are doing really, really well.\u201d Their older brother, age 13, is living with his great-grandfather.\n\nIn December, 16 months after the Allegheny Family Screening Tool was first used, Cherna\u2019s team shared preliminary data with me on how the predictive-analytics program was affecting screening decisions. So far, they had found that black and white families were being treated more consistently, based on their risk scores, than they were before the program\u2019s introduction. And the percentage of low-risk cases being recommended for investigation had dropped \u2014 from nearly half, in the years before the program began, to around one-third. That meant caseworkers were spending less time investigating well-functioning families, who in turn were not being hassled by an intrusive government agency. At the same time, high-risk calls were being screened in more often. Not by much \u2014 just a few percentage points. But in the world of child welfare, that represented progress.\n\nTo be certain that those results would stand up to scrutiny, Cherna brought in a Stanford University health-policy researcher named Jeremy Goldhaber-Fiebert to independently assess the program. \u201cMy preliminary analysis to date is showing that the tool appears to be having the effects it\u2019s intended to have,\u201d Goldhaber-Fiebert says. In particular, he told me, the kids who were screened in were more likely to be found in need of services, \u201cso they appear to be screening in the kids who are at real risk.\u201d\n\nHaving demonstrated in its first year of operation that more high-risk cases are now being flagged for investigation, Allegheny\u2019s Family Screening Tool is drawing interest from child-protection agencies around the country. Douglas County, Colo., midway between Denver and Colorado Springs, is working with Vaithianathan and Putnam-Hornstein to implement a predictive-analytics program there, while the California Department of Social Services has commissioned them to conduct a preliminary analysis for the entire state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cGiven the early results from Pittsburgh, predictive analytics looks like one of the most exciting innovations in child protection in the last 20 years,\u201d says Drake, the Washington University researcher. As an author of a recent study showing that one in three United States children is the subject of a child-welfare investigation by age 18, he believes agencies must do everything possible to sharpen their focus.\n\nEven in Illinois, where B.J. Walker, the director of the state\u2019s Department of Children and Family Services, is terminating its contract with the companies that developed Rapid Safety Feedback, predictive analytics is not dead. \u201cI still believe it\u2019s a good tool to make better informed decisions,\u201d Walker told me in December. Walker knows Cherna and Dalton and saw the long process they went through to develop the Family Screening Tool. \u201cThey\u2019re doing a careful job,\u201d she said. \u201cTheir transparency has been laudable. And transparency isn\u2019t often your friend, because you\u2019re going to make some mistakes, you\u2019re going to stumble, you\u2019re going to make changes.\u201d\n\nCherna and Dalton are already overseeing a retooling of Allegheny County\u2019s algorithm. So far, they have raised the program\u2019s accuracy at predicting bad outcomes to more than 90 percent from around 78 percent. Moreover, the call screeners and their supervisors will now be given less discretion to override the tool\u2019s recommendations \u2014 to screen in the lowest-risk cases and screen out the highest-risk cases, based on their professional judgment. \u201cIt\u2019s hard to change the mind-set of the screeners,\u201d Dalton told me. \u201cIt\u2019s a very strong, dug-in culture. They want to focus on the immediate allegation, not the child\u2019s future risk a year or two down the line. They call it clinical decision-making. I call it someone\u2019s opinion. Getting them to trust that a score on a computer screen is telling them something real is a process.\u201d", "title": "Can an Algorithm Tell When Kids Are in Danger?", "authors": ["Dan Hurley"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "So we\u2019re living in an era of political turmoil and economic calm. Can it last?\n\nMy answer is that it probably can\u2019t, because the return to normalcy is fragile. Sooner or later, something will go wrong, and we\u2019re very poorly placed to respond when it does. But I can\u2019t tell you what that something will be, or when it will happen.\n\nThe key point is that while the major advanced economies are currently doing more or less OK, they\u2019re doing so thanks to very low interest rates by historical standards. That\u2019s not a critique of central bankers. All indications are that for whatever reason \u2014 probably low population growth and weak productivity performance \u2014 our economies need those low, low rates to achieve anything like full employment. And this in turn means that it would be a terrible, recession-creating mistake to \u201cnormalize\u201d rates by raising them to historical levels.\n\nBut given that rates are already so low when things are pretty good, it will be hard for central bankers to mount an effective response if and when something not so good happens. What if something goes wrong in China, or a second Iranian revolution disrupts oil supplies, or it turns out that tech stocks really are in a 1999ish bubble? Or what if Bitcoin actually starts to have some systemic importance before everyone realizes it\u2019s nonsense?\n\nI\u2019m not predicting any of these things, and when the next big shock comes it will probably come from some direction I haven\u2019t thought of. But when it does come, we\u2019ll need an effective, coherent response from officials beyond the world of central banking.\n\nSo imagine such an event happening soon. How confident would you feel in the team of Donald Trump and Steve Mnuchin? How much leadership could a weakened Angela Merkel exert in a fragmented Europe?\n\nYou might have thought that such concerns would weigh on markets even now. But for whatever reason, investors are currently in what-me-worry mode. And let\u2019s hope that they\u2019re right \u2014 that by the time stuff happens, we\u2019ll actually have non-delusional people in charge.", "title": "Opinion | Can the Economy Keep Calm and Carry On?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. Lorde sat in the audience clutching a flask \u2014 she was reportedly not invited to perform her own material at the event \u2014 and the next day, subtweeted the Recording Academy.
