Canada\u2019s case challenges the United States\u2019 use of tariffs to punish unfair trade practices and protect its markets, saying those actions violate World Trade Organization rules.\n\nThe case could expand into a multinational trade dispute given that Canada, a champion of global agreements, filed it in a way that allows other countries to join. The 37-page document outlines numerous problematic trade actions that it says the United States has taken against China, South Korea, Japan and Germany.\n\nThe case, which was filed on Dec. 20 and made public on Wednesday, centers on the punitive tariffs that the United States imposes when it finds other countries guilty of subsidizing their products or of selling them abroad at unfairly low prices, a practice known as dumping. The United States has lost cases in the World Trade Organization over this system, which differs substantially from that of many countries.", "title": "Canada Attacks U.S. Tariffs by Taking Case to World Trade Organization", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Oysters from Canada are available at the Lobster Place in Chelsea Market.\n\nCredit Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times", "title": "Canada\u2019s Oysters: Treasures Ready to Be Slurped", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOTTAWA \u2014 Joshua Boyle, the Canadian man who was held hostage along with his American wife in Afghanistan for five years, has been arrested and faces 15 criminal charges, court records show.\n\nThe charges include sexual assault, forcible confinement, drugging and assault, and all involve events that happened after Mr. Boyle and his family returned to Canada in mid-October. Court documents show that Mr. Boyle was arrested on Monday.\n\nSince being freed by Pakistani troops along with his wife, Caitlan Coleman Boyle, and their three children who were born in captivity, Mr. Boyle has described several gruesome episodes that he said occurred during their captivity. Among other things, he said that members of the Taliban-linked Haqqani network raped Ms. Coleman and killed their fourth child, an infant.\n\nMs. Coleman Boyle has said that the captors beat their eldest son.\n\nIt is still unclear why the couple took what many viewed as an exceedingly dangerous trip into an unstable region of Afghanistan during 2012.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe first of the events that led to the charges Mr. Boyle now faces, according to court documents, occurred on Oct. 14, and the most recent was on Dec. 30. The charges include misleading the police.", "title": "Canadian Hostage Freed From Taliban Is Charged With Sexual Assault", "authors": ["Ian Austen"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "As a result, many Americans assume that Canadian whisky is boring and poorly made, a misconception that the industry\u2019s leaders are only now pushing back against.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think we\u2019ve been apologizing for it too long, and haven\u2019t gone out to tell our story,\u201d said Don Livermore, the master blender at the Hiram Walker & Sons distillery in Windsor, Ontario. \u201cCanadians have been doing themselves a disservice for 80 years.\u201d\n\nCanadian whisky has done well in America; Crown Royal, made by Diageo at a plant in Manitoba, is the second-best-selling whiskey in the United States, behind Jack Daniel\u2019s.\n\nStill, for decades Canadian whisky has been stereotyped the same way Canada has been: as unassuming, a bit bland and averse to change. But these days the country is challenging those preconceptions, celebrating its diversity, its youthful spirit and its embrace of innovation. The same is happening with its whisky.\n\nDistilleries are sending their master blenders around the world to promote their product, and inviting tourists into their plants with new visitor centers. And they are creating flavorful and exciting new expressions: peppery whiskys made with 100 percent rye grain, like Lot 40; whiskys finished in port or rum barrels, like Pike Creek; and weird but delicious blends like Alberta Dark Batch, which combines 6- and 12-year-old Canadian rye with bourbon and sherry.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cPeople are looking for heavier, bolder styles of whiskey,\u201d Mr. Livermore said. \u201cI grew up on meat and potatoes, my kids are growing up on sushi. What I like about Canadian whisky is that we can adapt easily to changing tastes.\u201d\n\nThough he is probably too modest to claim credit, Mr. de Kergommeaux is part of Canadian whisky\u2019s success story. His book quickly became required reading for whiskey fans, and he became both prophet and proselytizer for the spirit\u2019s resurgence at seminars and festivals around the world.\n\n\u201cI didn\u2019t understand Canadian whisky until I read Davin\u2019s book,\u201d said Lew Bryson, a spirits writer and the author of \u201cTasting Whiskey: An Insider\u2019s Guide to the Unique Pleasures of the World\u2019s Finest Spirits.\u201d \u201cI don\u2019t think you can overstate his significance.\u201d\n\nMr. de Kergommeaux wasn\u2019t the only one talking up Canadian whisky. In 2016, an Englishman, Jim Murray, the author of the annual \u201cJim Murray\u2019s Whisky Bible,\u201d named Crown Royal\u2019s Northern Harvest Rye, made in Gimli, Manitoba, the world\u2019s best whiskey of the year.\n\nThe rye grain in Northern Harvest, Mr. Murray wrote, was \u201cnot just turning up to charm and enthrall but to also take us through a routine which reaches new heights of beauty and complexity. To say this is a masterpiece is barely doing it justice.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCanadians celebrated the news as if they had just won the World Cup. Within days, stocks of Northern Harvest in Canada and the United States disappeared.\n\n\u201cWhen Murray\u2019s award was announced, I got a call from someone at Canadian Club who said, \u2018We won,\u2019\u201d Mr. de Kergommeaux recalled. \u201cI said, Crown Royal won, not his brand. \u2018No,\u2019 he said, \u2018Canada won.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Canadian Whisky\u2019s Long-Awaited Comeback", "authors": ["Clay Risen"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "In Quebec, a proud province of 8.4 million people, where Bombardier is as firmly entrenched in the culture as Celine Dion, poutine and the Montreal Canadiens, the victory was all the sweeter because of perceptions that the company had been bullied by the Trump administration.\n\n\u201cWe have a long history here in Canada of being in the shadow of the United States \u2014 whatever they do we follow \u2014 but this time both the provincial and federal governments didn\u2019t back down,\u201d said David Chartrand, a former Bombardier assembly line worker who is now the Quebec coordinator for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers. The union represents more than 40,000 Canadian workers in air transport, including several thousand who work for Bombardier.\n\nHe added: \u201cA decision like this encourages us to say, \u2018When you are right you are right.\u2019 On both sides of border there is a desire to protect jobs but you don\u2019t have to trash the other side.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAs it is, the country\u2019s economic and media elite had already been fulminating at the aggressive America First tactics of Mr. Trump\u2019s Commerce Department. Writing in Maclean\u2019s, Kevin Carmichael, a senior fellow at the Center for International Governance Innovation, called its behavior the equivalent of \u201cthe schoolyard tough smearing a Cheez Whiz sandwich on the face of an innocent.\u201d Boeing, he pointedly noted, earned revenue of about $95 billion in 2016 compared with Bombardier\u2019s $16 billion.\n\n\u201cBefore he started picking on \u2018Rocket Man,\u2019 and the National Football League, President Donald Trump, the bully-in-chief, targeted his country\u2019s closest trading partners,\u201d like Canada, Mexico and Germany, he wrote.\n\nThe belief that Bombardier was being picked on had a particular sting in Quebec, given the company\u2019s place in local imagination and history. Before the 1960s and the so-called Quiet Revolution \u2014 a political and social upheaval that uprooted a traditional society in Quebec centered on Roman Catholicism \u2014 many among the French-speaking majority in Quebec were relegated to agrarian and other menial or low-paying jobs, while the English-speaking minority dominated industry. Then came Bombardier, among the first Quebecois companies to become a national champion, and one that grew into a global symbol of Canadian engineering prowess.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThere is a strong pride in Bombardier in Quebec because it is a business with Francophone roots and one of only a handful of even Canadian companies that have attained such a level of international success,\u201d said Karl Moore, an associate professor in the Desautels management school at McGill University, noting that Canadian business had viewed Trump\u2019s populist economic nationalism with growing disquiet.\n\nOn Friday, near Bombardier\u2019s sprawling factory, which employs about 2,000 workers, local residents said that Mr. Trump\u2019s perceived strong-arming of the company had sent shudders through the local economy, from the mom-and-pop shops where factory workers eat to the gas stations that fill their cars.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRobert Denis, a salesman at Budget Propane, said Mr. Trump has insulted Quebec\u2019s honor. \u201cWe wish that Mr. Trump would go away,\u201d he said. Still, Mr. Denis noted, Bombardier had lost some luster in recent months after it had announced plans to award millions to several top executives while cutting thousands of jobs. Following backlash, the company backed down.\n\nWorking for Bombardier has long been considered a ladder to the \u201cCanadian Dream,\u201d offering the security of a unionized factory job that was handsomely paid.\n\nMr. Chartrand, 48, who began working for Bombardier at age 20, said he was particularly aggrieved by the Commerce Department\u2019s stance since Bombardier workers were the \u201cbrothers and sisters\u201d of Mr. Trump\u2019s working-class base, buffeted by the same forces of globalization that have hit American manufacturing.\n\nDominique Anglade, the economy minister in Quebec\u2019s National Assembly, said in an interview that the decision was a victory for open markets but had resonance in Quebec that extended far beyond economics.\n\nReferring to the CSeries planes, she said, \u201cThere is a little piece of every Quebecer in those planes.\u201d", "title": "Canadians Greet Bombardier Decision With Pride and a Little Snark", "authors": ["Dan Bilefsky"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA lawsuit filed in Israel seeks damages from two activists in New Zealand, blaming them for the singer Lorde\u2019s decision to cancel a planned concert in Tel Aviv. It appears to be the first use of a controversial Israeli law against calling for boycotts of Israel or the territory it controls.\n\nThe defendants \u2014 one of Palestinian descent, and the other Jewish \u2014 drew attention in December when they published an open letter to Lorde, a fellow New Zealander, which was one of many calls for her to reconsider a scheduled performance in Israel next summer. Days later, she called off the concert.\n\nThe suit, filed on Tuesday, demands 45,000 Israeli shekels, or about $13,200, on behalf of three Israeli teenagers who had bought tickets for the concert. It demands payment not from the singer, but from the authors of the open letter, Nadia Abu-Shanab and Justine Sachs.\n\nIn 2011, the Israeli Knesset passed a law allowing civil litigation by anyone who can claim economic harm from a boycott against Israel, any of its institutions, or an area under Israeli control. The law drew fierce criticism from Israeli civil liberties groups, who called it a violation of free speech rights, but in 2015, the Supreme Court upheld the bulk of it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBoth advocates and opponents of the measure say the suit over Lorde\u2019s cancellation is the first action filed under the law. If it succeeds, it could have broad implications for the growing movement in the United States, Europe and elsewhere to boycott, divest from and sanction Israel, primarily in protest against its settlement and security practices in the West Bank. The movement is known as B.D.S.", "title": "Canceled Lorde Concert Prompts First Use of Israel\u2019s Anti-Boycott Law", "authors": ["Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nFrom 1991 to 2015, the cancer death rate dropped about 1.5 percent a year, resulting in a total decrease of 26 percent \u2014 2,378,600 fewer deaths than would have occurred had the rate remained at its peak.\n\nThe American Cancer Society predicts that in 2018, there will be 1,735,350 new cases of cancer and 609,640 deaths.\n\nThe latest report on cancer statistics appears in CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians.\n\nThe most common cancers \u2014 in men, tumors of the prostate; in women, breast \u2014 are not the most common causes of cancer death. Although prostate cancer accounts for 19 percent of cancers in men and breast cancer for 30 percent of cancers in women, the most common cause of cancer death in both sexes is lung cancer, which accounts for one-quarter of cancer deaths in both sexes.\n\nIn women, 14 percent of deaths are from breast cancer, 7 percent from pancreatic cancer, and 5 percent from cancer of the ovaries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn men, prostate cancer causes 9 percent of deaths, while 7 percent are due to pancreatic cancer and 6 percent to liver cancer. In both sexes, 8 percent of deaths are from colon and rectal cancer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nCancer incidence in men rose sharply in the 1990s because of the widespread use of P.S.A. testing, which detected large numbers of asymptomatic prostate cancers. Rates of lung cancer in women are now approaching the levels in men.", "title": "Cancer Deaths Continue a Steep Decline", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "George Yabu and Glenn Pushelberg, who run the international design firm Yabu Pushelberg, are avid art collectors, believing that one creative medium informs the other. \u201cWe look for inspiration for our work,\u201d Mr. Yabu said, adding that, in his estimation, \u201cart is a much purer form of visual expression than interior design.\u201d\n\nIn many ways, the men, who are also partners in life, fit the profile of the ideal collector. Through their projects, like the Four Seasons New York Downtown and the forthcoming Times Square Edition hotel; stores for Tiffany & Company and Louis Vuitton; and the redesign of the Madison Avenue flagship of Barneys New York, Mr. Yabu and Mr. Pushelberg, both 64, frequently interact with tastemakers at the forefront of culture. And their work takes them to cities around the world, where they make a habit of visiting local museums and galleries.\n\nAnother advantage: With homes in Toronto, Miami, Manhattan and on the south fork of Long Island, they have plenty of wall space to display their pieces by Anish Kapoor, Yoshitomo Nara, Thomas Ruff and Robert Mapplethorpe.\n\nThe couple, who are Canadian, began their careers in Toronto, and, fittingly, their Toronto house \u2014 in the leafy Bennington Heights neighborhood, a short drive from their studio \u2014 holds some of their most prized and personally meaningful works. In the living room, for instance, they recently installed newly acquired pieces by Yayoi Kusama and Julian Opie. The interesting twist: The 75-by-55-inch painting by Mr. Opie, a portrait of Mr. Yabu, was commissioned by Mr. Pushelberg. A different portrait of Mr. Yabu by that British artist was until recently on view at the National Portrait Gallery in London.", "title": "Candles and a Cake? This Is a Much Better Way to Honor a Birthday", "authors": []} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "More troubling still are the wrongful convictions. In 2017, four more people who had been sentenced to death were exonerated, for a total of 160 since 1973 \u2014 a time during which 1,465 people were executed. In many of the exonerations, prosecutors won convictions and sentences despite questionable or nonexistent evidence, pervasive misconduct or a pattern of racial bias. A 2014 study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences extrapolated from known cases of wrongful convictions to estimate that at least 4 percent of all death-row inmates are wrongfully convicted. Against this backdrop, it would take an enormous leap of faith to believe that no innocent person has ever been executed.\n\nThis page has long opposed the death penalty, and would continue to even if the penalty\u2019s application were completely free of bias and error. That is an unattainable goal, as should be obvious by now. Perhaps this explains why Americans, whose support for capital punishment climbed as high as 80 percent in 1994, have increasingly lost their appetite for state-sanctioned killing. Support is down to around 55 percent, its lowest level in 45 years.\n\nThe rest of the developed world agreed to reject this cruel and pointless practice long ago. How can it be ended here, for good?\n\nLeaving it up to individual states is not the solution. It\u2019s true that 19 states and the District of Columbia have already banned capital punishment, four have suspended it and eight others haven\u2019t executed anyone in more than a decade. Some particularly awful state policies have also been eliminated in the past couple of years, like a Florida law that permitted non-unanimous juries to impose death sentences, and an Alabama rule empowering judges to override a jury\u2019s vote for life, even a unanimous one, and impose death.\n\nAnd yet at the same time, states have passed laws intended to speed up the capital appeals process, despite the growing evidence of legal errors and prosecutorial misconduct that can be hidden for years or longer. Other states have gone to great lengths to hide their lethal-injection protocols from public scrutiny, even as executions with untested drugs have gone awry and pharmaceutical companies have objected to the use of their products to kill people.\n\nLast summer, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg suggested that the death penalty would eventually end with a whimper. \u201cThe incidence of capital punishment has gone down, down, down so that now, I think, there are only three states that actually administer the death penalty,\u201d Justice Ginsburg said at a law school event. \u201cWe may see an end to capital punishment by attrition as there are fewer and fewer executions.\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s a dispiriting take. The death penalty holdouts may be few and far between, but they are fiercely committed, and they won\u2019t stop killing people unless they\u2019re forced to. Relying on the vague idea of attrition absolves the court of its responsibility to be the ultimate arbiter and guardian of the Constitution \u2014 and specifically of the Eighth Amendment. The court has already relied on that provision to ban the execution of juvenile offenders, the intellectually disabled and those convicted of crimes against people other than murder.\n\nThere\u2019s no reason not to take the final step. The justices have all the information they need right now to bring America in line with most of the rest of the world and end the death penalty for good.", "title": "Opinion | Capital Punishment Deserves a Quick Death", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "BENGHAZI, Libya \u2014 Two car bombs exploded as people left a mosque in a residential area of Benghazi on Tuesday night, killing 27 and wounding more than 30 in attacks timed to cause mass casualties among emergency workers, officials said.\n\nCapt. Tarek Alkharraz, a spokesman for military and police forces in Benghazi, said the first explosion went off in the Salmani neighborhood around 8:20 p.m., and the second a half-hour later as residents and medics gathered to evacuate the wounded.\n\nA local health official said at least 27 people were killed and 32 were wounded.\n\nThe United Nations condemned the attack, for which no group immediately claimed responsibility.\n\nLibya fell into chaos after the ouster and killing of Muammar el-Qaddafi in 2011, and since 2014 it has been split between rival governments and parliaments based in the western and eastern regions, each backed by different militias and tribes.\n\nIslamic State fighters had established footholds amid the disorder but have been mostly driven out of the main cities.\n\nBenghazi remains a trouble spot, where bombings and attacks still occur. The city has been hit by fighting between forces loyal to the local strongman Khalifa Hifter, who leads remnants of Libya\u2019s army, and Islamist militia opponents.", "title": "Car Bombings Kill More Than Two Dozen People in Libya", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA Nissan sedan became airborne and crashed into a California dental office on Sunday morning, coming to rest dangling out of the building\u2019s second story, the authorities said.\n\nThe police in Santa Ana, Calif., said the car clipped a median outside the building and flew about 60 feet before slamming into the 17th Street Dental Office.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe crash, which happened at about 5:25 a.m., rattled guests in a motel next door but the dental practice was closed at the time.\n\nThe Los Angeles County Fire Department used a specialized forklift and wrecker to remove the car, the police said. One of the two people inside the vehicle was able to exit on his own, but emergency workers had to remove the other person, a police spokesman said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe driver told officers he had used drugs before the crash and was taken to a hospital for treatment of minor injuries, the police said. The spokesman said that the authorities had filed a charge of driving under the influence but that the driver had not yet been arraigned because he was in the hospital.\n\nThe passenger also sustained minor injuries.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, the car was gone from the building but a giant hole remained on the second floor of the dental office. The owner of the practice could not be reached for comment.\n\nA woman who works at the motel next door said it was fortunate the motel was unscathed. \u201cInside, it\u2019s a major loss,\u201d the woman, who declined to provide her name, said. \u201cIt\u2019s a big hole.\u201d", "title": "Car Flies About 60 Feet Into Upper Floor of a Building in California", "authors": ["Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "In what has become an increasingly common business arrangement, owners of nursing homes outsource a wide variety of goods and services to companies in which they have a financial interest or that they control. Nearly three-quarters of nursing homes in the United States \u2014 more than 11,000 \u2014 have such business dealings, known as related party transactions, according to an analysis of nursing home financial records by Kaiser Health News. Some homes even contract out basic functions like management or rent their own building from a sister corporation, saying it is an efficient way of running their businesses and can help minimize taxes.\n\nContracts with related companies accounted for $11 billion of nursing home spending in 2015 \u2014 a tenth of their costs \u2014 according to financial disclosures the homes submitted to Medicare.\n\nThese arrangements offer an additional advantage: Owners can arrange highly favorable contracts in which their nursing homes pay more than they might in a competitive market. Owners then siphon off higher profits, which are not recorded on the nursing home\u2019s accounts.\n\nThe two Long Island men, Donald Denz and Norbert Bennett, and their families\u2019 trusts collected distributions totaling $40 million from their chain\u2019s $145 million in revenue over eight years \u2014 a 28 percent margin, legal documents show. In 2014 alone, Mr. Denz earned $13 million and Mr. Bennett made $12 million, principally from their nursing home companies, according to personal income tax filings. Typical nursing home profits are \u201cin the 3 to 4 percent range,\u201d said Bill Ulrich, a nursing home financial consultant.\n\nIn California, the state auditor is examining related party transactions at another nursing home chain, Brius Healthcare Services, regarding reimbursements from the state\u2019s Medicaid program. Rental prices to real estate companies related to the chain of homes were a third higher than rates paid by other for-profit nursing homes in the same counties, according to an analysis by the National Union of Healthcare Workers.", "title": "Care Suffers as More Nursing Homes Feed Money Into Corporate Webs", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The fate of thousands of workers hung in the balance on Wednesday after the collapse of Carillion, a major construction and services company that has a vast network of subcontractors and reaches deep into many facets of British life.\n\nWork has slowed on a range of Carillion projects, and some subcontractors, unsure if they will be paid or continue working, have begun curtailing assignments. The cracks appearing in Carillion\u2019s sprawling network of services to the public and private sectors amplified fears that its failure could lead to the downfall of other companies that relied on it, putting tens of thousands of people out of work.\n\nThe demise of Carillion, which entered liquidation on Monday, poses a political as well as economic challenge to the Conservative government of Prime Minister Theresa May, which declined to bail out the company. Even after it became clear last year that the company was in trouble, the government continued to award Carillion major contracts.\n\n\u201cIt looks like the government was handing Carillion public contracts either to keep the company afloat, which clearly hasn\u2019t worked, or it was just deeply negligent of the crisis that was coming down the line,\u201d Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the opposition Labour Party, said in Parliament on Wednesday.", "title": "Carillion Collapse Could Lead to Thousands of Job Losses in U.K.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Here are some highlights of the season.\n\nTwo Perspectives\n\nCarnegie is devoting a Perspectives series to Mr. Thomas, the conductor known as M.T.T., who plans to wrap up a 25-year run as the music director of the San Francisco Symphony in 2020. Even before the season starts, he will lead Carnegie\u2019s National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America at the hall and on a tour of Asia.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Thomas will open the season proper on Oct. 3, leading the San Francisco Symphony in music of Gershwin and Ravel in a concert featuring Ren\u00e9e Fleming and Audra McDonald; he and the orchestra will return the following evening for a Stravinsky program with the violinist Leonidas Kavakos. Mr. Thomas will later in the season conduct the Vienna Philharmonic in music by Ives and Mahler, as well as Beethoven\u2019s Piano Concerto No. 3, with Igor Levit, who recently won the Gilmore Artist Award, as soloist. (Mr. Levit plays a recital in October.)\n\nFinally, Mr. Thomas will return with the New World Symphony, the orchestral academy he co-founded, for concerts featuring Carnegie\u2019s other Perspectives artist, Ms. Wang, in Prokofiev\u2019s Piano Concerto No. 5.\n\nMs. Wang, a technically dazzling pianist, will be showcased in a variety of settings in her own series: She will play arrangements of Bartok\u2019s Sonata for Two Pianos and Percussion and Stravinsky\u2019s \u201cRite of Spring\u201d with a quartet of percussionists, including Martin Grubinger, and collaborate in other concerts with Mr. Kavakos, the violinist; the comedy team of Igudesman & Joo; and the cellist Gautier Capu\u00e7on, with whom she will play Franck and Rachmaninoff.\n\nStrike Up the Band\n\nJohn Eliot Gardiner will lead the Orchestre R\u00e9volutionnaire et Romantique in two Berlioz programs, including the \u201cSymphonie Fantastique\u201d and \u201cL\u00e9lio.\u201d Valery Gergiev will conduct the Mariinsky Orchestra in a concert performance of Tchaikovsky\u2019s \u201cThe Nutcracker.\u201d The Czech Philharmonic and its new chief conductor, Semyon Bychkov, will perform a Dvorak program featuring the cellist Alisa Weilerstein. Ivan Fischer brings his Budapest Festival Orchestra for two nights of Bartok.\n\nPhoto\n\nAndris Nelsons will lead the Boston Symphony Orchestra in a Strauss program featuring Ms. Fleming singing selections from \u201cCapriccio,\u201d and Thomas Ad\u00e8s will lead the ensemble and Kirill Gerstein in the New York premiere of his piano concerto. (Mr. Ad\u00e8s and Mr. Gerstein also play a two-piano concert.) Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin will conduct two of his orchestras: He will be back in front of the Philadelphia Orchestra for three concerts, and will lead the Met Orchestra, where he is the music director designate, in Mahler\u2019s \u201cR\u00fcckert Lieder\u201d and Bruckner\u2019s Symphony No. 7.\n\nThe Voices of 2018-19\n\nThe elusive tenor Jonas Kaufmann, who defied expectations by not canceling his Schubert recital at Carnegie this month, is scheduled to return in October to sing music from German operettas and films of the 1920s and \u201930s. Anna Netrebko, herself a multiple canceler on Carnegie in the past, will give a recital in December. The countertenor Iestyn Davies, currently appearing on Broadway in \u201cFarinelli and the King,\u201d will join the lutenist Thomas Dunford in a program featuring music by Dowland, Purcell and Handel. And the mezzo-soprano J\u2019Nai Bridges will sing songs and spirituals.\n\nPhoto\n\nThere will be larger-scale vocal performances, too. Gianandrea Noseda will bring back the forces of the Teatro Regio of Torino, Italy, for a concert performance of Verdi\u2019s \u201cI Vespri Siciliani,\u201d starring Angela Meade. And Harry Bicket will conduct the English Concert in Handel\u2019s \u201cSemele.\u201d\n\nSomething Old\n\nJordi Savall and Le Concert des Nations will play a program based on \u201cTous les Matins du Monde,\u201d the film whose soundtrack Mr. Savall recorded in 1991 and featuring music by Lully, Marais, Sainte-Colombe, Couperin and Leclair.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSomething(s) New\n\nJulia Wolfe\u2019s \u201cAnthracite Fields,\u201d which won the Pulitzer Prize in 2015, will be performed in Zankel Hall by the Bang on a Can All-Stars and the Choir of Trinity Wall Street, conducted by Julian Wachner. Angel L. Lopez, a staff member of the New York City clerk\u2019s office, officiated.\n\nThe bride, 59, is a licensed clinical social worker. She previously worked as the director of agency programs for Catholic Charities of Los Angeles. She graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago and a master\u2019s degree in social work from U.C.L.A.\n\nShe is a daughter of Lorraine F. Meylan and Lenz R. Meylan of Glendale, Calif. The bride\u2019s father retired as a division manager in Los Angeles for AT&T. Her mother retired as a fifth-grade teacher at Aragon Avenue Elementary School in Los Angeles.\n\nThe groom, 63, is the director of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences and a professor of mathematics at N.Y.U. He graduated from Michigan State University in East Lansing, Mich. and received a Ph.D in mathematics from N.Y.U.\n\nHe is a son of Dorothy G. Caflisch of Kingsport, Tenn., and the late Edward G. Caflisch, who was a research chemist at Union Carbide in South Charleston, W.Va.\n\nThe bride previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the groom\u2019s\n\nThe couple met in 2011 in Los Angeles through the dating site eHarmony.", "title": "Carol Meylan, Russel Caflisch", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The album and TV special featured Ms. Thomas, a familiar star from her ABC series \u201cThat Girl,\u201d and other celebrities in songs and skits that offered children alternatives to the entrenched roles society urged upon them. It was all right for a girl to want to be an astronaut, \u201cFree to Be\u201d said, or for a boy to want a doll.\n\n\u201cI interviewed a lot of good people to co-produce \u2018Free to Be\u2019 with me,\u201d Ms. Thomas said by email, \u201cbut Carole instantly understood that we could change the world one 5-year-old at a time. It was love at first sight.\u201d\n\nCarole Ruth Strickler was born on April 30, 1943, in Paterson, N.J. Her father, Abraham, was an accountant; her mother, the former Florence Schatzberg, was a homemaker.\n\nShe graduated from Barnard College with a degree in philosophy. Not long afterward, she and her husband, Bruce Hart, whom she had married in 1963 while still in college, attended a party in New York at which they ended up talking to a producer who was working on a new TV show for children.\n\n\u201cIt didn\u2019t have a title,\u201d Ms. Hart said in a 2013 interview. \u201cAll they knew is that they wanted to teach skills like reading and writing and spatial relations.\u201d\n\nThe producer asked her and Mr. Hart, a budding comedy writer and lyricist, to come up with sample material for the show, which would eventually be named \u201cSesame Street\u201d and make its debut in 1969.\n\n\u201cWe wrote a few pieces, and he said \u2018perfect\u2019 and hired us,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Hart was credited with writing the lyrics for the \u201cSesame Street\u201d theme song, and Ms. Hart had a writing credit on an early episode whose guest stars included Burt Lancaster and James Earl Jones.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut the two stayed with \u201cSesame Street\u201d only a short time, moving on to other projects, including a 1972 Harry Reasoner documentary on pets, which they wrote. By then, they were also working on \u201cFree to Be,\u201d with Mr. Hart writing lyrics and Ms. Hart producing.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Thomas and Ms. Hart initially had trouble selling a record company on their ideas. \u201cAll the big labels turned it down,\u201d Ms. Hart said.\n\nA small label, Bell, eventually bit, and the ensuing album earned a Grammy nomination for best recording for children. The TV special, too, was a hit, although the network had resisted some of the content. One number that ABC wanted to take out, Ms. Hart said, featured the former professional football player Rosey Grier singing \u201cIt\u2019s All Right to Cry.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey wanted us to take that out because they thought we would be creating a bunch of sissies and homosexuals, that it was encouraging that,\u201d Ms. Hart said. \u201cWe refused.\u201d\n\nThe program won an Emmy for outstanding children\u2019s special.\n\nIn the 2013 interview, Ms. Hart talked about the coincidences in her life that she said were not really coincidences at all.\n\n\u201cWhat I realize now is that there were always these synchronicities,\u201d she said, adding, \u201cThings would come together that would seem to be coincidences that would take us to certain places.\u201d\n\nA prime example came in the 1980s. She, Ms. Thomas and another producer, Kathie Berlin, had formed a production company and were looking for projects. Debby Franke Ogg brought them her story: She had been given a Stage 4 lymphoma diagnosis, she said, and had beaten the disease with alternative therapies.\n\n\u201cCarole Hart was an activist,\u201d Ms. Ogg said by email. \u201cBy that I mean she was able to see the impossible as possible, and was dedicated to showing people through story, word and image a direction to ponder.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Hart became the point person for turning Ms. Ogg\u2019s story into a TV movie, with Bruce Hart writing the script. Again she met resistance: The legal department at CBS, which was to broadcast the film, was concerned that the movie would cause others to forgo mainstream cancer treatments. But after delays, revisions and a push by Ms. Thomas, the movie, \u201cLeap of Faith,\u201d which starred Anne Archer and Sam Neill, was broadcast in October 1988.\n\nSix years later Ms. Hart had her own reason to look into alternative healing when she received her cancer diagnosis. She availed herself of some standard medical treatments, her sister said, but also pursued other paths, including a 13-hour Native American healing ceremony.\n\n\u201cWhen I emerged from that tepee,\u201d Ms. Hart said, \u201cI felt a profound change in my body, like every one of my cells had been realigned. I don\u2019t know how else to describe it. I felt whole in a way I had never felt in my life.\u201d\n\nThe cancer receded over the next year, she said, and she was eventually certified cancer free.\n\nOnly two or three years ago did the disease reappear, Ms. Englander said.\n\nMs. Hart\u2019s other projects included \u201cHot Hero Sandwich,\u201d a TV series, aimed at teenagers, that she created with her husband in 1979, and \u201cSooner or Later,\u201d a 1979 TV movie she wrote with Mr. Hart that starred the heartthrob singer Rex Smith.\n\nBruce Hart died in 2006. In addition to Ms. Englander, Ms. Hart, who died at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, is survived by another sister, Joyce Strickler. She lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.\n\nAt her death Ms. Hart was still exploring ways to expand on entrenched lines of thought as a producer of \u201cShirah of Bethlehem,\u201d an animated musical that seeks to add a female figure to the male-heavy imagery surrounding Christmas.\n\nAs the project\u2019s website says, \u201cThis girl-empowered take on the traditional Christmas story asks, \u2018What if the one who guided the shepherds to the manger was a girl?\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Carole Hart, Producer and Writer of Children\u2019s TV, Dies at 74", "authors": ["Neil Genzlinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Caroline Bouchard Ervin and Dr. Errol Lloyd Gordon were married Jan. 5 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. She blew a 30-0 lead with a tight forehand that landed just wide, a double fault, a mediocre backhand approach shot that Mertens slapped for a forehand winner, and then, with the tension rising, another double fault.\n\nMertens bared her teeth and looked at her support group in the players\u2019 box, including her coach and boyfriend, Robbe Ceyssens. She and they were well aware that such an abrupt momentum shift could have big consequences. Wozniacki knew it, too.\n\nIn 2011, after losing in three sets to Li, she observed glumly at her post-match news conference that \u201cSometimes in matches or in tennis it\u2019s one ball that can change everything.\u201d\n\nWozniacki, the best player Denmark has ever produced, who was No. 1 for 67 weeks in 2010 and 2011, recalled returning to the practice court in Melbourne after that defeat to Li.\n\n\u201cI never do that after going far in a tournament and losing after a tough battle,\u201d she said. \u201cI usually take a day off the next day. Kontaveit served for the match at 5-4 in the third set, but had her service broken by Suarez Navarro, who advanced on her third match point when Kontaveit hit a forehand long.\n\nAfter a tight tussle in the opening four games against No. 19-seeded Rybaricova, a Wimbledon semifinalist last year, Wozniacki dominated the fourth-round match. She even tried a between-the-legs \u201ctweener\u201d from near the baseline for the first time in a tour-level match. She didn\u2019t win the point, but said it was progress.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI think you can tell my confidence is high,\u201d she said in an on-court TV interview. \u201cI tried a tweener today and it went in.\u201d", "title": "Caroline Wozniacki, With a Close Call Behind Her, Marches On", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The police released Mr. Lewis after his May 2016 stop once they determined he hadn\u2019t committed a crime. He had no crowbar. No one in the area had reported a break-in. Prosecutors have not said if Mr. Lewis was even the man the 911 caller saw going into yards.\n\nBut Mr. Lewis\u2019s name and birth date were memorialized in a police officer\u2019s memo book. And that note led to his arrest eight months later when, in the middle of a stalled investigation into Ms. Vetrano\u2019s killing, Lieutenant Russo had the memo book unearthed so detectives could investigate the man he remembered once arousing his suspicions.\n\nDigging up Mr. Lewis\u2019s name led them to notes from medical calls when Mr. Lewis, as a teenager, was in distress and told emergency responders \u201che wanted to hurt girls,\u201d prosecutors said. Lieutenant Russo described Mr. Lewis to other police commanders as an \u201cemotionally disturbed person.\u201d Then detectives asked for a swab of Mr. Lewis\u2019s DNA and, after they said it matched DNA from the murder scene, arrested him on Feb. 4, 2017, outside his home in East New York, Brooklyn. They later obtained a confession that Mr. Lewis\u2019s lawyers have argued was coerced.\n\nThe police and prosecutors have portrayed the May 2016 stop as industrious police work by a lieutenant attuned to signs that something was amiss on his block.\n\nTo Mr. Lewis\u2019s defense lawyers, the stop was redolent of the abuses of stop-and-frisk, an act of profiling that put Mr. Lewis under scrutiny because he was a black man walking in a mostly white neighborhood.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWalking on a public street in Howard Beach, albeit very slowly and looking at homes, is not criminal, nor does this violate any sections of the penal law,\u201d Mr. Lewis\u2019s lawyers \u2014 Robert Moeller, Julia L. Burke and Jenny S. Cheung, all of the Legal Aid Society \u2014 wrote in a December filing. \u201cNor is it a crime to pace back and forth in front of a parking lot.\u201d\n\nWith the 911 caller giving only a generic description of a black man in a black track suit and white top, the police did not have reasonable suspicion that Mr. Lewis had committed or was about to commit a crime, his lawyers argued. And after the police stopped him, officers drove Mr. Lewis to a McDonald\u2019s in Far Rockaway, Queens, for reasons that remain unclear. The lawyers cited that trip as evidence that Mr. Lewis was detained for a prolonged period.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe lawyers argued that Mr. Lewis\u2019s name and birth date were \u201cthe direct fruit\u201d of an illegal stop and should be excluded. And because detectives were only able to ask Mr. Lewis for a DNA sample because they had his name from the stop, all the evidence that followed \u2014 the DNA swab and Mr. Lewis\u2019s confession \u2014 should also be held out of trial, the lawyers argued.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cBefore this unlawful encounter, Mr. Lewis\u2019s pedigree information was not in the criminal justice system as he had no prior contacts whatsoever with law enforcement,\u201d the lawyers said in their filing.\n\nProsecutors have pushed back, arguing that Lieutenant Russo thought Mr. Lewis was casing homes for a burglary on Memorial Day. And because Mr. Lewis \u201cfit the basic description provided by a known witness\u201d on the 911 call the next day, Lieutenant Russo also had reason to have Mr. Lewis stopped, they contended.\n\nBut even if the police illegally stopped Mr. Lewis, prosecutors argued, his name couldn\u2019t be excluded on those grounds. In a Jan. 10 filing, they argued that Mr. Lewis\u2019s name only led the police to information they already had, like his address and notes from his medical calls. And prosecutors cited previous cases that they said showed that letting a defendant\u2019s name be suppressed would \u201cundermine the administration of the criminal justice system.\u201d\n\nThe case is a reminder that stop-and-frisk, shunned by Mayor Bill de Blasio and used less and less by the Police Department, remains a hotly contested piece of some criminal cases. Police failed to fill out a required formal stop-and-frisk report in Mr. Lewis\u2019s case, an issue that a court-appointed monitor overseeing changes to stop-and-frisk policies has identified as a persistent problem.\n\nThe dispute over whether evidence the police gathered by stopping Mr. Lewis can be withheld from trial also highlights the erosion of the exclusionary rule, established by the Supreme Court, which says illegally obtained evidence should be kept from trials, said Stuart Green, a professor at Rutgers Law School.\n\nHe said a 2010 ruling by the New York Court of Appeals seems to have established that a name cannot be excluded from trial in New York, even if it is the result of an illegal stop. That ruling, he said, relied on somewhat \u201cflimsy\u201d reasoning and further limited what evidence could be excluded from trial.\n\n\u201cWhat they\u2019re proposing here is an additional exception,\u201d Mr. Green said. But, he said, \u201cIt\u2019s handled a bit roughly here, and I think more needs to be said about why there is this exception.\u201d\n\nThe rule about excluding evidence, he said, \u201chas been so shot full of holes that there isn\u2019t that much left of it in the end.\u201d", "title": "Case of Jogger\u2019s Murder Hinges, in Part, on Questions Over a Police Stop", "authors": ["Benjamin Mueller"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Breaking from tradition and bowing to the moment, Casey Affleck will not be attending this year\u2019s Oscars, ending months of speculation over whether the Academy Award-winning actor would be a disruptive presence at the ceremony during a season dominated and defined by #MeToo.\n\nMr. Affleck won the Oscar last year for his performance in \u201cManchester by the Sea,\u201d and by academy tradition, the best actress is handed her statuette by the previous year\u2019s best actor winner.\n\nBut following an extraordinary few months of revelations of widespread sexual harassment, and a concerted effort by powerful Hollywood women to rebalance the scales of power to end discrimination and abuse, many felt it would be inappropriate for Mr. Affleck to attend the ceremony.\n\nTwo women sued him for sexual harassment during the production of the 2010 film \u201cI\u2019m Still Here,\u201d which Mr. Affleck directed and which starred Joaquin Phoenix. Mr. Affleck denied any wrongdoing but settled with both women. Although the allegations continued to hang over him, they were not enough to derail his Oscar campaign.", "title": "Casey Affleck Won\u2019t Present the Oscar for Best Actress", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "JOAN MERRILL\n\nBELLEVUE, WASH.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nYour article takes Donald Trump\u2019s presidency seriously, as we must, and appropriately recognizes its unprecedented and problematic nature, but you come dangerously close to normalizing a very abnormal situation.\n\nHistory shows that it is possible for a person with serious pathology to have popular appeal and to gain control of a nation\u2019s government, and what can happen when one does. Those who think that this is not the case in our country now are mistaken, and our country could pay a price for a tacit acceptance of this situation.\n\nJAMIE BALDWIN\n\nREDDING, CONN.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nAny analysis of the Trump presidency, and the ways in which it differs from or upends the norms of previous administrations and the traditional support of the pillars of our democracy, should include the astounding fact that this president is a mythomaniac who either cares nothing for the truth or, in service of his bottomless narcissism, holds truth to be irrelevant.\n\nAs a clinical psychologist, I have seen the damage wrought in relationships by dishonesty and self-serving cognitive and communication distortions, and the consequences of failing to deal bravely with reality in order to protect a fragile and damaged ego. Ignorance of policy consequences, sexism, racism, and a disdain for intellectual achievement and science are all frightening enough in a president, but absurdly obvious pathological lying is an Orwellian nightmare. We \u201cnormalize\u201d this man and his presidency at our peril.\n\nELIZABETH L. BENJAMIN\n\nBOULDER, COLO.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nMany thanks for a comprehensive, accurate and superb description of President Trump. This country is saddled with a leader who is tearing our society apart. It sickens me that the Republican Party and its leaders can support a man who cares so little for basic human values. I only pray that the 2018 elections will result in a resounding rejection of the president\u2019s agenda, and that Democratic and progressive candidates will retake Congress.\n\nSAM SIMON, SOUTH NYACK, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Limits of the Reality TV Presidency,\u201d by Jon Meacham (Op-Ed, Dec. 30):\n\nYes, too much exposure can in fact be withering for an individual. But the extremities of President Trump\u2019s exposure may not have yet been reached. The article points to Senator Joseph McCarthy and his anti-Communism crusade as an example of what the end is for overexposure. But there are other, and I believe more apropos, examples from history \u2014 namely Hitler and Mussolini, loud buffoons sweeping up all sorts of grievances and actual hardships into their theatrics.\n\nMr. McCarthy was only a senator, whereas Mr. Trump is the infinitely more powerful president. The flaws and limits inherent in overexposure are boredom and attenuation of message \u2014 not weakening of power. Though Mr. Trump can suffer in some way from overexposure, his power \u2014 his scope of action \u2014 remains undiminished. It is not Mr. Trump\u2019s overexposure that should concern anyone, but his juvenile, often alarming, often puzzling dramatics and his ignorance. I\u2019m more concerned about being nuked than bored.", "title": "Opinion | Casting Aside Presidential Norms", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe main separatist parties of Catalonia have reached a preliminary agreement to re-elect Carles Puigdemont as leader of the restive Spanish region, even as he remains in self-imposed exile in Belgium, the Catalan news media reported on Wednesday.\n\nThe deal \u2014 reached over dinner in Brussels on Tuesday \u2014 would allow Mr. Puigdemont to deliver his acceptance speech this month either by videoconference from Belgium or by having another lawmaker read it in the Catalan Parliament on his behalf, according to the Catalan radio station Rac1 and other outlets.\n\nIn a Catalan election on Dec. 21, the three main separatist parties won 70 of the 135 seats in the regional Parliament, with 47.5 percent of the vote \u2014 almost identical to the result in 2015.\n\nThe result was a setback for Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain, who had called the election in the hope that voters would deliver a decisive blow to the secessionist movement. But the separatists will still struggle to form a coalition government, in large part because eight of their 70 elected lawmakers are either in jail in Madrid or with Mr. Puigdemont in Belgium to avoid prosecution in Spain.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMarta Rovira, a deputy leader of the separatist party Esquerra Republicana, met with Mr. Puigdemont on Tuesday evening. On Friday, judges from the Spanish Supreme Court rejected an appeal by the Esquerra leader, Oriol Junqueras, who has been in jail in Madrid since early November, pending his trial on charges of misuse of public funds, sedition and rebellion.", "title": "Catalan Separatists Seek to Re-elect Puigdemont", "authors": ["Raphael Minder"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "MADRID \u2014 The Catalan Parliament postponed a vote on Tuesday to re-elect Carles Puigdemont, the leader of the movement to break away from Spain, as president of the restive region, extending a standoff with Madrid that could force new elections.\n\nRoger Torrent, the speaker of the Parliament, insisted that Mr. Puigdemont was the only candidate that separatist lawmakers would present, though Mr. Puigdemont refuses to return from Belgium, where he surfaced in late October to avoid prosecution in Spain for sedition and rebellion.\n\nThe postponement came after Spain\u2019s Constitutional Court ruled on Saturday that Mr. Puigdemont could not be elected and sworn in without physically being present in the Catalan assembly. The court also warned Mr. Torrent and other senior members of the regional parliament that they could face criminal charges if they allowed a vote in absentia \u2014 possibly using a video link to Belgium \u2014 as Mr. Puigdemont had requested.\n\nCatalonia, in northeastern Spain, held a referendum on independence on Oct. 1, despite a Constitutional Court ruling that it was invalid, and attempts by Spain\u2019s central government to disrupt the vote; with anti-separatist voters largely boycotting the referendum, the proposition passed easily.", "title": "Catalonia\u2019s Parliament Delays Vote on Puigdemont as President", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Like bulbs planted upside down, these men and women sought sunlight and escape but could not find it. Like certain baboons, their backsides were red and chewed by existence. Their veins were flooded when possible with the relief of heroin; our veins with the pleasures of Johnson\u2019s resonant voice. \u201cTalk into my bullet hole,\u201d one man says. \u201cTell me I\u2019m fine.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe Largesse of the Sea Maiden\u201d picks up, to a large extent, where \u201cJesus\u2019 Son\u201d left off. Only a few characters recur, but these are essentially the same unlucky bipeds, sometimes glimpsed a few decades later.\n\nTheir friends are dying and their own bodies have begun to betray them. One reports that he \u201ctook my insomnia, my afternoon headaches, my doubts and my antacid tablets to San Diego and lost them in the Pacific Ocean.\u201d Several have found success of a provisional sort as writers or advertising men. Others tell their stories from prison.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cJust to catch you up,\u201d one writes an old girlfriend from jail. \u201cIn the last five years I\u2019ve been arrested about eight times, shot twice, not twice on one occasion, but once on two different occasions, etc etc and I think I got run over once but I don\u2019t even remember it.\u201d\n\nWhere did his life, or any of these lives, go wrong? Well, to put it in the poet Paul Muldoon\u2019s words,\n\nthe spot where we take a wrong turn\n\nis rarely marked by either an urn\n\nor a tire scorch.\n\nTo return to \u201cStrangler Bob,\u201d the story mentioned at the top of this review: Its narrator recalls his time in the county lockup in 1967, back when dogs and children ran free in the streets. In one liquid, very Denis Johnsonian moment, he remarks, in a long sentence that hovers over this collection:\n\n\u201cI wondered if this place was some kind of intersection for souls. I don\u2019t know what to make of the fact that I\u2019ve seen those same men many times throughout my life, repeatedly in dreams and sometimes in actuality \u2014 turning a corner on the street, gazing out the window of a passing train, or leaving a cafe just at the moment I glance up and recognize them, then disappearing out the door \u2014 and it makes me feel each person\u2019s universe is really very small, no bigger than a county jail, a collection of cells in which he encounters the same fellow prisoners over and over.\u201d\n\nNever discount the black humor in Johnson\u2019s humane vision. Another prisoner asks Strangler Bob, \u201cDo you mean to say you gobbled up a T-bone steak and red imported wine and all, and then you \u2014 you know, executed your wife \u2014 and then you had chicken?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe stories in \u201cThe Largesse of the Sea Maiden\u201d are not as cohesive or as plangent as those in \u201cJesus\u2019 Son.\u201d This is a lesser book, but only in the sense that the best later Sinatra records were lesser than \u201cIn the Wee Small Hours,\u201d or that Neil Young could not in later decades recapture the mood of \u201cAfter the Gold Rush\u201d or \u201cTonight\u2019s the Night.\u201d\n\nThese stories drift, but Johnson finesses his way through them, his prose vernacular and elevated at the same time. One can say about this book what one narrator says about the poems of a writer he loves: \u201cThey were the real thing, line after line of the real thing.\u201d\n\nThe story that sentence comes from is titled \u201cDoppelg\u00e4nger, Poltergeist,\u201d but it is destined to become known as The Elvis Story.\n\nIts narrator, Kevin, is an academic who has fits and outbursts in class \u2014 \u201cconniptions,\u201d in his words.\n\nHis best student, Mark, becomes a friend and an important poet, one who was once arrested for trying to rob Elvis\u2019s grave. Mark has now seized on a conspiracy theory: That Elvis\u2019s music went downhill after he left the Army because Colonel Parker had killed him and replaced him with his twin brother, who wasn\u2019t stillborn as popularly understood.\n\nMark confesses this theory to Kevin because \u201cyou understand what it is to be moved by Elvis Presley.\u201d Kevin remarks to us: \u201cI discount his theory, but I value the obsession. And I commend his nerve. Old southern graveyards harbor an unwholesome power comparable to that of nuclear disaster sites.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNear the end of the story Kevin tells Mark something that some people wish they had been able to tell Johnson: \u201cI\u2019m your closest reader on this earth.\u201d", "title": "Catching Up With Denis Johnson\u2019s Star-Crossed Drifters", "authors": ["Dwight Garner", "Books Of The Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe French actress Catherine Deneuve apologized to victims of sexual violence who decried a letter she signed with more than 100 other Frenchwomen denouncing the #MeToo movement and its French counterpart, #Balancetonporc, or \u201cExpose Your Pig.\u201d\n\nIn a letter published in the newspaper Lib\u00e9ration on Sunday, Ms. Deneuve said that while she stood by the original statement, published in another newspaper, Le Monde, she did not condone sexual abuse or misconduct.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m a free woman and I will remain one,\u201d Ms. Deneuve said in the letter to Lib\u00e9ration. \u201cI fraternally salute all women victims of odious acts who may have felt aggrieved by the letter in Le Monde. It is to them, and them alone, that I apologize.\u201d\n\nLast week\u2019s letter, which said that using social media as a forum for sharing experiences of sexual misconduct had gone too far, drew some praise but also international criticism. The signatories argued that the #MeToo movement had caused people who did not deserve to be condemned to face the same consequences as sex offenders.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRape is a crime. But insistent or clumsy flirting is not a crime, nor is gallantry a chauvinist aggression,\u201d the letter in Le Monde said. It went on to say that in the wake of the Harvey Weinstein allegations, \u201cfreedom of speech has been turned on its head.\u201d", "title": "Catherine Deneuve Apologizes to Victims after Denouncing #MeToo", "authors": ["Anna Codrea-Rado"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "One of the arguments the writers make is that instead of empowering women, the #MeToo and #BalanceTonPorc movements instead serve the interests of \u201cthe enemies of sexual freedom, of religious extremists, of the worst reactionaries,\u201d and of those who believe that women are \u201c\u2018separate\u2019 beings, children with the appearance of adults, demanding to be protected.\u201d They write that \u201ca woman can, in the same day, lead a professional team and enjoy being the sexual object of a man, without being a \u2018promiscuous woman,\u2019 nor a vile accomplice of patriarchy.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey believe that the scope of the two movements represses sexual expression and freedom. After describing requests from publishers to make male characters \u201cless sexist\u201d and a Swedish bill that will require people to give explicit consent before engaging in sexual activity, the women write, \u201cOne more effort and two adults who will want to sleep together will first check, through an app on their phone, a document in which the practices they accept and those they refuse will be duly listed.\u201d\n\nThey continue, \u201cThe philosopher Ruwen Ogien defended the freedom to offend as essential to artistic creation. In the same way, we defend a freedom to bother, indispensable to sexual freedom.\u201d Though the writers do not draw clear lines between what constitutes sexual misconduct and what does not, they say that they are \u201csufficiently farseeing not to confuse a clumsy come-on and sexual assault.\u201d\n\nTranslations of the letter were quickly picked up by Twitter on Tuesday, and responses ranged from supportive to hostile. Asia Argento, an actress who accused Harvey Weinstein of raping her, criticized the Frenchwomen\u2019s letter on Twitter.\n\nOn the other side of the spectrum, Christina Hoff Sommers, who coined the term \u201cvictim feminism,\u201d tweeted a quote from the letter and her remarks on it.\n\nIn France, tens of thousands of stories have landed on social media under the hashtag #Balancetonporc since the journalist Sandra Muller used it in October in a post on Twitter about an inappropriate come-on she received from a French executive.\n\nThe multitude of revelations in France has led to discussion of legislative proposals that would fine men for aggressive catcalling or lecherous behavior toward women in public, and lengthen the statute of limitations for cases involving minors. Marl\u00e8ne Schiappa, France\u2019s junior minister for gender equality, said that France\u2019s parliament would also debate whether to establish a clear age below which a minor cannot consent to a sexual relationship. The decision came after French prosecutors declined to charge a 28-year-old man with rape after he had sex with an 11-year-old girl.\n\nIn March, Ms. Deneuve defended Roman Polanski, the director who pleaded guilty in 1977 to having sex with a 13-year-old girl and who was accused by two other women of forcing himself on them when they were under age. While appearing on a French television channel, Ms. Deneuve said, \u201cIt\u2019s a case that has been dealt with, it\u2019s a case that has been judged. There have been agreements between Roman Polanski and this woman.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn concluding the letter, the writers return to the concept of self-victimization and a call for women to accept the pitfalls that come with freedom. \u201cAccidents that can affect a woman\u2019s body do not necessarily affect her dignity and must not, as hard as they can be, necessarily make her a perpetual victim,\u201d they write. \u201cBecause we are not reducible to our bodies. Our inner freedom is inviolable. And this freedom that we cherish is not without risks and responsibilities.\u201d", "title": "Catherine Deneuve and Others Denounce the #MeToo Movement", "authors": ["Valeriya Safronova"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "There was something about the recent big displays of American sisterhood laid out on the cover of Time magazine, and at the Golden Globes ceremony, where women turned up dressed in black with their \u201cTime\u2019s Up\u201d pins, that seemed to trigger Gallic irritation. In this week\u2019s letter, the signatories worried that the \u201cthought police\u201d were out and that anyone who voiced disagreement would be called complicit and a traitor. They noted that women are not children who need protecting. But there was also this: \u201cWe do not recognize ourselves in this feminism,\u201d they said, which \u201ctakes on a hatred of men and of sexuality.\u201d\n\nCall it a clich\u00e9 if you like, but ours is a culture that, for better and for worse, views seduction as a harmless and pleasurable game, dating back to the days of medieval \u201camour courtois.\u201d As a result, there has been a kind of harmony between the sexes that is particularly French. This does not mean that sexism doesn\u2019t exist in France \u2014 of course it does. It also doesn\u2019t mean we don\u2019t disapprove of the actions of men like Mr. Weinstein. What it does mean is that we are wary of things that might disturb this harmony.\n\nAnd in the past 20 years or so, a new French feminism has emerged \u2014 an American import. It has embraced this rather alien brand of anti-men paranoia that Ms. de Beauvoir described; it took control of #MeToo in France, and this same form of feminism has been very vocal against the Deneuve letter. Today, Frenchwomen, too, have the girls\u2019 nights out that Ms. de Beauvoir once found so foreign.\n\nWhen \u201cAmerica Day by Day\u201d was published, American women were incensed. The novelist Mary McCarthy couldn\u2019t stand the book. \u201cMademoiselle Gulliver en Am\u00e9rique,\u201d she wrote, \u201cwho descended from the plane as from a space ship, wearing metaphorical goggles: eager as a little girl to taste the rock-candy delights of this materialistic moon civilization.\u201d\n\nMs. de Beauvoir was in many ways easy to mock: She wrote in a direct, authoritative, self-assured way that may have sounded arrogant to readers unaccustomed to its bluntness. But the epidermic reaction across the Atlantic, to both Ms. de Beauvoir and to that letter, may in fact underscore the sharpness of the French critique. To many of us in France, Simone de Beauvoir could have been writing yesterday: \u201cRelations between men and women in America are one of permanent war. They don\u2019t seem to actually like each other. There seems to be no possible friendship between them. They distrust each other, lack generosity in dealing with one another. Their relationship is often made of small vexations, little disputes, and short-lived triumphs.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Catherine Deneuve and the French Feminist Difference", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAlbertus Magnus College, a Catholic institution in New Haven, on Wednesday rescinded the honorary degree it granted last year to Gordon Edelstein, the artistic director of Long Wharf Theater who was fired Tuesday night over accusations of sexual misconduct.\n\nThe college\u2019s board of trustees made the decision just two days after The New York Times reported that Mr. Edelstein had joked about having had sex with the school\u2019s nuns.\n\nThat joke was one of multiple instances cited by former employees and collaborators of Mr. Edelstein who accused him of physical and verbal sexual misconduct.\n\nIn a brief statement Wednesday, Marc M. Camille, the president of Albertus Magnus, announced the trustees\u2019 decision and said the college had notified Mr. Edelstein. In a longer statement on Tuesday, Mr. Camille called the accusations \u201cshocking and concerning\u201d and said \u201cthe reported allegations represent behavior that is in complete opposition to Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "As emotional and disruptive as the false alert was, it was not the most dangerous episode of its kind because it did not reach the military\u2019s chain of command or decision-makers in government, he said.\n\nHere is a look at a few cases when it did:\n\nPhoto\n\nOct. 5, 1960: The moon tricks a radar\n\nA false alarm came when an early warning radar in Greenland reported to North American Air Defense Command headquarters that it had detected dozens of inbound Soviet missiles.\n\nThe report thrust Norad to its maximum alert level, according to the Union of Concerned Scientists, but officials later determined that the radar had been fooled by the \u201cmoonrise over Norway.\u201d\n\nNov. 9, 1979: A \u2018war game\u2019 tape causes six minutes of worry\n\nComputers at Norad indicated that the United States was under attack by missiles launched by a Soviet submarine.\n\nTen jet interceptors from three bases in the United States and Canada were scrambled, and missile bases went on \u201clow\u2010level alert,\u201d The New York Times reported.\n\nWhen satellite data had not confirmed an attack after six minutes, officials decided that no immediate action was necessary, according to the Union of Concerned Scientists and The Times.\n\nInvestigations later discovered that a \u201cwar game\u201d tape had been loaded into the Norad computer as part of a test. A technician mistakenly inserted it into the computer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe tape simulated a missile attack on North America, and by mechanical error, that information was transmitted into the highly sensitive early warning system, which read it as a \u2018live launch\u2019 and thus initiated a sequence of events to determine whether the United States was actually under attack,\u201d The Times reported.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nJune 3, 1980: 2,200 missiles that never came\n\nLess than a year later, computers once again issued a warning about a nuclear attack.\n\nBomber and tanker crews were ordered to their stations, the National Emergency Airborne Command Post taxied into position and the Federal Aviation Administration prepared to order every airborne commercial airliner to land, according to the Union of Concerned Scientists and The New Yorker.\n\nPresident Jimmy Carter\u2019s national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, got a call informing him that 2,200 missiles were heading toward the United States.\n\nThen Mr. Brzezinski got another call: It had been a false alarm. An investigation later found that a defective computer chip \u2014 costing 46 cents \u2014 was to blame.\n\nSept. 26, 1983: Similar problems on the other side\n\nStanislav Petrov, a 44-year-old lieutenant colonel in the Soviet Air Defense Forces, was the duty officer at a secret command center outside Moscow when the alarms went off.\n\nComputers warned that five missiles had been launched from an American base.\n\n\u201cFor 15 seconds, we were in a state of shock,\u201d he later recalled in an interview with The Washington Post.\n\nColonel Petrov, according to his obituary in The Times, was a pivotal cog in the decision-making chain. His superiors at the warning-system headquarters reported to the general staff of the military, which would consult with the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, on whether to launch a retaliatory attack.\n\nElectronic maps and screens were flashing as he tried to absorb streams of information. His training and intuition told him a first strike by the United States would come in an overwhelming onslaught, not \u201conly five missiles,\u201d he told The Post.\n\nAfter five nerve-racking minutes, he decided the reports were probably a false alarm.\n\nAnd they were.\n\nThe satellite had mistaken the sun\u2019s reflection off the tops of clouds for a missile launch.\n\nPhoto\n\nAug. 11, 1984: A joke by the president prompts an alert\n\nPreparing for his regular Saturday afternoon radio broadcast, President Ronald Reagan quipped in a live microphone that he had \u201csigned legislation that will outlaw Russia forever\u201d and that \u201cwe begin bombing in five minutes.\u201d\n\nMonths later, The Times reported that two days after President Reagan\u2019s joke, a low-level Soviet military official ordered an alert of troops in the Far East.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe alert was said to have been canceled about 30 minutes later by a higher authority.\n\nAmerican intelligence officials contended the alert was \u201ca nonevent.\u201d", "title": "Causes of False Missile Alerts: The Sun, the Moon and a 46-Cent Chip", "authors": ["Matt Stevens", "Christopher Mele"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "And yeah, maybe some wall equivalent. We don\u2019t need to discuss that now. The Dreamers are an immediate crisis. But even if you thought building a monstrous multibillion-dollar barrier along the border was a good idea, it\u2019s not something that\u2019s going to happen anytime soon.\n\nHere is the current vision in the president\u2019s mind:\n\n\u201cWe don\u2019t need a wall where you have rivers and mountains and everything else protecting it,\u201d he told that congressional meeting. \u201cBut we do need a wall for a fairly good portion. We also \u2014 as you know, it was passed in 2006 \u2014 a essentially similar thing which \u2014 a fence, a very substantial fence was passed. (\u201cBut Hillary was not for a strong military, and Hillary, my opponent, was for windmills. \u2026\u201d) Plus torpedo the DACA plan.\n\nSo Trump, who told those Congress members he would \u201ctake the heat\u201d for anything they wanted to do to save the Dreamers, threw up a wall. How do we explain all this?\n\nA) Situational ethics.\n\nB) Extreme dementia.\n\nC) Just another day.\n\nHere\u2019s an answer. We are well aware by now that there are several incarnations of the president, from the Somewhat Normal Republican Trump (SNORT) to the Nearly Unhinged Trump (NUT).
