He recently joined the lineup after missing the first 36 games of the season with a hip injury.\n\nThe Clippers, meanwhile, are known to be fielding trade offers for Jordan, who is widely expected to pass on his $24.2 million contract option for next season to become a top free agent alongside James on July 1.\n\nWilliams, 31, has unexpectedly put himself into All-Star contention this season with fine play for the Clippers in the wake of Chris Paul\u2019s departure to Houston, while Hill has become expendable in Sacramento \u2014 even though he\u2019s in the first year of a new three-year, $57 million contract \u2014 because of the Kings\u2019 increasing focus on developing their young players.", "title": "Cavaliers Pursue DeAndre Jordan and Lou Williams Ahead of N.B.A. Trade Deadline", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "According to Cecile Richards, the president of Planned Parenthood for over a decade, protesters who wave anti-abortion signs outside one of the organization\u2019s clinics will sometimes return \u2014 a week, a month or a year later \u2014 for an annual medical exam.\n\nThe men in Washington, D.C., who have done battle with Ms. Richards (\u201cand they\u2019re almost always men\u201d) don\u2019t see that side of the organization, she said.\n\n\u201cFor women, access to reproductive health care isn\u2019t a political issue,\u201d Ms. Richards said. \u201cThe women who walk into Planned Parenthood clinics come from every background, every political persuasion.\u201d\n\nYes, she said, even women who support President Trump.\n\nNow, as Mr. Trump\u2019s administration tries to eliminate taxpayer funding for Planned Parenthood, thrusting the debate over abortion rights back into the halls of Congress 45 years after the Supreme Court\u2019s Roe v. Wade decision, Ms. Richards is stepping down, as first reported in BuzzFeed.", "title": "Cecile Richards on Her Life After Planned Parenthood", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The club\u2019s growth has coincided with signs of a rebirth in a city whose population has been inching up after decades of sharp decline. Amazon this week announced that Newark was among the cities on its shortlist for a second headquarters. And, along with the many new locally owned restaurants, other recent big-name additions to the city include The Halal Guys, Whole Foods and Marcus Samuelsson\u2019s restaurant, Marcus B&P.\n\nThe Supper Club has outlasted Mr. Martinez, who moved to San Francisco in 2015. He remains somewhat amazed by what he began, but not that it\u2019s still going strong.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s just something great about gathering for food with people you know and people you don\u2019t know yet,\u201d he said.\n\nRob Thomas, one of the earliest members of the club, now serves as its chairman and cheerful chief nudge on Twitter:\n\n\u201cHalf off steaks at the Ainsworth. You should be here.\u201d\n\n\u201cDo your taxes and then come to supper club. You gotta eat, right?\u201d\n\n\u201cHappy Friday. THIS JUST IN \u2014 we\u2019ve got supper club on Monday.\u201d\n\nMr. Thomas, 32, is chief of energy and environment for the city. He spends his days thinking about how to make the city more sustainable \u2014 building its communal infrastructure though shared meals seems like a natural extension.\n\n\u201cNewark deserves this type of positive network where folks come out and support their community,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMelvin Sykes, a member who was born in Newark and now works in real estate, agrees.\n\n\u201cI thought it was a great idea because all people hear is negativity about Newark,\u201d Mr. Sykes, 50, said. \u201cIt\u2019s a great way to give back. A lot of places have one foot in the grave, one foot on a banana peel. We support not only the restaurants, but the employees, who are making tips. It helps the local economy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Thomas and the club\u2019s executive committee choose the dinners, which are held twice a month, with economics in mind. Supper is always on Monday because it is typically the slowest night for many restaurants. The club works to move around the city, rotating old stalwarts with new venues that need to build word-of-mouth buzz.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKai Campbell opened Burger Walla on Halsey Street in 2014. Supper Club has visited the burger restaurant with an Indian twist a few times since, business that is always much appreciated.\n\n\u201cThey are intentionally trying to support the city,\u201d Mr. Campbell said. \u201cIt means a lot to folks. It meant a lot to us. There is community in Newark. There are people here in the neighborhood, willing to travel for good food. It\u2019s like field of dreams. If you build it, they will come.\u201d\n\nMr. Thomas guesses the club has eaten at 75 restaurants over the years, but keeping count is not the point. Everyone has their favorites. For Olya Arakhouskaya, a field engineer at New Jersey Transit, it was McWhorter BBQ.\n\n\u201cThose ribs,\u201d she said. \u201cSo good.\u201d\n\nMs. Arakhouskaya, 31, discovered the club last summer after moving to Newark three years ago from Belarus. Like many members, she consciously circulates between tables to find new faces.\n\n\u201cI always meet one or two new people,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s very important to me, being an immigrant, being new to the city. Here, I feel like part of a community. And they care about all aspects of life in Newark.\u201d\n\nBridges have sometimes been built beyond supper. They have eaten in one another\u2019s homes, joined an investment club run by one member, become neighbors who borrow sugar and meet for brunch and birthdays. Tamar Lerer and Peter Chen, both lawyers, invited some members to their wedding.\n\nThe couple\u2019s first introduction to the Brick City Supper Club was at El Merengue in December 2014, just after they had moved to Newark.\n\nThey were nervous, then welcomed and then amazed by that welcome.\n\n\u201cA lot of them have been here a long time,\u201d Ms. Lerer said of club members. \u201cThey don\u2019t have to reach out for new people with these open arms and open hearts, but they do. It\u2019s amazing.\u201d\n\nShe has since returned the favor, spreading the gospel of the Supper Club and creating a spreadsheet of restaurants so she is ready when office mates complain that there is nowhere to eat in Newark. She and Mr. Chen are at nearly every supper.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cTo us, Newark is the city,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd Supper Club is a big part of it.\u201d", "title": "Celebrating Newark, One Supper at a Time", "authors": ["Liz Leyden"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "That prompted the other cell members to move up the timing of their plans and to improvise attacks over the next two days that would amount to the deadliest attack in Spain since the 2004 bombings in Madrid. The assailants used a van to crush pedestrians along the popular Las Ramblas boulevard in Barcelona and nine hours later, they used another car to careen into tourists on a promenade in the seaside town of Cambrils.\n\nInside the bombed-out ruins of the group\u2019s explosives factory, investigators recovered 500 liters, or about 110 gallons, of acetone, a solvent used in cleaning supplies, and 340 liters of hydrogen peroxide, a bleach commonly used in hair salons. The two chemicals are the raw ingredients used to make triacetone triperoxide, or TATP, which has become the signature explosive used by the Islamic State in attacks in Europe.\n\nInvestigators estimate that the terrorist cell had enough precursor chemicals to make 200 to 250 kilograms, or 440 to 550 pounds, of TATP, according to the study.\n\nPhoto\n\nBy comparison, the suitcase bombs that killed 32 people at the Brussels airport in March 2016 and injured more than 320 had each weighed less than 20 kilograms. And the fighters dispatched from Syria to reign terror on the French capital in November 2015, killing 130 and wounding more than 600, had at most a few pounds of TATP in each of their respective suicide belts.\n\nThe Barcelona cell bought most of the ingredients for its homemade bombs on Aug. 1, 2 and 16, the study found. The two vans used in the attacks were rented on Aug. 16 for seven days, suggesting that the group planned to commit the attack that week.\n\nIn the rubble of the property in Alcanar, investigators recovered a notebook inscribed with the name of Abdelbaki Es Satty, the oldest member of the cell and its presumed ringleader and recruiter. In a sheet inside the notebook, they found a handwritten note in Arabic describing the cell members as \u201csoldiers of the Islamic State in the land of al-Andalus,\u201d the term the militant group uses to refer to the Iberian Peninsula.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWithin hours of the first attack, and again after the second, Islamic State\u2019s news agency, Amaq, claimed credit, describing the attackers as \u201csoldiers of the Islamic State.\u201d The claim was repeated and amplified in numerous other ISIS media outlets, including their online magazine.\n\nNo concrete evidence has emerged showing that the members of the cell were being coached from afar by Islamic State operatives, as has been the case in several other European attacks. However, investigators are still trying to make sense of the trips made by members of the cell, including four pairs of brothers, all of whom were in their 20s or younger, in the months before the attack.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor example, Younes Abouyaaqoub, who drove the van in the attack at Las Ramblas, visited France at least three times from July to December 2016, and again on Aug. 11 and 12, 2017, just days before the attack. In his last trip to Paris, he stayed at a hotel in Malakoff, located just six kilometers, or nearly four miles, from the Paris suburb of Villejuif, where on Sept. 6 the French authorities discovered a TATP lab run by men who had been making phone calls to Syria, say the researchers.\n\nTwo other members of the Barcelona cell made an unexplained trip to Zurich in December 2016, and approximately a week before the attack, another member of the group, Driss Oukabir, made a nine-day trip to Morocco. When questioned, his relatives said they had found it odd that he did not stop by to see his father.\n\nThe reasons for the trips remain unclear and they raise the possibility that one or more of the members of the cell traveled to make contact with ISIS operatives, the researchers say. What is known is that, during a trip to Paris, the cell members purchased a video camera and used it to film the Eiffel Tower. The same video, which was recovered in the debris, also shows Mohamed Hichamy, one of the members of the cell, standing in the safe house, holding TATP and saying, \u201cSpaniards, you are going to suffer.\u201d\n\nIn addition to the footage of the Eiffel Tower, a cellphone used by a member of the cell included searches on Google Maps for several locations in Spain, including the Sagrada Familia church in Barcelona and the Camp Nou soccer stadium, suggesting that these monuments might also have been targets.\n\nSpanish officials told their French counterparts that they had recovered the footage of the Eiffel Tower soon after the Barcelona attack last fall. According to the researchers, the French government determined that the cell may have intended to strike Paris, too, where the city recently decided to install a glass fence around the Eiffel Tower, in an effort to protect the landmark from small-arms and vehicular attacks.", "title": "Cell Behind Barcelona Attack May Have Had Sights on Eiffel Tower", "authors": ["Rukmini Callimachi"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Customs officers stationed at the American border and at airports searched an estimated 30,200 cellphones, computers and other electronic devices of people entering and leaving the United States last year \u2014 an almost 60 percent increase from 2016, according to Homeland Security Department data released on Friday.\n\nDespite the surge, Customs and Border Protection officials said the searches affected fewer than 1 percent of the more than 300 million travelers who arrived in the United States last year.\n\nHomeland Security officials say border searches are an important investigative tool and are used sparingly by its agents.\n\n\u201cIn this digital age, border searches of electronic devices are essential to enforcing the law at the U.S. border and to protecting the American people,\u201d said John Wagner, the deputy executive assistant commissioner at Customs and Border Protection.", "title": "Cellphone and Computer Searches at U.S. Border Rise Under Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cOnly thing we can keep doing is winning games,\u201d Shaquem Griffin, a senior linebacker for Central Florida, said after the Peach Bowl win against Auburn. \u201cThere\u2019s no more teams left for us to beat.\u201d\n\nTo be sure, Central Florida is not going to replace Georgia or Alabama in the national title game next week, or play that game\u2019s winner. And Oklahoma and Clemson were invited to the College Football Playoff semifinals, rather than Central Florida. Central Florida\u2019s season is over. Fine, Griffin argued, but that has nothing to do with the Knights.\n\n\u201cWhat more can we do?\u201d he said. \u201cWe won all of them, and I just feel that we should have had an opportunity to show our talents to any and every team that wants to go against us.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s far from unusual for multiple teams to claim a national title. Five claimed one in 1935; six did in 1981. In fact, from the end of World War II to 1998, just five national titles were not claimed by more than one team.\n\nIt\u2019s not even unprecedented to have a split in the era of the unified postseason, which began 20 years ago with the Bowl Championship Series. After the 2003 season, one-loss Southern California was not invited to the B.C.S. title game. It beat Michigan in the Rose Bowl and was voted No. 1 in the final A.P. poll. The Trojans claim that season\u2019s title alongside the B.C.S. winner, Louisiana State, which beat Oklahoma in the Sugar Bowl.\n\nThe case against Central Florida\u2019s championship is clear, of course. Its league, the American Athletic Conference, may like to call itself the sixth power conference. But college football\u2019s five major leagues have magnitudes more money to spend on coaches and facilities, and this nearly always translates to better recruits and better teams.\n\nThe widely respected Sagarin rankings, which attempt to rate teams according to the strength of their schedule, rank Central Florida No. 13. That is partly the result of some close margins: the Knights beat South Florida and Memphis by just 7 points each, both times at home, the latter in double-overtime. And it is partly the result of a schedule deemed to be in the bottom half of the F.B.S. in terms of strength.", "title": "Central Florida Claims a National Title. Want to Fight About It?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "While a cesarean delivery is sometimes necessary and can be lifesaving, it may have serious long-term disadvantages for both mother and child, researchers report.\n\nThe analysis, in PLOS Medicine, pooled data from 80 studies including almost 30 million subjects.\n\nCompared to vaginal delivery, C-sections were associated with a significant reduction in the risk for urinary incontinence and for pelvic organ prolapse, a dangerous weakening of the muscles that hold pelvic organs in place.\n\nBut for a pregnancy following a cesarean, there was a 17 percent increased probability of miscarriage and a 27 percent increased probability of stillbirth. The researchers also found nearly triple the probability for placenta accreta, in which the placenta grows too deeply into the uterine wall, and an increased chance of other placental problems.\n\nChildren delivered by cesarean had a 21 percent increased probability of asthma by age 12 and a nearly 60 percent increased likelihood of obesity up to age 5.", "title": "Cesarean Delivery Can Pose Long-Term Risks to Mother and Child", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Q. I used Google Hangouts for the first time in Berlin. Now, if I enter a new contact into Google Contacts, it assumes the phone number is German and I have to manually change it each time. Is there a way to change the default country?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nA. If your Google account seems to think you are still in Germany, one place to check for a \u201cdefault country\u201d designation is in the settings for the Gmail account that is associated with your Google Hangouts calls. In a web browser, log into that Gmail account and click the gear-shaped Settings icon in the upper-right corner of the Gmail window.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn the Gmail Settings screen, click the General tab if it is not already selected. In the Phone Numbers section of the page, a \u201cdefault country code\u201d pop-up menu allows you to set the United States as your home base. Click the Save Changes button when you are finished. If you use Google Hangouts or Google Voice on any mobile devices, restart them after you have saved the changes on the computer. Google\u2019s Hangouts Help page might have answers to other issues with the service.\n\nFor those unfamiliar with the software, Google Hangouts can be used to make video calls, as well as telephone calls from the computer\u2019s web browser; you need to have a Google Account and compatible hardware. A Google Hangouts app is available for Android and iOS devices, as is a Chrome browser extension. Google Hangouts can also send and receive text messages between users and groups.", "title": "Changing Country Codes With Google", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nSalma Hayek\u2019s desire for equality in the movie industry (\u201cHarvey Weinstein Is My Monster Too,\u201d Sunday Review, Dec. 17) will be realized only when screenwriters stop writing scripts in which men control the narrative.\n\nIn \u201cCasablanca\u201d (1942), Humphrey Bogart has to make up Ingrid Bergman\u2019s mind for her when she is torn between staying with him and going off with her freedom fighter husband.\n\nNot that much has changed. In \u201cLa La Land\u201d (2016), Emma Stone has given up on an acting career until Ryan Gosling persuades her to return to Los Angeles and drives her to an audition that impresses the producer, and she becomes a star.\n\nFor starters, someone, preferably a woman, should revise the \u201cstar is born\u201d template so that a famous actress makes it possible for a talented man who is languishing as a movie extra to achieve stardom. That would really be a breakthrough.", "title": "Opinion | Changing the Script", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The 2014 standoff, the focus of Monday\u2019s hearing, was set off when the Bureau of Land Management seized cattle from Cliven Bundy\u2019s ranch in Bunkerville, Nev., in an attempt to force him to pay decades of back fees for grazing his cattle on federal land. Mr. Bundy insisted he did not have to pay the charges because, he said, he had inherited water rights on the land. At the height of the standoff, hundreds of antigovernment activists, many of them carrying guns, rallied to the Bundys cause, until the confrontation ended with the withdrawal of federal agents.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the years since, the family became even more firmly entrenched in the deep and bitter debate over public land policy in the West \u2014 seen either as right-wing extremists or stalwarts in standing up against federal government overreach, depending on whom you asked. And the Bundys also became symbols of law enforcement failure, as prosecutors, through multiple trials, failed for the most part to convince juries that the family members and their followers, beyond their armed militance, were criminals.\n\nAmmon and Ryan Bundy and five of their followers were acquitted by a federal jury in October 2016 on all charges related to their takeover of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon earlier that year. Last August, another federal jury, in Nevada, declined to convict four men who were involved in the Bundy ranch standoff, and earlier this year a jury in Oregon split on charges against four men in the Malheur takeover \u2014 convicting two of conspiracy charges but acquitting two others.\n\nAfter Judge Navarro\u2019s ruling in December that prosecutors had withheld evidence in the ranch standoff that might have helped the defendants \u2014 including video taken surreptitiously within the ranch \u2014 prosecutors said in their court filings that fears of violence against witnesses were part of their decision-making in what evidence to release.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cAs a result of threats to witnesses and the speed at which personal information can spread on social media, the government concluded it could not simply turn over its entire database,\u201d prosecutors wrote in a brief before Monday\u2019s hearing. \u201cFailure to disclose the information underlying the court\u2019s mistrial order was due, in a few instances, to simple inadvertence, but in the overwhelming majority of instances to a good-faith,\u201d they said.\n\nThe defense team said prosecutors had violated due process rules and undermined the entire case, which they said could not now properly be retried. Prosecutors are also still facing an inquiry begun last month by Attorney General Jeff Sessions after Judge Navarro\u2019s mistrial order.\n\nDaniel Hill, a lawyer representing Ammon Bundy, said that if prosecutors decided to appeal the decision, they would have to overcome what he described as a detailed, point-by-point rebuke by the judge, which took her about half an hour to read from the bench.\n\n\u201cIt was the most unwavering, clear-cut and almost personal dismissal that I\u2019ve ever heard in federal court,\u201d he said. \u201cI am very confident of the concreteness and airtightness of Judge Navarro\u2019s findings.\u201d", "title": "Charges Against Bundys in Ranch Standoff Case Are Dismissed", "authors": ["Kirk Johnson"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Charles Dutoit is stepping down from his post as artistic director and principal conductor of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in London following accusations that he sexually assaulted several women between 1985 and 2010, the orchestra announced Tuesday.\n\nMr. Dutoit, 81, had originally planned to retire from the orchestra nearly two years from now, in October 2019, when he was to be named its \u201chonorary conductor for life.\u201d But after several women publicly accused him last month of sexual misconduct, the orchestra\u2019s board held an emergency meeting, consulted with Mr. Dutoit and, the orchestra said in a statement Tuesday, \u201ctogether decided to bring forward his resignation\u201d to take immediate effect.\n\n\u201cWhilst Mr. Dutoit continues to seek legal counsel to defend himself, the protracted uncertainty and media reporting makes Mr. Dutoit\u2019s position with the orchestra untenable,\u201d the orchestra said in the statement. The Philharmonic said it was \u201ccommitted to the highest standards of ethical behavior and takes very seriously its responsibility to maintain a safe working environment for all its artists, musicians and staff.\u201d\n\nHis departure from the Royal Philharmonic \u2014 which he first led in 1966 \u2014 follows announcements by several major orchestras that they would distance themselves from Mr. Dutoit. It was the latest indication that the reckoning over sexual misconduct is now international in scope, and has reached the world of classical music much as it has Hollywood, the news media, the restaurant industry and politics. The Metropolitan Opera suspended James Levine, its longtime conductor, last month while it investigates accusations of sexual misconduct against him, which he has denied.", "title": "Charles Dutoit, Conductor Accused of Sexual Assault, Leaves Royal Philharmonic", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Michel Gaubert, sound director (@michelgaubert)\n\nI used to have a whole suitcase full of equipment, but I don\u2019t need that much any more, only a little trolley with the computer, the hard drive, my iPad and a speaker, which allows me to bring more clothes. Because I\u2019m traveling to so many cities, I try to limit myself to just so many sweaters, so much underwear and then a ton of socks. Shoes, I try not to take more than eight pairs.\n\nI have a great Rimowa suitcase I share with Ryan [Mr. Gaubert\u2019s creative and life partner], and we each get a separate Rimowa of our own. The toiletry bags and personal belongings are for the individual bags, and the third is for a mix of our things. Scarves go in my bag because I wear them all the time. Summer or winter, I always have something around my neck.\n\nCoats are the real problem. Jonathan Anderson gifted me this beautiful shearling that looks like blue denim. I haven\u2019t worn it yet, so that is going to be my breakout piece this season. In a 25-page decision, Judge Terence Kirn concluded the lawsuit does not meet narrow Supreme Court exceptions that define when a tribe can sue nonmembers in its own court.\n\nSince the Cherokee brought their suit in April, other tribes have begun to sue distributors and manufacturers, but in federal court.\n\n\u201cWe absolutely believe that we had jurisdiction in tribal court,\u201d said Chrissi Ross Nimmo, deputy attorney general for the Cherokee. \u201cIt\u2019s disappointing that non-Indians can come into a tribal community and decimate it, and not be held to answer in that community\u2019s court system.\u201d", "title": "Cherokee Can\u2019t Sue Opioid Distributors in Tribal Court, Judge Rules", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Todd Ricketts, a co-owner of the Chicago Cubs, is expected to be named the new finance chairman of the Republican National Committee, replacing the casino magnate Steve Wynn, who was pushed out amid allegations of serious sexual abuse, three Republican officials said on Tuesday.\n\nSpokesmen for Mr. Ricketts and the R.N.C. did not respond to requests for comment on Tuesday afternoon.\n\nBut an official in communication with the R.N.C. said that Mr. Ricketts was in the final stages of talks about accepting the position.\n\nMr. Ricketts has become an ally of President Trump, despite a rocky start to their relationship.\n\nThe Ricketts family, which owes its fortune to the founding of the brokerage firm TD Ameritrade by the family patriarch Joe Ricketts, donated $5.5 million to a \u201csuper PAC\u201d seeking to block Mr. Trump from winning the Republican presidential nomination. Of particular concern are trade disputes and a longstanding argument over how to handle a nuclear-armed North Korea.\n\nLast week, the Trump administration unveiled tariffs on imports of solar panels and washing machines \u2014 industries dominated by Chinese and South Korean businesses.\n\nIf China does strike back, the two biggest likely targets would be the agriculture and aircraft industries, said Lester Ross, chairman of AmCham China\u2019s policy committee.\n\n\u201cFrom the Chinese government\u2019s perspective, I think it would be likely that it would target sectors that have political resonance in the United States,\u201d he said.\n\nChina imported $21.4 billion in American agricultural products in 2016, according to government data, more than half of which was soybeans.\n\n\u201cAgriculture affects a sector where the United States enjoys a surplus and where there are competitors in other parts of the world for the commodities that China imports,\u201d Mr. Ross said. \u201cAnd the producers are predominantly in states which voted for President Trump.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. That has made them fearful of complaining publicly about lack of market access and other regulatory problems. Their worries include being subject to unannounced government audits or facing antimonopoly investigations.\n\nIn AmCham\u2019s business climate survey, three-quarters of respondents said they felt less welcome in China, a slight drop from levels in the previous two years.\n\nBut American companies increasingly believe that some changes in China\u2019s business and trade practices need to be made, Mr. Zarit said.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a sense that strictly just dialogue has not really brought much in terms of progress,\u201d Mr. Zarit said. \u201cSo perhaps some pressure will help get us more progress to a more balanced economic and commercial relationship.\u201d\n\nOn paper China has more to lose from a trade war, as it exports more to the United States than it imports. Still, it is less trade-dependent than it was in the past, according to an analysis by Capital Economics, a London-based research company. Exports to the United States contribute only 2 percent to China\u2019s annual economic output, and Beijing has \u201cfar greater leeway to make life difficult for U.S. firms.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe chances of China acquiescing to U.S. demands by leveling the playing field for firms selling to or investing in China are low,\u201d it said in a report.\n\nIn an editorial last week, the newspaper Global Times, which is controlled by the Communist Party, said China could also restrict sales of American cars and the flow of Chinese students going to the United States. The state-run Xinhua news agency reported on Tuesday that Travel Frog had risen to the top of the free simulation game category in Apple\u2019s App Store in China. It is being widely discussed on social media, where users post photos of their frogs\u2019 adventures.\n\nThe secret of the game\u2019s appeal isn\u2019t readily obvious. But the frog is cute, for one thing. Some players say they enjoy the feeling of traveling vicariously.\n\nAnd it\u2019s also really easy.\n\n\u201cYou don\u2019t need to do a lot of things, you don\u2019t even need to think about anything,\u201d said Yu Ting, a 28-year-old accountant in the northeastern city of Tianjin. \u201cIt\u2019s not a competitive game, so it\u2019s very relaxing.\u201d\n\nThe game also has a strong connection to child rearing. Before the frog leaves on a trip, you have to pack its lunch. It worked. Today, the silver and mirror-clad embassy sparkles by the spinach-colored waters of the Spree, satellite dishes and antennas poking out on top.\n\nI\u2019m back in Berlin, having spent the intervening years reporting in Beijing as China vaulted from sixth place to second in global economic strength, pushing down Germany from third to fourth. Returning to this country from China, I am struck by how Beijing is asserting its interests here in ways that threaten Germany\u2019s core values, going well beyond intimidating gym-going women.\n\nGermany must end Chinese meddling in its hard-earned democracy. Berlin has a stronger hand than many Germans appear to realize: China does not want to lose the good will and cooperation of this technologically strong and politically influential partner in the heart of Europe. Germany should be pushing back against Chinese interference with consistency and strength, just as China does when it feels its core interests are threatened.", "title": "Opinion | China Reaches Into the Heart of Europe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDAVOS, Switzerland \u2014 A reclusive and influential senior adviser to President Xi Jinping of China emerged here on Wednesday with a public message that many in the financial world have been eager to hear: The country has a timetable for curbing its vast appetite for debt.\n\nSpeaking to attendees at the World Economic Forum, the adviser, Liu He, said that the Chinese government planned to bring its debt under control within three years. Mr. Liu said Beijing intended to focus on reining in the growth of debt among local governments and companies.\n\n\u201cWe have full confidence and a clear plan to get the job done,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Liu did not offer details of the government\u2019s plans, or a specific standard by which China could be judged on whether it had achieved its goal. But his speech was the latest sign that the Chinese government would de-emphasize debt-fueled growth in the coming years and would instead sharpen its focus on solving thorny economic and social problems, including a surge in borrowing.\n\nOver the course of about a decade, China has accumulated levels of debt that match those in the United States when compared with the overall economy. That has led to worries that the country with the world\u2019s second-largest economy would struggle under an immense financial burden.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther Chinese officials have made vague pledges about tackling debt before. A firm timetable from such a prominent figure, however, was likely to grab attention.", "title": "China Will Tame Its Growing Debt Load in 3 Years, Top Xi Adviser Says", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "The move was expected to affect a small share of car manufacturing in China, where 28 million vehicles were produced in 2016. China has dozens of small-scale automakers \u2014 some producing just a few hundred cars a year \u2014 and the central government has tried to consolidate its auto industry, a factor that most likely also played a role in the suspension. Model versions \u2014 for example, different combinations of an engine and transmission \u2014 are constantly being deregistered.\n\nCui Dongshu, the secretary general of the China Passenger Car Association, said that the ban would affect at most 1 percent of the Chinese market. But the government\u2019s decision to cite fuel economy in the deregistration of so many versions at the same time is nonetheless a signal of the government\u2019s commitment to fuel economy.\n\nThe country, which for years prioritized economic growth over environmental protection and now produces more than a quarter of the world\u2019s human-caused greenhouse gases, has emerged as an unlikely bastion of climate action after President Trump\u2019s rejection of the Paris climate agreement.\n\nChinese leaders are under intense pressure to rein in dangerous air pollution, a hot-button issue in China, where thick smog has at times forced schools and businesses to temporarily shut down. Late last month, China said it was going ahead with plans to create the world\u2019s largest carbon market, giving Chinese power companies a financial incentive to operate more cleanly.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re sending a signal to everybody \u2014 that this is for real,\u201d said Michael Dunne, president of Dunne Automotive, a Hong Kong-based consultancy on China\u2019s clean car market. \u201cThis shows their emissions standards have teeth.\u201d\n\nThe Chinese government has already become the world\u2019s biggest supporter of electric cars, offering automakers numerous incentives for producing so-called new energy vehicles. Those incentives are set to decrease by 2020, to be replaced by quotas for the number of clean cars automakers must sell. That has spurred global automakers to pick up the pace in their shift toward battery-powered cars.", "title": "China, Moving to Cut Emissions, Halts Production of 500 Car Models", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Creating a transport hub \u2014 the Khorgos Gateway, a \u201cdry port,\u201d or terminal without water for handling cargo for trains rather than ships \u2014 in one of the world\u2019s most remote places has involved an expensive exercise in social engineering.\n\nPhoto\n\nA new town, called Nurkent, has been built from scratch \u2014 with apartment blocks, a school, kindergarten and shops to serve the railway workers, crane operators, customs officials and other staff needed to keep the dry port running. Free housing is provided. The town currently has only around 1,200 residents, but there are plans to expand it for more than 100,000.\n\nZhaslan Khamzin, the chief executive of the company operating the dry port with help from DP World of Dubai, acknowledged that the place seemed inhospitable but, implausibly describing it as an \u201coasis,\u201d insisted, \u201cThis is the future.\u201d\n\nThe Chinese \u201care not fools,\u201d he added. \u201cBusinessmen count their money. If they invest money here, they know that in five or 10 years they will get their money back with a profit.\u201d\n\nKazakhstan\u2019s border area with China was a sealed military zone during the Cold War, when the armies of China and the Soviet Union clashed briefly in 1969 along their shared frontier just north of Khorgos.\n\nThe biggest and richest country in the part of Central Asia formerly ruled from Moscow, Kazakhstan has tried since independence in 1991 to stay on good terms with Russia but has also steadily eroded Moscow\u2019s once overwhelmingly dominant position in the region by expanding ties with China.\n\nThe dry port is just the latest step in deeper ties. Completion of an oil pipeline between Kazakhstan and China in 2009 broke an export pipeline monopoly previously held by Transneft, Russia\u2019s state-owned pipeline company.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt was Kazakhstan\u2019s president, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the country\u2019s sole ruler since it broke from the imploding Soviet Union, who first proposed reviving old Silk Road trade routes.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe idea was later latched onto and expanded by China\u2019s Communist Party leader, Mr. Xi, in a 2013 speech in Astana, the Kazakh capital, and figured prominently in the Chinese leader\u2019s speech to an October party congress in Beijing that charted China\u2019s future as a \u201cgreat power.\u201d\n\nThe shift toward China has roiled domestic politics in Central Asia by playing into deep anti-Chinese sentiments left by Soviet propaganda and fears of China that date back centuries.\n\nKazakh nationalists complain that their country, having gained independence from Moscow, now risks becoming a satellite of Beijing. \u201cWhen the Chinese come, the apocalypse follows,\u201d runs a Kazakh saying.\n\nWhen the Kazakh government announced legislation last year to let foreigners rent land for long periods, protesters took to the streets to denounce what many saw as the start of a Chinese land grab. President Nazarbayev, in a rare retreat, suspended the plan.\n\nBut Chinese working here say there is little that will stall China\u2019s march. \u201cWhether by ship or by train, it doesn\u2019t make any difference to us so long as things keep moving,\u201d said Fan Guoming, the Chinese shipping company\u2019s newly appointed representative in Khorgos.\n\nSwaddled in a thick down jacket, he turned up in Khorgos in December as temperatures dropped to minus 10 degrees Celsius (about 14 degrees Fahrenheit) to check on his company\u2019s investment.\n\nIt takes 45 to 50 days to send goods from Chinese factories to Europe by sea, but less than half that time by train through Central Asia. Transporting a shipping container overland costs around 10 times as much as by sea, but it is relatively speedy and still much cheaper than airfreight.\n\nPhoto\n\nThat makes overland transport an attractive option for manufacturers of high-value, Chinese-made goods like computers, which need to get to market quickly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo prevent fragile electronics from being damaged by winter temperatures that can plunge to minus 40 (the same temperature in Celsius and Fahrenheit), some of the containers that pass through Khorgos are heated. In summer there is refrigeration to prevent food and wine, which make up the bulk of goods transported back into China, from rotting.\n\nAs with many grand projects involving Chinese state money, however, expansive long-term ambitions have tended to obscure short-term calculations of profit and loss.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt is very hard to separate the hype from the reality,\u201d said Theresa Fallon, a China expert in Brussels who has studied the \u201cOne Belt, One Road\u201d program.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t make any economic sense to me,\u201d she added.\n\nThe Chinese president has made development of trade routes like the \u201cnew Silk Road\u201d the signature policy initiative of his leadership, which has often put politics rather than economics in the driving seat.\n\nBecause China exports so much more than it imports, trains that pass westward through Central Asia laden with Chinese goods have often had to return to China with little on board, a mismatch that makes it difficult to justify the route\u2019s costs.\n\nTo keep the trains running and encourage manufacturers to build factories in less developed areas, local governments in western China and elsewhere offer hefty subsidies that cut the cost of transporting a container by train through Central Asia by 30 to 40 percent.\n\nPhoto\n\nJittery about Chinese ambitions but anxious about being left out, Russia has both helped and hindered the project. Russia clearly worries that China could ultimately try to cut it out of the transport business to Europe by building up a route through Kazakhstan across the Caspian Sea that bypasses it altogether.\n\nPresident Vladimir V. Putin of Russia gave a big boost to what China calls the \u201cSilk Road economic belt\u201d by pushing to establish the Eurasian Economic Union, a Russian answer to the European Union. Starting in 2015, Mr. Putin\u2019s union has allowed cargo trains and trucks from Kazakhstan to pass into Russia without laborious customs inspections.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt the same time, Russia put up a serious obstacle when, in retaliation for Western sanctions over its 2014 annexation of Crimea, Moscow banned the import to and even transit through Russia of many European goods, particularly food.\n\nMr. Khamzin said this problem, though initially serious, was now easing as Russia lifts transit restrictions on various European products, including wine and meat.\n\nBuilding a business amid such shifting political and economic sands, Mr. Khamzin said, is a gamble. But, he added: \u201cIf you don\u2019t take risks, you won\u2019t drink champagne.\u201d\n\nAmong those gambles is the creation of the town of Nurkent itself. Streets are clean and apartments comfortable, but young residents complain about the tedium of living and working alongside a small number of people in an isolated settlement surrounded by wilderness.\n\n\u201cWe are not just colleagues but also neighbors. I see exactly the same people during and after work every day,\u201d said Alexandra Chesnokova, Khorgos Gateway\u2019s public relations manager, who likes her job but misses St. Petersburg, her previous home.", "title": "China\u2019s Ambitious New \u2018Port\u2019: Landlocked Kazakhstan", "authors": ["Andrew Higgins"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 The pace of growth in China\u2019s economy accelerated last year for the first time in seven years as exports, construction and consumer spending all climbed strongly.\n\nAt least, that\u2019s what the government says.\n\nIn reality, the pace of growth in China\u2019s economy is anybody\u2019s guess. Various signals suggest China\u2019s growth did speed up last year, which could give the government the room it needs to tackle an accumulation of serious financial, environmental and social problems this year.\n\nBut measuring the size and health of the world\u2019s second-largest economy can be difficult at best. Its official figures have become implausibly smooth and steady, even as other countries post results with plenty of peaks and valleys. Officials in far-flung regions are admitting their numbers are wrong. And outside experts crunching the data have come up with different \u2014 and usually weaker \u2014 results.\n\nWhat China Reported", "title": "China\u2019s Economic Growth Looks Strong. Maybe Too Strong.", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Those efforts won praise on Wednesday from Prime Minister Erna Solberg of Norway, who said in an interview that China\u2019s plans for a carbon market would help its economy grow and protect people\u2019s livelihoods at the same time. \u201cWe have to decouple energy use and CO 2 emissions from economic growth,\u201d she said.\n\nWhat happens in China has a crucial effect on global emissions. China produces more than a quarter of humanity\u2019s emissions of global warming gases.\n\nOfficials in Davos said they saw little indication that China\u2019s influence in the climate change effort was ebbing.\n\nIndia, for example, is considering whether to follow the United States in putting tariffs on solar panel imports to help its own industry, or whether to bow to the dominance of China, by far the largest maker and buyer of solar panels. China also dominates the business of making wind turbines and is focused on becoming a force in electric cars.\n\n\u201cWe are trying to promote our manufacturers, but they also have to compete with international manufacturers,\u201d said Ramesh Abhishek, India\u2019s secretary of industrial policy and promotion.\n\nThe stakes are high. Peter O\u2019Neill, the prime minister of Papua New Guinea, contended at the conference that a severe drought in his country could be attributed in part to climate change. \u201cThe world seems to think they have time, but there are real communities already suffering,\u201d he said.\n\nFalling Chinese emissions in 2015 and again in 2016 caused the entire world\u2019s energy-related emissions to level off in those years. That gave some hope to climate scientists of progress in stabilizing humanity\u2019s release of climate-changing gases into the atmosphere.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut China\u2019s National Development and Reform Commission released detailed data this week showing that the country\u2019s electricity consumption jumped 6.6 percent last year. Wind and solar energy grew quickly, but not nearly enough to meet the extra demand. Electricity generation from the burning of fossil fuels, almost entirely coal, rose 5.2 percent in China last year.\n\nBurning More Coal China\u2019s emissions of climate-changing gases from burning fossil fuels, already greater than the United States\u2019s and Europe\u2019s combined, resumed their climb last year as heavy industry expanded in the country. 10 billion tons 9 Range of estimates 8 7 6 5 Energy-related emissions of carbon dioxide in China 4 3 2 1 0 \u201902 \u201906 \u201910 \u201914 \u201917\n\nYan Pengcheng, a spokesman for the agency, emphasized Monday at a news briefing in Beijing that China had expanded its use of clean energy. China\u2019s generation of electricity by wind power climbed by about one-quarter last year, while solar power jumped by three-quarters, Mr. Yan said.\n\nBut the increases in wind and solar power both came from low bases.\n\nSome scientists have been warning since autumn that China\u2019s drop in carbon emissions in 2015 and 2016 might be reversed, and Monday\u2019s data confirmed this.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe increase last year is a one-off \u2014 it\u2019s not likely to be sustained \u2014 but Chinese emissions are not likely to go down, either,\u201d said Trevor Houser, a partner at the Rhodium Group, a New York consulting group specializing in China. Rhodium estimates that China\u2019s energy-related carbon emissions climbed last year 2.2 percent to 4.1 percent.\n\nBy contrast, China had somewhat weak industrial production in the second half of 2015 and the first half of 2016 because of a financial crisis. That hurt the Chinese economy and fossil fuel consumption in both years. China still burns coal to generate three-quarters of its electricity.\n\nWhile China\u2019s official figures for economic output show that growth did not falter in 2015 and 2016, and that there was a slight uptick last year, Western economists are skeptical of Chinese economic statistics. They say China\u2019s government statisticians appear to have understated the extent of the earlier slowdown.\n\nPremier Li Keqiang himself has said before that electricity consumption statistics are more reliable in China, and something he watches more, than overall economic growth statistics.\n\n\u201cSo the widely reported flattening of China\u2019s emissions while economic growth continued apace was misleading,\u201d said Robert Stavins, an energy economist at Harvard University. \u201cEmissions had flattened because of the slowed economy.\u201d\n\nMr. Stavins said that despite the uptick he remained optimistic about China\u2019s ability to downshift its emissions trajectory permanently.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs part of the Paris agreement on climate change, China pledged that its emissions would peak no later than 2030, and Mr. Stavins said that target \u201cremains very much within reach.\u201d\n\nChina has also said it will make its economy much more efficient than it was in 2005 in terms of how much carbon it emits per unit of growth.\n\nIt is too soon for experts to declare definitively that all human-caused emissions of global warming gases increased last year, as most countries have not yet released enough data.\n\nChinese officials have long pointed out that while their country\u2019s emissions may be high, that is mainly because China has a lot of people. Emissions per person were only slightly higher in China in 2016 than in the European Union, and were lower than in the United States.\n\nData from sources of human-caused greenhouse gases in China other than fossil fuels, such as from agriculture, won\u2019t be available for several months, but those emissions are smaller.\n\nThe backdrop for climate change worries here came in the form of snow drifts left by a blizzard that dumped more than six feet of snow in a week.\n\nKlaus Schwab, the executive chairman of the World Economic Forum, joked with Liu He, a Politburo member from China, which is hosting the 2022 Winter Olympics. \u201cWhen you have the Olympic Games,\u201d Mr. Schwab said, \u201cmaybe we can export some of the snow to your country.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s Emissions: More Than U.S. Plus Europe, and Still Rising", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher", "Lisa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "In October, Xi Jinping, China\u2019s president, told the nation that \u201chouses are built to be inhabited, not for speculation.\u201d\n\nReal estate fervor was on display on a chilly recent morning at an apartment complex in the eastern city of Nanjing. Would-be buyers spent the night in tents and under quilts, lined up for a chance to buy. So many cars arrived, according to people who were there and photos that went viral on social media, that traffic seized up for a mile around the sales office.\n\n\u201cThere were a lot of speculators,\u201d said Han Changlong, a Nanjing real estate inspector who attended the event. \u201cSome people believe that if they don\u2019t buy now, homes will become more expensive in the future.\u201d\n\nA tax is far from assured, and lawmakers have not indicated that one will be on the table when they hold their annual meeting in March. Still, experts say momentum is building.\n\nXiao Jie, the finance minister, wrote in late December in People\u2019s Daily, the Communist Party\u2019s official newspaper, that leaders at a major party meeting two months earlier had favored instituting such a tax. The slogan, Mr. Xiao said, would be \u201cLegislation first, full authorization, move forward step by step.\u201d\n\nA property tax could have a profound impact on a crucial part of the nation\u2019s economy. Real estate makes up nearly three-quarters of the assets of Chinese households, according to the Survey and Research Center for China Household Finance, an academic institute in Chengdu, in southwestern China. That compares with a bit more than one-third for United States households. Roughly a fifth to a quarter of China\u2019s annual economic output comes from property and related industries, like furniture making.\n\nBut housing is also the source of some of the country\u2019s biggest booms and busts. Local investors \u2014 many of whom do not trust the country\u2019s stock markets and are forbidden by Beijing to move most of their wealth abroad \u2014 simply throw money at housing. Real estate broker fees, often as low as 1 percent, are a small fraction of the typical 6 percent in the United States. Mortgage lending has leapt over the past two years, adding to the potential for financial turbulence.\n\nPhoto\n\nHousing in Beijing and Shanghai has soared beyond the reach of even many affluent families and speculators \u2014 at least for now.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther factors spur frantic buying, such as access to local government services, as well as cultural forces that emphasize homeownership.\n\nMa Xiaoguang, a 31-year-old mechanical engineer, and his wife recently bought an apartment for $227,000 in the farthest outskirts of Shanghai so their daughter could get permission to attend a nearby public school. But they do not live there, instead renting a place in a more expensive neighborhood. They found a tenant for their purchased apartment, but for only $180 a month.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI know the yield is too low,\u201d Mr. Ma said, \u201cbut I want to have a home, and an apartment makes my family and me feel safe.\u201d\n\nIt is not clear whether a property tax would cover all homes, or just second ones. Much of China would be starting from scratch, as the country does not have decades of real estate records like the United States and other places.\n\nOne longtime obstacle \u2014 figuring out who owns which apartment \u2014 appears to have been resolved. For years, many corrupt government officials accumulated homes and resisted creating a database of real estate records.\n\nBut motivated partly by Mr. Xi\u2019s nationwide corruption crackdown, the Ministry of Land and Resources announced in September that it had just completed a database of land ownership across the country. Real estate executives say that the database encompasses the beneficial owners of real estate held through companies and investment partnerships, although wealthy individuals in China have been known to disguise the extent of their holdings.\n\nChina\u2019s absence of a property tax is a legacy of the 1949 Communist takeover. Land ownership was gradually restricted, then banned. When the leadership allowed private citizens to become homeowners again after Mao\u2019s death, it created a system under which the government leased land to developers and others.\n\nIntroducing the tax would be a delicate task for a government prone to ham-handed policy changes. It could damage demand in places where thousands of new apartments are still coming onto the market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWhat would happen if real estate prices keep stable?\u201d said Li Xunlei, the chief economist at Zhongtai Securities in Jinan, in the east. \u201cWe have many speculators, and they may find it unnecessary to hold real estate that does not increase in value.\u201d\n\nHowever, cultural forces could set a floor. Young people in China are expected to buy a home before they can get married. Usually the groom is responsible for buying a home, though the bride\u2019s family frequently chips in. Thanks to the now-abandoned one-child policy, China has more young men than young women, setting off a male-led surge to buy homes to make themselves more appealing husbands. Shang-Jin Wei, a Columbia University business professor, found that rising real estate price increases in 35 big cities were strongly correlated with lopsided gender ratios.\n\nJerry Lu, a 24-year-old insurance salesman, said he was determined to buy an apartment so that his girlfriend would feel more secure. He waited in a long line in November in his hometown, Deyang, in the southwest, and bought one of the last apartments available, incurring a mortgage that will claim a third of his income for monthly payments.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t care if there is a real estate tax next year,\u201d he said. \u201cNo matter what, I need to buy one.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s Housing Market Is Like a Casino. Can a Property Tax Tame It?", "authors": ["Keith Bradsher"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Social media users circulated memes showing Fuman dressed as a police officer and holding a rifle. Some drew comparisons between the young boy and soldiers who endure harsh conditions protecting China\u2019s border.\n\n\u201cMy eyes welled up with tears,\u201d one user wrote of Fuman\u2019s visit on Weibo, a microblogging site.\n\nPhoto\n\nChina has a long tradition of lionizing figures who have suffered hardship but kept faith in their country and the Communist Party.\n\nMany people were critical of the rush to idolize the boy, though, saying officials were using Fuman as a prop and neglecting the broader issue of rural poverty.\n\n\u201cA salute under the national flag is not going to solve anything,\u201d wrote Zhishang Suping, the pen name of one commentator.\n\nOthers were concerned about the effect of the media hype on Fuman\u2019s well-being.\n\n\u201cIn this age of consumerism and amusing ourselves to death,\u201d said a commentary published by China News Service, \u201cit seems everything can be hyped \u2014 fortune, family, charity and even misery.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nDavid Bandurski, co-director of the China Media Project, said the government was using Fuman as an \u201cantidote\u201d to criticism of its treatment of impoverished citizens. He noted that Fuman\u2019s struggle was depicted as one against the harshness of winter, rather than the \u201csocial and political roots of his condition.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe invitation to Beijing essentially fuses this narrative of personal struggle with the ruling party\u2019s narrative of national struggle,\u201d Mr. Bandurski wrote in an email.\n\nThe focus on Fuman\u2019s story helped the authorities \u201ctemporarily avoid painful policy discussions and potential public blame,\u201d said Haifeng Huang, an associate professor of political science at the University of California, Merced.\n\n\u201cA worthy story has been trivialized,\u201d Professor Huang added.\n\nFuman returned to his hometown on Monday. The family has received about $1,200 in donations, according to news reports, and local youth charities have gotten hundreds of thousands more.\n\nIn response to Fuman\u2019s story, Jack Ma, the billionaire founder of the e-commerce giant Alibaba, recently vowed to help finance boarding schools for children who live in isolated rural areas.\n\nDuring his visit to Beijing, Fuman spoke about missing his mother, who left the family two years ago, and wanting to help catch thieves. Hern\u00e1ndez"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "China\u2019s wherewithal to play rough in a trade war with the United States is not as strong as it looks. Beijing is mulling whether to slow or halt purchases of United States Treasuries, Bloomberg reported on Wednesday. The reason may simply be to diversify assets. But as the largest foreign holder of Uncle Sam\u2019s liabilities with $1.2 trillion, China also appears to have some leverage as the Trump administration considers imposing tariffs. Like other retaliatory measures, however, ditching Treasuries would end up costing China.\n\nThe dollar declined around 0.6 percent against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, hinting at the challenge involved. Beijing would weaken the dollar if it sold Treasuries, which might in turn reduce the competitiveness of Chinese goods abroad. Officials could mitigate that by purchasing other dollar-denominated assets, but it\u2019s not clear there are enough alternative safe, liquid securities. Threatening to rush for the exits also means China risks selling into a falling market.\n\nThe cost of selling echoes a broader theme: While Chinese officials have many options with which to retaliate against potential United States tariffs, they have few good ones.\n\nTake agriculture, which contributed nearly a fifth of all American goods exported to China in 2016. Strict and effective enforcement of tariffs levied on staple goods such as soybeans and pork would hurt American farmers in Upper Midwest swing states. But it also risks generating higher inflation on the mainland. Looser de facto enforcement of product origins \u2014 more likely for commodities \u2014 would simply reroute supply chains through a third country. That keeps consumer prices in check, but it also renders the tariffs largely symbolic, which happened after Beijing slapped retaliatory tariffs on chicken parts from the United States in 2010, according to Brad Setser of the Center on Foreign Relations.", "title": "China\u2019s Weak Hand in Potential Trade War With U.S.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Others have found playing the instrument to be a source of relaxation. They join friends to play together outdoors, often with orchestral tracks blaring in the background.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s just so beautiful, I don\u2019t know how to describe it,\u201d said Zhao Baiquan, 55. \u201cNo matter how angry I am, it calms me down.\u201d\n\nThe repertoire in Sidangkou leans toward traditional Chinese songs and patriotic tunes, though there are some exceptions.\n\n\u201cSpring Comes to the North,\u201d a Japanese folk song, is a favorite. So is \u201cGoing Home,\u201d the 1989 Kenny G song that is widely played in Chinese shopping malls, schools and train stations as they close down.\n\nJazz is mostly avoided. \u201cIt\u2019s beautiful but too difficult,\u201d said Wang Bingjun, a worker at the Tianjin Shengdi factory. \u201cChinese songs are more familiar and easy to play.\u201d\n\nMany of the players are self-taught or follow along with online tutorials.\n\n\u201cHere we don\u2019t have teachers,\u201d said Chen Jinsheng, 56, a farmer who plays in a small saxophone band. \u201cLearning the saxophone isn\u2019t easy, and I\u2019ve taken many detours.\u201d\n\nVideo\n\nSome of the more advanced players in the village now use live-streaming apps to broadcast lessons online.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe saxophone first came to China after its invention in the mid-1800s and quickly found a place in Chinese brass brands. It later became a staple of nightclubs in the European-dominated treaty port of Shanghai before 1949.\n\nDuring the Cultural Revolution of the 1960s and 1970s, Western popular music came under attack as decadent and bourgeois. Jazz was banned and the saxophone \u201cdisappeared from the music scene,\u201d said Helen Yang, a professor of music at Hong Kong Baptist University.\n\nAfter China began to open to the world in 1978, the instrument gradually gained a following, largely in urban areas where jazz is more widely played. Now, Chinese factories produce more than 180,000 saxophones a year, said Li Yusheng, a prominent Chinese saxophonist who studies the industry.\n\nStill, while many Chinese families have embraced instruments like the piano and violin, skepticism about the saxophone lingers.\n\nWhen Mr. Wang of the Tianjin Shengdi factory first tried to start saxophone bands at nearby schools in 2003, parents were livid, calling the instrument disruptive and a waste of time.\n\nBut attitudes have shifted in recent years, he said. \u201cWe asked the parents whether they preferred their children watch a half-hour of television or play saxophone for a half-hour,\u201d Mr. Wang said.\n\nVideo\n\nNow, three schools in Sidangkou and the surrounding area have saxophone bands. Educators have developed a saxophone curriculum and created exhibits on the instrument\u2019s history.\n\n\u201cI fell in love with it,\u201d said Liu Junrui, 12, a fifth-grader. \u201cThe sound is cool. It\u2019s special. It\u2019s different from all other musical instruments.\u201d", "title": "China\u2019s \u2018Saxophone Capital,\u2019 a Factory Town Transfixed by Kenny G", "authors": ["Javier C. Hern\u00e1ndez"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Whether or not his company enters a partnership with GAC or another company, Mr. Marchionne will probably not be around to see if it pays off. During his news conference, he confirmed that this will be his last year running Fiat Chrysler. He began as the chief executive of Fiat in 2004 and under his direction the company took control of Chrysler just as it was undergoing a wrenching bankruptcy reorganization engineered by regulators in Washington in 2009.\n\nMr. Marchionne said his successor will be named sometime after March, when Fiat Chrysler expected to present a new business plan that will serve as a road map to guide the company\u2019s operations through 2022. Two internal candidates, Richard Palmer, the chief financial officer, and Mike Manley, head of the highly profitable Jeep and Ram brands, are expected to be among the top contenders.\n\nMr. Marchionne said that Fiat Chrysler \u201chas no intention\u201d of breaking up the company and selling Jeep or Ram. \u201cThe answer is no,\u201d he said.\n\nBut a partnership to sell GAC cars in the United States could make sense. Fiat Chrysler\u2019s Dodge and Chrysler brands no longer offer small or mid-sized cars, having dropped them from their lineups in 2016. Dealers selling Fiat-brand small cars, meanwhile, are desperate for additional models to offer. Many Fiat dealers sell only a handful of new cars each month and do most of their business in a variety of used models.\n\n\u201cFiat has limited potential in the U.S.,\u201d Mr. Marchionne acknowledged.\n\nFurthermore, Fiat Chrysler does not have an electric car in its lineup and Mr. Marchionne opposes the idea of investing the money to develop one.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know of any organization making money on electric vehicles,\u201d he said. Hybrids and electric cars together make up only 3 percent of all new cars sold in the United States, he noted. \u201cThat is not a good economic basis in which to do any type of investment.\u201d\n\nSome dealers, however, said they saw a need for Fiat Chrysler to get back into the mid-sized car segment and offer at least one electric model. \u201cIt may be a shrinking segment but I still have customers who want cars,\u201d said Wesley Lutz, owner of Extreme Dodge in Jackson, Mich. \u201cAnd it would be nice to at least have one hybrid and electric vehicle because you do have those green customers out there.\u201d", "title": "Chinese Carmaker May Use Fiat Chrysler for Foothold in United States", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "That Focus! will skip pieces using Chinese instruments was not so much an aesthetic choice as a logistical and philosophical one: It would have required hiring players, a difficult move budgetarily and educationally, since the point of the festival is to give Juilliard students the opportunity to play new music.\n\nImage Guo Wenjing Credit Casa Ricordi/Universal Music Publishing\n\n\u201cThe main exception in this festival is the performance of Guo Wenjing\u2019s concerto for erhu and orchestra,\u201d Mr. Sachs said, referring to the two-stringed Chinese fiddle. \u201cBut, as it happened, one of our alumni is both a first-rate violist and a busy professional erhu player. I also managed to get another piece into the festival after hearing it and realizing that the sound of the xun, a very ancient wind instrument, was very similar to the ocarina. When I asked the composer\u201d \u2014 Yu Baoyu \u2014 \u201cwhat he thought of doing it with ocarina, he responded very enthusiastically. One of our flutists jumped at the chance to do it.\u201d\n\nYet if the instruments are Western, there are still glimmers of what could be called distinctively Chinese qualities about the music on these programs. Some make references to traditional Chinese melodies, some to Chinese aesthetics or ideas \u2014 pentatonic scales, for example \u2014 and some to the kind of evocations of nature (mountains, flowers) that are widespread in Chinese culture. One young composer, among the seven commissioned to write a new piece for Focus!, had imbibed the contemporary European trend of getting unusual sounds from instruments, but had used those techniques to subtly evoke \u2014 not imitate \u2014 the sound of traditional Chinese instruments.\n\nOne younger composer, Liang Nan, will be represented by two intriguingly contrasting pieces: a thornily up-to-date \u201cEuropean-style\u201d new work, and a song he wrote in 2015 to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the victory over Japan in World War II. \u201cThe song, for soprano, cello, and piano,\u201d Mr. Sachs said, \u201cis very European-traditional, perhaps evoking the epoch of Faur\u00e9, but turned out to be so beautifully, creatively wrought that I decided to program it alongside the piece he has been commissioned to write, simply to show how two visions of music could flourish in one composer.\u201d", "title": "Chinese Composers With an Ear to the World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 A senior Chinese general who won the national spotlight by overseeing a grand military parade and who vowed unwavering support for President Xi Jinping\u2019s drive against corruption has come under investigation for graft, the latest in a string of People\u2019s Liberation Army commanders to fall.\n\nGen. Fang Fenghui disappeared from public view nearly five months ago and quietly retired from his posts, igniting rumors that he was under investigation. Xinhua, China\u2019s official news agency, confirmed on Tuesday that military prosecutors were investigating him on charges of giving and taking bribes.\n\nThe brief announcement gave no other details. But the charges that he had given, as well as taken, kickbacks raised the possibility that he may have paid his way up the ranks, some Chinese news media said. Mr. Xi has warned that such corruption threatens to shake Communist Party rule by eroding the loyalty and preparedness of the armed forces.\n\n\u201cIn fact, as early as 2003, he was already a senior military officer at military region deputy level,\u201d said a party commentary widely republished by the Chinese news media. \u201cThe target of his bribes must be shocking.\u201d", "title": "Chinese General Under Investigation, Joining a Line of Fallen Commanders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "The pitches frequently appeal to aspiring small investors like Walter Xu, a recent university graduate who was drawn to Qianbao by promises of sky-high returns. Qianbao looked like a real business: Its portal sold cellphones and appliances \u2014 with discounts for members \u2014 as well as big returns for those who gave it money. In exchange for depositing money, watching ads and writing reviews, it offered returns of as much as 50 percent. In all, Mr. Xu invested $32,000 of his savings in Qianbao.\n\nOn Dec. 26, when Qianbao\u2019s founder turned himself over to authorities, Mr. Xu turned to fellow investors on WeChat, China\u2019s popular social messaging platform, to commiserate. \u201cI talked until 3 in the morning,\u201d he said. \u201cI was shocked.\u201d\n\nNow, he said, he must put the episode behind him. \u201cI need to work and start over,\u201d he said.\n\nSome investors who lost their savings in Qianbao protested last week in the city of Nanjing, where the online investment platform had been based. Police acted swiftly, detaining the organizers of the demonstration and giving others warnings, according to a notice by the Nanjing police. Government censors appeared to have taken down some discussions about Qianbao on social media and removed some news articles about it.\n\nChina has been rife with investment frauds in the decades since its economic reopening led to a boom. But online versions have the potential to reach more people in a country with more than 700 million internet users, many of whom now conduct most of their financial transactions on smartphones.\n\nInvestors in online products are often drawn by promises of high rates of return and the idea that the investments are safer than China\u2019s stock market, which has long had a reputation for casino-like uncertainty. But they are often unsophisticated investors who are unaware of the risks, experts warn.", "title": "Chinese Investors Keep Losing Billions Online. Here\u2019s Why.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHONG KONG \u2014 Chinese police officers demolished one of the country\u2019s largest evangelical churches this week, using heavy machinery and dynamite to raze the building where more than 50,000 Christians worshiped.\n\nThe Golden Lampstand Church in Shanxi Province was one of at least two Christian churches demolished by the authorities in recent weeks, part of what critics describe as a national effort to regulate spiritual life in China.\n\nUnder President Xi Jinping, the government has destroyed churches or removed their steeples and crosses as part of a campaign that reflects the Communist Party\u2019s longstanding fear that Christianity, viewed as a Western philosophy, is a threat to the party\u2019s authority.\n\nPhoto\n\nGlobal Times, a state newspaper, described the building\u2019s destruction as part of a \u201ccitywide campaign to remove illegal buildings,\u201d and quoted an
