leaders.", "title": "Chinese Police Dynamite Christian Megachurch", "authors": ["Russell Goldman"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Swedish government is fully aware of what happened to Swedish citizen Gui Minhai on Saturday,\u201d Katarina Byrenius Roslund, the deputy director of the Press and News Department of the ministry, said by email. \u201cThese events have subsequently been handled with the utmost seriousness, and robust measures have been taken at senior political level.\u201d\n\nWhen he was taken off the train, Mr. Gui had been traveling to the Chinese capital for a medical examination at the Swedish Embassy, after he showed symptoms of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also called A.L.S. The disease attacks the brain and spinal cord, progressively impairing actions like walking, swallowing and using chopsticks.\n\nLast year, Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned Chinese dissident who won the Nobel Peace Prize, died under police guard in a Chinese hospital after he was belatedly found to have liver cancer.\n\n\u201cGui Minhai is exhibiting symptoms of a serious neurological condition, symptoms that did not exist before he was taken into custody in October 2015,\u201d said John Kamm, an American businessman and human rights advocate who has been working with Mr. Gui\u2019s family to try to win his release to go abroad for treatment. \u201cI pray we will not witness the death in prison of another person accused of political crimes.\u201d\n\nThe Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that it \u201chad no understanding of the situation you referred to,\u201d and suggested asking another ministry. The Ministry of Public Security did not answer questions faxed on Monday.\n\nMr. Gui, 53, was born in eastern China, went to study in Sweden in 1988 and became a citizen of the country in 1992. But in recent years, he worked out of Hong Kong, where he became a co-owner of Mighty Current Media, a small publishing house.\n\nSupporters call the detention of Mr. Gui and the four other Hong Kong booksellers a campaign by the Chinese government to shut down publishers of books offering unsparing criticism and also unflattering gossip about the party elite. Hong Kong, a former British colony attached to mainland China, became a center for producing Chinese-language books that were banned in China, but that mainland readers often bought and smuggled back.", "title": "Chinese Police Seize Publisher From Train in Front of Diplomats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Rolen (first): The Hall of Fame lists only 16 members as third basemen, the fewest for any defensive position. Rolen was a sensational defender, yet in 17 seasons he managed just one finish in the top 13 for Most Valuable Player voting. In fairness, Rolen had strong seasons for also-ran teams in Philadelphia, and then played in Albert Pujols\u2019s shadow in St. Louis. But he seems to fit best on the Graig Nettles/Buddy Bell level of third basemen \u2014 outstanding, but just under the borderline.\n\nSosa (sixth): In the decade after the 1994 strike, Sosa led the majors in homers, runs batted in and total bases; he is an important figure of that era. Yet he\u2019s polled no higher than 12.5 percent despite, like Bonds and Clemens, never having served a suspension for doping. With 609 career homers, Sosa should have a strong case. But it\u2019s hard to shake the notion that his best years seem so inauthentic.\n\nVizquel (first): Like Rolen, Vizquel was virtually ignored by Most Valuable Player voters; in 24 seasons, he had one 16th-place finish. His hallmarks were defense (11 Gold Gloves) and longevity (a record 2,709 games at shortstop). He was a very different kind of player than the dominant A.L. shortstops of his prime \u2014 Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez, Nomar Garciaparra and Miguel Tejada \u2014 but their presence obscured him. Ozzie Smith had no such N.L. rivals in the 1980s, and ranks much higher in defensive metrics than Vizquel.\n\nWagner (third): No pitcher with as many innings as Wagner (903) can match him in strikeouts per nine innings (11.9). His 2.31 earned run average is closer to Mariano Rivera\u2019s 2.21 than Hoffman\u2019s 2.87. That\u2019s dominance, and that\u2019s what voters want in a Hall of Famer. Then again, every Hall of Fame pitcher has at least 1,000 innings. And in 14 postseason games, Wagner had a 10.03 E.R.A.\n\nWalker (eighth): Of all the 10th choices on these ballots, Walker has gotten by far the most support. Eighteen voters have checked the top nine plus Walker, making that the most common ballot in Thibodaux\u2019s tracker. Walker could do it all, though his struggles to stay healthy made his career totals (383 homers, 2,160 hits) lower than you\u2019d expect from a star who spent his prime in a hitter\u2019s park in an era of extreme offense.\n\nLastly, we have Sheffield, a fourth-time nominee. It took a while, but on Tuesday morning, I finally found a ballot like the one I would cast, by Tim Kurkjian of ESPN. He voted for the top nine plus Sheffield, who hit 509 homers, rarely struck out, had the same O.P.S. (.907) as Ken Griffey Jr., reached base 1,088 more times than Walker \u2014 and won a championship. Sheffield gets docked severely for his defense at third base and in the outfield, but he has more offensive wins above replacement than Martinez, a designated hitter on the cusp of election.\n\nSheffield\u2019s case is complicated by his ties to performance-enhancing drugs, but the link is somewhat flimsy. He acknowledged using a cream Bonds gave him for his knee when they trained together before the 2002 season, but denied knowing it was a steroid.", "title": "Chipper Jones Will Get Into the Hall of Fame. So Why Not Gary Sheffield?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cBarry Bonds is the best baseball player that I\u2019ve ever seen don a uniform,\u201d Jones said. \u201cIt\u2019s unfortunate that some of the best players of this era have a cloud of suspicion, because you\u2019re talking about some all-timers.\u201d\n\nJones and Thome appeared on the ballot for the first time, and both gained entry easily, Jones with 97.2 percent and Thome with 89.8. Guerrero (92.9 percent) and Hoffman (79.9) made it on their second try.\n\nPhoto\n\nJones played 19 seasons for the Atlanta Braves, hitting .303 with a .401 on-base percentage and a .529 slugging percentage. Only two other switch-hitters, Mickey Mantle and Eddie Murray, hit more homers than Jones\u2019 468.\n\nAs the National League\u2019s Most Valuable Player in 1999, Jones led the Braves past the Mets in the N.L. Championship Series that October. He had torched the Mets for a .400 average in that regular season, and famously named his son Shea in honor of the Mets\u2019 old ballpark.\n\n\u201cI have never had so much fun playing the game of baseball as I did against that team, that organization, and in that city,\u201d Jones said.\n\nThome slammed 612 home runs across 22 seasons, including 13 years with the Cleveland Indians. He ranks eighth in home runs \u2014 and second in strikeouts, to Reggie Jackson \u2014 and his .956 on-base plus slugging percentage trails only 15 retired hitters on the career list.\n\nWhile Thome appeared in the postseason for five franchises \u2014 the Indians, the Chicago White Sox, the Minnesota Twins, the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Baltimore Orioles \u2014 he did not get there with the Philadelphia Phillies, who signed him away from Cleveland with a lucrative free agent offer in Dec. 2002. Even so, the Phillies honored Thome with a plaque in their Wall of Fame, and the Indians built a statue of him at their ballpark.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe message I would send would be that every Midwest kid can dream of a day like this,\u201d said Thome, a Peoria, Ill., native who was drafted in the 13th round in 1989. \u201cI\u2019m living it today.\u201d\n\nGuerrero was the last superstar for the Montreal Expos, electrifying the franchise for most of its final seasons. He moved to the Angels in 2004 (the Expos left for Washington a year later), and won the American League\u2019s M.V.P. award in his first season in Anaheim. After six years there, Guerrero made an All-Star team for the Texas Rangers and helped lead them to their first A.L. championship, in 2010.\n\nPhoto\n\nOnly five players can match Guerrero\u2019s career figures in both batting average (.318) and home runs (449): Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Ted Williams, Jimmie Foxx and Stan Musial. A fast runner in his early years, with an overpowering right field arm, Guerrero could hit nearly any pitch in any location. He was a classic \u201cbad-ball\u201d hitter \u2014 like the old Yankees catcher, Yogi Berra \u2014 and once got a hit on a pitched that bounced.\n\nAsked how he hit so well on pitches far from the strike zone, Guerrero said he learned the skill as a boy in the Dominican Republic, using a broomstick against a rubber ball. The pitcher would bounce the ball and try to knock over a folded license plate on the ground.\n\n\u201cThat actually opened up, to me, my hitting zone,\u201d Guerrero said through an interpreter. \u201cIn order for you to hit the ball, you have to be able to hit balls down on the ground. A lot of times pitchers in the big leagues perhaps didn\u2019t realize that sometimes you try too hard when the ball was thrown down the middle.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nGuerrero became the first position player from the Dominican Republic elected to the Hall of Fame. Two pitchers, Juan Marichal and Pedro Martinez, are also enshrined.\n\nHoffman retired in 2010 as the career saves leader, with 601; only Mariano Rivera has passed him since. Hoffman, who was drafted as an infielder by the Cincinnati Reds, reached the majors with the expansion Florida Marlins in 1993 and was traded that summer to the San Diego Padres. He earned 552 saves for the Padres, and his changeup \u2014 one of the best in history \u2014 helped him average 9.4 strikeouts per nine innings.\n\nHoffman learned the grip in 1994 from his teammate and catch partner, Donnie Elliott, then deadened the ball even more by shoving it deeper in his hand. The pitch came in so slowly that it made his modest fastball play up.\n\n\u201cIt evolved to more of a palmball,\u201d Hoffman said. \u201cIt allowed me to feel comfortable throwing the pitch like a fastball, and I got some decent action out of it.\u201d\n\nHoffman joins Hoyt Wilhelm, Rollie Fingers, Bruce Sutter, Goose Gossage and Dennis Eckersley as the only pitchers in the Hall of Fame who primarily worked in relief. Rivera, who retired in 2013, comes up for election this December, with Roy Halladay, Andy Pettitte, Todd Helton and Lance Berkman among the other first-time candidates.", "title": "Chipper Jones and Jim Thome Lead Large Class Into Baseball Hall of Fame", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "_____\n\n\u201cIt depends on the day but some of them would be short, if we don\u2019t have a lot of things to approve, they\u2019d be maybe 20 or 25 minutes. But some of them would be an hour, an hour and a half, if there\u2019s lots of things. And what those calls were about was to set the agenda for the Monday meeting with the executive committee. And the executive committee varied from time to time. The constants on the exact committee were the [Trump] children.\u201d\n\n_____\n\n\u201cThe process was very organized. This was not haphazard in any way. And every Monday, certainly from before the convention, like, let\u2019s say the month or so before the convention, to literally eight days before the election. That group met every Monday at Trump Tower. And if people were on the road, they would call in. But I don\u2019t remember them ever getting canceled. It was every Monday, and Bagger would send to these committee members by Friday close of business the agenda for the meeting, the resumes that the people were proposing hiring, and any other information that they needed to be able to make decisions.\u201d\n\nOn the percentage of avoidable problems caused by discarding the transition plan\n\n\u201cSeventy-five percent.\u201d\n\nOn the White House\u2019s progress on the opioids crisis\n\n\u201cI\u2019m more optimistic now than I was, let\u2019s say three months ago. Because I think they\u2019ve now given it to Kellyanne [Conway] to do. And there is now the responsible party at the White House that\u2019s coordinating everything and the cabinet now knows that.\u201d\n\n_____\n\n\u201cI think we had some impediments. Secretary Price was an impediment, right?\u201d\n\n_____\n\n\u201cHe did not like the idea of the commission, he was opposed to the commission being established in the first place.\u201d\n\nOn the president\u2019s rhetoric\n\n\u201cMy approach from the beginning was, my first election was about Jon Corzine. It wasn\u2019t about me. I was just the acceptable alternative to the person they have rejected.\u201d\n\n_____\n\nTo the president, \u201cI said, \u2018Now the next four years are about you.\u2019 And so his re-elect will be about you. Not about your challenger. It\u2019ll be about you.\u201d\n\nOn New Jersey Transit\n\n\u201cSo first off, this idea that, \u2018Oh, New Jersey Transit has been starved\u2019 \u2014 we had one big accident with, tragically, one person died because a guy had sleep apnea. O.K. And then this becomes like New Jersey Transit is falling apart. Before that you never heard anything about New Jersey Transit falling apart. Pre- that accident, you go back and look at the clips, there was not any big discussion about New Jersey Transit being in some crisis. It\u2019s not in a crisis. Now, can it be improved? Yes. But we\u2019re on track to get positive train control in by the federal deadline of December 18. And it\u2019s already fully funded. The new governor\u2019s not going to have put any new money into P.T.C. unless he wants to accelerate it. If he wants to accelerate it getting in before December 18 he could put more money in, I guess, and get it done a little more quickly. But he doesn\u2019t need to.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\n\u201cThe key to infrastructure in New Jersey is going to be getting the Gateway tunnel done. I mean, and that\u2019s nothing to do with New Jersey Transit. I mean, it\u2019s going to be New York, New Jersey and the feds getting together in an equitable way which Governor Cuomo now has agreed on. We agreed on it with the Obama administration and the Trump administration has not come forward yet on it.\u201d\n\n_____\n\n\u201cMy wife, up until about four years ago, took New Jersey Transit every day for 25 years, and she would complain to me all the time, no matter what. \u2018Oh it\u2019s too crowded, it\u2019s too hot in the summer, in the winter it\u2019s too cold.\u2019 I mean, meet a commuter who likes to commute? Like someone who says, \u2018Oh my commuting experience is so pleasant.\u2019\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n_____\n\n\u201cI think what the new governor will find when he comes in, especially with $2 billion a year being spent on infrastructure, is that he is going to have plenty of money available to him to do the things that he may want to do. And if that improves things, great. But the idea that somehow, people can\u2019t get into New York now \u2014 like the \u2018summer of hell\u2019\u2014 I wanted to kill Cuomo when he said that. It was, seriously, it was one of the dumbest things. And you know, Andrew and I have a great relationship, we\u2019ve worked really well for seven years, but when he said that, I called him, I said, \u2018What are you doing? That\u2019s all we\u2019re going to hear now.\u2019\u201d\n\nOn James Comey and the F.B.I. case on Hillary Clinton\n\n\u201cI think that Jim Comey was wrong in this respect. Put aside the merits of whether Hillary committed a crime or she didn\u2019t. He should have never been the one making that decision and announcing it. And once he did, he made the F.B.I. political.\u201d\n\nOn advice to those whom the president attacks\n\n\u201cThe sun will come up. O.K.? I mean because, he is, the president is an outspoken, direct, blunt guy. So O.K., he\u2019s going to say those things, but in the end, just keep doing your job and doing it well.\u201d\n\nOn the quality of the president\u2019s legal advice\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t know what legal advice the president is getting or not getting. But I would say that any legal advice that tries to predict when a prosecutor\u2019s investigation is going to end is just kind of shooting in the dark.\u201d\n\n_____\n\n\u201cThe president, quite frankly, doesn\u2019t get enough credit for the fact that he really has been very fair to Mueller. And you hear all this speculation about things. I will tell you this, I talk to the president fairly frequently, he has never even once even hinted to me about firing Bob Mueller. Never. Never. I think it\u2019s the exact opposite. I think the president just would like him to get the job done.\u201d\n\nOn the aides involved in \u2018Bridgegate\u2019\n\n\u201cIt was bad and stupid. And I was up by 30 points. The idea that like \u2014 the thing that\u2019s always bugged me about this, amongst other things, is that the idea that I would care for five seconds about whether or not I had the endorsement of the mayor of Fort Lee is laughable. Both on the basis of the fact that I didn\u2019t even know who the mayor of Fort Lee was, and secondly, because Fort Lee is a town that has no political significance at all. It\u2019s a little town. I don\u2019t remember how many voters there are in Fort Lee. But not a lot.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s insulting to me that people think I would participate in something like that. And I think the entire thing was stupid and ridiculous. And it\u2019s inexplicable to me what they were thinking.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n_____\n\n\u201cIt was covered as if I was already the nominee or the president. I mean every night, every night, every night, I mean there\u2019s been studies that were done that were given to us about the amount of the coverage that dwarfed like the I.R.S. scandal in the Obama administration by like 12-to-1, in terms of the amount of time in the evening news.\u201d\n\n_____\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s nothing you can do. And that\u2019s the switch. Telling it like it is and my personality still works with the people in this state. It just didn\u2019t work for me as much as it did before because some of them, mostly Democrats and some middle-of-the-road independents, abandoned me because it confirmed for them their fear about me. And when that happens, that\u2019s bad.\u201d\n\nOn the tax overhaul\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s significant, but I think there\u2019s ways we can fight back against it, in this sense. We should right now make property taxes fully deductible on state income taxes. It will only cost about $150-170 million dollars in the state budget, and we should do it right now, because if we don\u2019t, it will affect the real estate market in the state.\u201d\n\nOn election night\n\n\u201cI got home about 4:30 a.m. And Mary Pat, who is the soundest sleeper I\u2019ve ever met in my life, who can sleep through anything, was straight up in bed waiting for me. And she looked at me and said, \u2018Are we going to Washington?\u2019 And I said, I really don\u2019t know, but get ready.\n\n\u201cSo I think both of our expectations that moment was that he would probably offer me something that I was willing to leave office to do. I didn\u2019t know what exactly, but I figured there was probably something that he was going to offer me that I would say, \u2018All right, it\u2019s important enough for me to leave the last year.\u2019 But in the end he never did. Now two days later, I was fired as the chairman of the transition. And I got offered a bunch of stuff in the month of December and in the month of February that I didn\u2019t take because I didn\u2019t think it was important enough for me to leave the job.\u201d", "title": "Chris Christie Interview Excerpts: The Governor on Trump, the Transition and His Record", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "As the lone correspondent covering New Jersey for The Times, this could sometimes make coverage a little complicated. If I was out reporting a story, I would stop what I was doing to find a place to watch his news conferences streamed on YouTube. Often, this was the front seat of my car, with my laptop propped against the steering wheel and iPhone plugged into the car audio so I could hear; in the summer, with the windows rolled down, this earned me a fair share of bewildered stares.\n\nThere was also the near-midnight call I received from his office last spring, after a spate of rail delays and derailments had renewed a common perception of Mr. Christie as the central villain in the state\u2019s transit problems. He had been noticeably silent, but now the governor was announcing that he would instruct New Jersey Transit to withhold all payments to Amtrak until a \u201cfull review\u201d could be conducted. It was a vintage Christie punishment, meted out in the middle of the night.\n\nThere was the constant willingness to engage in banter with voters, both in-state and out, such as the woman from his hometown of Mendham on Election Day. I had gone to ask the governor a question about the likely election of Philip D. Murphy, but stuck around for the full, 17-minute impromptu conference in a chilly firehouse parking lot. About 15 minutes in, Mr. Christie got into an argument with a voter over town consolidation, sarcastically calling her \u201cfabulous.\u201d\n\nPerhaps no event in the final year of his eight-year tenure as governor showcased the national interest he still commands than when he was caught lounging in a beach chair, his family alone on a 10-mile stretch of beach that had been forced closed by a government that he shut down. Mr. Christie had already commanded our attention in a budget standoff that shut down the state government over the Fourth of July weekend. But it was the now-famous shots by Andrew Mills, a photographer for NJ Advance Media, finding their way into endless memes and cable news, that really seemed to seize the country\u2019s attention.\n\nIndeed, there was seemingly endless interest in the governor \u2014 from readers, co-workers, editors (Exhibit A: the assignment of writing this article) \u2014 on a scale that extends well beyond New Jersey.\n\nAnd for a governor who so relished the spotlight, with a natural ability to captivate and control it, it was a perfect storm of a final term.\n\nHe leaves office on Tuesday with a future uncertain, bound by state ethics laws from negotiating compensation for a next job while still holding public office. He\u2019s floated that he could be interested in media, or law firms, or even in the financial sector, but he maintains that nothing is certain. His only plans are to catch his idol, Bruce Springsteen, on Broadway.\n\nOne thing that is likely, however, is that whatever he decides to do next, we\u2019ll be paying attention. I\u2019ll probably have to pull over my car, pull out the laptop, plug in my iPhone and listen.", "title": "Chris Christie: A Beat Unto Himself", "authors": ["Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Harden stepped back from Curry for a 3-pointer as the shot clock expired to make it 114-108 with 1 minute 10 seconds left, then blocked Curry\u2019s 3-point attempt after a timeout.\n\nHarden finished with 22 points. Paul added two free throws with 28 seconds left.\n\nGolden State lost away from home for the first time since Nov. 22. The Warriors had won seven straight in Houston.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been a good streak, disappointing end to it,\u201d Coach Steve Kerr said. \u201cBut we didn\u2019t deserve to win tonight. We played pretty poorly, did a lot of things to hurt ourselves and we\u2019re playing a great team. Can\u2019t get away with it.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. It was just the sixth time in his career that he had attempted 20 or more shots while making six or fewer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt was just one of those nights where I personally didn\u2019t have the right vision on the floor,\u201d he said. \u201cSo I\u2019ve got to take that responsibility for that one. It was pretty bad.\u201d\n\nThe Warriors were wrapping up a five-game road trip and had won the first four games to tie a franchise record for consecutive road wins. But they struggled from the outset Saturday and trailed by double digits for most of the first half.\n\nIt was Harden\u2019s second game back after missing seven with a strained hamstring. He was in a much better rhythm than in his return Thursday night, when he scored a season-low 10 points. He had eight assists, two steals and two blocks Saturday.\n\nThe Rockets got the victory despite missing Trevor Ariza and Gerald Green, who were both serving the second game of a two-game suspension for an altercation with the Clippers. Clint Capela added 18 points for Houston on a night when the top reserve Eric Gordon went 0 for 9 from 3-point range and finished with just 6 points.\n\nGolden State led by 4 before Houston went on a 9-2 run, with the first five points from Paul, to take a 109-106 lead with about three minutes left.", "title": "Chris Paul Scores 33 as Rockets End Warriors\u2019 Road Streak", "authors": ["The Associated Press"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA number of women \u2014 including you, as the interim replacement for Charlie Rose on PBS \u2014 have taken over positions of men who were fired over sexual-abuse accusations. Are you surprised at the number of men in media who have been implicated? Of course I\u2019m surprised, especially when it\u2019s people you know and you\u2019ve worked with, and then this kind of thing comes to light. But on the other hand, the patriarchy has dominated for thousands of years, and people see it as their God-given right. It\u2019s not just sexual harassment or abuse or all the other sexual issues \u2014 it\u2019s everything. According to the I.M.F., when women are equally represented in all aspects of economy and business, it can cause national G.D.P.s to rise rapidly. In the United States, having equal numbers of women in the work force would raise America\u2019s G.D.P. by five percentage points. In India, by 27 percentage points. If people can\u2019t be persuaded to see a woman\u2019s right to control her own body as a moral issue, it\u2019s most definitely an economic one.\n\nThere has been some hand-wringing about the fired men: that a mass of male talent is departing the industry. Do you agree? That pisses me off. These talented men are suppressing talented women! You cannot put a figure on the number of young women who have been squelched or run out of Dodge because they haven\u2019t been able to tolerate it.\n\nWhat was it like studying how other cultures deal with sex for \u201cSex and Love Around the World\u201d while there\u2019s this crisis back in the United States? I set out to talk to people about their sense of empowerment, of agency over their own bodies, feelings, futures, marriages, their ability to be free in their own society, how much control they have over their sexuality. It just so happens that it dovetailed with this evidence that many people in the West have less control over that than we would like to imagine.\n\nI have to admit, watching it felt like a departure from the reporting we\u2019ve seen from you in the past. In asking people questions about sex, you inadvertently kind of reveal what you think about sex. I hope people will not be shocked. One thing I found: Everywhere we went, everybody had the same questions. You realize that we\u2019re all the same.\n\nYou\u2019ve been at CNN for 35 years. What has it been like for you, as one of the primary voices of the network, having President Trump make it a target? Of course I\u2019m outraged, but I don\u2019t take it personally. I think it\u2019s just a silly distraction. But do I think that we\u2019re in trouble? Not one iota.\n\nAmanpour is the chief international correspondent for CNN, the anchor of \u201cAmanpour\u201d and the host of the show \u201cSex & Love Around the World.\u201d Age: 60 Occupation: Journalist Hometown: London Her Top 5 Places in Report In: 1. Bosnia 2. Haiti 3. Afghanistan 4. Iran 5. Gabon\n\nThe criticism would be that CNN benefits from the attention. Well, that might\u2019ve been true in the early days, but I don\u2019t think anybody benefits from this kind of sustained assault. It\u2019s not just damaging to a network \u2014 it\u2019s damaging to civil society and to the United States\u2019 democracy, which is based on knowing the difference between truth and lies. Truth leads to democracy, lies lead to dictatorship and this is where I think people, whether it\u2019s the president or people around him, are not fully aware of the real impact of what they\u2019re saying. It drives wedges between people, and if anything, these recent elections have told us that the population has become so polarized that people can be affected by lies that are peddled and empty promises that are made, tribalistic policies that are rammed down people\u2019s throats, and you have to be really, really careful.\n\nDo you think that there are ways journalists could be making a better effort to build credibility? One of the big issues is that because of money, so much journalism is being cut back \u2014 not necessarily at the big operations, but in local markets, where it really counts. You have national or international news organizations parachuting into the middle of the country for a few hours, but you don\u2019t have as much of that great indigenous local reporting that you used to have. That\u2019s what harms the country, because that\u2019s where you get the real story.", "title": "Christiane Amanpour Believes in the Power of Local News", "authors": ["Audie Cornish"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI don\u2019t feel like he\u2019s been disloyal to me,\u201d Mr. Christie said in a two-hour interview last week in which he stressed both his close relationship with the president and admitted to few regrets about his record in two terms as governor. \u201cIt\u2019s been a long time he and I\u2019ve been friends, and talking with each other, through a number of different jobs for me and a number of different situations and iterations for him.\u201d\n\nSitting in an upholstered chair in a room at Drumthwacket, the governor\u2019s mansion, Mr. Christie defended Mr. Trump as well as his own role in the transition, which he said went off the wheels after his departure and was the reason for \u201c75 percent\u201d of the president\u2019s woes last year. To this day, Mr. Christie said he is unsure of what the president knew about his dismissal. (A new book about Mr. Trump by the author Michael Wolff suggests that it was at the request of Ivanka Trump).\n\nAs for his own thwarted presidential ambitions, he had a simple response to a question of whether he believes that without the Bridgegate scandal and Mr. Trump\u2019s entry into the race, he could have been the Republican nominee in 2016 and living in the White House today.\n\n\u201cI do,\u201d he said, then paused. \u201cI don\u2019t think there\u2019s any other way to answer it.\u201d\n\nAsked about his low approval ratings in New Jersey, the crisis over the state\u2019s infrastructure, and its budget struggles, Mr. Christie said there was little that he would do over.\n\n\u201cI feel like I\u2019ve done the job as well or better than anybody who\u2019s ever had it,\u201d Mr. Christie said. \u201cWould there be little things I would do differently? Sure. But over the sweep of the eight years, I think when I leave, people are going to see just how hard this stuff is. This is a tough state to govern.\u201d", "title": "Christie on His Relationship With Trump (Great) and His Regrets (Few) as New Jersey\u2019s Governor", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Christine Beshar, one of the first women to be named partner in a Wall Street law firm, where she established a pioneering child-care service for its employees, died on Jan. 11 at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.\n\nHer death was confirmed by her son, Peter.\n\nMrs. Beshar, who specialized in trust and estate law, was practicing until her death at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, which made her its first female partner in 1971, seven years after she was hired.\n\nAlmost 20 years later she pushed Cravath to become the first major New York firm to open its own child-care center for its working parents, an idea she had proposed. It began in 1989, after the firm had moved to midtown Manhattan from downtown, as an on-site backup service available to employees when other child-care arrangements fell through.\n\nMrs. Beshar\u2019s proposal had been born of necessity. She had taken only a week or two of vacation time after the birth of each of her children, and one day her son\u2019s babysitter failed to show up. In those days, parents rarely took their children to work.", "title": "Christine Beshar, Trailblazing Lawyer, Dies at 88", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nChristo has long been interested in mastabas, trapezoidal structures that originated in Mesopotamia. He designed a Texas mastaba in 1975, for example, and is devising plans to build a permanent one in Abu Dhabi, which he says will be the largest art structure in the world. But before then, he will build one this summer in Hyde Park in London that will be made up of 7,506 oil barrels and float on the Serpentine lake, behind Kensington Palace.\n\nThe temporary structure will be unveiled around June 20, in conjunction with an exhibit at the nearby Serpentine Galleries on Christo and his wife and artistic partner, Jeanne-Claude, who died in 2009. Standing about 65 feet tall and weighing 500 tons, the mastaba will be anchored to one spot but will still bob up and down. The Westminster Council approved the proposal last week.\n\n\u201cThe exciting part of the project is that it\u2019s detached from the urban landscape,\u201d Christo said in an interview on Sunday. \u201cYou have this incredible vegetation and open area.\u201d\n\nThe mastaba will use 50 times fewer barrels than the planned Abu Dhabi version; while that one will primarily be orange, the British mastaba will take on the colors of its country\u2019s flag \u2014 blue, red and white \u2014 as well as purple. \u201cThe mauve is very royal,\u201d Christo said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe project was conceived in October 2016. Last year, Christo tested its feasibility by building a model the tenth of the scale in the Black Sea off the coast of Bulgaria, his home country. As he has done in the past, he will fund the project, which he estimates will cost $4.2 million, through the sale of his art.\n\nWhile Christo has not yet worked on a project in London on the scale of \u201cThe Gates\u201d in Manhattan\u2019s Central Park or the wrapping of the Reichstag in Berlin, he has an extensive history in the city. \u201cI remember we would take a train there to take a bath in London, because we only had a shower in Paris,\u201d Christo said of himself and Jeanne-Claude. \u201cWe started going to London in the early \u201960s, the great years, when the Beatles were just coming out.\u201d", "title": "Christo to Build Floating Structure in London\u2019s Hyde Park", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAfter scores of owners filed safety complaints or shared concerns through social media, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles said Friday that it was recalling nearly 154,000 Chrysler Pacifica minivans to fix an issue that has caused some to stall suddenly while being driven.\n\nThe company discovered that under rare conditions the minivan\u2019s engine control module could incorrectly assess the operating status, potentially causing the engine to stall. Drivers found that they had to shut the vehicles off and restart them to resume driving. Some reported experiencing stalls in intersections or on highways.\n\nFiat Chrysler said it was aware of a single accident that was possibly related to the problem, but no injuries. The company said most of the stalling had occurred when the vehicles were idling or while starting, turning or moving at slow speeds.\n\nThe recall covers gas-powered Pacificas from the 2017 model year, a majority of the 180,000 Pacificas sold since the model was introduced in 2016. Hybrid Pacificas are unaffected.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast year, Pacifica owners began filing complaints with federal safety regulators about suddenly losing power on the road. After dealers and Chrysler engineers failed to pinpoint a problem, some customers called on the automaker to buy the minivans back, and the company came under pressure to determine whether a serious safety defect existed.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Center for Auto Safety, an advocacy group, filed a petition in November calling on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to open a formal investigation and order a recall.\n\n\u201cWe are pleased to see Chrysler respond appropriately by conducting a full recall of the Pacifica Minivans, because stalling is an incredibly dangerous condition that puts the lives of drivers, passengers and others sharing the road at risk,\u201d Jason Levine, the group\u2019s executive director, said in a statement.", "title": "Chrysler Pacifica Minivans in Recall Over Engine Stalling", "authors": ["Neal E. Boudette"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "It is a provocative moment for the art world, as the public debate about separating creative output from personal conduct moves from popular culture into the realm of major visual artists from different eras and the institutions that have long collected and exhibited their pieces.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re very used to having to defend people in the collection, but it\u2019s always been for the sitter\u201d rather than the artist, said Kim Sajet, director of the Portrait Gallery, which has a large body of Mr. Close\u2019s work. \u201cNow we have to think to ourselves, \u2018Do we need to do that about Chuck Close?\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cYou can\u2019t talk about portraiture in America without talking about Chuck Close,\u201d she added. \u201cThere are lots of amazing artists who have been less than admirable people.\u201d\n\nFor the most part, curators and museum directors say that making artistic decisions based on personal behavior is a dangerous road to go down. All of the museum officials interviewed said they plan to continue to retain and show their Close holdings, in part because he has not been charged with any crime and the accusations have not been proven in a court of law.\n\n\u201cHow much are we going to do a litmus test on every artist in terms of how they behave?\u201d said Jock Reynolds, the director of the Yale University Art Gallery, which collects Mr. Close\u2019s work. \u201cPablo Picasso was one of the worst offenders of the 20th century in terms of his history with women. Cities must band together to demand that Amazon make up for the myriad forms of displacement and stress that 50,000 new workers put on a city.\n\nThis should include large investments in public affordable housing, job training, green space, public transit and more. Additionally, cities must find ways to ensure that those residents most in need of jobs will be offered more than a part-time job with no avenue for advancement. If not, Amazon is not welcome here.\n\nDAVID DASH, BROOKLYN\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cLocal Expertise, in 238 Places\u201d (Business Day, Jan. 29):\n\nThe public paid for the data that cities provided to Amazon in their quest to become the site of the company\u2019s second headquarters. All the bid data \u2014 local resources, like the labor market and transit options, education programs and tax incentives \u2014 should be published as a resource for enterprises, planners, students, researchers, in short, everyone.\n\nThe money that paid for the submissions is tax money and, you say, \u201cfree research\u201d for Amazon. The information should be made public, free, in a central, easily accessible location and user-friendly form.", "title": "Opinion | Cities\u2019 Bid for Amazon Isn\u2019t a One-Way Street", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "The snag with Citigroup\u2019s decade-long climb back from the financial brink is that it\u2019s been largely driven by forces that its chief executive, Mike Corbat, doesn\u2019t control. Changes to the United States tax regime show that\u2019s sometimes a good thing.\n\nTax cuts just left Citigroup with a big loss, and a bigger opportunity. The $203 billion lender took a $22 billion charge in the last quarter of 2017 as it wrote down deferred tax assets \u2014 credits against future tax bills \u2014 and took a hit for deemed repatriation of overseas earnings. That left it deep in the red. But its new corporate tax rate of an effective 25 percent will hike earnings in the future. If the tax law had been in effect last year, the 9.6 percent return on tangible common equity Citigroup just reported for the year would have risen above 10 percent \u2014 already beating his target for 2018, and suggesting that Mr. Corbat can be more ambitious.\n\nBeyond that, the impact of the tax cuts becomes less clear, but they will probably still be helpful. If consumers and small businesses feel richer, as its rival JPMorgan Chase said last week they probably will, a beneficiary should be a company like Citigroup, which makes roughly one-quarter of its revenue from credit cards. Mr. Corbat warned last year that the cost of writing down unrecoverable loans was going to rise a little more than expected, and credit losses on its North American own-brand card business rose 10 percent in the quarter. More cash flow for households may keep that in check \u2014 and might actually encourage more borrowing.\n\nWhere Mr. Corbat can steer Citigroup directly, he is doing so. Expenses fell to 58 percent of revenue, compared with 59 percent a year ago. Investment banking was more mixed: Revenue from fixed-income trading, where Citigroup is heavily exposed to flaccid rate and currency movements, plunged by almost one-fifth. Yet the bank is collecting more advisory fees. Its share of the overall pot rose a little to 4.8 percent in 2017, according to data from Thomson Reuters.", "title": "Citigroup Steers Into Recovery, With Others\u2019 Hands on the Wheel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCitigroup said on Tuesday that the new tax law would cost the banking giant $22 billion, resulting in a loss for the fourth quarter of 2017 and slightly reducing the amount of capital it has to protect against future losses.\n\nBut it could very well be the most inconsequential $22 billion charge in the bank\u2019s history. Without it, Citigroup\u2019s quarterly earnings and revenue exceeded analysts\u2019 estimates. And the bank\u2019s chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, told investors in a statement accompanying its earnings announcement that the tax overhaul would lead to higher profits in the future. The company\u2019s stock rose in early trading on Wall Street.\n\nCitigroup is the second major bank to reveal a one-time loss related to the new tax code. On Friday, JPMorgan Chase said adjusting to the new regime would cost it $2.4 billion.\n\nCitigroup reported a net loss for the quarter of $18.3 billion. Excluding the tax charge, Citigroup\u2019s quarterly profit was $3.7 billion, or $1.28 per share, compared to $3.6 billion, or $1.14 per share, for the same period in 2016. Analysts had expected the bank\u2019s earnings per share to be $1.19.\n\nOf the $22 billion tax charge, $19 billion came from lowering the value of assets on Citigroup\u2019s books that the bank had planned to use to shield itself from taxes under the old, higher corporate tax rate. The top corporate rate under the new law will be lowered to 21 percent from 35 percent. Citigroup\u2019s effective tax rate for the fourth quarter was 24.9 percent.\n\nThe remaining $3 billion came from the cost of moving cash that the bank held overseas back into the United States, as required under the new law.", "title": "Citigroup Takes a $22 Billion Tax Hit, but Sees Higher Profits Ahead", "authors": ["Emily Flitter"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "The deaths of four squirrel monkeys used as subjects in a nicotine addiction study have prompted the Food and Drug Administration to shut down the research permanently and to establish a council to oversee all animal studies under the agency\u2019s purview.\n\n\u201cIt is clear the study was not consistent with the agency\u2019s high animal welfare standards,\u201d Dr. Scott Gottlieb, the agency\u2019s commissioner, said in a statement on Friday. \u201cThese findings indicate that F.D.A.\u2019s animal program may need to be strengthened in some important areas.\u201d\n\nDr. Gottlieb has called in an independent investigator to examine the agency\u2019s animal research programs, starting with those at the National Center for Toxicological Research, in Arkansas, where the squirrel monkeys were housed. The 20 or so study animals will be transferred to a sanctuary, the commissioner said.\n\nFederally funded medical research that relies on animals has been contentious for years. The National Institutes for Health has banned the use of chimpanzees in biomedical research and has retired hundreds of lab chimps, some of which have been moved to sanctuaries. The N.I.H. continues to finance research on other nonhuman primates for studies of neurobiology, metabolic illness and other ailments.", "title": "Citing Deaths of Lab Monkeys, F.D.A. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe advisory board was established in 1935 to advise the secretary of the interior, who oversees management of the country\u2019s national parks and monuments. Since taking office last year, Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke has come under criticism from environmental advocates for promoting President Trump\u2019s agenda of opening up the nation\u2019s public lands and waters to fossil-fuel exploration, and for reducing the protection of public monuments.\n\nThis month Mr. Zinke announced a plan to open up the majority of the nation\u2019s coastlines to offshore drilling. And in December, the administration reduced the size of two national monuments in Utah, Bears Ears and Grand Staircase-Escalante, by some two million acres, the largest rollback of federal land protection in the nation\u2019s history.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cFrom all of the events of this past year I have a profound concern that the mission of stewardship, protection, and advancement of our National Parks has been set aside,\u201d wrote Tony Knowles, the head of the advisory board, in a resignation letter dated Monday that was co-signed by eight other members of the 12-member panel. The Washington Post first reported the letter.\n\n\u201cWe resigned because we were deeply disappointed with the department and we were concerned,\u201d Mr. Knowles said in an interview. Mr. Zinke, he said, \u201cappears to have no interest in continuing the agenda of science, the effect of climate change, pursuing the protection of the ecosystem.\u201d", "title": "Citing \u2018Inexcusable\u2019 Treatment, Advisers Quit National Parks Panel", "authors": ["Coral Davenport"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Doctors Without Borders estimates that at least 6,700 Rohingya in Myanmar met violent deaths in a single month last year. Yet local investigations into the crisis, which began after Rohingya insurgents attacked Myanmar security posts last August, claim that not a single Rohingya civilian was harmed by the Tatmadaw, as the Myanmar military is known.\n\nMs. Aung San Suu Kyi has set up at least half a dozen commissions, panels and boards dedicated to the turmoil in Rakhine, including the Advisory Commission Board on Rakhine State, to which Mr. Richardson was named.\n\nKofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, chaired another panel, which was formed after an earlier military crackdown on the Rohingya in 2016. His commission recommended that the government of Buddhist-majority Myanmar allow unfettered humanitarian access to the epicenter of violence in northern Rakhine.\n\nTo this day, however, the Myanmar government has refused to allow United Nations investigators and the international media to freely visit northern Rakhine. Aid groups have been similarly stymied. Last month, Yanghee Lee, the United Nations special rapporteur on Myanmar who has been a vocal critic of the military crackdown, was denied a visa to the country.\n\nMr. Richardson, a former United Nations ambassador under President Bill Clinton, has a reputation as a diplomatic troubleshooter. He said last week en route to Myanmar that during his visit he intended to secure the release of the Reuters journalists, who were seized in December.\n\n\u201cOne of my objectives in joining the advisory board was to be helpful and try to sort out real, long-term policy solutions,\u201d Mr. Richardson said. \u201cBut I discovered that this board was being used as a cheerleading squad for the government.\u201d\n\nMr. Richardson said he had been \u201cvery shocked\u201d by how Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi and other board members had disparaged human rights groups, the United Nations and international media organizations over how the Rohingya disaster had been presented to the world.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was particularly critical of the advisory board\u2019s chairman, Surakiart Sathirathai, a Thai politician who, Mr. Richardson said in a statement, had sought to \u201cavoid the real issues at the risk of confronting our Myanmar hosts.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe board\u2019s agenda, Mr. Richardson said in the statement, was \u201cdevoid of any meaningful engagement with the local communities in Rakhine, whose people the advisory board is meant to serve.\u201d\n\nMr. Surakiart could not immediately be reached for comment.\n\nA spokesman for Myanmar\u2019s government, U Zaw Htay, said that Mr. Richardson did not understand the \u201crules and regulations\u201d of the board\u2019s meeting with Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi and accused him of overstepping his mandate.\n\n\u201cHe needs to understand clearly that he is supposed to give advice only about the Rakhine issue, not everything about Myanmar,\u201d Mr. Zaw Htay said. \u201cHe cannot say whatever he wants to say.\u201d\n\nThe departure of Mr. Richardson could deeply damage the credibility of the advisory board. Mr. Richardson was among a powerful coterie of global leaders, human rights advocates, journalists and diplomats who had championed Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi for her principled stand against Myanmar\u2019s military junta, which kept her under house arrest for more than a decade and a half.\n\nBut ever since Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi entered a power-sharing agreement with the military in 2016, she has grown distant from her international supporters. She has refused to meet with some of her former advocates and complained about a \u201chuge iceberg of misinformation\u201d related to the Rohingya.\n\nSome of Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi\u2019s closest advisers are now former military men. She spends much of her time in Naypyidaw, the cloistered, largely empty Myanmar capital that was built by the generals to remove themselves from the thrum of life in Yangon, the nation\u2019s largest city.\n\n\u201cShe is in a bubble where she has people always telling her how great she is,\u201d Mr. Richardson said. \u201cShe\u2019s in the classic situation that politicians and leaders get themselves in when they don\u2019t want to listen to bad news and they have psychopaths around them who don\u2019t want to tell them the real situation.\u201d\n\nA spokeswoman for Mr. Richardson said later that he had meant \u201csycophants,\u201d not \u201cpsychopaths.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhile certain individuals, like her fellow Nobel Peace Prize laureates Desmond Tutu and Malala Yousafzai, have publicly censured Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, others have cautioned that her authority is constrained by a military-drafted Constitution that keeps most of Myanmar\u2019s power in the hands of the Tatmadaw.\n\n\u201cI hope this will be a wake-up call for her,\u201d Mr. Richardson said of his resignation. \u201cBut I sort of doubt it. I think she has added me to her enemy list, which includes the United Nations, the international media, human rights groups, Nobel laureates.\u201d\n\n\u201cI\u2019m afraid,\u201d he added, \u201cit\u2019s a very long list.\u201d", "title": "Citing \u2018Whitewash,\u2019 Bill Richardson Quits Rohingya Post", "authors": ["Hannah Beech", "Rick Gladstone"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cRequest to Check Citizenship Stirs Fears for Census\u201d (news article, Jan. 3):\n\nThe grand bargain of America suggests that if you work hard, play by the rules and contribute to this country, then you should be able to create opportunities for yourself and your family.\n\nThis is why the latest move by the Justice Department to add a question on citizenship to the 2020 census violates this long-held American promise. Latinos and immigrants have long been considered hard-to-count populations because of language, housing mobility and lack of education.\n\nQuestioning citizenship, in an age of increased immigration enforcement, stands to increase the likelihood of an undercount, threaten a constitutional right to be counted, and jeopardize equitable distribution of public funds.\n\nThe demographics of our country are shifting, and the 2020 census will be one of the most important in the history of our country. Rather than play on fear and fuel an undercount, let\u2019s work together to strengthen the democracy we all hold so dear to our hearts.", "title": "Opinion | Citizenship and the Census", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cGone Missing,\u201d the 2003 musical with a score by Michael Friedman, will be performed next summer at City Center to honor Mr. Friedman, who died last year at 41 of complications from HIV/AIDS.\n\nAt the time of his death, Mr. Friedman was the artistic director of City Center\u2019s Off-Center series, which produces revivals of pathbreaking Off Broadway musicals and will stage \u201cGone Missing\u201d on July 11 and 12, the theater announced on Friday.\n\n(Read more about what Mr. Friedman\u2019s death meant for the theater community.)\n\n\u201cWe wanted to celebrate the profound vision of our friend and colleague Michael Friedman, who is sorely missed,\u201d Anne Kauffman, who now leads Off-Center with the composer Jeanine Tesori, said in a statement. \u201cWe\u2019re certain that Michael\u2019s voice will continue to break open what musical theater can be and inspire audiences and artists for decades to come.\u201d\n\nWritten and directed by Steve Cosson, \u201cGone Missing\u201d is a documentary musical borne of interviews Mr. Friedman\u2019s company, the Civilians, conducted with people about objects they\u2019d lost, like keys or a single shoe.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOther shows in the Off-Center season include Jason Robert Brown\u2019s \u201cSongs for a New World\u201d (1995), the Tony Award-winner\u2019s breakout musical, from June 27-30. The song cycle tells stories of love and life-changing decisions from the 15th century to the present.\n\n\u201cDon\u2019t Bother Me, I Can\u2019t Cope,\u201d a 1971 musical by Micki Grant and Vinnette Carroll, will be staged July 25-28. Ivan Fischer and his incomparable Hungarian forces are the first visitors in a strong week of touring orchestras passing through New York, and they are surely one of the finest and most consistently interesting teams operating today. The main event is Rachmaninoff\u2019s lyrical Symphony No. 2, accompanied by Bach\u2019s Orchestral Suite No. 2, and Beethoven\u2019s Piano Concerto No. 3. Denes Varjon is the soloist.\n\n212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org\n\nDAVID BRIGGS at the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine (Jan. 16, 7:30 p.m.). Currently an artist in residence at this Morningside Heights cathedral, Mr. Briggs is one of our finest organists, and also a particularly good transcriber of orchestral works for his own instrument. Hear that to good effect in this concert, where he plays Mahler\u2019s Symphony No. 5.\n\n212-316-7540, stjohndivine.org\n\n\u2018L\u2019ELISIR D\u2019AMORE\u2019 at the Metropolitan Opera (Jan. 16, 7:30 p.m., through Feb. 17). Donizetti\u2019s classic comedy returns in the Bartlett Sher production, and with three strong leads: Matthew Polenzani as Nemorino, Pretty Yende as Adina, and Ildebrando d\u2019Arcangelo as Dulcamara. Domingo Hindoyan, a product of El Sistema and the husband of the Met\u2019s current Tosca, Sonya Yoncheva, makes his house debut on the podium.\n\n212-362-6000, metopera.org\n\nNEW YORK PHILHARMONIC at David Geffen Hall (Jan. 17, 7:30 p.m., through Jan. 20). Joshua Weilerstein, formerly a Philharmonic assistant conductor, returns to the podium as a replacement for the disgraced Charles Dutoit, and leads an all-Ravel program. Inevitably it ends with the \u201cBol\u00e9ro,\u201d but on the way there is \u201cLe Tombeau de Couperin\u201d and the \u201cValses nobles et sentimentales,\u201d as well as the Piano Concerto for the Left Hand, played by Jean-Yves Thibaudet.\n\n212-875-5656, nyphil.org\n\nROYAL CONCERTGEBOUW ORCHESTRA at Carnegie Hall (Jan. 17-18, 8 p.m.). Daniele Gatti\u2019s appointment as the chief conductor of the Netherlands\u2019 foremost orchestra has made a great deal of sense: he and his players share a specialty in music from the Wagner-to-Mahler period. That\u2019s the focus here. On Wednesday, a typical Gatti program: the third-act prelude and \u201cGood Friday Music\u201d from Wagner\u2019s \u201cParsifal\u201d prefaces Bruckner\u2019s Symphony No. 9. On Thursday, there\u2019s Mahler\u2019s Symphony No. 1, and the soloist Janine Jansen, a Perspectives artist this season, joins in for Bruch\u2019s Violin Concerto No. 1.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nTALEA ENSEMBLE at Flea Theater (Jan. 18, 7 p.m.). A clever program from a clever ensemble, one made up of homages by composers contemporary to composers past. Hear Pauline Oliveros\u2019 \u201cQuintuplets Play Pen: Homage to Ruth Crawford,\u201d James Weeks\u2019 \u201cHoney Celebration\u201d (a nod to Schubert), Oliver Knussen\u2019s \u201cupon one note\u201d (looking to Purcell), and Kurtag\u2019s \u201cHommage \u00e0 R. Sch.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, theflea.org", "title": "Classical Music in NYC This Week", "authors": ["David Allen"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera.\n\nCLEVELAND ORCHESTRA at Carnegie Hall (Jan. 23-24, 8 p.m.). Whether you think this is the best orchestra in the country, like my colleague Zachary Woolfe, or simply very, very good indeed, any visit from this storied old band to New York is worth checking out. On Tuesday, Franz Welser-M\u00f6st leads the local premiere of \u201cStromab\u201d by Johannes Maria Staud, a favorite composer of the conductor\u2019s, as well as Mahler\u2019s Symphony No. 9. On Wednesday, an all-too-rare performance of a Haydn oratorio, \u201cThe Seasons.\u201d Golda Schultz, Maximilian Schmitt and Christian Van Horn are the soloists, joined by the Cleveland Orchestra Chorus.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nERIC HUEBNER AND STEVEN BECK at Miller Theater (Jan. 23, 6 p.m.). The first of this winter\u2019s pop-up concerts in Morningside Heights, where the audience sits on the stage and has easy access to beer, is a double-piano feast: Ligeti\u2019s \u201cThree Pieces for Two Pianos,\u201d Steve Reich\u2019s \u201cPiano Phase\u201d and, dauntingly, Pierre Boulez\u2019s \u201cStructures I.\u201d\n\n212-854-7799, millertheatre.com\n\nFOCUS! FESTIVAL at Peter Jay Sharp Theater (Jan. 19, 7:30 p.m.). For this year\u2019s Juilliard festival, director Joel Sachs has chosen to showcase composers living and working in China, with one honorable exception. This first of six free programs, which conclude on Jan. 26 with the Juilliard Orchestra proper, sees the New Juilliard Ensemble play two world premieres, from Wang Shuci and Liu Sola, plus music by Ye Xiaogang and that one interloper, Chou Wen-Chung, a student of Martinu\u2019s and Var\u00e8se\u2019s who has lived for decades in New York.\n\n212-799-5000, juilliard.edu", "title": "Classical Music in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Classical\n\nOur guide to the city\u2019s best classical music and opera.\n\nAMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA at Carnegie Hall (Jan. 28, 2 p.m.). This is a week oddly short of orchestral music, with even the New York Philharmonic taking a deserved break. Fill the gap with Leon Botstein and his adventurous band, and this program looking at Jewish composers in the Soviet Union. Music by Mieczyslaw Weinberg takes up the first half, with his \u201cRhapsody on Moldavian Themes\u201d and the Symphony No. 5. After intermission, a work you\u2019re unlikely ever to have another opportunity to hear: Veniamin Fleishman\u2019s \u201cRothschild\u2019s Violin.\u201d Fleishman was Shostakovich\u2019s student, and after he was killed while serving in the Red Army, his teacher completed this one-act opera, based on a Chekhov story.\n\n212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org\n\nATTACCA QUARTET at the Church of the Intercession (Feb. 1, 8 p.m.). Part of the Crypt Sessions, this fine young quartet, which made its name with a welcome survey of Haydn\u2019s 68 works in the genre, performs Beethoven\u2019s vast Op. 132, with its long, slow paean of thanks at its core. Fork out for the concert, and there\u2019s a wine tasting beforehand.\n\ndeathofclassical.com", "title": "Classical Music in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "At 46 minutes 17 seconds\n\nA Collective\u2019s Communion\n\nEarlier this month, I saw the composer and flutist Nicole Mitchell lead a new group on the closing night of Winter Jazzfest. On Sunday, at National Sawdust in Brooklyn, I heard another recent piece by Ms. Mitchell, performed by the International Contemporary Ensemble (ICE). Like some of the composer\u2019s other works, \u201cInescapable Spiral\u201d emphasizes communal aspects of music-making, with entrances of instruments occasionally cued by performers from another section. The graceful ease of the composition comes through in a video of the world premiere last summer at the Ojai Festival in California, by a group that included Ms. Mitchell, players from ICE and students from the University of California, Irvine. At one point, when a flute-and-clarinet trio finishes meditating on a gently flowing passage, ICE flutist Alice Teyssier gives a nod. An accordion enters, adding an edgier texture, and is shortly joined by another flute and an additional string duo, all of whom launch into some of Ms. Mitchell\u2019s more hurtling motifs. This movement between the placid and the chattering never seems forced or anxious, but rather like the product of a collective\u2019s communion. SETH COLTER WALLS\n\nRead our profile of \u201can innovative flutist with an Afrofuturist vision.\u201d", "title": "Cleveland Conquers: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments of the Week on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "While getting rid of Chief Wahoo will be applauded by opponents, some may see it as only the first step toward the ultimate goal of changing the team name.\n\nProtests against the team names, logos and mascots have flared occasionally over the past few decades. The Redskins are seen by many as having one of the most egregiously insensitive nicknames, though the team and the N.F.L. have expressed little interest in changing it. The Braves, of Major League Baseball, have also drawn criticism, especially for the so-called tomahawk chant performed by fans at games.\n\nIn 2014, under Mark Shapiro, the team president at the time, the Indians reduced the use of the Chief Wahoo logo and introduced a block C as their primary insignia. Shapiro, who is now the Toronto Blue Jays\u2019 president, said the grinning caricature made him uncomfortable. But Chief Wahoo was still used by Cleveland, including during high-profile games in the postseason (the team reached the World Series in 2016).\n\nSmall groups of protesters regularly gather outside Progressive Field before important games, such as home openers and playoff games. While the protesters frequently incur the wrath of fans passing by on the way to the stadium, they have been on amicable terms with the team itself, which often coordinated with the police and the protesters to ensure their safety and right to assemble peacefully.\n\nSome have sought action from the courts to outlaw the logo and the team name. During the 2016 postseason, Douglas Cardinal, an indigenous Canadian activist, sought an injunction from a Canadian court to prevent Cleveland from using uniforms depicting Chief Wahoo or the team name while playing in Toronto.\n\nThe petition was denied, and Manfred said at the time that the courts were not the venue to resolve the dispute. He did, however, promise to engage the Cleveland ownership about significant changes regarding the use of the logo. Last April, during the Indians\u2019 home opener against the Chicago White Sox, Manfred for the first time made clear his desire to get rid of the logo altogether and outlined his intention to push Dolan on the issue.\n\nAlthough the Indians will stop using the logo on their uniforms, they will not relinquish the trademark and still will be able to profit off sales of merchandise bearing the logo at the stadium and in the Cleveland area. But by maintaining the trademark, the team, with the supervision of M.L.B., retains control of the proliferation of the logo. If it relinquished the trademark, or announced an intention never to claim its protections, another party could legally assume control of it and use the logo in other ways.", "title": "Cleveland Indians Will Abandon Chief Wahoo Logo Next Year", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "These tiny, shrimplike creatures filter algae and microbes from water. They are devoured in turn by small fish, which are eaten by bigger fish. If rising carbon dioxide were to affect water fleas, Dr. Weiss reasoned, it could influence the entire lake ecosystem.\n\nWater fleas use a bizarre but sophisticated defense to escape predators. They can sense chemicals given off by fish in their vicinity, and in response they make themselves harder to eat.\n\nSome species grow a massive crest on their head, while others sprout spikes. Dr. Weiss and her colleagues found that high levels of carbon dioxide caused water fleas to make smaller crests and shorter spikes.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRather than the acidity of the water, carbon dioxide itself seems to be affecting the water fleas. When the researchers lowered the pH with hydrochloric acid, the water fleas responded normally to predators.\n\nDr. Weiss hypothesized that carbon dioxide interferes with the nervous system of the water fleas, blunting their ability to look out for predators.\n\nCaleb T. Hasler, a biologist at the University of Winnipeg, said that the new research addressed an unanswered question: the amounts of carbon dioxide that might harm freshwater life.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThis paper is really important because it starts to show where those levels might be,\u201d he said.\n\nDr. Hasler\u2019s own recent research hints that water fleas may not be the only freshwater animals to be altered by carbon dioxide. He and his colleagues studied minnows swimming in water rich with carbon dioxide and found that the fish don\u2019t respond as quickly to alarm signals released by other minnows.\n\nIn another study, the team studied two species of mussels. One species relaxed its muscles in water high in carbon dioxide, so that its shell gaped open. The other species clamped its shell shut, so that it could no longer filter food.\n\nThese sorts of changes may send ripples out across entire freshwater ecosystems. Mussels are vital for filtering food and keeping water clear, for example. If water fleas do a worse job of escaping predators, their population may decline, leaving less food in the long run for fish.\n\nBut it\u2019s not certain that inland waters around the world are building up carbon dioxide at the rate that Dr. Weiss and her colleagues observed in the German reservoirs.\n\nIn November, Dr. Stanley and her colleagues published a study of carbon dioxide levels in lakes in Wisconsin. Between 1986 and 2011, they detected no significant change at all.\n\nThe mismatch points to the complex chemistry varying from one lake to the next. While lakes and rivers all absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, some also draw in the gas from surrounding soils.\n\nThe chemistry of some inland waters causes a lot of carbon dioxide to be converted into other compounds. Some lakes and streams may support a lot of underwater plants that take up the gas, for instance, while others may have microbes can release more of it.\n\nMaking matters even more complicated, the carbon dioxide levels in any particular body of freshwater can change drastically over time with swings in temperature and other conditions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cYou can have lakes where the carbon dioxide increases tenfold at night,\u201d said Dr. Hasler.\n\nIn decades to come, as carbon dioxide levels continue to climb in the atmosphere, Dr. Stanley speculated, the picture will only get more nuanced.\n\n\u201cI honestly don\u2019t know where we\u2019re going,\u201d said Dr. Stanley. \u201cI\u2019ll probably put my money on increased variability from lake to lake. They\u2019re just going to be more extreme.\u201d\n\nDr. Weiss agreed that it wasn\u2019t possible to draw big lessons from the preliminary data. \u201cI think this study we\u2019re publishing is like a door-opener,\u201d she said. \u201cI hope there will be other scientists who will follow.\u201d", "title": "Climate Change Is Altering Lakes and Streams, Study Suggests", "authors": ["Carl Zimmer"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "I have researched climate change policy for over a decade now. For a long time, we assumed that climate policy was stalled because it was a problem for the future. Or it would affect other people. Poorer people. Animals. Ecosystems. We assumed those parts of the world were separate from us. That we were somehow insulated. I didn\u2019t expect to see it in my own backyard so soon.\n\nClimate change devastated ecosystems, species and neighborhoods in Houston and much of struggling Puerto Rico last year. Now climate change has ravaged one of the wealthiest ZIP codes in the country. We know now that even the richest among us is not insulated.\n\nThese extreme events are getting worse. But when I read the news after each fresh disaster, I rarely see a mention of climate change. Whether it\u2019s coverage of a fire in my backyard or a powerful hurricane in the Caribbean, this bigger story is usually missing. To say that it is too soon to talk about the causes of a crisis is wrongheaded. We must connect the dots.\n\nClimate change helped cost my friends\u2019 businesses\u2019 revenue. Climate change helped put my community in chaos for weeks. Climate change paved the way for lost lives next door. If climate victims here and across the globe understood that carbon emissions from burning fossil fuels played a role in their losses, perhaps they would rise up to demand policy changes.\n\nWe know this could happen because research from the political scientist Regina Bateson, now a congressional candidate in California, shows that being a crime victim can spur people into activism. Perhaps some of the people affected by the fires in California, the hurricanes in Puerto Rico and Texas, and the drought in the Dakotas will be similarly motivated. Maybe some of these climate change victims will become the climate policy champions we sorely need.\n\nIt is never too soon after one of these disasters to speak truth about climate change\u2019s role. If anything, it is too late. If we do not name the problem, we cannot hope to solve it. For my community, as much as yours, I hope we will.", "title": "Opinion | Climate Change in My Backyard", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nKARACHI, Pakistan \u2014 An elite climbing team rescued a French mountain climber on Sunday from the treacherous Himalayan peak known as \u201cKiller Mountain,\u201d in Pakistan\u2019s northeast, but her Polish climbing partner remains in peril after efforts to reach him were at least temporarily abandoned.\n\nThe climbers, Elisabeth Revol and Tomek Mackiewicz, began their ascent of Nanga Parbat, the ninth-highest mountain in the world, on Jan. 20. The two are believed to have reached the summit, at an altitude of 8,126 meters, or 26,600 feet, which would make them only the second team to do so during the notoriously harsh winter season.\n\nDuring their descent, Mr. Mackiewicz is said to have had acute mountain sickness, caused by the lack of oxygen in the lower air pressure that exists at higher altitudes, as well as snow blindness and frostbite.\n\nMs. Revol continued down the mountain alone and called for help from a satellite phone, and she was eventually met by two members of a four-person rescue team flown to the mountain\u2019s base camp on Saturday. She had frostbite on her hands and feet, according to Ludovic Giambiasi, a friend who posted updates on Facebook, and she was taken to Islamabad, the capital, later in the day and received medical attention.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe extreme weather conditions \u2014 winds of more than 50 miles (80 kilometers) an hour and a wind chill nearing minus 80 degrees Fahrenheit (minus 62 degrees Celsius) \u2014 forced the rescue team to postpone any plans to ascend further to search for Mr. Mackiewicz.", "title": "Climber Rescued on Pakistan\u2019s \u2018Killer Mountain,\u2019 but Another Is in Peril", "authors": ["Meher Ahmad"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn the end,\u201d Mrs. Clinton said, \u201cI decided to demote him, docking his pay; separate him from the woman; assign her to work directly for my then deputy campaign manager; put in place technical barriers to his emailing her; and require that he seek counseling. He would also be warned that any subsequent harassment of any kind toward anyone would result in immediate termination.\u201d\n\n\u201cI did this because I didn\u2019t think firing him was the best solution to the problem,\u201d she said. \u201cHe needed to be punished, change his behavior and understand why his actions were wrong. The young woman needed to be able to thrive and feel safe. I thought both could happen without him losing his job. I believed the punishment was severe and the message to him unambiguous.\u201d\n\nAbout five years later, Mr. Strider was hired to lead a \u201csuper PAC\u201d supporting Mrs. Clinton and run by a key ally, David Brock.
