The squad performed well, but the trip was never repeated. A year later, the Australian authorities gained complete control over the residence, employment and marriage of their country\u2019s Indigenous people, the start of a heavy-handed form of oversight that rendered future tours impossible.\n\nThe loss of opportunity foreshadowed how many Indigenous Australians \u2014 those who are Aboriginal or hail from the Torres Strait Islands \u2014 were excluded from cricket for the next century. In 1902, Jack Marsh, an Indigenous fast bowler from New South Wales, was dropped from a state match against a touring England team after the England captain refused to play against him. In the 1930s, Eddie Gilbert was considered one of the world\u2019s fastest bowlers, but he had to obtain written permission merely to travel outside his Indigenous settlement in Queensland. He was never picked for Australia.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Australia Letter Newsletter Damien Cave, our new Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEven as recently as 2015, one Indigenous cricketer complained to researchers that in his local club\u2019s locker-room fine system \u2014 where players were sanctioned for mistakes like dropping catches \u2014 he was always fined a modest amount simply because he was Indigenous. \u201cEveryone thought it was hilarious,\u201d he said in a report on the state of Indigenous cricket in Australia. \u201cI never said anything though, \u2019cause in a way the blokes thought it was kind of including me, but it actually really hurt me.\u201d\n\n\u201cCricket has this unfortunate trait where cultural bias sits there, and it\u2019s unconscious,\u201d said John McGuire, who played in grade cricket \u2014 the level below the state team \u2014 in Western Australia for two decades from the mid-1970s, and is a former chair of the Western Australia Aboriginal Cricket Council.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMcGuire spoke from bitter personal experience. In the 1980s, McGuire \u2014 who has two Indigenous parents and said he endured racial abuse in \u201cjust about every game\u201d of his career \u2014 became the 24th batsman from his state to score 7,000 runs in grade cricket. The other 23 all had been selected for Western Australia at some stage; even though he reached 10,000 runs, McGuire never was.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cPeople will say, \u2018It\u2019s not a race thing; we\u2019re not racist; our best mates are black Australians,\u2019\u201d McGuire said. \u201cBut the unconscious bias won\u2019t allow them to select an Aboriginal person.\u201d", "title": "Cricket Australia Picks an Indigenous Player and Searches for More", "authors": ["Tim Wigmore"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "FIFA said it initially tried to contact Rodchenkov last year through WADA but was told he was not available. In a statement Tuesday, FIFA said it was awaiting the reanalysis of the samples of Russian athletes who were implicated by a trove of data obtained from Moscow in November before trying to re-establish contact with Rodchenkov. The reanalysis of the doping samples, expected to happen later this month, may be necessary to establish further evidence to successfully discipline athletes. The lab in Switzerland that is conducting the analysis is giving priority to samples from the tainted 2014 Winter Olympics before the Winter Games next month in South Korea.\n\n\u201cFIFA will continue its investigations, working in close collaboration with WADA and exploring every possible avenue,\u201d FIFA officials said in the prepared statement.\n\nJames Walden, a lawyer for Rodchenkov, said FIFA officials had never gotten in touch with him.\n\nTygart said that was unacceptable. \u201cFrankly, it\u2019s exasperating. Clean athletes and the public deserve to have the impact of Russian doping on football, if any, resolved immediately. We are over three years into dealing with this mess and there is no excuse for FIFA failing to contact the star witness at this point,\u201d Tygart said Tuesday.\n\nRodchenkov is currently in hiding in the United States. His testimony ultimately led to the International Olympic Committee\u2019s decision in December to ban Russia\u2019s Olympic Committee from next month\u2019s Winter Olympics. After conducting their own investigation, the I.O.C.\u2019s investigators surmised that Rodchenkov, branded a traitor in Russia, had largely been telling the truth.\n\nRodchenkov has evidence of Russian soccer players being protected by the state doping program, according to Walden. Those claims first appeared in the explosive 2016 report for the World Anti-Doping Agency from the Canadian lawyer Richard McLaren. McLaren based his report on forensic evidence and the cooperation of Rodchenkov. The report said more than 1,000 athletes from across 30 sports may have had their samples covered up, including soccer players that were on Russia\u2019s 2014 World Cup roster.\n\nFIFA released a timeline of its investigation so far, which has yielded no evidence of doping by Russian soccer players. Critics say the organization is trying to avoid acrimony with the country that is playing host to the World Cup next summer. FIFA said if it can find evidence \u201cto demonstrate an antidoping rule violation by any athlete, FIFA will impose the appropriate sanction.\u201d\n\n\u201cFor all the time and work FIFA put into this defensive timeline, it could have picked up the phone and arranged an interview of Dr. Rodchenkov 10 times over,\u201d said Walden, the lawyer for Rodchenkov.\n\nPhoto\n\nRodchenkov remains an active participant in the ongoing process in which scores of athletes have been barred following a reanalysis of their samples. He plans to provide witness testimony to the Court of Arbitration for Sport during appeals proceedings for sanctioned Russian athletes.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFIFA is trying to manage the doping inquiry amid lingering scrutiny of its ability to reform in the aftermath of a sprawling corruption scandal in 2015. That scandal brought down most of its top leadership. Three of its former governance leaders recently published an article in which they concluded FIFA couldn\u2019t be trusted to change under its own steam, and that outside intervention was needed.\n\nTygart said FIFA\u2019s performance showed \u201cwhy reform to the global antidoping system must start with removing sport from attempting to police itself, because you can\u2019t both promote and police effectively \u2014 as this clearly shows.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Russia World Cup has had other problems, too. Sponsors have been slow to sign on for what is the world\u2019s most-watched event. Russia\u2019s broadcasters finally signed a deal to broadcast the tournament in late December after more than a year of balking at FIFA\u2019s demands.\n\nPresident Gianni Infantino\u2019s efforts to generate excitement for the tournament were torpedoed when a news conference before last month\u2019s World Cup draw was overshadowed by questions about doping and the continued presence of Vitaly Mutko, Russia\u2019s deputy prime minister, as head of the organizing committee. Mutko had days earlier received a lifetime ban from the Olympics for his role in the doping scandal. He had been Russia\u2019s sports minister at the time of the Sochi Games.\n\nMutko has since stepped down from the organizing committee and temporarily resigned from his post as head of Russian soccer\u2019s governing body.\n\nJiri Dvorak, FIFA\u2019s top doctor for 22 years until his ouster in October 2016, expressed surprise that his former employers had yet to reach out to Rodchenkov. Dvorak had an active role the last time a drugs scandal threatened to overcome the tournament.\n\nIn 1994, he resisted pressure from some of FIFA\u2019s most senior officials when the Argentine superstar Diego Maradona, then among the most famous men on the planet, was ousted for failing a drug test. \u201cThat was against opinion of some of the South Americans. But Maradona had to be removed because when it comes to things like this you have to act according to the laws and the regulations,\u201d he said.\n\nThe I.O.C. has defended its own prolonged investigation that ultimately reiterated what had largely been known for more than a year. The organization blamed the delay on the challenge of coming up with a scientific test that could categorically confirm the claims that bottles containing urine samples had been tampered with. Investigators in November also secured the crucial data from Russia\u2019s drug testing laboratory that helped the I.O.C. to identify athletes whose positive tests had been covered up.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRodchenkov\u2019s lawyer said while there may have been some natural skepticism when the whistle-blower first made the claims of a widespread doping conspiracy, the chemist\u2019s credibility as a witness has been strengthened by the world\u2019s antidoping regulator, its independent investigator and now the I.O.C.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s overwhelming evidence showing that he\u2019s told the truth,\u201d Walden said. \u201cAt this point we would have thought FIFA would want to talk to him as one of its first priorities.\u201d\n\nFIFA hasn\u2019t hired an independent investigator to analyze the suspected doping cases. So far no soccer samples have been analyzed by the Lausanne laboratory that developed the complex tests to detect anomalies in Russian samples. FIFA has asked for its samples to be given priority after the last of the Sochi samples are tested later this month.\n\nDvorak, now a consulting neurologist at Zurich\u2019s Schulthess Clinic, said FIFA needed to act quickly to avoid allowing the Russian team to play under a cloud of suspicion. Reedie, the WADA president, added that it was up to the federations to verify WADA\u2019s information and act accordingly.\n\n\u201cWe want them to go ahead and act on this because they are responsible for the results,\u201d he said.", "title": "Critics Say FIFA Is Stalling a Doping Inquiry as World Cup Nears", "authors": ["Tariq Panja"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "A Justice Department spokesman, Devin M. O\u2019Malley, said in a statement that the Census Bureau hac recognized that results of the American Community Survey are \u201cnot the most appropriate data\u201d for use in districting matters. \u201cThe Justice Department is committed to free and fair elections for all Americans and has sought reinstatement of the citizenship question on the census to fulfill that commitment,\u201d he said.\n\nA substantial undercount would affect red and blue states alike \u2014 deeply Democratic California has nearly seven million eligible Hispanic voters, while deeply Republican Texas has nearly five million. But the true impact would fall on Democratic representation at all levels of government, because Latinos and other minorities are largely reliably Democratic constituencies.\n\nThe last census failed to find 1.5 percent of the Hispanic population, the Census Bureau said, an undercount exceeded only by the 2.1 percent of African-Americans who were missed. No reliable estimate exists of how many more might be deterred from participating in the census by a citizenship question, but among several experts interviewed, the consensus was that it could be substantial.\n\nEven small variations can have large political consequences. In 1997, Republicans vigorously fought a proposal to statistically adjust census results to address undercounts and overcounts, in no small part because their own study suggested the tweaks could affect election results in as many as 26 of the 435 House seats.\n\nIn a so-called long-form version of the census that was dropped after 2000, about 17 percent of respondents were asked whether they were citizens, although not whether they were in the country legally. Since then, the citizenship question has been asked annually in the American Community Survey.\n\nThe citizenship question proposed by the Justice Department differs little, if at all, from the one in the American Community Survey. Experts fear, however, that requiring an answer from all Americans would cause many minorities to avoid responding to all census questions for fear that their responses would be given to other government agencies.\n\nThe dropouts would be likely to include not only undocumented migrants, but entire families who are in the country legally but who house friends or relatives who are not.", "title": "Critics Say Questions About Citizenship Could Wreck Chances for an Accurate Census", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nIn 1970, I was 15. I lived in the Bronx and attended high school in Manhattan on 89th Street near Central Park West.\n\nAfter school during basketball season I would walk to Public School 75 on 96th Street and West End Ave for basketball practice. Practice ended around 6 p.m., and I would walk to the subway at 96th Street and Central Park West to head home. I traveled the same route every day for months.\n\nOne evening, as I was walking east across West End, a young police officer stopped me and asked where I was going.\n\nI was taken aback by his question. I wondered why a policeman would be interested in my travel routine. I told him I was walking to the subway in order to get home.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe looked at me with a stern demeanor.\n\n\u201cDo you realize you are jaywalking?\u201d he asked.\n\nHaving grown up in the Bronx, I wasn\u2019t even sure what he meant. I looked at him quizzically without answering.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cYou crossed in the middle of the street against the light,\u201d he bellowed.\n\nI glanced to my left and to my right.\n\n\u201cWell,\u201d I said, \u201cthere weren\u2019t any cars coming.\u201d\n\nHis expression turned to something resembling disgust, and he proceeded to write me a $2 ticket for jaywalking.", "title": "Crossing Against the Light", "authors": ["Alan Aspis", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "OurBus, which started in May 2016 with a route from Kendall Park, N.J., near Princeton, to Midtown, is one of a handful of tech companies aiming to ease commuter stress by crowdsourcing rides and then developing apps that offer the routes in demand. Using available vehicles from existing charter bus services, it currently offers two routes from New Jersey to Midtown, and has plans to start a third one from Monroe later this year.\n\nAnother New Jersey company, Boxcar, started offering a similar service in response to the repair work at Penn Station last summer. In Manhattan, Chariot, a San Francisco-based shuttle service, began operating commuter vans last summer. These services are, in a way, larger and more complicated versions of ride-hailing apps like Uber or Lyft.\n\nOnce a route has been established, riders purchase tickets through an app, guaranteeing them a seat \u2014 so no more standing in the aisle, squeezed against other passengers. Vehicles come equipped with Wi-Fi. OurBus and Boxcar buses have bathrooms onboard and charging outlets next to the seats. And riders using Chariot and OurBus can track the progress of their vehicles on their phones.\n\n\u201cIt seems so much more convenient for people to go to their phone and to be able to see when the bus is coming and then to be able to get on the bus and know that it\u2019s a new bus and somebody is taking care of it,\u201d said Dani Simons, a spokeswoman for the Regional Plan Association, a research and advocacy group for innovative approaches to transportation in the New York region. \u201cThat shouldn\u2019t be so crazy. Public transit shouldn\u2019t be miserable.\u201d\n\nImage The bus and van commuter services rely on apps that are similar to those of Uber or Lyft. Credit Bryan Anselm for The New York Times\n\nBut some transit advocates are skeptical. A poorly selected route or a half-empty vehicle could exacerbate congestion, said Jon Orcutt, the director of communications and advocacy at TransitCenter, a research organization. \u201cEventually they\u2019re going to get stuck in the same traffic as the taxis,\u201d he said. And while tech-savvy riders can swipe a request for a new route, neighborhoods with residents that are less tapped into social media and the latest apps might get overlooked, said Ms. Simons.", "title": "Crowdsourcing the Commute", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 The journalist who started France\u2019s equivalent of the #MeToo social media campaign against sexual harassment is being sued for defamation by the man she had accused of making salacious and disrespectful comments about her.\n\nSandra Muller, a French journalist working in New York, started the hashtag BalanceTonPorc, or ExposeYourPig, in October with a series of posts on Twitter that encouraged women to speak out against sexual harassment and that accused a former television executive of having made humiliating advances toward her.\n\nThe former executive, Eric Brion, has not denied the advances but argued that she was wrong to characterize them as sexual harassment.\n\nTens of thousands of women in France adopted Ms. Muller\u2019s hashtag to recount their own experiences, spurring a debate on gender relations and sexual norms. Most recently, a letter signed by the actress Catherine Deneuve and scores of other women to denounce the #MeToo and #BalanceTonPorc movements set off a strong backlash.", "title": "Crude, Yes, but Not Like Weinstein: French Man Sues MeToo Accuser", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo raised an average of more than $32,000 per day for the last six months, according to campaign finance reports, and has now amassed a $30.5 million campaign chest in 2018 that so far has helped him scare away serious rivals in his bid for a third term.\n\nMr. Cuomo received donations from an array of wealthy individuals and companies, from big Albany lobbying shops to real estate developers, from Hollywood moguls to the pharmaceutical industry. Many of the donors have business dealings with the state.\n\nNew York maintains caps on donations \u2014 $65,100 is the maximum Mr. Cuomo can receive from an individual \u2014 but the limits and rules are some of the loosest of any state with such restrictions.\n\nMr. Cuomo took full advantage. He collected $129,200 from the hedge fund manager Joseph DiMenna and his wife, $50,000 from the billionaire philanthropist Eli Broad, $25,000 from the Hollywood executive Jeffrey Katzenberg and his wife, and $30,000 from Barry Diller, the billionaire businessman. Last week, three limited liability companies linked to the address of Brookfield Properties gave Mr. Cuomo a total of $150,000. Andrew M. Cuomo directed the department to halt the program.\n\n\u201cConcerns have been raised by families of inmates regarding the availability and price of products under this program, concerns we do not take lightly,\u201d Thomas Mailey, a department spokesman, said in a statement, adding that the pilot program, which was introduced in three prisons, would be suspended until the concerns were addressed.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn the meantime, we will redouble our efforts on the other parts of our multifaceted plan to eliminate contraband and increase safety in our prison system.\u201d", "title": "Cuomo Halts a Controversial Prison Package Policy", "authors": ["Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "In an interview, Mr. Cuomo explained his logic for shifting to a payroll tax. \u201cYou want to attack the income tax structure?\u201d he said of the federal plan. \u201cFine. We\u2019ll restructure the tax code.\u201d\n\nOn Tuesday, the governor\u2019s anger at Mr. Trump and Republicans in Washington animated what is normally a dry presentation; it also gave him a political boogeyman to blame for budget woes \u2014 which should be useful in a year where he faces re-election.\n\n\u201cOne move, all of that progress, wiped away,\u201d the governor said of Mr. Trump\u2019s tax plan, his voice rising. \u201cWe have to have answers.\u201d\n\nThose answers seemingly could touch on everything from internet shopping to snack purchases at vending machines, whose operators would be encouraged to go cashless, making tax collection easier.\n\nOne new idea for revenue is a 2 cents-per-milligram surcharge for the active opioid ingredient in prescription drugs, a root cause of the heroin epidemic that has seized the state and nation. The governor is also proposing an \u201cinternet fairness conformity tax,\u201d a holdover idea that would require so-called \u201cmarketplace providers\u201d like Amazon.com to collect sales tax. (It failed to win approval last year.) He reiterated a call for the closure of the carried interest loophole, a federal tax that allows some hedge fund managers to pay a lower tax rate on revenue from investments.\n\nJohn J. Flanagan, the Republican leader of the Senate, praised elements of Mr. Cuomo\u2019s plan, including a 3 percent increase in education funding, the largest chunk of state spending. He did not seem enthusiastic about the payroll tax idea, calling it \u201cvery challenging,\u201d though he said he had several discussions with the governor about the issue.\n\nIn a small surprise, Mr. Cuomo also said that he would ask the Department of Health to study how New York would be affected by neighboring states like New Jersey and Massachusetts legalizing or moving toward the legalization of recreational marijuana. The stance seemed to be a shift for Mr. Cuomo, 60, who was slow to embrace medical marijuana in the state, though he signed a limited legalization of such use in 2014.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHaving been stung by bad news in the city\u2019s subways during 2017\u2019s so-called summer of hell, a phrase coined by the governor, Mr. Cuomo is proposing an \u201caction plan\u201d of $254 million for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. This would be money taken from financial settlements and the accelerated transfer of funds from a tiny payroll tax paid in the 12-county M.T.A. service area.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe proposed opioid tax would raise an estimated $127 million in the coming fiscal year, while another plan \u2014 adding a 14 percent surcharge on profits made by health insurance policies \u2014 could raise $140 million, according to administration estimates.\n\nThe state\u2019s budget bills that are slated to be approved by April 1, the start of the fiscal year, are often a vehicle for nonfiscal policy, and this year was no exception, with the actual budget bills packed with issues like same-day voter registration and bail reform. Mr. Cuomo used the speech as a platform to propose a range of changes to sexual harassment policies in the state in light of the #MeToo moment; he called it \u201ca national crisis,\u201d which was given new life in Albany last week when a powerful senator, Jeffrey D. Klein, was accused of forcibly kissing a staffer in 2015. (Mr. Klein was in the audience, and has denied the allegation.)\n\nThe addition of sexual harassment to the budget process may create an awkward optic: There are no women among the four men who are charged with negotiating the budget \u2014 Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Flanagan, Mr. Klein, and Carl E. Heastie, the speaker of the Assembly. For his part, however, Mr. Klein said on Tuesday that he expected to be vindicated. \u201cWe have to strengthen our sexual harassment laws,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd I intend to push to make that happen.\u201d\n\nEven before the speech ended, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s call for a payroll tax \u2014 and his heated assessment of the direness of the situation \u2014 was drawing criticism. E.J. McMahon, the founder of the Empire Center for Public Policy, a conservative economic think tank, said that the new $10,000 cap on the state and local deduction imposed by Washington \u201cwill not devastate\u201d the state.\n\n\u201cAnd @NYGovCuomo\u2019s continued insistence on hyping the impact strains credulity,\u201d Mr. McMahon said on Twitter.\n\nDetails on what a payroll tax would look like remained scant on Tuesday, with the governor and the state\u2019s top budget official promising more information on Wednesday. But they seemed to envision a two-tiered process by which businesses could opt in to a payroll tax alternative, rather than a wholesale replacement of the income tax. The government might first designate certain categories of businesses eligible for the swap, and then those businesses could choose whether or not to participate, said Robert Mujica, the director of budget.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll run two parallel systems,\u201d he said. \u201cIf there\u2019s a desire not to make any of these changes, then you wouldn\u2019t participate in the system.\u201d\n\nMr. Cuomo conceded that the tax plan would be complicated but he pleaded with legislators on both sides of the aisle to embrace his plan for the state\u2019s financial future.\n\n\u201cThis is not a political issue, this is green, my friends,\u201d Mr. Cuomo said, adding, \u201cThis is the fight of New York\u2019s future.\u201d", "title": "Cuomo Says Budget Will Defend New York Against Trump\u2019s \u2018Economic Missile\u2019", "authors": ["Jesse Mckinley", "Vivian Wang"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGov. Paterson and Eliot Spitzer, said that while independent streaks are a hallmark of most state executives, and in particular of New York governors, Mr. Cuomo struck him as more independent than his predecessors.\n\n\u201cWhen you\u2019re the governor, you don\u2019t really think you need help from anybody,\u201d Mr. Gilchrist said, adding that Mr. Cuomo\u2019s independent streak is \u201cpart what governors do, and part Governor Cuomo.\u201d\n\nThe collaboration on the promised lawsuit, which the governors said is likely to be filed in a few weeks, may have more political impact than legal. Alphonso David, the governor\u2019s chief counsel, conceded that the collective nature of the suit does not much advance its legal standing.\n\nThe three governors plan to argue that the federal tax law\u2019s cap on state and local deductions singles out Democratic states and tramples upon states\u2019 rights to self-governance. That argument could be made for New York or New Jersey or Connecticut alone just as well as for the three together.\n\nStill, the more states that sign on to the lawsuit, the stronger the argument that states are being negatively affected, Mr. David said.\n\nBecause residents in many Democratic states pay high amounts of state and local income taxes and property taxes, the cap on deductions for those payments can cause their federal tax bill to rise sharply.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Cuomo has been signaling for months that he planned to collaborate with other governors in fighting the tax law, convening a conference call in December with Mr. Murphy and Gov. Jerry Brown of California to denounce it.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd he has publicly joined with the leaders of other states before, for example in soliciting federal aid after Hurricane Sandy, or pledging to reduce greenhouse gas emissions after President Trump withdrew from the Paris climate agreement.\n\nBut his contact with other governors has traditionally occurred behind the scenes.\n\nAlthough Mr. Cuomo and Chris Christie, the former Republican governor of New Jersey, worked together publicly on some infrastructure projects, most notably the Gateway Tunnel, the two men did most of their negotiating in private, Mr. Christie said in an interview last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. In 2011, Mr. Cuomo\u2019s then-secretary, Steven M. Cohen, called Mr. Malloy\u2019s secretary to tell him that his office operated on \u201ctwo speeds\u201d: \u201cget along, and kill.\u201d (A spokesman for Mr. Malloy on Friday said the two men were \u201cclose colleagues\u201d who had developed a \u201cstrong working relationship over the years.\u201d)\n\nThere may yet be opportunities for skirmishes between Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Murphy. While the two men have maintained frequent communication since Mr. Murphy\u2019s election in November, mostly regarding the tax bill but also as part of a dwindling group of Democratic governors \u2014 only 15 in the country \u2014 Mr. Murphy falls to the left of Mr. Cuomo, a moderate, on several issues. Mr. Murphy is a staunch proponent of full legalization of marijuana, including for recreational use, an issue on which Mr. Cuomo has been more skittish.\n\nBoth observers and aides to Mr. Cuomo predicted that the governor would continue to partner with leaders in other states, not only against the tax law but on other topics like immigration reform or climate change.\n\nMr. David said greater collaboration was a natural response to a hostile, Republican-led federal government. Bruce N. Gyory, a Democratic political consultant, said it would amplify Mr. Cuomo\u2019s bully pulpit and increase his clout among other Democratic governors.\n\nEither way, Mr. Cuomo benefits.\n\n\u201cFor the governor to be associated with such an effort and being the center of gravity of this effort,\u201d Mr. Muzzio said, \u201cit\u2019s good policy, and then it is good politics.\u201d", "title": "Cuomo, Typically a Lone Wolf, Shifts Toward Coalition Building", "authors": ["Vivian Wang", "Nick Corasaniti"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Political momentum to abolish or limit the use of monetary bail has been building across the country in recent years, as critics have pointed out it discriminates against people who cannot pay. In New Jersey, a law went into effect last year that has nearly eliminated cash bail by mandating that state judges release most defendants unless they are a proven flight risk or threat to public safety.\n\nThe governor\u2019s proposals are likely to meet opposition from police unions, the bail bond industry, district attorneys and Republican lawmakers who control the Senate. The fate of the bills is far from clear in the legislative session and may depend on what incentives Mr. Cuomo can offer to the Republican opponents.\n\nTaken together, the proposed bills address several aspects of the criminal justice system critics have long decried as unfair to the poor, chief among them the state\u2019s cash bail system and its restrictive discovery law, which allows prosecutors to withhold important evidence against a defendant until the eve of trial.\n\nThese laws give a tremendous advantage to the police and prosecutors and, in effect, discriminate against defendants with few resources, who disproportionately are black or Hispanic, defense lawyers say. Impoverished people are often unable to pay the bail set by judges in their cases and spend months or years in jail, unable to help with their defenses, and without knowing the strength of the case against them, defense lawyers say. Many accept plea bargains just to end the ordeal.\n\nThe measure that Governor Cuomo is proposing would eliminate cash bail for people facing misdemeanor and nonviolent felonies. Instead defendants would be released, either on their own promise to return to court, or with some other conditions imposed by the judge.", "title": "Cuomo, in Bid to Help Poor, Proposes Ending Cash Bail for Minor Crimes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Cuomo resurrected the possibility of congestion pricing last summer, declaring that it \u201cis an idea whose time has come\u201d following decades of failed efforts to adopt some version of it. But as the state moves toward an actual plan, congestion pricing could potentially become a thorny issue for Mr. Cuomo, who faces re-election this year.\n\nCongestion pricing aims to reduce traffic in crowded areas at peak times by charging a fee to dissuade some drivers. The last major effort by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in 2008 sought to charge drivers a flat fee of $8 to enter a congestion zone from Midtown to Lower Manhattan. It died in Albany after state legislative leaders refused to bring it to a vote. Other plans have sought to place tolls on the free East River bridges.\n\nMayor Bill de Blasio has opposed congestion pricing, saying that it would hurt lower-income drivers. Instead, he has proposed a tax on the wealthy to support the subway system.\n\nMany residents and elected officials in Queens and Brooklyn have long resisted any new tolls or fees to drive into Manhattan, saying that it would hurt commuters who live in areas with limited bus and subway service.\n\nOn Tuesday, Assemblyman David I. Weprin, a Democrat who represents Queens and has been a steadfast opponent of congestion pricing, said he was pleased that Mr. Cuomo was not considering bridge tolls. But Mr. Weprin remained concerned about how the governor\u2019s plan would affect lower and middle-class commuters who drive into Manhattan because they do not have convenient access to public transportation. He suggested that such commuters should be exempted from a congestion fee, or somehow issued a credit. \u201cThe devil will be in the details,\u201d he said.\n\nSenate Republican Leader John Flanagan, who represents parts of Long Island, has also been seen as a possible hurdle. He has previously said he could not envision a form of congestion pricing that he could support.\n\nCarl E. Heastie, the Democratic Assembly speaker from the Bronx, demurred when asked his opinion on the yet-to-be-fleshed-out plan.\n\nIn recent years, a growing fleet of Uber and other cars working for ride-hailing apps has exacerbated congestion on city streets. Candidates for governor and lieutenant governor run independently in the primary in New York. One current exhibit is about medicine in World War I, and our main exhibit area includes more than 100 vintage and modern-day Band-Aid brand adhesive bandages tins and packages. It also includes rare surgical artifacts, large-scale vintage advertisements dating back to 1886 \u2014 the year the company was founded \u2014 and displays of some of the company\u2019s best-known products.\n\nAre there other duties?\n\nI also oversee the company\u2019s more than 19,000 artifacts, and decide on new acquisitions. I also maintain the company\u2019s online museum, ourstory.jnj.com, which uses photographs, music and audio to tell the company\u2019s story, and the company\u2019s historical blog, kilmerhouse.com. We also partner with other museums and institutions to make the company\u2019s history of innovative health care better known to the public.\n\nWhat is the most unusual aspect of your job?\n\nMy office is the company\u2019s biggest artifact, the Powerhouse, which is the oldest building on the company\u2019s world headquarters campus. The building was originally constructed to generate electrical power to run manufacturing machinery, and could generate enough power to light a small city.", "title": "Curating Band-Aids, Both Modern and Vintage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe decision by Laura Raicovich late last month to step down as head of the Queens Museum after clashing with her board has prompted directors, curators and staff members from other cultural institutions to publicly champion her political activism.\n\n\u201cArt institutions must respond to pressing issues facing our communities,\u201d the group said in an open letter dated Jan. 30. \u201cWe call on the boards of our cultural institutions to embrace the civic role of our institutions by supporting and empowering courageous and caring leaders such as Laura Raicovich.\u201d\n\nThe museum said in a prepared response: \u201cFreedom of expression and tolerance are longstanding tenets of the museum,\u201d adding that Ms. Raicovich\u2019s departure was unrelated to these principles.\n\nIn addition, Kristian Nammack, a trustee at the museum, on Thursday resigned from the board, citing his disappointment with its decision to allow an event by the Israeli government, which featured Vice President Mike Pence, to take place at the museum in November.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThe Museum Board is in dereliction of its duty of care to its main constituency, the wonderfully diverse people of Queens, in allowing such hateful and divisive purely political entities into our community space,\u201d Mr. Nammack said in his letter. \u201cI stand in solidarity with Laura Raicovich, who resigned her role as executive director earlier this week, for much the same reasons.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Lancman accused Ms. Raicovich of anti-Semitism and called for her removal. The museum started an investigation into its handling of the event, which was eventually reinstated. Mr. Lancman has questioned the museum\u2019s delay in releasing the results of its investigation (the museum said it is due out in the next two weeks). \u201cProgressives lose their way when we tolerate anti-Semitism, or cast Jews and the Jewish homeland as lesser identities,\u201d Mr. Lancman said in a statement on Monday. \u201cThat won\u2019t be tolerated in Queens.\u201d\n\nThe curators\u2019 letter, initiated by Carin Kuoni, the director and chief curator of the Vera List Center for Art and Politics at the New School, was signed by important art-world figures including Mary Ceruti, the executive director and chief curator of the SculptureCenter and Helen Molesworth, the chief curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles.", "title": "Curators Speak Out in Support of Departing Queens Museum Leader", "authors": ["Robin Pogrebin"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "It is one thing for outside scientists to call for the removal of Rebekah Mercer \u2014 a leading Trump donor who supports groups that deny climate science \u2014 from the American Museum of Natural History, as several did in a letter released on Thursday.\n\nNow tenured curators within the museum have also raised their voices in protest. In a letter dated Jan. 19 and addressed to Michael J. Novacek, the museum\u2019s senior vice president and provost of science, 28 curators expressed their \u201cprofound concern\u201d about Ms. Mercer\u2019s alliances with and donations to organizations that they say \u201cchallenge and politicize climate change science.\u201d\n\nThe messages of those groups, like the Heartland Institute in Illinois and the Heritage Foundation, the letter said, \u201cdirectly contradict the museum\u2019s mission and impede our ongoing efforts to educate the public about the science of past and future climate change.\u201d\n\nA spokeswoman for the museum, Ann Canty, said that the museum\u2019s president, Ellen V. The Curran Theater in San Francisco will host the production from April 10 to May 6 to start off the theater\u2019s first full season after being renovated.\n\nSet to the music of the Go-Go\u2019s, including hits like \u201cWe Got the Beat\u201d and \u201cVacation,\u201d \u201cHead Over Heels\u201d tells the story of a royal family trying to prevent an oracle\u2019s prediction from coming true. The show\u2019s producers plan to open on Broadway after that, but further details of the run have not been released. It had an initial production at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in 2015.\n\nA new play by David Henry Hwang, the author of the Tony-winning \u201cM. Butterfly,\u201d will follow \u201cHead Over Heels\u201d in the Curran\u2019s 2018 lineup, which was announced Wednesday. Featuring music by Jeanine Tesori, Mr. Hwang\u2019s \u201cSoft Power\u201d examines Chinese-American relations in the present and future. Leigh Silverman will direct the production, which is scheduled to run from June 20 to July 8 after a premiere in Los Angeles at the Center Theater Group in May.\n\nIn the fall, the performance artist Taylor Mac will bring the holiday version of his \u201cA 24-Decade History of Popular Music\u201d project to the Curran from Nov. 21 to Dec. 1. \u201cTaylor Mac\u2019s Holiday Sauce\u201d reimagines the music of the season to explore the conflicted feelings many have about that time of the year.", "title": "Curran in San Francisco Gets Go-Go\u2019s Musical Before Broadway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "TUESDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Occasional national news pages notwithstanding, The New York Times adheres to strict standards when it comes to profanity, and so I will admit that I broke into a mild sweat when I read David Steinberg\u2019s notes for his puzzle.\n\nI didn\u2019t have to worry. Mr. Steinberg\u2019s theme is most definitely family friendly, and very clever to boot.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMuch to the relief of my copy editors, it turns out that Mr. Steinberg\u2019s theme has nothing to do with cursing, despite the FOUR LETTER WORDS revealer that he has stretched across the center of his grid.\n\nThis is the kind of early week theme I really enjoy, because even though the solve is relatively easy, that \u201cAha!\u201d moment is still there. How long did it take you to catch on to the fact that the words Mr. Steinberg included in his theme set were made up of only four letters?", "title": "Curses, Foiled Again", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "In 2017, about $150 billion in green bonds were issued, about double the volume of 2016, according the Climate Bonds Initiative, a London nonprofit group. Still, the market remains minuscule, compared with, say, the roughly $1.5 trillion in United States corporate debt issued annually.\n\nBonds labeled \u201cgreen\u201d have existed for about a decade, said William D. Sokol, director of E.T.F. product management for VanEck. Fixed-income securities financed environmental projects before then but weren\u2019t often called green bonds (or, as they\u2019re also known, climate or sustainability bonds). That changed in 2014 with the creation of the Green Bond Principles by the International Capital Market Association in Zurich, Mr. Sokol said. The principles are voluntary guidelines. Coupled with increased concern about climate change, they have fostered this niche, he said.\n\nMr. Sokol\u2019s company sponsors the VanEck Vectors Green Bond E.T.F., an indexed offering. Built around the S.& P. Green Bond Select Index, it began in March and carries a net expense ratio of 0.4 percent. It invests worldwide in about 80 government, international and corporate securities. Mr. Sokol said he viewed the E.T.F. as helping diversify the holdings of United States investors. \u201cIt\u2019s the same investment case as for global bond investing \u2014 diversification with a multisector, multicountry portfolio.\u201d The greenness of the securities in the index \u2014 and thus the E.T.F. \u2014 is evaluated by the Climate Bonds Initiative.\n\nTwo actively managed mutual funds also devote themselves to this form of investment: the Mirova Global Green Bond Fund and the Calvert Green Bond Fund. The Mirova offering, managed by Mr. Wigley, started in the United States in February. It replicates a fund that Mirova, which is based in Paris, has offered in Europe since 2015. The United States version of the fund, sponsored by Natixis Investment Managers in Boston, invests in a variety of countries and types of issuers. It has a net expense ratio of 0.7 percent.\n\nAmong its recent top holdings were bonds of both the French government and Southern Power, a wholesale electricity generator that is a subsidiary of the Southern Company in Atlanta.\n\nFind Your Fund Explore Fund Results \u00bb See how the largest, leading and lagging funds compare. Search by Category \u00bb Find funds by their type, performance, risk or expenses. For more fund information, search morningstar.com.\n\nSouthern Power generates much of its electricity using natural gas, and its parent company operates nuclear power plants. Its bonds are barred from some funds that apply environmental screens to their holdings, including Ms. Palm\u2019s Parnassus Fixed Income Fund.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe exclude any company that generates significant revenue from nuclear,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Wigley said Southern Power is shifting toward renewable energy and wind power in particular with its green bonds helping that transition.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe see the climate transition as a critical phenomenon,\u201d he said. \u201cCompanies that don\u2019t adapt could become default risks. So we see those that issue green bonds as better financial risks and want to support that.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Calvert fund began in 2013. Its manager, Vishal O. Khanduja, said he buys bonds that are labeled green and unlabeled ones with clear environmental aims. Calvert, which factors environmental, social and governance factors into its investment decisions, has a team of analysts who investigate the green bona fides of bonds, he said. All the Calvert bond funds \u2014 there are 10 \u2014 must clear environmental thresholds, but the green fund \u201cfocuses even more on the environmental pillar,\u201d he said.\n\nInvestors seeking a cheaper, more seasoned fund than the Mirova or Calvert one might look outside the strict green-bond niche to funds that invest more broadly \u2014 but still according to environmental, social and governmental principles \u2014 like the one managed by Ms. Palm at Parnassus. Hers, with a net expense ratio of 0.68 percent, began in 1992, and she took over in 2013. Another such offering is the TIAA-CREF Social Choice Bond Fund, which has an expense ratio of 0.67 percent and started in 2012.\n\nThat fund\u2019s manager, Stephen M. Liberatore, a managing director at TIAA Investments, said he aims to identify the best environmental performers and projects, regardless of whether their bonds are labeled green. That approach led him to Topaz Solar Farms. \u201cTopaz wasn\u2019t labeled, but it\u2019s a commercial-scale solar power project,\u201d he said. \u201cIt was once the largest in the U.S. \u2014 it\u2019s producing enough power for about 160,000 homes.\u201d Topaz is owned by Berkshire Hathaway Energy, a subsidiary of Warren E. Buffett\u2019s investment holding company.\n\n\u201cWhat my investors want is for us to use our expertise to get as close as possible to an end project with an environmental benefit,\u201d Mr. Liberatore said.\n\nA claim often made by proponents of green bonds is that investing in them addresses climate change and other environmental problems more directly than buying green stocks does. Bond proceeds, this argument goes, finance specific projects with the potential for measurable gains. With an equity investment, in contrast, you just own shares in a company with a reputation for environmental stewardship. The company\u2019s management still has discretion over its investments.\n\nJon F. Hale, director of sustainability research for Morningstar, said he regarded that argument as credible. \u201cWhen you think about impact, dollar for dollar, you probably are having a bigger impact\u201d with a green bond fund than an environmentally minded stock fund, he said.\n\n\u201cThere are estimates out there of the trillions of dollars in investments needed in renewables and energy efficiency over the next 30 years, and that\u2019s what these kinds of bonds are financing,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Hale cautioned, however, that investors shouldn\u2019t abandon prudence for the sake of environmental purity. They should still stick to such investing tenets as keeping costs low, diversifying and allocating their money based on their goals and tolerance for risk.\n\n\u201cAs an investor, you should be allocated across asset classes,\u201d he said. \u201cBut you can activate your desire for sustainability with your bond investments, too.\u201d", "title": "Cutting Carbon Emissions While Earning Cash", "authors": ["Tim Gray"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "KABUL, Afghanistan \u2014 When Ashraf Ghani, a former academic and World Bank technocrat, took office as the president of Afghanistan in 2014, he promised to change the way the country was governed by putting a new generation of Afghans into leadership positions.\n\nThe long war with the Taliban was still raging. A disputed election had almost fractured the country. The treasury was drained. The state operated more as a patronage network for the elite than a government delivering to its people.\n\nBut Mr. Ghani still saw an opportunity. He wanted to take a country stuck in a hostile geopolitical vise and held together by fragile compromises and transform it into a regional hub for trade and transportation between Central Asia and South Asia.\n\nTo carry out this transformation, he would rely on a class of relatively young Afghans who since 2001 had gained better access to quality education, embraced new ideas from beyond their borders and appeared ready to buy into Mr. Ghani\u2019s vision. He promised to increase the number of government positions for women, who had struggled to find leadership jobs beyond the token ones.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThree years later, Mr. Ghani\u2019s coalition, including his partner in government Abdullah Abdullah, has largely kept with that promise, injecting educated young people into senior positions across the government.", "title": "Cutting Into Afghan Patronage: A Struggle to Make Government Younger", "authors": ["Mujib Mashal"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "The question on the table after the cutoff of military aid to Pakistan is who will come under the most pressure: the Pakistanis, or the coalition fighting the Taliban.\n\nMuhammed Umer Daudzai, a former Afghan interior minister and ambassador to Pakistan, said the pressure on Pakistan had come too late, with the country having developed regional allies who would help it weather the financial toll.\n\n\u201cThe financial sanctions may not bite Pakistan because they have developed alternatives,\u201d Mr. Daudzai said. \u201cThe only area the impact could be huge, but it\u2019s a bit too early to judge, is the field of air force. The Pakistani system is still hugely dependent on the U.S. It can take a long time to switch from that.\u201d\n\nPakistani officials expressed both anger and caution over the American move. Several indicated that cutting off ground supply routes to Afghanistan was actively being considered, but that a formal decision was not likely to be announced on Friday.\n\nThe commander of the Pakistani Air Force also seemed to suggest that Pakistan\u2019s airspace might be blocked to the Americans. In Islamabad on Thursday, Air Chief Marshal Sohail Aman said his force was \u201cfully prepared to defend all the aerial frontiers of the country.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Friday, the Foreign Ministry released a statement saying, \u201cWe are engaged with the U.S. administration on the issue of security cooperation and await further details.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe believe that Pakistan-U.S. cooperation in fighting terrorism has directly served U.S. national security interests as well as the larger interests of international community,\u201d the statement said. And in a measured criticism of Mr. Trump\u2019s move, it said that working for peace requires \u201cmutual respect and trust,\u201d adding that \u201carbitrary deadlines, unilateral pronouncements and shifting goal posts are counterproductive in addressing common threats.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAcross the Pakistani political spectrum, officials accused the United States of making Pakistan a scapegoat for the failures in Afghanistan.\n\nImran Khan, a prominent opposition politician whose positions on foreign and defense policy are often closely aligned with Pakistan\u2019s security establishment, called for steps to disengage diplomatically from the United States.\n\n\u201cWe must immediately remove excessive U.S. diplomatic, nondiplomatic and intelligence personnel from Pakistan so that diplomatic parity is established according to international legal norms governing diplomatic relations between states,\u201d he said in a statement, adding that the ground and air routes for American military supplies should also be shut down.\n\nIn past cases when relations frayed and Pakistan blocked American access to its supply routes, the United States military relied on a more expensive alternative that connects Baltic and Caspian ports through Russia and Central Asian countries. But that route is vulnerable to Washington\u2019s chilly relations with Russia, which has used its influence over Central Asian states to limit access.\n\nAt its peak, when the United States had about 100,000 troops in Afghanistan, the alternative route helped with the transportation of about one third of nonlethal material with Russia\u2019s consent. The American-led coalition also used Manas, a major air base in Kyrgyzstan, as the transit point for almost all of the coalition troops and a refueling center for tens of thousand aircraft.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nKyrgyzstan, apparently in response to Russian pressure and incentives, first increased the annual rent to $60 million from $17 million, and then the United States left the base in 2014.\n\nFrom the American and Afghan standpoints, trying to change Pakistan\u2019s outlook has only grown more difficult in recent years as the relative consensus has broken down among major players in the region \u2014 like Russia and Iran \u2014 over the American mission to eradicate international terrorist groups in Afghanistan.\n\nIn private, senior Afghan officials said they were watching just how focused the United States would be in maintaining the pressure on Pakistan, a nuclear state that has long managed to shrug off previous American and international pressure.\n\nMore publicly, however, President Ashraf Ghani and his government were measured in their reaction, staying away from directly addressing Mr. Trump\u2019s move to freeze what could amount to more than a billion dollars in American aid.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe welcome any decision that contributes to bringing stability in the region and Afghanistan,\u201d said Haroon Chakhansuri, a deputy chief of staff to Mr. Ghani. \u201cWe want honest partnership in the region to fight against a common enemy, terrorism.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSome Afghan officials and analysts feared that Mr. Trump\u2019s pressure on Pakistan might escalate the violence across Afghanistan before it brings any change in Pakistani cooperation. Already, officials are bracing for more urban bombing attacks in the winter months, when the regular fighting slows down a bit.\n\nAlso vulnerable are about two million Afghan refugees in Pakistan, who feel an increase in harassment in such periods of high political tension.\n\nAn important factor in whether the American pressure could result in a change of Pakistani attitude is whether American diplomacy can appeal to China and Russia\u2019s shared concerns of militant extremism in the region, and persuade them not to give Pakistan a release valve. Russia is concerned about the rise of an Islamic State affiliate in Afghanistan, most of whose fighters are from the tribal areas of Pakistan, while China fears that an unstable Afghanistan provides sanctuary to its Uighur insurgency.\n\n\u201cYou have an anti-American sentiment in the region on the one hand, but on the other hand you have the fear of terrorism and extremism in the region,\u201d said Davood Moradian, the director of the Afghan Institute for Strategic Studies in Kabul. \u201cIf the U.S. uses active diplomacy, it can convince the regional players to align with efforts to stabilize Afghanistan, because they will not compromise on their own national security for the sake of Pakistan.\u201d\n\nMr. Moradian said factors that make Pakistan a military power, such as hardware and training, are oriented toward the United States, with China less able to easily fulfill them. And he described the Pakistani elite as more integrated in the West \u2014 with houses, business, and bank accounts there \u2014 and thus more likely to feel the pressure of targeted sanctions.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think Pakistan will be able to absorb sustained U.S. pressures,\u201d Mr. Moradian said. \u201cIn the Pakistan-American dynamics, Pakistan is far more vulnerable.\u201d\n\nHe continued: \u201cPakistan\u2019s success has been in absorbing pain for a short period, and then getting away. Washington has not been able to bear pain for a limited period of time in the hopes of longer success.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBefore the Trump announcement on freezing aid to Pakistan, senior Pakistani officials had shrugged off the threats. One official said every threat from Washington was pushing Pakistan closer to China. The two countries have a partnership to develop up to $60 billion in infrastructure in Pakistan under the \u201cOne Belt, One Road\u201d program, and have tightened their military ties.\n\nKhawaja Muhammad Asif, Pakistan\u2019s foreign minister, recently urged a revisiting of ties with the United States, which he called neither a friend nor an ally.\n\n\u201cThe world is vast enough,\u201d he said, \u201cand the U.S. is not feeding us.\u201d", "title": "Cutting Off Pakistan, U.S. Takes Gamble in Complex Afghan War", "authors": ["Mujib Mashal", "Salman Masood"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "When the javelin-throwing competition began at the Summer Olympics in Helsinki on July 23, 1952, few in the crowd of nearly 70,000 expected a medal for the American Cy Young, who turned 24 that day.\n\nYoung \u2014 a 6-foot-5 farmer unrelated to the Hall of Fame pitcher of the same name \u2014 was one of three Americans challenging Finland\u2019s domination of the event. Four of the previous five men\u2019s Olympic champions had been from Finland, and Finns had swept all the javelin medals at the 1932 Summer Games in Los Angeles.\n\nWith his second throw in the finals of 73.78 meters, or just over 242 feet, Young took the lead. Four rounds followed, including one in which Young fouled, but that did not matter. He was the new Olympic champion, bettering the Olympic record set in 1932 by Finland\u2019s Matti Jarvinen, who had set 12 world records over six years.\n\nOne of Young\u2019s countrymen, Bill Miller, won the silver medal, and a Finn, Toivo Hyytiainen, won the bronze.", "title": "Cy Young, Only American to Win Gold in Javelin, Is Dead at 89", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Last week, we learned that researchers had discovered two major flaws in microprocessors of nearly all the world\u2019s computers. The revelation came on the heels of a distressing series of major hacks: In 2017, Yahoo revealed that all of its three billion accounts were compromised, WannaCry ransomware shut down hospitals across the globe, and an Equifax breach affected approximately 145.5 million consumers in the United States. The latest news about the computer security problems \u2014 whose names, \u201cSpectre\u201d and \u201cMeltdown,\u201d appropriately convey their seriousness \u2014 is just the latest evidence that true digital security remains out of our reach.\n\nBut when these vulnerabilities are exposed and damaging attacks occur, there are few lasting repercussions. Almost without fail, stock prices bounce back, customers return, executives keep their jobs or exit with golden parachutes, and government mostly looks the other way. After the news of Equifax\u2019s massive breach, for example, the company\u2019s stock dropped roughly 35 percent. But it\u2019s already recovered nearly half of its lost market value, and Fortune reported that the former chief executive officer Richard Smith retired with as much as $90 million in compensation. Resilience is one of the hallmarks of stable, mature markets, but something isn\u2019t right here.\n\nThe tepid consequences are part of a growing problem. From a corporate governance and accountability perspective, cybersecurity today is being treated like accounting was before the fallout from the Enron scandal inspired the Sarbanes-Oxley Act\u2019s increased standards for corporate disclosures. With the privacy and personal data of hundreds of millions of people at risk, and especially now with the increasing ubiquity of connected devices in our lives, the security of digital assets is too important for that kind of treatment. We need to bolster a culture of responsibility around cybersecurity, combining stronger and more uniform corporate governance with a clearer government commitment to enact better defensive policies.\n\nA complex hack may not be a C.E.O.\u2019s fault, but it is absolutely his or her responsibility. Investors and consumers need to demand more from the executives to whom they entrust their digital lives. The same holds true for government. Protection of the welfare and livelihood of its citizens is a foundational principle of government, and yet for more than a decade there has been very little consequence for nation-states and state-affiliated groups who\u2019ve pilfered the intellectual property, and violated the personal privacy, of citizens and companies around the world.", "title": "Opinion | Cybersecurity Today Is Treated Like Accounting Before Enron", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "PRAGUE \u2014 President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic failed to win re-election in the first round of a presidential vote on Saturday and will face a runoff in two weeks against the former president of the country\u2019s Academy of Sciences.\n\nMr. Zeman and the runner-up in the first round, Jiri Drahos, advanced to a second round of voting because none of the nine candidates seeking the country\u2019s largely ceremonial presidency received a majority of votes in the initial round, held on Friday and Saturday.\n\nWith almost all the ballots counted by the Czech Statistics Office, Mr. Zeman had 38.6 percent of the vote compared with 26.6 for Mr. Drahos.\n\nPavel Fischer, a former diplomat, was a distant third with 10.2 percent. Michal Horacek, a songwriter, finished fourth with 9.2 percent, ahead of Marek Hilser, a doctor, who had 8.8 percent. The three pledged their support to Mr. Drahos in the runoff.", "title": "Czech President Faces a Runoff After First Round of Voting", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "PRAGUE \u2014 The Czech Parliament rejected the minority government of Prime Minister Andrej Babis in a no-confidence vote on Tuesday, a move that is likely to prompt weeks, if not months, of further political wrangling.\n\nIn the meantime, the minority cabinet, made up of members of Mr. Babis\u2019s party and affiliated experts, will continue to lead the country while Mr. Babis attempts to form another cabinet that would be acceptable to Parliament.\n\nIn Eastern Europe, resentment of Brussels and resistance to immigration have helped propel populist parties to power in several countries, notably Hungary and Poland. But the rise of the right there, in the Czech Republic and in Slovakia has also been driven by a variety of domestic issues.\n\nMr. Babis, a billionaire anti-establishment candidate who vowed during the campaign to fight corruption and introduce economic overhauls, is a polarizing figure. His political positions are hard to pin down, but they are tinged with populist rhetoric.", "title": "Czech Republic Faces Political Turmoil After No-Confidence Vote", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cFor all the talk of Russian meddling \u2014 and I believe they have meddled beyond a shadow of a doubt,\u201d he added, \u201cEurope is dividing itself, and they do not have to do much.\u201d\n\nOutside observers cited as an example of Russian interference a pernicious social media campaign against Mr. Drahos that accused him, with no evidence, of being a collaborator of the secret police during Communist rule.\n\nBut Mr. Koran noted that Mr. Zeman\u2019s success was most likely fueled by deep divisions in Czech society and the president\u2019s ability to tap into the anxiety of many Czechs who live outside prosperous cities.\n\nMr. Zeman, speaking to supporters at a hotel on the outskirts of Prague, said this would be his last campaign, vowing to abide by the constitutional term limits. He acknowledged how tight the race was, describing how his advisers had huddled nervously waiting for the numbers from Prague.\n\nIn the end, he was propelled to victory by a high turnout in the countryside. Over all, turnout was more than 66 percent.\n\n\u201cFive years ago, 2.7 million voters gave me their trust,\u201d he said. \u201cThis time, it was 2.8 million.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Zeman\u2019s victory will most likely be viewed with concern by the country\u2019s traditional allies like France and Germany, as well as leaders who are looking for greater integration among the European Union\u2019s member nations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey will continue to have to deal with an unpredictable, grumpy populist; with an oligarch prime minister; and the support of the communists\u201d in the Czech Republic, Mr. Koran said.\n\nEliska Haskova Coolidge, a Zeman supporter and influential public figure, said that many fears of those in the West were overblown. She said she thought that Mr. Zeman\u2019s goal was a healthy relationship with Russia, not a subservient one.\n\nMs. Coolidge, whose family fled the country after World War II, spent two decades working in Washington before returning home. She said she was no fan of Mr. Zeman\u2019s vulgarity, but was willing to overlook some of his flaws because she admired the depth of his experience.\n\n\u201cIt is so important to have a leader who understands politics and who has met with world leaders,\u201d she said.\n\nIn the end, Czech voters agreed.\n\nMr. Drahos conceded the race and congratulated Mr. Zeman. \u201cThis is not the end,\u201d Mr. Drahos told supporters gathered in Prague. \u201cWe will carry on.\u201d\n\nHe then led members of the crowd, some in tears, in a solemn rendition of the national anthem.\n\nMr. Zeman\u2019s re-election was also a victory for the country\u2019s billionaire prime minister, Andrej Babis, who was appointed by Mr. Zeman and supported his campaign. The president has vowed to stick with him even though Mr. Babis is facing criminal fraud charges. After his victory, Mr. Zeman again promised to give Mr. Babis all the time he needed to form a government.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe election was not only a contest of competing visions for the country\u2019s place in Europe and the world, but also a clash between two candidates with decidedly different styles.\n\nProudly antediluvian, with an admitted fondness for drinking and smoking, the acerbic Mr. Zeman has been criticized as contributing to the coarseness of the current political climate. His impolitic remarks \u2014 like jokes about \u201cliquidating\u201d journalists \u2014 have earned him comparisons to President Trump.\n\nMr. Drahos, the former leader of the Czech Academy of Sciences, has never held political office, and his inexperience was evident in the first of two debates. Looking nervous, he sat on the edge of his seat, while Mr. Zeman reclined and looked as if he were in his own living room, drink in hand.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the second debate, Mr. Drahos was more confident and more direct in his attacks on the president.\n\n\u201cMr. Zeman is the past,\u201d he said. \u201cHe is now a symbol of division and name-calling.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor many of Mr. Zeman\u2019s supporters, however, his indecency is his strength, and they say his blunt speech is needed to counteract cowardly political blather.\n\nMr. Zeman was elected in 2013 in the first direct presidential vote held in the Czech Republic after it broke free from Soviet rule in 1989. Although he has a long history in politics and had served as prime minister, he cast himself as a populist savior working for the common man.\n\n\u201cYou are not alone anymore,\u201d was the Zeman slogan plastered on billboards and echoed in meeting after meeting in small towns and villages. His victory then was seen by many as a rebuke of the right-of-center political establishment that had grown smug and out of touch.\n\nBut as the migrant crisis in Europe blossomed in 2014, and countries confronted the greatest flood of humanity seeking refuge on the continent since the end of the Second World War, Mr. Zeman was one of the first European politicians to seize on the issue.\n\nHe sought to seal off the country and defied efforts by the European Union to force member nations to share the burden equally by taking in migrants through a quota system.\n\nMr. Zeman said Muslims could never be integrated in Czech society and warned of jihadists who could \u201cblow the Prague castle up in the air,\u201d tapping into an anxiety felt deeply throughout the country and the region. The message would soon be championed by a host of populist leaders, including those in neighboring countries.\n\nBut this Czech election campaign was notable for the lack of debate on immigration. The Zeman position was the default position. Still, Mr. Zeman sought to portray Mr. Drahos as a danger to society. \u201cStop migrants and Drahos,\u201d read an ad in newspapers and on billboards. \u201cThis country is ours. Vote for Zeman.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Drahos returned fire by attacking a top Zeman adviser, Martin Nejedly, who is known for his close ties to Russia. \u201cStop Russian Invasion and Nejedly,\u201d the Drahos team wrote in a social media campaign. \u201cThis country is not yours. Vote for Drahos.\u201d\n\nThe question of whether the Czech Republic will continue to look to China and Russia was a critical issue in the last days of the campaign. While Mr. Zeman has often said he is committed to the European Union and NATO, he said during his victory speech that he would continue to support allowing Czechs to decide their own futures, including a referendum on membership in the bloc.\n\n\u201cI have come to the conclusion that many politicians and journalists have inferior intelligence compared to normal people,\u201d Mr. Zeman said. \u201cAnd, therefore, I want those normal citizens to have a chance to decide not only in a referendum, but also in direct elections for local government.\u201d\n\nHe also said he would try to be less \u201carrogant,\u201d but he used his speech to go over old grievances, including against Czech journalists who had repeatedly written him off.\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s another reason why I consider Czech journalists to be idiots,\u201d he said.", "title": "Czech Republic Re-elects Milos Zeman, Populist Leader and Foe of Migrants", "authors": ["Marc Santora"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Later that day, Judge William Alsup of Federal District Court in San Francisco handed down his ruling, writing that the administration must \u201cmaintain the DACA program on a nationwide basis\u201d as the legal challenge to the president\u2019s decision goes forward.\n\nIn his ruling, Judge Alsup laid out a road map for the government that officials appeared to follow. He said that previous beneficiaries of DACA, known as Dreamers, must be allowed to renew their status in the program, though the government would not be required to accept new applications from immigrants who had not previously submitted one.\n\nOn Sunday morning, Mr. Trump blamed Democrats for preventing progress on a legislative deal that would permanently legalize the young immigrants and give them an eventual path to citizenship in exchange for tougher border security and enforcement measures.\n\nThe president criticized Democratic lawmakers, some of whom have suggested that they will not support efforts to fund the government by a deadline later this week unless Congress passes the DACA legislation.\n\n\u201cDACA is probably dead because the Democrats don\u2019t really want it, they just want to talk and take desperately needed money away from our Military,\u201d Mr. Trump said on Twitter from his Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla.\n\nIn a second tweet, Mr. Trump said that immigration legislation should include an end to the diversity visa lottery system, in which the State Department encourages diversity in immigration by holding a lottery for those wanting to come to the United States.\n\nThe president has criticized the program as a threat to the country\u2019s security even though people selected are screened in the same ways that other immigrants are. Mr. Trump has also said that the program undermines efforts by the administration to allow immigrants who have skills that will be beneficial to the United States.\n\n\u201cI, as President, want people coming into our Country who are going to help us become strong and great again, people coming in through a system based on MERIT,\u201d he said. \u201cNo more Lotteries! #AMERICA FIRST.\u201d", "title": "DACA Participants Can Again Apply for Renewal, Immigration Agency Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 Two other challenges on gerrymandering are already before the Supreme Court. He had lost the support of one of the populist website\u2019s major investors, Rebekah Mercer.\n\n\u2022 Mr. Bannon was described by associates and friends as unable or unwilling to grasp the severity of his falling out with the White House and its potential effect on the Breitbart business.\n\nVideo\n\nA motive that isn\u2019t a gold medal\n\n\u2022 North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un, spent last year rattling the world with nuclear and missile tests.\n\nSo his announcement this week that the North would send a team to the Winter Games in South Korea next month has been welcomed in Seoul, even if few believe it was driven solely by the Olympic spirit.\n\n\u2022 President Moon Jae-in of South Korea warned today that Pyongyang would face stiffer sanctions if it resumed weapons tests.
