The foreign policy adviser to the Trump campaign drew the attention of the F.B.I. But he differs greatly from other figures in the Trump-Russia story. Audio\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 The Trump administration dropped Florida from its offshore drilling plan, after opposition from the state\u2019s Republican governor.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSeparately, we looked at how the administration has fulfilled the wish list of a major coal executive.\n\n\u2022 President Trump plans to attend the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, Switzerland, this month, an elite gathering of world leaders and business executives.\n\n\u2022 Toyota and Mazda are said to have picked Alabama for a $1.6 billion plant they plan to build.\n\n\u2022 AT&T canceled a deal to sell Huawei\u2019s new smartphone, the Mate 10, after U.S. lawmakers expressed misgivings about Huawei\u2019s ties to the Chinese government.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were up on Tuesday. Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets today.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\n\u2022 How to win at winter when you hate winter.\n\n\u2022 That game on your phone may be tracking your TV-watching habits.\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Use our basic template to make soup with whatever you want.\n\nNoteworthy\n\n\u2022 Interview with dossier firm is released\n\nSenator Dianne Feinstein of California, a Democrat, made public a transcript of the Judiciary Committee\u2019s interview with a founder of Fusion GPS, the firm that wrote a salacious report on Russian efforts to aid the Trump campaign.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRead Glenn Simpson\u2019s congressional testimony here.\n\n\u2022 The importance of preschool\n\nMany preschool teachers live on the edge of financial ruin.\n\nWould improving their training \u2014 and their pay \u2014 improve outcomes for their students? The Times Magazine investigates.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 #MeToo? No thanks, some women say\n\nThe actress Catherine Deneuve joined more than 100 other women in denouncing the movement and its French counterpart, saying the efforts had gone too far and created a totalitarian climate.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Carnivores wanted\n\nThe restaurateur Angie Mar has turned the Beatrice Inn in the West Village into a magnet for awards by following her culinary North Star: meat, in all its glory.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nTalking to Stephen Colbert, the actor James Franco denied accusations of sexual impropriety that surfaced after the Golden Globes ceremony on Sunday.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be chaos. He gave them 19 years of work, and how do they repay him? They tell him, \u2018Get out of here.\u2019 \u201d\n\n\u2014 Bertila Parada, who sent her son to the U.S. from El Salvador nearly two decades ago under a program that President Trump has now canceled.\n\nBack Story\n\nNinety years ago this month, Leon Trotsky, one of the early leaders of the Communist Party, was exiled by Joseph Stalin to what is now Kazakhstan, clearing the way for Stalin\u2019s complete control of the Soviet Union.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTrotsky, an ever-wandering revolutionary, was no stranger to exile.\n\nPhoto\n\nMore than a decade before, in January 1917, The Times noted his arrival in New York City: a \u201cRussian journalist and Socialist\u201d who had been \u201cexpelled from four lands.\u201d\n\nTrotsky and his family lived only briefly in New York \u2014 what he called \u201cthe city of prose and fantasy, of capitalist automatism, its streets a triumph of Cubism\u201d \u2014 before he returned to Russia to help lead the Bolshevik Revolution.\n\nAfter the death of Vladimir Lenin in 1924, Stalin and his faction propounded \u201csocialism in one country.\u201d Trotskyists bristled, calling for a \u201cpermanent revolution,\u201d global in scope, and accused Stalin of betraying Lenin\u2019s vision.\n\nThe feud between Stalin and Trotsky would culminate in the anti-Trotskyist show trials in Moscow and the terrifying purges of the 1930s. It ended in Mexico City, where Trotsky settled, when he was killed by an assassin wielding an ice ax in 1940.\n\nPenn Bullock contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. When President Franklin Roosevelt decided on a different location, the shape stayed, but the sides were made even.\n\nThe first architectural reviews were not glowing, but they improved over time.\n\n\u201cCalled too big, too barren and too expensive when it was completed for $83 million in 1943, the Pentagon is a thriving, functional success in 1968,\u201d The Times wrote for the 25th anniversary of the building, which it extolled as a place of community:\n\n\u201cEveryman, or Littleman, triumphed over all. Thousands of secretaries and office workers have turned the Pentagon into a cluttered, cosy, home-away-from-home.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSarah Anderson contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. Some of the ability to do these tests didn\u2019t exist years ago.\u201d\n\nWith the mystery presumptively solved, the outcome offers no real practical resolution: The attack, on April 26, 1994, occurred more than a decade before New York State law was changed, in 2006, to eliminate the statute of limitations in rape cases.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe hope that this knowledge brings a measure of closure to the victim and some comfort in knowing that this individual is behind bars, will remain there and won\u2019t harm anyone else,\u201d Oren Yaniv, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney\u2019s office, said in a statement. \u201cUnfortunately, we are bound by the statute of limitations, which expired well over a decade ago, making criminal charges legally impossible.\u201d\n\nMartin Garbus, the lawyer for the victim, wrote a scathing Op-Ed piece in The New York Times in 2013 after seeing \u201cLucky Guy,\u201d the Broadway show that lionized Mr. McAlary. He said on Tuesday that \u201cthe trauma from the news stories was nearly as great as the trauma from the rape; she had to live with those stories for 23 years.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe detective said it was my piece, in The Times, on the play, that led him to begin to think about reopening the case,\u201d Mr. Garbus said, adding that no one has yet apologized to the woman.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Garbus conceded there was very little officials could do now, legally. He said the woman, who is now 51 and married with two children, \u201cfeels relieved\u201d about the police breakthrough in her case, but was declining to speak about the matter. Mr. Garbus would not say what she does for a living, though she was pursuing an acting career at the time of the attack. He said that she now lives \u201cin the metropolitan area.\u201d\n\n\u201cShe was called a liar,\u201d Mr. Garbus said. \u201cSo she feels good about her vindication. She doesn\u2019t have to walk along the streets any longer and fear that someone is going to call her a liar. But what happened to her is terrible.\u201d\n\nMr. McAlary, a dominant tabloid reporter, went on to write a series of columns in The Daily News on the brutalization of Abner Louima by officers in Brooklyn, which earned him a Pulitzer Prize for commentary in 1998, months before he died at age 41. A libel suit that Mr. Garbus had brought against him on behalf of the woman was dismissed in 1997 after a judge ruled that Mr. McAlary was entitled to First Amendment protections to write about what the police had told him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Webb has a long criminal history: He was arrested for at least 10 sex offenses from 1968 to 1995, the police said. In 1995, he was charged with raping four women and attempting to rape a fifth, according to law enforcement officials and court records. He was convicted in October 1997 in connection with all five cases, and sentenced in December 1997 to 75 years to life in prison.\n\nMr. Davis, the police spokesman, said it was important to close the Prospect Park rape case, even with an expired statute of limitations.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an open case,\u201d Mr. Davis said. \u201cWe want closure on it. We want to try to do everything we can to show that we are going to fully investigate these things as thoroughly as we can.\u201d", "title": "DNA Helps New York Police Solve Infamous 1994 Rape Case", "authors": ["Al Baker", "Alan Feuer"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Dan Gurney, whose storied career as a racecar driver included numerous firsts, and who went on to become equally successful as a team owner and car builder, died on Sunday in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 86.\n\nThe cause was complications of pneumonia, his company, All American Racers, said in a statement.\n\nWhen Gurney began driving, only a few Americans competed in the worldwide Grand Prix races in Formula One roadsters. He became one of the most successful.\n\nIn 1959, he started driving Grand Prix cars for the Ferrari factory of Italy for $130 a week plus half of his prize and starting money. He earned $7,500 that year. By 1970, when he retired after 15 years of racing, he had won Grand Prix races in France, Mexico and Belgium.", "title": "Dan Gurney, Driver and Builder of Racecars, Is Dead at 86", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances.\n\nSHANGHAI DANCE THEATER at the David H. Koch Theater (Jan. 5 and 6 at 8 p.m., Jan. 7 at 1 p.m.). From the 19th century to the 1980s, the population of the crested ibis, a rose-hued bird found throughout Asia, dwindled from tens of thousands to single digits. The plight of the \u201cbird of good fortune,\u201d as it\u2019s called, is the subject of \u201cSoaring Wings,\u201d a dance-drama from Shanghai Dance Theater. The bird\u2019s fluid grace and quirky flickers are captured in modern choreography by Tong Ruirui, who also directed the production, to a score by Guo Sida drawing from classical Chinese music. The work makes a case for environmental protection and for renewing the bond between humans and nature.\n\n212-496-0600, davidhkochtheater.com\n\nAMERICAN DANCE PLATFORM at the Joyce Theater (Jan. 9-14 at various times). This showcase of domestic dance arrives at the Joyce with four pairings of stylistically and geographically diverse troupes from around the country. On Jan. 9 and 14 (evening), the innovative choreographer Caleb Teicher \u2014 also a stellar tap performer \u2014 shares a program with the dynamic Los Angeles-based contemporary dance company BODYTRAFFIC. On Jan. 10 and 14 (matinee), New York\u2019s Jessica Lang Dance splits the bill with Backhausdance from California\u2019s Orange County, both examples of polished virtuosity. On Jan. 11 and Jan. 13, the veteran modern dance company PHILADANCO!, hailing from Philadelphia, meets Halau O Kekuhi, hailing from Hawaii and noted for its explosive style of hula inspired by legends about the volcanoes.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org", "title": "Dance in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances.\n\nKADER ATTOU \u2014 COMPAGNIE ACCRORAP at the Joyce Theater (Jan. 23-28 at various times). For its Joyce debut, this French company brings \u201cThe Roots,\u201d a 2013 work by its director, Kader Attou, that expands the possibilities of theatrical hip-hop by melding it with contemporary dance, Indian kathak dance and circus arts. Eleven men, clad in casual office-wear, perform within a simple set that resembles a living room as snippets of Beethoven and electronica (among other music) plays. The polished corporate look and domestic scene soon succumb to a thrilling onslaught of tricks, tumbles, spins and synchronized gestures.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nDEAN MOSS/GAMETOPHYTE INC. at Performance Space New York (Jan 23-27 at 7:30 p.m.). Taking inspiration (and its name) from Rainer Fassbinder\u2019s 1972 all-female film \u201cThe Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant,\u201d choreographer and media artist Dean Moss introduces \u201cPetra,\u201d a new work that is part of the 2018 COIL Festival. The work, which features an all-woman, immigrant cast, also looks to a Hindu goddess associated with self-sacrifice to address the tension between ambition and dispossession and to critique the concept of \u201cdiversity management.\u201d\n\n212-352-3101, performancespacenewyork.org", "title": "Dance in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to dance performances.\n\nAMERICAN DANCE PLATFORM at the Joyce Theater (Jan. 12 at 8 p.m.; Jan. 13 at 2 p.m. and 8 p.m.; Jan. 14 at 2 p.m. and 7:30 p.m.). This festival, programmed by Christine Tschida, the director of Northrop at the University of Minnesota, wraps up this weekend with programs featuring shared performances. The newest pairing explores rhythm and showcases Ensemble Espa\u00f1ol Spanish Theater, which performs flamenco and folkloric dance, and Trinity Irish Dance Company. Other programs offer classic modern dance by Philadanco! alongside hula by Halau O Kekuhi; Jessica Lang Dance with, in its Joyce debut, Backhausdance; and BODYTRAFFIC with the tap ensemble Caleb Teicher and Company.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nAMERICAN REALNESS 2018 at various locations (through Jan. 16). This jam-packed festival shines a spotlight on innovative dance and performance. Highlights include the Jan. 12 premiere of Michael Portnoy\u2019s \u201cRelational Stalinism \u2014 the Musical,\u201d which was born from, as press notes state, \u201cdancers in museums moaning and leaning against walls, pestering visitors with boilerplate philosophical questions and busting their kneecaps on punishing concrete floors.\u201d (Well put.) Also opening this weekend are \u201cEverything Fits In the Room,\u201d by Simone Aughterlony and Jen Rosenblit, with Miguel Gutierrez and Colin Self on sound, and \u201c(do not) despair solo,\u201d a performance-lecture by Marissa Perel that explores choreography, disability, queerness and intimacy.\n\n646-837-6809, americanrealness.com\n\nASTANA BALLET THEATER at Alice Tully Hall (Jan. 17). This company hails from the Republic of Kazakhstan and presents a free program: \u201cKazakhstan Astana Ballet Gala.\u201d Along with \u201cHeritage of the Great Steppe,\u201d a work made up of sections from traditional ballets, the engagement showcases two works by Ricardo Amarante. \u201cLove Fear Loss\u201d is choreographed to the songs of Edith Piaf and inspired by her life, while \u201cA Fuego Lento\u201d takes a look at first love.\n\n212-707-8566, lincolncenter.org", "title": "Dance in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to dance performances.\n\nCAMILLE A. BROWN & DANCERS at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University (Feb. 1-2, 7:30 p.m.; Feb. 3, 8 p.m.; Feb. 4, 3 p.m.). Peak Performances hosts Camille A. Brown\u2019s \u201cink,\u201d the final dance in a trilogy of works investigating culture, race and identity. After looking at the stereotypes that black men face in \u201cMr. TOL E. RAncE\u201d and childhood games in \u201cBLACK GIRL: Linguistic Play,\u201d Ms. Brown points her choreographic lens on rituals, gestural vocabulary and traditions of the African diaspora with an aim of reclaiming \u201cthe narratives of African-Americans through self-empowerment, black love, brotherhood, exhaustion and resilience, community and fellowship.\u201d\n\n973-655-5112, peakperfs.org\n\nCOMPAGNIE HERV\u00c9 KOUBI at the Joyce Theater (Jan. 30-31, 7:30 p.m.; Feb. 1-3, 8 p.m.; Feb. 4, 2 p.m.). The French company unveils the highly physical \u201cWhat the Day Owes to the Night,\u201d a work for 12 French-Algerian and African dancers. Choreographed by Mr. Koubi, it is inspired by his father\u2019s revelation that his family hailed not from France, but from Algeria. They learned the news at his deathbed. The resulting production, which features capoeira, martial arts and contemporary dance, is Mr. Koubi\u2019s energetic exploration of his roots.\n\n212-242-0800, joyce.org\n\nJULIUS EASTMAN AND DANCE: MOLISSA FENLEY, ANDY DE GROAT, AND MORE at the Kitchen (Jan 30, 8 p.m.) In honor of the Minimalist musician and composer Julius Eastman, the Kitchen hosts \u201cJulius Eastman: That Which Is Fundamental,\u201d a series of performances and a two-part exhibition. This evening focuses on his work in dance; the highlight is a reprisal of Molissa Fenley\u2019s \u201cGeologic Moments\u201d (1986), a slowly building dance for six that was developed with the composer. In the program, Eastman\u2019s work as a choreographer is also depicted in formerly unseen video. An influential composer during the 1970s and 1980s, he died in 1990 at 49.\n\n212-255-5793 ext. 11; thekitchen.org\n\nLUMBERYARD IN THE CITY WINTER FESTIVAL at New York Live Arts (Through Feb. 10). After Kei Takei/Moving Earth Orient Sphere wraps up performances on Jan. 27, the playwright and performance artist Robbie McCauley presents the New York premiere of \u201cSugar\u201d (Feb. 1-3) as part of this festival that pays homage to established female dance and performance artists. In \u201cSugar,\u201d a solo show directed by Maureen Shea, Ms. McCauley performs an autobiographical solo focusing on her battle with diabetes and explores how food relates to issues of race. The festival continues with the choreographer, dancer and visual artist Dana Reitz (Feb. 8-10).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n855-459-3849, lumberyard.org\n\nNEW YORK CITY BALLET at the David H. Koch Theater (through March 4). The winter season continues with \u201cdance odyssey,\u201d a new work by the corps de ballet member Peter Walker featuring a principal cast of Ashley Laracey, Tiler Peck, Adrian Danchig-Waring, Zachary Catazaro, Anthony Huxley and Devin Alberda. As part of the company\u2019s New Combinations Evening on Feb. 1, it marks Mr. Walker\u2019s second work for City Ballet and is set to an arrangement of selections from several of the British composer Oliver Davis\u2019s works. That same evening is capped by Alexei Ratmansky\u2019s singular \u201cRussian Seasons\u201d and, in it, debuts for Maria Kowroski, Kristen Segin, Cameron Dieck and Troy Schumacher.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n212-496-0600, nycballet.com\n\nMINA NISHIMURA at Danspace Project (Feb. 1-3, 8 p.m.) The Japanese choreographer and dancer presents the premiere of \u201cBladder Inn (and X, Y, Z, W),\u201d named in honor of Ms. Nishimura\u2019s use of language to conjure internal landscapes. In the piece, she invites spectators and performers to focus attention on peripheral details of the architecture and sound of St. Mark\u2019s Church, which houses Danspace Project. Here, Ms. Nishimura performs alongside seven dancers to music composed by Masahiro Sugaya.\n\n866-811.4111, danspaceproject.org\n\nDAVID THOMSON at Performance Space New York (Jan. 31-Feb 2, 7:30 p.m., Feb. 4, 3 p.m.). In \u201che his own mythical beast,\u201d the choreographer David Thomson offers what he calls \u201ca meditation on the mythologies and contradictions of identity, race, gender and the black body in postmodern American culture.\u201d For it, his influences range from Alfred Hitchcock\u2019s \u201cRear Window,\u201d James Baldwin, high school fights and Trisha Brown. The work\u2019s guide? Venus, a character named after the Hottentot Venus, or Sarah Baartman, a black woman who was placed on exhibit in London and Paris in the early 19th century. Peter Born, along with Mr. Thomson, is the work\u2019s director.", "title": "Dance in NYC This Week", "authors": ["Gia Kourlas"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Hospitals, schools and other vital institutions will still get water, officials say, but the scale of the shut-off will be severe.\n\nCape Town\u2019s problems embody one of the big dangers of climate change: the growing risk of powerful, recurrent droughts. In Africa, a continent particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change, those problems serve as a potent warning to other governments, which typically don\u2019t have this city\u2019s resources and have done little to adapt.\n\nFor now, political leaders here talk of coming together to \u201cdefeat Day Zero.\u201d As water levels in the dams supplying the city continue to drop, the city is scrambling to finish desalination plants and increase groundwater production. Starting in February, residents will face harsher fines if they exceed their new daily limit, which will go down to 50 liters (13.2 gallons) a day per person from 87 liters now.\n\nJust a couple of years ago, the situation could not have looked more different here. In 2014, the dams stood full after years of good rain. The following year, C40, a collection of cities focused on climate change worldwide, awarded Cape Town its \u201cadaptation implementation\u201d prize for its management of water.\n\nPhoto\n\nCape Town was described as one of the world\u2019s top \u201cgreen\u201d cities, and the Democratic Alliance \u2014 the opposition party that has controlled Cape Town since 2006 \u2014 took pride in its emphasis on sustainability and the environment.\n\nThe accolades recognized the city\u2019s success in conserving water. Though the city\u2019s population had swelled by 30 percent since the early 2000s, overall water consumption had remained flat. Many of the new arrivals settled in the city\u2019s poor areas, which consume less water, and actually helped bring down per capita use.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe city\u2019s water conservation measures \u2014 fixing leaks and old pipes; installing meters and adjusting tariffs \u2014 had a powerful impact. Maybe too powerful.\n\nThe city conserved so much water that it postponed looking for new sources.\n\nFor years, Cape Town had been warned that it needed to increase and diversify its water supply. Almost all of its water still comes from six dams dependent on rainfall, a risky situation in an arid region with a changing climate. The dams, which were full only a few years ago, are now down to about 26 percent of capacity, officials say.\n\nCape Town has grown warmer in recent years and a bit drier over the last century, according to Piotr Wolski, a hydrologist at the University of Cape Town who has measured average rainfall from the turn of the 20th century to the present.", "title": "Dangerously Low on Water, Cape Town Now Faces \u2018Day Zero\u2019", "authors": ["Norimitsu Onishi", "Somini Sengupta"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "The play won a local competition and was performed at the well-known Hampstead Theater, where Mr. Kaluuya would later write and perform as a teenager. But after that triumph at age 9, he dropped theater for soccer, later finding his way back through improvisation classes at the Anna Scher Theater, a neighborhood institution that offered inexpensive drop-in sessions.\n\n\u201cBeing young, working class and black, everything you do is policed,\u201d Mr. Kaluuya said. \u201cIf someone hits you and you hit back, you are aggressive. If you cry, you are weak. You are kind of always pretending to be something. But in those improv classes, there was no pressure to be anything except honest, and that made me happy.\u201d Although he knew he had \u201ccaught the bug,\u201d he didn\u2019t have the confidence, he added, to express a desire to act.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf you are from the estates, you don\u2019t say that,\u201d he said. \u201cActually, the biggest problem is that you don\u2019t know it\u2019s possible. You don\u2019t have the vocabulary, conceptually, to articulate that wish.\u201d\n\nSeeing fellow students get parts on television shows, he began to attend auditions, and at 16 won a role in the BBC drama \u201cShoot the Messenger,\u201d starring David Oyelowo. Then came \u201cSkins,\u201d the BBC\u2019s controversial, long-running series about hard-partying teenagers.\n\nMr. Kaluuya didn\u2019t just co-star in \u201cSkins,\u201d he was also part of the writing team for the first two seasons, even as he was writing plays for the Hampstead Theater\u2019s youth program and completing his A-levels, the graduating examinations in the British school system. (Drama was one of his subjects; his former teacher has written that he was the most talented actor he has ever come across.)\n\nMr. Kaluuya wanted to go to drama school but couldn\u2019t afford it. Instead he kept writing for \u201cSkins,\u201d and in 2008 got a part in a play, \u201cOxford Street,\u201d at the Royal Court. \u201cThat was a breakthrough for me,\u201d Mr. Kaluuya said. \u201cI couldn\u2019t get seen for theater because I had no training. But that play led to \u2018Sucker Punch,\u2019 which changed everything.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor \u201cSucker Punch,\u201d written by Roy Williams, Mr. Kaluuya played one of the two leads, both young boxers. \u201cI\u2019d always been overweight and out of shape, but for this I trained for months and lost three stone\u201d or more than 40 pounds, he said. \u201cI gave it my all.\u201d He won rave reviews and several awards, and drew the attention of a number of industry figures, among them the director Steve McQueen, who cast Mr. Kaluuya in his coming movie \u201cWidows.\u201d\n\n\u201cI had noticed him on \u2018Skins,\u2019 and then saw \u2018Sucker Punch,\u2019\u201d Mr. McQueen said in a telephone interview. \u201cHe did this monologue while jumping rope which was amazing, and I was kind of mesmerized. He has that gift you don\u2019t see often, a presence even in his stillness. You feel what he is feeling, you see what he is seeing. When I was casting \u2018Widows,\u2019 I knew it was him.\u201d\n\nAfter \u201cSucker Punch,\u201d Mr. Kaluuya was cast in, among other things, the television series \u201cBlack Mirror,\u201d but he felt frustrated by the response from the British movie and theater industry. \u201cI wasn\u2019t trained, I was too big, they didn\u2019t want black leads, I don\u2019t know,\u201d Mr. Kaluuya said, clearly exasperated even at the memory. \u201cYou end up thinking, it\u2019s just a glass ceiling, isn\u2019t it?\u201d He decided to set his sights on the United States, found an American agent and won a part in the 2015 thriller \u201cSicario.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBefore shooting \u201cSicario,\u201d he read the script of \u201cGet Out,\u201d sent to him by his agent. \u201cI was like, how do I make this happen?\u201d Mr. Kaluuya recounted. \u201cI totally loved it. I knew it spoke to me and my friends. That rage at the end; I know that.\u201d He thought for a moment. \u201cI was fortunate that I had acting,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you had that anger on the street and let it out, you get arrested. I get applause.\u201d\n\nAs it turned out, Mr. Peele had seen Mr. Kaluuya in \u201cBlack Mirror,\u201d in the episode \u201cFifteen Million Merits.\u201d In an email, Mr. Peele wrote: \u201cIt\u2019s a soul-crushing performance in which he brilliantly performs the full spectrum of emotions I needed for Chris. Through most of the episode he\u2019s restrained and subdued, but by the end his passion explodes into a primal unhinged monologue that is a thing of beauty.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAlthough Mr. Peele was initially hesitant about casting a British actor instead of an American (a decision subsequently criticized by Samuel L. Jackson), he said that Mr. Kaluuya convinced him over a Skype conversation. \u201cHe put to bed my fears of any cultural rift in regards to race relations,\u201d Mr. Peele said. \u201cHe really GOT the script in ways many didn\u2019t. The risk excited him, where it made other American actors nervous.\u201d\n\nAfter Mr. Kaluuya flew to Los Angeles and performed the hypnosis sequence as his audition, the rest, Mr. Peele wrote, was history.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Kaluuya sighed wearily when asked about the controversy over his casting. \u201cIt speaks to the fact you are still getting policed,\u201d he said, adding: \u201cEven in the positive there is critique that a white person wouldn\u2019t get.\u201d\n\nThe success of \u201cGet Out\u201d hasn\u2019t immediately led to other roles, he said, although he is thinking about a script he likes. Meanwhile, he isn\u2019t exactly idle; he is writing a television series, as well as a film that he workshopped at the Sundance Screenwriters Lab, and has two movies (\u201cWidows\u201d and the Marvel \u201cBlack Panther\u201d) due in 2018.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s still a hustle!\u201d he said cheerfully. \u201cYou crack on.\u201d", "title": "Daniel Kaluuya Isn\u2019t Waiting for Your Approval", "authors": ["Roslyn Sulcas"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "What kinds of books bring you the most reading pleasure these days?\n\nBiographies, letters, journals \u2014 the records of people\u2019s lives, and the traces they themselves leave behind. This may be a middle-aged thing: When you\u2019re (somewhat) closer to the end of life than to the beginning, it\u2019s hard to resist the impulse to start \u201ctaking stock\u201d of yourself and what you\u2019ve done, and so it\u2019s interesting to see how the lives of talented or celebrated or important people looked to those people while they were still living those lives. And of course, what the letters and journals show is that most of our lives are mostly a jumble while we\u2019re living them, because we\u2019re caught up in the day-to-day for the most part; it\u2019s for the biographers to perceive the contours, once it\u2019s all over. I find that reassuring.\n\nWhich genres are you drawn to and which do you avoid?\n\nI was long immune to the allure of fantasy literature. Even when I was a kid, I couldn\u2019t get into \u201cThe Lord of the Rings\u201d and all the rest of it. I\u2019m not sure why, really. It may be that I got hooked on history and biography when I was still very young \u2014 ancient Egypt, Greek and Roman history, Plantagenet history, Elizabeth I, Mary, Queen of Scots \u2014 and I just couldn\u2019t imagine why anyone would need to invent a whole world or civilization when the ones we already have are so fascinating. But I may be evolving: I hugely enjoyed reading, and very much admired, all of the \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d books, which I tackled a few years ago for a piece I wrote about the TV series.\n\nUnsurprisingly, a genre I\u2019ve always loved is historical fiction. There are a lot of terrible examples out there, but when it works \u2014 when a deep sense of history (not just the props, but the spirit) is married to an authentic novelistic sensibility, as they are in the novels of Renault or Patrick O\u2019Brian or Hilary Mantel, to name a few of the best \u2014 it\u2019s tremendously satisfying. I find it amusing that this genre is still denigrated by some critics as being a lesser form of the novel. I always want to remind them that \u201cWar and Peace\u201d and \u201cLes Mis\u00e9rables\u201d are historical fiction.\n\nWhat\u2019s your favorite book to teach to students at Bard?\n\nYou\u2019re fishing! \u201cThe Odyssey,\u201d of course, is one \u2014 of the two Homeric epics it\u2019s the one that students tend to enjoy more. But I also love teaching Greek tragedy \u2014 it\u2019s at once so formally strange, so stiffly stylized and yet (of course) so eternally relevant in its themes. One of my favorite teaching experiences was when I participated in Bard\u2019s Prison Initiative last autumn, teaching Sophocles and Euripides to the inmates at a maximum-security facility about an hour from campus. I was blown away by the men\u2019s responses to the texts we read \u2014 by the way in which they brought what they knew about violence and shame and disgrace and guilt to dramas that are, of course, about those very things. As you can imagine, it was very different from what even the smartest 19-year-old undergraduates can bring to the seminar table.\n\nDo you have a favorite book about writing or about literary criticism?\n\nI have a favorite book of literary criticism, which is Edmund Wilson\u2019s \u201cAxel\u2019s Castle.\u201d I think most of us who are professional critics are shadowed by the secret fear that time will prove us wrong \u2014 the virtues of our enthusiasms will prove to be ephemeral, or the things we panned will turn out to be classics. What\u2019s so remarkable to me about Wilson\u2019s book, which he published in 1931 and which is contemporary with some of the authors he wrote about \u2014 Proust, Joyce, Pound, Stein \u2014 is that he got everything just right. And right away, too: Within 10 years of the publication of Proust\u2019s \u201c\u00c0 la recherche du Temps Perdu\u201d he\u2019d completely grasped everything about it that was important and revolutionary.\n\nWhat book might people be surprised to find on your shelves?\n\nI\u2019ve got piles of books about home d\u00e9cor and haute couture all around my house. I\u2019m currently slavering over the catalog for the Dior exhibition at the Louvre.\n\nWhat\u2019s the best book you\u2019ve ever received as a gift?\n\n\u201cA Titanic Hero,\u201d the biography of Thomas Andrews, the shipbuilder who designed the Titanic (and went down with it). I was a Titanic groupie when I was a kid \u2014 I belonged to the Titanic Enthusiasts of America \u2014 and one day when I was around 12 an old family friend who was visiting presented it to me. It\u2019s hardly a great work of biography but it\u2019s always been the first book I pack up whenever I\u2019ve moved.", "title": "Daniel Mendelsohn: By the Book", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nCOPENHAGEN \u2014 The inventor Peter Madsen is accused by the Danish authorities of binding and abusing the journalist Kim Wall on board his submarine before killing her, according to an indictment released in full on Tuesday.\n\nMr. Madsen has given shifting explanations for what happened to Ms. Wall, 30, a prolific Swedish journalist who disappeared after boarding the vessel on Aug. 10 in Copenhagen to interview him, and whose torso was found on a beach south of the city on Aug. 21.\n\nMost recently, he admitted to dismembering her body, but he said that she had died in an accident.\n\nIn the indictment, however, prosecutors say he brought a \u201csaw, sharpened screwdrivers, straps, strips and pipes\u201d to the submarine before the trip, arguing that these were part of a plan to kill Ms. Wall. He \u201cabused her by hitting her, stabbed and cut her and he killed her after which he dismembered her body,\u201d the indictment said.\n\nThe straps and pipes were tied to her torso and limbs to weight them down after he threw them overboard. The police investigation has not been able to establish the exact cause of death, but say that she was either strangled or had her throat cut.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe police said earlier that Ms. Wall had been stabbed repeatedly, including in her genitals, but had not previously said they believed that to have happened before her death.", "title": "Danish Inventor Abused Kim Wall Before Killing Her, Indictment Says", "authors": ["Martin Selsoe Sorensen"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "A field of four Democrats had been competing to take on Mr. Issa, including Doug Applegate, a retired Marine colonel who served in Iraq and almost defeated him in 2016; a former Obama administration official; and a real estate investor.\n\nMr. Issa had roughly $850,000 in his campaign coffers at the end of September, according to the most recent public filing available.\n\nBut his bare-knuckle partisanship had begun to wear on a district that is affluent and increasingly moderate. As chairman of the House Oversight Committee, Mr. Issa routinely ripped into Mr. Obama, his aides and his cabinet, as well as their handling of a gunrunning investigation known as Fast and Furious, the Internal Revenue Service\u2019s slow-walking of political groups\u2019 applications for nonprofit status, the terrorist attack on an American government compound in Benghazi, Libya, and many other matters.\n\nWithout Mr. Issa on the ballot, Democrats boasted on Wednesday that they were well positioned to turn the seat blue.\n\n\u201cAfter passing a devastating tax scam and fighting to rip away health care from millions of families, California Republicans clearly see the writing on the wall and realize that their party and its priorities are toxic to their re-election chances in 2018,\u201d said Drew Godinich, a spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.", "title": "Darrell Issa, a California Republican, Will Not Seek Re-election to House", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "From Theater Geek to \u2018Glee\u2019\n\nBy contrast, fame came easily to Mr. Criss. Even before \u201cGlee,\u201d he had garnered a following from his role in a satirical \u201cHarry Potter\u201d musical, which he put on with his post-collegiate theater company in Michigan. A YouTube version, with Mr. Criss as the boy wizard, went viral.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBy then he was already a seasoned performer. Raised in San Francisco, the son of a prominent banker, he began studying classical violin when he was 5. Not long after, he saw \u201cAladdin\u201d and decided he wanted to be the genie, or, barring that, an actor. The year of the Versace murder, he made his professional theater debut at age 10, in a local production of the 1954 musical \u201cFanny.\u201d His big number was \u201cBe Kind to Your Parents.\u201d\n\nHe spent the next eight years studying at the American Conservatory Theater\u2019s young conservatory program, while acting with 42nd Street Moon, a San Francisco troupe known for musical revivals. \u201cAfter school, I was raised by gay 20-somethings,\u201d he said of his adolescent years. \u201cThese are the people that I loved and looked up to and wanted to be around.\u201d\n\nHis early introduction to gay culture helped prepare him for a career in which his best-known roles and a good chunk of his fan base are gay, though Mr. Criss himself is straight. (His longtime girlfriend is Mia Swier, a TV director and producer.) He\u2019s a rare breed: theater geek filtered through California bro, which made an ideal combination for the pop dorkiness of \u201cGlee.\u201d\n\nIn the show\u2019s early days, he auditioned unsuccessfully for a few bit parts, including a football player, until Mr. Murphy finally took notice of him and cast him as Blaine in Season 2. \u201cI knew he could sing, I knew he could act, and I knew before we shot a frame of it, this kid\u2019s going to blow up,\u201d Mr. Murphy said.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe was right: Mr. Criss debuted on \u201cGlee\u201d in 2010, not long after getting a theater degree at the University of Michigan, and his cover of Katy Perry\u2019s \u201cTeenage Dream\u201d from his first episode shot up the Billboard charts. A vocal fan base kept the Kurt and Blaine romance steaming along, breaking television barriers as it went.\n\nMr. Criss burnished his overnight fame with stints on Broadway in \u201cHow to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying\u201d and \u201cHedwig and the Angry Inch,\u201d and recorded music as a solo artist and with Computer Games, an alt-pop band he started with his brother, Chuck Criss. In 2015, he helped found Elsie Fest, an outdoor music festival in New York that has been called \u201cCoachella for Show Tunes.\u201d\n\nMr. Murphy first floated the idea of the Versace project three years ago, when Mr. Criss was in New Orleans while Mr. Murphy was there shooting the pilot for \u201cScream Queens.\u201d Hearing the name Andrew Cunanan, Mr. Criss responded, \u201cOh, that\u2019s right! The half-Filipino guy!\u201d Later that summer, he was backstage at \u201cHedwig\u201d in full makeup and heels when Mr. Murphy called: \u201c\u2018Do you still want to do the Cunanan thing?\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChanneling a Killer\n\nIn the makeup trailer in Miami, a stylist painted a meth scab on Mr. Criss\u2019s leg and everyone got in a van. The morning\u2019s agenda: a fictionalized scene in which the increasingly desperate Mr. Cunanan tries to swim his way to safety, but quickly turns back. The van stopped near a jetty at the northern tip of Bal Harbour, with the Ritz-Carlton looming in the background.\n\n\u201cThis is going to be rad!\u201d Mr. Criss said, barely containing his enthusiasm. The first assistant director went over the shot: stare at the water; take off shirt, shoes and sunglasses; zip up backpack; jump in.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cShirt, shoes, sunglasses,\u201d the actor repeated. \u201cI like the alliteration of that.\u201d Mr. Criss gazed at the beach. \u201cLook at these colors, guys. It looks fake!\u201d\n\nThe waves were crashing hard against the concrete. As the crew shot the scene at the end of the jetty, it was decided that the water was too choppy for Mr. Criss to actually get in, lest they lose their star to sea. Still, by the end of the take he was drenched from ocean sprays, stripped down to soaking white boxer shorts.\n\n\u201cThat was insane,\u201d he shouted while he walked back, as someone swathed him in a white robe. He smiled into the sun and took stock of his luck: \u201cJust a day at the office. Who gets to do this?\u201d\n\nOn a break, I mentioned that he seemed to be having fun, and he bridled. \u201cI\u2019m really careful with that word,\u201d he said, his smile dissipating. \u201cThis is pretty gruesome material.\u201d\n\nDuring the eight-month shoot, he had been approached by several people who knew Mr. Cunanan. At an event in Los Angeles, he recalled, a Hollywood producer came up to him and said, \u201cOh, yeah, Andrew Cunanan, I used to hook up with him,\u201d and added that the F.B.I. had warned him to be careful while Mr. Cunanan was still on the loose.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfter a few takes, the crew moved to the beach to shoot Andrew\u2019s dejected return to the shore: \u201cmy anti-James Bond moment,\u201d Mr. Criss joked. He flung himself into the waves and trudged back onto the sand, kneeling and agonizing for the camera.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cShow us your face,\u201d the episode\u2019s director, Dan Minahan, instructed, and Mr. Criss revealed an anguished expression out of \u201cGuernica.\u201d After \u201cCut!,\u201d he instantly reverted to his sunny self, saying, \u201cI haven\u2019t been in the water since we got back to Miami, so: check!\u201d\n\nSitting down for lunch after the shoot, Mr. Criss described the series as a parable about \u201cthe ultimate creator and the ultimate destroyer,\u201d in which resentment turned Mr. Cunanan from aspirant to assassin. \u201cI approached Andrew from a pretty big place of hurt and pain and sorrow and sadness,\u201d he said. \u201cThe story doesn\u2019t horrify me as much as it breaks my heart.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnd that\u2019s why acting is such a fun art form to me, again as a bleeding idealist, a bleeding happy-go-lucky dude,\u201d he said, grinning again at his sheer dumb luck. \u201cPeople casually ask me, \u2018How\u2019s the show going?\u2019 And I will say with no ounce of irony or hyperbole, \u2018I\u2019ve worked and waited my entire life for this moment, and I couldn\u2019t be happier.\u2019\u201d\n\nMoments later, something close to an irony did cross his mind: \u201cIt\u2019s the life Andrew Cunanan would have dreamed of, frankly.\u201d", "title": "Darren Criss Plays the Happy-Go-Lucky Killer in the Versace TV Drama", "authors": ["Michael Schulman"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "When it comes to serving the disabled, Mr. Weprin said the city\u2019s subway stops are among the least accessible of any major American city. Disabled people who cannot access many subway stations and are compelled to drive, he said, would be unfairly burdened by a congestion fee.\n\nThose concerns may be legitimate, but the need for a congestion pricing plan is more pressing, said Nick Sifuentes, the executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign. \u201cWe can\u2019t legislate for the handful of people who may need to drive into Manhattan for a doctor\u2019s appointment, every once in a while, and leave the six million New Yorkers taking the train every day in the lurch.\u2019\u2019\n\nTo arrive at its conclusions, analysts working for the group used data from the most recently available American Community Survey, which details demographic variables as granular as mode of transportation by race and by income from 2011 to 2015. To decipher whether those New Yorkers commuted into the proposed congestion zone, the group sorted data from the previous five-year census, which recorded where people drive to, and then correlated it to Assembly and Senate district maps. (The commuting data from the 2011 to 2015 survey has not been released.)\n\nThe districts with the highest number of commuters who drive into the proposed congestion zone, the report found, are in Manhattan, where people take a mix of personal cars and taxis, both of which would be subject to a congestion charge. For example, the highest percentage came from the 73rd Assembly District on the Upper East Side, where 9.2 percent of those entering the congestion zone rode in private vehicles.\n\nDespite the report\u2019s conclusions, the fate of any congestion pricing plan, which would have to be approved by the Legislature, will likely depend on addressing the concerns of Mr. Weprin and other lawmakers who represent districts outside Manhattan.\n\nAfter the congestion pricing plan was released, Mr. Weprin convened a news conference in Manhattan where he was flanked by many lawmakers from the other boroughs.\n\n\u201cIf there were so few people driving in, I don\u2019t think it would produce anything near the revenue that they\u2019re claiming it\u2019s producing,\u201d Mr. Weprin said, pointing out the high volume of traffic that spills across the M.T.A.-controlled bridges and tunnels each rush hour. \u201cThere are a lot of people moving over them into Manhattan,\u201d he said. \u201cWhere are the people coming from?\u201d", "title": "Data Shows City Drivers Won\u2019t Face the Brunt of Congestion Fees", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHere\u2019s what to expect in the week ahead:\n\nECONOMY\n\nEuropean economic growth continues.\n\nOfficial data being released Tuesday is expected to confirm that the European economy continued to boom in the final three months of 2017, with no signs of a slowdown. Eurostat, the European Union\u2019s official statistics agency, will publish an estimate of the economy\u2019s growth that analysts expect will show that the eurozone is expanding at an annual pace of around 2.5 percent. But while Germany is suffering from labor shortages, there are still pockets of woe like Greece. Jack Ewing\n\nJanet Yellen\u2019s final Fed meeting.\n\nJanet L. Yellen will preside over her final meeting as Federal Reserve chairwoman on Tuesday and Wednesday. She will complete her four-year term at the end of the week and her successor, Jerome H. Powell, is waiting in the wings. The Fed raised its benchmark rate at its last meeting, in December, and another rate increase is expected at its meeting in March. The January meeting, however, is expected to pass quietly \u2014 one Wall Street analyst advised clients to hit the snooze button. If history is any guide, Fed officials will deliver tributes to Ms. Yellen at the meeting, but the details won\u2019t be shared with the public until the meeting transcripts are released in five years. Binyamin Appelbaum\n\nOIL INDUSTRY\n\nMexico to auction oil exploration blocks.\n\nMexico will auction 29 deepwater exploration blocks in the Gulf of Mexico to international oil companies on Wednesday as part of its broad opening to private energy investment. Among the potential bidders are the big oil companies Chevron, BP, Shell and Exxon Mobil. Mexico\u2019s deepwater reserves have not been developed but their geology is similar to productive fields on the side of the gulf controlled by the United States. The auction, covering areas over more than 27,000 square miles, is one of the last before Mexico\u2019s presidential election is held on July 1. The front-runner in the polls, Andr\u00e9s Manuel L\u00f3pez Obrador, has said he would review private oil contracts and the Energy Ministry is speeding ahead with auctions before President Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto\u2019s term ends in December. Last week, it announced a new auction of 37 onshore oil and gas fields for July 25. Elisabeth Malkin\n\nTECH\n\nA slew of tech companies will report earnings.\n\nEarnings season for technology companies will begin with a bang this week. On Wednesday, investors will be watching for further details from Facebook on how its plans to fix its problems, including claims of bogus news, will affect its business. That same day, Microsoft will report on whether its cloud computing business continues to grow at a strong clip. The three As of tech \u2014 Apple, Amazon and Alphabet, the parent company of Google \u2014 are expected to provide more insight on Thursday into how well devices like the iPhone, Amazon Echo and Google Home sold over the holiday quarter. Nick Wingfield\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHigher earnings expected from oil companies.\n\nThe message from oil companies this week is likely to be that their business is once again a moneymaking machine. Royal Dutch Shell, Europe\u2019s largest oil company, is expected to report fourth quarter 2017 earnings on Thursday, followed by Exxon Mobil and Chevron on Friday.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe operating environment for oil companies has improved greatly after some grim years caused by a price crash that began in 2014 and dropped prices to the $30 a barrel range. Prices have jumped in recent months thanks to strong global demand and output curbs orchestrated by Saudi Arabia and Russia; Brent crude has now climbed back to the $70 a barrel range. At the same time, oil companies have used low prices to force contractors and suppliers to reduce costs. The result, analysts forecast, should be sharply higher earnings compared with the same period a year earlier. Stanley Reed\n\nBANKING\n\nDeutsche Bank to release details on \u2018small\u2019 loss.\n\nDeutsche Bank, Germany\u2019s largest lender, will give details on Friday on what it has already said was a \u201csmall\u201d loss during the fourth quarter of 2017 because of tax changes in the United States. Deutsche Bank warned earlier this month that it would subtract $1.9 billion from its quarterly profit because of changes that reduced its ability to deduct past losses. At a news conference in Frankfurt, John Cryan, Deutsche Bank\u2019s chief executive, will also face questions \u2014 which he will probably decline to answer \u2014 about the bank\u2019s work for companies controlled by the family of Jared Kushner, President Trump\u2019s son-in-law. Jack Ewing", "title": "Data on Europe\u2019s Economy, Job Numbers and Janet Yellen\u2019s Goodbye", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The pioneer is Danai Gurira, a 39-year-old Zimbabwean-American actor and writer (best known as Michonne on \u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d) whose searing play \u201cEclipsed,\u201d about captured women in war-torn Liberia, was staged on Broadway in 2016. Now her drama \u201cFamiliar,\u201d about a Zimbabwean-American family in Minnesota, which was staged in 2016 at Playwrights Horizons in New York, is being presented next month at Woolly Mammoth in Washington, followed by productions at the Guthrie in Minneapolis and Seattle Repertory Theater.\n\nLast year saw two well-received New York productions of work by playwrights born to African immigrants: New York Theater Workshop presented \u201cSojourners\u201d and \u201cHer Portmanteau\u201d by Mfoniso Udofia, a 33-year-old Nigerian-American writer who is working on a nine-play cycle about a Nigerian-American family; and MCC Theater presented \u201cSchool Girls; Or, the African Mean Girls Play,\u201d a comedic drama by Jocelyn Bioh, a 34-year-old Ghanaian-American writer and performer.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s such a beautiful thing and an inspiring thing and a surreal thing to see a Ghanaian story on an American stage \u2014 I never even knew something like that would be possible,\u201d said MaYaa Boateng, a 26-year-old child of Ghanaian immigrants from Maryland who graduated from N.Y.U.\u2019s graduate acting program last year and is now developing her own solo show. Ms. Boateng said a visit by Ms. Gurira to her university \u201cis one of the reasons why I picked up a pen the very first time,\u201d and said seeing work by other women of African descent leaves her feeling that \u201cwe all have stories worth telling \u2014 they need to be spoken.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe trend is an outgrowth of demographics: African immigration to the United States has surged since the 1970s, so that by 2015 there were 2.1 million African immigrants living in the United States, up from 80,000 in 1970, according to the Pew Research Center.\n\n\u201cThe economic migrants are coming in extremely educated, and there\u2019s pressure on their children to do very well,\u201d said Onoso Imoagene, an assistant professor of sociology at the University of Pennsylvania and the author of \u201cBeyond Expectations: Second Generation Nigerians in the United States and Britain.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s pressure to pursue professional careers \u2014 medicine and law and pharmacy \u2014 but because they\u2019re becoming a large enough population,\u201d she added, \u201cyou have some saying, \u2018I don\u2019t want to do that \u2014 I want to do arts or music or fashion,\u2019 and you do have quite a number who are trying to create art that showcases their ethnic background.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe playwrights are emerging amid a rise in interest in African culture in the U.S. \u2014 including the work of contemporary Nigerian novelists as well as first-generation writers and artists. Several important theater performers are the children of African immigrants, including the British actors David Oyelowo, who played the title role in a 2016 New York Theater Workshop production of \u201cOthello\u201d; and Cynthia Erivo, who won a Tony Award as the star of a 2015 Broadway revival of \u201cThe Color Purple\u201d; as well as the American actor Michael Luwoye, who has just stepped into the title role of \u201cHamilton\u201d on Broadway. All three are the children of Nigerian immigrants.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re at a time right now where the word immigrant again has become something that seems sort of toxic, and when we hear the \u2018shithole\u2019 comment, it\u2019s very piercing,\u201d Mr. Luwoye, a 27-year-old born and raised in Alabama, said, referring to President Trump\u2019s reported use of that word this month in a discussion about protections for people from Haiti and some countries in Africa. \u201cThe plays that are coming up today, as well as the literature and the television, are at least attempting to humanize what it is to be an immigrant, or the child of an immigrant, so it\u2019s easier to connect with, rather than something that creates a stereotype.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe doors began to open with Ms. Gurira, who was born in Iowa, raised in Zimbabwe, and then moved back to the U.S. for college. Ms. Gurira was a graduate student at N.Y.U. when she started collaborating on \u201cIn the Continuum,\u201d a 2005 play seeking to humanize women with AIDS.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWhen I first started realizing I wanted to tell stories from an African female perspective, I felt pretty lonely out there,\u201d Ms. Gurira said. \u201cI had to be like a mad scientist and have the hypothesis that if I put a multidimensional narrative about an African woman in front of a Western audience, they will enjoy it.\u201d\n\nMs. Gurira, who is featured in the upcoming superhero film \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d said she is writing new work constantly (\u201cI am up to my eyeballs with writing,\u201d she said) and is thrilled to see other writers of African descent now getting productions. \u201cThere are so many stories to go,\u201d she said. \u201cThere is a hunger for this perspective to come out.\u201d\n\nMs. Udofia, born in Texas and raised in Massachusetts, trained as an actor and started writing when she was having a hard time finding roles on stage. \u201cI knew immediately what I would be writing about \u2014 I felt little pockets of anger and frustration because I wasn\u2019t seeing me or the people that I knew in a very nuanced way on stage, so I started writing them to show that we are here,\u201d she said.\n\nA founding artistic director of the Now Africa Festival, which seeks to introduce New Yorkers to African drama, Ms. Udofia is so eager to champion the work of others that she agreed to star in \u201cHomecoming Queen\u201d to support Ms. Anyanwu, even though she hadn\u2019t acted in years. \u201cIt\u2019s important to build kinship, and to dismantle the thought that there can only be one of us,\u201d she said. \u201cIt makes the foundation of the house stronger.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Bioh, who grew up in Washington Heights, Manhattan, had a similar path to writing \u2014 she wasn\u2019t getting cast in college productions, so she took a playwriting class. She had some success acting, landing a role on Broadway in \u201cThe Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,\u201d but also kept writing. Her work is funny \u2014 a deliberate counterpoint to what she sees as the grim story lines of many dramas about Africa.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI was just really alarmed at African stories only portraying struggle and war and famine and AIDS, and I wanted to add levity,\u201d she said. \u201cSchool Girls,\u201d a riff on \u201cMean Girls\u201d set in a Ghanaian school at which several young women are competing to represent their country in a beauty pageant, was a big hit for MCC \u2014 and the crowds were unusually diverse, thanks to outreach to African-American and African immigrant communities.\n\nOf course, identity can be complicated. LCT3 at Lincoln Center Theater this spring will present \u201cPass Over,\u201d a play by Antoinette Nwandu, a 37-year-old from Los Angeles whose biological father is a Nigerian immigrant but who was raised by her African-American mother after her parents divorced when she was a baby; she has only spoken to her father once since, and knows little about her Nigerian background.\n\n\u201cI definitely think that my heritage informs characters who are searching for self, who are wondering and grappling with whether or not they can remake themselves,\u201d she said.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Nwandu said seeing shows by writers with stronger knowledge about their African heritage inspires her. \u201cAnd of course this is another wave of first or second generation immigrants wrestling with belonging in two worlds, and it\u2019s very exciting to add to the canon of immigrant theater like \u2018Long Day\u2019s Journey Into Night\u2019 and \u2018Fiddler on the Roof,\u2019 \u201d she said. \u201cSeeing it now from an African lens and an African viewpoint is really thrilling.\u201d\n\nMs. Anyanwu, the writer of \u201cThe Homecoming Queen,\u201d found herself drawn to theater in high school. Her parents wanted her to be a doctor, a lawyer, or a nurse \u2014 something stable and financially secure \u2014 but she knew she wanted a career in the arts. \u201cI like the camaraderie, and the community, and the openness, and the rigor,\u201d she said.\n\nShe turned to writing, like others, when she encountered a shortage of roles as an actor. \u201cAs a black female performer, the reality is there\u2019s not so much work for us \u2014 Dominique Morisseau or Katori Hall will have a great play, but that\u2019s only four parts,\u201d she said. \u201cSo making things is a big part of my identity.\u201d\n\nAfter graduate school at the University of California San Diego, she visited Nigeria, and when she came back she started the First Generation Nigerian Project \u2014 a group of female Nigerian-American performers and writers in New York.\n\n\u201cThe Homecoming Queen,\u201d her first play produced in New York, is directed by Awoye Timpo, a 39-year-old daughter of Ghanaian immigrants. Ms. Timpo said the new work by children of African immigrants has the potential to change the way audiences see the United States.\n\n\u201cOur understanding of who we are as Americans, and what our history has been, hasn\u2019t embraced the complexity of all the stories that make America,\u201d Ms. Timpo said. \u201cWith this new wave of storytellers, we\u2019re getting to see who we are.\u201d", "title": "Daughters of African Immigrants Use the Stage to Tell of Two Worlds", "authors": ["Michael Paulson"]} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Bird Revelation\u201d is one of four specials he released in 2017, and in another of those, \u201cThe Age of Spin,\u201d he brings up a rumor that Bill Cosby paid for the microphone that the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. used in his \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech. It was Mr. Chappelle\u2019s way of expressing how hard it is to give up the comic as one of his heroes. In \u201cBird,\u201d he again leans on the gravitas of King to pivot from the pain caused by sexual misconduct. Mr. Chappelle criticizes the \u201cbrittle spirit\u201d of the female comic who said Louis C.K. masturbating in front of her hurt her career, before imagining what would happen if Louis C.K. masturbated in front of the civil rights leader, prompting him to give up his movement.\n\nWhen suggesting a handsome man wouldn\u2019t be accused of assault and rape, he says that if Brad Pitt did what Mr. Weinstein did, the response would be different. (\u201cGirl would have been like: I got the part.\u201d) But Mr. Chappelle is just rehashing a Chris Rock bit on sexual harassment from the 1990s (\u201cIf Clarence Thomas looked like Denzel Washington \u2026\u201d). It\u2019s a joke that has not aged well, and this new version does not do Mr. Chappelle any favors.\n\nMr. Chappelle opens this special by noting that sometimes the funniest thing to say is mean, and he\u2019s right. Comedy, to quote Steve Martin, is not pretty. But when Mr. Chappelle says some of the sexual assault victims speaking out are now experiencing \u201cbuyer\u2019s remorse,\u201d a particularly cruel turn of phrase, this is surely not the funniest thing he can think of. And it is expressed with as little empathy as possible.\n\nMr. Chappelle \u2014 who has always been far more savvy and engaged on race than on gender (his TV series \u201cChappelle\u2019s Show\u201d flashed a leering teenage sensibility) \u2014 is not aiming merely for transgression. He embraces this new movement, calls himself a feminist and offers sober political analysis, with a passionate argument for focusing on structural issues. \u201cYou got all the bad guys scared, and that\u2019s good,\u201d he says. \u201cBut the minute they\u2019re not scared anymore, it will get worse than it was before. Fear does not make lasting peace.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThis is not a joke. Nor is it reckless. It\u2019s expressing a moderate\u2019s caution and hope for reconciliation in the face of a revolutionary social movement. It\u2019s the same impulse that led Mr. Chappelle, hosting \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d just after the presidential election, to urge us to give Donald J. Trump a chance. (He has since apologized.) In his current incarnation, Mr. Chappelle often carries himself less like a mischievous outlaw than a comedy statesman. (At the close of Netflix\u2019s \u201cDef Comedy Jam 25,\u201d Mr. Chappelle, who as a young comic criticized how the show set expectations for black artists, delivered a reverential coda about its historical importance.)\n\nMuch of his 2017 comedy had a professorial tone, weaving long pocket histories into his act. But in this paradigm-shifting moment, when victims are speaking out and revealing secrets long buried, Mr. Chappelle is ignoring the historical context, the systemic barriers preventing women from speaking up about abuse or succeeding in comedy. It\u2019s perhaps why an audience member off screen balks at one joke, to which he responds: \u201cI know you\u2019re right, baby. I was right once. Remember that?\u201d\n\nFor many young viewers, some of whom know him mainly for his much-criticized recent jokes about transgender people, the answer is no. They don\u2019t remember \u201cChappelle\u2019s Show,\u201d which premiered 15 years ago, or that he quit the series abruptly. At the time, his reasons for leaving were slightly unclear but, because of an interview he gave, were widely seen as involving his discomfort with white viewers\u2019 response to his racial humor rooted in stereotypes. The departure helped cement his reputation as a comic with a social conscience, willing to pass up tens of millions of dollars because of a principle. In 2017, Mr. Chappelle made tens of millions of dollars from his specials, but one wonders how much he cares about why people are laughing at his new jokes.\n\nIn an abrupt pivot, he ends this unusually topical special by asking audience members if they want to know the real reason he left \u201cChappelle\u2019s Show,\u201d a mystery that lost its urgency years ago and suggests a comic nostalgic for old glories. In a funny bit of self-awareness, Mr. Chappelle says he never wanted to be a hero but, rather like Paul Revere, to be known for a single heroic act.\n\n\u201cPaul Revere\u2019s ride was only one night, then 40 years of him being like: Remember that time when everyone was asleep and I was up, and the British was coming?\u201d Mr. Chappelle says, pausing. \u201cBoy, good thing I was awake.\u201d", "title": "Dave Chappelle Stumbles Into the #MeToo Moment", "authors": ["Jason Zinoman"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Clint Eastwood also drew on Mr. Toschi for his portrayal of the title character in \u201cDirty Harry,\u201d Don Siegel\u2019s influential 1971 movie about a San Francisco police inspector, Harry Callahan, who hunts a psychopathic killer. Mr. Toschi, though, was bothered by Callahan\u2019s penchant for administering his own brand of justice. He is said to have walked out of a screening of the movie, which was released when the Zodiac investigation was in full swing.\n\n\u201cHe couldn\u2019t take it,\u201d Mr. Ruffalo, who spent time with Mr. Toschi preparing for his \u201cZodiac\u201d role, said in a 2007 interview with the website Collider. \u201cIt was so simplified.\u201d\n\nMr. Toschi\u2019s daughter said he always thought that a suspect named Arthur Leigh Allen, who died in 1992, was Zodiac. But, unlike Harry Callahan, he and his fellow officers were bound by the evidence.\n\n\u201cIf you get into who these cops were,\u201d Mr. Ruffalo said in another 2007 interview, \u201cyou realize how they have to take their hunches, their personal beliefs, out of it. Dave Toschi said to me, \u2018As soon as that guy walked in the door, I knew it was him.\u2019 He was sure he had him, but he never had a solid piece of evidence. So he had to keep investigating every other lead.\u201d\n\nIn a 1978 interview, Mr. Toschi estimated that he had talked to 5,000 people during the Zodiac investigation. His letter-writing misstep not only took him out of the investigation that year, but also brought a more serious accusation \u2014 that he might have written a letter from around that time that claimed to be from the Zodiac killer. He vigorously denied that speculation.\n\nOther letters claiming to be from Zodiac turn up periodically, most of them hoaxes, and new theories and even confessions surface from time to time. The case has inspired numerous books and episodes of true-crime television shows, including a five-part series on the History channel that concluded in December.\n\nMr. Toschi retired in 1985 after 32 years on the force. He worked in private security afterward. In addition to Ms. Toschi-Chambers, he is survived by his wife, the former Carol Bacigalupi, whom he married in 1957; another daughter, Karen Leight; and two granddaughters.", "title": "David Toschi, 86, Detective Who Pursued the Zodiac Killer, Dies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion), and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.", "title": "Opinion | Davos 2018 Diary", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Whatever. We\u2019re businessmen. We think the same way. You want to turn a profit and beat the competition. You don\u2019t want to get crushed. And you\u2019ll do what you need to do and say what you need to say to win.\n\nThat\u2019s the way the world is, folks. You think China doesn\u2019t know this? You think Russia \u2014 and you know this Russia story, collusion, there was no collusion, none \u2014 doesn\u2019t know? Why do you think they keep winning? China is getting bigger, stronger, while Europe just gets smaller and weaker. Angela Merkel, sorry, but she\u2019s a total joke. Lets in a million Muslims, illegals, terrorists probably, in one year, and the German people don\u2019t like it at all. Remember, a year ago, how it was like, \u201cMerkel is the real leader of the free world\u201d? Now she barely leads her own government.\n\nShe should have built a wall. Not smart!\n\nAnyway, China. Last year, Xi \u2014 we have a terrific relationship, by the way, Xi and I, but he could be a lot better on North Korea, believe me \u2014 Xi was here in Davos, saying he was, like, Mr. Globalization. And everyone was like, ooh, ahh, China\u2019s taking over, and adios America.\n\nYou have got to be kidding me. Have any of you here had your trade secrets stolen by China? Any of you think the Chinese play fair? You like human rights in China, pollution in China? Do some of you want to live in a world run by Xi? Because, be my guest.\n\nBut if you don\u2019t, then things have to change. It can\u2019t be, we\u2019ll play by all the rules, like a bunch of little girls, and China gets to cheat, and pretend that that\u2019s O.K. Because, believe me, cheaters always win. Nobody knows this better than me.\n\nSo that has got to stop. That\u2019s my message to you people. Do you want America first or China first? I\u2019m saying, it\u2019s your choice. But if it\u2019s America first you want, then you\u2019re going to stop playing us for suckers.\n\nWe aren\u2019t going to pay your bills while you take our jobs. We aren\u2019t going to fight your battles if you aren\u2019t going to buy our products. We aren\u2019t going to let you get rich off of us, if we can\u2019t get richer off of you. We\u2019re stronger than you and we\u2019re going to stay that way. We can leave the surrender stuff to our European friends. Got it?", "title": "Opinion | Davos Man Meets America First", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Separately, new campaign filings and news reports suggest that two pro-Trump groups are raising millions, then channeling the money into the Trump Organization and to Trump loyalists.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The terrorist cell behind the Barcelona attack that killed 16 people and wounded 140 others in August had an even more deadly plan, according to new research. The group may have targeted the Eiffel Tower in Paris.\n\nIn Syria, there are concerns that camps holding people suspected of supporting the Islamic State could help extremists spread their ideology.\n\nAs many as 1,500 of the more than 5,000 Europeans amid its ranks have returned home. Most of the rest are believed to be dead or still fighting.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 \u201cI just signed your death warrant.\u201d\n\nThat was a judge noting that her sentencing of Larry Nassar, the former doctor for the American gymnastics team, would far exceed his life span.\n\nShe added 40 to 175 years for various sex crimes against athletes, on top of 60 years on child pornography charges.\n\nWe collected some of the powerful statements from the more than 150 victims.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In Britain, an all-male charity event is shutting down after an undercover investigation by The Financial Times revealed that participants harassed female servers. The ensuing uproar reflected intensifying public anger over issues of harassment.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile in the U.S., our cultural critic writes about how Hollywood, ever nimble, has absorbed critiques of sexual exploitation and begun converting them into inspirational messaging.\n\nAnd we talked to some women in China, including the student above, who are trying to forge a #MeToo movement. They are grappling with a male-dominated culture, censors and officials who accuse them of colluding with foreigners.\n\n_____\n\nVideo\n\n\u2022 Researchers in Shanghai have successfully created two cloned monkeys.\n\nIt is the first time that primates have been cloned with the technique that produced Dolly the sheep in 1996 in Scotland.\n\nThe technique is still a long way from producing human babies, even if that were ethically permissible.\n\nBusiness\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 U.S. start-ups are trying to rebrand marijuana as a \u201cwellness\u201d drug to be vaped, eaten, dipped or dabbed. They see great promise in turning it into the drug of the future, our columnist writes.\n\n\u2022 The E.U.\u2019s steep fine against Qualcomm, the chip maker, reflects how Margrethe Vestager, the bloc\u2019s antitrust chief, has become the world\u2019s most aggressive technology regulator.\n\n\u2022 Strong economic growth is adding to pressure on the European Central Bank to end its stimulus program sooner than it planned.\n\n\u2022 England\u2019s loneliest railway station, where a train arrives just once a week, symbolizes the dysfunctions of Britain\u2019s transportation network.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Here\u2019s a snapshot of global markets.\n\nIn the News\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Simmering tensions between Turkey and the United States over a Turkish offensive against U.S.-backed Kurdish forces in Syria spilled into the open in a phone call between the two countries\u2019 presidents. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 Save the Children, the aid agency, suspended all of its operations in Afghanistan after Islamic State militants stormed its office in Jalalabad, killing five people. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 At least two people were killed when a commuter train derailed near Milan. [Corriere della Sera]\n\n\u2022 In Egypt, the last main challenger dropped out of the coming presidential election, effectively clearing the field for President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi to run virtually unopposed. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 The first trial related to the terrorist attacks on Paris in 2015 opened after concerns that protests by prison guards would block the suspect\u2019s transfer to court. [Associated Press]\n\n\u2022 The serpent in the Garden of Eden hissed the first fake news to Eve, and it all went downhill from there, Pope Francis wrote in a major document on misinformation. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 In Brazil, an appeals court upheld a corruption conviction against former President Luiz In\u00e1cio Lula da Silva, jeopardizing his quest to return to office. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 A dozen camels were disqualified from a beauty contest in Saudi Arabia because their owners used Botox on their animals\u2019 lips. [The New York Times]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Recipe of the day: Satisfy a sweet tooth with salted chocolate chunk shortbread cookies.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Should you give back the engagement ring?\n\n\u2022 Grief is not a problem to be solved.\n\n\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In the first part of a new video series, our Interpreter columnists explore why some democratic countries (like Hungary) have been backsliding.\n\n\u2022 In memoriam: Mark E. Smith, the songwriter of the British post-punk band the Fall, 60.
