Here are a dozen songs from one of the most daunting catalogs in rock.\n\n\u2022 Two former employees of Colette, the pathbreaking Paris concept shop, have taken their taste for sneakers and gadgets (and some of their customers) to a new spot nearby.\n\n\u2022 Australian Open: Caroline Wozniacki reached the final. Here is today\u2019s schedule.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nIn honor of Australia Day, Friday\u2019s holiday marking the anniversary of Britain\u2019s arrival Down Under in 1788, we\u2019re looking at one of the country\u2019s most recognizable exports: \u201cG\u2019day, mate!\u201d\n\nAustralian National University points to an early use of the greeting in \u201cThe Romance of a Station,\u201d a novel from 1889:\n\n\u201cHe pulled up, nodding to Alec\u2019s \u2018Good-day, Tillidge,\u2019 and replying in a short, morose manner, running his words one into the other, as a bushman does, \u2018G\u2019d-day, sir.\u2019\u201d\n\nA century later, the phrase was popularized the world over in a tourism ad campaign featuring Paul Hogan, the Australian actor who would later gain international fame as Crocodile Dundee.\n\nAustralians have a long tradition of abbreviating and slackening words and phrases, particularly by adding \u201cie\u201d to the end.\n\n\u201cAussie\u201d appears in references from World War I. A book by Gertrude Moberly, recounting the experiences of a nurse, described a \u201cfarewell dance for the boys going home to \u2018Aussie\u2019 tomorrow.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd Australians always have their \u201cmates.\u201d The nation\u2019s unique camaraderie, known as mateship, is especially evident during commemorations of the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps (or Anzacs), the World War I-era fighting force.\n\nAdam Baidawi contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online. Browse past briefings here.\n\nYou can get the briefing delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. We have four global editions, timed for the Americas, Europe, Asia and Australia, and an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights. Check out our full range of free newsletters here.\n\nIf photographs appear out of order, please download the updated New York Times app from iTunes or Google Play.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Davos, Donald Trump, Syria: Your Thursday Briefing", "authors": ["Patrick Boehler"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 President Trump will address world leaders and business elites in Davos, Switzerland, later today, possibly making good on his promise to \u201ctell the world how great America is and is doing.\u201d\n\nOn the sidelines, Mr. Trump has been in diplomatic overdrive. He worked to mend relations with Britain, saying he and Prime Minister Theresa May were \u201con the same wavelength,\u201d despite reports of strains.\n\nAnd with the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, at his side, Mr. Trump excoriated the Palestinians, threatening to cut off aid unless they \u201csit down and negotiate peace.\u201d\n\nElsewhere, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin unleashed market turmoil with an apparently offhand comment, that a weak dollar benefits U.S. trade.", "title": "Davos, Doomsday Clock, North Korea: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "1. President Trump met with his British and Israeli counterparts at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. He\u2019s set to give a highly anticipated speech tomorrow.\n\nCalling the reports of a rift with Prime Minister Theresa May, above left, \u201ca false rumor,\u201d Mr. Trump indicated that he might be planning another trip across the pond. The last one was canceled, averting the risk of large protests.\n\nAnd with Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli leader, at his side, he criticized the Palestinians for refusing to meet with Vice President Mike Pence during his visit to Israel this week. Palestinian leaders were angered by the administration\u2019s decision to move the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem.", "title": "Davos, Dreamers, Doomsday: Your Thursday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "____\n\nPhoto\n\n3. This year\u2019s flu season is now more intense than any since the 2009 swine flu pandemic \u2014 and it\u2019s still getting worse.\n\nThat\u2019s the word from federal health officials, who announced that the hospitalization rate \u2014 a predictor of the death rate \u2014 has jumped.\n\nThis year\u2019s dominant virus, H3N2, is usually the most lethal of the seasonal strains, and vaccines don\u2019t work that well against it. But let us repeat: It\u2019s still worth getting a flu shot, and it\u2019s not too late in the year. Above, a flu patient in California.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n4. Our Beirut bureau helped unpack the developments in northern Syria, where Turkey, a U.S. ally, is attacking Kurdish militias backed by Washington.\n\nThose fighters disavow nationalism and envision a stateless society without gender distinctions. And they have deep ties to a group that both Turkey and the U.S. consider a terrorist organization.\n\nYes, it\u2019s complicated. Above, U.S.-backed fighters at a funeral for fallen comrades.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n5. In South Korea, a fire at a hospital that doubled as a nursing home killed at least 37 people in the southern city of Miryang.\n\nIt was the latest in a string of tragedies that have heightened public concern over the country\u2019s safety standards. South Korea also has one of the world\u2019s fastest-aging populations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOfficials are still investigating the cause of the fire.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n6. \u201cOver the course of the trial, we became an army determined to expose the greatest sexual assault scandal in sports history. And we succeeded.\u201d\n\nRachael Denhollander, above left, the former gymnast and lawyer who was the first to go public about Lawrence Nassar\u2019s abuse, described the ordeal in an Op-Ed for The New York Times.\n\nBowing to the demands of the United States Olympic Committee, U.S.A. Gymnastics confirmed Friday night that all the remaining members of its board of directors would resign.\n\nNow that Dr. Nassar has been sentenced, the focus has also turned to Michigan State, which employed him for two decades. State and federal agencies are investigating who knew about his behavior, and the president and athletic director have resigned.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n7. Travel with us to the land of endless night.\n\nWe asked readers who live around the Arctic Circle \u2014 where in some places the sun doesn\u2019t shine for weeks after the winter solstice \u2014 to share their stories and photos of life there. Nearly 700 responded.\n\n\u201cOn a clear night, the number of stars is beyond understanding,\u201d said a hotelier in Finland. \u201cSometimes when you stop in the forest, it is so quiet you think that there is something wrong with your hearing.\u201d\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n8. Our personal finance columnist, Ron Lieber, has been on something of a crusade against Equifax since its huge data breach in the fall.\n\nOne of the most frustrating aspects of the debacle, for Mr. Lieber and the many readers who got in touch with him, is that there\u2019s no way to get the company to delete your personal information.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut you might be able to get your employer to do so. As a case study, he asked The Times to cancel its contract with Equifax for services like providing employment verification.\n\nAfter a few days of consideration, the company said it would do so.\n\nMarket Snapshot View Full Overview\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n9. Will the Grammys have a #MeToo moment? The awards show is Sunday, and a grass-roots campaign started this week encouraging attendees to wear a white rose as a symbol of \u201chope, peace, sympathy and resistance.\u201d Above, the singer Halsey spoke out against abuse at the Women\u2019s March in New York.\n\nBut pop music has not been rocked by the #MeToo movement the way Hollywood was, and some observers are asking why. After all, women are still woefully underrepresented in the industry: A new report found that only 9 percent of the 899 nominees in the last six Grammys were women.\n\nOur pop music critic put together a playlist of the Grammy gems in lesser-known categories. (You probably won\u2019t hear them during the broadcast.) You can sign up to listen to it on Spotify, too.\n\n____\n\nPhoto\n\n10. The initial texts cited J-Alert, a system used by the government to issue warnings to its citizens about missiles, tsunamis and other natural disasters. But NHK later said that the system was not to blame for the false alarm.\n\nMakoto Sasaki, a spokesman for NHK, apologized, saying that \u201cstaff had mistakenly operated the equipment to deliver news alerts over the internet.\u201d\n\nThe broadcaster\u2019s swift rectification of its error stands in contrast to the 38-minute delay by officials in Hawaii on Saturday to cancel warnings of an incoming ballistic missile. The last administration said, this is the contract, take it or leave it,\u201d Mr. Nespoli said. \u201cBut this is a blueprint for how to shut down a union.\u201d\n\nThe union\u2019s lawsuit accuses the city of violating the Taylor Law, which granted public employees collective bargaining rights, known as the Triborough Doctrine. The doctrine says that management must keep the terms of a previous contract in place while a new one is negotiated.\n\nThe carpenters\u2019 union has about 700 members who build and fix things for various city agencies, and they are among about 10,000 members of skilled trade union workers who are governed by the prevailing wage law.\n\nThey have the same protections as other unions, but can petition the city comptroller to set a prevailing wage based on what workers with the same job titles make in the private sector. The comptroller set the prevailing wage in 2015 but the carpenters, who have been without a contract since 2008, and the city could not agree on certain fringe benefits like paid time off.\n\nDuring the carpenters\u2019 last contract from 2005 to 2008, the wage rate was $41.71 an hour in addition to pension benefits, health care and contribution to a welfare fund. The package included 27 vacation days, 12 sick days, 12 holidays, and an annuity contribution of over $7 an hour. That package cost the city approximately $200,000 a person a year, said Robert W. Linn, the city\u2019s labor relations commissioner.", "title": "De Blasio, a Pro-Labor Mayor, Is Sued Over Bargaining Tactics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "And while Mr. DeFrancisco is hardly a Kardashian, the senator has been a steady, and often spiky, presence in Albany for a quarter-century, often jabbing Democrats, and some members of his own party, as well as keeping up a lively banter on the Senate floor.\n\nMr. DeFrancisco has indicated he will give up his Senate seat, and his departure gives Democrats another district to target as they try to secure a bulletproof majority in that chamber. (Republicans currently hold power by dint of an arrangement with nine Democrats, including the renegade Independent Democratic Conference.)\n\nRepublicans, predictably, reject that notion.\n\n\u201cWe are absolutely confident that we will win the 50th District Senate seat and grow our majority across the state in November,\u201d said Scott Reif, a spokesman for the Republican Senate majority.\n\nTo win statewide, however, Republican strategists estimate that their candidates need to garner at least 30 percent of the vote in New York City, and reaching that number may be a challenge for anyone, let alone a candidate without ample financial backing.\n\n\u201cIt really comes down to money: Who has the ability to pay for New York City broadcast television?\u201d said William F. O\u2019Reilly, a Republican consultant in New York. \u201cWithout it, it would be very difficult to reach that number in the five boroughs.\u201d\n\nWhile it is a fraction of the governor\u2019s stockpile, Mr. DeFrancisco has nearly $1.5 million in two separate campaign accounts, according to Board of Election records.\n\nNo matter the nominee, it seems that the 2018 race will be sharply divided between downstate \u2014 where the bulk of the voters, and millions of Democrats live \u2014 and upstate, which has been losing population for years, but continues to maintain deep red pockets of political conservatives. Says", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "SEOUL, South Korea \u2014 When President Moon Jae-in took power in South Korea last May, he vowed to make his disaster-prone country a safer place to live. But public skepticism over his ability to deliver has deepened with a string of tragedies in recent weeks, including a hospital fire that killed dozens of people on Friday.\n\nThe fire that engulfed Sejong Hospital in the southern city of Miryang was the deadliest fire in South Korea in a decade. It also came barely a month after another fire killed 29 people in December.\n\nBoth accidents revealed deep flaws in the country\u2019s safety standards, like the lack of fire sprinklers in the hospital, problems that are likely to further erode public confidence in Mr. Moon\u2019s ability to deliver his campaign promises just as the country prepares to host the Winter Olympics.\n\nIn Friday\u2019s fire, the government even had trouble delivering an authoritative death toll, a common problem in South Korean disasters. The local police, fire department and health authorities announced 41 had died, but later revised that number to 37, saying some bodies were counted twice. But they said that the death toll could rise again because more than 100 people had been injured, 10 of them seriously.", "title": "Deadly Fire Undermines South Korean Leader\u2019s Vow to Make Country Safer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "As is the case with many such urban attacks, there was initial confusion about the number of armed assailants. When the operation was declared over after 7 p.m., Mr. Khogyani said five had been involved and all were dead.\n\nMr. Khogyani said the victims included three Save the Children employees, one tailor across the street from the office and an Afghan commando; 24 others were wounded.\n\n\u201cWe could have ended the operation in the morning and killed all the attackers, but there were more than 45 civilians and employees trapped inside,\u201d said Mohammed Gulab Mangal, the province\u2019s governor. \u201cAll those employees were rescued to safety.\u201d\n\nBahadur Mushfiq, who works for Save the Children in Jalalabad, was among those trapped for hours inside in the office\u2019s safe room.\n\n\u201cWe heard a boom, and the gate of our office was blown away,\u201d he said. \u201cI don\u2019t know the number of people who entered our office, but they had grenades and climbed upstairs.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAbout 40 or 50 people were trapped in the room, he said, \u201cbut all of us got out safely except two people were slightly wounded.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOfficials said that the Jalalabad office of Save the Children shared a wall with another aid organization, the Swedish Committee for Afghanistan, and that the Swedish group\u2019s staff had been evacuated.\n\nThere are at least two schools in the area. There were also arrests in provincial towns.\n\nMr. Rouhani has urged demonstrators to avoid violence but defended their right to protest. He did so again on Monday on Twitter.\n\n\u201cPeople want to talk about economic problems, corruption and lack of transparency in the function of some of the organs and want the atmosphere to be more open,\u201d he wrote. \u201cThe requests and demands of the people should be taken note of.\u201d\n\nPresident Trump weighed in on Twitter on Monday, saying that the Iranian people \u201chave been repressed for many years.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey are hungry for food & for freedom,\u201d Mr. Trump wrote. \u201cAlong with human rights, the wealth of Iran is being looted. TIME FOR CHANGE!\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe protests are not just the largest in Iran since 2009. They also suggest a rejiggering of some traditional divisions.\n\nPeople who live in rural provinces, long viewed as supporters of the authorities, are now leading most of the demonstrations. And while people in Tehran have also taken to the street, the capital is not the center of the protests, as it was during the so-called Green Movement in 2009. In Tehran, many middle-class Iranians share the discontent but also fear insecurity.\n\nThe frustrations that led to the protests also appear different from the sentiments in 2009.\n\nThat year, a wave of demonstrations broke out after the contested election of a hard-line president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, and then turned into a wider protest movement against Iran\u2019s leaders.\n\nThis time, it is the failure of President Rouhani, a moderate, to deliver greater political changes and economic opportunity, despite the lifting of some of the sanctions against Iran as part of the nuclear deal. Young people are especially angry. The average age of those arrested is under 25, one official said.\n\nThe poor economy especially affects Iran\u2019s young people \u2014 more than 50 percent of the population is under 30, according to official statistics. Officially, youth unemployment is near 20 percent, but experts say it is really closer to 40 percent.\n\nWhen the protests started last Thursday in the city of Mashhad, demonstrators chanted slogans about the weak economy.\n\nBut as the protests spread, they have taken on a far more political cast. Increasingly, they are being directed at Iran\u2019s entire political establishment. Some demonstrators have even called for the death of Mr. Rouhani and of the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe strength and volatility of the protests have caught Iranian politicians by surprise. Some have denounced them as \u201criots,\u201d while others have acknowledged that the widespread frustrations at their root can no longer be ignored.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Monday in Tehran, the atmosphere was tense and security forces were out in large numbers. Protests occurred sporadically, with people shouting slogans and leaving. The day before, protesters in provincial towns tried to storm police stations, military and installations, and also attacked a seminary, state television reported, showing footage of burned cars and fires.\n\nProtests have taken place in at least half a dozen cities, including Karaj, Qazvin, Qaemshahr, Dorud and Tuyserkan, it said.\n\nAccess to the Telegram messaging app and the Instagram photo and video sharing app continued to be blocked by the authorities, cutting off the main communication tool for protesters. Special software used to circumvent the government filters could still be downloaded easily. And on Monday, as on other days, there were calls for protests online and on foreign-based Persian-language satellite channels.\n\nSome residents said they were determined to continue the demonstrations, and several hundred gathered at central squares.\n\nWhile the number of protesters in Tehran was small on Monday, the discontent was widespread. Many people on the streets complained about high prices, corruption and lack of change.\n\n\u201cWe need to improve our economy, and the people\u2019s voices must be heard,\u201d said a 28-year-old woman, a piano teacher in Tehran, who asked not to be named out of fear of repercussions. \u201cI\u2019ll go out tonight again.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nMany youths in larger cities enthusiastically voted for Mr. Rouhani when he was re-elected in May, raising expectations among many in the reform camp. But since then even many of the president\u2019s supporters say he has failed to fulfill his promises for improving an economy sorely hobbled by years of sanctions, corruption and mismanagement.\n\nEven the lifting of economic sanctions under Iran\u2019s 2015 nuclear deal with large foreign powers including the United States has not unleashed the growth Mr. Rouhani had hoped for, as key sectors of the economy remain under the thumb of obscure powers, including religious foundations and the country\u2019s Revolutionary Guards. There is mismanagement and widespread corruption in all levels of the state apparatus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBeyond that, the United States has continued other sanctions, making it still harder for Mr. Rouhani to make gains.\n\nThe economic frustrations do not appear to have been offset by the greater social freedoms that the president has granted young people. Under Mr. Rouhani, strict Islamic rules have been somewhat relaxed. Concerts have been allowed, and the morals police are largely off the streets. Illegal parties are usually no longer raided, although there have been exceptions.\n\nBut there is a wide gap between Iran\u2019s changing and modernizing society and Iranian leaders who insist on keeping up their anti-Western policies and the state interpretation of Islam.\n\nMr. Rouhani\u2019s decision not to include any women in his cabinet and his failure to put the relaxation of the rules into law have made many bitter.\n\nThe president has complained that power centers dominated by hard-liners have blocked many of his plans and decisions. Now some protesters are venting their frustrations at the political and clerical establishment.\n\nIn Takestan, west of Tehran, several people were arrested after attacking a seminary, the Iranian news media reported. In Karaj, also close to Tehran, a gas station was burned, a witness reported.\n\nEarlier on Monday, ILNA quoted Hedayatollah Khademi, a representative for the town of Izeh, in Iran\u2019s oil-rich but poor Khuzestan region, as saying two people had died there on Sunday night. He said the cause of death was not immediately known.\n\nState television announced that 10 people had died on Sunday, but did not provide a location. \u201cSome armed protesters tried to take over some police stations and military bases but faced serious resistance from security forces,\u201d a presenter said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIllegal protests continued last night in several cities with less protesters participating, but they were as violent and turbulent, making residents of these cities concerned about their and their businesses\u2019 security,\u201d the state television report said.\n\nThe videos showed burned cars, fires and wreckage on the pavement. The report also showed a fire-brigade vehicle that was said to have been seized by protesters in Dorud, Lorestan Province.\n\nBy Monday evening, riot police officers belonging to the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps waited in an alley near Tehran\u2019s city theater for a potential protest to start, as men and women anxiously walked the sidewalks. Others, families and couples, cruised around the area in cars. Many were young people.\n\n\u201cThey want to start, but there is too many police,\u201d one taxi driver said, looking at hundreds of people, and even more security forces. Plainclothes officers on motorcycles zipped by. Buses stood ready to take potential troublemakers into custody.", "title": "Deadly Iran Protests Prompt Warning of Harsher Response", "authors": ["Thomas Erdbrink"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "In June, he and a small group commandeered a helicopter in the capital, Caracas. They used it to drop grenades onto the Supreme Court building and open fire on the Interior Ministry in a brazen midday attack.\n\nMr. P\u00e9rez then unfurled a banner calling on Venezuelans to rebel against Mr. Maduro, to the cheers of protesters below. He later released a video in which he and a masked band repeated their calls of rebellion.\n\nWhile no one was injured in that attack, it was an embarrassment for the government, and it vowed to capture him.\n\nIt also signaled the rise of one of the most improbable figures in Venezuela\u2019s political turmoil last year: a police officer who had once starred in a low-budget action movie about a crime squad. Now, it seemed, he was playing a real-life version of the character he had portrayed.\n\nOn Monday, Venezuelans were glued to the unfolding events on social media. Early in the morning, Mr. Perez announced that his location had been discovered. Then he began releasing a series of videos.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re negotiating with the officials and the prosecutors,\u201d he says calmly into the camera in one of the first messages, appearing in a dark room. Other rebels can be heard in the background shouting into phones.\n\nIn a later video, posted after daybreak, Mr. P\u00e9rez turns the camera outside, where government officials can be seen calling up to him.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not criminals,\u201d he tells them. \u201cWe\u2019re patriots who are fighting for our convictions.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the videos, Mr. P\u00e9rez is heard saying repeatedly that his group will surrender because it is accompanied by civilians. He says they do not want a fight.\n\nBut in a later video, the two sides appear to have stopped talking and begun battle. A rebel in a helmet and flak jacket can be seen taking cover beside a wall while another holds a rifle behind a filing cabinet.\n\n\u201cHold your fire!\u201d someone shouts.\n\nWhile Mr. P\u00e9rez said last year that he had hoped others would take up his call, he has looked increasingly alone in recent months.\n\nAfter appearing in public during an anti-government rally in July, Mr. P\u00e9rez largely disappeared from public view. While some members of the security forces staged rebellions of their own in the time afterward, top military officials stayed loyal to Mr. Maduro\u2019s government. Mr. P\u00e9rez\u2019s abandoned helicopter was found by the government shortly after the June attack.\n\nPerhaps most demoralizing to Mr. P\u00e9rez and his followers was the disbanding of street protests against Mr. Maduro that took place after the president consolidated power by dissolving the opposition-controlled Congress and establishing a new one packed with loyalists.\n\nOn Monday, a video attributed to Mr. P\u00e9rez\u2019s mother was posted on Twitter in which she pleaded with the government to allow him to surrender.\n\nBut the firefight continued.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re throwing grenade after grenade,\u201d he said, his face bloodied as he crouched behind an oven with his rifle. \u201cThey\u2019re shooting at us. Venezuelans: Freedom forever!\u201d\n\nIn one of the last messages, Mr. P\u00e9rez appears exhausted. His face is covered with blood and he is panting. The sounds of gunshots ring in the background.\n\n\u201cThey don\u2019t want us to surrender,\u201d he says.", "title": "Deadly Siege of Venezuela Rebels Led by Former Action Hero Transfixes Country", "authors": ["Nicholas Casey"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nWhat to make of the new roles at Berkshire.\n\nIn naming Greg Abel and Ajit Jain as vice chairmen, the Oracle of Omaha may be further signaling that one of them is likely to succeed him as C.E.O. someday. (Both were also named to the board.)\n\nWho are they?\n\n\u2022 Mr. Abel is the chairman of Berkshire\u2019s energy unit, which earned $2.3 billion in 2016. He\u2019ll be vice chairman for non-insurance businesses.\n\n\u2022 Mr. Jain is the longtime head of Berkshire\u2019s vast reinsurance operations. He will become vice chairman for insurance operations.\n\nIs Mr. Buffett going anytime soon? Probably not. In the news release announcing the appointments, Mr. Buffett and his longtime partner Charlie Munger said that they would remain responsible for big investment decisions.\n\nThe context: Mr. Buffett has already said that his responsibilities would be split into three once he departs. His son Howard will be chairman. The investors Todd Combs and Ted Weschler will be the chief stock pickers. The big question has been who would take over as C.E.O.\n\nThe end of the bond bull market?\n\nYields on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note have risen for five straight days. On Wednesday, they traded above 2.58, their highest level since March, after Bloomberg reported that senior Chinese officials \u201chave recommended slowing or halting purchases of U.S. Treasuries.\u201d\n\nThis rise in yields has again ignited speculation that Treasury prices are set for an extended period of declines. Yields rise when bond prices fall. On Tuesday, Bill Gross of Janus Henderson Group declared a bond bear market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOf course, plenty of investors and market watchers, including on a number of previous occasions Mr. Gross, have called an end to the golden era for bonds over the years. Yet the bond bull market has marched on.\n\nStill, there are plenty of reasons for bond investors to be jittery these days. Central banks around the world are in tightening mode and are stepping back from the bond market. The global economy is gathering momentum and expectations for higher inflation are picking up.\n\nThe current rise has Treasury yields approaching the level that some say would trigger the end of the bond bull market. A year ago, Mr. Gross pegged that level at 2.6 percent, while Jeffrey Gundlach, chief executive of DoubleLine Capital and manager of one of the largest U.S. bond funds, said 3 percent was the line.\n\nCan bitcoin succeed in becoming a real currency?\n\nGoldman Sachs thinks so, at least in theory, but \u201cthe bar looks high.\u201d\n\nThe argument for: \u201cIf it proves capable of facilitating transactions at a low cost and/or providing better risk-adjusted returns for portfolios.\u201d\n\nBut the bar is high: \u201cThe currencies of most developed market economies already deliver these monetary services quite well. And if blockchain technologies go mainstream, as seems likely, the bar will look even higher. That said, Bitcoin (and cryptocurrencies more generally) may offer viable alternatives in countries and corners of the financial system where the traditional services of money are inadequately supplied.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSears again warns it will \u201cconsider all other options\u201d if its turnaround efforts fail.\n\nThe store chain is already considered at risk of filing for bankruptcy, as it struggles to survive a tough market for retailers. This morning, it outlined yet more steps that it\u2019s undertaking to stay afloat.\n\nWhat Sears said it plans to do now\n\n\u2022 The company has already arranged a new $100 million loan backed by ground leases and some intellectual property\n\n\u2022 It is trying to raise an additional $200 million, supported by the same collateral\n\n\u2022 It is trying to secure more than $600 million in a new credit facility, backed by additional property.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Cut some $200 million in costs that aren\u2019t tied to store closures.\n\n\u2022 Potentially close more Sears and Kmart stores.\n\nThese steps, Sears asserted, should help the company return to profitability this year.\n\nThe bad news: Same-store sales for the first two months of the fourth quarter fell about 16 percent. And adjusted losses before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization for the quarter are expected to come in between $10 million and $70 million.\n\nWhat Sears\u2019s chairman, Eddie Lampert, says\n\nFrom a corporate blog post:\n\nWhile these actions have so far helped our company survive the so-called \u201cRetail Apocalypse\u201d, many observers are not persuaded that Sears Holdings can be a viable competitor in the long term. It is obvious that to overcome such skepticism and obtain the support of outside lenders and our vendor community \u2013 which is crucial to the success of any retailer \u2013 we need to undertake further measures.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nA Chinese move that could spook the markets.\n\nFrom Bloomberg, citing unnamed sources:\n\nOfficials reviewing China\u2019s foreign-exchange holdings have recommended slowing or halting purchases of U.S. Treasuries, according to people familiar with the matter. China holds the world\u2019s largest foreign-exchange reserves, at $3.1 trillion, and regularly assesses its strategy for investing them. It isn\u2019t clear whether the recommendations of the officials have been adopted.\n\nFutures in major indexes, including the S. & P. 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average, were down in premarket trading.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat will Trump say in the home of globalism?\n\nHere\u2019s what the president plans to do at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, according to the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders:\n\n\u201cThe president looks forward to promoting his policies to strengthen American businesses, American industries and American workers.\u201d\n\nOther heads of state have promoted a very different message \u2014 including Xi Jinping of China, who defended globalism there last year. As the WSJ editorial board put it, \u201cDavos In, Bannon Out.\u201d (More on the latter later.)\n\nThe context: Only one president, Bill Clinton, has attended the forum in person. (Ronald Reagan spoke via videoconference.) And even some White House advisers suggest that visiting a gathering of world leaders, C.E.O.s, billionaires and celebrities appears to run counter to Mr. Trump\u2019s populist agenda.\n\nA tip for newbie Davos-goers: Plan on walking \u2014 traffic is bad even without a presidential motorcade to snarl it up.\n\nThe globalization flyaround\n\n\u2022 Emmanuel Macron visited China with a gift horse and a defense of global trade. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 British political leaders have made a direct appeal to the German business community to help forge a sympathetic Brexit deal. (Guardian)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The European Union is advising companies to prepare for Britain to become a \u201cthird country\u201d with no automatic right to operate in the single market. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Toyota and Mazda plan to build a $1.6 billion plant in northern Alabama. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nIs this a win for business leaders on immigration?\n\nExhibit A: Mr. Trump appeared ready to support a deal that would eventually give millions of undocumented immigrants a path to citizenship.\n\nExhibit B: A federal judge ruled that the federal program known as DACA, which shields some young immigrants, must be maintained, despite the administration\u2019s decision to end it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Mr. Trump appears unlikely to turn away from the populist stances on trade and parts of immigration policy that Breitbart and Mr. Bannon have championed.\n\nThe Mercer angle\n\nRebekah Mercer, Mr. Bannon\u2019s estranged patron and one of Breitbart\u2019s owners, pledged support to Mr. Trump after controversy erupted over the adviser\u2019s comments, the WSJ reports.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore on Ms. Mercer\u2019s role in Mr. Bannon\u2019s departure from Jeremy Peters of the NYT:\n\nHis situation at Breitbart grew untenable, said one person close to the situation, in part because Ms. Mercer, whose family finances conservative causes with their hedge fund wealth, became concerned that she could face legal exposure.\n\nWhat\u2019s next for Bannon?\n\nHe is reportedly building a new political advocacy group, but it\u2019s not apparent who would want to back him. (He\u2019s also lost his radio show on Sirius XM.)\n\nThe shareholder activism flyaround\n\n\u2022 Activist funds invested $62 billion in campaigns around the world, more than twice the 2016 figure, Lazard\u2019s year-end review found. (Lazard)\n\n\u2022 The internet performance company Akamai Technologies is working with Morgan Stanley to explore \u201cstrategic alternatives,\u201d including a potential sale, amid pressure from Elliott Management, according to unnamed sources. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhy is Kodak getting into virtual currency?\n\nThe official answer: The KodakCoin it has unveiled with WENN Digital will \u201callow photographers and agencies to take greater control in image rights management.\u201d\n\nThe cynical answer: Kodak\u2019s surged 34 percent after it announced a \u201cmajor blockchain initiative.\u201d\n\nCritic\u2019s corner: Tom Buerkle of Breakingviews writes: \u201cA blockchain platform could give photographers a better way to license their images and receive payment. But it\u2019s hard to see how that will reverse Kodak\u2019s decades-long decline.\u201d\n\nThe digital money flyaround\n\n\u2022 China is moving to eradicate Bitcoin mining over concerns about electricity consumption and financial risk. (FT)\n\n\u2022 The value of the virtual currency Ripple has continued to fall, as much as 24 percent over the last day. (Bloomberg)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe workplace misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 About three-quarters of women in jobs related to programming they\u2019ve experienced discrimination in the workplace, the Pew Research Center reports. Among men, it was 16 percent. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "DealBook Briefing: Buffett Succession Plan Gets Clearer", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Match Book,\n\nI am a recently separated university English professor, and an avid reader of poetry, short fiction and novels. I am a sucker for forbidden or unusual romances with strong female characters and equally strong prose. Colleen McCullough\u2019s \u201cThe Thorn Birds,\u201d Reynolds Price\u2019s \u201cBlue Calhoun\u201d and Eimear McBride\u2019s \u201cThe Lesser Bohemians\u201d are right up my alley, as are Samantha Harvey\u2019s \u201cDear Thief,\u201d Rachel Cusk\u2019s \u201cOutline,\u201d \u201cMariette in Ecstasy,\u201d by Ron Hansen, and \u201cThe English Patient,\u201d by Michael Ondaatje. I thought the love scene in the seaside cabin in Jennifer Egan\u2019s \u201cManhattan Beach\u201d was a tour de force in restrained eroticism. Neither Domenico Starnone\u2019s \u201cTies\u201d nor Ali Smith\u2019s \u201cAutumn\u201d gripped me as much as I\u2019d anticipated, and I\u2019ve never been able to get into Gabriel Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez\u2019s \u201cLove in the Time of Cholera,\u201d although perhaps I was too young or too na\u00efve when I tried. Can you recommend some good love stories for a woman recently on her own after 20 years of marriage?\n\nN. SMITH\n\nDENTON, TEX.\n\nDear N.,\n\nAs an English professor, you surely know the thrills of classic romance narratives \u2014 triangles, stolen moments and ill-advised liaisons, among other sublime pleasures \u2014 in books like \u201cWomen in Love,\u201d by D.H. Lawrence, \u201cTheir Eyes Were Watching God,\u201d by Zora Neale Hurston, and \u201cSummer,\u201d by Edith Wharton. These are always ripe for rediscovery and rereading.\n\nShort Stack\n\nAnd then there is the underappreciated art of seduction in short stories. The form\u2019s constraint provides the perfect come-on. Its limits, made for both innuendo and artful elision, align with passionate longing: You fall in love with what isn\u2019t there.\n\nUnsettled passions stir beneath much of the work of the Nobel laureate Alice Munro. In \u201cCarried Away\u201d (from her story collection \u201cOpen Secrets\u201d), a librarian with an affinity for order has her romantic life thrown into disarray by a series of peculiar, haunting encounters. The reverberations of an affair between a young actress and her director in Munro\u2019s \u201cThe Children Stay\u201d (from \u201cThe Love of a Good Woman\u201d) haunt her more than 30 years later.", "title": "Dear Match Book: Forbidden Love", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDear Match Book,\n\nEvery time I read an article about a movie or theater production I wonder what it was like to be part of the behind-the-scenes group that brought it to life. I enjoyed \u201cThe Devil\u2019s Candy,\u201d Julie Salamon\u2019s account of the making of the Brian De Palma-directed adaptation of Tom Wolfe\u2019s novel \u201cThe Bonfire of the Vanities;\u201d and Garson Kanin\u2019s novel \u201cSmash,\u201d about the creation of a fictionalized Broadway show. With both I felt as though I were behind the curtain/camera, or at least the proverbial fly on the wall. Can you recommend any other books, fiction or nonfiction, on that theme? I\u2019m not looking for something technical; I would like the books to be as equally character- and plot-driven as those mentioned above.\n\nBARBARA PROVUS\n\nTUCSON, AZ.\n\nDear Barbara,\n\nThe seductive charms of insider tales \u2014 alluring in books about, say, politics or advertising too \u2014 multiply in stories that feature actual scripted scenes. Facades make fine metaphors, and a constellation of celebrities, real and imagined, gives the stories extra wattage.\n\nThe attraction to glitz isn\u2019t limited to readers. Legions of writers have turned to stage and screen to craft compelling dramas. The writers and books I initially thought to suggest \u2014 Bruce Wagner; Carrie Fisher; Eve Babitz; William Goldman; \u201cThe Kid Stays in the Picture,\u201d by Robert Evans; \u201cThe Player,\u201d by Michael Tolkin \u2014 project a wider view of the glimmer, the glare as well as the lowlights of Hollywood and Broadway. I think you\u2019d like them all. But since you requested books about specific productions, I narrowed the focus of my recommendations accordingly.\n\nPage to Screen\n\nYour affection for \u201cThe Devil\u2019s Candy\u201d suggests to me that you might like \u201cMonster,\u201d by John Gregory Dunne, another fascinating, detailed account of the making of a thorny, star-studded film adapted from a book. Throughout his story, Dunne\u2019s straight-shooting tone comically belies the absurdly twisty tale of writing, along with his wife, Joan Didion, the screenplay for the 1996 movie \u201cUp Close and Personal,\u201d which starred Robert Redford and Michelle Pfeiffer and took eight years to make.", "title": "Dear Match Book: Tales From Behind the Camera?", "authors": ["Nicole Lamy", "Match Book"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Your foundation\u2019s reading list seems like the perfect opportunity to turn the page to 2018 with a more hopeful literary goal in mind: Read books, do good. All the books below share an urgent quality that I think aligns with your mission.\n\nPrisoners\u2019 Dilemmas\n\nTwo books about incarceration would make an eminently discussable pair. In \u201cThe New Jim Crow,\u201d the civil rights lawyer and legal scholar Michelle Alexander makes the case, with arresting clarity, that the biases in law enforcement \u2014 including, most notably, drug-crime sentencing that has led to the dire incarceration rates for black Americans \u2014 have created \u201ca new racial caste system as stunningly comprehensive and repressive as the one that came to be known simply as Jim Crow.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe galvanizing sweep of Alexander\u2019s book contrasts with the intimacy of \u201cReading With Patrick,\u201d Michelle Kuo\u2019s absorbing account of her mentorship and friendship with a gifted, troubled student whom she first met as a Teach for America recruit in Helena, Ark. Readers witness the transformative power of their moving lessons in both literature and life, lessons that endure and deepen in jail after Patrick is arrested on a murder charge.\n\nSpecial Arrangements\n\nGiven your foundation\u2019s philanthropic and literary proclivities, I recommend another book about an arts education program. In \u201cChanging Lives,\u201d Tricia Tunstall outlines the soaring successes of El Sistema, the orchestral music program founded in Venezuela in 1975 that aims to steer children\u2019s lives away from \u201cthe multiple dangers of poverty.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFamily Medicine\n\nCultural clashes between the doctors and parents of Lia Lee, an epileptic girl living with her Laotian Hmong refugee family in central California, are at the heart of Anne Fadiman\u2019s enduring book, \u201cThe Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down.\u201d Lee\u2019s story is tragic, but the compassion Fadiman shows for all figures in her book lightens the dark.\n\nHidden Figures\n\nThe grip of poverty guides two evocative chronicles of life on the margins, geographically disparate though their communities may be. Adrian Nicole LeBlanc spent more than a decade reporting her immersive saga, \u201cRandom Family,\u201d about the bleak and beautiful experiences of a network of kin in the Bronx. In \u201cBehind the Beautiful Forevers,\u201d Katherine Boo focused for nearly three and half years on Annawadi, a \u201csumpy plug of slum\u201d in Mumbai. The result is an artfully constructed account of the privation that persists alongside the surge of prosperity brought to India by globalization. Both books share a bracing lack of sentimentality, as well as a carefully wrought humanity; both will make you want to change the world.\n\nYours truly,\n\nMatch Book\n\nDo you need book recommendations? Write to matchbook@nytimes.com.\n\nCheck out Match Book\u2019s earlier recommendations here.", "title": "Dear Match Book: We Want to Change the World", "authors": ["Nicole Lamy", "Match Book"]} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Seven years later, a white juror, Barney Gattie, signed an affidavit explaining his reasoning. He said he had drawn a distinction between Mr. Tharpe and his victim, both of whom were black.\n\n\u201cThe Freemans are what I would call a nice Black family,\u201d Mr. Gattie wrote. \u201cIn my experience I have observed that there are two types of black people. 1. Black folks and 2. Niggers.\u201d\n\n\u201cBecause I knew the victim and her husband\u2019s family and knew them all to be good black folks, I felt Tharpe, who wasn\u2019t in the \u2018good\u2019 black folks category in my book, should get the electric chair for what he did,\u201d Mr. Gattie wrote.\n\n\u201cAfter studying the Bible,\u201d he added, \u201cI have wondered if black people even have souls.\u201d\n\nMr. Tharpe sought to reopen his case based on the affidavit, but state and federal courts ruled against him. The United States Court of Appeals of the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, stated that \u201cTharpe failed to demonstrate that Barney Gattie\u2019s behavior \u2018had substantial and injurious effect or influence in determining the jury\u2019s verdict,\u2019 \u201d quoting a Supreme Court decision.\n\nThe majority opinion on Monday said the appeals court should reconsider its decision not to hear Mr. Tharpe\u2019s appeal. \u201cGattie\u2019s remarkable affidavit \u2014 which he never retracted \u2014 presents a strong factual basis for the argument that Tharpe\u2019s race affected Gattie\u2019s vote for a death verdict,\u201d the opinion said.\n\nIn a similar case decided in March, Pe\u00f1a Rodriguez v. Colorado, the Supreme Court ruled that courts must make an exception to the usual rule that jury deliberations are secret when evidence emerges that those discussions were marred by racial or ethnic bias.", "title": "Death Penalty Case Heard by Racist Juror Is Reopened by Supreme Court", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Sherman, whose name was Bernard but who was known as Barry, had been so successful building the country\u2019s biggest Canadian-owned pharmaceutical company, Apotex, that Canadian Business Magazine listed him as the country\u2019s 15th-richest person, with a personal net worth of 4.77 billion Canadian dollars.\n\nHe had a reputation as a brilliant scientist, renowned workaholic and shrewd and combative businessman who filed hundreds of lawsuits aimed at opening the market to his generic versions of drugs. He was also known for \u201cat-risk launches\u201d of generic drugs, flooding the market before litigation concluded. He was 75, but showed no signs of tiring.\n\nHis personal life had been dragged into court in a lawsuit filed in 2006 by his cousins, who claimed they were owed part of the company\u2019s assets. An Ontario court threw out the case in September as \u201cwishful thinking, and beyond fanciful.\u201d\n\nMrs. Sherman, 70, was known as a bubbly and vivacious volunteer. Born in a displaced persons camp to two Holocaust victims, she was passionate about Holocaust education and spent much of her time volunteering and serving on numerous boards, including those of a university and a hospital.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe couple had four children and gave millions to charity.\n\nBut while they were well known in political circles and in the country\u2019s Jewish community, the Shermans were not household names across the country \u2014 until their dramatic deaths.\n\nMore than 6,000 people, including Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, attended their funeral, which was livestreamed. Ontario Premier Kathleen Wynne and Toronto Mayor John Tory delivered eulogies.\n\nIn their often-raw public reflections, the couple\u2019s family and friends described how loving the couple was and how, despite their billions, they remained down to earth and quirky. Mr. Sherman had a penchant for correcting others\u2019 grammar, and Mrs. Sherman loved cooking for large family gatherings while dressed in flip-flops and cow shirts.\n\nThe shock, horror and mystery of their violent deaths hung over the ceremony.\n\n\u201cOur parents never left anyone behind,\u201d said the couple\u2019s son Jonathan, wiping his face with a tissue. \u201cThey were taken from us.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe police announcement on Friday gave the Shermans\u2019 family and friends a sense of vindication.\n\n\u201cThis conclusion was expressed by the family from the outset and is consistent with the findings of the independent autopsy and investigation,\u201d the family said in a statement.\n\nFred Waks, a real estate developer and close friend of the Shermans who spoke at their funeral, said in an interview that \u201cthe police have finally come to the same place we\u2019ve all been since the murders.\u201d He added, \u201cAnybody who knew Barry and Honey, it was not possible this was a murder-suicide.\u201d\n\nHowever, the authorities have come no closer to understanding who killed the Shermans and why.\n\nThe police still have no suspects, Detective Sgt. Gomes said, despite six weeks of combing the couple\u2019s grand home in the city\u2019s north end, serving 20 search warrants, taking 127 witness statements and gathering around 2,000 hours of security videos from nearby homes and businesses.\n\nInvestigators found no signs of forced entry to the couple\u2019s home, Detective Sgt. Gomes said. While she confirmed earlier news reports that the two were found in semi-seated positions and were dressed, she would not comment on a theory raised in a local news investigation that the private autopsy showed marks on both their wrists, indicating they were bound together at some point.", "title": "Deaths of Billionaire Toronto Couple Were Homicides, Police Say", "authors": ["Catherine Porter"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "But the dispute among the president\u2019s defenders about the vulgarity he actually used did nothing to allay critics. \u201cI think it\u2019s all the same,\u201d said Representative Cedric L. Richmond, Democrat of Louisiana and the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, which Mr. Trump also mentioned dismissively during the Oval Office meeting, according to one participant.\n\n\u201cThe words don\u2019t matter,\u201d Mr. Richmond said. \u201cThe words just cement his sentiment that the people in those countries are less worthy, and he would like people from different countries. He chose the black countries to say he didn\u2019t want those people and one of the whitest countries to say he did want them. I think that\u2019s telling.\u201d\n\nAsked if he saw any difference between the two words, Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, the only black Republican in the chamber, was equally dismissive: \u201cNo,\u201d he said.\n\nAides to Mr. Trump, and allies of the administration, readily acknowledged that the president sprinkles most private interactions with profanity and rolled their eyes at suggestions that previous presidents did not use such language. They saw his main offense as using it in front of a Democrat \u2014 Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, who was in last week\u2019s meeting and on Tuesday again questioned the president\u2019s defenders about the word they said was used.\n\n\u201cI can tell you explicitly they are wrong,\u201d Mr. Durbin said in a CNN interview about the reports to the contrary. \u201cAnd let me also say, is that their defense?\u201d\n\nThe \u201cRashomon\u201d-like perspectives that have come to define most group meetings with the president gave his aides something to seize on to muddy the issue. But after an initial nonresponse on Thursday, the day of the meeting \u2014 most White House aides were at a party for a departing National Security Council official, Dina H. Powell \u2014 the aides swung into action long after the story could be contained, a fact that aggravated Mr. Trump\u2019s allies outside the building.\n\nThere were reports that the White House might have pressured senators to say that they heard something different. But just a few hours after the first reports of what Mr. Trump had said, Rich Lowry, of the conservative magazine National Review, said on CNN that he had been told the word was in fact \u201cshithouse,\u201d although people heard it differently because the other obscenity is more commonly used.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne person familiar with an account of the meeting from Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, who was there, said that the president did not use either word repeatedly, and that the context was his opposition to the type of immigration system that Mr. Durbin and Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, seemed to be promoting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAny harsh language was not specific to predominantly black nations, according to Mr. Cotton\u2019s account, and Mr. Durbin never spoke up in protest during the meeting.\n\nBut there is no doubt that one person at the meeting who did was Mr. Graham.\n\nMr. Graham, who was there with Mr. Durbin in support of their immigration plan, challenged Mr. Trump after the president lamented that there were not more Norwegians or Asians seeking to emigrate to America, although precisely when he did it was not quite clear.\n\nVideo\n\nIn an interview, Mr. Graham said that he responded to Mr. Trump\u2019s complaints about Norwegians not migrating to America.\n\n\u201cThe conversation was going down the wrong road, I thought,\u201d he said. \u201cHere\u2019s how I started, I said, \u2018If you\u2019re from Norway, Mr. President, you\u2019re a Norwegian.\u2019 But if you\u2019re from America what are you? It\u2019s not an ethnic group, it\u2019s not a religion \u2014 it\u2019s an ideal. You can\u2019t tell Americans by the way they look. People from all over the world want to be part of this ideal. And that diversity is our strength not our weakness.\u201d\n\nTestifying under oath before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday, Kirstjen Nielsen, the homeland security secretary, effectively confirmed that Mr. Graham had confronted Mr. Trump, a remarkable concession from one of the president\u2019s own appointees.\n\n\u201cSenator Graham gave an impassioned speech on what he believes are the American ideals,\u201d Ms. Nielsen said during questioning with Democrats on the panel.\n\nNotably, Ms. Nielsen refused to go as far as denying Mr. Durbin\u2019s account, which Mr. Cotton and Senator David Perdue, Republican of Georgia, effectively did on television on Sunday.\n\nShe insisted she had not heard Mr. Trump use either word but did not flatly deny that he had, even allowing that he had used \u201ctough language.\u201d\n\n\u201cAnything is possible,\u201d Ms. Nielsen told Senator Amy Klobuchar, Democrat of Minnesota, when she asked if Mr. Trump had used one of the words.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd how about the other, Ms. Klobuchar asked?\n\n\u201cAgain, it\u2019s possible,\u201d Ms. Nielsen responded.", "title": "Debate Continues Over What Trump Said. But Does the Exact Word Matter?", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Jonathan Martin"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDebra Messing and Eva Longoria used their red-carpet interviews on E! to side with Catt Sadler, the former E! host who left the network in December because she said her male colleague, Jason Kennedy, was paid twice as much.\n\n\u201cI was so shocked to hear that E! doesn\u2019t believe in paying their female co-host the same as their male co-host,\u201d Ms. Messing, an actress on NBC\u2019s \u201cWill & Grace,\u201d said on live television to the E! commentator Giuliana Rancic. \u201cI miss Catt Sadler, so we stand with her. The resulting tsunami killed nearly 230,000 people in 14 countries, making it one of the deadliest natural disasters in history. And it occurred during a full moon.\n\nThe Sumatra earthquake isn\u2019t the only large earthquake to have occurred beneath the moon\u2019s bright glare. Both the earthquake that devastated Chile in 2010 and the Great Alaskan Earthquake in 1964 also happened on a conspicuous lunar date \u2014 making it tempting to argue that more large earthquakes occur during the full moon.\n\nBut a new study published in Seismological Research Letters finds that the connection is nothing but folklore.", "title": "Debunking the Myth That Earthquakes and Full Moons Are Linked", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "1\n\n$7,590,000 77 Old Colony Road Toronto, Ontario, Canada An opulent six-bedroom, six-bath gated estate with more than 9,165 square feet of living space was the most popular listing in December. Broker Wish Sotheby\u2019s International Realty\n\n5", "title": "December\u2019s Most Popular Listings", "authors": ["Michael Kolomatsky"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Cathleen Decker of The Los Angeles Times put it this way: \u201cIn all the anger coming from liberal Dem groups today,\u201d she wrote that she had \u201cyet to see a scenario under which a longer shutdown would have resulted in a more positive outcome from their point of view.\u201d\n\nThe second reason to be skeptical of the critics is that their big assumption depends on the belief that a long shutdown would have put more political pressure on the Republicans and Democrats. As evidence, the critics cite polls showing that most voters believe the Dreamers deserve to remain in this country.\n\nOf course, polls also showed Obamacare to be unpopular in 2013. More important, recent polls showed that most voters didn\u2019t believe the government should be shut down over the Dreamers. Most polls also showed support for the Democrats slipping as the debate dragged on. And as I explained in my column yesterday, there is abundant evidence that a prolonged debate over illegal immigration helps Republicans, not Democrats.\n\nIn the end, I think a long shutdown was more likely to hurt the Dreamers than to help them. Congress would not have passed a law to protect them before reopening the government, and the Dreamers\u2019 allies in Congress \u2014 the Democrats \u2014 would be in a weaker position than they are now.\n\nThat said, the critics\u2019 disappointment stems from a profoundly decent instinct. They\u2019re worried about Dreamers being ripped from their lives in this country. I share the worry \u2014 and the anger at Republican leaders who refuse to solve this problem.\n\nBut it\u2019s just not the case that a minority party can force the majority party to do what it wants if only it summons enough righteous anger. It never has been. It\u2019s another version of the Green Lantern Theory of politics \u2014 that if you care enough and try hard enough, you can do anything.\n\nThe best hope for the Dreamers was not a shutdown that was somehow supposed to end differently from every other recent shutdown. The best hope, first, is to see if there is a solution over the next few weeks, away from the chaos and heat of a shuttered federal government.\n\nIf that doesn\u2019t work, there is only one reliable way to change a policy that the majority party won\u2019t change: Turn that party into the minority party.", "title": "Opinion | Deep Breath: The Democrats Did Just Fine", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Weather forecasts suggested the chill would stick for a while. As of Wednesday, a \u201cpowerful nor\u2019easter\u201d was bearing down on the East Coast, most likely bringing snow, ice, rain and strong winds, according to the National Weather Service. Some forecasters spoke of a potential \u201cbomb cyclone\u201d off the New England coast \u2014 essentially, a storm that could feel like a winter hurricane.\n\nThe impending snow and ice were expected to deplete road department salt supplies. In New Jersey, the Department of Transportation had used 104,000 tons of South American salt, 254,000 gallons of liquid calcium and 564,000 gallons of brine to clear roads as of Dec. 31. By the same point last winter, the agency had used less than half that in salt and liquid calcium and just over half in brine.\n\nPhoto\n\nHouseholds were paying more to cope with the plunging temperatures. The cost of residential heating oil at the end of December surged 13 percent, to $2.92 a gallon, compared with the same period in 2016, according to federal data; prices in Connecticut and Rhode Island exceeding $3 a gallon.\n\nConsumers were in a \u201cpanic,\u201d said John Cardinale, president of Pilgrim Oil Group, a sort of energy co-op that contracts with dozens of heating-oil providers along the Eastern Seaboard. On a normal winter day, Mr. Cardinale said, the Pilgrim network might get 250 calls from homeowners seeking heating oil. On Tuesday, he said, more than 700 calls came in.\n\n\u201cYou feel bad for people \u2014 this cold snap caught everyone off guard,\u201d he said. \u201cThey\u2019ve called almost every other company, and anyone we can help, we\u2019re helping, but we\u2019re so booked ourselves.\u201d\n\nFarther south, thousands of Duke Energy customers in North and South Carolina were without power for parts of the week, according to the utility\u2019s online outage tracker. The South Carolina Electric & Gas Company appealed to customers to scale back their energy use as a precautionary measure \u201cas extreme cold temperatures in the area put a strain on the company\u2019s electricity system.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nFor utilities, the shale-drilling boom of recent years made natural gas a primary fuel for generating electricity, as prices dropped and supplies grew. But a limited network of pipelines and an increase in exports has squeezed supplies in some parts of the country.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithdrawals from natural gas inventory in the last week of 2017 likely reached 219 billion cubic feet, nearly three times the amount taken out a year ago and more than double the five-year average, according to projections by analysts surveyed by S&P Global Platts, an energy-analytics provider.\n\nThe roaring demand for the natural gas is driving prices higher than the standard seasonal bump, analysts said. Other fossil fuels are becoming more attractive by comparison.\n\nISO New England said coal and oil had helped generate nearly 35 percent of the power provided by generators in the region as of Wednesday, with natural gas generating 24 percent. In the past, natural gas has typically accounted for nearly half of the area\u2019s electricity, followed by nuclear power, hydroelectric and other renewables; coal and oil together were responsible for less than 3 percent.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cThe mix is changing with this cold weather,\u201d said Jacob Kilstein, an analyst with Argus Research, an investment research firm. \u201cBecause natural gas prices are rising, coal and oil are reaching in to take its place.\u201d\n\nPJM Interconnection, which oversees the Mid-Atlantic grid, estimated that demand for electricity would reach 135,787 megawatts on Wednesday, nearing its record winter load of 143,129 megawatts, which was recorded in February 2015.\n\nThe icy weather is taxing oil supplies to the hilt, Ms. Blomberg, the ISO spokeswoman, said.\n\nInventories of commercial crude oil slid in recent weeks, falling by more than 50 million barrels year over year in late December, according to federal data. When used to generate power, crude oil is also subject to air emissions caps set by environmental regulations.\n\n\u201cAs oil inventories are depleted, replenishment of these fuels will be important given the uncertainty around weather and future fuel demands for the remaining two months of the winter period,\u201d Ms. Blomberg wrote in an email.\n\nThe price of gasoline, which is used in generators as well as in vehicles, rose in 41 states over the past week, according to GasBuddy.com. The $2.49-a-gallon price was the highest for the start of a new year since 2014.\n\nThe home-supply chain Lowe\u2019s is redistributing products such as pellet fuel, firewood, rock salt and snow shovels from distribution centers in warmer parts of the country to warehouses and stores in the Northeast, said Jennifer Popis, a spokeswoman for the company.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe demand for heating products in particular, she said, was \u201cincredibly strong.\u201d", "title": "Deep Freeze in U.S. Creates Heating Squeeze for Homeowners and Utilities", "authors": ["Tiffany Hsu"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "The detention of the Islamic State fighters is just one issue the United States is grappling with in its partnership with Syrian Kurds. American troops have fought alongside Kurdish-led militias on battlegrounds against the Islamic State in northeast Syria, and the Pentagon is showing no sign of backing away from them. At the same time, however, Washington is trying to tamp down escalating tensions in Syria between the Kurdish militias and Turkey, a longtime NATO ally that views the Kurds as a terrorist threat.\n\nUnited States Special Operations troops advising the Kurdish-led militia known as the Syrian Democratic Forces are cataloging fingerprints and other so-called biometrics of many of the estimated 200 to 300 detainees in at least three camps near Raqqa. The American forces also are interrogating the detainees to learn more about foreign fighter networks and threats to their home countries.\n\nBut American military officials see parallels with the Iraq war, in which militants, including Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the current leader of the Islamic State, were held for years at Camp Bucca, a sprawling American detention facility on the Kuwaiti border where they became more radicalized.\n\n\u201cClearly, we\u2019ve seen what happens when you have a group of highly trained, terrorist fighters held in detention for a long time,\u201d Col. Ryan Dillon, a spokesman for the American-led military coalition in Baghdad, said in a telephone interview. \u201cWe don\u2019t want to see that, and it\u2019s something we\u2019re addressing.\u201d\n\nIf so, the initial efforts appear tentative.\n\nThe Trump administration has quietly established an interagency working group, including officials from the State, Defense and Justice Departments, to help the Syrian Kurds deal with the problem. It\u2019s just realistic.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRoseanne,\u201d which went off the air in 1997, centered on a working-class family, a novelty for television at the time, and delivered big ratings and good reviews. The revival will bring back much of the original cast \u2014 including Sara Gilbert, John Goodman and Laurie Metcalf \u2014 and producers for the show said this was the perfect time to bring back a working-class comedy.", "title": "Defending Trump, Roseanne Wants Her Show to Be \u2018Realistic\u2019", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Delta Air Lines said on Friday that it was tightening its rules for transporting service and support animals in an effort to reduce misbehavior by dogs and other creatures that air carriers are required by law to allow on board.\n\nService dogs are specially trained to aid people with disabilities. Emotional support animals provide comfort and companionship to their owners and do not require coaching.\n\nDelta, which carries nearly 250,000 such animals a year, said that starting March 1, it would require documentation about their health and, in some instances, a promise of good conduct. The new rules make Delta\u2019s policy among the most demanding among major carriers.\n\nThe number of service and support animals, which federal regulations say must fly at no cost and uncaged, with some exceptions, has surged 150 percent on Delta planes since 2015. Customers, the airline said in announcing the move, had \u201cattempted to fly with comfort turkeys, gliding possums known as sugar gliders, snakes, spiders and more.\u201d", "title": "Delta Air Lines Tightens Rules for Service and Support Animals", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "At the center of \u201cGorilla and the Bird\u201d is a beautiful and profoundly affecting portrait of the Bird, McDermott\u2019s mother \u2014 a woman as real, raw and obstinate in her love for the Gorilla as he is in his love for her. Visiting McDermott in the psych ward, he writes, \u201cshe\u2019d flash photos she\u2019d brought with her of me looking \u2018normal.\u2019 To humanize me \u2014 to let them know not to discard this one. He is loved. He\u2019s coming back. Help him.\u201d\n\nWith deceptive effortlessness, this book carries the reader through both the peculiar twists and turns of a bipolar mind, and over some complex, shifting terrain in ethics and American life.\n\nTHE GLASS EYE\n\nA Memoir\n\nBy Jeannie Vanasco\n\n277 pp. Tin House. Paper, $15.95.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis carefully drawn, lyrical debut approaches memoir from another angle. It\u2019s a style choice that has become increasingly popular in the past decade, as, not coincidentally, M.F.A. programs have churned out a growing number of creative nonfiction writers whose work shuns traditional narrative structures and centers itself at the intersection of poetry and prose.\n\nVanasco\u2019s training and gifts as a poet are clear; the language, rhythms and density of her prose make for a hypnotic reading experience as she pieces together the shards of memory that make up a continuous narrative arc of the self.\n\nWhile, again, the through-line of this memoir is the story of the narrator\u2019s diagnosis of bipolar disorder, \u201cThe Glass Eye\u201d is also a haunting exploration of perception, memory and the complexities of grief. In language that is understated and economical, Vanasco brings to life the father she loved with an almost frightening force, and the dizzying collapse of reality she experienced in the wake of his death.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nVanasco\u2019s characters and settings are vivid, prismatic and surreal. The narrator observes the world of her childhood through this kaleidoscopic lens to enormously powerful effect; the shifts in perspective from that of a child to that of the narrating adult are seamless, lending the reader a sense that he too is as caught between equally viable realities, suspended in what the writer Scott Russell Sanders refers to as \u201cthe perennial present of memory.\u201d\n\nIn the latter third of \u201cThe Glass Eye,\u201d Vanasco draws too much attention to the writerly process of constructing the book. The array of metaphor and image becomes cluttered; the structural precision she has so far sustained slips slightly; and the narrative threads of memory, father and grief get lost, as Vanasco tries to force this strange and lovely lyrical work toward a closure that it doesn\u2019t need. But this promising author more than makes up for it with her singularity of vision.\n\nMENTAL\n\nLithium, Love, and Losing My Mind\n\nBy Jaime Lowe\n\n320 pp. Blue Rider. $28.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn \u201cMental: Lithium, Love, and Losing My Mind,\u201d Lowe\u2019s skills as a rock journalist are on full display \u2014 her writing is fast-paced, glossy and chock-full of New York names. This story too follows the onset, diagnosis and treatment of the author\u2019s bipolar disorder, but the book\u2019s stated aim \u2014 to be both memoir and journalistic exploration of the history and uses of lithium \u2014 is never realized. The result is a memoir that seems bent on dodging the usual memoir clich\u00e9s, but in doing so, overcorrects, falling prey to the solipsism it tries to avoid. There is very little in the way of scene or reflection, and this absence robs the book of both narrative pull and any emotionally revelatory power.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe research-driven passages feel like Wikipedia entries, summary and brief; additionally, there are a number of points at which the reader would welcome supporting evidence for the author\u2019s sometimes overly broad claims, such as the assertion that lithium is \u201cusually the first medication tried with bipolar patients\u201d and is \u201ceffective for most of them,\u201d both statements difficult to prove. The narrator herself stops taking lithium when it causes kidney damage, prompting a personal quest in which she travels to the world\u2019s natural lithium sources; however, this more concerted investigation of the element and its uses doesn\u2019t begin until more than two-thirds of the way through the book.\n\nWhile authors are rarely responsible for the design, title or marketing copy of their books, \u201cMental\u201d promises to delve into both personal experience and substantive research. Instead, the book \u2014 which is filled with photographs of the author, clip art and too-clever chapter titles \u2014 reads more like a rock bio than a memoir or a work of serious journalism. Coupled with misleading language, inadequate sourcing and a shaky sense of its own intentions, \u201cMental\u201d never adds up to more than the sum of its parts.", "title": "Delving Into the Bipolar Mind", "authors": ["Marya Hornbacher"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "The protesters, who included many middle-aged and older citizens, held up banners and chanted the march\u2019s main theme \u2014 \u201cProtect Hong Kong\u201d \u2014 during a walk of several miles to the city\u2019s government headquarters.\n\nOthers denounced a move by China last week that said part of a high-speed railway station being built in Hong Kong would be regarded as mainland territory governed by mainland laws.\n\n\u201cWe are here to tell the government that we will not give up,\u201d said Joshua Wong, one of the democracy activists jailed last year, who is now out on bail pending an appeal.\n\n\u201cWe have encountered many difficulties last year, including some of us being sued and jailed, but we will stand with Hong Kong people,\u201d Mr. Wong said. \u201cWe will fight for the rule of law, fight for Hong Kong, fight for the future, fight for the next generations.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo protesters who dressed up as People\u2019s Liberation Army soldiers said they were concerned about the reach of China\u2019s security apparatus. Others called for full democracy as the only lasting means to safeguard the city\u2019s way of life.\n\nThe organizers of the march said about 10,000 people had showed up. The police, however, put the figure at 6,200.\n\nThe demonstration was largely peaceful, though some protesters who later tried to gather in a square near the government\u2019s headquarters skirmished briefly with security guards.\n\nThe so-called Civic Square was where the 2014 pro-democracy protests first kicked off, when a group of protesters climbed over a fence and faced off with local police officers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDespite the defiance on show, some said they feared that Hong Kong would continue to be squeezed by Beijing.\n\n\u201cEveryone\u2019s doing what they can,\u201d said Andy Lau, who was among the marchers. \u201cIf we have the right to demonstrate then we should.
