And Ms. O\u2019Connell had started her job only last May.", "title": "Democratic National Committee\u2019s Chief Executive Quits", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe American people deserve the opportunity to see what he said and judge for themselves,\u201d she said. \u201cThe innuendo and misinformation circulating about the transcript are part of a deeply troubling effort to undermine the investigation into potential collusion and obstruction of justice. The only way to set the record straight is to make the transcript public.\u201d\n\nFor Ms. Feinstein and Mr. Grassley, two senior senators who worked closely last summer to initiate a joint Russia investigation, the breach was striking. But it reflects the growing divide between the two parties.\n\nRepublicans have repeatedly and vocally raised concerns that the dossier \u2014 a set of reports paid for by Democrats \u2014 could have been mishandled by the F.B.I. as it was opening its own investigation into the Russian effort and the Trump campaign. Democrats say scrutiny of the dossier\u2019s provenance is a distraction from the central question: Did the Trump campaign knowingly seek aid from Russia?\n\nDemocrats were still seething on Tuesday at the decision by Mr. Grassley and another Republican on the panel, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, to issue a criminal referral last week for Mr. Steele. The senators said they had reason to believe Mr. Steele had lied to federal authorities about his contacts with the media and urged the Justice Department to investigate.\n\nA spokesman for Mr. Grassley said Ms. Feinstein\u2019s decision was \u201ctotally confounding.\u201d\n\n\u201cHer action undermines the integrity of the committee\u2019s oversight work and jeopardizes its ability to secure candid voluntary testimony,\u201d the spokesman, Taylor Foy, said.\n\nMr. Simpson said he hired Mr. Steele in the late spring of 2016, and the former spy grew alarmed soon after getting to work. With Mr. Simpson\u2019s blessing, he reached out to an old contact at the F.B.I. in early July.\n\n\u201cTo me, it was like, you know, you\u2019re driving to work and you see something happen, and you call 911,\u201d Mr. Simpson said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCurrent and former American and foreign officials with direct knowledge of the investigation say that the federal inquiry did not start with Mr. Steele\u2019s dossier, early parts of which did not reach counterintelligence investigators at the F.B.I. until August, after the bureau\u2019s inquiry had already begun. But the officials have said that the dossier added material and buttressed what American law enforcement and spy agencies were gleaning from other sources.\n\nAccording to Mr. Simpson, it was not until late September, nearly two months after the F.B.I. investigation had begun, that the F.B.I. reached out to Mr. Steele. He then met with agents in Rome to brief them on his work.\n\nAt that meeting, Mr. Steele learned that his information was considered credible by the F.B.I. \u201cbecause they had other intelligence that indicated the same thing and one of those pieces of intelligence was a human source from inside the Trump organization,\u201d Mr. Simpson testified.\n\nMr. Simpson did not disclose the identity of the human source in his August testimony. But people familiar with the matter said that Mr. Steele, after being questioned by the F.B.I., came to believe that the bureau\u2019s human source was George Papadopoulos, a former Trump campaign foreign adviser.\n\nIn fact, the source was an Australian diplomat who had spent a night drinking in London with Mr. Papadopoulos in the spring, and then shared with American officials what he had learned from the Trump aide.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Simpson said Fusion played no role in deciding what to include in the memos that would eventually be compiled into the dossier.\n\nBut Mr. Simpson said that Mr. Steele \u201cbroke off\u201d his connections with the F.B.I. after The New York Times ran an article on Oct. 31 that said the bureau had found no conclusive or direct link between Mr. Trump and the Russian government.\n\nCiting law enforcement officials, the Times article said that \u201cnone of the investigations so far have found any conclusive or direct link between Mr. Trump and the Russian government.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSince then, investigators and journalists have developed extensive evidence linking Mr. Trump\u2019s associates to Russian government and intelligence operatives, but as yet there is still no public evidence of a direct link between President Trump himself and the Kremlin.\n\nAt the time, many in the F.B.I. did not believe Russia was aiming to explicitly help Mr. Trump. That consensus did not emerge fully until January 2017 when American intelligence agencies released a report saying that the Kremlin\u2019s intentions were twofold: to \u201cundermine public faith in the U.S. democratic process\u201d and to \u201chelp President-elect Trump\u2019s election chances.\u201d\n\nMr. Simpson, in his testimony, called the Times article \u201ca real Halloween special.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere was a concern that the F.B.I. was being manipulated for political ends by the Trump people and that we didn\u2019t really understand what was going on,\u201d Mr. Simpson said. \u201cSo he stopped dealing with them.\u201d\n\nThe concerns prompted Mr. Steele to share his work with a former British diplomat, who passed the information to Senator John McCain after the election.\n\nMr. McCain is believed to have then met with James B. Comey, then the F.B.I. director, to discuss the dossier. In January, weeks before the inauguration, the dossier became public after news broke that Mr. Comey had briefed President Barack Obama and Mr. Trump on Mr. Steele\u2019s work.\n\nThe release of the transcript broke what had more or less been a prevailing rule of secrecy around Congress\u2019s various investigations into Russia\u2019s efforts and the Trump campaign. Though pieces of information from witness interviews in the House and the Senate have leaked to the news media, only two complete transcripts \u2014 from House Intelligence Committee interviews with Carter Page and Erik Prince \u2014 had been publicly released among hundreds.\n\nIn a brief interview, Ms. Feinstein left open the possibility of releasing other transcripts from the committee\u2019s investigation.", "title": "Democratic Senator Releases Transcript of Interview With Dossier Firm", "authors": ["Nicholas Fandos", "Matthew Rosenberg", "Sharon Lafraniere"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader and Kentucky Republican, is expected to bring the bill to the Senate floor within the next month.\n\nHurdles remain. The House has already passed its own far more sweeping deregulatory effort. And progressive Democrats who warn that the legislation would return Wall Street to its more reckless past are mobilizing in hopes of derailing the legislation \u2014 even if that means attacking fellow Democrats who support it.\n\n\u201cThis bill increases the risk of another taxpayer bailout, and I will continue to challenge supporters of this bill \u2014 from both parties \u2014 to explain why they stand on the side of big banks instead of working families,\u201d said Senator Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat.\n\nStill, lobbyists, lawmakers and administration officials say this is the make or break year for overhauling Dodd-Frank.\n\nRob Nichols, president of the American Bankers Association, said the legislation would correct what banks view as regulatory overreach borne of a hasty legislative effort to shore up a cratering financial system after the 2008 crisis. \u201cWhat I do think is significant here is that you have a recognition that\u2019s been building for several years that parts of the policy response were misguided, ill-conceived and missed the mark,\u201d Mr. Nichols said.\n\nBanking giants such as J.P. Morgan and Goldman Sachs \u2014 which would see little in the way of change under the Senate bill \u2014 have said little about the looming legislation. But Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of J.P. Morgan, has been a vocal proponent of revising the Dodd-Frank law, saying in a letter to shareholders in April 2017 that \u201cpoorly conceived and uncoordinated regulations have damaged our economy, inhibiting growth and jobs.\u201d\n\nSome industry lobbyists have pointed out that rules ushered in after the financial crisis have in some ways been beneficial for the big banks, acting as a barrier to entry for any bank without the resources to handle the additional compliance costs.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bill that is working its way through the Senate was brokered primarily by Senator Mike Crapo, the Idaho Republican who chairs the banking committee, and moderate Democrats such as Senator Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, Senator Jon Tester of Montana, Senator Joe Donnelly of Indiana and Senator Mark Warner of Virginia. Eleven Senate Democrats are co-sponsoring the bill, making its passage in the Senate likely.\n\nBackers argue that the bill would offer much-needed relief to small banks and credit unions in parts of America that have been struggling under regulations that had primarily been aimed at the biggest banks.\n\n\u201cA lot of what was Too Big To Fail under Dodd-Frank became \u2018too small to succeed\u2019 because of the onerous regulatory burdens,\u201d Ms. Heitkamp said.\n\nUnder the bill, firms with less than $10 billion in assets would be exempt from the so-called Volcker Rule, which prohibits banks from making risky bets with federally-guaranteed deposits. Mortgage rules for small lenders would also be eased.\n\nPhoto\n\nSome critics of the bill say it goes too far. They argue that many of the institutions that received bailout money during the downturn would get less oversight.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s going to increase stress on the financial system,\u201d said Marcus Stanley, policy director for Americans for Financial Reform, a nonprofit organization calls for tougher regulation of Wall Street. \u201cIt\u2019s going to increase the risk to individual banks and when significant numbers of individual banks go bust, that increases the stress on the system.\u201d\n\nStill, in a sign of the fight to come, other critics \u2014 including some House members \u2014 say the Senate legislation does not go far enough. House Republicans passed a far more aggressive bill last summer, which would be far more crippling to Dodd-Frank. That bill would, among other things, remove the prohibition against using federally insured funds for risky lending and gut the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Under the Senate bill, it would remain intact.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMany House Republicans could find it difficult to back a bill that leaves the bureau unscathed, but weakening it has almost no chance in the Senate.\n\nThe Trump administration has signaled its support of the Senate bill, with Gary D. Cohn, director of the White House\u2019s National Economic Council, telling Bloomberg News earlier this month that the Senate bill would \u201cchange the regulatory environment for the vast, vast majority of banks in the United States.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn an interview with The Wall Street Journal last week, Mr. Trump said: \u201cWe\u2019re looking at Dodd-Frank very strongly and I think we\u2019ll have something on that.\u201d\n\nEfforts to loosen Wall Street regulations are already underway, even without legislation. The Office of Financial Research, which is supposed to spot red flags on Wall Street, lost its director last month and the Treasury Department is seeking to reduce its funding and staff. The Treasury Department has also issued a series of reports recommending changes to a number of other post-crisis rules, including rescinding a requirement that companies disclose the pay ratio between chief executives and workers.\n\nMr. Trump has been hiring regulators who have expressed reservations about \u2014 or been critical of \u2014 some of the post-crisis rules. In November, Mr. Trump tapped Mick Mulvaney, his budget director, to be acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Mr. Mulvaney once characterized the bureau as a \u201csick, sad\u201d joke.\n\nMr. Mulvaney has been hiring like-minded staff members to ensure that the consumer bureau\u2019s new leadership will not be prone to what he considers regulatory overreach. Mr. Mulvaney has also frozen the bureau\u2019s data collection system, a move that has slowed its ability to conduct examinations.\n\nMr. Trump is expected to soon announce a nominee to lead the consumer bureau. J. Mark McWatters, the head of the National Credit Union Administration, is widely considered to be the top choice, but the administration is still considering other finalists. Some bank lobbyists have raised concerns about whether Mr. McWatters, who has asked the consumer bureau to exempt credit unions from examination and enforcement, would give them preferential treatment.\n\n. The appointment last year of Randal K. Quarles as the Federal Reserve\u2019s vice chairman for supervision is also expected to benefit those seeking looser oversight: Mr. Quarles has suggested that some of the strictures imposed on the financial industry since 2008 should be relaxed.\n\n\u201cI think the bigger changes to Dodd-Frank in 2018 will come from changes at the regulators from the new regulatory team and not from new legislation, even if it is enacted,\u201d said Aaron Klein, policy director of the Center on Regulation and Markets at The Brookings Institution.\n\nDespite the bipartisan support for legislative action, it will not happen without a fight, especially when Wall Street is generating record profits and after companies just received large tax cuts. Moderate Democrats who sign on to a bill to help community banks can expect to hear from the party\u2019s progressive wing that they have defanged Dodd-Frank.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe dissension among Democrats was evident as the banking committee considered the bill last year. Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, and Ms. Warren were especially vocal in their opposition to a bill that they viewed as a dangerous giveaway.\n\n\u201cThis major move to deregulate the big banks is a major move to undermining Dodd-Frank,\u201d said Adam Green, a founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee. \u201cEspecially in these Red States where economic populism is the key to Democrats winning re-election in 2018, the folks in the most competitive elections should realize that doing the bidding of the banks is not especially helpful to them.\u201d\n\nMs. Warren is expected to mobilize her network of progressive activists to oppose the changes to Dodd-Frank. She is even prepared to make her Democratic colleagues cast difficult votes during the amendment process to drive home the point that banks that received bailout money should not be deregulated.\n\nFor Democrats who are crossing Ms. Warren on the issue, the hope is that the fallout will be minimal.\n\n\u201cWere going to agree to disagree,\u201d said Senator Mark Warner, a Virginia Democrat who sits on the banking committee. \u201cI don\u2019t think this is going to split open the kind of unity you\u2019ve seen in the Democratic Party.\u201d", "title": "Democrats Add Momentum to G.O.P. Push to Loosen Banking Rules", "authors": ["Alan Rappeport"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Immigration activists were furious that Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, and his fellow Democrats had given away the best leverage they had to ensure that the young immigrants were protected.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s morally reprehensible and it\u2019s political malpractice,\u201d said Ezra Levin, the co-executive director of Indivisible, a liberal group.\n\n\u201cLeader McConnell\u2019s track record of keeping his \u2018commitments\u2019 is thin at best,\u201d said Senator Jeff Merkley, Democrat of Oregon, one of the party\u2019s leading progressive voices.\n\nThe fierce backlash underscored the challenge confronting Mr. Schumer and more centrist Democrats as they attempt to negotiate with Republicans and President Trump to reach an agreement on immigration without alienating the more liberal factions of a party that has moved distinctly to the left. Their balancing act reflects the broader tension in the party as it tries to reconcile the fervor of blue-state opponents of Mr. Trump and the caution of Democrats in states where they must appeal to Trump supporters.\n\nDemocrats need to protect 10 Senate Democrats up for re-election in states carried by the president and appeal to the swing voters who could flip control of the House. Those vulnerable Senate Democrats were key to sparking the bipartisan drive to bring the shutdown to an end. Yet many of the Senate Democrats considered potential 2020 presidential candidates voted to keep the shutdown going.\n\nHeading into the showdown, Mr. Schumer and other top Democrats figured that Mr. Trump was at a vulnerable moment, given the uproar surrounding racially charged comments made in a recent meeting with senators to discuss immigration, disturbing words that came on top of persistent accounts of Oval Office chaos.\n\nAnd they saw the so-called Dreamers \u2014 the young immigrants brought to the United States illegally as children \u2014 as a particularly appealing group, as they faced deportation to countries they barely knew through no wrongdoing of their own. Polling consistently finds deep American sympathy for those immigrants, and under intense pressure from the left to stand tough, Democrats hoped the public would embrace the use of all possible measures to help them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut over the course of the weekend, Democrats increasingly came to realize they had maneuvered themselves into a difficult position that made many of the party\u2019s moderate senators uncomfortable. Republicans were not distancing themselves from the president despite his erratic swings on immigration policy. And while the Dreamers may be a highly sympathetic group, using them as a rationale for shuttering the federal government was not playing well.\n\nThe president, top Republicans and their allies had some success in framing the showdown as a case of Democrats putting the interests of \u201cillegal immigrants\u201d ahead of American citizens, a line of attack Democrats felt they could not weather.\n\nMr. McConnell, who sat at his Senate desk with a satisfied smile before the vote to reopen the government on Monday, archly drove that point home in brief remarks.\n\n\u201cI think if we have learned anything during this process,\u201d he said, \u201cit\u2019s that a strategy to shut down the government over the issue of illegal immigration is something the American people didn\u2019t understand and would not have understood in the future.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn relenting so rapidly, Democrats saw some tangible benefits. They managed to highlight the plight of the Dreamers while avoiding a prolonged shutdown that could have ultimately damaged their cause. And by conceding defeat on Monday, Democrats avoided widespread disruptions in government operations that would have cascaded during the week and beyond.\n\nThey also won the pledge from Mr. McConnell to allow broad bipartisan negotiations on immigration, overall spending, health programs and other unresolved issues. If those fail to produce an agreement by Feb. 8, he promised to open an immigration debate on the Senate floor. Senators on both sides of the aisle saw that as a breakthrough that could provide a chance for the polarized chamber to engage in what has become a rare occurrence: actual legislating.\n\nWhat they do not have is any certainty that Mr. Trump will back whatever legislation the Senate produces or that the House will even consider it.\n\nThe agreement to end the shutdown came after weekend negotiations among a bipartisan group of about two dozen lawmakers assembled by Mr. Manchin and Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine. Members of the group all saw the shutdown as unacceptable and contributing to public disgust with Washington, motivating them to pursue a solution outside the chamber\u2019s leadership.\n\nHere Are the Senators Who Brokered a Bipartisan Solution to the Government Shutdown\n\nThey say they are intent on finding a way to protect the immigrants covered by the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, program as well as fashioning a \u201cglobal\u201d agreement on spending, disaster aid and a variety of other issues that have defied resolution.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRepublican participation in the bipartisan group was crucial for Democrats seeking assurances from Mr. McConnell on the way forward. While they were nervous about accepting the word of Mr. McConnell given their history of clashes with him, they doubted that he would undercut such a substantial number of his fellow Republicans.\n\n\u201cI expect the majority leader to fulfill his commitment to the Senate, to me and to the bipartisan group and abide by this agreement,\u201d Mr. Schumer said. \u201cIf he does not, of course \u2014 and I expect he will \u2014 he will have breached the trust of not only the Democratic senators, but members of his own party as well.\u201d\n\nStill, immigration activists found fault with putting any faith in Mr. McConnell. And they noted that even if the Senate can draft a measure that attracts a broad majority, it faces a steep test in the House, which ignored a 2013 Senate immigration measure that passed with 68 votes.\n\nNegotiations will now begin with Democrats in a new posture. During a Friday meeting with Mr. Trump aimed at settling the dispute, Mr. Schumer said Democrats would agree to provide significant funding for the wall along the Mexican border that Mr. Trump has made a central and symbolic element of his agenda. They had previously opposed any funding for the wall.\n\nWhile Democrats gave that ground, they are not without weapons. Should the negotiations collapse, they will be able to pound Republicans for abandoning the Dreamers. They could also vote again to shutter the government, though that seems unlikely after this episode.\n\nAs lawmakers looked ahead to a few difficult weeks, Republicans chose not to crow over the outcome.\n\n\u201cI think we should be magnanimous,\u201d said Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the No. 2 Senate Republican, in what might be the most telling observation about which side prevailed.", "title": "Democrats Blink in Shutdown Impasse, Hoping for a Bargain", "authors": ["Carl Hulse"]} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "The ancient Chinese master bows in respect.\n\nFourth, the Democrats launched a series of devastating blitzkrieg assaults on themselves. Minutes after the Democratic leaders announced their capitulation, the entire left wing of the Democratic Party went into uproar. Kamala Harris was furious. Ezra Levin of the Indivisible Project called it \u201cmorally reprehensible and political malpractice.\u201d I don\u2019t even want to think about how many tears of rage must be streaming out of Cory Booker\u2019s eyes.\n\nBut of course the problem was not that the leadership capitulated on Monday. It was that the Democrats talked themselves into this crazy position on Friday.\n\nThe Democrats are the party that believes in government. It doesn\u2019t do them any good to make the federal government look dysfunctional. The Democrats are trying to defend a bunch of seats in red states. This immigration \u00fcber alles strategy was never going to play well there. The Democratic presidential contenders are going to be a big problem for the Democratic Senate candidates.\n\nFifth, the Democrats have set themselves up brilliantly for future capitulation. Mitch McConnell had already promised Jeff Flake a DACA vote down the road. Now the Republicans get to hold it knowing that the Democrats are not going to want to walk into another shutdown buzz saw. Stephen Miller, Trump\u2019s immigration aide, has always wanted to trade DACA in exchange for some onerous restrictions on legal immigration. Now it looks more likely he\u2019s going to get them.\n\nDemocrats, when you lose a negotiation to a president who doesn\u2019t know his own position, you\u2019ve really impressed me.\n\nIt\u2019s fitting that we had a government shutdown over the issue of immigration. Racially tinged conflict has been the defining feature of the Trump era. Most of the outrage has been caused by the president picking at the nation\u2019s wounds. But by now both parties have racial identity wings, which believe that political life is inevitably a power competition between identity groups. Both parties build their coalitions by magnifying racial identity and exploiting racial difference.\n\nBut there are some of us who are uncomfortable with the whole identity-politics drill. We believe that while racism is the central stain on American history, racial conflict is not inevitable. By reducing inequalities, by integrating daily life, we can eventually make our common humanity more salient and our racial difference less so. We believe that America has already made strides in this direction and that it\u2019s everyone\u2019s responsibility to make racial diversity a creative spark and not a source of permanent hostility.\n\nOne of these days some party should pay attention to us folks.", "title": "Opinion | Democrats Go for the Jugular! (Their Own)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Representative Nita M. Lowey of New York, the top Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, cast protection for undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children as a \u201cmoral issue,\u201d saying that resolving the fate of the so-called Dreamers was a prerequisite for enacting any long-term spending plan.\n\nBut Democrats face their own challenges. Senate Democrats running for re-election this year in states won by Mr. Trump are likely not eager for a government shutdown, worried that they could be blamed, just as Republicans were in 2013 when the government shut down for 16 days during their battle with President Barack Obama over his health care bill.\n\nAnd Mr. Trump is looking for a fight. On Tuesday he goaded Democrats on the immigration issue.\n\n\u201cDemocrats are doing nothing for DACA \u2014 just interested in politics,\u201d the president wrote, using the acronym for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, the Obama-era initiative that he rescinded. \u201cDACA activists and Hispanics will go hard against Dems, will start \u2018falling in love\u2019 with Republicans and their President! We are about RESULTS.\u201d\n\nDemocrats are under intense pressure from immigration rights activists to pass longstanding legislation, called the Dream Act, which would shield young undocumented immigrants from deportation and create for them a path to citizenship.\n\nLast month, thousands of people showed up for a pro-immigration rally on Capitol Hill, and nearly 200 of them \u2014 including two members of Congress \u2014 were arrested on the Capitol steps while demanding that Democrats insist on the passage of the Dream Act, even at the risk of shutting down the government.\n\nMore than 14,000 young immigrants have lost their protection under the DACA program since Mr. Trump ended it in September, according to Cristina Jim\u00e9nez, the executive director of United We Dream, an advocacy group. At the time, Mr. Trump said he was giving Congress six months to draft legislation codifying the program, setting a March deadline. Republicans say there is no urgency.\n\nBut immigrants\u2019 rights activists say they cannot wait.\n\nImmigrants who have lost their protection \u201ccan be caught when they are going to school, walking around their neighborhood, going to work,\u201d Ms. Jim\u00e9nez said. \u201cPeople are living in daily fear that they could be detained and arrested.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSenator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, has promised a vote if a bipartisan group of senators can reach agreement on a measure that would extend protection from deportation while also beefing up border security, a key demand of Republicans.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut Democrats fear that a stand-alone immigration measure could die in the House or be vetoed by the president. Senator Jeff Merkley, Democrat of Oregon, said Democrats had more leverage if protections were included in a spending package.\n\n\u201cIt doesn\u2019t help us to pass the Dream Act and have it be a separate bill that never makes it to the president\u2019s desk or gets vetoed on the president\u2019s desk,\u2019\u2019 he said.\n\nThe arrival on Wednesday of Doug Jones, the newly elected Democrat of Alabama, leaves Republicans with an exceedingly narrow Senate majority, 51 to 49. The Senate\u2019s major legislative accomplishment of last year, a far-reaching overhaul of the tax code, was muscled through using procedural maneuvers that allowed for a simple majority, party-line victory.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBut Republicans cannot use such maneuvers on a spending bill, which will require 60 votes for passage. That gives Democrats an advantage, said Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the minority leader.\n\n\u201cRepublicans know that a government shutdown falls on their back, because they\u2019re in charge of House, Senate and the president, and for the first time they need Democrats to accomplish their goals,\u201d Mr. Schumer said.\n\nWednesday\u2019s meeting is supposed to focus on spending levels, which were fixed in the 2011 legislation that ended another fiscal showdown. It will include Ms. Pelosi and Mr. Schumer, Mr. McConnell and Speaker Paul D. Ryan, as well as Mr. Trump\u2019s budget director, Mick Mulvaney, and his liaison to Congress, Marc Short.\n\nBoth Mr. Schumer and Ms. Pelosi said Democrats would use the session to insist on \u201cparity,\u201d meaning that military and domestic spending must be increased by the same amount. Republicans are far more focused on building up the military.\n\n\u201cThis idea that we\u2019ve got to increase domestic spending dollar for dollar, it has no basis in reality,\u201d said Representative Tom Cole, Republican of Oklahoma. \u201cIt\u2019s simply a way to try to use the military to blackmail the government to spend more money domestically.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Democrats say they are optimistic. Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis has warned repeatedly that his department cannot continue to function under short-term stopgap spending measures if it is to streamline and modernize its capabilities \u2014 and has met regularly with Democratic leaders to tell them so.\n\n\u201cIf they have the votes within their caucus they can do whatever they want,\u201d Ms. Pelosi said, referring to Republicans. \u201cThey have the ability to keep the government open, to put forth their valueless priorities. And so why are they accusing us of holding the Defense Department hostage?\u201d\n\nThe 2018 fiscal year began in October, but lawmakers have struggled to inch forward toward a long-term deal to fund the government. The lack of an agreement on raising the spending limits has essentially stalled the process, and a deal to raise those caps has so far proved elusive for Mr. Trump and congressional leaders.\n\nIn one case last year, a planned White House meeting fell apart after Mr. Trump took to Twitter to attack Mr. Schumer and Ms. Pelosi, who promptly pulled out of the planned gathering.\n\nAnd in recent weeks, as Republicans raced to pass their sweeping tax overhaul, the atmosphere on Capitol Hill was hardly conducive for a bipartisan deal.\n\nShortly before Christmas, the House and Senate agreed on the stopgap spending bill that is keeping the government open through Jan. 19, punting other fights into the new year.\n\n\u201cIt never seems to get any easier, right?\u201d Representative Mario Diaz-Balart, Republican of Florida, said at the time. \u201cJanuary\u2019s going to be a bear.\u201d", "title": "Democrats Outline Demands as Threat of Shutdown Looms", "authors": ["Sheryl Gay Stolberg", "Thomas Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The possibility of criminal charges prompted concern among civil rights attorneys who viewed it as a step toward the politicization of law enforcement.\n\n\u201cIn free democracies, you can\u2019t jail people for opposing the president\u2019s policies, policies that courts have found to be lawful,\u201d said Vanita Gupta, the chief executive of the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights and the former head of the civil rights division of the Justice Department.\n\nPhoto\n\nPresidents who have sought to intrude on the independence of the Justice Department have for decades been rebuked. President Trump has appeared to frequently cross that line, calling for investigations into Hillary Clinton and one of her aides and demanding that a career F.B.I. official politically aligned with her be removed from his job.\n\nTalk of criminal charges for elected officials also exacerbated tensions between Mr. Trump and local politicians who disagree with his administration\u2019s stance on immigration law enforcement, particularly in California, a state whose liberal residents have become a symbol of staunch opposition to much of the president\u2019s agenda.\n\nLast year, the Trump administration also threatened to withhold federal funding to sanctuary cities, including $28 million in law enforcement grants to state and local jurisdictions in California. In response, both the state and the city of San Francisco sued the administration. California Attorney General Xavier Becerra called the threat to withhold money \u201cbullying.\u201d\n\nMore recently, the state Legislature passed the California Values Act, which restricts cooperation with federal immigration agents. The law took effect on Jan. 1, drawing the ire of Thomas D. Homan, the acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. They also asked that the Justice Department provide the legal basis it would use to prosecute politicians in sanctuary cities.", "title": "Democrats Question Justice Dept. Power to Charge Sanctuary City Leaders", "authors": ["Katie Benner"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "In an optimistic light, the danger of failing on a DACA deal might seem relatively slight. After all, a Democratic Congress could block funds for deportations. A recent district court decision suggests that DACA could be kept alive until 2020 by tangling it up in the courts. And more than a quarter of Dreamers live in deep blue California, which declared itself a \u201csanctuary state.\u201d Politically, Democrats can pin the failure of a legislative fix on Mr. Trump and the Republican majorities, and could possibly do even better in the midterms by keeping the issue on the table.\n\nThis kind of hopeful thinking is seductive but dangerous. When the legal protection of 800,000 people is at stake, Democrats need to expect the worst, even while hoping for the best. That means assuming that if DACA expires without a fix, the administration will be aggressive about deportations, the Senate will remain Republican, judicial stopgaps will fail, a Republican will win the White House in 2020, hundreds of thousands will be pushed into the shadows and many tens of thousands will be rounded up, detained and ejected from the country.\n\nThis dark timeline might be unlikely, but unlikely things happen. (Donald Trump, I\u2019ll remind you, is president of the United States.)\n\nSo a deal that includes money for the wall ought to be a no-brainer for Democrats. Every viable proposal under discussion includes a hefty \u201cborder security\u201d element, but not any of them include a literal solid wall spanning the entire southern border. Last week, Kellyanne Conway, a White House counselor, said that Mr. Trump understands that \u201cpart of it will be the physical wall, part of it is better technology, part of it is also fencing.\u201d\n\nThe wall Mr. Trump promised isn\u2019t going to materialize, and he\u2019s not going to insist on it. Of course, Mr. Trump will say that new border security enhancements constitute a wall. But Democrats can vote for them without following suit.", "title": "Opinion | Democrats, Make a Deal With Trump to Protect Dreamers", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIn the history of a country, it is the same,\u201d he added at the service, attended by Mr. Kabila\u2019s wife and children, and by influential political figures.\n\nMr. Ekofo then went further, saying that the nation\u2019s laws had generally not been respected, and that he believed the state \u2014 unable to meet its citizens\u2019 basic needs despite an abundance of resources \u2014 no longer exists.\n\nThe country\u2019s top Muslim leader, Sheikh Ali Mwinyi N\u2019kuu, told a local news website, \u201cIf you have made a commitment to God and to men, you must know how to respect him.\u201d\n\nThe sheikh stopped short of endorsing the protests on Sunday but said he would not oppose them because the Constitution guaranteed the right to demonstrate. \u201cWe cannot in any way agree to trample the Constitution if it is peaceful,\u201d he said.\n\nThe local authorities did not authorize the march, setting the stage for a repeat of the December standoff. Cl\u00e9ment Bafiba Zomba, the vice governor of Kinshasa, said a second demonstration could \u201cdistort\u201d the outcome of a police investigation into the first. He also scolded organizers for declining his invitation to discuss the matter, according to a letter seen by The New York Times.\n\nOne of the organizers said the group feared arrest if they accepted the invitation; a senior police official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the official was not authorized to speak on the matter, confirmed to The New York Times that an arrest warrant for five organizers, including three named in the letter, had been issued but had not been executed.", "title": "Demonstrations Against Kabila in Congo Leave at Least 6 Dead", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE LARGESSE OF THE SEA MAIDEN\n\nStories\n\nBy Denis Johnson\n\n207 pp. Random House. $27.\n\nLet us review what is so good about Denis Johnson. I have often performed this exercise, with a modicum of writerly envy, over the decades of reading his work: What exactly is the alchemical magic in these pages? Everyone who started writing seriously in the 1980s or 1990s can tell you where he or she first consumed the morsels that eventually made up \u201cJesus\u2019 Son,\u201d Johnson\u2019s breakthrough 1992 story collection. To behold those lines for the first time was to see language unaccountably capturing emotions in a way unfamiliar in recent American prose. Johnson once noted that he was working under the star of Isaac Babel while writing \u201cJesus\u2019 Son,\u201d and it showed; just as Babel saw (for example) the Russian sunset as others had not previously, Johnson transformed his misfits and heroin addicts until they became like protagonists from the time of epics.\n\n\u201cAngels,\u201d Johnson\u2019s 1983 debut novel, was similarly revelatory \u2014 making the homely backdrop of a Greyhound bus journey suddenly appropriate to the highest American literature. If Johnson sometimes stumbled in later books (he was prolific), they were exceptions in a long, restless and varied career that included not only fiction but plays, nonfiction and some impressive poetry collections. (I recommend \u201cThe Incognito Lounge.\u201d)\n\nWhat made the effective books so effective? In part, it is the consciousness of mortality found everywhere in his best work. This is the guy, after all, who wrote \u201cResuscitation of a Hanged Man\u201d and \u201cAlready Dead.\u201d It is the rare Denis Johnson work that doesn\u2019t explicitly take up end-of-life questions. From the death-row sequences of \u201cAngels\u201d to the murder and car crashes and heroin addiction of \u201cJesus\u2019 Son\u201d to the Vietnam War setting of \u201cTree of Smoke,\u201d his 2007 National Book Award-winning novel, there is ever a wafting of mortal fumes across Johnson\u2019s paragraphs.\n\n\u201cThe Largesse of the Sea Maiden,\u201d Johnson\u2019s new and presumably final collection \u2014 he died from liver cancer in May \u2014 is no outlier. Without exception the five stories that make up this volume, averaging about 40 pages each, feature intimations of mortality. There\u2019s the former wife of the adman narrator, in the title story, who telephones to tell our man she\u2019s dying, but without specifying which former wife she is. (\u201cIn the middle of this,\u201d he notes, \u201cI began wondering, most uncomfortably, in fact with a dizzy, sweating anxiety, if I\u2019d made a mistake.\u201d) There are the murderous, delusional inmates of a county lockup in \u201cStrangler Bob,\u201d and the fanciful and grim formulations about Elvis and his lost twin that haunt \u201cDoppelg\u00e4nger, Poltergeist,\u201d the last story in the volume.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThroughout is Johnson\u2019s familiar anguish at our passing over. What makes \u201cThe Largesse of the Sea Maiden\u201d different is that in this case Johnson knew his own time was short, and embarked on his material with an admirable and pitiless openness he conveys through his characters: \u201cIt\u2019s plain to you that at the time I wrote this, I\u2019m not dead,\u201d one says. \u201cBut maybe by the time you read it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe movement across the whole of the collection echoes Dante: down, concentrically, into the revelations of illness and death, to \u201cthe phase in which these visits to emergency rooms and clinics increased in frequency and by now have become commonplace.\u201d", "title": "Denis Johnson\u2019s Death-Infused Last Stories", "authors": ["Rick Moody", "Denis Johnson"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "In some of her songs, like \u201cSnap, Crackle and Pop,\u201d she gave explicit tips on sexual technique.\n\n\u201cEven before I started doing it on record, I was naughty but nice in person,\u201d Ms. LaSalle told Blues Blast magazine in 2017. \u201cIt comes naturally. Because that\u2019s the way life is.\u201d\n\nMs. LaSalle was born Ora Denise Allen on July 6, 1939, near Sidon in Leflore County in the Mississippi Delta. She moved with her family to the Delta town of Belzoni when she was 7. She sang in church and heard country music and blues on the radio.\n\nAt 13, she moved on her own to Chicago, where she sang with a gospel group, the Sacred Five. Hoping to be a writer, she had a story published in Tan magazine. But after magazines rejected her other fiction, she turned to writing poems and, soon, songs.\n\nPhoto\n\nShe took her stage surname, LaSalle, from a French character in a newspaper comic strip. Her first single, in 1967, was \u201cA Love Reputation,\u201d a boast about man-stealing skills.\n\nChess Records released her next few singles before she and her husband at the time, Bill Jones, started their own production company, Crajon, in 1969. Ms. LaSalle also supplied songs for other Crajon performers; one composition, \u201cGet Your Lie Straight,\u201d was a hit in 1971 for the singer Bill Coday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor her next singles Ms. LaSalle chose a Memphis producer, Willie Mitchell, who also produced Al Green\u2019s hits. \u201cHung Up, Strung Out\u201d got her signed to a Detroit label, Westbound, in 1970, and in 1971 she wrote and sang the biggest hit of her career, the million-selling No. 1 R&B single \u201cTrapped by a Thing Called Love.\u201d It also reached No. 13 on the Billboard pop chart, her only Top 40 crossover in the United States.\n\nShe returned to the national R&B charts in the 1970s with songs including \u201cNow Run and Tell That,\u201d \u201cMan Sized Job,\u201d \u201cLove Me Right\u201d and \u201cMarried, but Not To Each Other,\u201d a song that also became a country hit for Barbara Mandrell in 1977.\n\nAfter divorcing Mr. Jones in 1974, Ms. LaSalle moved to Tennessee, where she met the disc jockey James E. Wolfe Jr., who would found the radio station WFKX in Jackson. They married in 1977; he survives her, along with their children, Ray Kight, Dawn Beard and Bridgette Wolfe.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn 1982, Ms. LaSalle eased her music slightly toward blues and signed to the Mississippi-based Malaco label, where she recorded for most of the next three decades and wrote songs for other performers, including Z. Z. Hill. On her 1980s Malaco albums, she was often backed by the renowned Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section.\n\n\u201cMy Tu-Tu,\u201d her 1985 version of the Rockin\u2019 Sidney zydeco hit \u201cMy Toot Toot,\u201d was a hit in the United States and in Europe, reaching No. 6 on the British Top 10.\n\nMs. LaSalle made gospel albums from 1999 to 2001, but she returned to secular music in the 2000s with albums like \u201cPay Before You Pump\u201d (2007).\n\nShe toured steadily, largely in the Southeast, with occasional trips to Europe. In recent years she made efforts to start a school for young musicians in Jackson.\n\nShe was nominated this year by the Blues Foundation for a Blues Music Award in the soul blues female artist category, alongside Mavis Staples and Bettye LaVette, and she was inducted into the Rhythm and Blues Music Hall of Fame in 2015.\n\n\u201cI can\u2019t say that I\u2019ve lived all of the things that I write about, but I have seen people around me that are living the things that I write about,\u201d Ms. LaSalle said in her Blues Blast interview. \u201cSo it\u2019s easy, because I observe people and the things that they go through.\u201d", "title": "Denise LaSalle, Singer and Writer of Earthy Songs, Dies at 78", "authors": ["Jon Pareles"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Dennis Peron, who openly dealt marijuana from a \u201csupermarket\u201d in San Francisco in the 1970s before leading a successful campaign to legalize it for medical use in California two decades later, died on Saturday at a San Francisco hospital. He was 71.\n\nJohn Entwistle Jr., his spouse, said the cause was respiratory failure.\n\nMr. Peron was identified with marijuana all his adult life.\n\nHe began smoking it at 17. He continued in Vietnam, where he served in the Air Force, and smuggled two pounds stateside in his duffel bag after his discharge.\n\n\u201cI came back and kissed the ground,\u201d he told Leafly.com, an online cannabis website, in 2014. \u201cI was happy \u2014 partly because I had two pounds with me. That started a career that would span 40 years.\u201d", "title": "Dennis Peron, Early Medical Marijuana Advocate, Dies at 71", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "After foraging through the Dumpster of discarded ideas, the Trump administration has dragged out another fetid reject as part of its campaign to roll back modernity, common sense and the will of the people.\n\nWe know Attorney General Jeff Sessions is a small, backward-looking man with even smaller, more backward-looking ideas, but what was the thinking behind his new federal crackdown on legal marijuana? Punish the blue states? Create cannabis chaos in the large swath of the American West and the other states where voters have said they want the police to spend their time on real crime?\n\nOr is it just another betrayal of the fools who voted for a man aptly described from inside the White House in Michael Wolff\u2019s new book, as \u201cless a person than a collection of terrible traits\u201d? For one way to really tick off Trump\u2019s base is to start arresting them.\n\nThere comes a time in the evolution of social policy when law enforcement, science, medical authorities and the majority of the public reach a consensus about changing course. At this moment, criminalizing marijuana has never been more unpopular, nor a more unjust way to ensure that otherwise law-abiding people have to fear the police.", "title": "Opinion | Department of Injustice", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "On that day, Ben Raines, a reporter for AL.com, published an article in which he told of discovering the charred wooden remains of a boat believed to be the Clotilda. A team of archaeologists who visited the site said that based on the dimensions of the wreckage and its contents \u2014 including charred timber, iron drifts \u2014 the remnants were most likely those of the slave ship.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThis is the proof that we needed,\u201d Ms. Woods said. \u201cI am elated because so many people said that it didn\u2019t really happen that way, that we made the story up.\u201d\n\nMs. Woods and other descendants said they were ecstatic about the news but still coming to terms with it. While the Clotilda had always been at the center of family lore, the common bond among neighbors in Africatown, they previously had to accept the story on faith.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAbout 10 of the 100 or so descendants of the Clotilda slaves who still live in Africatown gathered on Wednesday to discuss what should be done with the wreckage if it proves to be the Clotilda.\n\nShould it be removed and restored? Should it stay where it is and the land be protected? Should the wreckage be placed in a museum?\n\n\u201cWe want to tell the rest of our families about what happened over 150 years ago,\u201d Ms. Woods said. \u201cWe want to get some answers.\u201d\n\nLavon Manzie, a Mobile councilman who represents Africatown, said the possible discovery of the Clotilda is welcome news in a part of Mobile that is often overlooked. Last year, an artist painted a mural of the slave ship on a concrete wall in the neighborhood, a sign of the Clotilda\u2019s continued resonance in the community.\n\nMr. Manzie said the Clotilda slaves represented what was best about his state and America. They came against their will and did not know English or understand American culture. Still, he said, they managed to transform Africatown into a thriving community of agriculture, schools, churches and community centers.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a story of resilience and self-preservation,\u201d he said. \u201cIf you consider the circumstances of what these individuals had to learn and grow from and then reach the highest of success they can achieve, it is an amazing story.\u201d\n\nMs. Woods remembers the story of how her great-great-grandfather Charlie Lewis came on the Clotilda. As a child Ms. Woods learned that Mr. Lewis was the oldest slave on the ship, and that he was known as chief of the Tarkbar Tribe.\n\n\u201cCharlie only spoke the African language, so he passed the story down to his son Joe Lewis,\u201d Ms. Woods said. She said that he learned to read and write at the Old Union Baptist Church in Africatown and recorded the story.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Old Union Baptist Church has served as a hub for the community. Several slaves who arrived on the Clotilda were founding members of the church.\n\nListon Portis has lived in Africatown for 55 years and sees the story of the Clotilda as the history of the town.\n\n\u201cI was very excited and happy that they found the ship because I had heard about the ship all my life,\u201d Mr. Portis said. \u201cFor someone to locate it, it makes our story real and true.\u201d\n\nMr. Portis, a retired juvenile detention supervisor, is not related to any of the slaves who arrived on the Clotilda. But he said he knows the story because churches and schools in the community reinforce it.\n\n\u201cIt is very important to know from whence you come,\u201d Mr. Portis said. \u201cEspecially in the African-American community because we were not reading and writing, so our stories that were passed on molded us.\u201d\n\n\u201cTo actually see our history and know where we come from specifically,\u201d Mr. Portis added, \u201cit gives credence to our story.\u201d", "title": "Descendants\u2019 Stories of the Clotilda Slave Ship Drew Doubts. Now Some See Validation.", "authors": ["Sandra E. Garcia", "Matthew Haag"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Is your home bringing you down? As anyone who has lived in cramped, dark or tight quarters knows, your living space can have a big effect on your mood.\n\nFor ideas on how to bring positive energy \u2014 and style \u2014 into your home, we talked to Justina Blakeney, the designer behind the Instagram hit Jungalow and the author of \u201cThe New Bohemians Handbook: Come Home to Good Vibes.\u201d\n\nMs. Blakeney, 38, is a firm believer in using design to improve the quality of your life. Her own home, a 1926 bungalow in Los Angeles, is filled with color, pattern and greenery, which she said improves her mood and enhances productivity and relaxation. She offered some tips for creating a home that supports well-being.\n\nCLEAR THE ARTERIES \u201cDoors should swing freely, passageways should be cleared and zones should be created that support your daily routines and activities,\u201d said Ms. Blakeney, who discovered the importance of this after her daughter was born five years ago and the area behind her front door became a landing pad for shoes, strollers and other gear.", "title": "Designing a Feel-Good Home", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "PARIS \u2014 Not quite two weeks after Catherine Deneuve, Catherine Millet and more than 100 other women set off a firestorm in France with an open letter in Le Monde suggesting the #MeToo movement had gone too far, two days after the second annual women\u2019s marches around the world, and the day after the Screen Actors Guild Awards and its all-female cast of presenters, the couture shows began in Paris.\n\nThe most expensive, exclusive clothes in fashion, all made to order and off limits for most, do not necessarily seem like the kind of thing you\u2019d wear on the ramparts (unless they were red-carpet ramparts). But there was no way the question of what empowerment looks like in 2018 wouldn\u2019t be the core subject on designers\u2019 minds. It\u2019s simply one of the dominant conversations of the day.", "title": "Designs on Female Empowerment at Chanel and Dior", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Kevin Pyle is a graphic novelist, artist and illustrator, and the co-author, most recently, of \u201cMigrant: Stories of Hope and Resilience\u201d and \u201cBad for You: Exposing the War on Fun.\u201d\n\nFollow New York Times Books on Facebook and Twitter (@nytimesbooks), and sign up for our newsletter.", "title": "Desolation on the Border", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nThere is a reason that \u201cdoth protest too much\u201d \u2014 originally attributed to Hamlet\u2019s mother \u2014 has become a clich\u00e9.\n\nLast night, speaking to reporters on his way into the golf club he owns in Palm Beach, Fla., President Trump proclaimed himself \u201cthe least racist person you will ever interview.\u201d That\u2019s right: Of all the world\u2019s billions of people, Donald Trump sees himself as the one who is least affected by another person\u2019s race.\n\nThe more than 40 years that Trump has spent as a public figure tells a different story, of course. He has shown himself to be obsessed with race for that entire time.", "title": "Opinion | Details on the List of Trump\u2019s Racist Statements", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "But a closer look suggests that the industry may be headed for choppier waters than the hoopla in Detroit would indicate. While sales are healthy, consumers are actually buying fewer new vehicles. Purchases by individual customers at dealerships \u2014 known as retail sales and considered the most accurate reflection of demand \u2014 declined slightly in both 2016 and 2017. Some automakers are offsetting lower consumer purchasing by selling more cars to fleets like rental-car companies.\n\nMore worrisome is that the drops in retail sales have come even as manufacturers have resorted to heftier discounts, which eat into their profits. Sales incentives are now equal to more than 11 percent of the average vehicle\u2019s sticker price. As recently as 2014, that figure was below 8 percent.\n\nThere are other troubling signs, too. Interest rates have started rising, which increases the cost of financing or leasing a new car. Younger buyers are showing less interest in owning cars than older generations. And the supply of low-mileage used cars is growing, giving shoppers attractive and lower-cost alternatives to new cars. Close to four million leased vehicles will be turned in and offered for sale as used models this year, up from 3.6 million in 2017.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a lot of headwinds out there,\u201d said Mark Wakefield, global head of the automotive and industrial practice at Alix Partners, a consulting firm.\n\nThe auto industry has a long history of going from boom to bust \u2014 periods of rising sales and buoyant profits followed by inevitable sales slumps that leave idle plants and mounting losses. The last bust coincided with the 2008 financial crisis and nearly ruined Detroit. General Motors and Chrysler had to be saved by federally engineered bankruptcy proceedings.", "title": "Detroit Auto Show May Be Celebrating an Era About to End", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIf you have a chronic disease, you shouldn\u2019t be burdened by the cost,\u201d said York F. Z\u00f6llner, professor of health economics at Hamburg University of Applied Sciences, explaining the German approach. \u201cIt\u2019s not your fault.\u201d He and others note that conventional insurance is meant to cover unpredictable costs. But the costs of chronic illnesses are predictably high.\n\nGermany offers people with chronic disease better-than-standard coverage. Every German is required to have insurance \u2014 and guaranteed access to it \u2014 typically through more than 100 public nonprofit insurers. People can pick which \u201csickness fund\u201d to join, and the system is financed through a \u201ccontribution\u201d equal to roughly 15 percent of their income \u2014 nearly half coming from their employer and the rest from their paycheck. The total payment is capped at about 650 euros per month for adults, which includes coverage for dependent relatives.\n\nWhile co-payments exist \u2014 for prescriptions and hospital stays, for example \u2014 they are capped at 2 percent of gross earnings, and people with chronic disease pay half of that, according to Dr. Z\u00f6llner, with their out-of-pocket spending on health cost capped at 1 percent of income.\n\nSince expensive prescription drugs are a big component of many treatments, Germany\u2019s state health insurers have been negotiating prices with drugmakers since 2011, and drug prices there are generally lower than in the United States. The patient contribution for any prescription is five to 10 euros.\n\nKaitlyn West, an American with Type 1 diabetes who recently moved to Germany for graduate school, said that in the United States she had been paying on average $400 per month in out-of-pocket expenses \u2014 close to $5,000 each year. The amount fluctuated wildly depending on how her insurance policy at the moment covered her pumps and medicines.\n\nOn German public insurance, the monthly contribution is about $105 and her yearly out-of-pocket spending is capped at about $140 for supplies and $45 for insulin. \u201cThere are no fees for doctors\u2019 visits, no fees for my blood draws and no hassle getting things done,\u201d she said. \u201cThis system allows me to live a normal, stress-free life.\u201d\n\nThe German health system is based on the principle of solidarity, not individuality, Dr. Z\u00f6llner said. But reframed to appeal to current American concerns, it might translate: \u201cThere but for the grace of God go I,\u201d since at this point there are so many treatable chronic diseases. The congressional logic that led to the 1972 kidney-care exception could apply to any of those conditions.", "title": "Opinion | Diabetes Shouldn\u2019t Bankrupt You", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWomen who have had gestational diabetes have an increased risk not only for Type 2 diabetes later in life, but for heart disease and hypertension as well.\n\nGestational diabetes is diagnosed if there is any glucose intolerance with its onset during pregnancy, and about 6 to 8 percent of pregnant women develop the condition.\n\nBritish researchers studied 9,118 women with gestational diabetes, comparing them with 37,281 healthy controls. The study, published in PLOS Medicine, had an average three years of follow-up.\n\nThe women who had gestational diabetes were 20 times as likely as controls to develop Type 2 diabetes, consistent with previous studies, and the risk was highest in the first year after giving birth. In addition, these women were 2.8 times as likely to have heart disease, and nearly twice as likely to develop high blood pressure. The researchers controlled for age, body mass index, ethnicity, smoking and other variables.\n\nGestational diabetes did not increase the risk for stroke.\n\nThe senior author, Dr. Krishnarajah Nirantharakumar, a lecturer at the University of Birmingham in Britain, had this advice for women who were diabetic during pregnancy: \u201cMake sure you get yourself checked annually for diabetes, and also take the opportunity to get your lipids and blood pressure checked. If you\u2019re smoking, stop. And if you are obese, make an effort to lose weight, or at least not to gain weight.\u201d", "title": "Diabetes in Pregnancy Raises Risk of Heart Disease", "authors": ["Nicholas Bakalar"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Diana Seave Greenwald and Hugues Xavier Julien Le Bras are to be married Jan. 14 at the Housing Works Bookstore and Cafe in New York. Paul Seave, an uncle of the bride and a California Superior Court judge who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate.\n\nMs. Greenwald, 28, was until last month a Wiener-Anspach Foundation postdoctoral fellow at the Universit\u00e9 Libre de Bruxelles in Belgium. Later this month she will join the National Gallery of Art in Washington as the Andrew W. Mellon postdoctoral curatorial fellow. She graduated magna cum laude from Columbia and received both a master\u2019s degree in economic and social history and a doctor of philosophy in history from the University of Oxford.\n\nShe is the daughter of Ava L. Seave and Bruce C. N. Greenwald of New York. The bride\u2019s father is an economist and the Robert Heilbrunn professor of finance and asset management at Columbia Business School. Her mother is a principal at Quantum Media, a management consulting firm in New York specializing in consulting for the media, information and entertainment industries.\n\nMr. Le Bras, 27, works in New York as an analyst for J. O. Hambro Capital Management, a London-based investment company. He graduated with a law degree from Aix-Marseille University in Aix-en-Provence, France, from which he also received a master\u2019s degree in tax and business law. He also received an M.B.A. from Columbia.", "title": "Diana Greenwald, Hugues Le Bras", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI don\u2019t think that they killed Gateway,\u201d said Thomas K. Wright, the executive director of the Regional Plan Association, an urban policy organization, referring to the Trump administration. \u201cI think they took a very hard position as an early negotiating tactic.\u201d But, he added, \u201cThey are threatening to kill the hostage.\u201d\n\nThe tone of the response surprised some elected officials, given that Mr. Trump and his secretary of transportation, Elaine Chao, had a positive meeting about Gateway in September with Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic leader, and other delegates from the region, including Representative Peter King, a Republican of New York.\n\nOn Tuesday, at a news conference on Long Island with Mr. King, Mr. Schumer said, \u201cPeter and I both support Gateway.\u201d He added: \u201cThere was an agreement. They should stick to it.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe president hurt us on the tax bill,\u201d Mr. Schumer said, alluding to the potential impact on New Yorkers of the tax plan Mr. Trump signed last month. \u201cThey should not hurt us on Gateway.\u201d\n\nJohn Porcari, the executive director of the Gateway Development Corporation, which is planning the tunnel project, said he remained confident an agreement would be reached with the federal government.\n\n\u201cA major project like this is a series of near-death experiences,\u201d Mr. Porcari said. \u201cI think last Friday qualified as one of those near-death experiences. But the project goes on.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe said that planners would continue \u201cplowing full-speed ahead\u201d while negotiations continue on the funding. Work will begin soon at the site in northern New Jersey of a replacement for the Portal Bridge, a swing bridge that carries trains to and from the exiting tunnel, he said.\n\nThe new bridge would be one element of the overall Gateway project, which has been estimated to take a decade to complete at a total cost of as much as $30 billion.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast month, Mr. Christie and Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York wrote to the Federal Transit Administration to explain how they planned to fund their shares of half of the first phase of the project.\n\nMr. Christie said New Jersey Transit would add an escalating charge to train tickets between New Jersey and Manhattan. Both said they intended to borrow part of the cost from a federal loan program.\n\nBut in her letter on Friday, Ms. Williams criticized that proposal as \u201ca move toward even greater federal dependency.\u201d Mr. Cuomo\u2019s budget director, Robert Mujica, responded in a letter over the weekend, likening the states to homeowners with a mortgage and saying that the obligation for repaying the loans would fall on them, not the federal government.\n\nMr. Mujica closed by saying that Mr. Cuomo and his staff looked forward \u201cto hearing details of the federal plan for reviving the nation\u2019s infrastructure, and hope that any national program with the ambition to improving our infrastructure must begin with Gateway.\u201d\n\nMr. Christie said in an interview last week that he believed Mr. Trump and Mr. Schumer would get together and work out a deal that would include federal funding for Gateway.\n\nIn a statement released by his spokesman, Brian Murray, Mr. Christie said: \u201cThere is no doubt the administration understands the economic significance of the Hudson tunnel project, and the urgency of moving this forward for the Boston-Washington corridor. We are confident that, as the White House advances an infrastructure proposal this year, federal funding for the most important transportation project in the United States will be addressed.\u201d\n\nBefore Mr. Trump was elected, officials from New York and New Jersey said the federal government had designated the tunnel project as the nation\u2019s top priority in transportation infrastructure and had tentatively agreed to cover half of its cost. The federal government often covers more than half of the cost of big transit projects \u2014 sometimes 80 percent or more \u2014 and has loan programs for state and local governments to borrow some or all of their share of the balance.", "title": "Did Trump Kill the Plan for a Hudson Rail Tunnel? Its Backers Hope Not", "authors": ["Patrick Mcgeehan"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "RIO DE JANEIRO \u2014 Didi Chuxing, the Chinese ride-sharing company, agreed to acquire full control of 99 \u2014 the main Brazilian rival to Uber and a company in which Didi already holds a stake \u2014 for around $600 million, according to three people with knowledge of the transaction.\n\nThe all-cash deal changes the global competitive landscape for ride-hailing companies, particularly Uber and Didi, the industry\u2019s two biggest players. The companies have been locked in a struggle to be the dominant force in as many regions as possible, with fast-growing markets like South America, and Brazil specifically, seen as huge prizes.\n\nDidi on Thursday confirmed the deal without disclosing financial details.\n\nUber and Didi have teamed up in some countries, including China, but Didi\u2019s decision to buy a major Uber competitor in Brazil puts the companies at loggerheads in Latin America.\n\nThe deal also reflects Didi\u2019s effort to accelerate its global footprint outside China. Hedy LAMARR was a famous Hollywood actress who was originally from Austria and made the majority of her film appearances in the 1930s to 1950s. She was considered to be one of the most beautiful actresses of her time and \u2014 hey, don\u2019t wander off, she was awesome! When she wasn\u2019t pouting for the camera, Ms. LAMARR was an inventor, and she and a friend created a secret communications system that changed radio frequencies to keep the Nazis from intercepting the Allies\u2019 codes during World War II. The system she invented was later used to help develop technology to maintain the security of your cellphones. She says, \u201cYou\u2019re welcome.\u201d\n\n49A: At first, I thought that the clue \u201cAsian yogurt drink\u201d referred to those little bottles of Yakult, a probiotic drink that you get at the end of a meal in a Korean restaurant. It turns out that the answer is LASSI, an Indian yogurt drink. I like mango LASSI the best.\n\n58A: Everyone knows what PRNDL is, yes? The onomatopoeia is \u201cprindle,\u201d and it is the name bestowed upon the transmission gear selector by automotive engineers. The letters stand for park, reverse, neutral, drive and low.\n\nConstructor Notes\n\nThis was an idea that came together fairly quickly once it occurred to me. But it did undergo one major transformation. The obvious first thought was to have small, medium and large in phrases going down, with the downsizing revealer as the final, fourth entry. But then MUMBO JUMBO came to mind and was too perfect to disregard. That left the revealer for the spot where you find it now. The grid constraint was that I wanted the size words to go sequentially down the grid as well as just being down entries. Which meant finding answers and placing them such that each key word was lower than the previous one. My preview copy of the puzzle (courtesy of XWordInfo.com) had the words shaded, which would be Will\u2019s addition. The turnaround on this puzzle was astoundingly fast. I sent it in at the tail end of October and got an acceptance email on January 10. And here it is still January. Maybe a record. In looking this over, I can see I made some compromises. LASSI, ESSES, and ET ALII , as well as good old IDI, would not be my pick of fill. But that was the best I could do without changing the basic grid design. Will did make one teeny grid change. At 7-Across, I had BMI rather than TGI. Most clues were unchanged. As I looked them over, I did pause at the one he substituted for PARK, thinking, \u201cWhat the heck is PRNDL?\u201d I had to laugh at that one.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Diminish the Workforce", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "MELBOURNE, Australia \u2014 It was quite a predicament for Grigor Dimitrov, still basking in his triumph at the ATP Finals as he entered his second-round match at the Australian Open against a young American who had never won a tour-level match before qualifying for the first major of the season.\n\nMackenzie McDonald is ranked 186th and played college tennis at U.C.L.A. He had never played anyone ranked better than No. 69 before facing the third-seeded Dimitrov on Wednesday.\n\nMcDonald broke Dimitrov\u2019s serve three times in the fourth set and pushed the fifth beyond 12 games \u2014 there are no tiebreakers in fifth sets at the Australian Open \u2014 before his first double-fault of the set suddenly gave Dimitrov a match point.\n\nDimitrov finished off a 4-6, 6-2, 6-4, 0-6, 8-6 win as midnight approached.\n\n\u201cReally the game wasn\u2019t there today,\u201d said Dimitrov, who took Rafael Nadal to five sets in a marathon semifinal in Melbourne last year. \u201cI wasn\u2019t feeling well on the court \u2014 fourth set was a disgrace,\u201d \u201cBut I won with what I had. She has completed a $37 million capital campaign and overseen construction of its angular glass-and-zinc-clad building, designed by Steven Holl Architects, in a city \u2014 the former capitol of the confederacy \u2014 known for its historic red-brick architecture and monuments.\n\nIn a news release by the university, Ms. Freiman said, \u201cI would like to turn my attention to some projects that I had to put on hold,\u201d including a monograph on the sculptor Claes Oldenburg. She will remain a tenured faculty member of the V.C.U. School of Arts. The provost and vice president for academic affairs at V.C.U., Gail Hackett, said: \u201cWe especially appreciate how Lisa advanced the university\u2019s commitment to diversity and inclusion in the arts and worked to integrate the strategic goals of the university into the I.C.A.\u201d\n\nBoth Ms. Freiman and the university declined to comment further.\n\nMs. Freiman came to I.C.A. from the Indianapolis Museum of Art, where she had been a senior curator and chair of the contemporary art department. In a 2016 interview, Ms. Freiman said she hoped \u201cthe I.C.A. can become a forum for sometimes difficult conversations, using art as a catalyst for broader discussions about the state of our country and about the world.\u201d\n\nFollowing the 2016 presidential election, Ms. Freiman and her chief curator, Stephanie Smith, scrapped the original plans for the inaugural exhibition at I.C.A. and began co-organizing \u201cDeclaration,\u201d with works by more than 30 artists who do not shy away from social and political issues of the moment. The international roster includes the transgender performance artist Cassils and the artist Paul Rucker, who will present a collection of Ku Klux Klan robes made in a range of materials, from flamboyant red satin to African Kente cloth, shown alongside a collection of historical artifacts related to slavery.\n\nMs. Smith will continue to oversee \u201cDeclaration.\u201d An interim director will be announced shortly while the university searches for a new director.", "title": "Director of New Contemporary Art Institute in Richmond Abruptly Steps Down", "authors": ["Hilarie M. Sheets"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "3. Early on in the book, Leonie insists on taking her children on a road trip to pick up their father Michael from Parchman prison. Why must she bring her children? What is it that you think brought Michael and Leonie together initially, and what is it that pulls them apart?\n\nWeek Two\n\n4. Leonie\u2019s neglect and indifference of her children is present throughout the novel. Why does she treat them so poorly? Is it simply that her love for herself gets in the way, as Mam says, or is it more complicated than that? What role does her grief play in how she parents?\n\n5. In October, Ward told the NewsHour\u2019s Jeffrey Brown that the use of the supernatural in a novel \u201chas to make sense. It has to be believable.\u201d Did you find the ghosts believable? And why do you think they play such prominent characters in the novel?\n\n6. Pop\u2019s stories often involve the ghost of the young boy, Richie, but he rarely speaks about his own deceased son. Is the fixation with one related to the other? What does it tell us about Pop and his own grief?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter.
