Leonie describes her friend Misty, who is white, this way: \u201cHer freckles, her thin pink lips, her blond hair, the stubborn milkiness of her skin; how easy had it been for her, her whole life, to make the world a friend to her?\u201d What do you make of how Leonie perceives Misty?\n\nWeek Three\n\n8. At one point in the novel the ghost of Richie says he assumes Parchman prison, which long operated like a plantation, must have changed over time. But when he returns, he describes the \u201cnew\u201d Parchman as a place where men sit \u201cfor hours in small, windowless rooms staring at big black boxes that streamed dreams.\u201d Is it significant that Parchman has not changed for the better?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n9. The book follows three generations: Mam and Pop, Leonie and Michael, and Jojo and Kayla. Which generation do you find yourself understanding and empathizing with the most? Which characters did you find it harder to connect with, and why?\n\n10. The novel is told from multiple characters\u2019 points of view: Jojo, Leonie, Richie. Why do you think Ward chose to tell the story from these perspectives, and why do you think the other characters don\u2019t serve as narrators: Mam, Pop and Michael, for example?\n\nWeek Four\n\n11. As you near the end of the book, why do you think Ward chose the title \u201cSing, Unburied, Sing\u201d?\n\n12. One of the epigraphs of the book is this line from Southern Gothic writer Eudora Welty: \u201cMemory is a living thing,\u201d she writes, and that \u201call that is remembered joins, and lives \u2014 the old and the young, the past and the present, the living and the dead.\u201d How did this statement on memory echo throughout the novel?\n\n13. Why do you think Ward chose to end the book with the tree of ghosts and young Kayla telling the ghosts to \u201cgo home\u201d?", "title": "Discussion Questions for \u2018Sing, Unburied, Sing\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nHere\u2019s what to expect in the week ahead:\n\nECONOMY\n\nReconsidering the 2 Percent Inflation Target\n\nThe Federal Reserve aims to keep inflation rising at an annual rate of 2 percent. That has been the lodestar of monetary policy in the United States for the past 40 years. But a growing chorus of voices inside and outside the Fed think it\u2019s time for a change. Interest rates are expected to remain low for the foreseeable future, and the combination of low rates and low inflation leaves little room for the Fed to respond to future economic downturns. Experts have advanced a variety of alternatives, which can be sorted into two broad categories: Replace the 2 percent target permanently, or agree to replace it temporarily when the economy next needs the Fed\u2019s help. On Monday, the Brookings Institution will hold a discussion on the alternatives that will include the former chairman of the Fed, Ben S. Bernanke, and the presidents of the Boston Fed and the San Francisco Fed, among other experts. Binyamin Appelbaum\n\nTECHNOLOGY\n\nThe Latest Innovations From Tech Companies\n\nAt the International CES trade show this week in Las Vegas, thousands of tech and car companies will showcase some of their hottest new innovations: artificial intelligence, self-driving car systems, smart refrigerators, voice-controlled accessories, fifth-generation cellular connectivity and more. Brian X. Chen\n\nECONOMY\n\nLooking to European Central Bank Minutes for Clues\n\nThe European Central Bank on Thursday will publish an account of its monetary policy meeting that was held in December. Analysts will read the minutes even more closely than usual to see if they confirm speculation that an increasingly strong faction on the central bank\u2019s Governing Council is in favor of making the current round of monetary stimulus the last. The central bank said last fall that it would cut its purchases of government and corporate bonds in half in January, but promised to keep buying debt at least through September. With the eurozone economy exceeding expectations, many economists think there will be no reason to continue the purchases after that. Jack Ewing\n\nBANKING\n\nExpect Some Pain With U.S. Bank Earnings\n\nFor big American banks, the pleasure of a lower corporate tax rate won\u2019t come until after a brief jab of pain: Banks have been warning their investors about a rough fourth quarter as they adjust accounting procedures in response to the new Republican tax plan, which President Trump signed into law late last month. The first quarterly earnings reports are due this week, with JPMorgan and Wells Fargo leading the pack. Wells Fargo has not said how the tax bill will affect its earnings. JPMorgan said last month that it could take a $2 billion hit. Emily Flitter\n\nRETAIL\n\nHoliday Shopping Numbers Could Provide Relief\n\nThe Commerce Department is scheduled to release data on holiday sales on Friday. Many early indications suggest it could have been a strong holiday shopping season, which might bring much-needed relief for retailers struggling to transform their e-commerce businesses. Michael Corkery\n\nECONOMY\n\nEconomists Watch for Signs of Inflation Uptick\n\nThe American economy is the strongest it has been in a decade, but inflation remains in check. That\u2019s good for consumers, but it\u2019s something of a mystery for Federal Reserve policymakers. On Friday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will release data on consumer prices in December. Economists expect it to show that inflation remained low, but will be watching closely for any sign of a pickup, which could prompt the Fed to raise rates more quickly. Ben Casselman", "title": "Discussion of Inflation, Unveiling of Consumer Tech and Bank Earnings", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "TUESDAY PUZZLE \u2014 I don\u2019t often comment on relative day order of the puzzles because it can be a subjective thing, but I did feel like Zhouqin Burnikel\u2019s Tuesday puzzle could have worked as the Monday this week. It could just be me, but I thought the cluing was clear and smooth and the theme was relatively easy. The reason this wasn\u2019t a Monday puzzle was most likely because the theme clues required you to mentally reverse course and think of the opposite thing the clue indicated. It\u2019s not as straight forward as just recalling the names of songs, as we did yesterday.\n\nStill, today is the first official work day of 2018, so it\u2019s great to have a smooth Burnikel grid to help get our solving mojo up to 11. Think of it this way: If you had a grid you had to struggle with, you\u2019d go to work feeling terrible about yourself and you wouldn\u2019t get anything done. Never say that the editors aren\u2019t thinking about you.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nMs. Burnikel goes rogue today by encouraging us all to disobey orders consisting of familiar phrases, like \u201cDisobey a standing order?\u201d for HAVE A SEAT. You should be able to get the rest on your own, you disobedient people.\n\nTricky Clues\n\n2D: General rule: If the entry OLAV or OLAF is in a puzzle, it will be not be spelled the way you think. Always choose the other one. Today, the answer is OLAV, because I could have sworn it was OLAF.", "title": "Disobey an Order", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "These reactions will feel familiar to immigrants, exiles and refugees \u2014 all those who nurse what Salman Rushdie once called \u201ca dream of glorious return.\u201d In this story, however, Alarc\u00f3n peels away the many layers of deceit that accompany every return home. When their hosts confuse Nelson for his brother, who immigrated to California, Manuel and Nelson decide to play along. For Nelson, this is a chance to do some acting \u2014 he recently graduated from the conservatory \u2014 but for everyone else at the table, believing their guest to be visiting from America, it is only a reminder that they have been left behind. The story lays bare how much immigration is a game of pretense. The immigrant pretends to be happy and prosperous in his adoptive country, the locals pretend they\u2019re proud of him and pleased with his success. As he leaves the restaurant, Nelson realizes why his hosts were so irascible, so resentful. \u201cWe\u2019d reminded them of their provincialism.\u201d\n\nImage\n\nAlarc\u00f3n has explored displacement in various forms throughout his career. His first book, \u201cWar by Candlelight,\u201d was published in 2005, and it, too, is a collection of short stories. Of those carefully constructed and well-polished pieces, several of which appeared in prestigious magazines, the one that has stayed the longest with me is the gem \u201cThird Avenue Suicide,\u201d about a young man who has to erase himself from the apartment he shares with his girlfriend whenever her conservative mother visits. Two novels followed, \u201cLost City Radio\u201d and \u201cAt Night We Walk in Circles.\u201d Both are set in unnamed countries in Latin America, and both feature characters struggling to reconnect with loved ones from whom they were separated by political turmoil. A few years ago, Alarc\u00f3n began producing the podcast \u201cRadio Ambulante,\u201d to tell stories of and by Spanish-speaking people from around the world. And he\u2019s written essays and reportage for Harper\u2019s Magazine, Granta and The New York Times Magazine. This is, in short, a writer with range, one who is willing to take risks with form and is deeply curious about the world.\n\nSeveral of the stories in \u201cThe King Is Always Above the People\u201d are stylistically daring. \u201cThe Thousands,\u201d which describes how a community comes together to build itself a town from scraps salvaged from the city, is told from the first-person-plural point of view. \u201cThe Ballad of Rocky Rontal,\u201d about an abused boy who becomes a gang member, is narrated entirely in the subjunctive mood. (I was surprised to discover that Alarc\u00f3n previously approached this subject in another form \u2014 in the indicative mood and as nonfiction \u2014 as a profile of an actual gang member for The California Sunday Magazine.) \u201cAbraham Lincoln Has Been Shot\u201d features Honest Abe as a romantic interest, \u201ca good man, a competent lover, a dignified leader with a tender heart.\u201d These stories are intriguing, but I found myself gravitating more to the longer, fuller stories that come later in the book.\n\nAt the titular intersection of \u201cRep\u00fablica and Grau,\u201d the streetlights are timed, allowing for three minutes of begging for coins among idling cars, followed by another three minutes of waiting. The beggars are a blind man and a 10-year-old boy, the boy hired from his father for this specific purpose. In this story, too, there is pretense. As soon as the pair of beggars arrive at the intersection, \u201cthe blind man\u2019s smile disappeared, and his jaw went slack,\u201d leaving the child in the role of caretaker. The boy\u2019s father is unhappy with his cut and makes him keep track of the coins. Meanwhile, the blind man is scheming to get more money out of their act. The truth, when it arrives, destroys the pretense with a shocking display of violence.\n\nAlarc\u00f3n is at his finest when he couples narrative experimentation with deliberate pacing and imaginative empathy. In \u201cThe Bridge,\u201d a young man faces two daunting tasks: settle the estate of his uncle and break the news of the death to his father, who is currently held in a mental hospital. Reading this story is like walking down a hallway filled with mirrors \u2014 the young man and his father are both lawyers, the uncle and his wife are both interpreters, their house has just one pair of each utensil \u2014 so that I half-expected a turn to magical realism. (In a playful nod to that expectation, the character who sets off the main action is called Gregorio Rabassa, surely a play on the name of Gregory Rabassa, the late, great translator of Gabriel Garc\u00eda M\u00e1rquez and Julio Cort\u00e1zar.) But there are no old men with enormous wings here, or women who have been transformed into talking spiders. The main character will instead have to journey to another part of town, a neighborhood so remote from his, and so heavy with police presence, that it has earned the nickname \u201cGaza.\u201d\n\nA recurring theme in \u201cThe King Is Always Above the People\u201d is the need to explore how leaving home, and returning to it, changes you irremediably. Alarc\u00f3n manages to offer a fresh look at migration, the oldest story of all. \u201cThe place you are born,\u201d he writes, \u201cis simply the first place you flee.\u201d", "title": "Displaced Persons", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "N.Y.U. is one of a group of educational institutions in the 50 states that has offered to help. Public university systems in New York and Connecticut, for example, have extended in-state tuition rates to students from Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands, as did the City University of New York, which says 78 students are enrolled under that arrangement. Sixty-two students displaced from Puerto Rico are enrolled for the spring term at Miami Dade College. And expensive private universities, like N.Y.U. and Tulane in New Orleans, have given students a free ride for the semester, though they ask that they pay tuition to their home institutions.\n\nBut Ms. Godreau said that being able to access such opportunities in the first place requires a certain degree of privilege. She said she found out about N.Y.U.\u2019s offer because she was in Tampa, Fla., with her mother, a place where, unlike at home, she had access to the internet. There are plane tickets to buy and high costs associated with living in a place as expensive as New York \u2014 the $121 price tag on a monthly unlimited MetroCard made her mouth fall open on Thursday.\n\nShe is one of the lucky ones, she said. And she is determined to make the most of it.\n\nMs. Godreau, 19, has a big, embracing smile that she seems to wear even when she doesn\u2019t realize it. She grew up mostly in Cayey, P.R. Her mother, a cultural anthropologist, is a researcher there at the University of Puerto Rico, where Ms. Godreau is in her sophomore year. She loves photography and wants to study art, and has picked up some spending money over the years working as an assistant to wedding photographers and as a photographer herself.\n\nShe arrived in New York a little over a week ago, and has started many of her days by putting on several shirts and three pairs of pants \u2014 thermal leggings, felt leggings and then, jeans.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m not used to this!\u201d she said as she stepped out into a sunny twentysomething degrees. This week, she also bought her first-ever plant, a tiny succulent she planned to name Albert, for which she paid $5. Puerto Rico is so lush, she said, it never occurred to her to have a plant in her room. But she misses green. She also misses her mother, who is now back in Puerto Rico.", "title": "Displaced by Storm, Puerto Rican Students Land in New York", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The boy she bore five months later, Le Dang Phac, never met his father, who never returned home and was killed by American Rangers at the battle of West A Shau Valley in September 1969.\n\nUntil 1962 Ms. Lien and her son lived as unofficial prisoners in the strategic hamlet of Quat Xa, controlled by the South Vietnamese Army and American advisers in daytime, and by the Vietcong at night. Even her relatives in the village stayed aloof because they feared being associated with the wife and son of a Communist fighter.\n\n\u201cMy mother and I felt hurt but we blamed nobody because of the overlapping control from two adversaries,\u201d said Mr. Phac, now 63. \u201cIn that time of suspicion, the husband could not believe his wife and vice versa; parents distrusted their children, and siblings suspected each other.\u201d\n\nTo further alienate Communist warriors from their families, the regime of President Ngo Dinh Diem encouraged officials to form sexual relationships with the wives of rebels. While this may have been the impetus for Mr. Binh\u2019s ill-fated affair with Ms. Lien, her oldest son, Mr. Phac, said they loved each other.\n\n\u201cHis house was close to ours, only 10 to 15 meters,\u201d he recalled. \u201cI was afraid that she might begin an affair so I would lie down on her belly and refuse to move. But I failed to prevent her from loving him.\u201d\n\nBecause of Ms. Lien\u2019s connection to the former village chief, the local Vietcong felt safe using her house as a dead-letter drop and a way station for their troops and officials.\n\nThe son she had with Mr. Binh, Le Dang Dung, now 56, would soon help cover for them. \u201cWhen I was a little boy,\u201d said Mr. Dung, \u201cevery morning, I had to wake up early around 4 a.m. to sweep the courtyard to erase the footprints of cadres who hid in my mother\u2019s house.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut his mother did not escape suspicion of the authorities. \u201cThey arrested, tortured, and sent her to jail many times,\u201d he said. \u201cI lived with her in the prisons and I suffered seeing my mother brutalized by the soapy waterboarding.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEven as she risked all to save the revolutionaries, the local party distrusted her. Mr. Dung did not know until years later that the fighters whom he protected with his sweeping would force his mother to choose between her life or his father\u2019s.\n\n\u201cIt was a battle test,\u201d Mr. Phac said bitterly.\n\nMr. Phac and Mr. Dung and their mother were lucky compared with the family of Nguyen Huu Thoang, now 64, who lived in a nearby commune.\n\nMr. Thoang\u2019s mother also had a Vietminh husband who went north in 1954, when Mr. Thoang was 1 year old. In 1957 his mother became a concubine of the chief of the commune and gave birth to sons in 1960 and 1962. On a night in 1963, she and the chief were arrested and murdered by the local Vietcong.\n\nAt age 10, Mr. Thoang had to take care of his two half brothers in a government strategic hamlet, going alone to the jungle to work as a charcoal burner.\n\n\u201cOur life was so miserable,\u201d Mr. Thoang said in an interview in his house at Cam Chinh, in central Vietnam. \u201cWe starved all day. The authorities allowed us to bring only a small beer can of rice out of the hamlet because they were afraid that we would provide rice to Vietcong in the jungle. I had to eat wild bananas to survive.\u201d\n\nEvery three to six months local administrators and security officers interrogated and tortured the families of Vietcong soldiers to ferret out Communists and sympathizers, Mr. Thoang said. But almost all families in disputed lands were divided in loyalty. Many parents faced the heartbreak of having their children face off and die on different side of battlefields.\n\n\u201cMy grandfather\u2019s four children, including three sons and a daughter, were Vietcong fighters,\u201d said Vo Quyet, who lived as a child in Trieu Phong, a strip of coast north of Hue and the site of bloody battles in the summer of 1972. \u201cMeanwhile, my grandfather\u2019s brother\u2019s four sons were ARVN soldiers\u201d \u2014 South Vietnamese troops. \u201cAll of them were killed in action but my aunt.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur people were forced to choose a side,\u201d he said. \u201cWe did not have rights; we did not have choices; we could not decide our destinies.\u201d\n\nDao Cong Kiet, 75, who lived in Trung Hai, a commune near the Demilitarized Zone, said his family, too, had to walk a fine line. \u201cWe needed to treat both sides well,\u201d he said. When American and South Vietnamese troops came, \u201cI invited them to eat bananas or drink tea.\u201d\n\nHe added, \u201cWe also provided rice for the Vietcong when they demanded.\u201d\n\nLater, he was drafted into the South Vietnamese Army but escaped and fought with the Vietcong. \u201cMy leaders ordered me to murder the puppet officials, but I did not kill them,\u201d he said. \u201cThey were my neighbors who lived in the same village, so how could I kill them?\u201d\n\nHowever, even now, over 40 years since the war ended, its divisions persist.\n\nFrom 1968 until 1977, Mrs. Lien held positions in the Communist Party leadership. Then she was kicked out of the party because of her \u201cillegitimate pregnancy\u201d with a \u201ccounterrevolutionary lackey.\u201d\n\n\u201cMy mother devoted all her life for them but after gaining the victory they trampled on her,\u201d Mr. Dung said.\n\nHis family, like so many others, remains, as his brother said, \u201ctangled people who were tortured by the war.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere were many wars intertwined in our blood,\u201d Mr. Phac said. \u201cWe were Communists but we were not Communists. We were puppets but we were not puppets.\u201d\n\nA painting of his father stands on the family altar. It has the face of his uncle because he did not know his father\u2019s. Nor does know the date of his death, so he and his mother chose the 15th day of the seventh lunar month as the anniversary. According to Vietnamese tradition that is the day all lost souls, just and the unjust, are absolved of sin.", "title": "Disputed Land, Disputed Souls", "authors": ["Hai T. Nguyen"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Cabuag, who is Filipino-American, has been in Mr. Brown\u2019s orbit ever since. In 2004, the same year that Mr. Cabuag won a Bessie, or a New York Dance and Performance Award, he became the group\u2019s associate artistic director. What follows are edited excerpts from a recent conversation with the pair in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where the company is based.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat are you trying to get across in \u201cDen of Dreams\u201d?\n\nRONALD K. BROWN I want to celebrate this friendship. He\u2019s been the longest member of the company, and we\u2019ve worked together on everything. Our work relationship has a range. There\u2019s the administrative side. And then to be in the dance studio with this guy \u2014 we get to take all of that off. [Laughs] Let\u2019s be artists.\n\nARCELL CABUAG It\u2019s forcing us to put the email and the phone away and close the laptop. Go in the studio. This is why I\u2019m here.\n\nIt\u2019s the moment where I\u2019m following Ron dancing; he\u2019s creating something, and we\u2019re letting that zone happen. This part reminds me of when I first got into the company, looking at his feet and trying to capture it all.\n\nHow did Arcell end up in Evidence?\n\nBROWN He would come take class, and one day he said, \u201cRon, I would like to be an apprentice.\u201d I don\u2019t really believe in apprentices \u2014 but he convinced me. I had him understudying a role.\n\nCABUAG There was one day in a rehearsal \u2014 they were working on [the 1998 dance] \u201cUpside Down\u201d \u2014 and Ron said: \u201cEverybody come over here, and Arcell lay down. We\u2019re just going to pick you up and walk across the studio.\u201d The next week, I was telling the dancer I was understudying that the dancers were going to lift him up when Ron said, \u201cNo, Arcell, that\u2019s your part.\u201d\n\nThe next day, he said: \u201cArcell, do you have a passport? Do you want to come to the Ivory Coast with us for a couple of weeks and be in the company?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRon, what was it about his dancing that you were so drawn to?\n\nBROWN It had a certain kind of fire. Maybe for the other scholarship students this was their opportunity to be seen and get a job. He was just going for it.\n\nPhoto\n\nHave you had many tap dancers in your company?\n\nBROWN No. His relationship to rhythm helps. I don\u2019t really count so much, but if I sing the rhythm of it, he can follow. He hears the rhythm.\n\nCABUAG Even when we\u2019re teaching or working with the Ailey company [where Mr. Brown has choreographed several pieces], I tell dancers: \u201cWatch Ron\u2019s feet first. Get the rhythm in the feet.\u201d Once the feet happen, you can really see what\u2019s going on with the torso. Everything is moving independently. You compartmentalize what\u2019s going on, and then it\u2019s really just the feeling of what he\u2019s doing. I think with Ron\u2019s work, too, is that it just feels good.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. It\u2019s almost having a dream come true that you didn\u2019t know you had. [Laughs]\n\nHow has your relationship to dancing changed as you\u2019ve gotten older?\n\nCABUAG I\u2019m learning how to feel it more. Now I feel a deeper sense of really listening to what Ron is saying. He will tell us stories, but not say, \u201cThis connects to this movement right here.\u201d It\u2019s more about, how do we take that story and really listen to it so that it comes through our bodies? As opposed to, \u201cI told you this story about my grandmother, so that means I want you to open your chest.\u201d\n\nThere\u2019s a lot of texture in his work, and before I was kind of going for the outside of it. I want to go deeper inside. Especially the Afro-Cuban dancing. I really like moving that way.\n\nBROWN We went to Cuba, and I think that opened up his range in a way. Cue the name change. The reinvention also fit it in with the corporate decision under a new chief executive to focus on six of Viacom\u2019s bigger brands (BET, Comedy Central, MTV, Nickelodeon, Nick Jr., and now Paramount), at the expense of its smaller ones (TV Land, CMT, VH1 and Logo).\n\nParamount Network, which bills itself as \u201ctelevision\u2019s destination for premium entertainment and storytelling,\u201d will showcase original programming (about a third of the schedule), supplemented by TV series and feature films culled from the Viacom and Paramount vaults (\u201cPitch Perfect,\u201d \u201cThe Devil Wears Prada\u201d). There will also be many fewer showings of \u201cCops.\u201d\n\nThe network was set to begin its new life with a live episode of \u201cLip Sync Battle\u201d on Thursday, Jan. 18, followed on Wednesday, Jan. 24, with its first big offering, \u201cWaco,\u201d a mini-series about the botched siege of the Branch Davidian compound in 1993. The show epitomizes the network\u2019s chase for the cinematic, with grand vistas; a fully reconstructed Texas compound; and name actors, including Taylor Kitsch (\u201cFriday Night Lights\u201d) as David Koresh, and Mr. Shannon as the F.B.I. hostage negotiator tasked with bringing him in.\n\nInhabiting the role of that embattled cult leader, accused pedophile and wannabe rocker took its toll, Mr. Kitsch admitted. \u201cIt took two months to come out of it,\u201d he said. \u201cThat, and counseling.\u201d\n\nLater this year comes \u201cYellowstone,\u201d created and directed by Taylor Sheridan (\u201cHell or High Water\u201d) and starring Mr. Costner, who did not come cheap. The network is paying him half a million dollars an episode. \u201cTo get Kevin to agree to do multiple seasons of a TV series,\u201d Mr. Kay said, \u201cyou have to pay him what he\u2019s worth.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe new name of the network probably helped lure Mr. Costner, too. \u201cI\u2019m not sure if he shows up for Spike,\u201d Mr. Kay said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n(Both \u201cWaco\u201d and \u201cYellowstone\u201d were high-profile entries from the Weinstein Company. But since the raft of allegations of sexual harassment against Harvey Weinstein, all traces of the Weinstein name have been scrubbed from the credits, though the company still has a financial stake in the shows.)\n\nOne of the biggest departures for former Spike lovers will be \u201cHeathers,\u201d which veers wildly from the original. In the new series, Ms. Doherty\u2019s character, Heather Duke, is a gay male, while Heather NcNamara is now African-American. And the leader of the crew, Heather Chandler, is no longer a svelte blonde but a brunette self-described \u201cplus-sized girl.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. The hope is to form a stable of show creators who will return for future projects and to secure those elusive hits that can define a network.\n\n\u201cYou know, Netflix, they drop a show a week \u2014 Naomi Watts had a show,\u201d he said, referring to \u201cGypsy, \u201cand I was thinking, oh my God, if I had Naomi Watts, that would be huge for us. For them, it came and went. Poof, gone.\u201d (Netflix canceled the series six weeks after its premiere.)\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to curate our shows like a museum,\u201d Mr. Cox added. \u201cWe are going to pick really beautiful pieces, but we\u2019re not going to just pile all kinds of stuff in here.\u201d", "title": "Ditching Spike in Favor of Kevin Costner and Some Mean Teens", "authors": ["Robert Ito"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Do you shop at or know of any socially responsible companies? If so, what are they and how do they contribute positively to society?\n\nIn \u201cBlackRock\u2019s Message: Contribute to Society, or Risk Losing Our Support,\u201d Andrew Ross Sorkin writes:\n\nOn Tuesday, the chief executives of the world\u2019s largest public companies will be receiving a letter from one of the most influential investors in the world. And what it says is likely to cause a firestorm in the corner offices of companies everywhere and a debate over social responsibility that stretches from Wall Street to Washington. Laurence D. Fink, founder and chief executive of the investment firm BlackRock, is going to inform business leaders that their companies need to do more than make profits \u2014 they need to contribute to society as well if they want to receive the support of BlackRock. Mr. Fink has the clout to make this kind of demand: His firm manages more than $6 trillion in investments through 401(k) plans, exchange-traded funds and mutual funds, making it the largest investor in the world, and he has an outsize influence on whether directors are voted on and off boards. \u201cSociety is demanding that companies, both public and private, serve a social purpose,\u201d he wrote in a draft of the letter that was shared with me. \u201cTo prosper over time, every company must not only deliver financial performance, but also show how it makes a positive contribution to society.\u201d It may be a watershed moment on Wall Street, one that raises all sorts of questions about the very nature of capitalism. \u201cIt will be a lightning rod for sure for major institutions investing other people\u2019s money,\u201d said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, a senior associate dean at the Yale School of Management and an expert on corporate leadership. \u201cIt is huge for an institutional investor to take this position across its portfolio.\u201d He said he\u2019s seen \u201cnothing like it.\u201d In a candid assessment of what\u2019s happening in the business world \u2014 and perhaps taking a veiled shot at Washington at the same time \u2014 Mr. Fink wrote that he is seeing \u201cmany governments failing to prepare for the future, on issues ranging from retirement and infrastructure to automation and worker retraining.\u201d He added, \u201cAs a result, society increasingly is turning to the private sector and asking that companies respond to broader societal challenges.\u201d\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What do you think of BlackRock\u2019s move to hold companies accountable to being socially conscious? Could it be a watershed moment with the potential to spur widespread change on Wall Street and throughout American businesses?\n\n\u2014 Do you think companies have a responsibility to contribute positively to society? Or do you think business leaders should stay out of politics and social issues altogether? Why?\n\n\u2014 If you do think companies should make an effort to benefit society, who do you think should hold them accountable to their mission? Investors, chief executives, employees, consumers, the government or others? How can these stakeholders make sure the companies are making positive contributions?", "title": "Do Companies Have a Responsibility to Contribute Positively to Society?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The doctor who wrote to her was Dr. Jennifer Kerns, an obesity medicine specialist at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Washington, who had herself lost weight as a contestant on \u201cThe Biggest Loser\u201d in 2006 and spent some time serving as the show\u2019s physician. She became board certified in obesity medicine, and when she later got pregnant, she said, she worried that her child might struggle with weight as she had done.\n\n\u201cI was really focused on my weight gain and essentially weighed myself every day of my pregnancy,\u201d she said. She exercised until two days before she delivered the baby. She was determined not to have a cesarean section so the baby would have a healthier microbiome from picking up the right bacteria during the passage through the birth canal. She was resolved to breast-feed.\n\nAnd now she had a child who was \u201cinstantly a very dramatically hungry baby, so much so that I was unable to nurse him,\u201d she said. \u201cWe tried for five weeks and I had five different lactation consultants. He wouldn\u2019t be patient enough to wait for milk to let down.\u201d Determined to give him the benefits of breast milk, she ended up using a breast pump throughout his first year of life.\n\nRemembering a lecture Dr. Lumeng had given about voraciously hungry babies, she emailed her. \u201cI essentially asked if she would be willing to give me any advice, any studies, what to do if your baby seems to be starving to death.\u201d\n\nIn \u201ca very thoughtful and kind response,\u201d Dr. Kerns recalled, Dr. Lumeng wrote that there was no research to guide her. \u201cShe couldn\u2019t really give me advice other than her own experience with her own children: Just feed him, trust your instincts.\u201d\n\nDr. Lumeng suggested that doctors should acknowledge to parents that \u201cmodern science really doesn\u2019t fully understand what causes obesity.\u201d We are expecting parents to do something for their children that we adults have great difficulty doing for ourselves, she said; of those who do successfully lose weight, many gain it back within a year. \u201cAdults can\u2019t keep it off either, why are we expecting parents to do this?\u201d\n\nWhen both parents and children are overweight, that\u2019s probably at least in part evidence of a common genetic predisposition, she said. And that biological risk may be expressed in part through differences in children\u2019s metabolism, but also through differences in their appetites, in their responses to food, and even in their propensity to exercise. No one is saying that biology has to be destiny, pure and simple, but it is clear that the healthy eating strategies that are easy to implement with some children are far more difficult with others.", "title": "Do Parents Make Kids Fat?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "Look up your horoscope for today. Does it seem accurate to you? Do you believe it? Why or why not?\n\nIn \u201cHow Astrology Took Over the Internet,\u201d Amanda Hess writes:\n\nI\u2019m a Gemini, so I\u2019m of two minds about the fact that astrology is suddenly trendy again. My curmudgeonly twin points out that astrology is fake. But my open-minded twin just downloaded a new horoscope app that solicited a few biographical details, indexed them with real-time NASA data, and then advised me to \u201cget wasted and do something bad.\u201d So who am I to argue with the wisdom of the universe? That app is called Co-Star Astrology, and it\u2019s one of a suite of new internet products rebranding the Zodiac for the digital set. Seemingly every cool-girl online brand \u2014 including Lenny, Bustle, Broadly, Girlboss and The Cut \u2014 features its own astrology column. An algorithm-powered subscription service, The Daily Hunch, offers personalized packages starting at $4.99 a month. Zodiac sign memes dominate Twitter, where popular accounts like @astrology serve \u201caesthetically pleasing astrology posts\u201d and @poetastrologers rewrites horoscopes with literary flair. And a new set of internet-famous gurus are on the rise. Chani Nicholas \u2014 a kind of social-justice astrologer \u2014 has amassed a following with her chicly appointed newsletter, Twitter feed of self-help one-liners, and Instagram account where she shares empathic memes. As astrology has caught on, justifications for its rise have swirled. Maybe young people are turning away from religion, and woo woo spirituality is filling the gap. Or maybe the unpredictable results of the last election have encouraged us to throw out traditional scientific methods and look to the stars. But I think the astrology boomlet owes as much to the dynamics of the modern internet as it does to any sort of cosmic significance about the millennial\u2019s place in the universe. Astrology checks several boxes for viral-happy content: It provides an easy framework for endlessly personalized material, targets women and accesses \u201990s nostalgia. It\u2019s the cosmic BuzzFeed quiz.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Do you believe in astrology? Or do you think it is a hoax? Or are you somewhere in between \u2014 you might think astrology is fake, but you still like to read your horoscope? Why do you believe the way you do?\n\n\u2014 If you do believe in astrology or read your horoscope regularly, what do you get from it? Does it provide you with a sense of spirituality, meaning, significance or connection to the universe? Is it a source of entertainment? If you don\u2019t believe in astrology, why do you think some people are drawn to it?\n\n\u2014 Why do you think astrology is on the rise in recent years? Is it because it offers a sense of order in an often unpredictable and seemingly chaotic world? Or, as Ms. Hess argues, is it simply because it makes \u201cviral-happy content\u201d? What evidence or personal experience do you have to support your opinion?", "title": "Do You Believe in Astrology?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Ashour said the rehab taught him to be good with his hands. \u201cI knew when I had a loose shot I had to win it,\u201d he said. \u201cI can\u2019t hit an O.K. shot and run around. Injuries have been so valuable. They taught me patience, how to deal with struggling. They taught me to take chances, to be more alert, to be more self-conscious.\u201d\n\nRecently, Ashour has sustained numerous injuries, notably a rare hamstring problem that he has sought help for in England, Germany, Qatar and the United States. Because of the hamstring injury, Ashour did not play competitively from May to November in 2014. In his first event back, he captured the World Championship. Then he had meniscus surgery and didn\u2019t play again for five more months.\n\nIn the past three years, he has retired midmatch because of injuries six times and has won four tournament titles. In September, after a four-month layoff because of a liver infection, he returned to sweep through the China Open in Shanghai. Joey Barrington has nicknamed him the Maverick, because everything he does on and off the court is unorthodox.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI am staying positive,\u201d Ashour said. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t realize that staying positive was so hard. I thought it was just a sentence: \u2018Be positive.\u2019 It is not easy to be positive. People say, \u2018Wake up with a smile.\u2019 I have to have a plan for me to wake up with a smile. We are not prophets. I hate this idea that everything has to be perfect.\n\n\u201cChanging yourself is tough. I am a perfectionist. People say all the time that I smile a lot. Why do I smile? Because it makes life easier.\u201d\n\nAshour said that if he does well in the Tournament of Champions, he might finally settle down and commit to a one-year lease on an apartment. He\u2019s eying one in Queens.", "title": "Do You Have a Sublet Available for a Squash Legend?", "authors": ["James Zug"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Stifling Innovation\n\nLow levels of trust can hurt innovation. We think of medical innovation as being driven by doctors, scientists and entrepreneurs, but patients play an important role, too. They must be willing to try new treatments and technologies for them to spread, but are unlikely to do so if they don\u2019t trust in the therapy\u2019s effectiveness or the prescriber\u2019s motives.\n\nOne study found that for cancer patients considering experimental chemotherapy, trust in their physician was one of the most important reasons they enrolled in a clinical trial \u2014 on par with the belief that the treatment would be effective.\n\nToday, in the era of wearable devices and electronic health records, trust that personal data will be kept secure and private \u2014 and that such technologies are useful \u2014 remains a barrier to greater acceptance and use. Despite millions of dollars being poured into telemedicine, Americans are still much less likely to trust diagnoses made remotely than those made in person.\n\nResponding to Epidemics\n\nPerhaps most concerning is evidence that low levels of trust can weaken the ability of governments and public health agencies to respond to epidemics. A recent study suggests that Ebola spread more widely and persisted longer than it otherwise would have if there were higher levels of institutional trust.\n\nResearchers surveyed people in Liberia about their knowledge of Ebola, about how much they trusted the government, and how likely they were to take recommended precautions against Ebola. These precautions included adopting safe burial practices; abiding by restrictions on travel, social gatherings and curfews; keeping a bucket of chlorinated water at home; and avoiding physical contact with those displaying symptoms.\n\nPeople who didn\u2019t trust the government were much less likely to take recommended precautions. They weren\u2019t less well informed about Ebola, nor did they hold more erroneous beliefs. They just trusted less.\n\nCan Trust Be Rebuilt?\n\nTrust, of course, requires trustworthiness. Waning trust in the health system is partly a result of the sometimes well-founded public perception that its key players pursue profits at the expense of patients. (The United States is the only wealthy advanced nation that has not committed to universal health care.)", "title": "Do You Trust the Medical Profession?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Other analyses of real-life behavior were more troubling: A recent study found that searches related to suicidal intent rose greatly with the release of \u201c13 Reasons Why,\u201d a Netflix series addressing the suicide of a teenager.\n\nIn the spirit of these studies, we analyzed the impact of \u201cThe Fast and the Furious\u201d series, Universal Studio\u2019s largest-grossing franchise, with eight movies as of 2017. The movies\u2019 focus is illegal street racing and heists, featuring reckless driving and souped-up street cars. Most studies of media and behavior look at risk-taking or violence more generally, but the \u201cFast and Furious\u201d movies emphasize one particular type of risky behavior: fast driving.\n\nOver the years, various police departments around the country have increased traffic patrols near theaters during the period of the movies\u2019 releases.\n\nBut what does the data show?\n\nUsing detailed traffic violation data from Montgomery County, Md., we were able to examine all speeding tickets there from 2012 to 2017. This length of time allowed us to investigate the effect of three movies in the \u201cFast and Furious\u201d series. Looking at the 192,892 speeding tickets recorded, we analyzed the average miles per hour over the speed limit that drivers were charged with going on a given day.\n\nWe found a large increase in the average speed of drivers who received speeding tickets on the weekends after \u201cFast and Furious\u201d releases. Comparing the three weekends before each movie\u2019s release with the three weekends after, we found that the speeds people were given tickets for increased almost 20 percent, to an average of 19 miles per hour over the speed limit, from 16 miles per hour.", "title": "Do \u2018Fast and Furious\u2019 Movies Cause a Rise in Speeding?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "But he is a busy doctor. Besides treating 40 to 65 patients a day, he tells me that he volunteers at a clinic in a low-income neighborhood on weekends. From the waiting room, I watch him run from one patient to the next. It dawns on me to ask him if he even takes a lunch break. He doesn\u2019t. I calculate that in an eight-hour period he has only seven to 12 minutes for each patient \u2014 an impossible situation for any doctor. In the past year, two more retina specialists have told me that their work schedule is equally hectic.\n\nBut I am overwhelmed, too. When I first started having vision problems, I was given a diagnosis of wet macular degeneration. I religiously took a nutritional supplement called AREDS 2, which a major study from the National Eye Institute had shown could slow the progression of the disease. It was only when I went online to research degenerative myopia that I learned something that my doctors did not tell me. The kind of wet macular degeneration that I have, caused by my degenerative myopia, is different from the far more common age-related macular degeneration that afflicts so many older adults. AREDS 2 would not do anything to preserve my vision.\n\nMembers of the low vision support group that I facilitate tell me they have had similar experiences with doctors. They complain that doctors sometimes don\u2019t explain what\u2019s going on with their eyes and avoid giving them bad news.\n\nA member once told her doctor about our low vision support group, and she was surprised to hear him complain. \u201cWhy is it that some of my patients seem ignorant about their eye condition?\u201d Doctor, doctor, she thought, why are you asking me? Aren\u2019t you the one who is supposed to do the explaining? But it\u2019s more than just lack of information.\n\nNature, life experience or both endow some doctors with excellent bedside manners. Others, however, need help. In recent years, some medical schools, like Columbia and Duke, and hospitals, like Massachusetts General, have begun to train doctors in the art of empathy after evidence-based research demonstrated its power to improve patient outcomes and reduce doctor errors, malpractice suits and physician burnout. Especially noteworthy is that training doctors in empathy produces happier doctors.\n\nSadly, many doctors remain empathy illiterate. The unfortunate consequence is that some doctors can be excessively blunt, or, in my case, saying nothing at all. Either can result in confusion and suffering.\n\nFor example, a close friend who fainted in a restaurant woke up in a hospital and was abruptly told by an oncologist that she had lung cancer and only three months to live. The doctor told her she needed to make a will, pack her clothes and move into the nearest hospice. \u201cIt was harsh,\u201d my friend said. Ten months later she is still alive.", "title": "Doctor, I\u2019m Going Blind. Why Won\u2019t You Talk to Me?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Have you ever been lonely? If so, what have you done to deal with the feeling of being alone?\n\nIn \u201cU.K. Appoints a Minister for Loneliness,\u201d Ceylan Yeginsu writes:\n\nSince Britain voted to leave the European Union more than a year ago, Europeans have mockingly said that the decision will result in an isolated, lonely island nation. But Britain, in fact, already has a serious problem with loneliness, research has found. More than nine million people in the country often or always feel lonely, according to a 2017 report published by the Jo Cox Commission on Loneliness. The issue prompted Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday to appoint a minister for loneliness. \u201cFor far too many people, loneliness is the sad reality of modern life,\u201d Mrs. May said in a statement. \u201cI want to confront this challenge for our society and for all of us to take action to address the loneliness endured by the elderly, by carers, by those who have lost loved ones \u2014 people who have no one to talk to or share their thoughts and experiences with.\u201d Mark Robinson, the chief officer of Age UK, Britain\u2019s largest charity working with older people, warned that the problem could kill.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\n\n\u2014 Britain is not alone in its loneliness epidemic. The Times has also recently reported on social isolation in places like Japan, India and the United States. Do you think every country needs a \u201cloneliness minister\u201d? Is it a significant enough issue that the government should intervene? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 In the article, lawmakers stated, \u201cYoung or old, loneliness doesn\u2019t discriminate.\u201d Do you agree with this statement? Have you noticed that loneliness is a problem among people your age?\n\n\u2014 Based on your own experience and from what you\u2019ve read, what do you think is contributing to society\u2019s growing problem of social isolation?\n\n\u2014 What strategies have you used to cope with feeling alone? What would you recommend to others who might be feeling this way?", "title": "Does Every Country Need a \u2018Loneliness Minister\u2019?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nQ. Does magnesium help you sleep?\n\nA. Studies have found a link between low levels of magnesium, an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in a wide range of bodily processes, and sleep disorders. But if you are concerned you aren\u2019t getting enough magnesium, changing your diet may be a better option than taking a supplement, as \u201cthere is really sparse evidence that taking super-therapeutic doses of magnesium will give you a benefit,\u201d said Dr. Raj Dasgupta, a professor of pulmonary and sleep medicine at the University of Southern California.\n\nThe mineral is widely available in both plant and animal-based foods, and the kidneys limit urinary excretion of magnesium, so deficiencies are rare in healthy people. Leafy green vegetables, nuts, legumes and whole grains are good sources of magnesium; fish, chicken and beef also contain magnesium. Older adults and people with certain disorders, such as Type 2 diabetes, gastrointestinal diseases and alcoholism, however, may have inadequate amounts.\n\n\u201cMagnesium deficiency has been associated with higher levels of stress, anxiety and difficulty relaxing, which are key ingredients to getting good sleep at night,\u201d Dr. Dasgupta said. He noted that magnesium interacts with an important neurotransmitter that favors sleep.\n\nOne small double-blinded clinical trial of 43 elderly people in Tehran who were randomly assigned to receive either 500 milligrams of magnesium or a placebo for eight weeks found that those who received the supplement fell asleep faster and spent more of their time in bed asleep, but their total sleep time was not necessarily longer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn even smaller study of 10 people done nearly 20 years ago found that taking a magnesium supplement helped people with restless leg syndrome get more sleep.\n\nIf you suspect you\u2019re deficient in magnesium or want to take magnesium supplements, talk to your doctor first. Magnesium can interact poorly with other drugs, and taking excessive amounts in the form of supplements can cause stomach cramps, diarrhea and nausea. Including more leafy green vegetables, legumes, nuts, seeds and whole grains in your diet may be a better option, doctors say.", "title": "Does Magnesium Help You Sleep?", "authors": ["Roni Caryn Rabin", "Ask Well"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "But the glee was short-lived.\n\nA captains-pick-their-teams format was hatched by the league with the full intention to televise the draft, but pushback from the N.B.A. Players Association \u2014 not unanimous resistance, but enough \u2014 scuttled those plans.\n\nThe concept called for the respective winners of All-Star balloting in each conference, as captains, to divvy up the other eight players selected as All-Star starters by votes from fans, players and media members. Once the starting lineups were in place, James and Curry chose the 14 All-Star reserves, as selected by the coaches, one by one.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nYet it became clear in December that none of the potential draft drama anticipated by the basketball public would come to fruition, because none of us would have the opportunity to see the anguished looks on the faces of James and Curry when, say, they had to choose between a teammate and someone they\u2019ve always wanted to play with from the other conference \u2014 or the even more anguished faces of those waiting their turn to be chosen.\n\nAfter all that has transpired between the former Cleveland Cavaliers teammates over the past six months, imagine the anticipation as James surveyed his options when it came time to draft or pass on Kyrie Irving \u2014 and then having to field questions about how and why he made the decision.\n\nImagine the size of the chip that would have formed on both of Russell Westbrook\u2019s shoulders had either James or Curry, with the world watching, dared to pick another All-Star reserve ahead of him.\n\nImagine the tension, most of all, had the draft been packaged as a separate televised special \u2014 as the National Hockey League did three times between 2011 and 2015 \u2014 and how it would feel for the last two players waiting to be chosen.\n\nScrumptious is the word you\u2019re looking for to describe any of those scenarios.\n\nEven if the precise details of Thursday\u2019s draft eventually leak out, as so much business in the N.B.A. does, it just won\u2019t be the same. Not being able to witness the real-time reactions of every player involved snuffs out any usefulness for a player draft; James and Curry essentially confirmed as much afterward by taking to Twitter after their draft call to lament the absence of cameras.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere are three main reasons this format, which initially inspired so much hope among hoop romantics that it could pump some much-needed life into the league\u2019s midseason showcase, was conducted behind closed doors:\n\n1) The league did not want to risk embarrassing the last player chosen \u2014 or anyone else.\n\n2) The league did not want to put the captains in a position where they might upset teammates by passing over them.\n\n3) The league adopted both of those positions at the behest of the players\u2019 union. Some All-Stars want the draft televised, but some don\u2019t. So the league acquiesced.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd that left N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver to do most of the explaining in recent weeks. In a recent NBA TV interview, Silver said: \u201cThe goal was to improve the All-Star Game, not put a cherry on top of the cake.\u201d\n\nMichele A. Roberts, the executive director of the N.B.A. Players Association, declined interview requests this week through a union representative. But the N.B.P.A. did issue a statement Thursday to SB Nation, saying \u201cit was the absence of a consensus by prospective players likely to be affected that led to support\u201d for keeping the draft off the air.\n\nThe rampant tiptoeing around this whole thing is silly. It\u2019s the All-Star Game. It\u2019s a game, in other words, that doesn\u2019t even count. Let\u2019s hope Curry was right when he predicted last week that the television element would eventually come to fruition, urging patience because the new format still has its \u201ctraining wheels on.\u201d\n\nUncomfortable as it might be at the moment for an All-Star to be snubbed by a fellow All-Star on a public stage, for whatever reason, let\u2019s also not forget the wise words of Curry\u2019s coach in Golden State. As Steve Kerr told us during the 2015 N.B.A. Finals, and has been fond of repeating ever since, he and the players get paid \u201ca lot of money\u201d thanks to \u201cthe intense interest worldwide in the sport.\u201d\n\n\u201cWith that,\u201d Kerr often reminds us, \u201ccomes scrutiny and criticism.\u201d\n\nKerr gets it. There\u2019s a trade-off here. The N.B.A. is enjoying maybe the greatest period of broad relevance in its history, which has taken compensation to dizzying new levels, largely because the audience finds the league\u2019s various personal interactions and back stories so intoxicating.\n\nNo sports league on Earth lays bare its innermost feelings \u2014 its feuds, grudges and animus \u2014 better than the National Basketball Association. When so much of the league, as well as its television partners, is profiting so handsomely from life under the microscope, why pretend otherwise?\n\nThursday\u2019s draft simply wasn\u2019t the new format to implement if you don\u2019t go all the way. The various relevant parties that dished up this frustrating tease would be wise to drop the charade and embrace the sport\u2019s true identity here \u2014 pettiness and all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOr try something else.", "title": "Does an N.B.A. All-Star Draft Held in Private Make a Sound?", "authors": ["Marc Stein", "On Pro Basketball"]} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFor Doctors, Age May Be More Than a Number,\u201d by Haider Javed Warraich (Sunday Review, Jan. 7):\n\nThe article troubles me for many reasons, mostly for its hubris but also for its conceit. Dr. Warraich, who is 29, writes, \u201cIn medicine, a lack of experience may not actually be a bad thing.\u201d\n\nAs a recently retired general and vascular surgeon who was privileged to be part of the training of some 240 surgical residents, I feel qualified to comment. I happily admit that the \u201ctraining\u201d went both ways all those years. I\u2019d like to think the benefits were mostly in favor of the residents. After all, they learned when, why and especially how to operate. And most important, when not to operate.\n\nWould you want an inexperienced pilot or a pilot in training to fly your next flight? There is no doubt that medical students and residents are the lifeblood of the future of medicine. But there is no substitute for experience.\n\nSTEVEN KAHN, PRINCETON, N.J.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nI agree with Dr. Haider Javed Warraich. Young doctors have many good qualities that have nothing to do with age, for better or worse, But when he writes that \u201cnothing is more reassuring to patients than seeing a silver-haired doctor walk up to their bedside,\u201d I have to disagree.", "title": "Opinion | Does the Age of Your Doctor Matter?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "It has been proven time and again that football is, as Vince Lombardi said, a game of inches. Teams win or lose based on the smallest of distances. A deep pass glances off a receiver\u2019s fingertips. One or two links of a chain force a team to punt instead of keeping the ball.\n\nBut football is also a game of speed. And the measurement of that speed can help us understand why that deep pass wasn\u2019t caught. Or why that running back was tackled two chain links short of the first down.\n\nThanks to computer chips inserted into N.F.L. players\u2019 shoulder pads, we can measure and analyze the speed at which the game is played. The data, provided here by Sportradar, is used by teams to help make personnel decisions, scout opponents and even call plays. It also helps separate players who have \u201cgame speed\u201d from those who merely run fast at the N.F.L. Combine.\n\n\u201cCombine speed is overrated,\u201d said Tavon Austin, the Los Angeles Rams\u2019 speedy receiver. \u201cIt might give you a good look to see what you can run in a straight line, but football\u2019s not played in a straight line.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Combine Speed Is Overrated:\u2019 Tracking the N.F.L.\u2019s Fastest Players on the Field", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The Martian is actually Martin McDonagh, a playwright from the U.K. \u201cThree Billboards\u201d is his third movie (\u201cIn Bruges\u201d and \u201cSeven Psychopaths\u201d precede this one), and the second set in the United States. He\u2019s a dramatist and a linguist who can be glorious about the ordinariness and misery of duty and work. His plays \u2014 like \u201cThe Beauty Queen of Leenane\u201d or \u201cThe Cripple of Inishmaan\u201d \u2014 tether behavior to state of mind. You believe what people do because they appear to be making the choices \u2014 ugly ones \u2014 as opposed to an author you can picture yanking the strings.\n\nBut his movies are all strings. Often they feel as if other filmmakers are doing the pulling. \u201cIn Bruges\u201d featured two hit men on a chatty stroll in Belgium, and certain people\u2019s passion for it is fit for Valentine\u2019s Day. But it was Tupperware Tarantino to me.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo \u201cThree Billboards\u201d admirers and to the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, the outfit that hands out the Golden Globes, something about the movie rings true or feels timely. That presumption of truth is driving some of the annoyance over this movie. My favorite bad thing about \u201cThree Billboards\u201d is its ambition to play around with America\u2019s ideological and geographical toys.\n\nOne of the toys is the word \u201cnigger.\u201d Another is the concept of political correctness. There\u2019s a scene between Mildred and a hotheaded dimwit cop \u2014 the racist \u2014 named Jason (Sam Rockwell), in which she baits his racism by calling him a \u201cnigger torturer.\u201d He hits the roof. \u201cPerson-of-color-torturing\u201d is what Jason says you must call it now, with exasperated lament. They volley the word and poke fun at its impropriety. You can tell that Mr. McDonagh relished the application of absurdism to the political correction (he knows \u201cperson-of-color-torturing\u201d really is linguistic torture, maybe even for a person of color). But he also seems to like the loaded nonsense in the sound of the word \u201cnigger.\u201d What you hear in a scene like this is a kind of careless virtuosity. It\u2019s a fun scene that\u2019s sunk by how much fun it\u2019s having with things you\u2019re not supposed to have fun with. The whole movie is like that \u2014 it\u2019s like Mildred \u2014 rude for sport and proud of it.\n\nThere\u2019s certainly a place for a white artist to poke, laughingly, at our racial and class messes. (Mel Brooks, for instance, excelled at it.) But Mr. McDonagh doesn\u2019t want to do more than poke. The Danish director Lars von Trier tried a more explicit damnation of the United States with \u201cDogville\u201d (2003) and \u201cManderlay\u201d (2005). But I liked the nihilism in Mr. von Trier\u2019s respective approximations of racism and slavery, even if he followed a European habit, especially in documentaries, of diagnosing America\u2019s ills in the least surprising and most patronizing way.\n\nFor a movie that asks you to behold so much violence \u2014 defenestration and talk of rape, a bludgeoning, a suicide, charred skin, a dental drill that treats a thumb like drywall \u2014 \u201cThree Billboards\u201d feels weirdly benign. Its black comedy doesn\u2019t leave a bruise. The violence curdles into the cartoonish. The movie could be about grace and vengeance, but they\u2019re presented as hoary lessons and hokey contrivances \u2014 happening upon a deer, sharing your orange juice with the madman who tried to murder you, juxtaposing the reading of an inspirational letter with an inferno. There\u2019s no reckoning with anything, no introspection, just escalating mayhem. The mix of the silly and the serious puts the movie in Coen brothers territory. But they can adjust the settings for their cynicism. Even at their worst, they\u2019ve got their finesse. Mr. McDonagh just keeps bashing away.\n\nPhoto\n\nThis really is an action movie whose action is played for laughs. Mildred beats up teenagers and tells off priests. Her precision with a Molotov cocktail should land her in the Super Bowl. Ms. McDormand certainly makes the most of the tirade machine Mr. McDonagh has built for her. (Not since \u201cErin Brockovich\u201d has anybody gotten to tell off this many people with this much gusto.) You feel for Mildred, but you fear her more. When she approaches a table in a restaurant carrying a wine bottle, the audience practically begs her not to use it. By this point, Mildred is way past being a mad mommy. She\u2019s Charles Bronson.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut she\u2019s not the only bereft mother fueled by vengeance. The foreign language Golden Globe went, in a surprise, to Fatih Akin\u2019s \u201cIn the Fade,\u201d which has Diane Kruger as a white German who must endure the legal trial of the neo-Nazi terrorists who killed her Turkish-German husband and their young son. It doesn\u2019t rank up there with \u201cHead-On\u201d (2004) and \u201cThe Edge of Heaven\u201d (2007), Mr. Akin\u2019s masterwork melodramas. It\u2019s too well oiled a machine, too morally simple to be completely satisfying. But it\u2019s more clear-eyed and serious than \u201cThree Billboards\u201d about what it means to inflict pain. Maybe there\u2019s a way to laugh through rage, but Mr. Akin doesn\u2019t know what way that would be. Neither, I would argue, does Mr. McDonagh.\n\n\u201cThree Billboards\u201d is a cupcake rolled in glass. It all just feels off. The redemption of the racist cop doesn\u2019t bother me \u2014 Sam Rockwell studiously plays him as a dangerous dope. But the way two other black characters (Amanda Warren and Darrell Britt-Gibson) and a smitten dwarf (Peter Dinklage) bop around Mildred is almost Muppet-like. (Mr. Dinklage\u2019s stature is meant to be a source of unapologetic amusement. More stuff you\u2019re not supposed to have fun with!)\n\nEventually, the film introduces a temporary black police chief (Clarke Peters) who seems meant to draw out \u2014 Sidney Poitier-style \u2014 some of the bigotry coursing through town, or at least through the precinct. But he\u2019s as much a prop as one of the billboards.\n\nI thought a lot about this movie watching \u201cAmerican Vandal,\u201d an eight-part, sitcom-length show created by Dan Perrault and Tony Yacenda, on Netflix. It parodies the true-crime boomlet epitomized by \u201cThe Jinx\u201d on HBO, \u201cMaking a Murderer\u201d on Netflix and podcasts like \u201cSerial.\u201d And, like \u201cThree Billboards,\u201d the series revolves around jerks. Someone spray-painted 27 penises on 27 cars in the staff parking lot of a high school in Oceanside, Calif. And two student reporters investigate. The prime suspect \u2014 a stoner-skate punk senior named Dylan Maxwell \u2014 has been expelled. The two reporters poke holes in the case against him and explore a gamut of alternative culprits.\n\nLike Mr. McDonagh\u2019s movie, \u201cAmerican Vandal\u201d takes a circuitous route to earnestly asked philosophical questions about human nature. The show has a breezy confidence that never tips all the way into mockery. But it\u2019s a lot less impressed with itself. It undermines the piety and ethical lapses in nonfiction mystery shows, while sharing with \u201cThree Billboards\u201d a belief in semaphores and that people aren\u2019t any one thing. Also \u2014 and this feels important \u2014 it feels like the people who made this show understand their setting and the people who live there. I\u2019ve never been to Oceanside, but I believe this show\u2019s rendition of it.\n\nEven in a setting as generic as an American high school, the show has a sense of place. And it\u2019s a white show whose nonwhite characters don\u2019t feel like objects. I\u2019m not sure what Ebbing is. You can feel that uncertainty in the movie\u2019s cop-out of a finale, in its bewildering loftiness (\u201cOscar Wilde\u201d as a character\u2019s last words) and in the coveralls Mildred spends most of the movie wearing. Her job is at a rustic gift shop, but the coveralls point to the harder blue-collar work we\u2019ve seen Ms. McDormand do in movies like \u201cNorth Country.\u201d Here, these clothes signify emotional work, yet they feel like a put-on, too. Three billboards, sure \u2014 but outside a coffee shop in Portland, Ore.\n\nThe movie isn\u2019t an explicit work of politics, but it reaches something political in certain people in the same way it touches something emotional in others. And yet in arguing about this movie what I don\u2019t want, but where I\u2019m afraid we are \u2014 with lots of film this time every year \u2014 is in another fight over a movie\u2019s politics that manages to leave the movie itself behind.\n\nWhose fault is that? We\u2019ve been seduced and bullied into thinking of the awards season as a process of politics. The people who make the movies also run or finance \u201ccampaigns.\u201d There is opposition research, and, in the form of other award shows, primaries, so to speak. And it all culminates with the election night we call the Academy Awards broadcast. So it\u2019s only natural that we tend to think of best picture (and a few of the major, ancillary categories) as a kind of vote in which, while average people have no say, we\u2019re all invested in the symbolism and catharsis of the outcome.\n\n\u201cThree Billboards,\u201d which is not based on a true story but does have some reality flavoring, must appear worthy of elected office, in some way. This was at first the illusion presented by the people running the campaigns, and in turn over the years, has become the custom for lots of us.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe movie can\u2019t be just the misfire that it is. The enthusiasm for it has to represent the injustice the movie believes it\u2019s aware of \u2014 against young murdered women, their suffering dysfunctional families and black torture victims we never see \u2014 but fails to sufficiently poeticize or dramatize what Mr. McDonagh is up to here: a search for grace that carries a whiff of American vandalism. Of course, few movies can predict their moment, but \u201cThree Billboards\u201d might be inadequately built for this one.", "title": "Does \u2018Three Billboards\u2019 Say Anything About America? Well \u2026", "authors": ["Wesley Morris"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Democrats want to strengthen the social safety net; Republicans want to weaken it. But why?\n\nG.O.P. opposition to programs helping the less fortunate, from food stamps to Medicaid, is usually framed in monetary terms. For example, Senator Orrin Hatch, challenged about Congress\u2019s failure to take action on the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program, a part of Medicaid that covers nearly nine million children \u2014 and whose federal funding expired back in September \u2014 declared that \u201cthe reason CHIP\u2019s having trouble is that we don\u2019t have money anymore.\u201d\n\nBut is it really about the money? No, it\u2019s about the cruelty. Over the past few years it has become increasingly clear that the suffering imposed by Republican opposition to safety-net programs isn\u2019t a bug, it\u2019s a feature. Inflicting pain is the point.\n\nTo see what I mean, consider three stories about health care policies.\n\nFirst, there\u2019s the saga of Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act. The Supreme Court allowed states to opt out of this expansion. But accepting expansion should have been a no-brainer for every state: The federal government would initially pay the full cost, and even in the long run it would pay 90 percent, meanwhile bringing money and jobs into state economies.\n\nYet 18 states \u2014 all of them with Republican-controlled legislatures, governors or both \u2014 still haven\u2019t expanded Medicaid. Why?", "title": "Opinion | Dollars, Cents and Republican Sadism", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Separately in neighboring Syria, Turkey\u2019s president vowed to \u201cstrangle\u201d a proposed American-trained force that could put thousands of Kurdish militia fighters near its southern border.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 On Martin Luther King\u2019s Birthday, Americans reflected on the legacy of the civil rights leader.\n\nIn interviews, black Americans, including two of Dr. King\u2019s children, expressed frustration and disappointment about the direction of the United States in President Trump\u2019s first year in office.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve been involved in the civil rights movement since my college days, and I\u2019m not sure I\u2019ve ever been more confused than I am right now,\u201d one 94-year-old activist said.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 In Riyadh, the Saudi capital, the planned reopening next month of a luxury hotel is signaling that mass arrests tied to what the authorities have called a crackdown on corruption are winding down.\n\nThe hotel had served as a posh prison for princes and business executives.\n\nA film on emoji (our critic\u2019s review was harsh) was among the first to be screened publicly in the ultraconservative Islamic kingdom after the government ended a decades-old ban on cinemas last month.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Meet Nice Leng\u2019ete.\n\nShe started a program in Kenya that is creating a new rite of passage to replace female genital cutting.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn seven years, she has helped 50,000 girls avoid the agonizing and controversial ritual.\n\nHer work mirrors national and global trends. Rates of female genital cutting worldwide have fallen 14 percent in the last 30 years.\n\n_____\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Alexa, Google Assistant and other voice-based virtual assistants are everywhere. Here\u2019s our guide.\n\n\u2022 And Besan\u00e7on, the French capital of watch manufacturing, is making a comeback.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nThe event 80 years ago today would be historic, The Times announced: The first swing concert at Carnegie Hall in New York City. Benny Goodman, the jazz clarinetist, would perform.\n\n\u201cThe event will be decisive in the history of swing,\u201d a Times writer declared later in 1938. \u201cWhat will it sound like in this strange milieu of righteousness and uplift, and what will be its effect on swing?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFans of swing were concerned that exposure to New York\u2019s elite would eventually rob the grass-roots genre of its \u201celusiveness, its absolute freedom from technique or rules.\u201d\n\nThose fears were dispelled by Mr. Goodman\u2019s success in captivating the audience.\n\nCarnegie Hall \u201chad never seen an audience that behaved this way: listeners who not only listened but swayed to the music, made sounds and seemed ready to break into some kind of hysterical dance,\u201d The Times reported. Above, Mr. Goodman at Carnegie Hall in 1982.\n\nOur critic found the music liberating in a dark era of totalitarian ideologies. \u201cIt is not so much a doctrine set to music as it is a revolt against doctrine.\u201d\n\n\u201cIf the individual has his unhampered say in music, he may manage to have it in other fields,\u201d he wrote. \u201cDictators should be suspicious of swing.\u201d\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online.
