Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Dolores O\u2019Riordan, Baghdad, Romania: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": ["Patrick Boehler"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "The Cranberries were formed in 1989 as the Cranberry Saw Us and renamed the Cranberries after Ms. O\u2019Riordan took over as lead singer in 1990. Along with the brothers Noel Hogan on guitar and Mike Hogan on bass, the band includes the drummer Fergal Lawler.\n\nThe group arrived during the early 1990s ascendance of alternative rock: tuneful, punk-derived, guitar-driven songs that often made their way from college-radio playlists to commercial radio.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFour of the group\u2019s albums reached the Billboard Top 20.\n\nPhoto\n\nFemale rock singers like Sinead O\u2019Connor and Harriet Wheeler of the Sundays had recently preceded the Cranberries on the pop charts, and the band also drew deeply on the musical example of the Smiths, the 1980s band that propelled warm, rounded guitars and confessional lyrics with post-punk drumming. The Cranberries\u2019 1993 debut album, \u201cEverybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Can\u2019t We?,\u201d which included the career-making hits \u201cLinger\u201d and \u201cDreams,\u201d and the 1994 album \u201cNo Need to Argue,\u201d with \u201cZombie,\u201d were both produced by the Smiths\u2019 producer, Stephen Street.\n\nAfter \u201cZombie,\u201d the Cranberries lost much of their pop audience as their late-1990s albums grew harsher and more concerned with sociopolitical messages than with love songs. The Cranberries disbanded in 2003. In 2007 Ms. O\u2019Riordan released her first solo album, \u201cAre You Listening?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn an interview published in The Guardian last year, Ms. O\u2019Riordan described how the band wrote \u201cLinger,\u201d its first song together. \u201cI wrote about being rejected,\u201d she said. \u201cI never imagined that that it would become a big song.\u201d\n\nIn 1996, Neil Strauss, a pop music critic for The New York Times, described Ms. O\u2019Riordan as a performer who can \u201csing almost anything and make it seem musical.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. O\u2019Riordan\u2019s death was also announced on the group\u2019s Twitter account, where fans shared messages of mourning and of the impact that the group\u2019s music had on their lives.\n\n\u201cShe was part of my DNA, the soundtrack to my life,\u201d wrote one, Michael Traboulsi.\n\nMs. O\u2019Riordan was born on Sept. 6, 1971, and grew up in the Ballybricken area of County Limerick, Ireland. In 1994, she married Don Burton, a former tour manager for Duran Duran; the couple divorced in 2014. She is survived by her three children, Taylor, Molly and Dakota, and her mother, Eileen O\u2019Riordan.\n\nSix years after the Cranberries\u2019 split, the group reunited and began touring again. But last year, the band canceled dates on its European and North America tours because of Ms. O\u2019Riordan\u2019s ongoing back problems.\n\n\u201cThere have been some comments suggesting that Dolores could perform if she sat while singing. Unfortunately it is not as simple as that,\u201d a statement on the group\u2019s Facebook page said then.\n\nThe Cranberries released the acoustic album \u201cSomething Else\u201d in 2017 and had plans to perform shows in Europe and North America. But the tours were cut short or canceled because the band said that singing put pressure on the parts of her spine that were giving her so much pain.", "title": "Dolores O\u2019Riordan, Lead Singer of the Cranberries, Dies at 46", "authors": ["Christine Hauser"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Reiss first reported self-recognition in dolphins in 2001 with Lori Marino, now the head of The Kimmela Center for Animal Advocacy. She and Dr. Morrison, now an assistant professor in the psychology department at the University of North Carolina Pembroke collaborated on the study and published their findings in the journal PLoS One.\n\nDr. Reiss said the timing of the emergence of self-recognition is significant, because in human children the ability has been tied to other milestones of physical and social development. Since dolphins develop earlier than humans in those areas, the researchers predicted that dolphins should show self-awareness earlier.\n\nSeven months was when Bayley, a female, started showing self-directed behavior, like twirling and taking unusual poses.\n\nDr. Reiss said dolphins \u201cmay put their eye right up against the mirror and look in silence. They may look at the insides of their mouths and wiggle their tongues.\u201d\n\nFoster, the male, was almost 14 months when the study started. He had a particular fondness for turning upside down and blowing bubbles in front of the one-way mirror in the aquarium wall through which the researchers observed and recorded what the dolphins were doing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe animals also passed a test in which the researchers drew a mark on some part of the dolphin\u2019s body it could not see without a mirror. In this so-called mark test, the animal must notice and pay attention to the mark. Animals with hands point at the mark and may touch it.\n\nThe dolphins passed that test at 24 months, which was the earliest researchers were allowed to draw on the young animals. Rules for animal care prohibited the test at an earlier age because of a desire to have the animals develop unimpeded. During testing, the young animals were always with the group of adults they live with, and only approached a one-way mirror in the aquarium wall when they felt like it.\n\nRules for drawing on human children are apparently less strict, and they pass the mark test at 18-24 months.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFrans de Waal, of Emory University, who studies cognition in apes and other animals and is the author of \u201cAre We Smart Enough to Know How Smart Animals Are?\u201d , said in an email, \u201cGreat study.\u201d\n\nDr. de Waal worked with Dr. Reiss on an earlier study of self-recognition in elephants but was not involved in the dolphin research.\n\nHe said the study has value because science needs to go beyond asking whether species display mirror self-recognition (MSR) to ask \u201cwhether the emergence of MSR correlates, as it does in humans, with other milestones of development.\u201d Connecting the ability to the rest of development can help researchers \u201cbegin to answer the question of what MSR means.\u201d\n\nA small side note that doesn\u2019t have any apparent scientific significance is that Foster, the male, visited the mirror many more times than Bayley, the female.\n\n\u201cHe clearly was interested in viewing himself,\u201d Dr. Reiss said.", "title": "Dolphins Show Self-Recognition Earlier Than Children", "authors": ["James Gorman"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "The sociologists David Scott FitzGerald and David Cook-Martin have shown that the United States pioneered racially based exclusionary immigration policies in the Americas in the late 18th and 19th centuries. (Not long before he was elected president, for example, Theodore Roosevelt asserted the bigoted but then-common view that the Chinese should be kept out of America because they were \u201cracially inferior.\u201d)\n\nIt should sober Americans to know that authoritarian governments in Chile, Cuba and Uruguay ended racist immigration policies decades before the United States.\n\nThe current turmoil over immigration conflates several separate issues. One is DACA, the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which has provided temporary work permits and reprieves from deportation for undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children. These are the so-called Dreamers, who number about 800,000.\n\nAnother issue is the Temporary Protected Status program under which undocumented foreigners who were in the United States when disaster or conflict struck their homeland are allowed to remain in the United States. In November, the Trump administration ended the protection for about 60,000 Haitians, and on Monday the administration lifted it for almost 200,000 Salvadorans, most of whom have been in the United States for two decades.\n\nA third issue is the future of the roughly 11 million undocumented immigrants who have come to the United States over decades and have effectively integrated into American life. The Trump administration has ordered a broad immigration crackdown against them.\n\nAnd finally there\u2019s President Trump\u2019s imagined wall.\n\nWhat is concerning is not the wall, or the word \u201cshithole\u201d or the vacillation on the Dreamers or the Salvadorans. It\u2019s what ties all of these things together: the bigoted worldview of the man behind them.\n\nAnyone who has followed Mr. Trump over the years knows this. We knew it in the 1970s, when he and his father were twice sued by the Justice Department for refusing to rent apartments to black people. We knew it in 1989, when he took out a full-page newspaper ad calling for the execution of five black and Latino teenagers charged with the brutal rape of a white woman in Central Park. (The men were convicted but later exonerated by DNA and other evidence, but Mr. Trump never apologized, and he continued to argue as late as 2016 that the men were guilty.) We knew it when he built a presidential campaign by demonizing Mexicans and Muslims while promoting the lie that America\u2019s first black president wasn\u2019t born here. Or when, last summer, he defended marchers in a neo-Nazi parade as \u201cvery fine people.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump Flushes Away America\u2019s Reputation", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Donald Trump has passed his mental test. This may come as either a relief or a shock.\n\nThe results of the president\u2019s physical exam came out this week. This is normally not a big deal \u2014 when Obama and Bush got their reports, it was barely a yawn. But on Tuesday White House physician Ronny Jackson had to answer questions from the media for almost an hour.\n\nThere was a little curiosity about how anybody who eats so many cheeseburgers could be in good health. (\u201cGenes.\u201d) Skeptics pointed out that the report\u2019s enthusiastic descriptions of the president\u2019s tiptop condition seemed inconsistent with some of the statistics on his weight, cholesterol and plaque buildup in the arteries. If the doctor had simply said \u201cgood for an overweight 71-year-old guy,\u201d everybody probably could have nodded and moved forward.\n\nBut the big news was the mental test. Trump took something called the Montreal Cognitive Assessment and got a perfect score. Not perhaps the highest bar possible, unless you were concerned about whether he can identify pictures of animals and draw hands on a clock. But the test can be useful if there is, for some reason, concern that the subject is suffering from \u2026 um, dementia.\n\nJackson told reporters that he has talked with Trump many times over the past year and found him \u201cvery sharp.\u201d This is hardly surprising. When the doctor has a conversation with the president, the subject is probably always Donald Trump, a topic upon which our current chief executive is always able to focus like a laser.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump Gets His Sanity Grades", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "We don\u2019t talk a whole lot about class in America, where we prefer to pretend that we transcend such distinctions. But in 2017, American movies had that conversation, bluntly and hauntingly, and if you spent the holiday season catching up on the year-end crop of Oscar-minded fare, you visited unpolished places. You met unsatisfied people.\n\nThey spoke of being trapped on the wrong side of the tracks (\u201cLady Bird\u201d) or in the wrong sorts of clothes (\u201cI, Tonya\u201d). They tried to paint over their despair, as if a thick-enough coat of a bright-enough pastel could keep the disappointment at bay (\u201cThe Florida Project\u201d). They went to creative, even absurd lengths so that their voices might be heard (\u201cThree Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri\u201d) or that they could know the economic security that seemed forever beyond their reach (\u201cDownsizing\u201d).\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nI can\u2019t think of a previous batch of statuette-season contenders so politically on point and of the moment, and I credit \u2014 although that\u2019s not quite the right word \u2014 Donald Trump. His rise and presidency have brought so many of the cancers of American life to the surface, where we can no longer avoid them, and the movies reflect that. He\u2019ll be at the Golden Globes and the Academy Awards not just as the butt of a gazillion jokes. He\u2019ll be there as an inspiration.\n\nYes, some of the movies being celebrated now were first dreamed up or set in motion even before he announced his candidacy in June 2015. But they were propelled by some of the same discontents that he seized on and divisions that he exacerbated.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe themes of the Trump era are the themes of these movies. For racial anxiety, enter the nightmare of \u201cGet Out,\u201d which was released early last year but has roared back onto the radar for best-of-2017 lists. For the tense relationship between the federal government and the media, see \u201cThe Post.\u201d \u201cAll the Money in the World\u201d presents a self-infatuated plutocrat whose obsession with riches deadens his soul. His surname is Getty, but he may remind you of someone else.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Opinion Today Newsletter Every weekday, get thought-provoking commentary from Op-Ed columnists, the Times editorial board and contributing writers from around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nPut these movies together and you have a cinematic syllabus for a course on America right now. All the messes and the monsters are accounted for. And Hollywood, thank heavens, is poised to honor something other than the agonies and ecstasies of its own creative process, as it has done so many vanity-stroking times before (\u201cThe Artist,\u201d \u201cArgo,\u201d \u201cBirdman,\u201d \u201cLa La Land\u201d). It\u2019s looking outward, precisely when that\u2019s most important.", "title": "Donald Trump Goes to the Movies", "authors": ["Frank Bruni"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "He denounced Trump before he befriended and defended him. He graduated from the unpleasant experience of being Trump\u2019s punching bag to the unprincipled one of being his enabler. Like the majority of his Republican colleagues in Congress, he reckoned that he could somehow get more than he was giving up, which included his dignity. He reckoned wrong.\n\nRight now, we\u2019re supposed to \u2026 what? Thank Graham for his candor, because he effectively confirmed that in a meeting about immigration in the Oval Office on Thursday, a vulgar comment was uttered, and because he stood up to the president at the time, telling him that America was an idea, not a race?\n\nOr should we instead note how far Graham had previously traveled to prop up this same president? It was Graham who recently joined Senator Charles Grassley, the Iowa Republican, in undercutting the credibility of federal inquiries into Trump\u2019s ties with Russia by recommending that the Justice Department investigate Christopher Steele, the former British spy who wrote that famous dossier.\n\nDid Graham tell himself then that he was craftily staying in Trump\u2019s good graces so that he could coax the president toward saner, better immigration policy? How did that wager work out? We now know the answer, and so does Graham.\n\nHe\u2019s hardly the worst of the obsequious lot. On Monday The Washington Post reported that when Senator Tom Cotton, an Arkansas Republican, and David Perdue, a Georgia Republican, strenuously disputed the initial accounts that Trump said \u201cshithole\u201d in the Oval Office, it was not because his talk was actually statesmanlike. No, they heard him fume about immigrants from \u201cshithouse countries\u201d rather than \u201cshithole countries,\u201d and in that scintilla of semantic difference they found a rationale for muddying the waters and rallying around the president. I find a title for a tell-all about complicity in this rotten age. Call the book \u201cShit and Its Suffixes.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump Will Soil You. Ask Lindsey Graham.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-20 00:00:00", "text": "Professional women always walk a balance beam of respect, pushed to excel without seeming ambitious, pulled by social expectations of female niceness tempered by concerns that female likability exists in opposition to perceptions of female competence, inevitably blown off-kilter. What Mr. Trump demands of his female subordinates, though, is something greater than your still-sexist but wholly run-of-the-mill concerns about gendered expectations in the workplace. Women like Ivanka Trump, Hope Hicks and Kellyanne Conway don\u2019t just counsel the president and liaise with the press and public; they offer a feminine salve, simultaneously sanctioning Mr. Trump\u2019s sexist commentary and buttressing his ego by situating themselves as little girls in need of direction from Big Daddy (literally, in Ivanka\u2019s case). In return, Mr. Trump\u2019s usual hostility may be temporarily eased into something resembling benevolence toward them.\n\nHostile sexism \u2014 hateful misogynist comments or the physical abuse of women, for example \u2014 is easy to identify and condemn. (And to be clear, Mr. Trump has displayed plenty of that, too.) Benevolent sexism is more insidious. In the view of the benevolent sexist, women and men should occupy fundamentally different roles, with the men as patriarchs and women, with our naturally maternal and gentle dispositions, as helpmates and caretakers. In some conservative, religious or simply strongly male-dominated communities, you see this dressed up as a form of feminism \u2014 the idea being that women can find respect and purpose by tapping into our intrinsic maternal nature. When Mr. Trump\u2019s defenders use the fact that the president has employed and encouraged a handful of women \u2014 to, as we now know, also serve as his uncompensated therapists \u2014 as a shield against accusations of sexism, they are deploying a similarly mendacious argument.\n\nAnd women in places where sexism permeates every corner have little choice but to accept it if they want to get by, and so perform whatever psychological gymnastics necessary. Sure, your boss doesn\u2019t treat you the same way he treats the guys, but that\u2019s because you\u2019re different and special. So what if the requirements for being treated as \u201cspecial\u201d involve playacting hyperfemininity, stroking a man\u2019s ego and carefully managing his feelings? That\u2019s just how men are, and that\u2019s what men want.\n\nAnd yet taking this approach to rising through the ranks of the Trump White House \u2014 or any workplace \u2014 is a fool\u2019s errand, and it takes a toll. Most bosses are not as extreme as Mr. Trump, but it\u2019s not just right-wing men and gold-plated patriarchs who expect that female employees and co-workers will tend to their emotional shifts and personality quirks as readily as they do the day\u2019s to-do list. Assumptions that women will monitor and manage men\u2019s emotions span industries and political persuasions. It\u2019s not that subtly sexist men refuse wholesale to hire women; it\u2019s that they often hire a small number of us, with the unspoken but swiftly understood expectation that we will be the uncompensated \u201cchief feelings officer.\u201d Then they often lose respect for us because we play this very role.\n\nOf course not every man in the workplace demands this kind of emotional labor from his female colleagues; most don\u2019t. But when faced with bosses or colleagues who require this hybrid of good-daughter devotion and quasi-maternal coddling from their \u201cwork wives,\u201d women have two choices: Expend the unpaid effort and lose valuable time and energy, all while knowing you\u2019ll never be as respected as a man who doesn\u2019t have to handhold and head-pat his employer; or refuse to do it, and risk losing the job altogether. It\u2019s not just the craven Kellyannes and Hopes and Ivankas of the world who opt for the former.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump and His Work Wives", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Last Thursday, 11 of these \u201cforever prisoners\u201d filed a habeas corpus petition in the United States District Court in Washington, D.C. The men, all foreign-born Muslims, say their continued detention violates the Constitution\u2019s guarantee of due process and the 2001 law that gave presidents the power to send enemy combatants to Guant\u00e1namo.\n\nOne of the plaintiffs, prisoner No. 893, a 45-year-old Yemeni named Tolfiq al Bihani, has been held at Guant\u00e1namo for nearly 15 years. He was cleared for conditional release in 2010. The Saudi government agreed to accept him in 2016, along with nine other Yemenis. Those nine were all transferred, but Mr. al Bihani remains at Guant\u00e1namo without explanation.\n\nPresident George W. Bush may be guilty of creating the constitutional calamity that is Guant\u00e1namo, but at least he made an effort to empty it of men who clearly posed no threat to the United States, releasing 532 detainees by the end of his second term. President Barack Obama, who was blocked by Republicans in Congress from keeping his campaign promise to close the prison, established regular reviews of each inmate\u2019s case and worked intensively to negotiate the transfer of those who could not be returned safely to their home countries. In the end, he released 197 detainees.\n\nDuring the 2016 presidential campaign, Mr. Trump bragged that he would \u201cabsolutely authorize\u201d torture techniques like waterboarding, on the ground that terrorism suspects \u201cdeserve it anyway.\u201d The remaining Guant\u00e1namo prisoners appear fated to stay locked up not based on an individual assessment of their cases \u2014 there will be none of those under Mr. Trump \u2014 but because they serve as convenient symbols of the aggressive antiterrorist and anti-Muslim platform he ran on.\n\nAnd yet the men make a straightforward case for their release. The Supreme Court has ruled that prisoners at Guant\u00e1namo must have a \u201cmeaningful opportunity\u201d to challenge the legal and factual grounds for their detention, which means that the federal courts have the power to review those claims and grant any appropriate relief.\n\nIf the Constitution stands for anything, the plaintiffs argue in their suit, which was filed on their behalf by the Center for Constitutional Rights, it must stand for the proposition that the government cannot detain someone for 16 years without charge.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump vs. Guant\u00e1namo\u2019s Forever Prisoners", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "A justification for the change to one of the nation\u2019s largest social insurance programs for low-income people is that it would make them healthier. There is not strong evidence for that contention.\n\n\u2022 And Mr. Trump has again decided to stop short of reimposing strict sanctions on Iran. Two people briefed on his decision said he was expected to give Congress and European allies a deadline to improve the deal.\n\nPivotal test for surveillance\n\n\u2022 The House voted on Thursday to extend the National Security Agency\u2019s warrantless surveillance program for six years with minimal changes.\n\nThe legislation must still go through the Senate, but passing the House was the major hurdle.\n\n\u2022 The law was enacted in 2008 to legalize a version of a once-secret warrantless surveillance program created after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.\n\nPutting friends and family first\n\n\u2022 In an interview with The Times, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook\u2019s chief executive, discussed the sweeping changes the social media giant is making to prioritize content from people that its two billion users know.\n\nThe shift, which will de-emphasize content from publishers and brands, is the most significant overhaul to the News Feed in years. Here\u2019s what you can expect.\n\n\u2022 \u201cWe want to make sure that our products are not just fun, but are good for people,\u201d Mr. Zuckerberg said. \u201cWe need to refocus the system.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA former ISIS recruiter wants out\n\n\u2022 A 33-year-old woman from France has spent the last five years in Syria, where she eventually became a prominent propagandist and recruiter for the militant group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow, she wants to go home.\n\n\u2022 Our correspondent in Paris writes: \u201cThe quandary her case poses is an increasingly common one for France and other European countries: What should they do when citizens who are former Islamic State fighters or supporters want to return?\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe Daily Listen to \u2018The Daily\u2019: Vulgarity from President Trump Mr. Trump\u2019s disparaging words for Haiti and Africa have caused outrage worldwide. They have also raised a question about an American ideal: Who should be let in? Audio\n\nBusiness\n\n\u2022 A bumpy day for Walmart: The largest private employer in the U.S. cited the new tax bill in announcing wage increases, bonuses and expanded benefits to its hourly workers. But it\u2019s also closing 63 Sam\u2019s Club stores.\n\n\u2022 Morgan Stanley investigated accusations of harassment by one of its executives, the former congressman Harold Ford Jr., and found no proof. Then it fired him anyway.\n\n\u2022 What\u2019s $27 billion to Wall Street? Investment banks used to mint money by trading bonds, currencies and other complex securities. But that business is in decline, a trend that is reshaping the industry.\n\n\u2022 U.S. stocks were up on Thursday. Test yourself.\n\n\u2022 Ready for the weekend\n\nAt the movies, our critics review \u201cThe Commuter,\u201d starring Liam Neeson, and \u201cPaddington 2,\u201d starring the bear from deepest, darkest Peru.\n\nOur TV critic was unimpressed by \u201cPhilip K. Dick\u2019s Electric Dreams,\u201d Amazon\u2019s sci-fi anthology, but we have some other streaming ideas.\n\nWe recommend 11 new books, and round up the best theater, art and music offerings in the New York area.\n\nFinally, we visited \u201cMurder Is Her Hobby,\u201d an exhibition at the Smithsonian in Washington of 19 miniature crime scenes created as training tools for police investigators.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nThe comedy hosts had a hard time, for once, making light about one of President Trump\u2019s comments.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cVillagers will always say they had no intention of killing the elephants, the poison was intended for wild pigs.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Suwarno, director of Animals Indonesia, a conservation group, referring to cases involving farmers fed up with elephants that maraud their plantations.\n\nBack Story\n\n\u201cHello. I\u2019m Johnny Cash.\u201d\n\nWith those words, Mr. Cash kicked off a concert at a state prison in California that revitalized his music career and fortified his outlaw persona. Recorded 50 years ago on Saturday, \u201cAt Folsom Prison\u201d remains a landmark in American music.\n\nPhoto\n\nEntertaining inmates \u2014 while taunting their guards \u2014 was tame compared with the other exploits of the Man in Black.\n\nIn 1965, Mr. Cash accidentally started a forest fire in Southern California that burned hundreds of acres and devastated a population of endangered condors. (Mr. Cash told a judge, \u201cI don\u2019t care about your damn yellow buzzards.\u201d) Later in life, he was attacked by an ostrich and almost died.\n\nIn a dispute with his label in the 1980s, Mr. Cash released a parody called \u201cChicken in Black.\u201d He called the track \u201cintentionally atrocious,\u201d but it was the most successful thing he\u2019d done in years. (There\u2019s also a video.)\n\nMr. Cash, who died in 2003, was a Morse Code expert in the Air Force who eavesdropped on Soviet chatter. He was also an ordained minister and wrote a novel, \u201cMan in White,\u201d about the Apostle Paul.\n\nAs Mr. Cash told The Times in a 1969 interview, \u201cAin\u2019t nothin\u2019 too weird for me.\u201d\n\nCharles McDermid contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. In the end, Ponzi swindled more than $15 million in 1920, the equivalent of about $190 million today.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe trickery took Ponzi\u2019s name, as the headlines noted 10 years ago when Bernard Madoff defrauded clients of more than $50 billion. But the original scheme centered on postal notes.\n\nPonzi took advantage of international postal reply coupons, which allowed customers in one country to buy a voucher redeemable for stamps in another country.\n\nThe idea was that Ponzi\u2019s company would take investors\u2019 dollars, use them to buy foreign postal coupons, convert each coupon into a 5-cent stamp, and convert the stamps into cash.\n\nBut the plan was a fraud.\n\nInstead, Ponzi collected the money and paid off his investors while waiting for another influx of cash. Millions of dollars began arriving every week.\n\nPonzi\u2019s scheme was eventually exposed, and he later died in a charity hospital in Brazil, with only $75 to his name.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRemy Tumin contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning. But the controversy has consumed Washington\u2019s attention even as a critical deadline approaches to avert a government shutdown.\n\nTo keep the government funded past Saturday, lawmakers will need to pass a stopgap spending measure by the end of the week, but some Democrats are pushing to oppose any bill that does not also include a deal on DACA, the program protecting young undocumented immigrants. Those are for administrations with less drama, lower ratings and fewer reporters on speed dial. We knew the madness of Trump\u2019s court more quickly and reliably than we did the mischief of others, because his bickering enablers can\u2019t keep anything to themselves. Michael Wolff\u2019s \u201cFire and Fury\u201d is both a chronicle of that and proof of it.\n\nIt has new tidbits about Ivanka, Jared, Melania. It has nothing surprising about Trump. We already knew how much junk he ate. We already knew how misinformed and hypersensitive he was. We already knew that aides had questions about his smarts and qualms about his stability. All of this was out there not just from the beginning of his presidency but from the start of his campaign, and some of it was out there long before that.\n\nIn fact the hell of his election wasn\u2019t that he tricked American voters. It was that they\u2019d fully seen the florid whole of him and supported him nonetheless.\n\nSure, he peddled positions that he wasn\u2019t fixed to, made promises that he couldn\u2019t keep, touted a populism that he was bound to jettison and professed a caring that was entirely counterfeit. More than a few voters were certainly duped by that.\n\nBut his ethics? His character? These were on stark and regular display: in the fraud of Trump University, in the denigration of John McCain\u2019s military service, in the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape and in so much more. I sometimes wonder if, perversely, he got points for the fact that he would never disillusion Americans. They had no illusions about him in the first place.", "title": "Opinion | Donald Trump\u2019s Radical Honesty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDonnelly Rhodes, a Canadian-born character actor best remembered by American television audiences for playing an escaped convict on the sitcom \u201cSoap\u201d and a brusque doctor on the recent reboot of \u201cBattlestar Galactica,\u201d died on Monday at a hospice facility near his home in Maple Ridge, British Columbia. He was 81.\n\nThe cause was cancer, his agent, Lisa King, said.\n\nMr. Rhodes\u2019s television career began with westerns like \u201cMaverick\u201d and \u201cBonanza\u201d in the early 1960s and continued until 2016. Over the decades he appeared in practically every televised genre, from sitcoms to soap operas.\n\nHis experience on \u201cThe Young and the Restless\u201d in the mid-1970s may have prepared him for the plot twists and surprises of the soap-opera spoof \u201cSoap\u201d; beginning in 1978, during the show\u2019s second season, he played Dutch Leitner, a dimwitted criminal who helped Chester Tate, the philandering head of the wealthy Tate family, escape from prison.\n\nDuth then hid out at the Tate mansion and later wooed and eventually married Chester\u2019s daughter, Eunice.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Rhodes was on the show until it was canceled in 1981.\n\nMore than two decades later he played a very different character, the sarcastic, cigarette-smoking Dr. Sherman Cottle, on the Sci Fi Channel\u2019s update of the late-1970s series \u201cBattlestar Galactica.\u201d Dr. Cottle was the chief medical officer on a ship leading the remnants of humanity through space after a devastating attack by a robotic civilization. He joined the series in 2004 and remained with it until it ended in 2009.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Rhodes also had substantial roles on Canadian shows like \u201cDanger Bay,\u201d as a marine veterinarian, and \u201cDa Vinci\u2019s Inquest,\u201d as a detective. But he never became a household name, which he said in a 1989 interview was fine with him.", "title": "Donnelly Rhodes, Prolific Character Actor, Is Dead at 81", "authors": ["Daniel E. Slotnik"]} {"date": "2017-12-31 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nAndrew Miller and Richard Sokolsky (\u201cActually, Egypt Is a Terrible Ally,\u201d Op-Ed, Dec. 19) belittle Egypt\u2019s importance to the United States. Egypt is resolute in its fight against terrorism, militarily as well as through modernizing religious discourse and increasing tolerance.\n\nEgypt is also undertaking a challenging economic reform program that has been applauded by international observers and is strengthening its national institutions in a region plagued by eroding nation-states.\n\nThese efforts are aligned with America\u2019s long-term interests in the region. A country diligently working to this end should be supported, not alienated. America reaps many benefits from supporting Egypt and advancing our shared priorities. The assistance that the writers want to reduce has always been, and should remain, a tool to support allies, not one to \u201cextract concessions.\u201d\n\nThis is not to say that Egypt\u2019s journey toward a modern nation-state is complete. But the resolve of the Egyptian people and government is unshakable, and I hope we will be able to reflect and say that \u201cthe United States was our partner along the way.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Belittle Egypt", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-22 00:00:00", "text": "Now she has been clean for a year. Ms. Goldin is still feeling her way back into a world filled with ghostly reminders of addiction, but she decided that she was strong enough for a new battle. That began recently when, in her most personal project yet, she publicly confronted OxyContin\u2019s manufacturer, Purdue Pharma, and that company\u2019s longtime owners, who are also prominent art patrons: the descendants of Mortimer and Raymond Sackler, two of three physician brothers who built Purdue Pharma into a pharmaceutical behemoth.\n\nPhoto\n\nFoundations run by those members of the Sackler family have given tens of millions of dollars to institutions like the Victoria and Albert Museum, the American Museum of Natural History, the Solomon Guggenheim Foundation and the Dia Arts Foundation.\n\nThe January issue of Artforum published photographs by Ms. Goldin, including searing self-portraits, that depicted her life while addicted. They were accompanied by an essay in which she described her constant search for drugs: \u201cI went from three pills a day, as prescribed, to eighteen. I got a private endowment and spent it all. Like all opiate addicts my crippling fear of withdrawal was my guiding force.\u201d\n\nShe went on to announce the formation of an advocacy group and pressed the Sackler family and company \u2014 who, she wrote, \u201cbuilt their empire with the lives of hundreds of thousands\u201d \u2014 to fund addiction treatment and education.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI realized that I wasn\u2019t alone and that I had to help people,\u201d she said inside the courthouse. \u201cI always do what\u2019s closest to me. This is what I\u2019ve lived through. And I\u2019m a survivor of OxyContin \u2014 talk about hell.\u201d\n\nElizabeth A. Sackler, the founder of a center for feminist art at the Brooklyn Museum, responded to her essay with a statement pointing out that her father, Arthur M. Sackler, who had owned Purdue Pharma with his brothers, Mortimer and Raymond, died in 1987, before OxyContin existed. (It was approved for use in 1995.) No money from the drug had gone to his descendants, she added.\n\n\u201cThe opioid epidemic is a national crisis and Purdue Pharma\u2019s role in it is morally abhorrent to me,\u201d Ms. Sackler continued. \u201cI admire Nan Goldin\u2019s commitment to take action and her courage to tell her story.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nA spokeswoman for other members of the Sackler family did not comment. But in a statement to The New York Times, Robert Josephson, a spokesman for Purdue Pharma, said, \u201cWe are deeply troubled by the prescription and illicit opioid abuse crisis, and we would welcome an opportunity to sit down with Ms. Goldin to discuss her ideas.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Goldin elaborated on those ideas during an evening-long interview in Lower Manhattan that began at a cafe on West Broadway and moved to the courthouse on Centre Street, its cinder block walls plastered with old tabloid covers about the accused East Village murderer Daniel Rakowitz (\u201cThe Monster of Tompkins Square\u201d ) and the patrician Sydney Biddle Barrows (the Mayflower Madam). \u201cI love this place,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s the most New York place left in New York.\u201d\n\nThe conversation lasted until 10 p.m. Dinner was a Diet Pepsi, pretzels and peanut butter crackers, which Ms. Goldin selected from a courthouse vending machine.\n\nPhoto\n\nOver the years Ms. Goldin\u2019s photographs have captured the rebellious and transgressive realities of a pre-gentrified New York City. Among her best-known works are the 700 images in a collection titled \u201cThe Ballad of Sexual Dependency.\u201d They illustrate the world she inhabited, showing people having sex or shooting heroin, sometimes with excruciating intimacy.\n\nMs. Goldin said that her OxyContin addiction began with a prescription. In 2014, while she was living in Berlin, doctors prescribed 40 milligrams a day for tendinitis in her wrist, which later required surgery. Ms. Goldin said she ended up using 450 milligrams of the drug each day, seeking prescriptions from multiple doctors and finally turning to a dealer in New York who shipped her pills via FedEx. After years of OxyContin she moved to street drugs including heroin, which deliver a comparable high for much less money, a pattern that experts say has created the public health crisis that has terrified the nation.\n\nMs. Goldin, who is 64, kept working throughout, even preparing a major show at the Museum of Modern Art. But she said that the drug sealed her off from the rest of the world, leaving her dulled and depressed. \u201cIt\u2019s not a party drug. It\u2019s not a social drug.\u201d Addiction, she said, is \u201ca heavy foot on your head.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe overdose helped push her to finally confront her fear of withdrawal. She entered McLean Hospital\u2019s Fernside treatment program in rural Massachusetts, where, over two months, Ms. Goldin got clean. She began researching OxyContin and learned that Purdue\u2019s parent company had pleaded guilty in 2007 to a federal felony charge of misbranding the drug. Since then, a new federal investigation has begun and lawsuits have accused Purdue of deceptive marketing. Asked about those assertions in November, shortly after they were made, a company spokesman said, \u201cWe vigorously deny these allegations and look forward to the opportunity to present our defense.\u201d\n\nThe deaths related to opioids, some 200,000 from 1999 to 2016, remind Ms. Goldin of H.I.V.\n\n\u201cIn the \u201980s I lost a whole community and to my mind there\u2019s a generation missing,\u201d she said. \u201cSo are we going to watch now while another generation is being wiped out?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMs. Goldin\u2019s new group, Prescription Addiction Intervention Now, or P.A.I.N. \u2014 urged museums to reject future donations from the Sackler family. Its focus so far has been a petition on change.org demanding that \u201cthe Sackler family and Purdue Pharma\u201d fund rehabilitation centers, relapse prevention and holistic approaches; advertise the dangers of opioids; and re-educate doctors to stop overprescribing.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Josephson, the Purdue spokesman, said that for more than 15 years the company has supported much of what Ms. Goldin advocates. He said it funded state prescription drug monitoring programs and distributed federal guidelines for prescribing opioids. It recently announced educational initiatives aimed at teenagers, warning of opioid dangers, he added.\n\nMs. Goldin\u2019s group meets once a week in her apartment in Brooklyn and includes about a dozen members \u2014 former abusers, people close to addicts and others sympathetic to the cause.\n\nThe group has discussed making a documentary on OxyContin and also direct protests but is not yet ready to make its plans public, Ms. Goldin said.\n\nShe explained that detox treatments are often unaffordable and added that she hoped the petition could serve as a form of moral suasion, especially if friends of the Sacklers endorse its demands.\n\n\u201cI want people who go to cocktail parties with them to sign,\u201d she said.\n\nOn Saturday Ms. Goldin and three friends headed to the Upper West Side to give out leaflets promoting the petition during a women\u2019s march. Some in the crowd declined to take the fliers. But a man near Lincoln Center accepted one, saying his sister-in-law had died in West Virginia as a result of opioids.\n\nDuring a lunch break inside a cafe, a woman at a nearby table told Ms. Goldin that her son had been addicted to opioids. The two exchanged personal stories and hugged. Ms. Goldin and her friends began batting around ideas for future pamphleteering.\n\n\u201cWe can make some fliers for museum goers,\u201d Ms. Goldin mused playfully. Maybe next time, she added, \u201cwe\u2019ll go to the Museum of Natural History or the Guggenheim.\u201d", "title": "Don\u2019t Call Her a Victim: After Surviving Opioids, Nan Goldin Goes After the Makers", "authors": ["Colin Moynihan"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cThe Hell of This Year\u2019s Super Bowl\u201d (column, Jan. 24):\n\nI have been a fan of the New England Patriots since their first game in 1960 as the Boston Patriots. I generally admire Frank Bruni\u2019s columns and share his views of President Trump, but equating another appearance of the Patriots in the Super Bowl with Mr. Trump, income inequality, declining N.F.L. ratings and assorted other ills strayed into the universe of alternative facts.\n\nConsider the following:\n\nThe Patriots never trash talk their opponents. Does that sound like President Trump? They don\u2019t make excuses when they lose. Does that sound like President Trump? They praise their opponents. You won\u2019t find that coming out of the White House. (Have the Jacksonville Jaguars stopped whining about the penalties in the A.F.C. championship game yet?)\n\nThe Patriots are disciplined and prepared. They work hard. Does that sound anything like President Trump?\n\nThe Patriots are no symbol of income inequality. They play in a salary cap environment. Every team in the N.F.L. passed on multiple opportunities to draft Tom Brady before the Patriots snagged him in the sixth round of the 2000 draft. He went on to become the most accomplished quarterback of all time. Brady also restructured his contract so there would be more to spend on other players.", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Call the Patriots \u2018Trump\u2019s Team\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The Trump administration\u2019s decision to end the Temporary Protected Status for nearly 200,000 people from El Salvador who have been allowed to live in the United States for more than a decade comes as no surprise, given President Trump\u2019s attitude toward immigration and his past decisions to end protected status for Haitians and Nicaraguans. It\u2019s the wrong decision, on humanitarian and practical grounds.\n\nThe T.P.S. program was approved in 1990 to allow undocumented foreigners who were in the United States when disaster struck their homeland to remain in the country until it was safe to return. The Salvadorans were granted protected status after a pair of devastating earthquakes in their land in 2001, and their status was extended several times by the George W. Bush and Obama administrations.\n\nTechnically, the Department of Homeland Security is right that the conditions created by those quakes no longer exist. But the reasons the Salvadorans, like the Haitians and Nicaraguans, should be allowed to stay far outweigh the technically legal reasons to send them home.\n\nThere is nothing stopping Congress and the Trump administration from rewriting immigration law to avoid such harsh choices in the future. And President Trump signaled on Tuesday that he\u2019d consider compromise on the hundreds of thousands of so-called Dreamers, undocumented immigrants brought to the United States as children.", "title": "Opinion | Don\u2019t Deport the Salvadorans", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. The editor, Tim Herrera, emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.\n\nA close friend and I have this agreement: If one of us ever recognizes the other person\u2019s \u201cthing,\u201d we\u2019re bound to disclose what it is, no matter what.\n\nBut what is a person\u2019s \u201cthing,\u201d exactly?\n\nIt\u2019s that particular behavior, habit or mind-set that is self-destructive but that we\u2019re completely blind to. Personally, professionally or otherwise, it\u2019s something that\u2019s holding us back from achieving our full potential, but for whatever reason, we simply can\u2019t see it ourselves. (This piece from The Hairpin perfectly sums up having a \u201cthing\u201d and being told about it.)\n\nThat level of self-awareness is quite elusive: Although some 95 percent of people think they\u2019re self-aware, only about 10 percent to 15 percent truly are, according to one study.", "title": "Don\u2019t Let a Lack of Self-Awareness Hold You Back", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "Christopher Heywood, spokesman for New York City\u2019s tourism organization, NYC & Company, said \u201cnegative rhetoric coming out of the current administration\u201d was a driving force behind the group\u2019s marketing last year, which featured the phrases \u201cWelcoming the world\u201d and \u201cAll are welcome.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re not a political group,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re a marketing group, but there was so much at stake, we needed to be more engaged.\u201d\n\nThe nonprofit tourism organization Brand USA will begin its new marketing campaign with a sweeping, 40-minute film that showcases the United States through the lens of musical history. It hopes the approach the will convey that the United States embraces individuals and cultures from outside its borders.\n\n\u201cTravel has a way of transcending politics,\u201d said Chris Thompson, president and chief executive of Brand USA. \u201cI think our ability to use music, because it\u2019s so compelling and inspirational, it really allows us to rise above any of that.\u201d\n\nThe film will be shown at museums and similar locations in top overseas markets beginning next month, and will be augmented by digital and social promotion.\n\n\u201cThat strategy could be a very interesting one because it gets across a lot of the wonderful cultural influences that have permeated life in the States from everywhere in the world,\u201d said Damien Eley, executive creative director at the ad agency Mistress, which has worked with the Los Angeles tourism board on its campaigns. \u201cIt\u2019s a nice device to be able to show the depth of culture and diversity in the States.\u201d\n\nGetting a tone of tacit recognition just right is a delicate feat. The destination marketing organizations of New York and Los Angeles, which ran campaigns explicitly highlighting their inclusivity last year, have employed similar strategies to evolve their messaging to be not anti-Trump but pro-destination.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. White"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "In New York City, it is not unusual to find a day care center on the ground floor of a brownstone or high-rise, a situation that can force toddlers and tycoons to coexist side by side. In some instances, neighbors form a close bond with the business, while others might have a harder time making peace with teeter-tottering in the backyard next door.\n\nFor Wendy George-Bush, opening Weebee Kids Daycare was not only a strategic career move after the birth of her third child, it was a way to form a stronger connection to her community.\n\n\u201cThe school crossing guard knows us, she refers a lot of people to the day care for us,\u201d Ms. George-Bush said. \u201cThe man at the corner store \u2014 we go in there and the kids know him, they\u2019ll purchase items,\u201d she said, describing one of the day care\u2019s organized neighborhood outings.\n\nMs. George-Bush, 46, a former school safety officer, said while there have been some in the neighborhood who didn\u2019t like the idea of a business opening up in a residential space, most of the community has embraced Weebee Kids. The exhibition \u201cUncovered: The Ken Burns Collection\u201d will display 28 of them for the first time.\n\nMr. Burns has been buying American quilts since the mid-1970s, often on prowls through antique stores on the back roads of New England; before too long, dealers began coming to him.\n\nHe now owns about 75 quilts, split among his home, office, barn and lake house in New Hampshire. He also keeps three in his Manhattan apartment, including his favorite, the \u201cCircular Wreath\u201d quilt, which hangs above his bed. He did not tell the International Quilt Study Center about it, he admitted. \u201cI don\u2019t have a quilt that gives me more pleasure than this one.\u201d\n\nHe warmed to his subject. \u201cFirst of all, you\u2019re faced with a loud but controlled design of these circles and these spots and these dots and the borders. And then,\u201d he said, pointing at the white background, \u201cyou go in and you cannot believe the extent of the quilting. There\u2019s some mirrored or deeper round circular things that aren\u2019t in any way what the circles are, and there\u2019s combinations. One may be a pinwheel, followed by something that is more like a traditional flower, with blossoms, and then lots of leaves in between. If you consider the thousands of woman-hours that went into this, it\u2019s just an extraordinary thing.\u201d", "title": "Don\u2019t Tell Ken Burns Quilts Are Quaint", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "The scientists cited, among other destabilizing factors, the harsh rhetoric President Trump has exchanged with North Korea\u2019s leader, Kim Jong-un; Mr. Trump\u2019s disavowal of the Iran deal; the hiring of climate-change deniers at the Environmental Protection Agency; and the administration\u2019s plans to remake and expand the nation\u2019s nuclear arsenal.\n\n\u201cNeither allies nor adversaries have been able to reliably predict U.S. actions \u2014 or understand when U.S. pronouncements are real, and when they are mere rhetoric,\u201d the scientists found. \u201cInternational diplomacy has been reduced to name-calling, giving it a surreal sense of unreality that makes the world security situation ever more threatening.\u201d\n\nThe scientists added: \u201cTo call the world nuclear situation dire is to understate the danger \u2014 and its immediacy.\u201d\n\nThe clock was last set at 2 minutes to midnight in 1953, after the Americans and then the Soviets tested thermonuclear weapons for the first time, within 10 months of each other. That was also the year that the Korean War ended \u2014 or, some would argue, paused \u2014 and President Dwight D. Eisenhower unveiled Atoms for Peace, a program intended to convince Americans that nuclear energy could be used to support research, medicine and agriculture and not only to destroy.\n\nThat year, Eugene Rabinowitch, a former Manhattan Project scientist who co-founded the bulletin, wrote: \u201cThe achievement of a thermonuclear explosion by the Soviet Union, following on the heels of the development of \u2018thermonuclear devices\u2019 in America, means that the time, dreaded by scientists since 1945, when each major nation will hold the power of destroying, at will, the urban civilization of any other nation, is close at hand.\u201d\n\nThe clock has been adjusted many times since it debuted in 1947. Since 2010 \u2014 years before Mr. Trump\u2019s presidency \u2014 the needle has moved ever closer to midnight: 5 minutes in 2012, 3 minutes in 2015, and two and a half minutes last year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAlong with nuclear proliferation and climate change \u2014 which first factored into the setting of the clock in 2007 \u2014 the scientists said they were alarmed by the speed of technological change. They called on world leaders to manage the advances so that the benefits are reaped and the dangers countered.\n\nThey cited, among other threats, the hacking of computer systems that control financial and energy infrastructure; the development of autonomous weaponry that can make \u201ckill\u201d decisions without human supervision; and the possible misuse of synthetic biology, including the revolutionary Crispr-Cas9 gene-editing tool.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe clock does not lack for critics. For example, some say that warning people of danger actually induces political paralysis. Others question the judgments of the expert panel that oversees the clock \u2014 the bulletin\u2019s science and security board \u2014 including the finding that the safest moment was in 1991, right after the Cold War had ended.\n\nThe bulletin\u2019s scientists did not seem unduly alarmed in 1962, the year of the Cuban Missile Crisis, which, along with the early 1980s, was one of the moments when the United States and the Soviet Union came closest to catastrophic blows.\n\n\u201cOne of the things about the clock is that it doesn\u2019t change in response to individual events,\u201d Lawrence M. Krauss, a cosmologist at Arizona State University and a member of the board, said in a phone interview on Thursday. \u201cIt\u2019s really hard to compare, in an absolute sense, today to 1953. More important is whether the clock is closer to or farther from midnight. Is this year more dangerous than last?\u201d\n\nMr. Krauss acknowledged that in the \u201cfake news\u201d era, some critics were likely to accuse the scientists of having a political agenda.\n\n\u201cPeople can say it\u2019s a scam, but the point of this is to encourage public discussion,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat you\u2019re trying to do is get people to act.\u201d He said the clock \u201ccaptures, for one day, deep existential threats that for most of the rest of the year aren\u2019t talked about.\u201d\n\nBeatrice Fihn, executive director of the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons, which was awarded the 2017 Nobel Peace Prize for its work on a treaty that was completed last July, said the advance of the Doomsday Clock was \u201cobviously deeply concerning and worrying and reflects where we are today.\u201d\n\nSpeaking by phone from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Ms. Fihn added: \u201cThe risks for nuclear use have increased exceptionally these last years, so of course, doing nothing is not an option.\u201d Without disarmament, she said, \u201cthese weapons will be used.\u201d", "title": "Doomsday Clock Is Set at 2 Minutes to Midnight, Closest Since 1950s", "authors": ["Sewell Chan"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Dorothy Malone, the sultry blond actress who won an Academy Award for playing an unapologetically bad girl in \u201cWritten on the Wind\u201d and found television stardom as a repentant one on \u201cPeyton Place,\u201d died on Friday in Dallas. She was 93.\n\nHer daughter Mimi Vanderstraaten confirmed the death, at an assisted living facility, where Ms. Malone had lived for the last 10 years.\n\nMs. Malone was 31 and had been in Hollywood for 13 years when she was cast as Marylee Hadley, a spoiled, sex-crazed young Texas oil heiress, in \u201cWritten on the Wind\u201d (1956). The film, directed by Douglas Sirk, Hollywood\u2019s master of glossy melodrama, also starred Rock Hudson and Robert Stack.\n\nThe three starred again together two years later in Sirk\u2019s drama \u201cTarnished Angels,\u201d in which a reporter (Mr. Hudson) falls for the sultry wife (Ms. Malone) of a barnstorming pilot (Mr. Stack).", "title": "Dorothy Malone Dies at 93; Star of TV\u2019s \u2018Peyton Place\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cG.O.P. Senators Pursuing Author of File on Trump\u201d (front page, Jan. 6): Instead of putting party over country in an attempt to discredit a government source and longtime intelligence ally in Christopher Steele, a former British agent, Senators Lindsey Graham and Charles Grassley would serve their judicial oversight roles and the American public better by working with their colleagues to investigate the Russian attack on our political system.\n\nSince Mr. Steele did bring the findings of his research to the F.B.I. because he was concerned that Kremlin interference was a threat to our election, senators serious about judicial oversight should be grateful for his information, not referring him to the Justice Department for criminal investigation.\n\nAfter all, had any of the members of Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign gone to the F.B.I. when they first discovered that the Kremlin wanted to help Mr. Trump win the election, our country might not be in this mess now.\n\nJANE RUPERT, HUNTINGTON, N.Y.", "title": "Opinion | Dossier Author Targeted by Senators", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "He umpired his first major league game on April 10, 1962, and during his rookie year he learned a lesson he would never forget.\n\nPhoto\n\nAs he told it, he was in St. Louis, only his third game behind the plate, with Stan Musial at bat. It was the ninth inning, bases loaded, two outs and a full count. As the next pitch approached the plate, Harvey raised his right hand, signaling strike three. But the pitch broke outside by three inches.\n\n\u201cThere I am standing with egg on my face,\u201d Harvey remembered in a 1992 interview with Jerome Holtzman for Baseball Digest shortly after he retired. \u201cMusial never looked at me. He asked the bat boy to bring him his glove. Then, without turning, he said, \u2018Young fellow, I don\u2019t know what league you came from, but we use the same plate. It\u2019s 17 inches wide.\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cThat\u2019s when I realized why they called him Stan the Man, and I learned not to anticipate the call. I introduced timing to umpiring. That\u2019s my gift to baseball. My heritage. My legacy. Before, the umpires were always told: \u2018Be quick! Be decisive!\u2019\u201d\n\nWhen Harvey was chosen for Cooperstown, Tommy Lasorda, the former Los Angeles Dodgers manager, recalled how \u201cyou could see every time he was on the field, he gave every ounce of energy he had, and I can\u2019t say that about a lot of guys.\u201d\n\nBut Lasorda was not always thrilled with Harvey. One time, when Keith Hernandez, the Mets\u2019 first baseman, was batting, Harvey\u2019s calls of two balls and no strikes brought howls from Lasorda in the dugout. \u201cDon\u2019t let those guys intimidate you,\u201d Hernandez told Harvey. His response: \u201cNobody\u2019s ever intimidated me, son.\u201d\n\nDoug Harvey was born on March 13, 1930, in South Gate, Calif. He was a teenager when he decided he would become a sports official, figuring he could do better than those he saw. He got his start in professional baseball as a ticket taker and a bat boy for a minor league team in El Centro, Calif.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter attending San Diego State University, where he played basketball, football and baseball, Harvey began his umpiring career in 1958 in the California League, earning $350 a month.\n\nPhoto\n\nJoy Harvey, in an interview with Lee Gutkind for his book on umpiring, \u201cThe Best Seat in Baseball: But You Have to Stand!,\u201d remembered how, while her husband was umpiring in the low minors, \u201cwe scrimped and saved so he had enough money to drive up to San Francisco for a night and a day.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe first place we went was Candlestick Park. In all his years in baseball, Doug had never, up to that time, been in a major league stadium, so we went that morning and asked if we could go in and walk around.\u201d\n\nThey sat in the top row of the stands in a silent and windy park, and then, said Joy Harvey: \u201cIt came right out of a Grade B movie, but I knew for all he was worth, Doug meant for it to come true. \u2018Some day,\u2019 he said, \u2018I\u2019m going to umpire in this stadium.\u2019\u201d\n\nHarvey, who chewed tobacco during his umpiring years, was found to have oral cancer in 1997 and spoke out about the dangers of smokeless tobacco following his treatment. He is survived by his wife; his brother Nolan; his sons Scott and Todd; six grandchildren; and eight great-grandchildren.\n\nFor all of his authoritative presence, Harvey once became embroiled in a controversy in which he came out second best.\n\nOn July 14, 1978, he ejected Don Sutton, the Dodgers\u2019 star pitcher, after accusing him of throwing defaced baseballs in a game at St. Louis. The infraction carried a 10-day suspension, but Sutton, proclaiming his innocence, said he would sue the National League and Harvey for depriving him of a livelihood. The league president, Chub Feeney, never imposed the suspension.\n\nHarvey\u2019s reputation was evidently well earned, but there was at least one person besides the sometimes aggrieved ballplayer or manager who made sure he did not get carried away by his lofty aura.\n\nOne Christmas, Joy Harvey gave her husband a T-shirt that read: \u201cWe\u2019ll Get Along Just Fine as Soon as You Realize I\u2019m God.\u201d", "title": "Doug Harvey, Hall of Fame Umpire Players Called God, Dies at 87", "authors": ["Richard Goldstein"]} {"date": "2018-01-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe Dow Jones industrial average on Thursday closed above 25,000 points for the first time, setting a record for the 132-year-old index.\n\nThe Dow, which broke though the 25,000 barrier shortly after trading opened in the morning, ended the day 152 points higher, at 25, 075.13, a gain of 0.6 percent.\n\nThe other major stock indexes also gained. The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index, a much broader index, closed at 2,723.99, a gain of 10.93 points or 0.4 percent. The Nasdaq composite rose 12.38 to 7,077.91, a gain of 0.2 percent.\n\nThe Dow\u2019s climb continues an ascent that began in early 2016. Other major indexes have also reached all-time highs in recent days, including the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite.\n\nUnderpinning much of the growth is a belief that corporate America will enjoy economic tailwinds in 2018, including benefits from the recently passed Republican tax overhaul.
