De La Merced"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Arc\u00e1ngel grew up in the Dominican Republic, with dreams of becoming a baseball player. He played professionally on a Venezuelan team for one year, he said, before a shoulder injury ended his career and he left for America in 1989. It was his experience as a boy playing on teams \u2014 where children from working-class families like himself played alongside street children \u2014 that showed him how providing some structure, even in the form of uniforms, bats and gloves, transformed his teammates\u2019 lives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThese youths that were lost, you have to find them, and bring them in, so they could love God,\u201d he said. \u201cThis is not a personal mission; it\u2019s a mission for the good of society.\u201d\n\nOnce in New York, he found work in the bodega he now owns, stocking shelves and flipping eggs for breakfast sandwiches there for 14 years before he purchased the business from his boss over a dozen years ago.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBefore he bought the store, Mr. Arc\u00e1ngel said, he would ask the owner if the indigent men who stopped in to beg for change, coffee and muffins, could rest in the air-conditioned store in summer, or warm up inside when it was cold. \u201cAlways, \u2018No! Are you crazy?\u2019\u201d he recalled with a laugh. The month he bought the shop, he said, he invited in his first homeless guest.\n\n\u201cWe are wolves. We are men who cannot be domesticated,\u201d said William Arroyo, 57, who says he has lived underneath the bodega for five years after serving time in prison for murder. \u201cHere,\u201d he said, \u201cis the wolf den.\u201d\n\nThere were over 62,000 homeless people living in city shelters as of October 2017, according to the Coalition for the Homeless, an advocacy organization, a 75 percent increase from the number a decade ago. It is difficult to estimate how many more live on the street, but a survey conducted in February by the city\u2019s Department of Homeless Services found about 3,900 people living on the streets, an increase of nearly 40 percent from the year prior.\n\nMany customers buying egg sandwiches from Mr. Arc\u00e1ngel were aware that a rotating crew of men hang around the bodega for hours, sipping beers inside, or sit staring at nothing in the courtyard out back. But even the regulars do not know where they sleep.\n\nJorge Borgias, 33, works at the upholstery shop next door, and takes coffee breaks at the bodega. He, too, is homeless, he said, but lives in a shelter nearby. \u201cThey live there?\u201d he said. \u201cSomething must be wrong with the world.\u201d", "title": "Down the Aisles, a Secret Shelter for the Homeless", "authors": ["Sarah Maslin Nir"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Before assuming the post, she also had investments in major tobacco companies, including Reynolds American, British American Tobacco, Imperial Brands, Philip Morris International, and Altria Group. Those were also sold in October, along with many of her other holdings.\n\nA former Georgia health commissioner, Dr. Fitzgerald was appointed to the federal agency last July by Tom Price, a fellow Georgian who served as Mr. Trump\u2019s first H.H.S. secretary \u2014 until he too was forced to resign under fire, for traveling extensively on private jets and expensing more than $400,000 for those trips to the government. Mr. Price\u2019s investments in health-related companies had also come under scrutiny while he was in government.\n\nIn a September ethics agreement, Dr. Fitzgerald said she would divest from many stocks that might pose a conflict of interest. The other investments included CVS Health, Quest Diagnostics, AbbVie, and Zimmer Biomet Holdings, among others. But she also said that she and her husband, Dr. Thomas Fitzgerald, were unable to divest from some holdings because of legal or contractual restrictions. Those were GW Ventures and Greenway Messenger, which are limited liability companies formed to invest in Greenway Health LLC, an electronic health information company, and Isommune, a biotech company focusing on early cancer detection.\n\nDr. Fitzgerald pledged to avoid any C.D.C. work that would affect those holdings, drawing criticism from Democrats who said such recusals would limit her effectiveness. In December, Senator Patty Murray, the ranking Democrat on the Senate panel that oversees the agency, expressed concerns that Dr. Fitzgerald\u2019s recusals on issues involving cancer and opioids prohibited her from dealing with two of the biggest health problems in the country.\n\nAnd even as she divested from many holdings in health-related companies, some members of Congress continued to express concern that those investments could compromise her positions on a variety of agency matters.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt is unacceptable that the person responsible for leading our nation\u2019s public health efforts has, for months, been unable to fully engage in the critical work she was appointed to do,\u201d Senator Murray said Wednesday. \u201cDr. Fitzgerald\u2019s tenure was unfortunately the latest example of the Trump administration\u2019s dysfunction and lax ethical standards.\u201d\n\nBut Dr. Fitzgerald\u2019s predecessor at the C.D.C., Dr. Tom Frieden, issued a statement that suggested the latest investments causing concern were made by a portfolio manager without Dr. Fitzgerald\u2019s knowledge. In August, financial disclosures show she purchased stocks in several companies that might conflict with her activities at the agency, including Japan Tobacco, the drugmaker Merck, and Humana, the health insurer. The records show she then sold those and other health stocks in October.\n\n\u201cI have spoken with Dr. Fitzgerald and believe her when she says that she was unaware that a tobacco company investment had been made,\u201d Dr. Frieden said. \u201cShe understands that any affiliation between the tobacco industry and public health is unacceptable, and that when she learned of it, she directed that it be sold.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut Craig Holman, the government affairs lobbyist for Public Citizen, the consumer advocacy group, said not knowing about the investments a manager is making on your behalf is not an excuse. \u201cYou cannot just say the manager can do whatever he or she wants to do as long as I don\u2019t know about it,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s not the conflict of interest code.\u201d\n\nThe tobacco-related investments alarmed others. \u201cIt\u2019s astonishing that the director of the Centers for Disease Control, which plays a major role in reducing tobacco use, would purchase stock in a tobacco company,\u201d said William B. Schultz, a former general counsel for H.H.S.\n\nThe agency has been tackling several tough issues this year, including potential budget cutbacks and a flu epidemic that claimed more lives this week and closed some schools across the country. About 80 percent of the cases this season are of the H3N2 strain, and officials said last week the rate of hospitalization among flu sufferers was particularly high this year. The agency plays a critical role in tracking the number of illnesses and deaths and helping coordinate the public health response.\n\nSenator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee and chairman of the committee that oversees the C.D.C., said he looked forward to working with Dr. Fitzgerald\u2019s successor to tackle a host of critical health issues. \u201cHow to turn the tide in the opioid crisis, how to prevent more flu deaths, how to be ready for the next outbreak of infectious disease or food-borne illness,\u201d he said.\n\nA two-time congressional candidate, Dr. Fitzgerald, an obstetrician-gynecologist, was active in Republican politics and had close ties to other prominent Georgians \u2014 among them, Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, and an early adviser to President Trump.\n\nAs the state\u2019s public health chief, Dr. Fitzgerald made fighting childhood obesity one of her highest priorities. But she drew criticism from public health officials for accepting $1 million from Coca-Cola to pay for the effort. Her program drew heavily from the soda giant\u2019s playbook, emphasizing Coke\u2019s contention that exercise \u2014 rather than calorie control \u2014 is key to weight loss.", "title": "Dr. Brenda Fitzgerald, C.D.C. Director, Resigns Over Tobacco and Other Investments", "authors": ["Sheila Kaplan"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "When he testified on Capitol Hill in 2009, Dr. Melius cited the case of Leon Heyward, an inspector for the city\u2019s Department of Consumer Affairs, who had helped evacuate disabled co-workers from ground zero and later learned he had sarcoidosis, a respiratory disease.\n\n\u201cHis disease got worse,\u201d Dr. Melius said in his 2009 testimony. \u201cHe had to stop working. He was denied workers\u2019 compensation. He struggled to get by and needed to move to a smaller apartment. He later developed lymphoma and died last year.\u201d\n\nAn autopsy later ruled Mr. Heyward\u2019s death a 9/11-related homicide, Dr. Melius said.\n\n\u201cThere are many more people,\u201d he added, \u201cwho have suffered, who have become ill, and we need a system in place to provide not only the medical programs we have, but also the assistance to them, economic assistance.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nDr. Melius also helped devise the medical treatment and monitoring program that the legislation created. (It also applies to those affected by the Sept. 11 attack on the Pentagon and the crash of the hijacked plane in Shanksville, Pa.)\n\n\u201cHe was a rock to lean on,\u201d Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a New York Democrat who was the lead House sponsor of the law, said in a telephone interview. \u201cHe was the principal force for building the science that 9/11 caused these illnesses and deaths.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe law was named for James Zadroga, a New York City police detective whose death in 2006 from respiratory failure was linked to the dust he inhaled during rescue and recovery work at the World Trade Center.\n\nJames Malcolm Melius was born on June 16, 1948, in Great Barrington, Mass., and grew up across the New York border in Copake Falls. His father, Norman, was a farmer, and his mother, the former Helen Hodgkins, was a first-grade teacher.\n\nAfter graduating from Brown University and the University of Illinois School of Medicine, he received a doctorate in epidemiology from the University of Illinois School of Public Health.\n\nA residency in occupational medicine at Cook County Hospital started him on a series of positions dedicated to safeguarding the welfare of workers. He worked in Cincinnati at the National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health; and in Albany for the New York State Department of Health, the Center to Protect Workers\u2019 Rights and the New York State Laborers\u2019 Union, which represents mainly construction workers.\n\n\u201cHe had an early sense of wanting to do good and remain connected with working-class people,\u201d Jeremy Melius said in a phone interview. \u201cHe had a strong sense of service.\u201d\n\nIn the aftermath of an explosion and fire in 1980 at a hazardous chemical storage site in Elizabeth, N.J., Dr. Melius, by then chief of the occupational safety institute\u2019s hazard evaluations branch, coordinated the agency\u2019s response.\n\n\u201cHe flew in and got N.I.O.S.H. a trailer to do medical evaluations of the firefighters,\u201d Richard Duffy, a former official of the International Association of Fire Fighters, said in an interview. \u201cIt was one of the first times that firefighters were evaluated after a major incident, and that continues today.\u201d\n\nFour years later, Dr. Melius was part of a small group of American experts who traveled to Bhopal, India, to help the medical authorities there in their investigation of the long-term health effects of a poison-gas leak at a Union Carbide plant that killed thousands. He noted that exposure to the gas would cause irreversible damage to the lungs of 50,000 survivors.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDr. Philip J. Landrigan, the dean for global health at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in New York, said Dr. Melius had created innovative health and safety programs in the construction trades as well as assisting states and Canadian provinces on legislation that presumes that the dangerous work of firefighters is a major factor when they are disabled or killed by heart and lung disease and cancer.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s fair to say that Jim Melius was the senior medical officer in the entire American labor movement,\u201d said Dr. Landrigan, a longtime colleague who collaborated with him on the 9/11 medical program at Mount Sinai.\n\nIn addition to his son, Dr. Melius is survived by his wife, the former Melanie Boice, and another son, Ehren.\n\nIn testimony to a House committee in 2007, Dr. Melius said the government had failed to ensure the health of workers at ground zero. After the initial rescue phase, he said, further recovery work should have been halted pending implementation of a comprehensive safety plan that had been adopted.\n\nIn the future, he said, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration should be involved in providing a comprehensive assessment of a site\u2019s hazards, enforcing federal protection standards, and mandating that \u201cno work at that site should go forward without O.S.H.A.\u2019s certification that people are being appropriately protected during that work.\u201d", "title": "Dr. James Melius, Advocate for Workers\u2019 Health, Dies at 69", "authors": ["Richard Sandomir"]} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cGymnasts\u2019 Abuse Draws Sentence Likely to Be Life\u201d (front page, Jan. 25), about the sentencing of Lawrence G. Nassar, the former doctor for the American gymnastics team:\n\nJudge Rosemarie Aquilina, thank you, and if only there were more judges like you. But the story has not ended. At least the outcome has provided some relief for those young women and their dreams and aspirations, many of which have already been attained, but at a cost that no one should endure.\n\nYes, their suffering has been vindicated, and next in line must be Michigan State, whose president resigned on Wednesday, and the formerly iconic and now infamous Karolyi Ranch, the U.S.A. Gymnastics National Team Training Center. The disgrace falls on both institutions. Yet these beautiful young women will be scarred for the rest of their lives.\n\nThey have taken the first courageous step by telling of abuses that occurred in places we would have never expected. But they helped us understand that sexual assault is pervasive in our society.\n\nLet\u2019s hope that their scars will fade with time. Time is on their side. I pray that they will find full recovery and healing.", "title": "Opinion | Dr. Nassar\u2019s Crimes Against Gymnasts", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Dr. Ronald R. Fieve, who was a pioneer in the prescription of lithium to treat mania and other mood disorders \u2014 while avowing that some gifted individuals, like Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt and Winston Churchill, might have benefited from being bipolar \u2014 died on Jan. 2 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 87.\n\nThe cause was congestive heart failure, his daughter Vanessa Fieve Willett said.\n\nAlerted by his adviser, Dr. Lawrence Kolb, to groundbreaking research in Australia, Dr. Fieve (pronounced FEE-vee) began experimenting with lithium to mitigate depression in the 1950s, when he was a resident at the New York State Psychiatric Institute.\n\nHe and a colleague, Dr. Ralph N. Wharton, went on to identify lithium as the first naturally occurring medication to prevent and control a specific psychiatric disorder and reduce the risk of relapses.\n\nIn 1966 Dr. Fieve established the first lithium clinic in North America.\n\n\u201cDuring the 1970s, it was apparent that psychiatry was going through a difficult transition and suffering from an identity crisis,\u201d Dr. Fieve wrote in \u201cBipolar Breakdown\u201d (2009), one of several of his popular books.", "title": "Dr. Ronald Fieve, 87, Dies; Pioneered Lithium to Treat Mood Swings", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "FRANKFURT \u2014 Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, directed unusually sharp criticism at Steven Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary, on Thursday, effectively accusing Mr. Mnuchin of violating agreements among nations against starting currency wars.\n\nMr. Draghi, speaking at a news conference here, said he objected to \u201cthe use of language in discussing exchange rate developments that doesn\u2019t reflect the terms of reference that have been agreed.\u201d He then quoted from an agreement reached in Washington in October under which countries promised to \u201crefrain from competitive devaluations.\u201d\n\nMr. Draghi did not mention Mr. Mnuchin by name, but he was clearly referring to the Treasury secretary\u2019s remarks on Wednesday at a World Economic Forum panel in Davos, Switzerland, that a weaker dollar was good for United States trade. The comment was interpreted as an effort to talk down the dollar, which would breach the international nonaggression pact on currency rates.\n\nOn Thursday, Mr. Mnuchin told reporters in Davos that his comment had been misunderstood.\n\n\u201cI thought it was actually balanced and consistent with what I\u2019ve said before,\u201d he said, \u201cwhich is we\u2019re not concerned with where the dollar is in the short term. It\u2019s a very, very liquid market and we believe in free currencies. And that there\u2019s both advantages and disadvantages of where the dollar is in the short term.\u201d (After arriving in Davos, President Trump said during an interview that he wanted \u201cto see a strong dollar\u201d and that Mr. Mnuchin\u2019s remarks had been misinterpreted.)", "title": "Draghi, Chief of Europe\u2019s Central Bank, Chides Mnuchin Over Dollar Comments", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "We\u2019re more than two weeks into the new year, but chances are you\u2019re still writing 2017 on anything you must. You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.\n\nIn a surprise statement undercutting Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke\u2019s announcement last week that he would exempt Florida from President Trump\u2019s offshore drilling plan, a senior Interior Department official said Friday that Florida\u2019s coastal waters had not been excluded after all.\n\nThe Trump administration is moving to allow new offshore oil and gas drilling in nearly all United States coastal waters, lifting a ban on drilling imposed by President Barack Obama near the end of his term.\n\nBut after a meeting with Gov. Rick Scott of Florida on Jan. 9, Mr. Zinke had announced on Twitter that he was \u201cremoving Florida from consideration for any new oil and gas platforms.\u201d The abrupt decision has sparked demands for exemptions from governors of other coastal states.", "title": "Drilling Off Florida Is Still on the Table, Interior Official Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Most of the plan would require the approval of the state legislature, which is expected to receive it Friday.\n\nIn announcing his support last summer for congestion pricing, Mr. Cuomo said the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the region\u2019s umbrella transit agency, needs a new, reliable source of funds. Depending on how the prices are structured, the task force estimated that up to $1.5 billion could become available annually.\n\nWith New York\u2019s population at an all-time high, its streets snarled by mounting traffic and its famed public transit system in steep decline both above ground and below, it has become increasingly apparent that the city is choking on its own growth. Mr. Cuomo is gambling this proposal will succeed where earlier attempts have failed, though the dire transit situation, as well as improvements in technology, give it a far better shot at becoming reality than past attempts.\n\n\u201cNew York City traffic congestion now ranks second worst among cities in the United States and third worst among cities in the world,\u201d a draft of the report says. If not abated, the congestion will cost the economy of the metropolitan area $100 billion over the next five years, the task force estimated.\n\nThe governor is picking up a cause that was championed by former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in 2008, but that met stiff resistance. It died in the State Assembly without coming to a vote. The current mayor, Bill de Blasio, has said that he favors a tax on millionaires and has argued that congestion pricing hurts the middle class and poor who live outside Manhattan and drive into it.\n\nThe report dismissed those claims, saying only 4 percent of residents of other boroughs commute to jobs in Manhattan in a vehicle, or approximately 118,000 residents. Of those, it said, more than half were higher income individuals, and fewer than 5,000 of them would qualify as working poor.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs important as the study has been for the city, the openly hostile relationship between the governor and the mayor was reflected in the makeup of the task force: Of its 15 members, none are from the de Blasio administration. The report called for increased traffic enforcement by the city, and said the distribution of official parking placards should be subject to a joint review by city and state officials.\n\nPeople who live within the congestion zone would not be exempt from the new fees.\n\nThe new plan reflects a changed technological and political landscape since Mr. Bloomberg\u2019s effort. It was described by people familiar with its details who asked not to be identified because it has not yet been presented to state legislators.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNew technology can identify vehicles on any roadway and automatically charge them, so the task force was able to draw a narrower \u2014 and perhaps more politically palatable \u2014 cordon limited to the most crowded streets. In turn, that means drivers can enter Midtown and Lower Manhattan by two bridges without paying as long as they go directly to the F.D.R. Drive along the East River and then continue on it until they are out of the congestion zone.\n\n\n\nWith current street configurations, that is possible only at the Edward I. Koch Queensboro Bridge at East 59th Street and the Brooklyn Bridge downtown; coming into Manhattan via the Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges, drivers are only able to continue into streets covered in the zone.\n\nThe crisis in the transit system may also make it easier for Mr. Cuomo to sell the pricing plan to the legislature. When Mr. Bloomberg made his pitch a decade ago, the transit system was in far better shape. In fact, the Bloomberg plan was intended to address surging ridership and anticipated the budget pressures that led to maintenance cuts.\n\nSince then, the city\u2019s traffic problems have also worsened, even though fewer vehicles are driving into the central business district, the report said. In expanding and creating bicycle lanes and pedestrian malls, the city has decreased driving lanes for vehicles. The iPhone, released in 2007, led to an explosion of Uber and ride-hail cars that jam streets in Midtown and Lower Manhattan. Truck deliveries and rampant construction routinely block traffic. Midtown traffic now crawls at an average of 4.7 miles per hour, down from 6.5 miles per hour five years ago.\n\nEver more pedestrians and cyclists are fighting for elbow room on crowded sidewalks and streets: The city\u2019s population of 8.5 million has increased by a half-million since 2000. An estimated 60 million tourists visited last year, up 25 percent since 2010.\n\nThe gridlock is not only a problem for commuters. Kathryn Wylde, the president and chief executive of the Partnership for New York City, a group of top business leaders, said that longer commutes and work trips resulted in lost productivity, increased business costs, and higher fuel and vehicle expenses. In an analysis released this week, the partnership calculated that worsening congestion now costs the New York region about $20 billion annually, up from $13 billion annually in 2006.\n\nSam Schwartz, a former city traffic commissioner who served on the state task force, said that these recommendations could make a real impact in addressing New York City\u2019s transit and traffic morass. \u201cI\u2019m proud of the work that the panel has done, and I\u2019m very encouraged with the courage the governor has shown in raising congestion pricing as an alternative.\u201d", "title": "Driving a Car in Manhattan Could Cost $11.52 Under Congestion Plan", "authors": ["Jim Dwyer", "Winnie Hu"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Silicon Valley has birthed many highly valued and hugely hyped start-ups in recent years, including Uber, Airbnb and Pinterest. Few of those companies have made it out onto the stock market successfully.\n\nNow Dropbox, the online file storage company that is part of Silicon Valley\u2019s closely watched pack of \u201cunicorns,\u201d plans to try its luck. The company has filed documents to go public, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.\n\nIf Dropbox \u2014 last valued by private-market investors at about $10 billion \u2014 follows through on an initial public offering, it will become one of the highest-profile technology companies of late to seek a stock market listing. The company is on track to join Spotify, the online streaming giant, on the public markets, with Uber, Lyft and Airbnb expected to follow suit in the next few years.\n\nDropbox\u2019s filing has implications for other Silicon Valley unicorns, which are companies that were privately valued at more than $1 billion. There are cars being burned. There are politicians that are being burned \u2026 and yes, there are no-go zones in the Netherlands.\u201d\n\nMr. Hoekstra said the reporter\u2019s claim about the statement was \u201cfake news.\u201d The reporter then showed a video clip of the remarks, prompting Mr. Hoekstra to deny he had just used the term \u201cfake news.\u201d The exchange went viral.\n\nLast week, Dutch reporters had one question they particularly wanted to press Mr. Hoekstra on: Would he admit that his 2015 claims were false, or could he cite an example of a Dutch politician who was burned in recent years?\n\nLooking like a deer in headlights, the ambassador tried to brush off his interrogators. Maybe Mr. Hoekstra had watched President Trump spew lies and hate without apology for so long that he thought he could get away with it, too. Not in The Hague, apparently. The journalists came back repeatedly \u2014 \u201cThis is the Netherlands, you have to answer questions,\u201d one said.\n\nThey invoked a quote from John Adams, the first American envoy to the Netherlands, about \u201chonest and wise men.\u201d They were probably being ironic.\n\nThe ambassador looked uncomfortable, but it was refreshing to see reporters demanding honesty from an official and not letting up in the face of resistance. It would be good to see that more often on this side of the ocean, especially since the confrontation seemed to have had a salutary effect.", "title": "Opinion | Dutch Reporters Show How to Keep American Officials Honest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "For the first time on television, Dylan Farrow accused her father, Woody Allen, of molesting her as a child, telling \u201cCBS This Morning\u201d: \u201cI want to show my face and tell my story.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhy shouldn\u2019t I want to bring him down?\u201d Ms. Farrow, 32, told Gayle King during a conversation that aired on Wednesday and Thursday. \u201cWhy shouldn\u2019t I be angry? Why shouldn\u2019t I be hurt? Why shouldn\u2019t I feel some sort of outrage that after all these years, being ignored and disbelieved and tossed aside?\u201d\n\nMs. Farrow, the adopted daughter of Mia Farrow and Mr. Allen, had made the allegations before: First, they were investigated in 1992, and detailed in an article in Vanity Fair. This would be the year of a very public and acrimonious split between Ms. Farrow and Mr. Allen, as well as a bitter custody battle that would dominate headlines.\n\nDylan Farrow again raised the allegations in a 2014 letter published by the New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof. And on CBS, she went into detail about her experience during a period when Hollywood is reckoning with an industrywide movement against sexual misconduct that has brought down powerful figures in Hollywood such as Kevin Spacey and Harvey Weinstein.", "title": "Dylan Farrow Accuses Woody Allen of Sexual Abuse in TV Interview", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "I wanted to become an actor, too. I had no idea how anyone did such a thing, let alone become a star. I so wanted someone to look at me the way they looked at John Belushi \u2014 with admiration, fondness, respect and, dare I say, love. But I knew that was a pipe dream. He was hilarious, smart and bigger than life. I was awkward, painfully skinny and partially mute.\n\nSeveral Sundays after that first appearance, Dad gave me my big chance to wait on John. I slipped on some sawdust and almost landed in his lap. My father shook his head and disappeared into the office with a tall glass of vodka. I knew he couldn\u2019t bear to witness what would inevitably be a disaster.\n\nAfter all, I had clumsily on purpose/by accident broken most of his most recent wedding gifts. He had just married the playwright Eve Ensler, who thankfully adopted me and literally saved my life. Eve saw something in me I didn\u2019t even recognize in myself. She was the one who encouraged me to become an actor, and I ran with it.\n\nDad was relieved it was August, because I would be returned to my grandmother in Connecticut for the coming school year. I couldn\u2019t quite blame him. My Dorothy Hamill hair, white Capezio dance shoes and red tuxedo jacket had long outstayed their welcome. I was clearly channeling David Bowie and the New York Dolls \u2026 desperately searching for an identity.\n\nJohn Belushi looked at me with a combination of confusion and disappointment.\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re not Jimmy,\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cNo, I\u2019m not,\u201d I immediately apologized.\n\n\u201cWhere\u2019s Jimmy?\u201d John said.\n\n\u201cSick,\u201d I offered, lying through my teeth.\n\n\u201cWhat can I get you?\u201d I stammered.\n\n\u201cBacon and eggs,\u201d John said, diverting his attention to the script he was reading. \u201cAnd I want them runny.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cRunny?\u201d I repeated.\n\nJohn looked at me the way one looks at a dog who\u2019s missing a hind leg: sympathetic yet strangely curious.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI apologetically shuffled off and placed his order. Russell, our drunken chef, dropped some wet cigar ash into Mr. Belushi\u2019s meal, which was tragically not uncommon. I dutifully pointed it out. Russell groaned and wiped off the black ash with an even filthier cloth.\n\nI cautiously picked up the hot plate, weighing whether to run out onto West Fourth Street and hail a cab to some exotic destination, or deliver this pile of holy slop to his highness.\n\nAs I passed the bar, Benny the bartender was shoving his glass eye back into his head after dousing it with club soda. I delivered John\u2019s breakfast and sprinted away.\n\n\u201cWait!\u201d John shouted.\n\nDamn, did I not get it right? I thought he said bacon and eggs? I was sure of it!\n\nI raced back to his table, praying to the Holy Virgin Mary herself that there wasn\u2019t a dead cigar stuffed under his hash browns.\n\n\u201cYes?\u201d I mumbled.\n\n\u201cKetchup,\u201d John said.\n\n\u201cWhat?\u201d I politely asked.\n\n\u201cKetchup!\u201d John exhaled, annoyed that he had to repeat himself.\n\nI fetched some and gingerly placed it on the plastic green checkerboard tablecloth, the kind mostly reserved for Irish bars and wakes.\n\nJohn finally looked at me and smiled.\n\n\u201cThanks, kid.\u201d Egg yolk proudly dripped down his famous protruding chin.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow pathetically wonderful, I thought to myself: John Belushi acknowledged my existence. However brief this strange encounter, it gave me what I needed to hold on to.\n\nI waited on plenty of celebrities over the coming summers. Most of them were dismissive or irritated.\n\nBut when I finally hosted \u201cS.N.L.\u201d many moons later, the ghost of John Belushi seemed to tap me on my shoulder with his sword for good luck. I was standing on the very same stage where he performed \u201cSamurai Delicatessen\u201d! I said a prayer of thanks to him for inspiring me.\n\nMy father and Eve were in the audience that night, both happy and confused that I had made it so far. But most important, they looked at me with admiration, fondness, respect and, dare I say, love.", "title": "Dylan McDermott: The First Time I Waited On a Celebrity\u2019s Table", "authors": ["Dylan Mcdermott"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "The piercing replacement questions Mr. Seacrest and Ms. Rancic came up with for their guests also didn\u2019t really advance the cause. Samples: \u201cWhat were your New Year\u2019s resolutions?\u201d (Mr. Seacrest to Neil Patrick Harris); \u201cWhat are some strange secret talents you have?\u201d (Ms. Rancic to the cast of \u201cStranger Things\u201d). And the fact that while the hosts dutifully attempted to discuss the issues with the boldface names on their podiums, they didn\u2019t seem to really know what to do with the answers.\n\nEspecially when interviewees such as Debra Messing and Eva Longoria both decided to use their platform to call out E! itself for paying its female hosts less than its male hosts, and announce, in Ms. Messing\u2019s case, she stood in solidarity with Catt Sadler, who quit her job a few weeks ago after revealing she had discovered her male co-host had a much higher salary. Neither Ms. Rancic nor Mr. Seacrest wanted to go near that one.\n\nThey also generally forgot to ask the male celebs \u2014 many fewer than the women \u2014 who were wearing all black why they were wearing all black, though they did approvingly point out their Time\u2019s Up pins. And though they complimented the women such as Meryl Streep, Laura Dern and Emma Watson who brought activists as their dates on their choices, and stood there smiling awkwardly through the social-justice schooling, the lack of follow-up was palpable.\n\nIndeed, most of the responses seemed to sail right over the elaborately coiffed heads of the well-tanned hosts. How else to interpret the fact that Mr. Seacrest summed up the two-hour show, with its discussions of everything from the experiences of female farmworkers to the pay gap to the gender imbalance, by saying: \u201cIt started with big stars, ended with big stars, and the Globes start now on NBC with big stars\u201d?\n\nI\u2019m not sure what show he thought he had hosted (maybe last year\u2019s?). But it didn\u2019t sound like the one I \u2014 or most people \u2014 probably saw.", "title": "E! Network Fumbles Over #WhyWeWearBlack", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine released a report on Tuesday assessing studies about the health effects of e-cigarettes. The panel of experts conducted a comprehensive review of research in the field, categorizing evidence on various issues as conclusive, substantial, limited or nonexistent. Below are some of their conclusions.\n\nNicotine and addiction\n\nThere is substantial evidence that e-cigarette use can be addictive. Exposure to nicotine varies a lot, depending on the device and the e-liquid it uses, as well as the individual vaper\u2019s practices. But, the report said, there is also substantial evidence that nicotine intake from e-cigarettes, used by experienced adults, can be comparable to that of conventional cigarettes.\n\nModerate evidence: The risk and severity of dependence on e-cigarettes is lower than for conventional cigarettes.\n\nToxic substances\n\nTraditional cigarettes pose serious risks to human health, much of it from toxic tobacco smoke. There is conclusive evidence that most e-cigarette products contain and emit numerous potentially toxic substances, and that they increase airborne particulate matter and nicotine indoors. But despite that, the evidence suggests that e-cigarette aerosol contains fewer toxic substances and lower levels of them than smoke from conventional cigarettes.", "title": "E-Cigarettes\u2019 Risks and Benefits: Highlights From the Report to the F.D.A.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAt least two people were killed and dozens sickened by E. coli outbreaks in Canada and the United States that the authorities in Canada have linked to romaine lettuce.\n\nHealth officials in the United States are not yet ready to blame the American outbreak to the leafy green. Still, they say, the Canadian finding has proved helpful and both outbreaks appear to have been caused by related strains of the bacteria, suggesting the possibility of a shared source.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019ve done a really thorough job there, and I think that gave us a really good clue to start with,\u201d Dr. Matthew Wise, who oversees investigations into such outbreaks for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said in a telephone interview on Friday.\n\nIn all, at least 58 people in both countries have been sickened, and two \u2014 one in California and one in Canada \u2014 have died. In the United States, the C.D.C. has so far linked at least 17 reports of illness in 13 states to the outbreak.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada said in a statement last week that it was investigating 41 cases of illnesses linked to E. coli from November and December.", "title": "E. You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 The Trump administration has formally suspended a major Obama-era clean water regulation ahead of plans to issue its own version of the rule later this year.\n\nPresident Trump has taken aim at the bitterly contested rule, known as Waters of the United States, since his campaign, calling it \u201cone of the worst examples of federal regulation.\u201d Among Mr. Trump\u2019s first actions in office was an executive order directing his Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Scott Pruitt, to begin the legal process of rescinding the rule and replacing it with a more industry-friendly alternative.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Climate Fwd: Sign up for our newsletter to get our latest stories about climate change \u2014 along with answers to your questions and tips on how to help. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr. Pruitt took a major step toward completing that task, filing the legal documents required to suspend the Obama rule for two years. The rule was set to be implemented in the coming weeks, following a Supreme Court decision last week that gave jurisdiction of the matter to district courts.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHaving suspended the water rule, Mr. Pruitt is now crafting a Trump administration version, which is expected to include much looser regulatory requirements on how farmers, ranchers and real estate developers must safeguard the streams and tributaries that flow through their property and into larger bodies of water.", "title": "E.P.A. Blocks Obama-Era Clean Water Rule", "authors": ["Coral Davenport"]} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In the latest decision, European regulators found that Qualcomm, the world\u2019s largest maker of smartphone chips, abused its market dominance by preventing rivals from competing in the smartphone chip market thanks to an agreement in which it paid Apple to exclusively use its chips in iPhones and iPads between 2011 and 2016.\n\n\u201cQualcomm illegally shut out rivals from the market\u201d for a particular kind of microchip, Ms. Vestager said in a news release, \u201cthereby cementing its market dominance.\u201d\n\n\u201cQualcomm paid billions of U.S. dollars to a key customer, Apple, so that it would not buy from rivals,\u201d she added. \u201cThese payments were not just reductions in price \u2014 they were made on the condition that Apple would exclusively use Qualcomm\u2019s baseband chipsets in all its iPhones and iPads.\u201d\n\nThe European Commission, the European Union\u2019s executive arm, found that Qualcomm\u2019s practices had a significant, detrimental impact on competition in the region. \u201cIt excluded rivals from the market and deprived European consumers of genuine choice and innovation,\u201d the commission said.\n\nMs. Vestager said that she could not say how much Apple had ultimately received from Qualcomm in payments, but that it was in the \u201cbillions of dollars.\u201d\n\nShe said that internal documents reviewed as part of the inquiry showed that Apple had seriously considered using chips made by a rival manufacturer, Intel, during the period of its agreement with Qualcomm, but did not do so until the deal with Qualcomm had concluded.\n\nIf Apple had introduced a smartphone using products from a different chip maker, she said, Apple not only would have lost future payments from Qualcomm, but also would have been forced to pay back some of the money it had already received.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Vestager said that Apple would not face any repercussions because the inquiry had been focused on Qualcomm\u2019s practices. European regulators are also continuing a separate investigation into preliminary findings that Qualcomm sold its chips at below cost price from 2009 to 2011 to force a competitor out of the market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a statement, Qualcomm said that it \u201cstrongly disagrees\u201d with the decision and that it would appeal the ruling to the European Union\u2019s highest court.\n\n\u201cWe are confident this agreement did not violate E.U. competition rules or adversely affect market competition or European consumers,\u201d Don Rosenberg, Qualcomm\u2019s general counsel, said in a news release. \u201cWe have a strong case for judicial review, and we will immediately commence that process.\u201d\n\nThe fine on Wednesday came with Qualcomm in the midst of multiple takeover battles. It has sought to fight off a hostile $105 billion takeover attempt by a rival, the Singapore-based chip maker Broadcom. If completed, that takeover would be the largest technology deal in history. And despite that battle in the background, Qualcomm is still looking to complete a $38.5 billion acquisition of NXP Semiconductors.\n\nIn a letter to investors last week, Qualcomm raised its profit forecast, outlined plans to reduce its costs and promised to buy back shares if it was unsuccessful in its efforts to acquire NXP. Qualcomm said the Broadcom offer \u201cdramatically undervalues\u201d the company and \u201cdoes not reflect our clear path to near term value.\u201d\n\nQualcomm has been a longtime leader in cellphone chip technology, and its trove of patents, which include ubiquitous processes such as the way applications are downloaded from smartphone app stores and the use of airplane mode, remains one of the most lucrative assets in the world of wireless networking.\n\nFounded in 1985, the company helped build the modern mobile phone industry with its technology. For decades, Qualcomm engineers have made crucial innovations that have helped the sector develop and expand, and bolstered the company\u2019s results along the way.\n\nBut more recently, it has faced a multitude of legal and shareholder issues. The company in 2015 agreed to pay a $975 million fine for violating China\u2019s antimonopoly law. Later that year, an activist campaign within the company forced layoffs. In December 2016, Qualcomm was also fined $850 million in South Korea for unfair patent licensing.\n\nThen a year ago, the company was hit with separate lawsuits just days apart. First, the Federal Trade Commission filed a complaint against it for charging unreasonable fees to partners like Apple. Soon after, Apple sued Qualcomm over what it claimed were $1 billion in withheld rebates.\n\nThe continuing disputes have weighed on Qualcomm\u2019s results, cutting its profit by 89 percent in the fourth quarter. The company took a $778 million charge related to a fine imposed by Taiwanese regulators in October, and its results were again hit by the royalty dispute with Apple.", "title": "E.U. Fines Qualcomm $1.2 Billion Over Apple Deal", "authors": ["Chad Bray"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "ESPN has fired the former N.F.L. players Donovan McNabb and Eric Davis, who worked as radio hosts for the network and who have been accused of sexual misconduct in a lawsuit against the NFL Network, their previous employer.\n\nMcNabb and Davis are among a group of men accused of sexual harassment or assault in the lawsuit filed by Jami Cantor, a former wardrobe stylist for the NFL Network.\n\nESPN started investigating the allegations about four weeks ago, according to Josh Krulewitz, a network spokesman.\n\nCantor has accused McNabb, the former Philadelphia Eagles quarterback, of sending her sexually inappropriate text messages, and she has alleged that Davis, a former cornerback who won a Super Bowl with the San Francisco 49ers, groped her and made lewd comments. In a first-person story for Sports Illustrated, a makeup artist for the NFL Network, Erin McParland, also accused Davis of groping her.\n\nAfter the allegations in the lawsuit were made public last month, ESPN suspended McNabb and Davis. Elliott missed the extra point.\n\nFoles directed brilliant marches of 74 and 80 yards in the second half \u2014 one into a whipping wind, the other with it at his back. And Elliott atoned for his miss by converting from 53 yards at the end of the second quarter, then from 37 and 21 yards in the second half.\n\nThe Falcons, of course, memorably blew a 28-3 second-half lead to the Patriots in last year\u2019s Super Bowl. They will not have the opportunity to atone for that now, though Ryan got them close at the end.", "title": "Eagles Hold On Against the Falcons to Reach the N.F.C. Title Game", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "In halting Minnesota\u2019s quest to become the first team to play a Super Bowl in its home stadium, Foles destroyed the league\u2019s stingiest scoring defense, completing 26 of 33 passes for 352 yards and three touchdowns without an interception.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan. He\u2019s covered Kobe. And LeBron vs. the Warriors. Go behind the N.B.A.\u2019s curtain with the league\u2019s foremost expert in a new basketball newsletter. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe became the only quarterback in franchise history to throw for a least 300 yards and three touchdowns in a postseason game, and no moment was more symbolic than the first of those scoring tosses \u2014 a 53-yarder to Alshon Jeffery, who spurned the Vikings last off-season to sign with Philadelphia. Bouncing in the pocket, Foles stayed cool and delivered a perfect ball downfield despite getting smacked in the shoulder by the Vikings\u2019 Everson Griffen.\n\n\u201cEvery time he threw the ball,\u201d center Jason Kelce said, \u201che was on point.\u201d\n\nThat touchdown, which extended Philadelphia\u2019s lead to 21-7, devastated the Vikings, who have now lost their last six conference championship games. As any Vikings fan knows, the real Minnesota Miracle is not the last-second victory last week but a Super Bowl berth, which they have not earned in 41 years.\n\nThe primary symbols of Minnesota\u2019s futility across that span \u2014 Gary Anderson\u2019s missed field goal and Brett Favre\u2019s interception and Darrin Nelson\u2019s drop \u2014 have worn purple and white. On this night, it was the Eagles who inflicted the misery, not that it offered any relief.\n\nIt was Chris Long, a menace off the edge, who helped force an interception and recovered a fumble. It was Patrick Robinson, who wove through the Vikings on a 50-yard interception return for a touchdown that revived the building. And it was, unquestionably, Foles, who flummoxed the Vikings with passes long and short \u2014 even a flea-flicker touchdown to Torrey Smith \u2014 and rewarded the steadfast faith and masterly play-calling of Coach Doug Pederson to continue leading Philadelphia down a familiar path.\n\nThe last time the Eagles reached the Super Bowl, in the 2004 season, they defeated Atlanta and Minnesota before facing New England, just as they have, and will, in this postseason. They will be the underdog in Minneapolis, as they have been in both of their playoff games, and that will not bother them one iota.\n\n\u201cPeople can do whatever they want \u2014 count us out, count us in,\u201d running back Jay Ajayi said. \u201cWe\u2019re playing in the Super Bowl. They\u2019re going to have to sit back and watch us do that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat the Eagles emerged from a rugged N.F.C., ahead of recent conference champions (Atlanta and Carolina) and teams with Hall of Fame quarterbacks (New Orleans), would have been less surprising had Wentz not gotten hurt. That December night in Los Angeles, after Wentz left with a knee injury, and after Foles came on to direct them to a division-clinching victory against the Rams that improved their record to 11-2, safety Malcolm Jenkins gathered the team in a cramped Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum locker room and peddled positives. Nothing had changed, he said. The goal remained the same.\n\nPhoto\n\nAfterward, speaking to reporters, he said, \u201cDo we have a quarterback on the roster?\u201d\n\nYes.\n\n\u201cO.K., then,\u201d Jenkins said.\n\nThe Eagles had Foles, who, as his teammates will readily remind you, threw 27 touchdowns in 2013. He broke his collarbone the next season, then got traded in 2015, nearly retired in 2016 and returned to Philadelphia in 2017, to back up Wentz.\n\n\u201cYou feel like you played a great game in L.A., you have the best record in football, and you lose your most valuable player \u2014 or maybe the league\u2019s most valuable player,\u201d the Eagles owner Jeffrey Lurie said. \u201cHowever, we made such a concerted effort to make sure we could get Nick back on the team. Who knew it would come to this?\u201d\n\nFoles threw four touchdowns in his first start, against the Giants, but muddled through a tight win against Oakland and sputtered against Dallas in Week 17. Directing a simplified game plan last week, when the Eagles were the first top seed in N.F.L. history to be favored to lose its playoff game, Foles guided them over Atlanta.\n\nBut the Vikings?\n\n\u201cWhen people doubt you, you can feel it,\u201d Foles said after the game. \u201cWe\u2019re all human and I\u2019m keeping it real. When someone doubts you, you know. These guys that I play with knew that I would eventually just keep working at it. They know me as a person and they know me as a player, and we just kept working.\u201d\n\nAccording to N.F.L. research, the last five teams that won a playoff game on a touchdown in sudden-death or as time expired, as the Vikings did with Stefon Diggs\u2019s 61-yard catch against the Saints, lost their next game, by an average of 23 points. Minnesota, with a defense that ranked second against the run and pass and first in points allowed, seemed immune to such unraveling.\n\nBy the game\u2019s third drive, which ended with Robinson\u2019s interception, the Eagles had rendered Diggs\u2019s catch anticlimax. Long whacked the arm of Vikings quarterback Case Keenum, sending the pass fluttering toward Robinson, who knew at once that he would catch it.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t think it just pumped the offense,\u201d Foles said. \u201cI think it pumped up the whole city of Philadelphia. I think everyone down Broad Street heard that.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Eagles kept coming. Minnesota had dared Foles to beat them, but now the Eagles were daring the Vikings to stop him. Foles executed the run-pass option with precision, reading the Minnesota linebacker to either hand off or, more often, throw short passes \u2014 and usually complete them. In speaking about him last week, Offensive Coordinator Frank Reich cited Foles\u2019s pedigree as a coveted point-guard recruit before he chose to play football.\n\n\u201cHe can give you the no-look pass,\u201d Reich said. \u201cHe can be looking one way and hit a guy. He has that knack and feel.\u201d\n\nPhiladelphia pummeled the Vikings\u2019 units, one by one. The defense first, with a 75-yard drive, capped by LeGarrette Blount\u2019s 11-yard trucking of Eric Kendricks en route to the end zone. Then, with Minnesota in the red zone, a strip-sack of Keenum by the rookie Derek Barnett \u2014 taken with the first-round pick Philadelphia received for trading Sam Bradford to Minnesota \u2014 was recovered by Long. Keenum, harassed all night, committed all three turnovers.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re all just trying to get to the quarterback,\u201d Eagles defensive tackle Fletcher Cox said. \u201cCoach always says, \u2018Stop the run, go have fun.\u2019 We got a chance to do that and do a bunch of different things. We had a chance to go out and dominate.\u201d\n\nTheir defense did. Their offense did, too. The Eagles lost several players to season-ending injuries \u2014 a superb left tackle (Jason Peters), a middle linebacker (Jordan Hicks), a slippery running back (Darren Sproles), a special-teams ace (Chris Maragos) \u2014 but the rest of the team just kept playing. They kept playing and playing, winning and winning, and now look.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to the Super Bowl,\u201d Pederson said. \u201cWe\u2019re going to the stinking Super Bowl.\u201d", "title": "Eagles March Past Vikings to Super Bowl, Just as They Predicted", "authors": ["Ben Shpigel", "On Pro Football"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAcross the country and around the world, the hive mind of bettors and bookmakers has decided that the Patriots are 5\u00bd-point favorites over the Eagles in this year\u2019s Super Bowl.\n\nThat certainly seems reasonable, given that New England has a history of playoff success and the Eagles have been without their starting quarterback, Carson Wentz, since he was injured in Week 14.\n\nBut if you like the Eagles, here are some reasons to feel confident.\n\nThe Line Is Moving\n\nIn the immediate aftermath of the conference championship games, the Patriots were posted as 6-point favorites. But people began betting on the Eagles, and the line moved quickly to 5\u00bd. If you like the Eagles, you have the security that you are in a lot of company.\n\n\u201cI think it might come down a little bit more,\u201d perhaps to 5, said Jon Campbell, sports analyst at OddsShark, a sports gambling information site. That action on the Eagles is coming mostly from fans and casual bettors, he said. \u201cThe Super Bowl typically is a public game. It\u2019s a lot of recreational money.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAnd of course just because people bet one way, that doesn\u2019t mean they are right. They parked their cars on higher ground at Safeway and Walmart stores. They rushed up Pillar Mountain. Then, mercifully, the big waves never came, and within four hours, the authorities lifted the tsunami advisories that had once stretched from Alaska to the American border with Mexico.\n\n\u201cEverybody had to evacuate,\u201d Fran Latham, who runs a bed-and-breakfast in Yakutat, said of her town between Anchorage and Glacier Bay National Park. \u201cIt looked like everybody was at the school and the police department.\u201d\n\nThe overnight panic along the Pacific began after a magnitude 7.9 quake was reported at 12:31 a.m. local time in the Gulf of Alaska, according to the United States Geological Survey. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nThe shutdown ended, but Seth Meyers wasn\u2019t exactly rejoicing.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cPeople normally do not throw a bachelor party without a bachelor.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Justice Clarence Thomas, writing the majority opinion in a Supreme Court ruling that the police were entitled to arrest late-night partygoers at what some had claimed was a bachelor party.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\n\u201cRemember the Maine!\u201d was a rallying cry of the Spanish-American War. Many North Americans surely remember the Alamo. But has the U.S.S. Pueblo been forgotten?\n\nOn this day in 1968, the Pueblo, a Navy intelligence ship, was attacked and seized by North Korean patrol boats. Its 83 crew members were taken to Pyongyang and charged as spies, drawing a tense Cold War standoff.\n\nPhoto\n\nA Times editorial called the attack \u201chumiliating,\u201d and a prisoner drama \u2014 marked by fraught negotiations, forced confessions and propaganda ploys \u2014 dragged on for 11 months. Here\u2019s more about the Pueblo incident.\n\nThe Americans told of beatings, torture and deprivation, but they still found ways to get back at their captors. They slipped outrageous puns into self-written confessions, such as this one by the ship\u2019s commander, and surreptitiously raised their middle fingers in films and photographs. (The sailors said it was the Hawaiian good luck salute.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the end, Washington reluctantly apologized, and the Pueblo crew was home in time for Christmas. The Pueblo itself is still in Pyongyang, where it\u2019s a tourist attraction at the Victorious War Museum.\n\nCharles McDermid contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays at 6 a.m. Eastern and updated all morning.
