Check out our full range of free newsletters here.", "title": "Earthquake, Davos, Academy Awards: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 A tectonic drama on the Pacific Rim.\n\nMount Kusatsu-Shirane erupted in Japan, setting off avalanches, killing a soldier who was training nearby and injuring more than a dozen people, including several at a ski resort.\n\nThen a major earthquake struck off the coast of Alaska, prompting a tsunami warning that was soon called off, and hours later another strong temblor hit off the coast of Indonesia, rocking buildings in Jakarta.\n\nThe Mayon volcano, meanwhile, continued to billow ash in the Philippines, a day after officials raised the alert level for a hazardous eruption.", "title": "Earthquakes, Oscars, Narendra Modi: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Assange has managed to wear out his welcome over the years, alienating many of his previous supporters, including Edward J. Snowden, the former American intelligence contractor who leaked documents about surveillance programs.\n\nHe also offended potential supporters in the Democratic Party by allowing WikiLeaks to become the conduit for emails hacked by Russia from the Democratic National Committee and leaked to harm the presidential candidacy of Hillary Clinton.\n\nAmerican intelligence agencies have concluded that Russian hackers working for the Kremlin carried out the intrusions, but Mr. Assange insists he did not know the source of the emails, under the working rules of WikiLeaks. He has denied working for Russia or any other government.\n\nThe United States attorney general, Jeff Sessions, has said that arresting Mr. Assange is a priority. \u201cWe have professionals that have been in the security business of the United States for many years that are shocked by the number of leaks, and some of them are quite serious,\u201d he said last year.\n\nPhoto\n\nOn Thursday, Steve Goldstein, the under secretary of state for public diplomacy and public affairs, said that \u201cthe decision to grant Julian Assange citizenship is a decision between Julian Assange and Ecuador.\u201d He said the United States would \u201cnot discuss\u201d whether it wanted to arrest Mr. Assange.\n\nWhen Swedish prosecutors dropped their effort to have Mr. Assange extradited last year, they said it was not for reasons of guilt or innocence but because they saw no hope of compelling him to leave the embassy.\n\nThe British police say, however, say he is still subject to arrest on charges of jumping bail. And there is a strong possibility that the United States has issued a secret arrest and extradition warrant for Mr. Assange in connection with his assistance to Chelsea Manning, the Army private who was convicted of revealing state secrets.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nEcuador\u2019s announcement came after several days of speculation that the Ecuadorean government was ramping up efforts to find a solution for Mr. Assange. The country\u2019s foreign minister, Mar\u00eda Fernanda Espinosa, said on Tuesday that it was looking for a third-party mediator who could broker a deal to allow Mr. Assange to leave the embassy.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re considering, exploring the possibility of a mediation,\u201d Ms. Espinosa said, according to Reuters. \u201cNo solution can be reached without international cooperation and without cooperation from the United Kingdom, which in addition has shown interest in finding a solution.\u201d\n\nOn Wednesday, Mr. Assange posted the photograph of himself in the soccer jersey, and Reuters reported that his name had been recorded in a civil registry of Ecuadorean citizens.\n\nOn Thursday, Ms. Espinosa said that Mr. Assange had applied for citizenship on Sept. 16 and been granted it on Dec. 12. \u201cWhat naturalization does is provide the asylum seeker another layer of protection,\u201d she said. She said that Ecuador formally requested that Mr. Assange be given diplomatic status on Dec. 20 and that Britain rejected the request the following day.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Espinosa expressed irritation at recent news reports, saying she felt \u201cobliged to make statements about a matter\u201d that needed to \u201cbe managed with prudence and caution.\u201d She said the decision to grant citizenship to Mr. Assange had been made after careful consideration of Ecuador\u2019s obligations under its Constitution and under international law.\n\nMs. Espinosa also noted that the current government had inherited the problem from its predecessor. Rafael Correa, the president who decided to grant Mr. Assange asylum, was widely seen as wanting to burnish his credentials as a leftist leader who would not be cowed by the United States. But he found Mr. Assange to be a headache as well: In October 2016, Ecuador temporarily suspended Mr. Assange\u2019s internet access after WikiLeaks published documents from Mrs. Clinton\u2019s presidential campaign.\n\nMr. Correa left office in May after a decade as president. He was succeeded by Len\u00edn Moreno, who although an ally of Mr. Correa\u2019s has demonstrated little enthusiasm for Mr. Assange\u2019s cause. He has called Mr. Assange a hacker, and warned him not to meddle in politics.\n\nOn Thursday, Ms. Espinosa said Ecuador was exploring a variety of possible resolutions to the dispute. She mentioned \u201cdialogue with the United Kingdom\u201d and mediation by other states or international organizations that could \u201cfacilitate a just, lasting and dignified resolution for all the involved parties.\u201d\n\nShe said that Ecuador had \u201cthe best relations of friendship and cooperation\u201d with Britain.\n\nIn a separate statement, the ministry said Mr. Assange had \u201ccommitted to not intervening in affairs outside the scope of his asylum status,\u201d which seemed an oblique reference to his penchant for creating a stir.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGreg Barns, a lawyer who advises Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks, said in a telephone interview from New Zealand that the situation was \u201cintolerable\u201d for his client and for Ecuador.\n\nThe embassy is in the affluent Knightsbridge section of London, but he said Mr. Assange had been effectively \u201cimprisoned with no access to natural light and fresh air for a period of five and a half years.\u201d\n\nIn 2015, the London police ceased round-the-clock surveillance of the embassy, citing the cost, but warned that Mr. Assange would still be arrested if he left. In 2016, United Nations experts concluded that Mr. Assange had been arbitrarily detained in violation of international law. But Britain and Sweden argue that by choosing to jump bail and seek asylum in the Ecuadorean embassy, Mr. Assange has effectively imprisoned himself.\n\nMr. Barns suggested that the Australian government would be an obvious third-party mediator, given that Mr. Assange is a citizen of Australia, which has excellent relations with Britain.\n\nRicardo Pati\u00f1o, who was foreign minister of Ecuador under Mr. Correa and has described Mr. Assange as the victim of persecution, said he hoped that Britain would relent and allow a mediator \u2014 like a country or even a distinguished individual \u2014 to try to facilitate Mr. Assange\u2019s departure from the embassy.\n\nAnother former foreign minister, Jos\u00e9 Ayala-Lasso, who also has served as the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, said that diplomatic immunity would have been an elegant solution to the problem because it would have exempted Mr. Assange from facing punishment in Britain for bail jumping.\n\nBut since Britain has rejected that option, Mr. Ayala-Lasso said, it is difficult to see how mediation would work. \u201cThis is a conflict that is judicial-political in nature,\u201d he said, \u201cand Britain will not cede its position.\u201d\n\nJoaqu\u00edn Hern\u00e1ndez, an Ecuadorean scholar of international relations, said the problem was one of Ecuador\u2019s own making.\n\n\u201cEcuador never should have accepted Assange as a refugee because of his questionable reputation, but it was done anyway in search of international attention,\u201d he said in an interview.", "title": "Ecuador Gives Assange Citizenship, Worsening Standoff With Britain", "authors": ["Maggy Ayala", "Steven Erlanger"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Edgar Ray Killen, the former Klansman who was sentenced to a 60-year prison term in 2005 for arranging the murders of three young civil rights workers outside Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964 during the Freedom Summer drive to register Southern black voters, died on Thursday night in prison in Parchman, Miss. He was 92.\n\nThe Mississippi corrections department said he was pronounced dead at the hospital at the Mississippi State Penitentiary at 9 p.m. No cause was given, but the department said he had been treated for congestive heart failure and hypertension.\n\nMr. Killen was convicted of state manslaughter charges 41 years to the day after James Earl Chaney, 21, a black man from Meridian, Miss., and two white New Yorkers, Andrew Goodman, 20, and Michael Schwerner, 24, disappeared in a death trap set by a local deputy sheriff and a gang of his fellow Ku Klux Klansmen.\n\nHe was prosecuted in one of the South\u2019s major \u201catonement\u201d trials, in which the Mississippi authorities revisited civil rights-era atrocities. He was convicted of a crime that galvanized the civil rights movement, stamped the town of Philadelphia as an outpost of terror and inspired the 1988 Hollywood movie \u201cMississippi Burning,\u201d directed by Alan Parker.", "title": "Edgar Ray Killen, Convicted in \u201964 Killings of Rights Workers, Dies at 92", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "The Big City column in the Metropolitan section about a New York State prison program limiting prisoner purchases to six venders contains outdated information. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo canceled the program shortly after the Metropolitan section went to press. The online version of the column has been updated to reflect the change.\n\nCorrections: January 14, 2018\n\nARTS & LEISURE\n\nA picture caption with an article last Sunday about a Harlem dance pioneer being celebrated in a new exhibition misidentified the subject of the show. He is Arthur Mitchell, not Arthur Miller.\n\nBOOK REVIEW\n\nA Children\u2019s Books essay last Sunday about \u201cmalt shop novels,\u201d stories about teenage heroines\u2019 romances that were published between the 1940s and the mid-1960s, misstated the given name of a woman who read thenovels as a teenager and again as an adult. She is Jennifer Travis, not Janet.\n\nMAGAZINE\n\nAn article on Dec. 24 about Jordan Peele described incorrectly \u201cThe Secret of NIMH.\u201d It is an animated feature film, not a TV special.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022\n\nAn article on Dec. 24 about competition dance described incorrectly the relationship between the dancer Angel DiMartino Palladino and Dina Crupi, a dance-studio owner and teacher. While Crupi has seen Palladino perform at competitions, she was not Palladino\u2019s teacher.", "title": "Editors\u2019 Note: January 14, 2018", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-25 00:00:00", "text": "Last week, in an abrupt and unannounced move, the department began publishing a database of all pending civil rights cases. According to the database, which is to be updated monthly, the department is investigating 773 sexual harassment cases and 480 sexual violence cases.\n\nThe Obama-era guidance, issued in 2011 and 2014, reinforced the obligation of colleges and universities to respond to sexual assault claims and was widely hailed as strengthening protections for accusers amid increasing evidence that those institutions were skirting their responsibilities to investigate sexual misconduct. But it was widely assailed by men\u2019s rights and conservative civil liberties groups as heavily biased against the accused.\n\nIn an extensive policy speech announcing the new guidance, Ms. DeVos outlined what she described as a \u201cfailed system\u201d that violated students\u2019 due process rights and lacked public confidence.\n\n\u201cSchools must continue to confront these horrific crimes and behaviors head-on,\u201d Ms. DeVos said in September. \u201cBut the process must also be fair and impartial, giving everyone more confidence in its outcomes.\u201d\n\nMs. DeVos issued interim guidance that raised the standard of proof for accusers to \u201cclear and convincing evidence\u201d from a \u201cpreponderance of evidence\u201d and allowed cases to be settled in mediation sessions between the accuser and the accused. It also dropped time frames for completing investigations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThe new policy discriminates against women and girls and makes it harder for them to learn in a safe environment,\u201d said Fatima Goss Graves, the president of the National Women\u2019s Law Center, which is representing the litigants in the suit.\n\nThe plaintiffs in the suit, Equal Rights Advocates, SurvJustice and the Victim Rights Law Center, all advise or represent people who say they were sexually assaulted. The groups are being represented by Equal Rights Advocates, Democracy Forward Foundation, the National Center for Youth Law and the National Women\u2019s Law Center.\n\nIn the complaint, SurvJustice said that the group had not only seen \u201ca decrease in the number of sexual violence survivors seeking its services,\u201d but also observed a trend in educational institutions not responding at all, or not responding as promptly to its clients\u2019 complaints.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe group also wrote of \u201cstudents who have questioned whether they should continue with their plans to report sexual violence given the uncertainty regarding their legal protections and an anticipated lowered likelihood of success created by the policy change.\u201d\n\nThe Victims Rights Law Center, which focuses its efforts on rape and sexual assault, said Ms. DeVos\u2019s guidance was \u201cdevastating\u201d to its mission and operational activities.\n\nThe groups are asking that the guidance be rescinded as unlawful.\n\n\u201cWith each day that passes, this discriminatory policy will continue to cause harm to survivors of sexual harassment and violence,\u201d said Alice Y. Abrokwa, a lawyer at the National Center for Youth Law.\n\nIn their complaint, the groups wrote that Ms. DeVos and her acting leader of civil rights, Candice Jackson, made statements that revealed their bias against accusers.\n\nThey cited Ms. DeVos\u2019s policy address during which she asserted that \u201cif everything is harassment, then nothing is,\u201d and Ms. Jackson\u2019s dismissal of women who accused President Trump of sexual harassment as \u201cfake victims.\u201d", "title": "Education Secretary Betsy DeVos Is Sued Over Sexual Assault Guidance", "authors": ["Erica L. Green"]} {"date": "2018-01-15 00:00:00", "text": "Edwin Hawkins, a Grammy Award-winning singer who merged gospel and secular sounds in a career highlighted by the accidental crossover hit \u201cOh Happy Day\u201d in 1969, died on Monday in Pleasanton, Calif., east of San Francisco. He was 74.\n\nThe cause was pancreatic cancer, said his publicist, Bill Carpenter.\n\nMr. Hawkins, part of a musical family, was studying interior design at Laney College in Oakland, Calif., in the late 1960s and working with a group he and his friend Betty Watson had put together, the Northern California State Youth Choir. The group recorded an album, \u201cLet Us Go Into the House of the Lord,\u201d which they intended to sell locally to raise money for a trip to Southern California for a gospel competition.\n\n\u201cIt was recorded on a friend\u2019s little two-track machine,\u201d Mr. Hawkins told The Modesto Bee in 2008. \u201cIt was never intended for commercial purposes at all.\u201d", "title": "Edwin Hawkins, Known for the Hit \u2018Oh Happy Day,\u2019 Is Dead at 74", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "The Times quoted leaked audio recordings of an intelligence officer, Capt. Ashraf al-Kholi, coaching several talk-show hosts, as well as a prominent actress, about how to persuade their audiences to accept the American position on Jerusalem.\n\nIn an interview, one of the hosts, Azmi Megahed, confirmed the authenticity of the recording, and described the intelligence officer as a longtime acquaintance.\n\nAfter the article was published, Egypt\u2019s State Information Service said in a statement that no one named Ashraf al-Kholi worked for the intelligence service and denied the accuracy of the Times report.\n\nMr. Megahed then retracted his original statement, and in an Egyptian television interview said The Times had misquoted him. \u201cThis is the first time I\u2019ve heard of this Kholi man,\u201d he said.\n\nThe same audio recordings provided to The Times were later broadcast by an Istanbul-based television network linked to the Muslim Brotherhood, which Egypt has banned as a terrorist group. The suggestion of a connection with the Brotherhood added to the outrage from supporters of the Egyptian government.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe speaker of Parliament, Ali Abdel Aal, said the article proved that The Times was allied with the Brotherhood and with Qatar, which has supported the Brotherhood, and was stoking controversy in advance of presidential elections, state media reported.\n\nThe State Information Service, which also called the Times report \u201cinappropriate,\u201d said that Egypt had repeatedly declared its \u201cinalienable position on Jerusalem.\u201d Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry told reporters, \u201cEgypt does not speak with two faces.\u201d\n\nIn addition, a lawyer in Alexandria lodged a criminal complaint against The Times. Pro-government television anchors called on The Times to explain how the recordings ended up with the Brotherhood-affiliated channel, and suggested that the newspaper was secretly allied with Qatar. Egypt is one of four Arab nations that imposed a punishing boycott on Qatar last June, accusing it of financing Islamist terrorism and sheltering Brotherhood leaders.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur story was a deeply reported, consequential piece of journalism, and we stand fully behind it,\u201d said Michael Slackman, The Times\u2019s international editor. \u201cWe disclosed in the original report that the audio recordings were provided to The Times by an intermediary supportive of the Palestinian cause, but we had no agenda other than giving our readers the facts they needed to know.\u201d\n\nEgypt, which fought three wars against Israel, has positioned itself for decades as a champion of the Palestinian cause, which remains an emotional cause for most Arabs. But in recent years, critics have often accused Egypt of tacitly aligning itself with Israel, a charge that the government of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has denied.\n\nThe article comes at a delicate time for Egypt politically. The government said Monday that the first round of presidential elections would take place on March 26, with a result due on May 1. Mr. Sisi, who is expected to run for re-election, faces little opposition since his principal challenger, former Prime Minister Ahmed Shafik, pulled out of the race.\n\n\u201cI saw that I will not be the ideal person to lead the state during the coming period,\u201d Mr. Shafik said on Twitter.\n\nMr. Shafik\u2019s lawyers said that officials had pressed him to quit the race, threatening him with corruption prosecutions.", "title": "Egypt Opens Criminal Inquiry Over New York Times Article", "authors": ["Declan Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Sadat and other former candidates accused government officials of seeking to scupper their campaigns through intimidation and harassment. Printers and even hotels had refused to provide services on orders from government officials, they said.\n\nThe last significant challenger remaining in the race, the leftist lawyer Khaled Ali, will be disqualified if he fails to overturn a criminal conviction for public indecency on March 7. The prosecution followed a criminal complaint by a prominent supporter of Mr. Sisi.\n\nMr. Anan\u2019s campaign lasted just four days. In announcing his candidacy on Saturday, he lashed out at Mr. Sisi\u2019s record and pledged to appoint Hisham Geneina, a onetime anticorruption czar fired by Mr. Sisi, as vice president for human rights.\n\nThe choice appeared calculated to hit Mr. Sisi on some of his most sensitive points: his government\u2019s notoriously weak human rights record, and the prosecution of Mr. Geneina, who was dismissed in 2016 as Egypt\u2019s top auditor after he estimated that the country had lost $76 billion through corruption.\n\nMr. Geneina was later convicted of spreading false news and given a one-year suspended prison sentence. He is appealing the verdict, his lawyer said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThey want to get rid of the competition,\u201d said Mr. Anan\u2019s son, Samir. \u201cThere is no other way to look at this.\u201d\n\nMr. Anan\u2019s candidacy coincided with a moment of unusual flux in the top ranks of Egypt\u2019s security services. Last week, Mr. Sisi unexpectedly fired his spy chief, who had been considered a close ally. Three months earlier, Mr. Sisi dismissed his army chief in similarly unexplained circumstances.\n\nMr. Sisi officially announced his intention to run for a second term on Friday, but the series of abrupt changes stoked questions about whether Mr. Anan\u2019s bid had been receiving quiet support in rival corners of the military.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve heard that he consulted with some other retired officers but not with active-duty leaders,\u201d said Michael Wahid Hanna, an analyst with the Century Foundation. But, he added, the prosecution of Mr. Anan showed that Mr. Sisi still enjoyed unchallenged control over the military.\n\n\u201cWe know that there are divisions and rivalries,\u201d Mr. Hanna said. \u201cBut in terms of outward-facing decisions, Sisi and the regime still exert top-level control.\u201d\n\nThe first round of voting is scheduled for March 26-28, with a second round possible in late April if no candidate wins a majority of votes. About 20 candidates are running against Mr. Sisi.\n\nThe Egyptian leader got a boost from Vice President Mike Pence, who arrived in Cairo on Saturday.\n\n\u201cThe collaboration between the United States and Egypt has never been stronger,\u201d Mr. Pence later told reporters, adding that the two leaders had discussed a variety of topics, including religious freedom, the faltering Israeli-Palestinian peace process and the status of two American citizens imprisoned in Egypt.\n\nMr. Sisi is pushing ahead with his campaign. On Tuesday, state media published a photograph of the president having his eyesight tested as part of the medical examination that is required for all candidates.\n\nLater on Tuesday, military officers barged into Mr. Anan\u2019s villa, where they searched the premises and confiscated documents, his campaign partner, Mr. Geneina, said.", "title": "Egypt\u2019s Military Detains an Ex-General Seeking to Run for President", "authors": ["Declan Walsh"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "Two other candidates who have entered the race are currently facing charges that many believe are politically motivated. If they are convicted, they will be ineligible to run.\n\nSince returning to Cairo from the United Arab Emirates a few weeks ago, Mr. Shafik has spent most of his time in a suite at a luxury hotel in Cairo, declining to give interviews while Egyptian politicians and ordinary people wondered whether he was under arrest. His relatives and aides said that he was not allowed to speak to anyone nor go anywhere without the permission of Egypt\u2019s security agencies.\n\nEven though he prospered in the era of Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted from power in 2011 by a popular uprising, Mr. Shafik has a large base of supporters in Egypt. His military record, and name recognition, may have made him a strong candidate.\n\nHe fought in Egypt\u2019s two wars with Israel, in 1967 and 1973, and rose to command the Air Force. As minister of civil aviation, a post he held for a decade beginning in 2001, he oversaw the modernization and development of the national airline and the Cairo airport.\n\nIn a bid to bolster his support during his last days in power in 2011, Mr. Mubarak promoted Mr. Shafik to prime minister in the hope that he could resolve the crisis brought about by a popular uprising.\n\nMr. Shafik lost the presidential election to Mr. Morsi the next year by only about 2 percent of the vote.\n\nTo some of his supporters, Mr. Shafik was seen as a candidate who could have helped restore the stability they enjoyed before the Arab Spring erupted.\n\nThe Egyptian government has been overseeing a harsh crackdown on opponents since 2013. Hundreds have been killed in street protests and thousands jailed. Militant attacks, many by the Islamic State, have multiplied since, dealing multiple blows to the country\u2019s economy.", "title": "Egypt\u2019s Presidential Race Loses Popular Candidate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Egyptian officials disputed the report, which created an uproar in Parliament, with some legislators saying it was part of an international conspiracy to embarrass Egypt. At least one person on the leaked tapes has been interviewed by prosecutors.\n\nA furor has also erupted over the $4.8 billion Ethiopian dam, which is due to be completed next year. Egyptian experts fear it will greatly curtail their share of the river water as the dammed area is filled, which experts say could take from three to 12 years.\n\nMr. Sisi emerged grim-faced from a meeting in Cairo on Thursday with the prime minister of Ethiopia, Hailemariam Desalegn, at which they failed to resolve a dispute over the dam\u2019s impact. At a joint news conference, Mr. Sisi spoke of \u201cextreme concern\u201d at the lack of progress.\n\nA dispute over Egypt\u2019s share of the Nile waters and controversy over his position on Jerusalem are headaches Mr. Sisi could do without. And whatever the reason for Mr. Fawzy\u2019s defenestration, it underscores how Egypt\u2019s leader is willing to drop his closest allies if he deems it in his best interest.\n\nMr. Sisi\u2019s firing of his defense chief, Gen. Mahmoud Hegazy, in October was greeted with surprise, not least because the two men are linked through marriage. One of Mr. Sisi\u2019s sons is married to General Hegazy\u2019s daughter.\n\nThat dismissal, like Mr. Fawzy\u2019s on Thursday, was sudden, unexpected and unexplained. Both also followed episodes embarrassing to Mr. Sisi\u2019s government \u2014 in the case of General Hegazy, a militant ambush of security forces that killed at least 16 people.\n\nThanks in part to Mr. Fawzy\u2019s efforts to claw back influence, the General Intelligence Service had become an important channel in relations between the United States and Egypt in recent years. Jos\u00e9 Luis Men\u00e9ndez.\n\nThe bride, 30, is a litigation associate in the Washington, D.C. office of Debevoise & Plimpton, a law firm based in New York.. She graduated magna cum laude from Yale, from which she also received a law degree.\n\nShe is a daughter of Alicia M. Castilla and Mark E. Zelek of Coral Gables, Fla. His father is a civil engineer at Sidney B. Bowne & Son, an engineering consultancy in Mineola, N.Y.\n\nThe couple met in December 2014 through a mutual friend in New York.", "title": "Eileen Zelek, Brian Geiger", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The impact of migrants is felt throughout society, especially in the economy, which is heavily dependent on the diaspora. In 2016, El Salvador received $4.6 billion from abroad, mostly from the United States.\n\n\u201cThere are fathers who went up and left their children behind, and send back money for their education,\u201d said Luis Alberto L\u00f3pez, 37, director of Cofamide, or the Salvadoran Committee of Relatives of Killed or Disappeared Migrants, a nonprofit that works with Salvadorans whose relatives have vanished while trying to reach the United States.\n\nThe influx of returning Salvadorans would saturate an already dismal job market. But there is danger, too, for those returning.\n\n\u201cPeople think, \u2018Anyone who comes back from the U.S. has money,\u2019 so they\u2019ll be extorted,\u201d Mr. L\u00f3pez said. \u201cIf they try to start a small business,\u201d they will be asked for additional extortion payments.\n\nHe added: \u201cThe children who return will suffer cultural shock. Their parents can try to tell them what it will be like here, but it\u2019s one thing to hear about it, and another to actually live it. And even their parents will feel like strangers.\u201d\n\nMr. L\u00f3pez lost a brother who was kidnapped and vanished while trying to reach the United States in 2001. He fears that Salvadorans who return \u201cwill find it so hard here that they\u2019ll try to get back to the U.S.,\u201d and will meet the same fate.", "title": "El Salvador Again Feels the Hand of Washington Shaping Its Fate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "(Want to get this briefing by email? Here\u2019s the sign-up.)\n\nGood morning.\n\nHere\u2019s what you need to know:\n\nU.S. tells Salvadorans to go\n\n\u2022 The Trump administration is ending protections for nearly 200,000 people from El Salvador who have been allowed to live and work in the U.S. since a pair of earthquakes struck their country in 2001.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security said that because El Salvador\u2019s infrastructure had been rebuilt, the Salvadorans no longer qualified for the Temporary Protected Status program.\n\nTens of thousands of Haitians and Nicaraguans have also lost their protected status.\n\n\u2022 The immigrants face deportation by next year, at which point the U.S. could lose up to a million people, including so-called Dreamers, from its legal work force. We examine the choices before the nation\u2019s employers.", "title": "El Salvador, Oprah Winfrey, Alabama Crimson Tide: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "1. Nearly 200,000 people from El Salvador will have to leave the United States after living here for more than a decade, the Trump administration announced on Monday. Homeland Security officials said they were ending a humanitarian program that allowed the Salvadorans to live and work in the U.S. after a pair of earthquakes hit El Salvador in 2001.\n\nIt represents one of the administration\u2019s most consequential immigration policy reversals to date.\n\n\u201cWe had hope that if we worked hard, paid our taxes and didn\u2019t get in trouble we would be allowed to stay,\u201d said one Salvadoran with two children born in the U.S.", "title": "El Salvador, Oprah Winfrey, Stephen K. Bannon: Your Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "In theory, the problem shouldn\u2019t be difficult for Congress to fix. One approach would be to lift the 200,000 vehicle cap and continue the credit indefinitely, a move that would most likely be welcomed by makers and consumers of electric vehicles and has the support of green energy lobbying groups. But the price tag for the government could become prohibitive if electric car sales surge.\n\nOr Congress could phase out the incentives beginning at a target date that would apply to all manufacturers, or after total industry sales hit a level that suggests a move to electric vehicles is sustainable. Depending on the time or level of sales chosen, that could address concerns about the impact of the tax credit on the deficit.\n\nTesla and G.M. have not proposed a specific fix.\n\nMany countries have far more robust subsidies for electric cars than the United States, including most of Europe. Norway has by far the highest percentage of electric car ownership in the world (about one-third of the vehicles sold there last year were electric or hybrid), along with the most lavish subsidies, which include sharply reduced sales taxes as well as free parking and use of uncongested bus lanes. The country has set a goal of zero auto emissions by 2025.\n\nWhile no one expects the United States to go to such an extreme, revising the electric vehicle tax credit and bolstering other incentives for renewable energy could be a rare source of bipartisan agreement. When it comes to jobs, a top priority for both Congress and the Trump administration, the Department of Energy reported that in 2016, 3.38 million Americans were employed in the clean energy sector, 10 percent more than the 2.99 million employed in fossil fuels.\n\nHow the renewable energy subsidies managed to survive to be part of the tax law remains a subject of debate, but nearly every explanation points in part to Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa, the powerful Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee and a staunch supporter of renewable energy, especially wind. Iowa is a leader in wind power, which generates 36 percent of the state\u2019s electricity. The wind power industry employs 9,000 people in the state, according to the Iowa Wind Energy Association. (Senator Grassley did not respond to requests for comment.)\n\nTrying to tamper with the renewable energy subsidies and the electric vehicle credit, as the House version of the tax bill did, \u201cwas asking for trouble,\u201d said Dean Zerbe, former tax counsel for the Senate Finance Committee and a national managing director at Alliantgroup, which specializes in tax credits and incentives. \u201cCertain senators wouldn\u2019t budge on that.\u201d\n\nWith funding for the government scheduled to expire on Jan. 19, and with such a narrow Republican majority in the Senate, Republicans and Democrats in Congress have an incentive to find some common ground, which might include revising the electric vehicle credit.", "title": "Electric Vehicle Tax Credit Survives, but G.M. and Tesla Aren\u2019t Cheering", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The reclusive Italian author Elena Ferrante will join The Guardian as a weekly columnist, the newspaper announced Thursday.\n\nWriting for the London-based paper\u2019s Weekend magazine, Ms. Ferrante will \u201cshare her thoughts on a wide range of topics, including childhood, aging, gender and, in her debut article, first love,\u201d according to a news release. Her first column will appear on Saturday.\n\nMs. Ferrante is well known as the author of the so-called Neapolitan Novels, four best-selling books that trace the lifelong friendship of two women from Naples. But even as she has risen to international fame, she fiercely guards her privacy and writes under a pseudonym.\n\nThough Ms. Ferrante has had a long literary career, the arrangement is her first newspaper column. In a statement, she said she was \u201cattracted to the possibility of testing myself,\u201d calling the job \u201ca bold, anxious exercise in writing.\u201d", "title": "Elena Ferrante, Reclusive Novelist, Joins The Guardian as a Columnist", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "In a new study published this week, the same team, led by Lucy King, an Oxford University research associate, found that Asian elephants are also afraid of bees, though perhaps less so. It\u2019s the first step toward showing that the control strategy can also work in countries like Sri Lanka, India, Nepal and Thailand, where Asian elephants are 10 times more endangered than their African cousins.\n\n[READ: Hunt Elephants to Save Them? Some Countries See No Other Choice]\n\nThe Asian elephants behaved a little differently: They didn\u2019t shake their heads or shower themselves with dust, but they did make noises, shying away from the bees and touching one another\u2019s trunks or putting a trunk into another\u2019s mouth, perhaps as a sign of reassurance or comfort. The Asian elephants also sometimes slapped their trunks against the ground in fear.\n\nIt\u2019s not clear whether Asian elephants react differently to bees because the bees in Asia are less aggressive. Or maybe the elephants simply have different behavioral responses, the way people from one culture might laugh if they\u2019re nervous and those from another might fidget or talk fast, said John Poulsen, a tropical ecologist and assistant professor at Duke University, who has helped conduct similar elephant-bee research.\n\nIn Africa, Save the Elephants, a nonprofit conservationist group, builds wire and beehive fences at a cost of about $1,000 for a one-acre farm \u2014 roughly one-fifth the cost of an electrified fence, said Dr. King, who also heads the human-elephant coexistence program for the charity. The farm gets protection against elephants and a modest new source of income from a twice-a-year honey harvest.\n\nThe beehives have to be strung on a wire sturdy enough to hold them up, but not so sturdy that the hives can\u2019t sway in the breeze. Dr. King learned early on that a swinging hive causes the bees to flee, becoming more active and scaring the elephants.", "title": "Elephants Are Very Scared of Bees. That Could Save Their Lives.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-08 00:00:00", "text": "The fact that nearly everyone wore black to the 75th annual Golden Globe Awards hardly squelched the mood at the half-dozen parties that took place after the ceremony, scattered throughout the Beverly Hilton.\n\nFor the first time, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association hosted its own viewing and after-party, in the Hilton\u2019s garden room, where a fleet of engravers personalized the Golden Globe statues.\n\nEarly arrivals included Sam Rockwell and Elisabeth Moss, who ducked in to have their trophies customized. \u201cThere\u2019s a lot to celebrate,\u201d said a breathless Rachel Brosnahan, fresh off her win for \u201cThe Marvelous Mrs. Maisel. \u201cI was so moved by the all the women in black and the energy in the room.\u201d", "title": "Elisabeth Moss, Mariah Carey and Reese Witherspoon Party After the Golden Globes", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThere was a tennis boom, and then it was a bit quiet when they retired,\u201d he said. \u201cNow people are getting out of bed again to watch Elise play, so it\u2019s really nice.\u201d\n\nMertens and Ceyssens\u2019s first tournament together was the 2016 United States Open, where Mertens, then ranked 137th, won three matches in qualifying and then took a set off third-seeded Garbi\u00f1e Muguruza in a first-round loss.\n\nMertens intended to play the qualifying competition here last year. But she had entered a WTA tournament in Hobart, Australia, at the same time, and she needed to lose her second-round match against Sachia Vickery to be allowed to compete in Melbourne. After one game, Mertens called a medical timeout, but Vickery, who also had plans to play the qualifiers in Melbourne, beat her to it and retired from the match herself.\n\nMertens played on in Hobart and ultimately claimed her first WTA title there, launching her into the top 100 (Vickery lost in the first round of qualifying in Melbourne).\n\n\u201cIt was a little sad, because you want to compete at one of the biggest tournaments in the world,\u201d Mertens said of watching Melbourne from afar last year. \u201cBut it was also a good feeling, because not everybody wins a WTA title. It was mixed feelings but more happy feelings.\u201d\n\nMertens steadily climbed the rankings throughout last season, reaching a final in Istanbul; the semifinals in New Haven, Bastad and Luxembourg; and the third round of the French Open. She successfully defended her title in Hobart last week.\n\nHer draws in the last two Grand Slam events were daunting, putting her up against eventual finalists in the first round of both tournaments: Venus Williams at Wimbledon and Madison Keys at the United States Open.", "title": "Elise Mertens to Meet Caroline Wozniacki in Australian Open Semifinals", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA longtime Hollywood stuntman, Joel Kramer, was accused of sexual misconduct by three women over the weekend, including one who said he assaulted her when she was just 12.\n\nThat accusation came from the actress Eliza Dushku, now 37, who said on Saturday in a Facebook post that Mr. Kramer abused her during the filming of \u201cTrue Lies,\u201d the 1994 summer blockbuster.\n\nMr. Kramer, who was responsible for Ms. Dushku\u2019s safety on set, built up trust with her and her parents before taking her to his Miami hotel for what he said would be a swim in the pool followed by her first sushi meal, she said.\n\nHe took her to his room, where he drew the shades, turned down the lights, turned up the air-conditioning and went to the bathroom, she said. He returned naked, covering himself with only a hand towel, she said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI remember what I was wearing (my favorite white denim shorts, thankfully, secured enough for me to keep on). I remember how he laid me down on the bed, wrapped me with his gigantic writhing body, and rubbed all over me,\u201d she said. She said she remained motionless until he finished and told her they should keep quiet about what had happened. On the ride home, she said, he had her sit on his lap in the cab.", "title": "Eliza Dushku Says Stuntman Assaulted Her When She Was 12", "authors": ["Niraj Chokshi"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "KATHMANDU, Nepal \u2014 Elizabeth Ann Hawley, an American journalist who chronicled Mount Everest expeditions for more than 50 years and whose attention to detail and sharp sense of humor inspired fear and respect among climbers, died on Friday in Kathmandu, Nepal. She was 94.\n\nHer death was confirmed by Prativa Pandey, the medical director at CIWEC Hospital, where she was being treated for a stroke and pneumonia.\n\nOne of the founders of the Himalayan Database, a compilation of records for all climbing expeditions in the Himalayas in Nepal from 1905 to 2017, Ms. Hawley spent nearly her entire adult life in Kathmandu, Nepal\u2019s capital. She moved there in 1960 to work as a correspondent with Time Inc.\n\nThough she never scaled a mountain herself, Ms. Hawley endeared herself to many climbers. To maintain accuracy in her records, she grilled mountaineers before and after summit attempts, traveling to their hotels in her powder-blue Volkswagen Beetle to ask what they had seen at the top and to catch the occasional fibber. She conducted more than 15,000 interviews.", "title": "Elizabeth Hawley, Who Chronicled Everest Treks, Dies at 94", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "But Palestinians and Israeli supporters of a two-state solution said the moves revealed the true colors of the country\u2019s ascendant right wing.\n\n\u201cWe hope that this vote serves as a reminder for the international community that the Israeli government, with the full support of the U.S. administration, is not interested in a just and lasting peace,\u201d Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, said Monday, adding that he would respond by revisiting the authority\u2019s existing agreements with Israel. \u201cRather, its main goal is the consolidation of an apartheid regime in all of historic Palestine.\u201d\n\nDaniel Seidemann, director of Terrestrial Jerusalem, which focuses on the Holy City\u2019s fate in a potential two-state solution, said that \u201cwhat was winked and nodded about before is now being acknowledged publicly: \u2018We have no intent of sharing this land with anybody else except as a barely tolerated minority.\u2019\u201d\n\nMr. Netanyahu has publicly said that he supports a two-state solution even as his government has expanded settlements on the occupied West Bank. But Mr. Trump\u2019s support has tilted the scales, leading members of Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s government to conclude that Israel can take a stronger position without fear of forceful foreign intercession.\n\n\u201cThe map of external pressures has changed dramatically,\u201d said Menachem Klein, a political scientist at Bar-Ilan University. \u201cInstead of Obama, we have Trump. The European Union is divided, Brexit occupies the British agenda, Germany has coalition problems. There\u2019s no consensus in Europe, no single policy putting pressure on Israel. So this is a very easy arena in which we can go ahead.\u201d\n\nAt the same time, corruption investigations into Mr. Netanyahu and his advisers have weakened him politically and led to speculation that he could be indicted. That has spurred ambitious members of his party, and of his governing coalition, to behave as though 2018 were an election year, staking out positions intended to appeal to their base. The next parliamentary elections are not due until November 2019, but they could come sooner if the government were to fall.\n\n\u201cI don\u2019t discount that people are saying, \u2018Maybe we can get away with more now because nobody in the international community seems to care,\u2019\u201d said Shalom Lipner, an analyst at the Brookings Institution who was an aide to several prime ministers. \u201cBut the more impactful motivating factor seems to be politics. There\u2019s a certain amount of blood in the water right now, and everybody\u2019s smelling it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nArguably the most provocative, though least substantive, of the flurry of Israeli actions was a nonbinding but unanimous vote on Sunday by the central committee of Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s party, Likud, to support the \u201cfree construction and application of Israeli law and sovereignty in all liberated areas of settlement\u201d in the West Bank.\n\nIf such a measure became law, it would effectively annex Israeli settlements on land that the Palestinians demand for a future state and leave them with an archipelago of disconnected territory. The West Bank is now under military jurisdiction, though settlers are subject to civilian law, as Israeli citizens.\n\nMr. Netanyahu, who at the height of his political powers could have been expected to quash the vote, was not present for it. But most of the Likud ministers in his government endorsed the proposal, which was roughly equivalent to the adoption of a plank in a party platform. Party leaders acknowledged that Mr. Trump\u2019s hard-line support of Israel had created an urgency to seize the moment.\n\nPhoto\n\nEven as Likud met near Ben Gurion Airport, Israel\u2019s attorney general, Avichai Mandelblit, published a new formal instruction to all government offices on Sunday, as part of an agreement with the Justice Ministry, that any new legislation explicitly state how it should be applied on the West Bank, or else the responsible government agency must say why it should not apply there.\n\nJustice Minister Ayelet Shaked played down the instruction, telling Kan Radio that it would speed the application of Israeli law to areas where settlers live, which now sometimes takes years, she said, because it must first be adopted by the military commander, who lays down the laws of the occupation. \u201cWhat we did is an attempt to decrease the gap between Judea and Samaria and Israel,\u201d Ms. Shaked said.\n\nBut opponents of the occupation said the little-noticed bureaucratic move had great significance. \u201cThe Knesset cannot pass laws that are valid in Japan,\u201d said Hagit Ofran, an advocate at Peace Now, a leftist group that opposes settlements, referring to the Israeli Parliament. \u201cYou can only legislate in places that you have jurisdiction. And if they claim jurisdiction over occupied territories, it means they\u2019re annexed.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMr. Seidemann, of Terrestrial Jerusalem, said that measures applying Israeli law to Israelis living in the occupied territories would formally set up a democratic system for Israelis while leaving Palestinians subject to military rule.\n\n\u201cThat narrows the comfort zone between Israel and the a-word rather dramatically,\u201d he said, referring to apartheid.\n\nIf Mr. Trump\u2019s recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel spurred efforts to entrench the country\u2019s West Bank settlements, the Parliament\u2019s approval of a bill early Tuesday will make it far more difficult to cede parts of the Holy City to the Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe bill that was debated, an amendment to the basic law on Jerusalem \u2014 the closest thing in Israel to a constitutional amendment \u2014 contained two elements that supporters of a two-state solution called pernicious.\n\nOne, which passed around 3 a.m. after hours of protests by the opposition, raises the legislative bar to ceding any part of Jerusalem to a foreign entity. Until now, a peace deal that gave up any part of the city could have been ratified either with a supermajority in Parliament, or with a simple majority and a national referendum. Under the new law, it may be ratified only with a supermajority, or 80 of 120 votes.\n\n\u201cThis is the current right-wing ideological majority shackling the future,\u201d Mr. Seidemann said. The law itself, however, could be reversed, by a simple majority vote in Parliament.\n\nThe other effect, and the more significant one in the short term, would have cleared away potential legal obstacles to redrawing the municipal boundaries of Jerusalem. Some of Mr. Netanyahu\u2019s allies have sought this power to remove Palestinian neighborhoods from the city, enhancing the Jewish majority in municipal elections.\n\nProponents had in mind several fast-growing Palestinian neighborhoods, like Kufr Aqab and the Shuafat refugee camp, that are within the city limits but outside the security barrier that Israel built to prevent terrorist attacks. Largely denied city services because of concerns about the safety of municipal workers, those areas have become boomtowns of unregulated construction by Palestinians seeking affordable housing.\n\nThose neighborhoods now include perhaps as many as 100,000 Palestinians who can vote in city elections. A chief sponsor of the bill, Ze\u2019ev Elkin, the minister of Jerusalem affairs, told The Jerusalem Post recently, \u201cWe are facing a ticking demographic time bomb\u201d in those neighborhoods.\n\n\u201cWhat it actually means is the establishment of the first Bantustans of Israel,\u201d said Ms. Ofran of Peace Now. \u201cLike in South Africa \u2014 they said, \u2018They have their own townships, they run independently, run their own services,\u2019 while having actually zero resources to do that. We have Jerusalem, a poor city but with huge capacities, a huge budget, the national government\u2019s help, and now you\u2019re telling us that if you throw them away, they can do by themselves.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a lie,\u201d she added. \u201cIt\u2019s doing exactly what they had in the apartheid regime.\u201d\n\nIn a surprising twist, however, the leader of the right-wing Jewish Home party, Naftali Bennett, insisted that the municipal-boundaries language be dropped from the bill, saying that making changes to the city\u2019s borders was at odds with the idea of Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s \u201cundivided\u201d capital.\n\n\u201cPeople tried in the past to partition Jerusalem,\u201d Mr. Bennett said. \u201cIt is not within the authority of any Jew, of any Jewish body, or the entire Jewish people, to give up any part of the land.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAviv Tatarsky, a researcher for Ir Amim, a Jerusalem advocacy group that lobbied against the bill, welcomed Mr. Bennett\u2019s change of heart after waking up to learn of it. \u201cWe will send him flowers and say thank you,\u201d Mr. Tatarsky said.", "title": "Emboldened Israeli Right Presses Moves to Doom 2-State Solution", "authors": ["David M. Halbfinger"]} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "Emily Caroline Grossman and Michael James Diamond were married Jan. 27 by Rabbi M. Bruce Lustig at Capitale, an events space in New York.\n\nMrs. Diamond, 30, is a certified public accountant within the technical accounting consulting practice of RSM, an accounting firm in New York. She graduated from Emory University.\n\nShe is the daughter of Ellen C. Grossman and Dr. David R. Grossman of Ocean Township, N.J. The bride\u2019s father, an ophthalmologist, is a partner in Ocean Eye Institute, a group practice with five offices in Ocean County, N.J. Her mother is a trustee of the Jewish Family and Children\u2019s Service of Monmouth County in Asbury Park, N.J.\n\nMr. Diamond, 32, is a manager in the advertising platforms division of Google\u2019s New York office. He graduated magna cum laude from the University of Michigan. He is a member of the New York leadership council of Upwardly Global, a nonprofit organization in New York focusing on employment opportunities for skilled immigrants and refugees.", "title": "Emily Grossman, Michael Diamond", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "The Airbus A380 lives on, for now.\n\nThe Dubai-based airline Emirates threw a lifeline on Thursday to the A380, the world\u2019s largest passenger aircraft, putting in a $16 billion order for up to 36 of the planes to be delivered starting from 2020. The agreement, which includes a firm commitment to buy 20 aircraft and an option for 16 more, comes just days after Airbus said it would end production of the A380 if it did not receive more orders.\n\nWhen Airbus started delivering the A380 a decade ago, it pitched the plane as the future of aviation, offering a solution to airport congestion and to increased demand for international travel. The number of planes that can land at an airport on a given day is limited, the European company argued, so the A380, with the capacity to carry more than 500 passengers, would allow airlines to transport more passengers.\n\nBut the bet on the four-engine plane turned out to be a financial disaster for Airbus as the industry increasingly used smaller airports, a shift that favored its main competitor, Boeing, and other manufacturers of midsize aircraft.\n\nAirbus did not book any orders for the A380 last year; in fact, orders for two planes were canceled. The poor performance for the aircraft overshadowed an otherwise decent year for the company. On Monday, John Leahy, Airbus\u2019s chief operating officer, said that if the company was unable to agree on a deal with Emirates, the superjumbo\u2019s days might be numbered.", "title": "Emirates Offers A380 a Lifeline, Signing $16 Billion Deal With Airbus", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "According to Nielsen\u2019s, the final episode of \u201cM*A*S*H,\u201d in 1983, had the highest rating of any fictional show in U.S. history, 125 million. But few shows can rival the positive response that the \u201cI Love Lucy\u201d birth episode, and the arrival of Ms. Ball\u2019s second child, elicited.\n\n\u201cOne million viewers responded with congratulatory telephone calls, telegrams, letters or gifts,\u201d The Times noted in Ms. Ball\u2019s obituary in 1989.\n\nAnna Schaverien contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nThis briefing was prepared for the European morning and is updated online.
