Contact us at europebriefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Emmanuel Macron, Donald Trump, Pope Francis: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-21 00:00:00", "text": "Sept. 16, 2017, had the potential to be an awful day on the National Mall in Washington. It started with a rally, organized by a group of Trump supporters, called the Mother of All Rallies Patriot Unification Gathering. Counterprotesters from a group called Black Lives Matter of Greater New York began shouting at the crowd. The event\u2019s organizers shouted back, and the two sides began moving toward each other. As the situation became more combustible, onlookers recorded the scene on their phones.\n\nSuddenly, however, the confrontation took an unexpected turn. Tommy Gunn, the organizer of the pro-Trump rally, invited Hawk Newsome, the head of the Black Lives Matter group and the leader of the counterdemonstration, onto the stage. \u201cWe\u2019re going to give you two minutes of our platform to put your message out,\u201d Mr. Gunn said. \u201cWhether they disagree or agree with your message is irrelevant. It\u2019s the fact that you have the right to have the message.\u201d\n\nMr. Newsome accepted the invitation and addressed the hostile crowd with evident sincerity. \u201cI am an American,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd the beauty of America is that when you see something broke in your country, you can mobilize to fix it.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Empathize With Your Political Foe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "Before they left, the researchers tagged four birds with satellite tags and \u201cwater switches\u201d that allowed them to track how far the animals traveled and how often they entered the sea. The data confirmed that the penguins continued to take moonlight swims throughout the breeding season. The researchers believe the males ceased their hunting activity once the females laid their eggs.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe findings, published in the Journal of Experimental Biology, suggest that previous research on emperor penguins was focused on too small a population to be taken as representative for the entire species, Dr. Kooyman said.\n\nMore Reporting on Penguins\n\n\u201cAlmost all the studies about winter breeding have been conducted from the research station Dumont D\u2019Urville, which is about 100 meters away from a colony,\u201d he said. That colony, which was prominently featured in \u201cMarch of the Penguins,\u201d is also 100 kilometers from the ice edge, making it impossible for penguins that breed there to take breaks for fishing.\n\nThe colony that Dr. Kooyman observed was farther south than Dumont D\u2019Urville, and was located only about 10 kilometers from the ice edge. Thus the authors suggest that the length of a fast depends largely on the breeding colony\u2019s proximity to water. The male emperor penguins in Cape Washington probably fast for about 65 days, they estimated.\n\nAdditionally, the discovery that penguins \u2014 who are believed to be visual hunters \u2014 can successfully hunt in the dark may be good news for a species that is contending with loss of habitat because of a warming planet. Researchers have expressed concern that the loss of stable ice in Antarctica could make it difficult for the animal to perform their breeding ritual.\n\n\u201cIf there\u2019s global warming, the bird has the resilience to go south, where they will continue to have stable sea ice for breeding that they would not have in the northern colonies,\u201d said Dr. Kooyman.\n\nAs for why the researchers waited 20 years to publish their findings, Dr. Kooyman said he had hoped to return to Cape Washington to conduct a more detailed study.\n\n\u201cI think that emphasizes the difficulty of observing what we did,\u201d he said. \u201cBut after 20 years I said, \u2018Well, I think it\u2019s time to write something about it.\u2019\u201d", "title": "Emperor Penguins: Good Dads, but Less Dedicated Than You May Have Thought", "authors": ["Douglas Quenqua"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Keeth, then 11, and his younger sister, Erinn, 10, were the first students to enroll in the Peter Westbrook Foundation on the Upper West Side. \u201cAt the time, my world was all within a two-mile radius in Brooklyn,\u201d said Mr. Smart, speaking from his temporary Chelsea Piers office on Atlantic Avenue near the construction site. \u201cFencing opened up that world into Manhattan.\u201d\n\nHe and his sister attended a junior high school in Park Slope and eventually Brooklyn Tech, and after school they would take the subway to the fencing club, do their homework from 4 to 6 and then train from 6 to 10 p.m. They also worked with a personal trainer some days at Chelsea Piers, which opened in 1995.\n\n\u201cAfter that, everything else was very easy,\u201d Mr. Smart said. He went to St. John\u2019s University on a fencing scholarship, while working toward the Olympics. \u201cMy parents always wanted us to balance education and fencing,\u201d he said. When he and Erinn were invited to move to Colorado Springs to the Olympic training center, the Smarts declined.\n\nIn the summer of 2008, his sister won the silver medal in Beijing, and a day later Mr. Smart won his. \u201cThe pressure was on,\u201d he said, laughing.\n\nAfter getting his M.B.A. at Columbia, he was recruited by Bank of America, where he worked in wealth management for five years. \u201cBut it was pretty dry,\u201d he said. \u201cI didn\u2019t like it.\u201d\n\nHe worked with a fitness technology start-up for a couple of years, but then saw the listing for the Chelsea Piers general manager position on LinkedIn.\n\nSam Bernstein, chief operating officer of Chelsea Piers Fitness, and whose father, Tom, is one of the founders of the original Chelsea Piers, was just getting the Brooklyn project off the ground this past autumn when he saw Mr. Smart\u2019s resume, which stood out from the others \u2014 being an Olympic medalist will do that. Mr. Bernstein, 26, was an athlete himself (he had been captain of the Yale golf team and had played on the pro tour), and he set up an interview with Mr. Smart.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Smart clicked with both Bernsteins and with the Chelsea Piers co-founder and principal investor David Tewksbury, 56, who once played hockey for Yale and regularly plays at the Chelsea Piers Sky Rink.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI still am an athlete,\u201d said Mr. Tewksbury. \u201cJust a heavier, slower one.\u201d\n\nThe golf-playing Mr. Bernstein, along with Mr. Tewksbury and Mr. Smart, are now a three-man team trying to expand the Chelsea Piers name. \u201cYou have three elite athletes from three different generations, from three different sports, coming together on this to drive it,\u201d said Tom Bernstein, 65.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn much the way Chelsea Piers has become a social as well as an athletic destination for people over the past 22 years, Tom Bernstein hopes the new gym will be more than just a place to work out.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ll hopefully take that culture to Brooklyn,\u201d he said.\n\nThe gym will occupy the ground and basement levels of a new residential building at 33 Bond Street in Downtown Brooklyn. Gym construction began two months ago and should be completed by May. The facilities include a 25-yard, three-lane pool, yoga studios, Pilates, weights, cycling, cardio and large spaces for functional training. Work tables, lounges and a cafe will provide social and creative spaces as well, which will include readings, live music, a gallery, member socials and other cultural events. Babysitting will also be offered. Alas, there will be no ice rink, no driving range and no fencing studio.\n\nFounding memberships for the Downtown Brooklyn club will cost $150 per month, but access to both the Brooklyn and Manhattan facilities is available for $225. (Chelsea Piers also has an enormous complex in Stamford, CT.)\n\nChelsea Piers in Manhattan \u2014 including the health club, the field house and Sky Rink \u2014 employs around 1,000 people. Mr. Bernstein, along with Mr. Smart, is now hiring between 50 and 75 new employees for the Brooklyn venture.\n\n\u201cThis might be our first foray into Brooklyn, which will open some doors and lead to some other things,\u201d said Tom Bernstein. \u201cConsider this the beachhead for Brooklyn.\u201d\n\nMr. Tewksbury agreed. \u201cIf we could find a larger space in Brooklyn that could take the field house, that would be the logical next unit to bring to Brooklyn. And we\u2019re open to that.\u201d\n\nMr. Smart says it\u2019s sometimes astounding how much Brooklyn has changed since his days as a public school student here. \u201cI really witnessed this area of Brooklyn transform over the years,\u201d he said. \u201cI love it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to his new work duties, Mr. Smart finds time to volunteer at his old fencing school to help with fund-raising. He also fences occasionally at the clubs his teammates have opened since their Olympic glory days. He is currently working with fencers hoping to qualify for the 2020 team, acting not only as a trainer but also as a guide for what to expect when the Olympic Games end. \u201cI come to the club and show them other paths available,\u201d he said.\n\nAfter a couple of days of fencing, though, his body doesn\u2019t bounce back the way it once did. His wrist \u2014 fractured three times in his career \u2014 often hurts, and he suffers from tendinitis in his ankles and knees.\n\n\u201cWaking up sore every day is not fun,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I do miss traveling and competing. I don\u2019t miss the training, though, six days a week.\u201d\n\nFor Mr. Smart, the new gym will provide not just a new office closer to home, but a new workout space for him and his friends in his neighborhood, who don\u2019t have many options to choose from. From his home in Ditmas Park, his commute is only a few stops on the train, but once the weather warms a bit, he\u2019ll be riding his bike.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an easy coast downhill,\u201d he said, smiling. \u201cThough getting back home is a little tougher.\u201d", "title": "En Garde! Chelsea Piers Heads to Brooklyn", "authors": ["Helene Stapinski"]} {"date": "2018-01-23 00:00:00", "text": "RONALD HIRSCH\n\nKENNEBUNKPORT, ME.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cShutdown Ends, Setting Up Clash Over \u2018Dreamers\u2019 \u201d (front page, Jan. 23):\n\nThe debate over the government shutdown revolved around the question of which party would sustain the most political damage, and no one doubted that there would be plenty to share. In that political calculus the players who were not represented at that table were the people who elected these politicians to be their voices in government.\n\nDoes anyone really believe that a shutdown is an acceptable way to handle disagreements? The mud did fly, and, as always, it landed on all of us.\n\nASHLEY HOLLISTER, HARTFORD, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe liberal media characterizes President Trump as bumbling and incompetent. On the contrary, I believe he knows exactly what he is doing. He is a con artist, an extraordinarily talented one. His latest victim is Chuck Schumer. Based on Mr. Trump\u2019s proclaimed sympathy for the Dreamers, and several meetings with the president, Mr. Schumer set up a confrontation with Congress, believing he had Mr. Trump covering his back. He set up expectations among liberals that he would do whatever is necessary to secure a deal for the Dreamers.\n\nThen, when there was no graceful way out for Mr. Schumer, Mr. Trump snatched the football away. Gotcha! Humiliated, Mr. Schumer had little choice but to tuck his tail between his legs and back down, using a meaningless promise from Mitch McConnell, another con artist, for cover that is as transparent as plastic wrap.\n\nROBERT MADDEN, TARRYTOWN, N.Y.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nLots of talk from folks on both the left and right that Chuck Schumer \u201cblinked\u201d in the showdown. I look at it differently. Senate Democrats dug themselves into a hole by opting on Friday to vote against a continuing resolution to keep the government operating. I like to think that the Senate Democrats who voted to reopen the government chose to stop digging.", "title": "Opinion | Ending the Shutdown: A Sellout or a Smart Move?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "BRUNI: Joe Trippi, you mentioned something that has greatly concerned me, too: the dangers of stridency. What qualifies as too strident when it comes to Democrats and the right messaging and positioning and candidates for the midterms? What are a few things you\u2019ve observed recently \u2014 tactics, statements \u2014 that made you wince and think: \u201cThat\u2019s too strident. That\u2019s not wise.\u201d\n\nTRIPPI: A partisan from either party who is in a marginal district and lashes out at the other side is likely to hurt themselves with these voters. How is this candidate not going to add to the chaos and hostility in Washington? How is this candidate going to get anything done for me?\n\nDemocratic activists want someone who is going to attack and fight the Republicans at every turn. That will work great in a Democratic district \u2014 it may work to attract support and money and win praise from the base. But in marginal districts, particularly places that have voted Republican for years (like Alabama, for instance), that will squander an otherwise winnable district or state.\n\nWe can\u2019t be a one-size-fits-all party. I should point out that Doug Jones did not have a competitive primary, whereas the G.O.P. had exactly the ideological fight we need to avoid in marginal districts. It\u2019s the candidates we nominate in the primaries of 2018 that will determine how successful we are.\n\nBRUNI: Governor Patrick, but aren\u2019t the \u201cmeans\u201d really everything? Single payer and Medicare for All are a world apart from Obamacare, and when it comes to how things play out in the political arena, Republican strategists tell me they\u2019re champing at the bit to have their candidates campaign against any plan that they can brand \u201csocialized medicine.\u201d\n\nPATRICK: I get that, but it doesn\u2019t trouble me. For example, Obamacare started out as a Republican idea, conceived by a right-leaning think tank and tried out (successfully) in Massachusetts. When President Obama proposed and passed it in Congress, it soon became clear that the only thing Republicans didn\u2019t like about it was the Obama part. Now they want to fuss about alternatives, including Medicare for All or even a Medicare option in the marketplace. But they have yet to propose any idea to ensure health care for everybody. That\u2019s the revealing truth. And that\u2019s what\u2019s wrong.\n\nBRUNI: As a member of the (very populous) camp of Americans who believe that President Trump is a great danger to us and that we desperately need him to be checked by at least one chamber of Congress in Democratic control, I have to admit that I\u2019m spooked by some of what I\u2019ve seen recently. A Washington Post/ABC News poll over the weekend showed that 58 percent of Americans rate the economy good or excellent \u2014 that\u2019s a 17-year high. Another recent poll showed that the generic-Democratic versus generic-Republican difference had collapsed from over 10 points to just six. Tell me why I shouldn\u2019t \u2014 or should \u2014 be hugely worried.", "title": "Opinion | Enough Trump Bashing, Democrats", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "Bailenson is the director of the Virtual Human Interaction Lab at Stanford, and most of his book reads like a remarkably interesting report on the cool new experiments he\u2019s conducting. He\u2019s found that virtual reality can help people overcome PTSD, endure painful skin-grafting procedures and practice surgery. An early chapter deals with quarterbacks using the technology to go over what they might have missed during practice. And although his discussion of certain applications of V.R. can sometimes read like an advertisement, he gets what it\u2019s really good at, at least for the time being: creating pricey, immersive experiences that are planned in advance, either by capturing something live or by creating it.\n\nImage\n\nThe N.F.L. knows that the moment a quarterback gets the ball, a million things will happen over the next few seconds that can be caught by expensive cameras, and they made the bet that the cost of capturing those moments to train one person to be better at his job would be worth it. The other objective, committing the time and resources to build something immersive \u2014 say, underwater field trip experiences for children who would not otherwise have the chance to swim with sharks \u2014 needs more broad application to justify the currently steep price.\n\nBailenson defines V.R. as a scientific and cultural tool. He explores the idea of creating interactive stories \u2014 and even has words of advice for their would-be directors \u2014 but it\u2019s clear that he\u2019s first and foremost a scientist, testing hypotheses and proposing new therapies.\n\nLanier\u2019s book is, by contrast, intimate and idiosyncratic. He carries us through his quirky and fascinating life story, with periodic nerdy side trips through his early thinking on more technical aspects of virtual reality. If you liked Richard Feynman\u2019s autobiographical \u201cSurely You\u2019re Joking, Mr. Feynman\u201d but thought it was rather self-indulgent, this book will prompt similar reactions. You could almost say that Lanier\u2019s vivid and creative imagination is a distinct character in this book, he discusses it so much. Midway through, Feynman himself makes an appearance, and it seems as if we\u2019re meeting an old friend.\n\nLanier has been credited with inventing the term \u201cvirtual reality,\u201d and he founded one of the original companies to produce it, VPL Research. He goes over the technology\u2019s history in detail, outlining not only the obstacles to getting consistent hardware but some personalities and interpersonal conflicts that ultimately led to his company\u2019s breaking up. He also demonstrates the role personal connections and interactions play in Silicon Valley. This narrative illuminates the overlooked importance of women, referred to by Lanier as G.N.F.s, for Grand Networking Females, in making the connections and taking up the work essential to starting tech companies. For example, at the moment that Lanier was offered start-up funding and needed a corporate lawyer, a G.N.F. introduced him to the right people. Although Lanier goes out of his way to give credit to these women, I\u2019m left with that familiar sinking feeling that, although successful in their own right, they formed the social glue upon which all companies depended but never became as famous as the men they helped.\n\nIn the late 1980s, Lanier was a sought-after speaker in California, an enthusiastic supporter for theoretical, mind-bending experiences that technology would someday offer to audiences of blissed-out hippies. (Lanier discusses lots of drug use in the book but says he doesn\u2019t personally partake, \u201cnot even marijuana.\u201d) Two consequences of this early guru persona come out in the book: First, he offers dozens of different definitions of V.R. as a holistic force and cure-all. Second, he comes off as both a technically savvy inventor and a cult leader.", "title": "Enter the Holodeck", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-06 00:00:00", "text": "For Christians around the world, the official end to the Christmas holiday occurs on Jan. 6. Known as Epiphany, or the 12th Day of Christmas, it commemorates how a star led the Magi, or the three kings or wise men, to the baby Jesus.\n\nCountries celebrate on the evening before and on the actual day with parades of decorative floats and people in costume as the kings bearing gifts. The festivities often feature light and music shows, and clowns and jugglers who throw candy to the crowds.", "title": "Epiphany Celebrations Around the World", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "An added benefit, he said, is that it would improve U.S. Soccer\u2019s relationship with FIFA, the sport\u2019s global governing body which has criticized the U.S. for sticking to a March-through-December schedule rather than the August through May schedule used in Europe.\n\nSome of his language and proposals mirror the claims of those who have taken their grievances against U.S. Soccer, and M.L.S., to federal court. M.L.S. and its owners counter that a plan like Wynalda\u2019s would crater the country\u2019s top division and waste the hundreds of millions of dollars they have invested in it since it began play in 1996.\n\nTo Wynalda, this misses the larger point. When the federation talks about business, \u201csoccer gets lost in the shuffle,\u201d he said. \u201cYou end up failing to make a World Cup, and then nobody knows who\u2019s to blame. But the people who run the machine, if you will, will continue to tell you everything is just fine.\u201d\n\nFor those in the audience in Columbus, Wynalda\u2019s challenge to the soccer hierarchy was music to their ears. Many fans of the local M.L.S. team, the Columbus Crew, believe they are suffering the brunt of what they see as their club\u2019s decision to prioritize profits over its connection to the city. Anthony Precourt, the owner of the Crew, has said he will move the team to Austin, Texas, next year unless an agreement can be reached on the construction of a downtown stadium.\n\nWynalda spoke to their grievances. He also speaks to the grievances of those in charge of the second-division North American Soccer League, many of whom believe U.S. Soccer has stymied them from legitimately competing with M.L.S.\n\nIn early January, responding to speculation that he did not have the resources to mount a campaign, Wynalda told Sports Illustrated that he had received financial support from Riccardo Silva. Silva owns Miami F.C. in the North American Soccer League and is one of U.S. Soccer\u2019s loudest antagonists. The N.A.S.L. has sued U.S. Soccer in federal court over its second-tier status. Miami F.C. has filed a claim at the Court of Arbitration for sport, arguing that FIFA\u2019s rules mandate the implementation of promotion and relegation. A victory potentially could be worth tens of millions of dollars to Silva, enabling his team to rise into the top division without paying an expansion fee.\n\n\u201cWe are very aligned with Mr. Silva and his belief system,\u201d Wynalda said, \u201cand he wants, clearly, to see change in this country.\u201d", "title": "Eric Wynalda Discusses His Financial Problems \u2014 and Everything Else", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-02 00:00:00", "text": "Erica Garner, the civil rights activist and a daughter of Eric Garner, died on Saturday, two days before the New Year and in the middle of the holiday season \u2014 a time when we\u2019re all encouraged to be with our families. It is impossible to think of her death without thinking of her father\u2019s death, the devastation their family must feel and the ways that black families have been destroyed throughout history.\n\nOther families could devote themselves to spending time together around tables piled with celebratory food. But the Garners had to keep vigil around a hospital bed, because Erica suffered a heart attack on Christmas Eve and spent most of last week in a coma. She died unfairly young, at 27. That\u2019s three years after her dad died unfairly young, at 43, when Officer Daniel Pantaleo of the New York Police Department placed him in a banned chokehold.\n\nErica Garner is survived by her two young children. If both she and her dad had been alive this holiday season, they would have almost certainly spent it together. \u201cHe was a family man,\u201d she said about him, in one of the last interviews she gave before her death, on the third anniversary of the grand jury\u2019s decision not to indict Officer Pantaleo. \u201cLike all the holidays, any type of events, he was always there. He always made sure you knew he supported you any way he can.\u201d\n\nSince the country\u2019s founding, black families have never been able to thrive. Slavery broke them apart by allowing family members to be sold at auctions to different owners, and by prohibiting slaves from legally marrying, since slaves were classified as property, not people. Millions of black family members were killed during slavery and the lynching era, from 1877 to 1950. The modern legal system separates black families at higher rates than other families through many methods, including disparate sentencing schemes. Black defendants often receive far longer sentences than similarly situated white defendants.", "title": "Opinion | Erica Garner and How America Destroys Black Families", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "The block\u2019s evolution unfolds through its diverse residents, who included the Fabers (owners of a factory in Brooklyn that made No. 2 pencils); the Davises (whose red-and-yellow baking powder cans remain a kitchen staple and who were scandalized when a widowed heiress married her chauffeur); relatives of the Goodyear Tire family; Marion Davies, the film actress and paramour of William Randolph Hearst; Duke Ellington; and Saul Bellow.\n\nAmong the unsavory characters who found refuge in 1934 at 334 Riverside, which by then had been renovated into a rooming house, was the book\u2019s title character \u2014 Bernard (Bennie the Bum) McMahon.\n\nHis leg was, indeed, sawed off (both, actually \u2013 one amputated, the other severed so his body could be stuffed into a steamer trunk) after he suffered a self-inflicted shotgun wound after what was then the largest armored car heist in American history. The robbery at the Rubel Ice Company warehouse in Bath Beach, Brooklyn, totaled $427,950 (about $8 million in today\u2019s dollars).\n\nMr. Wakin wrote that he was drawn to his subject because while the seven townhouses on Riverside Drive were \u201cdeeply familiar\u201d to him, \u201cI knew nothing of the lives that were carried on within these walls.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nHe continued: \u201cAnd some day one of those forgotten stories would be mine. Other people living in my home would wonder about the anonymous residents of generations past.\u201d\n\nMs. Shapiro was researching an article on St. Stanislaus Bishop and Martyr Church in the East Village, the oldest Polish Catholic church in the New York archdiocese, when she stumbled upon the name of Billy Gawronski, whose story, she wrote, \u201creads like that of some character sprung from the pages of Robert Louis Stevenson or Mark Twain.\u201d\n\nBilly was born in 1910 in a Lower East Side tenement and raised as a teenager in Bayside, Queens, in what seemed like an age of infinite fortuity.\n\nHe had already achieved fame, of sorts. When he was 14, his stray mutt won first place in a dog show sponsored by the New York Women\u2019s League for Animals and he was featured in The Daily News.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe was enthralled when his favorite librarian at a local branch provided him with a copy of \u201cDick Byrd: Air Explorer,\u201d a biography of the pioneering polar pathfinder, but was bitterly disappointed when, because his father insisted that studying for finals at Textile High School in Manhattan took precedence, he was not allowed to attend the June 1926 parade for Admiral Byrd, who had just returned from his airborne North Pole flight.\n\nLess than two years later, though, Billy swam across the Hudson from Manhattan to Hoboken and stowed away on Byrd\u2019s ship for the first American expedition to Antarctica (the author drew many details from Russell Owen\u2019s coverage in The Times). He was discovered, but was eventually enlisted as a mess boy.\n\nHis mother begged Byrd not to take her son on subsequent expeditions. As a result, Billy never returned to Antarctica. But the teenager had experienced the adventure of a lifetime.\n\n\u201cThe expedition provided an escape from the dreary future in his father\u2019s upholstery business that had seemed so unavoidable at 17,\u201d Ms. Shapiro wrote. \u201cIt introduced him to a world of danger and discovery that had existed only in his scrapbooks and library loans, and gave him the basic seaman\u2019s training with which he made a career.\u201d", "title": "Escape from New York, or Embracing It Within One City Block", "authors": ["Sam Roberts"]} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "NAIROBI, Kenya \u2014 The prime minister of Ethiopia on Wednesday announced that the government would close a notorious detention center and release some prisoners across the country, including some members of political parties.\n\nThe announcement was hailed by human rights groups as an amnesty for the country\u2019s political prisoners, who are estimated to number in the thousands, even though Hailemariam Desalegn, the prime minister, did not explicitly mention political prisoners in his address.\n\nSome wondered exactly whom the prime minister intended to release.\n\n\u201cIt was absolutely not clear what the prime minister was saying,\u201d said Yacob Hailemariam, a lawyer in Addis Ababa, the capital. \u201cThe whole thing is filled with vague statements and vague promises. He was very equivocal, and we will have to wait to see what he really meant.\u201d\n\nThe government of Ethiopia \u2014 Africa\u2019s second most populous country and an important United States ally in the fight against terrorism \u2014 has never acknowledged that it holds political prisoners, which would violate the country\u2019s Constitution.", "title": "Ethiopia Says It Will Close Notorious Prison and Free Some Inmates", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nAMSTERDAM \u2014 The Stedelijk Museum has canceled a major retrospective of the architect and designer Ettore Sottsass that was scheduled to open in April, after a conflict with his estate over the exhibition\u2019s content.\n\nOn Friday, the Stedelijk, which is the Netherlands\u2019 leading museum of contemporary art and design, announced its decision to cancel the show, which it said would have included more than 400 art and design pieces, some from its own collection and some on loan from about 30 institutions and collections. It said in a statement that the Sottsass estate and a gallery representing the designer had attempted to \u201cdictate\u201d the content of the exhibition.\n\nThe Met Breuer offered a Sottsass retrospective in New York last year, which was hastily assembled and received mixed reviews. The Amsterdam exhibition would have been significantly larger than the Met\u2019s.\n\nThe Met declined to comment for this article.\n\nMr. Sottsass, who died at age 90 in 2007, was trained as an architect and helped found the influential Memphis Group of Italian designers. He became renowned as a design maverick for his postmodern, colorful furniture and products, such as the red plastic Olivetti Valentine typewriter.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJan Willem Sieburgh, the Stedelijk\u2019s interim managing director, told The New York Times in a telephone interview on Tuesday that Mr. Sottsass\u2019s widow and heir, Barbara Radice, had made it clear to him that she would not only withdraw her support and her art from the exhibition, but that she would also speak publicly against the show.", "title": "Ettore Sottsass Exhibition Canceled After Museum and Estate Clash", "authors": ["Nina Siegal"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Before long, these clients included major museums \u2014 the Art Institute of Chicago, the Cleveland Museum of Art, the National Gallery in Washington \u2014 and private buyers like Paul Mellon and Norton Simon, whose Pasadena museum Mr. Thaw did much to shape.\n\nHis closest institutional tie was to what is now the Morgan Library and Museum, which in the 1950s was one of the few New York museums to have a curator of drawings. In 1975, after the museum had expanded its acquisition parameters to include 19th-century work, the Thaws decided that the Morgan would be the recipient, in incremental allotments, of their ever-growing holdings. The Morgan exhibition \u201cDrawn to Greatness: Master Drawings From the Thaw Collection,\u201d which opened in September and closes on Sunday, marked the completion of the gift, encompassing more than 400 sheets.\n\nAmong them were works by modern and contemporary artists in whom Mr. Thaw took particular interest. In the 1950s, on summer vacations in East Hampton, N.Y., Clare Thaw had struck up a friendship with the painter Lee Krasner, Jackson Pollock\u2019s widow. With Ms. Krasner\u2019s cooperation, Mr. Thaw began preparing the multivolume Pollock catalogue raisonn\u00e9, an annotated listing of all the artist\u2019s known works, in the 1970s, hiring the art historian Francis V. O\u2019Connor as co-author.\n\nAt Ms. Krasner\u2019s death in 1984, Mr. Thaw served as executor of her estate and helped establish the Pollock-Krasner Foundation, which gives grants to artists in need.\n\nThe Thaws had established their own foundation, the Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw Charitable Trust, in 1981, using the proceeds from the sale of a single van Gogh painting. The trust supports the arts, the environment and, of particular importance to Ms. Thaw, animal rights.\n\nBy then Mr. Thaw was preparing to retire as a dealer, discouraged by the direction the field had taken. \u201cThe astronomical growth in wealth over the last generation has fueled merely an interest in treating art as a financial asset,\u201d he wrote.\n\nIn 1987, the Thaws moved from their farm in Cherry Valley, in Otsego County, to Santa Fe, N.M. There they began collecting Native American art, eventually acquiring more than 1,000 objects. They later gave the entire collection to the Fenimore Art Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., not far from Cherry Valley. A wing designed by Hugh Hardy was built in 1995 to house it.", "title": "Eugene V. Thaw, Influential Art Collector and Dealer, Is Dead at 90", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-24 00:00:00", "text": "In contrast to Mr. Trump\u2019s pullback from international trade agreements and his renouncing of the Paris climate accord, the European leaders emphasized their commitment to prosperity through global commerce.\n\nIn place of Mr. Trump\u2019s unilateralism, the three European leaders pledged to strengthen the bonds of the European Union and the 19 nations that use the euro currency.\n\nThey underscored their commitment to multilateral approaches as the salve to trouble, including widening economic inequality, terrorism and the ravages of climate change.\n\n\u201cIf we want to avoid this fragmentation of the world, we need a stronger Europe, it\u2019s absolutely key,\u201d Mr. Macron declared. \u201cFrance is back. France is back at the core of Europe, because we will never have any French success without a European success.\u201d\n\nA year ago in Davos, the role of world-leading defender of globalization fell to Chinese President Xi Jinping. His address followed Britain\u2019s shocking decision to leave the European Union, and only days before Mr. Trump\u2019s inauguration.\n\nPhoto\n\nTo an audience fearful that the global, rules-based trading system was unraveling, Mr. Xi\u2019s commitment to internationalism drew a mixture of relief and acclaim. But China was at best a compromised claimant to that role, given its preferential credit for state-owned companies, its theft of intellectual property and its jailing of dissidents and journalists.\n\nMr. Macron put forth his own credentials as a leader singularly able to help guide Europe and the global economy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur vision, our DNA in terms of the relationship between freedom and the furtherance of individual rights, is unique,\u201d Mr. Macron said.\n\nHe described a sense of responsibility to translate French values into a form of capitalism that can deliver growth along with increased opportunities for middle-class and working people.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a transformational moment for Europe,\u201d said Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund. \u201cThere is clearly determination to deepen European governance. These leaders do believe in the rule of law. They do believe in globalization.\u201d\n\nAmong the many casualties of Europe\u2019s decade-long economic crisis was a sense of collective purpose among the region\u2019s leaders. The downturn was exacerbated by the unique defects of the euro \u2014 a shared currency that operates without a joint budget or political agreement among member states.\n\nMr. Macron has devoted his first months in office to arguing for the creation of a shared eurozone finance minister along with eurozone-wide budgets, enabling better coordination of economic policies when crisis returns.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMs. Merkel has expressed cautious support while assiduously avoiding blessing anything that smacks of transferring German wealth to the less prosperous countries of the Mediterranean \u2014 a radioactive proposition among German voters.\n\nThe German chancellor has in recent weeks grappled with complex negotiations toward forming a coalition government composed of her Christian Democratic Union and the more left-leaning Social Democratic Party after inconclusive elections last fall.\n\nMany analysts have assumed that political fragility in Germany would complicate Mr. Macron\u2019s efforts to win German support for his integration proposals. But the coalition taking shape would bring a more pro-European orientation, many analysts say.\n\n\u201cI came here thinking about the fractured world, and one day later I feel I\u2019m in a converged world,\u201d said Charles-Edouard Bou\u00e9e, chief executive of Roland Berger, a global consultancy with offices in Shanghai and Munich.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn her speech here on Wednesday, Ms. Merkel reaffirmed her commitment to completing a so-called banking union, a system that shares the risks of financial breakdown across national borders.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe cast the drive to better integrate Europe as a historical responsibility of grave import, noting that the concept of the European Union dates back to the effort to limit future bloodshed in Europe by building economic ties.\n\n\u201cWe have to ask ourselves, when we have fewer and fewer people who remember these events of history, have we learned the lessons of history?\u201d Ms. Merkel asked.\n\n\u201cMany people seem to worry, will multilateralism find an answer to the problems that mankind has in a fair and equitable way?\u201d Ms. Merkel said, seemingly referring to Mr. Trump. \u201cWe think that shutting ourselves off against the world, isolating ourselves, will not lead to a good future. Protectionism is not the right answer.\u201d\n\nFor years, Italy has been the face of Europe\u2019s most deep-seated problems: its banks stuffed with terrible loans, its communities full of young people who have moved in with their parents for lack of jobs.\n\nBut even Italy is now sharing in Europe\u2019s economic expansion, though joblessness remains rampant. The country\u2019s prime minister used the stage here to argue that now is the moment to attack economic inequality. Either that, or the forces of populism will triumph, he warned \u2014 a clear worry about Italy\u2019s approaching national elections, and the ascendant Five Star party, which has been hostile to the euro.\n\n\u201cWe must not give in to the idea of a world destined to be split between a cosmopolitan digital elite and an army of precarious and underpaid local workers,\u201d Mr. Gentiloni said. \u201cThis worry, and these frustrations, are our main concern.\u201d\n\nThese sorts of mission statements are increasingly dominating the political conversation in Europe \u2014 nowhere more than in France, where Mr. Macron, a former investment banker, has pledged to make his country more appealing to business while strengthening unemployment benefits and training for castoff workers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe centerpiece of Mr. Macron\u2019s efforts are the labor reforms he introduced last summer, making it easier for employers to terminate workers. In his speech here, he cast that not as a means of relinquishing labor to the unsentimental winds of capitalism, but rather giving start-up companies relief from the strictures of national labor contracts negotiated by unions.\n\nEmployers have in recent weeks used their newly acquired authority to fire to do just that, while the supposed Nordic-style worker protections Mr. Macron has promised have yet to materialize.\n\nMr. Macron promised to fill the void, vowing to spend 15 billion euros \u2014 about $18.6 billion \u2014 over the next five years on education and retraining.\n\n\u201cIf I cannot explain to people that globalization is good for them, and that it will help them develop their own lives, then they will be the nationalists, the extremists who want to get out of the system,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd they will win in every country.\u201d", "title": "Europe Is Back. And Rejecting Trumpism.", "authors": ["Peter S. Goodman"]} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "More than three months since Germany\u2019s inconclusive national elections, efforts to form a new government have come down to a last stab at reviving the partnership between Chancellor Angela Merkel\u2019s center-right and the center-left that governed the country for eight of the last 12 years. The political uncertainty does not seem to be unduly troubling for Germans, who are doing quite well in other respects.\n\nBut Europe, and the world, are in urgent need of strong leadership from Berlin as quickly as possible, so the sooner the Germans sort out their politics, the better for all.\n\nThe sort of bargaining that has gone on since the Sept. 24 elections has been a critical national conversation on immigration, health care, education, infrastructure and the like.\n\nBut several factors have made the current situation different. One is that the traditional major parties, both Ms. Merkel\u2019s Christian Democrats and even more painfully their past partners, the Social Democrats, took a drubbing in the September vote, while a xenophobic far-right party entered Parliament for the first time. In the changed political chemistry, the Social Democrats strongly resisted entering another \u201cgrand coalition\u201d with Ms. Merkel, and it has taken a lot of cajoling to get the Social Democratic leader Martin Schulz into coalition talks.", "title": "Opinion | Europe Listens Anxiously as Germans Talk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "The nuclear deal \u201cis in the background of all this for the Europeans and for Rouhani, too, especially given sanctions renewal in mid-January,\u201d Ms. Geranmayeh said.\n\nSo far, the European Union and its member states have issued statements condemning the violence and warning the Iranian government not to overreact. But the statements do not support the protesters or condemn the Islamic government as explicitly as Mr. Trump\u2019s Twitter messages do.\n\nEuropean officials say they are for now resisting American efforts to issue a more critical joint statement at the United Nations or at the U.N. Human Rights Council in Geneva, as called for by Nikki Haley, Mr. Trump\u2019s ambassador at the United Nations.\n\nMr. Trump has already \u201cdecertified\u201d Iran last October for not, in his view, living up to its commitments under the nuclear deal, negotiated in 2015 under President Obama. But even then he signed a waiver on the sanctions, which he must do every 120 days.\n\nOn Tuesday, the White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, said Mr. Trump had not decided what he will do about the sanctions.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cWe certainly keep our options open in terms of sanctions,\u2019\u2019 she said. \u201cIn terms of signing a waiver later in January, the President hasn\u2019t made a final decision on that. He\u2019s going to keep every option on the table.\u201d\n\nIf he does not sign, renewed sanctions will affect both American and European companies, given the power of the dollar and the American banking system.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe reimposition of sanctions could also further undermine the standing of Mr. Rouhani, while allowing Iran\u2019s hard-liners to argue that it had been wrong to trust the United States on the nuclear deal, which could founder.\n\nThe Europeans have been pushing Washington hard, especially in Congress, to preserve the nuclear deal with Iran despite Mr. Trump\u2019s regular and longstanding criticism of it as \u201cthe worst deal ever.\u201d\n\nWith protests against the Islamic government in Iran and its economic performance, including the vast sums it spends supporting Shia allies abroad like Syria, Hezbollah and the Yemeni Houthis, Mr. Trump may decide that to waive the sanctions again would only give more economic help to a regime he disparages.\n\n\u201cPeople on the ground in Iran are still trying to figure out where all this is going,\u201d said Ms. Geranmayeh, the Iran expert.\n\n\u201cThe E.U. is quite different from the Trump message, expressing concern over what\u2019s happening but trying not to harm those demonstrating in Iran, while creating a certain degree of expectation \u2014 \u2018Rouhani, we are watching you,\u2019 \u201d she added.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Europeans are important for Mr. Rouhani, too. They are the biggest potential investors in Iran and also have been fierce defenders of the nuclear deal that Mr. Rouhani supported against deep skepticism from the hard-liners and Iran\u2019s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.\n\nThe European Union\u2019s statement, issued Tuesday night by the high representative for foreign affairs, Federica Mogherini, says that the deaths of demonstrators are \u201cinexcusable\u201d and calls on the Tehran government for restraint, while noting that Mr. Rouhani has said Iranians have the right to peaceful political protest.\n\nIt says that such rights are fundamental and \u201capply to every country, and Iran is no exception.\u201d\n\n\u201cWe expect all concerned to refrain from violence and the right of expression to be guaranteed, also in light of the statements made by the Iranian Government,\u201d the statement said.\n\nMs. Mogherini has been criticized for delay in making the statement, but the European Union works by consensus, and diplomats have been caught on holidays.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe British Foreign Secretary, Boris Johnson, was criticized for responding too blandly to the situation, but on Monday he also called for freedom of expression and the right to demonstrate peacefully to be respected, and said that the issues raised by the protesters were legitimate.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn a telephone call with Mr. Rouhani on Tuesday, French President Emmanuel Macron also asked for restraint and agreed to postpone a visit scheduled for this week by the French foreign minister, Jean-Yves Le Drian.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, the German government issued a similar statement, urging the Iranian government to initiate talks with the protesters and respond proportionately.\n\n\u201cThe federal government considers it legitimate when people courageously protest their economic and political woes on the streets as is happening in Iran at the moment and they have our respect,\u201d said a government spokeswoman, Ulrike Demmer.\n\nThe European Union and other signatory members, France, Britain and Germany, have regularly defended the Iran nuclear deal against American criticism and said Iran was in full compliance.\n\nThey have argued that the deal is only about the nuclear program, not other Iranian actions, some of which are already sanctioned. But Mr. Trump thinks the accord was too limited and did not do enough to constrain Iranian actions in other areas.\n\n\u201cIf the Iranian regime would use more violence to crack down, then I\u2019m sure the European Union would take a tougher stance,\u201d said Raz Zimmt, a research fellow at the Institute for National Security Studies and the Alliance Center for Iranian Studies at Tel Aviv University.\n\n\u201cBut for now the Iranian regime doesn\u2019t want to use too much force,\u201d fearing escalation inside the country and a harsher reaction outside, he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut he expressed skepticism that the European efforts to push Mr. Rouhani would significantly hasten economic reforms and civil liberties.\n\n\u201cI doubt that Rouhani will be able to do something significant without the approval of the supreme leader, and the supreme leader, as we all know, is quite concerned with any change in Iran,\u201d Mr. Zimmt said.\n\nThe European Union has also been firmly opposed to Mr. Trump\u2019s decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel\u2019s capital. European officials have been troubled also by a symbolic, nonbinding resolution by the Likud Party, led by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, to annex Israeli settlements in the West Bank, across the green line that marks Israel\u2019s pre-1967 boundaries.", "title": "Europe Resists Trump\u2019s Call for Tougher Measures on Iran", "authors": ["Steven Erlanger"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThey actually fight over you,\u201d the Hungarian trumpeter Tamas Palfalvi said in a phone interview.\n\nFor audiences, the program offers a chance to catch musicians on the cusp of major careers. Past participants include the pianist Igor Levit, the violinist Patricia Kopatchinskaja and the cellist Jean-Guihen Queyras \u2014 all artists with an appetite for adventure and wide-ranging collaboration. That innovative spirit has been increasingly emphasized by ECHO through the addition of a robust commissioning program that allows the \u201crising stars\u201d to have a work tailored to them by a composer of their choice.\n\nOver the past five years, a professional development aspect has been added, too, offering targeted coaching in engaging with listeners. \u201cIt\u2019s important for them to learn from the beginning that it is part of their job to communicate with the public,\u201d the general and artistic director of the Elbphilharmonie, Christoph Lieben-Seutter, said in an interview.\n\nIndeed, the program\u2019s ambitions are high. \u201cWe ask existential questions,\u201d said Andrew Manning, the secretary general of ECHO. \u201cWhy this art form? Why do we do what we do? What is the vision of these artists? And how can I use the prestige of this wonderful range of concert halls, from the 19th-century Concertgebouw to the Elbphilharmonie, to enable that vision?\u201d\n\nThe resulting concerts \u2014 I saw four of the six presented in one week in Hamburg \u2014 weld outstanding musicianship to charisma, humor and a twist of the unexpected. By the end of the festival I started to wonder who the true beneficiaries of the initiative were: It seemed quite possible that these young musicians and their fresh ideas were throwing a lifeline to the venerable concert halls, rather than vice versa.\n\nEmmanuel Tjeknavorian, an Austrian violinist of Armenian origin, presented a solo program of eye-watering virtuosity that included Christoph Ehrenfellner\u2019s deliciously changeable \u201cSuite des Alpes.\u201d In a nod to the Bach solo-violin Partitas, this new work offered arrangements of Austrian folk dances juxtaposed with alienating variations on them that used acrobatic and novel techniques, condensing into one the wholesomeness of a dirndl with the searing angst of an Elfriede Jelinek novel.", "title": "Europe\u2019s \u2018Rising Star\u2019 Musicians Give as Much as They Get", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nI took my fianc\u00e9e to the Embers on East 54th Street for an evening of jazz in April 1961.\n\nWhen the night was over, I had enough cash to pay the bill but had miscalculated and did not have enough to tip the waiter, who refused to take my check. I was dismayed by the prospect of leaving without giving him the $10 I felt he deserved.\n\nA man and woman sitting next to us recognized my dilemma and offered to cover the tip. The man, too, refused my check and also would not give me his address so that I could repay him.\n\nSeveral weeks later I was at a small tailor shop on Second Avenue near 53rd Street for the final fitting of a suit I was having made for my wedding. My fianc\u00e9e and I were getting married in August, on my birthday.\n\nAfter leaving the shop, I started to cross the avenue. There, coming the other way, was the man who had covered the tip at the Embers.\n\nI pulled a $10 bill from my pocket and gave it to him in the middle of the street.", "title": "Evening at the Embers", "authors": ["Paul Eggermann", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.\n\nORAN ETKIN: GRAND OPENING CELEBRATION CONCERT FOR TIMBALOOLOO SOHO at City Winery (Jan. 13, 11 a.m.; doors open at 10). You usually have to travel to New Orleans for an authentic jazz parade, but the musician Oran Etkin promises to lead one in Manhattan at the conclusion of this event, which honors the opening of his music school in SoHo. But while the school is new, his program, Timbalooloo, is not: Mr. Etkin founded it in 2005 to teach jazz and world music to young children as a conversation among instruments. This concert will feature Mr. Etkin\u2019s quintet and two of his favorite musical characters: Clara Net (his clarinet) and her mother, Big Mama Tuba. At 12:30, after the performance, everyone will parade from City Winery to the school for a ribbon-cutting ceremony.\n\n212-608-0555, citywinery.com/newyork\n\nFAMILY FILMS: \u2018UNLIKELY FRIENDSHIPS\u2019 at the Museum of Modern Art (Jan. 13, noon to 1 p.m.). Friends are supposed to have a lot in common, but sometimes the most rewarding relationships are between the most different individuals. This free program of international animated shorts, geared to children 5 and older, explores such unusual connections, offering discussions and suggestions for follow-up gallery activities. The movies are \u201cThe Gossamer\u201d (2016), a Russian look at a friendship between a spider and a human knitter; \u201cThe Happy Duckling\u201d (2008), a British tale about a child and the duck that follows him; and the Oscar-winning \u201cThe Lost Thing\u201d (2010), from Australia and Britain, in which a boy bonds with the strange tentacled being he finds on a beach.\n\n212-708-9805, moma.org/family\n\n\u2018I HAVE A DREAM CELEBRATION!\u2019 at the Brooklyn Children\u2019s Museum (Jan. 13-15, 11 a.m. until closing). This holiday weekend will be filled with dreams, and not just those of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.: Young museum visitors will contribute their own visions of social justice to programs honoring his birthday. From Saturday through Monday, those activities will include \u201cMake Art Not War,\u201d at 11:30 a.m., in which children will add their handprints to a mural of a 1964 quotation from Dr. King: \u201cThe time is always right to do what\u2019s right.\u201d From 1 to 3 p.m., they can listen to his \u201cI Have a Dream\u201d speech while writing their hopes on cloud-shaped cutouts that will soar in a museum display. \u201cKids Take Action!,\u201d at 1:30 p.m., will aim for concrete change \u2014 children will write letters to their City Council members \u2014 and \u201cSylvia\u2019s Story Corner,\u201d unfolding on a real Brooklyn bus at the end of each day, will chronicle Rosa Parks\u2019s transformative action on a Montgomery, Ala., bus in 1955. On Saturday only, the museum will also sponsor a neighborhood Brooklyn Kids March. At 3 p.m., visitors will make signs and posters, then at 3:45 take small steps toward a better world.\n\n718-735-4400, brooklynkids.org/mlk\n\n\u2018JOURNEY TO OZ: A WIZARD OF OZ STORY\u2019 at Symphony Space (Jan. 13, 11 a.m.). If you\u2019ve always longed to follow the Yellow Brick Road \u2014 and not just as an armchair traveler \u2014 this may be the production for you. Presented by the Experiential Theater Company as part of the Just Kidding series, the hourlong \u201cJourney to Oz\u201d enlists members of the audience to carry out tasks in the adventure, whether it\u2019s creating a cyclone, oiling the Tin Man or assisting the Wicked Witch of the West with her makeup. Children will also be invited onstage to help perform certain scenes, so expect lots of Munchkins and flying monkeys and a whole succession of intrepid Dorothys.\n\n212-864-5400, symphonyspace.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018SAVOY! DANCING THROUGH THE SWING ERA\u2019 at Flushing Town Hall (Jan. 14, 2 p.m.). It may be hard to get people of different ages to talk together, but who can object to dancing together? The Queens organization Project Connect aims to bridge any generation gaps through lively movement, particularly the Lindy hop (named for Charles Lindbergh\u2019s historic trans-Atlantic flight). Its interactive show, free to children and teenagers, uses big-band music to recreate the mood of the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem in the 1920s-1940s as it follows the fate of Lillian Carlyle, an aspiring dancer. No sitting still allowed, especially at the end, when audience members will learn the shim sham, a swing-era line dance.\n\n718-463-7700, Ext. 222; flushingtownhall.org\n\n\u2018TURNING 15 ON THE ROAD TO FREEDOM\u2019 at the Sanctuary Theater at the Center at West Park (through Jan. 20). Lynda Blackmon Lowery\u2019s 15th birthday, on March 22, 1965, occurred as she and other demonstrators were walking the 54 miles between Selma and Montgomery, Ala., during the historic voting rights march led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Ms. Blackmon Lowery chronicled her eventful youth as a civil rights protester \u2014 at 14, she had already been jailed nine times \u2014 in her memoir, \u201cTurning 15 on the Road to Freedom,\u201d which the actress Ally Sheedy has adapted into this solo theatrical production, starring Damaras Obi. In 2015, Ms. Blackmon Lowery told The New York Times that even children \u201ccan be history makers,\u201d and she will appear on Monday, Martin Luther King\u2019s Birthday, at a 5 p.m. special benefit performance to answer questions from the audience.\n\nturning15ontheroad.com", "title": "Events for Children in NYC This Week", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.\n\nCAMP FAIRS at St. Jean Baptiste High School (Jan. 20, noon to 3 p.m.) and Congregation Rodeph Sholom (Jan. 21, noon to 3 p.m.). The winter chill may make sunny hikes and campfire songs seem far away, but this is the time to choose where young family members will spend the summer months. These free fairs, sponsored by New York Family and the American Camp Association of New York and New Jersey, and running on select weekends at various locations through March 11, will each feature 40 to 60 camps, including both day and sleepaway, single-sex and coeducational, and all kinds of themes. Dozens of camp directors will attend, along with Renee Flax, the camp association\u2019s expert.\n\nnewyorkfamily.com/camp-fairs/registration\n\n\u2018DREAMS OF SAND\u2019 at Flushing Town Hall (Jan. 20, workshop at 1 p.m.; performance at 2:15 p.m.). You could call Borja Gonz\u00e1lez the sandman, but he won\u2019t put anyone to sleep. An artist born in Spain, he tells stories with his hands and a fleeting medium: sand. Mr. Gonz\u00e1lez will begin this Queens appearance with an interactive workshop in which he\u2019ll teach participants how to work with this material, first on paper and then on a small light table. In his wordless performance, accompanied by music and large projections, he\u2019ll create a narrative about the lives of two people through elaborate drawings of sand.\n\n718-463-7700, Ext. 222; flushingtownhall.org\n\nGUSTAFER YELLOWGOLD at Symphony Space (Jan. 20, 11 a.m.). He may not have been around as long as E.T., but he does hail from outer space and has been thoroughly charming children since 2005: He\u2019s Gustafer Yellowgold, who comes from the sun and from the imagination of Morgan Taylor. A cartoonist and musician, Mr. Taylor creates songs and videos about Gustafer, who looks like an animated drop of butter and now resides in the colder climes of a rather fantastical version of Minnesota. This concert will include songs from Mr. Taylor\u2019s latest CD, \u201cBrighter Side,\u201d which was recently nominated for a Grammy Award for best children\u2019s album.\n\n212-864-5400, symphonyspace.org\n\nMIL\u2019S TRILLS WINTER BASH at ShapeShifter Lab (Jan. 21, 11 a.m.). Amelia Robinson, a.k.a. Mil, is inviting children to celebrate \u201cRidiculous Nonsense.\u201d That\u2019s not only the title of her new album, but it\u2019s also the spirit of this annual Brooklyn event, at which she\u2019ll gather musicians from the record and young players ages 8 to 13 for a rousing, tune-filled party with raffles, giveaways and music videos. Ms. Robinson, who specializes in the electric ukulele, has dedicated her album to the spirit of play, and Namaste With Nat will get the audience in the mood with a preconcert all-ages yoga session.\n\n646-820-9452, milstrills.com\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018O BABY MINE: SING A SONG OF SHAKESPEARE LIVE!\u2019 at Joe\u2019s Pub (Jan. 21, 1 p.m.; doors open at 12:30). Shakespeare as children\u2019s music? Well, why not? The 2014 album \u201cO Baby Mine: Sing a Song of Shakespeare\u201d used the canon as inspiration for pop tunes for the young, sometimes incorporating a bit of the poetry and sometimes just a theme or conceit. Now a group of musicians is performing all the songs live in this concert, presented in association with New York City Children\u2019s Theater. Examples include \u201cNightingale\u2019s Lullaby,\u201d inspired by \u201cRomeo and Juliet\u201d; \u201cThere Are Bees,\u201d a riff on Ariel\u2019s \u201cWhere the Bee Sucks\u201d song from \u201cThe Tempest\u201d; and \u201cOh Father,\u201d a sweet song that will still remind moms and dads of \u201cKing Lear.\u201d\n\n212-967-7555, publictheater.org\n\n\u2018THE SNOWY DAY AND OTHER STORIES BY EZRA JACK KEATS\u2019 at St. Luke\u2019s Theater (playing in an open-ended run). When the author and illustrator Ezra Jack Keats created his most famous character, Peter, in 1962, he helped change the face of children\u2019s books, literally and figuratively. Peter was black, and though he was a little boy, he was a huge pioneer. Now his adventures have been adapted by Jerome Hairston in this production, directed by Julia Beardsley O\u2019Brien and playing on Saturdays at 11 a.m. The show features four books about Peter: The first, the award-winning \u201cThe Snowy Day,\u201d which explores the boy\u2019s discovery of snow; \u201cWhistle for Willie,\u201d about his pet dachshund and learning a new skill; \u201cGoggles!,\u201d in which Peter and a friend encounter bullies; and \u201cA Letter to Amy,\u201d which centers on a first friendship with a girl. With incidental music by Victor Zupanc, shadow puppets by Charlotte Lily Gaspard and just three actors \u2014 Tay Bass, Jahbril Cook and Garrett Gray \u2014 the 45-minute play gives life to a boy who transformed the literary world by inviting children into his private one.\n\n212-239-6200, thesnowydayplay.com", "title": "Events for Children in NYC This Week", "authors": ["Laurel Graeber"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.\n\nBROADWAY PLAYHOUSE: LEONARD BERNSTEIN at Merkin Concert Hall (Jan. 28, 11 a.m.). This is a chance for young New Yorkers to celebrate their wonderful town \u2014 and the eminent composer who helped give it that name. Part of the Kaufman Music Center\u2019s Broadway Playhouse series, which introduces a new generation of theatergoers to classic musicals, this program honors Bernstein\u2019s centennial with excerpts from works like \u201cWest Side Story,\u201d \u201cCandide,\u201d \u201cOn the Town\u201d and \u201cWonderful Town.\u201d Children (the recommended ages are 4 through 11) will be encouraged to sing along to the numbers \u201cNew York, New York\u201d and \u201cAmerica,\u201d and some can even go onstage to take part in musical games.\n\n212-501-3330, kaufmanmusiccenter.org\n\n\u2018CRAZY FOR KNISHES!\u2019 at the Museum at Eldridge Street (Jan. 28, 11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.). Pizza wars and cupcake wars have raged, but knish wars? That was indeed the case on the Lower East Side in 1916, when two businesses making that doughy snack opened across the street from each other. Their history inspired Joanne Oppenheim to write the children\u2019s book \u201cThe Knish War on Rivington Street,\u201d which she will read at this event. (She will also sign copies.) Ms. Oppenheim is to explain the role that young neighborhood residents played in the battle, and those hungry for knowledge \u2014 or just plain hungry \u2014 can enjoy the products of Yonah Schimmel Knish Bakery, a local purveyor.\n\n212-219-0302, eldridgestreet.org/events\n\nKIDS \u2019N COMEDY: \u2018NEW BEGINNINGS\u2019 at Gotham Comedy Club (Jan. 28, 1 p.m.). The tween and teenage stand-up comics who take part in this series probably have a New Year\u2019s resolution in common: to be hilarious. But at this 90-minute show, they\u2019ll also tackle the promises their peer group tends to break, as well as other occasions for wintry wit. The material, recommended for humor fans 9 and older, is allowed to be political but never profane.\n\n212-877-6115, kidsncomedy.com", "title": "Events for Children in NYC This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 A decade after the world descended into a devastating economic crisis, a key marker of revival has finally been achieved. Every major economy on earth is expanding at once, a synchronous wave of growth that is creating jobs, lifting fortunes and tempering fears of popular discontent.\n\nNo tidy, all-encompassing narrative explains how the world has finally escaped the global downturn. The United States has been propelled by government spending unleashed during the previous administration, plus a recent $1.5 trillion shot of tax cuts. Europe has finally felt the effects of cheap money pumped out by its central bank.\n\nIn general terms, improvement owes less to some newfound wellspring of wealth than the simple fact that many of the destructive forces that felled growth have finally exhausted their potency.\n\nThe long convalescence has yielded a global recovery that is far from blistering in pace, and geopolitical risks threaten its demise. Many economists are skeptical that the benefits of growth will reach beyond the educated, affluent, politically connected class that has captured most of the spoils in many countries and left behind working people whose wages have stagnated even as jobless rates have plunged.", "title": "Every One of the World\u2019s Big Economies Is Now Growing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Inside the Crypto Castle\n\nWhether it\u2019s all built on sand or not, the crypto castle has risen. There\u2019s an actual house called the Crypto Castle, and the king is Jeremy Gardner, 25, a rakish young investor with a hedge fund who has become the de facto tour guide for crypto newcomers.\n\nEarly one afternoon, he opened a bottle of ros\u00e9 while he charged half a dozen external batteries so he wouldn\u2019t have to ever plug in his phone in Ibiza, Spain, the next week.\n\n\u201cI do I.C.O.s. It\u2019s my thing,\u201d he said. He wore a pink button-front and pink pants. \u201cIt\u2019s me, a couple V.C.s and a lot of charlatans.\u201d\n\nAn initial coin offering is a way to raise money: A company creates its own cryptocurrency and investors buy into the new coin, without actually buying a stake in the company. Mr. Gardner led an I.C.O. for his start-up Augur, creating an \u201cAugur token\u201d that he then sold to raise real world money. These tokens sold fast, and it is one of the forces that kicked off this boom. For a time, the value of Augur, a market-forecasting start-up with few customers, exceeded $1 billion.\n\nPhoto\n\nPhoto\n\nAbout eight people live in the Crypto Castle on any given night, and some of Mr. Gardner\u2019s tenants brought out snacks (Cheez-Its and a jar of Nutella). One of the bedrooms has a stripper pole. Mr. Gardner leaned back into the sofa and rested his feet on the table. He recently did an I.C.O. for a start-up after-party. \u201cYou can I.C.O. anything,\u201d he said. He runs Distributed, a 180-page magazine about cryptocurrency that comes out about once a year. He is now raising $75 million for his hedge fund, Ausum Ventures (pronounced \u201cawesome\u201d). He said his closest friends are moving to Puerto Rico to get around paying taxes.\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re going to build a modern-day Atlantis out there,\u201d he said. \u201cBut for me, it\u2019s too early in my career to check out.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe wears a bracelet from his Burning Man camp (Mayan Warrior) and a necklace that is a key on a chain. \u201cI was given this necklace and was told my net worth would go up, and it\u2019s gone up six x since then,\u201d he said.\n\nHe drew a chart to explain the crypto community: 20 percent for ideology, 60 percent for the tech and 100 percent for the money, he said, drawing a circle around it all.\n\nA roommate on the sofa perked up and asked if he\u2019d ever invest in his lucid dreams start-up (the idea is a headpiece that induces them). Mr. Gardner did not seem impressed: \u201cProbably not,\u201d he said. A reality show wants to follow him around, but he\u2019s skeptical that it can add to his life.\n\n\u201cI literally have a date with Bella Hadid not having a reality show,\u201d he said.\n\nA few weeks after we first met, as the Bitcoin price exploded in December, Mr. Gardner seemed shaken. People had begun making pilgrimages to the Crypto Castle, knocking on the door, hoping Mr. Gardner could help them invest.\n\n\u201cNothing feels real, it doesn\u2019t feel real,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m ready for crypto assets to go down 90 percent. I\u2019ll feel better then, I think. We learn that the administration holds special animus for what it calls \u201cD.O.J. women,\u201d or women who work in the Justice Department. Wolff writes that after the white supremacist mayhem in Charlottesville, Va., Trump privately rationalized \u201cwhy someone would be a member of the K.K.K.\u201d The book recounts that after the political purge in Saudi Arabia, Trump boasted that he and Kushner engineered a coup: \u201cWe\u2019ve put our man on top!\u201d\n\nBut most of all, the book confirms what is already widely understood \u2014 not just that Trump is entirely unfit for the presidency, but that everyone around him knows it. One thread running through \u201cFire and Fury\u201d is the way relatives, opportunists and officials try to manipulate and manage the president, and how they often fail. As Wolff wrote in a Hollywood Reporter essay based on the book, over the past year, the people around Trump, \u201call \u2014 100 percent \u2014 came to believe he was incapable of functioning in his job.\u201d\n\nAccording to Wolff, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Reince Priebus, the former chief of staff, called Trump an \u201cidiot.\u201d (So did the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, owner of Fox News, though he used an obscenity first.) Trump\u2019s chief economic adviser, Gary Cohn, compares his boss\u2019s intelligence to excrement. The national security adviser, H. R. McMaster, thinks he\u2019s a \u201cdope.\u201d It has already been reported that Secretary of State Rex Tillerson called Trump a \u201cmoron,\u201d which he has pointedly refused to deny.\n\nAnd yet these people continue to either prop up or defend this sick travesty of a presidency. Wolff takes a few stabs at the motives of Trump insiders. Ivanka Trump apparently nurtured the ghastly dream of following her father into the presidency. Others, Wolff writes, told themselves that they could help protect America from the president they serve: The \u201cmess that might do serious damage to the nation, and, by association, to your own brand, might be transcended if you were seen as the person, by dint of competence and professional behavior, taking control of it.\u201d\n\nThis is a delusion as wild, in its own way, as Trump\u2019s claim that the \u201cAccess Hollywood\u201d tape was faked. Some of the military men trying to steady American foreign policy amid Trump\u2019s whims and tantrums might be doing something quietly decent, sacrificing their reputations for the greater good. But most members of Trump\u2019s campaign and administration are simply traitors. They are willing, out of some complex mix of ambition, resentment, cynicism and rationalization, to endanger all of our lives \u2014 all of our children\u2019s lives \u2014 by refusing to tell the country what they know about the senescent fool who boasts of the size of his \u201cnuclear button\u201d on Twitter.\n\nMaybe, at the moment, people in the Trump orbit feel complacent because a year has passed without any epic disaster, unless you count an estimated 1,000 or so deaths in Puerto Rico, which they probably don\u2019t. There\u2019s an old joke, recently cited by Josh Marshall of Talking Points Memo, that describes where we are right now: A guy falls from a 50-story building. Worker Accused of Stealing Trove of Secrets Offers to Plead Guilty", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Khuzami, 61, a Brooklyn native, has been a partner in the law firm of Kirkland & Ellis, based in its Washington office, since leaving the S.E.C. in 2013.\n\nWhile a prosecutor in the Southern District from 1990 to 2002, Mr. Khuzami met and worked with Mr. Berman, who also began in that office in 1990. The two men have remained close friends, Mr. Khuzami has said.\n\nIn 1995, when Mary Jo White was the United States attorney, Mr. Khuzami was a member of the team that won the convictions of an Egyptian sheikh, Omar Abdel Rahman, and a group of other men who had plotted to blow up the United Nations, the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, and other city landmarks.\n\nHe also served for three years as the head of the Southern District\u2019s security and commodities fraud task force.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
