Finds No Evidence of Workplace Misconduct", "authors": ["Peter Libbey"]} {"date": "2018-01-30 00:00:00", "text": "SAN FRANCISCO \u2014 Want to get rich quick through Bitcoins or other virtual currencies? You\u2019ll have to do it without Facebook.\n\nThe social network said Tuesday that it would ban all ads for Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, in order to stop promotions that it sees as \u201cfrequently associated with misleading or deceptive promotional practices.\u201d\n\nUnder Facebook\u2019s new policy, no ads from well-known digital currency exchanges or for initial coin offerings will be allowed. Among those who will be affected is James Altucher, a self-described \u201ccrypto genius\u201d whose viral ads have become a talking point in how the cryptocurrency boom has led to scams and wild price fluctuations.", "title": "Facebook Bans Ads for Bitcoin and Other Cryptocurrencies", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "It\u2019s easy to find similarly blunt statements from Silicon Valley leaders. For example, when a French official described her determination to encourage tech innovation without extreme income inequality, the venture capitalist Marc Andreessen responded mockingly on Twitter: \u201cCapitalism, without all that messy capitalism!\u201d And when India rejected a proposal from Facebook to introduce a free version of internet access that was limited to Facebook and a small assortment of other sites, Mark Zuckerberg, the company\u2019s chief executive, responded more in sorrow than anger. \u201cHistory tells us that helping people is always a better path then shutting them out,\u201d he explained, gliding past the Indian government\u2019s argument that introducing incomplete access to the internet was a worse path.\n\nBut 2018, it seems, is going to represent what Silicon Valley would call \u201can inflection point\u201d on the morality graph. Facebook is leading the charge, with the announcement last week by Mr. Zuckerberg that the company felt \u201ca responsibility to make sure our services aren\u2019t just fun to use, but also good for people\u2019s well-being.\u201d In practical terms, this means that Facebook will be reducing the amount of so-called public content \u2014 often provocative posts from businesses and news organizations \u2014 in favor of personal content, posts from friends and family.\n\nThe public faces the unsatisfying question: Is it better to suffer an engineer\u2019s neglect or an engineer\u2019s concern?\n\nSince Facebook\u2019s earliest days, Mr. Zuckerberg has been fascinated by the power to understand and manipulate users by applying algorithms to the data it collects. In 2005, speaking at Stanford, he described how he and a friend were \u201cseeing if we could use the information that we had to compute who we thought were going to be in relationships. So, we tested this about a week later, and we realized that we had over a third chance of predicting whether two people were going to be in a relationship a week from now.\u201d Through this deep knowledge of its users, Mr. Zuckerberg explained, Facebook could determine \u201cwhat actually matters to each person on a more granular level.\u201d\n\nMore than a decade later, Facebook is still using these social-engineering tools to probe its users\u2019 psyches. Now, however, the company, which reported $4.7 billion in profits in the third quarter, assures us that these tools will be refashioned to take account of the health of our society. In December, Facebook\u2019s researchers tried to answer the question of whether social networks were a force for good and returned with a split verdict.", "title": "Opinion | Facebook Doesn\u2019t Like What It Sees When It Looks in the Mirror", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "Posts from people you know will rise to the top.\n\nWithout that kind of explicit direction, though, Facebook\u2019s top priority will remain posts from your friends and family.\n\n\u201cTo do this, we will predict which posts you might want to interact with your friends about, and show these posts higher in feed,\u201d Mr. Mosseri wrote. A video attached to his post said that indicators the algorithm takes into account are likes, comments and shares.\n\nFacebook will remain customizable, with the options that allow you to limit your exposure to certain people \u2014 even if those people are your pesky siblings or that one over-the-top uncle. One option is to quietly \u201csnooze\u201d a Facebook friend, which will cause their posts to disappear from your feed for 30 days.\n\nFacebook says that it has long been its policy that \u201cfriends and family come first,\u201d language that appeared in the site\u2019s \u201cNews Feed Values,\u201d which were posted in 2016.\n\nFacebook expects you\u2019ll spend less time on the site.\n\nImplicit in the changes that Facebook introduced this week is that for many users, the News Feed had become mindless scrolling, moving from one autoplaying video to the next, without offering people much of substance. It was serving up junk food.\n\nIn an interview with The New York Times, Mark Zuckerberg said that it was the company\u2019s expectation that many users would be gravitating to other sites to get their viral fix. But with more than two billion monthly users, Facebook has gained a foothold that allows it to play a longer game. And Mr. Zuckerberg said that if people begin to feel better while on the site, that Facebook\u2019s business, and its users, will benefit.\n\n\u201cI expect the time people spend on Facebook and some measures of engagement will go down,\u201d he said in his post about the changes. \u201cBut I also expect the time you do spend on Facebook will be more valuable.\u201d", "title": "Facebook Is Changing. What Does That Mean for Your News Feed?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "The change may also work against Facebook\u2019s immediate business interests. The company has long pushed users to spend more time on the social network. With different, less viral types of content surfacing more often, people could end up spending their time elsewhere. Mr. Zuckerberg said that was in fact Facebook\u2019s expectation, but that if people end up feeling better about using the social network, the business will ultimately benefit.\n\nChanges to Facebook\u2019s News Feed are not new. The Silicon Valley company constantly experiments with what shows up in the News Feed, and in the past it has also said it would prioritize posts from users\u2019 friends and family. But Thursday\u2019s shift goes beyond previous changes by prioritizing posts that have generated substantive interactions. A long comment on a family member\u2019s photo, for instance, might be highlighted in the News Feed above a video that has fewer comments or interactions between people.\n\nFacebook has conducted research and worked with outside academics for months to examine the effects that its service has on people. The work was spurred by criticism from politicians, academics, the media and others that Facebook had not adequately considered its responsibility for what it shows its users.\n\nAfter the 2016 election, for instance, Mr. Zuckerberg initially shrugged off qualms about Facebook\u2019s effect on the outcome, even as outsiders pointed to the proliferation of fake news stories on the site that had attacked Hillary Clinton. Mr. Zuckerberg later said he had been too hasty and dismissive of the concerns. More recently, he began signaling that Facebook was rethinking what it shows people on the site.\n\nLast week, he posted on Facebook about his goals for 2018, including \u201cmaking sure that time spent on Facebook is time well spent\u201d and adding that \u201cthis will be a serious year of self-improvement and I\u2019m looking forward to learning from working to fix our issues together.\u201d\n\nOn Thursday, he said many of the discussions about Facebook\u2019s responsibilities had prompted the company \u201cto get a better handle on some of the negative things that could happen in the system.\u201d", "title": "Facebook Overhauls News Feed to Focus on What Friends and Family Share", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "The same criticism has also engulfed other social media companies such as Twitter, which on Friday said it was emailing notifications to 677,775 people in the United States that they had interacted with Russian propaganda accounts around the time of the 2016 election.\n\nFor publishers, Facebook\u2019s new ranking system raised immediate concerns, including whether crowdsourcing users\u2019 opinions on trustworthiness might be open to manipulation.\n\n\u201cIt is absolutely a positive move to start to try to separate the wheat from the chaff in terms of reputation and use brands as proxies for trust,\u201d said Jason Kint, the chief executive of Digital Content Next, a trade group that represents entertainment and news organizations, including The New York Times. \u201cBut the devil\u2019s in the details on how they\u2019re going to actually execute on that.\u201d\n\nHe continued, \u201cHow does that get hacked or gamed? How do we trust the ranking system? There\u2019s a slew of questions at this point.\u201d\n\nThe new system could also potentially favor publishers who are partisan. Facebook users, asked to rank which news they most trust, could choose sites that speak most clearly to their personal beliefs, in effect reducing the prominence of publishers who try to maintain an objective tone.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nDavid Kaye, the United Nations\u2019 Special Rapporteur on freedom of expression, said that Facebook would probably face more difficult questions as it rolled out the new ranking program globally.\n\n\u201cWhat will happen in situations where a community determines that a news source is trustworthy, but that news source is censored, or illegal, in that country?\u201d asked Mr. Kaye, noting that in many parts of the world, governments controlled all official news channels while independent news sources were outlawed or forced to publish pseudo-anonymously.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the past, he added, Facebook has abided by local rules where it operates abroad.\n\n\u201cWhat will Mark Zuckerberg do when the needs of the community, in what it determines is trusted news, are different from what the government determines. Who will Facebook side with?\u201d said Mr. Kaye.\n\nRaju Narisetti, the chief executive of the Gizmodo Media Group, the unit of Univision that operates Jezebel and other sites, said there was a \u201cgreat irony\u201d that Facebook, which has traditionally left decision up to an algorithm that incorporates the behaviors of its members, would open the decision-making to its users on such a matter. He added that the user-generated ranking system \u201cis a massive abdication of its social responsibility, as a vital platform, to be a good custodian of the Fourth Estate globally.\u201d\n\nOther experiments that Facebook has tried with news in the past have sometimes gone awry or had unintended consequences. For example, a recent test to remove all news publishers from the News Feed and to place them under a separate tab in six countries, including Bolivia and Slovakia, yielded an unexpected result of magnifying the amount of fake news on the platform.\n\nIn his post on Friday, Mr. Zuckerberg said the newest change \u201cwill only shift the balance of news you see towards sources that are determined to be trusted by the community.\u201d\n\nFacebook said news would be prioritized according to the new ranking system starting Monday, before expanding globally. Some Facebook users have already been asked to rank the trustworthiness of news sites which appear on the social network. In one survey, people were asked if they recognized a number of websites and then asked, \u201c\u201cHow much do you trust each of these domains?\u201d They were able to choose from a range of answers, including entirely, a lot, somewhat, barely and not at all.\n\nThe Silicon Valley company said it would continue polling users to refine and select which news outlets garnered the most trust. It declined to say how many people were polled or which news outlets they were asked about.\n\n\u201cAs part of our ongoing quality surveys, we asked a diverse and representative sample of Facebook users across the U.S. to gauge their familiarity with, and trust in, sources of news,\u201d said Todd Breasseale, a Facebook spokesman. \u201cWe boost links from sources with high trust scores and demote links from sources with low trust scores.\u201d\n\nMr. Zuckerberg has been moving Facebook toward taking more responsibility for what shows up on the social network, especially after the criticism over the 2016 election and the interference by Russian agents. Earlier this month, he described his 2018 goals as including \u201cmaking sure that time spent on Facebook is time well spent.\u201d\n\nIn Friday\u2019s post, he hinted that ranking the credibility of news sources was just one step, with more potential changes to come.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201dI\u2019ve asked our product teams to make sure we prioritize news that is trustworthy, informative, and local,\u201d he wrote. \u201cAnd we\u2019re starting next week with trusted sources.\u201d", "title": "Facebook to Let Users Rank Credibility of News", "authors": ["Sheera Frenkel", "Sapna Maheshwari"]} {"date": "2018-01-17 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 Facebook said on Wednesday it was reopening and broadening an internal investigation into the possibility that Russia had used the platform to influence the British vote to leave the European Union.\n\nReports that the Kremlin had used Facebook and other social media to try to sway elections in the United States, France and other countries have raised widespread suspicions that it had played the same game in the June 2016 British referendum. Russia has long viewed the European Union as a threat, and promoting the groups that favored Britain\u2019s leaving would be one way to weaken the bloc.\n\nBut the possibility of Russian interference has threatened to further complicate the torturous negotiations with Brussels over Britain\u2019s departure, known as Brexit, by undermining the credibility of the referendum.\n\nAfter the British Parliament asked Facebook, Twitter and other social media companies last year for information on any Russian efforts to sway the vote, Facebook said in December that it had found no evidence of manipulation.", "title": "Facebook to Take Broader Look at Possible Russian Role in Brexit Vote", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-28 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cFacebook Doesn\u2019t Like What It Sees in the Mirror\u201d (Op-Ed, Jan. 17): If Facebook wants to take a more morally enlightened, responsible approach to social engagement, as Noam Cohen suggests is desirable, it can start by revising its algorithm. Facebook\u2019s recent overhaul of its News Feed that prioritizes what family members and friends share may simply reinforce what users already believe.\n\nA constructive step to bolster the social tolerance that underpins a robust society would be to provide users with more exposure to divergent opinions. Facebook could do this by changing its algorithm so that it increases the weight assigned to posts that provide dissonant information \u2014 messages that offer a different social viewpoint than the user holds. For example, if a user usually likes liberal posts, Facebook could configure it so that a conservative post gets prominent play in the News Feed.\n\nBy presenting an information environment with greater exposure to positions that challenge an individual\u2019s attitudes, Facebook could increase open-mindedness, in keeping with Mark Zuckerberg\u2019s aim of \u201cadvancing human potential.\u201d\n\nRICHARD M. PERLOFF, CLEVELAND\n\nThe writer is a professor of communication and political science at Cleveland State University.", "title": "Opinion | Facebook\u2019s News Feed: Add Some Dissonance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "Facial exercises may significantly reduce some of the signs of aging, according to an interesting new study of the effects of repeating specific, expressive movements on people\u2019s appearance.\n\nThe study, published in JAMA Dermatology, found that middle-aged women looked about three years younger after a few months of exercising, perhaps providing a reasonable, new rationale for making faces behind our spouses\u2019 backs.\n\nAs all of us regrettably know, the human face changes with age. It begins to accumulate the grooves and wrinkles that connote either lengthening years or deepening character, depending on your viewpoint, and also starts, almost invariably, to sag.\n\nThis sagging occurs in large part because the fat pads that underlie the skin on our faces thin with age. When we are young, these pads snuggle together like Lego pieces, providing much of the structure of the contours of our faces. But as the pads change with age, their connections loosen and gravity draws them downward, leaving cheeks hollowed and visages generally droopier.", "title": "Facial Exercises May Make You Look 3 Years Younger", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "The Tab\u00e0rnia initiative went viral on social media shortly after Dec. 21, when Catalonia\u2019s separatist parties retained their narrow parliamentary majority, winning 70 of the 135 seats in the Catalan Parliament, in a snap election called by Mariano Rajoy, Spain\u2019s prime minister.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhile the vote was a setback for Mr. Rajoy, whose own Popular Party finished last in the regional election, it also confirmed the split within Catalan society and left the separatist parties with an uphill struggle to form a new government.\n\nOn Tuesday, Catalan lawmakers are to decide whether to re-elect Carles Puigdemont as president. He was removed from office by Mr. Rajoy in October, after he and other separatist lawmakers declared unilateral independence. Mr. Puigdemont then left for Belgium and has since refused to return to Spain to face prosecution for rebellion.\n\nMr. Rajoy\u2019s government is counting on Spain\u2019s judiciary to stop Mr. Puigdemont\u2019s political return. Should Mr. Puigdemont be re-elected, Mr. Rajoy warned that he could extend Madrid\u2019s direct rule over Catalonia, using the same emergency powers that forced Mr. Puigdemont\u2019s ouster three months ago.\n\nOn Saturday evening, members of Spain\u2019s Constitutional Court voted unanimously that Mr. Puigdemont would need to appear in person in the Catalan Parliament to be sworn in.\n\nWhile the separatist lawmakers are struggling to form a new government without incurring more sanctions from Madrid, Tab\u00e0rnia\u2019s mock president, Albert Boadella, was elected unopposed.\n\nIn the waning years of the Franco dictatorship, Mr. Boadella was a co-founder of Els Joglars, a theater company that used mime and comedy to challenge censorship under Franco\u2019s regime. Since 2006, however, Mr. Boadella has refused to produce a play in Catalonia, after suffering what he called a campaign of hatred for helping launch Ciudadanos, or Citizens, a staunchly anti-secession party that has grown into a national political force.\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the December vote in Catalonia, Ciudadanos won a quarter of the votes, making it the largest single party in the Catalan assembly. But Ciudadanos is leading the opposition, not trying to form a government, because the three separatist parties won a combined 47.5 percent of the vote, enough to give them a majority, under a voting system that favors their dominance in rural areas.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Boadella accuses the separatists of pushing Catalonia toward \u201cthe most absolute ruin.\u201d He is beginning his mock term as president of Tab\u00e0rnia in a self-imposed exile because \u201cthis territory has become insufferable for the lovers of liberty and good humor.\u201d\n\nEven if Tab\u00e0rnia is a lighthearted pushback against the separatists, Mr. L\u00f3pez Alegre noted that the Spanish Constitution, which forbids unilateral secession, does allow the creation of new autonomous regions.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd while Tab\u00e0rnia highlights the opposition to secession in and around two of Catalonia\u2019s largest cities, residents of the Val d\u2019Aran, a tiny mountainous community along the border between France and Catalonia, have also been warning that they could break away if Catalonia seceded from Spain.\n\nPere Rusi\u00f1ol, a co-founder of Mongolia, a magazine of political satire, sees Tab\u00e0rnia as \u201can interesting provocation to underline the contradictions of Catalan nationalism.\u201d But if Tab\u00e0rnia ever became a serious political project, there could be \u201ca real danger of Balkanization,\u201d he said, even perhaps like the violent breakup of the former Yugoslavia. \u201cWhat is a game would then look scary,\u201d Mr. Rusi\u00f1ol warned.\n\nFor the separatists, however, Tab\u00e0rnia is an irrelevant case of sour grapes, coming after an election that failed to yield the decisive blow to Catalonia\u2019s independence movement that Mr. Rajoy had anticipated. Tab\u00e0rnia is something like Peter Pan\u2019s \u201cNeverland\u201d for the unionists, said Salvador Garcia Ruiz, the chief executive of Ara, a pro-independence newspaper.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe territorial tensions within Catalonia, he added, are manageable and comparable to those provoked by other heated political debates, like Britain\u2019s referendum on leaving the European Union or the election of President Trump in the United States. \u201cIn democratic countries, such differences are resolved at the ballot boxes,\u201d Mr. Garcia Ruiz said.\n\nTab\u00e0rnia\u2019s theoretical borders would contain two-thirds of Catalonia\u2019s 7.5 million residents. Unlike the Catalan republic that Mr. Puigdemont and other separatists want, Tab\u00e0rnia would swear allegiance to the Spanish monarch, Felipe VI, while using its own flag and coat of arms.\n\nTab\u00e0rnia is a parody, but one that feeds into the debate raised by the Catalan independence movement over \u201cthe limits of the principle of self-determination,\u201d said Manuel Mu\u00f1iz, the dean of the school of international relations at IE University in Madrid.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe mock territory raises the issue of \u201cwho is to vote and when\u201d within a democratic system, Mr. Mu\u00f1iz said. \u201cAre regions the ones entitled to decide on their independence or would cities also qualify? Or should it be neighborhoods within cities?\u201d\n\nSimilar questions, Mr. Mu\u00f1iz said, could apply to \u201cScotland, London and other constituent parts of the U.K. once a slim majority of Brits took the decision to leave the E.U.\u201d\n\nPablo Iglesias, the leader of Podemos, Spain\u2019s far-left party, recently criticized the promoters of Tab\u00e0rnia for fueling a \u201cwar of flags\u201d that he said helps neither Spaniards nor Catalans.\n\nBut Mr. L\u00f3pez Alegre, the spokesman, said the goal was never to fragment Catalonia itself, but instead to try to end what he sees as a disruptive chapter of Catalan secessionism.\n\nTab\u00e0rnia has its own flag and symbols. \u201cActa est fabula,\u201d the Latin saying for the \u201cplay is over,\u201d is the motto on its coat of arms.", "title": "Fake Country Carved From Catalonia Means to Mock Separatism", "authors": ["Raphael Minder"]} {"date": "2018-01-10 00:00:00", "text": "(\u201cFake News\u201d was chosen as the word of the year for 2017 by both the Collins English Dictionary and the American Dialect Society, in case you were wondering.)\n\nThe jeans, which cost $90 and come in gently faded denim with a mid-rise and straight legs, were a trending product on the brand\u2019s website by Tuesday, with 30 percent of the sales originating in the United States. By Wednesday, they were sold out.\n\nStill, not everyone was so thrilled with the idea.\n\nThen some commentators got a little snarky about upset liberals.\n\nPresumably part of the issue is that Topshop, while known for its slogan items (it has sold an average of one slogan T-shirt a minute since September, according to a spokeswoman), is not really known for its political positions, so the jeans smack of bandwagoning as opposed to a call to arms during a sensitive cultural moment.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Open Thread Fashion Newsletter A look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWhether you think the jeans are a travesty or a triumph, however, the truth is that clothes have always been a popular outlet for political positioning, and this is increasingly true in the Trump administration. Mr. Trump is, after all, a president who loves branding of all kinds, is obsessed with image and visual messaging, has an alliterative way with a nickname and whose occasionally garbled use of language (remember covfefe?) has become part of the national lexicon in a way that practically begs a coffee cup.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe flurry has all picked up steam since the presidential campaign, which included fashion statement making and symbolism on both sides: women who dressed up in pantsuits or suffragist white to support Hillary Clinton, and Mr. Trump and his \u201cMake America Great Again\u201d red baseball cap. That particular accessory was adapted late last year by the entrepreneur Elon Musk, who created \u201cBoring Company\u201d black baseball caps to promote his Los Angeles tunnel-drilling initiative.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe fashion runways, too, have been full of messaging. There was Dior\u2019s \u201cWe Should All Be Feminists\u201d T-shirt version of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie\u2019s TED Talk and Prabal Gurung\u2019s all-slogan show finale, with models wearing multiple phrases on their shirts, including \u201cI am an immigrant\u201d and \u201cWe will not be silenced.\u201d During the Globes, Connie Britton wore a shirt with the message \u201cPoverty is Sexist\u201d embroidered across the torso. Last summer, Mrs. Clinton modeled a special T-shirt made to raise money for Planned Parenthood bearing a pointed quote from Mr. Trump that became a cause unto itself: \u201cNasty Woman.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nAll of which suggests that while we can whine all we want about the superficiality of addressing these issues via style, none of this is going away any time soon, and it will probably get more \u2026 well, trendy. We\u2019ve just moved on from tees and hats to pants. The whole wide wardrobe world is now up for word grabs! (How\u2019s that for a tongue twister?)\n\nIt\u2019s only a matter of time before some other clever denim company takes a page from Topshop\u2019s book and realizes that Mr. Trump has recently provided us with yet another gem of a phrase, a version of which is just bound for clothing: Very Stable Jeanius.\n\nCan\u2019t you just see it?", "title": "Fake News Jeans: Travesty or Sign of Our Era?", "authors": ["Vanessa Friedman"]} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThe world of social media has become a de facto public square. Much of our politics and business is conducted there, yet it remains in many ways a kind of Wild West. Today\u2019s report is one of the first to shed light on the machinations taking place in the shadows: a sketchy digital economy where fake accounts known as bots, some modeled on real users, are bought and sold \u2014 the lifeblood of a booming trade in influence and deception.\n\nThe investigation began last March, when Gabriel Dance, a deputy investigations editor at The Times, ran into an old friend, Mark Hansen, at a conference. Mr. Hansen, the director of the Brown Institute for Media Innovation at Columbia University, had been studying the use of bots on social media. He mentioned that Devumi, a company selling social media followers to users hoping to increase their influence (or manufacture its appearance), seemed to be using bots with information, pictures and biographies taken from real users. (Selling followers is ostensibly a violation of the rules of most social media platforms \u2014 Twitter forbids buying followers, retweets or likes, for instance.)\n\nThe Times investigative team was already exploring social media manipulation, \u201cpartly because of the Russia investigation, and reporting into firms like Cambridge Analytica,\u201d said Nicholas Confessore, a reporter for the team, referring to a data company that worked for Donald J. Trump during the presidential campaign and is now under congressional scrutiny. \u201cWe were looking for a way into describing the economy of false influence on social media.\u201d Devumi would be an exemplar of how that economy worked.\n\nTo begin untangling Devumi\u2019s bots from real Twitter users, the Times team purchased tens of thousands of bot followers, including from Devumi itself (25,000 at a cost of $225). The team could then analyze the overlaps in whom the bots were following \u2014 a group so wildly disparate and geographically diverse that there was little chance so many humans were following them all \u2014 and thus begin to track which users were probably paying for them. Combing through those users\u2019 followers led to still more bots, who led the team to yet more users. The result, Mr. Confessore said, was a \u201cworld of fake accounts that were interconnected.\u201d Millions of them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOn an account-by-account basis, it can be very difficult to tell if something\u2019s a bot,\u201d Mr. Dance said. \u201cSome things are just weird. There are weird people.\u201d On the aggregate, however, certain tellingly inorganic patterns become apparent. So Mr. Hansen of Columbia University, along with the graphics editor Richard Harris and Jeremy Ashkenas, formerly of The Times, developed software that would pull data from Twitter that the team could then analyze. Thousands of accounts all simultaneously deciding to follow the same real Twitter user, for example, was \u201ca very strong indicator of centralized control,\u201d Mr. Harris said. \u201cAnd so we had this process that we called fingerprinting, which allowed us to pretty easily look at someone\u2019s Twitter account and determine whether they had artificial followers or not.\u201d", "title": "Faked: The Headquarters. The Followers. The Influence?", "authors": ["Ed Winstead"]} {"date": "2018-01-07 00:00:00", "text": "In an on-field interview after the game, Matt Ryan laughed when asked how the game had compared to the Falcons\u2019 difficult season.\n\n\u201cThis game was kind of the way our season\u2019s been: tough,\u201d he said. \u201cWe had to grind it out.\u201d\n\nRyan completed 21 of 30 passes for 218 yards, doing his best to deal with tremendous pressure created by Aaron Donald, the Rams\u2019 dominant defensive tackle. Most of Atlanta\u2019s damage came from its running game, which ground down the clock once the lead was built. The strategy let the Falcons dominate time of possession, 37 minutes 34 seconds compared with 22:26 for Los Angeles.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. N.F.L. rules explicitly state that a teammate may not lift a ball carrier to continue his forward progress, but the penalty is rarely called, and the Rams did not challenge the touchdown.\n\nColeman added 40 yards as the Falcons combined for 39 carries for 124 yards. That helped set up plenty of opportunities for Jones, who had nine catches for 94 yards. It was a rare red-zone touchdown by Jones in the fourth quarter that iced the victory.\n\nThe loss by the Rams ended a remarkable turnaround year in which the team improved by seven wins from last season, while its offense went from the worst in the N.F.L. to the most potent.\n\nThere were flashes of that offensive brilliance on Saturday night, with quarterback Jared Goff having a strong game after a silent first quarter. Todd Gurley II, who led the N.F.L. in yards from scrimmage, averaged 7.2 yards a carry on his way to 101 rushing yards, and receivers Robert Woods and Cooper Kupp had their share of highlight-reel plays.\n\nBut the Falcons, who had preceded the Rams as the league\u2019s top-scoring team, had more to offer on both sides of the ball, and they will move on to face the top-seeded Philadelphia Eagles in the divisional round.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe ghosts of the Super Bowl collapse could hardly be exorcised by one playoff win, but the perseverance the Falcons showed in Los Angeles should give them something to build on.", "title": "Falcons Hang On Against the Rams for a Tough Playoff Win", "authors": ["Benjamin Hoffman"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nRock isn\u2019t dead \u2014 at least not this week, as Fall Out Boy opens at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Louder Newsletter Every week, stay on top of the latest in pop and jazz with reviews, interviews, podcasts and more from The New York Times music critics. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cMania\u201d (Island), the band\u2019s seventh studio album, became its fourth record to reach the top of the chart, and its third in a row, with the equivalent of 130,000 sales in the United States, according to Nielsen.\n\nOf those, 117,000 were made as copies of the full album \u2014 a high proportion, as streaming increasingly takes over. The United States has been the world leader in these categories for so long that we have stopped believing it could be any other way. But other nations, seeing us lose focus, are seizing the chance to rise.\n\nScientific and technological leadership doesn\u2019t happen by accident. It results from an open political and competitive economic system, from a commitment to recruit and train top talent from all social and economic levels, and from sustained investment. Since World War II, federal investment in research has been a key to keeping the United States at the forefront. Federal dollars have enabled scientists and engineers to investigate advanced ideas and the most unlikely technical solutions, to develop new knowledge before it\u2019s clear whether it will be profitable. That new knowledge has revolutionized health care, spawned new businesses and created the digital world. As President Ronald Reagan put it, \u201calthough basic research does not begin with a particular practical goal,\u201d it\u2019s \u201cone of the most practical things government does.\u201d\n\nOther nations understand this and are aggressively challenging our lead by trying to copy the United States model. They are making scientific investment a priority and are pushing for partnerships between government, universities and industry.\n\nChina is the clearest example. Since 2000, China\u2019s spending on research and development has grown by an average of 18 percent each year, while ours grew by only 4 percent. This has placed China a decisive second in R & D expenditures behind the United States, where the government and private sector together invest far more than any other country. Even so, the share of R & D funded by the federal government declined to about 25 percent from just over 30 percent from 2010 to 2015.", "title": "Opinion | Falling Short on Science", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Now, as he tries to force North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons capability and ensure that Iran never acquires one, Mr. Trump is poised to make public a new policy that commits America to an increasing investment in those very weapons, according to a draft document made public by HuffPost and confirmed by The Times.\n\nA major departure in the new policy is the plan to build new low-yield nuclear weapons. The rationale is that most modern weapons are so powerful that no one believes they will ever be used, so lower-explosive warheads are needed to maintain an effective deterrent. This logic is insane.\n\nThe United States already has immense nuclear and conventional capabilities, and experts say there is no evidence these so-called more usable low-yield nuclear weapons will force adversaries to behave better. Enlarging the United States arsenal will certainly lead other countries to seek equivalent arsenals of their own, while also raising the odds that weapons fall into terrorists\u2019 hands and heightening the risk of accidental war. Investing huge sums this way is also unlikely to protect us from tomorrow\u2019s threats.\n\nThe administration, however, would have us believe that America is falling behind in military capability. Mr. Trump was compelled to act, the document argues, primarily because of Russia\u2019s \u201cunabashed return to Great Power competition,\u201d including modernization of its nuclear weaponry. Russia is unquestionably a growing problem that needs to be confronted, but that\u2019s a cynical rationale for a president who so far has refused to acknowledge the Kremlin\u2019s interference in the 2016 election or its threat more generally to Western democracies.\n\nMaking matters worse, Mr. Trump, in a separate decision on Friday, continued to put the 2015 deal that froze Iran\u2019s nuclear program in jeopardy. The president warned European allies that they must agree to overhaul the deal in 120 days, or he would withdraw the United States from it. Although he again stopped short of reimposing sanctions, his demands would effectively require renegotiating the deal, something the other parties to the agreement have refused to do.", "title": "Opinion | False Alarm Adds to Real Alarm About Trump\u2019s Nuclear Risk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-14 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThis story isn\u2019t going to go away,\u201d Mr. Moore said. \u201cIt\u2019s going to haunt his re-election campaign all the way to the August primary. Everyone is going to want to talk about their story \u2014 that morning when they were terrified, and why it took the governor so long to respond.\u201d\n\nMr. Ige issued a statement on Sunday apologizing again for the bungled alert. \u201cI can personally assure each and every resident and visitor that steps have already been taken by the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency to ensure that a situation of this type never happens again,\u201d he said.\n\nAcross Hawaii on Sunday, people spoke about gathering their families for what they thought would be their last moments, until the \u201cfalse alarm\u201d announcement went out.\n\n\u201cWhy did it take so long to correct the mistake?\u201d said Jamie Higa, 34, a real estate agent. \u201cWhoever is responsible clearly failed to do his job. The governor isn\u2019t directly responsible for what happened, but he is our top elected official.\u201d\n\nRepresentative Colleen Hanabusa, who is challenging Mr. Ige in the Democratic primary in August, repeatedly questioned in an interview why it took so long for the alert to be rescinded.\n\n\u201cThirty-eight minutes \u2014 and the fear and the anxiety and everything that it caused for the people and for our visitors,\u201d she said. \u201cThis is going to have a major consequence for our visitor industry as well. Either people think we are incompetent, or we are not safe.\u201d\n\n\u201cThe governor and his administration did not handle this correctly,\u201d she continued. \u201cYou cannot have people driving 100 miles an hour on the freeway and having visitors shelter in place. Immediately, what he should have done is checked and verified whether it is real or not real, and if it was not real, tell people immediately, not 38 minutes later.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Ige\u2019s campaign issued a statement defending his handling of the event and saying that the governor had focused over the last year on ensuring that Hawaii was prepared for an attack, particularly as tensions rose between North Korea and the United States. A missile launched from North Korea would land in Honolulu in about 30 minutes, giving people very little time to prepare.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThis is an inappropriate time to involve politics with the matter at hand,\u201d said Glenna Wong, the communications director for the campaign. \u201cGov. David Ige has the utmost compassion for our citizens who endured yesterday\u2019s fear and heartache, and has assured each and every resident, community and business stakeholders, and visitors that a false alert will never happen again.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt is unfortunate that she is using yesterday\u2019s event to draw attention to herself while offering no solution,\u201d she said of Ms. Hanabusa.\n\nThe governor\u2019s aides said the state moved quickly to inform people that it was a false alarm in posts on Twitter and on Facebook. They blamed the delay in sending out a second alert on a flaw in the state emergency system: It had no process for recalling an erroneous message. That is now being changed, they said, and two people must now approve an alert before it is sent out.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAs the crisis rose and receded in less than an hour Saturday, other officials in the state were quicker \u2014 and more visible \u2014 than the governor in trying to reassure a panicked public, including Ms. Hanabusa and Hawaii\u2019s other representative, Tulsi Gabbard, who is also a Democrat.\n\n\u201cHis challenger was on air with a local television station before he was,\u201d said Rebecca S. Ward, who conducts polls in the state for The Honolulu Star-Advertiser. \u201cThe governor has come under fire in the past for lack of leadership. And I\u2019m afraid that yesterday reinforced that. I think there\u2019s no question but that this is going to be a major hurdle for him in this re-election.\u201d\n\nTim Hart, 58, a construction worker spending Sunday on a beach in Kona, said he faulted Mr. Ige for keeping a low profile.\n\n\u201cThe governor really didn\u2019t do much until hours and hours after the fact,\u201d he said. \u201cTulsi Gabbard got the bull by the horns and in less than 10 minutes, she was tweeting.\u201d\n\nNeil Abercrombie, the previous governor, whom Mr. Ige defeated in a Democratic primary in 2014, called the episode \u201ca monumental example of failure of leadership \u2014 incredible.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s beyond incompetent,\u201d he said. \u201cIt is stunning. It should have been rescinded instantly.\u201d\n\nAs officials tried to reconstruct exactly what happened on Saturday, a spokesman for the Pacific Command in Hawaii said the military had moved quickly to push back against the Hawaii state alert as soon as it was known to be incorrect.\n\n\u201cUpon confirming yesterday\u2019s message was a false alarm, Uspacom Public Affairs worked quickly to inform the public through traditional and social media channels,\u201d Cmdr. David Benham, a military spokesman, said in an email Sunday, using an acronym for the Pacific Command. \u201cWe will use this as an opportunity to improve our internal processes as well as coordination with State authorities. \u201c\n\nThe Pacific Command first told Hawaii media that there was no approaching ballistic missile at 8:23 a.m. \u2014 about 13 minutes after Hawaii sent out the alert.\n\nHawaii\u2019s economy depends heavily on tourism. Ms. Hanabusa\u2019s concern that the false alarm might discourage people from visiting the islands was shared by state tourism officials.\n\nGeorge D. Szigeti, the president of the Hawaii Tourism Authority, called the mistake \u2014 which sent terrified tourists searching for shelter \u2014 \u201cregrettable and completely avoidable.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere is no cause for travelers with trips already booked to Hawaii or considering a vacation in the islands to change their plans,\u201d he said. \u201cHawaii continues to be the safest, cleanest and most welcoming travel destination in the world, and the alarm created today by the false alert does not change that at all.\u201d", "title": "False Missile Alert Looms as a Black Eye for Hawaii and Its Governor", "authors": ["Adam Nagourney"]} {"date": "2018-01-13 00:00:00", "text": "Federal, state, and local officials must work together to identify vulnerabilities to false alerts and fix them, he added. \u201cWe also must ensure that corrections are issued immediately in the event that a false alert does go out,\u201d Mr. Pai said.\n\nJessica Rosenworcel, an F.C.C. commissioner, also expressed concern about the system\u2019s failure. \u201cEmergency alerts are meant to keep us and our families safe, not to create false panic,\u201d she wrote on Twitter. \u201cWe must investigate and we must do better.\u201d\n\nThe episode appeared to be the Wireless Emergency Alerts system\u2019s most serious misfire since it became operational in 2012 to modernize America\u2019s decades-old approach of using television and radio to notify the public about impending weather, safety and other hazards.\n\nFederal officials said then that the near ubiquity of mobile phones made them the most effective means for warning of hurricanes, terrorist threats and missing persons. Emergency alerts are still broadcast via TV, radio and air siren, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.\n\nPhoto\n\nArriving with distinct ringtones and vibrations, the wireless alerts resemble text messages when they pop up on cellphone screens, but they rely on different technology. All wireless carriers participate in the system, and Hawaii\u2019s emergency agency is among hundreds of federal, state, local, tribal and territorial authorities with the power to use them, according to FEMA.\n\nThere are three types of wireless alerts: those issued by the president; those involving imminent threats to safety or life; and Amber Alerts for missing children. More than 30,000 alerts have been sent since the system\u2019s introduction, according to the communications commission. In 2016, law enforcement officials in New York used the system to circulate a kind of digital wanted poster in hunting for a man wanted in bombings in Manhattan and New Jersey. The alerts are free; consumers can use their phone settings to opt out of getting all but those sent by the president.\n\nThe system has come under growing scrutiny in recent months, with public safety officials complaining that it requires upgrades on several fronts. Critics say alerts are often sent too widely, sowing fear among people unlikely to be affected by the threat in question. There have also been calls for the alerts to be sent in languages other than English. The communications commission has approved some changes, but they will not take effect until next year.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nLast month, officials from Harris County, Tex., met with commission officials about their frustration over how, during Hurricane Harvey, they could not pinpoint alerts to area residents most likely to be affected by the storm without alarming a broader swath of the county.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe commission, which sets the technical standards for the alerts, is under pressure to update its rules to force wireless carriers and phone makers to work together to ensure that the system is more effective. Last week, Mr. Pai announced a proposal to update the alert system to improve its location-targeting ability.\n\nThe inability to target more precisely the areas facing potential threats has deterred some public safety officials from issuing alerts. Senators Kamala Harris and Dianne Feinstein, Democrats of California, wrote to Mr. Pai in October that state residents had not gotten emergency alerts to leave their homes as wildfires raged nearby because of substandard location-targeting and other technical problems.\n\n\u201cThese emergency services are caught in a bind between notifying individuals in imminent danger and risking mass panic,\u201d the senators wrote in the letter.\n\nBruce G. Blair, a nuclear security expert and a research scholar at the Program on Science and Global Security at Princeton University\u2019s Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, said he immediately suspected that the alert was false because it involved such a significant national security threat that was directed solely at Hawaii.\n\nIf there had been a missile fired toward the United States, military and intelligence officials would have first notified the president, who would have then decided whether to issue a national emergency alert, he said, although he added that it was reasonable to believe that Hawaii, given its proximity to North Korea, would be on heightened alert.\n\nStill, Mr. Blair said, the episode did expose a potential system flaw that has significant implications.\n\n\u201cThis,\u201d he said, \u201cis a system that is hackable and prone to human and technical error.\u201d", "title": "False Missile Warning in Hawaii Adds to Scrutiny of Emergency Alert System", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat cooking traditions do you and your family have? Are there certain types of food or ways of preparing meals that are specific to your family\u2019s way of life or culture? If so, what are they and how does participating in these food rituals make you feel?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to learn how indigenous populations in Canada preserve their heritage through cooking.", "title": "Family Cooking", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-01-26 00:00:00", "text": "Kamilla Benko\u2019s debut, \u201cThe Unicorn Quest,\u201d another first-in-series novel, sneaks a tribalism parable into a Narnia-esque story structure. The book begins with two sisters, Claire and Sophie, exploring the eerie old mansion of their recently deceased great-aunt, so you know it\u2019s only a matter of time before they discover a portal to another world.\n\nThe fantasy kingdom of Arden is a place where magic is intrinsically tied to art, but rather than its citizens finding unity in their shared abilities, they have segregated themselves, geographically and culturally, into four different mini-nations: Forgers (who sculpt mystical metals), Spinners (who can weave threads into man-eating carpets and such), Tillers (who would all score an A+ on a Hogwarts herbology exam) and Gemmers (who have power over rocks and jewels). And it\u2019s more extreme than just Blue State-Red State rancor. The Ardenites are hard core about these divisions: One young character\u2019s father was executed because of her parents\u2019 mixed marriage. Some of the groups will grudgingly do business with one another, but for the most part, Arden is isolationism run amok. And no group is more universally reviled than the Gemmers, the former ruling class who infamously committed atrocities against their own people. When one character discovers ancestors in the Gemmer bloodline, the reaction has the horror of a progressive activist who learns there are slave owners in his family tree.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIt\u2019s the appearance of Claire and Sophie that serves as a catalyst for change in Arden. When the girls uncover a dangerous conspiracy, it will once again take members from different magical guilds to unite as a team and prevent the resurrection of a legendary queen. (Different queen, this time \u2014 no ants.) Benko does a stellar job of painting Arden for the reader (the battlements on a castle are \u201ccut like jack-o\u2019-lantern teeth,\u201d for instance) and clearly delineates the distinct cultural elements of the different guilds, like the smoke-scented streets of a Forger town and the vine-coated walls of a Tiller home. Also clear is how much more wonderful this world would be if these cultures were ever allowed to mingle.\n\nThe true heart of this book, though, is the relationship between Sophie and Claire. Sophie, the older and bolder of the two sisters, has recently recovered from a mysterious illness and lengthy hospital stay, leaving Claire to both hero-worship her older sibling and fret about her like a helicopter parent. And when the sisters find themselves separated, it is Claire\u2019s dedication to and need for her older sibling that drives her on her quest.\n\nRather than pitting groups against one another, Catherine Gilbert Murdock (\u201cDairy Queen,\u201d \u201cPrincess Ben\u201d) presents an anti-discrimination tale with a much more individual focus in her Dark Ages fable, \u201cThe Book of Boy.\u201d The central character, known only as Boy, lives a life harder than most, which is saying a lot, since the story is set during the Black Death. In addition to all the standard hardships you\u2019d expect for an impoverished medieval orphan, Boy must also endure being the constant target of rage, ridicule and fear. Terms like \u201cthing,\u201d \u201cfiend,\u201d \u201cmonster\u201d and \u201chunchback\u201d are thrown at him regularly. Saddest of all, Boy takes these insults to heart. Despite the sweetness and selflessness that is so obvious to the reader, Boy thinks of himself as a mistake \u2014 something made \u201cwrong\u201d \u2014 and wishes for nothing more than to be a \u201creal boy.\u201d\n\nThen along comes Secundus, an ersatz pilgrim with a mysterious past who recruits the na\u00efve and overly trusting Boy to assist him in liberating (i.e., \u201cstealing\u201d) holy relics so he can use them as a bargaining chip to get into heaven. (The book is firmly rooted in Christian lore.) Secundus is the first person to recognize that there\u2019s more to Boy than the hump between his shoulders \u2014 like preternatural agility and the apparent ability to communicate with animals. The adventure the two embark on features thrilling chases, many comic observations from Boy (a sheep, for instance, described as a \u201cwet, smelly cloud\u201d), and more fart references than one might expect in a religious allegory. And the climactic revelation of Boy\u2019s true nature is a genuinely surprising twist.\n\nBut \u201cThe Book of Boy\u201d runs into pitfalls. Readers who feel bullied or excluded for being \u201cdifferent\u201d may heavily invest in Boy\u2019s internal debate over whether to hide his true self. This goes double for kids with disabilities or those who are gender nonconforming, as those are two specific points about which Boy is taunted. Unfortunately, the artistically ambiguous ending gives no explicit answer to the question. While Boy ultimately learns to love himself for who he is, we never quite get the assurance that anyone else in his cruel world will. Will Boy have to be content with a future in which he can be his real self only in private? It\u2019s open to interpretation. Yet surely many kids could benefit from having this answer spelled out for them. Perhaps the main lesson here is to remember that one person\u2019s uplifting finale can be a major downer to someone else.", "title": "Fantasies for Young Readers, With an Eye on Today\u2019s Fears and Divisions", "authors": ["Christopher Healy", "Children S Books"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "Farhad: Hey, \u201cSpectre\u201d was James Bond. And apparently there are a handful of movies called \u201cMeltdown,\u201d including a 2014 zombie comedy.\n\nBut let\u2019s get back to computer bugs. So as serious as these flaws are, they\u2019re of biggest concern to cloud service providers \u2014 that is, companies like Amazon, Microsoft and Google, which let other companies host their data in enormous data centers. As The Verge explains, the bugs in theory allow data to leak from one hosted account to another \u2014 basically raising questions about the security of hosting your stuff in the cloud.\n\nObviously these bugs aren\u2019t going to kill the cloud, but it does point to the concern of centralization online. Now that we have these huge companies running the internet, they\u2019re going to become the biggest targets for attackers.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? I think the thing that worries me here is that a software patch to fix Meltdown could result in slowing your computer down by as much as 30 percent, which is nuts! Can you imagine how long it will take me to tweet insults at you after that?\n\nAnd as for Spectre, fixing the issue could actually require redesigning how computer chips are built. This whole thing has the big tech companies freaked out, from chip makers like AMD and Intel to software giants like Google and Microsoft. And honestly, they should be. People should probably be more worried about this than they appear to be, but it\u2019s difficult to convey a sense of urgency about complicated technical issues when the president of the United States is tweeting about the possibility of nuclear war.\n\nSocial Media Is Still Wild\n\nMike: And that might not even be the weirdest thing on the internet this week. Social media superstar Logan Paul stepped in it big time, posting a video of himself stumbling upon a person who had killed themselves in Japan\u2019s \u201cSuicide Forest.\u201d His discovery was an accident, but the posting and presentation \u2014 he and his entourage treated the whole thing as a kind of a thrilling spectacle \u2014 were entirely Mr. Paul\u2019s choices, and they were terrible. The internet rightly flew into an outrage almost immediately after he posted the video to YouTube, and eventually Mr. Paul pulled down the clip and apologized to his fans and the dead man\u2019s family.\n\nFarhad: Oh, that\u2019s interesting, Mike, but before you go any further let me just ask one small thing: Who? Logan Paul? I\u2019ve never heard of him and I\u2019m certainly not a subscriber to every one of his channels, definitely not.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMike: Er, O.K. But seriously, the whole thing really sours me on the internet and vlogging culture writ large. To me, it\u2019s a prime example of how social media stars and lifestyle bloggers seem to lose perspective on what\u2019s appropriate to share. When your entire success is based on capturing every moment of your daily life, it might be more difficult to step back and say, \u201cHey, maybe sharing this would be completely insensitive?\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s more worrisome is that this sharing culture seems to be fast becoming normalized and ubiquitous, advanced by the many tools we have at our disposal to put more of ourselves online. Even slayings and suicides have been live streamed. And the ability to attach these things to massive social networks means everyone has a built-in, captive audience.\n\nIn short, Black Mirror isn\u2019t so much a satire anymore \u2014 it\u2019s basically a reality show.\n\nFarhad: I think this story presents a growing issue for YouTube. If 2017 was the year that everyone noticed the dangers of Facebook \u2014 prompting Mark Zuckerberg to announce that he\u2019s spending this year trying to fix the platform \u2014 I suspect our attention will now increasingly shift to YouTube.\n\nIt\u2019s becoming the world\u2019s biggest platform for information, its influence surpassing even Facebook\u2019s. How YouTube polices itself \u2014 how it\u2019s aiming to improve the place, and the backlash its efforts generate \u2014 is probably going to be one of the bigger stories of the year, I\u2019d guess.\n\nBut that\u2019s too heavy for the new year. I\u2019m going to go watch \u201cMeltdown.\u201d\n\nMike: Don\u2019t forget to take a selfie with the TV. Ta ta for now!\n\nFarhad Manjoo writes a weekly technology column called State of the Art. You can follow them on Twitter here: @fmanjoo and @MikeIsaac", "title": "Farhad and Mike\u2019s Week in Tech: Another Huge Security Flaw", "authors": ["Farhad Manjoo", "Mike Isaac"]} {"date": "2018-01-12 00:00:00", "text": "We should probably get used to such slim pickings at CES. As I\u2019ve been saying for a while now, traditional \u201cgadgets\u201d seem to be dying. We saw more evidence of that trend this week when GoPro, the extreme-camera company, lowered its revenue forecast, shut down its effort to build a drone, laid off 20 percent of its staff and said it would be open to a sale.\n\nMore and more gadgets, now, are really run off services or content in the cloud \u2014 Amazon\u2019s Alexa, for instance, or the fitness videos created by Peloton, the fitness start-up I wrote about this week.\n\nOn the other hand: When the self-driving suitcase is perfected, I\u2019m buying one.\n\nTwitter Isn\u2019t Stopping Trump\n\nWhen President Trump tweeted a threat of nuclear war against North Korea this month, it at the very least seemed to constitute a threat of violence that might violate Twitter\u2019s terms of service. The company has lately been trying to crack down on abusive accounts. So some people on Twitter started to wonder, would the company possibly decide that Mr. Trump had crossed the line?\n\nOh, no, not at all. On Monday, Twitter said the tweets of world leaders got special deference from the company; world leaders can now essentially say anything on Twitter. \u201cBlocking a world leader from Twitter or removing their controversial tweets would hide important information people should be able to see and debate,\u201d it said.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI don\u2019t think anyone is surprised by this. And I saw some good arguments for allowing the president to stay on Twitter. As Will Oremus at Slate argued, barring Mr. Trump from the site is a \u201cmisguided fantasy\u201d that wouldn\u2019t really stop the underlying problem of his saying things that many people consider outrageous.\n\nStill, I do think there\u2019s something to the argument that Twitter \u2014 by its very nature a platform meant for people to yell things at the news, usually without nuance \u2014 encourages the sort of reflexive communication that we probably don\u2019t want in our world leaders.\n\nSure, if Twitter barred him, he could always just go on TV and say what he had planned to tweet. But that would be slower and less automatic, and perhaps \u2014 I\u2019m going out on a limb here \u2014 he might not blurt out threats of nuclear war.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nComputer Security Is a Mess, Almost by Design\n\nWe\u2019re still seeing fallout from Meltdown and Spectre, the two big computer chip flaws that were announced last week. Intel said this week that its fixes for the two flaws would slow computers down by single-digit percentages; the exact performance hit depends on what you\u2019re doing on your machine.\n\nThis is a small slowdown, but it\u2019s not insignificant. After all, people buy new computers for speed, so being hit with a slowdown after you\u2019ve already purchased the thing is going to make lots of customers seethe.\n\nThere\u2019s a bigger story here: When technology is found to be insecure, many companies evade any great degree of responsibility for the problems. As Nathaniel Fick, chief executive of the security company Endgame, wrote in The Times, \u201cCybersecurity today is being treated like accounting was before the fallout from the Enron scandal.\u201d There are few lasting repercussions for flaws, and after a time everything goes back to normal. Equifax, for example, has already partly recovered after its massive breach.\n\nUnless the government steps in with stricter penalties, this system seems headed for catastrophe. Everything is interconnected now; it\u2019s only a matter of time until there\u2019s a hack big enough to cause widespread social and economic disruption. We should probably do something about that, maybe?\n\nBig Changes to the News Feed\n\nFinally, in a late-breaking update, Facebook said on Thursday that it would be making huge changes to make you feel less terrible about using the service. It\u2019s an unusual goal for a tech company \u2014 Facebook plans to alter its News Feed to increase your interactions with friends and family and reduce how many posts you see from brands and publishers, all in an attempt to make the service more \u201cmeaningful\u201d for users.\n\nThe move could have wide repercussions for media outlets \u2014 which depend on Facebook for traffic \u2014 and potentially for Facebook\u2019s own bottom line. But as with all Facebook product changes, it will probably be months before we know how the move plays out. One thing is for sure: Initially, you\u2019re bound to hate it, because that\u2019s just how it goes with anything new online.\n\nO.K., that\u2019s it for now. Tune in next week for another Mike-free newsletter. Bye!\n\nFarhad Manjoo writes a weekly technology column called State of the Art. You can follow him on Twitter here: @fmanjoo.", "title": "Farhad\u2019s Week in Tech: A Power Outage at CES, and Facebook Wants to Get \u2018Meaningful\u2019", "authors": ["Farhad Manjoo"]} {"date": "2018-01-19 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nEach Friday, Farhad Manjoo, technology columnist at The New York Times, reviews the week\u2019s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.\n\nGood morning, readers! It was an interesting week in the tech world. Let\u2019s get to the news.\n\nU.S. Apple! U.S. Amazon!\n\nOne thread in the yearlong backlash against the tech industry concerns inequality. Many tech giants are built on scale \u2014 the idea that they can serve billions of customers while employing far fewer people than corporate giants of yore. Those dynamics are good for business, but they don\u2019t make for great optics. There\u2019s a danger that tech C.E.O.s come to be seen as out-of-touch coastal elites.\n\nWell, they want you to know they aren\u2019t.\n\nAmazon is so all-in on America that it wants to open another headquarters here; on Thursday, the company announced the 20 cities that made its cut as possible locations. There\u2019s one city in Canada \u2014 Toronto \u2014 and several coastal enclaves (New York, Washington, Los Angeles), but there\u2019s oh-so-much Middle America here, too. Wherever it ends up is, at this point, almost beside the point; Amazon has won so much positive coverage from the selection process that it can already count the story as a big win.\n\nMeanwhile, in its own very well-designed press release, Apple announced this week that it would bring a historic pile of cash back to America. The company has about $270 billion in cash, but it had parked most of it overseas for tax reasons. Under the new tax code signed into law last year by President Trump, Apple said, it will pay $38 billion in taxes on that money \u2014 the largest tax bill ever paid \u2014 and invest billions in new facilities and people in the United States. The company is also giving many of its employees a $2,500 bonus.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nApple\u2019s announcement made Trump very happy. And the president\u2019s victory lap is, I think, somewhat deserved. Trump and the tech industry have not had the warmest relationship, but it\u2019s clear that his campaign \u2014 in which he constantly harangued Apple and Amazon for perceived slights \u2014 has shaken the industry from its presumption that everyone in the country loves it.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? Now that there\u2019s just so much stuff on Netflix \u2014 so many comedies, so many dramas, so many dumb movies, so many smart movies \u2014 it has become not just another premium cable channel but something like a replacement for TV itself. In other words, it\u2019s indispensable. You can expect to keep paying for it forever.\n\nA Smart, if Tardy, Speaker\n\nRemember HomePod? Probably not. Last summer, Apple unveiled a smart speaker inspired by Amazon\u2019s Echo and Google\u2019s Home, because it is apparently the rule in the tech industry that if one big company does something, every other company has to do it, too. Think Same.\n\nThen, nothing.\n\nA new Apple device is usually a Big Deal event, one of those campaigns that Apple rolls out with the precision of a military conquest. But nobody heard anything more about the HomePod until late November, when Apple announced that the timing had slipped and that HomePod wouldn\u2019t come until after the holidays.\n\nIt was a crucial miss \u2014 the Echo seems to have had a gangbusters holiday, with Amazon expanding its head start in the category by probably tens of millions of devices. In a widely passed-around post, the venture capitalist M. G. Siegler wondered whether Amazon was so far ahead that HomePod was essentially dead on arrival.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nWell, we\u2019ll see. Apple announced this week that HomePod was back in action \u2014 available to order on Friday, and in stores starting Feb. 9.\n\nIt\u2019s still an odd announcement; Apple provided only a short demo of the device in June, so people brave enough to order will be going in blind. But you count Apple out in the hardware business at your peril. It will be fun to see what happens here.\n\nDemocrats vs. Silicon Valley\n\nMy colleagues Cecilia Kang and Daisuke Wakabayashi had an interesting article this week about the growing tensions between the tech industry and the Democratic Party. Democrats and techies have long been reliable allies \u2014 techies donate tons of money, and Democratic candidates get to show off their association with widely admired visionaries of the future.\n\nThat\u2019s past. Now that the tech industry has become more a cause of national angst and confusion rather than of wondrous gadgets and money, Democrats are being called on to police the business more stringently. Lefty activists want antitrust investigations of big tech companies and regulations on political advertising \u2014 a generally more combative relationship between the government and the pursuits of business.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere\u2019s another side to this story, too: While tech C.E.O.s have very publicly sparred with President Trump on a variety of issues, they\u2019re all enjoying a once-in-a-lifetime windfall of profits from the Republican tax plan. As rich people running wealthy companies, the tech industry\u2019s leaders have short-term corporate interests that are obviously very well served by the low-tax, low-regulation Republican Party.\n\nIt\u2019s an election year. It will be interesting to see whether Democrats run against tech, whether tech sticks with Dems and, always, what Trump does with all this.\n\nFarhad Manjoo writes a weekly technology column called State of the Art.
