Credit Vittorio Zunino Celotto/Getty Images for Kering\n\n\u201cWe recognized the economic, social and environmental role of an industry that can sometimes appear trivial,\u201d said Cristiana Falcone-Sorrell, senior adviser to Klaus Schwab, the forum\u2019s chairman. Celebrities have often added some sparkle to the mix (Cate Blanchett and Elton John will be in town this year to accept awards for their service to philanthropy), and luxury brand chief executives have been in the audience, but the fashion industry has never before had such a strong foothold in the agenda.\n\n\u2018We know that the fourth industrial revolution is disrupting fashion as much as it is disrupting other businesses,\u201d Ms. Falcone-Sorrell said, \u201cand that the industry is facing many challenges that need to be tackled in a systemic way.\u201d", "title": "Fashion Topics Get a Spot on the Davos Agenda", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-11 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Taylor, known among the Mot\u00f6rhead faithful as Philthy Animal, died in November 2015 at 61. Mr. Kilmister died a month later at 70.\n\nMr. Clarke occasionally contributed vocals to the group, in addition to his chunky chords and squealing licks and solos. On \u201cBeer Drinkers and Hellraisers,\u201d a ZZ Top cover from a 1980 Mot\u00f6rhead EP, Mr. Clarke traded lines and harmonized with Mr. Kilmister, a strategy they would also employ on the band\u2019s version of \u201cI\u2019m Your Witchdoctor\u201d (originally performed by John Mayall & the Bluesbreakers).\n\n\u201cThe best years of my life were in Mot\u00f6rhead,\u201d Mr. Clarke said in a 2016 interview, \u201cand what we did together I think still stands the test of time.\u201d\n\nMr. Clarke, who was born on Oct. 5, 1950, in Twickenham, a suburb of London, left the band while it was on tour in the United States after the release of \u201cIron Fist\u201d in 1982. He went on to form the two-piece hard-rock group Fastway with the former U.F.O. bassist Pete Way in 1983.\n\nFastway released seven albums, including its 1983 debut, called simply \u201cFastway,\u201d which Mr. Clarke called a personal favorite. \u201cI loved it because it was all my pent-up stuff,\u201d he said. The album \u201cAll Fired Up\u201d was released the next year, and the band would go on to tour with AC/DC.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Clarke reunited intermittently over the years with Mot\u00f6rhead, including in 2000 at a 25th-anniversary concert at Brixton Academy in London. The show was documented on a live DVD titled \u201c25 & Alive Boneshaker.\u201d\n\nPhil Campbell, Mot\u00f6rhead\u2019s guitarist from 1984 to 2015, said in a statement that Mr. Clarke would be remembered for his \u201ciconic riffs\u201d and that he had been a \u201ctrue rock \u2019n\u2019 roller.\u201d\n\nThere was no immediate word on survivors.", "title": "Fast Eddie Clarke, Mot\u00f6rhead Guitarist, Dies at 67", "authors": ["Anna Codrea-Rado"]} {"date": "2018-01-01 00:00:00", "text": "Diagnosing a lung disease like tuberculosis with a urine test may seem illogical, but a group of American researchers is now a step closer to that goal.\n\nScientists at George Mason University have improved by at least 100 times the accuracy of testing for a sugar shed by tuberculosis bacteria, meaning that a simple dipstick urine test may soon become possible.\n\nThe researchers\u2019 study was published last month in Science Translational Medicine.\n\nTuberculosis kills about 1.7 million people a year, according to the World Health Organization \u2014 more than are killed now by AIDS. While many people carry inactive bacteria, about 10 million fall ill annually and develop coughs that transmit the infection.\n\nIf they could be found and treated sooner, more would be cured and the spread would slow.\n\nFor decades, tuberculosis was diagnosed by chest X-rays, skin or blood tests, or by reading sputum samples under a microscope. But the W.H.O. has condemned skin and blood tests as inaccurate, X-rays detect only advanced damage, and microscopy requires trained pathologists.", "title": "Fast, Cheap Testing for Tuberculosis? Soon It May Be Possible", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-09 00:00:00", "text": "The new group will not seek to negotiate contracts as unions do, but its leaders say it will most likely push for a higher minimum wage and for many other issues fast-food workers support, including affordable housing, immigration reform, better police-community relations and improvements to New York\u2019s subway system.\n\nThe Restaurant Law Center \u2014 the legal arm of the National Restaurant Association \u2014 has filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking to overturn the law. Among the center\u2019s arguments is that requiring the restaurant owners to forward money to workers\u2019 groups is unconstitutional forced speech under the First Amendment.\n\n\u201cWe think this law is a way of trying to get restaurants to fund groups\u201d that \u201cwill harass restaurants with money from the restaurants,\u201d said Angelo Amador, the law center\u2019s executive director. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t make any sense.\u201d\n\nWhen the New York City Council passed the law \u2014 which applies only to the fast-food industry \u2014 there were questions about whether an organization could persuade 500 workers to contribute.\n\nBut Janice Fine, associate professor of labor studies at Rutgers University, said: \u201cThe fact that they\u2019ve signed up 1,200 is impressive. It\u2019s a kind of initial proof of the concept.\u201d\n\n\u201cWhen I speak to people in other cities, they get really interested,\u201d she added. \u201cThey can imagine a law like this one where they are.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Fight for $15 campaign and the Service Employees International Union, which has contributed tens of millions to that effort, pushed hard for the New York law. While the Fight for $15 has won major victories \u2014 getting Seattle, California and New York State to enact laws calling for a $15 minimum wage \u2014 the movement has not achieved its goal of unionizing fast-food workers.\n\nFight for $15 leaders are concerned that even if they were to persuade workers at dozens of McDonald\u2019s locations to vote to unionize, it would be extremely difficult to get McDonald\u2019s or its franchise operators to agree to a contract.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWithout a formal union, the Fight for $15 has been eager for a reliable way to finance a fast-food workers\u2019 group. The New York City law, which was enacted in May and took effect in late November, is the first of its kind.\n\n\u201cWhat\u2019s important about this law is it provides for a way for fast-food workers to help sustain a nonprofit organization that\u2019s dedicated to advocating for issues that members say is important to them,\u201d said Tsedeye Gebreselassie, chairwoman of Fast Food Justice\u2019s board and a senior staff attorney at the National Employment Law Project. For example, the group\u2019s leaders said many members were interested in pushing for reduced transit fares for low-wage workers.\n\nFast Food Justice\u2019s leaders say they hope to get 5,000 workers to contribute by the end of 2018, and 10,000 by the end of 2020. (New York City has about 65,000 fast-food workers.) Contributions from 5,000 workers would mean revenue of more than $800,000 a year.\n\nThe Restaurant Law Center\u2019s lawsuit asserts that the New York law and Fast Food Justice are merely mechanisms to help the service employees\u2019 union ultimately unionize fast-food restaurants. Its lawsuit also argues that the law should be overturned on the basis that the National Labor Relations Act already regulates labor organizations.\n\nFast Food Justice asserts that it is not the type of labor organization regulated by federal law. It also argues that the New York law doesn\u2019t violate restaurants\u2019 First Amendment rights because the money being forwarded belongs to the workers and not the restaurants. But the Restaurant Law Center says even having to process the payments violates employers\u2019 free-speech rights.\n\nEven though LaShawn Herbert said her employer, Shake Shack, treats her well, she is a strong backer of the Fight for $15 and Fast Food Justice. She noted that when the Fight for $15 started in New York City in late 2012, the minimum wage was $7.25 in the city. Since then, it has jumped to $13.50 for fast-food workers and will rise to $15 at the end of this year.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s come a long way,\u201d she said. \u201cThe whole point is help people so they can make enough take care of their family and so they don\u2019t have to be on welfare.\u201d", "title": "Fast-Food Workers Claim Victory in a New York Labor Effort", "authors": ["Steven Greenhouse"]} {"date": "2018-01-05 00:00:00", "text": "I haven\u2019t yet read Wolff\u2019s book \u2013 do I really have to? \u2014 but the basic outlines of his story have long been familiar and uncontroversial to anyone with open eyes. Trump is morally and intellectually incapable of being president. He has also exploited his office for personal gain, obstructed justice, and colluded with a hostile foreign power. Everyone who doesn\u2019t get their news from Fox has basically known this for a while, although Wolff helps focus our minds on the subject.\n\nIt seems to me that that the real news now is the way Republicans in Congress are dealing with this national nightmare: rather than distancing themselves from Trump, they\u2019re doubling down on their support and, in particular, on their efforts to cover for his defects and crimes. Remember when Paul Ryan was the Serious, Honest Conservative? (He never really was, but that was his public image.) Now he\u2019s backing Devin Nunes in his efforts to help the Trump coverup.\n\nAs Brian Beutler says, Republicans have become the Grand Obstruction Party. Why?\n\nThe answer, I think, is that the cynical bargain that has been the basis of Republican strategy since Reagan has now turned into a moral trap. And as far as we can tell, no elected Republican \u2013 not one \u2013 has the strength of character to even attempt an escape.\n\nThe cynical bargain I\u2019m talking about, of course, was the decision to exploit racism to advance a right-wing economic agenda. Talk about welfare queens driving Cadillacs, then slash income taxes. Do Willie Horton, then undermine antitrust. Tout your law and order credentials, then block health care.", "title": "Opinion | Faust on the Potomac", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "LaVoy\u2019s widow, Jeanette Finicum, had thick white hair with a fringe of bangs. Her loose black T-shirt read, \u201cIt matters how you stand,\u201d a quote from LaVoy. A pin near her breast read, \u201cI am the virus,\u201d referencing a quote from Oregon\u2019s longtime Democratic senator Ron Wyden, who described the ideology of the occupiers as a virus after they were arrested. She was a soft-spoken mother of 12, and at one point, she stepped onstage to share a video montage that included images of armed federal agents and burning cars, followed by \u201cpeaceful\u201d images of cowboys, including LaVoy and Ryan Bundy. \u201cI ask: Who are the real terrorists?\u201d she said to the crowd.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nKrisAnne Hall, a 48-year-old lawyer and former prosecutor, was the evening\u2019s keynote speaker. Hall averages 260 speaking engagements a year; the Southern Poverty Law Center once included her on its list of 998 anti-government groups and figures in the United States. She teaches that almost every federal agency, other than the military, is unconstitutional. \u201cDo you think the federal government is out of control?\u201d she asked. \u201cWe need to wake up. Nothing needs to happen except America needs to have a revolution of the mind.\u201d\n\nKate Dalley of a Utah affiliate of Fox News Radio wore heels and a red trench. \u201cI want to talk about truth in media,\u201d she told the crowd. \u201cI know you laugh when I say that, because it\u2019s kind of an oxymoron.\u201d The media, she told us, was controlled and infiltrated, and the scripts were already written by the powers that be. She talked about the history of journalists working for the C.I.A. \u201cThey included journalists from The New York Times, Time magazine, which was already bought and sold by the elite anyway, The Washington Post, TV networks like CBS.\u201d Robin Olson leaned forward and gave me a pat on the arm. \u201cIt will be O.K.,\u201d she said. \u201cWe still like you.\u201d\n\nIn a 1992 photograph of America taken from space at night, the land in the Eastern half of the United States resembles a smear of the Milky Way, while the Western half resembles bright star clusters in empty space. A visitor to eastern Oregon would find country covered in sagebrush and juniper, hills painted with belts of ocher, orange, brick-red sand, Mars-like pillars formed by waterfalls and volcanic sludge, glacial lakes, volcanic uplifts, ancient seabeds and between all this, small human settlements: wheat fields, alfalfa farms and cattle ranches. The geographer Paul Starrs writes about the photograph in his essay \u201cAn Inescapable Range, or the Ranch as Everywhere.\u201d \u201cThe dark space is ranching,\u201d he says. \u201cRanching\u2019s realm is really, then, definable as being where most people are absent.\u201d\n\nI thought about this photograph when I first returned and began speaking with the people. After only a few generations living here, what made them feel the land so completely belonged to them?\n\nRobin Olson told me that a lot of the region\u2019s thinking about politics in the West originated from a publication called Range magazine. \u201cWhat you will find,\u201d she told me, \u201cis that it was never about the sage grouse, never about the spotted owl and never about the wolf. It was about getting people off the land.\u201d I asked Robin about the sage grouse, whose population had plummeted from 16 million to a few hundred thousand, and she told me, \u201cI don\u2019t think they are really endangered.\u201d The sage grouse \u201cjust happened to live in almost every Western state\u201d and that\u2019s why \u201cthe government chose it.\u201d\n\nRange could be found in almost every grocery and tack store in rural Oregon. The glossy quarterly claims a readership of around 170,000, half of them ranchers and farmers in the rural West. Range, its website says, is \u201cdevoted to the issues that threaten the West, its people, lands and wildlife,\u201d and it intends to \u201chalt the depletion of a natural resource, the American cowboy.\u201d In an article from 2012, the Endangered Species Act and the spotted owl are described as tools \u201cused by radical environmentalists and government agents to destroy the timber industry in the 1990s.\u201d The publication calls Rachel Carson\u2019s \u201cSilent Spring\u201d a work of liberal propaganda. It is critical of the concept of global warming and suggests the real concern is global cooling. The magazine published features on the Malheur occupation and articles supporting the Bundys\u2019 fight against the federal control of Western land.\n\nIn many ways, it seemed, the people were constructing their ideas of the land upon a fantasy of the past. In the 2003 book \u201cWhere Land and Water Meet: A Western Landscape Transformed,\u201d Nancy Langston, an environmental historian, writes about how each wave of white settlers to the Malheur ignored the history preceding their own. When Peter French first arrived in 1872, Langston writes, \u201cthe place had seemed nearly empty to him, and indeed it was this apparent emptiness that made the watershed such a fine place to establish an empire.\u201d Of course, the land was not empty at all, but belonged to the Paiute Indian tribe, which had been living in the region for at least 13,000 years. In the decades after the land was designated a wildlife refuge in 1908, under the orders of President Theodore Roosevelt, conservationists built dikes, storage dams, canals, ditches and channels, and sprayed rotenone, an aquatic poison, to kill invasive carp. All these manipulations were done to make the Malheur seem wild again, the way it was before white settlers arrived.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the 1970s, the Federal Land Policy and Management Act shifted the focus of the Bureau of Land Management from resource extraction to conservation. The policy marked the beginning of the Sagebrush Rebellion, a grass-roots revolt among ranchers, loggers and miners against environmental laws, like the 1964 Wilderness Act and the 1973 Endangered Species Act. Rural communities believed these new restrictions and regulations undermined their prosperity and shifted the fate of small-town economies into the hands of the federal government. If an endangered species lived on the range, for example, the bureau could decide to cut cattle numbers. Such protections fueled theories that the government was trying to eliminate ranchers to control the land.\n\nThe history of Oregon is filled with stories of violent and racist groups. Communes, cults, alternative religious communities, militias: The state has been home to nearly 300 of them since 1856, including the Christian Identity movement, Posse Comitatus, Aryan Nations and the Roy Masters\u2019 Foundation of Human Understanding. African-Americans were legally barred from residence in Oregon until 1926; the state, according to some historians, was essentially founded as a kind of white utopia. No one in my family, three generations of Oregonians, had ever heard about that.\n\nWhen my mother revised her understanding of the past, her romance with the West came to an end. A few years ago, she decided to start using the word \u201cgenocide\u201d to describe the fate of the American Indians at the hands of white settlers. My grandparents had been involved in cults and fringe religious groups, and my mother and father attended past-life readings. One day she handed me a stack of these readings. On these pages was a story scribbled in the curvy cursive loops of the religious leader who told my mother that she had once been a brave pioneer on the edge of the Western frontier defending hard-won land from the onslaught of Indians.\n\nFor many years, my family made it a habit to drive out to places like the Malheur and other remote areas. We carried rock picks. We found artifacts and fossils in the cracked mud of dry lake beds. We searched behind the high school baseball diamond in Fossil for the imprints of ancient ferns and crawled through buildings abandoned by the cult of the Rajneeshee. We saw arrowheads scattered on land where scientists uncovered the bones of ice-age sloths. We dug up an agatized root and dragged it home. We slept under the stars or in a trailer my father sometimes hitched to the truck. My mother filled my backpack with survival gear, and my father always carried a loaded gun. We cut down trees where we saw one; built a fire where we wanted one; slept on the ground in the valleys, among the sagebrush, near Indian burial sites. The eastern Oregon desert felt like a world that belonged to me. I felt antipathy toward visitors; even a lone hiker on the trail felt like a disturbance. In these moments, I figured that I, too, had arrived to an empty place. The rest of the world, the rest of America, were distant news.\n\nIf you drive two hours south of John Day on Route 395, you\u2019ll pass 1.7 million acres of Malheur National Forest, and end up in Burns, a town of a few thousand people. Outside Burns, on an old ice-age lake bed, is the ranch of Joe Cronin. In the spring, Cronin\u2019s ranch fills with birds from the neighboring Malheur National Wildlife Refuge: great egrets, trumpeter swans, black crowned night herons.\n\nAt 7 a.m. one day last January, there were more tractors on the road than cars. Cattle huddled in the snow-covered fields. I drove beneath a wood ranch gate, fitted with steer horns, and Cronin stepped out of his house to greet me in the driveway. He was a blue-eyed, 68-year-old, with a white goatee, wearing a plaid Elmer Fudd hat, baggy bluejeans and a mossy-oak camo coat with matching gaiters. His wife, Gay, made coffee in the kitchen, and their son Dirk loaded frozen hay bales onto a tractor bed. This was Cronin\u2019s \u201chome ranch,\u201d where he housed his cattle in the winter and provided shelter for their newborns. In the spring, he gathered the cattle in trailers the size of semis and hauled them north, into the Malheur National Forest, where he owned 320 acres of land. He also had a permit that allowed him to graze his cattle for five and a half months of the year, usually June to October, on lands in the Malheur managed by the U.S. Forest Service. Every year he and Gay attended a required meeting to discuss the terms of their permit. Usually, the Forest Service decided how many cattle he could let out on the range and for how long. If an endangered species lived on the federal land, the terms of the permit were subject to change.\n\nCronin told me that he wasn\u2019t at the Meeting That NEVER Happened because he was advised by his lawyer not to attend. He called the Bundy takeover of the refuge a protest and didn\u2019t see anything wrong with that. He was quiet for a minute. \u201cWell, they probably shouldn\u2019t have taken over that refuge, but what I liked about it was that it got this conversation going about government overreach. People wouldn\u2019t believe it otherwise.\u201d He remembered the day the F.B.I. came to Burns and barricades went up at the courthouse. The school turned into a staging ground. He said the town looked like \u201csomething out of that \u2018Red Dawn\u2019 movie, for Christ sakes\u201d and that \u201cit was World War III in Harney County.\u201d\n\nJoe and Gay didn\u2019t travel much because the cattle always needed to be looked after. In Burns, they didn\u2019t have a local radio station, and they got their news when they could from television. Cronin didn\u2019t attend college, and the farthest east he had traveled was Boise, Idaho. \u201cI\u2019ve worked out here all my life,\u201d he said. \u201cThat\u2019s my degree.\u201d Joe had the sleep cycle of a lumberjack, waking up at 3 or 4 in the morning and going to bed around 7 in the evening. It was what his family had always done. In 1955, Joe\u2019s dad took a job at the Edward Hines sawmill, which purchased a 67,400-acre tract of timber in the Malheur National Forest. Burns was a vibrant timber town until around 1973 when the mill started laying off workers, and the unemployment rate in Harney County reached 30 percent. The mill closed after the Forest Service restricted the cutting of old-growth forest in the mid-1990s. For-sale signs went up and people moved away. Cronin graduated from high school in 1968 with about 120 people in his class, and his grandson\u2019s class will graduate with about half that many. The biggest employers in the region are now the Forest Service, the Bureau of Land Management and other government agencies. Cronin was in the logging business for years, but it was hard to make ends meet. He bought a small ranch in 1994. He started with four cows, and after 10 years those four cows turned into a 600-head operation. He didn\u2019t use antibiotics or hormones, and his cattle were grass-fed, no fertilizers in the field. Each calf was born into his open arms.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAfter he fed the cows, he took me for a drive on some icy back roads. Near Rattlesnake Creek, we stopped to gaze at a herd of half-starved mule deer. \u201cOur main problem,\u201d he said, \u201cis with the Fish and Wildlife Service.\u201d A few years ago the agency found the bull trout was vulnerable, including on the river that runs through Cronin\u2019s land and determined grazing cattle endangered the fish\u2019s spawning grounds.\n\n\u201cThey say the cows are killing the fish,\u201d Cronin said. \u201cI think it\u2019s a vehicle to remove cattle off national forest. I can\u2019t see anything wrong with that river. I think the government science is slanted.\u201d Cronin asked a riparian ecologist who had been at the University of Montana to run an independent analysis of Little Crane Creek, where his livestock grazed. \u201cHe said that it was one of the healthiest riparian areas he\u2019s ever studied,\u201d Cronin said. \u201cExcellent shape.\u201d The ecologist sent a copy to Cronin and another to the Forest Service office in John Day. \u201cNever heard anything about it,\u201d Cronin said. \u201cBut if I\u2019m hurting that stream, I want to know about it. I just don\u2019t understand it. They are saying the numbers are down. I think there ought to be an independent study. We just get the feeling that the science is out of touch all together.\u201d\n\nCronin\u2019s friend David Torrence came up the road in a pickup. People called him \u201cBig Hat.\u201d He wore a gray hoodie and a pretty big hat. There were two Chihuahuas in the passenger seat. He and Cronin caught up on the weather and chatted about the bald eagles in the canyon. \u201cThe Forest Service didn\u2019t let us haul logs in the canyon,\u201d Cronin told me, \u201cbecause of those birds. They said the trucks were waking up the birds. Look at all of them.\u201d\n\nBig Hat asked about me. Cronin looked my way. \u201cShould I say it?\u201d he said. He meant my New York Times affiliation. Big Hat got out of his truck, stuck his sun-wrinkled face in the open window and folded his arms over the door. He asked about the meeting I attended in John Day. \u201cWas there any violence or anything?\u201d he said.\n\n\u201cThere was no violence,\u201d I said.\n\n\u201cYou know, Trump,\u201d Big Hat said, \u201che has been having all this with the media, you know? How they twist [expletive] up and everything? I was watching the news, and it showed a local reporter who was at the meeting. She told Jeanette [Finicum] she was expecting violence and demonstrations, you know? Jeanette was all teary-eyed, and she said: \u2018Hey, we are not outlaws. We are not criminals. We are full-blooded American ranchers. We don\u2019t want no violence.\u2019 \u201d He pointed at me. \u201cYou people are talking about violence and the meeting hasn\u2019t even started? We just think that the government got too much control.\u201d He opened his mouth and shook his head. \u201cWe just want to live our lives.\u201d\n\n\u201cI told her my story,\u201d Cronin said. \u201cI get up at 3 a.m. and start watching Fox News. I\u2019m so pissed off by 5 o\u2019clock, it\u2019s time to go to work.\u201d\n\n\u201cHey, hey,\u201d Big Hat said. \u201cFox News is a good channel.\u201d Big Hat said he voted as a Democrat until Donald Trump\u2019s election. \u201cTrump has been the best guy we\u2019ve dealt with in 30 years,\u201d Big Hat said. \u201cI voted for Trump. But all my sisters and stuff are all pissed off at me because I\u2019d been a Democrat.\u201d\n\nCronin switched parties because of gun control in the \u201980s. \u201cI went right up to the courthouse and changed to a Republican.\u201d He tapped the gun on the dashboard: a .22 Magnum he\u2019d packed for 30 years. \u201cI don\u2019t have a permit to carry concealed,\u201d he said. \u201cI\u2019m one of those guys who wants you to see my goddamn gun. See where it\u2019s at. Almost put it away for you but thought, No, she just needs to see me the way I am. It\u2019s part of our lifestyle.\u201d", "title": "Fear of the Federal Government in the Ranchlands of Oregon", "authors": ["Jennifer Percy"]} {"date": "2018-01-16 00:00:00", "text": "In Phoenix, a community organizing and advocacy group, Puente Arizona, had already helped prepare six applications on Monday, even though it was a federal holiday. On Tuesday the applicants only needed to put them in the mail \u2014 with a tracking number to avoid any problems with the United States Postal Service that plagued the renewal program in the fall, when more than 1,900 applicants were rejected for being late because of mail delays.\n\nIn some cities, though, the DACA push in response to immigration authorities reopening renewal applications was slower than others. Geoffrey Hoffman, the director of the immigration clinic at the University of Houston Law Center, said on Tuesday that the clinic had received only a handful of inquiries from DACA recipients.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been very sparse,\u201d Mr. Hoffman said on Tuesday. \u201cI would say there\u2019s still a fair amount of uncertainty with regard to whether these applications will be accepted,\u201d he added.\n\nBut another legal services group in Houston said it had received 50 to 100 emails, calls and walk-in consultations since the federal judge\u2019s injunction last week.\n\nOn Sept. 5, when the Trump administration announced that it was phasing out the DACA program, which grants the deportation protection and work permits to young people who were brought to the United States illegally by their parents as children, it allowed only those recipients whose benefits expired between Sept. 5, 2017 and March 5, 2018 to renew for a final two years.\n\nAccording to the immigration agency, 132,000 out of the 154,000 people eligible to renew applied in the fall. But this time, anyone whose permit had expired since Sept. 5, 2016 or was canceled at any time could apply.", "title": "Fearing DACA\u2019s Return May Be Brief, Immigrants Rush to Renew", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "What soothed investors\u2019 concerns? Facebook said on its call with analysts that the average price per ad increased 43 percent in the quarter.\n\n\u201cThe impact it has on monetization is certainly not clearly negative,\u201d Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook\u2019s chief operating officer, told analysts.\n\nThe stock is up 1.5 percent after hours.\n\nFacebook tops expectations.\n\nThe social media giant reported its fourth-quarter operating profit jumped 61 percent to $7.35 billion after the close Wednesday.\n\nThe numbers:\n\n$4.27 billion\u2014 The company\u2019s profit for the quarter, including a $3.19 billion tax charge.\n\n$12.97 billion \u2014 Facebook\u2019s revenue for the quarter, up 47 percent from the fourth quarter of 2016.\n\n1.4 billion \u2014 The number of daily active users, up from 1.37 billion in the third quarter.\n\nDealBook\u2019s take:\n\nDigging deeper, there were several impressive numbers in Facebook\u2019s earnings. Its operating profits as a percentage of revenue, or operating margin, ballooned in the fourth quarter to 57 percent, up from 52 percent in the same period last year. Its average revenue per Facebook user increased at a 28 percent clip in the fourth quarter of 2017, compared with the same period in 2016. That year-on-year growth rate is higher than the 26 percent recorded in the third quarter.\n\nBut there were numbers that investors will keep an eye on. Changes Facebook made to its news feed reduced the \u201ctime spent on Facebook by roughly 50 million hours every day.\u201d Daily active users in the United States and Canada actually fell to 184 million in the fourth quarter of 2017 from 185 million in the third quarter of last year. But Facebook still managed to generate a huge amount of revenue from the United States and Canada. The region accounted for $6.4 billion of revenue in the fourth quarter of last year, a 40 percent jump from the same period in 2016.\n\nAnother figure that might cause concern is the growth in capital expenditures, the money a company spends as it invests in new initiatives. Capex hit $2.26 billion in the fourth quarter of last year, a staggering 78 percent jump from the same period in 2016.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\n\n\nStocks briefly dipped into the red on hawkish Fed.\n\nThe Federal Reserve, as was widely expected, left its benchmark interest rate unchanged in a range between 1.25 percent and 1.5 percent. But the market focused on the change to the Fed\u2019s inflation language.\n\nToday\u2019s statement on inflation:\n\n\u201cInflation on a 12\u2011month basis is expected to move up this year and to stabilize around the Committee\u2019s 2 percent objective over the medium term.\n\nThe statement from the December meeting:\n\n\u201cInflation on a 12\u2011month basis is expected to remain somewhat below 2 percent in the near term but to stabilize around the Committee\u2019s 2 percent objective over the medium term.\u201d\n\nThough the market expected the Fed to raise rates at its March meeting, that language change caused stocks to briefly turn negative. The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500 index, which had traded as high as 2839, slipped to 2817 an hour after the Fed\u2019s statement. It recovered in the final hour of trading to finish up at 2824.\n\nReactions:\n\nEconomists at Bank of America Merrill Lynch wrote that the change to the Fed\u2019s inflation language was \u201cdecisive\u201d and a hawkish signal. The bank also noted: \u201cAdding to the conviction of higher inflation, the FOMC noted that market-based measures of inflation compensation have increased in recent months but remain low. This shows that the Fed is taking notice of the recent shift in market perception about inflation.\u201d\n\nIan Shepherdson, Pantheon Macroeconomics: \u201cIn short, the statement sets up the March hike, which will be followed by Jay Powell\u2019s first press conference. We\u2019re expecting continuity of approach, at least for a while.\u201d\n\nGreg McBride, Bankrate.com: \u201cWhile there is a lot of continuity between Yellen and Powell, many other faces on the committee are changing, and this could mean a Fed that is more inclined to raise interest rates than what we\u2019ve become accustomed to under Janet Yellen.\u201d\n\nG.E.\u2019s troubles could cost it a 122-year honor\n\nAnalysts over at Deutsche Bank think the chances are increasing. They write:\n\n\u201cGE continues to face substantial challenges including earnings and cash pressure, tough global power generation markets, aggressive downsizing, shrinking its portfolio, management shake-up and SEC investigations.\u201d\n\nThe analysts add:\n\n\u201cAs the company\u2019s absolute share price has continued to drop (and as the share prices of the other companies have been increasing), GE increasingly falls into the category of outlier and consequently a likely candidate for removal, in our opinion. \u201cThe committee reportedly prefers for the Dow to incur no more than a 10:1 ratio between the component companies\u2019 highest share price and lowest share price. Currently, the ratio between Boeing (the highest) and GE (the lowest) exceeds 20:1.\u201d\n\nThe context: A S&P Dow Jones Indices committee meets twice a year to review the makeup the Dow industrials.\n\nG.E. was among 12 original Dow components when the index was started in 1896 and is the only one of those companies still in the Dow. After briefly being removed twice during the Dow\u2019s first five years, G.E. has been a member of the index for more than 110 years.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nThe C.F.P.B. setup is constitutional.\n\nA federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau\u2019s director can only be fired by the president for cause. The NYT\u2019s Stacy Cowley reports:\n\nWhen Congress created the bureau seven years ago, it specified that the director \u2014after being nominated by the president to a five-year term and confirmed by the Senate \u2014 could only be removed for \u201cinefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance.\u201d That is different than the structure of most other federal agencies, whose leaders can typically be removed at will by a president. Last year, a three-judge appeals court panel found that setup unconstitutional. On Wednesday, the full court issued a new ruling vacating the previous decision and upholding the constitutionality of the agency\u2019s structure.\n\nPhoto\n\nTensions grow between Britain and the E.U. over finance\n\nThe European Union appears to be leaning against striking a special deal for London, instead giving the financial center more limited access to the European single market.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Jim Brunsden of the FT, who first reported on the news, citing unnamed sources:\n\nEnsuring that financial services are not badly hit by Brexit is a top priority for the UK, since the sector is Britain\u2019s biggest source of exports and tax revenue. Theresa May\u2019s government has also argued that if the City is damaged it would adversely affect financial stability and EU groups\u2019 cost of financing, while contributing to the fragmentation of the sector. But participants said that in the EU27 meeting the European Commission played down the risks of cutting off the City to EU businesses, saying the financial sector was mobile enough to adapt.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nJPMorgan\u2019s former top lawyer is heading to Simpson Thacher\n\nStephen Cutler, who until the end of 2015 was the bank\u2019s general counsel, will become a litigation partner at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, according to the WSJ.\n\nSince then, he has been a vice chairman of the firm. Before joining JPMorgan in 2006, he worked as the head of enforcement at the S.E.C. and as a top securities lawyer at what was then Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr.\n\nMore from Sara Randazzo of the WSJ:\n\nMr. Cutler said he is looking forward to returning to the practice of law, something he has done less of in recent years. He said he started talking to Simpson about joining after a conversation over breakfast with a partner there late last fall. He will continue to teach a course at Columbia Law School on the role of the in-house counsel.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nMeet the boutique that helped craft the Thomson Reuters deal\n\nIt\u2019s Canson Capital Partners, which wasn\u2019t even licensed to operate until three months ago. Its founders:\n\n\u2022 Matteo Canonco, a former global head of financial sponsors at HSBC\n\n\u2022 James Simpson, a former co-head of advisory for Europe at HSBC\n\nMore from Dinesh Nair of Bloomberg, who interviewed Mr. Canonaco:\n\nCanonaco\u2019s ties to senior Blackstone executives may have helped the three-man shop in London\u2019s posh Mayfair neighborhood secure the mandate on one of the three largest takeovers of the year. The newcomer\u2019s win mirrors the success enjoyed by smaller boutique advisers including Robey Warshaw LLP and Evercore Inc. as well as rainmakers such as Michael Klein in landing key roles \u2014 with juicy fees \u2014 on some large transactions in recent years.\n\n\u2014 Michael J. de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nBoeing is powering the Dow again\n\nShares of Boeing are up 6.3 percent after the company\u2019s earnings easily beat expectations.\n\nThe aerospace company reported a profit of $3.06 a share excluding the tax gain. Analysts had expected $2.90 a share. Revenue jumped 8.9 percent to $25.4 billion. Analysts had forecast $24.7 billion in sales.\n\nBoeing\u2019s rally Wednesday has accounted for about 50 percent of the Dow Jones industrial average\u2019s 250 point gain in early trading.\n\nBoeing\u2019s 12 percent rally over the past year has powered the Dow\u2019s run to record highs. Earlier this month when the Dow surpassed 26000 just eight days after topping 25000, Boeing accounted for about a third of the index\u2019s 1,000-point gain.\n\n\u2014 Stephen Grocer\n\nPhoto\n\nTrump wants action on infrastructure\n\nAt least, that\u2019s what the president said in last night\u2019s State of the Union address. But how much progress can he make on either front?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore from Julie Davis and Michael Shear of the NYT:\n\nHe said he would bring Republicans and Democrats together around a $1.5 trillion infrastructure plan to \u201cgive us the safe, fast, reliable and modern infrastructure our economy needs and our people deserve.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump offered few details on his infrastructure proposal. A report by McKinsey & Company says that a comprehensive fix would cost $1.8 trillion, while the American Society of Civil Engineers put the price tag at $2 trillion.\n\nAll but $200 billion is supposed to come from private investors, but lawmakers are skeptical. Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, told reporters, \u201cYou tell me how we pay for it, and I\u2019ll tell you what we can do.\u201d\n\n\u201cLeveraging private dollars is a good start,\u201d he added, \u201cbut we got a lot of work to do.\u201d\n\nDon\u2019t forget immigration\n\nCongress has until Feb. 8 to agree on government funding, and Democrats say they still want a deal to protect the young immigrants known as Dreamers. The White House\u2019s immigration proposal isn\u2019t sitting well with them \u2014 nor with some House Republicans. Meanwhile, businesses are preparing for the worst if legal protections for the Dreamers expire in March.\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 As the national deficit approaches $1 trillion, both parties are expressing concern \u2014 while pushing to increase spending. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The Justice Department and the F.B.I. are bracing for the release of a secret memo alleging improprieties in the surveillance of a Trump campaign aide. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 What companies are doing with their tax savings. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The head of the C.D.C., Brenda Fitzgerald, bought shares in Japan Tobacco despite leading an agency charged with reducing tobacco use. (Politico)\n\n\u2022 Expect populist politics to stick around, Eduardo Porter writes in his latest Economic Scene column. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Todd Ricketts, the Chicago billionaire, will replace Steve Wynn as the Republican National Committee\u2019s finance chairman. (WaPo)\n\n\u2022 The Treasury Department\u2019s list of Russian oligarchs was compiled primarily from Forbes\u2019s list of global billionaires. (Forbes)\n\nWhat companies are doing with their tax windfall.\n\nPresident Trump also touted the trickle-down effect of the tax overhaul during Tuesday\u2019s State of the Union address:\n\n\u201cSince we passed tax cuts, roughly three million workers have already gotten tax cut bonuses \u2014 many of them thousands of dollars per worker.\u201d\n\nThe tax law indeed has prompted hundreds of employers, including at least 40 members of the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index, to pass on savings to workers.\n\nMuch of those perks have come in the form of one-time bonuses. Many companies have also said they would increase base wages, expand benefits and raise charitable donations.\n\nHere\u2019s a closer look at what companies are doing:\n\nPhoto\n\nCan Buffett, Bezos and Dimon transform health care?\n\nWarren Buffett has called the U.S. health care system \u201ca hungry tapeworm on the American economy\u201d because of its ever-growing costs. So his Berkshire Hathaway has teamed up with Amazon and JPMorgan Chase to create a new \u2014 and as of now largely undefined \u2014 health care provider.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOur colleague Peter Eavis had four questions about the initiative:\n\n\u2022 What is it, beyond the thin description of an independent company \u201cfree from profit-making incentives and constraints\u201d?\n\n\u2022 How big will it be?\n\n\u2022 What expertise will these companies bring?\n\n\u2022 How will this venture cut costs?\n\nThe numbers that matter\n\n\u2022 $18,764: the average premium for family coverage for employees nationwide, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 30 percent: the current amount of the premium paid for by workers.\n\n\u2022 5 percent and 7 percent: how much the shares of Anthem and Cigna fell yesterday. (Insurers and prescription benefits managers as a whole took a hit on the news.)\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Margot Sanger-Katz and Reed Abelson offer reasons to temper expectations. (Upshot)\n\n\u2022 Robert Cyran writes, \u201cAmazon is already perceived as a potential threat to many U.S. businesses. Add other big employers, and the threat is multiplied.\u201d (Breakingviews)\n\nPhoto\n\nXerox\u2019s deal is the end of an era\n\nOne of the icons of 20th-century corporate America, the long-struggling company will now be controlled by Fujifilm Holdings of Japan.\n\nIt\u2019s a complicated transaction\n\n\u2022 Xerox will be folded into an existing 55-year-old joint venture.\n\n\u2022 Xerox investors will receive a special cash dividend of $9.80 a share and will own 49.9 percent of the combined business, which will be publicly traded.\n\n\u2022 The move is expected to save at least $1.7 billion in costs, though Fujifilm will cut 10,000 jobs.\n\nThe context: Xerox has struggled over the years with a decline in corporate printing, and it spun out its business services unit last year. Two of its biggest investors, Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason, have pressured the company to explore a deal \u2014 including revising or ending the Fujifilm joint venture.\n\nBehind the deal: Fujifilm relied on Mitsubishi UFJ, Morgan Stanley and the law firm Morrison & Foerster. (It is also borrowing from Citigroup and Morgan Stanley.) Xerox took advice from Centerview Partners and the law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThomson Reuters is a huge post-crisis L.B.O.\n\nBlackstone\u2019s $20 billion deal (including debt) for control of the company\u2019s financial and risk division highlights the growing ambitions of private equity firms \u2014 and how they need to spend nearly $1 trillion in uninvested capital.\n\nBehind the deal\n\nBlackstone believes that the financial and risk division, which includes Thomson Reuters\u2019s Eikon terminal service, can continue to grow. \u201cWe are excited to partner with Thomson Reuters \u2014 one of the most trusted companies in financial technology,\u201d Martin Brand of Blackstone said in a statement.\n\nMeanwhile, Thomson Reuters gets a cash infusion as it competes against Bloomberg LP and tries to deal with customers spending less on financial data. Bloomberg pointed out that the company\u2019s controlling Thomson family is essentially retreating to the news business.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Gillian Tan writes, \u201cDespite the $20 billion price tag, the deal seems like a bargain.\u201d (Gadfly)\n\n\u2022 Lex writes, \u201cAny spinoff would put paid to the Thomson family\u2019s decade-long hopes for combining a media business with financial services.\u201d (Lex)\n\nPhoto\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 The trial in Waymo\u2019s lawsuit accusing Uber of stealing its driverless car technology is set to start today. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The Justice Department and the S.E.C. are investigating whether Apple violated securities laws concerning its disclosures about a software update that slowed older iPhone models, according to unidentified sources. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Google\u2019s rivals have complained to European regulators that the search giant is still stymying competition in online shopping, despite an order to change its behavior. (WSJ)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 An app that inadvertently revealed the locations of military personnel is the latest sign that we need better control over our data, writes Zeynep Tufekci, a professor at the School of Information and Library Science at the University of North Carolina. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 SoftBank\u2019s Vision Fund finally struck a deal to invest $300 million in Wag, the dog-walking start-up. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nBitcoin keeps on falling\n\nJanuary has been the worst month for the virtual currency in three years, with its price down 30 percent. And it\u2019s because of the very thing that Bitcoin and other digital currencies were supposed to be free from: central authorities and regulators.\n\n\u2022 The S.E.C. froze a $600 million initial coin offering yesterday run by AriseBank.\n\n\u2022 China has continued to clamp down on Bitcoin mining.\n\n\u2022 South Korea is still weighing legal checks on virtual currency trading.\n\nAdd in Facebook\u2019s banning of ads for digital money, and mining or trading virtual currencies has become a lot harder.\n\nBut not everyone has gotten the memo: The Japanese messaging service Line has plans to open its own virtual currency exchange, while the embattled publisher of Penthouse magazine wants to promote its own adult-entertainment-focused token.\n\nPhoto\n\nCan Wynn\u2019s board be trusted to investigate its chairman?\n\nAs Steve Wynn faces allegations of sexual assault and other misconduct, the board of his casino empire is increasingly coming under scrutiny, too.\n\nThe proxy adviser ISS has long criticized the compensation of Mr. Wynn over the years, going so far as to say that the company had an \u201coverall corporate governance profile that ranks among the worst, not the best, of U.S. companies.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe board said that it was setting up an independent committee to look into the allegations. It will be led by Patricia Mulroy, Wynn\u2019s only female director and a former official at Nevada\u2019s gaming commission.\n\nMeanwhile, investigating Wynn are gaming regulators for Nevada, Massachusetts and Macau.\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 Vice said that its chief digital officer, Mike Germano, would not return to the company after sexual harassment allegations against him prompted an internal investigation. (Och-Ziff)\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 Volkswagen suspended its chief lobbyist on Tuesday amid a growing furor over experiments on monkeys that were meant to promote the virtues of diesel-powered vehicles. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Facebook Calms Concerns About Ad Revenue: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-03 00:00:00", "text": "In the December round of economic projections, the median forecast of Fed officials was that the economy would grow 2.5 percent in 2018, up from a median forecast of 2.1 percent in September. The tax cut was the primary reason for the higher estimate, Ms. Yellen said at a news conference.\n\nThe estimate reflected the view of Fed officials that the benefits of the $1.5 trillion tax cut will be attenuated by higher interest rates, as the federal government seeks to borrow more money.\n\nThe account also said that some firms were likely to give the windfall to investors or use the money to pay down debts rather than making the types of investments likely to expand the economy.\n\nThe internal debate about how quickly to raise rates revolves around the pace of inflation. Last year was the sixth straight year the Fed fell short of its 2 percent inflation target.\n\n\u201cOne thing is for certain and that is that inflation has become the most important economic variable steering the Fed\u2019s policy,\u201d wrote Chris Rupkey, chief financial economist at MUFG.\n\nSome officials have sought to suspend rate hikes until inflation shows greater strength. Charles Evans, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, voted against the December rate hike, and said in a post-meeting statement that the Fed needed to demonstrate a commitment to its target.\n\n\u201cI am concerned that too many observers have the impression that our 2 percent objective is a ceiling that we do not wish inflation to breach,\u201d Mr. Evans said in the statement.", "title": "Fed Plans to Raise Rates in 2018 but Lacks Consensus on Frequency", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-18 00:00:00", "text": "Several major hospital systems, including Ascension, a Catholic system that is the nation\u2019s largest nonprofit hospital group, plan to form a new nonprofit company, that will provide a number of generic drugs to the hospitals. The Department of Veterans Affairs is also expressing interest in participating.\n\nIn all, about 300 hospitals are now included in the group. Other hospitals are expected to join.\n\nDr. Harrison said they planned to focus only on certain drugs. \u201cThere are individual places where there are problems,\u201d he said. \u201cWe are not indicting an entire industry.\u201d\n\nDr. Kevin A. Schulman, a professor of medicine at the Duke University School of Medicine who has studied the generic drug market and is advising the effort, said: \u201cIf they all agree to buy enough to sustain this effort, you will have a huge threat to people that are trying to manipulate the generic drug market. They will want to think twice.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe idea is to directly challenge the host of industry players who have capitalized on certain markets, buying up monopolies of old, off-patent drugs and then sharply raising prices, stoking public outrage and prompting a series of Congressional hearings and federal investigations. The most notorious example is of Martin Shkreli, the former hedge fund manager who raised the price of a decades-old drug, Daraprim, to $750 a tablet in 2015, from $13.50.\n\nHospitals have also struggled to deal with shortages of hundreds of vital drugs over the past decade, ranging from injectable morphine to sodium bicarbonate (the medical form of baking soda), shortfalls that are exacerbated when only one or two manufacturers make the product.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re seeing an acceleration of both shortages and escalation of prices,\u201d said Dr. Richard Gilfillan, the chief executive of Trinity Health, a large Catholic system that operates in nearly two dozen states and is part of the group. \u201cThere\u2019s not been any effective push back on either of these.\u201d\n\nIntermountain executives would not discuss many details of the project, citing fears that competitors could shut them out of the market by quickly dropping the price of the drugs in question, then raising them again later. They said they would focus on drugs whose prices have risen sharply or that have been in short supply.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re going to have to hold that very close to our vest,\u201d Dr. Harrison said. The company will either rely on third-party manufacturers or decide to make the drugs themselves.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe new company will initially focus on selling to hospitals, but officials said they may eventually expand to offer the products more broadly.\n\nDr. Carolyn Clancy, the executive in charge of the Veterans Health Administration, said its pharmacy experts have consulted with the other systems about the project and is now working out the details of its possible involvement. \u201cOur strong interest here is minimizing the impact of any shortages of generic drugs,\u201d she said. While she said the agency is able to negotiate good prices for veterans, \u201cwe don\u2019t necessarily control supply\u201d and have experienced many of the same shortages, including the recent lack of saline fluids, as the other health groups.\n\n\u201cWe are constantly scanning the horizon and constantly attentive to interruptions of supply chains of medicines,\u201d she said.\n\nIn addition to Daraprim, several old, off-patent drugs have seen sharp price increases over the past several years. In 2015, Valeant Pharmaceuticals International became a Wall Street darling after it sold investors on its business model of buying up old drugs, then raising the prices precipitously. That year, it sharply raised the prices of two heart drugs, Nitropress and Isuprel, adding millions to hospitals\u2019 drug bills almost overnight. Valeant\u2019s practices led to a series of investigations and Congressional hearings as well as a shake-up of the company\u2019s leadership.\n\nRepresentatives for the generic drug industry have noted that many of the most high-profile cases have involved old, off-patent drugs for which there has been no generic competition.\n\nThe trade group for generic manufacturers, the Association for Accessible Medicines, said its members generally welcome competition. \u201cThe whole generic industry is premised on competition, and that competition brings dramatic savings for patients,\u201d said Allen Goldberg, a spokesman for the group.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut generic drug makers have also come under scrutiny.\n\nThe hike in the price of doxycycline hyclate, an antibiotic, which increased to $3.65 a pill in 2013 from 5.6 cents in 2012, led to a congressional investigation as well as state and federal price-fixing inquiries into some of the industry\u2019s biggest players. Last fall, a coalition of state attorneys general broadened a lawsuit over price fixing, accusing 18 companies of engaging in illegal practices involving 15 drugs.\n\nAnthony R. Tersigni, the chief executive of Ascension, said he and other hospital executives felt they had little choice but to try to solve the problem themselves. \u201cWe took the position collectively rather than waiting and hoping for the generic drug companies to address it,\u201d he said. \u201cWe have to address it head on.\u201d\n\nIntermountain executives said that they would seek approval to manufacture the products from the Food and Drug Administration, which has vowed to give priority to companies that want to make generics in markets for which there is little competition.\n\nThe project boasts a high-profile list of advisers, ranging from Bob Kerrey, the former Democratic senator of Nebraska, to Dr. Donald Berwick, a former administrator for the Centers of Medicare and Medicaid Services, as well as two former executives with Amgen, the drug manufacturer.\n\nErin Fox, a drug shortage expert at the University of Utah, said the idea of creating a nonprofit drug company is promising. \u201cI think anything that increases the number of suppliers will help,\u201d she said. She added that the trick will be in selecting the right third-party manufacturer to ensure good quality.", "title": "Fed Up With Drug Companies, Hospitals Decide to Start Their Own", "authors": ["Reed Abelson", "Katie Thomas"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "The White House said the idea was very preliminary. The administration has thrown its support behind the development of more secure wireless networks using 5G technology, according to two administration officials who would speak only on the condition of anonymity because the discussions were at an early stage. Some White House officials have pushed for greater federal involvement in the private sector\u2019s efforts, but the administration doesn\u2019t prefer the idea of the government building a network on its own with public funding, the people said.\n\nDiscussions on the government\u2019s involvement in 5G networks are likely to take at least six months before reaching the president for consideration. In a news conference on Monday, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, said any discussion was at its \u201cearliest stages.\u201d\n\nThe Trump administration is becoming increasingly concerned about the economic and security threats posed by China\u2019s development of mobile technology and 5G networks. Among the concerns is the ability of the Chinese government to spy on American citizens and businesses.\n\nThe American government has long been suspicious of Huawei, a giant Chinese technology company that is behind much of the 5G network development in that country. This month, AT&T dropped its plan to carry a new phone model from Huawei. The company has declined to comment on its reasons for dropping the deal, although government officials have expressed concerns over security on those phones.\n\nThe introduction of 5G, or fifth-generation wireless technology, is expected to make browsing and streaming over mobile phones much faster. It is also expected to promote the adoption of what is known as the internet of things, where all sorts of machines and appliances \u2014 such as refrigerators, cars and health monitors \u2014 connect to the internet with nearly zero lag time.\n\nPhoto\n\nWireless companies said that they had already started building their 5G networks and that any government-run network would be disruptive.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIndustry standards have been set, trials have been underway since 2016, and later this year AT&T is set to be the first to launch mobile 5G service in 12 U.S. locations,\u201d AT&T said in a statement.\n\nAny nationalization project could be a difficult sell politically, since the Trump administration and other Republicans have strongly criticized big government projects. But it lays bare the differences between two camps in the administration that have been present since Mr. Trump\u2019s inauguration: economic nationalists and China hawks.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAmong those officials aggressively pushing the 5G network are two China hard-liners: Gen. Robert S. Spalding II, the senior director for strategic planning at the National Security Council, and Peter Navarro, the director of the White House national trade council.\n\nOn trade issues, Mr. Navarro has faced off against officials who favor a more free-market approach, like Gary D. Cohn, the president\u2019s chief trade adviser. The national security adviser, Gen. H. R. McMaster, has also opposed aggressive trade moves against China, in part because the administration needs China\u2019s support to rein in North Korea.\n\nWhite House officials said the debate over a 5G network had not yet developed enough to pit the two camps against each other. But one official said that if the telecommunications industry was not able to agree on plans to rapidly develop a network, it could yet lead to such a split.\n\nStephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trump\u2019s former chief strategist, is among those concerned about China and the development of 5G technology. When he was still in the White House, Mr. Bannon met with American telecommunications executives about what would be needed to develop a robust 5G network. He has told associates that he fears China could dominate the technology.", "title": "Federal 5G Network Proposal Is Panned by F.C.C. and Industry", "authors": ["Cecilia Kang", "Mark Landler"]} {"date": "2018-01-29 00:00:00", "text": "Federal authorities have filed civil and criminal charges against a group of Wall Street banks and individuals that they say tried to manipulate markets in gold, silver and certain financial products, including by showing potential customers fake prices.\n\nThe actions, filed over the past several days, are part of a yearslong effort by financial regulators and the Department of Justice to stamp out behavior that gives the biggest banks an advantage over smaller market players.\n\nThe Commodity Futures Trading Commission fined three European banks \u2014 Deutsche Bank, HSBC and UBS Group \u2014 for improperly influencing the prices of precious metals futures contracts, which traders use to wager on anticipated price changes in these assets. Deutsche Bank agreed to pay $30 million to settle its case; UBS is paying $15 million and HSBC $1.6 million.\n\nThe Justice Department, which worked with the commission to investigate the banks, did not take any actions against them. A Justice Department spokeswoman said its investigation was continuing.", "title": "Federal Charges Filed in Price \u2018Spoofing\u2019 Inquiry on Wall St.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe stance of monetary policy remains accommodative, thereby supporting strong labor market conditions and a sustained return to 2 percent inflation,\u201d the Fed said in the postmeeting statement.\n\nThe announcement made little impression on financial markets because it left the Fed\u2019s plans unchanged. The Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index rose 0.05 percent on the day to close at 2,823.21. The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury, which has climbed over the last few months on market expectations of stronger growth and inflation, closed at 2.7 percent, down 0.02 points on the day.\n\nMuch of the economic strengthening happened under Ms. Yellen\u2019s leadership, a period during which the Fed extended the economic stimulus campaign it began after the 2008 financial crisis. While critics warned that the Fed had exhausted its ability to improve economic conditions, and would instead unleash inflation, Ms. Yellen convinced her fellow Fed officials that the economy had room to grow, and events proved her right.\n\nOn Wednesday, some Fed employees wore shirts or jackets with the collars turned up, or popped, in a tribute to Ms. Yellen, who favored that look in public appearances.\n\nMr. Powell, a Republican with a background in investment banking, consistently voted in favor of Ms. Yellen\u2019s policies as a member of the Fed\u2019s board, and said during the confirmation process that he intends to continue the gradual unwinding of the stimulus campaign.\n\nThe next meeting of the policymaking committee is scheduled for March 20 and 21. If the Fed raises rates, it would be the sixth consecutive quarterly tightening of monetary policy.\n\n\u201cFor a while now, the Fed has been very predictable in the face of a pretty benign environment,\u201d said Luke Bartholomew, an investment strategist at Aberdeen Standard Investments.", "title": "Federal Reserve Leaves Rates Unchanged", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-01-27 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cIt was great to spend some time with him and the rest of the team at the Laver Cup,\u201d said Cilic, who played with Federer on the victorious Team Europe. \u201cWe got to know each other better, and Roger is an amazing guy and a big inspiration for most of the players.\u201d\n\nBut Cilic has to set all that aside, along with Federer\u2019s big-match mystique, to win his second Grand Slam singles title. \u201cThe majority of my focus is to try to focus on myself, my own game,\u201d Cilic said. \u201cNow, reaching another final is completely different than all the others that I played. This time around, I\u2019m a different player, different person, slightly different game, slightly different understanding of the game and different mental processes during the matches. I have to keep that for the final.\u201d\n\nIt is easy to view the final as a foregone conclusion: Federer winning in four sets, tops. He is 8-1 against Cilic and thumped him, 6-3, 6-1, 6-4, in the 2017 Wimbledon final, when Cilic was suffering from severe foot blisters and ended up in tears on a changeover. One of Federer\u2019s coaches, Ivan Ljubicic, is Croatian like Cilic, and knows Cilic\u2019s game well.\n\nThe second-seeded Federer is as fresh as a 36-year-old father of four can presumably be at this stage, after winning all of his matches in straight sets and having to play for only 62 minutes in the semifinals after Hyeon Chung retired with severe foot blisters of his own when trailing, 1-6, 2-5.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cYou do take the faster matches whenever you can because there\u2019s enough wear and tear on the body,\u201d Federer said. \u201cThere\u2019s enough tough matches throughout the season.\u201d\n\nThe surface in Rod Laver Arena, though apparently not quite as quick as in 2017, suits Federer\u2019s attacking game beautifully. In his last 40 outdoor hardcourt matches, he is 37-3.\n\nThere are always big numbers in the mix when it comes to Federer at this stage, but he can surely see the allure of trying to win his 20th Grand Slam singles title. A year ago, when he arrived at the Australian Open after a six-month injury break, he had 17 and had not won a major title since Wimbledon in 2012.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a number that I honestly didn\u2019t think I\u2019d get to or be close to,\u201d Federer said of No. 20. \u201cLast year before this tournament I would have been happy to say that I\u2019d win one more Slam before the end of my career. I\u2019d been trying for four or five years to win one more, and I would have said, \u2018One more? Great!\u2019\u201d\n\nAfter winning last year\u2019s Australian Open and Wimbledon, he is here at 19, just one win from becoming the oldest man to claim a major singles title in the Open era since Ken Rosewall won the Australian Open at 37 in 1972. (That would not quite be an apples-to-apples comparison because of the comparative weakness of that 1972 field, which was missing many leading players, including Stan Smith, Arthur Ashe and Ilie Nastase.)\n\nBut several coaches in Melbourne do see a pathway for the sixth-seeded Cilic to spring an ambush, just as he did in the 2014 United States Open semifinals on his way to his only major title. He also nearly did it in the 2016 Wimbledon quarterfinals before Federer saved three match points and prevailed in five sets.\n\n\u201cObviously Roger goes in the favorite,\u201d said Neville Godwin, who coached last year\u2019s surprise United States Open finalist, Kevin Anderson, and is now coaching Chung. \u201cBut Marin does have a chance if he can press Roger and get the points moving and maybe try and expose Roger on the backhand side, because Roger can be exposed there. Marin has the good weapons to be able to do it.\u201d\n\nGodwin added: \u201cHe also has to serve really well, hit his spots really well. Because if Roger gets on to something, he\u2019s so good.\u201d\n\nFederer and Cilic are both good company, and in November when Federer was in the Maldives with his family, Cilic was on the same island.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Marc Stein He has covered Jordan.
